reviews.review: A Spectacular Display of Ancient Roman Architecture. The Forum is a delightful stroll through several hundred years of Roman architecture, structures from every period in the empire stacked, sometimes haphazardly, atop each other. Ever angle grants a fresh view on fountains, collonades, columns and other such structures of ancient stone. Well worth a visit, and coupled with the Colosseum at least a few hours of sightseeing.

Do This With a Tour Guide. I would recommend getting a guide for all of the area of ancient Rome. The guide will be able to navigate and explain everything. I can't imagine trying to visit all these sites without guidance.

The Night Tour of the Forum should not be missed for anything!. it was about 9pm when we were walking past the forum and noticed a queue of people waiting to enter. Perplexed at the apparent late hour we started to ask questions as to what was going on and were informed that there was a 'night tour' until the end of October. We didn't have anything better to do at that hour and were already tired from long walks all day and decided to pay what I thought was a rather exorbitant 20E each to join the next tour in 15 minutes time. WOW - I cannot express how utterly astonishing and absolutely fantastic this was. The organisers have installed state of the art lasers, cameras and computer graphics and you literally live right through the forum in the time of Julius Cesear. The tour lasted about 50 minutes and when it was over I was happy to pay again to go again. It is totally worth every Euro that they charge and I would advise that nobody even contemplate going anywhere near Rome without booking this tour. The latest tech is used to engross and totally immerse the viewer into ancient Roman daily life and every little aspect of that life is brought to life with the use of stunning animations, lasers and ground breaking tech which is available in just about every major language. The research and the work and the preparation that has gone into making these tours is fabulous and you walk away feeling not only like you visited Rome but that you also grasped a teeny weeny sense of Julius and the glory of the Empire when it was at its peak. The tour brings together all of the nitty gritty detail that you just do not get walking around the Forum with a guide book

ancient covernament center of Romans. This plaza is surrounded of the ruins of ancient Rome as well as churches build afterwards.This was a center part of happenings (market, triumphrat after returning from wars, speeches and even trials of criminals and so on).The plaza has been excavated and as a result of it we can see the ancient roman road of big basalt stones and the height difference of about 25-30 meters from the ancient times till the seventeenth century.
Walking. Put on your walking shoes and go explore this wonderful attraction. Best when you have a guide or the Audioguide!

A must see. What an amazing place, even better than the Colosseum. There were excellent information boards all through the site that explained the buildings and what they were used for. The only down side was that we didn't realise how extensive it was, definitely should have worn my sneakers.

The best place for pictures. Our best pictures of our entire Italian vacation were taken at the Roman Forum. The greenery juxtaposed with the architecture and relics set against the backdrop of the azure sky was breathtaking!

Always something new (old). As an active archaeological site, they are always uncovering something new (old) here. Amazing to see what was buried over the centuries and see the past come to life. If you have the time, they project movies on some of the evenings to illustrate how the ruins once looked in their glory.

Breathtaking!. We enjoyed touring the Roman Forum so much. When we arrived the line to purchase tickets was pretty long. We could have purchased tickets online and gotten into the shorter line marked "reservations". While my husband waited in the line to purchase tickets I stood under the shade near the reservations line. I noticed that many people seemed to have problems with their reservations. Some were coming on the wrong day while others had problems showing they purchased tickets when showing their phones to the workers. This line moved very slowly. I would advise that if you purchase tickets online that you print out a hard copy of your tickets. As for the Forum, it was so interesting, beautiful and historic. It wasn't too crowded and we toured at our leisure. I highly recommend visiting the Forum when in Rome.

Massive & Majestic. It's pretty incredible to walk the grounds upon which Caesar walked in the birthplace of Rome. Don't miss the courtyard of the virgin statues...legend has it that if these maidens maintained their virginity for 30 years (starting at age 10), they could marry anyone they chose. If not, they were thrown into a pit with a loaf of bread and a lantern and buried alive.

Crucible of Rome Began Here!. We visited the Roman Forum at Night just at the beginning of a Monsoonal Rainstorm. It did not deter from the beauty, history and splendor of the site, however. While heavy rains poured and a fog set in, the origins of Rome told the story of the ancients who lived here. The force of History was very powerful as you gaze upon the ruins.It is wonderfully lit at night and was empty due to the weather but this only added to the mystique. Wear good walking shoes and bring an umbrella if there is even only a slight chance of rain as it gets very slippery.

AMAZING. Had the skip the line tour of the Colosseum and Roman Forum and was really looking forward to the Colosseum, not knowing really what the Roman Forum is/was. Wow what a truly amazing place, you take a photo you turn round and then you take another, it's hard to know where to look. In our tour we probably spent 60-90 minutes walking round and it flew by.Does get busy but not to the levels of the Colosseum mainly due to it being a large area and much more spread out. Be warned though many areas not suitable for wheelchairs/buggys due to the 'pavement'.Highly Recommended

Enchanting. We visited the Roman Forum in a group of 25 people at night. It was simply enchanting. We walked up from the streets, wading through night crawlers who were simply out to have fun, and hustlers who were eager to sell anything from a scarf to shoes and toys for a few bucks. It was a windy night, so the scarf sellers enjoyed some patronage. To think that the first of the three arches of the Roman Forum was built in 29 BC is mind-bogling. The other two arches were added in 81 AD and 203 AD. That is a feat of which the Romans are justifiably proud. The Forum houses the temples of the gods in addition to temporal powers such as the senate and the rostra, the platform from which political leaders like Julius Caesar addressed the people. No single building on Planet Earth today compares to the Roman Forum in sheer multi-disciplinary relevance and aesthetic awe.

stunning views of ancient Rome. This was worth the wait to get in (even though we had reserved tickets online) and coping with the crowds. first tip - book online in advance. You will not escape the queues completely but it will help. A ticket covers the Colosseum, the Roman Forum and the Palatine. At the moment it will cost you about 16 Euro. We had a voucher by e-mail that could be exchanged on the day of our visit (any time) by going to the reserved ticket desk at the forum. There was still a queue to get into the forum entrance as you went through security. It took us 20 minutes - I have been told since that if you go to the Palatine entrance further down the road you may get in quicker. It is very crowded at first, but thins out as you go round. Highlights where the remains of the rostrum where Mark Antony made his "Friends, Romans, Countrymen" speech and the house and temple of the Vestal Virgins. It all suddenly seemed so real. Sadly there is nowhere to shelter if it rains (as it did very heavily) so if the weather looks bad do take umbrellas etc.

Birthday visit. We had a Canadian/Italian guide called Christian. Absolute star! Funny, informative, helpful! He made the tour so enjoyable. Interacted with the tourists very well and made everybody laugh and make what would've been a mediocre experience, so much better!

Short walk over the hill from the Coliseum. Must have a ticket for the Forum (as well as one for the Coliseum). Cobblestone walk up over the hill and large stone steps going down into the Forum. Not disabled-friendly. A must-see area though. The ruins are amazing, as is the Basilica.

Just WOW. Wow what can I say this place absolutely blew me away, it is spectacular and by far my most favourite place we visited in Rome. So much to see and to think you are walking exactly where the romans did all those years ago is just magical. A must see experience, we paid 12 euros each on the day for that and the coliseum an absolute bargain the queue went reasonable quick. Take your time going round there really is so much to see. Enjoy!! :)
Best view in Rome. This place is a hidden gem, fascinating history and lovely views across the Rome skyline, climb to the top and just spend time looking across and down

Impressive!. Amazing place! I got there early, before the guided mass came in and spent some hours being absolutely in awe of the site. So much to see, and it's all so impressive. Really cheap as well (12€ for both forum & colosseum). When in Rome, go here!

Fantastic. The forum has such great historical significance, you can't miss it. We took a guided tour and that really helped understand just what was there. It was a thrill to walk on the same paving stones as the Caesars did!

Very humbling. In Rome to see the sights ,and theses are a must see.A very large area lots of up and down hills but worth every bit of effort to stand and get a glimpse of where the Ceasers of Rome ruled. Some buildings ruins 2000 years old . Although no rest areas can be hard going.

Walk in the footsteps of ancient Romans. It is truly amazing to walk the paths in this area, knowing that the ruins have stood for thousands of years. While some parts require imagination to know what they once were, it is still a magnificent area. There seems to be no guided route to follow, you just walk the paths in whatever order you want.

Amazing!!. The Roman Forum is an amazing visit, and needs several hours to really take in. I would highly recommend getting on of the many books which show Rome then and now, as to take this around and look at the ruins which can been seen now, and then to flip over the covering page to see it as it was in use really brings the place alive.We were glad we made this visit early on in our time in Rome, as we kept seeing the Forum from other viewpoints around the city, and it really helped to have a full understanding of its position and use in ancient Rome.This is usually part of a visit to the Colosseum. It probably rates more highly than the Colosseum for me.Recommend leaving enough time to fully explore the Capitoline hill and park area too.

Activate your 3-D fantasy. There are nice and easy walks outside and around the forum, you will see most of the important "stones". Best with a "before-now"-book, sold in every tourist shop. We spent rahter this money instead of buying a ticket.

Use your imagination or you'll struggle. We visited (two parents, two children - one of whom knows everything about Ancient Rome) on an overcast morning, on our way to the Colosseum. The incredibly helpful man at the Rome TI in Vatican City recommended we approach our morning this way, so that the kids would get their tickets at the much, much shorter line at the Forum (we had Roma Passes for the adults) which they would need later for the Colosseum.Our kids used the Rick Steves' audio tour to get an overview, and we used the Rick Steves Pocket Rome section to get our bearings. Mainly we just wanted to experience the place itself, and enjoy walking where the ancients walked.

So atmospheric. If visiting Rome allow yourself a few hours to visit the Forum.It's a place of outstanding history, and so atmospheric.There is so much to see, almost to much to take in.Remember your camera.

A Once in a Lifetime Experience . No long description is necessary. This amazing, historical place is just overwhelming to see. You are awestruck by the grandeur and the beauty of the ceiling and the ambiance of history, and religious pageantry.

Like nowhere else on earth. Nowhere else on earth can you get a feel for what the Roman society was really like at its very epicentre. I spent a long time wandering around the Forum and probably would have stayed even longer had it not been raining so heavily. Like any ruinous area you have to use your imagination a bit but its not hard to visualise the full extent of how the city would have looked 2000 years ago. Absolutely incredible. Well worth the entry fee. Get tickets in advance and there really is no queue at all, just go straight in. I did Palatine Hill first and then walked down to the Forum area.

ancient rome. This place is included in the colosseum ticket, better to enter this area before the other featured places, it's a huge area that needs walking and hiking so you can see the view from the top, it reminds me of my History class, ruins, of important goverment buildings, it is once the center of Ancient rome, it can be reached by walking rom the Piazza Venezia, so there"s a lot to see if you start walking from the Piazza, you will never miss this site once you get to the Colosseum...

I wonderful place to wander round and imagine yourself back in ancient Rome.. The day we visited the Roman Forum the weather was a bit iffy but that didn't stop us wandering around trying to imagine the place as it was, mentally rebuilding the structures and of course taking hundreds of photographs. The site is absolutely fascinating and well worth a visit.
antique monuments. This place is famous well enough on its own. If you travel on a budget, you can see enough from Palatine Hill.

Breathtaking . A real surprise. I was expecting ruins and columns, the norm for Roman historical stuff but this place was not only huge but it was easy to visualize this ancient plaza and all the movement and ancient Roman people walking these streets. This is a place where a lot of walking (more than I expected) takes place. This was also a tad bit more interesting (please don't hurt me others who may disagree) than the Colosseum. Do not get me wrong, the Colosseum inspires you and is beautiful to walk around in (you can see my review on that too) but this gives you a real idea of ancient Roman life. This is a large property and calls for walking on uneven paths, very inclined hills, stairs and rocky areas. There are areas that are easier to walk on for you folks with leg, knee or feet problems or parents with younger kids and strollers. However you won't get to see a lot of interesting sections. Even still, we spent several hours here and enjoyed it so much. Highly recommend it and can't wait to come back to Rome and see it all over again.

The Best of Ancient Rome!!!!. Coupled with the neighboring Colosseum (a separate attraction), the Forum is the best glimpse into the Ancient seat of power of the Roman Empire. It is an honor and a treat to visit it. You can walk the perimeter and look into the Forum for free. But to truly immerse yourself, and admission is necessary. To stand at the site where so much history has transpired, including the murder of Julius Caesar, is incredible. In recent years, excavations have uncovered Augustus and Octavia Caesar's home. Tours just began this year. It is a true delight to see the living quarters of one of history's most famous figures. Take good walking shoes and pace yourselves. This is a 3 hour stay to give the site justice.

The Forum. Visited here as part of a tour group whilst in Rome. To actually walk on the same stones that Roman soldiers walked on just blew me away. The guide showed us photos of how the Forum would have looked in Roman times. Amazing. Also, how, centuries on, Roman buildings were built on and still remain standing today. Fantastic.

An Abundance of WOWS!!!. Oh my goodness, where to start with a review of the Forum.It is jaw-droppingly (not a real word I know) amazing. To wander among the ruins and marvel at the incredible architecture and the outstanding skill of human beings was a total privilege. You must let your mind and imagination take you back to the days of the glorious Emperors who ruled this amazing city and just soak up the atmosphere. The Palatine is equally as awe-inspiring. I think I must have been Roman in a previous life.Buy your tickets before you go, online through the official website and you don't have to queue to get in.Enjoy
Impressive. We had a guided trip to Colosseum, The Palatine Hill and Forum Romanum, and it was amazing! Incredible views and lots of interesting information, highly recommended!
Walking around in pure history. It's quite impressive to walk around this area and use your imagination what happened here on daily basis. We absolutely loved it as all thh rest of Rome.
Ruins and more ruins. In the area of palatine hill... mostly ruins but you could still get a vibe of how this area was...columns are huge and again overcrowded with students and tourists....nice

Ruined by security. We visited Rome a year ago and decided to come back with our children. One major difference is the increased security, which is not a surprise. But, whoever set the scanners up obviously never tried to visit as a tourist. After visiting the Colosseum we tried to carry on to the Forum, only to find a 100 metre queue. Why, security scanners, but only two of them. Looking at the speed of the queue it would have taken at least an hour to get in. Tip, you now need to split up activities and come early morning, the Forum itself is incredible and a must see.
Historical structure place. No double to say Roman Forum is one of the place you should explore when you visit to Rome.Its histories make you suprise about the Roman people in the past.

More Than You Know. The Forum is not a single building but rather an assembly of constructions that was the political and economic center of Rome until the Fall of the Empire. You can wander through the ruins and look at rocks and interesting formations of the remnants or take a guided tour which will enhance the experience immensely.

Historical ruins. The ruins are magnificent and full of historical information. Just let yourself imagine an active day in the Roman Forum hundreds of years ago and you will be amazed by the size and scale of the forum. Its beautiful. Allow yourself sufficient time to take a leisurely tour. Carry lots of water and towel on a sunny day and wear comfortable shoes.
have a guide. Guides know so much interesting stuff and you can bypass lengthy ticket counters and line-ups. It isn't a great deal extra
If in Rome . If you go to Rome and do not go here i question why you would go to Rome at all. I could have spent days in here. But get an audio guide and plan on 3 hours minimum.

Ancient history. The highlight of our Italian holiday was a walking tour of the Forum and Paltine Hill. The Walks of Italy tour booked online was guided by a young Italian archaeologist who took us on a historical journey and history lesson on the Forum and the Emperors of Rome. A truly magnificent and memorable tour.

Beautiful, make sure to get a guide!. Our tour guide Rachel from LivItaly was incredible and was able to share tons of history about the Roman Forum from the view on the Palatine Hill. I highly recommend getting a tour guide, it makes walking through so much more enjoyable when you know what you are looking at. We also went in May which meant we missed the crazy summer crowds and we had beautiful weather.

Full of historical significance. TAKE A GUIDED TOUR, this is a must see and was made quicker and more enjoyable by having The Romen Guy tour guide taking you through. So many interesting structures and buildings that it was tough to absorb it all in one trip.

Amazing sight just lack of information . As mentioned previously the buildings and structures are amazing and the place oozes with history and the immense power and wealth depicted by the buildings. However, because the area has been built up over centuries and there are several 'layers' of Rome built upon each other, without a guided tour or structured audio guide you struggle to really understand the layout. Guided tours are expensive (there is definitely a market in Rome for minimising the info / details on standard tickets in order to force you in to paying for a guided tour). And the audio guide was as random/ confusing as the layout of the buildings. Go early as the queues are long are the crowds at the key view / photo opportunity places are 3-4 deep at peak times. Make sure you get the assistant to thoroughly explain the audio guide as they try to rush the queue through and if it stops working then you'll never re-find the function again. But still an amazing feeling of how Rome may have been like.

" Center of Roman Life". The history of the Roman Forum is incredible. It was considered the center of Roman life, since it was a market place, a site for celebrations, speeches, legal proceedings. To walk among the ruins of this site, is just mystifying. We participated in the tour, which was part of the colosseum tour with City Wonders. Recommend this tour and reserve this tour in advance.

Interesting tour. If you enjoy history this is a must do. It's worthwhile to do this along with the coliseum through a reputed tour guide as they explain it beautifully. On a hot day it's very tiring, plenty of water fountains around to refill your bottle though. We signed up for the Rome in a day tour with 'when in Rome' tours. Very interesting stories.

Best To Visit During the Offseason (Oct - Apr). Not sure what I can add to 11,000 reviews other than this is the time to go as the crowds will be getting lighter.The Forum was the center of civilization for a good 500-1000 years depending on the dates you use, and although what you are seeing are the brick foundations of buildings, you don't need much imagination to cover them with marble and add thousands of ancient people. Every time I visit Rome I hit the Forum just to let my mind wander. There is so much to see that it's impossible to catch it all in one day.A tour with a knowledgeable English-speaking guide is recommended. I've done it with/without the audioguides and have found myself eavesdropping on the guides because the audioguide isn't easy to use and doesn't add much.The emperor Augustus once remarked that he had found Rome a city of bricks and left it a city of marble. Much of that marble has been stripped and used in buildings throughout Rome (including the Vatican), but the bricks that remain are well worth the price of admission.

Imagination Needed. To see the Forum one must ignore what is visible and imagine what was there. The area is large and you'll need time and a guide to get a lot out of this site. But it is worth the time and effort. Good bit of walking so maybe do it early rather than later in the day. Heart of ancient Rome.

Should see. We saw this location as part of our Coluseum tour and would highly recommend it. We did have a tour guide and I know personally if I had gone on my own I would not of appreciated as much as I do now.

Our best day out!!!. I want to live in the forum, me my partner and our 7year old had the best day here, for our daughter she really enjoyed it too but her highlight was the fact that there were two or three huge wild bunnies laying around and they actually let her stroke them! Lol! But in all seriousness you cannot visit Rome and not visit here, it's one of the places when it feels as though it sends you through time and you can actually imagine living amongst the Romans all those years ago!!! My favorite place!!

Not as much to see as I expected. It was a rainy day when we visited, not ideal for outdoor viewing. After walking up a hill and waiting in line for entrance, I was told to go back down the hill, around the corner, and stand in another line to purchase entrance tickets. Thirty minutes later, we entered the Forum area. It was interesting to wander through the ruins, but I've seen far more in previous tours, so it didn't add a great deal to my knowledge. If you are only visiting Rome for a short time, there are many more sights to see that will delight you.
Amazing ruins!. Definitely worth a visit whilst you're waiting for your time slot for the Coluseum. Part of the same area as Palatine Hill so do them both together.

Large spectacular site. Ticket price also includes the Colosseum. The main delay is getting through security but it was slightly quicker than other sites in Rome.This is a very large site with lots to see. Sadly we had already been to the Colosseum and done a fair bit of walking and found we were too tired to look at everything. however what we did see was spectacular.

Impressive. Right opposite the Colosseum, this is another of those must see sights in Rome. You can see it from outside looking in, however it's far more impressive from amongst the ruins. (Your ticket from the Colosseum covers this and Palatine hill anyway). It's an interesing sight to visit and imagine the beauty of the architecture as it would have once been.

Blew me away - stunning place. For me, in the four days we spent in Rome, this was the number one place we went to.The Roman Forum is incredible and in truth difficult to put into words how stunning and mind blowing it is without going to see it for yourself.The buildings and ruins are simply breath taking and you stand there in awe of how grand they are and imagining how it would of been back in those days.Just incredible but don't take my word for it - go and see it!

GREAT WAY TO SPEND AN AFTERNOON.. We spent the afternoon wondering around this pile of rubble, quite a large area with various bit and pieces from old Roman temples, an amazing place if one uses their imagination

In my view, the jewel in the crown. We spent an entire day in the Forum; we wished to absorb the atmosphere, and the best time is as early in the day as possible. We sought advice and went mid-week (when the tsunamis of cruise-ship devotees were thin on the ground) to explore this truly wonderful site at our leisure; located in a depression, it's often too hot to loiter, but we brought shade with us (wide-brimmed hats and sun umbrellas) in order to survive the heat... it was worth it.This is a site nobody should miss when visiting Rome.

Travel back in time. The Roman Forum gives you an unsurpassable impression of life in ancient Rome. The relics are present in an understandable and yet accurate way. 12,- € for the entrance ticket (which also gives you access to the Colosseum and Palatine hill on two consecutive days) is excellent value for money. Although the lines at the entrance my seem frightening (and the omnipresent ticket touts will do everything to foster this impression) they proceed quite quickly (we waited less than 30' on a sunny autumn weekend noon).

Incredible historical site, deserves better presentation. One of the 'must do' sites of Rome, the Forum is an extensive array of ancient roads, villas, temples and buildings. Leave plenty of time to explore the Forum as it is quite extensive and do take plenty of sun block (or a brolly) any time between June and September. Irrespective of season, flat shoes are a good idea as there are cobblestone everywhere (not just in the Forum - a lot of Rome is cobbled).To get the most from a Forum visit, it is worth reading about the history in advance - there is information in English around the site but it is not particularly illuminating. By way of contrast, the exhibition of the recently discovered church of Santa Maria Antiqua, which is on the site of the Forum, is brilliantly presented and well worth a look.
must visit. I live in Rome and this is a place I always reccomend to visit. If you wanna try to undestrand the size and the glory of the ancient city of Rome you must visit this place

Gorgeous at night!. I think the most amazing way to explore Rome is to just walk around and keep discovering beautiful, historic monuments at every street corner. Aided by audio guides that can be downloaded, it's a great way to enjoy the city. We chanced upon the Forum on a late evening walk. It's absolutely stunning, spectacular and breathes history. Don't miss it!
History Comes Alive. Before you visit this site, buy one of the Before/After books so you can get a better idea of what the Forum originally looked like.
Awe inspiring. Truly an amazing historically significant place. It's much bigger than I imagined. Definitely see it at night it's beautiful!

Exceeded all our expectations. The Colosseum, the Palatine Hill, the Roman Forum: All great monuments to Roman history, of course. We treasured visiting them all, but at the end of the day I think we enjoyed the Forum most of all.To see where Julius Caesar and the other great Romans walked, to spend time in this place that reflects daily life of one of the great civilizations of the world is an incomparable experience.

Always impressed by this site. Considering the age of these structures I'm so glad that the ruins survived as well as they have. One of the best things about Rome is how so much antiquity is preserved amongst modern day life.

Nice. I really like this place because of the history present in there, every part of it if full of history and it's nice. the price is okay, not expensive and you can enjoy three attractions with one ticket.

Nice place to wander. Before going, I had read that there was little in signage and that the structures were pretty minimal. That is more or less true. However I went from the Colosseum, up Capitoline Hill and then down through the Forum. I didn't care that I didn't know what every structure was or the history of very rock. I just found that knowing basically what went on there was sufficient. I found it a lovely walk - very green - among the old stones of what was left of this Forum. It is big enough that you aren't oppressed by crowds. I didn't examine each rock, but just soaked in the atmosphere.

Go early in the day. Incredible place to visit , don't miss it but go early to beat the tour buses and crowds. The ticket covers the Forum, Coliseum and Palatine Hill for 2 days. We did the three over two mornings, getting there for a 9.00 start on both days - this way we beat the queues, the crowds and the heat (even in October). One word of advice - wear flat shoes or trainers as the ancient ground is very uneven - we saw a few trips and falls when we visited..
Feel the history with this worth historical ruins. We spent 4-5 hours in this historical area . Amazing tour. Every item is worth to understand what was the living in those years.

Remarkable place of history. This is an extraordinary place, full of amazing archaeology and history. It's the sort of history that you learnt about in school, the type that makes you go 'wow, that actually happened here!'The grounds span the palatine and the forum and the ticket allows you to roam the entire site. You can spend the best part of a day wondering the grounds, the museum finding areas to explore and sit and admire this amazing place. There's little to say that hasn't already been said. But if you visit Rome, this is a must see. If you take a camera, you'll take loads of photos!
Very interesting . We did this as part of our Colosseum tour, its tremendously interesting, you will not be disappointed.

Fabulous !. This is also a must see while visiting the colosseum. It involves slot of walking but Definately worth the trip. Wear flat good walking shoes. Amazing what is being unearthed! How it endured all this time still standing. Worth the visit while in Roma!!

The roam in Rome. Just finished the Expat tour, 26 days very fast paced but so much fun Kev our guide was a hoot, while in Rome we found out visits to forum and colluseum were free on Sundays Forum well worth a visit, allow plenty of time,another place to hunt out is the ice bar, and the free fizz water at the metro station by the colluseum .another must is the parks on the hill. A easy city for self walk tour, you see so much as you get lost around the streets
Must do with lots of walking.... This is again one of the places you must see in Rome. wear good walking shoes to really get around this place as it is big!. with plenty to see and learn about.
Very interesting. This is directly across from the Coleseum. It makes you feel like you are walking in Rome 2000 years ago.

Walk through time. The ruins are amazing. It easy to stroll amongst the ruins to get an idea of how the Romans lived. It is a must see if this is your first trip to Rome. Go back at night to see the dramatic lighting.

Historic ruins up close and personal. At first, I wasn't sure what the Forum was all about. So walking into it from the Palatine Hill area seemed like just more ruins. Broken statues here, columns in disarray over there. Rubble all about. But if you take your time with the Forum area, appreciate that it's not like the Coliseum. It's not just a single site or arena, but instead a series of buildings and gardens and pathways and just a big gathering spot for old world Rome. But do yourself two favors: (1) take your time. Set aside maybe two hours (more if you're really into it) to just slowly absorb it all. (2) Bring a guide book on the Forum, helping provide the background for all the different areas your walking through. Without a guidebook, you're just looking at ruins with no real context.
Fantastic. An insight into what would have been Rome's busiest spot in its heyday. Extremely interesting and fantastic to stroll through. Great for pictures.

Open air museum in a very beautiful scene!. I love the place!!! I've made a combo (there is a combo ticket with Colosseum, the forum and the Palatine hill) and was very nice! The area is cover with pieces of art and stunning views as well as lots of panels with information about the place. This combo attraction, for me, is a must go!

Great for history buffs. Best done as part of a tour or with someone who knows and can explain well the history behind all that you are seeing. You also need to be good at visualizing what things "would have looked" like.

The forum . The forum is great. The history behind it and the story bring the forum to life again. Seeing the grave of Julius Caesar definitely made the trip worthwhile. Walking through the ruins makes you think about life back then and about how far we have advanced in technology.

Roman History Lesson. We went early October, visiting the roman forum, palatine hill and the coliseum on the same day as you can purchase a ticket for all three, and palatine hill and the roman forum are within the same site. When getting your ticket and entering I strongly suggest going to the Palatine Hill entrance rather than the Roman Forum or Coliseum. When facing the Roman Forum entrance which is across from the Coliseums main entrance, Palatine Hill is to the left heading around the site. I guarantee the line will be much shorter and quicker. I would also recommend that if you don't have a guide, get an audio guide at the counter which is €5 from memory. Although most the ruins have information, there is so much more you can learn from the guide, even about the Emperors themselves. The only drawback from entering via Palatine Hill is you'll be listening to the audio guide's information in reverse order as it starts from Roman Forum, however I don't think this matters that much. If you really love your Roman history strap yourselves in for a long visit, we were there for 3 and a half hours and probably could've stayed even longer, there is a lot to see!

Very unpolite security-guard.. A small securityguard with black hair and a cap looking army-like made this nice place a very bad experience October 11. He had to look in our bags as a securityguard, which absolutely is ok. But it is not ok to speak to us as if we were prisoner's trying to escape prison. He was rude and unpolite. Rome cannot be happy to have such people working in their beautiful places. Palatine and Forum are marvellous. But give that person the sack. We have been visiting Rome more then 15 times, and never had such bad experiences.
Rome wasn't built in a day!. Really interesting to see ruins from early Roman empires. The place has a majestic feel to it. On the downside, there is a lot of walking involved.
Fanytastic area of Roman activiit. Worth at least half a day wandering around. The extent of the building work is colossal and studied at length

Interesting place but overcrowded with tourist. It is certainly worth of visit, but be aware that it is totally overcrowded with tourist. With the same ticket you can see Colosseum as well. The ticket is valid for 2 days.

Big place, requires a lot of walking.. It was a big place with lots of historical ruins to see. But the area (including Colosseum) is just as sandy/dusty as usual.
This was the 2nd time I visited the Forum, but the queue is just the same as anytime, long and getting longer....
Make sure you visit. I was amazed at just how large this place was. If you go to Rome, be sure to put this on your list of things to see.

Major "AWE" factor. This was so incredible to see. It was amazing to visit this site.
Tip... It was easily accessible from were the airport Hilton's free shuttle drops you off.

An incredible historical site!. This gem can be accessed from various points. I walked through from the back of Piazza Venezia which provided a stunning view overlooking the ruins before walking down to the rear entrance. Enjoyed a couple of hours walking round. Plenty of notices providing info on relics. Best enjoyed on a dry day as imagine the uneven terrain could be tricky when wet.
Roman Forum. Roman Forum, beautiful place to visit and live the story from the inside, if you go to Rome do not miss this wonderful place

Something you have to see.. We visited the Forum and Colosseum on the same day. it was very interesting. Quite a few people but not terrible. We were there on a Friday. Something you just have to see. We had a guide for our group of 6 and it was very nice.

Wonderful place to visit. We visited both the Roman Forum and the Palatine Hill. Start with the Palatine Hill and work your way down to the Roman Forum. The Palatine Hill has stunning views over the city and eventually over the Roman Forum. The ruins of the palace are stunning and in better condition that the Forum itself so it's such a shame that so many people don't visit the Palatine Hill.The forum is great, walking around you really feel like a Roman. Make the most of the map given to you and do a little research before you go because it really helps. Out of context it may just seem like a lot of rubble but when you know what each area was it becomes a lot more interesting.The whole area is outside so on hot days don't forget your sunscreen! There are much needed water fountains dotted around too and the water is lovely.
Very Educational . Going to the ruins was one of the best experience I learnt my history lesson in the actual Roman city and definitely A ced my history class about the Roman history
Fascinating history comes alive. It's well worth getting a tour guide to really fully appreciate this amazing historical site and skip the queue.

Fascinating!. I was exhausted with jet lag when I went here, and didn't get the recorded tour. I missed a lot that way. I would definitely suggest getting a tour of some kind. It was very hot in Rome, also so bring water!
The Breath of Ancient Times. Don't just look at it from outside, it's definitely worth going in! Same holds for the Colosseum. The queues cam be a bit disheartening though...

I Felt Like An Ancient Roman!. During my last trip, I had an excellent visit to both the Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. The two attractions are combined under one ticket. You can also buy a ticket combined with the Coliseum, but I had been there before so I did not. If the line across from the Coliseum is too long, walk around the block to another gate. Doing that decreased the wait for admittance from 45 minutes to under 5 minutes.Upon entrance, the best way to cover the area is to tour the Palatine Hill first, and then cover the Forum. That assures that most of your walk will be level or downhill. The stairway from the Palatine Hill to the Forum is long and steep; you don't want to climb it.You should be sure to take pictures of the Forum from the viewing area on the Palatine Hill. The views from up top are spectacular. Then head down and go to the Forum entrance to get the full experience.Be sure to bring a water bottle or cup with you. Numerous fountains are available where you can refill the water. The water in the fountains is safe to drink.Access to this attraction is easy from the Coliseum subway station. You should be careful around the station entrance. We inadvertently walked into the middle of a PLO protest. Fortunately it had full police coverage and was peaceful.

Dream come true. As a casual fan of Roman history, it was a dream come true to find myself standing in the Roman Forum--albeit having come here straight after a transatlantic flight. It wasn't the easiest opening to a 2+ week long Italy trip, but it was a rewarding one.

Walk Through the history of emperors.. Difficult large basalt stones make you have to focus more on where you are walking rather than casually just strolling but take time to pause look around. It is a good idea to study the 3d models on youtube before going. We didn't use a guide because there is much speculation on what and where and we had time to stop and sit if we chose. The arches are awesome in themselves. Pay attention to the most sacred spot in the forum the Lapis Niger. ( Black Stone ) Even the romans venerated this pre-rome subterranean site just in front of the Septimius Severus Arch. I wanted to walk up to it but.. I dare you to explore. Note the exit is tricky .. you will have to backtrack to get out which is not ideal.
Simply a must.... Share a romantic walk with your loved one, or stroll around with a group, you will not be disappointed.`

I am amazed at the scope and size of Ancient Rome. It's part of a 12 euro ticket including the Colosseum.I never expected that scale of the remaining vestiges , either in good condition or at "ruins" level. The forum and Palatine Hill can only be described as huge. A great deal of it is in good shape to give you a real feel for how life in ancient Rome was and how truly impressive the empire was.Some of the buildings are awe-inspiringly huge. Allow 2 hours on average to just get around the site.This is another attraction where there is no queue early morning 8.30am to probably 10, or later afternoon from about 4pm.Definitely exceeded my expectations.
Rome visit. This was part of a guided package tour that we took and it was excellent. A must see when in Rome. This city is just wonderful...full of life and history

Stunning views. What a fantastic way to spend a few hours walking and looking around the Roman Forum. There is so much to see and take in that you will at least need two hours. This is a must place to visit.

Wow wow wow. Think that title says it all what a beautiful place the ancient part of Rome with its ruins and temples can spend hours there and did. Second visit now definitely not my last just have something to eat prior as only have vending machines

Make sure you use. this part of the combined Colisseum ticket and give yourself plenty of time. The combinedRF/Palatine Hill/Farnese gardens etc site is enormous, full of interest and well worth the visit. The Via Sacra particularly gives you a real idea of what the street could be been like in its heyday, either when walked or seen from above.
A eternal place. We visite Roman Forum and Palatine hill toghether. It took us three hours , so much to see. There are night tours also. Very sunny no shade.

Historic Delight. Can't rave enough about how great and wonderfully charming this was. We had a fantastic time walking around the forum and was very impressed by it's sheer size. It is so impressive the history here and you can learn and absorb so much about the greats in our history and how they built the centre of Rome. Make time for this attraction, and either get a tour or take some electronic tour. I would say a good few hours here is well worth your time. We had a three way ticket for the Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill (which is accessible from the Roman Forum).
Magnifico. The view, the ruins, the architecture! Everything was beautiful and the staff was okay. The queue moved very fast!

Much more than I expected!. My husband and I toured the Roman Forum as part of our Ancient Rome tour through Viator. Our guide, Laura, was excellent. She was very knowledgable about the site and we learned much about this place. The Forum was more extensive than I had imagined and really gave me a better understanding of the history of the Romans. Some parts date back to the 7th century BC. Much has been unearthed and rebuilt, but work is still continuing. In this site one can see what is left of the Temple of Julius Caesar, the Curia, the tomb of Romulus, the Arch of Septimus Severus and the Rostrum where Shakespeare had Marc Antony give his "Friends, Romans and Countyrmen" speech. There are many temples to be seen and one can also learn about the role of the Vestal Virgins during the Roman Empire. Definitely allow time to take in all that is preserved.
History comes alive. A visit to the Roman Forum makes history come alive. It’s a must see when in Rome. Recommend a tour so you get the full impact of what took place here.

Walking into ancient history . We loved this visit and recommend it. As two people who are more history-dunce than history buff, we needed a little bit of research to work out what we were looking at.. but even a couple of knuckleheads like us were taken in by the epicness of this place.

Imagination beyond 3D required. The excavated roman forum is great place to visit especially palatine hill but surely with audio or video guide as most places are into pieces and you have to do is imagine by building 3D imagery based upon history. This is place not worth strolling without historical background.

Walk on 2000 Year Old Streets. This was just an awestruck tour.... being able to walk on the streets that were used 2000 years ago, seeing where the vestal virgins originated, seeing the ruins of temples that you read about. Amazing. This tour truly made history come alive!

If you come to Rome and don't visit you are an idiot.. Its the Roman forum. Go. But buy your tickets ahead of time, set aside two days (gives you multiple sites) bring water and snacks and wear sunscreen! Once you are in you are in and it is huge. If you don't know much about history I recommend you get a guide. The ruins are beautiful and fun to walk around, but you need a guide to bring to bring it to life.
high climb. after visiting the colloseum we decided to view the roman forum from the palatine hill, but be aware it is a long climb to the top even for us who are very mobile

Fantastic visit for the ancient Rome history geek. My review might be a bit biased since I love the history of ancient Rome. But for me it was a dream come true to see all the remains of the ancient society.
Must See. Historically significant site. Our tour guide was completing her Phd in Archaeology, so she added a unique perspective and information to our tour.

So much history!. It is impossible to describe how it feels to be walking through Ancient Rome, knowing that people were doing this thousands of years before you in the same streets. Looking at the same (albeit more complete) architecture as you. The information placards were really helpful to explain what you were seeing without needing a tour guide or a audio tour. Most of the tour guides I overheard did not give much additional information that wasn't on the placards. I used my Roma Pass to get in for free. The line was not long at all, about 5 minutes. It covers a lot of space and is on a hill so be prepared to walk around for a while. There are places you can sit and just enjoy the views. From the top of the hill you can see a pretty good view of the ruins and much of the city on that side of Rome.
A must See. This is very cool to see all the old structures and how they lived. You can just picture it. One should get a tour to explain everything.

Magnificent as it sounds, the Roman Forum :). It includes huge structures and monuments and you can experience wonderful views from top lands inside. It should be done in a sunny day and most probably after you visit Colosseum. After these two, everything else would sound small to you :)

spectacular. Amazing roman ruins where one can walk right through the former buildings, seeing houses, temples, basilicas, palaces, a market place, and many columns, all behind the statues of the Roman Emperors that had them built.

Amazing, Jaw Dropping, Beautiful!. This is my 2nd time going to the Roman Forum and the saying is true, It's better the second time around. Brought back memories from 2004 and created new ones for me, my wife, my sister and her husband. Thank you, Roma!!!

Part of City Tour. This was a part of our walking city tour of Rome. Unlike Paris, Rome has not invested in selling maps of the area wherein we can find out more about the attractions. We were at the beck and call of our local tourist guide who frankly did to the best of her abilities. Just a quick photostop is enough time to spend at this place.

Amazing . The centre of the great Roman empire; where it all began. This alone makes this place simply fantastic.What ruins are left give a glimmer of what the place was like when it was the heart of the great republic turned empire. 14e will get you entry to both the forum and the colosseum so very reasonable.You can spend hours walking, imagining and learning. A must see!

Drink a lot of water!!. This amazing historic site can be acessed with the same ticket you purchased to enter the Colosseum and the ticket is worth for two days,so you don't have to see it all in the same day. I would highly recommend visiting it on separate days,as the Forum really contains a lot to go over. Make sure to give yourself enough time to go slowly in the summer when the days are really hot and above all,drink a lot of fluids, I almost passed out from the heat and the sun that day.

Allow plenty of time. We did the tour of the Colosseum in the morning and the ticket we purchased had entry to the Roman Forum and the Paletine, which we chose to do the same afternoon. As they are so close this made a real full day as you could spend hours wandering around the forum. My criticism here is we didn't get a map with the booking and on times the attractions etc are not very well signposted and information signs atre limited. When we visited there was a dreadful modern art exhibition in the Paletine, spoiling any photographs as the word LOSER appears in the middle of my photograph, made of shiny metal !! Use the water fountains to fill up your water bottles they are everywhere around the forum, the water is cold and safe to drink, we didn't pay for water all the time we were in Rome. There is no coffee shop only vending machines.
This is ancient Rome. So much to see - ruins of temples, homes a whole picture of life thousands of years ago. No visitor to Rome can miss this.

Vast amount of area to walk through.. If you are at the Colosseum you are a stones throw away from the Roman Forum, so might as well buy the ticket and explore.Many tour groups going through this area, you do not need a tour if you have a good guide book, or downloaded information from the web.

Not much to see apart from a load of old stones. The Roman Forum was on my walk from the Colosseum heading towards the Trevi Fountain. I am sure that the buildings were worth looking at years ago, but there is not really much to see now

A trip back in time . . . .. I was fortunate enough to experience this site with Walks of Italy tour group. During the excursion, it began to rain causing everyone to leave other than me, my wife and the tour guide. Once the rain stopped, we got essentially a private tour. Take some time to examine the ruins and also spend the extra money for a guide. Otherwise, you will not gain an understanding of the magnitude and importance of this ancient wonder.

Walk Where the Caesars Walked. A step onto the ancient paver stones will take you back more than 2,000 years in history as you walk where the Caesars walked. Buy your tickets across from the Colosseum and make your way into line. Expect to spend at least an hour or more here, so you have time to inspect the ancient buildings and numerous pieces of columns and stone work lying about.

Amazing. Of all of the places still remaining from Ancient Rome this is the one for me that allows you to get a real impression of what Rome really was like. it would have been better if there had been some seating, as there are a lot of steps and the floor obviously is cobbled so can be hard on your fleet. Also whilst I can understand not wanting to spoil the atmosphere with modern buildings, just be warned the toilet facility is poor and there is no cafe facility. However there are fountains with natural spring water that you can drink, and tucked under one arch way is a vending machine. Many of the signs are not in English so if you are really interested make sure you collect some info from somewhere. I loved the place it really is the heart of Ancient Rome.

A walk through history. An absolute must. If you visit here make sure you enter via Palatine hill near the colosseum, walk on 2000 year old cobble stones and take in the Roman Forum from the terrace at Palatine Hill. You will get a great view over the whole forum from there and can then really start to imagine what it was like.Once you go down into the ruins of the Forum it is amazing the history around you, the place which has the funeral pyre of Julius Caesar to name but one of many amazing points.

So much to see!!!. Incredible, do not miss!!! You could easily spend a day at the Roman Forum. We did a guided tour for 1.5 hours and then walked around on our own for several hours. The weather was perfect when we visited however would be hot in the summer. Not much shade but so much to learn.

Superb ruins, interesting modern art. Close to Monti where we were staying, we found the forum to be well worth the visit, good exhibitions, opportunity to linger and soak up the atmosphere, not overcrowded, a taste of Ancient Rome. Lots of interesting ruins, statues interspersed with modern, moving artwork covering the migration to Europe.

Great experience. Great experience, and a fantastic historic place. I would recommend this to anyone, but it is very important to have a auido guide or a normal guide, since there are lots of small things you wouldn't understand without a guide. Also the signs aren't that great, and doesn't include a lot of information. Use the Rick Steves audio guide app. Free app on the phone which has all the information you need and a map.

Surprising in its beauty and scale!. We visited the Roman Forum as part of a Colosseum/Roman Forum City Wonders tour group. This place is massive...surprising since it is in the heart of a bustling city. Very easy to get to by Metro (right across from the Colosseum - Colosseo Metro stop). There are placards that explain each structure and describes the historical background of each. There's also an optional self-paced audio tour available (we explored the Forum with the tour group). Be prepared for plenty of walking and climbing (on stones, up and down hills and stairs). V-
Historic. A must visit for all fans of history. It feels surreal to be walking through what is quite literally history!
WOW!!. So much history. This is an amazing place. You should really take the time to go through this place. So much history.

Through Eternity Tour [Underground Colosseum Tour, Forum & Palatine Hill]. This was a Fabulous Tour. Fredricka knew her history and made visiting the sites come alive! [Visited Colosseum, Forum & Palatine Hill] The tour is very educational and shouldn't be missed!

A walk back in time. The Roman Forum is amazing. You feel that you are walking the same streets as Julius Caesar. We saw pictures painted in 1763 that look exactly like the forum does today. Truly timeless.
Awesome!. The Roman Forum was the most interesting of the attractions in Rome. It really brings you back in time to ancient Rome.. just imagining what was there is really overwhelming.
It all happened here!. It maybe just a pile of old stones,but this was once the centre of the world.Soak up the atmosphere,the events these stones have witnissed is truly awe-inspiring!

Amazing archeology. The Roman Forum is an amazing trip into the past. There is a large area that has been restored and is well marked with directions to many areas. The variety of buildings is impressive.
Unbelievable History Here. We enjoyed a self paced walking tour of the Forum using the Rick Steves free download to our smart phones. You can really soak in the history this way!

Spectacular. We did the Colosseum night tour and the next day went back to go to the forum. As the guide had given us so much information about the forum we wanted to go in to see it and I would say we weren't disappointed about it. It is so beautiful and I would say it's a must see for anyone interested in Ancient Rome. It truly is an amazing place.

Wow! The History!. We visited the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill (really like one very large area) in four and a half hours. We could have easily spent longer there as we are both very interested in ancient history, but on a hot day there's not a lot of shade and there's a lot of area to cover. We entered by the Via Sacra, near the Arch of Titus, which seemed to be the only place to grab an audio guide. Be aware that you must leave a form of ID and therefore have to come back to the same place before you leave. We arrived at open, 8:30am. There were no queues. The staff were nonchalant, almost to the point of rude but that is quite common at the tourist attractions in Italy. The audio guide was quite informative but tricky to use at times. It's like a little mobile phone and the map is on a different screen to the attractions so you're always switching around. There were also some errors and things that didn't match up, particularly in the Palatine Hill part. Also, it has a loud speaker, you don't really hold it to your ear like a lot of other audio guides, so you really only need one between two people. The ruins themselves are absolutely incredible. There are some great views over the forum from Palatine Hill. Thoroughly joyous to walk through a piece of ancient history and imagine what once was.
Amazing!. Better to see with a historical perspective! We had a guide prior to walking the site. Very warm on a hot day. You are surrounded by stone structures. Take water!

Must see.. When you are in Rome, certainly for the first time, this place has te be seen. You have to walk around, despite of the crowds. You have to have the feeling of walking through streets were 2000 years ago people lived and did their things.
Truly Splendid. For insight into the lives of the ancient Romans lived, wandering around The Forum cannot be beaten - one is transported back in time.
Read up first or get a tour, a lot to know!. Essential visit to feel what is was like 2000Years ago in Rome. Very interesting history everywhere. Walk where the center of the world was 2000 years !

My favourite bit of Rome . This in my view is the place which all tourists must visit in Rome, as there is so much to see and you can really get a feel for the Roman way of life as you walk through what would have been the hub of their community. It was definitely worth getting the audio tour, which you could listen to interesting facts and stories about the forum with. It is all outside though so it is best to do when it is not raining

If you enjoy Roman Archeology. Roman architecture on a huge scale, you can place yourself back in ancient Rome by walking through the ruins. We got a guide which really helped fill in the history. Allow a full afternoon to explore.
OOOooozing Age!. The Roman Forum was lovely to walk around on an early morning, there is a lot of History here and lots of signs for information! Duration could be from 1 - 4 hours

Ancient City Within A Modern City. The Roman Forum Is A Wonder To Behold; A Two Thousand Year Old ' Ghost ' Sitting Within The Centre Of Modern Rome. A Combi - Ticket For 12 Euros Gains You Entrance Into The Forum, Palatine Hill & Colosseum & Should Keep You Active For Half A Day. I Entered At The Palatine Hill Gate & Enjoyed A Gentle Stroll Along The Only Real Tree Shading Available & After An Hour Or So Started The Forum Excursion. You Could Get A Very Full Look At The Majority Of The Forum At Street Level But It Is Worth Paying The Modest Entrance Fee For A Close Up View Of The Buildings, Roads And Temples That Will Give You, With A Little Imagination A Real Insight In To The Lives Of This Wonderful, Ancient Culture.P.S. Ensure You Take Water & Maybe A Small Umbrella Or Parasol With You As Most Of The Site Is Unshaded & Even In Late September The Temperature Can Reach The Low To Mid Eightees ).

The Heart of Ancient Rome. The Roman Forum lies in the center of Rome, and it was the beating heart of the ancient empire. This was a center of government, politics, religion, and commerce. A collection of ancient monuments and buildings are clustered here. The Arches of Titus and Septimius Severus are here, numerous temples and basilicas, the Curia Julia, and various monuments, as well as the Via Sacra. An absolute must-see for anyone with an appreciation for the history of ancient Rome. As some of the ancient buildings and monuments are in ruins, you will need to bring a good guide book or take a guided tour to get a deeper appreciation for this amazing place. It would be very helpful to the millions visiting here each year if better signage, including depictions of what these buildings and monuments once looked like, was installed.

Not to be missed.. Rome is just such an amazing city...the history is literally everywhere. I suspect the challenge for many travelers is prioritizing. The Forum would be near the top of my prioritized list. There is just something about the experience of being in this place that is hard to describe. For history buffs, well, welcome home!!! Here is a little tip for you. I found the best view of the Forum to be from the balcony of the Capitoline Museum. It takes a little work to find that balcony, but it's there and worth the effort. And the Capitoline Museum, by the way, would be at the top of the above mentioned list.
Great place to take a walk through. Absolutely fascinating to see such old structures still standing. A must see on the day you're visiting the Colosseum!

Roman City Centre. If you have the time and love history, the Roman Forum is for you. There are some signs but you can imagine the streets as they are well preserved. If you can get a guide or audio guide your experience will be the best. But even without the buildings left are very impressive!
Impressive piece of history. I recommend a full day with Audio Guide to help understand how the place evolved and the meaning of each building.Amazing place.

Truly amazing. For a great price you get a very large view of Ancient Rome. You can spend hours walking through, you can pay an extra 6 euros and get an audio tour or even take up with one of the constant tour groups. Also the trails are marked easy medium or hard to cater to your walking abilities which make it good for the older tourists.

Wow. Even if there is mainly some rocks left it is still easy to picture its grandeur. Lots of signs to explain what you are seeing. As for photos with good light, you probably have to visit twice since the forum is stretched east - west. All in all, for a peek from the outside, an early visit is best, if you pay entrance and enters you'll get good views from the Palantin hill in the morning as well, but in the afternoon you'll get a good view from Capitol hill where some balconies gives you a free view.

Wear comfy shoes!. A step back in time in this amazing space! The sight is absolutely huge and there is so much to see.The surfaces are quite uneven in most areas however there are colour coded routes for easy, difficult and hard so should be an option for most abilities.The area is full of gems and interesting information. I wouldn't recommend on very wet days as I imagine the surfaces could become quite dangerous but most other should be OK as long as you dress appropriately!There are several drinking fountains throughout the forum to keep hydrated :-)

Huge and demanding, but fantastic. Forum Romanum is huge, and you can easily spend a day there if you're intor history and ruins. We spent half a day, which is also OK, as one gets a little "fed-up" with ancient marble, but I could clerly have taken another half day sometime later, as there is plenty of stuff to see. The downside is the horrendously poor guidance given as you try to imagine what it has looked like, so my advice would be to study a book about and images portraying the forum before you go there, so that it all makes a little more sense...

Awesome view of ancient Roman ruins.. We came here after the Colosseum and Palantine Hill. This was much much more impressive than Palantine Hill and I wish we had skipped it altogether for this. There is a great selection of various ancient buildings rich with history. Do not skip out on a free map though. We made that mistake and did a lot of backtracking to find the exit. A guide might help, but we took a bunch of detailed pictures and then referred to our guide book back at our Airbnb location to appreciate what we had seen. Also, watch where you walk here. The large cobble stones can roll an ankle pretty easily if you aren't keeping an eye on where you are walking. It isn't as bad as Pompeii, but we saw a view ankles get om nom nomed by the gaps between the cobblestones.

Walk In Historic Rome. When you visit the Roman Forum please first read its history and a description of the ruins. The magesticy of the Forum is its history. To truly enjoy it I would visit it an a cool day as walking up the Palatine Hill and through the Forum on a hot day left me dehydrated and exhausted. If you want some magnificent pictures get there when it opens to avoid the crowds.
Ancient Rome. Go with a guide so that you can soak in the amazing historical and architectural value of this stunning monument to human achievement

Enter from the other end!. The first entry is near the Colosseum and thus quite busy. We entered via the alternative at the other end of the site which was much better. The place is stunning with a description by every building. All very impressive and interesting. Good value with a combined entry ticket for both the Forum and Colosseum.

Quintessential Rome!. Rome is such an ancient city and one of the best places to see this is at the Roman Forum. I suggest taking a guide so you can understand all of the history behind all of these amazing ruins

So Much History in One Place. Most interesting. Such an important historical location - excellent information signs.Top tips - wear sensible footwear as there are uneven surfaces. Enter via the Palatine Hill in order to avoid queuing for ages.

Amazing. Absolutely blown away by this fantastic site. Visited after the Colleseum (combined ticket price of 12 euros and very good value for money). Amazing to think these monuments are still standing after all this time.

Interesting history. The Roman Forum is a history filled place to visit. The admission is included with the ticket to the Colosseum. I would recommend reading about the Forum before visiting so you know what was once here and the historical significance. Make sure you bring water if the weather is warm, as there is really no shelter from the elements. If you like visiting ancient Roman ruins, this place is a must-see!
Walking tour of the Coliseum and the Forum. We went to see the Coliseum originally but the Forum was equally as impressive and the views were spectacular.

The Roman Forum Should Be On Your List. Rome is a place of history and the Roman Forum was at the core of the ancient city and its seat of government. We were part of a guided tour (Gartour) and I have both walked around on my own (years ago) and had the guide so I have to admit to having learned more about the place the second time 'round. The history of the place can be transmitted to one sImply by walking along the paving stones. The triumphal arches are spectacular and crammed full of 'stories' that the images in relief are prepared to tell. Having a guide helps a lot!
So much to look at. Taken back by the amount of architecture to see, hard to believe it's been stood for so many years and hopefully many more.

Do not under estimate. The size of the forum and the wonder of it. Allow plenty of time to wander around as you walk around another corner and there is another ruin to look at. The size of the forum is massive, but wonderful to wander around.

Monument valley of the antiquity. Amazing, overviewing the forum is almost like overlooking a vast space of nature in its glory. To me it is majestic, knowing this was the place where emperors walked around and decided to conquer the compass.
Giant ruins. Roman Forum ruins are just as awesome as Colosseum, but can be overlooked. The sculptures are massive and it breaths with the history.

A must but requires some planning. The Roman Forum (and the Palatine Hill, which shares the same entrance) is included in the same admission ticket to the Colosseum and is, to a certain extent, more interesting. The Roman forum is a collection of (ruins of) major structures (buildings, structures, memorials) of ancient Rome. On the top of my head, I remember the temple of Vesta, the Regia (the Royal residence), and the Curia (the meeting place of the Senate). Of particular interest was the Basilica Julia, an ancient structure that was converted into a church. It has several audio-visual stations where you can have a better glimpse - explanation of the ruins. Since it is indoors, some of its corridors provides a nice insulation from the heat, if you are visiting during the summer.On the minus site, we have some problems with the audio guide - it seems that some times it freezes, especially when using the gps. It was quite annoying, although it was relatively easy to solve by rebooting the device - the audio guide is simply a cheap smartphone with gps that runs continuously the guide app.A harder problem was to locate yourself in the map and select highlights without a pre-planned itinerary. You probably won't have stamina to see and listen to all stations in the audio guide, especially if you go during the hot months of summer. The problem is that most points of interest do not have a proper description on site, so you basically need to rely on your audio device. Also, it is not clear which path/route you should following, and it was a bit tricky to plan it on site.All in all, this is a must to do in Rome, but I think some homework needs to be done before the trip. Without proper explanations and descriptions, those ancient ruins would be no different than construction debris, which can become quite annoying, especially under high heat of the summer. I suggested studying the ruins and having your itinerary set, then have the audio device furnish the proper significance of the sites you are seeing. A guided tour with a human guide is also a great idea. As a suggestion, check the night tours that they offer during the hot months of summer, where in addition of the human guide, you would also benefit from the cooler night temperatures.
Up Close. I liked this because the line to get in were non-existent and the crowd inside was manageable. The forum was impressive.

A must visit when in Rome. It was great to wander around the ruins and picture the importance of the area back in its hay day. Unfortunately a storm hit us halfway through and we struggled to find shelter. Lucky for the hawkers who managed to make umbrella and poncho sales in the place. I'm sure they jumped a few fences to get in, regardless of it being a paid venue with x-ray security systems.
Forum - so much to see. There are so may ruins you could spend an entire day! The history is amazing. Pictures cannot do all of this justice.
Roman forum. Another very picturesque place with all the sights in the area great for walking easy to walk also. All sights are easy to find and well lighted at night.
A One-of-a-Kind Experience. A challenging walk (especially on a hot day) but well worth it for the view of Rome at the top, and the experience just of being on such a remarkable site.

An Inspirational Site. As with the other locations in this area a visit to the Roman Forum is awe inspiring. To realize that Romans were living, working, and playing in these areas over 2000 years ago is mind boggling. The site as a whole is an archeological dig. There are a number of explanatory signs in the area, however I regretted that we had not taken a guided tour. Fortunately there were a number of other tours and we could eavesdrop on them.

Ruins to take you back to history. an impressive spread of historical ruins, give yourself atleast two to three hours to soak in the meaning of what you are witnessing. the whole complex would have been so populated 2000 years ago with beautiful temples and public spaces. Visualise ancient Rome when it was the most powerful empire in the universe.

MY ABSOLUTE FAVORITE!!!. I am not a history buff but this was my absolute favorite site of our entire trip. We had a tour guide named Dennis who was an archeologist and had so much knowledge of Roman history. I find it fascinating that marble columns and relics were just lying around in the Forum. At one point is dawned on me as I was leaning against a marble column that Julius Caesar or Cicero could very well have leaned against the same column. Unbelievable!

Must see. If your in Rome you must see the forum. My partner and I chose a guided tour with Special Quality Tours. It's worth taking a tour as our tour guide Mircea was very knowledgeable and it is a better experience when your getting a history lesson as well as seeing the sights.
Awesome. A visit to the Forum is an awesome walk through Western World history. Make sure you have time to take in this marvelous site.
Roman Forum. Last stop on our tour of Italy and definitely worth it. Don't leave Rome without seeing it. Historical as well as beautiful.
History at its best. Historic views of ancient times. Interesting areas to see and imagine you lived hundreds of years ago.

Amazing site with so much to see. We weren't expecting to see so many buildings, columns and foundations, it was a huge area and there were lots of English information boards. The scale of it is amazing and we wished we'd read up on it a bit more before we entered or had hired an audio guide.  It could be tricky walking on the very uneven stones if you have a mobility problem. Also if it's a hot day, take a drink in with you. A must see,!
Great place. So much history well worth visiting get tickets online when you purchase Colosseum tickets saves ques

Loved it. Good walking shoes a must, very uneven surfaces & quite a few steps, but that said not to be missed. This was part of an organised tour & our guide was very informative on the history. We are in our seventies, hence the organised tour, but wish we could have spent longer here at our own pace. Definitely recommend.
So much to see. You could literally spend the whole day exploring, it's great walking around it all and to be surrounded by so much history

Combo Ticket Gets You In. We purchased tickets for the Colosseum at 12 Euros that included Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum - great value!
Be prepared to walk a lot. There is a city water fountain inside, and we brought an empty water bottle to enjoy the cool water. So many amazing sites to see so read up a little before you enter.

Just blew my mind!!!. When you gain entry to the Colosseum you also have entry to Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. Some of the most incredible photo's I have in Rome overlook the Roman Forum which was ancient Rome's showpiece centre, a grandiose district of temples, basilicas and vibrant public spaces which is now a series of ruins but on a landscape that it quite breathtaking. The tour of the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum was my favourite day in Rome, never to be forgotten, picturesque, historic, incredible!!!
Great History. Great place to see and a must see. Make sure you visit the tomb of Julius Caesar. Probably not a good day to go if it is too warm as there is a lot of open sights.

Ancient Roman ruins . This is a place you can imagine history of Rome being played out. Lots of ruins of government buildings in clay colors. Many columns left standing in the sun. Very interesting to take a stroll through these ruins.
Feel like a Roman. Standing in the Forum and visualizing Julius Cesare driving his chariot through is my favorite thought

A snapshot of how the Romans lived. Half-close your eyes and you can almost visualize the ancient Romans in their togas strolling to the Forum. They may be ruins, but these buildings almost speak their own history!

Roman forum is beautiful. The Roman Forum has a lot of history and you can see it when you walk down the streets you can even go in to Caesar's home on top of the hill and see how he lived that is cool

Proper ruins. along with the pantheon, i was looking forward to seeing the roman forum and it didn't disappoint!!!! no exit signs though, took a while to get out of it. a number of items were under construction during our time here, it is still brilliant.

Put on your walking shoes. This place is way bigger than it looks, and it looks amazing. The first thing you should do, before you get really tired, is climb the stairs and walk to the overlook to take in the sheer size of this place. An added bonus is the views of the city that you can get from up there. Then climb down and walk it from one end to the other. Fantastic!

Amazing!. We saw the Colosseum and then the Roman Forum. It was wonderful and so interesting. I would definitely get an audioguide if you aren't doing a tour. You can miss so much information and it's hard to walk around by yourself and truly appreciate what everything was.

unmissable. The Forum is amazing. Entry is covered with your Colleseum ticket. This place is huge! So much to see - you could spend the day there. No food allowed so eat before going and wear good walking shoes - some steep hills and steps. If possible get a guide - well worth a long visit
Beyond. A fantastic must see in Rome. Gladiator Tours showed us above and beyond. An historical site that was worth it.
Very hot and very ancient!. It gives a real sense of the layout of the buildings and what life would have been like. Not much shade on a hot day!
