Very impressive. This was part of our entry ticket to the Colosseum, which we did independently. It is possible to have a guided tour, but we had books on the Forum, and felt we wanted to walk at our own pace. Plenty of information posted around the site.

History, history, history. We opted not to have a guide or audio guide for this site. We took a nice walk through the grounds taking in everything we had already learned about Rome and the Colosseum. I enjoy history and architecture and really loved just taking in the views and what is left at the Roman Forum. I think it's a must see!

Interesting history, not much to see. Visited the Roman Forum during our Rome tour and expected there to be more standing structures, however most of it was in ruins. Fortunately this was only a short portion of our tour which allowed us to appreciate it.

Simply stunning Historic setting. What did the Romans do for us? They asked in the Monty Python movie. Well it is here for all to see, Palaces, Roads, temples, hypercausts, basilica, shopping arcades. All over 2000 years old. If you want to see the remains of this fabulous culture then visit the Forum
A stunning area of Roman history. A walk through the Forum is a step back in Roman time. It's hard to believe you are walking in such old structures.
Awesome. This place is awe inspiring. Even to try and imagine how magnificent it would have looked in its day.
Wow. We so loved this piece of Roman history and spent some time wandering around. Again if you were apart of a tour group the history is brought to life

Wonderful place. Big territory, a lot of artifacts and architectural monuments. The Forum has several entrances. There are drinking fountains (free) and vending machines with bottled water (expensive). 2-3 hours you need to see everything.

A must see !!. We went on an organised tour of colleseum and roman forum. So glad we booked at home prior to trip as the queues are horrendous... the forum is a must see ..untouched Rome. Fascinating..
More than just rocks. Well worth the effort to visit. Can be arduous on a hot day so take plenty to drink. Audio sets are available at a reasonable cost and are essential to the whole experience.
good. interesting but not as much here to see as the other surrounding attractions - was part of a tour that we took to the colosseum and pantheon

Let your imagination run...relive the ancient times. The Roman Forum is a must visit site. The guide can help you picturise the place as it was during that time...you can let your imagination run and visualise the life during that period.
Awesome. Take your time here because everywhere you look is awesome! I couldn't get enough photos. Unbelievable history & architecture, not to be missed.
Best ruins ever. With two male teenagers it sure did fascinate them enough to keep walking around with me to see every single part of this wonder. We loved it! Defo a must!

THE BEST IN THE WORLD. if you wont feel the history is the perfect location!!!
the only place for feel this!!!!! roma is this!!!!!! no other city
have this incredible old old history !!!!!!!!!one time in the life you
have need visit this city magic
The center of government and city life.. The life of those who lived and worked here is highlighted. The locations and uses of buildings and spaces is discussed.
Must See. Unbelievable wonderful, so much to see and take in. To get all the information it is best take a tour.
Must See. Unbelievable wonderful, so much to see and take in. To get all the information it is best take a tour.
Amazing history!. Take a guided tour of the Roman Forum. It will give you a better perspective on thousands of years of Roman history. It's fascinating!

Guide Not Needed. This is a part of the Colosseum complex and a group ticket with a guide is quite common. However, I suggest you get your own ticket, there are no lines for this area and it is a large place so you need lots of time which the guide will use up telling you background stories that you can read up on Wiki on your own before getting there. No point standing in the heat listening to stuff you already know.Many beautiful things to see here as you wander around, in many ways reminiscent of the remains at Herculaneum or Pompeii.
Tracy at The Forum . Visited this site with Chris from Crown Tours Italy. It's a beautiful site and a real must. You can't know Rome until you see and understand its beginnings. It's just awesome!

Not to be missed!. Very interesting. Did this in combination with the Colosseum and the Palantine Hill. Guide spoke to us before entering then left us to wander round on our own which was nice. Don't miss the church with the mosaics.

Impressive and thought provoking. To stroll round the Roman forum brings history to life. All the names are brought to mind and the various monuments/ruins are impressive. We wanted to take our time so used an audio guide rather than a guide. Unfortunately the audio guides did not work well and were hard to use which is our only negative comment.
well worth visiting. I had read that the forum was disappointing and cannot agree. There was so much to see, lots of information displayed, great atmosphere and fantastic views of Rome as well.

A glance to the past. The forum is an amazing opportunity to have an idea of how roman lived in the past. The old chapels are amazing. Make sure to wear comfortable sneakers before going and prebook your ticket ( usually the same ticket of the colluseum ). And must have an audioguide.

Amazing views . This is the second time I have been to this attraction. I would say it is pretty amazing if you're into history! It does get kind of repetitive being it is remains and statues! But I def recommend. It is a huge part of ancient Roman history. If you're not into that I wouldn't spend the money on it lol. Very big attraction !!!

History comes Alive. As many times as I have been to the Forum, every time I am privileged to go the experience just gets better. Imagine all of the people and events that occurred in this relatively compact piece of earth. For history buffs its the closest thing to heaven.This trip I did the self guided tour although if you have never been ,some of the expedia sponsored tours are the best. Throw that in with the Coliseum and Palatine Hill tours, you have made it a memorable day. Wear sturdy walking shoes as the footing can be treacherous. No doubt, the Roman Forum it is one the most special places on earth.
Time traveling!. Wonderful experience through ancient rome. Good for a walk, Good for chilren. Take time to breath and feel the experience.
Well worth the money. Arrive first thing in the morning. Take sandwiches and fluids as you will be their most of the day as there is just so much to see.

So much to see and do. Amazing ruins, lots to look around, plus the Palatine museum.Regular drinking fountains and vending machines with snacks and drinks. Toilets do get very busy.Located next to Colloseum- buy a ticket here that also covers the Colloseum (12 euros each when we went) and skip the lines.The entrance on Palatine Hill is quieter than the main entrance.Best to go to the viewing platform earlier in the day as it does get very busy.Take your camera for some amazing shots of Rome.

WOW!!. The size and the grandeur of the structures are amazing today---it is hard to fathom just how majestic this must have been at the height of the Roman Empire. We had a great guide, but our tour was the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. The site is overwhelming with artifacts and structures, and one could really spend a complete morning or afternoon learning and appreciating---and still want to know more. There literally are relics everywhere---they could be doing archaeological digs here for years and only scratch the service. The Arch of Titus, the House of the Vestal Virgins, the Arch of Septimius Severus, the remains of the Temple of Castor & Pollux and the remains of the Temple of Saturn---lots to see.

Great piece of history and culture. We selected a guided tour of the Roman Forum along with the Colosseum including the underground area. Booking the tour was a definite requirement to first bypass the long queues and secondly to have an experienced guide tell you the history of everything. It was 36 deg on the day of our visit so a hat and sun cream were essential along with a endless supply of water. There were several places where you could refill your bottle with good clean cold water from the same source the Romans used all those years ago. There is little shade out in the forum so ensure good protection on a hot day.

Must see. It s beautiful to stroll at various times. Sun light is best early morning and late afternoon. It is lovely to set on the s benches on the sides and admire the monuments around. I suggest visiting two hours before sunset and stroll to the Coliseum, spend some time there and stroll back. You will enjoy it day and night. It was nice to set next to the coliseum listening to street music players for some time when the weather permits.

tried it once on our own, but then grabbed a tour.... which was well worth it as the history of this area is complicated and seeing it made much more interesting in context. But don't worry, if you're like us and hate to plan ahead, there are several tour companies lining the streets that were offering same day (ours was within the same hour) tours.

was very interesting. we did the forum tour at night. i would recommend this as during the day it is very crowded. it was a lot of fun and very interesting. our guide was really good and knowledgeable
Amazing ruins. Amazing structures still exist. Can't imagine what the area looked like with more buildings on top of one another!
A great place to visit. If you like ancient ruins, etc then you will love the Forum. Lots to see and explore, make sure you take some bottled water as there is a lot of walking involved.

A feel for Ancient Rome . We visited whilst waiting for our slot at the colosseum. It is a wonderful place to stroll around and there are some very good spots to take in the views and sights. It was a very hot day but there are shady spots to take shelter and the ice cold spring water from the drinking fountains is most welcome. Well worth a visit.

Inredible history right front of us. We have visited the famous Forum Romanum and absolutely loved it. The size is HUGE, There are plenty to see and the whole experince put you back in time. Much easier to imagine how things could be back then. Just amazing. I'd go again when in Rome again.

Massive site full of history. The Forum was the centre of political, judicial and commercial life in Ancient Rome. It is now a confusing patchwork of ruined temples, basilicas and commercial buildings so do some homework before you get the there. When you arrive a good starting point is to climb up the steps to the top of the Palantine. From there you get an excellent view of the Forum and all of its major monuments like, Temple of Saturn, Arch of Septimus Severus, Temple of Romulus, and can therefore work out or refine your route.You need a good couple of hours as a minimum to cover all the sites of the Forum
Interesting but couild be better. A fascinating look at ancient Roman life. Very interesting but very limited information provided so a guide would be good.
Back in time . You can really imagine what the forum would be like in times gone by. An amazing sight with so many artifacts and so much to see.

Fascinating tour for history dunce. Great tour guide brought this alive and made me want to know more. Go as early as possible in the morning, no shade on a hot day, book ahead as there are long queues otherwise. The tour covered Coliseum, Palatine and Forum and would have liked a tour of just the Palatine and Forum.

Interesting. We visited the palentine hill and the forum after being at the colosseum for the morning (opposite each other) . The colosseum and palantine hill are enough walk on their own but all 3 together is too much, especially in the heat. Very interesting to look around and would recommend going

Perfect history telling site of Rome. I preferred this over the colloseum just because it provides such a perfect view on the big history of Rome. Definitely worth doing the km in the site and a great view from the balcones!

Fascinating. Best to go out of the peak heat times as little shade and no refreshments once inside, although there is a set of toilets.Great to see so much ancient antiquity in the heart of a modern city. We'd seen coliseum previously but had to pay for entrance there and to palatine hill as well, but still worth the fee even though we only made use of the one site.

Bad for Caesar - Good for Travelers. We walked the perimeter of the area, taking pictures and reading about its history. Not sure Caesar really met his maker here, but you can certainly imagine it happening on these grounds. Who knows? What exists is a fingerprint of a long dead world of advanced people who understood so much about the world they inhabited but had very little understanding of the world beyond...their loss
Just amazing. We were very impressed by the Roman Forum. An absolute must when visiting Rome! We suggest to book a tour with Real Rome Tours - so you get many interesting informations.

Worth visiting on its own - very interesting. Like many other travellers I saw advice to buy admission for the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill in order to expedite entry into the Colosseum. Well I wanted to come back here and say that I found the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill WAY more interesting than the Colosseum. While not huge like Pompeii it was so interesting to wander around what essentially looks like an ancient town square. There was a variety of things to see as far as architecture and statues, along with a bit of natural beauty and pleasant panoramic views. There was also a museum display or two to see. Again, I found this visit much more pleasant and interesting than the Colosseum.
A must visit for every traveler. The Roman Forum is a must visit for every traveler. Walk back through history and then stop for a nice meal or enjoy the crowds.
great history. walking around and seeing stones still with inscriptions on and parts of buildings still standing gives you an idea of what this place must once of looked like, a must visit
Stunning . A must visit. So much history to be discovered here, more than you could imagine. A good couple of hours can be spent here with history at every turn
Favourite place in Rome!. The Roman Forum is such a beautiful place, walk up Capotiline Hill where you have the most amazing view over the Forum and Rome, then head down for a walk through the ruins.
Lovely to walk around and breath history. Just going there, walking around and enjoying the surroundings it's worth the ticket! Great to visit after Colosseum and worth spending around 1 hour.
Family trip to Italy. Wonderful area to walk around and feel the history. Great for pictures and scenic views of the area.

Lots to see. Did this as part of a guided tour. Lots of different and well preserved buildings to look at in the heart of Rome. Guide gave very detailed explanation of its history which was fascinating. Would highly recommend.

Great way to skip the line for collusseum.. You can buy a combined ticket and enter collusseum from the inside of this amazing "park"Remember to bring water and snacks, the place is huge.I would recommend a tour guide because the history of many of the ruins are hard to imagine without the history.This is a place to walk for hours.Don't go to this place stressing through it. Take it easy and you will enjoy it a lot!
Good for Historians. Old ruins of the Roman Empire are there as excavations. You can try to understand the way of living of the Romans. A part of the travel to city of Rome, yes.

A place full of history; a walk through ancient Rome. Walking through the Roman Forum is like you take a journey in ancient Rome : you can see the ancient temples, remains of churches when was done the business with slaves or grain, the remains of the important places that made history in Ancient Age. I was fascinated to discover between the ruins of the Forum a small dark and litlle room called Area of Caesar. The legend says in that place Mark Antony put the body of Caesar (after his assassination) to be honored as a god. In this place I saw a yellow rose ...put there in the memory of a Great Caesar.
so interesting. So much to see, you need to give yourself plenty of time, take a drink and a snack! Also an umbrella, we had a thunderstorm while there!

walk back in time. A must see place.Did this as part of the colleseum tour which honestly in hind sight was too expensive. Do it your self and save yourself some euros to spend on wine and pasta.Do have a good look around and go to Palatine hill and look at the circus massimo don't be too excited as its a bit of a disappointment but you must see it in order to "do Rome" Loos are right at the back of the forum they take a bit of finding.Security is strict be prepared to get your bags opened up its the same everywhere it's for your safety so don't be upset or annoyed.All in all a nice few hours spent and the weather was great so happy people.

Located in the heart of Rome. It is a rectangular forum located in the centre of Rome which housed several ancient Government buildings now in ruins. It was the venue of public speeches, criminal trials, song, dance and festivity during the early Roman Empire. It is located in a small valley between Palatine and Capitoline Hills and adjacent to the impressive Colosseum and visited by several million tourists each year.

History at it's best. It's so amazing to see how Rome looked back in Roman times. The fact that it has been protected and kept this way for centuries tells me the respect that the Italians have for their history.
Nice story. I recommend to take a guide there it is came with the palatiom and the coliseum guide too.I recommend the guide cause this place have a nice story behind it

Outstanding. This is amazing and fascinating Place to visitCould do with a few more sign in English to explain the various remains and their history for the independent traveller However we had a good guide book to help Make sure to wear a hat as it is really hot and there is not a lot of shelter There are toilets in the site and although you cannot take water /liquids in with you you can fill from the fountains inside with water that is safe to drink as it is filtered in from hills outside the city.This goes for the colosseum too.Amazing historical site

Take a private tour.... Far more important and historically vital than the overcrowded Colosseum, but much more difficult to grasp. We ended up splurging a bit on a private tour with Daniella Hunt of Mirabilia Urbis Tours (review elsewhere), and suddenly this collection of collapsed columns and stones sprung to life. She brought home how this was the centre of Western European culture and the defining place for concepts like nation states. It is unmissable and so vital to one's understanding of this amazing city and its influence on almost every aspect of our modern world...

Spectacular!. This site blew me away. There is so much history to explore, architecture to marvel at and monuments to behold. I'd recommend spending at least a full morning or afternoon there to do it justice. There is a great worth-seeing exhibition on just now too so get there before it finishes. I so loved this site, with its wonderful views and f I'm lucky enough to return to Rome for a third visit I'll definitely be back.

Something you must see in your life time. Visited in August, it was hot but it made it feel more authentic if that makes sense! beautiful place, so interesting. I took a wonderfully organised tour, highly recommend it along with seeing the colloseum.

Takes you back in time. There is so much to see here that you need to allow plenty of time. Many parts are well labelled in several languages including English. You need to be fairly fir to see a lot of it as there are lots of stairs and slopes. The joint ticket for Forum and Colosseum allows you to visit the second place on the following day.

Discover ancient Rome. If you are a history enthusiast or just simply enjoy ancient history, this is a place in Rome that has to be on your short list.Tickets are available online and combine entry to Palatine, Collosseo and Roman Forum.

It reeks of history but get a good guide. The Forum is one of the oldest places in Rome. The ruins are fascinating but to benefit most try to go with a knowledgable guide.The forum is close to the Collesium and is at the heart of City and must see attractionThe excavations here are ongoing and it's easy to get lost
Beautiful . We didn't have much time here but you could easily spend half a day here. So much to see here. Very beautiful place

Old Rome at its best. The forum is one of Romes attractions that is best seen with the assistance of a tour guide as they have so much knowledge about what happened here and how it developed, we managed to get a tour guide who took us round the forum and the colosseum one after the other.

Fascinating Look into Rome's Past. I would advise visitors to do a fair amount of reading about The Roman Forum before you visit the site. A good understanding of the layout will help you enjoy the visit more. Start at the gate nearest the Colosseum and work your way down the main pathway. Note that sturdy shoes are a must because of the rough cobblestones. You can then take side strolls into the various areas along the main path. Expect heavy crowds and kids with selfie sticks making glamour shots to be in your way. Be sure to bring along a water bottle from your hotel. If you run out there is a free tap flowing from an aquifer below The Forum. Pure and cold and refreshing.

A great visit once you know how to negotiate the ticket booths!. The site itself is always amazing, however getting the tickets and entry is now a nightmare. I cannot understand the thinking behind the signage and where you actually get your tickets. It creates more queues and delays.However once you have them, and get in to the area it is a great experience. So more now open than a few years ago, but they should remove the 'art' that's been dotted about the place.

So many layers of history. There aren't many places where you can see so many centuries of buildings stacked on top of each other - to the point where our guide says "ignore that one, it's medieval and much to modern to be of any interest"! This place makes historical figures, such as Mark Anthony and Julius Caesar come alive.
You have to visit. A must visit after Colosseum. Take your time to walk around and enjoy the history and views. If you are a couple it's even better, enjoy ever views with a kiss

Centre of the known world. The historical, architectural and political significance of this place was emphasised by our excellent guide Alessandro. He provided insight into each aspect of forum, was humorous and encouraged enquiry from our group. Although our tour was expensive it was worth the cost to ensure that we were suitably informed as to every aspect of how the Roman Empire was governed from this extraordinary civilisation.

The Forum. Adjacent to the Colosseum and tucked below the Paletine Hill the Forum provides an opportunity to fully envisage life in ancient Rome.The queue is long so I would advise the following:1. Buy your ticket online in advance and your wait at the Forum will be no longer than 10 minutes.2. Visit in the morning as the afternoons are crowded.3. Take an audio guide (€7) for the Forum & Paletine Hill.

Forum at night, amazing!. This was the highlight of my Rome visit. We were a little tired from sightseeing during the day, I think our tour started at 9:45pm. However, the temperature was better, there were very few people, and our Archeologist guide Frederica was very knowledgeable and obviously passionate about what she does. I think we paid $20 per ticket, a great deal for the value of the tour. My only suggestion would be to have people buy or borrow flashlights as navigating around the cobblestones & steps at night can be tricky.
Simply the best place to visit!. Stunning. Although much of it can be viewed from the outside it is still worthwhile paying for a ticket and going into the Forum.
A piece of history . Just two minutes walk from the colosseum, all of which you will be standing in long lines... But if you have the time, don't miss that piece of history.
Amazing and Grand. Second visit here. It's a great place to take photos and get the feel of ancient Rome. The weather is great in September so wear comfortable shoes and enjoy!

Unbelievable. What an experience seeing this. You study it in school and see it replicated in movies but being there is completely different. Wish I could step back in time and see what it looked like in its prime. You won't be disappointed.

architecture is stunning. The history is captivating, and the architecture is stunning. Don’t forget your camera. Something useful to know is the Roman Forum is Included with the entry fee to the Colloseum (triple ticket). Alongside the ruins there is a museum, which covers the history of the Palantine Hill.

So Historic. This is a visually stunning place and full of history. I do however think you'd be best seeing it with a guide who can tell you exactly what your looking at or download an audio guide prior to your visit as there is not much signage at the actual site.Another must-see location.

a must see. we were advised by our hotel to visit this location early in the day before the crowds build up which meant we could take our time and enjoy it at our leisure. wonderful history but just be aware that if you are unsteady on your feet its a bit of a trip hazard. we visited the colloseum in the same visit as they are next to one another.

Collection of ancient ruins. This site is spread out over quite a wide area and is a pleasant stroll without too much overcrowding. I would advise the purchase of a guide book or tour so you know what you are looking at. Also wear insect repellant as there is green space
Worth seeing. For history lovers especially it's really interesting and worth a visit, really wonderful. A musft see

Incredible and historic. Roman Forum is fabulous. We opted for a shorter experience through it walking around with an abbreviated guide. You can spend as long or as little as you want here. Close to the Colosseum and can make for a solid day to go from one to the other. The most difficult part was actually finding an exit from the Roman Forum.

History at its best. My review of this is short because there is not much to see but if you read up on it there is so much history from this spot. It will take minutes to spend at this point and read up on it afterwards to understand what took place centuries ago.
Best sightseeing in Rome. This is it. The quintessential Rome of your dreams, and nothing else comes close. Just go. Whatever it takes.

Great historical site; needs better signage . While this is an amazingly cool historical site, the signage leaves something to be desired. We were fortunate that we had a private tour guide with us who filled in the information gaps and we noted other tourists standing nearby were listening to our guide to learn more about the historical ruins.Worth going to see? Absolutely yes.Worth seeing on your own? Only if you have a really good written guide.Recommendation: make sure you are with a guided group, most likely as part of a multi-site tour group
Amazing archaeologic place.. Seeing the ruins of Rome is amazing. Every time I visit they have done more excavations which makes it worthwhile to go again and again..

Overshadowed by the Colosseum. Good, but as one of the few historical parts of Rome not still as it was in the same condition as it's prime it seems somewhat forgotten.Good to sit and look over, the whole landscape is great to just take in.Also lots of street entertainment, some evening dancing in the street can make a trip!

Showcase of Roman Empire. The Forum faces Palantine Hill and Capitoline Hill. At first glance, it looks like a collection of ruins, which it is. You must use your imagination to see the immense importance this was to the ancient Romans. The ruins include temples, basilicas and arches. The arches were used to commemorate victories and elections. The Forum was the nucleus of many activities including gladiator matches and public speeches, and became the showcase of the Roman Empire because of its statues and architecture. It was an important center of Roman activity. It was the place where individuals are allowed to express their views on anything. Only Roman adult males could speak at the Forum. The Forum was used for festivals and religious ceremonies.

Fascinating. We visited the roman forum as part of a tour that also took in the colosseum. Needs to be visited as part of a tour. But be warned, the crowds are large and the queues are long. Our tour guide was excellent and was well worth the €40 each. Gotta be done.

Much more than I expected!. I didn't look into this too much before going, but it was part of the skip the line ticket we bought and we were surprised by how much interesting history is found here. We had a Rick Steve's walking tour downloaded to my phone so we could hear a narrative of what we were seeing as we walked around. Pretty cool to walk on the same stones that Caesar and others surely also trod.

Nice ancient city. Ticket chains to the Forum is much shorter than to Colosseo but tickets are the same - they allow you to visit both - Colosseo and Roman Forum.You can walk in the Forum for hours - its quiet there. Even crowds of tourist doesn't disturb you.

Our Own Visit. Roman Forum was an excellent place to visit close to the Colosseum. We completed this trip in the afternoon, and we went without a guide. All the sites have explanations to read at the areas, so even if you don't have a guide you can still enjoy the History.
Covers a larger area than expected. We didn't bother walking round the Roman Forum ruins but enjoyed the great views from the top of Palatine Hill where you can see it all.

A trip must see!. This was my husbands favorite part of the trip. Since we missed our tour at the colosseum, we didn't have a tour guide here. BUT, I downloaded Rick Steve's walking tour before we left. Thank goodness! It was the perfect way for us to walk around and learn about the Forum at our own pace. VERY COOL pieces of history.

Fabulous ruins and history. Great views of the old city. So much history to see and more being discovered as digs continue to this day. Well worth the visit to tread the same roads as so many did centuries ago.
Beautiful. Superb history and great views. Lots to explore and see here, take your time to wander round and discover everything.

Amazing! . Visited as part of a tour of the Colosseum and just wow to both! Extremely fascinating and stunning! Pictures are not tell same as actually being up close and wow with eyes wide open, speechless I was with how truly amazing everything is! Definitely a must see! Highly recommend!

Prepare yourself. This is the place it all happened, and you will not believe how inspiring it still is. Every site has a story, every stone a piece of history, every step you take is in history. A fantastic site and mind blowing experience.

A must see. The effect of walking amongst these buildings that have stood for thousands of years cannot be underestimated. No secret tips needed here - it's all plain to see. So worth the entrance fees.

Great site. The remnants of history are beautiful and the crowds don't seem as big since it's an open space. We used a guide since it came with the Colosseum tour and we almost ditched it, but we were glad we didnt.
Learn a lot about Rome. This was a very educational space, seeing how Rome has been built on top of what was Rome was a real eye opener.
Stunning. Just walking through the ruins and trying to understand how the Roman Empire functioned was more than interesting. So interesting. The architecture, the society. Fenomenal

Walk Through History. We visited this sight on out way from the Colloseum as they are beside each other & it was an interesting walk if at times frustrating due to the lack on sign posts to guide you around. It has been well written about in numerous books & is well worth a visit to see how the Ancient Romans lived. The frustrating part comes when you get to the end & as we had hoped to carry on through to the Campitoline Museums on the hill.Unfortunately the exit is back through the Forum & out towards the Piazza Venezia then a walk back around to the front of the Piazza.
Impressive . Plenty of history to look up to explain this area. Rome has so many ancient ruins. Nearby is the Colosseum and Capitol Hill with a representation of Romulus and Remus.

Great spot for history and photography. I loved this place but I'm finding it very difficult to describe. The ruins are really cool, and the scenery is really nice as well. If you have a panoramic option on your camera this is a fantastic place to make use of it. The price for the ticket was included in the one for the colosseum, and they're right beside each other so you can make a day out of seeing both at once.

Go prepared!. Fascinating place if you're interested in Ancient Rome but read up about it first or hire a guide. Be warned, it really is a vast area and to do it justice requires stamina and comfortable shoes. Look out for the green parrots flying between the trees.

Amazing!. Along with the Palatine hill, this is a MUST do. It will show you how advanced Romans were compare to the rest of Europe. Explore the forum streets and climb the hill for amazing 360 views of Rome.
Vacation. Best visited with a tour guide. You need to have a working knowledge of what you are viewing and why it was built so many centuries ago to fully appreciate it.

Fantastic.. We visited this as part of the Colosseum tour and I found the whole area extremely interesting. The ruins really captivated me and was a very memorable visit. The guide was included in the Colosseum tour although we took the tour of The Forum later that day. Late afternoon and there were very few people around.
So much to see. This was included in our "Roman Guy" tour of the Colosseum & it was fabulous. Lots of walking, but well worth it as you oversee all of the Roman Forum ruins

Well worth visiting ...give yourself plenty time. Visited this along with the Palatine gardens. In all, this took 5 hours. We opted to go on a self guide ..ie we read up about it before going and decided on a DIY visit so we could take our time and not feel rushed by a tour guide. The average tour is about 2-3 hours. We did request 2 audio guides but since only one of us possessed ID we could only have 1 guide. Note: Your ID will be retained by staff until the audio guide is returned.There are no cafes only a couple of vending machines, so a packed lunch is essential. Words fail me in trying to describe this magnificent site - suffice to say it is enormous as are some of the remaining pillars and building walls.

A must do!. Our tour of the coleseum included a guide as well for the Roman Forum. Stan was wonderful and gave a great tour then let us go explore afterwards. Starting looking down into the old city and hearing the key parts made it a bit more interesting when we got to ground level. Don't miss this one!
Yet another great tour in a day. Mindblowing that you're actually allowed to wander where Romans walked and lived. So much history, so little time. Have to spend more next time, which will be soon.

Right next to Palatine hill, might as well do both. As suggested for Palatine hill, you should go there early. Highly recommend to go and buy your ticket early and see the place before the crowds. I can't imagine what the summer crowds are like but even Sep was long.

Early visit recommended! . Arrived 10 minutes after opening and no queues, paid for our ticket (ticket price includes Palatine Hill and Colosseum for 2 days, very reasonable price) and walked straight in. Do not leave it any later, as we were leaving the queue was insanely long! Be prepared for plenty of walking and plenty of steps. Early morning was best as it was quiet and relatively cool. You can get an audio guide at €7, one between 2 was good. We spent a good few hours walking around, and we didn't even get to all of it!

great photo opportunities. I didn't love visiting the Roman Forum as a part of the tour. It was too hot in July and I was almost passing out on the heat. This part of the tour is the most exposed to the sun so bring a great hat and loads of water if you are going to come here in July. Great photos to be taken. History buffs will love this but turns out I'm not one of those.

Completely breathtaking. Make sure you have a cpl of hours spare, comfy walking shoes and lots of water! This place deserves a good couple of hours to explore and take in..... Amazing to see centuries of history and walk where ancient history and the roman empire was at its best!!
Everything was great!. Wear your best walking shoes because this is a must see....every nook and cranny of this place is so worth it.

Huge site, just amazing. What a wonderful place, takes you back thousands of years. It is so amazing to think how clever the Romans were so many thousands of years ago. As it is all outside it is definitely preferable to visit on a fine day.There are many crowds visiting the colosseum but the ticket for the Forum together with the colosseum is pretty good value and both sites are worth it.

Impressive. A good way to spend your day on a sunny day! I must admit that we saw it from outside, from the outskirts of the sit, because you can see almost everything and I didn't consider that I want to see the ruins from up close, but the big picture!

Crowded but must see. Whatever remains that have been excavated is spectacular but this area is largely unsheltered so it can get really hot when the sun is out. Highlights include Caesar's altar where he was burnt when he died. Best to join a tour to get more insight on the Roman Forums. A Lot of the relics are actually housed in the Vatican Museum now.
MUST SEE!!! --- takes you to a different place & time!. when in rome, this is definitely an experience!!! even in the ruins, you can see how ancient romans value beauty and symmetry!

Beautiful view of Old City Rome. We did a Colesseum, Palatine hill, and forum tour. It was very long and became boring at times. However, the forum was filled with neat sculptures and building remains. If you can, find a picture of what they believed it looked like thousands of years ago in order to get the whole idea.

Amazing and beautiful . I recommend buying the Colosseum ticket online through the Colosseum as it also gets you admission into the Forum and they are only a short two minute walk apart with the tickets being valid for two days. It took us about 90 minutes to get through the Forum so I would suggest leaving two hours for it. It was unbelievable and still in fathomable to see something built by the Romans so many years ago. We didn't do a tour and enjoyed our visit but as it is no self explanatory, if you are interested in the details, a tour could be the way to go. We enjoyed a visit to just take it all in. One of the highlights of my trip to Rome.

Jaw droppony. This was my absolute favourite attraction/landmark from our Rome trip.Incredible to imagine what it must have been like in its heyday. Wear comfortable shoes, very rough terrain and cobblestone roads, hills, and stairs.The Rick Steves audio podcast tour is excellent, and added to our visit immensely.Price includes the colosseum- 12 euros and the pass if good for two consecutive days so you don't have to do this all in one.I will admit on a hot day it's a lot. A lot of walking and sweating and climbing so bring an empty water bottle (no water allowed inside the colosseum) and fill up at the water fountains provided.

Wonderful ruins. Absolutely amazing to be able to wander freely amongst 2000 year old ruins. The one thing that would make it better would be to create a fully restored (or replica) building as a living museum. Just so much to see....almost too much to take in. Don't leave Rome without visiting. Do wear good shoes though as the ground underfoot as not at all even and there are lots of steep stair and hills. Take water!

Truly Awe Inspiring. Our personal tour guide took us through the Roman Forum after our tour of the coliseum and it was so amazing. Don't miss it, but don't go without a tour guide. There is too much historical information to try to do it on your own.

Beautiful Site. We visited the Roman Forum in conjunction with the colosseum. It was an incredible site and well worth walking through. Be aware that it will take a large portion of your day and requires a lot of walking on uneven terrain with lots of steep hills. Take water with you!

Good visit on a late afternoon. The Forum is basically ruins.But the best spot to seem them is from the Palatine Hill, so don´t miss it (this was my third time to the Forum and the first time I took the time to climb the Palatine Hill)

Roman Forun just next to Colloseum. Visited May 2014. I as awestuck by the huge architecture and the ruins surrounding it. The church entrance is locked maybe because it is more ruins inside, but the whole grounds included in the Roman Forum is worth experiencing. Visited after the Colloseum, no queue and the colloseum ticket included the forum visit. You feel like minute creatures in this ruins even with so many people!!

hot and humid and up hill. My tour guide was very knowledgable and walked us all over including every hill she could find. It should be an hour vist but she stretched it 3. I had to buy a book with an overlay page to appreciate what these pile of rocks used to be .

Headless statue anyone?. My problem is I like to be able to visualise things as they were which means the Roman Forum and I were never going to get on. If you like looking at floor plans this is for you. If you can get excited just imagining what something was like before most of it disappeared then you will enjoy this. It's part of the Colosseum ticket and I think I know why :)

Extremely hot.... We recommend buying the tickets online (you can buy ticket for Colosseum+Forum, as they're about 200 meters apart, and the ticket is valid for 2 days). The Forum is simply stunning, and I believe even people who aren't history aficionados will be amazed. To go through the whole place thoroughly, you'll need at least 2 hours. The only thing you should avoid is going here while it's generally hot and sunny outside. There aren't many water-refill points, and the temperature gets really high. We went there improvidently, it was around 1 pm on a bright, summer day - the temperature was above 40°C. My girlfriend actually almost collapsed.
Wow. Can't believe the Romans could build something like this so many years ago. Even though it is ruins, it's still amazing to see . History surrounding this is amazing, I was blown away.

Combine with Colosseum, Palatine and Circus Maximus. The heart of the ancient Roman political, commercial and religious center, which complements the tour to the other sourrinding historical sites: the Colosseum, circus Maximus and the palatine. By visiting this combo you'll get most of it and learn and understand how the ancient Romanssi lived. Roman Forum must sees are the basilica ('court house') and the Vesta temple. Really a great place to visit when in Rome.

Not Self Explanatory. This was part of a cosmos tour in Italy. You need a guide for this place. It is not Self Explanatory. Along with the ruins there is the museum which covers the history of the Palantine Hill. There are also seasonal exhibitions. The hill also provides some very good views of Rome and of the Circus Maximus.

Amazing!. You cannot describe in amy words how brilliant it was to go here, and see these icons of Roman architecture stand out amongst the rest of the surroundings. Truely an amazing place, and everyone should see them.i actually prefered this to the Pantheon!

Incredible! . We absolutely loved the Roman Forum. It's hard to believe that it was covered so long under the earth! Just to imagine all of the activities that happened there was so cool. Definitely a must do!
Amazing, astounding. No words can describe this place. Tip - book your tickets online first, you'll walk straight in with no queuing.

sightseeing.. amazing place. a lot of history to view. a lot of walking too but definitely worth it. you will be surprised how much there is to see. make sure you have plenty of water with you as its very hot.

History buffs MUST go here. We saw this as part of a City Wonders group tour and it really was amazing! The history in this area is mind blowing. I enjoyed looking at all the different structures from different eras. I've never seen anything like it.
Can't Miss. This was a tour stop for us and it can't be beat for the historical significance and obviously great pictures. Definitely history 101.
Highlight of visit to Rome. Headed to the Roman Forum 90 minutes before close time, which was great as it was cooler and less busy than at peak times. This was the highlight of our trip to Rome!
2016 Anniversary Rome. We enjoyed the Roman Forum guided by an excellent Historian. Amazing beauty in every direction. You are in awe of everything you see.

Not just a few ruins. Included with the entry fee to the Colloseum we think the Forum is probably the best attraction in Rome. Along with the ruins there is the museum which covers the history of the Palantine Hill. There are also seasonal exhibitions. The hill also provides some very good views of Rome and of the Circus Maximus.

So much to see!. We did a City Wonders tour, combining the Colosseum and the Forum. There's so much to see that even without loitering too much we easily spent over 3 hours between both places. It's certainly good to have a guide as you get so much more from the visit. You get some amazing photos.

An ancient city, a rectangular plaza. Comprising an area of roughly one-quarter mile by less than one-fifth of a mile, it is a do-able walk and it is free (but the Colosseum admission will cost extra). It isn't possible to walk through the actual structural ruins themselves but getting close enough for some really good looks is possible. The Forum sits in a valley between the Capitoline and Palatine Hills. It was the hub for commercial, political, judicial and religious activities. This was the heart of ancient Rome.Entry is very close to the Arch of Titus and the end is a little ways past the Forum Square, close to the Temple of Saturn. The exit is close to the Arch of Septimus Severus. Just outside the exit lie the steps up to Capitoline Hill (there's an admission price to tour it).The Arch of Constantine and the Colosseum are located outside of the Forum's entry point.The Forum flourished for about 1,000 years (500 BC to 500 AD) and its demise was hastened by the active "recycling" program, scavenging materials for use elsewhere. In the Middle Ages, it was the local "cattle field". It took a Christian Pope to bring it back to life through excavations so that its lessons would not be lost.Signs along the way are particularly helpful in identifying the remnants of the various arches, structures, and fields. Packing along a tour book or getting an audio guide ($5 EU) might be helpful (we were on a guided tour) and allow for adequate time, maybe upwards of 1 1/2 hours (2 would be good) if you plan to actually read the signs in front of the monuments.This should go without saying but ... wear a hat and sunscreen, dress comfortably (shoes with sturdy soles), pack water along, and take your time. This is not an Olympic event.There is no way to convey the enormity of the structures and how small and insignificant one can feel when seeing the whole of the Forum revealed for the first time.

First Sunday of the month is free!. Definitely worth visiting. Lot better with a guided tour, otherwise is hard to understand what were the buildings for... There are almost no panels with information and very few places with shadow and not many water taps so make sure you have enough sunblock and water with you if you go on a sunny day. Our recommendation: Take a guide... we wouldn´t have understood anything without him because is soooo many different ruins!

Do not miss a visit here. Amazing and really interesting, especially with our guide Water fountains in the grounds, apparently with spring water, lovely and coldthis is amazing, and overshadowed by the Coliseum, good walking shoes and take your time
History Lesson 101. A great place to learn about the Roman culture and history. Combined with other attractions like palantine and colooseum, a good 2-3 hours will pass by.

wonderful. as part of a tour that included the forum. Our guide was really important to get the full picture of this areas history. the tour was cut short due to weather conditions but still worth the visit
Ms. Lucy. Beautiful walk in antic Rome. You will travel in time. So many beautiful buildings. Nice architecture.

Wow is all I can say, I could have walked it all day.. Incredible venue, get Rick Steves book and bring it with you for information, oh, and also get the audio tour for both Palatine Hill and the Forum, it is worth it.

A Must See!. Take a good guide book. Allow plenty of time. We were rushed and although we had visited here before - I felt disappointed that we had such a brief visit this time. Stand there and visualize what it would have been like.
Do with Colosseum tour. Mind boggling, how did they do this. Do this tour with the Colosseum and before the Vatican to get perspectives of where the resources came from.

A sprawling piece of 2,000+ year old history. I was on crutches for our trip to the Roman Forum thanks to a scooter accident in Capri, so we only saw a fraction of what the area has to offer. Regardless, it is an impressive and historically significant area that—along with the Colosseum and perhaps the Vatican—is the top sight to see on a visit to Rome.

Combine this with a tour of the Colloseum. Your entrance ticket to the Colloseum will include a visit to the Forum, located just a short walk away. You can spend hours here and will get more out of it with a good guidebook or an audio tour. Do not miss this important site.

Old and wonderful. Next to the Colosseum, the Forum is fantastic historical site. It would have been better if we came to visit later in the year. Coming from a cold-weather country, it was hard to adapt to the heat in September. Also be careful where you step as much of the ground is uneven.We use the Roma Pass to get into the Forum but it didn't seem like there was much of a line in the morning.
Wow. This is one of the best spots in Rome. Just seeing all the ruins in there original positions. To much there to explain.

Great guide. Went on a combined tour of the Roman Forum & Palatine Hill with an excellent guide (sorry can't remember his name). The guide has a passion for Ancient Rome and was extremely entertaining in his comparisons between Ancient Rome and the customs, language and sayings still in place today. Had only planned to visit the Colosseum however was so pleased we paying the extra for this tour as well
lot of stones. A lot of ruins that recall the duty Rome empire and especially Julius Caesar.It is near the Colosseum and racecourse, where the emperor was room for 300,000 spectators

Simply amazing . Right next to the coliseum the Forum is a MUST ! The history here is amazing ! And it is so intact .... Everywhere you look it is breathtaking But be prepared to walk and stand .... Can be quite tiring if you've just done the coliseum but well worth it Get a ticket online in advance - get the triple that is The Coloseum, forum and palatine hill altogether - they are all right next to each other and saves queuing

An acquired taste.... Absolutely loved it, however, it's not going to be for everyone.Requires an appreciation of history, an imaginative mind and a good set of walking legs!Your entry is included with the Colosseum so would recommend adding this to the list. Set in beautiful gardens that adorn the hill make for a perfect backdrop to an insight into a world of immense power and strength.Some brilliant photo ops among the gardens and numerous free water stops along the route to compliment the walking.Could have spent all day there, wandering around reading and imagining about what once was.
Cant say enough. Seriously-dont miss this-the history is beyond belief-use a guide though-you need to really understand what is here-couldnt believe they didnt find all of this until 1899

Ruins everywhere!. This is another site near the Colosseum that was visited for free since it was the first Sunday of the month. We went when it was very hot out but luckily had brought water with us (foundations are around to get water). We enjoyed walking around the ancient ruins and grand arches. Definitely a must see.

History galore. A great site to visit. We looked around as part of our ticket to see the colosseum and you need to have good walking shoes and take your time. Was really hot day so plenty of water.You will enjoy the site though.
Amazing experience . Next to the Colosseum. Walk between the two. The architecture is amazing. Leave plenty time. Is on hop on hop off bus route

history uncovered. loved my visit to the roman forum but did it with a tour guide because they can bring the forum to life as it can be hard to imagine when looking at some of the ruins that are still standing not to be missed

The sour remains of an empire. The Roman Forum is a poetic space. There are no entire buildings, temples or churches. Nothing is complete, and yet every stone, every brick can tell you a story with love, blood or devotion. A beautiful place to visit and rest in the shade. There is water fountains that help you all the way.

It's the Roman Forum. You have to see it, there's no other way. Go on a sunny day so you can take beautiful pictures among the ruins. The triumphal arches are in really good state. Then go up to the Palatine Hill to check out the ruins of the imperial palaces.

Roman Forum : Back in history. Ruins at Roman Forum will surely take you in history. It's a different place compared to other attractions of Rome. Although it will make you tired but being near to Colosseo and entry is covered in Colosseo ticket , so one should not miss it. If in Rome prepare yourself for walking tour irrespective of many other european countries.Enjoy :)

Could do with more info. I know they want to sell add ons to the tickets like audio tours, and luckily I already know a lot about ancient rome and find it interesting. Unfortunately if you don't you mightn't enjoy this on a standard ticket. I liked the forum but my boyfriend is less interested in archaeology and history and found the forum boring until I showed him what it was like back in the day

Sheer scale is breathtaking. Beware, this place is much bigger than you think, we did the audio tour and the information is so much more than the labels, to really get into the details, you will need at least 4 hours. Shade is hard to come by. If you are time short, go with a guided tour for the main highlights, but still allow plenty of time.
Part of the Colosseum tour. This is included in the Colosseum tour and if your legs can take it, well worth strolling around to see how the Romans lived.

Totally Breathtaking!!. You could never appreciate just how amazing this place is from photographs, you have to see in person, it will take your breath away. I recommend taking an empty water bottle with you as water is not allowed to be taken inside due to security but there are free water fountains once inside. Also wear good comfortable shoes & allow a few hours to fully appreciate everything. Entry is included to the Roman Forum with your Colosseum ticket. Enjoy!!
lots of history. We took a private tour of Colosseum and roman forum. We saw most before heavy rain. We snuck into a small old building where many people were hiding from the weather. It was fun

Definitely worth a visit. If you are not too tired after Colosseum, you should definitely head to Roman Forum, where you will get a taste of the ancient times. Allow for at least 1.5 to 2 hrs to have time to enjoy everything it has to offer.
Interesting site. All part of the tour, this area is also very interesting. Don't forget your water! Avoid the long queues and take a guided tour.

The remains of what was once. It was at the same time exhilarating and wistful. All that history. And all that beauty, in ruins. All the people who had walked there before me. And all the lives lost. If you let yourself get immersed by the feeling, you can almost hear millions of voices who have been there. A very powerful experience.

It felt like I was back in ancient times. You cannot visit the forum without getting a sense of what Imperial Rome must have been like. Walking on the Via Sacra and imagining the parade of captured slaves and conquering generals really brought my ancient history courses to life. The view from the Capitoline Hill was something not to be missed.

The Roman Forum is a must see in Rome!. We visited the Roman Forum and found it to be very interesting. We complimented our tour with Rick Steves audio guide which explained everything we were looking at. So much history here!
very interesting!. Use your imagination as you walk around past the ancient forum area. Lots of ruins and VERY interesting to look at. Well worth the walk around. Don't miss this area.

Impressive ruins. Really great impressive ruins of the all-day life of ancient romans. With a church, remainings of houses, an old market area, baths, nice gardens, an arc,... And also a very nice view from the top of the tower! Impessive

Great visit. You buy tickets for this as part of the entry to the Colleseum ..very interesting place ..full of history and some great buildings ...it can be quite hilly and the paths are bumpy ...make sure you have plenty water with you as you are often open to the elements and on a hot day it can be hard work but well worth a visit

Best attraction!. I was completely blown away by the forum! It's so much bigger than I thought (2 square kilometers) and was amazed at how everything was just right there in front you definitely a MUST if your in rome

History lovers dream. I have been here twice now and love it. Walking the paths of Ancient Rome the ruins of old temples and the palace gardens. You can spend a good 5hrs taking it all in. Expect to walk a lot so comfortable shoes are a must.

SO MANY AMAZING VIEWS. If you're someone who knows how to appreciate architecture you'll love looking at these ruins. There's something about them that makes you feel so impossibly small but in a good way. There's also a really good spot there to take a nice picture of the Colosseum! But yes, it was really pretty, especially when you climb to the top to take a pano of the whole roman forum.

A good day to explore. Next to the colesseum. The queue was long but there's no getting around it. 12 euros for the Roman forum and access to the colosseum. We didn't expect to be in there for nearly 3* hours but it took us that long to see everything. You can get an audio guide however they want you to leave a driver's license or something and we didn't feel comfortable doing so. There was some signs but more about the rocks and less about what they actually was and what they would of looked like which was what I wanted to really know. You must see it when you to Rome and if you don't want to you can look over the side it's especially lovely at night all lit up.
well worth visiting. This is included in the ticket to the Colosseum and has spectacular view of Rome. Entry was free on the Sunday we visited.

Roman Forum and Colosseum . Of course you should visit these two locations in Rome! I did the Roma Pass and walked right into the Colosseum instead of waiting on a huge line. (Would definitely recommend the Roma Pass). Both the colosseum and the forum did not disappoint. The history was fascinating, and the architecture was stunning. Being from the Unites States, I've never seen structures that are older than 350 years. My only criticism is that some of the people who dress up like gladiators for photo ops can be kind of aggressive (and I'm from NY, so I'm used to aggressive "hard-sell" tactics). Also, it was pretty hot when I went (wear sunscreen)! However, these things still don't affect my view of the Roman Forum. Overall, a very positive experience!

An amazing afternoon. The Roman Forum is a fantastic experience, especially if you are interested in ancient history. The ticket cost was 12€ (Coliseum + Forum) and totally worth it.It was a really hot summer day, so my advice if you visit in this time of the year: Bring a bottle of water with you.

Wear Trainers!. We spent 10 nights in Rome and tried to see all the sites, there are a lot! The Forum was one of the highlights with loads of viewpoints and an impressive spread of monuments. Make sure you wear trainers as it feels like a mountain exhibition sometimes, and the marble and dusty ground is very hot for sandals. Also make sure you have plenty of photo space on your camera as there's so much to see!

Nice place needs better organization . We went the forum and saw the special exibition of the early bizantino church near palatine hill. Very interesting. My comments the booth with the tickets was hard to find. Maybe a suggestion to sell tickets also at the places that are exits only now. Better signage would be welcome as well. We had a hard time finding the exit ☺
Take a tour of Ancient Rome. The best way to enjoy Ancient Rome is by joining a tour. It is just too much to absorb on your own. Who after all remembers Ancient history from school ?

Marvels of the ancient world. You can get a combined ticket for the Roman Forum with the Palatine Hill and the Colosseum, which is great value! Unfortunately there is no audio guide included for the Roman Forum, so it's best to come equipped with some information beforehand as there is scant detail to be found at the site itself.The Forum is an impressive collection of ruins that, despite being in ruins, still conveys an awe inspring sense of grandeur and history. You can get stunning views of the Forum from the Palatine Hill, and walk among the ruins to take in up close views. Essential viewing when you are in Rome.
Great place to spend a day. Great place to spend a day. Don't forget to bring water because this place will take up to 2 hours to visit and more.
stunning historic buildings. there is a lot to see here in the roman forum. do yourself a favour and visit the forum in the winter time since in the summer it is extremely hot.

Impressive walk through with a guide. The Forum is a neat place to walk through before or after a visit to the Coliseum. The ticket you get for the Coliseum can cover the Forum and Palatine Hill. It is really a better visit with a qualified guide. You can get a personal tour with a guide for 70 Euros an hour which covers the tickets and three hours is plenty. There is a scanner and security line for the Forum which took less than minutes to go through.It is so easy to not get what you are looking at without a guide.

Magnificent. A fabulous experience for a history buff, from the old Roman Road to the steps where Caesar was murdered. We were lucky enough to even see some archaeologists on a dig. The temples, the arches, the various pillars, the house of the vestels, the stadium; it's all there in one big massive place. Tips: As usual bring a bottle of water and don't be afraid to run out as there are heaps of water filling stations around the forum thanks to the various aqua ducts. It is going to be hot, so bring sunscreen and a cap. Remember to spare 4 to 5 hours to check the whole place out.Finally; make sure you buy a ticket from the forum before you go to the Colleseo, the queue is smaller and entry into the forum will give you a fast pass to enter the Colleseum.

Nice to spend an hour to two . It was nice place to stroll after colloseum visit .We spent one hour which was two less a time to spend at such a huge and great historic site but since we just came from pompei ; we were at ease of not skipping too much.Its nice reminder of history. If the weather is better it will be nice visit but unfortunately for us it was tooo hot.U wud go back in time if u read the notes at the sites. Nice for sometime spent

It's the heart of the ancient city!. Walk and explore the area. Read the history of the Romans and how this area was used. Being here is so much more rewarding with a little knowledge about what you're seeing.

Live History. The Roman forum is an icon of Rome. If you don't go here you may as well skip Rome (it is that big of a staple). Have a guided tour because you can image the buildings and the lives of ancient romans better with a good storyteller.

Great place of interest in you like history. Depending on your point of view this is either a pile of old rubble and ruins or a place of magical imagination Luckily for me it's the latter! Again having a guide with you in the know brings it to life and helps you understand what your actually looking at. Get it as part of a combined tour along with colosseum/palatine hill or you can visit this by yourself if you prefer Tip : Wear good footwear for these trips

Ceasar's grave not to be missed.. Foro Romano gives central Rome a very special atmosphere. I would definitely recommend a guided tour because it can be difficult to get a good overview on your own. And don't miss Ceasar's grave.
Historically informative . A lovely walk, very picturesque and informative! Beautiful spot to just sit and take in the views! Lots of roman architecture to take in and free to enter!
Jaw dropping. It's just an amazing place with a rich history. The ruins are fantastic to look at and just imagine what it must have been like.

Not built in a day!!. So much to see, so much ground to cover, and such a rich history, the Roman Forum offers a glimpse into ancient times, with architecture that still withstands the tests of time. RECOMMENDED for ALL!!!

Peek into ancient Roman World. Roman forum gives you glimpses of ancient Roman kingdom. With some well preserved walls, columns, doors and artifacts, you can create a mental picture of how ancient Rome would have looked like.

fabulous forum . great place to visit so interesting with great views only wish we could have explored more definitely goback here. look out for fresh water fountains you can top drinking bottles up with all fresh and clean there are also toilets and a small cafe.
Absolutely stunning!. An absolutely stunning attraction. Really beautiful place to walk around and think that this is definitely a must see for Rome.

Amazing History. I love Roman history and this is the epicenter! I am glad that they have added some signs as a number of years ago there were no markers at all. Right now the Curia is being renovated so you can't even see inside it, so be warned, but it looks like they are undertaking some exciting new excavations in front of it, so can't wait for that! Wear good shoes and a book, audio tour (Rick Steves has a free one) or get a guide for best experience.
very impressive. Nice place for walk, to see the museum,garden, good view of the Rome,To learn more about the roman people

Anoter Don't Miss. Right next to the Colosseum (and included in the same entrance fee), This was downtown Rome in the time of the Roman empire. If you ever took Latin in high school or college, you can imagine what the area was like in it's time, Very impressive.
Much bigger than expected. Wow what a place but its massive and lots of hills, good walking shoes needed and plenty of sunscreen very hot in Rome in August

Another.place to see. It's hard to visualise how this must have been as it has been so changed over the years. It's amazing how much is still standing in spite of rich families, popes and civil governments. The fact that it is so much lower than the surrounding churches etc only emphasises what it must have been, with the Colosseum adjoining

The heart of the city that was Rome. It's like and outdoor sculptors workshop, with decorated marble lying about and beautiful arches and temples still standing 2000+ years later. Really feel that one is walking where ancient feet have tread.
Rome's heart. One of the most famous places in Rome. The history lives here and to know this site means to know the roots of the city.

A must see, especially if you're already at the Colosseum. The Roman Forum is so cool. It's amazing to see what Rome looked like thousands of years ago. Definitely recommend getting a tour to get the inside scoop on what happened where.

To see what was once the centre of th civilised world. We toured the Forum along with the colosseum and palatine hill. it is truly and awe inspiring site. ancient history you can get right up close to. Its worth booking a guided tour as they give you so much background information and amazing details
Get a taste of ancient Rome. Definitely worth the visit ..after all these years still in great shape..The arch of triumph 2000 years old . Can the go wrong

Use a tour guide, and combine with a Colosseum tour.. It's best to use a tour guide as we did. I would not have learned much about the buildings and sites if I did a self-tour. We started out at the northwest section, near the Arch of Settimio Severo, walked along Via Sacra, and ended at the Arch of Titus, before proceeding to the nearby Colosseum. Viewing highlights for me were the Curia Julia (the old Senate building), the House of the Vestal Virgins, the Temple of Antoninus and Faustina, and views of the Palatine Hills.If you're doing a guided tour, it's ideal if you can get a combination tour of the Forum and the Colosseum.

Fantastic!. Went on a tour of the Forum with a tour guide. So informative! If going during the Summer, make sure to bring a water container. There are a couple of places to get water from public fountains in the venue.

Must-see and ..... ... a part of the Colloseum Combi ticket. What I didin't like so much was the weak desription of the various places. Without a tour guide it is rather difficult to get a good understanding of the large site

Don't Miss the Light & Sound Show !. We visited the forums late one evening and discovered the light and sound shows running at both the Augustus and Caesar Forums through October. There is very little publicity around this for some reason but both shows are spectacular :- The intent of the shows is to tell the story of the monument and rulers with the help of 3D light projections and wonderful sound effects. The shows run either every hour (Augustus Forum) or every 20 mins (Caesar's Forum) and start around 8 pm each night- Tickets are available at 15 Euros for each show or a combined 25 Euro ticket to both. Tickets can be bought either right in front of Augustus forum or at the Trajan Column near Caesar's forum. Booking online for Caesar's show is recommended as only 20 people are permitted per show and tickets sell out quickly.- The Augustus forum show is more like sitting in an auditorium with projections in front of you while Caesar's forum show is more interactive and you walk through the ruins. Audio headsets are provided for both shows with ability to choose preferred language.These shows are a very good opportunity to understand more about the ancient Roman history in a fun and cool way. Sadly, they are running only for limited time but do try to catch them if your schedule permits.
Interesting by night. I am not a very history person, but this place and the entire walk around it is beautiful at night. Photographs do not do justice to this place

Beautiful, spend a whole afternoon here!. There's so much to see in the Forum, we entered with our Roma Pass (less than a 2 minute queue) and stayed here for a couple of hours. There's so much to look at. Take some food and water and just relax here!

Go with a guide for a more valuable experience . We went with a tour from Walks of Italy to see the Forum, some palaces and the Colosseum. It started off as 5 people but two dropped off because it was hot and a lot of walking. I don't think it would have been the same without the guide telling us the history and stories of what we were seeing. Plus he got us in to some places not open to the public. It was fascinating but I would do it early in the morning if you go in a hot month.

Fantastic . You can't come to Rome and not see the Forum! We took an historical guided tour which included the colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Forum. We bought our tickets for €30pp while queuing for the colosseum that morning, and didn't regret it. The Forum is amazing, fantastic architecture and views. It wasn't too crowded when we were there mid afternoon. It's only a short walk across the road from the Colosseum, we walked up Palatine Hill first and then down to the Forum. Highly recommend the guided tour of you want the historical background to Rome and the emporers!

Start here before you go to the colosseum. You can buy a deal that combines the forum and the colosseum here. The lines are shorter here. The place is very impressive and interesting. Some of the ruins are well preserved. It is better to come with an audio guide which can easily download from the web. The place is more relaxed than the colosseum so you can find a place on the grass to rest a bit before you stand for hour/s in the colosseum lines.

History history history . Most important place of Roma visit if you came bcs of history. History addicting guys need 1 full day or more, just short visit need 2 hours. It's worth to spend any single second there ... So impressive... Nothing to say more ! Must visit ! If guided tour will be better to learn...

Far more than I expected. We had a tour that included both the Colosseum and the Roman Forum. The Forum far exceeded my expectations. From the Colosseum it doesn't look as big and impressive as it really is.I would recommend doing a tour, as we got a lot out of the explanations from our guide (Carlotta from What a Life Tours). She helped put everything into perspective.

Beautiful ( and included with the Colosseum tickets). A nice example of ancient Roman architecture - and you get a fabulous view of the Colosseum from here, too. Once again, be ready for x-ray security but the crowd normally is nothing compared to the main Colosseum building. I could almost feel that I had been transported to another era.
Just do it!. Take your time. Stroll and absorb! THIS is true ancient Roman glimpse. Best value for money in town.

Roman Forum. What a day we had, with a little bit of imagination and a good tour guide you can be transported back to the days of Julius Caesar and before. We spent about 5 hours in here and would easily have stayed longer.

Walking in Caesars footsteps. Hard to imagine that Caesar, Nero, Augustus all walked these floors but they did. Yet they are still on view for free. I understand you can buy a ticket to see the Colosseum and get to see the Foro Romani too. We did not but you can see almost everything anyway. Not far from the Colosseum, this ancient part of Rome is stunning when you consider half the world was administrated from these buildings. Now ruins of course but sufficiently well preserved to imagine life here. It gets hot in Rome and it is important to have a supply of water, sun cream and good shoes. You can walk for miles around these ruins. Well worth seeing. We avoided the guided tour as we bought guide books before we came to Italy but the tours are cheap enough. You can browse at your leisure with a good guide book though and tours tend to rush you through. Augustus' market, Trajan's column, Dopoglio Museum and Colosseum are all within walking distance of the Foro Romani. Piazza Venizia is also within the same area. You can almost take a panoramic shot with all of these ancient attractions in one.
Nothing special. I felt that to see the Roman Forum from a distance is more exciting.. It is just ruins , very ancient one but still nothing beautiful or extraordinary to walk inside them.
Massive. Great to see Ancient Rome. Very interesting and packed full of board with information on. Phenomenal building ruins and being able to visualise a day in old Rome.
Roman Forum was fascinating. A bit difficult to understand what you are looking at initially - went to the top of palatine hill which gives you a birds eye view of the forum.
Historic Ruins. The structures that are still standing are great. I can only imagine what this place is like back in the day. I bet it was incredible. They have such rich history.

Mine of Roman History. This is one awesome place, and a mine of Roman history, where the roman people even B.C. used to dwell. One place which reflects how unevely dwellings were made in that time, I believe people interested in history would love to visit this place.. We visited this place and could see the entire city from top, which was a mesmerizing view.A very long walk through the Roman Forum but worth an experience..

After seeing the colosseum, the forum was not as spectacular. After visiting the colosseum, this was not as good. Lots of ruins and partial columns, scattered over a vast area. It is worth a brief visit, but there are many other places to see that would be a better use of time. Maybe it's me, but this pales in comparison the colosseum.

Wow!. It's so hard to imagine how life was back in those days.Visiting is August is quiet challenging as the heat is enough to make you look for shade!But as nice stroll through the forum at your own pace, allows you to see the magnificent columns that randomly popup, the gardens and buildings that once stood there, remind you of how life used to be.Best to bring an umbrella for cover from the sun!

Soaked in History!. A definite must-do 'when in rome'! Entry is included in your Colosseum ticket. Book it from the official site (coopculture). Strongly suggest not to look at other sites as I have found them to be very overpriced. Carry food along with yourself as there's only a vending machine inside and that too was not adequate as I found later. Water is not allowed inside as there's an airport style security check at entry. Suggest doing this just after Colosseum and if you are short on time or effort to walk and have to pick any one between palantine hill and Roman Forum, go for Forum. There's lot of walking and some pre-read or a guide will definitely add to your experience. Rick steve's free download to this effect will come handy. There may be other such services online so do a bit of google and wiki.

Surreal and a must do when seeing the Colosseum.. Best to do combo-ed with the Colosseum. We did a combo tour, booked on the spot, with the Colosseum for a total of 17 euros per person, as we had already purchased the entrance fee. This enable us to skip the lines. It can be very hot and highly recommend stocking up on water and wearing comfortable shoes. It is really just magnificent to walk through the roads and feel like you're in an ancient Roman city. Do NOT skip.
