A must see. It's huge!!! Get there early before it gets too warm (summer visitors), embrace the whole area and do not miss and inch of this fabulous historical sight
Full to the brim with history. Very interesting place a must see just so much history, you can't take water in now which is not great when it's 32 degrees heat though.

Beautiful ruins and history . Really cool to see all of the ruins that were excavated. The forum is enormous so bring your walking shoes and water! Fountains everywhere to fill up. It was. A very hot day so we could only bear to stay an hour. Included in your coliseum pass. Buy tickets here for coliseum as line up is much shorter.

A walk through Ancient Rome's city centre. The best way to enter the Roman Forum is via Palatine Hill- I would highly suggest buying a collective ticket for entrance into Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum rather than buying on the day (go to the official ticketing website 'coopculture [dot] it' for your options). The line for entering these significant ancient grounds is long enough with a pre-bought ticket (with security scans being the main reason for delay into the site), so you can imagine how long it might take if you also need to line up to purchase a ticket as well!Despite much of the evidently enormous structures that used to once stand in the Roman Forum being long gone, it is not hard to imagine how impressive and grand the Roman Forum must've once been from what IS still standing. For example, the front portico standing from the remains of The Temple of Saturn and the Arch of Septimius Severus still looms majestically against the sky and they are examples of exemplary roman architecture and design.The ruins that you see as you walk through and explore the site will probably not mean much to the uninformed visitor as there are few detailed signs around the site, but if you are sincerely interested in what the remains of each ginormous building used to be, their purpose and significance, then there are audio and guidebooks that you are able to purchase to guide you through. While you only see what remains of a great and powerful ancient empire today, it is not hard to imagine how incredible the Roman Forum must've been at its peak and what a sight to behold it must have been. The Roman Forum along with Palatine Hill covers an enormous amount of ground, so make sure you bring water to keep fully hydrated, a hat and sunscreen to protect yourself from the sun and good walking shoes!

another for the history buffs,. Amazing pierce of history , much of it still standing from ancient times. You can buy a ticket for th forum , in with the palatine. beware if you haven't a lot of time , you will not cover it all , the ruins are extensive. and well worth the visit.

Blast from the past . Blast from the past at its best... enjoyable more if the weather is fair with occasional clouds as it could get really hot ...queuing is a bit of a nuicenance but well worth the wait
Fabulous. The view from the top is spectacular and you can see right round the city - highly recommend this tour

Long walk through history. The Forum is right next to the Colosseum and have a lot of ruins. Try to tour this site on a not so hot day also get your tickets before you go, this will save you time. Do it with a tour guide so that you can understand what you are seeing. I did a tour with a tour guide and I learned and saw a lot.

Must See for Rome. This business center of ancient Rome is really amazing. The site's foundations, buildings and some walls are well enough preserved to be able to understand how the Romans met and transacted business. A great place to view the Forum is from the Piazza Venezia, which towers over this lower ground. A Must-See for Rome tourists.

This is something that makes you mind works.. Although righ now it is just a remaining bunch of rocks and some old wall sometimes building it creates a vision how people were great in the past. Something that is definitely worth to see,
Amazing Ruins. After 2000 years, remains of the heart of ancient Rome stand to show us. One can Imagine standing in the ancient city amongst the Senators and Emporers.
Amazing ,Spectacular. Was amazing ,go to the top and look down as the view is stunning seeing how they lived all those years ago. And wander round so interesting . Not to be missed .

A Slice of History. I need to go back and see it again with a tour since there was so many ruins. We saw it after visiting the coliseum and it was amazing. To see the foot prints of these old buildings and the columns of the ones still standing are just awe-striking.It is on my list to see again on my next trip.

An enlightening walk around ancient Rome. My recommendation is to visit the Patine hill or the Roman Forum before the Colosseum. Carry a lot of water and take some snack, it can get very tiring. Renting an audio guide or taking a tour would not be bad idea at all...

Wonderful place!. My favourite place. The history is incredible and you can imagine how the area looked in it's splendor. I'd recommend getting a hotel near here as it's lovely to walk along the main street at night when it's lit up.The palotine hill ticket let's you explore the ruins closer. Water is not allowed in but the fountains are safe to drink.
Amazing. To wonder through these streets, or lookdown on them from the streets that surround the forum is an amazing experience. A good tour guide brings it to life, Unmissable
Great site - loads of buildings, big area to explore, loved it. Loads of buildings to explore, big area, great information, loved it! Site is great insight into life in ancient Rome.

Basic tips for the best visit! . Allow at least an hour to fully explore the forum, climb palatine hill and get some great photos. Download Rick steves audio guide + map, it's brilliant. Not only do you save money on a professional tour, or hiring an audio book but it's full of great information. It would be hard to fully appreciate this place on your own. Take a water bottle, heaps of places to fill it up. The forum is very exposed and it gets very hot! Only small vending machines (self-bars) to buy food so take your own, or hold on until later! Wear good waking shoes, lots of climbing and uneven cobblestones. Buy tickets from the palatine hill entry. The price £12 covers the coloseum too, and there was 4people in that queue versus the hour wait I saw at the coloseum entrance!
Very expansive - need to purchase tickets prior to entry.. One can view the general environs of this site without actual paid entry. Lots to see, and diggings are still underway.
Lovely walk through History. Interesting to see and learn about what Rome was when you visit the Forum . A lot has been lost but you can picture what went on with a guided visit to the Forum
We enjoyed it even more than the Colosseum!. Lovely to walk around in these ruins and get a sense of a life once lived. Still lots of beautiful things to see and experience here amongst history.
Walk through the Roman Forum after your tour of the Colosseum!. My recommendation ... a proper tour with a guide. We went with City Wonders VIP Tour. Rosie was excellent!

Walk around the ruins of the old Rome. This place is one of the best places in Rome. You can walk around the ruins of the old city and imagine its historical glory. Visit in February was really good idea, because outside wasn't very hot temperature. I recommend to start day here, because you can buy ticket which is common for Colosseum too. From Forum Romanum, you can also go to the Palatine Hill, which also worth it. From Forum Romanum there is also nice view of Colosseum, where you can take photos.

The Forum. After leaving the Colosseum we walked up the Via Sacra into the forum as part of our tour. Loads of stuff to see and the gardens of the Vestal Virgins.We saw the spot where Julius Caesar was cremated.This now leads on to the Palantine hill were the rulers of Rome lived.
Included in the price of the colosseum. The roman forum is included in the price of the ticket for the colosseum, which is a must. Very fascinating place to walk around.
Worth a visit. Fascinating to see the old buildings and ruins of the Romans. Lots of opportunities for good photos as well.
Pretty nice. It´s good to see Forum Romanum but it was a lottle bit crowded and it was nothing that impress me very much
On Segway. We visited this on a segway so got a bit of history explained, would be lost without. Well preserved and worth a look

Walk with Julius!. A visit to Rome would not be complete without a visit here. That being said, there are so many interesting sites to see in Rome that it can get overwhelming. You can hire a private guide, join a tour group or simply download a free podcast from Rick Steve's who will cover the important points. The walking surface is uneven, so wear good shoes with an even sole (no heels!) & take care if you have a disability.
Where's my History teacher when I need her :) !. Wonderful to wonder and stop and contemplate the past worlds ... Picnic snack and soak up some sun worked a treat here ...
Interesting. If you're a history buff, you'll love this place. Go with an audio guide. You have to walk a lot , so wear good walking shoes.

Likely better with a guide. So we spent some time at the Roman Forum, and felt like you could get a lot more out of it if you went with a guide or as a part of a tour. It was very interesting to see the old buildings and what was left, and the signs there were helpful, but I think we missed a lot by not having a guide.

Pleasant . Lovely to wander around, although like us you'll likely quickly get lost in this maze. Entry is included in the admission price for the colosseum but it is a lot less crowded. It's definitely worth visiting.

So much history, make time for this. The roman forum has so much history and you could spend a day here, I would recommend an audio guide for 5 euro, or a guided tour so you know what you are looking at, or read up on a guide book before going. Very interesting and worth a visit, you can buy a ticket to entry to the colosseum and into the roman forum + Palentine hill

Buy your tickets for the Colosseum here!. Obviously the main headline attraction of Rome is the Colosseum. The Roman Forum is an after thought. We were told to buy our combo ticket at the Forum to avoid the long lines at the Colosseum. Great idea! I think we stood in line maybe 2 minutes at the Forum for tickets. Then all you have to do is go through security at the Colosseum. And by the way, the Forum is pretty cool. Look into downloading a free podcast with an audio guide of the forum. You can go at your own pace and it's free. Pretty cool to visualize all of the history that happened here.
Very well preserved. We went there with Seqway. It is suprisingly well preserved. We managed to take some great photos. Definitely worth checking out.

absolutely huge.. This is a must see when the weather is good, incorporate with the Coliseum. A lot of walking is needed and over some rough ground. it's broke out in a few different sections and can take many hours (2 for me but I rushed through). Pictures galore.

Lunch . Molto bene
So happy i tried this place as I was in Roma.
For the canonisation of Madre Teresa, all I can say is fresh quality food & pasta ok
Always looking forward to eating in Rome.
Roman Forum. Brilliant afternoon on a guided tour. So historical and interesting it's unbelievable.Just stunning. Go with a guide.
Roman Forum. I recommend going first to the collesum, and then going to the Forum. You can get into both locations on the same tickets.
So much history. This place was really interesting to walk through. Definitely recommend going with a tour guide or an audio guide, or something to help you understand what you're looking at!
Underground Tour worth it. Third visit but first time for the underground. Worth the extra $$ because you go to areas that others aren't allowed so not as many other tourist.

Amazing history. Few other sites can cram so much history into such a small space, not that the space is small. You can see the place where Caesar was burned and his temple was built. It, however, no longer stands. Romans still place flowers and coins on this spot today in his honor/memory.

Amazing site. I enjoyed Roman Forum even it was burning hot and I was tired. The ruins of several buildings provides you insights to Roman architecture.
Entry to Roman Forum comes with Colosseum ticket, you don't have to buy it separately.

Just wow. The feeling you get when you realize the age of these stones... priceless. A lot of the Forum structures visible from free-access areas around it, but there are also beautiful parts you can't see without going in.

A dream come true..... Walk in the footsteps of those romans you read about and admire the wonderful architecture they achieved when Christ lived. See the remains of the temples to their ancient gods and WONDER! You simply must not miss the forum.

Combine with your visit to the colloseum. We visited straight after the colloseum. It was surprising how much of the Roman architecture was still visible. Lots to see including church ruins and mosaics.
The only down side was that there could have more descriptions on some of the features so you knew what they were. Also, people blatantly disregarded the no flash photography signs.
Well worth visiting.

A must do on your trip to Rome. Here you would benefit from a guide as the Forum is very spread out. Buy your tickets to the Forum and Colosseum the day before going to avoid the long queues. Certainly worth taking your time. You can skip the Colosseum queue by entering through the forum and doing this area first.
Amazing . last visited here about 30 years ago and forgot how amazing a site it is, so many things to see. A great insight into how Rome looked back then
Walking theough history.. You walk through rome as it was 1900 years ago, with the buildings "slightly" reduced. One can imagine the splendour of rome.

Walking back in time. If you take this path reading before about ancient Rome you discover that you are part of a masterpiece of mankind.In a space where sqm is huge in price history guverns over financial opportunities. Enjoy.
Hot August visit. Gorgeous historical buildings. Fantastic church with some great displays. Not much protection from the sun!!

amazing. It's few steps away from Colessum and for me, it's much much more fascinating than it. You literally walk the ancient Rome, and if you are a history buff you cannot live this place before 2 hours.
Amazing views and architectures. Visit immediately after the Colosseum. Great views over Rome...a must in any itinerary visiting Rome

History wherever you turn. Its liking walking back in time and visually trying to see what it could have looked like. It is fascinating and the only place that comes slightly close to it is Athens. Visying Rome is not complete without walking through the forum.

Sum of ancient history. Even if this site doesn't have a harmonious style, the ever changing turmoil of it's architecture in history, if one pays attention to the details, is a travel through the Greek and Roman public life, with later addition of Christian buildings. Please imagine the scale of the basilica Constantinii, as only the lateral arches still survive and are dominant to the entire forum. On the other end, the tabularium still stands after two thousand years and hosts a rich museum, that also has terraces which enable a perfect view of the valley.

History beckons. My wife and I visited The Forum on a baking hot day (even though we set out early) and fairly soon regretted that there was absolutely no shade! The site itself was, though, splendid. Having booked a couple if tours for tgecweek we went we didn't take up the option for the forum which was, with hindsight, a mistake. There's such a lot to see and having someone knowledgeable to "paint a picture" would only have enhanced the venue. Personally I do wish they'd reconstruct one or two buildings, just to give you a taste if ehat it would have been like but, hey!, that's just me :-)Thoroughly recommended whatever your budget.
A great slice of ancient Rome. We spent a great 2 hours at the Forum and thoroughly enjoyed all the ancient sights. When you buy a ticket for the Colosseum you also get the Forum as well.
Just a hike . Very uneven ground and not much to see. It all looks the same and there is very little information if you don't do a guided tour.

My favorite of all the ancient Roman tourist spots. Don't miss the Forum and invest in a guide. We used Caesar Tours and were very happy with them. The history here is unbelievable and it makes you want to go back to school and study the history of the Roman Empire all over again.

Roman heritage and art of history. Firstly the ticket is common here for colosseum, so u buy tickets at either place it will be valid. Roman forum is so huge and it takes atleast a day to roam around at easy pace. There are so many artifacts and piece of history not to be missed when ur here. Sadly I was on a hot sunny day and got really sweaty. It would be better to plan it towards evening time as weather gets better. Otherwise recommended place for sure n not to be missed.
Incredible. Walking round here is just incredible. All of Rome really you're surrounded by beautiful architecture and amazing history but this was something else. Beautiful!

So much history in this large site beneath the Palatine Hill.. The area called the Roman Forum has much to see and reminds us of the glory of Rome in the arches present in many locations as well as the vast scope of the area. There is a recently discovered ancient church previously buried beneath another church which was very exciting for our guide. This ticket can be purchased together with the Colosseum ticket and it is smart to do this on line prior to your visit. Saves so much time!

Mesmerizing. Much larger and expansive than the imagination may have portrayed it. It stretches a long way with many statues, columns and stories of the long ago residents. Very interesting information of the residents, vestil virgins and activities held here.

A day at the Forum. I went on a very hot day, around 10am, the queue was short and the audio guide is well worth the price (total price about 18 euros). The whole place is incredible and the recently renovated Oratorio of the 40 Martyrs is stunning and the views from all aspects of the Forum are breathtaking

Brilliant!. Amazing and historic place. its great to walk around and see the history right in front of you, so close to the colosseum as well. Theres a lot of walking around though, make sure to pack a comfy pair of trainers. We paid to enter the Forum, wasn't expensive so worth a try, however if you don't want to pay you can get stunning views from outside the area.

Connie reed . We went here this morning very beautiful place packed with history tour guides to help u if you need them staff friendly and helpful bring plenty of water if u do forget they do have vending machines hidden so ask staff also water pump to refill a definite place to visit great day out

Roman History. The place where civilization started. Most buildings are 2000 years old and only parts of the building remain. If you wanna learn more of Roman history or are casually interested like me, then you better go there.

Ancient ruins next to Colosseum. We took a guided tour of the Colosseum which included the Roman Forum. It was an amazing walk through time. Beautiful ruins that are worth seeing. It took about 3 hours to do the Colosseum and walk through the Roman Forum. You could totally do this tour without a guide. I just like to be told about the history and learned a few things along the way!

Itinerary must-see!. This is obviously a must-see on anyone's itinerary! So much history contained in one location! But beware that there can be a lot of rambling with no shade, so dress accordingly - and take a guide book or go on an organised tour. Otherwise you'll be mostly heading past lots of broken buildings without a real understanding of their purpose or history!TOP TIP! At the eastern end of the Forum is the Colosseum. Within the grounds of the Forum museum area there is some raised ground, which is an excellent place to take photos of the Colosseum without hoards of people. There was almost no-one there when we were there!

See this but with a guide. We had a great time seeing the Roman Forum, but it was helpful that we had a guide who was explaining everything to us, otherwise I'm sure we would have been a little lost. They also sell some great books that have before and after photos of the Forum, this was a great purchase that our guide shared with us, and it was good to see what the forum looked like back in the day.

So much history and worth a visit. So much history and so many ruins to see, but not very much explanation or very good maps on site. Even the guide books don't have great maps or explanations even using 3 different ones. So read up before you go so you know what your looking at.

Great place to explore. There is a lot packed into this area. Great vistas from up above, lots of history in the ruins. You may want to consider doing a tour of the Colosseum and Forum to get the most out of it.

Fantastic. I liked Colloseum, but I loved Roman Forum. It's a shame, that Christians took this heritage to build the Vatican and we can't see the full glory of Roman Forum.I recommend to take a guide. We used free Rick Steve's podcast and map. Just Google for it.

Decent visit. Ruins of the Roman empire that was at once the political epicentre of the great empire. Today it is in ruins and one would have to expand their imagination even after guide and audio mediums to really understand their importance and structure
Interesting history. I downloaded Rick Steve's audio guide and did a tour of the Roman Forum. It was so interesting to see the remains and hear the history of this ancient cite.

You have to have some imagination. The first time I cam I wasn't impressed. But return visits proved my initial impression wrong. I strongly recommend doing this with a guide--you really can't appreciate the history without one. Mainly ruins, but really incredible ruins.

A must see. I did the tour of the Forum and Collessum and it was amazing, i recommand to do both tour and to buy the ticket for both attration (14 euro) at the forum, the lineup is a lot faster (1h faster)
Wonderfull. This is like being on a film set you can imagine the people walking around in there toga,s buzzing with slaves and street vendors in the market. Stunning

Phew. A whole lot of walking!. You walk in the footsteps of Anthony and Cleopatra and really get a feel of ancient Rome here. Yes, it is all ruins but you still can be awed by the splendour that once was.

Roman Forum. Worth spending a good part of the day here and not necessary to have a guide, but it is necessary to have a really good guide book if you opt to go round the Forum on your own.Some steep steps in places but you will be carried away by the sense of history and spine tingling chills as you step out on the same stone slabs as ancient Romans and Emperors.

Included in Colosseum tour, so enjoy!. We saw the Roman Forum as part of our City Wonders - Colosseum tour. The tour was excellent, the guide was really good and we all enjoyed it. The only downside to the Roman Forum for us, was the heat and sun in August. There are not many places to hide or get shade in the area, so get some water, wear a hat, and enjoy the amazing history.

Very Interesting. We hired an audio guide and decided to wander at our leisure around the site, but didn't realise just how big it was when you include Palatine Hill! Make sure you're in comfortable footwear and bring plenty fluids with you if you plan to visit - we went with the short audio tour (est. 1.5 hours) on the audio device and we were still there 3 hours later! Very interesting though.

This place is huge. There is so much to see here you really need to study the map and figure out what you care about. If you just show up you can be overwhelmed. Or bored. If you don't know what you're looking at you can't differentiate and you may not care enough. A little reading ahead of time will make the forum so much more enjoyable.

One of our favourite visits thanks to Rick Steve Audioguide!. No queues here when we visited. No need to come earlier than the 8.30 gate opening time if you already have your ticket ( buy online and use for colosseum too). No security check so entry is quick and you can bring water ( many fountains and clean toilets inside). At 8.30 we were wandering the streets completely alone for a few mintues which was awe inspiring. We were not impressed with colosseum audio guide so downloaded the Rick Steves guide for the Roman Forum. That was fantastic, I really recommend it, but be aware it doesn't cover Pallatine hill. Really wish we had an audio guide for that too. We were here / on the hill from 8.30 to 12 and didn't look at the ruins on the hill in detail, or visit Pallatine museum. With a picnic lunch you could easily spend the entire day here. Equally, you can brush over some parts and do it in a morning. The ground is loose red dirt, our feet and legs were filthy when we left. I was glad to be wearing sandals as easily rinsed my feet down. Plenty of shade but of course it is pretty hot from 10 onwards in August.
Awesome history if you are interested in Ancient Rome.. This is included in the Colosseum ticket price. I recommend a tour (book through TripAdvisor/Viator) to get the best understanding of the site.
Breathtaking... Of all the sights in Rome this one gives you the sense and history of ancient Rome. Best viewed by climbing the steps to the right of the Palazzo Venezia.

Lovely historical site. amazing place to walk around and imagine roman markets
go in time to see evening film (dont need to pay as there are steps slightly further back to sit and view whole thing)

Well worth the walk . If your into your history take the time out to walk this huge expanse of land and ruins. It's so worth it!! There are no restrictions as to where you can and can't go, there are no hassles trying to sell selfies sticks. You can just wander at your own pace and leisure and take it all in. One of my favorite days out during our visit.

Aewsome. What a spectacular place to talk through. You could take a whole day to see is place. Full of history and ancient buildings. The only thing was if they could have more signage as to what we were seeing if you went on your own but fantastical all the same.
Wonderful. Think this is where we saw the chariots race worth a visit as it is on way to other things. Best to wear hats etc as not much shade here

Superb. Sensational place to walk through and learn, We had an amazing time walking around the Forum - The views and history of this place are fascinating.As if you are going to go all the way to Rome and miss out this place!Definately take your time and do this!
Ruin. Our tour stopped here for photo opportunities. But very little to see. It may have an ancient history behind it. But very little to see. Just a ruin.
Worth a visit . Entrance with colosseum tickets. Worth a walk around. Very hot and no water fountains so be prepared. Amazing to see the ruins and signs easily followed.

A world of history at your feet. I found walking around The Forum one of life's grand visits. We spent 4 days at The Inn At The Forum (5*) and history started less than a block from our door. There are endless ways to enjoy this area (Forum, Coliseum and Circus Maximus). We took a late evening City Wonder's tour with Irene (amazing!) that walked through the Forum, ending with a tour of tour of The Coliseum. There were only 2 or 3 groups of people around, which was marvelous. Seeing streets and arches where Rome's leaders walked over 2,000 years ago, then walking 100 steps and seeing the balcony where Mussolini made his wartime speeches was truly priceless.
Beautiful.. This was included on our tour of the coliseum. It was great to see with a lot of historical information.

Nice place. I enjoyed wandering around this place,
Imagining what it would have looked like in its prime. There are some lovely places to sit, it's free which is always nice, street music adds to the atmosphere. Few parts unable to enter, I think those places are reserved for the guided tour. Worth a visit.

Part of the coliseum tour I took from my hotel. This was absolutely beautiful def worth taking a tour for this one there's so much to see it was part of a tour taken through my hotel (hotel Trevi collection) great hotel modern rooms
Palentine hill was also included in the tour

Wear comfortable shoes. There is a lot to see and the place is huge. If you buy your entry pass before you go, you can use shorter lines. You will want a book or guide so that you know what you are looking at. It makes the experience more interesting.

Absolutely amazing. We visited the Forum a couple of times during our stay in Rome as it was in walking distance from our hotel. One should not miss visiting the Forum while in this beautiful city.... the ancient architecture and history is mind blowing.

Amazing views and history. Definitely worth a photo opportunity and there are plenty of places to take an amazing picture from. You can also pay to walk around the ruins if you want to delve into the history up close.

Great History Lesson. I enjoy the forum more than the Colosseum, every time I visit I discover a little bit more of its history that i didn't know. Arm yourself with a good guide book or audio guide and step back into 2000 years of history.
Live life as an ancient Roman. My girlfriend and I love this place. How much do we love it? Enough to walk around in this maze of ruins for more than 4 hours on a hot day (40 C°).

The Government Center of Rome. The Roman Forum was what Capital Hill in Washington is for the US, the center of the Government, and today even after all the damage of all the building cause by earthquakes, time and vandalism of many years ago you can still see the beauty and great architectural in the buildings today. The Forum is right besides the Colosseum, Palatine Hill, Circus Maximus, St Paul Basilica and other sites, in one day you can visit that entire area. Once inside you can walk through those ruins and realize that you are walking in a historic place that is not fantasy but very much reality of the things that happened there. You be able to see where the Senate building was the Temple of Julius Cesar where Julius Cesar was cremated etc. As stated before in this area you will be able to see numerous of must see sites of Rome in one day.
History alive . Everyone has to see it once. Amazing view, spectacular buildings and ruins. Im gonna remember this forever :-)

Good to go. Roman forum is very near to the colosseum, you don't have to buy a separate ticket,its included with colosseum. There is alot to see. If you would like to know the history then take a guided tour.
Amazing. Do not miss this. My return visit after 30 years was much more impressive than before. What a fascinating site - not to be missed.

Amazing. To stand in the shadow of where the ancient Roman's once stood was worth the heat and crowds. As you walk around the ruins you come across little tucked away places that are really cooled despite the heat and you get an idea of how the Roman's were able to escape the heat back then. It was an unexpected find/experience.
roman forum. you really do need to have a good guide with you as there is so much history and places of interest to find out about
WOW a real beauty. Cant believe my eyes, architecture , the ruins, early as the Romans a history please dont miss to see this while in Rome
a long walk so wear comfy shoes.. our guide Geff, was fantastic, the two hour tour brought to place to life! we then carried on walking around going back over what Geff had told us!
History buffs. The Roman Forum is perhaps the most interesting place . Make sure you have a tour guide or you will never understand the importance of the Forum.

Ridiculous and inhuman toilet situation. The Roman Forum was an interesting experience. It is a huge site, very interesting to know that this was the heart of life in ancient Rome, very impressive and you can see the wealth the Romans had of everything. What was not so impressive was the toilet situation. With so many visitors coming to the site, hundreds and hundreds of tourists. There are a few toilets for the men and only 2 toilets for women, one of which is a disabled one. The mens toilets, my husband was in the queue when the women attendants were cleaning them and they closed most of them and left only 2 I think open and that was because my husband insisted that they not close the second one! On the woman's side I waited for at least 45 minutes as there was only one toilet open of the 2 that should have been available! The disabled one. I presume the women attendants had done the same, the cleaned one and closed it! Come on this is not on, there were small children and old ladies waiting to use the toilets. These women came to where we were queing as they had a cupboard at the back or something and they saw the big queue getting bigger and they just left without opening the toilets smiling and smoking! It looked as if they were laughing at us at the queue. They should be fired for treating tourists this way. This is inhuman! Only one women's toilet in the whole forum with so many visitors! This didn't seem like a city in Europe, on a touristic site! This was worse than a third rate country! And something should be done. I complained to our guide as did others and the guide said they had already complained to the authorities! The Colisseum I have been told is the same!
Use the alternate entry with no queue. Use the alternate entry with no queue further up the road. Allow enough time to wonder around and take water and snacks.

Audio guide helpful!. A must see in Rome and lots of free water. You will spend an entire day seeing this and the Coliseum. Lots of write ups and boards make this helpful but the audio guide was really great. Must see and consider the audio guide.
Amazing history. Its a long walk and hot in summer but it is incredible. The histiry and how the city was built is amazing. They were so clever. A must see attraction.

well you must see the vestal virgins place having come all this way. frankie howard did not say how hot this place gets and how uneven the site is - where there are paths they need work - a lot of work - there are no cafes so take your own water bottle and refill- also the northern exit is shut

Free with you Colloseum ticket and free for kids!. Well worth a wander but if you want to understand what you are looking at, you need to read up or get a guide or take a tour. However, it is stunning, magical and very romantic.

Incredible feeling of greatness when here!. On buying a ticket for the collesseum it also includes the Roman Forum which s right next door. Best to go as early as possible as it involves a lot of walking through centuries ago history. Incredible place where you can feel or imagine the greatness of this city in Roman times. A must-see when in Rome but time consuming as well. With a day in Rome we only had time for the Trevi Fountain and the Colisseum which we went to on the underground. Beware of pickpockets as we did have an incident on the underground but fortunately nothing came of it as the pickpocket chose the wrong pocket but the three women involved were thrown off the underground by a local who came to our rescue. We already knew about it and had taken our precautions. They usually target foreign men.

So much history.. We visited the Roman forum as a part of a paid walking tour. It was extremely hot due to being the middle of the Italian summer however there a few places you can fill up water bottles for free. The Roman forum is full of amazing history and I highly recommend visiting it on a guided tour to get the full experience. Be careful which walking tour your book as the one we were on had over 80 people on it making it hard to hear the group leader speak. It was disappointing to hear that majority of the Roman forum was destroyed to build Vatican City as in its full glory would have been spectacular.
A touch of history, beyond the senses. Stories from the past will tie you with these ruins long after you leave Rome! Be sure to look for a local guide!

A walk amongst the Vestals. The Roman Forum was the heart of life in ancient Rome, and its ruins reflect its importance. It is special to walk amongst the ruins of the Temple of the Vestal Virgins and the Colisseum at the end, all under the shadow of the Palantine Hill. A must for Rome!

A must when in Rome. Really enjoyable few hours, the site is huge. Make sure you take water containers and sunhat on a hot day. We used Rick Steve's free audio guide app which covers the Forum but not the Palatine Hill. Make sure you use the Palatine Hill entrance there are always fewer queues than the Colloseum end. The Forum and Palatine Hill sites together are really big so you may be there a while. There is no cafe on site so if you are there a while and have children it's worth making sure you have things to eat. The Palatine Hill museum on-site is a welcome respite from the heat.

Walk along the same boulevards as did the ancient Romans.. The Roman Forum, although in ruins gives you an immersive experience of how the place looked 1800-2000 years ago. From the ruins of the temple of Saturn near the Capitoline Hill to the Arch of Constantine the place is filled with layers of ancient history. The water fountains not very different from how the ancient romans used it were really a blessing during the hot summer month when we visited.
Amazed by the Romans. Being here is a must! Seeing the past civilization and what they could build amazes me. They were very smart people and it's simply beautiful. One of the best places of Rome!

Beyond superlatives. This has to be one the greatest attractions in the world. Exhibit after exhibit that would be an attraction on their own. Its worth reading a history of ancient Rome before you go to understand just how significant these buildings really are. And just when you think you have seen them all climb the Palatine Hill to see another twenty or so! Worth a visit to Rome just to see this place.Its a pity that now there is an entrance charge because really this needs 3-4 visits to get the full impact and its very tiring in the afternoon sun after 5 hours walking around - take food and drink! But at effectively €6 its a worth every cent, as long as you have the stamina and the concentration to take it all in.The best tourist attraction we have ever been to.
Excellent Worth a Vist. If you like ancient history this not to be missed but suggest go early as by Midday it can be we hot & there is little cover.Suggest getting. Colosseum tour as well

Ancient Roman ruins. We had taken a day tour from our cruise. It was not possible to enter all attraction and reach back in a day's time. Therefore we just saw from outside only. It was very hot during day time.

Worth a visit if you are visiting Colosseum. We join a guided tour of Colosseum which includes the Roman Forum adjacent to it. Not much left of the Forum but the guide was quite good in pointing a few interesting sites. The terrace next to the Forum has a great view of the whole site.

The Center Of Ancient Rome. Roman Forum is an amazing collection of ruins, and it included several monuments, temples, and meeting places. Worth a visit if you have time. Try to go early in the morning because in summer it is very hot here.
Must see. This is indeed a walk through time to understand about the roman empire. Do not forget to see the sound and light show in the evening. It is worth the 15 euro which is charged.

Good Educational Experience. We didn't get to spend enough time here to really explore and enjoy the Roman Forum - but it was a great experience and a glimpse into what life was like in ancient Rome. I would definitely go back and explore more and/or go on a guided tour (hard to navigate with just the map). There are (at least) two entrances - one right across from the colosseum and one on the main street that leads to the colosseum (we used this exit instead of having to walk back through the Forum to the 'front' part. Not a lot of shade or trees, so bring water, sunscreen or a hat.

Words don't do it justice. We did a Rick Steve's audio tour that we downloaded beforehand to explore the Roman Forum. This was perfect. We just followed along with the audio guide and it really helped us visualize what the Forum was like when it was at its prime. There are only a few "water fountains" at the Forum so I would fill up at one of those at the beginning if you are touring the Forum during the summer months.

Avoid in the midday heat!. Well worth a visit, especially when buying the combo ticket for the colosseum too. Fascinating history, good views from the top of the hill. Just avoid in peak heat hours as there is little shade!

Excellent - worth getting a tour. Did as a joint package with the Colosseum with Gladiator tours. Roman Forum was definitely the better tour.Greg our tour guide was excellent. We spent 90 minutes there, but could definitely have done with more. We were led to ourselves at the end which was brilliant, but was late in the day.if you can afford the time and money, book a tour for the Colosseum and Roman Forum that gives you time to walk around. Take a hat and plenty of water.

Roman ruins.... Our Colosseum ticket included the Roman Forum as well.
It is quite interesting and there are information boards in English.
There is very little shade, so be aware of this when visiting on a very hot day.

Ancient ruins scrapyard. So what can I say that hasn't already been said?It is simply amazing, walking thru open-air museum of ancient antiquities from ~2 millenniums ago - the scale and breath of this area is beyond imagination. Between the Catholic churches and Mussolini robbing the place of the marble for their own projects, commoners taking souvenirs and privateers stealing it to sell to ambitious curators - it's amazing what is still here, and what is still hidden. They say the 3rd Underground line is taking so long to finish because of all the antiquities they're still finding. What other museums lack, is the ambience of the surroundings that this all belongs here and not in buildings scattered across the world. We took two different tours here and only scratched the surface.So yea, check it out, bring some snacks, sit in awe and then do it again.

Roman history is alive. This setting is amazing. Walk in the Roman era and see Caesar's tomb. The ruins are breathtaking. Wear comfortable walking shoes as the ground is very uneven and the climb is steep. Very difficult (almost impossible) for wheelchairs, walkers, and strollers.

Wonderful wander through ancient history. We were lucky enough to be here on the first Sunday of the month when entrance is free. From the Colosseo Metro we walked right on Via dei Foro Imperialli where's an entrance on your left into the Forum site. There's so much to see & we would have liked to go further, but it was very hot & we'd already done loads that day.

Nice place. Worth a visit if you have time as it's close by the colosseum. Make sure to be there early to avoid the heat and the crowd. I would definitely recommend if it's part of a half day tour along with the colosseum.

Stunning. If you like a mish mash of Roman history and architecure then this is the place to be there you can see so much activity through the years.There is a charge for entry but on the same ticket allows you to see the inside the colosseum which is easily walkble from here.

Ancient ruins. Best to downloaded some sort of audio guides otherwise it can be hard to know what you are looking at (we downloaded the free Rick Steves guide and it worked well). Best not to visit during the hotest hours of the day, as there is not much shade to hide/walk under at all. We entered from the Palatine Hill entry where the queue is much much shorter (you can go between Palatine Hill and the Forum without exiting)

Hot hot hot. Visited the Forum after the coliseum,good view from palatine hill, take plenty of water even tho there are a few drinking fountains and sturdy shoes ,defiantly not a place for women's comedy shoes

All part of the colosseum package. Came her late afternoon at the weekend.So much to see.Beautiful, peaceful in places.Look out for the two rabbits.A grey and a black one.Huge and only two of them apparently.views are amazing

History Like No Where Else. In the day take a tour - if the guide is good you will be amazed by the development of the City of Rome over the centuries. By night we were fortunate to see the lazer show which depicted the ruins as they were over two thousand years ago.
lots to see. try to go early morning and visit the colessum and forum at the same time. get a skip the line ticket as it can be crowded. there is lots of walking

Family sightseeing visit Included as part of the colosseum tour. Excellent Roman relic. Showing how day to day Rome lived and breathed. Only problem I have is that there has been a lot of restoration and its not clear which parts are restored and which parts are original.
Worth a visit. We had combined tickets with the Colosseum. Together they make a very good value. We did not get any guides, just walked around and read some plaques.
Must see Ancient Rome. If you want Columns and Ruins, this is the place. Avoid the heat of the day as there is little shade but great to wander around between the running soaking up the atmosphere
Roman Forum. next to the Colosseum. Buy combined ticket with the Colosseum, this is cheaper and you do not have to stand in line very long.

Visited as part of Colosseum and Palatine Hill tour. Visited as part of Colossem and Palatine Hill tour with City Wonders. Well worth seeing as so much history. Advise go early as it gets really busy.
rip off. been to Rome twice before and both times the forum was free very very disappointed to find out you know have to pay to wander around

Great history site. You can do the forum without a guide, but better with one. Usually good to book with a tour for Colosseum too. Wear good walking shoes. Most of the ground is cobblestone or other stones so flats or gym shoes. Easy to turn an ankle. Very open. Doesn't take that long. You could do a guide book but definitely want to do more than just look at the ruins. Walks of Italy Andrea is a great guide. Really knows what he is talking about and gives wonderful and interesting stories. Security required.

Every step touches a landmark of human history. If you can book a whole day here in order to enjoy everything. Apart from what has been already mentioned. There are some recent discoveries open ot the public. That is the findings of the Paleo-Christian complex at the feet of the Palatine Hill, including the extensions planned by empress Galla Placida. Becaureful not to miss the pool of the Vestal Virgins right behind their temple. Up on the Palatine, Augustus' home is a must-at-any-cost, there is quite a queue because only a small number of visitors are allowed at the time, yet totally worth it, with surviving frescoes from the times of Octavian Augustus first Emperor.

Old world charm. Really old world...I am so impressed with the Romans that I wish I could go in their era to live that life. Beautiful area giving a glimpse of Roman life. Gets very hot in summer, so be prepared with sunscreen, hats, umbrellas, water... Go after vising the Colosseum.
Amazing. We visited the Forum, Palatine Hill and the Colosseum all in one guided tour and loved every minute.

As part of a jump the queue package. The guide for the Forum was a nice funny guy from Nigeria. He knew his stuff and kept people engaged with his explanations. Plenty of time to look around yourself after the official bit. If there was more info at the signs infront of each relic it might not be necessary to have a guide. Very hot the day we visited, take plenty of water, though people are selling it to you everwhere. Can't believe they let a man in who had a dog in a backpack cage on his back!

Awesome experience. It's difficult to comment the Roman Forum, being such an amazing collection of wonders, from temples, to mausoleums, to churches.I strongly suggest you buy an audioguide to get the best explanation of each monument and the area.Once you are there, do go to Palatino and enjoy roman emperors' houses

Amazing. Lots of walking! The sight is really big and it's nice to see especially if you know that the whole place had to be excavated from deep ground. Not to mention the historical background. Bring a bottle of water with you if you're visiting it on a hot summer day.

Beautiful Area!. We enjoyed strolling through the Roman Forum with our two children. Lots of area for the kids to walk and some amazing history for the adults to see! Not 100% stroller friendly, but doable!

Great site!. Well worth the time to see, allow yourself 2-3 hours to do the forum and palatine hill. Buy your combo ticket for these and the colosseum here to avoid the crazy queues. The audio tour is also worth while for this as it gives you a lot more insight than the signs alone.

Going back in time. This was one of my most favourite experiences of all of Rome... Having been to the Colosseum, the 12 euro ticket gives you entry to the Roman Forum. A plethora of ruins; a town, a home, a palace, a shop... You could feel the history seeping from every brick. It was quite unbelievable really, the sheer amount of columns...with their intricate details just strewn about the place....1000s of years old. It was however midday, so very hot with little shade. If you're older & or need rest, perhaps you have children, this may be a little struggle to get through it all! Fortunately they have the 'self-serve bar' aka a vending machine so getting our hands on water was never a problem. A must, is to walk to the top of an old building which has a gorgeous garden and viewing platform. The views are extraordinary. There is this most magical spring that also drips down off the rock side into a pool in a cavern, and then as you walk up the stairs, it presents itself again as another pool - it almost defies gravity. The information all had an English version, which I found to not be the case at all sites...so this meant you could really engage with all aspects. A real opportunity of a lifetime.

Great history. Out of all the historic landmarks in Italy, this is the only one without caution tape or scaffolding or any modern things. This is a definite must go. One of the hills overlooks the whole of the Colosseum. 2 hours there is definitely not enough. Allow at least 3 hours for this place.

Stand in the middle of history. A truly breathtaking experience. Sadly this area is not a vast or well kept as in Pompeii, but it is incredible to be inside. So much to see and make out what was standing in front of us so many years ago. So much history packed into this place, you won't be disappointed if you're considering visiting.

A must see! . We bought the Rome pass and this ticket allowed us entry to the coliseum and forum, I would highly recommend doing both monuments at the same time.This is a very impressive area of the city which must be visited to fully appreciate the city.

Another of Rome's Must Sees.. We had the two day pass and did the Colosseum one day and the Forum the next. At the Forum we walked around some then came across this small tunnel and went through it. There was an open field with not much to view. We continued reluctantly and found a hill top with a lot of ruins and a museum. The whole are was really neat but we enjoyed the museum the most.

Colosuuem Package Tour. As part of the package tour but still worth seeing the Forum. Plenty of information available to read and see the buildings/ruins to give you an insight into how life was in Rome in the past
Wow!. Love antiquity sites very enjoyable too hot great,afternoon then walk up to Palatine Hill would recommend

Worth seeing. Again we had a skip the queue ticket which was perfect - we still arrived early and it was perfect as we were virtually there on our own at first.It did get busy but there were enough places to escape. There is an audio guide but they like you to leave a piece of ID - like a passport or credit card.We did take the audio guide and it was informative and did give us a focus to the trip. It was amazing to see the achievements of these people without machines.
Roman forum. A great trip to the area in the heart of the novel. It remains very damaged, but worth seeing. Make sure you visit for hours as open space.
#2 after Colisseum. From my point of view this should be on the 2nd spot in your list for Rome!It just can't be described in words, you NEED to go there!

My Holiday Ruins. Walk through here on your own and what you will see is a pile of crumbling stones. Some may resemble buildings, others may be just another stone. My tip for seeing the Roman Forum is to have a fantastic guide to help you bring the forum back to life. This is the second time I have done the forum in three years. The first time the guide was very factual and that was it, which was interesting, but felt a bit like a history lesson in school by the end and you just couldn't wait for the lunch bell. This time around, we had a guide (Marco from the Nederlands) and he was also factual but a good story teller. He told it like a story and got us involved in the story and I learnt so much more and it also became a memorable experience. Tip: Get a good guide, it will mean so much more.
Incredible!. Amazing - what a legacy to leave behind. Try booking a ticket through ETicketing Coopculture - it will include the Roman Forum, Palatine Hill and the Colosseum.

Amazing and huge!!. The forum is absolutely huge, the colosseum ticket gives you the right to go in there too and you have two days to do it. I did them on the same day, which I thought was a mistake. I was exhausted and didnt see everything in the forum. Would def go on separated days next time! So impressive, realy a shame I couldnt see it all.

Need more signs. The place itself is huge and beautiful. We forgot to get a map when we went in so we were a bit lost. There weren't enough signs to direct you where to go and the signs were small, it took us some time to find our way to the exit, end up spending more time than necessary there.
Must see. As the brochure advises... wear comfortable shoes, and on a hot day take an umbrella and some water. You won't be disappointed.

So much ancient history!. We went to the Roman Forum as part of the tour of the Colosseum and it was well worth it. A lot is left to the imagination but so much is left that is easy to know what it is. This was the center of the ancient city of Rome and important government buildings. The Forum was the center of commercial activity. One of the important areas was the complex of the Vestal Virgins. The baths as well as 2 of the fire pits are still in place. This was located right below Palatine Hill where the emperor lived. To get to the Forum from the Colosseum, you have to walk on the ancient road. It is awesome to walk where Romans actually walked. This is a must see as part of the Colosseum area.

You are literally retracing history with each step!. I have been through the Forum over the years over a dozen times and each time I see something I'd missed the time before. The fact that it is even uncovered and revealing the secrets of 2000+ years ago is almost unfathomable. It is one of the most important sites in Rome, top 5 and should never miss missed!

Loved visiting this place. We enjoyed our visit to the Roman Forum. I downloaded the Rick Steves app on my phone and downloaded a nice walking tour of the Forum which was really interesting. It was nice knowing what I was looking at and learning the history of the place. I highly recommend visiting this place.

Extensive ruins!. It seems that everywhere you look in Rome, you will see some archeological ruins. But the Forum is not to be missed. It is a lovely time to wander through this ancient forum and imagine what life would have been like at that time.

One of our favorite places. We visited for the first time in August, and totally enjoyed exploring the Roman Forum. We had planned to be there on the first Sunday of the month, which has free admission. While we didn't get there until Noon or so, the line wasn't too bad. Yes, even though it was free, we still had to stand in line to get an actual ticket and then go through the security section.I brought along my trusty Rick Steve's book and it was really helpful in giving us info about everything. There aren't too many placards otherwise.It's a big place, with some shade, but be prepared for lots of sun in the summer! You can buy cold drinks at a vending machine sort of located in the middle of it all. The ruins were in great condition, and I bought a book later in a souvenir shop that showed a drawing of what the forum would have looked like in its time.

GREAT. The Roman Forum is a must see for any tourist. A slice of history, filled with exciting ruins.However if you have younger children I wouldnt necessarily reccomend this as the path is very uneven and pushing a pram or carrying a child would be inconvient (and they would probably be bored).
History lesson. This site is all about Roman history! Depending on the time, one can learn so much history and about ancient romans, their life style, architecture etc. We had a great time.

Walk in the Footsteps of Emperors. Truly incredible. Walk where the Emperors walked hundreds of years before and see the remains of ancient temples. Particular favourites of mine were the Temple of Saturn, Temple of Castor and Pollux (489 BC!) and the Arch of Septimus Severus.You can visit the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill on a joint ticket with the Colosseum. Ticket covers two days and the Forum/Palatine count as one site. Aim to to get there early. With my ticket and 8.30am arrival I pretty much walked straight in and not many people were about. It's also cooler and easier to get shade at that time. By the time I left around lunch the place was very crowded. Be sure to do some research before your visit. I didn't use a guided tour, just some reading up and a good guide book. As well as looking up, watch where you are walking as some areas are very cobbled and it's easy to lose your footing.

A must see definitely!. This is a very interesting place due tomits historical signifacance and you must visit in when in Rome! Make sure you get there at least two hours before closing time so that you have enough time to see all. When it is time to close they will kick you out and you won't be able to visit the entire place. Also, buy tickets in combination with the Colosseum as it will be cheaper this way!

I fori di Cesare sotto la luna. Beautiful night walk in the heart of ancient Rome. I fori di Cesare are a must see during the vacation. An amazing place which has been at the heart of the politics for centuries during the roman empire. Incredible ruins that spells the scent of what ancient Rome must have been. The walk lasts just a bit more than 1 hour and I had wished it would last much much more....

Beautiful historical sight!. Very well preserved buildings that take your breath away. Each building is very well labelled with who lived in it/ it's intended purpose which is very insightful. Be sure to use your colosseum ticket for free entry (€16).
Amazing.... No need for a guided tour.. get a map and a guide book and take your own sweet time to marvel at the glory.

The beating, many facited heart of ancient Rome. The Roman Forum is not a single entity but several sites which overlap physically and in different times. Although the best known building used by the Senate is here, it is not the place where Julius Ceasar was killed. It was being repaired at the time and the senate was meeting at Pompey's Theatre which can be found in the Argentina Square. The exact spot is marked by a tree at the bottom of some steps leading to a Cats Refuge! When you walk through the forum it is worth having a professional guide rather than relying on a book or pamphlet. They can bring the place to life so that you almost feel you are rubbing shoulders with the past.
Interesting tour before the Colosseum. We recommend Colosseum and Vatican tours.Luni for the Colosseum Kiara for the Vatican.Wear comfortable shoes and bring water!
Follow the Rick Steves walking tour. Despite the heat, we really enjoyed the Forum. We followed the 2015 Rick Steves walking tour and it was great. Decent public bathrooms, a couple water fountains.

Excellent well preserved site, worth a visit. The ticket to the Colosseum also allows visits to the Roman Forum- the ticket is valid for two days if one wants to take it easy. There is a lot to see and take in, and lots of walking. It is not the best place for those who cannot walk. A guided tour may help in bringing the stones to life, but we didn't use one and read the descriptions at each site instead. It one likes history this is worth a trip.

Remarkable attraction. We visited the forum as part of our Colosseum tour. Our guide was very knowledgable and was able to paint a very clear picture of what the forum looked like and it's many uses. As an Australian visitor it is mind blowing to see sites which date back so far.
Pretty cool . When you arrive in this area all that stuff you thought you forgot in history class rushes back . The forum was pretty cool . You really get a feel for Ancient Rome here
Great place a Must. We could enjoy panoramic view and imagine back to the Roman period how great it was. Nice maintenance.

One of my Favorite Places in The World. I found the Foro Romano first in 1972 as a college student and deemed it one of my favorite places in the world. One can wander for hours either above on the streets and parks looking down on it or actually through the ruins. I prefer to be down with the architecture to truly enjoy it. Centuries of history are beautiful to behold.

Mr Reaper . Spent a good couple hours wandering around the Forum after visiting the Colosseum, the site is quite large & spread over a good area with kits to see, there is a option to rent headsets so you can listen & learn as you walk around the site or you can just read the information boards which are in English whuch are dotted every feet as you wander round the ruined site, well worth a look & be amazed by the age & the History of this wonderful site
Beautiful. To see these remainings of old times, that is very beautiful and very interesting. We just walked around and the silence there in the middle of the big city is unbelievable

The Splendor of Ancient Rome. Take a guide if you can, and hopefully they will have a photobook of illustrations that show what the actual structures were in the forum, and how the existing remnants were part of them. Warning: on a very hot day, this place is sweltering and may be unbearable. Always bring water along, since this is a lengthy walk. Bathrooms are available.
A real must to see. This is the oldest part of Rome. You need to get a good guide or hire the head phones otherwise you won't have a clue what all the buildings and ruins are.

Worth it, don't forget this attraction, right next to the Colesseo. A big site, very interesting, lots of history, there is a very old 'church' on the site really worth visiting inside, the mural paintings are just stunning!Best is to buy a combined attraction ticket here (which include the Colesseo), the line-up is shorther here than the Colesseo.

Fantastic. Truly amazing visit! Queue wait time was 40 minutes. Wear a hat, apply block out and take plenty of water. There are free water stations to refill bottles. Definitely need a map as the area is vast. The cost of the Palentine Hill, Roman Forum & Colosseum is covered by the one ticket price.

Good but confusing. We enjoyed the Forum, but found it very confusing to get out. The exit signs are inconspicuous and small. It has a great view of the entire site from on top to include a nice view of the Colosseum. Bring lots of water or try to barter water sellers down to at least 3 Euros for 2 bottles.

Takes your breath away. We went here on a second day after our colosseum visit using the same ticket which is valid over 2days. We entered at the forum entrance at around 10am, and we were able to walk straight up to the ticket entry point with zero wait time. Upon entering we started our rick Steve audio guide. This was brilliant and I was pleased to have used it. Although we started so to speak at the end of the audio guide, it was most easy to select the interest point and cover the tour. We managed to find several shady places to sit while we listened and soaked up the history. We stayed 2 and half hours, which for us allowed us to cover the highlights for us, you could have easily have stayed much much longer, but the heat and the crowds were by then starting to intensify. So glad we visited.

The time machine. Walking through the Forum will inspire you to no end. To stand at the spot where Julius Caesar is said to have been assassinated, Antony's speech was delivered and the resting place of Julius Caesar himself, the imposing palaces, the senate, all lying in ruins! Deeply humbling experience.

Amazing ruins. Visited the forum and colosseum as part of a guided toor.
It is heart breaking to see that such magnificent buildings were taken appart few hundred years ago to be used for building churches...
Walking around the Roman Forum. Lots of walking. Easier to walk it than the Colosseum and not as crowded. Hot in July. Take a bottle of water with you.

Plan to take some time to wander. Adjacent to Palatine Hill, best to do both at the same time but these two areas are immense -- plan on taking some time and a lot of walking to properly wander and explore! This, along with others such as the colosseum, which is right across the road, are the heart of ancient Rome and, although in ruins generally, you have to be impressed at what was and must have been the huge scale of the then center of it all. Take a water bottle and wear a hat -- can be very exposed.

Everything I hoped for. We saw the queue opposite the colosseum and thought we would visit palatine hill first. Turns out you can walk down near the central gardens into the forum without queueing, from palatine hill! Use the Palatine entrance to the south West of the colosseum, as if you were walking toward the Circus Maximus along via Di San Gregorio. All the queues are less in the afternoon so see Palatine first then down to the forum, (there's a lovely viewpoint in the gardens number 23 on the map, see photos). By then the colosseum queues are smaller. We were told by a street vendor that you can't take any liquids in but we shall see...
What a place. Such a historically rich place. Although the area was vast and it was such a warm day, it was worth it becAuse of the amazing ruins. Definitely recommend

My favorite place in Rome. This place was truly amazing. I enjoyed seeing the Colosseum, but something about the Roman Forum took my breath away. There's so much to see and so much history to walk amidst. It floored me.You can easily spend a whole afternoon here (or you could rush through it in about an hour, probably), so be sure to give yourself enough time!
Step back in time. It was easy to see how the ancient Romans lived. Visit this area early in the morning before the crowds grow or before it heats up.
very interesting. I was amazed at how well conserved some of these places were. Architecture is fascinating for structures that have been standing for such a long time

Walking thru grand structures. Just a few steps away from the Colosseum (also comes with a combined ticket with the Colosseum), you can experience the rubbles of a once grand structure. It is such a stretch, with hills and remains of where buildings have been. If you go up on the hill on one side, you can have a great 360 view of the vast structures (the Forum, the Colosseum and the piazza venecia).

Essential place to visit in Rome!. Fantastic site in Rome, take a walk through ancient remains and see the Romans foundations of the city! See where the Romans lived, worked and worshipped and the place where supposedly Rome began - the she wolf is said to have fed Romulus and Remus here! Easily a full day trip - especially with a trip to the colosseum too! Top top: Take a water bottle to refill at water fountains and a snack! Hat and sun cream needed there is no shade! Best tip: buy your ticket here and not the colosseum! The que is much much shorter and you can then use this to skip past the hour long ques at the colosseum when you are ready! At only 12 euros a ticket visiting the Roman forum, Palatine hill AND the Colosseum was an absolute bargain and should be something on everyone's bucket list!

Walking in the footsteps of Saints. This is another site not to be missed how often do you get to walk the same paths that characters from our history books have walked. We found it hard to grasp that you have all of this smack bang in the middle of a city. It truly is breath taking
Must see!. Hired a private guide with Eyes of Rome which was well worth it. I think a three hour two was 180 Euros. Franco was our guide and would recommend.

Photographer's paradise!. A must see when in Rome, absolutely! It is now one of the most important archaeological sites of ancient Rome and the old buildings do really look very mystical. For a photographer it is a true paradise!

Ruins of the old times. This long walk across the Fora Romano makes u wonder about the might of the Roman empire and their subsequent fall... Earthquakes have ruined the place but it still vibrates life...
Roma forum. It's part of the tour with the palatine hills which is a good thing to do but i recommend to go with a tour guide we took crown tours and we had a amazing tour guid name christian
Must see in Rome. We took a tour for the Roman Forum and it was worth it.Our tour guide was exceptional, she explain everything in detail. What a great place, what a history!

A Must. We had a great guide (private) who made the place come alive. So much amazing history. Definitely suggest you have a guide or buy audio unless you already know everything about it. Guides also get you past the lines that are everywhere in Rome. We also walked up to the Palatine, which was definitely worth it. Check out the museum on top.
Incredible time travel. Amazing ruins of the original first Rome settlement that gives an idea of how its culture, economy and politics were. Highly recommendable.

Ancient days of Rome. I can recommend this place if you are truly interested in history. We bought the combo ticket, which is 12€ and you can visit the Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill together in 48 hrs. We have spent around 3 hrs in the Roman Forum, but it was still not enough. You have to walk a lot and it was very painful after a while. There is so much things to see. I think it deserves a whole day to see everything and read about the history of the buildings as well.

Roman Forum. What a placeWe saw the place as part of a tour group. I thought it was incredible really with plenty to seeOur guide Colin was very good although the tour wasn't very longTake plenty of water as it was pretty steamy mid day.

Experience this with an overlay book.. Before you tour the Forum get your hands on one of the Rome plastic overlay books for this area. They are available online. You can really appreciate what the ruins represent when you can see the picture of what each arch and building used to be part of. The Forum is a magnificent testament to the construction skills of ancient Rome. A must see in Rome.

Large site. The Colleseum tickets include the visit to the Forum. The site is huge and largely in ruins. Well worth the walk around but hot and little shade. Remember your water, there were toilets on the site. Having got in we then found there were no other places to exit so you have to retrace your steps to get out.
Fantastic. A really wonderful wander around ancient Rome - so much to see. It was a hot day, though there are fountains around - we did do a fair bit of shade-jumping though to enjoy the views!

Really intressting. I didn´t plan on going to the Forum, but is was included in my guide around Colosseum so I went. I had walked passed it almost every day. It is one off those things that I was surprised by and does stand out in my mind.

Amazing site. The site is massive and just stunning. We went in the morning before lunch (arrived at about 10:30 or so) and the place had barely any people around so we could walk around in the lovely quiet and enjoy the views without them being obscured. It is such a beauty where you can see different things from the place where the homes of those who lived there to where the shops would have been and even the garden at the top (beautiful, must go there even if you are afraid of heights just stay away from the edge and you will feel fine as its just like another floor on a building and you are standing in the middle. Sometimes you forget how high you are. Please take this from someone who is very afraid of heights). At the top there is 3 machines where you can get food and drink (which is thankfully cold) to find it you need to walk to the back of the gardens (if you are coming from the hard route) but there is a sigh next to the toilets by the garden showng you the way. Near the machines, there are a couple of benches in the shade of trees where you can relax for a bit especially on a hot day in the company of the singing birds. This is something you would have to give yourself a few hours depending how fast you walk the route you take (they have different ones depending on your ability to walk. If you arent good with stairs or inclines go the green route. Its a bit longer than the harder ones but brings you to the same place) but also on when you go as it would be a bit longer when more people are there. I would recommend about 2 to 3 hours if you go in the morning and miss the main traffic as you get the best experience then but if you go later pre book your tickets to miss the long queue like any place you want to visit in Rome where you have to buy a ticket.

Really interesting . I recommend you get an audio guide as there is so much to see and understand . This with palatine hill will take a couple of hours, if you like history you will wish to take your time. We were pleased to see free water taps around the site to refill bottles .
Ancient Rome. A must when in Rome. The history the engineering is just hard to describe. Yes it can be crowded but you must see it.

Impressive. It is impossible not to be impressed in front of the enormous Basilic that sits in the roman forum. Entrance to the forum includes the palentine hill, so I recommend it to fans of history.

No trip to Rome would be complete with out seeing the Forum. There is very little left of the Forum Romanum, but what there is should not be missed. The history of these ruins is deep and rich - and beautiful.

An insight into Roman Life of old.. A great place to come with older children to really get them interested in history. Even though it is mostly ruins you get a great sense of all the political and social going-ons of the time.

Fascinating!. Having bought our tickets for the Colosseum, entry to this site was included in the price. The Roman ruins are truly remarkable and there are plenty of boards with information about different structures and artefacts within the forum. Take plenty of water with you as it can get very warm walking around!! We were only here for a couple of hours as we were time-limited but we could have easily spent at least half a day here!
Amazing. There are free water fountains throughout, bring a bottle and you don't have to buy water. Also there are installations giving history on each monument.
You can't lose !!. You can't lose this amazing place, here you can remember the Roman Empire times and you'll see a small part of they history.

An absolute must.. The Roman Forum is so rich in history and well preserved that it is definitely a must see. Make sure you allow a lot of time as there is a lot to see and please walk to the top as the view is outstanding.

A must in Rome!. Its definitely worth a visit. 1 hour is enough too just walk around and see. Buy Colosseum and forum Romanum tickets together at the entrance of Forum Romanum (The line is much longer at Colosseum)

Hot but Worth It. The Roman Forum is one of the must-do things in Rome. We visited during the hottest time of the year, and we entered at the gate behind the Emmanual memorial, and should have entered on the Palantine Hill to get in a shorter line. However, despite the wait, the Roman Forum columns and arches and statues were all we could wish for. Lots of great photos and we learned much ancient history.

See a glimpse of History. We visited Cesar's Palace and The Roman Forum on a 9-day tour of Italy. Located right next to the Colosseum, it is a look back in history. Passing by the Arch of Triumph and Walking down the street in front of the entrance of The Forum it is easy to imagine the parades of Roman soldiers returning from their many conquests. The sheer size of the Palace is mind boggling. Visualizing the daily events of the business owners and Roman Senators in the buildings and on the streets where you are standing blows your mind. Seeing the detail in the construction and decoration on the ruins was amazing. Definitely a must see.

Amazing history cannot be missed!. Wow wow wow! The Roman Forum is absolutely amazing!! I definitely recommend you get a tour or at least research it yourself as it makes your experience even better, there are signs though in Italian and English which you can read as well! I still can't get over this place, the history and how its still beautifully preserved its amazing!

Ancient Rome's centre. It seems scarcely believable that you are stood in the fulcrum of the RomanEmpire- the stones you are stood on, were trodden by Caesar, Cicero, Hadrian, Trajan...this thought, alone, is enough to blow your mind and to warrant the admission fee.

Amazing. The Roman Forum provides an amazing collection of ancient ruins. The walk is interesting, though without a tour it can be hard to know what you're looking at. Never-the-less, very interesting and well worth a visit.

A view into history. The forum gives a great insight into Rome and its history. Go first up to the viewing platform to get an overview from above - it helps to put the ground-level sights into context.
Amazing. Another must see, beautiful and amazing to think this is still standing. There is so much to see. Allow yourself plenty of time to ensure you can take time to appreciate this.

Center of Ancient Rome. Next to the colosseum , you can walk the grounds for free but get a guide it really brings the ruins to life. Make sure you hike up the hill to see the forum in its entire splendor .

Where Rome ruled the world. The forum is a place of business and politics. The original senate building where Julius Caesar was murdered on it's steps is still completely in tact.
