You can stand on the place where he died and see where they carried his body. On top of the Palatine Hill is Caesar Augustus's home and it is still complete and in tact. You can see how this ruler lived and don't miss his escape tunnel in case he was attacked. There are two important arch's here. One is the arch of Titus and I do not remember the name of the other. You can almost visualize the shoppers milling about at the stoah's or stores as we know them. Just arched holes in the walls for each store person to sell his wares. On the far side of the forum heading away from downtown Rome you can still find one of the old roman red brick roads with ruts made by the chariots. We bought a guide to the forum and went on our own, I think we saw more than the tours did...they are limited time wise, we were not. It's just fantastic if you have some knowledge of history and a sense of imagination.

Amazing history. Just an amazing day. Beautifully preserved ruins. Be prepared for long line and lots of people. We didn't take a tour, but loaded Rick Steves audio tour on our cell phones. We were able to tour on our own timetable yet learn all of the history and interesting tidbits that Steves brings to his audio tours.
Amazing. This was an awesome site to see! Absolutely breathtaking. It's crazy that it has been around for so long! So much history. Definitely a must do!

Whatever you do in Rome, do NOT miss the Forum!. What an incredible walk through time! The size and scope of the Forum and its surrounding buildings cannot really be photographed or described adequately. My only advice is: just go!

Truly an experience to remember. It was amazing to walk where Julius Caesar walked. The signs were quite good. It's a little tricky walking on the stones, but to be where the ancient Romans walked was an unforgettable experience.
Again, part of the Colosseum tour. as I stated regarding the Palatine hill. It was good to visit but not on its own. Regardless, wear something comfortable.
Worth Visiting. Go, but definitely bring a guide and try to go when it's not the high season...very very crowded and very hot.
Awesome. Make sure you have a hat and water - worth going up Palatine first to look out on the Forum. And don't miss Augustus' palace near the museum at the top - that was truly awesome!
Hot and crowded, but fabulous.. At some point you will stand where Julius Caesar was assassinated and much of ancientvRoman history was made. Can't beat it.

Ancient Rome, best tour in Rone. If you want to see ancient Rome, go here. Especially if you want to be outside. It's a huge area, plenty of shady walkways, free water fountains throughout. Unbelievable views. If you must choose between this and the coliseum, choose this. I promise, you won't be disappointed.

Loved our visit to the Roman Forum. Here are our tips:1) Your Colosseum ticket covers the admission to the Roman Forum also. So, save your Colosseum ticket to enter the Roman Forum.2) Download Rick Steves audio guide to the Roman Forum. It helps a lot for interpreting what you are seeing. Otherwise, you are just seeing a pile of ruins.3) The temple of Vetsa virgins was great site. Do not miss it. Their temple, living quarters, and the swimming pool are really excellent. The site is somewhat hidden from the main pathway.4) Be prepared to walk a lot. Carry a lot of water, it was hot when we visited in August.

Incredible. It's rich in history and just overall incredible. However, we ended up walking around the RF after we went to the Colosseum, it was around 27/28 degrees celsius and we barely got around half of the RF because we were getting so tired. I would either recommend doing the two separately, or just not doing it in the heat.

Not a good idea in summer. I was really looking forward to seeing the Roman Forum. The ruins are quite stunning but the statues have all been removed and are housed in the Vatican. Unfortunately, we went in the heat of summer and we nearly collapsed from dehydration. Others we met weren't so lucky. They had to be carried away in ambulances.There is only one water fountain in the area and zero shade. The signage isn't that great either.Also, the staff were a bit useless when telling us how to exit. There is a lot of conflicting information and that didn't help us at all.Best to visit when the sun goes down, I'd say.

Friday Night at the Forum. Did the Friday night tour of the Roman Forum ( this is run by the Forum itself and they do tours run by archaeologists every Friday from March to Sept/Oct). Cost is 15 euro per adult. The tour was incredibly atmospheric & lovely & cool in the night air. Our guide brought us around the main ruins, including the place Julius Cesear was cremated, Septimus Severus' Arch and then through the Basilica Julia to an ancient church which was buried for 1000 years after an earthquake. This has been open to the public since March 2016 & has an incredible light show which highlights the different layers of frescoes from different eras that they uncovered. We went in at 9.45 and finished just before 11.30pm. It was fascinating.

History everywhere!!. The whole Rome is like a museum! Everywhere you see, you can see history! Roman Forum is the place where you can see many stages of the history of this ancient town. Here you can find emperor Antonios' house and ancient roman temples next to a protochrisrianic church. That was really amazing! Roman forum is next to Palatine Hills and Coloseum. I recommend that first you can visit Coloseum, next Palatine hill and next Roman forum, because Palatine hill and Roman forum are connected and from Palatine hill you can have a pretty nice view of Roman forum and then you can go visit it. The ticket is the same for Coloseum, Palatine hill and Roman forum at 16euros. All of them need about 5-6 hours to be seen. I really recommend it
What an amazing city once upon a time. What an amazing city once upon a time. Such beauty and hostory. Be sure to do some research so you know what your looking at.

Grand remains. The forum is a beautiful walk through history. There are so many parts to it and all amazing to look at. Put your trainers on, take bottle of water and get lost in time admiring the sights!
Included in your Colosseum ticket price. Go see it!. As with my review on Palatine Hill, this is a package deal with your Colo ticket. No brainer here folks; check it out.

Amazing Archeology. I have always just wandered around the Forum, just enjoying looking at all the ruins and trying to transport myself back in time. I've never taken a tour here and that's kind of foolish on my part because I know I'd appreciate it so much more if I had a better education on the history and architecture here. But even if you don't do a tour, prepare to be awed. Maybe read up before you visit.Like everyone says, it can get very hot in summer and there is little shade.Right across the street from the Coliseum.

Take some time to stroll around. Although you can see quite a large part of the Forum from the outside, it is really worth braving the lines and getting into the area. You usually get a combo ticket for the Forum and the Colosseum, and it's worth giving yourself a few hours to see both. The forum area is much bigger than I expected and you can see a lot of interesting structures and buildings, as well as park-like areas to stroll around in.

Impressive. After visiting the Colosseum we went across the street to the Forum. You could easily spend the entire day explore this area. So much great history in this area. If you don't have tickets, recommend going to the side entrances (vs the one across from the Colosseum). There was a long line at the one across the Colosseum and we walked right in through the side entrance. Considering we were going to walk across the Forum, this allowed us to see more of the Forum inside and not double back. Wonderful way to spend several hours.
Historic site. Fantastic roman ruins. Really helps to bring history alive. Part of ancient Rome not to be missed. Close to the Colosseum and Palantine Hill

The ruins. You cannot go to Rome without visiting the ruins and there are many of them. During our stay, they were still digging in many places. This place, in particular, is fantastic. You must use your imagination at times but well worth it.

Something to behold every time you visit. Love this place. So much to see and explore. You could visit 10 times and still see something new. And since it's all spread out, it's not such as madhouse as some of the other famous sites.

Beautiful!. Be prepared for a lot of walking! Comfy shoes are a must! However once we skipped the queues with our pre-booked tickets, inside was beautiful. You can see a lot of the Forum from the roadside however it is not the same as being immersed in it inside, allowing you to see the grandeur of the architecture! You could, if you wanted, have a guided tour however we went it alone. All in all, a beautiful place to visit filled with history!

Maximus tours. Its difficult to imagine how old these buildings in this area actually are. One thing I took away from the tours is that everything was burried under rubble and dust which had to be dug out. One of the buildings is a building on top of an old building.

So Much To See. The Roman Forum is like taking a step back in time. From the cobblestoned streets to the palace to even what is thought to be the servants quarters. Easily one could spend a few hours exploring the area. What surprised us was that up on the hillside was a lot of shade and nice breezes, which was appreciated on a hot August afternoon. The Forum is directly across from the Colosseum so it is easy to take in both on the same day, just allow for plenty of time. If I had to choose between the two, I would visit the Forum because of the many different areas and structures. There are many markers with information explaining the history and buildings which is handy when following the printed guide. A great day spent there and enjoyed by all in our group.

Blown away. Amazing. You could spend hours and hours here, it is so vast. It totally blew me away. Very very hot though if you come during the day, but various drinking fountains around to fill up water bottles.

Impressive. Like most other of the Roman area's this was impressive. There is not much info you can get unless your with a giude or have a travel guide on hand. We had one from Fromers that describe what we were looking at.

Walk in the Emperors' Footsteps. This is a must visit when touring Rome. This was ground zero for Hadrian, Titus, Severus, and Caesar to name a few. Take your time and make sure you see Temple of Saturn, Curia, Temple of Castor and Pollux, House of Vestal Virgins, Arch of Titus,and much more. Next walk up to Palatine Hill where the Emperors lived along with Senators and other well to do power brokers.

impressive, lots to see. very good and well worth a visit. allow lots of time because it is much bigger than it looks. amazing views from palatine hill. there are drinkable water fountains around Rome which are very useful in the hot weather.

A must when in Rome. We combined the visit with a tour of the Coluseum the access to the ruins is great a little imagination is required but they do date back 2000 years. We used a tour guide which I would advise so you get the most from the visit.
a highlight of my visit to rome.. wow, wow, wow. a must visit. You need time as there is so much to see. Walk to Colosseum from here, garden and view of Rome is incredible.

A must, specially with school age kids. Take your time.. I would recommend to do some reading before or take a guide of some kind. Otherwise you may loose important things. Not everything is so obvious like in other ruins.

History at Your Fingertips. This larger than life walk-through is incredible. I think it's a must-see and it's definitely worth the stop if you love history and knowing the years that have made this area famous. It's definitely worth the stroll.

Visit Ancient Rome and have a little downtime in this haven.. We went hee as part of the Colosseum bundle we had bought and I nealy didn't join the guided tour. I am so glad my sister insisted we didn't go on our own. I learnt so much and this place is amazing. It is incredible that it is still there. As my nephew said - 'We are standing in Ancient Rome'. There is a lot to see. Bring water or you will be tempted to be ripped off by water sellers outside the attaction. You could even bring a picnic. We were in a bit of a rush but I recommend taking your time.
Yet another must see!. Just wander around and immerse yourself in this historical marvel. We spent hours there and I would be very happy to go back to see the areas we missed.
Yet another must see!. Just wander around and immerse yourself in this historical marvel. We spent hours there and I would be very happy to go back to see the areas we missed.

Good History lesson. Please see my post on palatine forum.Audio guide is helpful if you do not use the tour guide.You will need to have an ID card as a deposit for the audio guide. Be prepared for some queuing. There is only one slow booth at the entrance.I would recommend seeing the forum first followed by the palatine hill and then finish the visit at the colosseum. This will help u beat the queuesBook your tickets online at Coop culture. Print out the tickets and not just the voucher.This will save you queuing time.

Fascinating history. You have to have a look at the Roman Forum when in Rome, otherwise you haven't truly been there! These ruins still stand after so many hundreds and thousands of years - fascinating!
Amazing . Remarkable and impressive. Walking through history, close look at the evolution of an empire. Very hot in July make sure you have a bottle of water. Is a must see.
Seriously lacking any precise information!. Great historical site but seriously lacking any logical information. Make use you take along a good guide book and good walking footwear.

Wander around. It's the best suggestion I can give, just wander this area and take in the history - which is fascinating. Take a tour if you have the time - they have a Colosseum/Forum tour that will take you through it all.
great place to go. Great time out, loads of walking, very interesting. Would suggest comfortable shoes and watch your step especially with young children.

I never thought it is so big. Nice to see and take your time. It is big and lots to see. If i have a chance, i will ask someone to guide me in this place. It have so much history. But the do provided a description.

Entry included in the colosseum ticket. Vast area to explore, stunning architecture & a fabulous view of the colosseum. There are information boards in both Italian and English so no need to pay for a tour.

Impressive. We visited straight after visiting the colloseum and palatine hill. As stated before it shows how fantastic the Romans were at building etc. Unfortunately travelling in July it was very very hot so we didn't stop long perhaps half an hour.Bit of advice wear sensible shoes it's a bit wobbly underfoot.

If this was an internet site, I would "favorite" it!. Visiting the forum was likely my favorite part of my entire trip. I believe this place touches anyone that visits - whether you like history or not. Included in one ticket is the Colosseum and the Forum (a bunch of preserved Roman buildings located beside the Colosseum should you not know exactly what this refers to), so you don't have to worry about buying multiple tickets.The Colosseum is a true gem. Such history preserved. The lines were decently long, but not unbearable. There were several lines to choose from as many people chose to visit with a guide. We decided to visit ourselves, and not purchase tickets beforehand. It seemed to work well for us as we went in the morning to miss the biggest crowds in the afternoon. When visiting the Colosseum, there are two levels open to the general public - make sure you see things from the lower and upper levels as you experience things slightly different and get great shots from the varying locations. They have water spouts (comes out of a hose) for you to fill your water bottle up. Great drinking water for the price ;) (ie free).The forum is quite big and fully outside. It's hot, so make sure you bring lots of water as there are no fountains or drinking stations like in the Colosseum. It took us several hours to visit the whole thing. There is lots to see and lots of variation in the buildings. Things seemed to flow well and crowds were well dispersed when we went - never felt crowded or jammed packed. There are no real information plaques or anything to provide a background, so know your stuff beforehand, or go in just to appreciate the architecture - either way, you'll enjoy yourself.The place is located close to a bus stop (although we walked from the place we were staying) so it's accessible via public transportation.Plan on staying half a day to a full day there if you want to take your time, appreciate what you're seeing, and seeing it all. It's not a place you can only spend an hour or two at.Let me know if you found this helpful! Thanks!

Foro Romano. The Roman Forum or Forum Romanum is a rectangular plaza surrounded by the ruins of several important ancient government buildings at the center of the city of Rome. There is more to see than the Palatine Hill and give more sense of the Roman Era but the ruins may confusing. There is some ruins that barely recognize but the sign will help you to recognize them. Again this is a combo in the colosseum ticket so just enjoy the walk and play with your imagination of the Glorious Roman Empire. The visit to colosseum will be not complete without visiting this site.
Amazing . Of course this is an easy review. The history here is truly awe inspiring. Make sure you make this a must see on your trip through Rome

Cool. This was included in our Colosseum ticket and definitely worth visiting as you get to see the Palatine Hill as well. There is a small museum here and lots of ruins to check out. We actually spent more time here than the Colosseum since it was open and not as crowded. Really enjoyed it.
Incredible. You will walk cross over stone full of Roman history. Places with the soul of Julius Caesar or Cleopatra
Roman History. great history.we bought tickets to visit the Forum afterwards. The entrance is opposite the Coliseum and up a slight slope.
A must see!!. A walk through the forum transforms you to another time...simply amazing to imagine what it was like to live in Rome during the best part of the Roman Empire.

Trip 2 milleniums back. It is a trip back in the heart if the roman history. I rented a audio tablet that helped a lot to understand what was each of the monuments. One can easily imagine how it was a long ti e ago!
Stunning!. Stunning views, great history. Get their early as it can be busy, great views from the Palatine hill over the forum.

True Ancient Rome. The only equivalent place I have seen is Persepolis( the Persian city) in Iran. It is hard to believe these buildings were mage thousands years ago. There was one fountain you could refresh your water bottle. If you buy your ticket at Colosseum you can use it to visit Roman Forum as well.

Another slice of Roman History before your eyes. When we visited the Coliseum we also bought tickets to visit the Forum afterwards. The entrance is opposite the Coliseum and up a slight slope. Travellers should be aware to wear sensible shoes because of the uneven paths.It's best to see the Forum from up above so once you enter the site go up to your left to the Palatine Hill and observe the place from up there. Temples, walkways and villas are a plenty and the whole area is a revelation for the history buff. While we were having a rest here we suddenly became invaded by a local tour, but we stayed and listened and found the experience very informative.We then walked back to the bottom and took a walk through the site from ground level. The area is stunning and people are still excavating the ruins. You can see the place where Caesar was cremated at the time Rome was a republic, and then see how Octavian (Augustus) created the modern Rome that we see today. Photo stops capture some wonderful views here and it's another site not to be missed. Just don't do the coliseum without doing this too. It will be a waste of a day otherwise.

Lovely day wandering around. We spent most of a day wandering around the Forum and Palatine Hill. They have done a good job preserving and documenting. All placards in Italian and English. Plenty of places for water, shade and rest. Educational and enjoyable. My favorite day.
True Taste of Ancient Rome. So much to see. Humbling to stand in such an incredible place, still standing after thousands of years.
Julius Caesar lived here!. One of my favorite places in Rome! How can you visit Rome and not walk the oldest street in the world?! If you love history, this is a must!!
World famous place. It was nice to see the remains of the Roman imperium that you've seen only in history books in the school. The place is compact and easy to access.

Brilliant. I have reviewed Palatine Hill in error ( Roman Forum and Palatine Hill merge into one) thinking I was reviewing the Roman Forum. I ( we ) loved this place, expansive, a good few hours ( most of the day ) were spent here, most of them in awe of what we were capable of all those years ago. Outstanding.

Great. We did the roman forum in a tour along with the paletine hill and also the Colosseum. All 3 are right next to each other so would recommend doing it all together. Tour was extremely interesting, led by an english speaking italian tour company.
Near the Colosseum , Forum is The better part of the tour of both.. When you see walk up the hills to see everything they built hear, you can't be anything but amazed. A must see.

Cool History. The Forum is filled with rich history, and I would recommend stopping by if you're near the colosseum. I wouldn't consider a must see, but if you have a guide to explain the history to you, it's truly amazing.
Interesting place. Historical and interesting place to see in Rome. I enjoy visiting this place specially if you know the history in Rome.
You must visit the Forum. Try to go on a tour or with a guide and visit both the higher and lower levels. The stories are endless so allow plenty of time to absorb it all.

Interesting. Worth the visit, heat in August very hard to bear, lots of people so long long lines to security even with a ticket about 40 mins in sun before you get in. You need an audio or tour guide to get the most out of it. Be aware the exit to capitalize museums is closed so you have to backtrack to exit and walk around to them

Too huge-Roman Forum with Palatine hill. Combine Roman Forum with Palatine hill and its a huge walk around the whole campus and we were lucky to have Rahul from Europe Odyssey had a personalized tour for us.Cheers to him.
Start of civilization . Absolutely fascinating place to walk around. Make sure to get a guided tour from Cristian at Crown Tours. One of the highlights of our trip

The forum really gives a sense of what Rome was like for the privileged. We loved the forum, some parts are that well preserved that you can almost see and imagine what it would of actually been like 2000 years ago. There are so many buildings and ruins and arches to see it would take forever to go through them and that would ruin the experience of discovering it for yourselves. We visited in July so if you go at a similar time be prepared for it to be hot and dusty. The forum needs a lot of time, I reckon you could spend all day here and more but I believe most people give a half day because it does get to the point where you find yourself saying inwardly 'oh look a boulder on the ground, another column'. Cynical as this sound, I know, but there are a lot of columns and a lot of debris all over as you would expect at a ruin. I am just trying to give an honest view. I like history but don't love it, so this place impressed me and I can see how you could spend loads of time here but if you're on a time budget you need to be strict with yourself and I'd say half a day is enough!
Wonderful. So a wonderful place with so much going on and hidden gems you don't get told about definitely worth a visit if you get the chance
A first time Must See. The Forum is a "must see" for first-time visitors to Rome. So much of our modern Western culture is explained and all that ancient history we had to study just comes to life.

Centre of Ancient Rome. It is not easy to move around these ruins without having some knowledge of the 10 centuries of history, from the 6th century BC to the Byzantine age, only then the monuments become meaningful. You can only close your eyes and imagine how grand this Forum was with its majestic columns and sculptures. A word of advise, you should go on a guided tour of these wonderful ruins. Only then, you will be able to appreciate all its greatness.
Roman Forum . Ace! Visited on the same day as other local attractions. Street entertainment was interesting,however the architecture and ancient culture was awesome!

Highlight of our trip. We booked with the official site CoopCulture to see the Colloseum and got the Forum and Palatine Hill included in the two day ticket. Had such a relaxing day wandering around experiencing the site. The map you get when you come in is marked with the water taps to refill your water bottle and the vending machine room - a cold fizzy drink was just what we needed in the sunshine!

Breathtaking to walk the streets where Caesar trod. The Roman Forum is peerless, the vast, fascinating remnants of the greatest city of the ancient world. Definitely worth getting a guide to interpret it for you - it brings the entire place to life. And don't neglect the Palatine hill which is part of the same complex. Unmissable.
Amazing. The Roman Forum is huge and the history behind it is amazing. We had gone through on a tour and was provided with so much information that made us appreciate the experience even more.

When exiting the Colosseum, turn right. The Foro Romano is a place of history with many hidden gems. I am a fan of visual history, so this place keeps adding to my vision of the Roman Empire. Plus, after the Colosseum trip, you get an even wider picture of times back then.
Highly recommended, especially since it's on the same ticket as the arena.

Truly amazing and historic. We went here with a combined Colosseum and Forum ticket, bought in advance from the official website. Entered along via Sacra near Arco di Tito. Before visiting the Forum walk up the Palatine Hill and take in the views, spectacular. Then wander down to the Forum area. There is a huge amount of history to take in and see, don't rush it, take your time and enjoy. We didn't take a guided tour as we like to explore are our own pace, but took along a very useful Pocket Rough Guide to Rome guidebook, which gave us the essentials. This was one of the highlights of our trip to Rome, absolutely love this area.

Good value and worth a look. This is attached to the Palatine hill, except they had a covered exhibition which was very impressive and you walked up a huge corridor to outside views of Rome and this was fantastic.

Not Great for Wheelchairs. There is a lift down to the forum which is great however some areas of the forum are not accessible at all. I had to leave my wheelchair on several occasions but even struggled on my crutches as it was so uneven. This is an amazing historical site and I don't know how they could make it accessible as it has the original roads throughout. If you attend this site in a wheelchair do expect to miss large sections of the forum and to have a very bumpy ride. However it is still a must see and disabled people and their carers are free.

Collective summary of ancient Rome. In viewing this archeological site you will be able to get a visual summary of ancient Rome. It is especially beautiful at night time with the lights on the buildings. A true sense of the ancient Romans.

Interesting and Educational. Just so much to see , so much to learn ... I tried to build it all up again in my imagination and wished to be there in those days just for a bit.Truly amazing place to visit

Guided tour is almost a must . Unless you know a lot of Roman history, some sort of guided tour should be chosen when visiting the Roman Forum. The site itself is packed with old Roman buildings, everything from houses used by the noble families, to churches and arches.

Been to Coliseum ... then you must visit Forum. The Coliseum ticket can be used to enter the Forum, so its worth a visit, walk among the beautiful buildings and take some shade beneath the shade of one of the many trees within the area. Savor the moment and enjoy.

Incredible!. If Rome is a crib of the European Civilization, the Forum proofs it without the doubt! Just the size and the beauty of what's left, the ideas and their execution in architecture and landscape left us subdued and humbled. When you count years in thousands instead of hundreds, when every date has "B.C" after the number, when you think what technology was available then one wants to take the hat off and kneel !

History like no where else. This is such an amazing place to learn about a society where so much of modern day came from. I highly recommend a guide to really learn the most about not only the ruins and architecture of this place but also the time period and how many words/ ideas come from that time. This is a a amazing place and HUGE and hot and crowded. I am SOOO glad we went. But here are some recommendations:It gets hot- wear a hat, go Early, wear sunscreen and cool clothes, bring WATER. Go with a tour group. We used a Viator tour and it was excellent. We got so much info. Otherwise you are just staring at ruins. Granted, you can use a tour book but it's so huge, you could wander all day - a tour guide helps you go directly to the things you want to see. I almost Never use a tour guide - I'm a Rick Steves fan and usually just use his books. But - this one is worth it - both to "skip the line" but also to get so much extra info and know which ruins to look at and to learn about. There are bathrooms and water fountains but they are few and far between so bring water. Also- the tour we booked through Viator- for both Colosseum and Forum was excellent. Didn't make it to much on Palatine hill but allowed you to continue on your own after your tour. We chose to get lunch somewhere cool instead. It's a lot of walking in the heat. I was told no strollers and we have little kids so that was frustrating because there were tons of other people with Strollers. Our tour guide kept showing us pictures of the ruins we were looking at and then side by side a picture of what it might have looked like back then Very Helpful!!I highly recommend the Viator tour!!

A nice stroll along the bylanes of history . The Colloseum, Roman Forum and the Palatine hill are Co - located. It's a combined ticket you get for all three places. It's really worth taking a stroll and marvelling at the ancient structures still standing.Had not taken a guide. But if you wish to make it more interesting the you must.

#1 Must See in Rome. We spent all day and didn't even see everything. There is so much history here, I couldn't stop myself from saying the word "wow," all day long. I was in awe the entire day. There is a lot of walking involved. It got really hot when we were there and the bathrooms weren't too great. We luckily had some water of our own, but other than that there was only a few vending machines. The price was extremely reasonable.

Step back in time!. I was expecting Tony Curtis or Charlton Heston to jump out any moment, it is a real life Cecil B De Mille grand scale production set!! Unbelievable, its like time travelling, you can imagine it all happening around you.we loved it!

Great Slice of Roman History. My wife and I visited the Roman Forum during our visit to Palatine Hill. Absolutely stunning archaeological site with much to offer. Please take my advice and do not visit during the worst part of the day when the sun is at its zenith as the site offers little by way of shade. Make sure to get tickets on the East side of the Forums on Via Dei Fori Imperiali as the queues here are much shorter than by the Colloseum.

Ruins in Rome. The Roman Forum is a collection of ruins of buildings along an Avenue that leads to the Piazza del Colosseo (The Coloseum) in Rome, Italy. The details of each ruin are prominently displayed on plaques in front of each site making it quite easy for self-guided tours. The Forum is a must see on any visit to the Eternal City.

Holiday . Definitely worth going after you've been to the colosseum to get an appreciation for the history. Download the Rick Steves tour on this and walk through each part . It took about 2 hours but was well worth it learning so much. Make sure you take water and snacks as there's no kiosk there. There is access to toilets inside and different parts are marked with green or orange to indicate easy or hard walk .

Huge with amazing views!. It doesn't look much from the entrance but wow once inside there's so much to see!!! The views were the best we saw on our whole visit you can see most of Rome! It is huge there's so much to see and if it's a very hot day I recommend a hat and plenty of water as its all outside with not much shelter around! There are drinking fountains around to refill bottles! Right next to the Colosseum so do both in a day if you can! Right by the metro and bus and tourist hop on hop off bus connections. Highly recommended

A must see in Rome. We were lucky enough to have a fabulous tour guide, who gave us the opportunity to explore this ancient site, The structures that have been found & even today they are still finding places is just amazing. There is a security scan to get into the site, please make sure you have comfortable shoes on, & take plenty of water, the views from here are amazing but listening to the history was just wonderful.

Ancient Experience and a must see - Tip to avoid the queue. Forum Romanum - 2000 year old history. All the family enjoyed the visit - especially our 12 year old son.You can avoid the ticket queue next to the Colloseum ticket office in 3 ways:1) Trough the official Foro Romanun online ticket office, which will give you a faster lane access to tickets. 2)You can also join a group, which is offered by private ticket sales agents. This is very expensive (30€ instead of 12). The 3rd way is interesting: Foro Romanun also has a smalle ticket office on the Via dei Fori Imperiali - Biglietteria Foro Romano. No Queues.

An impressive set of ruins. We visited on a hot August afternoon, but were actually able to find a shady spots to sit and listen to the free Rick Steves audio tour that we had downloaded earlier onto our ipads. In the middle of the afternoon there was little to know line at the ticket counter.
History at it's best. Take you time when visiting Roman Forum and read the information blocks. Avoid rainy days as not all footpaths are sealed...
Wow - so much history in one place. Second time here and still awed. Great structures and history . Took tons of photos and drank lots of water. No shade so summer sightseeing was difficult.
Did this as part of a 3 part tour. of the colosseum, palatine hill and the forum. They are all a must do. I would try to get a proper tour guide for about 50 p/p.
One of the must do stops for any tourist. You'll find this attraction right in the heart of the city. For the best value get your tickets from the Forum site that include the Colosseum.
Part of Grand day tour with Avventure Bellissime. Made fabulous by our personal tour guide Franccesa. I wouldn't just visit and look without learning the story behind the ruins.

Anciet site.. Light at night - just another historic sight, with high security presence at the current time. Not a place to play or explore after dark. A large parking precinct which means high traffic problems during the night hours. Interesting as is all of Rome but don't be too worried if you miss it.
Recommended!. The Forum was the pulsing heart of Rome, the city’s main piazza where citizens of every social level met to exchange opinions, do business, buy in the markets.

Alot of walking. hopefully when you do this it isnt 95 degrees. it was a beautiful walk and learning about the history and that they are still finding acient items is amazing. wear comfortable shoes and bring water..
Caput mundi.. It's one of the most impressive and beautiful archeological sites of the world. It deserves a visit for one day. Take it easy and enjoy the atmosphere of ancient Rome.

Interesting but book a guide. Very interesting and with some great views of Rome too. There is so much to learn about how the Roman society worked and it all comes to life of you bring your own private guide. I do recommend this as you will loose out on a lot just walking the Forum.
2nd visit and the best. We enjoyed seeing the ruins of the Roman Forum with a guide. It is amazing to see and hear about the structures.

An amazing part of history of this beautiful city. We walked through after our Colosseum tour. What an amazing and visually stunning place. And to imagine all the history that happened there is exciting. Don't miss this BEAUTIFUL site.

Incredible!!. This you have to see!! I never knew they had found all this! You can see how they lived and what the streets looked like and most of it is very well keept! Take guide and you will get out moore of your visit, we got lucky and got a archaeologist!!

Summer vacation. The third of the three attractions in the same area. A ticket included as three attractions Colosseum, Palatine Hilland the Forum. Doing a guided tour to use was quite good, this way you get information about the three that you would otherwise miss or not know. Standing in the middle of it gives you a small glimpse to the size of the Roman Empire. It's amazing how politics has worked to build all three attractions, who and how are interesting stories to hear. If you go to the Colosseum and Palatine Hill you can not miss the Forum. If in Roma do not miss them, they are a must, we enjoy them immensely.

A must. I do this every time I get to Rome. Not only is this place the foundation of much of our law and civilization, new discoveries are being made all the time. Just because you have "done" it ince....don't pass it up again!
One of the best arch sites i have been. This is one of the most impressive archaeological sites i have ever been. It is enormous, clean, well marked and with all information handy. A must see

A must see. This tour can be done with or without a guide. Make sure to watch your steps on the uneven pavement road. Bring water or water bottle to fill up because even at our 5 pm tour it was very very hot. Make sure to read the signs to learn more about the area.
Fun....Great Tour, historical. 2012 was a very historical tour based on the legends of Romulus and remus as well as authentic history. Viator trip.
Walk through history. Very powerful site to walk through. Easy to feel insignificant in light of all the history these relics have witnessed.

So much to see!. The Forum was an outstanding look into the past civilizations of Rome. The historical significance is mind blowing. It's a lot of walking and a tour is really helpful but if you have the energy, stick with it after the tour and look around on your own with a book in hand to identify your surroundings. Where else can you stand next to where Julius Caesar's burial pyre once stood. Great area and easy to get to. enjoy!

Know the history!. Lots and lots to look at here. There are so many historical points of significance. Be sure to read all of the signs. Soooo much information to take in and appreciate. A great place for anyone interested in history or architecture!

Fantastic exhibition of Santa Maria Antiqua. The Roman forum of course does not change much over time any more. I did my first visit there as quite young man in 1976 and did not then understand much except the Senate house, arch of Titus and the temple of Vesta. The area where the church of Santa Maria Antiqua is located has been closed for all my previous visits, and thus it was a delight to find it open, and portrayed in astonishing way using modern technic to show how it was in early days. Besides the history of the church the access is now given to places to show how the Palatine Hill and Capitoleum were connected. The ticket sold nowadays includes access to both to Forum and The Colosseum. I urge anyone not just buy the ticket to avoid the Colosseum queues but see the forum and the Palatine - preferably with reading in advance.

Amazing amount of History. Last thing we actually did on our trip, and actually only because it was left over from our Colosseum visit.Really pleased we didn't miss it, to think of the history surrounding the area is beyond belief.

Fantastic Underground Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill Tour. We had an amazing 5 hour tour of the underground Colosseum (including third tier), Forum and Palatine Hill with Eugenia D'Andrea with Through Eternity Tours. We only planned a couple of pricey "experiences" while in Europe and this one was definitely money well spent. I honestly felt that we would've missed out had we not had access to the underground areas of the Colosseum. If you can get a reservation to tour underground through the official Colosseum website, be sure to grab it. If not, book a tour with this company and use the promo code RICKSTEVES for a 10% discount. This was the best deal I found since we weren't able to get a tour through the official website (books up far in advance during summer months).Just be sure to bring lots of sunscreen (I'm not kidding-apply beforehand and bring it with you) and a water bottle for everyone. There are several refilling spots throughout the tour.

Roman Forum. A couple things to keep in mind. One, it's hot during the summer, so don't go during the hottest time of day, and two, there is hardly any shade so take something to protect your skin. Other than that very interesting place and beautiful views of the city!
Great attraction. Another wonderful attraction in Rome and a must visit. Walking about is very enjoyable; but a guide is very useful to assimilate the full history of the place.

Where it all began. This tour needs a guide - otherwise you miss all the important detail of what you see, the history behind it and curious little trevia like - why some statues show emperors with shoes and some without? (Right answer - those built after the emperor's death showed a diety and required no shoes). Learn about the Cloaka Maxima and who the city grew by just looking right and left.

Beautiful. A great follow up to the Colosseum, A great deal of the ruins are indeed ruined and hardly identifiable but the buildings/structures standing are really interesting and impressive. Just get yourself the inclusive ticket for Palatine Hill/Roman Forum and Colosseum

The history is amazing. The town center of Ancient Rome! Think about that when you're walking through it. It really is incredible. I'd strongly recommend taking a tour through it or at the very least an audio guide as you walk through because it is kind of hard to tell what's what as you're looking at it.The Forum is a must-visit.

Interesting Ruins. The Roman Forum, located near the Colosseum, provides an interesting look at life in the days of Ancient Rome. This area is overrun with tourists during the summer and parts of the Forum were under renovation when we visited. Nonetheless, no visit to Rome would be complete without a stop here.
Loved it. Part of our three hour tour of the Colosseum and Palantine Hill. Not a lot of tourists on the Hill when we went, so that made it even better to hear the history and explore the grounds.

One can spend endless time here .... I'm sure if I had had the time and was alone in this venue, I would have spent hours going around and listening to the history of each dilapidated pillar, temple etc. Just imagine - 2000 years ago, this was the center of Rome! How one wishes he/she could be transported to that time!Close to the Colosseum and Palatine Hill, this is a MUST VISIT for all those who love history and what made Rome.

This is exactly what I wanted to see in Rome. When you think of Rome and the ancient Roman ruins, this is the place that you're envisioning. It is a massive area in an ancient valley that has all of the old ruins, structures, columns, and temple remnants that you want to see. There are guided tours, but I just downloaded Rick Steve's audio tour for free and used that. He leads you pretty completely through all of the structures and gives some good background.

Awesome - mostly accessible for wheelchair travellers. To think that these have been maintained so well for posterity has to be lauded. It was a great experience to learn about these buildings and about the people who built them. It is mostly accessible for people on wheelchairs. I didn't see any accessible toilets anywhere, though.
Roman Forum. Don't do with kids - unless they are historic freaks! we got in - saw Titus arch and left. This must be done with people who like history and worthwhile to read up before you go.
Interesting look at history. You are free to wander around a number of historical buildings. Lovely views. Definitely worth a visit.
Wow. Wow-- like most of the ruins in Rome. Try to not get overwhelmed by the crowds and the heat-- grab yourself a quiet spot and admire the beauty of these magnificent remnants of the Roman Empire.

Wow. We visited on a very hot day (take suncream with you in the Italian heat)and spent nearly an entire here. We took in many sites of the centre of European culture 2000 years ago and it was astonishing to see the effort and workmanship that had gone into buildings and the original town district. This is a must do for everyone but get there early as this is a very busy attraction and very popular. I cannot really say much more as it really has to be seen to be appreciated. It is accessible on foot or by public transport but there is no parking. This is a definite recommendation.
Don't miss this. Absolutely fantastic. When in Rome... Don't miss this. The amount of history not least from ancient Roman times is breathtaking and an absolute must-see.
Fantastic. Go. Experience and see the place that Rome ruled the world from. The cradle of Democracy. Simply breathtaking (especially when it's 35C) :)

History Lovers Paradise. Make sure to grab a guide for this site. There are combined tickets for this and the hill and colosseum. My suggestions is to get the combined ticket for these three sites for early in the morning as they are all in walking distance of each other and is a four hour tour. Then during the heat of the day head to the Basilica and the church museums.

Roman Forum and Palatine Hill - must sees while in Rome. My family of four (with two teens) really enjoyed walking through Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. If you purchase tickets to the Colosseum, these two sites are also included in the admission price. We went to the Colosseum on our first day and used the same ticket to get into Palatine/Forum on our second day. Splitting it up into two days worked out great! All you need to do is walk to the entrance... you do not need to wait in line again. Since we didn't wait in line, we didn't buy a headset. I do think that would have been helpful to learn more about what we were seeing, but the line was so long that we just decided to walk through at our own pace. Try to go back to this area at night to see the light show if you can. Very enjoyable...

Exceptional Food and Service. On the periphery of the tourist area, this restaurant is exceptional Recommended by my landlord, the food was fabulous and the portions were generous. The manager brought me a few items to sample at no charge.
Roman Forum, a step back into time!. Walking the Roman Forum is a step back in time, well worth the walk the expansive area of ruins. Visit early or late as you are fully exposed to the sun.

rome holiday. This is the same entrance has the palatine hill when you go up the wide path join the que on your right (make sure you have your tickets which you should have brought at the bottom or the colloseum) the que goes quick they sacan you and your bages but food and water is no probs once in you can follow youe nose.

Roman Forum. The Roman Forum is part of some incredible history! Would recommend downloading Rick Steves' app prior to visiting this site. It will likely take a couple hours to get through this area as it is large and has lots of different areas to check out. Would not miss this!
Imperial Rome. This area was where the emperors of Rome stayed. From this location, Rome ruled the world. This is a must see thing.

A glimpse of old Rome. Although you can view The Forum from various free vantage points around it you can actually walk around it at your leisure as patr of the ticket you buy to enter the Collosseum. We spent about 3 hours exploring the site and viewing it from every possible vantage point. Amazing.

Great day out - Prepare well though!. We visited this as part of the Palatine Hill. They are actually all in the same venue and you can barely distinguish a line between them besides the obvious 'hill' part. Very educational and I suggest you get ten audio tour for €7 each. The ticket is part of your Colosseum ticket so you will very much enjoy this considering it's a free add in. Take a water bottle for the free water fountains and take some earphones for the audio tour and the ears will be in all day.Enjoy!!

Not enough information . It's a very impressive place to look at, but I expected more information on the social history and what it was like in that time, rather than what type of brick it was etc. as I'm not really interested in that. We didn't book a guided or audio tour because we just didn't have the time, but looking back if we had I probably would have learnt a bit more. I won't rate it too low as that wouldn't be fair considering I didn't have a guide, but you're going and you're a history buff please don't think you'll get by on the free information. Also it was too hot to even concentrate! Obviously that's not the Roman Forum's fault, but if you can't handle the sun like I can't then then go earlier in the year.

A must see. The Roman Forum is a short walking distance from the Colosseum, both accessible from Colosso metro station, but definitely recommend combining the two in a guided tour or you likely won't have any idea what you are looking at. There's little shade and it's hot and dusty in the summer, so wear close toed shoes and bring a bottle of water, you can always refill at the many free water fountains (which can be found not just here, but all over this beautiful country!).
Interesting. Part of the Palatine Hill tour, again you need to take a tour so it all makes sense! Very interesting...

Included in colosseum ticket . Visited with my husband and was blown away for your €12 ticket you can see Roman forum and colosseum. We went colosseum first then headed over here you might have a short queue to get past bag checks. Once inside we were shocked at everything there was to see including view points with amazing sights and getting up close to what is left of these great structures

Take your time, lots to see. The Roman Forum is absolutely breathtaking. It gets very hot in the summer although there are a few shaded areas and museums around to cool off in. Make sure you take your water bottle and fill up as you wander around. The area is so big with lots to do and you could easily spend 2-3 hours here. Your entry ticket to the Colosseum will also get you entry into the Roman Forum and the Palatine Hill as long as you use them all within two days.
Excellent. This is a very interesting and beautiful place with very nice bars and restaurants close by! Get a prepaid ticket rather than que !

Life time dream. I wish I could add more stars for the rating. Been I life time dream to come and was in no way disappointed the place is simply breathtaking and you can feel the history. If travelling in summer bring water with you as it's very warm but there is plenty of water fountains to fill up around the way
Take a guided tour!. We took a tour and we're glad we did-we wouldn't really have understood what we were looking at without it. Very impressive.

Roman Forum still providing entertainment.. Another amazing monument that is centuries old. Amazing that today they still have events there. There is ongoing archeology digs that can be viewed from above.

Absolutely loved it! Hours and hours and hours here. This place is a gold mine for photography. I also love ruins because you have the liberate of exploring everything at your own pace.If you're keen get the audio guide because it will be worth it. But don't do a guided tour because they are so pricey. If you do the colosseum and Roman forum on the same day leave this last because you'll spend more time here. And please explore every path. As long as it's not taped or barricaded your fine to see!! Take advantage of that

Awesome history 2,500 years ago. . The Roman Forum is really a name for all the Roman ruins in the city centre are are located next to the Colosseum. There are many smaller areas that have information plaques of the Roman Forum and you are able to walk around to several public veiwing areas to see this historic spectacle. It is worth doing a little research to know what you are looking at or purchasing illustrative books to bring the Roman Forum to life. Or you can do it the easy way and include this in a guided tour. The guides are very good and will give lots of information about what you are veiwing. Best metro station is Colosseo.

Enormous site with plenty of history to explore. A wonderful part of history preserved to various degrees that can be easily explored on foot. Uneven surfaces and steps mean it is best visited by able bodied people though - Strollers and wheelchairs would be difficult.Very hot in the sun, and not much shade, so be sure to wear hats, use sunscreen and carry a water bottle.It was worth taking a tour to skip the line (queue) and to hear interesting information about what we were seeing. Columns, huge structures, incredible architecture, original roads and floors, and all so ancient. Amazing.Definitely worth a visit to this attraction.

Unforgettable . It is a must-see spot in Rome!! Do not miss it!! The price is not that expensive and you must spend a whole day there. It is an amazing experience! If you like History, you won't regret it!!

Did this as part of City Wonders Tour with Colloseum - Very informative. We did this as part of the City Wonders Tour of the colloseum and the forum. Our guide was very informative and made it very interesting. You get headsets and earpieces and I would highly recommend doing this tour along with the vatican tour which we also did. You meet near the metro stop and then you get given your earpieces and headsets. You then walk around and she explained the history of things as we went, we dont have to queue to get into the forum with other people as we are a group so this is great. She take you to places in the forum and points out things and explains the history of it. You go up to Capitol Hill and look down and go around the palaces up there before making you way to the colloseum.The forum is a very vast site and there is a lot to see and take in and it is great to have someone explain things to you and the history behind it and they also have diagrams of what it would of looked like from where you are stood for you to visulise exactly how it would of looked back when it was in use. Thoroughly enjoyed it and thought our guide was fantastic.

Get there early!. Lines form before the 8AM opening. Get there early to avoid the crowds and the heat. Mussolini destroyed some of the ruins but what remains is stunning. We wandered about for 1/2 hour. It is near the Colosseum. Also take it at night when all lit up.
Historic Rome. It was very hot when we were there and the Forum is quite dusty. Ensure you have water with you. The historic buildings are well preserved and very interesting.

If it's your 1st time in Rome, you must tour the Forum. If you are visiting Rome for the first time and maybe don't think you will get another chance, then the two sites you must see are the Forum and the Vatican. The Forum is the center of ancient Rome, basically the cradle for much of what eventually developed into Western civilization. Did you know a "basilica" started out not as a church but in ancient Rome as a large public meeting hall where many legal proceedings were held? In the Forum you will see the remains of the huge Basilica of Maxentius and Constantine, to the right after you enter past the Arch of Titus. You can also see the spot where Julius Caesar was cremated and the rostrum where Marc Antony made his famous oration at Caesar's funeral. You can stroll the Via Sacra and imagine a glorious Triumph parade winding around the Palatine and down the Via Sacra towards the Capitoline.We visited at the height of tourist season in mid July 2016, and it was crowded. There is really no reason to pre-purchase tickets (which give entry to the Forum, the Colosseum and the Palatine Hill) on the web. Just go to the ticket office at the Palantine Hill entrance a couple of hundred yards south of the Arch of Constantine. Even with enormous lines at the Colosseum and the Forum ticket offices, very few tourists are interested in the Palatine so the line there is really short.However, unless you are freakishly knowledgable about ancient Rome, you must use some kind of guide when touring the Forum. Otherwise it's the equivalent of touring the remains of a city bombed to rubble. Very little is labeled, so you won't know what you are looking at. You could join a tour, in which case you don't need to worry about tickets but you can't explore on your own. We used Rick Steve's free audioguide downloaded to our phones. It's pretty good and did help us understand what we were seeing and imagine the grandeur of the Forum in its heyday.The Forum is ideal for history buffs and anyone remotely interested in ancient Rome. I wouldn't recommend it for young children since the walk around can be long and hot in the summer with very little shade and nothing a youngster can really relate to. High school and college age kids should appreciate it.For a fantastic panoramic view of the Forum, go to the Capitoline Museum, cross underneath the Campidoglio plaza to the northern wing of the museum, and make your way out onto the balcony overlooking the Forum.
Beautiful and historic. You get a feeling of being in ancient times, but you need to know your history or you will get lost in the information.

bring your hat and water. It's so wonderful that Rome has preserved the remnants of its past.You can walk the length of the Forum from the Arch of Titus, past huge columns and archways and see modern buildings in the distance. Be advised that there is another security check point even if you've entered after seeing the Colosseum. The sun beats down as you wait so be prepared. If you exit the Forum to the right before the very end and make a left it's a short walk to the Museii Capitolini--but it's up a steep flight of steps.

An amazing trip into history . Together with the Coloseum this is the most impressive sight. We didn't have to wait in line for more than 10 minutes to buy a ticket (witch is very cheap). And it's a very smart idea to buy a combination ticket for the Coloseum because the lines there are endless. With the combi ticket you have 2 days to visit both and the line at the Coloseum is remarkably shorter than the line without a ticket. Once inside the Forum you can walk around for a day. We had over 35°C so we took time to cool down every now and then in the shade. But what an amazing sight! The ruins of the old temples and the bricks of the old roads...you can imagine perfectly how life was in the ancient city...the centre of the trade. We were just speechless looking at the architectural achievements and walking in the middle of them. Visiting the Forum teaches you more about history then any book will do. A must do and definitely a must see when in Rome!
A pleasant journey to the history of Rome. A lovely sight too just imagine the life in ancient Rome. Loved every second of it.Just wear comfy shoes and also a hat if you go in summer.
Check the block. These ruins are not in the best of shape, but still worth the effort to go see them. Best Viewed from Palentine Hill

Ancient feel. I enjoyed the Roman Forum very much. There is a lot to do here discovering all the ancient ruins. The ticket to here is together with the colosseum and palatinus. But if you buy your ticket here you can avoid the huge line at the colosseum. Enjoy!

Layers of history. Spent an enjoyable few hours around the forum and Palatine hill on a day that wasn't stiflingly hot. There are so many layers of history in Rome and the forum is a great place to get a sense of this.I would suggest that a guide of some description would be very worthwhile. We tend to just wander round these types of attractions but we found that information displays were a bit lacking in interesting detail so had to turn to the internet to help us as we explored. The queue for the forum was very short compared to the Colosseum so well worth adding to a visit of this section of Rome.

Fantastic place. The Roman Forum is definitely a must see while in Rome. It is beautiful and impressive! One of the most beatifull historic place I have ever been. Since it is huge and with a lot to see, I would recommend 5 to 6 hours just there. With the same ticket you can go to the Coliseum and also to the Palatine. As far as I can remember, tickets are valid for 2 consecutive days. We went with three children, including one baby. I do not recommend you to take pushchair there because there are a lot of steps to climb and the pavement is very irregular; once it is an ancient site. I also recommend that you take some snacks because they don't sell anything there. There is a water fountain where you can fill water bottles. Don't forget to bring sun cream, hat and sunglasses with you. Totally worth going.

Stunning. Totally worth it. A must see. Take lots of pictures. Incredible knowing the majority of structures were built during the reigns of Caesar & Augustus.Not too crowded. There are toilets inside & water machine (to buy) or right at the end we spotted a fountain with drinking water. It was 36' so wear a big hat & sun cream cuz the heat was intense & no shade. Go in the morning rather than mid day.
Do not miss this attrction. Magical feeling to watch on this ruins. I felt like I have moved by time machine to ancient Rome.Or I recognized some scenes from historical movies like Gladiator.

Awesome. We booked our tour with "the Roman guy" and loved the tour. It was 4 hours and be prepared to walk a bit as the terrain is uneven. We saw the Roman forum, imperial palace and colosseum in this tour. Would recommend to anyone.

Fascinating. Take your time.. There is so much to see and take in - just imagining the area 2 centuries ago with cattle grazing several meters above the existing floor level and then thinking of the peoples who have walked the paths you walk today, the history they created and their impact on western European civilisation.

Always great.... Love returning here every time.. so much to see. The queuing in peak tourist season is a bit heavy... even when you buy a ticket online you queue to 'convert' it into another piece of paper. ..

Worth the Visit. We went here as part of our Walking Tours of Italy tour. It is very interesting to walk around and see the different areas. Would have enjoyed spending more time here. Close the colloseum and other attractions.

Meet Julius Caesar in person. Straight from the history books. Can be a long wait if you haven't prebooked as popular attractions. Interesting and wonderful to walk in the footsteps of the Romans you read about. Well presented and tidy with good info.

Historical Masterpiece. Is an interesting site worth visiting. Would defiantly recommend for the different monuments and views. We went during the day and was a struggle because of the intense heat and direct sunlight so you will need to make sure you have plenty of water and sun screen!!

Very worth seeing.. This was the center of ancient rome. The $15 books showing what it looks like now compared to how it looked originally are very worthwhile to get a better perspective. Also a good tour guide makes it more interesting.
For historians. The ruins shows really how Rome was in the old times. Its Worth seeing but itd not neccesary to spend to mych time there. Use the sidewalk that runs Next to Roman Forum
Very cool if you really take your time. This is the essence of ancient Roman life. Take your time; look around. There is A LOT to see. Put it on your Roma trip to-do list!
The Forums. There are several Forums and all are with walking distance of one another .a great place to picnic, just watch out for the seagulls! They will snatch your foccasia!
We had an excellent guide!. Our guide was booked by the hotel Golden where we were staying. This was made more interesting by the tales were told of how it was used!

the best. Right next to the Palatine Hill and the Coloseum, you can get in with the same ticket for all three.
It was majestic.

A part of History. The forum is right next door to the colloseum, and its a huge area so if you want to see it all, allow a good 2-3 hours. Its like walking through a ghost town and some of the relics are very well preserved bearing in mind they are nearly 2000 yrs old. You do not need a guide but you will get more from the visit if you read up about it in your guide books the night before.There is not a lot of shade so take water with you and a hat, the sun was draining when we were there. The queues to get in are nothing like the colloseum but you can pre book a combination ticket direct from their website at only 14 euro PP, an absolute bargain.

Well worth the visit. You can read book and look at photos but until you experience this place, you really cannot fathom the immense history all around you.Get on a tour or get an audio tour to guide you around.Go in the am before too many people and too hot.

Must Do!. See it with a tour and absorb all the history this place has to offer! We did a tour that included the Colosseum , Palantine Hill, and the Forum with "I Love Rome" tours and we learned SO MUCH! Amazing!

this is Spectacular-so much History compacted into this space. the Ancient History that took place inside the Roman Forum is incalculable. An absolute must do! there is some hills and walking, and can get warm but that is no matter compared to what you will see. get the ticket with the Palatine Hill. Use the Rick Steve's audio tour, it is perfect, and gets you through the maze of structures and historical highlights, otherwise it would be a wish-mash of chaos to figure it all out on your own. One of my highlights of our trip!
Must go there.. Have a guide if you can, but not necessary. Go earlier in the day in summer. It is really hot and crowded in Rome at that time.
Walk among the ruins . The history is long and deep. Take a knowledgeable guide and a camera. This was a fantastic place to spend a few hours and learn about the history of this beautiful city.

Walk thru history. Every step given inside the area of Roman Forum is like walking thru a ghost city. It's really nice to walk and imagine how that city used to work. Since it's ticket is with the Colosseo, it's really worth to see.
Fascinating. Really worth a visit but you need a guide book with information to understand the original use for everything.

Fascinating. Take loads of water, some kind of some shade, a good guide and soak up the history. It is a wonderful place, but without some kind of guide, quite difficult to picture how it used to be. Our guide gave us some good information and really added to our visit to the Forum.

Vacation in Rome. Wonderful history and breath taking views from various levels throughout the ruins. One of the netter attraction in my opinion. Self guided tours or optional guides are available. EXCELLENT!

Italy and Greece 2016. Walking down towards the forum was breathtaking. To look upon the area and see the ruins and to imagine what it must have been like to see it in its glory, with people walking around.
I was in total awe of the lifestyle and beauty the resident experienced when they went about their daily lives!
Amazing. I had been to the Forum before but this time I had a guide from Gladiator Tours and I learnt so much more. An amazing place. Well worth paying the extra for a guide.
Stepping back in time. One of the most pleasant experiences while walking in the footsteps of the ancient Romans. The setting is overwhelmingly impressive. A must see and visit in Rome.
Bring your walking shoes.. There was just soooo much walking to be done. The site was amazing, just be sure to wear comfortable shoes.

Just pure awesomeness. Imagine, just imagine. You walked the same cobblestone way that Julius Caesar, Augustus and other great emperor walked.
Imagine all tourists being the people in the past.
Imagine all the buildings are still as they were.
You will experience history in the Roman Forum.
Just love it!

buy audio-gid & be prepared to listen lots of interestic info about Roman times. buy audio-gid & be prepared to listen lots of interestic info about Roman times. I reccomend to take water and food because there are no place to take a rest or buy smth. WC is hard to find but they are quite clean

Magnificent. Chanced upon this beauty after our visit to the Colosseum. It was an awesome sight, which allowed us to imagine how ancient Roman life would have been. Its outdoors so it'll be good to bring water if visiting in summer

Worth each and every penny. The churches, the squares, the gardens, the fountains, are all fantastic. I suggest to bring a sandwich, or something to eat, because you might get hungry during your long walk in this area.

Citybreak in Rome. One of the best archeological sites in the world. Buy online tickets to escape the queues. A 2-3 hours visit to cover all the artefacts. Take water with you when is very hot as you can not find inside.

You have to have some sort of guide and lots of water in summer. If you visit this without a guide book or some sort of guide its just a bunch of old stones. With a good guidebook its a place of history and culture, where modern civilization was born and legends were made. The facilities are scarce, there are no snacks or beverages sold inside so be prepared with water bottles especially in summer, there are a few water fountains to refill. Lots of construction so part of it might be closed. A hat is a must.

Great place to see history. VERY nicely kept, and to walk around and imagine the people who where here so long ago, walking on those very pathways, is mind blowing. Very well preserved and all of the staff that we encountered were very friendly.

Safer Than Ever. The Roman Forum is one of my very favorite places on earth. Until recently pick pockets liked to roam there too.Now, the Roman security force has installed airport type security systems at the entry on the Colosseum side . There people are divided into two groups so that the pick pockets are separated from groups they like to try to infiltrate. The ruins are meaningful especially to those who have studied the space in advance. It is an honor to walk in history. Of course, you can see where Julius Caesar's funeral bier was...flowers mark it.

A must see in Rome. We pre booked a tour with Viotours, that took us through the Colosseum and then toured the Forum. We enjoyed both, but I thought the Forum was incredible. The group was larger, with microphones. The guide was very good.

MUST DO. This is right across from the Colosseum and if you buy a ticket for the Colosseum it's good for the Forum and one other place I can't remember. I just love seeing old remains of places and this is definitely a place you need to include in your itinerary!

Steeped in History. Fantastic experience and well worth a visit. Bonus is that there are a number of water points where you can refill your drinking water bottles for free...and cool off if you wish. We visited on a really hot day and the numerous bushes/trees gave welcome shade. Also public w/c on site. For ladies may involve a wait but not very long. Even when it is busy there is plenty of opportunity to see all you want to, and take photos. Admission to Colosseum of 12 euro also covered admission to Forum, though it is necessary to wait in line as there are security procedures at the entrance...not an issue...especially with current world events.Allow plenty of time to see everything...certainly not to be rushed. Uneven path surfaces may be problemmatic for those with mobility problems.

Best Attraction In Rome. I visited the forum for the second time in Rome. It was my husband's first time at the forum and he loved it. The forum offers a lot for visitors to see as they walk around. If you like ruins then you would like this attraction. It takes about 1 1/2 hours to fully see it, so be prepared to walk. I would definitely recommend coming here; especially because the entrance fee is included in the Colosseum ticket.
Roman Holiday. worth the in depth tour...I have been before and it was just too hot to navigate...but put on the list

An excellent attraction that you must visit. The Roman Forum is located in the more southern part of Rome and is next to the Colosseum. The price is only 12 euros per person and that includes the Roman Forum and the Colosseum. The Roman Forum has plenty of ancient ruins and is a very big attraction. It might tire some people on extremely hot days because there isn't much shade besides the church. The church in the forum hosts an exhibition which is fantastic and my favourite part of the forum. There is amazing effort put to make this exhibition and even has projection mapping. There is no souvenir shop in the forum but there are plenty of bathrooms. There is also plenty of viewing platforms to get great views of the Roman Forum and the Colosseum. Overall, you should definitely visit this attraction, especially since it's included with your ticket to the Colosseum.9/10

You will be amazed!. You must walk thru this place. I was amazed at the level of preservation and the fact they are still excavating in areas. You're on the ground looking at structures that I'd imagined would be behind locked museum doors. Its an incredible place.

A fine example of ancient Roman architecture . If you like old buildings then this one's for you. Very very old and amazing to look at. Only problem I found is that these old buildings become a bit of a blur after you have seen about 10 of them. Lots a fine food outlets nearby.
An Inspiration. Really took us back in time, hard to believe that the centuries we had gone back as we wandered the streets and buildings in very very hot weather..

Amazing. We did the Colusseum, followed by the Roman Forum, and then Palantine Hill. Worth doing all together. Took us about 5 hours in total I'd say. So impressive. We were first time visitors to Rome - Absolutely loved it. Don't think you could find a poor restaurant if you tried. felt very safe. Good public transport system
A wonderful surprise. My husband and I stumbled across this place. We were just walking around and all of a sudden, we came to this AWESOME archeological site. Absolutely amazing.
Take a guided tour. We used tickitaly, well worth it to have a guided tour and got to see the Coliseum as well. There is a lot walking.
Ancient Ruins a must see. The Roman Forum is a must see when is Rome . Its right next to the Colosseum so plan to visit at the same time . Hire a guide and get to know more about the Roman history .
Spectacular!. Loved this location for amazing photos. Can get great shots of the Forum with the Coliseum in the background.

Very nice. It's a nice spot, but you have to do this with a tour or a guide because of the extra information you get.
Your ticket is for the Colosseum and the Forum, so it's definitely worth it!
Inside the Forum there are water taps to refill your bottle.

Center or roman life - The forum. There is some much in the forum, you almost need to do a little homework before you actually see it, It was the center of everyday Roman life - a market, the temples, and a place for businessmen to meet and discuss things. Also memorials and tributes to various leaders and (successful) conquerors. if you don't really have the background info, you will still see a lot of extremely interesting ruins, and there are a pretty large number of placards and signs with short explanations, but to really get an understanding, read up just a little or pay for a guided tour.

Worth the sweat!. The lot of climbing and walking is definitely worth the view and the exiting ruins! Take a lot pf water, good shoes, and most importantly, buy your tickets before the visit online! We had to wait for an hour to get ours!

Layers of Roman history. Another gotta see place - plan on 90 minutes at a minimum. Don't go when it is really hot unless you don't mind that - not much shade. But do go - just plan according. Suggest you enter from the north side (away from the main entrance near the Colosseum - that entrance is near (in back of) what is known as the "Typewriter" - aka the Monument to Victor Emmanuel.
Beautiful at night. Personally I think this is best visited at night. It's beautiful in the morning but the lights at night make it more magical
Good ruins. Nice ruins, should get the audioguide for best information. Can do in the afternoon in the summer, but its hot and you will sweat

Worth a visit. This is right next to the Colosseum, so you should visit if you are there. Its better to go with a guide who can explain a lot more about the history of this place but it may not be too difficult to roam around by yourself too. The place is huge so you can spend a lot of time and if really interested read through the signboards placed on many of the structures to know more about their history and significance.

A must for history buffs. These ancient historic ruins are fascinating to visit, as they are right there in the center of the city. It's easy to combine with a visit to the Colosseum (the ticket for this is included with the Colosseum tickets). Interested people should hire a guide. A must for history buffs!

STUNNING. What a stunning thing to see in a purely magical city of Rome. These ruins have been around so long and its amazing to see them in the flesh. There is still a lot of uncovering work happening so prepare to see builders and cranes

Too Much to Take in in One Go... So Go Back Again Tomorrow! .
