The Roman Forum is one of the three big historical attractions that you can visit on a multi-pass ticket, that also includes the Colosseum (although you must queue again to visit that site due to enhanced security measures), so if ancient rocks are your thing, this is a must-see.I'm not quite sure where the Forum began as we just flowed into it from the ruins and gardens of Palatine Hill, situated just above.There are so many glorious photo opportunities to be found, there's something new to see looking up, down, along, in the shade in the sun - take plenty of camera film or a big SD card!One of the great things about Rome are the constantly running drinking fountains dotted around the city that allow you to refill your water bottle for free - the Forum has a couple of these taps plus toilet facilities within the site.Given that this is one of three attractions on your very good value ticket, it's easy to skip round so quickly that you don't really look at things, you just see them through your view finder... Well good news: your ticket is valid for two days! We didn't return the next day, there is far too much to see with just four days in Rome, but if you've been to this city before, seen the Vatican and the Spanish Steps, for the price, you won't find a better two days of Entertainment.
Ruins with a lot of History. Visited the place when in Rome. A place with a lot of historical significance. It's amazing and a must see.
Visited with "Romearound"Excellent tour with Jill. Got this tour as a bonus when we did the Colosseum tour with Romearound. Jill was an excellent guide
Worth the wait. Right outside the Colosseum. Its worth waiting in line to get in the complex and see another part of roman history. Quite a bit of walking but worth the effort.

Highly recommended for good views and history buffs!. Highly recommend visiting if you are into history or want great views of the architecture. To take in the full splendor, it is highly recommended to be done as part of a guided tour. Be warned that this is an open space and the summer heat may get in the way but still very much worth it!
Roman ruins. You don't have to buy a ticket to see the Forum, you can view it from street level. An amazing place, you should definitely visit, even if you you don't have a ticket.
Fascinating History. This is great for learning about Roman history and helping to understand the influence on modern Rome.

Wish I did a guided tour. Roman forum was amazing to see. I just wish I did a guided tour or audio tour. I felt I missed out on alot by walking around by myself. Not everything has signs with information.
Overwhelmed with the history. We were overwhelmed with the history and grandeur of everything that we saw in Rome. Everyone was very helpful and very eager to show us their history.

Historical, but not much to see. So the forum is amazing, except that it's been pretty well obliterated. And that happened relatively recently... Anyway, walking through the history is worth the time, especially since it's so close to other sites.

On our Viator tour we visited the Colloseam and the Roman Forum. Our Viator tour took us first to the Coliseum and then the Roman Forum, and then to Palatine Hill. We started the tour at 8:30 before it got hot. Looking back I might check out tours after 4pm. Amazing with a good tour guide, which we had.
Awe inspiring. It mind boggling to think you are walking on the same ground that Cesar and others walked on. It is an emotional event for me.

Very much worth it. Probably the most treasured part of our visit to Rome...really awe-inspiring to stand amidst the ruins of the heart of the Roman Republic. Felt more meaningful than the Colosseum, which celebrates human nature at its worst.

Much more than I expected!. I was not aware of just how big and how much history the Roman Forum had to offer! I was pleasantly surprised by the stories and history our guide told us about. This is absolutely worth a visit, and, if possible, I recommend a guided tour.

Home of the elite of ancient Rome.. Include this site with a tour of the Colosseum and Palatine Hill (we did ours with City Wonders who I recommend).
Very interesting couple of hours spent trawling through ancient history brought to life by our guide Sara.

This is a must see!. We were lucky to have a private tour guide, it is very much worth it. Among the attractions of the Roman Forum, is the actual place where Julius Cesar was cremated. Walking the whole Forum give you a very good idea of what life was like during the Roman Empire, as well as how the Barbarians, stole and pillaged Rome.

Must See. I've visited Rome about five times now and been here on three separate occasions. Every time I'm struck by the riches of details, the history of the site and the pleasantness of strolling around. Coliseum ticket can be bought with access to forum and the palatine hill (this hill is a must great views and lovely atmosphere). Bring bottled water and sunscreen on hot days to prevent dehydration as it's an open site with little cover.

This place is so cool. Hire a local expert guide and appreciate what it has to offer.. This is so cool. I would argue this is more important for you to see than the colosseum. There is so many layers of history there. You miss it if you don't have someone to point it out. We were fortunate to have found a tour company with great local connections. There are so many important things packed in one place. Bring a water bottle. Important to hydrate. Cool thing is that Rome has all these cool fountains with clean cold drinking water. Take advantage and fill up your water bottle regularly.
Nice . I used my Roma pass to gain entry here. It is a nice archaeological ruin right in the middle of Rome. I recommend you get a tour guide or at least read up before visiting.
Nice Place. A lot of history but you need a very proffesional guide. We were in a group of 5 people only and couldn't explain it with details and was in a rush.

Impressive but very hot there!. It is worth a visit specially on Sundays as entrance is free. If you have got a good guide, you will better enjoy the full history of the place and its surrounding.From the terrace, you have a full view of the ancient city, or part of which is left.You also get a stunning view of the Colosseum from the lower grounds.

How did they build that? incredible.. We wondered at the building ability of the people centuries before. Walking through quiets your soul to daydream what it was like hundreds of years ago. We also took the paid evening tour through the area...really nice to see and help with your imagination!

Ancient Rome improves with Age. The Roman Forum is a time capsule of the ancient city. I went 40 years ago and it was very impressive. Now it is even better. The excavations continue to add depth (one city after another built on this site as new levels are dug). Seeing the dirt line on buildings that are 20 or more feet above the ground shows how much history has been hidden. A guide is valuable on this tour because he/she knows a lot that is not in the guidebook. Paired with the Coliseum makes for a great morning's tour!
Fascinating. Absolutely loved this place - fascinating. Again, an extremely busy attraction, but parts of it were almost deserted.
got to see. Amazing history and amazing to see. We had a tour guide who had a book to show us what it would have looked like originally which was very helpful.

Again a visit worth the effort.. It is a general wander above what was a forum where supposedly Ceasar was killed. The will be a new board walk available soon to get closer the the ruins. Pay to do some research first
Amazing. Just go! Your ticket covers the Colessieum and Palatine Hill. It's just amazing to see and walk where so much history took place.

Finally!. After visiting in the past we finally visited the Foro.Purchase your ticket across from the coliseum. The ticket includes both the Foro and the coliseum. Visit the Foro first as the lines a smaller if non existent! Take your time to stroll and learn! The descriptions of the ruins really helped with understanding the city/ culture and civilization. It is wild to walk along the paths and ruins that have been there so long. It is warm(hot) and direct sun so dress appropriately with clothing and shoes. Just remember that entrance and exits are limited so you just can not enter and leave wherever you want. Main entrance by coliseum another is on side between coliseum and campi d'olio (?).Use your ticket for later in the day to head back to the coliseum without the lines!
Awesome . So much to see so little time. Plan for a least half a day. Tour guests was good but ran out of time to see the whole thing.

Loved Santa Maria Antiqua!. Another great place to wander through when you have plenty of time in Rome. Draining in the heat of summer, still worth seeing.On this trip I especially liked seeing Santa Maria Antiqua, a part of the ruins which had not been open to the public on my last visit. It's great that new areas are opened up, and that restoration and maintenance works go on continually to improve the site.

Forum and Palatine Hill were amazing. Loved visiting the Forum and Palatine Hill (really one site). A few tips though:- it can take quite a while. The site is large and has a number of small sites/museums you can spend time in. The ruins are extensive and amazing. - Almost impossible to take a bad picture, but show up early if you can, especially during the summer/high seasons to reduce the crowds. - When hot (30+ degrees), water is essential. There were no vendors inside the site that we saw. There were a few fountains if you have an empty bottle. Water would be a good idea, even when not hot. - We'd skip the audio guide next time, as the numbers didn't sync with the map, so it was cumbersome and didn't add to our experience. Also, if you rent the audio you have to leave ID, which means you have to leave by the same gate you entered, cutting down your options. - Plan to do the Coliseum right after (it is right there), unless the crowds are too big or you're too tired. - The combined ticket works for the Coliseum if you buy it and is valid for two days, so you can come back the next day.
Nice. This was certainly a nice attraction. But if you are have a limited amount of time, I would say skip the Forum and spend more time at the Colosseum which is directly across from the Forum.

Worth seeing. Interesting ruins, a must see to understand what Rome is all about. Fantastic views from the Palatine Hill. Be prepared for a long day if you plan to visit the Colosseum and then the forum

Amazing. Rome is amazing, the Roman Forum is Epic. If you are a history buff, give yourself enough time to check this out. We used the Rick Steves audio guide which gave a very good overview for our visit. Tons of photo-ops. Get there when it opens! You will get a bunch of time where its not too busy because of all the people who go to the Coliseum first. Also, there is an entrance on the North side of the site that is lesser known and so a better place to get your tickets :) Keep in mind this is totally outdoors - even more reason to get here early before the sun comes out
Hot day. Its a nice place to see and very interesting. Its definitely a must visit if your in Rome. Carry a bottle of water and wear good walking shoes.

Crazy. Walking around in the Roman Forum is an experience like no other. You feel like you're transported back in time, to another place whose scale of grandeur is many times more magnificient than our current time.
Amazing example of an ancient Roman city.. I recommend seeing this with a tour guide so that they are able to point out all the ruins. One of our favorite places to visit.
History in Center of Rome. We took a Viatour night visit to the Forum and Colosseum. A different experience at night with lights. Breathtaking and awe inspiring.

Walk amongst history. To be able to walk amongst and in the footsteps of history. To be able to touch these ancient monuments is a privilege. Buy skip the line pass on line for 2 sites at €14 is well worth it
Must see after Colosseum. Bring water and umbrella if going in the summer - very hot throughout the Roman Forum, but definitely a must see.

Must See - Be Prepared. Visited November 2015 - not too hot!
I must admit that I failed to purchase a thorough enough guide book, or book a guided tour or buy an audio tour.
Please be prepared, as it is difficult to understand otherwise.
It is, of course, a wonderful place and a must-see.

So much history. It is amazing to stand amongst so much history and it is hard to fathom how many people from our history books once walked the same area. This was the end point in our tour and I wish we spent more time here. Definitely recommend.
Viewed on colosseum and palatine Hill tour. Fascinating to see the ruins and remains of the roman forum steeped in history and full of interesting facts.
Lots to see. As part of a guided tour of the Colosseum, was taken to these forums. Would not have thought to go otherwise, very glad I did. Lots of ruins and monuments within.
Interesting!. Ruins Rule! Nice walking experience, A lot to take in, and, if I had to do it again and I would do a tour with a guide, would help to fill in the blanks!

Must Visit in Rome!. The Roman Forum is an incredible historic site. This place houses the ruins of what used to be the city-centre in ancient Roman. You will see humungous structures that will leave you awe-struck. I highly advice you to listen to an audio guide, without which you won't be able to truly grasp the significance of this magnificent place. It can get quite hot during the day, so carry a bottle of water.
A lot of history. It doesn't matter if you walk around the area and look on your own, or take a tour. This is rich in culture and worth taking a couple of hours or more to visit.

Still chuckle when my wife says "ooh this bits in ruins". Dotted around the area near the Colosseum are some of the most awe inspiring ruins of the Roman Forum.Re-live some of the ancient feelings and explore these as best you can.Get a guide or a good tour book so that you can appreciate what you are looking at. well worth the trip
Sunday morning trip. Queue to get tickets queue to get in and you can see most of it from outside. Probably good if you were on a history field trip. But not for me, the best bit for me was the exit!

Here is where it all started! The Roman Forum. The Roman Forum was one of three places we visited as part of our guided tour of the Colosseum. Without a licensed, knowledgeable guide, I may have not understood the historical or archaeological significance of the ruins. Highly recommend a guide. We were there in early July, and it was HOT! But totally worth it. Just go prepared: hat, water bottle you can refill for free at public fountains, comfy walking shoes, sunscreen, and camera. Only one restroom but clean. Non-smoking. Lots of walking!

One of the greatest wonders of the world!. We did a walk with a tour guide. It was grand. A must see! There are some tours with smartphones that show what the forum would have looked like during its peak. Very cool.

Not to be missed. There is not much of Rome that is not ancient. I would think the Roman Forum would be among the most ancient, The history of the forum is worth reading up on before you visit but visit you must!

Poor Cousin of mighty Colosseum!!!. Roman Forum along with Palatine Hill and Colosseum forms the trinity of attractions at one site and have one entry ticket applicable for them. While this place is full of ruins from the Roman era with tons of history buried inside, people are more attracted to the colosseum next door and this would get a casual look around at the best and so is the case with Palatine Hill. The scorching sun in the summer months makes this even worse and pushes the people to hurry up and end up at Colosseum.However, if you have ample time and a keen historian, please take a guided tour and your plate will be full with historic facts!!!

Great views and architecture. We stopped here as part of our Colosseum tour and weren't disappointed. It had a whole host of ruins and buildings which were rich in history. Definitely walk up the hill to see palatial hill and Romulus's house. Great views over the circus maximus.
insight to the past!. We loved this walk even though we had already walked much of Rome that day. It was interesting and despite the heat well worth the effort.

Impressive. Amazing place with lots of history and remains of what used to be a brilliant and vibrant ancient city. We did this in combination with the Colisseum and it was an awesome look into the ancient roman way of life. Loved it!

Amazing ruins, must-see desintation. Part of the big 3, in my opinion (Coliseum, Parthenon, and Forum) to visit when you are in Rome. The line to get tickets at 9am wasn't too bad - probably 1/2 hr. You can download the Rick Steves' audio tour to take in with you if you want to get some of the background or rent one of their audioguides however it appeared that much of the information was contained in their signs. Only a couple of places to get water. Very historic.

Walk in Ancient Rome!. If you go here do a little homework or bring a guide. There are depictions of what the area looked like in its time and it was spectacular. Though it is now in ruins, it still transports back in time.

The heart of ancient Rome. Adjacent to Palatine Hill and next to the Colosseum, the Roman Forum is an archaeological fest. For me, here more than anywhere else, it was possible to get a picture of life for the citizens of Rome back when it was the power base we've come to learn of.No explanation from me could could do it justice, go and experience and enjoy.
Immerse yourself in history. Absolutely fantastic, to walk the same paths as Romans did 2000 years go blows your mind. It is very exposed to the sun so take water.

Interesting, but underwhelming. After visiting the Colosseum, I found the forum less interesting, but well worth the visit. Maybe it was the 97 degree temperature that day with little shade available, but I was happy to be done with the tour.

A walk through history!. It's amazing to walk within the forum and to see and touch the places that were vibrant so many years ago! The ruins are incredible and there is so much to see! Make sure to buy the combo Roman Forum/Colosseum ticket at the Forum- the ticket line is much shorter!

Amazing!. Our tour guide was wonderful and without her, I don't think we would have gotten as much out of our walk. Spectacular ruins. Difficult to describe in a review but something that I am so glad we got to see while in Rome!
A Time from the Past. So much history. To walk where the Romans walked and to see where Julius Caesar was killed. To see how this area was buried for so many years..

Extensive and impressive. What a fabulous site! On the first Sunday of the month in the summer, you can get in for free! There are signs, but having a guide talk to you and use stories can be very helpful in getting a better sense of what you are seeing. It's a lot of walking, but to see all the different buildings and climb the steps to get the overview - it's really worth it. On hot days, look for the water fountains at the top of the hill to fill your water bottle. Although there are plenty of people selling water, why not get it for free? Don't miss the Santa Maria Antiqua basilica, the soaring ceilings and brickwork are fantastic.

Huge overload of info! Amazing place . This is quite frankly amazing.....to walk in the same places and see what people would have seen 100s of years ago.
We took the audio tour but it was somewhat confusing. I would recommend just reading all the many signs. A place to take 100s of photos, and then afterwards realise you've taken too many!

The place from which all started and enlarged gradually outward. That was a really strenous long walk among all these ruins, that used to be first in Roman Kingdom, then in Roman Republic and finally in Roman Empire, important ancient government buildings at the very center of Rome, we may say in its core. Under the scorching sun, we nevertheless slow proceeded from one architectural fragment or vestige to another, looking attentively at each one.This whole place is situated in small valley between Palatine Hill on the southeast and Capitoline Hill on the northwest.In fact, it forms a rectangular forum ( plaza) surrounded now by the ruins not only government buildings but also the different temples, museums, basilicas, antiquariums, carceres or prisons and stretched central plane used to be a market place where all Roman public life had been undertaken.And what looked like such Roman life ? Here, there were the triumphal processions and elections, then public speeches, criminal trials, gladiatorial matches and surely the commercial affairs which were carried out between the different parties.We've seen also here the intermittent archaeological excavations.The oldest structures representing the royal residences are The Regia, the Temple of Vesta ( godess of the hearth and its sacred fire), the complex of the Vestal Virgins and many more.Later in Roman Republic and Empire were built the shrines and temples honored to greatest Roman Emperors as Julius Caesar, Augustus, Constantine the Great and others.Good to see and refresh the memory of what we were taught in our school days.
Might Ruins!. Ruins spread in a very vast area. A good level of walking needed. Not for children and Aged persons. Wear a comfy pair of shoes to visit.
beautiful setting. Next to palatino hill, really lovely setting, overall view can be seen from the hill, bit like looking down on a fantastic folly, plenty to see as you walk round.
fworth a visit. what anexperience ,but what a walk ,take your hat sunscreen and water and enjoy.amazing it has lasted so long

Must vist. located adjacent to the Colosseum and accessed from the same entrance. Has the main highway used by victorious Roman Emperors upon their return from conquering the world. Various ruins to view with informative notice boards at all locations. Still has remains of broken columns strewn about the site.

Included as part of Colosseum ticket. As an option within our entry ticket to colosseum we decided to take a quick visit, however as it was 36 degrees it was a short visit for us. Good area for some pics.

Amazing sight with ancient ruins. Our tour included the forum and the colosseum, would recommend that combination for all visitors. We had a guide which helped a lot in identifying buildings, structures and all the history.
Lots of walking and lots of ruins-. This was incredible for a history buff like me, but U really need a guide to explain the significance of what your are looking at.
Good, kinda long. Really interesting especially with a guide but it's kinda long and gets boring eventually so stomach the uninteresting structures and relish the interesting ones.

Grandoise , must do in. It is amazing, takes you back to the time, it is grandpise . We cisited apduring the day time and also night time with all the lightening work it is amazing. They project the history and the reconstruction of the building on the walls which is not ot be missed.

So much architecture and truly amazing. Didn't have much time to do all the Forum as like the Colloseum it is so vast. You can buy tickets for both from a small ticket office and you get a discount for under 25's if you can prove your age. I love this about Rome!! So full of history and wonder and would like to come back in the evening next time too. Not to be missed.

Beautiful, must-see views of ancient Roman civilization. While it requires some imagination, walking through the Roman Forum is an incredible window into a very ancient past. There is a long line to get in, but the tickets allow entry to Forum and Colosseum. This can be tough to do when it's very hot out because it requires a lot of walking and little shade, but it's a must-see in Rome.
Part of Colosseum tickets and well worth the visit.. Part of Roman history and very interesting, various paths to follow and informative.Could do with more water points and seating areas

Incredible . As a ancient History nerd this site just screams of awesome! We visited with a tour company and that is the best way to do it. A visit in the afternoon is best and in the summer prepare for the heat and wear comfortable shoes!

2000 years plus of history. As part of our Collosseum trip we were taken to this area of ancient history where so many stories from our school days and films came alive. Who does not know Julius Caesar, Mark Anthony and Cleopatra to name just a few. If you only do one trip, do this one.

Wasn't my thing...at least for Rome. Honestly, there is SO much in Rome to do and we did A LOT. This was one of the last things we did and although it was amazing...we took a tour and I could have done it without the tour and just walked through. Honestly, the tour was WAY too much for me to take in and I couldn't imagine much. Like, she would say, see this pillar? It used to be a part of this type of building and would have been built during this time and the building would have been used by blah blah blah. And then she did it another 100 times. So after about four pillars, I was wore out. We walked through the area the next day and I just looked around and I enjoyed that more.

Great view of the Coloseum. Thie Roman Forum is another amazing attraction. Good to get a guided tour to give you great details. Also, as you go through the forum, great photo opportunities of the coloseum. Our favorite pics are taken from the forum.

A meeting place. The Roman Forum was used as a meeting place for the people of ancient Rome. There was an indoor section that was used in the winter and an outdoor part used in the nicer weather. People from all walks of life were welcome to come and speak or listen to others. As we walked along we may have been walking along the same path as Julius or Augustus Caesar. Amazing history!

Another must see when in Rome. One cannot miss seeing the Forum when visiting Rome. While very little is left, with a good guide and some illustrations it is easy to imagine what it once was. Standing amoung the ruins it is a bit over whelming to comprehend the extent and magnitude of the history that has occured over the millennia.

Amazing ruins, full of history. The Roman Forum is located next to the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. One ticket will allow you access to all three sites, student discounts are available. There is no barrier between the Forum and the Hill so make sure you explore both fully. We really enjoyed strolling around and discovering what these sites had to offer. There are signs with descriptions dotted around so you can figure out what's what. However a guide may be a more pleasant/easier option. Interesting to see what remains of the ancient world and to soak up the history.

Interesting place take your time to take it in!. The Roman Forum is definitely one of the places you should see if you are in Rome. A lot of people seemed to skip through it really fast and I can only assume they either didn't care for it or didn't bother to get the audio guide. My friends and I spent a good 5 hours listening to all the points on the audio guide and taking in all the history in the Forum and the Hill (about 3 hours in the Forum and 2 on the Hill). Take food and water with you especially if it is hot and you have kids - the Roman Forum and the Paletine Hill are an 'all in one' site and while there are 2-3 public water fountains, the only place to buy food, or cold drinks are vending machines, one set at the Forum and one up on Paletine Hill. By the end of the day both sets were sold out of water or had stopped working and were eating people's money. Beware the machines that say that they don't give cash. This means they don't give change and I lost 5 euro to one of these as I didn't know that meant no change when it had a change compartment on the panel! One of my friends had a coffee from the machine and thought it was pretty good. A lot of the Forum and Hill area was looted back in the Renaissance and later, so don't expect perfectly preserved buildings in all their original glory, but it still remains a fascinating place to visit to get a feeling for how the center of Rome operated in its heyday.

Treasure trove of history. The Forum was the site of many different activities, from religious temples and shrines, to courts and government offices. Be sure to get a guide who can explain what it all was and how it functioned.
Pleased that we made the time.... The expanse and scale of the place was surprising and brought a higher understanding of the grandeur that was ancient Rome.
Magical. Don't miss this. A step back in time. Really interesting. The guide we had was amazing. We learned so many things we never knew. We also did Palatine Hill as part of the same tour. Excellent

Fascinating. I found this place fascinating. It is just a big open space with lots of ruins but they are the coolest ruins. They run from rocks that are barely recognizable as runs to huge columns that stood outside of Caesar's home. There is no where to get a drink so brinf water with you on hot days. Plan to spend 2-3 hours here and definitely make the trek up Palantine Hill for the best view. This is very close to the Colosseum.

My favourite Roman Site. Nothing! Absolutely nothing in Rome matches the richness, the wow factor of the Roman forum. The heart of the ancient city that ruled the Mediterranean world is an absolute must see! Make sure you buy a ticket online and print at home to avoid long lines, especially in summer. The ticket is combined with a visit to the palatine hill, the home of the Roman republican aristocracy and later the sight of the imperial palace. I recommend to first climb and explore the palatine and then slowly descend into the forum. There are a number of Terraces with spectacular views of the entire forum and colosseum. Take some lovely pics and descend in the forum, walk the Via Sacra and explore the many remains of temples and churches. The latest site is the Santa Maria Antiqua, an imperial atrium which later became one of he first Christian churches. Beautifully restored wth some amazing early frescoes. At the foot of the hill it is connected with the emperor's ramp leading to the palace on the palatine. Fascinating!Hot, Exclusive tip: If you want to avoid the massive lines under the hot Roman sun, use the palatine hill entrance on Via di San Gregorio, which runs between the colosseum and the circus maximus. There's barely any people entering from that side. Be smart!Been to the forum 4 times and keep going back. It's very special. Give yourself tome to enjoy it and let your imagination run wild. Have fun!
History at your feet. As you walk through this place you are walking through history. Caesar,brutus, the Vestal Virgins, Paul. so many many events happened right here

A "Must Visit" if yiou can stand the heat. A remarkable glimpse of life as it was lived 2k years ago. It's hard to comprehend the full story in one visit, several are needed followed by book research. Good idea is to use a guide or to tag on along with one. Look out for the sharks at the payment kiosk, they will try and fiddle your change, I watched it happen to Chinese tourists in front of me.
Roman forum . What a great piece of history, I have been several times and both times were just as good. Would recommend having a tour guide. Brilliant place to visit

Transports you back in time.. The Roman Forum is free on the first Sunday in the month. This is a real must see, you can get such a sense of time and history. There is so much that is still standing almost intact. If you're really lucky you might get to see an opera performed there.

Time flies. Everybody should take a stroll through history and I guess this is the only place in a majour city. I recommend visiting the Fori, monumemtal site where most of the action took place right before the emperors and the senate eyes and then go to Ostia Antica for a step back into history, where the commercial part of the city will make you wonder if we have really gone that far. Shops, the anfitheatre and the harbour well worth the visit. If in Rome through the summer try a night tour at the Fori. Astonishing!

Centre of the Roman Empire. The Forum was the centre of the Roman Empire. Use your imagination and you can see Caesar strolling among the citizens. The Forum is surrounded by ancient buildings. It's in the centre of Rome, easy to find.
Another amazing sight.. As was most of our Euro tour, this sight was just amazing. The history on display is so awesome it almost makes you forget how hot it is.

Light and sound show - forum of Cesar - a must do!!. Don't miss it!! The same company has 2 light and sound shows - the forum if Augustus and the forum if Cesar. We saw the latter at the Forum. Because the forum is so dilapidated, it's hard to get much out of a day time walking tour, even with a tour/ guide. The video and sound effects really brought everything to life. In the words of our 11 year old son "the best non-food experience of our Italy trip".

For those who love history... An absolute must!. For my second trip to Rome I really wanted to come back here. In my first trip, we took a guided tour that rushed us through the Roman Forums in about half an hour and completely skipped the Palatine Hill. I knew there was so much we missed so I was determine to come back and really see the sites and I was not disappointed. The Forum is just a ways from the Colosseum and the ticket will allow you to see both the Forum and Palatine Hill. I suggest you arrive early, bring good shoes, water, and enjoy! You can easily spend 3-4 hours here if you want to see all the sights. The Forum itself is quite large and some of the ruins tower above you. It's quite something to see!

Heart of the City. Standing amidst the ruins it's impossible to appreciate how large the temples and structures would have lorded overhead. This area bore witness to men and events straight out of the greatest moments of history. Unsure why the rostrum does not get more attention but a great place to visit.
Ancient history here. It's just amazing! So much history, wonderful architecture - true ancient atmosphere. Simply unbelievable place to be!

Roman Forum. This place is connected to Palatine Hill, and I would recommend walking up there while visiting Roman Forum.Roman Forum is a place I think requires a guide of some form. We went there without any guide, and didn't get anything out of it other than the sight itself. You should also know that there is virtually no shadow at all here, and it gets very hot in the summer.

Ceaser Shuffle!. You can spend a whole day seeing this amazing site. In fact I recommend it. Bring lunch as there is no way to get out and come back in; once you leave, you're done. However, there are spots to get fresh water from the roman aquanauts (these are now pipes but you feel Roman when you drink from these seeming holes in the rock). If you are visiting in the summer, make sure you are dressed appropriately. Finally, get tickets to see this, and the Colosseum together. Make it the true Roman experience.

Really enjoyable and interesting. There are a range of buildings here from 8th century BC to 6th century AD, all in various states of ruin. This is what remains of the Roman government buildings and central Roman life. You get a ticket for Roman Forum, Palatine Hill, and the Colosseum.

Too Much to Take In. There is so much history in and around the Forum, you have to walk slowly to even start to appreciate the place. It is incredible what remains of buildings that were erected 1,700 and more years ago, by some of the best builders the world has ever known.

Not that exciting. We went in the heat of the summer so it was hard to enjoy when you're so hot all you can think about is being in the AC. This was probably my least favorite tour of everything I did in Rome. Still more impressive than anything we have in Kansas though haha.
A lot of history. The Roman Forum is so interesting because of all the history in that area. There are a lot of ruins and background -best done with a tour.

My travel partner want to walk in the steps of the Roman greats. Simply astounding – a must see for visitors to RomeI hate standing in line so we bought the Rome Rass which includes two major destinations, direct entry with no standing in line and free public transit for three days.As a crowd hater I'd say that the Forum wasn't too crowded in mid May. Our Rome pass allowed us dedicated line for quick entry to the site.There are continuous restorations happening and you can see how they have worked to maintain this piece of living history.We arrived at first opening on a cloudy day and we were admitted immediately. If you arrive early before the worst of the crowds you can see entire site in about two to four hours depending on your interest, tolerance and footwear. My travel partner wanted to walk in the steps of the Roman greats and this we certainly did. I tried to listen to some podcasts guides while we got our bearings. I always find the tone of these guides to be unbearable. Another unforgettable site to visit in Rome. Remember to bring drinks and a snack as nothing is available within the site.

Amazing. A full day is not enough to soak in this place. History on top of history. A tour guide or guide book is needed to understand everything in the forum. you simply cannot understand everything without one.

Historic and a great experience. We were part of a group, keep in mind this is a combo ticket so we were able to see the Colosseum as part of this. There is a lot of history here and you can see many of the famous landmarks and buildings. We were lucky enough to have a good guide who was able to point out the major points of interest.

History brought to life. it's amazing to see ruins around the city but this is something else. this is a city that is still standing ( well, kind of)- i recommend a tour guide, there are no signs describing anything- bring water bottle- no restrooms inside- no stores inside- they have drinking fountains where you can fill up your bottle- bring a few snacks- in summer: bring a hat, sunscreen, umbrella ( for shade), wear running shoes, hand fan, be prepared to stand in the sun for long periods of time ( in a tour group), you will sweat a lot in the heat! ( we went in June)- you don't need to get a tour guide but then you won't really understand what each building is or what the city looked it etc. - this is a must see if you like history, or want to see real ruins in the middle of the modern day city, it's amazing. you will never see something like this in the states.
A lot of History. Walking through here is like walking through time. With a little imagination you could see what it was like back then.
A must in Rome. Part of historical Rome so a must if you have the time, won't take long and easy to find walking near Colosseum.

Very interesting sight. Really enjoyed wandering around the Roman Forum. Try to get on a good tour. Mine was a bit lackluster, but I heard others were really engaging. It was extremely hot, but they have water fountains all over.

HISTORIC SITE. This was part of our 3 hour guide of the colosseum and surrounding areas .. very enjoyable listening to the history and imagining what it used to be like in those days. you MUST have water with you as it is extremely hot in the summer months. Well worth a visit

Ruins that seem to go on for miles!. The sheer scale of this place is what makes it spectacular. That, combined with those tall bushy-topped trees that only seem to be in Rome, make this place quintessentially Roman. A definite highlight.
2,000 Years Ago Among a Modern City. It is all excellent walking through the Roman Forum. The majesty, the history and the feel are simply amazing. We will return to take in the culture again.

A must. So much history!!! A must when in rome. Tips: know where the water fountains are and stay hydrated especially during the summer months. You will walk alot and will go uphill and down. Girls don't wear heels! Can't believe we saw some girls in heels the pavement is rocky uneven and can be slippery make sure you have a good pair of walking or running shoes on. Don't pay for a tour. Download a free audio tour online. We spent about 2 hours learning all sorts of increadible history and facts about the Roman Empire without spending a cent and felt like we got alot more than what we would have got if we paid for a guided tour. Most of the negative reviews tend to be about the worthlessness of the tours so don't go that route. Take your time. There is so much increadible history you will want to use your imagination and spend the time recreating what the forum felt like. It truly is a remarkable and unique space unlike anything in the world.

Super Cool - Make Sure you go UP for the Amazing Views!. Absoslutely surprised by this one. We got there and thought, "Yay, another arch..." And were presented with the option of walking down (not a bad idea) or uphill (tough call in the sweltering July heat wave) but going up was the best choice by far - not only did we get to see some amazing views, but the path down took us through everything the lower path would. Astounding all around. And the watering spots are phenomenal - fresh, clean, cold and abundant. Just bring a water bottle or two and refill at will.
do it.. just do it. but download an audio tour podcast. really amazing to see these ruins but also to understand what they were and how important the entire area was/is.

A very interesting day in Rome. The Roman forum was something we didn't expect to see in Rome as you hardly ever think of it before going to Rome. At the counter for buying the tickets to get into the Colosseum we found out we could buy tickets that included both attractions for 12 Euro per person. We took it, and after the Colosseum visit we again queued up in the sun to get into the forum. The attraction is full of history and its a must go in Rome. If you are interested in history and everything Roman related; this is the perfect place. Plus its close to the Colosseum. A must go when visiting Rome.
Another don't miss in Rome!. Be sure to see the Forum along with the Colosseum and Palentine Hill. You won't be disappointed. It was part of our tour. Amazing history, not too crowded.
Close to colosseum. Can be visited via metro. Take guided tour so you get everything out of the historic site. You can feel the old Rome here!
Do not Miss!. The most ancient place you can be in Rome! Way before Renaissance and everything else! But don't forget to go with a guide - audio or a book - otherwise you won't enjoy it.

Tour was LONG and hot. We enjoyed the interesting history and architecture in the Roman Forum, but our tour was SUPER long and VERY hot. Be prepared for the uneven large stone roads that make it difficult (but not impossible) to use a stroller.

Skip the line tickets, good walking shoes and a hat are very much recommended.. Visited in July 2016. It was very hot.
Skip the line tickets, good walking shoes and a hat are very much recommended.
Visit right after the Colluseum and before Palatine Hill. Do Palatine Hill last as your admission covers all 3. Palatine is the least interesting and requires the most walking.

A must for Rome. Use a guide (of any kind). We used a guidebook that had a walking tour of the Forum. You can also pay guides to take you through, but the walking tour was great for us. It definitely helps to have a little more background info. The sites are marked, but you may not even know where to look for them if you are just wandering on your own. Can get very hot, so bring your water. A great thing to do the same day you visit the Colosseum.

Highlight of Rome . Absolutely loved this place, didn't have any expectations before we went, so glad we didn't skip it! If you want to know all about the history of Rome this is the place for you, incredibly interesting. We didn't have a tour, just read all the signs but we overheard some tours which seemed to only have 2/3 people on them. If you can get one of these you'll get the best from the Forum
Wow. Just bang smack in the middle of Rome while this amazing city goes about its hectic business lies the Roman Forum. Amazing history. Just wander for hours. Our camera did not stop flashing.

Like Everything in Rome...WOW. Again, this place is an amazing look into history. With imagination and information, you can appreciate the sheer feat of construction undertaken by the Romans. The area is large and requires at least half a day to look around. A good pair of walking shoes is a must as is some wet weather gear if rain is forecast as there are few places to escape the elements. In summer, make sure you have some water.
Beautiful ruins. Lovely preserved roman ruins, entrance right next to the Colosseum. We went in the morning when it opened and enjoyed the forum.

Roman Forum / Foro Romano / Palatino / Palatine Hill . You get access with the ticket to the Colosseum (€12 for an adult or €14 if you book online). Don't know if you can buy a ticket just for this.It's outside the Colosseum, to the north-west, approx' 1 minute walk if you exit at the right spot. Just past the Arco di Constantino. It's a large collection of a variety of statues, arches, gardens, pillars, relics, etc.There were vending machines within a small air conditioned building but these were nearly empty early/mid afternoon. Don't remember seeing any water taps so go prepared.Lots of steep inclines, steep steps, loosely cobbles paving so go in flat, sturdy shoes or trainers.Downside - there's very little shade.

full of history. ancient ruins that give an insight into old rome. audio guide available but not overly clear where this could be found. would have been good to know what we were looking at although their are sign posts of information
Next to the Collosseum. You can walk through the remain of what used to be the shopping center for the Romans. It is just across from the Collosseum.

Roman beauty. This place is beautiful. There is so much to see, the views are splendid. It's located next to the Colosseum so worth doing on the same day. Defiantly do the Colosseum first as it gets extremely busy early (booking in advance will save you a lot of time). The Roman Forum is a must see. Where good walking shoes, you'll regret anything like sandals. Wheelchairs will find this environment challenging.

great. The Roman Forum was referred to as the marketplace by the citizens of ancient Rome. It is an impressive – if rather confusing – sprawl of ruins, the Roman Forum was ancient Rome's showpiece centre, a grandiose district of temples, basilicas and vibrant public spaces. It fell into disrepair after the fall of the Roman Empire and was later used as pasture land. In front of the arch are the remains of the Rostrum , an elaborate podium where Shakespeare had Mark Antony make his famous 'Friends, Romans, countrymen…' speech.

Everyday Life - Then!. So many of the sights in Rome commemorate special occasions, for example, Constantine's Arch, and others were for special events, for example, the Colosseum. But to get something of a insight into everyday life in Ancient Rome, gaze into the Forum and use your imagination. It's easy to find, but in July, it's hot!

Yes, do it!. This site is so amazing, it should be a must on every traveler's list. It's hot in the summer, so be prepared. Tons of walking, so wear comfortable shoes. Your ticket into the coliseum gets you in here too.

Awe inspiring must see . This was our favorite part of our Colosseum/Palatine Hill tour and one of our top sights we have seen around the world. The true heart of Ancient Roman civilization, absolutely amazing to stand in the middle of it and imagine all of the men walking around, the Pagan temples converted to churches that were able to survive...absolutely incredible to just take everything in. Definitely at the top of my bucket list and so happy I crossed it off.I highly recommend booking a tour as there is no signage anywhere to tell you what is what - tour guides are informative and maximize the experience. Bring a LOT of water and get ready to climb that hill, it gets really hot and there's little shade. An absolute must see when you're in Rome. You cannot skip it!

amazing. be careful of the crowds and the heat in the summer; there's really very little cover. get tickets online and print them out before you get in line- it will make the experience faster. I would recommend a guided tour- I wish we had done one.
Very impressive. That was really nice place to seeing. I definitely recommend this place to visit for adults and children.

Nice park with amazing history . Me and my wife went here in June and loved it. I like it better than the colloseum even if that is the big attraction. Be aware that it can be like a frying pan especially during the summer, bring water and some cover for the sun. Don't miss this place!

The centre of an empire!. You need a whole day to explore this huge archaeological site. Very well organised by Italian archaeologists and the only thing I would add is maybe a few more signs to some key points of the Forum. For a history buff a visit here is more important than a visit to the Vatican. If you visit in July or August you need a hat! You get to walk among ruins exposed out in the sun and there are very few spots that you can find yourself in the shade. It's a must! This is the true heart of Rome.
Wonderful Atmosphere!. It's so easy to imagine the to-Ings and fro-Ings of everyday life. Loved watching the many cats who live here!

Get a knowledgeable Guide. We visited the area, which is rich with attractions and ended up at the Roman Forman. You can't go wrong just making a visit but with the right guide you will see history come alive.

Tons of history here . The Roman Forum is where the government of Rome was . The civilization is noticeable here . Ancient buildings , temples, homes, water , etc. I'd suggest learning a little (many some YouTube videos!$ before you go so it is not overwhelming .

Amazing History. We got there early to avoid the crowds and it worked! No queues at the ticket box to talk about and enjoyed meandering around with a reasonable amount of people before the heat of the day kicked in. By 11am the tour groups were piling in en-mass, which made it un enjoyable and time to move on.
Of course. You can't go to Rome without a visit here. Recommend a knowledgeable guide unless you are an historian,

Always impressed. I love the glory of Rome, and the forum is where its at.Next time I will walk thru it, I ran out of time this round, but it always impressive. I recommend you buy the buy to see how it looked back in its day

A must see. It is easily possible to add the Roman Forum to the day you tour the Coliseum and Palatine Hill. Exploring all 3 in a group gives you a very good picture of the daily life in Ancient Rome and the mastery of the builders so long ago. Really remarkable. Best with a guide, but totally doable on your own with a good guidebook.
Wow!. don't miss this on your trip. it's huge if you take in the fortress museum too. well preserved and the museum provides audio ipad for the tour

History doesn't get much better than this. If you like history this place is a must do. The ticket for this was bought as a package with the Colosseum from the ticket office between the two, don't buy from the many dodgy touts.

Unmissable. If you do a bit of forward planning when preparing for your visit to Rome, the results can be exceptionally good. Nowhere is this more the case than with the Foro Romano. The whole site is open air but if you have not done the homework you will simply see a pile of ruins near the Colosseum.Now here is a useful tip if you are pressed for time and want to get the best of the Foro Roman without having to pay the entrance. Go up to the Campidoglio (this is the square on Capitoline hill right behind the Vittoriano "wedding cake" Monument") then walk down the far corner on the left. You will come out very very close to the enormous Septimus Severus arch, and will have an opportunity for wonderful photos.

Poor audioguide. The location is amazing especially for history fans but unfortunately the audioguide is very confusing.No guided tour is available.If you go make sure you read before about the forum history and take a bottle of water since there is no place where you can buy water just a public fountain with drinking water.
impressive . it is one of my favorite places in rome. if you're standing on the ancient road in the forum you might feel the spirit of this place...

Good old Rome at it's best. Take a guided tour. It is the most amazing place in Rome. Loved the historic importance and atmosphere in the ruins of the old Forum Romanum. We had no problem imagining how impressive and busy it must have been 2,000 years ago.

Could spend the whole day here!. Very interesting ruins with so much too see, and great photo opportunities, I could have spent the whole day here! It is just a little walk from the Colosseum, it was included as part of our red bus hop on hop of tickets when we purchased the Colosseum ticket.

Awesome but needs some knowledge to fully appreciate!. Downtown ancient Rome!No really, Foro Romano (Roman Forum) is essentially the downtown of the capital that used to ruled over the vast Roman Empire. Sadly, downtown ancient Rome was left to deteriorate and even faced deliberate destruction as people used to dismantle for free building materials. Fortunately, some remains, possibly because they are harder to move.However, to the untrained eyes without pre-trip studying, Foro Romano is nothing more than random columns and rocks...Yet if you read only for a bit or even just take the time to read the few explanation blurbs and look up Google Maps on the spot, you will be awed that you are standing so close to so much history! How amazing is it to pass by what remains of the prison that once held Saints Peter and Paul? How crazy is to casually walk through the remains of the HQ of Roman Curia, once the world's most powerful political entity? Or perhaps it's nothing compared to the remnant of the grand basilica* that would make St. Peter's Basilica look like a parish church, right?To many people, the Roman Forum is merely the necessary path to reach the iconic Colosseum, but I highly suggest you do a brief reading of Roman history or a quick search on Google on the spot as you walk through here because I think this is the definitive proof that makes Rome the Eternal City and it would be a shame to walk through these historically significant sites assuming that they are nothing more than rocks.*"Basilica" used to mean large assembly hall but it's now more commonly used as a designation of church buildings*The scope of this review covers both the free and ticketed portions of the Roman Forum---PAID PART OF THE ROMAN FORUMSome parts particularly the more complete sections are ticketed. The admission cost is €12 for a combined admission to access the Colosseum and Palatine Hill for 48 hours. Buying the ticket here first is actually the best way to bypass the long wait at the Colosseum!---tl;dr version:1) Remnant of ancient Rome's downtown2) Remains of many historically significant sites2) Needs some knowledge or Google search to fully appreciate
Great. wonderful to walk and observe this ancient section of Rome. this is a history fans dream. nice to take your time and study each section.

Full of history . Lots of ruins and pillars with history knowledge info boards. If you are interested of history this is a must visit site in Rome. Tickets cost 12€ or 7,50€ if you are 18-24 years olds EU citizen and with that same ticket you can visit also palatine hill & colosseum. Wear suitable shoes!

Enjoyed it more than the Colosseum.. Buy your combo ticket (Colosseum, Roman Forum, Palantine Hill) at the Palantine Hill entrance down the street from the Colosseum- much shorter line. This was amazing too much to take in in a quick trip. The grounds are massive. With only two exits/entrances, you can spend almost as much time finding your way out as you spent touring the sights. Drop a pin with your phone at the entrance you use. It will save your tired feet when you're ready to go. Take a map when you enter. It's helpful. Bring lots of water and a few snacks. You'll want to take breaks in the shade when you find it. There's an indoor museum within an ancient church. Go in. It's a nice air conditioned break from the heat, and when you climb to the top observation deck, you have an amazing view of the entire complex. I think I enjoyed the Roman Forum and Palantine Hill more than the Colosseum.

Take a walk in history. When I learned that I was headed to Rome I quickly made a list of the places I had to see and the Roman Forum never made it on that list, but by fate I still wound up there and what a great experience.The forum is huge, I had no idea what I was going to be seeing, I’m sort of sad that I didn’t do research and take a walking tour to learn the history of it. I did happen about an English walking tour and kind of just mingled in for a minute and learned some great things but then they went on their way and I was still wrapped up in looking around.I went into the Forum around 11am and didn’t come out till almost 3pm, so much history to look at, make time to explore the Forum, maybe even do a walking tour to learn about it, next time I am in town that’s what I am going to do.There are public water fountains throughout the Forum that has ice cold water running through it, which plenty of people were taking advantage of , it was a warm day when we visited the Forum.When in Rome, take a few hours out of your day and go walk in history and see the past, you don’t be disappointed.

A lot of Roman history. From the Colosseum, its just a short walk to the Roman Forum and we got entry by using our Roma Pass. The Roman Forum is an incredible area of Roman history right in the middle of Rome. There are some areas accessible to wheelchairs and prams but not everywhere.
Motherdaughter2016. Amazing place so much history gardens were beautiful can't believe the structures are still in such good conditions well worth a look

Amazing bit of history in central Rome.... We returned to the Forum for the third time and were amazed to find there was now a charge to walk through the area. We also had difficulty finding the entranceway. It is a very special place and we didn't mind the charge....we only wish we knew and could find the entrance. There seemed to be only one entry and exit...not a good idea in emergencies!!!! But don't miss it as it is amazing,
Really worth a look!. Not great with a pram/stroller (obviously). We walked around the outside and this was still pretty spectacular.
Ruins as far as you can see!. We got there at opening and there was no line, we walked around and enjoyed the area for an hour before the crowds arrived.

So. Much History Here. There is so much to see here. The Arch of Titus, the Temple to the Vestals, the place where Juius Caesar was cremated, it goes on and on. This was the center of Roman civic life and illuminates how we feel about democracy. It is cluttered with all different kinds of shrines, temples and tributes. There is no adequate way to describe everything. Just go, take your lunch, get a good guide or guide book and explore explore explore. You could easily spend an afternoon or day if you are into the history.

View from the Palatine Hill is terrific. The Forum is one of my favorite places in the world but the signage is pitiful. They give you a small map – the numbers on the signs go higher than the numbers on the map and the audio guide numbers are different still. There are very few English signs. This is a magnificent historical site for any student of Rome that is crying for some interpretive archeology and signage or perhaps an app. As a result, get the audio guide which was a Samsung GS4 phone on our visit. Do go up to the top of the Palatine hill to see the gardens and the great view over the Forum below.

A Step Back in Time. Allow plenty of time to walk around this collection of ruins. The area is big enough to absorb summer crowds, without the lines and the jostling you'll find at the Colosseum or the Vatican Museum.

Plan a full day, research prior!. Young kids, or people ignorant to the incredible history that comprises the Roman Forum, might look at this and think, "Big whoop! Old stuff!" It is overwhelming what can be experienced here in the Forum. Think, before the world knew of Jesus / Christianity, temples were built to Roman gods, say for example Castor and Pollux. Yeah, a temple is still there from the 5th century BC!!! The spring of Juturna mixes mythology with real battles. The war with Jerusalem is commemorated with an arch completed in 82 AD, the Arch of Titus. Scenes of the sack of Jerusalem are depicted, this mammoth arch is copied over and over again all over the world. These are just a few of the amazing ruins in the Forum. Do a little research, and really enjoy this incredible place!

A Funny Thing Happened On The Way To The Forum... Pickpockets!!!. My wife and I are seasoned world travelers and were driving by car throughout Italy during a month-long adventure. Happily, we had seen much of Rome years ago before it became a total money grab.Regrettably, like the Colosseum and the Palatine Hill, we found the Forum to be another Roman ruin of great historic significance that has been turned into an amusement park experience... complete with hucksters, scammers, tour guides, gypsy pickpockets, long lines of tourists and a $58 entrance fee for two. We were happy to avoid the madness and simply used a telephoto lens for our photo memories.

An important part of Rome. This is another tourist attraction, but rightfully so. It is an important part of Roman history. Maybe because it was soon hot, but I just wanted to get to the Colesseum and got out of the sun, that I was not that interested in the stone structures,even though the guide has many historical facts.

Enjoyed it more than expected. Very near the Colosseum & Palatine Hill . I was surprised how rapidly time passed as we walked around & absorbed the beauty & grandeur. Our Colosseum tour also gave entrance to the Forum after a quick
Palatine walk. To think how much of the modern world came from thoughts & ideas from the Forum...

Private tour guide helped us re-create this. We had a private tour guide, and she really knew her stuff and brought books with re-creations to help us and our 8 year old envision what this site used to look like. The history was nice to hear from her. I don't think we would have liked it as much without the guide. It is a rather sunny spot, so bring something to keep the sun off of you.

A real insight in to Ancient Rome. A walk back in history - let your imagination run wild.Although much of this can be viewed (for free) from walking around the outskirts of the Roman Forum from the public highway I would highly recommend going in and seeing this up close and personal. Besides entry to it is included in your tickets for the Colosseum.For me the Roman Forum captured the true beauty of Rome and every night I went back to see it light up at night. Top Tip - go round the back of Capitoline Hill for the best views of the Roman Forum, especially in the evening.
Spectacular, just do it. Make the time to see this when you come to Rome. It will be a highlight of your trip. Stunning examples of ancient architecture and splendour.
Heart of the Roman Empire. As the heart of the ancient Roman Empire, the Roman Forum is a must for anyone interested in history.

Must-see in Rome. We enjoyed wandering the Forum on our own one day and then revisiting it with our guide, Alessio, by viewing it from above, on the hill. There are fascinating layers of history here, and even when it is fairly crowded, you are outside and able to wander at your own pace to photograph and examine. (It's nothing like being squeezed into the Sistine Chapel.)

An Amazing Part of Roman History. The Roman Forum is incredibly special given its importance to the politics and religion of Rome. There was an indescribable feeling that came over me knowing that I was walking the same steps as important figures in the history of Western civilization. I highly recommend getting a tour guide or an audio tour for your visit. There is just too much to see and you run the risk of missing out on a lot of fascinating history.

Rushed but worth it. We had to fit in the Forum on our last morning so we rushed it a bit but we really didn't want to miss it. A Colosseum ticket also covers the Forum but we were lucky enough to get in for free as it was the 1st Sunday of the month (a good planning tip!).Be warned, I can't tell you how many people in the queue had to start again as they hadn't picked up a ticket at the bottom. Everyone has to report to the ticket booth for a ticket, so you can't send one person to get them. You all have to go.Despite the queue being long, we only had to queue for about 20 minutes in the end.There are signs letting you know which routes are which and which are easy/medium (Forum) or hard (Palantine Hill). We didn't do the latter due to lack of time. I was wearing flip flops and was fine walking round.We've all seen the ruins on to but it's much larger in reality. The temple is amazing and dominates the site. There are plenty of info boards. They have also provided areas of shade which were very welcome in a 35 degree heat. If doing the Hill too, do it first for a great photo over the whole site, then head down to do the Forum especially as the exit is at the edge of the Forum part.

Get a guide!. This is a very big area with lots to see but without a good guide, it's hard to know what you are looking at. A good guide brings the whole thing to life. There are plenty of guides around, most of them will do the forum, the hill and the Colosseum for about E30-35 per person.
Excellent tour.. Once again City Tours stepped up to the plate and delivered another good tour. Beautiful views from the top.

Roma History. Take a tour so you can know what was what before and after. This is where each victory is being parade down the street. Not many standing structure is left through time, but it's good to know the history behind it.
A walk through Ruins. This is a must ..... ruins to the left of you, ruins to he right. An architectural feast of ionic columns, bricked walls and the view is awesome.

Important tourist attraction but not fun for children.. Great history but not much fun for children. Lot of ruins and spread out. Can be tiring. It is next to Colleseum and no restaurants . gets hot in summer when sun beats down.
Seeing Ancient Rome is a Must. When visiting Rome, don't miss out on its rich ancient history. The forum is one of the sites on the top of the list!

Mindblowing insight into Ancient Rome!. Incredible information! Really made the everyday Roman's life come alive. It was very hot the day we went and although there are places inside to get water, don't forget to take some as well! I took my 11 year old son and he loved it!
a must see. The Roman Forum is historical and a must see if in Rome. It is easy to walk around in but depending on the time you are there, it can be quite hot like in the summer months.

Walk on the same ground as Julius Caesar and Mark Anthony!. I knew about the Colosseum but I admit I didn't really know what to expect of the Roman Forum. Wow, wow, wow. It is stupendous! Phenomenal! Fantastic! This is history at its best -- the center of the greatest city in the greatest Empire in human history. The best way to appreciate this incredible site is with a good professional tour guide such as Walks of Italy. Then come back early in the morning the next day and gaze upon the Forum without all the tourists. If it's summertime, bring water!

Still excavating. Roman ruins are still being excavated. I don't know why this surprised me, but it did. Everywhere we walked we saw evidence that Archeologists are still attempting to discover what this early world was like.
Make sure you have a guide. A guide will make it a better experience so you know what you are seeing. There are great views of the ruins as well as the Colloseum in the background.

Amazing . So much to see and learn, therefore I would definitely recommend a knowledgeable guide. Biggest key and biggest bronze door was a great story. We went in summer, needed water, hat, good walking shoes and a pair of sunnies. Remember to take all! Try to use bathrooms before going.

Stand right next to where Julius Caesar was cremated!. For any lover of history, to be able to stand at the same place where Mark Antony eulogized Julius Caesar, where Caesar was cremated by the crowds, and where Augustus built a temple around his ashes - is just incredible! They stood *right there* and so did I!I didn't realize how much access you actually have to the site, thinking it was only something you could walk around from behind gates and fences. Sure you can do that for free, but with a ticket you get to walk throughout the Forum and come face-to-face with the intact Senate House, the ruins of the Temple of Caesar, and so many other amazing structures. If you're an archaeology and history nut like me, consider taking a guided tour (spring for the House of Augustus tour!) and then coming back the next day on your own just to wander around. The guided tours are great, but they cover so much that you don't get time to explore and take it all in. Side note: to see where Caesar was actually assassinated, go to the cat sanctuary about 20 minutes walk from the Forum. It's built around the ruins of the Theater of Pompey (temporary senate house at the time), and there's a pine tree growing at the spot where he was stabbed to death!

True essence of Ancient Rome. The Forum is rightly considered one of the must see sights of Rome, and needs a good two or three hours to explore. There seems to be an important new artefact around every corner, and despite the heat (early July in Rome is not designed for those from a cool climate) there was plenty to keep us happy, with shade and free water readily available. The new exhibition of medieval frescoes is also excellent.
Incredible. It is basically a graveyard for Anicent Rome. Walked around here for 4 hours and took everything in. Can get some incredible photos

Amazing Roman remains. This place is awesome, you could easily spend few hours just looking at the remains and strolling around. The structures and sculptures are astonishing, just makes you wonder how long it took them to build all this... and there is even more

Walk through the real old Rome. You can see much of the Forum from the outside, looking down, but it doesn't compare to wandering through it because you experience so much more intimacy in relating to the various buildings, ruins and quirky spaces. We didn't bother with a guide or audio-guide and didn't find that limited our enjoyment of the experience. We suggest that you experience the Palatine Hill as part of your visit.

Must go. I love history. And it was very interesting. Need good pair of shoes as it is a lot of walking. Get one of those books which has now and then pictures so you can exactly see how amazingly everything was built .
Prepare your trip. there is so much to see you need to prepare your trip to ensure you see everything! take a hat and water - although there are waterfountains everywhere!

Walk in the steps of the Ancient Romans. Walking around the ancient site on a hot July day, reading and learning about this old civilisation, or was it civil? Seeing the relics and monuments and photographing them at will was a most memorable afternoon. When I visit next time I will do deeper into this amazing old story.

Much more to see than we expected. The queue across from the colosseum was so long that we almost gave up. We walked up the side on the main road to find some refreshments and found a side entrance with a tiny queue.It was well worth going in. We actually enjoyed it more than the colesseum. There was so much to see. Make sure you go up to the top part too. We almost didn't and would have missed so much. The views were amazing and lots more to see.

Not to be missed!. You cannot appreciate the amount of structures remaining in the Roman Forum until you are standing in the midst of it all. Only in the last few centuries has it all been excavated for us to enjoy. This is a walk right down from Palatine Hill via steps, and we did this on a tour in the daytime that was a combo with the Colosseum and Palatine Hill through Walks of Italy. Original statues and buildings are there. All three places were close together and not to be missed when you are in Rome. This is another place that is probably best done with a guide or you really won't appreciate who the buildings belonged to or what their purpose was in ancient times. The guides have wonderful stories that you can imagine being right in the moment. Wonderful photo opportunities of Roman ruins. I believe the Forum is closed at night, so if you do a combo tour, it has to be in the daytime or you'll just get a distant view, which is not the same experience at all. No cover up required for any of these since they are not religious sites. Our teenager found these interesting as well.

Worth the price of a guide. We had a guide take us through the Colosseum and ancient Rome, which was very helpful but limited the amount of time we had with specific points of interest. We only spent a few hours doing both, which was enough to soak in the experience before lunch and more adventures the rest of the day. Definitely a must see.

" Worth a visit " . Went thru the Roman forum while visiting the paletine hill and then the Roman Colosseum , great place to visit you can take a bunch of great pictures plus all the history behind all this broken buildings.

Must see with a guide.. This is an expansive area of ruins and there is layers of history that without a guide explaining it to you will leave you feeling a bit lost. There are not many signs explaining different areas so this is where a guide is helpful. Wear comfortable shoes.

Incredible. Buy the combined ticket for the Coliseum and palantine hill. It's cheapConsidering the experience. Being a little historically interested it's amazing. You can walk around on your own or book a tour. I recommend booking a tour as there aren't many information signs.

A must . If you purchase your ticket for the coliseum you can add the Grand Forum onto your ticket as its a short walk from there. It can get very busy but worth a visit. Would of liked to go early evening to get the sunset photos but it was so busy and so much to see in Rome in two days!!

fabulous (in the literal sense). Rome is incredible and the Roman Forum is just another reason why. Would agree with another reviewer though that it was difficult to know what we were looking at sometimes.The history is almost unfathomable too much to appreciate in and hour and a half. That said this would only make me want to go again and I have already drawn books out of my local library to learn. It's simply incredible and has an aura about it it that is truly awesome. Go there and see it.

You dont need to go in to see this! . We just went up to the top of Campidoglio and either side gives an amazing view right over the whole roman forum! It was too hot to walk through ruins with no shade. This way we had a great view and it didnt cost a cent.

Great site but admissions could be better. There is no question that the Forum is a must on a visit to Rome and it has been reviewed so many times. I just want to comment on getting into the Forum. We purchased tickets online to skip the queue...but the queue for the prepaid tickets was longer than the line to purchase tickets at the gate. It seemed that everyone picking up tickets had issues of some sort. Even though we entered early in the day there were no site maps available. Our tickets said they were good for two days, so we did a quick walk through the Forum on the way to the Colosseum thinking that we would return for a more relaxed and thorough exploration later. As soon as we got outside the gate we realized that we could not get back in with those tickets. It was our fault for not having been more careful reading the fine print, but really, what is the point of a two day ticket that can only be used for one admission?
History Buffs. part of full day tour , a walking history tour, educational , peaceful, marvelling at how these structures were built & still standing

What Rome is about. A visit here is a must but research is essentail or choose a good guide to take your tarty round these wonderful ruins.
A young member of my party who has very little appreciation of Roman history did remark "Rome will be OK when it's finished! So a short history lesson is in order before such a visit !

Best place to visit. I was more interested in some of the other landmarks in Rome but this was my favourite. It can take as long as you like to look around and the photo ops are endless. Would certainly revisit.

Piece of Rome history. We found it difficult to know what we were looking at. It would be good to have images of what the buildings actually looked like. If you are into history then you will probably enjoy it.

A walk with history. Like the Colossuem, the Roman Forum is a must. The history is overwhelming. We didn't do a tour, just purchased admission tickets. I would recommend getting a tour or study up before hand. I feel like I missed some things that a guide could have pointed out. Again, purchase your tickets early, long lines. Can be very hot so I recommend going early in the morning.
Lovely walk. Few steps from Colosseum. Lovely for a sunset walk. Extremely romantic for couples. Stunning reminiscences of the past times. A must see!

Great historical site.. We visited using our Roma pass so did not have to queue. There is no water and very little shade inside so take water and a hat with you. Very few places to sit and rest. But great places to stare in awe and wonder. Immense site and some good labelling in Italian and English which help you understand what happened there. There is also a great walk around the site at a slightly higher level which is free and is well worth it for the bird's eye view. Everything is immense and wonderful.

A place to make you think.. There are some fascinating things to see. Loved the Temple of Vesta as I've heard about it many times. It's hot, so don't forget flat shoes with grip ( the cobbles can be slippery ), some sunblock and a hat, a big bottle of water and take lots of time. There are some fascinating plaques, audio guides if that's your thing, and if you like photography you'll love it.

Massive & Incredible. When I went to Colosseum, I signed up for a guided tour for Colosseum and the forum. Due to my lack of research, I almost missed this one, but thankfully, I was able to see this incredible landmark. It's unbelievable that everything was under the roof. My tour guide was very humourous he made the tour more interesting. At the sight, there were drinking water fountains. People collected water in their bottles to drink it.
