My brother and I were fine with drinking the water, but if you are sensitive, stick to spring water. Also, expect lots of walking.

Wonderfully preserved!. You get entrance to the forum with your collosseum ticket (and vice versa!) and the two sites are a 5 minute walk apart. It's amazing to walk around here with the modern city built up around it - how lucky we are that the remaining ruins were never knocked and built over. When we came 15 years ago the house of the vestal virgins were closed, so glad to see that it is open again - my favourite part of the forum. Plenty of places to sit and rest, have lunch, fill up bottles, toilets etc so you could spend hours in here - we did! Soak up the history of the place and get a sense of what ancient Rome must have really looked like.
Very interesting. Great way to several different eras of history in one place. Easy walk from the coliseum and the kids found it interesting as well

Ruins of Ancient Rome. This sprawling site gives you a glimpse back in time at the political, social, and economic dealings of the Romans. Bring a good guide book or take a tour with a company like the Roman Guy because there aren't a lot of markers to explain what you are looking at and it can be difficult to contextualize.
An old Etruscan burial ground. A large area of ruins close to the Colosseum. Ancient Rome's showpiece dating back to the 7th. century.

Evocative Ruins of the Centre of Ancient Rome. Walked around the ruins of the Roman Forum on the same day as doing the Colosseum and Palatine Hill.The ruins of the Forum are for the most part in a worse state than the other two, but with a bit of imagination it is possible to reconstruct the ancient Forum that was the heart of Rome under the republic and early emperors.There are exceptions, the two monumental arches erected by Titus and Septimus Severus are in good condition, and the columns of the portico of the Temple of Saturn, as well as the Temple of Antoninus and Faustina are all in good condition, as is the Curia (meeting place of the Senate), although that is mostly a reconstruction.Facilities and cover are also somewhat lacking, so make sure you have water with you on a hot day, but it is well worth a visit!
Must see. It's a must see tourist spot. Bring an audio guide or a map since the signs are not much. The view from the terraces of Campidoglio was stunning.
Where Rome began. History nerds like me - this is a must! Of course - where the Roman Republic started. Must see where government buildings and temples co-existed.

It's beautiful but a tough walk to visit in the heat. Absolutely beautiful and I enjoyed every moment, just note that there is a lot of walking and some difficult stairs in places. The crowds are dispersed so it's not too bad. I found one covered vending machine with soft drinks and snacks that had a line about 5 people deep. Be prepared and bring a few bottles of water and snacks and you should be fine. I strongly suggest a guide so you understand what's in front of you.
Interesting piece of history!. We did a walking tour of the colosseum and forum. It was very interesting with amazing bits of history! Beautiful ruins!

Incredible ruins!. A must-see, even if you have a short time in Rome. The admission price of 12 Euro includes the Colosseum, Palatine Hill, and the Roman Forum. All three can be managed in one day. There is access to nearly every ruin at the Forum. There are not many signs explaining what each building or monument used to be, so it is helpful to have data, a map, or take a guided tour. It is incredible to believe that some of these ruins are nearly 2000 years old!.

You have to do it.. It's absolutely jaw-dropping. Pictures simply don't do it justice. The scale of the ruins is most impressive. Fascinating stuff. If you can do just one thing in Rome, make it this.
As Amazing as the Coliseun. Spent 90 minutes walking and listening. Again I used the Rick Steves audio guide and thought it did a great job. It is like walking through history.

Part of an unmissable Roman experience.. The Forum was part of a tour that included the Colosseum and the Palatine Hill. You can walk in the footsteps of those ancient Roman senators and emperors. You cannot really go to Rome without seeing these ancient sites - it is part of the Roman experience.

History Revisited. Lack of time prevented us from fully exploring the Forum. However much of it is visible from a walk around its sides and we were able to identify much of it from our excellent guide book. It is amazing that so much of it tat was built BC still remains. Well worth a more in depth second visit.
Walk around the ancient sites. Nice area for walking around the still well preserved ancient sites. Try and buy one of the many books on sale with the pictures of past and present forum

Always something new to see!. An amazing adventure as you walk the street of Julius Caesar! I like that they have a degree of organization, but you still feel the rawness of ancient Rome...no Disney here, this is the real thing!

back in the past. A must see when in Rome. We had a guided tour with City Wonders who do really seem the best talking to other people. You really get to see old Rome properly and is a lovely walk around taking it all in.
Historic place!. What a wonderful visit. We really like walking the forum. Wear comfortable shoes as you will walk quite a lot! It was breathtaking at times.

The Forum. The Forum is the area in Rome from where all business, government and society operated. Remains of the original structures are abound. With some imagination you can picture yourself 2,000 years ago. In advance you should read up about the site to get the maximum benefit.
Unbelievable. It is amazing to walk the same streets Romans did 2000 years ago. The size and scale is hard to imagine without being there to see it.
You need a good guide. You need a good guide or guide book to explain the intricacies of all there was to see. Lots of temples to see and learn about the vestal virgins...

Much to see. The forum Romano is a must when going to Rome.Som notes I wish someone told me before entering:1) the ticket sais that it is valid for 48hours, BUT if you read the tiny letters on the bottom, you will see that you just have one entry. So although the ticket is valid for 48 hours you can just enter one time!2) The ticket gives you entry to forum romano, palatino and the museum at palatino. To get the most of the ticket:- Bring a backpac with water and food. Then you can go around the forum before lunsh, then eat lunsh in the palatino garden, the go around the garden and visit the museum after lunsh. Do not plan anything else the day you visit forum romano.3) to wear: a hat for sun protection, loose pants in light material or a loose, long dress, a top that covers your sholders, a backpac and comfy shoes. (this is guidelines for a comfy visit)
Must see!. Incredible to be surrounded by so much History. Make sure to have a tour guide to know what you are looking at.

Love this place. The history of this place is amazing, ancient ruins and magnificent arches and temples everywhere, it takes your breath away to be stood where so much history has taken place, it's truly amazing. Just walk around and soak it all in with the awesome colosseum in the backdrop.. Don't go to Rome without walking around here..

Wonderful visit. The Forum is just incredible- be ready to walk around a lot. I suggest doing a guided tour, we used Through Eternity and they were incredible. There is a huge amount of history you experience when walking through these ruins- it is incredible the amount that was excavted here. I highly suggest going through the forum!

Fascinating Tour of Ancient Rome. Definitely worth visiting this site as part of a tour as you will miss so much otherwise. It was very hot so bring water, a sun hat and sunglasses and plan to do a lot of walking.

walk amongst history. The forum like the coloseum had so little information boards which is to its detriment, maybe it's to encourage you to go on one of those guided tours i dont know. So not fully knowing which ruin you're looking at and maybe how it used to look i think makes you miss a dynamic. But that aside its a great location bang in the centre of Rome. The fact that some columns are still standing thousands of years later blows my mind. It's quite a large area and if like us you walked everywhere in Rome it gets quite tiring but definitely get to the view point and look out over Rome and the ruins below they are stunning.
Beautiful. Had a lovely wander around. Discounted entry as an EU citizen under 26 which was a bonus. I would definitely recommend this to people of all ages, it was very interesting.
Nice experience . Have been in Rome 5 days and have enjoyed my tour. Problem always is the bathroom situation. Nonetheless less it's amazing to stand here...

Amazing, well worth visiting. The forum is just one of so many beautiful ruins left in Rome. It is easy to get to on the metro and walking distance from the Collusseum. The size of the ruins is breathtaking. Well worth a walk through.

Heart of the Roman Empire. This area, the heart of the Roman Empire represents the glory that has since faded. Though there isn't much to see, it is easily the most important historic sight in the city and a must visit place to learn more about the great civilization.
the grounds.. This is a great place to visit and to see all the sights. To find out the history behind the grounds.

Amazing. This was amazing. To think that these people could have built all of this and it's still standing. The dirt picture is where the alter was that ceasur was cremated. But the locals say that is wrong, actual spot was 300 meters away.

I really enjoyed this tour!. So educational to learn about this area in Rome and to see the ruins was very interesting! This was one of my favorite tours. The buildings that are left have such detailed architecture. Recommend this tour

Not for me . As the title, unlike the colosseum most of the sites to see here are pretty busted up and I just didn't get what the great attraction was. There are a few things that are still in a viewable state (like the church with the huge bronze doors - with a working lock from about the 6th century!). I started to think that half of it was just left there to make an attraction out of it. Like a broken small piece of pilar (about 8 feet in length) left with grass growing around it that had been cornered off with no explanation. If you are short of time don't worry about skipping, there is far more to see in Rome that is more worthy of your time.
Beautiful walk. If you want to get a feel of what being a Roman was like, this is the place! Never thought it could be this well preserved. Totally worth a visit
Lots to see! Must see the church!. Lots to see but not a lot of info on around except for when you go to the church which was restored with the amazing wall art inside. Definitely a must see!

Do it.. Although one can look over the forum for free from the roads around it and get a great overview, it is absolutely worth paying the 14 euros (also gets you into Paletine Hill, same entrance and Colloseum) to wander around. Just seeing Julius Caesar's burial place is special enough.If you visit before October 2016 be sure to see the spectacular Sta Maria Antica. No one tells you about it at the entrance but having read about it we were lucky enough to view this extraordinary excavation. It is included in your ticket and closes this October for some reason.Be aware that there are no maps at all and it's very hard to find things like toilets, with staff giving completely wrong directions..we had to ask tour guides (not ours) where things were as Staff extremely unhelpful. See if you can download a detailed map before going to avoid wasting time like we did. Otherwise...Enjoy!
A wonder. One of the wonders of the ancient world, its conservation is on-going on a large scale. Book it along with a ticket to the Colosseum.

Not as good as some of the other structures. A huge ground area with structures having the foram and other important buildings of those times. However not worth the 12 euro which is taken for the entry.
Love the history behind. Went there on the guided tour. Love the history behind it. If you are not on a guided tour, there are some information boards that tells you a little of the history.

Vatican Tour Company Colosseum / Forum / Palatine Hill Tour. Eugene was well qualified and did not seem to mind all of our questions. To get a tour of the Colosseo, along with the Palatine Hill and Forum was wonderful. Eugene was full of history to help us. We really liked him.I was skeptical arranging all of this remotely and spending so much money. Vatican Tour Company was definitely worth it. Your communication is excellent.
Beautiful. Enter from the Palatine hill entrance and you can skip the line. Read up on it and don't miss the 1700 year old bronze doors.
Roman Forum. Outstanding archilogical site. A must when visiting Rome and right by the Colosseum. Great to explore, take water, it can get very hot with little shade

More fun for the family than anticipated.. You think you will go to teach your kids a history lesson and then you lost in the grandeur of the place. Go. Just go. Walk and talk. Learn a few things but mostly just soak in the scene.
Walking Historic Rome. Getting tickets before hand is probably recommended. We lined up for about 15 min to get our tickets. Kids are free.
Roman history personified. Imagine the Roman elite perusing items for sale from all over the world, cavorting and carousing among the upper echelon, enjoying the finest foods and drink!

Take a walk through history.. My mum and I both loved the forum. It's incredible to be in the exact place where so many things I studied in history class happened. We did the Rick Steves audio guide which was very informative, (he warns you at the beginning it can get confusing and he was right). Definitely leave time in your visit to spend a few hours here. There are no in and out privileges with your ticket, and the Palatine Hill and the Forum are considered the same area - so make sure you leave enough time to do both. We thought because the ticket was valid for two days we could go out for lunch and come back. It is not so, (make sure to read the fine print!)
If short on time you can pass. Although you have nice views this is a 30 minute side trip. Gives some perspective of the area and how the victory marches may have looked.

Amazing place. If you want a real history lesson spend some time at the Roman Forum, but go prepared for little shade and full sun. You can hire a guide or an audio guide, but for the latter you'll need to show ID. There are many buildings in the Forum and it covers a big area. Go to the top of the belvedere for a fantastic view over the area and the colosseum. You'll probably have learned about the Romans in school, but a visit to the Forum will bring all that to life. Excellent place.

Do your homework or book a tour. This is one of those HIGHLY historical and relevant places for Western civilization (and some middle east as well) but do not go without doing your homework...you need to use your imagination a lot and there are dozen of things to be...like knowing that you are walking were Julius Cesar and other Roman walked....if you can, book a tour.
A Must See in Rome. Structures remain from the time of the Romans. Highly interesting and with a guide you get the full benefit of just how impressive the Forum is.
A Walk Through Time. It is sad to see what remains of the ancient Roman Forum. But it is also amazing to walk through an area that is 2,000 years old.

Amazing to see but recommend a tour. Really interesting to walk around the remains of buildings in the Forum but definitely recommend getting a tour/audio guide. Me and my girlfriend didn't do this and feel it would've had a huge impact on our visit.

Roman vocation. We took night excursion and it was unbeliveble experience.Although,if u are very much in historical ditails,u may feel thatit was not enough time...As for me,I simply enjoyed the moment and of course the biggest impression was in the church,where the guide showed 3d paintings on the walls,so u could really get the picture how it was many years ago...

Amazing place. Very old city and save quiet good,
go to there after Colosseum (include the same ticket).
take your time there and go around.
free water and toilets also nice

Really interesting. Super interesting. Wide area which is full of antichue to discover. We didnt have audio guidance, what would habe made experience More interestin (we had thight schedule) have to visit place in rome!

Imagine Ancient Rome. Imagine walking in the footsteps of some of history's most well-known Romans: Julius Caesar, Marc Antony, Octavian (Augustus), Cicero, and so on. Walking through the Roman Forum you get a sense of how great the Empire was. A site not to be missed.

Not much signage. I think to enjoy this tour you really would need to buy a guide or download one beforehand. Otherwise you will literally walk around a lot of old rocks and have absolutely no idea what it is you are looking at. There is no point going in for free if you cant read it. Also, there is little shade and no benches so don't go during the hottest time of the day!

Interesting. The forum gives a good insight into the roman way of life although difficult at times to imagine what was originally in place as so little original building remains.. An audio guide helps ID is needed to hire an audio guide.

Knowing some basic histories will make trip fruitful. If you buy the ticket to Colosseum, you can visit roman forum and palatine hill as they are in one package. I won't said is a waste of time but if you know nothing about the stories behind, it will be hard for you which happen to me. I compared this to Pompeii that I visited and hence, I feel here is harder for you to imagine how roman city looks like in the past. There are some building or places which are still visible. Weather is pretty hot during the day, so apply sunblock/bring umbrella/water(if you like me who want to protect my skin).

Be prepared to walk a lot! We left the coliseum and headed directly to the Forum. My husband is completely enthralled . This time period is my husbands absolute favorite. We we to the Forum immediately following the 19,000+ steps we mastered at the coliseum. We had a great time.
Spectacular roman remains at the Roman Forum. If you love your old rocks, this roman ruin will please you no end. Absolutely brilliant to what has been uncovered and how the city was 2000 years ago.

Spectacular history. The ancient Roman ruins are impressive and its fascinating to imagine the buildings in their prime. We had a tour guide that took us around and talked through the history for a few hours. It was amazing but i was disappointed we didn't alott more time because we only saw a fraction of the forum in that time. I really recommended the tour guide though.
Must See but. take a tour- it will add so much understanding as you walk the streets of the Roman Forum. Chiara with Journey to Italy was incredible!

One of the highlights of Rome. This is where the Roman empire started and it's incredible to see. You don't want to miss it. It's right next to the Colosseum. One of the most fascinating things I saw during a 2-week trip to Italy. It's best to use some sort of audio guide or personal guide. I used Rick Steve's audio guide and also listened in on a tour. It really helps put it all in perspective.

The Reopened Santa Maria Nova makes it worth a revisit!. We have been to Rome three times, and each time we hit the Forum, but this time, with a private guide and the opening of the church and restoration of its frescoes, it was really like a new experience. Go early before it gets hot and crowded!

Excellent. History on show. How could you not be impressed by this city of a long gone past. The amazing architecture of a bygone era is mind blowing, how did they achieve this without the modern help of the machinery of today?

Amazing . It was so cool to see history right before your eyes. There is lots of walking and we used the Rick Steves guide we downloaded, which I would recommend some kind of walking tour. Expect to spend much of your day here

Fascinating!. The Roman Forum has a fascinating historical background. I got goosebumps just thinking that Julius Caesar had walked on that very ground. Please do not visit without a written or an audio guide. Without knowing the rich history of each structure, everything will just look like ruins and you will feel lost.

Excellent To visit. I did this as part of a Colosseum Tour which was 3 1/2 hours. It is a long tour and a lot of walking but worth it. Make sure you have a bottle of water as its hot in summer and many open areas.

Feel ancient Rome. By paying about 12 EUR per adults (children are free)you can visit both Closseum and Roman forum . when you walk around ruined ancient Roman buildings you feel that you are in 2000 years ago.I think it is better to allocate one full day to visit both Closseum and roman Forum.

Crossroads of the world!. This was part of our package. We were pretty tired when our guide ended the tour, but we stayed on for about an hour on our own. There is a lot more to see than what our guide had time for. We particularly enjoyed the recently opened 1st Century AD church which contained some very nice mosaics and frescos.As others have mentioned, there is a lot of good, free information on the web.

Loads to Take In. I went here after visiting the Coliseum and I did not realize how HUGE it was. I was very thankful for the many people selling water as it took about 3 hours to get though most of it. I was there that long and still did not see the entire thing. I would highly recommend doing this when you had a lot of time. There was a few smaller museum type buildings inside and everything had a sign with it's history close by.

Better than Colosseo. First thing to know is your ticket is good for 2 attractions: Colosseo, Foro Romano e Palatin (last 2 together).Don't rush, you have you have 2 days to visit (1 per day if you like).If you want to visit the Colosseo first, buy your ticket at the Foro Romano e Palatin entrance (between the forums and the coliseum) you will save a lot of time!Next decision is with or without audioguides, I would recommend the following:-Foro Romano: Yes-Palatin: No-Colosseo: NoWe had the audioguide only for the Colosseo and would have done it the other way around.Impressive and beautiful, you can spend the entire day reading and walking through the ruins. You can relax on top of the hill as there is a beautiful park (Giardani Farnese)Plus, you get a great view from Roma and the Colosseo (from Palatin).Pack a lunch though, because the only thing you'll eat is a bag of chips or peanuts (vending machines).Oh, and bring a bottle of water, there are plenty of fountains on-site to refill (sunny and 36 degrees celsius when we visited).Enjoy!
Amazing ruins. Did this as part of Colosseum tour. Great history and amazing ruins. It was so hot out that we were worn out by the end.

A must see in Rome. In complement with the Coliseum, visit the Roman Forum. You will not regret it. You will see how the Roman city was organized, will understand the Roman life.The ruins are in very good conditions. In addition, it is a very good promenade.The Roman Forum + The Coliseum + walk around, consider 1 day, and start early. But avoid the restaurant nearby. In case it is very hot, take some water, you can fill in your bottles in the fountains inside the Coliseum.

History right in front of you. My family used a free Rick Steves audiotour on our iphones to navigate the Forum. There are signs by most structures that describe their function in Roman times. They are in English also. There is signage to help stay oriented but some of the structures are difficult to identify. There is so much history here. You really get the feeling of ancient Rome. There is little cover so be sure to wear a hat and sun screen in the summer. There is some construction and renovation work so the exit seems to change from time-to-time. You might ask when you enter, where the exit is because there are not a lot of staff further into the Forum. There are a few bathrooms but no food service or vending so plan accordingly.

Must do. Walking through these architectural fragments slowly and thoughtfully can give a sense of life from so long ago. Probably best done with a guide to help decipher one area from the next. (I've reviewed our tour separately).

Amazing historical site. Visited the forum as part of a walking tour to the colosseum and palatine hill. Would definitely recommend this as we got all the history and more from our very informative guide Jaber. Just an amazing place the history, the architecture a great insight to life in those times

The piece de resistance. For most, Rome is defined by the Colosseum, but I would actually rate this sprawling site, places at which are still under the archeologists' gaze, as the high-light of my visit there. Fortunately, this is not a either/or choice, as these iconic sites are co-located.

Watch for pick pockets. This was part of our guided tour after the Colosseum. Our guide warned us to watch our things and told us pick pockets pose as tourists with a map and things. We had stopped at the spring fountain for water and when we were listening to our English speaking guide a young man walked into our group and asked what language is this in English. Red flag for me! He seemed to be alone, had a map and half empty water bottle, he would act interested and touch his phone like he was taking a photo but it was not on camera mode. He walked with us for the rest of our tour and we all were aware of him and kept an eye on him. When one of our friends went to take a photo with both hands on her camera in a small space where Cesar was burned he got next to her. Another friend saw what was happening and moved in, she put her hand on our friends purse and moved her away from him. She said he gave her the evil eye. We're pretty sure that the other young lady in the area was working with him, but he got nothing from us. The Forum has alot of interesting sites to see, just be aware of others near you. The pick pockets do this every day there, it's their job!

Excellent. This was the final part of Viator's "Skip the lines" tour of the Colosseum and the Roman Forum. Worth the price and skipping the lines. Wonderful lesson in history. Make sure you have plenty of water as it is a 3 hour tour and especially on hot days.
A bucket list wonder!. A must see when in Rome. All you need is a little imagination and a little knowledge to bring this ruin alive.

Night tour with guide and illumination. We had the good fortune to be guided through at night by Gabriel in a small group. This was clearly something to recommend.In 75 mins we had insights into history with cameos, the multiple layers of ruins and internal illumination of the frescos and tiling in the different buildings which really gives you great look at what the building were like.The other advantage was avoiding a 40+Celsius day in Rome - the night was relatively cool.Recommended and would repeat.

Open air museum! Love it. I just love the fact, that you can walk around there... sit there and watch, eat your snack.. go up to the hill and see the view. Just amazing place! All what you can see, the history, the architecture - or what is left of it.. It once must have been incredible!Will come again - for the third time!

A must for visit!. I have been to Rome for several times, but I never thought of paying extra money for the sites. This time I did and I must say it's one of the best experiences I have ever had. I planned to spend the afternoon around the Colosseum area and I saw this package deal of tickets for Colosseum and an extra site. I decided to go for it as thinking that it's a budget save. The site was amazing. We visited the place in April time, and the weather was absolutely perfect during the afternoon - not too hot and there was plenty of sunshine. The weather got chilly only after 6 p.m., which was around the time when the site was closing. As a photography lover, I was crazy taking photos around the site and enjoying the historical learning. Palantine Hill was just on a hill next to Roman Forum. I heard from some people that the choice of visiting palantine Hill only is better than Roman Forum as it could allow them to have a full view of Roman Forum anyway. I am not sure whether I would have changed my mind if I had chosen Palantine Hill instead, but at least I know the actual walking experience in Roman Forum was absolutely worth it. I spent 1 hour there until the site was closed. If you are a historian or photography lover, I would recommend at least 2 hours of visit at this place.

To avoid people get there early!. I brought my ticket online and arrived on opening time and was the first person on the site. It's not as busy as the colosseum but again the best time to go is early as there is no crowds and you have plenty of time to walk around and get great photos with out people getting in the way. There is a little indoor museum/chapel towards the end of the site.. I highly recommend checking it out as there is some amazing ancient paintings on the walls and creepy music that really makes you feel like your in the moment. I arrived at around 8am for the opening time of 8:30am.. To be honest I probably could have rocked up at 8:15-8:20 as I was the only one with the online ticket, everyone else was queuing to buy one. Hope this helps

Ruins and sun. No need to elaborate, this is the Forum. Not much shade though, so it can be tasking on a hot day. Very little signage, so bring a book if you want to know what is around you. It has a combined entrance with the palatino (that is nice and shady with great photo ops on the forum and the Colosseum).
A must.... This place is magical. You may not feel it after a few hours of looking at ruins and walking around but this is somewhere really unique. Take comfy shoes and some water with you.

My Favourite Site In Rome. These ruins really are breath taking and we spent hours here and at the pantheon. The grounds were equally beautiful and from higher points there were fantastic views of Rome. There is also a brilliant unspoilt view of the Colosseum and we were able to take photographs without anyone around. I actually enjoyed this site more than the colosseum itself.

History in the open air. Go early and get your tickets for the colosseum from here. Take lots of water and shade. There are water fountains dotted around the forum but you need a few bottles to keep going. V hot in July. Superb views of the city and colosseum. Beware the gladiators offering photos they will ask you to pay. Worth the fun so long as u are prepared to pay.
Amazing historical monument. Amazing historical monument - a must see when in Rome. We didnt do a guided tour, rather just walked around oursleves and took our time.

Historical site. What a shame. All the marble stolen. We had a guide with a degree in history and Roman archeology. Extremely good with the history of the forum, the buildings, streets etc. I closed my eyes and could visualize the Forum on its glory days. What an experience. If in Rome please go to see the Forum.

The Forum. Visit this with a tour guide and do it with the combo ticket for the Colosseum, the Forum and Palatine Hill.
Without the tour guide you will not be able to appreciate what you are seeing
Like going back in time. I got a real feeling of ghosts here and the sense of history all around me. Definitely worth your time. A guided tour is nice for the information it provides.
The Forum. This is a great attraction but you need a great deal of imagination and good shoes for walking. Well worth doing.

Very nice site. Very nice but to visit it you need at least 2 or 3hours !! I highly recommend to bring food and water! There is only one part where you can buy food and drink.
It's a beautiful and amazing historic place!

Fantastic visit. Absolutely fabulous. Well worth a visit. It was a very hot day and we visited the Colosseum as well but found it rather a lot to do in the heat in one day. Wish we had used the audio guide.
Must take a guide or audio tour. Good if you take a guide or hire audio tour. If you don't there is limited explainations of what you are looking at.

Only let down by an emergency phone call from home. So much to see you do need a guide ours was amazing, but there is so much to see you would probably need to make a return visit just to make sure you hadn't missed anything, it was an archeological phenomenon that takes your breath away, leaving you hungry for an explore, which City Tours allowed us to do, we were hungry so didn't, but would have loved to otherwise. definitely worth a revisit.
Need imagination. The overall grounds are worth the visit, but the forum itself needs a lot of imagination to see what it once was.
Great history. We used the walking tour guide and got to see this, Palatine Hill, and the colloseum. avoided lines and got a great history lesson
Amazing. Amazing,but not in hot weather....if you would like to see everything you must spend a half day there but it worth it!

Another classic, must see site. A fascinating place. I recommend having some sort of audio tour or guide as there is so much fascinating history to imagine. Parts were closed when we were there, so it was a bit confusing as to how to get in and out. The walking is very uneven, so older travelers should be careful.

Great for history lovers. This used to be free but is now a combined ticket with the Coliseum so wort the visit if you're seeing the Coliseum anyway. Bigger than expected, lots of interesting ruins but would not say it is suitable for most kids as they could get bored if they do not understand the significance. Advisable to take enough water with you (in a cool bag in the warm weather) as they charge 2 euro inside or 1 euro 60 at the vending machine.

Don't miss it. But you need a guide. This ancient place is so interesting. To appreciate it, understand it, you need a guide. We had Danielle from Maximus Tours, who did a great job. She is highly recommended. Ask for her.But you can download for free Rick Steve's audio guide and that will do the job too.This site is a must! Don't forget to see the Arch of Titus. And a guide for this is a must.

very interesting but better with a guide. been twice. once with Rick Steves Audio tour and once with a guide. 2nd time was so much better. too much history and information , you do have to use your imagination some to fullly apppreciate.
Beautiful History. Easy access across the street from the Colosseum. You need a ticket which can be purchased when you get your Colosseum entrance.
Interesting specially for for history lovers. It is interestibg to visit and take a walk in there trying to imagine how people used to live thier daily life there and how every thing was

If only we could go back in time. Great to walk around with kids and explore, go early to avoid the heat. There are many water fountains to refill bottles. Kids are free so only 12 euro per adult with Coliseum included, exceptional value for money.
Ancient Rome. Make sure to go with a guide and, to fully appreciate this incredible site, you should read about it before you go. Good hiking shoes are suggested.

You've got to see this too!. You'll need some kind of audio tour to understand what you are seeing. It's pretty cool imagining the different people like Julius Caesar walking along these paths. Great architecture.
Incredible. A testament to the Roman empire, it is incredible to think that some of their buildings are still standing almost 3000 years later. Wear comfy shoes!

Heart of Ancient Rome. The Forum and the Colosseum are the heart of ancient Rome and are not to be missed. Just to see the scale of Roman architecture is to sense the grandeur of this historic culture.

Must do with the Colosseum and palatine hill. You have to do it with the colosseum and the palatine hill. I strongly advise a guide. If summer be sure you have sunscreen and a hat; water if you are a thirsty person otherwise you'll pay the opportunists which will wait for you to get thirsty.

Do this. Buy your ticket (12 euro each) at the entry booth just southeast of the big white Victor Emmanuel monument on the south side of Via dei Fori Imperiali, specifically where it intersects with Largo Corrado Ricci. The lines are shorter. I suggest allotting about three hours to see the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill, as they are essentially within the same perimeter. Be warned--this is a vigorous activity--there are completely uneven street surfaces and very steep stairs, many of them. Do yourself a favor and forego the expensive audio handset tour--the handset is a pain to use and we just gave up on ours. They also make you leave an ID for the handsets so that you must return them to that exact spot later on, which is very inconvenient because the complex is so large and has other exits you may prefer. So stick to the map they give you which is pretty good. The signs inside will explain most things anyway, also making the audio handset redundant.

Much better than the colosseum. Very fascinating, there are a lot more remains in comparison to the Colosseum which made it much more interesting - i would recommend a tour guide to take you round as you are told facts which were really engaging about the history of each building. I would definitely recommend visiting!

On your checklist !. If you arrive in Rome, is an objective which should not be missed, preferably visited in off season, it is less crowded and cooler :). During the low season, no need to book tickets online!!!

Amazing. Take a guided tour. It takes some of the time off the trip and the information if you get a good guide is amazing. We paid for a private tour which included underground access to Colleseum and our guide was a history, art and archeology teacher at Uni! Very informative

It's HUGE!. Much like Palatine Hill, we didn't really know what this was other than a few ruins! The site is huge and very interesting. What blew my mind the most was that at the time of the Romans, the street level would have been 4m lower! The engineering on the buildings is amazing. There are toilets here and there is a vending machine tucked into a little room where you can buy drinks and snacks - this was very welcome as we needed Water (there isn't any shade really).We spent just over 3 hours doing the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum.You can use your tickets for the Colosseum to gain entry.

Ancient Rome at it's glorious best. You cannot go to Rome without visiting the Roman Forum. And go here FIRST before going to the Colosseum. Buy your tickets for both at this location and avoid the long queues once you get to the Colosseum.

Fabulous.. This is a real life time machine. It basically spans the life of the Roman empire.
Almost a thousand years. I would have loved to seen it at it's zenith.
What history. Go on a cool day if you can or early in the morning.
We went the last week in October and it was still 22C.

Hugely historic site. It's a bigger place than I expected and there's a lot to see. There's little organisation when you're in there so it's worth having a guide book etc with you. Most of the buildings are in ruins but seeing them first hand is worth the visit. It was quite busy but there's plenty of space to move around - you probably need a few hours to wander through the Forum.

A Must :). We visited the Roman Forum as out ticket was joined with the entrance of the Colosseum :) We truly enjoyed the visit as this attraction adds to the historical and ancient spirit of Rome and to miss it would be a shame.

old and interesting.. Ruins are located right next to the Colosseum and we found very interesting. A fairly large area and takes a while to look over the entire ruins including a steep walk to the lookout.Would recommend a visit. We did not have a guide however ruins are well documented as you walk around.

A must see for an Ancient Roman experience!. One cannot visit Rome without seeing the Roman Forum, the whole area is fascinating and really takes you back to the days when the city would have been bustling and Roman civilization was at its peak! It can take a whole day to really cover the area in its entirety though, so plan ahead for when you take the day out for this.
Great. This tour was informative. Enjoyed hearing all the history behind it. We had a tour group and I would recommend that for anyone visiting.
Interesting!. I especially enjoyed the hike on Palatine Hill. First Sunday of the month is FREE, which was a great bonus. However, doing that and the Colosseum in a day can be a long one of ruins.

A must visit. Of the attractions we visited on our flying visit to Rome, this was by far the most interesting. There is much to see and there is much more room and less people than you'll find at other places of interest

Steeped in history. Still being excavated after all these years, but on an over view it's not hard to see why. Sprawling ruin with visable organisation, a feet of engineering that is mind blowing when you consider the tools at hand, no doubt about skill, but how? Lovely to stroll around but bear in mind there is little or no shelter from the weather, totally exposed to the sun. We never tire of seeing this wonderful site. Not easily accessed for physically challenged.
Well appinnted. Well appointed place with lost of interesting views of the Roman architecture. Sadly one cannot go down and wander along the ruins.
Thrilling!. The walk from the Colosseum to the Forum is awe-inspiring. We were even able to watch archeologists working on an active site.

Must see.. I liked this walk among the ruins the best. Seeing where Romans ruled and governed and lived was amazing. Felt connected to history while viewing the funeral pyre where Ceasar was put to rest after his assassination. The capital building was a model for all modern capital buildings. The Vestal Virgin home was quite a story.
A must to see, with the Coliseum. Ancient Rome at it's best. Need good walking shoes. Take your time, and have a good guide book at your side.
Night visit of the Caesar Forum. Beautiful experience, a modern way of enjoying heritage. With lights, stories, photos and videos they make you go back in the past, 2000 years ago.
Great!. Go really early to avoid any queues and the crowds inside, and buy tickets in advance! Really interesting, worth getting an audioguide
Ancient remain. A Place to visit. Foro Romano has the remains from the roman days. Its free entry. Its after the colosseo

So many ruins to see. In a city that contains so much history and so many ruins, here are some more to see. These are best viewed from atop Palatine Hill. Down below are the various ruins of ancient government buildings and temples in the center of Rome. It is hard to imagine that all of this low-lying territory was, at one time, wetlands. All of it was drained in the seventh century BC.

Wish there was more. It's amazing to think that it was this relatively small area that ruled the entire known world! An amazing achievement. It was wonderful to walk on the same roads trod by Caesar, Nero, Mark Antony, Brutus et al. What a shame more has not survived the ravages of time. Just one thought. The temple Augustus built on the site of Caesar's cremation might direct visitors to the Piazza Argentina where the remains of the Campus Martius are as Caesar was assassinated on the steps of the Curia Pompiae behind the centre temple on that site.

Interesting ruins. Took a lot of photographs...it is still being researched and dug. Good views of the ruins. There is a large column with all kinds of sculpted designs on it...it is not covered but in the open air with all kinds of areas of which to take good photographs.
Beautiful place. We visited this place as a couple with both an audio guide. Actually one audio guide was enough. Very impressive area!

Good breather after the main event, the Colosseum. Tickets come in a trio with the Palatine Hill and the Colosseum and are at cost on-line on coopculture.it the ruins are impressive albethem a little confusing. And the forum is also en route to the piazza novana where you will need lunch and refreshments after the Colosseum.

Leave plenty of time to visit. Part of palatine hill, leave a good 3-4 hours or more to visit. Lots of walking. Lots of history and boys (teenagers) loved it. But did not eat prior to going so hungry and could not really allow enough time to see it all.
Amazing. We visited with Walks of Italy on a 3 part tour. I would highly recommend them as the quality of the tour was excellent. This is such an amazing area to see in Rome.

Incredible feeling, it was like to be living in the old roman empires!. It was crowded, however we spent several hours walking and admiring each and every place!
The experience with the olives trees, surrounded by the ruins of several important ancient government buildings at the centre, make you feel in the ancient times.

A must see place in Rome. If you like to get an impression of the past centuries, and if you want to picture yourself an image of the ancient, early Christian and medieval Rome this is the right place for it.
More cool ruins. Make sure you get an audio guide so you know what your looking at. Julius Cesar's tomb in in the middle of all the ruins.

Use a guide or read in advance!. Do yourself a favor and use a guide or study the history of this amazing site in advance..Best to do both! One could spend several hours / days in the Forum and merely scratch the surface. The architectural remains are very interesting to view in person. Understanding the history is what really makes the experience worth the visit.We used a guide for the "Skip the Line" Colosseum tour which included the Forum visit and it was money VERY well spent.

A great way to spend a couple of hours or so soaking up Rome's history.. Took a while to find the entrance - don't follow Google maps! Best way is to head towards the Colosseum from the Piazza Venezia and you can't miss it (on your right). Proper Roman ruins. We bought a book showing how the buildings looked when they were built and how they look now, which was really useful to get an idea of what it was originally like. Unbelievable to think how long some of buildings have lasted and I was surprised that you can walk in amongst the ruins and on a Roman road - didn't see any "do not touch" signs. Very interesting and well worth a 2-3 hour visit.

Love it!!. If you are the least interested in history you must go here!! It does not get any better than this - it has everthing you ever could want and wish for. You have to go and see for yourself - words can´t describe it!!

Interesting for History Buffs. We started our Italian sightseeing from the Roman Forum/Palatine Hill/Colosseum. We picked up tickets to all three at the entrance to the Roman Forum. It was a beautiful walk all around the place and quite incredible to see the remains of an ancient city. The area is beautifully preserved and it's hard to imagine that the modern day city is humming and buzzing right across the street.

They now charge a fee to get in. I visited Rome a few years ago and had a great visit to the Roman Forum, which is in close proximity to the Colloseum and can be done the same day. Sadly on this year's visit we learned that there is a $15EU fee/person - and since we felt this was a similar walk to the one at the Colloseum we decided not to visit. Too bad..
Ancient ruins. An amazing insight into the past, but make sure you read up on the history of the forum so it makes the trip worth it.
Amazing. We visited the Roman form with our teenage daughter and we were all amazed by the ruins in the Roman form it was nice to walk around and by able to touch history

Must see sights for all humanity. To see the place from where this mighty empire was governed is a must see for all.The fallen stones and columns all tell their story, need a good guide to explain this story to appreciate it more
Engrossing. So much history. Well worth a visit whilst in Rome, but would recommend a tour guide to do this site it's full justice

Practical hints for your Roman Forum visit. It goes without saying that the Roman Forum is an iconic site of the ancient city, and a must-see at least once in your life. So my comments here relate to the best way/time to visit this amazing location.If you are visiting under your own steam, I would recommend that you combine your visit with a look around the Palatine Hill and the Colosseum. You should allow something like two to four hours for the whole thing, depending on your eye for detail, allowance for breaks, interest level, and stamina. 3. For an independent combination visit, it is far better to go mid-afternoon (in the summer, at least) -- say about three o'clock. Start at the Palatine Hill ticket office (along Via di San Gregorio). At this time of day there should be no queue for buying tickets, which admit you to the Palatino, the Forum, and the Colosseum (12 Euros for the lot). This is because the Palatino is the least visited of the three sites, and anyway most group tours and individuals insist on going in the morning. Walk up the gentle slopes to the ruins, take a look around (really bad signage, so a guide book would help). Then make your way to the viewpoint over the Forum -- a quite amazing sight! And then descend the steps down to the Forum itself (which if you reverse the order of this visit is quite an upward hike in the summer heat).4. Look around the Roman Forum. Better signage here, but still not great. After you have had your fill, head over in the direction of the Colosseum, where you will find an exit (exit only, not entrance) that takes you just a couple of hundred meters to the Colosseum entrance point. Here, you join the (at 4 or 5 pm non-existent) queue for ticket holders (you show the same ticket you bought at the Palatine Hill). Whereas the queue to BUY tickets here is long, even at this late hour. Soon you are inside, and while there are still crowds around you will find very few groups since they all go in the morning or at lunch time. Spend as long as you like inside, and when you exit, you can walk around the outside of the Colosseum taking photos in the late afternoon/evening sunshine (the whole site closes at 7:15pm in summer months).That's it. Hope this helps you enjoy your visit!

Very interesting BUT if you don't have a lot of time in Rome it would not make my top 10!. I know people LOVE the Forum and it was very interesting but only if you are in Rome for many days and have seen everything else. Trip Advisor is all opinion based and this is my opinion. I have been to Rome five times and on my 5th visit this year I did make it to the Forum. I enjoyed myself very much but was so glad I hadn't wasted time on my other trips when there is so much else to do in Rome that I feel is higher on the list. Remember in the summer it is very hot, not much shade and dirt. Wear great shoes (not sandles or open toe), bring a hat and water. If your in Rome for a shorter time go to the Vatican (even if your not religious), Trev i fountain, Parthenon and surrounding neighborhood. Go out to the Appian Way and the underground catacombs. This attraction will bore most kids (including your 18 year old kid) unless they are super into history.
Forum. One of my favorite part of Rome. Much better with a tour guide to get the rich depth of history and the amazing place that it once was. You are also up close and personal in this area.

Very interesting.. We went here as part of a Rome tour; it was interesting and fascinating to see that a lot of the original art work was still on display. You could still see all the colours of the paintings. The history of the place is fascinating like the fact that there were woman who were supposed all be virgins and those who were suspected of not being virgins were buried alive as they were not allow to spill the blood of the chosen few. It has a lot of steep areas and loose stones so wear suitable foot wear.

Check out the Roman Forum!. If you are fascinated by ancient Rome then the Roman forum is a must visit when in Rome. Just like the Colosseum, it makes you FEEL how it could have been in the old times. The hills are beautiful and the view spectacular. Check it out!

Too much history to digest !. These few monuments are in absolute shambles and are nothing more than eye candy. Very forgettable. Give the expensive tour a miss if short on time. Also lots of walking to do.
2000 years of civilization in one place.. A must see when visiting Rome. Hard to find any other place which can offer so much ancient experience.

A must see!! . We visited here as part of a guided tour and we are so glad it was included as otherwise we would have walked around this site not knowing what we were looking at and not appreciating it for what it is.I suppose it also helped that we had an amazing tour guide that you could tell that he loved what he does. Amazing to think that this historical site was buried under debris till excavating began in the 19th century.
Must see. You can't go to Rome without seeing the forum. We went on a half day tour of the coliseum, forum and palatine hill ( city wonders) which brought the history to life.

Free entry when you pay for Colosseum. You get free entry to the Forum when you pay to enter the Colosseum which gives you 2 days to visit the sight. I would recommend having a break before you visit as there is plenty of walking to do here. Lovely ruins to view and you can climb high to get a great view of Romes city centre.

We were with a group guided tour. If you love history and want to learn book a guided tour, we lucked into finding colosseum and Vatican tours (review left for them)and our guide renata was so enthusiastic she made the tour. Otherwise we'd just have been looking at rubble. A wonderful trip back in time and amazing the Romans were so far advanced for the time. Where did we all go wrong!
Interesting. Took a tour which continued on from the Collosseum, history explained, this is the heart of Rome. Not to be missed.
Totally amazing!. No idea it was so extensive. So many things to see. Need another day there at least. Use the entrance opposite the Tourist Information as there were no queues.

Visit Roman Forum first. Roman forum is a visit we do along with Palatine Hill, the entrance is beside the Colosseum ut is less crowded to enter at Palatino Hill down the avenue. It´s a huge place with many historical places and buildings so take your time to see all things, I spent a whole afternoon. Many people visit this place and colosseum at the same day...so tiring...better visit Forum first ( where is easier to enter ) and the Colosseum the next day, the same ticket is valid for 2 consecutive days but only one visit each.

History!. Walking among the ruins is fascinating. Make sure to go into the museum to see the frescos and get the explanation that is projected in the dark and narrated about some of the frescos. Read up before, take a tour, listen to an audio guide or at least read the signs. This place is fascinating.

More Than Just Crumbled Buildings. Though many of the magnificent buildings are gone you need to see the Forum. You just imagine the magnificence and glory of one of the greatest empires on earth. You walk on roads that ancient Romans walked on.

A must see!. An amazing and beautifully picturesque sight of Ancient Rome. I actually enjoyed this more than the Colosseum as it was less busy - you can also skip the queues at the Colosseum by buying your tickets here which admit your entry to both as well as Palatine Hill.

Awesome!. I kept saying to myself "Men in togas walked here". There were tons of people, but the place is huge, it didn't matter. We went in the heat of the day because we had no choice, but if you can, go as soon as they open. You have to buy a ticket to see most of it, but it is worth it.

Highlight of holiday.. You could spend a whole day here in combination with the Palatine Hill. Gives a great insight into Roman life and the grandeur of their architecture. Very useful information boards. Can be a bit tiring on a hot day as there isn't much shade in the forum.

The impressive Ruins. The erstwhile social, political and commercial hub of the Romans , the roman forum lost its importance somewhat after the fall of the Roman empire.The massive granite columns what we see today are all that remains

Worthwhile. We visited the Forum right after our visit to the Colosseum. It was still early morning which was a blessing because the heat (late May) was draining and there's little shade. It's difficult to imagine what the ruins would have looked like in their hey-day, so I would suggest watching some video recreations before your visit, or looking at pictures that recreate the buildings. This helped us to appreciate what we were looking at during our visit. Visiting the nearby Capitoline Museums also provides some wonderful views of the forum.
Travel back in time!. A wonderful glimpse into civilization's beginnings. Book a tour, or download an app to get the most of this unique experience. Best done early before it gets too hot.
Walk through history. So much history, what a great place to wander around! My tip would be to go early, mid-afternoon you have the heat, and there are lots of people and tour groups!

Preparation essential!. Get a good guide book, David Watkins or Amanda Claridge both cover it in detail, a good pair of shoes, a hat and water. Do some reading before hand, even if you take a tour, as unless you have some background knowledge you will be completely overwhelmed and confused by what you see. What remains of the Forum needs interpreting and a little imagination. It also helps if you have some knowledge of Republican and Imperial Rome and the time line so you can place the various ruins in the right period. The Forum was in use for over a thousand years so it is multi layered and far from complete with numerous structures overlaying other partly excavated ones. You also need to appreciate that some of the restoration work is less than perfect so all is not as it seems.This is a live archaeological site with several areas being restored or excavated so you may not get access to the complete area. On my latest visit the Curia was closed.You will also need a good couple of hours to do it justice. If you have any interest in ancient Rome you will find this absolutely fascinating. This site was literally the centre of the known world for what we now call the West and shaped our history for over a thousand years. For that alone it is worth a visit.

Pleasant area to visit. It is said that this is the very essence of ancient Roman life. Some of the buildings are well preserved whilst othets are ruins. You get 'free' entrance to here and Paletine Hill on the same ticket as the Colosseum. You need a large junck if time to make the visit worthwhile. There is nowhere to buy resfreshments in here and you can't leave and re-enter so plan your visit around meal times.
Worth visiting. Close to the Colosseum you can visit the roman forum. It is worth paying a visit to continue your exploration of the ancient Rome.

One of must see in Rome. Though it is always crowded Forum Romanum is one of the things anyone should see while visting Rome. It goves you a glimpse of the scale of the public buildings in Ancinet Rome

Antica citta di Roma. Roman Forum is the next visit after Colusseum as the same ticket is valid to enter in the Roman Forum. You cannot miss visiting the "Antica Roma". ALl the Histoy is Inside and better if you take a guide so to know about each column, monument, every ruin that is inside

Fabulous site not to miss. The tour through Viatour of this site, Palatine Hill and the Underground of the Colusseum are a must while in Rome. Just take the earliest time available to avoid the crowds and the heat. Be ready to walk lots of stairs to totally enjoy this.

Loved it very much. It is very vast so if you want to see it properky at least put 2 , 3hours. There is view point that you have to walk all the way up but then you will see the whole area under your feet. Also they had a temporary exhibition which was nice as well.

Good to see. This is good to see however with the metro redevelopment it was mostly covered over. I think going around this place a tour guide really does help. Not the audio tours as this was rubbish.

Across from the Colosseum. The Forum is really a huge open area across from the Colosseum which was essentially the residential area of ancient Rome. The ruins are worth walking around, but wear good shoes and bring a water bottle. You can book a guided tour but at least have a guide book to help you out.

Grand at night. Same with the Colosseum, you appreciate the grandeur more at night (since they are in the same area). Had the opportunity of seeing the moon shining in the middle of the Arc of Titus which made the experience all the more amazing.

Have to bring vivid imagination.. There are mostly broken columns and buildings, but coming from thousand years ago are still impressive. It is good to walk through here and imagine how people in ancient Rome used to spend their free time.

A lot to see.. The Roman forum is vast and you should be able to get in with the ticket purchased for the Colosseum. The three points that I feel are important to share are: take drinking water, wear comfortable trainers and give yourself plenty to time. There is a lot of hilly walking, if the day is hot water is a must and there is so much to see you will need plenty of time to get around.

you need imagination. a remarkable place where we stayed around 3 hr.... I strongly suggest that one should review some books or websites which provide reconstruction scenarios of this area. It may help you to enjoy all ruins deeper. Honestly, three-hour is too long! One to two hours may be more adequate. It is suggested that you may buy tickets here and use the same tickets to visit the arena later, which will avoid you from the long line out side of the arena.

Best in Rome. Forum Romanum is very often forgotten in the shadow of Colosseum. But the real roman time memories and feeling is here present. The area includes two museums and tens of old roman buildings to be seen and visited. Reserve time for this, but on Your mental toga and walk up to Palatinos. Buy doubleticket Foru/Colosseum and print it out before entering.

Great experience!. We spent hours here. One of the best things we did on our tour. Third trip to Rome but first time a the Forum. Would highly recommend buying on of the books that show what it looked like back in the day.
Lost in ancient. If you want to discover and feel lost in ancient history, get in the ruins and walk on roman steps.This is one the most impressive memories of your life.

Great day . This was amazing and open with great views. I would suggest either a tour or reading up on it before you go as it will make it more enjoyable. They do combined tours. Very open and interesting
History. We were on a guided tour. The area is full of ancient ruins that hinted to the glory of ancient Rome.
Real feeling of Rome. Must see in Rome. To do with comfortable shoes in a good no raining day and with a guide to really understand the history of that place.

Worth a look. I really enjoyed it here, cause I personally find it so interesting, and I like trying to imagine what it used to look like, even if you aren't overly interested in it but have gone to the Colosseum this is included in your ticket so you may as well go and have a wander. If you I interested in learning about each part I would definitely recommend you do a guided tour.
Sense of history. Very clean, well preserved and worth a visit. Queues to get in not too long and not crowded as lots of space. Not good if suffer from mobility problems.

Rome must see. I agree with the other reviewers, if you visit in summer it is very hot with a lot of steps and walking but worth it to see the Forum. There is so much interesting history but the monument has very little in the way of plaques, etc, so come prepared with your own guide or their audio guide if you are not doing a tour. They have places to refill water bottles and plenty of sitting stones, some in shade. It is nice just to be there, surrounded by history, IMO so we spent much time just looking around...

Amazing History. We enjoyed walking around the ruins and learning about the history of Rome. There is a lot of walking so make sure you are wearing comfortable shoes. We used our Roma Pass to enter, visited Palatine Hill, then walked over to The Colosseum.
Must see. Have visited the forum on almost every one of my 30 plys trips to Rome. Less crowded in late afternoon.
Fantastic . Beautiful place but get a guide it will be much more appealing if you do, we had one via viator and he was amazing and really new the history of the place

Site seeing. This area of Ancient Rome is amazing with sites of many of the buildings that were in existence over 2000 years ago, the scale of the buildings is beyond belief, if only we could build like that today

So much history at the Roman Forum. A must do with a guide to get all the facts and history of the area. Bring water and a car, very hot in the summer and plenty of walking. We walked the area for about 1-1/2 hours.
Fabulous Forum!. Amazing ruins. Just loved wandering around here and soaking up the history. 5 min walk from Colessium so easy to do both sights in a morning if not too crowded.

So much to see!. Temples, buildings, statues, gardens, and more! I was in awe walking around the old Roman Forum grounds, surrounded by ancient buildings and history.Do yourself a favor and get a Roma Pass. You'll get 3 full days of public transit and free entry to 2 main attractions (I used mine for Colosseum/Roman Forum and the Castel de St. Angelo). You also don't have to stand in line for tickets!

A Funny Thing.... ....OK not very original but certainly very cool! Take the tour that includes Palatine Hill and the Coliseum about 3 hours total. We had a fairly knowledgeable guide which I prefer to the self paced version but either will help flesh out the historical details.

Awesome!. This is a must-see when in Rome. The ruins and buildings are so well preserved and fun to see. This is the same ticket as the Colosseum and Palatine Hill, plan on spending a half day to see all of them.

Good but a little over rated. We visited the Roman Forum as part of a skip-the-line tour from Viator for Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum. In the beginning the Roman Forum looks really nice but after a while it gets too redundant. If you are very into history you will enjoy it but if you are short on time this is something you can miss!

Interesting. We had paid for entry to the 'Coliseum' and found that the price included a visit to the 'Forum'. Really interesting as you walk around the ruins. Great views over the City from the high points.

unmissable for ruin lovers. If Roman history or ancient ruins are your thing, you cannot miss this place. Superb. The Colosseum and the Palatine hill are included in the ticket. Indeed, the views from the Palatine are spectacular. If you are here in the summer, bring water and a sun hat.
Fantastic. lovely to walk around and the hill area is very tranquil for rome. Grab a guide book to fully appreciate the scale of what it once was and imagine it as you walk the pillars and ruins

Amazing. We saw many guided tours doing the Forums while we were there, but honestly this is easily done alone with a decent guidebook and you get more time to take everything in and absorb the atmosphere.I think it's actually one of those few places when it comes to "trawling through ruins" as my Mum would put it that has retained enough architectural structure to be interesting and give you an idea of what it would once have been.One tip I would give you is if you are going to Rome for a week, go to the Coliseum and Forum early on in the week, buy an Archeological Ticket. At 23 Euros it's not cheap, but the ticket lasts for 7 days or 9 entries, whichever comes first, it includes the Forums, the Coliseum, the Baths etc etc. Well worth it.
Worth the walk!. Be prepared for the heat! But if you've got that covered, this area will be worth taking in, with a guide, otherwise they are just stones without a story.
Fantasy. If you don't know - what it is - it is rather boring. You need to know what it is and history. Use your guidebook, or read before going.

Santa Maria Antiqua. This review is not about the whole Forum but rather the newly opened church of Santa Maria Antiqua.This small site, which is tucked next to the Temple of the Vestals and the Temple of the Dioscuri, and nestled against the side of the Palatine Hill, has just undergone a multi-decade renovation and restoration. It contains the 6th-9th century remains of dozens of marvelous, Byzantine style frescos as well as the original encaustic icon of a 'Madonna and Child', the earliest surviving such icon from the western half of the former Roman Empire. There is also a nearby 'Oratory of the 40 Martyrs', and a portion of the original Roman Imperial ramp that led up to the residencies on the Palatine Hill. The surrounding Flavian walls have also been restored, and the chapel given walls and a roof in keeping with the design of the original.With your Colosseum/Forum/Palatine ticket, admission to this site is now free until September 11th, 2016. Since it only opened to the public on March 17th of this year, I assume that soon afterwards a fee of 12 or more euros (as stated on numerous websites) will be charged for admission, and this free admission is a simply way to build up a public buzz about the significance of the art.And marvelous it is, not just in what remains---in some cases, palimpsests of 6th-9th century frescos overlap one another in a puzzle quilt of faces and forms---but in how the state-of-the-art educational, digital light show and music illuminate the history and meaning of the images in the two side chapels. I was honestly so mesmerized, I stayed through two screenings of the 5 minute cycles for each chapel.If you know anything about the history of early Christian art, especially its Byzantine influences, or are curious about the transition from Roman to Christian styles, this site is an absolute must see.

Ruins worth visiting while you visit Colosseum. This are great ruins to visit and can be done free with Roma Pass on the same day you do Colosseum, Imperial Forum and Palantine Hills can be done in one go and will take upto 4+ hours. If you love history and know a little bit about Roman empire, you will enjoy the grandeur of these places. Make sure you get the audio guide.

Roman Forum was a site to see. The Roman Forum was quite hot with a lot of walking. Take water with you. We got in with our Colosseum ticket and only found that out by accident. It is not the place for the elderly that can't walk well. It needed more signs to tell you what you were looking at.
like the Palatine Hill fantastic to visit. this is huge and between this and Palatine hill i would give yourself a day to see it all, a guide would allow you to get the most out of it

Great adventure and great story . Fantastic to be able to walk the forum and take a look at the history. It can get VERY hot with little shade. Allow a number of hours and bring water. It's a fantastic walk but steep steps in places so be prepared. Great views out over Rome.

Awesome history.... Ever since I can remember I've always wanted to visit and see the Roman Forum. It is definitely a very cool and historical place worth the visit. However, if at all possible my strongest recommendation is to visit during spring or fall. I went in the summer and it was miserably hot. If you must go in the summer make sure to take plenty of cold water, a hat, and cooling towel to place around your neck and shoulder to help cool you down.

Old Roman history. The Roman forum was part of our tour along with the Colosseum. It is right next door and not a long walk over. So much history and very happy to have a guide point out all the little details and tell information about the different structures. You get more of a feel for old Rome and how things were back in that time. Structures are a little spread out but worth walking and seeing everything. Most things are out in the open so suggest going in the morning if it is going to be a hot sunny day.

Fantastic. We went here first thing in the morning and it wasn't that busy, as we were leaving in the early afternoon it was filling up and wouldn't have been as nice if we'd arrived then with the crowds of other people. Great to see the ruins and it covers a lot bigger area than we thought, you are able to wander around freely. There is a new exhibit at the Santa Maria Antiqua which was incredibly interesting and well done.
great historical walking. Walk through it in the evening, special lighting. Easy access, historical roman background, easy to find and walk at no cost

Absolutely incredible. Most stunning and beautiful architecture and history in the Forum. Walking in the footsteps of ancient Romans is breath taking. Even if you aren't into history you will definitely get a buzz from this experience. Take the time to explore it fully. You wont be disappointed.
Need a guide.... In order to get the most out of the Roman forum you need a guide; otherwise you'll be lost and miss a lot.

Amazing history. This is a terrific family outing. Be prepared for much walking, but there are shady places and places to refill one's water bottle (be sure to bring your own!). The forum is replete with history and teenagers with plenty of energy will appreciate the climbing that is possible (from the lower levels to the upper levels).This is not truly wheelchair accessible - the ground it too uneven. Also, be sure to plan your exit before entering. We encountered many people desirous of exiting to the coliseum, but due to the metal detectors and security, no exiting in that direction is allowed.
Extremely interesting. I found this site to be one of the most interesting in Roman history. We took a tour with Gray Line and out guide was outstanding

Most genuine thing left?. Great walk, sooo much to see. The statues and buildings are just the start too, the more you look around you'll realise that this is probably the closest you'll ever be to old Rome. Because it's more open, the tourists are spread out and you can actually look around and enjoy yourself. No guards hurrying you through, no one standing on your toes etc. Little tip: If you buy your ticket for the Colosseum in advance, you can get tickets to the Forum and Circus Maximus included. Use the money saved for more Gelato!

It's like stepping back in time!. Amazing. People who say this is just a few old ruins haven't properly visited this. A walk through the old ruins was haunting but fascinating. We had a guided tour who had advised us from the Palpatine which buildings were which (and go up there for best photo opp's). We were then left to explore ruins on our own time. It's so big so didn't feel too crowded, and the caution system for wheelchairs/prams and the elderly was a really nice touch, telling people what areas you would need to traverse down steep hills and others which were easier to climb. This was also good as a lot of old ruins were trying to modernise too much it takes the feel away, however they have this just right at the Forum!

Be sure to have a guide. Without a guide, you want realize the significance of the ruins and you might as well just stroll by and look without buying a ticket. Understanding the history is worth the guide.

Triumphal Arches!! . Who doesn't love these cool structures!! I know I do and here you will find a bunch of really cool ones in an amazing setting of overlaying remnants of Rome's deep past. Take your time and explore as much as possible - rest often and contemplate more. Imagine the civilization that built the Forum and your understanding of how it made the world we know today - powerful ripples that still shape our world.

Second entry down the road with no lines..... The lines for the forum/Palatine hill was HUGE at the main entrance, opposite to the Colosseum. Even the ROMA Pass line was a painful sight.If you walk down the road a little more, south of the colosseum towards the horse racing track at the bottom of the Palatine Hill, there is a second entrance, which has nobody there. Use that. Saved me over an hour.Enjoy!
Not enough time. Visited the Forum after the coliseum, long queues meant we didn't get enough time to explore the full site.

Wonderful. This was one of my favorite sites, in my recent trip. I'd recommend going with a guide as there are not information on site to inform you of what you're looking at.This area is definitely a must see.

Give this lots of time!. You buy a combined ticket for the Colosseum and the Forum. If you have enough time, do them on different days or you will be overwhelmed. There is so much to see in the Forum, I guess you could spend days here. There were a number of guided tours going on around us and it would probably help to orientate you to have a guide if you can afford it. We were looking for Sta Maria Antiqua - an extraordinary early Christian building discovered 100 years ago after an earth quake. Have good shoes, sunshade, plenty of water, a good guide book and time and energy!
Part of the half day Coloseum Tour. This was included with our half day Coloseum Tour. lead by the City Wonders guide Chira. It was a great half day in Rome.
Amazing. Absolutely a must-see location for all visitors. Magnificent architectures and stories. Recommend being part of a tour group with a knowledgeable guide
All Day Affair. Do this with the Palatine and you won't regret it. Do NOT try to do all that AND the Colosseum! Be sure to see the Palatine museum - and get tickets ahead!!
Interesting. Very fascinating place. The feeling of being right in the center of history. However, some signs or plaques with information would be helpful.
Forum a must. Fantastic to see these ancient ruins. So much history. You could spend hours walking around. It does get very hot here so make sure you have a hat/water!

lovely. part of pallentine hill, lovely peaceful place lots of walking about, again get a gude to show you round i cant stress enough how much better your experience would be to get guides to all your tours if you not on a tight budget, makes everything alot better.
Do not do this in a rush. Used city wonder.com to take a 3 hour walking tour of Colosseum, Roman Forum & Palatine Hill - stayed on longer to investigate on my own

Historic. Was nice to see these ruins after the colosseum. Is lovely to see historical ruins and see what they were. We had a tour guide (linked with the colosseum) and she was full of information about the ruins

You have to pinch yourself. Almost feels like you have walked into a movie set - except it is real! Amazing to think this has endured centuries and is still here to tell it's story. Hopefully it will continue to be preserved to remind us how amazing our fore fathers were and what wonderful things we are able to create.
