Origin of the Republic. What we see here today are the ruins of what it was one of the most important places in Rome. Judgments, gladiators and famois speeches happened here as well as the beginning of the Senators and the Republic.
Some parts are still to see of the glorious marble floor and some columns are still standing.

It seems silly to say GO to the Forum, but you MUST!. For centuries the Forum was the center of the most powerful and far flung empire the Western world has known. The ruins are extensive and inspiring. While having visited before and being overwhelmed, this time we hired a local company "Through Eternity" to lead us through the complexity of the site - they are really good. This is not an "easy" tour due to the enormity of the site and the heat in Rome, but an absolute MUST. If you are in Rome and don't go to the Forum, you have made a terrible mistake.
Go Back Into Time. If you see the Colosseum you must see the Forum. It will amaze you to see and learn all about the history of Rome

Beautiful Ancient Ruins. If you love ancient ruins, the Forum is not to be missed. Unless you're a history buff or educator, I would definitely suggest having a tour guide that explains the different aspects of the Roman Forum. The area is very large and comprised of many different building ruins. They are beautiful and it is so incredible to realize what important decisions in history were made right in that area.

Tours by Locals. My wife and I did a private tour with Tours by Locals.
Our guide was a PhD Archeologist.
I love ancient history and this tour was probably around $200, but I loved every minute.
3 hours in the Forum and Palantine Hill with a guide one-on-one.
I highly recommend private tours for technical topics shush as the Forum.
Great to see. A wonderful site, we could of spent quite a while soaking it all in, may be good to have a tour guide or audio guide to fully appreciate
Near the Coliseum. Amazing to see these ruins and realise just how old they are. Lots to look at and take in. You can see massive chunks of buildings that have fallen.

Facsinating, but get a guided tour. I found the Forum to be a fascinating slice of history, although I know others find ruins to be boring. Get a guided tour. I went with City Wonders and the guide (Serafina?) was excellent; enthusiastic, knowledgable and with good English.

Get up close and personal with ancient Rome. The Forum, there are two ways to access it, either directly or from Palatine Hill. There is not much left to see, but with a guide there is more to be learnt. The ruins are just that, you can see them outside of this area for free, what access to Forum allows is, here you can still touch the same surfaces once seen and felt in Roman times.

Walk the paths of the Emperors. This is my favourite place in Rome. You walk down the streets of the Forum and you can imagine yourself to be in the city of Augustus and Vespasian. The atmosphere is wonderful and there is something interesting every couple of steps.
A Rome TOP TEN. Amazing that some of these old structures are still standing. Offers an insight into the lives of early Romans. Get a guide to get the full effect.
Forum. A must see for all visiting rome. Very good ruins and a great insight into the history. Very busy but lots of water fountains to drink from

An open air museum. Get a feel of history, and walk through it. The ruins will transport you through time. Just give it a try. Advisable to brush up on Roman (or that part of world history) to appreciate the ruins. There's a connection to Palatino so the moment you go out of the place, you have already visited two attractions.

Even better with a guide . We explored the Roman Forum with Through Eternity tours. Our tour guide Mario was exceptional. My husband and I normally do our own research and tour without a guide but we were thrilled we decided to go with Mario. It was a once in a lifetime experience.

Go prepared. A must see, but go prepared for the sun and heat. Very helpful to have a guidebook or tour. You could spend hours wandering around. With current closures and construction, some of the access and egress are currently limited. Ticket for this also admits you to the Coliseum.
AMAZING. Absolutely loved the Roman Forum. Take your time and go through it slowly. So amazing to walk through history and be amongst these monuments.

Words arent enough to discribe this place. First make sure to get the Roma Pass, although this is a free site across the street is Palastine Hill and the colosium, all require a fee. However, it is all free with Roma pass. This site is lovely and words cant begin to discribe this place. This is more of an experience that could only be apprechiated with your own senses.
Anniversary trip. I would recommend stopping for this attraction simply to absorb some fascinating history. The ruins are beautiful and the setting is surreal. Loved it.
Fascinating ruins. Really interesting to wander amongst the ruins and then up to Palatine Hill (which we preferred because of the views).
All roads lead to Rome. The amount of history that you are walking over is just amazing. It's almost difficult to wrap your mind around it. Wear comfortable shoes and if its hot sunscreen.
My 50hh. Again steeped in Roman history this place was fantastic just magical ,if like us you love anything roman this is a must like the walk on up to Palentine hill after well worth it .
A Must See when in Rome.. A walk around the Forum was a must do activity for me because I have always wanted to visit and I was not disappointed!!!! Fabulous.
THIS IS A MUST SEE!. This is a MUST SEE along with PALATINE HILL. The ruins and history of this important place is a must do attraction while in Rome. Fabulous!

Lots to See. We entered the Forum on a Saturday afternoon. Crowds weren't too bad. We bought our tickets in advance online - definitely the best way to maximize your time.The Forum is large, with a lot of sites to see, so plan accordingly. Highly recommend you visit with some sort of guide - whether a paid guide or and audio one - so you know what it is you're seeing. We followed the Rick Steves' app audio guide which did get a little confusing as far as where to go. A beautiful place of history.

worth spending time, can walk, bicycle, segway.. old city of Rome was quite low lying than what we see of today. The floods must have been a frequent affair in old rome. But amazing to see the kind of planning done even without the modern equipments. Pure intelligence & vision.

This was the Roman Empire.. Spent an afternoon alone in the Foro. Could not believe I was actually walking on the exact roads as all those great men and women who came before. It was as if I time-travelled and I lived in the height of the Roman Empire. This was my first time in Italy, and I think coming to the Forum really made me understood how the Roman Empire was one of the greatest empires in the history of mankind.
The start of our democracy lies here too.. It takes a while to visit it. So much to see, so many relics. Take your time to read the signs or take a guided tour.

Lots to See and Learn. The experience learning what the ruins were, including how the height of water impacted finding them made this one of favorites in Rome just behind the Colosseum. We love history and that knowledge made sense in relation to what we saw. We had a tour guide, but a book would be quite helpful also to make sense of it all. Bring water and/or a hat, it's hot in the bright sun.

The Roman Forum. I suggest only those who really enjoy knowing history and architecture to go for this. Its a long walk as the Roman Forum is spread over a vast area. You must take a guided tour to understand the extent of the glory of the Romans or you will feel like your just walking between rocks! They tell you all about the history of Rome from the very beginning, they cover the twins and the ages after that. Its good for all the Julius Caesar fans! You get to see the first ever built temples and structures in Rome. Its amazing the effort the government has put to recreate the things which were destroyed hundreds of years ago.
Just too are inspiring to describe. There is no much to see over the complete area and its so diverse. Take a good guidebook or google and make sure you see all of the idiosynchrasies
Interesting place!. We found a secondary entrance with no waiting in line. We used Rick Steve's iPhone app guided Audio tour, and it was good. We were able to go at our own pace and we learned a lot.
Great for a walk. Good for a long walk around the area, Bring food, water with it, Gets crowded as the area is a main attraction also apart from the colosseum and palatine hills.

Lot of history that you wont remember but worth a visit. it has too many ruins in it and it big as well. it is difficult to remember everything but i do recommend a visit to appreciate the 2000+ history of rome.
Worth walking around. Awesome spot, I prefer to walk around the exterior, save cash, save time, besides you have better vantage points of the Forum from street level.

Impressive. Have a picnic around the ancient architecture and enjoy the view. There's a lot to see and read, the view from the palatine hill is awesome. I would recommend going to the Foro Romano first in order to get a ticket which you can use for the palatine hill as well as the colosseum. 7.50€ for European citizens.
Phenomenal scene . A great place but go with a guide as it is not well currated and there is little by way of explanation of what you are looking at.

Worth a look. After seeing the coliseum the forum is the next logical (and included in your ticket).
The grounds are lovely, however after seeing the coliseum they pale in comparison.
Definitely worth going
AMAZING!. SO so much history. Could spend so many hours here but it was phenomenal. Our tour guide was great! So much to see and walk through. Great for pictures and great views
Over The Top. All of Rome is Over The Top. So much around for so long. The architecture the skill - its beyond imagination.
Worth seeing. Great place to spend the day in. If you enjoy sightseeing this would certainly suit. Convenient location and unforgettable experience
Great to walk around!. Great to walk around, if you have time you can spend all morning or afternoon walking around the area.

Still can't get our heads around how some of this stuffs still standing!. See my review of the Palatino also. Best way to enjoy the Forum and Palatine Hill is to make a day of it. Take a packed lunch, plenty of sun cream if hot, and a hat, and refillable water bottles. Get an audio guide (we shared one quite successfully), and be then take your time to soak up the history. The most amazing remains which still stay upright despite 2-3000 years of weather, earthquakes, fires, wars, and goodness knows what else! Do not visit Rome without visiting if you have even a minuscule amount of interest in Roman history!
Neat place. Very large place and you need time to visit. I recommend a guided tour to make it easy. It will cost you but after the tour you can stay as long as you want. Lots of history

CITY CENTER OF ROME 2000 YRS BACK. The forum was the center of everyday life for the average citizen thousands of years ago, and the feeling you get walking around is unforgettable. It is just beside the Colosseum & one should not miss it.

Go in a take a look... You won't be disappointed. My partner and I visited this on our first day in Rome. The queue was huge for the colosseum so went for this instead and we weren't dissappointed. You can see the impressive history of the city. You can take an audio guide if you want but we were happy to read the information that's in front of each monument. Its worth checking it out and isn't too expensive
Incredible . Wander the Roman streets, get inside the temples and relive life in one of the worlds most important archaeological sites. It's a wonder for a reason and totally unmissable.

Favourite site in rome. Steeped in history this place you could spend a whole day in easily. So many incredible significant sites you can wander through, get close to and see how things were built. An absolute must. And great bonus of water fountains flowing. Take snacks to keep you going as lots of walking.

Amazing for history. Having gotten the Roma Pass I chose the Colosseum and Roman Forum as one of my included visits.Rome is studded with little gems of history and the Roman Forum is no exception. Definitely give yourself enough time to wander around. Lots of great pictures to be taken. Not a lot of shelter/shade so plan accordingly for the weather.

Right in the center of Rome. Roman Forum is right in the center of Rome and it feels like you miles away. It's one of those places to visit and hear the history. Every spot is incredible to stand and imagine yourself there thousands of years ago...

What can I say, a MUST for any history enthusiast. So exciting, full of so much history and stories. I find the place most enjoyable early in the day, before 9 am, later on the site itself and the streets surrounding it get so crowded you can't move. A must, with a guided tour it's quite the learning experience.

Amazing. The forum is definitely one to visit. The Roman ruins show how skilled the Romans were building these unique buildings. They transport you back to the Roman age imagining what life was in those times. It is only a short walk from the colosseum and would advise anyone to start their tour at the forum and then go on to the coliseum when the queues have shortened.

Well worth a visit !. The Roman forum is huge ! Its a large selection of buildings and temples that are as well preserved as our castles in the UK. It takes a few hours to walk all of it and its on varied levels. The views from the palatine hill are worth a look too.

History and Ruins. History and ruins of ancient Rome are what you will appreciate in the Roman Forum. We suggest that you go in the morning and have a good tour guide or downloadable audio guide so that you will understand the story behind the buildings, columns and all.This attraction is near to Colosseum and Capitoline Hill. A must see.

Excellent Guide. My wife and I toured the Palatine Hill, Forum and Colosseum in May, 2016. Our tour guide's name was Chiara and she was fantastic. We took a lot of guided tours on our honeymoon but she was the best guide we had. She was very knowledgeable of what she showed us, was patient with the group and set a good pace. Unfortunately, when we toured the Colosseum she had to turn our group over to another guide. This guide was probably quite knowledgeable but we had to use hand-held audio devices which was very awkward and it made it hard to hear the guide. Most people in the group didn't bother with them. Again, if you happen to get Chiara as your guide you're in for a very good tour!

Imagine what Rome was in the past. Take your time, walk the cobbled stones roads, visit the temples and ruins, stop in the courtyard lined with statues among climbing roses, and imagine what Rome used to be in the past.
Bunch of walking, but it's worth it.... The view and the historic matter of the walk is amazing... Lacks english touristic info, though... But besides that, great visit!

One of the world's great historical locations. Only a small proportion of the Forum's building are still there, but this is truly one of the world's great historical sights. We were surprised at how much still remains, and the archeological work and excavation that has been done is remarkable. It was amazing to stand at the center of the Roman Empire, which ruled the Western world for many centuries. We found it very helpful to have a private guide (we had a terrific guide, Bruno, from Walks Inside Rome) to explain each of the ruins, as well as the history of the area. We learned a lot on the tour and during our visit to the Forum.
construction site. nothing much to see here. it looks like they are mostly still digging here. i was kind of disappointed.

Get a good guide in order to maximize the experience. It was my fourth trip to the Forum, the first being in 1975, and last month's visit was the best. The Viator guide told so many stories and pointed out things that a tour book cannot, or even the self-guided audio tours. Amazing place! A privilege to walk where ancient citizens and dignitaries trod centuries ago.

Blown away. Period.. Pls wear comfortable shoes when visiting. Venue is right beside the colossuem. Personally, this is a Must visit place. Wow. You can learn about the history of the structures that were built, how the roman rulers had planned and managed their resources. The ancient columns still stand there. Be sure to visit the Bath as well, pretty big going by ancient standards. All in all, fantastic experience you will never forget!
Awesome history lesson. Did Roman Forum with a private tour, which included Palatine Hill and Colosseum. It is a can't miss when in Rome

City centre of the ancient Romans. The Roman Forum gives you insight into how the ancient Romans used to live. It is a result of years of excavations, and some parts are still under scaffolding as excavations are still being done. I would recommend a tour guide or audio guide as the place is quite big with little written explanations.

A portal back in time.. Walking around the Roman Forum is probably the closest I've ever felt to escaping the current day and age. The forum was the center of everyday life for the average citizen thousands of years ago, and the feeling you get walking around is unforgettable. In my opinion, it is far, far better than the Colosseum, and truly ought to be one of the Top 3 Things to Do while in Rome — there's just so much to ponder and take in!If you go on the first Sunday of the month, the Colosseum + Forum + Palatine are all free.
Another Must See in Rome. this again was one of our stops on the private Rome tour with Easitalytours. Overlooking the Forum is what i expected Ancient Rome to be.

A Must-See SIte...with a warning!. The Forum is a fantastic place to visit. On our trip to Italy, it is the location where we took the most photos. When going through the Forum you are seeing the heart of the entire Roman empire.Being able to enter temples, to see the handiwork of Rome, see the actual site where Julius Caesar himself was cremated, walking past the statues of the Vestal Virgins, etc., was unbelievable. You actually are wandering through history and you get a bit of a feel for daily life in ancient Rome. Of course, I am interested in history…but my wife, who does not enjoy history was also enthralled. This is a sight not to be missed on a visit to Rome. You will always remember it, as will your family.We paid for a tour through OverRome, and it was expensive, but very much worth it. The guide (Julia) was great – very friendly, knowledgeable, and kept it interesting for everyone. I did not feel rushed nor overburdened with data...she stuck the wright chord with everyone.We were there in March, and the weather was perfect.One important warning…When you enter the site you have to go through security. The guards insisted that we take off watches, etc. Don’t take off your w watches and small valuables…put them somewhere, but not in the bin for the metal detector. I did, and my watch – a gift from my wife -disappeared. I was the last of our group to go through, and after thoroughly studying what happened, I had to come to the sad realization that the security people had to be the people who took my watch. This also explained their complete indifference when I mentioned it was missing. I related the incident to others who frequently travel in Italy, and they related that this was not uncommon.

Lots of history but watch your footing. Loads of historical ruins and architecture to look at but if you aren't too steady on your feet or have small children think twice as there are lots of steps and rough ground to cover if you make the most of your visit.

Our favourite thing to do in Rome !!. We visited the Roman Forum early morning and loved it. It was amazing to walk amongst such history. One can really imagine how it used to be many centuries ago, and it is quite humbling. As it was early there weren't many people and it was really nice to find ourselves almost alone at some point. We spent more than 1h before heading to the Palatine Hill. The highlight of our trip !!

A lot bigger than I thought!. Truly the heart of the ruins of Ancient Rome. The Roman Forum area was much larger than I thought it would be. My friend and I spent the better part of the afternoon between here and the Palatine Hill. Again, don't forget to bring water on a summer day. It can get hot!

Amazing view of history. Amazing history unearthed in recent times.Lots of people hawking guided same-day combo tours at the Colosseum for a fee. If doing self-guided tour, consider: 1) buy the 12€ combo ticket at the Palatine Hill gate (walk past Constantine arch about 300 meters), 2) see Palatine Hill 1st & the Forum next (downhill walk from Palatine Hill to the Forum), 3) to avoid feeling beat, take a break and see the Colosseum later on or the next day (combo ticket good for two consecutive days), 4) use Rick Steve's free Audio Europe app for both the Forum and the Colosseum.On a previous trip, I bought a book that showed the current building in ruin and a film overlay showing the buildings in beautiful, vibrant colors as they may have looked back then.The area around Arch of Septimius Severus was under construction in May 2016.

Worth a visit after googling about it.. Alas. It was raining.. But my kids enjoyed it. Couldn't spend much time as it was evening already after the colosseum trip. The restoration efforts are commendable.

It awesome-ness takes imagination to fully appreciate. This is where it takes some real imagination (and no small dose of curiosity) to come close to fully understanding and appreciating Rome's ancient ruins for all they once represented. You may be perfectly satisfied by the photo ops here, as they inspire amateur and professional photographers alike. But unlike the mostly-intact Colosseum, the crumbled buildings and lonely pillars of the Roman Forum are in a much more advanced state of disrepair. You have to work harder (think harder) about them to put the pieces back in place. But the Forum is an absolute must for those with an interest in world history and architecture, for it was this once prime real estate that was the center of civilization. A 2-3 hour walking tour is highly recommended, ideally one booked in advance and one that allows you to skip the ticket lines. Would also highly recommend taking along a small book called Rome Reconstructed available throughout Rome. It has detailed color renderings of most all the existing ruins and utilizes a system of transparent overlays with each that allows readers to quickly see what they looked like in their heyday. For 14 euros, we found this book an indispensable aid for our ruin-viewing.

The Imperial Forum is Rome is another historical wonder!. Walking around the Forum - one can just visualize events of many centuries ago. The walks are mostly easy, with some climbing - but the remains of another time are fascinating!

It's the Forum People!. How can you go to Rome and not go to the Forum? If you are a fan of Hollywood epics about Roman history you must see the Forum, and if you are just a fan of history, you must see the Forum! In the heart of a modern city is the vast expanse of history that makes you feel a million miles and many centuries away from present day.

Get your camera ready!. We loved our afternoon wandering around at the Roman Forum. Your mind can't help wondering what it was like to live in Rome when the Roman Forum was a happening place to be! Our entry was free with entry into the Colosseum.

Photographer's dream. Not having much awareness of this place before visiting Rome, I was delighted to explore the many ruins and grand structures throughout it. Free to enter and adjacent to the Colosseum, it's a must-do when in Rome. A lot to see and very photogenic.

worth the time and effort. Immersed in history and people. Get a map and wonder around. You can spend the whole day on the 3-part ticket for fori+palatino+colosseo. There are several fountains so do not worry about running out of water, it's heavy to carry... keep it to last till the next water stop.

Full of History!. Wear some good shoes and water. The area is quite complex and large. A lot of the area is full of ruins, so it helps to research ahead of time to help imagine the complex as it was in the past. Takes a few hours to see it all.

Toured this with Palatine Hill and the Colosseum.... We had a package tour of this along with Palatine Hill and the Roman Colosseum. It was so well worth it just because of the knowledge gained and the fact that you're walking where so many ancient Romans did.

Amazing step back in time. A visit to Rome is not complete without a walk about the Forum. It's a good stop on the way to or from the Colleseum. At the entrance you will need to show the inside of your bag to security - not a thorough look through to be sure. There are inclines and uneven pavement so good walking shoes (for my daughter and I our adidas) are helpful. We visited with a guide and so got a great overview of what the area looked like once upon a time leading up to now. It really is amazing - the history, architecture that survives -- truly awe inspiring. My son, who is a history and mythology buff, really enjoyed seeing the structures he's only heard about til now. Take a peek at the location where Caesar was cremated (people still leave coins and flowers) and be sure to admire the view from above as well as in the midst of the ruins. Terrific photo ops. On a sunny summer day it can be brutal, so if you've got a water bottle bring it -- you can refill it -- and take your time perusing. What's the great rush anyway?
Stroll around the forum?. A stroll around the forum, in May with poppies nestling in amongst the grass and ruins is a sight not to be missed. Get above it...the views below are fabulous.
Must-see. This is so much a part of Western civilization and culture, it must be seen. If you can take your time and hike around, it's great, but even a short visit is a must.

Wonderful historical area. I loved walking through this wonderful historical area. The monuments and remaining structures were interesting and I am glad I had the opportunity to see a piece of history.
Bring your Walking Shoes!. Definitely worth taking the time to wander through the Forum. Amazing ruins. Some significant slopes to maneuver.

A vast complex...tough on a hot day. We got the coliseum and Roman forum multipass. The forum is an immensely vast area with ruins all over to enjoy. We went on one of the hotter days of the year and without too much water, which was a mistake. Some of the ruins require a good amount of imagination to enjoy. Others ruins are better, like the arch when you enter (from the coliseum side). To illustrate how huge the area is, for some paths there are 'easy', 'medium' and 'hard' paths! If you are going with small kids...good luck as they are likely to be tired quickly!
Historic. Not the most beautiful view but interesting nonetheless. Can;t miss the experience of seeing such an ancient structure.

So much history . So much to see- overwhelming
We bought the audio guide but felt there was too much info on the guide so we gave up and read the signs which were very informative
Amazing to think we were in the sabe place that so many famous Romans has walked
Great place to visit but almost too much to take in!

great roman ruin to see. What a great place to see. unexpected pleasure after climbing up palatine hill opposite collosium.
It was very hot that day, so welcome stroll around these old stones was just the ticket, very relaxing place full of history.
best to do collosium/palentine hill/roman forum in morning,before all crowds visit and you can look round in some comfort

Travel back in time with the ruins of Ancient Rome . The place is amazing, definitely to be visited. One useful trick is not to stay in a long line from the side of Colosseum, but to go from the other side and enter the Palatine hill first, there were no lines there and we saved a good amount of time, and from palatine hill you will first observe Roman Forum from the top and then go down and see the ruins closely.
Center of history . The Roman forum was the center of the ancient city of Rome, you can still see how it would have been, and get a feel for the size. Worth seeing.

Just Incredible. We have been to Rome 3 times & each time we visit the Roman Forum there is more that has been excavated...it is just incredible to see this area...you just look at it in awe....how did the Roman's have the know how & materials to build these magnificent structures....a must to visit....

a special monument. if someone visits Rome, he has to visit Roman Forum. it is an old small ancient village in the heart of Rome with many monuments, rocks and statues. Every point in that Ancient forum has a small sign which informs you for each one of these monuments.

Wonderfuly Grand. you can enter the ground level of the site with the same ticket for the colosseum. At the same time, one can enjoy the site from contemporary ground level with no tickets. Its always a good idea to be there before sunset to enjoy day and night lighting.

Something new to see around every corner. On a previous visit to Rome, I walked past the Forum on the way from one landmark to another. The ruins look pretty spectacular from a distance, but I didn't really know what I was looking at from the side of the road. This visit was different - I hired an audio guide and followed the guide map given and was entranced with the sights and descriptions for the next 3 hours! Over 50 identified buildings / artefacts along the way, all with a narration as well as summary message boards in place, really bring this old commercial and political centre of Rome to life. Highly recommended - with access to the Capitoline Hill and the museum included in the price of €12 - as well as entrance to the Colosseum; this is brilliant value. The ticket is even valid over 2 days - so you can split your visit accordingly!

Breathtaking . If you love history you will love this. I did not even like history for a long time, but it was seeing history up close and personal that changed my mind. The history here is beyond belief. You are walking were Peter and Paul walked when imprisoned. You saw where they were jailed. You walked where the Emperors of Rome walked. I recommend getting a good tour guide. We were fortunate and had one who brought it all to life. I highly recommend seeing the Roman Forum and be amazed.

A must visit. This is very beautiful and price-worthy area, like traveling back in time to the beautiful roman kingdom! It shall not be rushed true, pick a day which is not too rainy and just relax, take your time and admire the beautiful surrounding - both the great achitectural buildings and the nature

Ancient Rome Politics. Remarkably well preserved forum where you can see the remains of temples and other buildings of state, including the senate as well as the place where the body of Julius Caesar was burnt. Essential for ancient roman history buffs.

The Forum - Palatino. One of the main attractions of Rome, to be visited together with the Colosseum (they're 10 mins walk apart). Some dodgy cobbles to be aware of - they won't be much shade on a hot summer day - plenty of history to absorb.

Be sure to visit Santa Maria Antigua Church. The current admission fee to the Forum is €12, which includes the Forum, Palatine Hill, the Santa Maria Antigua Church, which is open until October 30, 2016, as well as the Colosseum. The ticket is good for 2 consecutive days, but you have to visit the Forum, Santa Maria Antigua Church and Palatine Hill at the same time. You can visit the Colosseum the next day. It is more expedient to purchase your entrance ticket at the Forum. The ticket lines at the Colosseum are very, very long and there is a separate line for those who already have their ticket, which is shorter.The Roman Forum is fascinating. I would suggest renting the audio guide or at least having a very good guidebook and map. Unfortunately, the Senate House has been closed for some time now. I don't know why or when it will reopen.Maria Santa Antigua Church has not been open to the general public for over 30 years. It is located at the foot of the Palatine Hill. It will be open until October 30, 2016. This is a "must see." The church was damaged by an earthquake in 847 A.D. and has recently undergone extensive restoration. There is a very informative audio presentation depicting the history of the church and its renovations. The frescoes are incredible.On Palatine Hill, in addition to the archaeological ruins is a small museum, which is worth visiting. When we were there, the House of Livia, unfortunately was closed. It is always "hit or miss" as to what is open and closed. The museum was closed when we were there in January 2016.

Wonderful place but..... Lovely place. Really regretted not having a guided tour tho. Not many information signs up, and the audio tour wanted to take and hold my driving licence or passport til I gave the device back. Not on your nelly. Will def go back, but with a guided tour

Extensive area to explore. This area is Large. We used a one hour Steve Rick's audio for starters but then realized it left out many areas. We continued to explore for another hour or more and still did not see all areas.

Impressive!. They sell you a two-day ticket for the Colosseum and the Roman Forum but you cannot visit them twice so beware! You are allowed only one entry only! Start with the Colosseum in the morning, go out for lunch then you will have the whole afternoon to enjoy the Roman Forum. You will need it as it is vast and so interesting! Go to the museum as that is where some of the statues are and other artifacts.
Average. It's not worth paying for the ticket to see it from close range because the idea of a forum disappears. Just look at it from a distance.

A Must See!. This was my whole family's favorite site to visit. We listened to Rick Steves' downloaded audioguide on our phones and walked through every part of the Forum. The history of the place is phenomenal. We loved it! As for practical considerations, the paving stones of the Via Sacre are very uneven and can be hard of anyone with knee troubles. The dust can fly up at any moment and get in your eyes, so be aware. There is a clean water fountain for refilling water bottles. If you are in Rome, this site is a must see.

If you can't feel, smell and taste..... ....history in the Forum then you need to check your pulse. Buy one of the overlay books that show "then and now" and use it as a constant reference book. Do not allow your self to be rushed when visiting this birthplace of civilization. We had the pleasure of spending six full hours exploring the forum, not counting the Colosseum , Circus Maximus or any of the nearby museums. It still wasn't enough time. Have a seat on the remains of a bench or the steps of the temple, closure eyes and go back in time. The ghost of all of the great Roman emperors and historical figures are alive and well in the forum. It was a spiritual experience from a historical perspective. Breathtaking and magnificent. To think of all who have walked those paths and grounds.....

How you imagine old Rome to look. Best visited after the Colosseum.
After going through the entrance, turn left at the arch, head up the hill and look for a passage through the wall on the left. Follow the path over the grass to a viewing platform overlooking the whole Colloseum

Superb but take your time. As we walked around there was more and more to discover, with the highlight being a view of the whole area from the top of the Palatine hill. Each part of the forum had a fascinating story, although we did find the audio guide tried the attention span of our children a little bit.It can get hot and dusty so you might want to take a few breaks, but it is well worth exploring - a great complement to the Colosseum.

Save your money and imagine from outside. You can walk amongst the large stones, gaze at the columns and arches that remain from a metre away and imagine how it might have looked when there were temples and buildings there.OR, you can not spend 12 euros, view it from a distance in its entirety and imagine the same thing.I just dont see the point - thousands of tourists taking the same dull photos to bore their family and friends with, wandering aimlessly around reading about how it might have been 2 thousand years ago - or with a guide whose accent is so thick you can barely understand them barking out centuries and vaguely familiar names at you.It is impressive, I get it - but it is just as impressive for free from a distance.

Great place but not outstanding among others. I am not saying this is not a good landmark in Rome, but right after Colosseum and other landmarks. Kids just felt tired and we walked through very quick. Not very impressive. Maybe should have spent a little more time. This is still a place you need to see but just below par comparing to others.
Amazing. Filled with history ! but you should walk about an hour or one and a half to see the full site ! but it's worth every step

An amazing site. I'm only giving this 4 stars, rather than 5, because the headset tour, or whatever it's called, doesn't make it abundantly clear as to where your attention should be drawn, in so far as it often becoming clear, as I was listening to the narrative, that I was looking in the wrong direction. I was always standing in the right spot, as they are numbered on a map you are given to accompany the tour, however the cues were a bit lacking. The narrative was otherwise good, and indeed the area, what is left of it, still left a great deal to fuel the imagination. Indeed you can never truly see through your mind's eye what was actually there, however the narration and ruins do help you to piece together some of the missing architecture. Some reviewers suggest a tour guide would have been better, which I think we will try when we return later this month.
What a site !!!. This site really gives you an impression of the size and splendor that was ancient Rome and shows just how advanced the Roman empire was.

Fascinating collection of antiquities, very nicely presented. If you decide ahead of time to not hire a guide, be prepared for very high pressure and misleading tactics from the hordes of guides who'd love to take your money. We decided we didn't want a guide, and we stuck to our decision. We found that the information posted throughout the Forum was very helpful and adequate. There were a few things that we wanted more detail about - easily looked up later in our hotel (or immediately on our cell phones). If you want a guide, by all means hire one. I'm just saying that we liked being able to go at our own pace through the site (we spent 3 hours, plus another one at the Colosseum).

take your time there is a lot to see. Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum are unbelieveable places to visit. There are temples, houses, shops and triumphal arches from all different eras. The area is massive and you should spend at least a day there. We entered via Palatine Hill and the crowds were not as big; our mistake was we visited as part of a Coliseum tour when we should have done this separately.

Fantastic visit. Thoroughly enjoyed visiting The Roman Forum, such an interesting and important part of history. We bought the joint Colosseum, Forum and Palatine Hill ticket at the entrance to the Forum, which saved time at the Colosseum. There are information boards at the archaeological remains, so you can learn about the history without a guided tour.
Great start to a day of Roman hostory. Get a guided tour- not much info to be gained via sporadic signs. I would start on this side- and then go to the "newer" side.

what to say, one of the wonders of the world!. the Roman forum is a voyage of discovery. It is much better to do the tour with a guide or study a bit before going otherwise it won't say much. But with some help it could be one of the most rewarding experiences for a traveller: to have a glimpse into the life of the Romans

A Rome Must-See.. I think it would be impossible to take in everything about the Forum unless you spent hours there. Our tour with Walks of Italy of the Colosseum, Palatine Hill, and Forum was a great overview of all the highlights.

History around around. Definitely worth seeing and listening to a tour as you walk through history here. We downloaded the free Rick Steves tour and it served us well. Watch out for the guys selling water and trying to change the price on you once they hand it to you. Hand it back and they will honor the original price to make the sale. Buy the skip the line combo tickets.

Full of Roman History. Another very great place to visit for any body interested in Roman history! My advice would be to visit this place with a guide who will help in explaining the different structures and their interrelationship.
Very impressive. The forum is very impressive, and had helpful signs all over with information for tourists - but a tour guide would have been even better!

Go early and skip the audio guide. The forum is all you expect.We went first thing in the morning and faced no queue for tickets. We bought the multi pass and went to the Colusseum after the Forum.We had purchased the audio guide and tried it but found we were just happy wandering the entire site and reading the available information. This is not a 1 or 2 hour visit if you want cover the site properly so set aside a good part of your day with the advantage being that if you start early morning you can then join the security queue (long) at the Colusseum by mid afternoon.When we got back to the central area of the Forum early afternoon the crowds were massive compared to what we had enjoyed in the morning. Remember rule number 1 for popular tourist sites - go early.

The heart of Ancient Rome. The Forum was the heart of Roman politics and religion, so to come to Rome for a trip to take in the history of Rome without spending time at the Forum would be an unthinkable thing to do. Situated on the Palatine Hill, the Forum's ticket is included with the ticket for the Colosseum nearby, and is valid for 48 hours from purchase. If you buy the Roma Pass, entry will be free provided you make this location one of your first for visiting. If you want to simply take the scenery in at your own pace, simply make your own way around the site in order to take in the sights and read the information panels that are placed around the area. A tour is useful for finding out additional bits of information (for example, which Pope decided to try and claim a part of one of the temples!) that would otherwise be overlooked on information panels. The biggest thing to be aware of however is that this site has limited shade, and limited toilets too. Bring plenty of water if the temperatures are high. If travelling with children, be aware that this area is extremely open, meaning care should be taken to avoid overexposure to the sun. To those who have studied the history of Rome, you will be transported back in time; whilst sitting there it was easy to envisage Romans visiting the site, and honestly quite an amazing thing to behold.

Best of the trio sites. Take your time exploring the area and be taken back two centuries to the ancient Rome city. The Roman Forum was our favourite site during our one week stay in Italy and if we were to visit the forum again, would definitely take an audio guide.  We spent nearly two hours here, had the weather been nicer, we could have spent over three hours exploring the forum area. Note: If you plan to go the Colosseum, Roman Forman and Palatine Hills remember three things; i. Roman Forum and Palatine Hills count as one entry if using the Roma Pass, ii. if you get the combo ticket for all three sites it is valid for 2 days, and iii. do not get combo ticket from the Colosseum due to the much longer queue.We started at the Roman Forum and because we had a Roma Pass, did not need to queue (there was a queue of about 50 waiting to get tickets and a family of four in the reserved ticket queue); we went straight through to where the security guard is standing. If you need to purchase tickets, get them from the Palatine entrance, when we were leaving from the Palatine side, people were getting tickets without having to wait. When we went to the Colosseum, even with a Roma Pass we had to queue 30 minutes to get through the queue outside and go through all the security checks. If one does not have the Roma Pass or the combo ticket, the queue at the Colosseum for purchasing tickets was longer.

Amazing site. Reading the history of this on the signs and listening to Rick Steves' walking tour gives one a lot of insight into how and why these structures were built. Note - walking on the large, uneven paving stones can be very difficult and tiring.
A trip back in time. Must-see place in Rome with lots of history to take in. Get's extremely warm in summer, so get there early in the morning.

A Trip Back in Time!. This place is great and certainly a lot more interesting than I was expecting! it's well laid out and a lot bigger than you would have imagined. it's a great way to spend a few hours wandering about and getting a feel for what Rome used to be like. Add it to your visit to the Colossem for the full effect!

Massive in size, takes hours to walk around. The ticket for the Colosseum includes the entrance to Roman Forum. It has 3 entrances at least what I saw. It is very big, Took me 2,5 hours to walk around even with my long legs and speedy walk and I skipped many parts as well. So be prepared. Nice ruins everywhere. Because of the time you spend here the lack of toilets was a let down.
Just do it!. Included in the ticket price for the Colosseum, you should pack a snack and head to the forum/palatine hill area. There are great locations to stop and have a snack among the ruins.

Wonderful step back in time. Its like being transported back in time 2000 years. Best get there early or late afternoon to avoid the crowds. If you don't want a guide it costs 12 euro pp for Colosseum - Palantine hill and Roman Forum

A must see with the Colosseum!. The Roman Forum may seem at first just a gathering of old bricks and ruins, but it holds much more to that and is worth a visit with the Colosseum next to it! I would suggest to take your time, as I have seen hoards of tourists just running around and they were missing what the Forum was all about: Reflection. The Forum is a marvel of engineering where the time has opened up entire basement and building's profile of many stories high allowing the visitors to imagine how living there must have been. The Forum was not only a commercial hub but a political and religious center where many great events and decisions were made. If you walk all the way to the back, you will also discover where the Palace of the Emperor was built and some gardens and mosaiques are still in good condition. I'd advise to read about it, watch documentaries and movie/series (Gladiator, Rome, etc.) before visiting Rome and the energy of the sites will come to life!

Stunning! So much more then we expected!. When we realised that entry to Palatine Hill and The Roman Forum were included with our Colosseum ticket, we weren't really expecting all that much. We couldn't have been more wrong. This in my opinion was THE highlight of our trip to Rome and I'm not 100% sure that we managed to see everything. The site is huge, and I would recommend that you set aside a very large chunk of a day to fully appreciate it. The history just surrounds you everywhere you go, and you really can imagine the full scale of what was once there. Every time you turn a corner you come across something new, and the views across the Form as you come down from Platine Hill are truly stunning.

Forum. gotta see this place! Amazing to think that people uncovered the buildings and structures that were built so many years ago. Hope that the city and country of Italy can keep the beauty alive for many more years to come.

Never gets old.....yes pun intended . Every trip we come here. This time there was a fabulous exhibition on which I believe is open until September (best check). We do colosseum on same 12 euro ticket .... Tip, buy it at the forum entrance as much smaller queue.Toilets in the middle and self bars for drinks inside. Pretty special place!
Stunning . Amazing site with lots to see. Arch of Titus, Palatino Museum, etc etc. Needs more than one visit to take it all in. Little shade so bring water and sunblock!

Fascinating Site. Steeped in history, each point of interest is explained in detail as you wander around although a good guide book would be a bonus, so much to see even though I couldn't find the spot where Caeser was stabbed. Be sure to bring a bottle or two of water, and if you need refreshment, there are a couple of hard to find areas with vending machines which stock snacks and drinks.

Wow, incredible site to just sit and think of history..... The site is significantly larger than I had ever dreamed and was just breath-taking. We just took our time strolling the grounds and thinking about how much history is there in the site. Spectacular without a doubt. Give yourself at least 90 minutes to tour the area.

Guided Tours will show you how it would have looked. Took a coliseum tour that also walked through the forum with a guide with a book showing the recreated buildings back when they were new. Loved the vestal virgins home.
Hire a Guide. Ended up loving the forum. Best part of it was catching the fun little tidbits of information from other people's tour guides. Learn from me--hire a guide.
This should be better protected. Interesting and should be better protected. People can just walk all over and desecrate history. Even some of the shops are used to house vending machines.

hubbys surprise birthday treat. how can you put into words something so awesome, its outstanding, its beautiful and its worth going to rome just to see it, cant wait to go back and do it all a bit more leisurely

A window to the past.... This is simply the most incredible historical site that I have ever visited.The ruins of the capital city of the Roman empire are so telling about how the ancient Romans lived. Even just looking at how long these structures have survived is a bit much to comprehend! We bought a combination ticket to the colosseum and the forum before we left for Rome and boy are we glad we did! By 10am the queues were astronomical! I would highly recommend to pre purchase the 'skip the line' tickets. Waiting in the queue we passed would certainly sap the fun out of the day. We just had to take our print out receipt straight to the desk.I did find once we were inside that the signage was pretty none existent. If you are interested to learn about the site I would recommend buying a detailed guide book and taking it inside with you. I wish I had done. A must visit in Rome, this was really the highlight of my trip. It truly is like stepping back in time.

Amazing to take in!. We had glanced at books, that had what would have been there. Wish we would have bought one. 1/2 day does not do it justice if you want to take in each portion of the city. We were too tired to do a tour group, but I would definitely spend the money next time with a tour or at a minimum audio tour. Its breath taking to know the details!
A great piece of histry. While it doesn't get a lot of promotion this is a very interesting site with great history. Probably best taken with a good guide but demonstrates some great roman history.

Large and Dusty. It's included in your Colosseum ticket so take a 30 min stroll among the ruins and use your imagination to see where commerce and politics took place in the ancient world. IF crunched for time, then no worries skipping it. You can google the history and fun facts!

Best to take a our here. The ruins are interesting, but without the background stories, they really do not do it justice. You can often get a complementary tour with the guide company from the Colosseum, but shop around, some guides are great, others are not.

Spectacular!. This is a spectacular feature from Rome's past. While the city has ruins around every corner this is its best with buildings, arches and inscriptions all on one huge excavated site. You will be amazed and your camera will be overheating. You simply cannot miss this wonderful site.

Most people go, but be warned: there really isn't much there. This place is packed with guides and tour groups, but unfortunately there is very little to see- it's all ruins!. Other than the Arch of Titus, the best thing about this place is that you are standing where Caesar did. For authentic ruins, try Pompeii. To see Romans used to have in their homes, the very excellent and oft-ignored https://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g187791-d190989-Reviews-Museo_Nazionale_Romano_Palazzo_Massimo_alle_Terme-Rome_Lazio.html
Part of Colosseum visit. This was included in the Colosseum ticket and was excellent value for money and very interesting, we spent the whole day visiting both and also Palatine Hill.
way bigger than you think. this was part of the coliseum ticket and ,if I had to do it over, I would see them separate days as this site is so huge and complex you cannot do it justice in 1/2 day
The forum. Another excellent attraction. Need again to walk around without a guide as you need time to take in the whole place. When you realise what went on here you really appreciate it.
Immerse yourself deep in history.... The original forum of the world - first ever democratic scene of the world. Fantastic history with amazing architecture. I never wanted to come out....

All roads lead to..... The centre of the Empire. Although so much has been lost there is still so much to see! Two Triumphal Arches, temple ruins, where the Senate met... For any student of Roman History this is a "must see".
Great . Take water and take your time with a leisurely stroll around the Forum before heading to the Colosseum. Splendid views from the Palatine too.
Amazing . The forum with all its ancient structures is a must for history buffs, Trejan's column is outstanding.
Beautiful ancient architecture and a must see.. Beautiful ancient architecture and a must see if you are visiting Rome. Be prepare to do some walking.

Amazing to ponder what it must have been like. The Forum has not been fully restored so it's possible to see the state of ruin it currently holds. Bring sunscreen as there is no shade inside the grounds. You can view some of the Forum grounds from the top of the Vittoriano (Wedding Cake monument) on Piazza Venezia if you take the elevator up to the top (nominal fee but short line).

The History!!!. This according to me was the best attraction is Rome. Especially so if some one is interested in History. You can take hours to explore every nook and corner. The ancient places of worships, the church of Santa Maria, Palantine Hill, the numerous ruins of houses and Augustus residence. These are just a few things. The exhibit and the short presentation with lights and projector in Santa Maria is great and tells a very interesting story of early Christianity. The panoramic view of the entire place from the top of Santa Maria is beautiful. If you take the exit near the palantine hill then just before the exit there is a great place which gives a good view of the colosseum.
The History. This is a must see,please go with a tour guide as this helps a lot,and make sure you have comfortable shoes on,as i found out the hard way,
Walk Amongst History. Amazing how close you are able to get to such historic structures. I had no idea of the magnitude of this area, foolishly thinking it was just one structure.
Worthwhile -spectacular site. Huge site - use a good guide to help focus your trip. Find a quiet spot and just sit and be present and take in the whole setting.

Probably need a guided tour to fully appreciate. To be fair, we were very tired after a long day of sightseeing, but we didn't really enjoy the Roman Forum as much as we had hoped. It was great to see some of the incredible ruins, but we would have benefited from a guided tour to help us.
Its nice. I spent an hour or so walking through the Forum and it really does have some good old fashion Roman History. If your looking for the History of Rome this is a good place to start.
The Forum. We loved the Forum it was huge! it covered a lot of ground and we both have bad knees & backs. we just took our time plenty of benches & garden area's to stop for a rest :)
Stroll around Ancient Rome..... This is a must of a visit on a dry day. Immense open air museum...take a guide book with you or join a walking tour to get the best out of it.
very interesting area. we did this tour with a guide and found it very interesting. This is a large area and there are plenty of steps and very little shade so go prepared

Guided tour of the roman forum. Brilliant. Took a guided tour of the forum, its an amazing place, but to know what its really like you need to take the tour and they will explain everything. The guide was friendly and knowledgable. The forum itself is pretty much just ruins but you can see how impressive it must have been so many years ago. Definitely one of the places to see in rome and right next to the colluseum amongst other things.

Captivating trip in history. I would suggest downloading Rick Steve's audio guide, or renting an audio guide, so you can tour the forum at your own pace. It's easiest to buy the combo ticket for the Palatine Hill and Colosseum at the Forum's ticket desk to avoid the longer Colosseum lines. The history of the Roman Forum is absolutely incredible! Bring your own water and snacks though on a hot day!

Crowded but WOW!. Roman forum is one of the highlights of Roma. All the ancient sights and poles with the view from Palatine ( and the fact, that there is one ticket to Roman forum, Colloseum and Palatine) make Roman forum full of people.
Historical place, a pearl. We loved this place with its parks etc. A wonder they still are quit good in condition after 2000 years...

Spectacular!. This was a fantastic site, but it took us a while to get our heads round it. We paid for an audio guide but soon packed in with that as the numbering of the points of interest did not flow in a logical order and the handset was difficult to use. So don't bother with this as it is a waste of money. However our guide book came into its own and we used this as a basis for our tour in the end. Between the guide book and the information boards we worked out everything we needed to know / see and really enjoyed our visit. An amazing site with real historical interest.

Landmark. Along with the Palatine hill the Forum is also in the same complex. Once a marketplace the pillars that remain are huge and impressive. One can spend the entire day here going through the excavated ruins and imagine the bustle of the place eons ago. The place is well maintained with the history written on placards.
Great Archicture. We had another beautiful day lots of people walked around it sapped up the atmosphere.I liked the architecture of the place.Took lots of pictures.

very interesting. The forum is huge offering some breath-taking views of Rome. We did this on our own but I would recommend doing a tour with this as the knowledge the guide would provide would definitely be of benefit
A trip to the past. Rome is full of archaeological wonders, you trip over pieces of history when you walk down the street. The forum offers an amazing view of the past
Great time. Forum Romanum really took our breath away. There is just so much history and beauty around that it would be such a shame not to walk around. With a guid or not, definitely worth to visit

Unreal. The Forum was the seat of all government of the Roman Empire. Religion, commerce, and government were all run from the Forum. Hard to believe that Caesar, Nero, and the lot ruled from this location. The ruins are amazing to look at and know that they were build 2000 years ago.
Stepping Back in History. Have your walking shoes on and be ready to be transported back in time. You can picture yourself as a Roman Senator or just a plain citizen.

Wow!!!. So beautiful!! So impressive!!! Strolling in the heart of old Rome with beautiful well preserved arches, monuments..... Such a beautiful experience!!! Just splendid day in the footsteps of Ceasar!! Very close to the colosseum! Actually they sell you a ticket for both!! And it is very close to the rose garden and the piazza Venezia!! You can easily spend half a day strolling in the Roman Forum!! A must on any visit to Rome!!

Don't Miss the Roman Forum!!!. The Roman Forum area contains so much more than just the Forum. Around it are the ruins of ancient temples, the commerce market, justice buildings, and triumphant arches that were in use from 509 BC to 476 AD. Once you have seen the area by walking around it, you can and should make a point of seeing ariel views of the forum area from Palatine Hill and Capitoline Hill. These views are breathtaking.
Ancient Rome fantastic. Brilliant. I would recommend a good audio guide or book rather than a tour so you can appreciate the forum at your own pace.

Amazing to think of what went on here. As with the Palatine Hill visit book this one together with the Colosseum tour to avoid queueing. This is such an amazing sight and the sheer size of how this used to be takes your breath away. Make sure you look at everything, don't miss a thing.

Important Roman history, best done with a tour. Get the full Rome experience - buy a combined Colosseum-Palatine-Forum tour package and learn about the founding of modern civilisations. Can be very hot in summer so be careful!

Enjoy the details. Make sure that you have lots of time to walk around leisurely, to enjoy the flora as well as remnants. Do not rush to just take a photo with the panorama of the city in the background, do stand there for a couple of minutes and watch the light and the shadows, observe people milling around below, look at the sky, and you will really feel Rome.

Hard work. The site itself is fine.However.Rome is not a big subscriber to the concept of signage, and the Roman Forum (and palatine Hill) are no exception! The scale of which this site is, is immense - watching it on TV documentaries does not do it justice at all. Just be aware that working out how to get out at the end can be frustrating with incorrect translations/directions on the 1 sign in the place!Highly recommend booking your tickets online, and getting the ticket that covers all 3 sites as is the same price as just to get into the Colosseum.

Definitely worth seeing. If you're visiting Rome you will no doubt be visiting the Colosseum, why not walk a few extra meters and visit the Roman Forum too. There is just so much history which takes your breath away. I would thoroughly recommend everyone taking the time to visit this remarkable site. If you can, book a tour too!

No need to pay admission. My opinion most likely will not be a popular one, but my advice to any traveler headed to Rome is to not actually pay to go into the Roman Forum. Instead, head up along the road Via dei Fori Imperiali and take Via di San Pierto in Carcere to over look the who Roman Forum. Unless you want to read every plaque or every info board, this will be a great view (for free) of the entire area and provide you a GREAT photo spot of the Roman Forum and the Colosseum. You'll want to stand next to the Acro di Settimino Servro for the best pictures!
Highly recommend this. This tour can be purchased when you buy your Colosseum/Forum/Palatine Hill tickets (buy the combined ticket). It's really awesome.
Wonderful.. Truly wonderful to see, but make sure you take drinks with you as there is nowhere to buy any and such a large area takes a long time to explore, worth going.
Historical. Included in a guided tour with Palantine Hill and Coliseum, Worth seeing and hearing about, an amazing 3 hour tour.

archaeologica site. Well worth buying a ticket combined with colosseum, if you're interested in history. Fantastic work going on to restore parts of this significant site. Tip! Take a photo of the description beside the the ruin your are photographing.
Amazing. Perfect walk for those, keen on ancient history - full of ancient relics - every stone and part of a building has historical value. Hers, you are fully in the ancient atmosphere.

Roman forum by night. After dinner in Indian restaurant nearby we bumped into a audio video show happening at 9 pm, it was showing history of temple and forum built by Augustus , it was great to know the history with very good visuals, it cost 15 euro for adult And 10 for kid above 6, they should have kept free for kids as my 8 year old son was not too keen. Nonetheless he enjoyed visuals .. Highly highly recommendable to view this at night.

Historic heaven. Again we did an audio tour which really brought it to life - so much to see here. Amazing to think how the Romans built on top of buildings on buildings raising the level of the land. Definitely worth visiting.

You have to - your in Rome. Obviously a big part of Rome is the history, so would be crazy not to visit the Forum. Private guides will take you through a back entrance - included in price of Colosseum ticket.
Amazing. Our American guide, Mat, told us we were standing on the third level of what was a 5-storey building and they were still finding the lower floors

Dont Bother. There are far better sights to see in Rome than this its basically just ruins of government buildings, we went as part of a pre-booked tour but personally i would not recommend especially if you have young children its really not worth the entry fee.
Wonderful. You can feel the history as you walk around. Amazing value for money when booked with the colosseum and palatino

Lovely walk through ancient ruins. The forum is a must see for a trip to Rome. It's much more helpful to either walk through with a guide that can explain the area/temples or spend some time in advance reading about the forum. We found it crowded on the weekend so returned on a weekday for a better experience.

The most important place in Rome according to me. If you like Roman history and their architecture, this is the most important place for your in Rome. It takes few hours so plan well before entering the place. Also ensure that the camera batteries are fully charged. There are so many photos to be taken and still you will not be satisfied. The Roman Temples are highlights here.

If you like ruins and Roman history, you'll love the Forum. Lots of ruins which tell the story of ancient civilization in Rome. My suggestion is to get a tour guide, as it's often difficult to tell what each of the ruins were in Ancient Rome.There are ancient marbles walkways, that you almost imagine Julius Caesar walking on as he strolled through the city. Columns, busts, marble, all shapes and sizes of ruins I. This rectangular area called the Roman Forum.The Main Street is called Via Sacra and runs through the middle of the Forum. The Forum is in the same ticket that you purchase for the Colosseum, so it's a good deal. Wear comfortable walking shoes. Not handicap friendly since the walkway is uneven

Great experience on Roman history and archaelogy. Make sure to wear good quality shoes/boots when venturing to the Forum. To make the most of the forum, you should give yourself atleast 6 hours to explore at leisure. We purchased the ticket from the forum (currently Eur 12) which is valid for 2 days and is valid for both the Forum and the Colosseum. (We visited the Colosseum on day 2, and since we already had the tickets, the queue was much shorter)..

Standing the test of time. Incredible to believe how the structures here and the history just stays alive! As you stand looking down on the ruins you can't help but imagine all the Romans and servants walking and trading here! A must see place when in Rome

It's A-mazing!. Wow loved it! There is so much to see. Do an audio tour to really understand what you are seeing, or have a really good guide book. Once inside it was very difficult to find the exits as excavation is still ongoing. Felt like a rat in a maze, an amazing maze but literally couldn't find the exit for a hour and we weren't the only ones.

Wonderful visit. Had the opportunity to join a tour of the Roman Forum and this allowed us to get a great insight into the history of the attraction. Highly recommended visit while in Rome. Be a bit wary of the exits as they're not marked clearly.
Beautiful gardens. Stunning forum and gardens. A lot of work is currently being carried out. Only able to walk on directed paths and little opportunities to sit and rest or picnic.

Walk Amongst the Ghosts. Few places are as good for getting to really see how people used to live, over a period of thousands of years. Ruins and structures have been used and reused many times and can now be examined from a modern perspective.
Lots of history but.... Yes there is lots of history but as it's mostly fallen down you have to imagine how it was when it was in daily use.

Value for money!!. Don't even bother going to the Colosseum - it's really overrated. Go to the forum instead - an incredible place!! So much history - cannot believe the size of the aqueducts which are still standing!

Long weekend in Rome. Joined with the Palatine Hill so you only have to queue the once. This can be seen for free from the road but there is so much more to see inside. Was very crowded but not enough to restrict your access to any part of it. Definitely one of Rome's must sees.
Quaint. This area is located right beside the Colosseum, it is full of ancient structures and you can almost visualise the ancient community which once lived here if you pay close attention.

Large are full of Roman ruins. Beautiful to see. I was a bit annoyed with street vendors selling trinkets and being quite insistent (some of them don't take no for an answer and keep harassing you even if you say no). Otherwise good for photos

Old and beautiful!. We observed the Roman Forum from above with a guide and she explained what we were looking at in this huge venue. It is a spectacular view but way too much to comprehend without someone with experience explaining what you are looking at. So, that being said get a guide or it just looks like a large field with old pillars and ancient remains. It was free and amazing and I am glad I saw it!
Beautiful place. Dont miss the Palatine Hill. Buy your ticket from Roman Forum or Palatine Hill entrance. The area is huge. and so much history. Must take the tour with a guide.
Interesting history and recommend with a guide. Ruins have a lot of history. Lot of walking downhill and uphill. The flowers if in bloom give a lot of colour.

Ancient Rome try to image it here. I wanted to image Cleopatra in the forum! Or Marc Anthony.. and even Brutus! They were all here, even stripped of the marble for other uses in other times... this is timeless
Should have downloaded an audio guide.. A bit much to navigate without guidance. Should have downloaded an audio guide in advance. Worthwhile.

Great piece of history. We were lucky to get in without standing in line. This place is huge and you could spend here hours or even a day just wandering around, enjoying the view and taking pictures. Amazing what people created so many years ago.

A hot day but worth it.. Dont miss this place, get a guided tour and meander round some spectacular ruins of ancient Rome.
**tip** wear trainers or good walking shoes as the surfaces are terrible and poorly maintained. Which the people who look after this brilliant place would do well to address.

I would pay twice as much to see it again. I would suggest doing this with a tour guide. I think without the tour, you may miss some of the wonderful things this ancient area has to offer. I used Through Eternity, and it actually rained on us most of the tour. Don't fret, just make sure to carry an umbrella or rain jacket just in case. There is so much history in this tiny space all the way down to the way the stone road was made - The Sacred Way- and to any Latin student, you know this name! Book a tour and make sure to see this if nothing else! The package deal for a tour includes the forum, the palantine hills, and the colosseum. Mine was around 40 euro, lasted 3.5 hours, and was definitely worth the money! My only disappointment was that we didn't spend a longer amount of time inside the forum.

Fantastic . Loved the roman forum. This was part of the same ticket price for the Colosseum. Sooooo big probably didn't see everything but walked around for hours lots of steps so make sure you have water but you can fill your bottle up at the designated water fountains.
Beautiful walk through this area.. A lot to see. you can walk along ruins and a park. You can visit a chapel and climb the stairs to a viewpoint.

Fantastic place bursting with history. We went round with an organised tour with Italy With Us and the experience was not to be missed. The ruins were very well preserved and it wasn't too crowded. Water fountains were inside so allowing us to survive the afternoon heat. Unique place, recommended.

historical. This is a must see on your trip to Rome. Close to the Colosseum, you walk up Palatine Hill. Magnificent ruins of the old senate buildings and archways to view. Book in advance to avoid the queues.
Roman Forum. You have no idea how big these places are. Truly amazing fetes of architecture. Marble is awesome to see.
Take your time. Really: plan plenty of time for this... walk around, soak in the history, appreciate the views.... We only had a few hours and this wasnt enough which was a pity

A must see.. Get areal feel for ancient Rome. There is a lot to see and most of it boggles the mind. The information posted on the ruins and in the Forum is pretty hopeless so get a decent guidebook. This seems to be common on Italian historic sites, just a jumble of ruins with little to tell you what they were or looked like. I'd avoid the guided tours, the ones we saw were huge and gave no time to stand and ponder.Get there early and take sunscreen and water, there is no shade or facilities inside the Forum.

Private guide worth it at twice the price. We hires Ilara using Rick Steeve's travel guide. She was of immense help in having us picture what the forum looked like at its peak. It is a most imposing place. Three buildings remain mostly intCt because they where turned into Christian churches. The scale of the temple of Venus and one of the basilicas is most impressive. Don't miss this world Treasues!
Viewing History. When you visit Rome seeing the Forum is a must. Though most is ruins, pictures help one visualize what it must have looked like at its peak.

Craze-Amazing. Been here twice, and still can't soak in all the history. As with the Colosseum, do yourself a favor and download the Rick Steves App with walking tours (download the tours before you leave your hotel) and get this walking tour. It is free, and it makes this experience so much better than walking without any idea of the history and stories to be told.

History. Took this in as part of a guided tour of the Colosseum and Palantine Hill and i would encourage anyone to do the same as it just helps bring the place to life!You'll find a few places to refill your water bottles too which is great!

Outstanding. This was by far the highlight of my visit. It is massive and you could easily spend a day here watching the world go by. Take water and snacks as once you are in there are no cafes. It is worth exploring every inch, so much to see from different aspects. Don't miss it.
Full of History. Gives an idea of how well this was built - leaves you wondering how it was completed. There is a lot of restoration going on but still worth visiting.

OK but Heaps of Steps. Probably after doing the Colosseum it was too much for us to tackle more steps and climbing hills. We did go there but didn't spend time exploring the area. If you are young and energetic you would enjoy it but we are both late 60's and not fit.

Gotta see but use Rick steve's podcast (free) go at your own connivence!. This place was a crowed nightmare when we visited. It was Sunday (stupid) and went on a tour. City tours (dark Rome is the old name)I believe. Started out badly. Long line just to checkin for tour. Divided us in groups of 25 and off we went, along with hundreds of their other groups. This is at 10. It was worse the Disneyland. We figured out , go before 10 or after 1. That's when the tour ends along with all the others. (Starts at 3 again) people are eating lunch too. The crowds diminished quite a bit after these tours left. What I'm saying is these tours create massive crowds. We still waited to get in too. Mainly do to security checks. These places are worth visiting for sure but head out in less popular hours and download Rick Steve's pod cast for all the sites in Rome. He does a great job and it's free!

a big step back in history. The Roman forum is accessible with a combo ticket at 12€ with the palatin and the colosseum. the story of this place through the ages is very interresting, but take a guide or at least an audio-guide otherwise you will see only old stones. Free the first sunday of the month.

Not to be missed. You should join a walking tour that includes this location. It will not be meaningful unless you have someone who can set the stage of what you are looking at because it is awesome. If you aren't in Rome for the antiquities you can skip this. This gives a good idea of what life was like during the apex of Rome.

Historical wonder. Do tour of this location with the Colleseum. History on top of history, see how the ancient Romans built on top of other sites and layered history. Walk on roads built before Christ and used by Caesar. See temples to the gods, emperors and imagine ancient life in this focal point of society. Wear good walking shoes as the ground is uneven and would be very slippery in wet weather .

An awesome site in the centre of Rome.. If you plan to take in the ancient history of Rome then I would say that the Forum is a must. It is a huge site filled with ancient roman ruins that give you a sense of the scale of Ancient Rome. It is perfect for a leisurely walk round on a wonderful sunny day, taking in the history. I think they do audio guides and I would say it would be worth having one as there is not a lot of information around about the Forum.Normally it is about 12 Euro for access to the Forum, ColosseumAnd Palatine Hill, which I think is great value for three sites and you could easily spend a day wondering around them. On the first Sunday of every month these attractions are free, making it even better value. They crowds do not normally start descending on the sites until about 11, so I would recommend getting there early so the sites are quieter.Another tip is that the forum and Palatine Hill shut earlier than the Colosseum. When I visited visitors were stopped from entering the Forum at about 2.15, compared to 6.15 at the Colosseum.
