So to avoid disappointment I would suggest seeing these two sites first and saving the Colosseum until last.I had a great time here and would recommend it to anyone.

Fascinating historical site - Forum/Palatine Hill area. We saw as part of our coliseum ticket, not sure if there is a forum-only option. Cannot evaluate cost./value. We stayed in a hotel in the ancient city area, so were able to walk to the Forum/Palatine Hill area during some free time one afternoon. We wandered at our own pace and enjoyed it. Unfortunately the signage along palatine area isn't very helpful - gives some information but I felt I was lacking the background story. I had downloaded a 'Rick Steves' chapter but it was just Forum area so I didn't bother. The whole complex is huge and has a great deal of beauty. Lots of wild flowers in spring and great photo ops. If there is a brochure or guidebook at the ticket booth I would suggest grabbing one because otherwise you can spend some time not exactly sure what you are seeing. But worth the visit regardless.

Wow. There is a lot to take in here and make sure you have flat comfortable shoes on for this. There can be long queues here so look to get a ticket that can hep you jump the queues. There are a number of signs around the Forum to help give you information about all the buildings that are here

The history, the history!. You can't walk through Rome without seeing historical sites. The Forum Romanum is certainly one of the highlights and we were lucky enough to see it during daylight as well as at night (that one weekend where it is lit up). Also, having a knowledgable and friendly tour guide makes this experience even more interesting.
By Night. Much more interesting than the Trevi Fountain. Definitely worth taking time to see and particularly impressive at night. Projected light show an added bonus.

The forum meeting place,Rome. I started early and did the Forum,Palatine hill and Colloseum in one day although the ticket allows 2 days.Well signposted and a guide is not needed.For access.see my review titled "Hose of Augustus" for special advice.Its amazing that 2,000 years have passed and that these sites have survived whilst other fantastic sites have vanished.Its all open air so theres no shelter from rain and take water as theres little offered.An amazing view of how the Romans organised public spaces and well worth the visit.

Amazing . Right next to the coliseum and included in that ticket purchase. Definitely worth seeing as the history and beauty is incredible. This and the coliseum are my number one favorite sights in Rome.
Incredible . Amazing Roman ruins, wonderfully well preserved. Roma bella Roma. A stone throw away from the Colosseum and Palatine hill
Just do it. Incredible. If you like history it is marvellous. If you don't to is still remarkable. Such a lot left and they really built big and high 2000 years ago.

One of our favourites. This was one of our favourites attractions to visit in Rome - really large area so you didn't feel so crowded like the colosseum. Tip - enter via the side gate away from the Colosseum for a quicker entry

Good. A good all day activity
Didn't make it round to see everything as we left to go to the Colosseum but everything we saw was amazing
Lots and lots of walking but is a great thing to see

Lot of walking We. We spent the whole afternoon in the Forum and the Hill lovely views from the top but a lot of steps but plenty to see can see the circus maximus from the top probably the bet place to see it from
Top visitor attraction. If you go nowhere else in Rome go here as it is the centre of past Rome. Even if you are not a history buff you will still enjoy the scale and beauty of the Forum.

More pillars than they know what to do with. In any other place the masonry on the floor would be in a display case. Here there are stacks of masonry lying about. They have enough to do keeping their existing stuff upright. The task is never ending. Well worth a visit and a great way to spend half a day with a camera on a sunny day.

Not as impressive as the Agora in Athens!. i was looking forward to seeing this area more even than the Colosseum, I must admit to being a bit disappointed by the amount that is there. The atmosphere (and remains) are not on a par with either the Agora in Athens or Beth Shean in Israel.

Extremely interesting. We toured this using a guide which made it so much more interesting, when you think of the history in front of you, it is just amazing. You can do it on your own, but try a guide to get more out of the experience.

Ancient Ruins. Something to definitely visit while in Rome. Not really much to see or do -- it's just a broken down weather beaten, historic structure. Not even that nice looking. But, a FAMOUS must see if in the city.

Don't go to Rome and miss the Forum. The ancient Roman forum is a must for anyone who enjoys history. It is a wonderful feeling to walk down the streets that Caesar walked on. Some of the ruins are in better condition than others but all give you a look into what it must have been like in its heyday.
Another city landmark. Again, walked around it. Did not enter the Forum. It was nice to see from the outside. Didn't visit the Forum due to time and other priorities.

Fantastic!!!!!. When we entered it looked like very little was there but as you walk to the main area it is magnificent. So much history in one place and you get a real feel for life there
Wish we had been on a guided tour as probably would have learnt more. Not too bothered as will be back in Rome again

If you have even a passing interest in the history of ancient Rome, you must see this.. The heart and soul of ancient Rome, this site is a fascinating excursion into the past. One can begin to sense the grandeur and terrible majesty of this ancient kingdom that played such an important role in the formation of western civilization.

Part of our Ancient Rome Tour. We took a 3-hour private "Ancient Rome" tour that included the Colosseum followed by walking through the Roman Forum, etc. The ruins are all very close and we liked having a guide help us get around and explain what we were seeing. Not sure I would do this part again if it were no part of a comprehensive tour, but packaged together it was easy and interesting.
Step back in time ... Fantastic experience to visit the forum. You can see it from thecoutsidecwithoit paying but we paid to go in in ( about 12 euros) and its well worth it. Such history !
first visit. Still using Federica Dal Palu of Miles & MIles Tour, we spent good time wandering the Roman Forum with her excellent explanations of what we were walking through.

This place is shocking. Take a guided tour if you know nothing about history. If you do, just walk through, making frequent stops. Take pictures. What's a Roman forum? Think of a shopping mall. Now add a theatre and a couple of temples. And some pretty, eye-candy type, architecture. This is where "they" hung out. Pick a sunny day and walk leisurely.

Must See. Don't dismiss these ruins just because they're not as famous as the Colosseum. Get into a guided tour (There are tons outside and it would be best to combine a Colosseum tour with this- a lot of guides give a discount if you take them both for that) There are so many interesting facts and remains about the lifestyle of the Romans.

The ruins of ancient Roman life. The Forum was the meeting place of Roman life. Here, you'll find the ruins of courthouses, arches, temples to ancient gods and basilicas. It's near the Palatine and Capitoline Hills, and the Colosseum.
interesting. historic site, beautiful views, picture worthy sites, lots of walking, overall worth a trip to it ! we visited the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum in one day.
nice. very beautiful. did it in morning when quiet and was peaceful and historic. would highly recommend doing with colosseum.

Need a good guide . We took a tour guided by an archaeologist so we were able to fully appreciate the history of the area. Looks like a bunch of old ruins but when you know the history and use your imagination. It can be a dramatic setting. Invest in a guided tour for the ruins.

must visit once in Rome. This place is full of history and makes you wonder about life 2000 years ago. Amazing structures. Buy ticket online to avoid the queue, pick the como deal for Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatino. Check on the ticket but is should be valid for 2 days (but one entry only).
WOW. Beautiful, full of history. great views. I had no concept of how big it was. Really enjoyed visiting here; could have stayed longer. So much to see, so little time!
So much history. There is so much history to take when when walking through the forum, one can almost imagine what Rome was like when it was the center of Empire.

Awesome Experience . This was one of the coolest places. Lots of photo shots. Lots of walking so bring your walking shoes.. takes at least 3-4hours. Tons of things too see. I would suggest going in a group tour. This way you won't miss anything.. so much to see..

Heading back here. This is history. Along with the Palatine hill this gives you an idea of the strength and power of ancient Rome. Will be going back here to have another wander on a fine day as it is just so much to take in.

Doable and yet missable. The Roman Forum was the main square of Rome for many many years, specially during Julius Caesar's dictatorship. This place is now in ruins, but you can still see some columns, and ex-pagan temples (now churches) dotting the perimeter. You might enjoy it, imaging the Romans walking about, discussing stuff in the square. Equally, you might not find anything interesting about this place. If you are an architecture student or an artist, there is a lot to keep you busy. Oh, and Julius Caesar wasn't killed here. Apparently, he was killed elsewhere and his body was brought here for the Romans to see. All in all, glad I did it, but now that I have, I know that if I hadn't I wouldn't have missed a lot.
Amazing Site. It's view is really give you the ideal of Roman life style and have to visit. Have to walk little, but the views are worth
25th Anniversary. Another must see if your exploring the coliseum. We had an excellent tour guide that was very knowledgeable of this area.

nice long walk,although more info needed along the way.. this was a great place to walk since during the mornings not many people gather here. the walk however,could be more interesting if there were more signs about each ruin seen,. in order to have more info.

Our mistake was to do it on our own - sure wish we had more time and a knowledgeable guide.. We had been taken to an overlook into the area of the Forum and heard a bit about it during our organized Italy tour. We returned another day on our own, not realizing the scope of all that was in the area, nor with sufficient time to see it all. We got to see Trajan's Market and the remains of some of the forums but know that there was MUCH more to it all and would have loved to have been guided through the area by an expert. If we get back to Rome we will definitely return and expect to spend much more time there.

Beautiful ruins. It was a lovely sunny day when we visited - so much to see and very close to The Colosseum. The ruins are just beautiful and they are set amongst wonderful trees, flowers and foliage. Along the main pedestrianised area there are lots of street performers too. An entertaining few hours spent here.

Not What We Imagined. This is located in the vicinity of the Colosseum and consists of ruins of numerous buildings. We had always been under the impression that it was one building. Even though it consists of ruins, it is still a very impressive site.
Amazing Views. A lovely place to visit, magnificent views and plenty to see. We visited the Forum on a warm day and got to see quite a lot.
Spectacular . The views from up on Palatine Hill are just amazing and the buildings of the forum are just staggering.
Unmissable. We spent from 10:30 to 18:00 here (and the Palatine and Colosseum) and could have spent longer. Note that the ticket allows entry on two consecutive days. Great value!
Roman culture. If you want to know about the roman culture just visit this place.. its superb.. you can watch movie inside about it...

so beautiful don't miss it!. The Roman forum is absolutely stunning. we had a beautiful day for it which made it even better. It wasn't expensive and there was so much to see. didn't get a guide but I didn't think we needed one. definitely do this if you are in Rome!

Beautiful!!!!. Such a beautiful place, so many lovely photos were taken during our walk around.
The weather was amazing which made the walk so much nicer but wouldn't have stopped if it rained!
The history about the Roman forum is so interesting, a must see during your visit!

Allow yourself some time. We visited the Roman Forum on a hop on hop off bus tour . It cost us €12 to do both the Froum and the Coloseum - inexpensive and fabulous. We recommend you allow yourself a good 2 + hours here as there is much to take in and of course there is lots of walking so comfortable shoes a real necessity. Also take some water as there is no where we saw that had this available.

Walk In The Steps Of Ceasar. The Roman Forum was the centre of life in Rome It is best to take one of the guided tours other wise your looking at stones and ruins with no idea of their history. You get to walk in the footsteps of history to stand in the same place where the funeral of Julius Ceasar was held over 2000 years ago was a fantastic experience I will never forget

So much history, no signs. Unless you are an absolute expert on roman history I would recommend a tour of the Roman Forum as there are virtually no signs in the forum. Apart from that however it is a beautiful walk through history.
Great set of ruins. Roman Forum came with Colosseum tickets, interesting but wouldn't spend more than one hour. Was on limited time

Okay but not spectacular . One of those sites you've heard so much about but there is very little left hence little to see. If you're in the area give it a look but not something I'd go out of my way for.
So very interesting. A lot of walking but worth every step. After our tour you could almost feel what it must be like to have lived during that time

Imagination required. So little left - largely ruins. Might be best to review artist drawings before seeing the Forum in person. Yet, we had a good sense of the history and historical importance of the Forum, and so it did not disappointed. Suggest doing the Coleseum 1st.

Make sure you find your way to the Forum!. What can one say...it's the forum. Walking the streets where Rome was ROME. Seeing where they cremated Caesar. It is so amazing. Give yourself time to soak all in.
Relaxing. As the forum is spread over a large area. We found it a relaxing area away from the hustle and bustle off the Colosseum area. Museum is a plus and very interesting.

Awesome on a sunny day. Really enjoyed this! No need really to get an audio guide as there is lots of information on signs all about. Recommend walking up the Palatine Hilll - gorgeous views to be seen, and walking to the section of the forum behind the hill. It's much quieter there. Do mind the uneven pavement though - can be very slippy and muddy after a shower.
A must. There's so much to see but it was well worth going to see ,I would recommend going to see this it was a very hot day when we went so take a hat
History. What a wonderfull piece of History.Get a combined ticket with the visit of Monte Palatino ! Both activities must be done if you're in Roma !

great place with baby/children. with my 3-years-old baby , we were happy here. she loved here, ran, jump, smelt flowers etc. You should go there , if you want to say that I see all the things in Rome.
Amazing view. Incredible to look at! Quick tip - if you walk round the side of the forum, there is a hill you can walk up for a much better view - without any people in the way!
great photo op. I must have taken 100 pictures walking through this area, very interesting, a bit too many people for my liking, maybe try to go early in morning to avoid crowds.

A must visit attraction. Gives an insight into the early roman life. Whatever is left is so grand and majestic that it is hard to imagine what the actual place would have been!!! The huge columns and partly visible domes leaves one wondering how the people then would have created such masterpieces. Spend atleast 3 to 4 hours to explore each and every corner of the huge place.
Step back in history. Walking through the Roman Forum instantly takes you back in time. A wonder to see on your trip to Rome.
Forum Romanum. This is the definite place where civilization took a big step forward in history. Architecture and Art overwhelming
Brilliant. By far the best place to visit in Rome. Many hours were spent walking through the streets and imagining the past.....a must see!!

A MUST SEE - BUT a guide is important. This is a wonderful historical site but it really helps to go through with a guide who can not only give you the basic history but the stories that go with the history.

Awe-inspiring!!!. I would definitely visit again. I had an absolutely amazing time visiting the site. I joined a tour when I arrived at the site which turned out to be an inspired choice. Makaila was the best tour guide of the trip for me (I had 3 different ones for different experiences).

Lovers of history, rejoice! . Whenever I'm in Rome, I will come here! I love it, it's littered with history! If you, like me, love to "absorbe" history and let your imagination fill in the details in the ruins around you then you could easily pass half a day here. Take a bottle of water with you, refill it from the water taps provided within, and you're set. Of course, I have given this 5* but I've heard a guy say while perusing the ruins "so basically guys, Rome is just a bunch of rocks"- so I guess he'd be a 1*!
Roman History. Part of the complex of roman ruins near the coliseum. very interesting and a must see while in rome.

Walking Tour Made History Come Alive!. We loved the small group walking tour we did before we went into the Colosseum. It was well worth the expense as we had a very knowledgeable guide who brought it all to life.
Roman Forum. Never knew this existed before actually arriving in Rome. Again a must see. It does cost to enter but well worth it.
marvellous. Well worth a few hours exploring and being amazed at the history of Ancient Rome. There is a great museum too which helps you understand how it evolved.

What a sight!. Loved it! Leave yourself a good few hours to do this attraction justice. We took the audio which was good but best to pick out particular parts you want to know more about. Great views from the top. Stayed there ages!

Crowds, Crowds. This was the last part of our tour where we had also done the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. Again very interesting and loads of history(obviously!), but very busy, personally I preferred the views of it from Palatine Hill, but it is another thing you have to do when in Rome. Also as it the last part of three and a half hour tour in temperatures nudging 90 degrees, think everyone's minds were beginning to wonder a bit. But definitely worth a visit.

Find your own way around.. The Italians don't do good tourist signs . We are used to idiot proof signs for designated trails which are not present here. We spent about 2hours finding our own way and enjoying the history.If you have purchased a Combi ticket make sure to join the line for security on the right side going up to the Forum entrance. Some made the walk up and were turned away to rejoin at the bottom. Some hawkers present , the best was a local selling frozen water in bottles for 1 Euro. You do need liquid with you if its warm.
A must see. One of the few things that's free, but I recommend the audio guide to get more out of it. Very expensive. Wish people would not talk during the viewing, they are so rude

Roman life. not far from the colosseum and well worth a visit.As you walk around you can imagine life in roman times as when you read about the area you can imagine people shopping just as they do now

Awesome!. Was really impressed with the sheer size of this place! Really takes you back in time to an era that is wonderfully preserved. Must see! The line without reservations was about 1hr...not bad.
Strange one. This bit of Rome was a bit of a strange one for me. It's made up of loads of different things. Theres a great deal of fragmented history to be had here. Worth a visit but take a guide

My personal favourite in Rome. Walking down from Palatine hill leads you directly into the Roman Forum. It has to be one of the best tours in Rome. The builidings and temples are out of this world. Such an eye opener to see with your own eyes how the Romans lived all those thousands of years ago. Hard work for anyone with limited mobility or wheelchairs but worth every bit of effort.

Cassells. This is a very large area with some steep climbs but it is well worth a visit, especially for those with an interest in history. It took us six hours to cover the location, and even then more time could profitably be given to it. The audio-visual facility could do with a better system indicating the direction to the next information point. Visitors should bring a water bottle to fill at the many water fountains from which cold refreshing water can be obtained free of charge - a visit to the Forum can be a thirsty one, especially in hot weather. All-in-all an excellent visitor experience.

FRom here the world was governed. Coming down from Palatine Hill one is left with a feeling of absolute awe that two thousand years ago the world was governed from here and the great men like Julius and Augustus Ceasar and Nero walked these same paths and byways. Coming from a country barely 200 years old the mind just boggled

Make a night time visit to the Forum and surrounds. We got a little lost heading back to the Apartment after dinner and found ourselves wandering past the Forum just after dark. The lighting and various laser light shows on the buildings are magnificent and every bit as good as a day time visit
You can feel the history. You need to be able to imagine the buildings in their past form. Than you will be able to see, how great builders the Romans were...
Wonderful place + incredible temporary exhibition! . Wow, you could wander for hours and still discover new places. The temporary exhibition of S. Maria Antiqua church is amazing! Do not miss it!

nice place for a pleasant walk. Peaceful place filled with residues the remains of the ancient Romans life. It is worth to go there for a nice walk among the tall, old trees and loud but relaxing sounds of ubiquitous cicadas. Beautiful views guaranteed! You can purchase a ticket to the Colloseum, which also includes an entrance to the Forum.

part of the Colosseum tour. not recommended for those who have difficulty climbing or walking
You really need a tour guide to appreciate the site

Amazing. Get an audio guide.
Comfy shoes .....cool clothes (temp not fashion).
It's amazing how complete the huge pillars and some walls are.
We paid 12euros each which included entry to the hill (palatine) and the Coloseum. (Great que jumper). Toilets are great xx
Wow. This in an amazing place, hard to believe Romans were able to do all this without the technology we have today. Prebook your visit

Lovely day out . If the sun is shining this is a brilliant way to spend a few hours. However as it is completely open I would not recommend it in the rain. Would be a nice idea to take some food or a picnic to save rushing around to make it for lunch. We purchased tickets here for the joint colleseum visor which saved some time and student discount is also accepted.

Ruins of a world empire. When Rome was the centre of the world many hundreds of years ago, the centre of Rome was the Forum. Just about everything took place within the Forum. It's a place filled with history, although much of it is very degraded. The place has its charm... as you walk around you can easily imagine how things were hundreds of years ago.

Wander of with your thoughts into ancient Rome.... The "Foro Romano" is a combined visit (paid entrance a 12 euro's) together with the Colosseum and Pallatine Hill. In retrospect, the Colosseum is much more impressive but i wouldn't have wanted to miss this either because it is believe that Julius Cesar is burried here and that is just one of the impressive locations there. All incredible place where you can let your feelings wander off and think about tha past.....In my eyes; a must see on your to-do list.
its a must. one package with the koloseum which is the must visited place. near from the koloseum, very easy to find

Beautiful place. Visited the forum after the Colosseum and was lucky enough to have an amazing tour guide. I learned a lot of interesting information today. (Who knew that the Romans had central heating and air con? Or the history of the word salary?!)There's not technically a lot to do, but the scenery is amazing. It's incredibly serene and peaceful. We didn't want to leave! When you are in the middle of the forum and sitting on one of the many benches, looking at the statues and surrounding rocks, you can't help but feel like you have jumped back in time 2000 years.

Roman forum with a 12 euro ticket . Really worth a look - get guided with the audio guide as I had no idea what I was looking at and the guide map they gave you does not correlate to the audio numbers scattered around. Lots of potholes to fall over so be careful - it's a long walk up to the top for the more elderly of us but there is a drinking water fountain at the top so take you water bottles to re fill - the museum at the top was ok but the film was boring and lacked any information. Toilets were a blessing - the views from the top where amazing and worth the extra walking
Disappointing. Having a combined ticket with entrance to the Colisseum, meant we made the visit. More could be made of the site, information boards very helpful.

So interesting. Along with palatine hill this is probably my favorite of all the attractions, there's not a fantastic amount of information along the way so a good guide is essential to get the best out of your visit.

Stunning beautiful and eery.. We spent nearly 6 hours here and only left because it was closing. SO much history to take in and it's utterly fascinating. Would thoroughly recommend dedicating a whole day to visiting this place.

The Ruins of Ancient Rome!. Roman Forum is a site where we witnessed ruins of Ancient Rome. There is no point roaming around the Roman Forum without a Guide that walks you though the chapters of History books!
Beautiful and full of history. We saw this as part of a tour and was glad we did so we could get all the history on what we were looking at. It's amazing and an absolute must see when in Rome.
Good site to visit. You are given a great understanding of how the old marketplace was in ancient Rome by visiting this site

Civilization's Birthplace. You MUST visit the Roman Forum the precursor of today;s Senate
Remains of the marble covered buildings gives one an image of the real glory of Rome thousands of years ago.

Beautiful. Lovely place to walk around, beauitiful buildings eg remains of ancient temples combined with pretty flowers and a relaxing atmosphere. Full of history and wonderful views. Highly recommend, one of my favourite places in Rome. Get there early to avoid crowds. Entry included ion ticket to Colosseum so very good value and very close to Colosseum
Beautiful. Wonderful insight into ancient times, and found much more interestim than the colosseum. Buy your pass here first to skip lines at colosseum.

A must for every tourist. The Roman Forum and surrounding areas are the centerpiece of tourism in Rome and compete directly with the Vatican as a visitors' attraction. Arranged as an irregular rectangle, the Forum limits with the Campidoglio in the Nortwest, the Colosseum to the Southeast and the Circo massimo in the Southwest. There is ongoing archeological exploration o=in all these areas, so the place keeps changing. From NorthWest to Southeast, you will visit the Fontana della Rea Roma, the palazzo Senatorio, the Tabularium, Carcere mamertino, the Septimus Severus Arch, the Templo di cesare, the Tempio dei Dioscuri, the Antiquarium Forense, the Arco di Costantino, ending at the Colosseum. There are many other important archeological findiongs in this very large area, so plan at least 3-4 hours for your first visit: you will likely return several times, especially if you are a history fan. This large area is open and the Roman sun can be powerful. make sure you wear sunscreen and a hat and carry water or other beverages with you. There are no commercial entities inside the archaeological park, so whatever you need, carry it with you. You need to buy tickets at the neighboring museum, which you should visit anyway, since it provides a great overview of the site and the history of Rome.

A must in a trip to Rome. After the Colosseum and Palatine Hill nothing would surprise me. Surprise !! Amazing site that reminds what mankind can build and destroy on its own. Worth reading about before you visit or consider taking a proper tour.
Worth a visit . There is lots to see in here it could take up most of your day. Wear suitable footwear as you will do lots of walking and will go up quite a few stairs.

Oh how I wish I had more time here. This was part of a Viator colosseum tour and although we had plenty of time here as part of that, if I go back to Rome and I hope I do this is where I would love to spend more time. This is so impressive and once you understand the way the Romans built on top of other buildings over many centuries it becomes even more impressive. It is a great site and well worth a visit

Ancient ruins amongst modern buildings. I will never tire of walking through this slice of ancient history. It is so refreshing to be able to walk touch and explore something that has been here for so long Too often are we cut off or made to see from a distance those things that take our breath away. I love to be able to touch something that has a completely different culture from generations ago its like being allowed to breathe it all in. Take your time and imagine what went on hundreds of years ago. A place not to be missed,in fact all of Rome is amazing, put it on your bucket list.

Don't miss the Forum when in Rome. I had no idea how awe-inspiring the Forum would be. Literally the center of the ancient world. Here is where the Roman Empire began. We had trouble with the AV handheld tour deviced we rented on site (plus they were filthy - recommend bringing wet wipes for all of these devices when visiting). Difficult to follow the numbers referenced, though it may have been user error. We gave up and managed quite well with the (free) Rick Steves audio tour I had downloaded to my phone in advance. Because this is such a large, important site, I'd use a private or small group guide next time. Don't miss the recently excavated 6th century Santa Maria Antiqua Church. Beautiful restoration project. April was a good time to come - not too hot. Good idea to review your Roman history before coming!

An absolute must if you are interested in history.. Visit with a guide to understand the layout and the history. To walk through the centre of the capital of the Roman Empire is an incredible experience
Interesting . It is an interesting place where you need to use your imagination as there are a lot of ruins (to be expected). Do your homework before you go so as you know what your looking at

Ruins ruins ruins. Yes this is Rome and ruins are everywhere but I believe some explanations if in the map or on the way would help.Or you need a good preparation or take a guide if not look at it from outside.

Amazing Remains of Ancient Rome built 2000 years ago!. The Roman Forum, the remains of Ancient Rome built 2000 years ago! Ancient Rome's showpiece centre, a grandiose district of temples, basilicas and vibrant public spaces. The site, which was originally an Etruscan burial ground, was first developed in the 7th century BC, growing over time to become the social, political and commercial hub of the Roman empire. Citizens of ancient Rome referred to this space, originally a marketplace, as the Forum Magnum, or simply the Forum.It was for centuries the center of Roman public life: the site of triumphal processions and elections; the venue for public speeches, criminal trials, and gladiatorial matches; and the nucleus of commercial affairs. Here statues and monuments commemorated the city's great men. The teeming heart of ancient Rome, it has been called the most celebrated meeting place in the world.Located in the small valley between the Palatine and Capitoline Hills, the Forum today is a sprawling ruin of architectural fragments and intermittent archaeological excavations attracting 4.5 million sightseers yearly.Many of the oldest and most important structures of the ancient city were located on or near the Forum. The Roman kingdom's earliest shrines and temples were located on the southeastern edge. These included the ancient former royal residence, the Regia (8th century BC), and the Temple of Vesta (7th century BC), as well as the surrounding complex of the Vestal Virgins.

Really great place to spend the morning. This place is immense. Not too crowded and rather inexpensive to visit. Admission is included with the Coliseum. There was a line up to get in due to security check but once in, you can wander around the area filled with ruins and imagine what it would be like there 2000 years ago. It wasn't crowded so you can go at your own pace and take some nice pictures.

Center of Rome for 10 centries. The Roman Forum served as the focal point for civil and economic life in Rome centuries ago; yet one can still walk along and admire these majestic remains. Again, this is another "must see" when visiting Rome.
The Forum!. Seeing this all in person was absolutely amazing. With so much history, I highly recommend a tour guide.

A unexpected bonus when visiting the Colesseum. Thought we would just spend an hour visiting the Colosseum and low and behold ending up spending most of the day next door exploring ancient Rome as well. And this is exactly what the Roman Forum is, you can spend hours here just walking around and admiring the ancient buildings and statues from an period in history that is long gone. We visited many of the attractions in Rome over the 7 days we were there (in fact we ticked virtually everything off our to do list) and this was one of my favorite sites. The bonus is that the entry fee to the Colosseum also includes entry into the Roman Forum (which is a very short walk away). An absolute must to see in my humble opinion.

So fascinating . Loved getting to stand in such historic locations. So fascinsting to see all of the forum in person.Lovely place for photos, with many places to stop and enjoy the sights significance.

Budget a while to see the site. There was so much here. We took a guided tour with Rome Tours, which was wonderful. But we just didn't have enough time because our kids pooped out. The Forum is kind of boring for kids, I think (confirmed by my 13-year old) - the Colosseum is so much more engaging for them. The Forum is fascinating for adults, but it definitely takes 2-3 hours to really start to get the lay of the land, and longer to delve deeper.

Huge site! Expect to spend some time here. I thought this was a great place to visit, a ton of ruins all kept together in one location--it gives you a great idea of what ancient Rome looked like. I bought a ticket for this in conjunction with the Colosseum thinking we could do both in one day. We probably spend 4.5 hours in the forum alone wandering around looking at it all. If you timed it right you probably could do both but it would be challenging and we ended up splitting them up across two days
Amazing. We took part in a tour of the forum and Colusseum which was very informative. Amazing to walk through part of Ancient Rome and get a taste of what life was like back then.

spectacular relic of history. I was really unlucky during my previous trip to Roma as the site was shut down around 4pm just as I was about to enter! I saw people being ushered out as I walked towards the entrance and I had to give this site a miss. I was able to visit the site this time with my mom and it was like walking among giants to see such a huge historical treasure kept intact right inside a busy city like Rome. It's got quite a lot of uneven steps so do tread carefully when on site!

Fantastic maze of treasures. 2-3 hours of great scenery and intricate moments.. What a great place to walk around, could get hot in the summer but worth a few hours to wander around and take in different views around Rome as well as genuine historic interest (even for those not big on history).
Roman History. the roman forum is like going back into history. we visited this area and the Pallantine Hill with a private tour guide. Well worth.
wonderful. so much history beneath your feet and all around you. It is amazing these things are still standing in 2016! Don't miss this.

Huge playground. This is really enormously large site and deserves longer time for visiting it. It offers a lot for adults imagination as well as for the kids (to play hide and seek :-) It is unbelievable what the Romans were able to build more than 2000 years ago! Highly recommend!

Roman Market Place. Before coming to this place, i though these will be ruins of roman empire. But once i entered and went to the main areas of it, i understood how big it is and how beautiful as well. Its almost 400 years old, but some of the places still have that feeling of Roman. Beautiful architecture and builds design. You can still see the original old marble in some places. Try going to the hanging garden as well, the view from it is breath taking and amazing. Pack some food and plenty of water, you are going to need it. If you like History and Culture you are going to spend an entire afternoon on this.
Another highlight of the city. Hard to say what's the best place in Rome but I love the history here. I always enjoy touring here and of course Palatine Hill

Lovely day, lovely site. We were in the colosseum and heard a guide say the queue at Via Gregoriana entrance of the forum near the buses was much shorter so entered there and he was quite right! We hired the audio guide which really helps to make sense of it all! It was a beautiful day and just a pleasure to be on the Palatine Hill amidst the trees and flowers. Some wonderful views of Rome. You will need water and a snack if you are planning to see the Colosseum and the Forum immediately afterwards.

Ancient Roman ruins close to Colosseum. I visited this important Historic site in May 2016. I used a 3 Day Roma Pass that I purchased on line before my vacation to Rome. The Roma Pass allows 3 day travel on transport inclusive of fast track entry to 2 Museums/Historic sites. The Colosseum and Roman Forum count as one site and can be visited over 48 hours. I visited the Colosseum and Forum over the Monday and Tuesday. The Roma Pass counted these two historic sites as one item. The Colosseum can easily take up a couple of hours and more of observation, the forum also can easily take at least 2 to 3 hours and more of observation. Palatine hill within the forum, the area of the Empirical palaces is located within the historic Forum area. The Roman Forum is surounded by the ruins of several Roman government buildings of ancient historic importance. It was the centre of Roman Public life for centuries. The location is between Palatine Hill and Capitoline Hill. Some of the Roman empires earliest shrines and temples were located on or near the Forum. The temple of Vesta and surounding complex of Vestal Virgins. The Shrine of Vulcan, the Republic of Romes formal Comitium, the birth place of the Roman Senate and Republican Government. Many important buildings overtime were constructed around this area. There are 8 granite columns remaining of the temple of Saturn, an important temple that doubled as the state treasury. Behind this temple are the ruins of the temple of Concord, temple of Vespasian and Titus. The Porticus Deorum Consentium (Portico of the Harmonious Gods) located at the bottom of the ancient Roman road that leads up to the Capitol i. Rome and to the Temple of Jupiter at its summit.

Historical delight. You definitely need a tour guide to understand about the Forum. We had Rosetta from Rome your Way Tours who made it come alive you could virtually see the people walking around when you listened to her quite amazing
Amazing. A must to see and with a guide it is even better (you can skip the horribly long queue). Make sure you are wearing a hat during summer, easy to get burnt :)
Great preservation of old Roman ruins. This place simply reminds you of history, and amazes you to see how they must have built such beautiful structures in an organised forum.

Amazing but you'll need a tour guide . The forum is astounding, or more appropriately it was astounding. There is still plenty left that will impress. But to bring it to life you'll need a tour guide. As they can elaborate on the ruins as there is no diagrams or pictures on the various monuments showing you what they looked like. Long walk over hilly terrain not suitable for anyone with disabilities

Absolutely breathtaking. You will need a couple of hours for the Forum but do not miss it. Just walk along the paths and soak up the atmosphere, the feeling of being able to spend the time where the citizens of Ancient Rome used to spend their time is surreal and amazing. A truly wonderful experience.

Historic. Came here as part of the Colosseum Tour. It's a beautiful and ancient area that is well preserve. Also great location for picture taking. You learn so much history here. Be prepared for a lot of waking. At this entrance you can also submit your vouchers from the hop on hop off Bus to get your time ticket for the Colosseum. Go early as it does get crowded. Also wear comfortable shoes and hat! Went during the summer time and it was hot.

Rome holiday. Very interesting and beautiful ancient monuments. It feels like you're taking a journey through the history walking by these amazing ruins. There's so much to see and it's definitely a must see place in Rome

A must visit place while in Rome. Amazing place to visit all ruins are there but amazed to see how these were made without machinery and equipment . really hats off to craftsman and especially the labour or slaves who carried those stones and made HUGE marvels .
Foro Palatin Colosseu. Combined ticket to all 3 attractions. the Foro, the tempels, and tito arc with all the history behind them you must not skip it.

Great experience. The ruins were very interesting and there were many signs with history and additional information. I would recommend that you buy a ticket for entry into both the Colosseum and the Roman Forum. We spent almost the whole day just visiting these two along with Palatine hill. I have given a four because, personally, I didn't enjoy this part as much as the Colosseum or Palatine Hill.

Ancient Rome in all its spendor. Interesting to see right around the corner from the Piazza Venezia. Not as large as I thought and only some of it remains. Lots of tourists all around trying to snap photos.

Very, very cool. This is a really cool attraction. It is pretty big and is a lot of walking but worth it. You can see the remnants of many old buildings from thousands of years ago. There are helpful plaques throughout with information about what you are seeing, but sometimes it is confusing what they are describing. A map probably would have been helpful. The front gate advertised a free app that you can download to help guide you through (we did not know until we got there so did not have it) that I think would have been helpful. We did not do a tour or the audio guide and got though fine.Also, there are water fountains throughout the forum that are really nice to fill water bottles up with! Also! When you buy a ticket for the forum at the gate, it includes entrance to the Colosseum as well. There was almost no line when we went to the forum and entered from the North side. There is an entrance on the East side as well, near the Colosseum but we found the line to be long there when we left. It was nice to not have to wait at the Colosseum where there was a longer line (though you have to wait in the security line regardless.)
Huge and immense.... We loved seeing the old Roman ruins. I'd recommend a private tour to help understand what life was like and where all of the buildings used to be. A definite must-see.
Amazing history!. You can't fail to be overawed by the history of this place. Well worth spending a few hours wandering around the ancient ruins.
Part of the Palatine. A part of the Palatine/Colliseum/Circus Massimo complex of structures. Stunning buildings. A must see attraction.

Imagination required. This really is a very interesting place, yes once again you do have to stand and use your imagination but you can most definitely imagine Julius Caesar standing on the balcony orating to his Senate. You can also see where the Vestal Virgins lived and how they lived. Definitely one not to miss
Wonderful history. It was interesting to actually get see and experience a site that is so rich in history it's a must see for anyone who visits Rome.

Real ancient Rom. I stumbled upon this site. I had it in my mind when going to Rome I'd only visit one archeological site Pompeii. My friend beged me to visit the forum. I did and it was amazingly beautiful. I recommend. Note wear good comfortable shoes, the whole forum has very old stone streets.

lovely combination with the Palatine Hill as well as the Colloseum. History with a capital. Amazing remains of ancient times. Unfortunately you have to read the map upside down in order to follow the path which is kind of dangerous because one trips very easily. It might be handy to adjust the map to reality, for on the map the Colloseum is on the right; however in reality it is on the left. It shouldn't be too difficult.

So much to see. I went to the Forum with my wife and toddler immediately after seeing the Colosseum. While I loved the Colosseum, the Roman Forum blew it out of the water.There are so many impressive ruins on this site. The pictures don't do it justice on big the area is and the scale of the buildings. If the Forum was still enact, it would be on the shortlist of most impressive sites ever.I would recommend getting a guide or doing heavy research before going. We have a friend from Rome who showed us around. Her dad is a history professor so we were in good hands, but without her or a guide we would have been lost. There is just so much to see.This is the birthplace of western civilization and politics. Take the time to spend a couple of hours wandering. There are multiple places to get good shots of Trajan market and the Colosseum. We used are Roma pass to get in. It allowed us to skip lines and we were in within five minutes. Book in advance to avoid lines, especially as it gets hotter. Come with an open mind and prepare to be amazed!

Worth the visit.. We loved enjoying such a culturally and historically loaded place. The ruins are a must see! Do not be put off by the big queues it's well worth the wait especially as you get 24 hours to visit the Roman Forum, Palatine Hill & the Colosseum all using one ticket. Make sure you see all 3. Each one is amazing in its own right ☺

Incredible view of history. We were amazed at how much of the ruins are left. You could only be amazed at how grand it must have been at its prime. Although the entry cost to the Forum and Colosseum is very a reasonable price, you could actually see a lot of the Forum without going in and seeing it from above gave you a good overall view of the layout. But still well worth paying to do in, and the ticket is required to enter the Colosseum.
Extraordinary. The Roman Forum was tranquil and enjoyable to look at however my personal preference was with Palatine Hill versus the Roman Forum and this is the reason I've gone with 4/5.

Go back in history!. The Roman Forum was the core of an ancient city, the place where a very great empire was ruled from. Viziting it you can see and understand that it was an example of urban organization and its legal institutions, a creator of startling new horizons in architecture. The views were great and by walking through it you feel you step into history. A must see!

Great to Visit. We enjoyed the feeling of wandering around places with such historical significance. Only query is why no effort is made in Rome to remove the overgrowth of weeds from their historical monuments.

Walking through history. This is a must see in Rome. You get to see the ruins of Rome. We were lucky enough to get a tour with an expert in Roman history, so we learned so much about the whole area. You can use your imagination to see what it was like to be in Rome back then.
History upon history.. So many layers of history in one location. Did this a part of the Colosseum "Skip the Line" tour. Again, recommend doing as a tour. You can be lost otherwise.

A must see - so do not miss it!. Admission to the Forum, Colosseum and Palatine Hill comes on the ticket - such good value. With ruins it is always difficult to really appreciate how life was lived without reading up before hand. excellent exhibits and museums on site too. No food or drink on sale!

Very interesting. This was included in our tour of the colosseum with a different guide we used gladiator tours and the gentlemans name was Gregory who made it very interesting and witty the views were fantastic and learned a great deal by taking the tour you wouldn't have known the history by yourself.

amazing. the history of this place is stunning... we took a guided tour here, and learnt so much, to walk in the streets where roman emperors walked is mind boggling!!!! a must visit to this open air museum..
Roman Forum, nice place to visit.. By visiting the Roman Forum you take a big stap back in history. We loved it. In the evening it is very nice lighted.
Beautiful Ruins. Entrance tickets can be purchased with Colosseum tickets online to save money and cue times. The ruins were breathtaking.

Wonderful ruins. Amazing ruins that give you a real feel for what it was like when Rome ruled most of the known western world. Even the sewers under your feet still work and yes they are Roman. Buildings are in a remarkable condition and well worth a walk around.

For those interested in history . Amazing history of how it was in the Roman empire.
A walk through the ruins with a guide is highly recommended.

Amazing all the way to the top!. We just finished visiting the colosseum and to our surprise, our admission included Palantine Hill and the Roman Forum. We walked up the pathway into an incredible space! We moved our way up the path thru gardens and structures to an amazing top view of the city and colosseum. We ended up staying an extra 2 hours!

Roman Forum and Past Glory. The area of the Roman forum is near Palatine Hill and the Colosseum. If you enjoy archeology, history and ruins you will love working your way around this area. There is beauty in the decay when you look at inlaid marble that seems to be arbitrarily placed in the ground, or the yellows and golds in a broken pillar. You know you are walking where emperors, gladiators, early Christians such as Paul and Peter walked. It is amazing.

Worth the visit. Well worth the visit. Great value when considering it is included with Colosseum and Palantine Hill. Triumphal Arches were beautiful, the Sacred Way was excellent walk with pagan churches

“Take the time to visit - dry weather activity!”. We got a combined ticket giving access to The Forum, The Colosseum and Palatine valid for access 2 CONSECUTIVE days and it was well worth it. You could spend hours walking around, amazing history and great views of the city. Definitely a dry day activity though as its all outside! I'm not sure where The Forum starts/finished and the same with the Palatine! The whole area is just amazing. There are lots of levels and some steep steps in places but there are different entrances so if your not overly steady on your feet please don't feel like you have to miss out there is plenty to see at all levels.

The feel of ancient living. You can really feel like you return to the ancient time when you visit this place. Every first Sunday of each month, you can visit Colosseum, Roman Forum, and most of the museums in Rome for free. As Colosseum and Roman Forum entrance is just opposite each other and they shared same ticket, it is better to queue for your free ticket in Roman Forum entrance as the queue is significantly shorter than Colosseum. You need to keep your ticket and you can use the entrance for those who already have ticket to enter Colosseum. We easily spent 3 hours in Roman Forum and if not because of our hungry stomach, we might spent more time there. We went up first to look at the view from above, where you can visit some of the museums and look at Rome city skyline and Roman Forum from above. Then we walked our way down and walked around the ruins. It was really a magical experience.
Stunning location. We did VIP tour of Colosseum with Walks Italy who were great. Guides are excellent! Scenery and history is incredible!

Must visit in Rome. Palatine hill and Roman forum is very close to be as a single location but there's a long queue at the Palatine hill entrance. So recommended to take the Roman forum entrance. It's better to take a guide to get the whole picture of this ancient site. and be prepared to spend a whole lot of time at these places. But for me, the best place is the COLOSSEUM.
Wow. A fantastic place to visit, amazing to see the Sights and gave a good insight into how Romans lived. Wouldn't of missed this trip and as a bonus, we had the sun!

Wander like a roman through the ruins of the old Forum. The Forum gives you a very good idea of how life was in the old Rome. You cab explore ir on your own, but in that case it is advisable that you know a few things about the Roman empire, or with a guide. Both ways, just take you time and enjoy. As the area is hilly, it is not always an easy stroll.

Great for History Lovers. the tickets for the forum include entrance to the palatine hill and the Colosseum. it's better to arrive early because it is less crowded and the sun is not strong yet. there are signs around but to really understand everything it's better to take a tour or to get really ready and informed about the place. for my opinion it is amazing to see what survived and what was once built...Not suitable for wheelchairs.wear comfortable shoes

Worth a walk!. Amazing to see and walk around the ruins. Me and my other half are not great history lovers, but definitely worth seeing when in Rome. It was a beautifully sunny day so it was lovely walking around and imagining what was there.
A lot of walking so make sure you wear comfortable shoes!

Classic Rome at its best. Tours/tickets of the Colosseum include the Forum, which is a grouping of structures that housed the workings of the Roman Empire for more than a thousand years. The area is rich with history and like the Colosseum, is a must-see. A guided tour helps with a fuller, more complete visit.
Roman Forum - Amazing History. See my review on Palatine Hill for more information. Amazing history. Use the Rick Steves download for a great tour.

Great for History Lovers. Viewed this attraction on three separate days from different locations and was able to see ho grand it must have been in its heyday. There are lots of individual places inside to visit for the real history lover amongst us.

Great place, but not for wheelchairs. Not suitable for wheelchairs. We struggled along several paths but it was hard work. There aren't smooth paths, it's very bumpy. Anyway, it is very interesting and we really enjoyed our visit. The difficulties with the wheelchair didn't diminish our enjoyment of this attraction.

A great place to wander. We were there early in the morning. We also purchased the headsets and got the map. We spent about 2 hours wandering around and had a great time. There were lots of people and I can't imagine what the place is like in June or later in the summer. We learned a lot about the history and I drink from one of the fountains of ancient Rome.

A piece of ancient history. The Roman Forum was in fact the heart of Ancient Rome, all the things happened here. With an effort of imagination you could feel like 2000 years ago. It is also the perfect place for historians, researchers or history teachers :)

Go at night. Forum is so large that unless you're a student of Roman history, it can be an overwhelmingly important pile. We walked past it one day but returned after dinner to see it lighted. Some years, the lighting plan is better than others. This year, it was so-so. The ideal is to illuminate softly or brightly - depending on structures -the most important features. That's true of much of Rome. My favorites at night are the Forum and the Gianicolo hill on the other side of the Tiber.

Experience the Ancient Rome. It takes at least 2-3 hours of quality time to visit all of the corners. Do not go there unless you have studies a little background about the ancient Rome and the shape of the town before turning into ruins. Wear good shows so you do not get frustrated.

A time-warp experience. Walking through amazing Roman history.Unequalled.. I consider myself luck for having the chance to walk through this forum. In a sunny day visiting this place is an instructive and relaxing walk hrough history. A not to miss while in Rome.

Great. This is another great place to visit just to view the remains of amazing structures. You can take an audio tour or a guided tour, but be warned there is a lot of walking so where your most comfortable shoes!

Reliving my childhood - love this place. Great memories came flooding back of visiting here as a child , I love the forum , history comes to life ! And the new audio guides with augmented reality and further historical information are a must ! Also buy your tickets here for Colosseum and you will fly by the queue there !Do take the time and walk up to the palatine as well , the whole area is so well preserved and has an abundance of water fountains and facilities which are a fantastic addition to make your visit more comfortable
Lovely. A wonderful look back in time. Very dusty however in summer and very hot - would reccomend going at different time of the year

Visit this only if you are a history buff. Well, Ben Hur certainly didn't ride a chariot around in this place. Surprisingly small physically and expectation-wise. It was fun to visit but not as exciting as other places in Rome.
Amazing!. I had no idea this even existed and was blown away by the scale and size of it. So well preserved. I felt like I had stepped back in time! Must see!

Lots of walking but worth every step. The Forum in July is hot; suggest getting there early in the morning or as late as possible. Avoid midday sun. It is always crowded in the summer but, hey, you can't go to Rome and not see its Forum!
Nice area. I would recommend you the place to relax a bit of the vivid city. There are some flowers and places to rest in the shadow. Besides you get an inside to the great old roman history.

Just cool to walk through here. This was really cool just to walk in the same place that other had done so long ago. It is such a shame that those christians destroyed anything that wasn't a church. Still it is just great to be there and take it all in.

Do not miss. It is across the street from the Colosseum and a part of the same ticket so no reason to miss it once you go to Colosseum. Great experience to walk and admire the ancient ruins. Make sure you read about what you see...
history all around. Really enjoyed a warm afternoon in April strolling around here. great historical site, had downloaded rick stein audio tour v good

Gateway to The Past. As you approach the Main Gate to The Forum its not hard to imagine yourself being accompanied by a horde of Wraiths making the same journey as they did in life long ago. The Gate itself seems unaltered by the Centuries and you pass under it in the same manner that the illustrious and the infamous of Rome`s Glorious and Gory Past also did 2000 years ago. There still stands the place from which a Heart-Broken Mark Anthony addressed the Crowd that had gathered by his dear friend the Assassinated Roman Emperor Julius Caesar`s Funeral Pyre. Reduced to Ruins though they be enough still exists of the Buildings to transport one`s imaginative mind back to those All-Powerful,World-Ruling,Days. One Roman friend of ours, Maria, said on our visit last August (2015) that they all live among a lot of Decay. I suppose that`s true to an extent, but its a decay that fires other people`s imaginations when they see it. The Italians must be commended for being the first Nation that applied themselves to preserving the Wonders of Architecture that exist in their Ancient Cities. They deserve the Title of `Care-Takers of Culture` for their efforts to preserve what is not being produced in this modern age. The French have a great Cultural sense and Attitude of Responsibility for the creations of previous Centuries as well.Hence, by those far-thinking efforts of long ago the rest of the World can come and see and also find pleasure and delight for the senses in all that has been carefully restored and maintained.

History of the world. Wonderful place to see and truly comprehend history of the world. But, make sure to have a good guide or guide-book, we heard a lot of nonsense being told by some guides while passing by. A must see place in Rome!

Marvellous!. Being a fan of ancient Rome, the Roman Forum was on top of my to-see list in Rome. So much went on in this small place, literally tons of history in one spot. Highly recommended for all history lovers! Great photo/selfie spots too :)
Good to see. The forum is s good place to visit while you are in Rome.They're sited into the Centro Storico and they are great ruins of the ancient roman city,

Lizards, frogs and great views!. We all loved walking round here, seeing the different sites and views of surrounding Rome, great history. Saw lizards and other mini beasts, so kids really enjoyed it! A little bit difficult with a buggy.
steeped in history. if you go to the Colosseum, them its well worth a trip round the Roman forum, If you buy a ticket for this large site, it includes entrance to the Colosseum for approx 12 Euro's

A center of public life. An area of five acres that was once the heart of the western civilization is a rectangular forum surrounded by the ruins of the important government buildings. It was the center of public life in the ancient times, the main site of triumphal processions, public speeches, elections and criminal trials. It is hard to enumerate all the important monuments, buildings and spots, but it takes just a little imagination and some history knowledge to appreciate this place.

Tons of History. We toured the Forum as part of a longer tour that also included the Coliseum and the Palatine hill. We had a guide who was quite knowledgeable. I highly recommend Francesca. She was great!

Roman Forum--great for history lovers. I do love history, so was disappointed that I couldn't see the Forum in my first visit in 2008. So in 2013 I was in Rome again, and had the chance to see the Forum with a tour guide. I learned so much! I never would have learned all this if I didn't have a guide.It is nearly impossible to actually know what you are looking at without a guide. Without a guide it is just a bunch of rocks. A guide can bring it alive.
If you like history...this is for you. Imagine seeing where Roman Senators and citizens lived and what it must have looked like covered in marble.
Included with the tickets . Very big , took some building ,a good visit but takes a while to walk around , one of those ticks you must do, help when you watch the Roman films on the telly
amazing. Do keep atleast 6 hours to see the colloseum, palantine hill and the forum. This place has so much character, history and beauty, it only can be experienced!

Make sure to have a guide. Whether you have a person, a book, or a downloaded audioguide as we did you don't want to visit this site without some guidance as there are no plaques about to explain what you are looking at otherwise!

Amazing.... but pick up an audio tour kit. All of the major sites have queues for both security and entrance, so be prepared to stand around for a bit and travel light as it's no fun repeatedly pulling everything out of your back for an x-ray. They are also somewhat disorganised, which if you are chilled and happy to 'go with the flow' doesn't matter, but if you are a grumpy old sod looking for reasons to gripe, then it's a good excuse to make the rest of your visit utterly miserable for your companions.As with the Palatine Hill and Colosseum, the Forum leaves a lot to be desired in terms of information on what you are actually looking at. There are a few info boards which (thankfully) are written in both Italian and English, but most of the buildings and statues retain a secret anonymity which is frustrating if you are keen to know what the place is all about! Our visit in April was probably one of the best times to go. Once we had calmed down after our unsatisfactory experience with a tour guide at the Colosseum we were able to enjoy the tumbling roses, sweetly scented orange blossom and the sheer enormity of the site whilst we tried to recreate it in our minds' eye without the benefit of the audio tour which we managed to miss picking up on our way in.You'll also find handy little vending machines with snacks and hot/cold drinks hidden away in what would have been Roman shops 800 years ago. They were a welcome pick-me-up after a lot of walking, but as with most other things on the site, are not signposted so it's quite easy to miss them.Now I’m going to say a few words about being a tourist in Rome, and I will include it with reviews of all the places we visited because I wish I had known prior to my visit and maybe it will help you on yours!Firstly, Rome is an elegant city. Tourists in shorts, crop-tops and mini-skirts stand out like a very sore thumb. This attire will mean you are unwelcome in churches, (especially the Vatican and the Vatican Museums) where it is regarded as disrespectful. Expect to be turned away if you are dressed like this. We witnessed from one lady in microshorts and a strappy top and her partner in vest top, Bermudas and tattoos, being politely asked to cover up or leave St Peter’s which did not go down well after waiting for hours in a queue.If you dress smartly you are less likely to be bothered by hawkers, tables materialise in apparently packed restaurants, and you are treated with respect. It’s worth going for ‘smart casual’ if you want to get the best from Rome.Secondly, footwear. Roman streets are mainly cobbled and very gappy. Stiletto or kitten heels are going to be mighty uncomfortable. Wear block heels, wedges or flat shoes and you won’t go far wrong. Most Roman ladies seem to run around in loafers or boots. Another thing to consider is that there is A LOT of walking involved wherever you go. Walk your shoes in thoroughly before you get there and you will save yourself a lot of pain and blisters. Nevertheless, it might be a good idea to pack some plasters in your handbag so you don’t limp yourself out of action. I don’t suppose I’m the first person to lose a toenail after three days walking around the city.Be polite, smile, say hello, please and thank you in Italian and you will be appreciated as much as you appreciate the Eternal City.

Rome in Mid April. One of the highlights in our visit to Rome and there is so much history. We used a private guild from Bruno Tours and her name is Maria. She has so much knowledge about the history of Rome and made our visit so perfect. It was absolutely amazing!

High light of my trip to Rome. The Roman Forum along with the Colosseum were the best part of my trip to Rome. We went there on the first day, and nothing we saw later could match up to the greatness of these attractions

Santa Maria Antiqua. Being lucky enough to travel to Rome 2-4 times a month, I took one half day off to visit Basilica of Santa Maria Antiqua. It is a real treasure. A church built within the Emperor's Palace that traces back to Fourth Century AC and was heavily damaged in 847AC by an earthquake. It was lost and discovered only in early 1900. Closed to pulic since ever, restauration took about 15 years but, after your visit, you will understand why.

Must See Place !. Roman Forum and Palatine Hill is actually one place (kind of a same place situated within the same location) as you can enter from any of the entrances. But strongly recommend to use Roma Forum entrance as long queues can be formed by Palatine Hill entrance.

Fascinating to see how people lived so long ago. I found it fascinating to see how people lived so long ago. Much remains, even though it is in ruins. It is handy to have a guidebook/ tourguide who can explain everything that you are seeing. It should be noted that you only need one ticket to gain access to the Roman Forum, Palatine Hill and the Colosseum. A must see for those interested in Roman history!

The history of Rome. Probably my favorite place I visited when in Rome. Expect to spend half a day at least walking around here and Palatine Hill, which is connected. So much history to take in. I had an audio guide by Rick Steve on my phone which was a great addition.

True Rome . This place gives you the goose bumps - you can spend days after days just standing and watching in wonderment - only complaint the audio guide! It could have been so much more interesting ! There is just so much scope !

Visit here and be amazed at the antiquity.. After seeing the Colosseum, our tour group came here. Our tour guide helped to understand the age of this place and what was built here. We broke away from the group here so we could stay and spend more time viewing the area.

Important visit in the eternal city. Visiting the Roman Forum, after visiting the Colosseum was like a trip way back in ancient history. The Roman Forum has much to offer and you can't stop imagining all the ruins like they once were. Great place!

AWESOME!!. Me and my partner had an archaeological card which allowed us to access this amazing site and others for a reasonable price for 7 days. Loads of walking and things to take pictures of. A must see!!
Interesting!. Another must see whilst in Rome! The Forum was interesting however very busy which meant it was very difficult to look around freely. Still definitely worth a visit.

A view to the past. If you are visiting the Colosseum you should make time to take a look to this place. (if you have a guide from a tour even better). its on a walking distance. Its nice to see what remains of a such a powerful empire.

Magnificent. Roman Forum is a number 1 attraction in Rome. Packed with Roman history, it feels out of this world to be there. Together with Colosseum, it exceeded my expectations. BTW the ticket for the Forum is also valid for the Colosseum and it is a 2-day ticket, good to know. I advise entrance Palatine Hill as it is less crowded than the main entrance.
A wonderous sight. When seeing the Forum for the first time, you get the sense of ancient Rome and how things were. It is really a spectacle and a great place to visit.

Just wow !!. The history behind this place is mind blowing: we weren't originally going to go in as you can walk around the outside but I am so glad we did. Walking where thousands of years ago kings walked and some of the same road remains . The buildings that still remain left me completely speechless. A MUST !!

AUSOME !!!!. We went to Roman Forum because it was included in the Colosseum ticket, It is one of the amazing historical spots in Rome.You will love it.Also it is too photogenic, So do not forget your Professional Camera to take a few good shots.Highly recommed it if you are visiting Rome.

Great area full of old ruins but lacking in good organisation.. Great area to spend 2-3 hours. Full of old ruins, some very large and magnificent. Other smaller and less so. Everywhere you look you see history and when you think of how old this is you get your breath taken away. But the are lacks a lot in planing, there are some signs with long texts. No signs with photos and far between signs with maps so you have no clue where you are or where your going. Its a bit like a big maze. More informations would give better understanding what you are looking at. This was by far not the only place in Rome lacking information signs.

Unmissable. I don't think you could say you'd visited Rome unless you had walked around the Forum and taken in the history. The number of buildings still standing and the general area is amazing - not a big leap of imagination to go back to ancient Rome. Very little visual guidance to tell you what you're looking at, so I would recommend either a guided tour or a good guide book. Apparently you can also get into the Coliseum much more quickly by going via the Forum first and getting a ticket for both.
Roman Forum. Roman Forum is unbelievable historic attraction and it is recommended as one of Rome's attractions. Well preserved and worth the visit.
So much to take in!. Amazing historical centre of Rome, near to the Colosseum. Covers quite an area with all the ancient temples, forums and monuments to take in. Fantastic.

Awesome. Really interesting to see in person. Had a book with overlays to show what sites looked like when intact. Lots to see on your own did not use guided tour. Lots of up and down walking as in most of Rome, need good flat shoes with a thick sturdy sole.
Large area of roman living. This is a large area giving you lots to look at from Roman times. Included in the colosseum ticket along with Palentine hill and free first Sunday of the month
Grand Ruins. The package tour included the Colloseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum, definitely work doing together as they work well to complete the Ancient Rome experience.

Amazingly unlabeled. The Roman Forum is one of the most historical places on earth. To the Italian/Rome government, it is a tourist trap.Lots of cool old things that you won't have any idea about what they are.

The Glory of Ancient Rome. We had purchased our tickets to tour the Forum/Colosseum ahead of time on-line and printed our tickets. We had no wait at all to enter the Forum area to tour. You can easily spend several hours walking through this amazing area. Ruins, yet - but still amazing architecture and art scattered almost casually throughout the grounds. Don't miss the site of Caesar's assassination - just a mound of stones in the stone remains - but an important part of history and legend. On the way back to our hotel we walked by Torre di Argentina - another site of Roman ruins, but this one is home to a rescued colony of cats. They can be seen lounging around the fallen relics and columns and basking in the sun on top of large stones. Down a stairway in the far corner, you can visit the Cat Rescue colony between the hours of 12 Noon and 6 PM. And don't forget to return in the evening - see the glow of the lights reflecting and playing over the ruins of Ancient Rome. Beautiful.

Amazing. . Favourite place we visited in Rome. Loved it. So much history to see its unbelievable and so well preserved. Queues also much better than at the Colosseum. Also if you are pregnant make it known to the ticket people as you get to jump the queue!

Essential viewing if visiting Rome. A joint Colosseum / Roman Forum ticket is a bargain €12 which makes it probably the best historical experience value on Earth. I strongly advise taking 2-3 hours and exploring the whole Forum site at a leisurely pace, relaxing and absorbing the atmosphere. Despite being in the city it's very quiet and peaceful. There is more than enough space to accommodate the large number of visitors and the place doesn't feel crowded even when it's busy. Don't miss this.

Stunning ruins - beautiful to photograph. This is a continuation from the Palatine Hill and there is a lot to see, with the remains of lots of different buildings to walk around. We were lucky enough to have lovely weather and it is very photogenic. Do not miss this if you are visiting Rome.

Powerful Step into History. My husband & I were taken back in time as we walked on stones more than 2000 years old. Visiting the ruins of a great city with the remains of shops, living quarters, palaces & temples was an incredible experience.

No stroller . This is a great site to walk through. Aloow a couple of hours. We travel with a 5mo baby and used a baby carrier, which worked very well. It would be impossible to push the stroller through here.
Historical. What can I say. A must see if you are in Rome. Amazing how much History you can learn from this place.

Great remains. The history of this area and it's excavation is fascinating, brought to life for us by our guide, Fernando, with walks of Italy. It is more than just Roman remains (including those of Julius Caesar), but also evidence of the civilisations that have followed the romans.

Roman forum tour a must.. This is our 2nd visit to Rome and our 2nd tour of the Roman forum. It is amazing. We normally book through Viator although other tour sites are available. Costs include skip the line tickets for both the forum and colosseum (approx £40pp). You can pay and enter yourself but going with a guide adds a lot of value. Be warned in summer months it can be extremely hot in the forum so take plenty of water and lotion. This, however, was not a problem at our recent visit in wet, cool, April.

Amazing. I really only went to the Roman Forum because it is included in the Colosseum ticket, but it completely exceeded my expectations. We listened to the Rick Steves audio tour and then wandered around for some time. It is so dense with history. I highly recommend. I enjoyed it more than the Colosseum.

Don't miss it!. Another must see in Rome! The history in this area is absolutely amazing. Don't miss it! If you can get a tour guide to explain everything that happened in this spot, do it! There's so much to learn here!
Worth a visit.. Interesting to see, a lot of steps to walk up, very close to Coloseum. Can be visited on same tour as Coloseum and Roman Forum.

Ancient ruins that require a guide to provide information. Had tickets to the colosseum that provide free access to roman forum n palatine hill. Suggest u have a guide for roman forum n palatine hill which interconnected to get the full history lesson.for first timers, suggest going to the colosseum early morning followed by the palatine hill (short walk) from.colosseum exit and heading down hill to the roman forum thereafter.
Visit Roman Forum with Roma Pass. Buy a Roma Pass to use public transport and to go to museums like Roman Forum, Collosseum and Castle St. Angelo.
