A Look Into the Past. If you are going to Rome for the first time I highly recommend you go through Context Travel and arrange a visit with a scholar. They take small groups of only 5-6 so you get full history etc. If you have been before and want to just wander around be sure to get tickets ahead as lines can be very long. Read up on the Forum so you know what you are looking at. I love the view from Capitoline Hill looking down on the forum and especially later at night there is a mist that rolls up the Sacra Via and you can almost imagine the Emperors coming into that area after their conquests. It is very ethereal.

It's okay not to pay. Unlike most people who have reviewed, I chose not to pay the entrance fee to the Roman Forum, and then queue for hours to get through security to get in. If you're only in Rome for a day or so, and want to make the most of your time without having to queue, this may be the better option for you.What I did instead was walked to the left of the queue up the small hill, as if to walk into the forum. From there there is a path that winds around the outskirts of part of the forum. Be warned that this path is a dead end, but before you get there, you do get some good views of the forum from the top of some hills on the way round. Another good place to see the majority of the forum for, without charge, is the terrace of the Vittoria Monument that you can see from the forum (the massive white stone building with green chariots and horses on it).

Loaded with history. Walked around the Forum Romanum and the Palatine Hill with a guide. Highly recommendable to do this site with a guide, otherwise you'll just be walking around between lots of buildings and remains of buildings.

Very Ruin. Much Wow. It's impressive, but most of it is gone. Still amazing to look at and imagine what would have been. On the way between other sites and you can look down into it, or actually go in if you want.

Part of the extensive ancient Roman ruins.. If you have plenty of time, you could do as we did and combine a walk around the Forum with the Palatine Hill and perhaps the Colloseum. You could get Roman ruins overload! But it is a fantastic experience. I would suggest taking a tour round the centre of Rome in an open topped bus. We used the yellow bus that has links to the Vatican....£20 for 72 hours unlimited travel....jump on and off...headphones and frequency of every 15 minutes. When you have seen the area...go walking. I think you will understand the layout far better.

Ann amazing wonder. What is key here is getting a good audio guide. I found it difficult to really visualize what was here, given what is left. A single column here, a single marble slab there... it needs context. That said, this is a bucket list item and is truly amazing to see.

A step back in time. It is worth paying for a guide. Our guide explained what all the buildings were that we could see from the top and what they had all been used for so that we had a real feel for how the Roman way of life had been. Tthe view from the top is amazing and the walk through all the ruined streets was a real step back in history.
Great tour. We did this on the same tour at the Colosseum and didn't have to queue which was good as there was a long one.

Great site and good audio tour. This is a large area and worth taking throne to stroll around and listen to the audio tour.
Seems a bit unusual that many of the ruins are covered in weeds, but they are interesting nonetheless.
Entrant is included with your colosseum tickets - I'd suggest possibly starting here and then finishing with the colosseum.

Worth it only if you have a history passion or great visualization sklls. When it was free it was worth it but now that they charge it is tough to convince yourself to see ruins in the middle of Rome. I studied the art of rome and it was still hard to gain a full perspective on how things used to be in the forum. If you are a history buff in need to see where Caesar and the like ruled, then it is a must. If not, there are plenty of other things to do.
Amazing ruins.... Difficult to say what part of Rome was my favorite...so I will say all of it. April is the perfect time of year to visit becasue the weather is absolutely perfect.
Beautiful. This will take you a few hours, take your time and explore the whole this! Some of the view are breath taking.
Great for history lovers!. A required stop in the eternal city. As with most attractions in Rome, it is wise to get there as early in the day as you can.
Good place with great culture. The Roman Forum is a great place to visit with many temples. Remember to visite the Spring of of Juturna and the Temple of Caesar.

I can't believe this is only #12 on things to do!. Visiting the Roman Forum was my absolute favourite thing to do in Rome! There is just something so magical about walking through all those ruins and imagining what it looked like. You buy a single ticket for all three attractions - Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill and you the ticket will give you two days access to the sites. Whilst we initially planned to cover all three in one day we soon ran out of time! It is worth noting that Palatine Hill and Roman Forum must be seen on the same day as the ticket won't allow two visits on over two days to these two sites. We started the morning thought accessing the Palatine Hill entrance - which is recommended due to the length of queues and we purchased audio guides for all three sites (remember to save ur receipt so u can pick up your audio guide for the colosseum).Whilst it was interesting, I don't think it is absolutely necessary to have an audio guide, there is information available as you walk through. I cannot stress enough how absolutely beautiful it was! I really thought I would be completely enamoured by the colosseum but it was the Roman Forum that was my all time favourite!Be prepared for a lot of walking! Wear comfy shoes and don't worry too much about carrying water with you as there are a lot of water fountains available.

Amazing place, next to the colosseum. Our ticket to the Colosseum also got us access to the Roman Forum, we were expecting a secondary site but this is another wonder and really should be on any visitors 'to see' list. It's much larger than we imagined, go in via the entrance near the The Arch of Constantine as there was no queue here at 11.30 am, else where the queues were huge. Go to the museum on the top, look at the wonderful views, take your time and imagine yourself back in the glory days of Rome.
Just a walk through. Between the Palantine and the Colliseum this was a quick walk through. Can't hold a candle to the others.

Ancient Rome. We had a very interesting tour of the Roman Forum, it is a must whilst visiting Rome. The remaining arch's and columns give you some idea of the sheer scale and grandeur of the ancient empire.
Imposing . Wow what a building. It is huge and imposing. Very impressive. We were walking to the Colosseum and mot looking for the Forum but when we saw it we were blown away.

Transport yourself.... ...back in time. I wandered around with my husband and tried to imagine this place abuzz with activity. It was fun for me to refer to the map I had downloaded on my phone to see if I could recognize which foundation was once what building. It's also a great place to test your panoramic pic-taking steadiness. :)

Use a Little imagination. Very cool to see the Forum from a far and explore once you were inside. The Forum was much larger than we had expected. You can definitely imagine how this spot was the most important place to be during its prime time. Be aware that the forum is below the current grade level and you will have to walk up and down ramps to get in and out of the Forum. We discovered on the way out of the Forum that there is only 1 exit and fairly difficult to find if you are not paying attention.

Fascinating. The Forum and surrounding ruins are fascinating insights into life as it would have been in Roman times. However, you should hire a private guide and doing it yourself, you will not understand all that you are looking at.
A funny thing.... A number of Roman forums are dotted around the Coliseum / Palatine hill area. Fascinating history and many of the signs are in English as well as Italian.

Couple with your tour of The Colosseum. An incredible tour - also taken with a tour company. While the tour was good - I wish I had the xtra time to view things on my own. Going with a tour company means you have the advantage of hearing all the history and stories, but you miss out on the luxury of really getting up close and viewing as well as taking time to get `the perfect shot`.My hint: Go on your own; there are tours coming through every five to ten minutes... listen in to them !

Majestic Place to go to, but uneven ground. The Roman Forum is a must-see, especially if already going to the Colosseum or Palazzio Piti (it's the same ticket). Use the Rick Steeves Audio Guide Tour, it is very all-encompassing. Be careful with the uneven ground as this could be hazardous for some. Be sure to bring water with you.

Can you NOT visit the Forum?. I love this place...but having read Roman history for over 50 years, I know some of what I am looking at. The place is poorly marked and almost forces you to take a guided tour. Which I did this time, in deference to my young companion, and I missed alot of the places I know well but were ignored in favour of the Readers Digest view of the Forum. Necessary for a first timer but sadly the great history here was quickly walked by!

Really interesging. We went to the Roman forum midweek and it was really busy however really interesting very well looked after and well signposted. The palatino hill is next to it. You can get some really lovely pics here.

Amazing. Pay the money and do a private tour so you get all the information you need. This place has some amazing stories to tell. The terrain is a bit rough and its not good for wheelchairs or prams. A lot of history to hear about here.
WOW!. The history and sights here are breathtaking. Definitely a must see if you are in Rome. Make sure you walk around and see it all!
Forum is a must. Get a guide book or audio tour. There is too much you can miss with out guidance. Do the Forum and Palatine in the morning and the Colosseum in the late afternoon.

Amazing. Stunning views over the city of Rome with beautiful gardens and roses that actually have a perfume. Didn't spend too much time here as had so much else to see and only had 2 days to see it. Will definitely return to give it the attention it deserves. This and Palatine Hill was included in our entrance ticket to the Coleusseum and the ticket gave us 2 days to see all three for just 12 euros.

More of Ancient Rome. It was a little hot and there's not much that will give you some shade from the sun. Wish I had worn a cap or had an umbrella. I may have not wanted to rush being in this area if I was not feeling the heat of the sun.

History walk through. Fascinating place to visit. Worth prebooking the tickets to queue for less time, but really amazing place to walk around. Clearly inspirational as a fellow tourist was inspired to recite from Shakespeare's Julius Caeser in situ at the site of his cremation ceremony.

Brilliant. When we first got in here it was beautiful, then it got a bit boring, same thing over and over again, but the further you go into it the nicer it gets, the views of Rome city are fantastic and the history in the Forum is very interesting also, make sure to visit Palatino also as it is amazing. You will get fantastic photos here and amazing views of ancient Rome. Enjoy

..going back in time.... Our ticket for the Roman Forum, was part of our Coloseum ticket, and we had plenty of time to do next day on the ticket. Skip the line touts, on and offline are not required.History in a large open space, just a magic way of allowing yourself to be put into Rome's past. A definite for your Roman holiday. Lots of information around the place to fill in the blanks

Roman Forum. Forum Magnum.The heart of the Roman Empire.located between Palatine and Capitolie Hill this plaza had seen all: elections and triumphal processions, criminal trials,gladiator fights, memorable public speeches, international trades treates were still signed or canceled here.Ps: get( if possible ) your tickets on line and print them( or snap a picture of the page)- no free wifi there, so u won't be able to download anything from your email. If it's a hot day sunscreen, water and a hat ( umbrella) will be your best friends. Do not recommend high heels because of the uneaven pavement

Amazing site, but wear comfortable shoes. You can spend all day walking through the ruins, gardens and museum on this site and probably still not see all of it. There are an incredible number of things to see and it can become a little overwhelming. We found no cafe's on the site but you can buy drinks from a vending machine. Good idea to take in some refreshments/packed lunch so you can take your time and spend the day enjoying the site.The ground is rough and very uneven in places and has quite of lot of climbing up and down slopes/steps. Comfortable walking shoes recommended.

Just amazing....A step back in time..... An amazing place to wander around the ruins. Not far from the Colloseum its easy to walk around and there are so many books that will give you the details of all the arches, buildings and leaders of the time. incredibly atmospheric you can feel the Roman times. Beautifully situated its a mecca for anyone interested in Roman history.
Worth a look, on the way to other places. As this is so close to so many other places you need to see, you will plenty of chances to look around this area

Vast area of ancient ruins. We visited the Colosseum and didn't realise that the ticket included entry to the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill so, we went back on our last day and paid the entrance fee again. We were not disappointed as this place is a large open museum. You can imagine the might of Rome by just seeing the ruins of the buildings that once stood 2000 years ago and also on Palatine Hill was where Romulus founded the city according to legend and where emperor Augustus built his palace. The Colosseum and Roman Forum was my favourite attraction in Rome. You can definitely spend four to five hours here so wear some comfortable shoes, bring a little pack lunch cos you might want to have a sit down and a bite whilst taking it all in.
Not to be missed. Whilst it is very busy it is a large site and there is time to wander - the organised tours seem to rush through which misses the feel of the place.

Great place. This is a great place which we have visited in the past with no queuing etc, unfortunately you now do have to queue, firstly for the ticket to go inside, then secondly to get into the site. such a shame really but with the age of security it is a necessity, you now have to have everything go through scanners, which causes delays. you can get a good idea and pictures by walking passed the entrance and following the pathway up to the top, think this is called Palatine hill.
Much History. This is a place to be in awe of history if you have a vivid imagination like me. In my opinion a guide is a necessity to grasp all there is to see.
History in front of you. Lots to see, a guide book is helpful an there is so much to see. lots of walking and steps and could be hot in the summer.
Surprisingly the best bit for me!. Unbelievably interesting - you can get so close to history !! SO much to see its vast! Great photo ops of the Coliseum !

Feel the past. This is one special valley, between the hills of Rome. You can imagine how grand it must have been.Today, however, it's an organized ruins site.You really need a guide to appreciate and understand what you're seeing.

Art, history and movies. Think about Julio Cesar, Erodes and cia...Pure emotion. Very interesting for arts, history, archaeology and religion. It is a mixture of everything! Be prepared for long walk! There is vending machines in the lower portion in the middle (is hidden) Study a guide before the visit and get a map of the place to understand better what you are about to see.

Great day with lots of walking. Had a good day at the Forum, the ticket we bought was the Colosseum and the forum but it takes a full day to see both and a lot of walking and steps, we did it over two days to we could take our time.

A dive into Roman history . Few places along the Mediterranean basin allow experiencing the magnificence of Roman architecture as the Forum in Rome. The sightseeings are jaw dropping and the experience won't ever be forgotten
My favorite in Rome. Really amazing if you really get into the stories of the ancient city. Vesta virgins, Julius Cesar, etc. You can almost feel how the ancient Romans lived.
part 2 of a tour. nice and informative. walked around . understood how the Romans lived how advaced was their civilization

Great place to visit . One of the must see places in Rome.
We were pleasently surprised with the scenic view of Roman ruins.

The forum wasn't built in a day and you need more then a day to see it all. Simply amazing. It goes on and on. The architecture is so impressive. This should be top of your list in Rome. Lines are much shorter then the colosseum.
When in Rome.... Interesting area of Roman ruins excavated around 1700 & continues today, worth linking this with a Colosseum trip & include a guide then you get the history & interesting bits...

The centre of ancient Rome.. This should be part of the ticket for the Coloseum and the Palatine Hill. Queues can be shorter here so if you do not get tickets online or use the Roma pass, think about a quieter ticket office here first. The Forum is vest and contains temples, courtyards, columns, statues (although most are reproductions with the real ones in the museums). It gives a sense of the size of ancient Rome and the vast public areas. A wonderful place to wander and get the spirit and romance of a small part of grandeur of Rome. remember to take water and sun protection. There are self service stations around for drink and the fountains are drinkable water sources. Allow plenty of time - it is a large area.
walked by. walked past and saw enough..too many lined up to get in but can get a good idea by looking from outside.

A walk into history!. A long and pleasurable walk in the alleys of history was a good surprise. Enjoyed it at our pace. Lot of tourists are all around and its a feel good place to be.You get to see the sites you have only read about in history books , its a delight indeed!
Full of History. Our entrance fee was included in the price we paid to enter the Colosseum. The ticket was valid for the day so we visited the Forum in the afternoon.
Amazing ruins. If you enjoy ancient ruins (and if you don't then why are you going to Rome?) then these take some beating.

Unbelievably fabulous. The Forum is amazing, beautifully landscaped, but get there early. Repeat - get there early. Huge crowds, and there isn't a lot of shade. But it is so sublime, you actually forget the heat.

Fascinating . A great example of Roman ruins on a large scale. It's fascinating to see how Romans lived all those years ago. Make sure you read up on this place before you go as the signage isn't great.
Just incredible!!!. Felt like I was living in the height of the glory of Rome. A must-see visit when in Rome, spectaculor to walk around and listen to the history of this place.

Loved it! . Favourite attraction in rome. Would definitely see with a tour to get the most out of it. Such a beautiful place for a stroll on a nice day and so much interesting history from republic times to imperial history to renaissance.
nice to see. All outside but be amazed at the architecture and the views across to the Coliseum. Large area with much to explore.
Need I say more. To fully experience this one take a tour, it will explain what you ate looking at. If you are into ruins I would advise a 30 minute train ride to Ostia Antica.
Incredible history!. The amount of architecture, artifacts and statues still remaining here are incredible. Do not miss this area!

Get a Tour!. The Forum is an amazing place with so much history that aimlessly walking through it is a waste of time. Get a guided tour or make sure you understand something before going in. I loved it because I know the history but my friend was totally bored and didn't appreciate it as much as I did.

Inspiring . Another very interesting historical sight that is well worth the visit . Would recommend visiting with a guide and this can be combined with a trip around the colosseum. Lots of uneven cobblestones to walk on so wear comfortable strong shoes sadly not suitable for someone with walking difficulties.

Walk in the steps of the Romans. Our favourite attraction in Rome. A real sense of history. Don't take the audio tour, we found we were rushed. Just take your time and read each of the information boards.
Highlight of our trip!. I couldn't believe I was actually here! It was truly an amazing experience. It was almost overwhelming seeing all the historical ruins.

Well Preserved Ruins, great visit. Pretty cool when you think about how old this site is. You can spend a little time here or a lot. We were traveling with 9&10 year olds that can do limited amount of history and imagination so we spent a more limited time. History buffs may need more time. Don't forget to walk around the corner (away from the Coliseum) to see the Campidoglio (hilltop square) designed by Michelangelo. It also houses a couple of museums. Also, you can get a great picture of the Roman Forum from the top of the coliseum.

Worth the queueing. The route round was a little haphazard and you need a guide book because information notices were few and afr between. Audio help was available and in hindsight we should have bought it.Mercifully a strategically-sited drinks station served ice-cold drinks from a range of machines so take coins! Not a rip-off. As for tyne forum itself, amazing.

Do it early. To understand Rome see the Forum at the start of your trip. The Forum and Palantine are far more interesting than the Collaseum so don't rush to get there it's easier to see it at the end of the day anyway
enjoyed more than the coloseum. Went to the Forum first (so as to beat the queue at the coloseum). Very very interesting place with the most amazing views, wonderful smells from the gardens.

One of the most historically interesting, architecturally magnificent and overall breathtaking places in the world.. The Roman Forum is a must visit in Rome. If I could just visit one historical site, I would probably choose this. The ruins of the temples, the market, the palaces and the public buildings of ancient Rome form a beautiful site, where you wander around reading about the roman history and feeling you are in ancient Rome.

There is probably a better use of your time and money!. You can wander through the ruins, but in Rome there are much better things to see. It is hard to imagine what the buildings once looked like in the current situation. A good view would be from Palatine Hill.

Huge and lovely area to appreciate and visit!. Roman Forum + Palatine Hill and Colosseum are usually sold in a 2 day ticket so if you opted for these tickets, come only to the Forum after the Colloseum as it is a huge area and queues are less. There are so much to see and each angle offers a different perspective. If you are financially able, book a guide with reputable company instead of just walking around sightseeing as you will apprecate the place better. I enjoyed my visit here and it is suitable for long walks with family.

A View of the Past. This area of ancient Rome gives one the opportunity to explore the many structures and monuments still preserved from the Roman era. Maund of Viator Tours gave us a wonderful tour and great narratives about the structures. She was knowledgeable and answered questions well. We were able to take pictures and visualize life in ancient Rome. We were able to linger longer after the tour to explore our own options.

Well worth a visit.. Entry by ticket which combines the forum and the colosseum.
It is situated opposite the colosseum and covers a large area, with many interesting buildings in different state of repair.
Do enter the villas on the left which leads to very nice gardens with great views over the whole of the Forum.

Wonderful place. It's so exciting to see where ancient Rome was and to think of the people that lived and worked there so many years ago. It truly puts things into perspective. I would recommend taking advantage of a tour guide because there is just so much to learn about while you are there.

Part of the 2nd half of our 9hr tour.. My wife and I had pre-booked a guided 9hr tour, with the 1st half consisting of the Vatican, Sistine Chapel & St Peter's Basilica. After a provided lunch we embarked on the 2nd half which included The Colosseum, The Forum and The Capitol. I would highly recommend the whole tour. We found it very enjoyable and informative, although it did rain during our tour, so we returned the next day on a self guided walking tour.
Love it!. The Roman Forum and Palentine Hill are amongst my favourite places in Rome to wander and explore. Make sure you take your time and don't rush.

History. You can take tickets for Colosseum and The Riman Forum and do we did, you can visit in different days both of the objectifs, both are a piece of history in front of you, lovely feeling, take your time when visiting the Roman Forum, it is absolutely facinating!Hope you will like it as much as we did!!

So much to see. So much to see here. You can spend hours and hours looking at all of the ruins, or just stroll through marvelling at the sights. There is not much information on the ruins, so I would suggest taking a guide book to fully understand the sights. Set aside a minimum of 2 hours to walk slowly through, but it is easy to spend all day here.

A wonderful place to walk through. We walked through this area with a tour guide who explained the history behind this area. Truly amazing and should be vidited in addition to the other areas in Rome. If you're a walker, definitely worth adding to your walk around Rome.
Breathtaking experience. A great tour guide helped us with exploring the ancient Roman Forum. Incredible day in Rome and one we will never forget.

Historically important.. If you're interested in Roman history then the Forum is a must. It is not as in tact as many other sites, but includes the remains of many very important buildings. As a former student of classical studies it was a must.

Friends Romans and country men, Lend me your ears.... You can almost imagine the emperors walking along the streets in their Togo's! It is interesting for all age groups. Again try and avoid gladiators!
Facinating. This is a fascinating place to visit. It is like walking through ancient history. Highly recommend a guide tour so you understand what you are seeing.

Forum and Palatine Hill. The Forum and Palatine Hill go together. I have been there several times and the tour guide can really make a difference. This last time was with Walks of Italy on the VIP Caesar's Palace tour with Fernando. I highly recommend this.
I love this place. I visit the Forum every time I'm in Rome. It's amazing that so much of it has survived the centuries.

Wander around for hours. Center of Ancient Rome, you can walk around the ruins for hours looking for beautiful little pieces of architecture and art. Or just wander around trying to take in the atmosphere of ancient times. The same ticket you buy for the Colosseum lets you in here, too. The ticket is good for two days, so you can even come back a day after you toured the Colosseum.

This is the heart of ancient Rome. Regardless of how you go about it, with a guided tour or freelancing, this is the essential element of your introduction to ancient Rome. This was the heart of the city and the country, where trade was effected, where laws were passed, where the people worshipped their Gods. Yes, it's mostly rubble now, but there's enough left to give you the feeling that you can envision the grandeur that was once the Roman Capital. The last time I was there, the Senate (Curia) building was open, but it isn't now. I could imagine the debates that went on there, determining the course of Western civilization. Remember, this is the place where Europe spread it's wings.

Truly amazing . What an amazing space!!!Truly inspirational. So much to see. Not really disabled friendly. Take water in on a hot day as there are no cafe facilities on site. Toilets are available, but don't expect much!The ticket price includes Palatine Hill.
Great morning spent here . We booked a skip the line ticket that also gave us free entry in to the Roman forum Amazing placewell worth the visit, give yourself a free hours to really appreciate it

Together with Colosseum the real ancient Rome. One extremely interesting area to walk around in and contemplate ancient Rome, how it was for real. Everything you've seen in movies really comes to life here.

It's where the history comes from. It's pretty awe inspiring to think that you're walking around ruins that are thousands of years old. Imaginations important here. Picture the buildings, imagine the flow of the area. Images of the original forum (artists renderings) helped us a lot with this. Enjoy some of Rome's fresh cool water from the taps as you walk and wonder.

So much history in one small area!. The Forum and the Palatine are a wonderful time machine. The best Roman ruins really are in Rome (go figure!). The concentration of ruins in the Forum are like nothing seen elsewhere (and I have visited a lot of Roman ruins in France and England). The variety of stone, the constructions: temples, markets, housing, and how one is built almost on top of the next. Not to mention the history - the events that happened here. The arch of Titus celebrating his victory in the Holy Land, the pools of the vestal virgins....Combine this with a wander up the Palatine hill to look at more ruins!Utterly wonderful.

So much to see, so little time. I probably wore out my kids (and a pair of shoes) walking around this historic site. Everywhere you look is something special, and so much imagination, wondering how it all must have looked 2000 years ago. Could easily spend days here exploring.

Heart of Ancient Rome. The heart of Ancient Rome this is a great place to walk around and see the ruins of the old buildings. This is included in the ticket for the Colosseum. It's also great to walk around the streets and look down into the Forum before going into the actual Forum. Be sure to have at the vary least a guide book with you so you can make out what the various ruins and temples are.

Stretch your imagination!. As with other ruinous attractions in Rome, you need a good imagination as to what the site looked like in all its glory. Well worth a visit though if you love Roman antiquity. take plenty of water to drink on a hot day.

The most amazing historical experience. I spent almots 4 hours just wondering around these ancient ruins, trying to imagine myself in the past, what it was like. I suggest an audio or guided tour for information as the info around the site is limited.To me it was far more enriching than the Colosseum which is just 1 monument whereas here it is so many and so much to see!!!

Plan to spend some time. I did not realize before going in, how sprawling this site is. We spend over 4 hours and that was walking at a decent pace. Great photo ops and you can get close to many of the Ancient ruins.

Great place for history on Roman buildings. This is a large area (with the Palatine Hill) and we spent up to 6 hours walking around. It could do with an audio guide. Tickets are cheap and include the Forum and Colosseum valid for 2 days. Cannot do all in one day.

Extraordinary. We liked the place more than anything else in Rome. It reminded us of our glorious, civilised past societies and reminded us the height of excellence Romans reached in architecture, city planning and building engineering. Above all they created the democracy and laid the foundation for the modern world. Truly a remarkable place to take a walk and get inspired and be overwhelmed.

Definitely a must go. My husband and I were getting tickets for the colosseum and bought them for the other thing they were offering tickets for, not knowing that the "other thing" was the forum. We walked in not really paying attention and figuring we'd be in and out and then head over to the main thing we wanted to see: the colosseum. Wow were we wrong! Once we walked in we realized where we were. Spent a few hours walking around and just being amazed by everything there was to see. Be sure to go up the ramp from the church. The view outside from the palace is one in a million. You won't regret going to this place.

Surrounded by beautiful ruins. Enjoyed my stroll through this area. It is full of ancient character and pretty overwhelming with the amount of history. It is very easy to become complacent with what this place means to us living today.

The iPod tour really helps!. The Roman Forum is a beautiful place to walk round. It is hard to understand though, so I would recommend to hire the audio visual tour at the entrance ticket office (the staff give you an iPod to take around). It helps you get an orientation and discover what the monuments are that you walk about with virtual reconstructions, as well as great mini film clips.
Must see. If you want to know everytjing about the Roman Empire and how it started I highly recommend getting a tour and visit this place ..

Visit with a guide. . There is so much to see on this site and we were lucky enough to purchase the services of a guide. While you can walk around the site with a book it's just not the same as being someone who knows what that are talking about. A must visit site and well worth the entry fee.

Really liked this. Buy official tickets from office only!. Don buy tickets from English tour operators outside the colosseum they then take you to local people who do not speak English to hand over money and give you already used tickets in return. Apart from that the experience at The forum was lovely lots to see beautiful walks feels distinctly Roman and views def worth a visit
Took a tour!. So glad we opted for a tour of Ancient Rome! City Tours was an informative tour for us. Saw a lot of the ancient ruins.

Absolutely worth it. We paid €12 for Colosseum and Roman Forum and this is so beautiful. The queue was big. We did not paid to skip the line and we were inside about 20 min later. This was on Sunday around 6pm.
Roman Forum should be everybody's to do list. We spent inside about 3 hours but the time was flying.

Where is Julius Caesar buried?. Using Rick Steve's podcast, we walked through the ancient Forum and had time to linger and take photos of this astonishing place. Buy your combo ticket for the Forum, the Colosseum, and Palatine Hill online to avoid the very long lines. See if you can find where Julius Caesar was buried....

Interesting experience. Allow at least one and a half to two hours to fully explore the Forum and make the climb to the top of Palatine Hill. Lots of interesting sights and stories of the past. Well worth a visit, but avoid climbing the hill in the midday heat. Even in April it was hot!

Walking the Via Sacra is a bucket list experience. The names and associations of the Forum are legend and deep history. I felt like the dust that I stirred up with each footstep was somehow sacred here. Julius, Augustus, Titus, Brutus...all here. Among countless others throughout thousands of years. The stones here, worn smooth, let you know that you are walking the paths of many who came before. A bit mushy, I know, but I was truly awestruck here. Its a necessary tour when in Rome for the first time. It gives you some roots to appreciate the depth of Rome's importance to the world.

Heritage walk. 1000 years of history is hidden in 5 acre of area. Lot many monument at one place. We listened Rick Steve audio but considering magnitude of information it is better to have audio guide.
Favorite part of Rome. Walking through the Forum was my favorite part of Rome. We just did a self guided tour using a guidebook but I wish we had sprung for the audio guides.

Ticked off the bucket list. As part of my other review to the Colosseum, the entry here is 12€ inclusive of the Palatino and Colosseum for 2 days - but only 1 entry per attraction.
The forum gives you more than just an image of ruins, inside there's more to see and learn about the history and findings.
A huge tick off our bucket list!

The original seat of power for the Romans. Access to the Forum is included in the ticket for the Colosseum although part of it is involved in the work to complete Line C of the Metro and has been closed off. You shouldn't go to Rome and miss this place because of its importance in the Roman world.
The heart of Rome. Vast expanse of Roman ruins which are lovely to wander through. Lots of information boards explaining what you are looking at.

An amazing piece of history. This is a must see ... but do your homework as there is so much to see and take in that it can be overwhelming. Study a bit first so you know what you are looking at and what you may wish to specifically find. You can't visit Rome without coming to the Forum.

Must see in Rome. We so much enjoy wandering around the Roman Forum that we visited twice during our recent three day visit to Rome. There is so much to see and learn about this ancient civilization that a visit to Rome would be incomplete without a visit to the Forum.When we visited the Forum some years ago, entry throughout the site was free and since you can spend many hours here, the flexibility to come and go as you please was so much appreciated.Unfortunately, you now have to buy a ticket that gives you entry to both the Roman Forum and the Colosseum and although it's valid for 48 hours, you can only enter each site once. So even if you want to leave to get a coffee or come back at another time of day, you have to pay again, which is a great pity.Its best to go early in the day or very late in the afternoon when its quicker to get through the queue for tickets and to pass through security.

A Site For Explorers. I'm not sure I realised how much physical history was available to see in Roma, the forum is a must see. Your can spend as long as you wanted seeing two thousand years of history and there is a good little museum at the top of the hill. Thoroughly worth while and if you hire a guide I'm sure the experience would be even better
Amazing !. You can just not believe how ancient the remains of the temples are ! You must go with a guide, we pre booked on line before leaving home. This is a must.

Allow time to see the Roman Forum alongside the Colosseum. A single ticket gives access to the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. Whilst a lot of the forum can be seen without needing to pay to go in, if you already have a Colosseum ticket it is well worth the time to go in and explore close up.Like the Colosseum, I can imagine the Roman Forum could be a nightmare for small children or those with mobility restrictions. Lots of uneven surfaces, so wear the right shoes. If you're worried about twisting an ankle, this is not the place for you!

Put This on Your Bucket List if You Love History!. First, reference Zero Mostel's 1962 famous movie, nothing funny happened on the way to the forum. But, visiting this place really the key to understanding the grandeur of classic era Rome. We went with a Gray Lines tour, and despite the tour guide's Catholic propaganda about how great the post-Roman times were (they most certainly were not), a tour guide is needed to really interpret this huge place and get some of the history, unless you have a good guidebook with you. Big props to Rome for planting the wonderful trees and other landscape touches throughout the area.

Fascinating . This is most definitely worth a visit. I visited by myself and then again with a tour to find out more about the history of the place. I went in an entrance further away from the colosseum, off the main road. No queue at all and they didn't even ask to look inside my small bag. The queue at the entrance by the colosseum was huge and lots of security checks. As it was the second place I went to after getting my Roma Pass I was able to walk straight in without any queue for tickets at all. I preferred the Palatine Hill area which connects onto this (it's all one big area and you can just wander between the two) but the buildings here are extremely interesting. There are toilets around and drinks machines on the Palatine Hill, although I'd suggest just filling up a bottle with water from the free drinking fountains that are around. You could easily spend a lot of time here so take comfortable shoes!
Lots of history. Everything was being restored during this time. It will great to see after restoration but so many areas were blocked off during this time.

Fantastic view of what Ancient Rome offered. Following on from a frustrating trip to the Colosseum the Forum was a fantastic contrast and relief and enabled us to potter around the civic centre of imperial Rome and left us to use our imaginations to wonder how it was. A magical and calming experience.

Awestruck by the history. Like being in the middle of an important part of human civilization. The place is filled with intact, semi intact and pure ruins. To make a sense of it all I suggest making some research and a guide would be to great help for getting a grasp of it all. It is also good to wander down from Palatine Hill as you'll get a good overview of the area. Let your imagination run freely and you'll hear the buzz of this historic place where so much of the history was decided.

Wow! What history!. We visited the forum while taking in a Rome in a day tour and truly enjoyed walking amongst all the history so freely and openly. Wish we had more time to wander around a bit more.

Fascinating slice of history.. We walked through and it's a wonderful feeling to think about how long the Forum has been in use. Would highly recommend going through with a knowledgable guide given there's so much history and archeology information that wouldn't be obvious as a regular tourist.

Stunning.. The Roman Forum, was amazing, you walk down the paths to where the shops were and the layout of the Temple of Venus. The views at the top of the Forum looking down towards where the Colosseum is, gives you a wonderful view of all of the forum. It really is a special place. You must go. Wear good strong shoes for all the places on this tour.

An interesting walk.. We used our "jump the queue" tickets here that I had bought via the internet before leaving home from The Colosseum booking office sight and they worked a treat. I walked straight up to the Forum ticket office handed over my e ticket piece of paper and was given our tickets for all three attractions ie; Colosseum, Forum and Palatine Hill. These tickets last for two consecutive days. The Forum is steeped in history and there are description boards written in English just in case you have forgotten to bring any sort of written guide with you. There is so much to see but very little shade if it is a very hot day as it was when we went. So have an umbrella with you to use as a parasol!

Beutiful and well worth visiting but do not payy for more than one auiodguide!. The audoguideses have no earplug so it works well to have just one for two people. We got one, and I asked for two as we were a couple and got that. Instead an explanation that one works well for two people would have been great and I got a refund.We bought combined ticket for the Colosseum but the lines were so long that we could not use the ticket and paid audioguide there.This I could not refund. The ticket is for 48 hours, but you can only entry once, so if you go for a coffee break you can not return.
You can't miss this .... After the Palatine Hill wander down to the Roman Forum and just ramble amongst the centre of the ancient city. Fantastic.
A chance to experience Ancient Rome.. A chance to experience Ancient Rome. With our guide giving us insights into the what, where, when and why, he really made it come alive.

Don't leave Rome without seeing this!. This was the absolute highlight of my trip to Rome. We got a combined ticket for this and the Colosseum which was great value at 12 euros each. Don't be fooled into thinking (as I was!) that this is just an add-on to the Colosseum ticket- it is phenomenal and I found it much more enjoyable than the Colosseum. Allow plenty of time to see everything (we spent around 3 hours there).

Breathtaking. Absolutely must see. Get a tour if possible for extra information to help get a better understanding of the history. When in Rome has good tour guides, if your lucky you might get martina!

Take snacks! . There are no cafes only vending machines inside so we advise to take a picnic or snacks as you can spend hours here there is so much to see. You must see Santa Maria antiqua church towards the main part. Stay for 10 minutes and see the light show when they dim the lights it is spectacular and some really advanced technology made this one of the best things we saw on our trip! We got entry using the pre purchased collisium combo tickets ordered through coop website. The gardens smelled beutiful.

Awe-inspiring but disorganised. We visited as a family and the children were mesmerised by the ancient relics and temples. In true italian style, so much more could be made of this incredible place, there was a distinct lack of information or a simple guide unless you wanted to pay for a guided tour. Perhaps the audio guide would have been a good idea!

Gives a real good sense of history. You should not go to Rome and not visit the Forum. You get a really good sense of the scale of what the Romans built, which was a real feat of engineering when you consider the tools available.We spent a few hours there, the day was perfect for site seeing at about 24 degrees. There are water fountains around with perfectly safe drinking water, there are also a few toilet facilities but the queues were long.The information about what is what was limited but I could have/should have bought a guide book.Really good value considering your ticket gets you into here, the Palatine Hill and the Colosseum.Do it, you won't be disappointed !!

Excellent breathtaking. We took a guide and the 18€ price covered the Colosseum. It was worth having the guide to point out all the historical buildings and to explain the origins. Warning there are lots of steps and you need to be reasonably fit. . About disabled access, l could not see any.

Wow wow wow. The remnants of this beautiful ancient city was truly incredible to see. The forum is located across the road from the Colosseum so it’s great to visit The Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill in the same visit. You can purchase a combination ticket for all 3 sites online for 12 euro and it even allows you to skip the lines. We used Rick Steeves’ free audio guide to lead us through the forum. From the Arch of Titus right down the Sacra Via it was an incredible visit. Just walking along the stones where great Roman leaders and statesmen once walked was an unbelievable experience. The forum is quite big and has many sights to see so it is advisable to get an audio-guide or guidebook or something of the sort otherwise you will likely be quite lost. Also, it is completely open so if you are going in the summer make sure to take sunblock, sunhats etc. If you’re going in winter, dress very warm as its just stones and concrete in a shallow valley. Wear really comfortable shoes as the ground is uneven in a lot of places and there is a lot of walking involved. Definitely a sight not to be missed in Rome.

Like walking into the past. Wandering around this former center of the city is like stepping in the past. The juxtaposition of modern buildings in the distance and the ancient ruins is what makes Rome special. Suggest you get a guided tour with a historian for context.

Beautiful Views. Just across from the Coliseum, I paid 30 euros for the tour at the Coliseum and it included the Roman Forum. I enjoyed the Forum more because there's more to see, a lot of flowers and green grass, you can actually sit for a rest and enjoy nature. If you go all the way to the top, you will see a lot of beautiful orange trees. You can also get a nice new of part of the city. A lot of narrow steps and up hill walks but you can chose not to go up. I loved the couple of hours here.
Ancient Rome. We could have spent an entire day roaming this site. It's unfortunate that the signage is lacking. It warrants a tour guide.

Impressive. A comprehensive ticket covering the Coliseum, Forum and Palatine is more easily purchased at the Forum entrance (shorter lines) than at the Coliseum.
A comprehensive tour requires two hours before you ascend to or descend from the Palatine Hill.
Be sure to bring a hat as well as sunscreen/sunglasses as there is little shade on a sunny day.
Good. Well worth a visit, our tour guide was great and this was free as it was part of our coliseum your package. It helps if it's a nice day to fully appreciate this!
Wonderful. The ancient ruins were great. We walked around for hours. My daughter made sure we had comfortable sues on. the uneven ground is torture on your feet, but the sights were beautiful

Dedicate a day. I would definitely recommend dedicating a full day to the Forum and Palatine Hill alone. We attempted to do too much in one day and found by the time we got here we had to rush ourselves. The Forum is beautiful with a lot to look at and a lot to take in. Wasn't too crowded in November which was lovely as well.

Truly Ancient Rome. The sheer scale of the site is breath taking .To think it was originally marshland between the Capitoline and Palatine hills! The various ruins and columns are best visited with a guide or audioguide to fully understand the functions of the various temple ruins and open spaces. There is just so much to see.Make sure you have a bottle of water as it can get very hot .The wild flowers growing on many of the banks add a certain beauty to some of the areas which are just piles of old stones.You can imagine Mark Antony making his speech on The Rostrum.A truly special place to visit. It's definitely worth walking through as we hadn't done so on aprevious visit to Rome , but also worth viewing from above to see its size.
Interesting. This place is amazing, the history fascinating, our guide was fantastic, I definitely recommend to get a guide we used 'Gladiatours'.
Wonderful!. The Roman Forum was an amazing site. We really enjoyed taking a tour and our 4 children enjoyed it too. Don't miss it!!!

The Roman Forum. A large sprawling valley between Palatine and Capitoline Hills with amazing architectural pieces that date back to many centuries, B.C. A great place to ramble on a sunny, breezy afternoon.

Lovely. This is best place to feel and get back in the Roman time. Don't miss the old church inside , they have screen projections that help you understand more, really worth to spend about half day in here, mostly a sunny one.

Free to view- wear comfortable walking shoes!. We spent about 2 hours just walking through the various ruins that make up this tourist attraction. We incorporated this as part of our day trip to the Colosseum and the surrounding tourist attractions. Definitely wear sunscreen, a hat and some comfortable walking shoes, as there are many steps as well as a large area to cover. Beware of pickpockets.

Yes a must see BUT ..... As a historian I fully acknowledge the importance of this site but as in the case of the Emperors New Clothes maybe someone has to say....is it really a top attraction? Basically it is a pile of stones surrounded by wild flowers. Everything else is heresay. We are told it is important and we must imagine ....but based on what? For most people, and certainly the numerous school parties, this must be an exercise in 'so what'. So much more could be done with this site.Information boards showing illustrated reconstructions with brief informative and entertaining sections would make this so much more accessible to the general public and would be a start. Some examples of positive engagement with the tourist market have taken place as in the frescoes on show in the newly opened church but as it is I am sure people leave this site feeling it is 'done' and virtuous because the visit is completed but what real understanding or enjoyment was gained? Wake up Rome.
Awesome!. Use a tour guide to visit the Forum, the history is a necessity to appreciate the ruins. Climb capital hill to see the best view.
Very cool!. Lots of walking here, so wear good shoes. We loved it. So many neat things to see and so many great views. Go in the afternoon. Less crowded.

Amazing if you love ancient ruins. Tomb raiders listen up, there are lot's of cool ruins to see here. You;ll have to pay a small admission fee but if you have the time, it's a cool place to visit. myself, I just saw it from the outside but it was still nice.

Ancient yet beautiful!!. After visiting the colosseum we head towards the Roman forum and palatine hill... It's a wonderful places with ancient ruins of all sorts, the weather was amazing and there were lots of nice places to sit. It's a must see attraction, I would also recommend taking the hike up palatine hill as again, it's beautiful! You can see everything.

Brilliant for Roman History fans. The Forum is a huge area (and don't forget to see the part over the Via del Colosseo which is free) comprising the ruins of many temples and burial places of past emperors. My favourite being the altar of Julius Ceasar. Good on a nice day but if raining, you will get wet :-) Would not imagine much fun for kids as you would need a good couple of hours to walk round it all. Make sure camera battery has lots of life in it.

Rich in history. A great place to visit. Huge area so wear comfortable shoes and be prepared to soak up a lot of history! Don't bother booking in advance as the queues move about 4 times as slow as the main queue who paid less to gain a better service. Other than the poor service at the beginning, the Roman Forum is definitely a place to visit when in Rome.
Great to see the history of the area. Worth a visit if near the colosseum. Great to see the old ruins and have a wonder round for an hour or two.
Beautiful. We did not actually enter the Roman Forum but we walked around the outside and it is beautiful. Worth a look

an ancient market place. If you love shopping and history, this place is it. it is the olden time market place for Rome. It is easy to walk around the site. it is also easy to visit from Palatine hill and colosseum. a must go place
A trip through history. The Roman forum located close to the colosseum should not be missed. It's history and site of Julius Caesar's tomb is unforgettable.

this place is MASSIVE...bring COMFY shoes. This is right next to the Palatine Hill...Colosseum + Palatine Hill + Roman Forum are a good day activity. Lots of walking, lots of cobblestones that might make feet hurt if you're not wearing appropriate shoes.

Incredible. Such a stunning place to visit. A whole town near enough! Walking through all the cobbled streets and seeing the ruins lets you really imagine how it once would have been years ago.
Plenty of shady spots to sit in and some free water fountains dotted about for those hot days!

Spectacular. They've added much security since our last visit two years ago. We toured late in the day (early evening) with a local tour guide. It was very nice. We toured the upper levels (palace area). Great views of the lower areas.
Interesting. Very interesting look at what used to be a center of town. Recommend doing a tour to know what you're looking at

Essential to do with a guide. I wasn't originally going to visit the Roman Forum but ended up there as it was tacked on the end of a guided tour to the nearby Colosseum.Thank goodness as it's fascinating. But do go with a guide who can point out things to you - otherwise it looks like a pile of (historical) rubble.

Amazing, Guide Needed. This is an amazing place to see and behold- with one huge exception. It takes a great amount of knowledge to understand the history of the area and comprehend the significance of what this place represents. You really need an approved guide to get the full value out of touring this site. I was here on the VIP colosseum tour with Walks of Italy. Our guide was invaluable. It would have been near worthless to tour this site on my own. Beautiful and powerful.

Interesting to see so much history!. The Roman Forum was very interesting and next door to the Colosseum. Lots of sign posts with information to explain what each thing is and you can see as long as you like going from section to section.

Great Site but you really do not need to pay to enter it , just walk around it on the local roads. Great Site but you really do not need to pay to enter it , just walk around it on the local roads, all of it is visible .
Incredible. Get your walking shoes and explore this wonderful place.Be sure to see Julius Caeser's tomb. Take water

Our Tour Guide Made This Experience For Us!. The history and beauty of the Roman Forum is incredible, but our tour guide (Jonathan Silvestriuk) made this an unforgettable experience. His knowledge of the history, passion about the people and the culture, and delightful sense of humor made this tour one of the highlights of our time in Rome. His recommendations of where to eat were amazing as well!
Amazing site in the centre of Rome. View it from the Palatine Hill, hen walk down and enjoy it. It is soaked in history, and you will need a guide or a guide book to get the most from it.

Interesting but over our head!. There is lots to see but very difficult to appreciate if (like us) you don't know that much about Roman Culture. It is so old and broken over the ages that you can't really imagine what it was like before.Definitely worth a visit especially in association with the Colosseum or Palatine Hill but how much you benefit will depend on your knowledge. We just walked through it after the Palatine Hill.

Great ruins and the stories behind it.... We spent an afternoon at the Colosseum and Ruins... Roman Forum... tons to see; guide provided a good summary of what this area looked like/was like centuries ago... another great tourist adventure.
Roman Holiday. to stand at the top of the hill look down and think of the days gone by was mind blowing ,beautiful and thrilling.

Facilating site to visit. The Roman Forum was fascinating with a rich history and much of it is still very well preserved. We took the GrayLine walking tour and the guide was very informative. I was surprised at a bit of security that was there though it was rather a mote point since the area was so expansive it would be difficult to cover everything. I appreciated their effort. Beautiful old churches and ruins to explore.
So much history!. This is not something to be missed. It's so full of history that's truly indescribable. I highly recommend downloading an audio tour though for context!

Very Interesting. This is one of the "must see" attractions in Rome. It is advisable to arrange tickets in advance (we didn't and so queued for about 45 minutes). Once inside you are free to wonder the various ruins. It also affords great views of the city and the Colosseum. It is very popular and extremely busy all the time so be prepared for that!

You just have to go!. This is probably one of the main reasons you come to Rome and it is an amazing site if you're interested in Ancient Rome. It was a hot day and there is not much shade.We had an audio guide which to be honest was probably too detailed for our needs and the lack of signage meant that at times you didn't really know where you were straight away. I have one of those books showing before and now pictures and I think that this is more useful. Still enjoyed looking around and there is a newly opened exhibit opened which was interesting and provided temporary shade!
old roam. be ready to walk and you defiantly need guide to know more about the place and how they used to leave before. no to much left also you can see roam from the tope

Stunning roman ruins. Do a little reading before reaching Roman Forum to enhance your experience. in summer, best to visit early morning or late evening to avoid the heat. It is usually clubbed along with a visit to the Colosseum.

Spectacular walk in ancient Rome - take the cool iPod guide too!!!. If you are going to the Colosseum, do not miss out on the Forum! It feels like walking around ancient Rome in a beautiful setting in the heart of the city! I took the family and we used the iPod rental that you can get with your ticket - it really helps to give meaning to the many ancient ruins you see as you walk around and gives fantastic film clips, fotos and 3D reconstructions. Enjoy it!

One of the best experience in Rome. Indeed it was one of the best attraction in Rome, but watch out for weather since the Forum is outside the bad weather can ruin the good vibes this place is giving. You can climb the hill to get a better view over the Forum. It is full of history.

wow. the ruins of the roman forum are really impressive and I can only imagine what they looked like in ancient Rome, shops, gardens, temples, baths, institutions...you can understand more easily with a guide or audio guide
Loved it. I love Rome. I just am a amazed by it every time I visit. This trip was no different. Just a nice relaxing wonderful visit to the forums. It's a must see.
Interesting. Interesting ruins showing how the romans lived. Great views of the city too. A lot of steep jills and steps here so not great if you are not able to manage well.

The heart of old Rome doesn't dissappoint!. It is amazing what remains of Old Rome. The area is fascinating with all that has gone on there. Beginning with the Arch of Titus, the ruins are another must see for archeological buffs.

A glimpse of the ancient Roman city.. A stroll around these ruins takes you back thousands of years to a time when immense riches, skill and ambition contributed to the construction of a vast city of huge architectural significance

Stunning!. This was by far one of my favorite spots. It was busy but easy to navigate. We went on a free day and the lines weren't long at all. I am sure in the summer it is a different story. The history in this space was amazing...another great Rick Steves podcast to listen to.

Must-see Roman ruins next to the Colosseum. A little reading in advance will enhance your experience of the Roman Forum, I used Rick Steve's audio podcast and map also. The rear entrance to the Forum is MUCH quieter with shorter lines, and you can also purchase your combo Colosseum ticket there. Could be very hot mid-day in summer, best to visit early or late then.
Amazing. Just amazing... I can't imagine how glorious would it be to see it 2000 years ago when it was most beautiful ever..
Take a tour . We had a guide as part of a package after the Colosseum think you need a guide to walk round to explain the areas and past history it could be hilly in parts but good view down also.

Impressive . These ruins are really impressive and we can only imagine what they looked like clad in all the white marble etc.
Did this on a combined ticket for Forum,Palatine Hill and Colosseum which cost €12 and covers 1 visit to each over 2 days which we thought was excellent value.

Wonderful. You can take a lot of photos by walking around the outside. So if you don't want to pay you can get the photos here. But if you want to see the Colosseum them spend the extra and get a ticket here it's quicker than the colosseum.
Buy a book before you go!. There is a baffling range of ruins on display here. You get more out of the experience with a good guide book with a map of the sight as the labelling is not brilliant.

Beautiful. This place must of looked beautiful before the Roman Catholic church plundered it to decorate the Vatican. You get a sense of what life must of been like by walking around and taking in the pure majesty of the buildings. It was very hot when we visited so the little drinking fountains were a welcome relief and safe to drink from or fill up your empty bottles.
Worth it. So much history and beautiful city view from above. It's amazing that these things are still around for our generation to admire.
Unreal. So much history and excitement...especially when you are on a guided your and actually hear the stories and know what each place was built for.

Great to get a scope of Roman life.. The shops, the pools, the gardens, the spot where Caesar was killed. It's all here and they all help to give you a sense of scope to the everyday life and also to the changing influences Rome went through. You can walk around and see evidence of the influence of different cultures and changing power structures. I enjoyed the small explanatory signs posted around in certain areas that teach you what you are looking at and what the purpose of the place or item was. Not to be missed.

Fabulous. Walking around the Roman Forum is pretty amazing. Keep your guide book handy though as a bit of information coupled with some imagination is required to really understand what you're looking at. After you've walked around it all, find a good vantage point and just look at it altogether - amazing. Don't miss it.

Prepare he legs and take a water bottle!!!. What a huge site! We went to the colleseum first and that also gave us tickets to the roman forum. We had a small wait to get in, but it was worth the wait. We first checked out the old town section which was very interesting, quite hilly but well worth checking out, we then decided to check out the palace which was absolutely massive!! Just when we thought we had explored it all we would find another area of this huge palace! We spent about 5 hours there! It's amazing to thinkwhat it would have looked like in all its glory fully decorated and functional all those years ago. Definitely a must do in Rome!
Great in the Sunshine. We visited the Forum under a combined ticket with the Colosseum . The ticket is a two day ticket and included the Pallatine as well.
loved it..well worth it. Lovely to walk around and be in amongst the ruins. Awesome site, no shade on a hot day so be aware of this but really enjoyed it.
Amazing History! . A must see when visiting Rome! It is amazing to see the Historic site! You will not be disappointed!
Cool visit!. If you entered from the Palatine Hill, it will go straight to the Foro Romano.. One ticket for both including the Colosseum which is nice!!
Brilliant. Good walking shoes needed and sun cream on a sunny day, brilliant place and thanks to a knowledgeable guide fascinating place to visit.

Wakes up your imagination. A very well documented site with history for all ages. We downloaded Rick Steves's audio tour for free and walked all around the site listening to the narration. This kind of thing is great fun for me.But it was August and it was hot. Good idea to bring a water bottle as this area is sunken in to the ground like a bowl and no breeze to cool you off.Also, if you are interested in Palatine Hill, you MUST do that on the same day because your ticket will not be good for the next day. Nobody told us that and we were disappointed big time.

Amazing Ruins. Palatine Hill & the Roman Forum is worth walking and taking in the amazing history and beauty of Rome. We had a guide which made the experience interesting and explained a lot of important historical facts.

Amazing!. The Roman forum is an amazing place to visit, it takes a while to look around, as it is close Palantine hill, so you visit both at the same time. Lots to see, get a book or a guide so you know what you are looking at. There are water stops spread around the site, so you can refil your water throughout your visit.

Great ruins and history. Did a tour via Viator, got us through the line fast and had a knowledgeable guide to talk about what everything was. I think this is a must see with the Colosseum and Palentine Hill. I think the guide changed it from sight seeing to something more, but there is a schedule so you do have to move along with the guide

Very nice few hours. This was a second choice originally but I'm so glad we did as walking around and having a look up close was brilliant, on a sunny day this is a great few hours and it's not as busy as some of the other attractions

Humbling place. So glad we paid for a tour of the Roman Forum (with Colosseum & Palatine Hill) as it brought it to life (Tours of Italy highly recommend). Seriously humbled to be so close to where Julius Caesar was cremated. Awesome place of ancient history.

This is a must visit place . Although most of it is run down (it is in ruins) it is a nice place to meander through and grasp the history of the Roman Empire. It's nothing compared to Pompeii however. If you don't want to pay the entrance fee or queue for hours then you can see most of it from the roadside on the way to the Colosseum. The best place to view it and get a grasp of its layout is an "aerial view":- Go up the hill on the right hand side behind the Victor Emanuel monument (the big white marble edifice in Piazza Venezia) and you have a Birdseye view. One thing to note:- They sell a two day pass which gives you entrance to the Roman forum and the Colosseum but you can only enter each site once. The Roman Forum and Palatine Hill are classed as one site so you can't go to the forum one day and the hill the next

Breathtaking ruins. The overlook to the Forum provides a breathtaking view of the expansive site. Don't miss this overlook after leaving the Palatine and before descending down to the Forum. What a treasure of antiquity.

Interesting. I would recommend using the audio guide or a tour; otherwise, there isn't any concept as what you are looking at. We were using the audio guides which were informative but the audio guide map had toilets on it which were only planned so it was a bit frustrating.

Fascinating!. I was surprised by how much I really enjoyed my visit to the Roman Forum. This place is truly fascinating. I would recommend getting a guide book specific for the Forum. Mine only had a little section on it, so I didn't get as much out of it as I probably could have. If the weather is warm when you visit, I'd make sure to go in the morning or late afternoon as there is barely any shade or shelter.
A Must See!!!. Roman history all at your fingertips. The grounds are beautiful to sit a spell as well as walk and take in all the energy of the past.

Very nice place to view and hang for a bit. This is a cool place to view. We got the guided tour and 30 minutes to roam about. Thirty minutes was not enough for me! Getting the tour was great to learn what exactly it was all about, but then you need a while to explore. GO SEE IT!

A glimpse into Rome's glorious past. My husband and I had planned to make a day of understanding and appreciating the glorious past of Rome. We bought a ticket that would help us get into the three important attractions- The colosseum, The palatine hill and the Roman Forum. After a visit to the Colosseum, we entered the Roman Forum. We used the Rick Steve's guide book and audio guide to make our way through the wonderful Roman Forum. We made the mistake of going out of the Roman Forum for food and had to buy another ticket just to get back in. So I would advise you to buy some food or eat something before you enter the Roman Forum. Do not miss the grave of Caesar, the senate house, the house of the vestal virgins, temple of turn and venus and the spot from where Marc Anthony gave his famous speech. The list is endless...to keep it simple, don't miss anything and take your time to appreciate what remains of the Rome's glorious past. The view of Roman Forum is spectacular from the Palatine Hill in day and even better at night when it is completely lit.

Stepping back in time. Get there early.The line ups can get very long so buy your tickets in advance.Allow for some time to explore and even hire a guide. Plenty to look at.after you visit try to get up to one of the outlooks to take some great pictures.

Nice views of the Colosseum. Make sure you get the audio/video guide. It's great to see but without much meaning if you're only walking around the stones without knowing what you're seeing. Just remember, you have to leave your id to rent the device, so you'll have to go back to the same point to retrieve it before making your way out. It's worth it to go to the stand close to the exit you want to go out of and start from there.

poor audio guide. We chose an audio tour instead of a guided tour which was a mistake. From the outset it was not clear what route to take, you had no map so had to keep flicking back to the digital map to try and find out where you were. There is written information at each point of interest in English and Italian so much better to wander at your leisure or join an organised tour.

Roman relics. If you book a Colosseum tour you will see this anyway as tickets usually include entry to the Forum & Palatine Hill. With only ruins here it is difficult to imagine the original scale involved but essential viewing, especially as it leads up to the unmissable view from the aforementioned Hill.
Amazing. Better than colosseum. If the line is long, go to eat and come back little bit after. Thats how we did and walked straight in!
A must!. I loved the Forum. It's big and with lots of spots to visit. Just beautiful. The views of Rome from the Forum were great too.

Brilliant. Don't forget to look a little further for this gem. Better than colosseum . It is across the road from the colosseum and a walk up stairs etc. views of Roman Forum from the hill are great. You can walk amongst the ruins and peep at some archeological digging behind the screens.

Build the ruins with your imagination. Use your imagination when walking around and use your fantasy to find out how impressive this was at it's glorious days.Impressive what the romans could do back then.

Beware people trying to shake your hand. Had a fabulous time exploring inside the forum. So much to see. Overwhelming at times as there is so much history, stunning ruins and people everywhere. When we left (outside the main gate) a man tried to offer African bracelets to the children. Upon declining them he took my hand with a friendly smile - at this point he tried to remove with that same hand a gold ring on my finger. Luckily the heat had meant my rings were snugly on and he couldn't remove. Please be aware of scams like that.

Amazing Site!. Very large site. Be prepared to queue both for tickets and to get in (there are X-ray machines). Tip: plan to spend an good part of the day there, there are only vending machines once in so take some food if you need to eat. Good views across the site without going in from the roof go the Vittorio!

Very cool place to walk around. Very cool place to walk around and take in the history. Completely free of charge, you can stroll amongst the archeological sites, the former Roman Empire temples, the place of Caeser's burial, and more. Great views up to the Colieseum and the Palantine Hill.

Excellent. The Roman Forum is situated in the area between Palatine Hill and the Colosseum is one of the most important archaeological sites in the world.
In There you can find different way for different age people for exp. easy way for old people and hard way for young people

Incredible!. I love visiting the forum just for the atmosphere and the sense of history about the Roman Empire. There are so many impressive ruins and lots of useful information about them to keep your imagination occupied for hours. A very impressive place.

Amazing architetchure and an amazing place to go. This place is very good to go if you are ever in Rome. It is brilliant for architecture lovers and even for people like me who arent so keen it is still an amazing visit.

How Spectacular. We haven't gone on the tour yet but we will. You look at the whole area occupied by the forum and several things spring to my mind. How did they build something so spectacular and why is it so much lower than the current street level? The scale of the buildings are impressive, the intricate details that you see in real life rather than in photos or on the pages of books makes it somehow seem more real.

Worth a visit! . As with palatine hill, I recommend avoiding tour groups and instead finding a good book and giving yourself a good few hours to explore! We arrived early in the morning and enjoyed being away from the crowds. The ticket price also lets you into colosseum and Palatine hill.
Impressive. It is simply mind blowing the size and architectural skill the Romans had and Palatine Hill enables you to look over the Roman Forum as well as the Circus Maximus.

Spectacular Ruins! All Over. I beg to differ that you have to use a tour guide. Some of the ruins in my opinion is self explanatory. We are just 2 blokes who love sight seeing and buildings plus there are some information boards around the ruins which gives an insight to the areas. Around the forum you have the circus maxima and the palatine hill. Next time I visit with my wife I would probably use a tour guide. However I would highly recommend you go and see the ruins.
Get a guide and enjoy the walk!. So so so much to see, it can be a bit overwhelming without a guide! I would recommend looking up Dolce Vita Rome tours with Alex Mariotti. GREAT tour!

History lovers delight!. Walk through the roads that once led to the heart and soul of the old Roman Empire. This place held the religious and government headquarters of old Rome. This is worth a trip. Be sure to be ready to spend a few hours to really soak it in.
Vacation. Wow, what can I say. It is just beyond belief at the age of all of the attractions and the condition they are still in. I was amazed beyond belief.
Beautiful afternoon. Perfect day for a stroll, crowds were not bad. Great day walking through history. Tour was very informative.

So much history in such a small place.. As part of of the city wonders tour this location was shown to me in a way that I had not seen it before. The forum was so very interesting I could have spent hours there. There's even some shade and clean public washrooms available on site.
Must see!!!. Must see!!! It took us 3-4 hours to tour this place. We wanted to stay longer, but it was evening time. Great views of Rome, great place to have backpack lunch.

An well preserved historic site.. We visited the Roman Forum and the Colosseum on the same day. I would strongly recommend getting a tour guide. Most guides will show you the Colosseum then the Forum for one price. You can get a guide beside the queue to get into the Colosseum. They will show you it first then the Roman Forum. Your ticket gets you into both also. The Roman Forum is vast. There are many place to get refreshments inside so have coins with you. There is the occasional large map to guide you. There are not very many toilets in the area - a problem if travelling with young kids.
