Hustle and bustle. Personally I think the forum is best viewed from the Palatine Hill or the Campogoglio rather than down among the hordes of noisy tour and school groups. Of course it's attractive and iconic so must be seen, but preferably from a short distance.

Wonderful day...... What say more!? The place is known all over the world, the day was absolutlely fantastic....sunny and blossom everywhere. Walking in the middle of the ruins see temples columns.....not a lot of people... one's can feel back 2000 years.... here just a wiew from above the Circus Maximus......perfect!

Great to see. really enjoyed the trip including palentine hill (included in the tickets for colosseum). We started with palentine hill, which gave us great views of the city and the roman forum, and walked our way down. Definitely recommend doing it this way round rather than Roman forum first.
Beautiful area. Great experience with a guide. The only problem was getting out of the forum. Exit signs are a bit misleading.

Must see with tour guide. Have visited the Roman Forum 3 times. Tried to do without a travel guide and it was a failure. There is so much history among the ruins that it must be seen with someone who knows the ruins and what you are looking at. Spend money on a tour...it is well worth it.
History in abdunance. I have visited several times. Having a guide made a huge difference in the experience! So much history and I found hard to do on our own.

Have guide or do research. We had a guide for this, and I was glad we did. (We used Rome: Tours of the Vatican with Tom & his Team). She made sense of the ruins. She also had this cool handy book that showed photos of how the buildings look today, and it had clear overlays comparing it to how it looked in its prime. But be warned for this trip: wear sunscreen. The Colosseum and Forum don't have shade. My kind fellow reviewers forewarned me of this, and I am so grateful of that advice that I am here to second that motion.

Forum makes the combo with Colosseum. After visiting the Colosseum and the Forum, our family actually agreed that we preferred the Forum (as well as the adjoining Palatine Hill). So much history to explore and with all the buildings, ruins, views, and sights to see, it gave a broader mix of things to enjoy beyond the Colosseum (which you have great views of from the hill as well).

A must see on your visit to Rome. We had no idea of the scale of the Forum and it made such a difference having a guide as trying to put the ruins into context would otherwise be quite difficult. To get an idea of how big the site is walk up Palatine Hill for an amazing view. Great value

Forum. Busy.. but able to get around without a guide.. plenty of info on boards or an audio guide is available.. allow plenty of time to get around we didn't pre book.. in with trip to Palatine also booked for Colosseum at same time

Wow. A huge expanse of ancient ruins...each one with a highly significant history. Some of the buildings were amazingly well preserved...the one with the original bronze door with working lock in particular. The view from the palatine hill was spectacular...made good use of the "pano" there!

So much to take in. The entire area is huge, and there is so much to learn and see. We got a ticket which was included in the Colosseum and relatively cheap. It was understandably busy but that should never put off anyone.

Fantastic heritage . ..but take drinks and food, and prebook...the queues are always shorter for these. It's a long hot day so be prepared...but worth setting time aside with great views across to the Colosseum. If you can, split up the days for both with a two day pass online. Ignore the touts, go early...really early, and enjoy.
Fascinating attraction. There is so much to see and you can spend a few hours wandering around, this is the best place for seeing Ancient Rome.
Great display of Rome's Antiquity. These ruins of ancient Rome makes you imagine what it was like in Rome during the Empire. You can actually see the whole area from the Capitoline Hill above it.

An awe-inspiring place. It's just difficult to believe this place is so well preserved. There are ruins everywhere but everything's so well kept. There's a lot to see. It's gorgeous.However you really need to do some research beforehand. If not, you won't be quite as interested as other people.

Surround yourself in history. The Roman Forum is a must see on your trip to Rome. Just a short walk up from the Colosseum. The queues are relatively short, 10-15 mins at Easter weekend. The Roman forum covers a vast area with all the ruins of a stunning city laid bare. It's lovely to meander round the ruins taking it all in. Many group tours come here so you can get a lot of extra information listening in if you didn't fancy actually going round with one like we didn't. The ruins are very picturesque in themselves as there is really old wisteria everywhere which sets it all off beautifully. Allow a couple of hours and plenty of memory on your camera! Beautiful and probably my favourite bit of my trip to Rome.

Viva Roma!. Completely a surreal experience. To see the Colosseum up close was daunting and unreal. To touch history and imagine life in those times was awesome. To see ruins surrounded by a great bustling metropolis, has you mind spinning and confused. We took the la Rinascente City Sightseeing tour for $18 per person. You can hop on and off the bus. Really great experience.

Better than the Coliseum. The portion of the Roman Forum that you pay admission to visit is a great find. Your ticket is good for two days and admits you also to the Coliseum (one visit to each, the Coliseum and Forum). The Forum is more like a park full of astounding historical gems. You can leisurely stroll among the structures of the ancient Romans and enjoy a relaxing park atmosphere at the same time.
Great. Out guided tour incurred the Forum. It's just amazing and tour guide great and informative - get a real feel of what it was like

A great day out. My son and i had a great day here. my advice would be get a good book rather than a guide as then you can do it at your own pace and visit the bits that interest you. Don't miss the new church exhibit which was amazing.
Plenty to see. Well worth a visit before or after visiting the Colosseum. We noticed the queue near the Colosseum was much longer than the entrance on the main road.

Mostly Ruins - Ancient Rome in Small Area. You can enter the Roman Forum area with your Colosseum ticket (Palatine Hill too!). I would recommend a guide or a good map for your walk through the Forum. Most of the structures are in ruin with little context or idea how they looked before. We did a tour guide one day and came back for a slower walk-through another day. There are some public water refill stations and restrooms scattered about. The amount of history contained within this small area is amazing. We walked around the forum for a little over one hour.
Historic Place. Take a guided tour otherwise the place looks no more than ruins. Headset guide not very helpful, don't waste your money.
Worth a visit. An interesting place full of ruins and history. Worth a visit with a guide if possible or with old photos so you can appreciate what it once looked like.
nice place. here you can see a lot of history and if you have imagination you will really enjoy this place views and architecture is briliant

A lot to see. The Forum is a must see stop in Rome. You could spend a lot of time walking around the Forum and Palatine Hill. There is much to see and in the spring you will be greeting by the fragrance of blooming flowers. I recommend viewing the Colosseum in the morning followed by a lunch break and then several hours in the Forum and Palatine Hill.

Roman History Through the Ages. You should do this as a guided tour. Otherwise you will spend countless hours without knowing what to look and what to concentrate. A cursory reading of Roman history is advisable before you visit this place. Got lot to walk. So be prepared for that.

First stop. We just had luck because we was early there and not too much people, its huge place you justvhave to walk and walk, amizing views its enough to visit just once for life, we pay 7€ for audio guide but we doesnt listen its not necessarily!!!!

Roman Forum. The guided tour had a good amount of information, but left me wanting more (especially for the price). Whether you go with a guide or not, definitely find a way to learn about what's what!

The most amazing place i ever been to - MUST SEE. Honestly, I didn't know about this place. I found out it was included with the Colosseum ticket and right next to it so I went there. WHAT A PLACE! This is the closes thing to being transported to the past and walk inside Rome. Everything is beautiful, you can just get lost and you keep finding these little paths full of beautiful sights and amazing gardens. Dont leave without going here! Save this for a sunny day! And bring some food and water

AMAZING. This takes a lot of walking and there are no rest rooms in the area. Plan out your day accordingly and bring water. This sight is fantastic and takes your breath away. It is a fantastic experience to ponder this amazing location.

Fantastic bit of history . What a fantastic place. It is a must see in Rome. We did not have a guide and did it at our own pace. You walk through and can literally touch history. It is such a mind blowing experience to see this history first hand. My only criticism is that if you go in with no guide there is no signage to say what direction to take. It's not very well signposted in general.

It an amazing area but you need a guide. This whole area is fairly breath taking. The shear size and scale of the once Roman town is amazing BUT...Without some sort of guide the area is not much more than lots (& lots) of scattered bits of old buildings. Probably not fair considering the age and significance of the area but I'm not sure why they haven't extended the audio/visual guide from the Colosseum to include the Forum. We did have a small guide book to assist us but they have missed a trick here...Still worth a visit and is included in the Colosseum tickets.

Great by day - even better by night. We stayed close to the forum so had the chance to see it at different times of day. Very interesting, but at night the subtle lighting brought the forum into a new level. Light and shade give this part of Ancient Rome a living atmosphere, on the night we visited a violinist created a backdrop of sound to extend the lifting effect.

If You Love History You'll Love This...... Couple with a visit to Palatine Hill and the Coloseum this piece of Rome is magnificent. expect to spend half a day here, take water and food as there's no shops available within the Forum and Palatine.
A great tourists attraction . This was an excellent place to visit it really gave you a sense what old Rome would be like. My tip would be to wear sensible shoes as the place is massive.

Very interesting. It was very interesting to visit the whole area and to hear some information by the audioguide we rented. It was totally worth it. I think that the Roman Forum is a must-visit when you stay in Rome for several days!

Simply Amazing. This is a must visit while in Rome. You get to see the spot where Caesar was cremated and the spot Mark Antony gave his famous speech.Forum and Palatine Hill ticket is included in the purchase of the Colosseum ticket.There is a toilet just inside the entrance, use it as there is not another one I could find. Bring a water on a hot day.I visited the Forum as part of a tour group, see my review of Real Rome Tours.
amazing. The Roman Forum was amazing and just so hard to believe all the things that happened here! I would say if I went again I would recommend a tour guide or somebody that knew some history.
Ancient Rome at its best. We took a tour that included the Forum, Palatine Hill, and the Collosseum, and it was amazing. The Forum is an amazing look into ancient Rome.

Ancient history at your fingertips. Make sure you take time to walk thru everything. We took a guided tour and we got a lot more out of it. There is a point that you just see ruins. It's good to have someone to explain. It can get very crowded.
Checked one off of the bucket list!. I don't know why, but I am pretty darned happy that I finally got to see the spot in the Forum where Julius Caesar has a memorial. People still put flowers there!
Really interesting. We had a guided tour of the Roman Forum included with a guide from the colloseum - valuable as it really bought the area to life so to speak!

Wow!. The Roman Forum is a must-visit when in Rome! We had already purchased and printed off tickets online, so were able to join a short queue to enter straight away. Within 10 minutes we had cleared the queue and security. Once inside, we were overwhelmed by the formidable history around every corner. As well as studying the ancient ruins, there are plenty of beautiful gardens to explore, where you can get away from the crowds and relax whilst enjoying a great view of the city. The Foro Romano CANNOT be missed!

Power of Ancient Rome in very close... Must go!. This attraction is in one pack with Colosseum and Pallatine Hill. Take it and go. I was 4 times in Rome and finally this time I got there. You do not wait! This is very much worthy to go and see. There are crowds like in Colosseum but if You come early (before noon when everybody's in Colosseum first) or late up to the evening. Take You time. Try to feel the atmosphere. It is good to buy a guide or book which shows the imaginatin how the places looked like in ancient times. This really helps to understand. I think it is not good idea to see all 3 attractions (Colosseum, Pallatine and Forum) at once.... this is just too much to really appreciate it fully. Anyhow - go there. It looks much diffrerent from down there that from Via dei Fiori Imperiali.

Prepare to walk through history.. Lots to do and see (much more than the Colosseum) so I suggest planning a good amount of time for this. Go to the Colosseum early, when it opens, and spend the rest of the day until sundown at the Roman Forum. You can grab lunch in-between sights.
Brilliant. Good place to wander around and understand how the romans used to live, Some of the information was very interesting to say the least!

spot on.. arrive early and there an no queues at all. Walked straight in.
You can hire an audio guide for 7 euros which I would recommend.
We were there for 3 hours and im sure we missed some bits. Well worth the trip if you avoid the crowds.
Lovely. Must see. Not stroller friendly. Lots to see and touch. Need a good imagination, much like palatine hill. I recommend seeing it at least once. Not crowded in march.
Absolutely beautiful . This is the most impressive collection of monuments and ruins I've ever seen. You must go and spend at least 1.5 hours taking it in. Fantastic. Brilliant.

Awesome!. This place is just as nice as the Foro Palatino, it's ticket comes by default with the Colosseum ticket so DON'T Miss it.
Make sure after you finish your visit to take the road connecting the Colosseum with Piazza Venezia, just like a wonderful open museum.

Wonderful place. Visited with my daugther yesterday and it is amazing! We didnt get a guide, just strolled through. I recommend climbing up to the palatine and from there over to the other side. Fantastic views!

Rome's great past and Empire.. My first visit about three years ago to this area brought many a great memory of the exceptional Great Roman Empire. I never expected to see all the exceptional remains of the Roman era.
Surely not to be missed !.

DON'T MISS THIS OPPORTUNITY!. See this amazing historical area. Leaves you completely in awe, I wouldn't know what could compare! We happened to go on a sunny day and our pictures were out of this world.
Gorgeous, especially on a sunny day. One of my favourite places in Rome. We didn't buy the audio guide and we regret not doing so. We will definitely come back to the Forum next time we are in Rome

A rather humbling experience. Roman forum is quite awe inspiring and humbling at the same time. Its the closest I've ever come to walking through history but also wondering how such a great empire that Rome had came to crumble away in the manner it did. If you are even slightly interested in history or the Roman empire it goes without saying this is unmissable.

Admission into the Roman Forum is included in the price of the Colosseum tickets. This attraction is right next to the Colosseum and admission into the Roman Forums is included in the Colosseum ticket price. It was fascinating to see and take lots of pictures.

A Roman pick and mix. Loads of stuff to see here, most of it great. Columns, towers, arches and on and on. Do your research beforehand and get a feel for the layout from the Palatine Hill before descending into it, for maximum benefit. There is no shade and it can become a cauldron in the summer. Much better for me this time round in the Spring sunshine.

After all these years, still impressive. We have been to Rome six times in a time periode of 22 years and every time this site managed to amaze us. This time we visited a restaured and just opened exhibition about a piece of Tiberius palace which after the collapse of the Roman Empire was converted into a church. It was carefully restaured and now opened for the public. Beamer presentations made it easy to understand what kind of work had to be done here. The final result is interesting and very impressive.

From Titus' Arch to Cesar's Temple, lots of imagination required. From Titus' Arch to Cesar's Temple, lots of imagination required as recommended by Rick Steve who tells you to imagine the hordes of tourists as toga wearing ancient Roman citizens. Lots and lots of interesting tidbits from the Vestal Virgins pools, statues, and houses to the multitudes of left over temples and other structures you will not be disappointing in the least bit. Don't rush your pace, do this on your own with a good guide book and or a downloaded narration track. Take and hour or two and let it all sink in...you won't regret it.
must see. the forum is really to be enjoyed with a tour guide or an audio guide. we downloaded a free audio guide by Rick Steves, and the tour was priceless!
Breath Taking. A must see ancient ruins. It is difficult to describe the site, you must visit it and enjoy the feeling and the view for yourself. You will not be disappointed

Walk on their streets. You can feel the atmosphere like if you were there in the ancient era. Like if you walked the streets with the old romans. You have to see this. All the huge buildings around ... they were really all about the size ;)

I dont usually give 5 stars. but this one was amazing. This Place is Amazing. Its like seeing ancient Rome in a panoramic view. You can imagine How the Romans Lived. Sadly, I was only able to go up the top to see the overview and wasnt able to see what was down there. but seeing it . made me marvel at how amazing the Romans were. I would love to go back to this placeI went on Sunny Breezy Day. and not a peak season
One of the highlights of my vacation for sure. We were here twice on our vacation but saw it from different angles. We took a bike tour which included going here. A must see for sure
Great place packed with histiry. Most certainly worth a visit, nice and relaxed although people with mobility problems may struggle. Fantastic views of the colosseum.

What a walk . It's amazing, I really loved this because I got to walk around and enjoy the history. You have to want to walk around a lot to see everything you possibly can. It is a one of a time experience and you just have to see it! I do not recommend this to children under 10 because you can't run a round and there is a lot of interesting reading to do which i enjoyed. There are 2 museums on the hill also.Things you should know.not a lot of pick pocketing .good amount of walking . IF YOU BUY ONLINE TICKETS (which I recommend unless you want to wait for two hours) YOU MUST PRINT YOUR VOUCHER OUT !.good time
Well preserved. If you like history, this is the place to see along side the Colosseum. Unbelievably well preserved.
Stunning. My friend and I spent more time here than we thought we were so seduced were we by the simple majesty of this site. It is definitely worth a visit - despite the crowds! Go!

Best place in Rome. I could spend day after day exploring this site. Will have to return at least once if not more PS you will need to use your imagination and take a good guide book but it is well worth it.
Amazing!. Great visit here. Make sure you give yourself ample time to walk by all the building and read about them!
Ancient Rome. took the guided tour from coloseum and well worth the price. quite a lot of walking but incredible scenery.
all included..Don't miss. the ticket price is included in the ticket for the Colosseum. it's a bit of a walk (rather trek), sport shoes or rugged boots are advisable

Ancient Rome. we visited Roman Forumas part of the Colosseum tour, our guide was amazing and made the tour really interesting.He really brought the place to life with the information that he told us. The view from the top is fantastic

Amazing . We arrived at the Forum as part of our tour with the Colosseum we were guided through its levels of history with the guide starting off at its earliest part in time and how it grew and how we see it today. The Roman Forum is a place if historical sights with live excavation digs still ongoing unearthing unknown history that has been layered on.

Just wonderful, but read up first!. This is not, as Daisy put it: "where rocks come to die, but the former heart of the empire. So much to see, so either do a 40 minutes walk through or spend half a day here. Reasonable signposting, but get a decent map and guidebook and enjoy your journey through temples, basilicas, springs, rostra, Curia etc. Golfing tone to climb for fab views over the forum.

Amazing experience!. This is a simply stunning site, walking around you can really imagine what it would have been like back in the day. We took a tour through "colosseum & Vatican tours" who I'd really recommend and give you a great overview of the history, well worth checking out!

Phenominal area. this was for me the highlight of ancient Rome again we had a guide who took us to all corners of the Forum.One footnote not many public toilets so long queues when we were there.Overall the place is incredible and being improved upon all the time.

Awe-inspiring . Even though we visited at Easter weekend we never had to queue having purchased tickets over the Web in advance. However were told of the site closing at 3pm only as we entered and this was not advertised anywhere. The Forum and Palatine Hill is extensive and there is a lot to see. Even though I never really studied Roman Civilisation before this site sparked an interest in knowing more.
Apart of palatine Hill. Roman Forum is apart of Palatine Hill so you might as well add the audio tour to your visit, and explore it all!

Captivating history . Only briefly saw the Roman Forum, but from what I did see the history or the remains were captivating yet over whelming. I am aware that you can go down and walk through the Roman Forum and see much closer and in greater detail of what remains, which I wish we had had time to do but were limited due to our short time in Rome!
Political History of Ancient Rome. This was included in a bike tour that we did of the major attractions in Rome and gave up some great historical facts about the Roman Forum

Do Not Miss!. The history of Roma is right here. If you have time review the history in advance there is SOOOO much to enjoy! The Temple of Saturn, The Temple of the Vestal Virgins, The Garden of the Vestal Virgins and the memorial to Julius Ceasar, The Temple of Antonius and Faustina. This was second trip and I feel I got more out of it and different information as well.

Simply amazing!! Just make sure you pee before you go in.. Well worth the visit. So much to see. Will easily spend more than 2 hours. Public toilets were few and far between with rediculously long queues. Make sure you take care of business before you go in. But don't let this deter you. This is one of the best sights in Rome. Don't miss it.

Could spend all day here!. The joint ticket for Roman Forum and Colosseum is a bargain. The Roman Forum is fascinating with so many amazing things to see. I've been twice (a few years apart) and I could still spend all day here because there is so much to see. If you're going during the hot months it's a must to take a bottle of water around with you. In my top 3 of things to do in Rome and I should think everyone else's too!
Amazing demonstration of elite engineering in Ancient Rome. This forum can be seen as part of a group tour of the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. Worth paying for a guide if time is short.
Amazing. This attraction is very beautiful and full of history. I would definitely recommend this to anyone visiting Rome!

You need good walking shoes!!. The site is huge, and I did find it difficult to imagine how it was. I would suggest doing some homework before you go, to get an idea of the layout so that you can understand just what you are walking through
amazing ruin. amazing ruin but was not impressed with the location or area right across the street from the Colosseum very overcrowded and dirty area,
Bah, just broken stones. Without a tour guide is just a set of broken stones... but even does not worth the try... should be improved in many senses
Another must see. Forum Romanum - Here it started and here it ended for the Roman empire. I felt stunnted seeing the 2000 years old senate building still standing

It has a connection to the Palatine Hill. The tour we did of the Colosseum, included the tour of this amazing historic site. From bottom to top,from end to end, the jaw dropping constructions just leave you in wonderment of how in their time they had the knowledge, the skills and abilities to construct such huge buildings that have survived time and the ravages of nature. I don't think that there would be a single construction company anywhere in the world today, that could repeat the process.Again do yourself a favour and see this at least once in your life.
Must visit.. Simply iconic visitor attraction, if interested in the Roman era. The very heart of the ancient city, statues and memorable.
Took this in with the Colosseum. We took this in as part of a guided tour of the Colosseum. A long walk but really worthwhile learning about the Roman beginnings.

Roman Forum. You should visit this with either a good guide or an excellent guide book which will explain things to you, but the guide is better, IMO, because if he/she is good they can answer all your questions & even though I have visited this in the past, I still had numerous questions.
So interesting. Absolutely amazing the wealth of knowledge to be learned by the ancient Romans. Strolling through the streets you get a feel of life in Ancient Rome. I recommend a tour guide.

Outstanding . My 8 year old daughter and I loved it here and spent many hours just wandering around in the spring sunshine soaking it all in. It's hard to imagine that whilst immersed in here, you are in fact in the midst of a bright and vibrant modern day city. However it's very easy to imagine what it must have been like when this was the city of Rome all those thousands of years ago. Our entry price was included in our ticket to get into the colosseum.
Roman traces. Ruins are well preserved, each an every history attached with this place have been mentioned in the board so it's easy to understand in case you miss tour guide words.. ;)

A trip down history lane. One of the attractions that are an absolute must when in Rome. The sheer size of the ruins in the Roman Forum is awe-inspiring. Do not skip the descriptions placed near the main sites. You learn a lot about Roman history and culture from those few lines. Apart from the columns of the Temple of Saturn and the impressive Arch of Titus, I was impressed by the Church of Saint Maria Antiqua (constructed in the 6th century). It is actually the oldest Christian monument in the Forum. Take your time to admire the artistry in the sculptures and other small details spread out throughout the Forum.
Amazing!. Fantastic place, steeped in history, amazing to think you are walking in the footsteps of the Romans. Well worth a visit.

Surrounded by such history!. Rome is certainly the city to visit if you want to be immersed in such history, and this place is where you can certainly soak it up! It was amazing to walk around and dream of what it would have been like in the past. We were limited for time, but you could easily spend an entire day wandering around and still not feel like you had seen it all.

Amazing, but better to read some background about it before you go. I saw some of tourists were taking photo of the Roman Forum from outside without getting a ticket and entering the paid area. You can do that if you have limited time and you can absolutely get good pictures and good view of almost all of the momentum without paying. But it feels different when you can be that close to those momentum. It depends what you are looking for.If you wanna go in, better read some information about the Forum or to have a guide (/book). As you will only be seeing ruins which was heavily damaged and you would not understand what they are/were without some information and will get bored very soon.worth going

Gorgeous. The history of this location is amazing you will find it much more intriguing with a tour guide to give you the stories behind it however then continue TL wonder and explore after to see the books and crannies not passed through via the tour. I wish we had stayed longer but it started to rain on us when we went. So much to see and daydream about its incredible

Walking on history. This place is absolutely fabulous. Breathtaking views, buildings, statues, fontains, orange trees, flowers, birds, peace and quiet. You need one day to see everything that this wonderful place has to offer.
Amazing . This place is amazing. Lots to of history and so much to see. I recommend a tour. You could spend a couple of full days here. Map out what you want to see and enjoy!

Nice to see. Did not buy tickets to see Roman Forum. We went on a road to the top and we looked over a watch area. It was better for us then to walk it. It was very hot and but we still were able to see it.

Part of the Colosseum stop. This is a good attraction. The entire Colosseum area is a "top shelf" ancient historic area. The Forum, Palatine Hill, Muse Capitolini, Monumento Vittorio Emanuele 2 are all easy walking distance, all top notch. Do not miss Muse Capitolini
Get lost in History. This is the best possible walk through history. The ruins are still well preserved. The sensation is sensational and if you are into the past then you'll be dreaming.

Lets go Underground. Modern Rome is around 70ft above the original Rome, newer buildings being built on the ruins of others. This area depicts the way that Rome used to be, the Forum being the marketplace for goods and produce in the open air. Also worth a look is the place at which Julius Caesar was cremated after his assassination by his son Brutus. Lots of other very interesting sites to see in this location.

Wow, wow and wow!. I actually found this far more incredible an interesting than the colosseum. It was vast and amazing to be walking streets and partaking in a vista that had been around for so long. If I had to choose only one thing to do in Rome (apart from eat gelati), this would be it.

a walk through history. when you have the chance to visit such a test ancient engineering know, you always have the impression of being able to walk next to those ancient people, who millennia before us have trod the same our roads. the Imperial Forums are a wonderful testimony, come down to us in a great shape, showing all their glory despite the years have weighed on them. It is always beautiful walk among the ancient columns, visit the ancient temples and see where they are still evidence of ancient entertainment moments of the ancient Italic peoples. gaurd, if possible, by someone who knows the site, because you can tell a thousand curiosities that are not listed on the guides and that will make your walk more enjoyable and memorable.in case you want to go see it at night, you can not enter directly into the holes, but it will be great to see the magnificent parade of the ruins from the road that runs right beside you and allows you to look, take pictures, and also the tables that list the information useful.

Like walking back in time. Walking around the Forum was like walking back in time. you could see the people bustling about going about there business, almost hear the noise and smell the smells of the markets and life then.Well worth the visit. Take a drink and a few snacks with you and be prepared to walk a bit sometimes over bumpy ground.
Get ready for a hike!. We spent several hours walking around the forums. One thing I would suggest is getting a book about the forum before going, it will help you know what you are looking at.
Very impressive. Remnants of the Roman Empire all in one place, monumental and breath-taking, worth visiting together with Coloseum & Palatine Hill
What a place!. Just imagine that you are walking streets of Rome couple thousand years ago! No lines, no crowds, but we visited in February. You can buy combine ticket for Forum and Colosseum.

Beautiful Views. I loved the Forum. Many people flock to the Colosseum, but if you walk across the street to the forum you can get amazing views of the ruins, the Colosseum, and the city. You don't have to fight for a view and you can take your time walking through the gardens and ruins. Depending on where you wander, it can be very quiet and relaxing.

Ancient Ruins. Rome's ancient ruins, its a massive complex. In here you'll see Temple Of Romolus, the ancient Roman government building, etc. You'll need at least a couple of hours to fully see all of it. You'll also need a good walking shoes since the path sometimes are not flat and there is a also a steep stairs to climb. One of its exit leads directly to the Colosseum.

Very historically interesting. This place made my mind go mental, I was able to quite vividly imagine what life was like in ancient Rome. It was well worth the visit. The only downside was the amount of people visiting the same day.

A day at the Forum. Having read the books by Lindsay Davies (the Falco Novels) so many of the buildings' remains were familiar to me that I was able to guide my partner through and give him a mini history of them and their uses. Was amazed at how small the Curia was, considering ti was the centre of the Roman world! but the whole forum site is amazing and worth the queue (about an hour) to enter it.
Fascinating!. We had entry here as part of the ticket we bought for the colosseum (€12 each). There are some really fascinating things to look at and also some great opportunities for photographs.

Be ready to walk and explore. When you purchase a ticket to Colosseum, this includes a visit to the Roman Forum. TIP: Be sure to explore the areas both high and low, as the views are fantastic. Be ready to walk quite a bit, but quite worth it to see all of this amazing, historical area.
Near Colosseum-must see. Take trip to skip a lines to visit Forum and Colosseum.Worth to go there with guide as you may miss a lot of details
An ancient walk. That was my "travel in time" walk in Rome. For those who can feel the history and not just see stones then this is a perfect place for you
Amazing. Give your self plenty of time to view this one, you buy a 2 day ticket that covers you also for the Colloseum and you need it.

Amazing. Thanks to the Roma pass, which allows us to visit the Roman Forums with the same ticket. In the same vicinity as the Palantine hills, you definitely need couple of hours to really traverse the whole area.

Great piece of history. We toured the Roman Forum as part of the Colosseum tour and we are so happy we did. It was beautiful and really interesting to try to picture what it would have looked like back in the day. Great history!

Tour of the Roman Forum. I was lucky enough to visit the Roman Forum and thought it was magnificent. I took a guided tour and found it well worth the money as you miss all the queues. I would definitely make this a stop if visiting Rome.
Great with a tour guide. Loads to see and learn about. Would be pretty boring without a tour guide though so make sure you get one
Fantastic. This place is amazing, full of history, and keeps you fit. Loads of ruins to look at, can get busy, but no big problems.

A must see !. The Forum is included as part of the admission to the Colosseum if you use the Roma pass and is well worth a visit. You can take a couple of hours wandering around the ancient remains which are truly spectacular

Beautiful. The roman forum, is a really interesting place to visit in. The entrance to it is included in the Colosseum ticket (which is valid for 2 days). The place is quiet and nicely preserved and along with the Palatine Hill (which is in the same area) it is perfect for a nice walk after visiting the Colosseum. Just remember, in order to not wait 30-40 minutes in the line to get, take a little walk just round the Roman Forum (on via dei Fori Imperiali) in the direction of Piazza Venezia, you will find another entrance to the area with a lot smaller line to wait
My favorite. Another got to see location in Rome. Use your Roma Pass to see the Colosseum and Forum in a continuous trip. Spectacularremains of Rome and the way it was.
The Forum . We greatly enjoyed this "living history " brings everything to life ..can imagine the Romans in their daily lives, shopping, politics and discussing their world.

Ancient Rome at its best. Very under-rated part of Ancient Rome. Although it might not seem as glamorous as its neighbour-the Colosseum - this is not to be missed. I spent a whole afternoon wondering through the ruins, with an audio guide, and casting my mind back 2000 years ago. I imagined walking in the footsteps of Julius Caesar, Mark Antony, Nero just to name a few. The sense of history is overwhelming. I felt the audio guide suited me perfectly, because I could retrace my steps, and walk at entirely my own pace. Wonderful!
History. Be sure to buy tickets ahead. Going back into history . The architect was outstanding and worth seeing! Combine with palatine hill, be prepared to spend at least 4 hrs.

2nd visit and just as amazing!. Visited Rome 2 years ago and only managed to see part of the Roman Forum as it was our last day and we didn't have enough time to see it all. This time we spent a good couple of hours here and it's just amazing the amount of things that are still standing after 2000+ years, loads of remnants of buildings, arches etc. A must visit after you've been to the colosseum.
Bonus with your Colisium ticket. Be sure to visit this place, lot of serene little corners to sit and chill and take in the amazing sites.

Fascinating. A MUST-see for everyone. Quite amazing to think how old and how brilliantly constructed. Dont get stuck in the long queue by the Colloseum, go in the Via Gregoria entrance and PRE-BOOk or Roma Pass.

Self guided tour. We took the opportunity to use our Roma passes and tour the Roman Forum ourselves. We used the Rick Steves pocket guide to Rome and were able to learn a lot about all of the areas located with in the walls of the forum.

You've got to visit the Forum and Colosseum. You can’t really visit Rome without wandering around the Forum (and then going on to the Colosseum). One ticket covers both of these sites and the Palatine Hill. The most impressive thing about the Forum is the scale of the site, considering that it is in the heart of a modern capital city. You can get a feel of what it must have been like in Ancient Rome.So why is this not a 5-star review? Well firstly, apart from the triumphal arch and the columns, there isn’t much very spectacular to see. The site is impressive for the quantity of surviving stonework rather than the quality. Secondly, even in early March the site was crowded with steady streams of visitors – in summer it must be murder. To see intact buildings without huge crowds try visiting Ostia Antica instead (or as well).A final point, if you’ve purchased (or are planning to purchase) a Roma Pass. It makes sense to visit the Capitoline Museums followed by the Forum/Palatine Hill/Colosseum on the first day of your pass as this will use your two free museum admissions on relatively expensive museums that are next to each other. You’ll then get reductions in any subsequent (probably less expensive) museums that you visit.
A bit dull. A lot of old stones, not very well explained or marked out. You need a good guidebook or guided tour to know what you are looking at.
excellent. amazing well worth the trip. its a walking distance from the colosseum and contains lots of history. It also has a mini museum located in it. Lovely walking around when the sun is shining.

Always Amazing!. Every time I visit Rome I am amazed wandering by the Roman Forum. How one city can have this much history is awe-inspiring! The forum is so easy to access and you get an excellent tour just by walking along the street and reading the self-guided signs. All around you are ancient ruins built upon other important historical sites.

Ancient history comes alive!. Enjoyed our visit here immensely. There is so much history among the ruins and you can find little niches where you can just sit and reflect on it. There are sea gulls everywhere so watch out for them but they made for excellent pictures atop 2000 year old statuary. We didn't take any guided tours so we had to stop and read a lot. If you want to get everything out of your visit, I would suggest a guided tour of some kind. I feel we missed some good stories.

Getting a better sense of history. A must see for all Rome visitors. If you have never visited before, buy the Colosseum pass also together. Buy tickets in advance to skip long long lines. Book a tour of the place to get its full richness and context. They won't provide you with a map of the Palatine Hill or the Roman Forum. Audio guides are a waste of money.

Loved the forum. Our tour guide brought the forum to life for us and just incredible to be standing on stones where ancient Romans had gone about their business. A 'must do' for anyone interested in Roman history.

One of the most remarkable ancient sites ever.. We can not recommend a visit to the Forum highly enough - it really is a must-see for any visitor to Rome. It is a large place which houses many, many temples & basilicas. It is also where the site of Caesar's cremation took place & people still leave flowers & other tributes there.Of course, many of us will have seen pictures, paintings or TV programmes of the Forum, but to actually walk on those ancient flagstones where we know the great names of the Roman Empire once walked, is quite an experience for any history-lover.

Read up before visiting.. The Roman Forum is walking distance from the colosseum and has this immense history attached to it. I knew an iota of it and I honestly wish I had read up more about it before visiting. There are fact boxes so somethings (especially that of the vestal virgins) are quite easy to understand from reading on it but some either leave you confused or wondering what the hell it is. I think joining a walking tour group would be highly beneficial if you're interested in the story and history behind it all but if you're not looking to spend money, Google might be your best friend as you go along or better if its prior to your trip. All in all, it was a beautiful experience and you tend to understand the whole analogy behind Rome being the eternal city. A walk up to palatine hill is highly recommended not only for the view but the gardens too.
piece of history. it is amazing to see that much of history in one place. worth checking, walking around is a great experience.

Part of the Palantine. If you're going to the Colosseum and then planning to go to the Palantine then one ticket bought for the Colosseum covers all three places. It's a great place to visit but going all around every view will take up to two hours possibly. Very worth it however if you're willing to spend a day in this corner of Rome.

Ancient ruins. We combined a visit here with one to the Colosseum (see my review of that - we bartered for a group tour outside it which also included a tour of the Forum a few hours later so that we had a chance to get some lunch).The Forum itself is fairly big and our guide took us around the main sights. There are also signs in English to read too. We just had enough time at the end to get some photos of the sunset just before the place closed.

You can view this from the hill above, to save time or money. I chose not to sign up for a tour of the Roman Forum in the interest of saving time. There are so many beautiful and historic sites in Rome and I chose to skip this one.Instead, we climbed the staircase that looks like a ramp from Via Del Teatro di Marcello, up to Piazza Campidoglio, and walked behind the various buildings until we found the perfect spot to view the Roman Forum from above. I was satisfied with this limited but FREE view of the ruins.
interesting. wow, very interesting place, walking around trying to imagine what it was like in the old days is brilliant, every place in rome is worth a visit

Take you time to visit Roman Forum. Though it is possible to visit the Colosseum and Roman Forum on the same day with same ticket which is recommended but I visited them on two days coz I was living there for a job. You can get a free ticket on first Sunday of every month. If you can plan your visit to Rome by targeting the first Sunday of a month then you can save a lots of money if you are in a big group.
Amazed so much remains. The Forum is well worth a visit you can walk through areas of ancient Rome in the footsteps of the Emperors and imagine what it must have been like 2 millennia ago.
Tour with guide. We did this with a guide in a small group. It was a sunny day and there was a lot to see and a guide is good to explain points of interest and its history.

A good walking tour . It was a cold day and we had a day in Rome , me and my husband enjoy walking and hence arms with a map, we started off walking around the Roman forum , we first went to the colosseum, walked around it and continue on towards the Pantheon , taking in many sights on the way, there was lots to see, I did struggle since I could not find toilets on the way, found. Lovely pub , had an orange juice, though the Guinness beer was tempting. Stopped at the pantheon , walked on towards trevi fountain and finished at the piazza del popolo and then found a lovely vegan restaurant at via margutta

Great Place to escape the crowds. This is a great place to visit, without the hassle of a lot of people around you. Again I would go early in the day, straight after the you have been to the big "C" You can get your ticket from the big "C" to save time. Nice to take a blanket and relax with a cool drink

Absolutely one of the best things you can see. The Forum is spectacular - it covers a huge area with many stand out buildings, or remains of them. For me it was way more impressive than the Colosseum, which is a bit of a letdown once you've braved the crowds. The Forum is very busy too with masses of guided tours, but there are so many awe-inspiring sights and fantastic views that you can almost forget the other people. There are a few exhibitions in covered areas, there are also drinking fountains and decent facilities (with toilet seats!!!!) but be warned that there isn't anywhere to eat (well not that I found). The walk up to the Palatine Hill is quite tiring but well worth it again. Allow at least an hour to an hour and a half to see this place.
Lots of Ancient ruins . Once the heart of Roman life. Beautiful ancient roman ruins, we spent a couple of hours here just walking around talking it all in.

Either study in advance or get a guide. The Roman Forum is a riot of different buildings in ruins, spanning several centuries and many having served several different purposes. If you want to get the most out of your time there, it is worth having either studied the area ahead, or get a guide (or do both). We visited the Forum as part of a City Wonders tour that also included the Colosseum and the homes of Augustus and Livia on the Palatine Hill. Our guide Ambra was fantastic. She was extraordinarily knowledgeable, accessible to a range of people with varying levels of exposure to the history, and friendly. At its base, it would be a beautiful walk through somewhat jumbled ruins, but if you want to come away with a sense of it importance to Roman civilization, an advance investment of study time, or an investment in a good tour, is important.
Amazing. Just amazing to walk around and think of this place being the center of Roman society thousands & thousands of years ago. Truly surreal.

Leaves you full of admiration!. Even non-history buffs (but does anybody come to the Eternal City without being interested in its incomparable history?) must be impressed by its size, erstwhile splendour and sophistication. This is a MUST on anybody's itinerary.

A bit overwhelming and a lot to take in.. A very interesting place to visit with a lot to take in. It can be rather confusing, especially if feeling a bit weary. Having said that there is a lot to see and some impressive structures. Can only imagine what it would have been like in its glory.

Great for History Buffs. We took a tour round the sight with City Wonders and the guide was excellent, full of very interesting information, if there is a next time here, we will go without a guide and purchase a guide book and walk round ourselves, I could have spent all day here so much to see. Palatine Hill was also included in the tour. I don't think that I would have enjoyed it in the summer, too hot and crowded

Another Interesting Roman Site. The forum is within walking distance from the Colesseum and should not be missed. Again, an independent tour is possible but would be much better with a local guide that can explain the history. The restoration of the area is amazing complete with the small building where Caesar was cremated. His palace is on a hill overlooking the Forum and can be reached by a lengthy hike.

A Magnificant Structure. We have been several times. We always see more and learn more about what the Forum was like as Rome's city center. Guide books help a lot as you walk around however a guide is worth the price.

Let the place guide you. I think the best way of visiting Forum Romanum is go there in the morning when there is not a lot of people making photos but go there in the morning and find a place just for you where you can seat and "feel the place". See how the sun lights the stones, see those people who lived there in ancient times, with their problems, matters ... enjoy.

Nearly as good as Pompei. Loved Pompei when I went years ago. Didn't expect Forum to be quite as good but it is amazingly atmospheric. House of the Vestal Virgins was just lovely. Security presently very strict - not a problem but do allow plenty of time to get in.
Nice break from the hustle and bustle of the city.. Entry comes with the Colosseum ticket. Make sure to take a few hours to explore all that the forum has to offer.

This place has so much in it!. We could have spent far more time here than we had. There is so much that happened here in this area, the Roman Empire was governed from these few acres. Plan to spend some time, get an overlay book, and look everywhere.
This what Rome is all about! Phenomenal! Huge! Epic!. This what Rome is all about! Phenomenal! Huge! Epic! Get a guide! You will learn so much more with someone who can explain and show you properly

Great historical perspective. It is a truly amazing location to experience the grandeur of ancient Rome. The ruins are impressive from an architectural perspective. Definitely worth at least several hours.

Walk Through Archaeology. The Roman Forum is an opportunity to see layers and layers of Roman history piled up on each other. You will see Roman Temples converted to Medieval Churches. You look back up to Palatine Hill and get an incredible view of how massive the palaces were. Unique opportunity to walk through history.

If you are a Roman History Buff.. it doesn't get any better than this!!!. I had the advantage of working in Rome with Fatima TV and The Peet & Reet Show for a period of 3 years and it was only until the final year that I was able to spend some time at the Forum and the Coliseum which is right next door. To walk on those grounds was indescribable when you saw the architecture, ruins and realized who had trod those very same paths. My son who is a Roman History Major was with me for a visit and gave me a superb tour. When in Rome do as the Romans did and the Forum is definitely the place to do it. I am certainly not a history fanatic and I found it truly amazing! Put aside a day for sure to really experience this jewel of Rome.

Only 2 entrances open at the moment. Interesting site, not as much information available as at the Colisseum which is accessed on the same ticket. After you have purchased your ticket there isn't much signage towards he 2 entrances. We like many others wrongly went up Palatine Hill which is a dead end. The gate we used is on the same road as the ticket office after the big arch, further down on the right hand side. It didn't say how long the other entrances will be out of use. If you walk to the far end you get an overview of Circus Maximus which is actually quite overgrown & underwhelming.It is worth a visit into the free museum within the site.
Amazing view. Interesting architecture. Very well preserved! Another must see attraction when you're in Rome. But quiet busy to go too during Easter break..

Impressive piece of history right before your eyes. I didn't spend nearly enough time here (or in Rome, generally) and will definitely be back. The Forum is so incredible as you just learn the history and see a piece of the past right there. Magnificent and I think for most people it will take longer to explore than your might realize.

Fantastic sights to see all around. Similar to Palatine Hill, this is a great walk filled with wonderful views of old Roman architecture. Great views all around. Note that this is free on the first Sunday on each month like the Colosseum.

Great historic place.. We went here on a beautiful sunny day and spent almost the entire day there. The audio guides we got at the entrance were really good and provided extensive information on the exhibits. Very impressing, but after lunch it got pretty crowded, so be early to enjoy the quiet. Also be aware that they only have two security checks so that the line can get pretty long. Go when weather is nice!
History. Great trip back in history with wonderful guides who were very knowledgeable and accommodating. Be prepared for lots of walking but there are plenty of places to stop and rest along the way.
History in the air!. Unfortunately we wen't to Forum Romanum shortly before it started to rain. But history lays in the air on every step. For antic culture lovers this is a must!

I was on my way to the forum. At the end of the via national, there is a little roundabout, great fun for watching how Rome traffic operates btw, there was a large chunk of Aincent Rome which turns out to be the Museo Forums. Go in , walk in the footsteps of Old Romans, marvel at the art, masonry, carvings and the overall hooogeness. Was I blown away , yes, thanks to a Latin Master many many years ago at school. ( Thank you Big Dan Garvie) he brought the stories of the Aincent World to life and now here I was. Explore, have fun, people watch. Orate from the top of the steps to the citizens of Roma. I did. ❤️
Incredible!. I could spend hours and hours here just wandering around the Forum. It's incredible. If only Mussolini hadn't built a highway straight through the centre of the site!
weekend visit. a great place to absorb the atmosphere of the original Rome, close to the Coliseum and other historical sites

Excellent historic site!. Excellent historic site, maybe not as much wow factor as visiting the Colosseum but worth doing at the same time. Guided tour is definitely worth the money and your time so you get a feel for the layout of some of the buildings and their history when they were intact.
Wow. This is Rome in all its glory. Once again, to envision what this would have taken to complete is inspiring.

Get A Guide !... Or at least take an "audio tour" !. How can you review this place ?... It's stunning, historic, artistic, politically significant, and was the home of some of the world's greatest (and not-so-great) rulers... dictators... emperors... and warriors. We downloaded a free audio guide from Rick Steevesto guide us on our journey... but you can spend a few dollars and rent one when you visit. there are many groups with professional tour guides... but there are also many local folks happy to earn a few euros by showing you around... When in Rome... visit this place ! Good shoes, and maybe a bottle of water would be a good thing to have available.

Plan a Long Visit. Wow - we were totally impressed with the Roman Forum. We had expected to stay about an hour and ended up staying about 3 hours. The Roman Ruins are truly beautiful and the space offers you the opportunity to contemplate what life was like for the Romans. Also - there are many amazing photo spots.

True beauty of Ancient Rome. I visited the Roman Forum as part of the Colosseum and Ancient Tour which was great as many of the ruins around the Forum were explained to us - however I would have liked to have spent longer walking around here as there is so much visually to take in. This site has been preserved extremely well and it is fascinating to walk around. Definitely give yourself time.

The Original Rome. While this used to be free, it is now only accessible with a ticket to the Colosseum (12 euros/person, 2 euros extra if booked online in advance). This is merely a collection of Roman ruins, which seems unimpressive unless you know the history behind it, so do a little research beforehand or hire a guide. The spot where Caesar's body was burned can be found here, which warrants a visit in and of itself. To get here by metro, buy a BIT Standard Ticket at any station for 1.50 euro, which allows you a 1-way trip of any distance (100-minute time limit is enforced if you're using the bus), then take Line B to Colosseo; Rome has the simplest public transit system in Europe because there are only 2 metro lines that run like an "X" through the city.

Must See in rome. If you are going to the Colosseum, the Forum is a five minute walk away and will show you the heart of the Roman Empire. A guided tour is recommended for easiest understanding of how the buildings were used.Recently, the houses of Augustus Caesar and his wife were opened to the public on a limited basis (pretty much only accessible with a tour group). The buildings are incredibly well preserved with the original frescos in great condition.

Ruins . I thought the 3-day card meant we didn't have to queue but security queue was so long we gave it a miss. Memories of a visit years ago are of the emotion of being in such an historic location. There's very little left to see so save your money - you get a good view of the fight from the campidoglio
Short visit to Rome. Short time in Rome should have planned so much to see so much to absorb. Full of fascination you can't help but to be transported back in time.

Heart of ancient Rome. The Roman Forum was the heart of the ancient city of Rome. It has ruins of the ancient government buildings, monuments and temples. Here you will find triumphal arches like the Arch of Septimius Severus and the Arch of Titus and temples dedicated to Saturn, Vesta and Caesar. On my first visit to Rome, we were unable to explore the Roman Forum with our tour guide, due to lack of time and only managed to explore Colosseum and Palatine Hill. However, this time around, I had the time to visit the Forum.I downloaded a free audio guide online and that served me quite well, viz a viz, exploring the Forum.However,I do recommend having a guided tour to get a real sense of the place’s history and importance. If you are not into history and ancient ruins and don’t really have time, you can choose, just to walk around the perimeter of the Forum and have an overview of the Forum from various vantage points.I recommend the viewing terrace, at the back of Campidoglio Square for some nice selfies with the Forum as your background.Please keep in mind that if you are buying a ticket to visit the Colosseum, you might as well visit the Forum and Palatine Hill, as they are included in that ticket.

So much to see. Take a guided tour to get the most out of it & see it at night when it is lit up! It gets very busy & there are lots of queues. We booked through coop culture got a combined ticket for colosseum, Palantine hill & forum, very good value for money. Wear comfy shoes!
Rome 2016. A great place to visit- so much to see & a guide is strongly recommended-was included in the Colosseum tour so all told the price was great value for money

Worth a longer visit!. First of all I have to say that me and my friend paid 45€ each (very wonderful price) for a guided visit of the Colloseum and Forum Romanum, which I can only recommend! Second I advise you to plan quite a few hours (3-4 or more) for both visits. The visit to the Forum Romanum in a guided tour is simply beautiful. You learn about the history and architecture of it and experience the different levels, gardens and monuments. As it is all outdoors and quite a long walk, I recommend that you wear flat shoes and bring a water bottle (which you can refill there).

Much better than expected. We went thinking we would spend a couple of hours but actually took most of the day. The phone guides are really worth getting as they help bring the whole thing to life. Make sure you allow enough time and try to get there fairly early in the morning to make sure you can see everything as it is much bigger than you expect and there is a lot to see.
A Must See - Once. If you're really into history, you could spend a day in the Forum! But give yourself 2 hours to walk thru even if you are not!

Wonderful. So much to see. I love all this sort of stuff & you really get a taste of being in Rome in Ancient times. You must get a guide to appreciate it fully though. Luckily I had booked a private tour which include The Colosseum & Palatine Hill.

So much to see!. We visited last Sunday. The weather was perfect and admission free, so there were a lot of people. However, the site is so large and there is so much to see that most areas didn't seem that crowded. We spent 2 hours seeing the sights and learning more about Roman history. One could easily spend another 2 hours seeing more. I hadn't appreciated the size until this visit.

The Forum is massive, a great day walking and touching history. Wear good walking shoes when you visit the Forum and plan to spend at least half of a day although you could easily spend a full day. We did some reading ahead of our visit and studied maps of what is here so that we had a plan of attack. We also got the audio tour and found it very helpful. We actually split our visit up and did it in two half days. This worked well for us. This is an outside activity so take along what you need to respond to the weather. Overall this is an amazing place.

Impressive. A must see, when in Rome. Walk through Palatine Hill to The Forum and then onto The Colliseum. Will take you a morning but well worth it. (and your entry ticket is valid for a few days for all of them) avoid the Colliseum queues and buy your ticket at Palatine Hill

Best with a guide of some sort. I liked this stop on our itinerary. While the plaques aren’t particularly interesting at all, Rick Steves’ audio guide helps bring it to life. (You can download the guide as a podcast or it’s in his free app.) We got a ton of amazing photos here.
Magic way. The street neat this place is magic...it's fantastic to go on this street. We suggest this way to everybody.
Beautiful . This location set up the rest of your day on your way to the Colosseum and the plantine, you get a quick view of old romen times

Very interesting place. Walk by this most days when in Rome and its amazing how well preserved it is.
The tourists shows in the summer moths are very good

History and architecture. I love walking through the history of this place, and I am always amazed by the work that the ancient Romans put into this development it is astonishing. Makes one think where did we go wrong.

Essential for historians. Enter by the Hop On-Hop Off bus stop once you've bought a combined Colosseum-Forum ticket from the booth by Septimus Severus Arch.You climb the side of the Palatine and walk the Via Nuovo for views over the Forum. It's not as big as we remembered and there's not all that much there as it's been plundered or built over. Still, it's essential for anyone interested in Romans to make this pilgrimage. Why? Vestiges of the Vestal Virgins, a huge temple to Julius, Mark Antony's speech site and the other monumental arch. The Antonino and Faustina Temple shows you what the Forum must have been like in its heyday.Negatives: the closed entrances and lack of a simple guide like NT and EH supply to their sites.

What a surprise!. Well! It has been quite a few years since we last visited the Forum and it came as quite a surprise to find that you now pay have to pay an entrance fee! How do I feel about that? Well I'll be happy and willing to pay the next time I go if I see that the money is actually being used for conservation work on the archeological sites and not just to fill the pockets of the Comune of Rome! Bear in mind: make sure you get the combined ticket which enables you to visit the Forum, Colosseum and the Palatine. (cost at the time of this review: 12 Euros); if you are going during a busy time (school holidays, summer holidays etc) it's probably worth paying the 2 Euros reservation fee for the Colosseum; opening hours vary but they DO hustle people out before the stated closing time (it was unbelievably, at 4:30pm on a beautiful sunny day at the end of February! So they go by season and not sunset!) Look up as well as around you, there's so much to see above your head! Once last thing - a piece of (obvious) advice to the ladies: wear sensible shoes! The Roman roads and all that walking are painful at the end of the day, even with sensible shoes! Enjoy!

Walking through Time. What a breathtaking place to visit! It's amazing that it's been preserved in the middle of a city. We lucked out by visiting on the first Sunday, so admission was free--AND the predicted rain held out until the end of the day! It was great walking around with blue skies and wonderful temperatures! Strolling around the Forum is like taking a step back in time. The architecture, the columns, the greenery--everything around us was something to take in and imagine what it was like when people actually lived and worked on the cobblestone streets we were walking upon. It's a once-in-a-lifetime experience, and one we will never forget.

Best part of Rome!!! . This was the most gorgeous, awesome place in Rome in my opinion!! It was very impressive and we spent a while there. Definitely worth the money. It's a great place to take photos. Definitely best in nice weather.

I wanted to "stand where they stood." This was the tour to do that.. This was a great tour to take to get a sense of the ancient city. The tour guide was informative and helpful. The goal of Rome was for me to stand where they stood. This did that. The Palatine Hill tour also helped me get a sense of the time.
A guide. It is defenately a place you should visit with a good guide only, otherwise it is just a bunch of stones. Same goes for palentine hill.

You could spend hours here!. Roman Forum was included as part of a walking tour after the colosseum but we would recommend just going to this by yourselves to see it at your own pace because the place is huge. Very interesting and full of amazing history
Great place to see. Good walk around is attached to the Pantheon with both it took us 4 hrs. to walk around both and free with roma pass.

Amazing. Great place to visit. You could spend almost a full day here discovering fascinating well preserved ancient constructions and beautiful works of sculpture.
It was, probably due to the nature of the hilly terrain, nowhere as busy as the Colosseum.

Very Interesting! Included with entry to Colosseum.. Ruins litter the area from the Colosseum to Capitoline Hill. Entry is included with the entry fee for the Colosseum. Wear comfortable shoes and watch your step.

One of the seven wonders of the world. This is a place everyone should see in their lifetime. You need to either go on a tour to learn about each part of the forum, I downloaded an app which talked us around the forum. Simply amazing to see

Journey back in time!. This is a truly breathtaking place! We bought a guide at the Colosseum which covered the Forum as well because there is so much to see and it is that much better when you can understand the significance of the buildings and monuments to the Ancient world. The pass for the Colosseum covers the Forum as well and it is just across the street. We went around noon and only waited about 15 minutes to get in, even with LOTS of tour groups around. It is definitely a must-see, especially if you are already planning to visit the Colosseum - don't skip it!
So picturesque. You can't and won't miss it! It is beautiful and so picturesque! Be prepared that there a lot of tourists.
Breathtaking architecture!. This fascinating historical site is rich in legends and history. It's amazing how the ruins were preserved so well through ancient times!

Very interesting - lots to see!. Lots to see in the Roman Forum. Visited the same day as the Colosseum and Palatine Hill with a combined ticket. Very interesting for anyone who enjoys ancient Roman ruins.
A historical masterpiece. Another must. Start at the top by visiting the Palatine Hill , then follow the path of the ancient Roman elite down to the commercial and political hub of ancient Rome
Excellent. Incredible views from the Pallatine hill. A place packed with history. The entrance is included in the Colloseum ticket.

It felt like you were walking along the same "streets" as the Romans did.. This was one of the highlights of my trip.
It felt to me that I was actually walking along in the "footsteps" of the ordinary Romans, you could visualise the streets, life and activities of the residents.
Access with the same admission ticket for the Coleseum and Palatine Hill so good value and my actual favourite of the three.

full story. Fori Romani ( the name in italian) with Colosseo are places that everyone must see one time in the life. Its was just Wooooow!!!! First: I love the roman story, so for me been in rome was just a dream that become true!!!! Beautiful feel when you are around the forum because you think about story and what the roman did in the past and how bigger was the Imperium!!!! This place is more bigger then you can think....ABSOLUTELY RECOMMENDED

All of western history in a nutshell. Walk through ruins that were once majestic castles, temples, and public spaces. Tourists walking the streets here today are no different than the centuries old roman pages, workers, and politicians that tread upon the same stone walkways. Try to visit on a weekday and in light sunny weather, as the whole area is an open-air complex. Excellent for a history buff or architecture students. Combined tickers are 12Euros for Palatine, Forum and Coliseum inclusive. I suggest you get tickets at the Palatine entrance, the lines there are usually shorter.

Allow a couple of hours to explore the ruins. I wish we had set aside more than an hour to explore the ruins at the Roman Forum because they are huge. They are located immediately next to the Colosseum and include the remains of several important ancient government buildings. It was expanded up until the time of Constantine and remained the political focus of the Western Roman Empire until its fall two centuries later. Doors from the Curia (Senate) were taken to St. John of Lateran's Basilica where they remain today. Entry into the Forum is included with your ticket to the Colosseum. The Arch of Constantine, Palatine Hill, Roman Forum, and Colosseum are all next to each other and should be visited together. We left locks on Palatine Hill and put the keys in shadow boxes we made for our travels to Rome. Set aside at least 2 hours for the ruins and do a guided listening tour. Upon exiting on the Colosseum side of the Forum, was a sketch artist named Roberto selling custom sketches of the landmarks near the site. My friend and I each bought one for 30 euro each and love them.
Must See. You get access here with your Colosseum ticket. Plan on spending more time here and be prepared to walk

Much bigger than we thought!. A real life history lesson, worth visiting. Roma Pass comes handy to skip lines but once inside it is amazing. Please allow up to 3hrs to see everything tho, there is a hill with a viewing platform as well as 2nd part of the forum and a park to visit.
Well worth a visit, as near to Colosseum. Amazing to see these ruins and still some flooring in place after all these years - very interesting

Fantastic culture. Linked to the palatine this place is amazing, free to roam at your leisure, guide signs telling you great information, toilets & drink machines around the site too, included in the entry fee of the colosseum which makes it a cheap visit too
ancient rome. go into deep rich history of rome from this group of well preserved ruins and archeological site and discover how mighty romans rule the world once upon a time.
Full of history. A fascinating place. Taking a guide book or the audio is essential to understand the history of the place.
Travel back in time. Very hot and not shade, but we had the best tour guide that made us forget the heat! Excursion from the cruise ship Norwegian Epic, fabulous history, a must see!
Excellent. Unbelievable. Stunning really and I have no other words. Highly recommended. Ruins are still so beautiful. Will definitely be back.
Amazing!. The history, architecture and sheer scale has to be seen to be believed. No photo can give you the full impact of the place.

Western History. The Roman forum is spectacular to behold, as so much has survived of what was the center of the greatest western empire.
Reading a bit of history before going it sure to add depth and meaning to your visit.
Worth visiting many times.

So much to see and learn. Well worth a visit. We combined this with a guided tour of the Colosseum and loved it all. it was a three hour walking tour and our guide was an archaeologist who had experience of uncovering some of the ruins on display and she had so much knowledge to share with us. The tour was at a comfortable pace, but make sure you go to the toilet beforehand and take water with you. We went in February and was reported as the best time of year to go. Can get very crowded during holiday season and weekends.
Fabulous . A little cluttered with seemingly randomly placed artefacts but interesting. Ticket combined with Palatine Hill and Coliseum.

Roman History . We were able to get in here with the combo ticket we bought and I'm so glad we did. This place isn't that we'll signposted, and you find yourself rambling around. I do like history and all the information there was about certain temples etc, therefore personally I was not to disheartened that we didn't pay for a guide. The place is nice to walk about and photograph.

Breathtaking views of the city. Take plenty time to soak up the atmosphere of this unique site. At 12Eu each this was good value for a world famous attraction where you can spend all day if you wish. Also buy your ticket for the Colosseum at the same time and avoid the queues there.
Roman Forum visit really enjoyed it. you will really enjoy a visit to the Roman forum and won t be disappointed we had a guide for this as it was part of our guide for the Colosseum
Awesome!!!!. This area is incredible, so much to see but you need a guide really to appreciate all the different parts and what they were originally
Awesome. Like palentine hills, roman forum also takes you on ride back in hisotry. Those who like to know history can spend days here.

The best tourist attraction in Rome!. The Colosseum is good and the Pantheon is great, but the Forum is the best AND offers the best view of the Colloseum. There is so much to see, so many amazing stories to imagine. Fantastic.
Great. This was really the highlight of our trip to Rome. Defenitly worth visiting. Would recommend to anyone!
Great History. I am a history buff so honestly I couldn't not love this. It is fascinating to see this historical site and stand where so much happened so long ago.

If barbaians did not destroy it, italians will do nowdays by negligence. Amazing and worth it to see, but almost no indication and few description of the monuments. Is better to come prepared by knowing what you will see and avoid to pay private guide that stand outside, mostly because they are not professional prepared.

History. Walking through the Forum Romanum gives you a feeling of being part of history. Inform yourself before visiting the Forum and you enjoy it much more then when you're not informed. Go see the Colloseum also and watch Romulus & Remus at the beginning of the Forum.

Interesting!. This is again part of the combined ticket for the Colosseum and Palatine Hill and is very interesting and informative along with lovely surroundings.
Definitely don't miss!

Lovely walk in the sun shine. After visiting the colosseum we then used the ticket to get entrance into the Roman forum. This place is fantastic, and you'll spend hours in there is you cover the whole grounds. Definitely a place to go if it's sunny, probably avoid if raining as there is no cover anywhere.Wonderful place to get great photos and learn the history of the place.

So much history it is a must. this was the center of old Rome and as such really does need to be visited. the boards are in Italian and English and give some great information about the ruins. It is easy to imagine the glory of the place and we had a great few hours wandering around here pretending to be British captives brought from England and seeing Rome in all its glory. If you are in Rome for the history this has to be done and is well worth the visit.

Another "must see". You can see parts of it from other places, like the Campidoglio, but there is nothing like getting down into it and walking around all those historic places. Access is included in tickets to the Colosseum/Palatine Hill (good for two days). Would recommend spending a few hours here, probably on a different day from seeing the Colosseum, if you have the time.
