Entrances are off the Via de San Gregorio, South or SW of the Colosseum at the traffic lights (with access to Palatine Hill), or Via dei Fori Imperiali.
Married in Roma. majestic back drop to any photo's along with a major historical center. A must go for any history buff.

Fab day. Ancient rome busy place great for taking your photos try to research some facts before going so you can understand what your looking at much bigger than I was expecting started off at palentine hill then arrived here at the lower level.small church with some sculptures also there.

A must see. good walking shoes and be patient as the signage in Rome is designed to confuse all tourists. An extension to the Metro system has got in the way of seeing entrances & you may walk up and down, steps & hills again before you find the way in. Need several hours as large area. Take a water bottle, snacks as nowhere to buy any.

Peaceful ruins. We went here after the Coliseum on a really hot July day, and found it quite peaceful compared to the Coliseum - less crowded, more spacious & lots of ruins to take in! We were on a tight schedule, had 3 children in tow and didn't really do it justice. We entered through Palatine Hill entrance (no queue) using Coliseum combo tickets & entered the forum directly from Palatine. I would definitely go back, & take a tour/audio guide.
City . My husband really enjoyed this...... we had a guide that walked us through there and telling us lots of information really interesting

Downtown Rome. I love walking through the Roman forum the history is just mind-blowing. The sheer volume of ruins is breathtaking and if you go on a guided tour you get to learn all about the history of the forum. The thought of walking in the same foot steps as Caesar just gives me chills. This is a joint ticket with the coliseum so make the most of it. If you get to visit when the sun is shining it even better.

Walk through history!. Amazing walk through history! You could stand in line to buy tickets and walk the site but it is also a good option just to walk around it and not miss that much. It is near to the Colosseum and the Palatine Hills and they privide a lovely view as well.

take the guided audio tour.. An amazing place that is steeped in history, linking many of the major sites in central Rome, a must see.Beautifully preserved, ancient Roman forum beneath the Palatine hill. Be sure to take the guided audio tour.
Amazing history. There's an app called Roman Forum where you can have a virtual reality peak in how the place looked 2000 years ago - pretty impressive.
The new old world . The best experience u can have there, roman forum plus palatino hill, big history small prices. The world is to small for me ✈

Amazing stroll through history!. How many times in my life have I thought about the Roman Forum? The political intrigue, Caesar, Brutus, (Yes, I know he wasn't actually assassinated here, but he was cremated here!), etc? Given that, it was a marvelous afternoon strolling first up the Via Sacra and through the Forum. The sheer volume of ruins here is remarkable, and I really enjoyed seeing the ruin's ruins. Meaning, this spot has been used for so long, being built, torn down, and rebuilt that in some places you'll see older ruins under ruins from Caesar's time. Some of these would have been ruins he would have marveled at. Just remarkable. My favorite spot here is an unassuming mound of seemingly rubbish that it what's left of the dais upon which Caesar was cremated. A must visit.
Again an iconic stucture. just opposite the colleseum is this huge structure. read more about it to enjoy it to the fullest. can engage local tour guides. very architecturally inspiring

Stroll anong the ruins. Amazing scope of history to view and stroll through and very nicely lit up at night for an evening walk when it is cooler and less busy. Lots of benches to sit and watch people ad soak up the ancient feel.

Walk Where Caesar Walked! . I find it amazing that the ruins and Forum are around for us to enjoy today. A few hours can be spent exploring the grounds at your leisure or by organized tour. The history is so rich and there is plenty to see. Wear comfortable shoes as most the pathways are gravel and dusty. Bring a camera because this will be a highlight you will want to capture, and can! Many of the museums in Rome have restrictions on photography but the forum is accessible and will provide beautiful shots. Dawn or dusk provides optimal light and even daytime is good for capturing the giant shadows cast by the ruins.
A mind-blowing history lesson!. This is the site of numerous temples and basilicas, with further discoveries ongoing. Includes the site of Julius Caesar's cremation.

so much to see. You could easily spend half a day looking around this complex of world important buildings and tying them in with all you have seen and heard regarding ancient Rome.Lots of people but then it can take it.As Marc Anthony said from the middle of this area "friends, Romans, Countrymen lend me your ears" "Oh and your imagination"

Loved it!. So much history is a relatively small space is overwhelming! The history and architecture, for me was hard to get my head around, simply stunning! More information boards would be helpful to know what you're looking at. Bargain to be included in the price of the Colosseum ticket!

So much history. This was by far the most interesting place I visited in Roman. There was so much history on show for such a small area. There were ancient roman ruins where ever you looked; the area being steeped in history. I spent a good hour and a half exploring and learning about the temples, monuments and ruins on show. I would defintely go back again.
Six nations. Wow this place is a must. Didn't get time to visit last time we were in Rome. Get yourself a guide. Truly amazing history. We really recommend this. Enjoy.
A hidden gem!. Be prepared to walk a lot over this Forum! Again a n amazing place,full of history and very vast. It goes for miles , a great place where you go back in time. A must do tour.

Together with the Colosseum. Consider to take a guided tour, there is a lot to know and understand about this place, the ticket to the Forum is also good for the Colosseum and better buy it in the Forum Cashier.

A huge historical masterpiece. Tips: Enter from the Palatine entrance to get sweeping views before submerging yourself in the ruins. i came after lunch which was relatively quiet. the roman forum is huge, photos do not give due justice in terms scale and scope. It was an amazing feeling walking through 2000 years of history. the crumbling temples and pillars just give a different feeling then anywhere else in Rome like how small we are in the grand spacethe highlight is the Arch of Septimius Severus. its Huge and quite elegant. and also the Bacilica of Maxentius the largest and the most highly decorated building there.

Positively Overwhelming. Before my trip to Rome, many friends suggested I should skip Roman Forum, because it's "just ruins, and not even special ruins". My motto is that I can visit only super-shiny and great-looking things. You need a bit of history and a bit of everything else. You have to have a complete impression of a town and it's "being" as a whole.That being said, this area was the place I enjoyed the most. Not only for its historical importance and me imagining the ancient settlements, but also for its open space. Finally a place where you can breathe, walk and enjoy in peace without being clammed and stuck with thousands of people in small space.
Amazing. A unique experience walking through ancient Rome in the middle of modern Rome - quiet surreal and awe inspiring.

Really Something to See. The Forum, including Palatine Hill are true works of art. The history that is there is something to behold. We really enjoyed this site, trying to imagine life back some 2,000 years.

Incredible to see this city!. They have done now an special effects little museum inside with technology that was not there before. I have visited many times, since my family lives in Rome, i have been there about 12 times. Read before you go so you can see and recognize what you are looking at.

Words are not enough, great place of old Rome. You can feel the Roman life of the ancient. Read before you go carefully about all the buildings, because they are almost all ruined, but we figured it all out.

Well worth seeing. We came back the day after The Colosseum (tickets valid for two days and only 14 Euro) as we had more time.The grounds have a certain aura about them and you can imaging what life was like in Roman times.Comprehensive information boards explain each exhibit but tours also available if you wish.Have to visit here if in Rome.....

Must visit. Amazing place full of history. You have to visit after or before Colloseum. It's amazing to walk through the ruins. This is amazing about Rome. Everywhere you look it's a pieces of history. Great city! Be aware that the tickets to Colloseum are available also for Roman Forum and they are available for 2 days.
Less crowd in February . We stayed at the Rome Times Hotel and it was a easy walk to the Roman Forum, it took us 14 to get here. We came here on a Sunday and the crowd was much.
Walk for hours. The ticket for the Colosseum is good for the forum too. Spend as long as you want walking through the historic grounds of the roman empire. amazing to experience.

Awesome and humbling. Its amazing that some much of ancient Rome has survived, despite being in the centre of a city that has been continuously lived in. The Forum is probably one of the single most important locations in the world, given how many important events took place here - and it is completely aweinspiring to be able to walk along its roads, and to see its temples - including the location where Caesar was cremated. I found the the whole experience to be utterly humbling.The only downside is that, because Rome has so much history, they have been a little careless in maintaining some of it - and some ancient artifacts are placed in highly inappropriate locations, simply because it might look better.

A One of a Kind Stroll through Millennia of History - Watch for Early Closures. This is one of those places that has so many layers of history it's hard to absorb it all. See the exact spot where Marc Anthony said, "Friends, Romans, Countrymen, lend me your ears!." Marvel at traces of medieval hoologans trying to cut down ancient marble pillars to make cement. See where the mad emperor Caligula was murdered by his own palace guard.Some of these tidbits were on signage provided by the Italian Archaeological authorities, most were not. Be sure to take along something that helps you grasp the context and interrelationships of what you see. I brought along Rick Steves' walking tour of the forum on my iPad. Made all the difference. TIP: if you bought a Roma card be sure you use it on the Colosseum/Palatine Hill/Forum sights. They are the most expensive attractions on the list and only the first two sites you visit are free.We had planned to continue our tour of the Forum until 8:30, but were surprised at a closure announcement about 4:30. Check their website the day of your visit to see when they actually close. It worked out for us, but just barely.Highly recommended. One of the things you MUST see when in Rome.
Rome. A must after the colosseum a good walk though history amazing to think we Brits where so far behind them
breathtaking. Amazing especially when you learn that all the marble and precious stones that were once there are probably in the vatican museum...gave me goosebumps when i stepped into it

It's what you come to Rome for!. We had missed doing the Forum in May 2015,because the weather was too hot. Although the weather forecast for our visit was not good this time, we decided to go for it - luckily the forecast was totally wrong, and we had a sunny but cool day, perfect for wandering around this wonderful place. There are various entrances, and we found the one near the Wedding Cake was the best bet. Although a little slow, the queue did finally get us to the reception, where we paid for the Forum audio tour - you can pay a little extra for the Palatine Hill as an extra. The audio tour was easy to use, and it is very informative, as well as easy to collate with the numbers around the Forum. If you have ever had an interest in the Roman Empire, this is the place to be. To see where Julius Caesar was cremated after his assassination, to stand where Cicero gave his orations, and to see where the Vestal Virgins lived was amazing, you could feel the history all around you. We did go up the Palatine Hill, where there are panoramic views across the city, and down to the Colosseum. There are water fountains around the site for refreshing yourself with the famous Roman waters. A fantastic experience which must be done if in Rome.

Get your Colosseum tickets here!. I absolutely loved the Roman Forum. It was a great build to seeing the Colosseum, and didn't have the same queue length for entry. I travelled in September, and the weather was baking hot... take plenty of water (and snacks, as the kiosks are pricey) :-)

Incredible!. So many ruins to explore and wonder through. If you have interest in mythology and roman culture, this is the place for you when you can see the ruins and the old temples people you to spend their lives in.

Stunning and you need a full day combined with Colosseum. The sun was out and warm (in Feb) - ideal for this visit probably too hot in summer, go on a tour for this - Real Rome Tours very good as they are informative without being boring

Stunning and you need a full day combined with Colosseum. The sun was out and warm (in Feb) - ideal for this visit probably too hot in summer, go on a tour for this - Real Rome Tours very good as they are informative without being boring

A bit of history within the modern world.... I found the forum to be so interesting because these ancient structures are surrounded by modern ones and busy streets. The forum is huge with a lot to offer as well as great views if you can find them. Wear good shoes and enjoy a step back in time (:
Worth a visit. Definitely worth a visit as part of the joint entry ticket to the colosseum, forum and palatine hill. Probably best to visit on a dry day as there is no shelter. Fascinating ruins!

Wonderful. Can't believe this is still standing and has survived so long. You can wander through at your leisure and get an idea of what Roman life was like as this is the main part of what was the Roman Rome.

Stroll through decades of history. After visiting the Palatine Hill our exploration continued in the Roman Forum. We climbed down some stairs, which offered great views over the Roman Forum. The ticket is included in the Colosseum ticket, but also in the Roma Pass (combined with the Colosseum). It was just another great way of taking in all that Rome has to offer. You could walk for hours and never get bored. It sure takes some time to understand the significance of the place and somehow you fully grasp it once you get back home. The Roman Forum leaves you craving for more.
A delight. And you get to see it again while wandering around Rome.. So much to look at and imagine. Very nice wandering around. Many glimpses from other streets not even inside the premises.

Overwhelmed by modernity. You sort of come across the forum like it has been plonked there by mistake. Of course it is stunning in its antiquity but hardly stands out next to the Colosseum and other grand buildings. Personally I preferred Pompeii or indeed any number of preserved Roman sites.
Kids loved it. This site is really neat to see. My kids loved exploring and pretending they were adventures. They could have stayed all day. A must in rome.
Steeped in history. Great experience. Was pleasantly surprised to visit this site on the back of my Colosseum tour ticket.

Allow time to wander. Do allow plenty of time to wander around this amazing site. There is so much to see over a huge area. Take a good guide book with you though as the information boards are not too good. We spent over 3 hours in here so take some water and a bite with you.

Ancient Ruins. Now, if you like can see a lot of this for free, you do not have to go inside to see the ruins. If you do you have access to the Palatino and the Colosseum as well. Also if you are visiting the Colosseum then the Forum is the place to buy the tickets to avoid the ridiculous queues at the Colosseum. For the free option you can nearly walk around the entire perimeter of the forum if you really want to budget.

Excellent. Absolutely loved our trip to the Forum and Palatine Hill (it's all one site). It's just across from the Colosseum and it's €12 to get into both sites. Our tips would be: wear good shoes and be prepared to do a lot of walking, bring a water bottle to refill at the drinking fountains, bring lunch with you because there's no food inside and they wont let you come back in if you go out to get food, if possible avoid going in the rain or high summer because there's very little shelter and either bring a guide book or use the audio guide/ a tour guide because there's very few signs to tell you what you're looking at as you walk round.

A PLACE FOR THE IMAGINATION. Your imagination runs wild when taking in these ruins. It's amazing to see the level of preservation in the centre of a city. We passed this site every day on our 4 day stay in Rome and the impact it was having on people viewing it was as interesting as the site itself!

Superb. If we had more time, we would have gone back to this 2 or 3 more times. It was absolutely gorgeous to walk around and view the ruins. Sunshine, history, beautiful walking? Who could ask for more. Unfortunately, we went before lunch, all of us needing to refuel and relax. Loved it.

nice and wanderful. when you are in this place, you will see how littel we are, and how big the romen were, the buildings are relly sooo big, so nice, every thing was made perfectly, how they study things in the past, how they calculated every thing perfectly,whenever you are there have fun with sun and i advice you just walk and walk and walk, walk to see better the stregth and the opera of romans, to make sport, and to have the sun on your body while you enjoy your trip, tray to take the hand of your girlfreind or boy freind, because the italiens are so sexy that may rob your couple (mafiosi) LOL,go there and enjoy your trip.

The heart of the Ancient Roman Empire. We spent a perfect afternoon exploring this ancient site. This was a marketplace, the center of government and life. You'll see various styles of architecture, churches built on top of temples, arches, columns, statues...it's a wonderful place to lose yourself for a few hours. A must see and right next to the Colosseum.

walking through history. We had a private guide which I think is a necessity here - it is hard to understand what you are looking at with out a good guide to help you imagine what Roman life was like.

Was nice but not clean and disappointing on how it is being maintained. I don't think that you can rank a piece of history less than "very good" but it looks like the forum is not being well taken care of. When we were there graffiti was on some of the structures, the landscaping was a mess, and there was no oversight as people were walking all over buildings and monuments. We were surprised that there was no security or someone trying to preserve this historical area.

Do not miss this but get a local guide for the history. We had a local guide who grew up in Rome and she was awesome. Just the history of this area is staggering. Its overwhelming. Do your reading and homework before you go here, so what is then shared by the guide means more and you can truly enjoy this moment, its fantastic.
If you have extra time go. I wouldn't say I didn't enjoy this stop but after seeing the coliseum I was not at all impressed.....

Awe-inspiring feeling. The center of Roman public life. This small valley between the Palatine and Capitoline Hills has has got so much of history that one can spend the whole day researching. I recommend ones takes a guided tour of this place to understand each structure. A place worth visiting for the history enthusiasts.

4 go sight seeing. amazing place to visit well worth the queue well worth the money plenty to see & take in top tip take a bottle of water with you & refill from any of the water fountain its ok to drink from these
Roman Forum. The broken pillars and walls really took me to the past. You need to walk a lot, carry water bottle always. Specially Palatine Hill + Roman Forum ticket together.
it's a must!. amazing area that you can just stroll around and take in the sights before or after a visit to the Colosseum. Highly recommended. 1-2 hours is fine.

Ancient Rome, Must Visit! . Get your ticket in front of Colosseum, and you can visit both the Roman Forums and inside the Colosseum. Be there early in the morning, otherwise you would not have enough to explore the whole site and Colosseum before sunset. I spent 10 hours for both. It's amazing historical place!
Very interesting. Went to the Forum as part of our Colosseum guided tour. Very interesting buildings and history. Definitely walk up to the top part for great views across Rome.
A must see!. It's amazing to get to see the Roman ruins. The detailing on the buildings is so impressive from hundreds of years ago.

Only interesting for the historians of archaeologists.. Ok, I do appreciate it's significance to Rome's history but as a site for visitors it's quite boring unless you are really into old ruins. You really do need a tour guide which we did have and she explained what the "bits" were but you need a very good imagination to fully appreciate how things may have looked in the past.If you are limited for time in Rome then go somewhere else as this is really not worth the time, effort and money.

History heaven! Ancient Rome brought to life.. Utterly breathtaking - the size of the monuments, the realisation of their age and the incredible craftsmanship, the history and architecture and archaeology - just mind-blowing. I'd recommend a whole day's visit for the best experience possible. Buy tickets at the Palatine Hill entrance for a shorter queue!
You simply have to go . Stunning stunning stunning. Endless history and just so much to take in. Miss it and it's your loss. Excellent place for history lovers

Understated centre of ancient Rome.. Many buildngs and ruins that were central to the government and life of ancient Rome. See how and Hadrianm Julius Caesar and others governed Rome. The romans do not make enough of this magnificent site.
Top of the List. It has to be the number one place to go when visiting Rome. There are triumphant arches, temples and more. There is so much history in one place that it is hard to take it all in.

Great site, so much to learn. I recommend this tour. Multiple sites, at the same time relaxing scenery. We visited Roman Forum in February 2016 and it was perfect - no lines or crowds and weather wise it was very comfortable 65 degrees.

Excellent attraction. Although you can see much of the site for free from the surrounding streets there is nothing like pounding the Roman streets to get a feel for the sheer size and quality of the area
An excellent attraction
An absolute must-see. The heart of ancient Rome, just steps away from the Colloseum, in the heart of the city's downtown area.

Great value and views! . This is well worth a visit. Great views across Rome and lots of incredible structures to marvel at. I personally found it amazing. You almost find it it impossible to believe the scale and quality of engineering. Be warned though there is a lot of walking (some on uneven ground) to be done, so make sure you've got decent footwear on!

More information than when I last visited. Audio tours available but worth downloading one before travelling or at least bringing a half decent guide book. Would advise seeing this before the Colosseum as it adds context and perspective.
Amazing. Absolutely outstanding, an amazing piece of history. Despite some parts being closed for maintenance, there was still a huge amount to take in.

Ancient Ruins. Just visiting the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill today in glorious sunshine.Buy the joint ticket for here and the Colosseum to save time later. We continue into the Forum and were pleasantly surprised at the sheer scale of the site. It's in the state you would expect old ruins to be in but still there are enough sections remaining to help visualise how things would have looked in the Roman era.Not a lot of signage but just wander would be my suggestion then walk up the Palatine Hill and you realise that with status you rise to the highest sections of the hill and look down at all around you.Great photos throughout. Hard on the news and back and make sure you wear very sensible shoes. Worth the visit as the are some fab photos to be taken including views to the Colosseum.Well worth the 12 euros
Nice place. I bought tickets for Colloseum, Roman forum and Pallatine hill.Roman forum is ok I really liked Pallatine hill
Hail Caesar!. I always wanted to see the Forum and when I finally did, all my dreams were fulfilled. The idea that I walked the same paths as Caesar and Cicero just blew my mind!

Roman Forum. We toured this on our own after we had gone to the Colosseum, it was a REALLY REALLY Hot 93 degree ( at least) day in August! We toured on our own, however I would recommend downloading Rick Steve's rome app before you go and you can listen to it as you tour. Unfortunately it didn't work on my phone when I tried!

Must see! But with a guide.. We visited the Forum as part of a walking tour which included the Colosseum and we are soooo pleased we did. The scale of the Forum is unbelievable! But I do feel without a guide telling you what things are or used to be and where things were etc I think we would have spent 10 minutes looking at a huge ruin and walking away. Our guide was incredible, with so much historical knowledge she just kept you so interested and wanting more.

Epic Epic Epic. No words to describe it, it is just amazing, wonderful, full of history. Though some monuments are destroyed, you can feel how Roman people live in the past, and how advance they were. Honestly, it is epic. That street that contains Colosseum and Roman Forum is historical

Fantastic attraction, hopelessly organised. Visited February 2016 as a family of three.Queue for ticket office was idiotically slow. Only two windows open. Be warned they would only take credit/debit card payments. Cash not allowed.When we did finally get tickets we then couldn't find the way in! Entrance closest to the ticket office was closed. Very poor signage. We finally found entrance where there was another queue albeit it turned out this was for another ticket office and so actually you could avoid this.Overall a frustrating visit but the attraction itself, when you get in is well worth it. Cost for two adults was Euro24 with my 16 year old free.

Go with a good guide. The Forum is fascinating. We booked at tour through City Wonders. Francesca is an archeologists and provided interesting detail throughout the tour. I would not have gotten as much out of it had I just read a few tour blurbs and wandered through on my own.

Ancient Rome in all of its glory. This was our first trip to Rome and visiting the Roman Forum was certainly on our to-do list. We heard about the long lines and how you can spend a lot of time waiting so we booked a Colosseum Tour with Special Access to Underground & Arena Floor through Expedia. The tour was conducted by City Wonders and the whole tour was AWESOME!!! It started with a guided tour of the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill and ended with an incredible tour of the Colosseum. This tour allowed us to bypass all of the lines tied to all three of these sites and our guide gave us a very comprehensive tour of each site and provided us with so much incredible back story to really help our group really understand what we were seeing. The magnitude of the Roman Forum is striking. It encompasses a very large area and while they are ruins, you do get a good feel for just how impressive this area really was back in its day. The guide that accompanied us throughout our tour was awesome and really helped bring it all to life for us. So much better than an average audio tour. The entire tour (Roman Forum/Palatine Hill/Colosseum) was awesome! I'm so glad we paid the extra money for that very unique and enjoyable experience.
Pretty amazing. Spend a few hours exploring the ancient ruins and taking some great pictures to cherish what once was.
Historical hideout. We came here on our last full day. The place is amazing: history, vary nice park, nice panorama to the city. We were amazed all of sights.

History tour. Enjoyed the Rick Steves audioguide tour of the Forum and appreciating the Roman architecture that remains. Beautiful afternoon activity. Picturesque with the warm afternoon sun. The entrance and exit were a bit confusing to find, however eventually we entered thru the palatine hill entrance after leaving the colosseum

Ancient Rome at its best. When in Rome do what the Romans did,the forum is one of the most interesting places in central Rome. When your wandering around the mighty ruins you soon get the gist of how thing were, the remaining buildings give a good visual view of the way the Romans ran their lives. Everything is massive as was their beliefs in gods, the layout gives good indication as to what each building was used for. This was one of the areas where senators and dignitaries lived and worked. The temples are well defined and the temple of vestal virgins is clear to see along with other important structures. Easily spend a good half day believing yourself to be an important Roman lost in what must have been a fabulous ancient city.. Will spend more time exploring next time we visit.

Worth the visit. Huge area allow plenty of time walk around buy combined colluseum ticket and you can use next day. Popular site tour buses stop right by entrance.We visited in February would imagine in summer its very hot some shady places. Toilets inside entrance!

perfect for ur slice of roman history. this place is great for ancient roman bluffs. the audio tour they supply is adequate. plan to spend an afternoon here as the palantine hill has a museum in it. you can look at various roman structures and then walk up the hill to look at 15th century papal financed constructions.

Striking. My partner and I were taken aback by the Forum. The sheer size of some of the ruins give an idea of how grand it must have been. The best view was from the side of palatine hill that drops down into the Forum. We did Palatine hill first but would probably have preferred to do the forum first and have learnt where everything was and what it was before looking down on it. The audio guide was useful and interesting and I would recommend it.
must-see. I spent in total around three hours exploring around the area, rich history and unbelievably beautiful

You need to visit this and stay for as long as possible!. I was absolutely amazed when we went round here. There is so much to look at we actually came back the next day to do more! Find a map of the place as you can easily miss parts by not knowing how to find it. Also go into the museum they have with artifacts as old as 600 BC. There are signs up in English to explain what most things are.It's really hard to describe how amazing this place is. If you like history or the Romans or old things/buildings then you have to visit here. I'd give at least 3 hours for your trip (the longer the better!). You can get a joint Colosseum/Forum ticket but buy it from the Forum ticket desk as the queue is always considerably smaller there. Joint ticket is 12.00 euros and valid for 2 days. There is also discount for EU members aged 16-24.priced at 7.50 euros.

A Must See Location in Rome. This is such an awe inspiring sight in Rome. There are many ruins and columns still remaining of this once bustling and affluent area and walking through it makes you wish you could have been there when it is was at its peak. When you buy a combination ticket for 12 Euros, you can visit this and the Palatine Hill one day and the Colosseum on the second day.
A must see. It is amazing to walk through here and imagine the gatherings that took place. I didn't take a tour, next time. I was here on a beautiful sunny day and I enjoyed it immensely.

Great History, but get a tour guide. . There is so much to see it can be a bit overwhelming. I've gone a few times, but this time was so much better due to the guide. It is like turning on the lights in a dark room.

Brings your history lessons to life. Excellent venue to walk around and take in the buildings which remain as well as the ruins of ancient Rome. History brought back to life, not a venue to visit if raining however.
Magical. Entry via Palantine Hill..You wont be disapointed with the Roman Forum. A must when visiting Rome. Take you camera.

Amazing Place to Visit - don't miss it.. Well worth the visit. Such a broad span of history contained within such a small area. There are temples, the home of Augustus and Julius Caesar, the remarkable Arch of Septimus Severus which is in amazing condition and last but not least the Forum itself where the political debates of the day were conducted.There were restrictions on movement when we were there because of refurbishment.

Sentimental return. Been here several times but nostalgia wins! Error 1: should have pre-booked. Error 2: should have seen the small notice by the coliseum entrance to the forum which told us the Via Sacra was not open. Otherwise, it was the charming muddle it always is. Feel free to wander uninformed as most were doing but better, do your homework and probe the history.

Amazing 5/5. This was one of the best attractions we did on our trip to Rome. There is so much to see and the history is unreal. Best to do this on a dry day as it wouldn't be as good in the rain. Is worth the visit but can be a long day.

Exceptional architectural beauty. Throughoughly enjoyed. The sights were incredible. Great value. Well looked after - this showed off Rome as you imagine it! One exit was closed due to refurbishment and this confused many - did take us a little time to find the correct entrance,

Must see. A great Tour and totally worth the money. Very informative. Pre book if you can as there are dozens of touts at the Colosseum all touting for the same business. We found Gladiator purely by chance.

Nice place to visit, get the combo pass. We purchased the three part pass that let's you access the Palantine Hill, the Roman Forum, and the Colesseum. I would recommend making a day of it. Make sure you bring plenty of water and sunscreen if you go during the summer. Be prepared for a lot of other people/crowds.

Roman Forum. fascinating location of ancient rome with plenty to see. we spent a lot of time walking around these remains of what must of been a once great city. As with most of rome walking is intense so a level of fitness is required. you can catch one of the sight seeing buses where you can jump on/off at certain locations. you would need to get off at the coliseum and head down the road left at the metro.
Add this to your list. Next to the Collisium so easy to find and a good walk if you are fit and healthy - a beautiful chapel at the top of the hill and interesting ruins throughout

Don't go in the height of summer. Did the colosseum then here. It is huge but due the time of year we went was do able I should image in the height of summer it maybe to hot. Full of history as is all of Rome.
You have to see it. Consider booking a tour with an outside vendor (City Wonders or the like) so that you can fully appreciate this amazing bit of history.

Take a Guided Tour. We went here on our own, with just our Lonely Planet pages, and it wasn't enough. To be fair, we have seen amazing ruins all over the world, and perhaps we have become a bit difficult to impress. If you've never seen ruins, you will probably love it! That said, I do think it's hard to really appreciate all there is to see here without a guide. Had we had the guide we had from the Rome Free Walking Tour, I know we would have had a very different experience.

Amazing Ancient Architectural Achievement. The Roman Forum is a collection of ruins that reflect the incredible skills and knowledge possessed by the ancient Roman people. Standing in the midst of these structures makes you appreciate that people were able to do so much with so little. As with most of the historical sites in Italy, visiting the Roman Forum with a knowledgeable tour guide makes the experience so much more enjoyable.

Wear sturdy shoes. There was so much to look at, it was amazing to see ancient ruins up close and be able to go inside some preserved buildings. There were maps and information boards dotted around the site. To really explore this site and see every inch of it, allow a few hours as there is so much to see. It is still worth a shorter visit though as even a brief glimpse of the history thee is impressive. The ground is not even, so is cobbled, some stoney, very muddy puddles in places if it is just after rain so wear appropriate footwear. Ensure you go to Palatine Hill whilst you are there too for fabulous views of the forum.
Re visited 35 years Larer. I visited here with my family approx 35 years ago! Still looks similar to what I can remember, amazing place to visit.

Breathtaking . Stunning - an absolute must when in Rome. We bought a combined fast track ticket for the forum and the coliseum from just out side for only €24 for 2 adults and 2 children. I really wouldn't see the need for an expensive tour - I enjoyed taking a leisurely stroll, and letting my imagination re build the views. This was part of our hop on hop off stop (another must when in Rome )
So much to see! . Had a great time here! So much to see plus a nice long walk up the hill. Don't forget the ticket you buy here is also valid for use in the colosseum and works over two days.

Just amazing! . As a seasoned worldwide traveller it's not often that I continue to be amazed, but the sheer amount of ancient buildings in a relatively small site just blew me away! We had combined the Forum with a walk around Palatine Hill and our heads were just swimming with the fantastic array of sites, even our teenage kids were speechless! Do book ahead online to save time queuing, at 22€ for adults, kids go free, the combined Colosseum, Forum and Palatine Hill entry is a bargin! Other UK tourist sites please take note!
Roman Forum. Although visited here before its a must for those wanting to experience Ancient Rome. We would recommend that you wear supportive footwear as very uneven under foot.

Amazing. Bought our tickets at the Forum fair wait about 40mins mid morning and note they only take debit or credit cards - no cash. Fantastic place to walk round but not many toilets 20min queue - make sure you aren't desperate! Great views of the city and a jaw dropping historical artefact round every corner. Well worth the 12 euro combined tickets for Forum, Colosseum and Palantine. Under 18s are free if you xan prove their age. Fabulous.

Poor entry signage with a long walk. Whilst the Forum and surrounding area is well worth a visit, best combined with the Colosseum, you have to have a strong constitution. The original entry gates are closed and you have to walk quite a long way just to get in ! Signage is poor and dont just walk up the hill , as we did, or you reach a dead end by the church. There are no refreshment kiosks at all anywhere nearby nor outside the Colosseum , where there used to be. Major tube line building work alongside detracts from the experience.

It's nice to walk around an un-crowded area. My ticket to the Colosseum included the Forum and it was actually nice to just walk around the uncrowded area of Rome, seeing all the pillars and such. I wouldn't say it's so fascinating that I'd wanna linger here for too long, but having a nice walk through was nice.

Beautiful place. Not a lot to say on this one except stunning views of history past, I fell in love with Rome and the stunning views, you could almost feel the history of bygone days. Completely amazing

A MUST SEE. The Forum is one of the must see's of Rome and as it is right next to the Collesseum is very simple to get too. Yes it is full of fabulous architecture, yes it is great to walk around and yes it is fabulous. However, be prepared for masses of people doing exactly the same as you. In summer it is heaving, there are very few bars or cafes around so take your own water and plenty of it. The Palatine is next door with fewer people if you really can not stand crowds. My husband lasted about 40 minutes in the Forum before leaving. However, going to Rome without seeing the Forum is a bit like eating fish and chips with no vinegar!!!! It really has to be done!!
Fun experience. Was enjoyable to walk around as part of Palatine Hill. Many fantastic old buildings with exceptional architecture and design!

Ancient Rome . We spent out three days in Rome without a guide and I guess that detracts from the experience because we had no idea what anything was. Than said the buildings are so pretty and old that it's amazing to be around them. There are loads of old things here. Really old. It's fab

So much to see!!. We were amazed at how much there is to see at the Roman Forum and Palentine. Entry was included as part of our ticket to the coliseum but you are able to come back the next day if you don't do both on the same day which is what we did. So glad we did it this way as we were there for hours! Fascinating!!

The view though!. If you could get all of ancient Rome in one selfie, this is where it would happen. This is a pretty big place, so grant at least 2 hours if you want to explore a little but if you are in a hurry, go to straight to the overview for those selfies...unless you or your best friend are history buffs your memories won't even realize you didn't walk though the ruins!
Wonderful . Another great visit definitely would suggest that you go with a tour guide to have the full experience, our guide Emma was fantastic, a wonderful experience, so much to see and take in
Best with aguide. This was part of our full day tour and was so much better when visited with a guide. Unbelievable history

Walk in the past. Use your imagination here to visualise the action taking place as the heart of the Roman Empire what surprises you is how small the area is. It is worth a visit, walk around it from different directions.

Walking in ancient footsteps - amazing . The Roman Forum was the centre of the Roman Empire in the ancient world up to 4th century AD. This was the centre of government buildings and important temples. This was where all the decisions of the future of the Empire were made. This is where Julius Caesar was murdered and Augustus was made Emperor. Really, I could write pages on the historical significance of this location!Located between two of Rome's famous hills, the Palatine and Capitoline Hills, it is now an ancient of ruin but impressive nevertheless. I would recommend that you look at a 3D simulation of what the Forum looked like in its glory before you visit to fully appreciate the grandeur of the buildings. Or if not, make sure you carry a map with you, especially if you continue onto Palatine Hill as it can be easy to lose your way!The views from Palatine are breath-taking so don't miss it and of course you must visit Domus Augustus (Augustus' Villa) - it is by far the largest house there (Of course!) and you really get a feel of Roman living it up!
My favortie. I couldn't have enjoyed this more. Practically empty on a Saturday morning in January. It's so massive and it's nestled in the heart of busy streets and restaurants. I love it.

History Lovers will enjoy this.. Combine this with Palatine Hill and the Colosseum. We did a tour with all three combined and it was very well done. The history and the stories that we learned about Rome were very fascinating. From here, you can also walk down to a few of the major basilicas in Rome.

Walk through History. You really go back in time! It's spectacular to see the ruins. I download the Rick Steves audio guide and walk the Forum in about 90 minutes. The guide probably needs updating as they have re-opened certain areas that were renovated, but you get the gist of history and can stop and move at your own pace. Really worth the trip, especially if good weather!

Amazing part of history. Was my second time touring through the Roman Forum.Amazing how many things are intact. Its like stepping back into history. With info available like to even who owed which house. There is no shade on this walk and is very rocky so wear good shoes and bring a hat and water
Fantastic trip into history. To me, this was the 'Rome' I wanted to see. Lots of walking on uneven surfaces, but breathtaking architecture and scenery.

touring tips. This was the political seat of the Roman Empire. Truly amazing and a not to be missed site. It was awesome to walk the same streets where the Romans walked - what history!Note: uneven pavement so watch your footing. Better to wear sneakers than sandals.Very crowded so either go early or late. The middle of the day was jam packed.We followed the Rick Steves audio guide and had his book with us also. The audio guide was great however it was hard to follow which site was next. It would be best to look at the Forum map ahead of time to see where all the sites are ahead of time to follow the audio tour.Taking our time to walk slow, listen to the audio guide, read the book and taking lots of pictures took us around 2 hours so budget enough time to see it.They had announcements in various languages warning about pickpockets so things must be bad so be aware and watch out. That was the only place in Rome where we heard this announcement.If you like my review, I hope you'll click the 'helpful' button; those of us who write reviews live for those and it motivates us to do more.

History Buff's Dream. It's a must see for anyone interested in history. You might be advised to take water and/or a picnic with you, to wear comfy shoes, and to go with plenty of time. There are two entrances - one down past the bus stops (in view of the triumphal arch) and one down the street from the colosseum (towards capitaline hill and across from the ruins of the imperial forum -which has no entry fee). Having a guide - audio, live, or a book is *VERY* helpful here. Without it, it's a bunch of ruins. With guidance, it comes alive and tells a magnificent story. FYI: The going is a bit rough, though, and would be hard (or impossible) for wheelchairs, walking impairments, and strollers. Take your time - if you rush through this site, you'll feel like you ran a marathon due to the uneven walkways and hilly area it sits on. We did the colosseum and the forum on the same day and were beat by the end. But oh, was it worth it!
Must visit. Trip to Roman Forum can be done along with visit to Colosseum as you get a combined ticket for these attractions.
A walk into history!. Visited the Roman Forum through a combined ticket for the whole area. If you are into culture / history, it will be worth getting a audio guide and just walk through history.

The essence of ancient Rome. We visited the Forum on a sunny day at the same time as visiting Palatine Hill. Really atmospheric and a reminder how civilised the Romans were in some ways and barbaric in others.

Great piece of history. If you go in the Colosseum area and you want to visit it than it worth paying a visit to Roman Forum also. You can get a ticket to include this place also and BTW it is quicker to buy a ticket from the Roman Forum and then to just skip the line for Colosseum.
Very nice place to walk around. Do homework before to understand what happened in that region and how it was used to be. Be prepared for walking, nice and comfortable tennis shoes is mandatory.
Visited after Colluseum, must see.. This place gives a great impression of how the Romans lived. You can clearly tell thata lot of movie inspiration about Roman life comes from here.

"Time Machine" experience. It was like being transported to the era of the Roman Empire. So beautiful. If going in the morning try getting inside the area and not just see it from via dei fori imperiali.
Excellent. Take your time going round! such alot to explore lots of people you can buy refreshments from machines on the sight very interesting

Visiting with a toddler or baby?. We traveled with our 17 month old baby. Tried to use the stroller but it was close to useless in the forum and Palatine Hill however we did bring our baby Bjorn We and carried our little guy everywhere! If you get a baby backpack like the We you'll use it in Rome. Can't go wrong!

Good afternoon out. First of all I'd invested in a good guide book. The book recommended going up to the Capitol hill to get a good panoramic view of the forum. It was very impressive & beautiful.There is a combined ticket for the forum (including the palatine hill) and the colosseum (12 euros Jan 2016). It lasts 2 consecutive days and allows 1 access to each site. It's a good idea to buy the ticket at the forum because queues are a lot shorter here. When inside just wander and soak up the atmosphere. My guide book was invaluable as it explained the individual buildings of the forum and palatine in detail. There are many touts outside offering tours (at a price), we didn't to bother. We spent all afternoon here only leaving when they closed up for the day
Ancient history alive. One big tip. Roman Forum have two entrance one from Colosseum which is a full of people and you stay very much to enter and one from north in 5 min we walk in forum.
A Must for History Lovers. Together with the colosseum and palatine hill is a must when visiting Rome. It's amazing now so of its day it must have been incredible. Just go and soak up the atmosphere

Together for the Colosseum this place is free every first Sunday of the month!. Together with the Colosseum and the Palatine Hill this is free every first Sunday of the month and is really very interesting. Allow for a lot of walking for the elderly - at least 3 hours in all.

Superb insight into the Roman way of life. The Forum is an amazing place, when you look at how the buildings were constructed, the arches of triumph, the imposing buildings for different settings for different events. Surely one of the more appealing visitor attractions in Rome.

Just amazing. Once visiting the Foro Romano, Palatino & Colosseum make sure you start in the morning, so you do not have to rush through the sites. Note that on site the purchase of tickets must be paid with a credit card. The lines were not long in January, wish I had hired a guide.

So much history to see. We first viewed this from the Palatine viewpoint which gave us a good overview of the area before we walked around it. There is a lot to see as you wander around so allow plenty of time.

Yes, and no. Ruins, glorious ruins. But these guys are really really ruined. I enjoyed the ambiance of the place, but came away wondering just how much I had actually seen. For the History, worth the trip. For the visual experience....meuh.

Mark & Denise.... Gemma met us by the forum...no pressure but suggested a tour...the que was immense so we agreed & took a tour of the Forum & Colosseum...Wow...our guide Renata is a class act, do seek Renata out...a font of knowledge, passionate & 3 hours for around 35 euro per person (for both forum & colosseum) in our view good value...the company is "skip the line";colosseumandvaticantours.com...felt like Rome was very welcoming with these guys...5star...
Excellent historical site. Make sure you book a tour for this to have all the ruins explained as this really adds to the experience and is well worth it!

Wonderful!!!!!. Did a guided tour of the Colosseum/Roman Forum. Loved hearing the history and stories from a guide..totally worth paying a little more for a tour-plus you skip the lines! MUST see in Rome! Also, it is spectacular at night with some of the buildings lit up from the outside!!Big heads up here...while I was here an older lady tripped on the cobblestone and banged her head up real bad..an ambulance came right into the forum. PLEASE, be extremely careful walking!

What a place. I have wanted to go to Ancient Rome since I was a boy. I have just read the Cicero books by Robert Harris and so to actually touch the roster where he stood and orated and to see the Curia where Julius Caesar walked was fantastic. I literally walked back in time down through the layers of history back into the books where it all became much more real.

What You Think of When You Think of Ancient Rome. The forum has the remnants of buildings that were built approximately 2000 years ago. You can't help marvel at the size and details that the Roman engineers were able to achieve. This is part of the same ticket that gets you into the Colosseum. Allow most of the day to explore these and the Palatine hill.

Beautiful gardens . This site is next to the colosium and can be bought together with the colosium or separate. We had a guide take us through both which was very entertaining and helpful. You can get guides for any language. Go to an official tout- they wear ID badges.I went with Gladiator tours- highly recommend. Our guide Annette knew her stuff and had visual books to see too. They are located next to the colosium down a street with lots of rainbow flags.Lots of uneven steps and no lifts, so be careful. Overall very pretty and a great place to visit.

A truly amazing view into history. To visit Palatine hill and the Forum is simply breathtaking. There is so much history here and so any bits to see that it is just wonderful to wander through the place and try to take it all in. That said, I suspect you could visit many times and see new details every time - it is amazing and I can't wait to go back!

Roman Remains. A very good place to see how the city landscape and the architecture was like during Roman age. It can be super hot in summer so spring or autumn would be better time to visit around this place.
Absolutely stunning. All those historical characters I learned about at school, in documentaries, films and TV come to life here, an amazing experience, not to be missed.
Awesome. Had a guided tour of Palantine Hill, The Roman Forum and the Colosseum and to see all the ancient structures , albeit slightly weathered, is amazing. A must see.

Where world history was made. The Roman Forum does not look impressive now. The flagstones are uneven and worn; but let history wash over you and you begin to experience what it was to be a Caesar. You will see the ruins that surround it. This is where decisions were made, where generals marched off to conquer the .known world. Much of what you see has not changed in thousands of years. Seeing the Roman Forum gave me a real buzz. It's worth a trip.

Interesting but would have been better with a knowledgeable guide.. Interesting but would have been better with a knowledgeable guide.Lots of history but too much to absorb from a guidebook. Allow plenty of time. You can avoid delays at the entrance by entering from the Palatine hill entrance.

Absolutely love this place! . This place is just amazing. Definitely gets your mind thinking about how the place was built and how it looked once before. One of the few places in Rome I would go back to over and over again. Ticker price is also super worth.
Full of history. We toured the forum with an exceedingly well informed private guide who really knew her stuff and had a talent for presenting it on an organized and interesting way.

Stroll amongst the ruins. The ticket for the Colosseum also gives you entry to the Forum which is worth spending time in. Wander amongst layers of history covering hundreds of years of Roman dedication to gods and emperors.
Great ruins. Nice visit and looking at ancient ruins was amazing. Great time thief too. Takes two or three hours to walk around. Bring water!

when in Rome..... ...you must visit the Forum. Although not as crowded as the Colosseum, you are never alone in the Forum. This is more of a free walk around than a museum Be sure to prepare well with you guide book and set a side a couple of hours to walk around this amazing historical area.

Roman history on a small scale.. This a great place to go to. Much more worth of your time than the Colosseum. As the ticket to the Forum also gives you entree of the Palantine hill and the Colosseum you better buy it at the Forum. No queues
Guided tour. Worthwhile visit. We had a guided tour. Very informative. Nice place to stand back and appreciate the whole site from a height.

Can't miss it. Part of your tour no matter how you do the tour. The forum is so big you can't miss it. There was some conservation work going on whilst we were there and the workers were keen to help put with questions. We didn't take any set tour as we like to ramble and take our time.... That is what I love about Rome

A Must See in Rome !!!. When visiting Rome there are a few "must see" places ..... and of course the Roman Forum is certainly one of those that you really shouldn't miss. Beautiful, easy to get to and find and you are off to the next stop -- maybe after a nice gelato on the way :-)
Unbelievable.. It was a very interesting place...full if so much history. Made me wish I had taken more notice in history at school.
a walk in encient rome. this visit u can encounter the history of rome by handgrip , and some can imagine the their roots to these place. like the titus arch for israelies
History at its finest. Spent hours walking around. Remember to take a water bottle and refill it from the spring. Recommend a book to read about what you are looking at
Looks better from the outside. Looks better from the outside and lines to get in to the attraction can be quiet long so worth planning it ahead

Awesome to walk where Caesars did. I can't help it, I'm impressed by these ancient ruins and the stories that I have grown up about Rome and Julius Caesar, etc. Of course over the years it has been built upon many times and the result today is a very haphazard mixture but it still boggles the imagination. Just reflect back upon it in its heyday, how advanced they were compare to other civilisations. Just awesome to see it in the flesh

Walk Among the Ruins. The Roman Forum is a few steps away from the Colosseum. When you step into the gate you have stepped back in time. It is filled with broken columns, huge chunks of marble and other artifacts. You can just wander around the huge area and imagine what you are looking at. It will take a while, and might be better if you had a guide book or guide to tell you what you are seeing. Well worth the time.
Not to be missed!. Everything ancient Romans built was built to impress, to intimidate and to awe. Two thousand and some hundred years later the Roman Forum still invokes the feelings above.

History students dream. It seems that almost everywhere within Rome you can stumble on some remnant of the Roman Empire. It's thrilling to walk in the same area where Marc Antony or Caesar had walked.

Great for history and getting a sense of scale of ancient rome. We got a pass to the hills and forum so much to walk around a lot of ruins but worth the visit has plenty of information points to give you dorm information of different areas of what they are. We didn't to a tour guide or what not just wondered around I usually like taking a lot of photos so this was one of them places, and also being able to get up high was good for the views over the city too, well worth it

Regally interesting visit. Self guided tour, really enjoyed it. Ruins are reasonably well labelled to allow you to self-guide. Over heard some tours and think this would be the best way of getting the most out of the forum.
Very impressive. This is a truly nice experience to walk in the forum...you can easily imagine how it was 2k years ago. I warmly recommend it!!

Huge, but great. There's a lot of ground to cover, and we did so without any guide, map or rhyme or reason. This worked out fine, although if you take a guided tour, I'd bet you'd get more out of it. Entrance to this was included with the colosseum ticket which we almost didn't realize, so definitely take note of that so you don't end up paying twice!
Such a lot to see!. An essential visit but you will need a lot of time and stamina it took us 6 hours but bring water there are no facilities except toilets.

allow plenty of time for this. These excavations are right alongside the colloseum and these two will take you all day. The forum is well worth spending time and the view from the top after you come out of the orange grove is stunning. We visited in February, Jumper and no coat, no waiting to enter and the amount of space meant you were not waiting for other people to move before you could appreciate the surroundings or take the photographs. There were plaques and signs with information in English as well as Italian but might be worthwhile trying to download a free guide before your trip and I would recommend sensible footwear. Might not be one for young children but we did see one in full centurion outfit and he thought it was great.

Bring good shoes!. Rome is filled with great history and archaeological marvels, but as a lot of it spreads out you will need to walk, a lot. I definitely recommend bringing comfortable shoes! This place in particular requires a lot of walking if you want to see all of it. There is at least one building that you can go in that has mosaics and statues so keep an eye out for that. I suggest taking your time and make sure to see as much as possible - it's definitely worth the visit for any history buff.

Enjoyable walk. We did the Forum during our visit of Palatine Hill. It is a good site to visit when you have some good weather.We visited the site using our Roma tourist passes. It would be better if we were provided with a map containing some basic information on the various ruins (hence only 4 points). It would have been an amazing sight to see the fully constructed buildings before their demise over the centuries. Make sure you have good walking shoes when visiting Rome.
Exciting History. great for history if you love learning about it all, if you're in rome and only have a couple of days you could give this a miss if you're not big on your history.

Must see while in Rome. You can not go to Rome without visiting the Roman Forum. While the site is mostly ruins, you can still sense the enormity of the Forum in its heyday. Attached to Palatine Hill with a entrance next to the Colosseum, you can spend an entire day in this area. Well worth the entrance fee.

Great historical place!. Incredible amount of history here! We were lucky to join in with a tour guide, who just happened to be recommended by Rick Steves--wish we could remember his name now, this was years ago unfortunately. Highly recommend doing a tour here, otherwise you could miss out on what all the buildings were and the colorful history there.
In the middle of everything.... How cool is it to stand in the city surrounded by ancient ruins? Spend a few bucks and walk where the ancient Romans (and the occasional Greek) walked.

Just so incredible.... It was just so incredible walking through the Roman Forum on a sunny winters day. Even more incredible how a lot of the ancient architecture has been maintained for so long. Definitely worth visiting!

A must see. Free with your colosseum tickets along with palatine hill. An incredible site that you can get lost in for hours! Watch your step and make sure you wear sensible footwear. Seems obvious but easily forgotten. Oh, and make sure you know where the entrance is. We didn't and like a lot of other lost tourists we spent an awful lot of energy climbing up a hill to a random church. Save your legs for palatine hill!

Need an imagination. I don't know why, but I struggle to appreciate things that are no longer there. And that's pretty much how I feel about the Roman Forum. I understand why most travellers to Rome enjoy it - there's a lot of things still standing and it's obviously of a huge scale - but I personally just didn't enjoy it. Perhaps I've not got the imagination required for such an historic venue?I'd recommend comfy trainers if you intend on walking round the forum/colosseum all day - it gets tough in that heat and it's quite hilly throughout. My girlfriend & I are pretty fit but it drains you!

If you like history and ruins this is an amazing place. If you like history and ruins this is an amazing place to visit. It will take you a couple of hours to inspect every corner and every bit of ancient stone but it is totally worth it.
Beautiful. do this with palatine hill. They are almost together. Have to visit this since you cannot get a sense of hsitory without it!

three hours well spent!. We spend sunny three hours (unfortunately with too much wind) in the forum. What is a pity, that quite some areas are unaccessible. Recommendation: buy the tickets in off peak hours and come back with them during their usable time of two days. Better than standing in line. With the tickets in your hands, you can jump the line :)
Very Educational. Excellent tour of the forum which gives you a good birds-eye view of what life was like hundreds of years ago!
A view to the pass. Roman Forum is undoubtedly, one of the most interesting places to visit while you are in Rome. The landscape to the pass is just mindblowing.

Fantastico!. Such a fabulous place. Make sure you take walking shoes and are prepared for a walk but the sheer history held here is incredible. I was blow away by the fantastic sights and the preservation of such old monuments. Definitely visit here! Costs to get in but the ticket covers here and the colosseum and is well worth ever penny.

Plan on Spending Hours. Not a sight to be taken in within an hour or so. Plan on spending at least a half day. Wear your walking shoues and be prepared to meander all over the place in different directions.

Put on comfortable walking shoes!. You definitely need good walking shoes if you are doing the Forum. It is quite a large area to cover and quite uneven paths. My suggestion would be to take a guided tour otherwise you will never know what each of the ruins was.If you take a tour - take notes as you go as there are so many ruins that you will forget what each one is by the time you finish your holiday and you are looking through your photos!Also suggest that you take water if going through summer as very open and potentially hot - we went in January and still could have used a water bottle!

History Buff Heaven. I am fascinated by Roman history and architecture and therefore loved this place! Takes a good few hours to see it all and it's a tiring day. Lots of hills and uneven ground. Might be a tad boring for kids or if you have little to no interest in the actual history of Rome.

Past ruins. This is another of the unbelievable sights I just love Rome, it is so exciting and there is so much past history. When I was walking the cobble streets you could still see the chariot wheel marks, it sent shivers up your spine...It is a must for those who love to travel....it is hard to believe that this forum is still standing.....

Magnificent. Visited Sunday 31st January. Tip - enter via Palatine hill so you get a nice gentle walk up before the steeper descent into the Forum. Plus the queues are a lot shorter, with or without pre-booked tickets. Too many impressive structures too describe. Highlights for me were the Vespasian arch, the temple with the massive bronze doors (forgotten its name) and the view up to Palatine hill. Great value.

Read and know a little bit of the history and let the imagination take place. we went there with a guide, who was very helpful in providing insights of the area and explaining to us on what we are looking at ( what we would have been looking at if I were there centuries ago).. All the famous names I read in history lessons came running back in mind, names like Julius Caesar. And looking and picturing the ancient city in mind was an experience by itself!!The guide also informed on the places where it used to be markets and gladiatorial matches. It was a storyline tour.. which here i would like to suggest for first timers to consider going with a walking tour (preferably small group)Its an amazing place to visit...( speaking for the self)..i had to take my time to digest and finally realise that I am walking, seeing and touching some of the oldest artefact in human history. It was like a dream to me!.I bought a book on artists illustration on how the place used to look..and googled and view the place in advance before visiting..Arriving on site. I had really nice experience together with my imagination the journey was awesome!! plus the weather was pleasant..so while planning for a visit here.. pick for a day where you won’t have issues to stay outdoor long.. Rainy day would definitely not be in my list.
A walk down History Lane!. This place was filled with so much history and so many stories. We had a guide that took us through which we highly recommend. It really makes you appreciate the sights.

Stand where Caesar stood. I loved visiting here being able to stand in the heart of ancient Rome.To imagine how great this place would have been with all the colourful statues lining the road.To stand at the senate and feel that connection with Caesar and Pompey etc.Fortunately the place is large and easy enough to walk around at a leisurely pace.Bring a guide book so that you can appreciate some of the history and the architecture.You can easily spend a half day or more taking in the atmosphere.Well worth a visit if you want to be in a place where so much history was brought to life.

A must see in Rome!. The forum is worth your entire visit. It's beautiful whitewashed facade is gorgeous to look at and many times the flowers are in full bloom. Pay close attention to the many details and smaller statues at the forum. They're remarkable. You can see this on the Hop On Hop Off bus also.
Favorite place to walk with history. I don't now how anyone can walk in the forum and palatine hill and not feel the history of the Romans
Amazing. We had this as part of a tour, and it is absolutely amazing. Try to get a guided tour so you can learn more about the Roman Forum.

HUGE!!. This was much larger than expected and we really enjoyed walking around and exploring all day.we managed to do the Colosseum in the morning first thing and then the forum. We did go when there was almost no lines.highly recommend

Exercise your Imagination. I hope that everyone can see this place at least once. These are the buildings that started the world! Many of the buildings are missing the majority of the walls or floors but using your imagination could create wonders and worlds of old!
A must see. A definitely interesting place for people interested in history and architecture. Buy yourself a tourist guide book to understand the history of the place.

Visit in October. Visited the forum in the morning as it can get quite busy and warm later in the day. You could spend hours if not days here talking it in. We were there for a few hours and tried to see as much as we could but I know we only covered a small part. In saying that I don't believe we missed out. It definitely gave us a flavour of it however true historian's would probably want to see the whole thing.The tickets for the forum is a combination ticket for something else too (can't remember what that is just now) Would recommend this to take in the history of the city. Some great views from the higher spots in the forums.There are a couple of places in the forum's with toilets which is handy.
Interesting, old Roman Forum.. When in Rome... Go to the Roman Forum! It's only next to the Colloseum. Take a tour, you'll find out so much! In the sun it can be pretty hot but that's Rome.
So much history. I recommend going to Palatine Hill first. You will have great views of the forum and a nice perspective of the full layout.
Christmas Trip. We spent three hours wandering around this. Buy yourself a basic guide to Rome and take it round with you. It was fascinating!!

Stepping into history . The most impressive of all Rome sights. Don't miss out as these ruins feel SO real, one can imagine life in the ancient times. Ticket for both the forum and the colosseum costs €12 per person. Worth every penny!! Under 18s go free.

A must see when in Rome!!. This is a fascinating area to explore when in Rome. We had a combination tour which also included the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. I highly recommend this since there is so much to learn while in the forum. Our guide had so much to share during our visit. You can easily spend a few hours here. We really enjoyed it!

The Forum.....what a majestic view !. After Colosseum, I took a cycle ride to The Forum. It is spread all over a huge area and it is lovely to get lost in that. There are still people exploring and finding new things from this area.
A history students delight. It definitely takes you back in time to the days of Caesar and the ancient Roman Empire. Must visit. Guide recommended

History for days!. The Roman Forum is great for the history buff - you learn about how the ancient Romans once used this place as a important meeting place and marketplace. Wear comfortable shoes, there's a lot of walking.

A must visit for history buffs!. This site gives you a sense of what life must have been like during the days of the Roman Empire, especially Imperial Rome- with the related Colosseum and Palantine hills being a short walk away.

Trip well worth doing but make sure to set aside time. The vast landscape of the Roman forum draws you in. It is an experience well worth gaining. The descriptions on the site are very informative and help build your understanding of what happened in the area. It does take a few hours to visit. If you are going to the Colosseum as well, I recommend going to the Roman Forum first, you can purchase your tickets for the Colosseum and Forum together and you can then skip the queue for tickets at the Colosseum.

A wonderful site and experience !. One of the highlights of our visit to Rome was our half-day at the Forum Romanum. We gained an insight into the majesty and glory of ancient Rome and its empire... a must-see !

The center of the ancient Roman world. It was very interesting to learn how the Romans used to live and how their "downtown" was set up. Several tour companies that give tours of the Colosseum include the Roman Form and Palatine Hill for free as part of a 3 part tour so if you are going for the first time, it's smart to book one tour and pay one price for all three. And it's definitely better to have a guide your first time, as you will learn a lot more history about the ruins. I would not recommend this tour for small kids unless they are really into history. Make sure you pick a day where it isn't going to be sweltering outside, as there isn't much shade. However, if you do go on a hot day, there are free water fountains all throughout the city in Rome and there is one on Palatine Hill with cold, good drinking water to refill your bottle if needed.

Fantastic History. The Forum is one of the most historic places in the world. However, we would have been completely lost without a tour guide. We have twice retained Giovanni Tanoni, who is a Professional Licensed Tour Guide in Rome.With Giovanni's guidance, the Forum came to life and made a lot more sense than if we were stumbling around alone. You need to wear comfortable walking shoes, as the pavement is uneven and rough in spots. Also, the Forum is not a great place for young children or toddlers. If you are in Rome, you should see the Forum once, but it lacks the grandeur of the Colosseum, the Vatican, or many of Rome's other great treasures.

Impressive walk. There is so much to see such a large archeological dig area, discovery after discovery must have been made when looking in the area. Rome must have been one special place 2000 years ago.
Must visit!. The Roman Forum is an amazing architectural site that takes you down the history of Rome! A guided walk through the ruins is highly recommended!

Take a guide. We did, Eva from the company 'Together In Rome', She was the font of all knowledge concerning the Forum and the Colosseum and totally made the tour a fascinating adventure through Ancient Rome. Wonderful.

Rome in its Glory. The Roman Forum was brought alive by our tour guide Eva from the tour company "Together in Rome." This very well preserved site is astounding. The architural remains of the temples, homes and meeting square gave us incredible insights to life in Ancient Rome. Walking along we saw a round carved depressions set in a pattern that was actually a game used with pebbles! Carved in another stone was the word oracle where a fortune teller may have told someone of what the future held. It was one of our favorite places to visit. Don't miss it!
The Heart of Rome!. Truly a magnificent thing to behold! Walking up from the Colosseum or looking down from the Capitoline Museum, you can get a real sense of what was once here.
Spectacular. This really brings history to realization. It fills in the gaps of your imagination of what it must have been like to live in ancient Roman times

Just walking through History of 2500 years old !. Just walking through History of 2500 years old ! Seen the buildings, the streets, roads, and much more in a magic atmosphere in the center of Rome, just walking through and remember and feel the past ...

Impressive. Walk around and try to imagine what it must have been like. Very nice view from the terasse of Palatine Hill. Do not forget to have a peek at the Circus Maximus. Although the is hardly anything left, it still is impressive to see the shape of the circus where once the horseraces took place.

Walk in the footsteps of the Romans. A must see part of Rome with so much history . although mostly ruins We took the guided tour which completely brought the whole place to life . You don't need to be a history buff to enjoy this and so much to see that you need a few hours - great gardens and views across to the Coloseum on the top of the hill so allow time for this too. Second time here but you see a bit more and learn something new each time - pay extra and get a guide it's really worth it.

No signs! We couldn't get in!. We were walking in Rome and really wanted to visit the Forum. We could see people walking, through the fence, but were informed that the entrance was blocked and that we must go another way. We walked and walked and never did find the entrance. It was quite frustrating as we are history lovers. In general, signage is poor in Rome. Very often we could not discover the name of the street we were on (we looked on the corners of buildings, where they usually are).
wow..... this place is amazing. it's just unreal how old everything it. our guide had an app that showed what it looked like when it really there. wow! just take it all in.
