Great for history lovers. I visited the Forum as part of a 3 hour tour of the forum and Colosseum through a company called City Wonders. Our guide was a qualified archaeologist who was a brilliant speaker and funny too. It was pouring with rain on the day we went but we had umbrella's and it didn't detract from the beauty of the place too much. The history on this whole archaeological area is fascinating, especially if it is told to you by someone with such knowledge and a great sense of humour as our guide. It's not somewhere so go back to repeatedly, but the Forum has to be seen at least once to appreciate it. I particularly loved going inside the basilica on the site.

Disappointing, not enough information. I was really disappointed by what was offered at the Roman Forum. There is absolutely no signage or information available next to each of the ruins, so it's very difficult to grasp what it used to be. We had a walking tour with a guide, but she struggled to be heard by such a large group and a lot of people lost interest.I feel like simple information boards and pictures showing what each ruin used to look like would be an incredible feature to have, they don't need to be in the way or blocking any of the views but something needs to be added in otherwise it just feels like you are walking amongst a lot of rubble which is a great pity.

Stunning. We decided to do the Roman Forum and Palentine hill together ( they are beside each other) well worth the walk around, wear flat shoes for this visit, take water too, oh and don't get sucked in by the so called artists with their paintings? I did but hey ho the prints are lovely! This place is huge so leave a bit of time for it.

Interesting . Wondered around here after visiting the colasseum. It was not too busy and do you could stroll leisurely, there are snipes of information available as you walk round. It is a bit of a maze to get back out if though!

So much history in one place. I definitely recommend getting a guide or using an audio guide as you walk through. There are so many important pieces of history you would miss without a guide of some sort.

geat for history and architecture lovers. you still see pieces on the ground belonging to temples and churches that are gone forever, the stones on the streets are still the original from the roman times, great place to think about how much we lost and to be amazed and how the Romans built and how much effort it must have taken, great

Great Ruins. I've seen many a ruin in my life (Ephesus in Turkey, etc) and while not as "glamorous" as other sites, it still holds historical significance. Wander amongst the ruins and you'll see how life was when Rome was ruled by emperors.I loved this site and it was amongst the hits of our stay in Rome. Bring water, as in the summer it can get quite hot and the sun is intense, but do not miss this site.
Inside a movie. It feels like you are inside a movie that turn out to be real. I can only say you have to visit to feel it

Perfect is not enough word to describe . I can't say perfect it is wonderfull ,amazing. 2 hours is maybe enough to visit (it is closed 16.30 )I fall in love with this place. For a while you will wish that I would live here in the history . it is amazing .

Great place to see. Not a far walk from the colosseum, this is a place also full of Roman history and architecture. I really enjoyed seeing the many things in the Roman Forum. Not as amazing as the colosseum but worth the money to visit.

Historic visit. Visited the Roman Forum after visiting the Colosseum as the entry ticket covered both attractions. Nice historical tour of the grounds, with plenty of information on display. The amount of guided tour groups were annoying at times as they slowed us up in parts. It was great learning a bit about Italian history. Well worth a visit.

Very nice. If you are fun of history and especialy Roman history, you gonna love this place. There are so many things to see, that you must have a guide or at least a guide book! Otherwise you will miss a lot of things

It's All Ruins. Although you'll see people from every country and age, I think this is for the serious Roman history buff. It can get a little overwhelming to see ruin after ruin and trying to imagine what happened in that spot, but to know that life and business and social times all happened here is pretty incredible.Regardless of the time of year, try to go when it's the coolest part of the day. Walking around the Forum with the sun beating down on you drags your attention away from why you're there.
A lasagna. Such a neat place to explore! We took a tour and it was amazing. The area totally shows Rome's history, layers upon layers built.

A must see in Rome. You can view the Forum from various vantage points for free, so if you have limited time or money, that is what I would advise. (Ditto, the Colliseum next door.) If it is a nice day and you have the time and $, it is also worth a tour.

Following in the footsteps of history.. This is quite a large site so I advise giving yourself enough time to do the site justice. Buy a combined ticket which provides access to the Colesseum, the Forum and the Palatine Hill. The ticket lasts for two days and saves queuing at each venue to buy separate tickets. The site involves a lot of walking with steps in a number of places, so if you are bringing a wheelchair or a buggy plan your route and allow extra time. However there is a route at the top of the site which still allows you to view a large section of the ruins, without having to navigate some of the trickier parts. Buy a guide book or take the audio tour would be my advice, unless you enjoy the guided tour type of visit.

A lot to see. The Forum is the place to buy your two day ticket as the queue is much shorter than the Colosseum. The two day ticket doesn't allow re-entry so you need to cover the site in a single visit - be prepared for a lot of walking! A lot of the site is cobbled so not suitable for pushchairs/wheelchairs. There is only very limited (self vend) refreshments on site, so if planning to stay for a while take your own drinks and snacks or sufficient coinage to use the vending machines!
very interesting. we went straight here from pantheon hill, entry was easy as they are quite close was amazing to see where so of the most important decisions ever made happened

Magnificent . Absolutely fantastic ancient place. This is wgat you read about in the books in school and then suddenly you are there. Fantastic.A goid advice is to come in low season. It's not packed and it's more easy to enjoy :)

Part of a 3 part ticket to the Colosseum - Don't skip it!. Absolutely gorgeous! Spend the whole day between the colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Forum. Filled with historical tributes and temples it is a must for any visitor to Rome. Be aware it isn't really suitable for wheelchairs, we saw some that were really struggling. The forum is in an untouched stage!

Lots of History, Make Sure to Have an Audio Tour. We went here after leaving the Colosseum. It was a bit difficult to find the entrance as the one closest to our location was closed due to construction. We took an audio tour, which was completely necessary, otherwise you don't know what you are looking at. You could take a guided tour as well (saw a few of those as we were touring the area) but we like going at our own pace. Another historical must-see.
History infront of your eyes. Allow yourself plenty of time to walk round the site and read all the notice boards, An amazing place....

awesome historical ruins.. Plan to spend at least a day here. Your visit includes the Colosseum. I would suggest getting an audio guide, but you can share it with a friend or your partner; key is to bring your own earpiece/headphones as the ones supplied only come with one ear piece. The ruins are well preserved, and gives a sense of perspective as to how Romans lead their lives back in the day. The ruins here are in better shape than the one in Ephesus Turkey.
Great value. A lovely morning, exploring a fantastic site. A guide book helps but not necessary. Take a camera and snacks!

A vast amount of history. We visited here after the colosseum, I don't know if it was a mistake as we were very tired in the heat and didn't manage to get round all of it. However from what we did see it was beautiful and such rich quality of history and stories. It's a must-visit! But make sure you're well-hydrated in the heat!

So beautiful! MUST SEE. Simply amazing place to wander around and watch centuries of history before your eyes. You won't get tired of looking at it for hours.
Totally recommend!

My favorite in rome. Don't miss this and the forum. Allowance a good few hours to walk and explore. This is beside the colluseum. And your tickets allows you entry to all 3 but queue for colluseum were over 2 hours long and it is not that impressive on the inside. Buy your ticket online to skip the queue. Dont miss the forum and palatine hill, they are beautiful.
When in Rome .... Another must while you're in town, and an amazing way to literally see the layers of history .. .and an eternal work in progress

Interesting. The Roman Forum is very profound. To be able to walk next to buildings that are so very old is just amazing. It doesn't cost anything, so it's good for a free activity. Obviously you can't go up and touch them, though there wasn't any security when we visited. It's beautiful and a lovely hour of the day.

Amazing Walk through History. A amazing walk through the history of ancient Rome. Really intersting seeing the monuments that have existed for so long. Our experience was made better by a independent guided tour that made the place come alive. Big tip- Wear sensible footwear as the old Roman Roads are a little dodgy.

I couldnt leave.. Oh to walk among the debris and splendor of Ancient Rome! To finally SEE all i have pathologically seen on countless documentaries with Mary Beard... and that other guy that had a panic attack in the Cloaca Maxima...bought a Roma Pass at the airport and used my free entry for the Forum, of which i walked and walked all day in the July sun and no sunscreen, numb from the excitement! What a beautiful place to be! With my mouth hanging open and staggering around in the wrong shoes, my eyes couldn't take in everything i wanted to see at once. I selfied myself to death and made sure of barraging Facebook with them in order to prove i was there! BYO water as the water "peddlers" charge through the nose, karma is satisfied in the evening watching the police chase them away...along with the hand bag sellers along the Colosseum. Drag your teenage Gothic morose daughter here to put some colour...and some great culture in her face!

good. Takes the whole day to walk through the palatine hill and roman forum. I recommend you keep aside hole day. Also go in a guided tour. we did not have a guide and we could not really learn all of the history it is very beautifull. wear walking shoes some areas are slippery

So much history in one site - included in your Colosseum ticket so go see it!. The Roman Forum is a large rectangular area close to the Colosseum featuring a number of Roman remains, temples, columns, arches, etc. There are plenty of signs to explain the various structures you can see which include the Temple of Saturn, Temple of Vespasian and Titus, Arch of Septimius Severus, Temple of Caesar, Temple of Castor and Pollux and the Temple of Vesta (of Vestal Virgin fame).We didn't spend a huge amount of time here, perhaps an hour, but there is lots to see and you could easily fill a couple of hours wandering around. Admission is included with the Colosseum tickets (as is Palatine Hill) to for no extra cost make sure you don't miss the Roman Forum.

Unique. To walk the same track as the great characters of classical Rome has a special buzz about it.The many different buildings/ruins can take some imagination to piece together, especially as buildings which never stood together are now seen as neighbouring ruins.

Seeing the first buildings of Western Civilization is just awesome. Any trip to Italy should include at least a day in Ancient Rome, in my opinion. There is so much basis in modern society that was formed in these few square miles. Any tour you take is unique and fascinating and teaches you so much about where we came from. Well worth the time you spend here.

Take it all in.. Me and my boys loved it here. Theres so much to take in. No matter how long you have here its not long enough, there is just so much to see, it is simply fantastic. History oozing out of every brick. Got to go back.

Great end to an afternoon of ancient history. My son and I visited the Forum last after the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. We loved walking around the ruins, chatting about the history. The information boards were helpful as well. We found washrooms at the far end of the site (opposite end to the Arch of Titus). Well worth the price since the ticket is for the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Forum.
So large. This takes up acres of room, entry valid on the Colosseum ticket so go. Pillars, buildings, everything is here.

Impressive. To me this was the most impressive attraction of Rome, together with the Palatine Hill. It's an incredible feeling to walk in a place that is so old and so full history. I found the audio guide rather useless, as all the information it provides can be read at the place. An absolute must see. Great place to spend a few hours walking and marvelling at what you see.
An Awesome Wander. We found this such an breataking tour as we were completely wrapped in the grandeur of what this place once was!
Impressive. Mostly ruins, but a lot went into it. Take a guide to get all the information. Hard to believe they didn't even know it was there 100 years ago.
Amazing. I love Roman history and was in my element during our Roman forum tour. I wish we could have spent more time here! Highlight of Rome along with the nearby Colosseum.

Enjoyable. Enjoyable afternoon spent discovering the ruins, with some interesting structures. Some spots had lovely views over the city as well. The reason for the "average" rating was the difficulty in finding our way out, there were not enough signposts with directions so we found it difficult to find the exit, and found that other visitors had the same problem when asked them for directions.

A site not to be missed. We spent the day starting at Palantine hill and then walking down to the Roman Forum. Simply fascinating and amazing well preserved ruins with lots of information which made it all the more impressive. There are no cafes in the Forum or on Palatine Hill so take plenty to drink with you.

Great site - but consider a guide. We went to the Roman Forum after Palatine Hill, before the Colosseum (all not he same day). The ancient ruins are beautiful and fascinating. We enjoyed our wander through. However, we spent the least amount of time at this site - mostly because we didn't know a lot about what we were seeing. We had the Rick Steves walking tour on our phone and were reading it as we walked, but it was completely inadequate for what we were seeing. I wish we would have had a tour guide to take us through he forum and help bring it to life. It was obvious in visiting there that there was great significant in each of the buildings (I enjoyed the temple of romulus the most), but I just wanted to be able to appreciate it even more - which I couldn't do without a little more information and knowledge.e

Central Part of the History of Rome. Recommend doing this in a combination tour with a guide. We did our with Walks of Italy, which included the Colosseum and the Palantine Hill. It was great! Well worth it! Plan for the whole morning or better part of the afternoon.

Don't miss it. Saw this with the tour company Walks of Italy.....excellent tour guide, very knowledgable, small group at a time. Well worth visiting. Expect to do a lot of walking over uneven terrain.
Fantastic. You should allow at least half a day to see this and some of the other sites around the Forum, also be sure to have a good pair of tennis shoes when walking there.

Lots to see, admire and take in. You need a few hours to do justice to the ruins here. Most of the guide books for self-guided tours are ineffective here because it involves a lot of walking from place A to place B and there are a lot of marked and labeled ruins at the actual site that are not all comprehensively described in guide books. So the recommendation is to leave your guide book in your backpack, enjoy the ruins, imagine you were in ancient Rome and soak in the atmosphere of this place which is vast and very very impressive.
OMG. Unbelievable place to see!!! Def a must see when going to Rome! So beautiful and historic, you don't want to miss out on this place!

Wonderful Wonderful Wonderful. You should visit the ancient market to walk along the monuments and feel this unique aura that somehow gives you a sense of belonging, like it is still living and breathing. déjà vu. Go up the palace and see that view from above. I'd go again.

Beautiful place to visit. Again definitely recommend you visit this place whilst in Rome. We decided to walk around as part of a tour which due to the time of day was slightly rushed. If you are going to visit its best to go early in the day so you can soak in more of the surroundings.
Amazing. We walked through the Forum for hours, it was great to walk through, and even in some of the ruins. There is so much history packed into one place, it's just a great overall experience.
Amazing. No trip to Rome would be complete with out it. A very special place to explore. The birth of so many ideas, a trip back in time,

Amazing !. This is our send time to the Forum and I cannot believe how much we missed the first time round. You can buy a combined ticket for the Forum and Colosseum which lasts 3 days.There is so much to see and you really need a few hours to see everything, we started off at Palatine hill and then went onto the Forum. We also saw the temple of Romulus which was mindblowing as the original lock on the door is still working although they have lost the key!Really worth a visit when you are in Rome.

Overwhelming history. You have to visit the Roman Forum, no matter how little time you have. Preferably, save at least 2 hours to actually have time to enjoy it. There is so much to see and so many incredible panoramas. It's amazing. Plus, if you start at the Colosseum entry and exit at Vio Fori Imperiali, you are super close to the monument Vittorio Emanuele II. Regarding the tickets, we booked them online so we'd skip the lines.
Very well preserved. Can be fully seen from a high ground and you can admire it quite well. It's very well preserved and looks really amazing.

The heart of Ancient Rome . Nothing else can be said that hasn't already been written about this wonderful location. Located between the Colosseum and Piazza Venezia and alongside Fiori Imperiale, this is a must see for any lover of history and Rome.

Lovely attraction. You can wander around this attraction all day if you want to do it is well worth the visit It was raining the day we visited it however not spoilt as plenty of street sellers selling ponchos!
Walking in a piece of history. This is part of your Colloseum ticket. It is absolutely amazing and you feel like you are in a movie set, with these pillars and temples. Almost unreal.

You can pay to get in or see it from several free vantage points. If you like clambering amid the ruins and do your homework / reading from the guide books or audio guide, probably admission (which also gets you into the Palatine palace complex ruins and Palatine museum of Roman sculpture - or the 23 euro 7day Roma Archaeology pass gets you in here + Altemps, Balbi crypt, P. Massimo, Baths of Caracalla + Domitian, Tomb of Cecilian Metella). There are good views from the Via Foro Imperiali en route to the Colosseum, but if you duck into the side street behind the Vittorio Emmanuelle memorial (the wedding cake) you can get a great view from just behind the Arch of Sept. Severus / T of Saturn. Also great view from back galleries of the Capitoline Museum. HINT - no washrooms in forum area, up in Palatine complex some at Museum, and also a self serve machine for water and snacks as you go towards the Farnese vineyards.

Misleading reviews of the Forum. I've read some reviews of the Forum--including a few in professional travel magazines--that give the impression those who visit will be primarily looking at a confusing rubble of stones. I suppose that is one way to view it, but another is to remember that these are ancient ruins--and to my mind completely astonishing because of that fact. In the first place I was completely unprepared for the number of the ruins--not only in the area of the Forum, but elsewhere in Rome. Secondly, it was very interesting that these buildings had been reclaimed in the middle ages to become churches. What I found was a fascinating mix of history and purpose--religious sites mingled with a "shopping complex" and public square. And while it may be difficult to determine what this specific formation or that is--at least without further study--it does not detract at all from the wonder that all this is still here for those of use in the 21st century to enjoy. I encourage everyone to visit and simply take in the essence of it--which is actually one of the only places which I don't find the crowds to be distracting.

This is where it started. No, I can't describe the Forum for you. Very fat books have been written about it, and the production continues. We have been visiting here for over 40 years, and my point today is that, slowly, the areas open to visitors are getting larger. A few years ago the Temple of Romulus (no, not that Romulus) became accessible, and this year the sensation is the opening of the ramp connecting the Forum with the imperial palaces on the Palatine above, complete with a small exhibition. A byproduct is that now you can also see the Oratory of the 40 Martyrs (Medieval wall paintings) and the little sanctuary of Giuturna next door. And most excitingly, we are promised that the church of Santa Maria Antiqua will be open bu April. We can't wait!

INCREDIBLE. This is a must go sight!!! I was amazed by all of the ancient ruins! I used the Rick Steves audio guide app and it really enhanced my experience! Get the pass that gives you entry to the Colosseum, Palatine Hill, and Forum.

So full of history!. This was a must for me. It's a site spread over a large area, so allow yourself plenty of time for the visit.The ground is a bit rough and is uphill at times, may not be suitable for people with mobility issues. My ticket was included in the entrance fee for the Colosseum.
What a history. Really interesting place, with lots of ruins. Just next Colosseum and from here you can reach Palatine Hill
wondeful. old part of rome ,I think it is the real rome lots of interesting historical sites I mloved it I recomend it

Stunnning views and amazing history. The Roam Forum / Palantine Hill ranks with Colosseum as a MUST SEE - but GO VERY EARLY (ie queue up before it opens) with a pre-paid ticket to avoid crowds. Huge area of roman history next to Colosseum. There is SO MUCH to see here… even has 2 museums within it! Romulus museum is small yet very detailed. The main museum on Palantine Hill is great and explains a lot of history of the place! We felt Forum/Hill was better than Colosseum - but best part is - when you buy a Colosseum ticket, you get tickets for the Forum as well... there are 2 main 'levels' - the extensive grounds and then the views from the Hill. You could easily spend a day here... relaxing in the shady trees overlooking Rome, wandering through the amazing historical ruins... when in Rome, do not miss this!

Favourite place in Rome!!. My partner and I visited Rome in November, 2015, and we were lucky enough to visit the Roman Forum on a combined ticket with the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. The Roman Forum turned out to be our absolute favourite place to see in Rome, which we didn't expect. The forum houses ancient ruins of important government buildings, and was a market place in ancient Rome. In the forum you have the opportunity to see the remains of ancient temples, churches, and important government buildings (e.g., the records offices, etc.). It's a must-see when in Rome.

A fascinating peak into Roman history and life. Wandering around the forum for a 2-3 hours is well worth the time and effort, especially if you have a guide to help explain what you are seeing along the way. The forum area is large enough that you can often get away from the crowds. The triumphal arches are truly impressive as is the remains of the temple of the vestal virgins.

So much to see!. The Roman Forum is HUGE! It might not look it from the outside but this place requires some serious walking to see everything. First, if you come out from the Colosseum, make sure that you read all available signage telling you how to get in. My dad and I ended up walking about 2 extra miles only to find that 2 of the 4 entrances were closed. Once you get in, you realize that this place is massive. What would be great is if they had a self guided tour that took you through the important parts. There are so many temples and forums and porticos that it can be a bit overwhelming.

Dont forget you get this free with the Colosseum ticket. Worth doing in the morning and Colosseum in the arvo when less busy. You need more time as it include Palintine. So much of ancient Rome still in the city.
Another great Rome site. This is another great Rome site to visit along with Palatine Hill right across from the Coliseum. Usually the tour tickets to the Coliseum include these sites as well.

Ancient trip. By visiting this spot you would definetely experience a flash back to the ancient Rome. Some of the monuments are being reconstructed. You can also view the Roman Forum from the street that leads to Via Corso. But I would definetely recomed to skip inside (the ticket is included with the Colossum), and I recomend at least 2 hrs to see the whole thing.

Two times here, I will repeat soon.... There are several attractions in Rome. All of them, fantastic. The Roman Forum is one of them, you need to go, especially if you have few days and very limited time. This spot you can't miss. Worth the visit.

So grateful to have the chance to visit!. Follow the advice of those saying get your tickets in advance or save 2 euro and get your ticket for Palatine Hill, Roman Forum and Colosseum here or PH! No line and I saved 2 euro. Also, get a guide or the audio tour. There were lots of things I missed I'm sure simply because I had no idea what I was looking at. That being said, there is still so much stuff to see here. Even though it is just ruins, it is the ruins of ancient Rome and that is crazy to me. Stuff in the United States that is "old" is only hundreds of years old if that so all these temples, statues and remains are great to see and learn about. Be careful and bring sensible walking shoes. Bring a water bottle and fill it up at the fountains in the area. Water is completely fine to drink and you don't have to pay for it!
Stunning place to visit!. wonderful experience, one of the most ancient roman place. the feeling are unique, you need to visit this place, use comfort shoes, boots are the best

A must see. Buy your 2-day ticket here first and then use it to tour the colosseum on the second day. If you don't want to buy a ticket, the site is open air and can be viewed free of charge from the street above. Download Rick Steve's helpful audio guide to your smartphone and listed as you wander about.

Probably need a audio/tour guide to appreciate it.. It is a nice walk around, we had a free entry because the Colosseum is free on the first Sunday of every month and this site is included in that ticket. Nice to walk around, but probably need a tour guide or audioguide to appreciate what you are looking at. A little overwhelming.

Walk among Roman ruins is what you do in Rome. Of course you plan to walk around the ruins while in Rome. Yes, there will be crowds, but the several forums are adjacent to one another, so you can see a lot in a small area. You can either view the ruins for free and get close to some of them, or pay a price to walk through them.
Awesome. Real beautiful bunch of ruins. If you can, grab a book or photos showing how it used to look compared to what it is now. Really made the visit
Breathtaking. Once the Colosseum is ticked off your list GO and stroll around the marvelous Forum - See the Circus Maximum from a height and marvel at the ruins of Rome. Extremely impressive.

Very cool - but go with a guide!. Walking through the ruins of the Forum made me feel like I was back in ancient Rome, especially when we had the stage set and were shown the highlights by our Context tour guide.

A lot to see. You could easily take half a day looking at all there is to see in the forum. There was a hippodrome,garden areas, Romulus home area , Augustus' home, a museum, walls, arches, columns. You could walk up to three - four miles so be prepared. I don't remember any drinking fountains. If you bought a ticket to the Coloseum, the forum is included.
The best :). It's good to visit here because you will see how Romans lived by just being here. all the monuments/building has decent explanations in front of them! Great place.
Ancient. This place really gives you a true feeling of Ancient Rome. So amazing that all this history is right in the middle of all the modern day Rome.

Awesome piece of history. You will definitely want to spend a whole day for this place and palatine Hill. The ancient ruins is huge and filled with lots of places to look at! Definitely the best place for archeology visits in whole of Rome.

Amazing ruins. We saw these as part of a Hop-on-Hop-off tourist bus tour. Amazing ruins but there are lots of parts you can't get access to due to the fact that they are trying to keep the ruins intact. Just something to bear in mind.

Amazing Place. One of big USP of Rome ...must watch for anyone ..Try and buy online tickets directly for
Colosseum-Roman Forum & Palatine Hills ...they are all combined in one .
..should reserve about 4-6 hours for these 3 places

So much history. It felt surreal to wander amongst the amazing ruins. We spent quite a bit of time just wandering and taking it all in. It really is worth a visit, as I dont think a trip to Rome would be complete without being there.

Great place to wonder & wonder. Lots to see & read & take onboard.
Its great to be in front of buildings & finally get a sense of the scale of the old Roman city centre.

Walk the ancient stones of the Forum!. The history of this part of Rome is just amazing, and you can feel the past as you walk along some of the stone paved streets of over a thousand years ago...take your time and enjoy the views of the hills surrounding this place.

Beautiful, ancient Rome.. The Arches are magnificent but just a small portion of this treasured area. Walking among the ancient ruins of Rome was surreal. Thank goodness for pictures that proved we were truly there! Cold well water was available near the main entrance that faces the Colosseum. (take advantage of this free water source) Good walking shoes are a must. I recommend reading up on the history of the area before your visit to truly appreciate what you are seeing. No on-site guides but you really don't need one to navigate around the area. Lots of tourists in the late morning on the day we visited but the area is so large that it was not a problem.

Missing information everywhere. So, I really like history, but I don't understand much about it, I went to Rome with great expectations and this visits was one of the most expected by me and my wife. The site it's interesting, but cmon , there is nearly no information available, I think the focus here it's for you to hire a guide, I went in without a audio guide or a tour guide and was hard even to get around the site, no maps available for you to pick, no description of the sites and where you had a sign or something it was so old you could almost not read it , if you go in, get a guide or at least the audio guide
Very interesting. Reasonably well preserved. Highlight was place of Ceaser burial. Also understood the meaning of Nero fiddling when Rome was burning

A walk through classical History. An extremely pleasant stroll through the heart of imperial Rome, paths intertwined with magnificent monuments and ruins with attractive greenery the roman forum felt somewhat idyllic and peaceful despite being quite busy. A great place on all levels

Great Tour!!. This was include in our Colosseum's Viator (City Wonders). We were very lucky to have Francesco as our guide. Unfortunately, there are just 5 starts to qualify this tour and its guide. I wish I could add another one. Excellent tour, highly recommended.

beautiful ancient Rome. great preservation of buildings from Ancient Rome, however not well explained via signage. We used a tour (includeed Colosseum) which made it a far better experience as we understood the significance of each building.

Awesome historical site. Located near the Colessum. We booked a guided tour,. The tour was very informative, well organized. Our tour gude was able to answer any questions our group had, He actually work excavating the site.
A step back in Time. This should be on EVERYBODY'S list when visiting Rome. You literally step back in time. The buildings and structures are upwards of 2000 years old

Walking through the Roman Forum is like experiencing history. Walking through the Roman Forum is like experiencing history. I was surrounded by the ruins of several important ancient government buildings. Most of the ruins were more than 3000 years old. Even though i wasn't on tour, it was still easy to get information because there were signs on every point. Thus i could still learn the history but although in a limited way. I recommend taking a tour if you want to fully understand the historical background behind this ruins. During summer where the temperature was around 30°, it’s very important to wear a hat and a sunblock, because in Roman Forum there weren’t any building that could give you shelter from sun.

a great site, rather poorly managed. The Forum and Palatine Hill are usually visited together on the same ticket as the Colosseum. The Forum and Palatine are beautiful, immense archeological sites with magical beauty and a unique place in the history of Europe. Yet, the site is badly managed, with very few signs and explanations and no map. Many dead-end paths that suddenly end on an empty wall. If you don't come prepared, with printed maps and a good guidebook, it is better for you to see the site from the street. There are vending machines (incl. coffee) and restrooms on site. There are also some elevators but they might not function properly. The Palatine Hill, away from the Forum, contains many lesser known archeological sites, like a giant hippodrome. You can really keep wandering and discovering things for yourself. Not many tourists go that far.

Full of history!. This is definitely one for you history lovers! The Roman Forum is beautiful and is not short of historic information. We took a Segway tour which saved us a whole lot of walking (I definitely recommend) and had a guide who was full of knowledge about the Forum. There is a lot to see so those who aren't a history/architecture fan, steer clear, of Rome in general! The forum is lovely at night/evening and is a prime example of Ancient Rome! You cannot see Rome with seeing the Forum!

Download the free Rick Steves Roman Forum audio walking tour podcast . Absolutely amazing! My fiancé and I tried to rent the audio tour headset, but they were out of English audio, so we ended up downloading a free podcast by Rick Steves. It's one of his walking tours that takes you through the Roman Forum and directs you to the sites in a certain order. We didn't get to listen to the audio provided by the Forum, so I can't say this is better, but I'm guessing that it is because I've never had a great audio tour provided by a site. The podcast we downloaded was informative with lots of cool facts and humor and was an easy, fun listen that was about 50 minutes long. Just search Rick Steves Roman Forum.The Roman Forum closes early, so make sure you leave yourself plenty of time. The line in the morning was super long-- we attempted to go then, but opted to wait and had some wine at a nearby bar and then lunch at another restaurant nearby-- and that was the right decision. When we went back at 1:30pm the line was short and we waited about 10 minutes. But be aware that they stop selling tickets at 2:00pm and that you must exit the entire property by 4:30pm. 1.5 to 2 hours is plenty of time to view the Forum and soak it all in.The history of this site is fascinating, so don't miss it!
Amazing. Amazing to stand in it and think about all that went on 1000's of years ago. the Roman well ahead of their time

Some real History here. You get to see the Forum, walk through it and see how gigantic it really was. As you walk along the paths you go higher and higher and the view from the top is hard yes but it is worth it. A must see.

When it`s time to go. When we were here, we had been walking all day and ended here. So when they started to close we were kind of dragging. That is we were walking slowly. The personnel that work here can be a little aggressive when they start to close as we were all but physically assisted out. It`s truly an amazing area and even if you`re not tired they have to understand, people seeing this for the first time can not help but be a little star struck at everything. This was a great trip and if you can try to find a tour group to hook up with as it adds to the historical value but don`t get stuck with them if you want to go see something specific.

For you history lovers!!!. Tickets to the Forum are combined with the Palatine Hill and the Colosseum.A nice tip for my fellow travellers: I suggest to buy the tickets either to the Forum or Palatine Hill (or online) during lunch time (as these 2 sites are less packed than the Colosseum, and the queue is much shorter during lunch). This way, you won't have to wait for the crazy queue at the Colosseum when you'll go there, and you'll be more incentivized to visit the Palatine/Forum which have to be on your Roman agenda.Walking in the middle of the ruins, aged 2000 years is just so special. it is packed with history and I recommend going there with a good touristic guide explaining the different ruins/monuments, as otherwise you may not enjoy it as much.It is a quite big area, and for some reason it is less packed than the Palatine Hill or the Colosseum, which I enjoyed a lot!

Roman History Biganza . We took a cheap guided tour that also included a tour of the coliseum which was amazing .Even if you go it alone and are not super into history there are great veiws of the city and of roman ruins that make great pictures.A must . visit while in Rome
Take a guide!. Roman Forum is saturated with history, that you will miss without a guided tour! The Forum is absolutely amazing- and a must see, but get someone to guide you through!

Segway tour was best idea ever!. We took a Segway tour of the Roman Forum and Collosseum which saved us from walking. Do yourself a favor and walk in the museums and churches, but save your back and feet and Segway around these places!

One of the best things to visit while in Rome. The visit to the forum was informative and very enjoyable. We learn't things about Rome that we did not know. The guide was true lover of her own city. She told us about celestial virgins and that Julius Ceasar was known to be buried there. So much to see and learn. I would highly recommend The Roman Forum as one of the places to visit while in Rome.
Excellent time. My girlfriend bought a 2 day pass to view the colosseum and forum for $12. They were both close by and provided a fantastic historical insight into Rome. Amazing deal- well worth it.

Often overlooked gem. Most people often visit the Colosseum, but fail to visit/notice this wonderful gem that is included in the ticket for the Colosseum as well. Even though there was no guided tour, my family had great pleasure walking around the attraction and we felt as if we were brought back in time. Moreover, the place is big enough such that its not overcrowded, which made it an enjoyable experience. Queues were short to enter the attraction despite the heightened safety checks.

Wonderful! So much history!. I saw this as a part of a guided tour. I don't think it would be as interesting without a good guided tour. Either way definitely a place for great pictures - beautiful scenery! Also TONS, TONS of walking!!! Zero assistance for people with disabilities.
When in Rome.... In its day, this was the place where things were happening. A hub of activity where people came to do business, hang out, and see and be seen.

Fantastic with a guide, at a minimum with guide book . Otherwise it is hard to appreciate the significance of each relic or monument. We had a guide for the colosseum and forum especially orientated to families with young kids. This really help put each into perspective and painted the picture so the kids (& the adults too) could really understand. No queue when we went all be it in winter. Best photos are at the top of the hill, after the exit
Very nice place, Must see. Take your time, at least 2 hours. The place is very nice. I recommend read a little about it in advance. Not areas were open at the time if the visit. Signage was lacking.

A lot of walking. It was perfect weather in October to visit. We bought our tickets through getyourguide.com. The line at the box office around 8:30AM was small and it was nice to pass it. We did not buy the headphones but wish we did. There is a lot of history and buildings in this one location. This is where you book your time for the Colosseum visit.

AMAZING!!!. This was my favorite place in Rome, it has so much history! Plan more than a half day to spend there if you like ancient stuff and ruins. There are some hidden places as well. When you get there, start with a panoramic view from the Campidoglio before going down. Also, the sunset is magic from the campidoglio terrace....If you have the Roma Passa you can skip the line! It is just across the Coliseum, so very easy to get there by metro.

See this the Colosseum and Palatine with one guided tour.... All three sites are available as one guided tour, this is the only way to really see everything, plus you of course get the benefit of an experts knowledge...you will also not stand in a queue for over an hour....these three attractions are a very good reason for visiting Rome...

Good value experience. We visited the Coliseum and bought a ticket which included a guided tour and a visit to the Forum - about 17 euros each and a bargain. Plenty to see and good information boards. Audio guides are available, but it's easy to just wander around and get a feel for the place without one.

So much history in one place.. An amazing sight with so much history. So many interesting historical sights in one place. Allow plenty of time to see as much as you can. Audio guide was useful but hard to identify the points sometimes. Definitely somewhere I want to visit again in the future.

A must see (bring sunscreen). Bring sunscreen. There's not a lot of shade. This is, of course, a must do in Rome. We didn’t take a guided tour, but did the tour in the Rick Steves pocket guide. We found that sufficient. It was an enjoyable visit.

Yarn.....if you're not into history.. So just walk through it, don't pay anything for tour, if this is not you. Get to the Colosseo or Piazza Venezia through this long avenue. You might like it. Too hot in the sun, so schedule your visit carefully at the right season. If it rains, either you can pray, bring your own umbrella, or just walk fast and get to Piazza Venezia coffee shops. By the way, if you need "polizia", the station is located at the Piazza Venezia arcoss the street on Via del Plebiscito next to the coffee shop you've just passed. Check your belongings and watch your surroundings at all times. This area is another hot spot for thieves. Lock your passport at hotel and only keep a copy of it on you will help.

Ruins. If you love ruins this is the place to go! There are different information boards in English scattered among the ruins and explaining what once existed. Hard to believe the structures they created so long ago!

Great place to wander on a sunny day. Great views of the city from it's ancient walls as you wander the ancient orange groves and try to imagine what the city was like back in its hayday. The ruins are spectacular and afford many great photo ops. We went on the first sunday of the month by chance and it was free.

Wonders of Rome. The house of the Vestals was one of the highlights as we felt it was the best preserved. The imperial path was also interesting. As horse owners we thought of how grand it must have been to ride up this path.

Impressive. Could use more indications. . Really enjoyed the visit. There are many things to see and it's definitely a good site. Only downside is that there is little directions and indications so it's a bit of a maze plus you sometimes don't really know what you're looking at.

Interesting monument, a must visit. Another one of the must visits in Rome. Don't recommend a tour guide - just go on your own. Buy a ticket online if you like though we bought it at the spot. Best on a sunny day - don't go on a rainy day.beware of pick pockets. Just a nice place to walk around and explore.
a taste of 'Roman' Rome. Really interesting, but make sure that you wear sensible flat shoes otherwise you could break your ankle!

Amazing History. Sometimes you are lucky enough to repeat history. The first time I visited Rome was 16 years ago and after having been to Greece and seen the ruins, I was somewhat disappointed in the condition of the many ruins in Rome. Over the last 26 years, amazing strides have been made to uncover and clean important parts of the History of Western Civilization. The changes that I witnessed on this visit were monumental and made the cost of admission worth it. The fact that workers were active while tourists were wandering around in awe taking pictures was an indication of how important this grande restoration project is to the Italian people.The Forum is just one of the many must see sights in Rome and throughout Italy whether for the first time or fifth and one you just cannot miss.

Wonderful Historic Site. Plan to spend a couple of hours here and book a tour. The tour guides know much more than the average tourist making it more enjoyable. Bring a water bottle if traveling on a hot day.

Second part of Palintine tour . Can't get enough of this. It's amazing and thankful that someone didn't destroy all this incredible history. Time spent was worth it. Most of the structures are so large it's hard to get a perspective on photos. You have to be there. December sunny day was a perfect time to see it.

Stunning!. My sister and I were amazed at how much is still there. It really puts the ancient city into perspective in terms of its size. Lots of walking so wear comfortable shoes. Three sets of toilets there which are clean and well sign posted as imagine in the hotter months you would need to drink plenty.

A Glimpse of Roman Rome But Give yourself Plenty of Time!. Phenomenal but bigger and more to see than expected. So, if you start on Palatine Hill, you can walk down the hill to the Roman Forum, and then further down to the Colosseum. Easy to spend the entire day on just these three things. If I had to do it again, I'd see the Palatine Hill and the Forum in the morning, have lunch, and then be fresh for the Colosseum in the afternoon. Lots packed in here. Consider getting the audio guide in your language for the Roman Forum. Or, you can buy a guidebook in English at the Palatine Hill gift shop for 10 euros that tells you about all 3 sites. Take your time, don't rush!

Incredible site - a must see. Just incredible to imagine what the Forum looked like back in Roman days. Well worth your time to stroll through the Forum, Also, take time to get to higher ground on multiple sides to take in the scene. Rick Steves walking audio tour (free iPhone app and down load tours) provides the information you'll need.
Full of history. You could walk around here for hours, looking at everything and soaking in the atmosphere. good signs and great views from further up

Nice Walk & Historic Views. A nice walk along the historic buildings and sites. When purchasing our ticket for the Coleseum it allowed for entry into the Roman Forum. We enjoyed the views and trying to imagine the way in which the Romans had to live in previous years.Take a few hours to walk through and experience the history and the sites. Pack a nice picnic basket or sandwiches just to have some lunch under the trees.

fantastic. You can walk out of the Coliseum take a right and walk down to this attraction. You can picture the carts that used to go over the cobble stones and see the buildings of the old market and buildings. I loved it and well worth a visit.
Good place to see. This came with our Collseum tickets and we walked around but to me there was nothing that impressive and I didn't find a very clear path to follow to see what exactly to see in it.

Star gate. What can I say for the greatest civilation ever? Even now the most important building's like white house are designed like these ancient architecture. That means that in human history nothing better created till now. Shame that everywhere is situated a church but this is normal because they try to steal again a part of this glory.....

Roman Rome. Fabulous variety of Roman ruins. Due to queues and general tiredness upon entry did not get an audio guide, but to really appreciate the history it would be best to pay for a tour or get an audio guide if possible.
New years day. Well . completely taken back by the beauty of Rome. . And this also was quite amazing always good when you have sunshine and excellent light to achieve the moment on camera!

Holiday in Rome. A visit to the Roman Forum is a special experience, waking on places where the romans emperors lived and ruled people of half antic world.An emotional return into the past, searching each of us our roots.
Fantastic. Git to be on your to do list when visiting Rome. The history is all around. We had a prepaid guide and it was worth every penny.
Walking back in time. This was spectacular to see. it is not as well preserved as other roman artifacts, but it is still impressive to walk through the forum and see so much of ancient history.

Awe-Inspiring. The Roman Forum is truly awe-inspiring. I was there in August 2008, and at least then, you could actually walk through the site, it's not just an archaeological site you can look at but not touch. While it probably doesn't help preservation efforts, as a tourist, I really appreciated it because it helped me really connect with the place. And for every structure still standing, there's five, if not more, structures that have crumbled to pieces over the centuries and whose absence is palpable.

Amazingly well preserved!. Visiting the Roman Forum requires extensive walking over uneven surfaces so wear walking shoes and if the weather is hot the stones reflect heat so dress comfortably. It is a large square area with paths traversing old gardens, residences and buildings. Many structures are well preserved and you can picture the daily lives of the Romans in the area. Very interesting and worth the visit!
So much history!. It is a lot larger than I expected. And so much to see. Forum Romanum is only one of many interesting places in Rome, but this is well worth a visit.

Ancient History at its Best.. All of the Roman artifacts are very interesting. I especially like this area and imagine the happenings here thousands of years ago. For the western world, this was the center of the universe. I highly recommend that you go here while in Rome.
Amazing sightseeing. The Roman Forum is a great landmark in Rome truly magnificent in its grandeur and the architecture is masterful given how long ago it was constructed. A must see when in Rome.

Good Attraction. It is worth visiting . One has to be careful and choose which area of the forum to visit. We preferred the Temple of Saturn and the actual Roman Forum street. A lot of walking! It will take one at least 3 hours to visit the attraction, so prepare in advance for it.

A History Lesson Tour. Entrance from the Colosseum is closed and please make sure you ask around for the correct direction. Some reading before your visit will definitely help to understand those ruins history during your tour. A pair of comfortable hiking shoe will make the tour less stress.

Walking back in time. This attraction has great views, deep history, and a lot of walking. Enjoy the sights of life in the Roman era where Democracy gets it's roots. Escape in to the wonders of what used to be and enjoy all of what it has to offer. A must while in Rome!

Second best ruins in Rome . Amazing ancient site,well curated,beautiful,great for pictures,for history and architecture lovers.Really nice to walk through and around while appreciating ancient art and ruins.

Roman History!. The Roman is a well worth visit before or after the Colosseum. One has to be careful and choose which area of the forum to visit. We preferred the Temple of Saturn and the actual Roman Forum street. A lot of walking! It will take one at least 3 hours to visit the attraction!
Long day adventure. Went to the forums (& colosseum) with three friends and spent an entire day there. Bring comfortable shoes and a light jacket in the cooler months, it gets cold in the shade.

Great Visit. I visited this place in January and was one of the highlights of Rome. The history of this place is so rich that it amazed a tourist like me. Honestly? A must-visit in Rome. Trust me on this!
Wonderful at Dusk. Really lovely at Dusk, the crowds are a little lower and the sky paints the building gorgeous colors, sublime.

Series: Must visit & see! . We bought tickets to the Forum + Colosseum from Forum's ticket sale and got there after 5min of lining. Awesome history, nice landscapes & breathtaking structures. Ticket to Forum & Colosseum is ~12€ (including both) and trip with guide is ~35€ (tickets included, both Forum+Colosseum) and I prefer you take guided tour. You will miss out so much history without.

Stunning. We looked round here straight after looking at the Coliseum. Amazing, so much to look at and it's nice just to be able to wander round and take it all in. I'd advise you to have a guidebook handy as there is so much to take in you need a bit of help. Take some water with you. We went in October and it was really hot even then as it is in a little valley and a real sun spot.
History! . Pure history to walk along in this very old area. Amazing how they could build so many years ago. There was also a long line here, but not as long as for Colesseum. A must when in Rome.

Hard to imagine without actually see it!. A person thinks they have an idea of the magnitude of Rome in ancient and middle times, but if you haven't toured the Roman Forum with a guide like Renatta from Italy Wonders you have no idea! I am not a history buff, but I do enjoy it and know more than an average person would. I learned so many new things from the tour and seeing the ruins with my own eyes it is unimaginable. I could go back everyday for a year and I wouldn't get a full picture, I think.

amble at leisure amid the ruins. The forum is a great feature of Rome, despite - or perhaps because of - its rather chaotic and random nature. Clearly it was changed and added to over the centuries and then left to decline, so you have a mass of half-standing ruins, piles of columns and other bits of stone work and so on. As with the Colosseum (see separate review) it would be good to find more information on site regarding the history and what you are actually looking at but it is a fabulous place to amble or sit in the sun and just wonder at. If you are lucky, you may see some of the famous cats living in the ruins. Most people walk through from the Colosseum end parallel with the Vai dei Forii Imperiali, using it as something of a thoroughfare, but if you have time, be sure to cover the whole site, as the far end is under-visited and has a view down onto the Circus Maximus, site of chariot racing and other sporting events in its day.

It really once was........ The fact that the Caesars once paraded through these streets, flaunting the spoils of their conquests, humans and animals, and riches plundered from distant lands.........all of this is very difficult to imagine.......but we know it happened...and in a way, still does. It is so big, and real, and important, and lasted for so long....that it is really quite hard to put your arms around it. Not much actually remains, but it was there.
Must see experience!. Perhaps one of the most amazing experience in Rome, a must-do while in Rome. Highly recommended and please leave ample time to enjoy the artifacts.

Crowded, Maze like, not very interesting.... Doesn't really worth the time and effort when you have so many similar structures to see around rome's streets. It was hard to figure out how to get out, and there were only two toilets in the entire site.
must see. must see for sure but be prepared to walk a lot!!. tour guide recommended!! can also be done on a rainy day. good price.

A great place to walk round!. If its history or archaeology you're interested in then you must come here. Situated pretty much next to the Colosseum, you can't miss it. You can walk around at your own pace and experience what it would have been like to live in Ancient Rome!

Step back in time. Amazing piece of history, the centre for political administration of ancient Rome. You can really imagine the pomp and splendor of how it would have been walking through these ruins.
Breathtaking to see Ancient Rome.. We took a tour of Palatine Hill, the Roman Forum, and the Colosseum. Of course the Roman Forum is a ruin but it is spectacular none the less.
Back in the roman time.. It is one of the best preserved roman city. With little imagination you can feel you are stepping back into the roman time.
A reminder of ancient glory. Walk through the ruins and try to imagine the magnificence of the ancient Rome. You can feel how people were living there and walk on the foot steps of emperors!

pictures can't do it justice. If you are interested in archaeology and ancient Rome, allow yourself several hours to roam through this extensive area studded with the remnants of downtown Rome in the age of the Caesars.

Soak it all up. This place is central in Rome and gives you a real feel for life during those times. You really must see these ruins. We visited at night time and saw it all lit up and wow what an amazing experience. The only thing is that at night all the bats are in the trees surrounding the forum and they "rain" bat poo on you (literally) so beware - you will soon work out why most people walk on the road and not on the footpath!! Still, stay away from the trees and enjoy the history.

Great place to sense the history. Here you will see where Caeser was cremated as well as many pieces of Roman history. Some of the walkway is original and make sure you top into the temple. Excellent place for pictures.

Walking in the footsteps of the Ancients. Wonderful experience especially with a very interesting tour guide. The picture painted in words and the feel of the centuries around you. Beautiful day spent in an unforgettable place. Needs to be experienced in person rather than seen in pictures.

Ruinous heart of the city!. Best seen from above on the highest terrace of the palatine hill, especially as the sun sets it does obscure the ruins and throws shadows from the remaining temples. Walking the old Roman road studded with huge blocks of granite are works of art, slippy on a wet day it is still easy to imagine the processions and triumphal marches, it's literally walking through history - area could be improved with more information and perhaps some illustrations along the way describing each temple but otherwise excellent, if like us you go after the colloseum then prepare to be very tired, especially if you want to see the palatine.

So much history. The Roman Forum is surrounded by the ruins of several important ancient government buildings at the center of the city of Rome. The teeming heart of Ancient Rome, it has been called the most celebrated meeting place in the world, and in all history. I was here in December and it was very crowded - but lovely weather.
Very nice . So full of history! Having a tour guide is a must, otherwise if you don't hear the history you can't fully appreciate it!

Heart of Ancient Rome. What can I add that everyone else hasn't?This is one beautiful place, it is the heart of ancient Rome and it still a plenty of it standing. Enjoy just being there, absorb the atmosphere, take great pics and WEAR COMFORTABLE SHOES.

I actually prefer it to the Colosseo .... The forum is great - it never gets that busy.It's lovely to walk around and soak up the feeling of ancient Rome.After visiting the Colosseo don't forget to cross the road and enjoy a stroll around the forum.
the forum is great!. loved the forum it was a fun spot, had no complaints and learned and saw a lot,not a must spot, but good one!

So much to see. One of my favorite locations to get a full sense of the Roman culture and lifestyle. Mostly ruins, but with a guide like Sonia Tavoletta, the roman lifestyle will come alive. Don't a couple of the good photo opts as you look out over the ruins of the Forum.

The world evolves before your very eyes. The history that is all within that small area known as "the forum" is incredible! Starting a few centuries before Christ and continuing for centuries! It's mind boggling!

Spend A Whole Day Here!. Incredible site full of history. Bring your lunch, a drink, your guidebook, and your most comfortable shoes. So much to see, learn, and observe. Fascinating Imperial Fora and the Roman Forum--Caesar, Augustus, Nerva, and Trajan's marks were made. Loved seeing the archeological work being done as we walked from site to site, and the backdrop of the Il Colisseo as we wandered around in amazingly warm temperatures in November!

Increbible place and site. This site is increible and awsome in all ways!!! Take your time at this site and when you by tickets also by the ticket to Colluseum! You need at least 2 hours for this attraction. Mailn and i were her for 3 hours and we loved every momonet of it!!!! Malin and i recommend a visit here when you are in Rome!!!

A maze of wonders . This place is like a maze of wonders. It will make you enjoy the beauty of the structure. Go the to top of the hill to see it from above. I suggest that when you buy the tick you buy also for the colloseum so you avoid the que
Must See. Huge area of ruins of the great Roman Empire. Most in veryt good condition. You need to sphere at least a half day to visit

To the Glory of Rome. Visited Aug 2013: The Roman Forum is surrounded by the ruins of ancient Roman buildings in the city centre. Originally a marketplace, Roman citizens referred to it as the "Forum Magnum". For centuries, the forum was the heart of Roman public life with triumphal marches, public elections, public speeches, criminal trials, gladiatorial games, and commerce. Statues and monuments commemorated the "Glory of Rome"!

A Must See. Always crowded but a must see for any Rome visit. Easy to get to and centrally located. Admission charge but not a bad way to spend the morning. Interesting to see how the ancient Romans lived and worked.

exceptional place . across from the colosseum, this is a fabulous place to visit. Unfortunately 2 out of 3 entrances were closed and the signs were inadequate but a must - see. go in through piazza venezia enrrance

The glory of ancient Rome. No visit to Rome is complete without a wander around the ancient Forum, the center of the empire. Even our teenage children were enthralled by the cobblestoned streets and the ruins of the temples and buildings, some of which were turned into churches. We were especially thrilled by the massive columns and steep steps on the temple of Antonius and Faustina; the domed temple of Romulus, with its gloriously painted ceiling (and the view of the church through the window at the top); the little, easily missable door in one of the buildings that supposedly led down to the underworld; and most of all the Arch of Titus, built in the first century, which depicts the Romans conquering and plundering ancient Jerusalem, and carrying off the golden candelabrum. A little knowledge of Roman history and mythology helps make what you're seeing in the Forum clearer, but you don't need to be an expert, and there are signs on the main sites.
A day with Jerry as our guide. You can do it alone, but a guide will help make the Forum come alive! After touring the Coliseum, it is a good afternoon of insight into life 2000 years ago!
Good site. Buy the headphones and wear substantial shoes there is a lot of uneven walking, Great venue, very interesting

Lots of walking. There is a lot to see with a great imagination of what Rome used to be. Make sure you war god shoes though because it is a lot of walking with stairs and hills. There are fountains to fill water bottles. However your bathrooms are poorly marked and limited.

Along with Palantine Hill, a must visit. Simply awe inspiring. Have to leave yourself plenty of time to visit because its simply so vast and there is so much to see. Along with Palantine Hill was the highlight of my visit to Rome. Id recommend going in off season so it isnt as busy, as we particularly appreciated being able to walk round without huge crowds

Magnificent. When you realize who has walked here over the last 2500 years it is absolutely amazing. Julius Caesar, Augustus, Nero, Trajan, Napleon and so on. And the events that this place has seen, it breathes history

Wear walking shoes!. Wear walking shoes! When you buy a ticket to the Colosseum, it includes entry to Palatine hill and the Roman forum (which are both at the same place). I would suggest doing the hill first, great views of the forum below and if you get tired or your feet start hurting, at least you saw it all from above before you decide to call it a day.
Must see where in Rome. This is amazing - being able to walk on the same road as Julius Cesar - Priceless. The story behind the excavation alone is mind boggling. Another "must see" when in Rome

Major restauration in progress to preserve this amazing monument. Take your time, don't rush...there is so much to see. Many entrances are currently closed due to this work, so be prepared for a major walk from Colosseum. I love traveling in December to avoid the SpringSummer crowds...but even at this time of year there are many people from all over the world at this site. Don't skip Palatine Hill and the upper areas, there are less people and many things you don't often see in tour books. I have been there several times and it is always breathtaking. To imagine how long ago this place was a thriving center...and still has more magic than almost anywhere you can be. Wear comfortable shoes, the cobblestones are not easy. Again, take your time, breathe in the history and enjoy an amazing experience. Go early in the morning to avoid big crowds and longer lines...

Amazing. We toured the Roman Forum with a guide from City Wonders who did a great job giving the history and explaining what we were seeing. To imagine that you are walking on stones that were used by ancient Rome is inspiring. The artifacts are everywhere.

Thoroughly enjoyed walking through the ruins. My favourite section out of the trio of attractions, it was a truly fantastical feeling to walk through the ruins and read up on little excerpts on the establishments that stood where I was standing. While I expect it may be a little too 'well manicured' and small in size for some, for me it was a perfectly-sized time capsule and the remaining architecture and surrounding views was simply charming. Makes you wonder about the level of skill it took in that time to construct the amount of intricacies still to behold. The forum does not cover so large an area that you feel like you might miss out, and it leaves enough time to explore the remaining attractions in the area comfortably.
History Lesson. This place could be of special interest to history lovers. This was the commercial, political and religious center of Ancient Rome.

Roman Empire's Glory Days. Another must-see site after the Colosseum. Part of the two-day pass and adjacent to the Colosseum, it's another must-see in Rome or else, your experience "Roman" experience is incomplete. Take a leisure walk in the pathways, watch the imposing columns, the different buildings and other ancient structures. You can just imagine how glorious was the Roman Empire during its heyday.
Very Interesting. right next to the Colosseum. If you take the Colosseum CityWonder tour includes the Roman Forum. Very interesting historical information.

A marketplace extroidinare. The Roman Forum is at the base of Palatine Hill and is a plaza surrounded by the ruins of several important ancient government buildings and temples and was originally used as a marketplace. Also the Roman Senate met here. There are some restored buildings along with the ruins of many others. From this area we saw the start of the Appian Way which is the oldest and most important roads, built in 312 BC. Its purpose was to move troops and supplies in and out of Rome quickly and easily. The road began as a leveled dirt road upon which small stones and mortar were laid. Gravel was laid upon this, which was finally topped with tight fitting, interlocking stones to provide a flat surface. The road was raised in the middle (for water runoff) and had ditches on either side of the road which were protected by retaining walls. Upon the defeat of Spartacus' army, in 71 BC, 6,000 slaves were crucified along the 200-kilometer (120 mi) Via Appia from Rome to Capua. The Appian Way was also used by the Allies during WWII in 1943; and it also served as a part of the men's marathon course in the 1960 Olympics.

Wonderful place..... After you finish the Colosseum, you get the opportunity to wonder through the Roman Forum. This is a must. You will see the ancient ruins of Rome and all the magnificent places the Romans lived and worked at. You will see everything from Brothels to shrines to the ancient roads.... Excellent education for the whole family....

This is where it all happened. Certainly much of it is gone, strip mined to build churches through the centuries, but there is enough left to tell the story and it is still very impressive. Just make sure you hire a good guide to explain it all because the signage and any written information you get just will not quite do it for you.

Got to visit to appreciate the Roman Empire. Place is walking distance from Coliseum and must be visited to appreciate and imagine the glory days of an Empire. Also kids can get a photo with the Gladiators.

Roman Forum Visit 20151205. Toured with City Wonders-Dark Rome as part of Colosseum-Palatine Hill tour. Amazing ancient Roman ruins. Some parts of ancient structures are now part of current buildings. Amazing chance of a lifetime activity.
Rome in a nutshell . Classical music, excavation, and - rare in Rome - an almost unobstructed view. Gave us the roman feel, and is quite close to the Colosseum.

Takes you back in time, great way to escape the city pace. A great way to escape the city pace, duck in and experience the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill and imagine yourself in the heart of the Roman empire. One ticket gets you access to this, the forum and the Colosseum

great archaeological park full of old treasures, lots of walking involved. We walked here after the Colosseum. It was a hot October day and lots of walking to do. It was nice seeing all of the old sites. We did NOT get the audio guide, so it was nice to have read about the place before our trip - however you don't need to do either to enjoy this. All is walking and going outdoors - it was a rainy day but we had clear ponchos folded up in my purse so no worries but we were prepared. I think we were only able to go into one building, the Temple of Romulus (legendary founder of Rome).

Moving and fascinating a chance to explore the beginnings of Rome". We spent a happy two hours here, exploring, imagining, rethinking what we learned at school. Can be uncomfortable underfoot, but it's really worth it.

Absolutely amazing. Be prepared for a lot of walking, several sites to see, the complex offers the Roman Forum and Pallatino with the same admission, a bit difficult to find out when one starts and the other ends. Also great views of Rome from the Pallatino side. A must!
Breathtaking ancient ruins. Huge place full of old ruins and temples. Ticket is 12 euros with admission to the Colosseum and Palatino as well. I would recommend it to all lovers of ancient ruins!
Huge. This place takes hours to navigate, take stout walking shoes, well worth a visit, the views are amazing
History, history, history. How cool is it to walk where Julius Caesar once walked. Streets and buildings 2000 years old! Too much to see and absorb in a single day.

Lovely and a must see. Entry comes via a ticket that allows entry to Palatine Hill and the colluseum but this was the gem. There was soo much to see and experience. we were looking around for 2 hours.
Really Impressive. A great insight into the Roman structure of the city. Right next to the Colosseum, book a tour that includes both and save your self some money. Definitely worth a visit

Impressive. Wear your trainers and take a packed lunch this place is surely one to spend hour in. Careful however, the ticket you purchase grants you access to the Colosseum too, check the closing time as it is EXTREMELY early. We in fact missed it

huge area of attraction. went there last autumn with my husband.. a lot of tourist and we didn't go in.. but it's worth checking out the place from outside.. we manage to take some nice pictures.. ancient and that's the point of visiting rome.. be careful with taking picture with the gladiotor, if you're willing to spend 20euro and above then i think it could be worth it

Be sure to go to the Palantine Hill area of the Forum. Watch your step and be careful walking among these ruins. There are lots of cobblestones and uneven walkways. That being said, since my last visit, the ruins of Augustus's house and the remains of the home of his wife, Livia. have been uncovered. If you want to visit the interiors you must book a separate tour. Walking through the streets and in and out of the alleys with their temples and alter areas brings you back and lets you get a feel for what this area was life during the glory period of the Roman empire.
Like in a movie prod!. Didn't expect so many ruins when we entered the forum. This place is fabulous, it is worth to take at least 2 or 3 hours to go around.

You must go. We walked through here at the beginning of our Colosseum tour, its a very interesting place, but I was so glad we had a tour guide....much of it is just rocks and you cant really tell what anything was...i would suggest having the guide.

Roman Forum, great stop, worth the time. This was part of a package tour. The forum and colosseum would be great together, we also toured the Vatican the same day. That's too much. The forum was very educational and impressive.

Worth nothing. We bought a ticket and were disappointed.
We got no map, there was no signs...nothing
You can see everything from outside and there is even a better view from there.
The worst part was the security check and the lady at the cashier.
Not recommended for more than a street view.

One of the Top Attraction for any Visit to Rome. You are taken back in time to the early Roman era to see how people lived then. One need a good private guide and a copy of an overly book that shows what each of the structures looks like back then and now. Plan to spend most of a day there!

Make sure you have a few hours to spend at the Roman Forum.... The Roman Forum is quite expansive. There is a lot to see. Make sure you have a few hours to spend here if you want to see everything. There are lots of little nooks and crannies with interesting historical facts. It can be crowded, so make sure you stay with your group.
Interesting.. Very interesting with lots to see and do, Vast in everyway and spread out over miles, all very overwhelming to be fair, loved every minute of it, Ancient architecture at its very best.

Long walk. This place was awesome I just couldn't stop imagining how this place d houses d shops would have been back in d day. I recommend to wear comfortable shoes as this is huge and u need to walk a lot along with climb stairs up n down. I had my 14 months DD with me. Baby wearing saved us.

Go back at night. We saw this during the day and enjoyed it. We decided to walk back at night. We thought it would be lit up but it was not. As it turned out a show was about to start so we paid, took our earbuds and watched an AMAZING show. They use lights, lasers and "magic" (i have no idea how they did some of it) to re-create everything as it was 2000 years ago. It really brought it to life.

A must see. What a magnificent place. I read some say you see enough from the high ground outside but that is not true. It costs €12 for a combo ticket with the Colosseum over two days. You have to go inside. BUT even though it has to be one of the most important and accessible historical sites in the world - the information you get on site is woeful. Woeful. Woeful. The Italian's do not do information like us Brits. Buy a book and then go in. But go in you must.
Nice place. We've decided not to get inside as you can walk around it and see the ruins. In my opinion it's not a must see.
Fabulous!. Another part of Rome not to be missed. A real trip back in time, makes you marvel at the achievements of the Romans whilst we were living in mud huts and hitting each other with sticks!
Interesting place!. Comes with entry for combo ticket or entrance w plantine hill..really interesting structures for you to imagine what the roman empire looked like..have to go!
Birthday visit . 1 of my favourite places to visit in Rome I could stay here for hours so much to say would highly recommend anyone visiting , even if it's raining still good fun

Arrive Early and Enjoy. Early risers, listen up. Thinking I wouldn't have to fight a huge crowd early I arrived at the Roman Forum at 8:30 a.m. when it opened. Much to my surprise, I began walking around and admiring all of the beauty and I was there about 40 minutes before I saw anyone else in this huge monumental area. It was like taking a private tour of these incredible ruins! I exited about 10:15 a.m. and headed to the Coliseum where much to my chagrin the line was short and moving fast. The saying is true - the early bird gets the worm.
