You Cannot Go To Rome and Not Visit This. This was just amazing. The history here... I was on a tour and the guide was incredible. Right next to the Colosseum. A short walk up the hill brings you to Pallatine Hill, which I would definitely do as well. I just can't imagine coming to Rome and not stepping foot here.
Every visitor of Rome must see it. We staid one day there and made many fantastic photographs in the excellent weather. There are so many things to see!

Ancient History comes to life . We walk through ancient history as we traverse the path of Forum. Unfortunately there is no official tour nor any signs in Forum. We used Rick Steve's audio guide & it was good. The private tours are expensive. Hope they come up with an official tour.

Amazing piece of history. Although there are several areas of Roman Empire history around the city, this is the place to really feel and appreciate the full extent. The information signs are very good and we used our DK Rome book to follow it in more detail which meant that it took us around 3+ hours to get round by which time we were too tired to do much of Palatine Hill. In hindsight we should have taken something to eat and planned to be there all day!

Roman Forum - just around the corner. As a new resident of Rome, I walk past the Roman forum each morning on the way to the Metro. An amazing spectacle of Roman history. An absolute must-see, but this location, perhaps more than any other requires a good guide or guide book in order to appreciate the historic dimension of what you are seeing. Unfortunately because of construction of the Metro C line, there are a number of fences in the area between Cavour and Colosseo that will obstruct your view. However, walk around behind, or view from above from a vantage point behind the Capitoline Hill. It is also an amazing place to stroll in the evening - well lit & romantic.
Amazing, layer upon layer of history!. A tour guide is a must to get all the information needed to appreciate what your looking at! The depth of history is staggering.
Nothing funny happened on the way.... OK, it was very cool. Our guide was able to breathe a bit of life into it. This place is a MUST see if you are a history buff.

Journey to the past. Awesome experience to walk where many ancient Romans walked in the ancient time. Amazing how it is properly designed and things are put in place to serve specific purposes. It gives us an overview how the ancients lives their life.The forum is an open place, and it requires lots of walking. It is difficult if you have baby stroller with you, just what we have experienced.

Imagin that you are in the roman days!. the '' Roman Forum'' are the ruins of several important buildings in the center of Rome.You can walk to the forum an explore the ruins of the old government buildings of Rome.If you choose to make the walk in the forum you should imagine that you are back in the roman days! It is great!

Sprawling spectacular ruins. Combination ticket to Colosseo and Roma Foro is 12 Euros. Be prepared for a good walk if you want to see more fo the ruins. Our Fit Bit pedometer registered 25,000 steps for this day! But relax, nothing strenuous. Just easy walking pace with soem steps and gentle grades. Nice walk on a beautiful sunny day in November! Definitely worth the visit. Be prepared to spend some time to soak in the ambiance and the fact that humanity, as sophisticated as ours, were here two millennia ago.
Beautiful . This is a beautiful place to walk around even in December. It's really helpful if you have someone that knows the history or if you have a readable guide to explain things.

Interesting . From Palatine hill you can walk down to the forum and explore the ruins of the old government buildings in ancient Rome.If you are interested in the history and the makings of the forum, getting the audio guide at the entrance of the forum would be helpful. I did not get it due to lack of time and regretted it as the history is so rich and worth knowing.Lots of uneven steps and roads. So wear comfortable shoes. There is a restroom around this area so you can freshen up before exploring.
History. Interesting to see the layout of the ancient capital of the Roman world. Lots of walking and can get tiring especially on a hot day but definitely worth visiting.

Awesome. I really enjoyed visiting the Roman Forum. To just imagine what it was like walking through the streets as a roman back in the day. It's one of the most impressive areas in all of Rome, and to me, very picturesque! And the fact that it's all included as one price to see this and the Colosseum! Definitely recommend!
Nicely Historic. Great to visit and learn ancient history. It was being restored so we were not allowed access to all of it but give it 2-3 hours to go through

Like stepping back in time. So many different things to see. It isn't far from the Colosseum so best to fit the two into one day. My partner really enjoyed this. Restaurants are very expensive in this area

Views are spectacular. What can you say, the title says it all.Everything has been preserved so very well. Only issue for me is that the barriers stop you getting some really good photos, but the attention to details on it all is a wonder to see.The ampitheatrè was tremendous, especially when we were told the big building in ruin overlooking was Julius Cesar's house. Little things that make it all make sense.....
Surreal and overwhelming. The history here is incredible. It's truly overwhelming. We used the free app from Rick Steves as our audio guide, and that helped quite a bit.

Following in Roman footsteps.. Following from the Palentine Hill (you are already on site) is the Forum. This was the heartbeat of ancient Rome. It is very difficult to put into words the magnificence of the site. With a little imagination you can reconstruct the buildings in your minds eye and be on the bustling streets of ancient Rome. There are information placards by every monument (see pictures) but to do the site justice I would recommend a little research of the site. Look out for Caesars tomb. There are renovations on going at the site and it would appear the site will be extended in the future. As I say a little knowlage of the buildings would enhance the experience, but in my opinion the future of ancient Roman history is very safe in modern Roman hands. We visited out of peak season and it was still a little crowded.
sightseeing. Because of the rebuilding it was little disappointing but never the less a must see in Rome - not necessary to spend too long there

Awesome!. You can still get a feel of ancient Rome as you walk round the Forum, the ruins are vast and in places very intact. Despite the crowds you can still get away from it all here. Wear suncream and be prepared for the heat as there is very little shade. This place really is awesome!

Good to see. We were able to learn about the history of this ancient civilization. It was beyond cool. Be sure to bring good walking shoes, because the ground is rough and uneven, and not very handicap accessible.

For history lover.... Traveling to Rome it's like traveling back in history. Roman Forum is just one of hundreds of cultural and historical interesting sights you should visit while there. We really loved it.By origin it was a market place for centuries, where speeches held, tribunals and fights held and many more things..

Pretty cool. The forum is pretty cool, but I wish it could have been in better shape. They was doing some work to the grounds while we were there. I like that they had little maps & pictures around, it helped with the experience. Many great picture spots.
Wow. Complement to Palatine Hill and Colosseum. Expansive stretch of preserved excavations from Imperial Rome. A must see!

Use a guide or read up on this. There is SO much of this to take in, we were happy that we had a tour guide.. These are RUINS, so imagining what it was like is hard without guidance. Tons to see and enjoy though!

Very large, very impressive, allow a lot of time.. There is alot to see in the Roman Forum, because its right next to the Colosseum many people suggested that you could do the colosseum in the morning and the roman forum in the afternoon and you could. However I wouldn't recommend it unless your on a limited time scale, theres alot of walking and crowds involved and I don't think you'd appreciate it all. We did the colosseum one day the roman forum the next. We brought the audio guide, it had two options the 1 hour or 2/3 hour tour. We chose the 2/3 and regretted it, there were around 60 points to stop and listen and each one was about 5 minutes long. Unless your very into your history you don't need the extensive overview that it gave.I suggest using the map and maybe find a free pod cast with an interesting narrative and wondering through the suggested route. There was some very impressive ruins and when you reach the higher points you could get a really good view of what old Rome was really like. All in all we spent a good 4/5 hours there, it can be done in less.

A little bit more about the history of Italy!. So many things to see around here. Ruins, beautiful gardens, beautiful views and of course lots of walking in order to get to see all these! Don't forget to wear comfortable shoes!!

Fantastic - a must see.. Very interesting spot for an insight in to Roman life of yesteryear. Allow plenty of time to wander around as he site is vast but easy to get around. Runs beside Palatine Hill and right beside the Colosseum. Absolutely worth the visit and your time while in Rome!
The Roman Empire continue . The ground is filled with Roman's history that will last forever and the generation to enjoy. This is amazing ground just to walk around and feel the spirit, a must see.

One of the usual suspects.... A place that you must have seen but doesn't really give a nice close impression. It's a public place that can be viewed from the street. Good to see how used to be, but little guidance.
History of Rome. This involved a lot of walking and reading to make sense of what sometimes was a jigsaw. But it was worthwhile,very worthwhile and full of deep inhalations and gasps.

History at its' best. A real glimpse into "everyday" roman life hundreds and hundreds of years ago. Just so much history just scattered around. Absolutely breathtaking, and the sheer scale of the buildings is mind blowing. A real "must do" if visiting Rome.
Lovely gardens. Lovely gardens next to the coliseum. Large gardens which are beautiful but quite hilly and take quit a whil to get around.
lots of walking. no problem getting in, great views, great sights and experience, though much walking around. You must have a look at it standing from at the Capitol Hill as well.

Ruins of all kinds. Just experts can recognize the real meaning of different stones and structures. There is a lack of information on some buildings, leading the visitors on important path is not clearly marked. You need guided tour or a book with schemes of different stages of development, to recognize basilicas, temples, part of an old church. Some arcs are impressive, details of columns, too . It is nice that forum is without street vendors and stands but some other helpful things as benches are not there. You need a lot of time when you visit forum and Palatine Hill. Find comfortable shoes.

It is really incredible to see buildings, that have lasted for ~ 20 centuries.. Go to Palatine hill. The view from there is amazing. The walk from the hill to the forum is easy. I highly recommend it.

excellent visit, festooned in ancient artefacts. Combined with the Colosseum, this is an excellent and great value visit. We went in the morning so the queues were non existent. It is a vast area and covered in ancient buildings. It is also on two basic levels. I did get the feeling that the area was untouched over many centuries, Other cities may have bulldozed to make way for developments but not here, right in the heart of Rome. Congratulations to Rome. You can really visualise how it must have been in ancient Rome.

We linked it with the Colosseum. The walk around the Roman forum puts the magnitude of the buildings into perspective, when you see the size of the structures it really makes the Colosseum look like a small arena. not that it isn't impressive, but just let your imagination take you back to what this city used to look like. Take some water if it's warm there are not a lot of places to get any refreshments. We found a vending machine up on Palatine hill but not much else. If you don't like history then this is possibly not the place you will enjoy but then why else do you visit Rome ?

Outstanding, especially at night. After getting settled we started walking. The forum was the first old roman site we came across. It was early evening so the lights were on.I was not prepared for how stunning the ruins would look in person. If I had seen nothing else the trip to Rome would have been worthwhile.
Honestly waste of time. Can see part of it without paying to go in just by walking by. Not that much to see other then the ruins which can be seen all around the city. Not that interesting either.
Amazing to imagine the Senators and Nobles Walking Through the Remaining Ruins. It's hard to imagine that this much still remains of these columnedstructures standing in the shadows of the coliseum.
Absolutely fabulous. One of the most fascinating sights in Rome. A true step back in time. Wear comfortable shoes and use an umbrella if you visit in summer to protect yourself from the heat.

How can you not go?. Stunning remains of ancient Rome. Walk the streets that were alive 2000 years ago. It is fantastic. Like all Italian monuments and museums, you don't get a hand-out or map (unlike our humble sites in Canada), so come prepared with appropriate information. It is truly breathtaking.

Amazing architectural. Gorgeous. A definite must for anyone remotely interested in Roman history and or in archeology! A walk through the ruins of the Roman Forum. See centuries of old buried buildings and sculptures still breathtakingly beautiful today!
Roman History. Visit during the day time , it's impressive to see that and imagine roman life, beautiful and free to visit with the ticket from the colosseum. You need maximum 2 hours.

Must see if you're in Rome. There's so much to see in Roman Forum,that every time we're visiting, we're discovering something new. It makes you nearly feel the history behind it... And there's a great view on the Colosseum from one of the terraces. If you buy a ticket to the Colosseum, the Roman Forum entrance is included in the price (and the price is very reasonable). Make sure to take some water with you and to reserve at least couple of hours for your visit.
Very interesting. Great place to visit. You should plan at least 2-3 hours for your visit. You can buy a ticket here, which is also valid for the Colloseum. This will save you some time there.

Incredible historical site beautifully preserved. Not sure how this isn't the #1 thing to do in Rome (fine fine Vatican and Colosseum have more obvious wow factor but still...). The best view is probably from inside the Palatine on the far hill so you can really imagine what the Forum once looked like but going down to explore the many temples and read some of the history is worth it. You feel as though you should don a toga and hold a tablet. Your ticket to the Colosseum is valid to Palatine & Roman Forum so no reason not to visit after. It's 10000% worth it
History under your feet. Excellent history lesson with or without guide. It is recommended to read a little prior to the visit. Winter closing time is at 3.30pm

Back to the past. I was in Rome three times. Each time I had to visit Forum Romanum. This is the place when I can imagine how it was eg 2000 years ago. You just need to launch your imagination :) One issue I have noticed - some tourist do not respect that place. They take stones, kick elements - somthing should be done about that.

No Where Else In The World. There is only one Roman Forum. Not other site is like this. Do not go alone and watch out for gypsies with children. The Arches are grand and photo ops everywhere you turn. Stand where Julius Cesar stood and soak up the history.

If in a rush, skip entrance and admire from the outside . The Roman forum is a marvel and treasure that gives us a glimpse of the past to Roman ancient civilization. Unfortunately when walking around the inside, there's nothing much I learned up close that I could have done from the outside. The city surrounds the Roman forum and gives a great view of the entire forum. I would skip going inside and just view from the outside.

Thought Provoking. If you're looking to do something outside and take your time wandering, this is a fantastic collection of ruins to walk about. We did this early in the morning in conjunction with Palatine Hill before breaking for lunch then doing the Colosseum. If you really want to know what the area contains, make sure you grab some type of guide - it will really add some depth to your visit; otherwise, it's just a bunch of broken buildings. I found the area around the House of the Vestals most interesting, along with the supposed "Temple of Romulus" and it's artifact display. If you have the stamina, would recommend doing this and then walking up Palatine Hill for the views over the ruins and city.
Ancient Gem. Located next to the Colosseum, the Roman Forum is worth a visit. Would advise getting a joint ticket for both the roman forum and the colosseum

History . We did this as part of our tour with City Wonders which included the Colloseum and Palatine Hill.
Our tour guide was very informative and we learned a lot during the whole tour.
Amazing to see the before/after pictures.
I'd recommend this tour.
Take the time .. Leave yourself the time to truely appreciate this site. Its extensive but worth the effort. Read the signs to understand the history

Scum Gladioaors in Rome. By all means, stay away from "Gladiators" in Rome. They are thieves and scum.
They appear to be very polite and fun but they are real snakes. Be aware!!!

An era of style. When you get to Palatine Hill, you will have the pleasure of looking down at the Roman Forum. I kid you not, you will appreciate the Roman Forum so much more. Even with the half structures, with a little imagination you can see how vast the structures were, and you can kind of get an idea of how they lived, (I would have fit in nicely).

A must-see in Rome!. The forum is a must-see attraction in Rome! Located just by the Colosseum, the place is very historic and inspiring. I just wish I had a guide there, as there is not much information available around the place. Ihave been there in July, when it's super warm, so try to go early in the morning of you are there during summer. The adimission ticket for the forum is valid for the Colosseum too, ad the queues in the forum are usually way shorter, so buy your tickets there.

Steeped in history. Can't tell you about other times of the year but in December there were no queues. The ticket we had for The Colosseum gave us entry into The Forum.To appreciate this place you need to have some interest in history, particular the relevant Roman period and have some imagination. You'll be walking on the same flagstones and paving as were once trod by Julius Caesar, Brutus, Cassius, Hadrian, Nero, Augustus, Claudius, etc. You can visit the temple of the Vestal Virgins - couldn't help but think of Frankie Howerd at this point ..... oh well, please yourselves :)Get an audio guide, it'll take your experience to another level.Talking of levels - you can spend a lot of time up close and personal with the relics littering the ground before going up to the top of The Palatine and looking down from above.Can be a lot of walking and some uneven flooring.Really wish the 'guardians of Italy's antiquities had started conserving The Forum much earlier - so much is in a very poor state.For info, didn't see anywhere to get food or drink but there were toilets.Note that whatever the closing time is they'll actually stop you going in an hour before...

how did they do that?. How do you get tens of thousands of pounds of marble or granite on top of columns without a crane? Im not sure anyone knows, but it is remarkable to see. We incorporated the coliseum tour with Palatine Hill and it was impressive. Must do it with a tour guide or you will be lost and it will lose its appeal very quickly.

Well Worth a Visit. The Forum was the center of Roman culture and politics for 100's of years and then was completely covered with water. What you can see was under water for 100's of years and is actually well preserved. You will see the temple of Caesar and many other monuments and Public buildings, including the Treasury. Well worth a visit, but bring your imagination.
Impressive. During day or by night, it's impressive to see that and imagine roman life in this place, beautiful and free to visit
Must to go. Obligatory stop in Rome. Book a day and get lost in the area. If possible take a guided tour for a good understanding. Simply wonderful, a must!

Transported back in time. The unmistakable feeling of history is over whelming. A beautiful area altogether and I am pleased that we didn´t miss it.I kept wondering how they carted all those pilars and large stones around. I bet men were alot stronger in those days haha.Not a lot to do there other than look at old buildings and ruins, so children may be bored.

Fascinating to imagine how crowded and important this site was!. Recommend reading up on the site so you can understand what you're seeing or go on a tour. We went with Through Eternity's Underground Coloseum & Roman Forum/Palatine tour. Worth it.

Center of the civilized world at one time. The Forum was once the place where Rome's most important temples and political buildings were housed. This area is free (although the Colosseum & Palatine Hill require a ticket). There are audio tours and guided tours, but we just downloaded Rick Steves' audio tour and used that. Not a lot of signs, so some sort of help from a guide book or tour guide is helpful. Walk the Via Sacra (the main street of the Forum) and relive some of the history of Ancient Rome.

oldest place I've ever been!. This is real Rome. The city beyond the Coliseum. You never know what you will find inside the Forum. Seeing the old arches, columns, buildings, etc. is fascinating. Be prepared for hills, cobblestone walks and long distances.

The ruins of a once great empire. The forum is breathtaking. Walking around amidst what was the center of the city that ruled most of the world is humbling and experience unlike any other. We went with a guide and enjoyed it greatly.

Roman Forum Tour. Was part of tour including the colosseum and palatine hill,tour guide had pictures of how it possibly would have looked and this helped understand what the remains of buildings were.

Interesting . A lovely place steeped in history, however not very well signposted. Not alot of shade and it got quite warm, in summer I can imagine it being very hot. Not very good for people with walking difficulties and take water with you.
Nice Place to see ancient structures. This is a place where you could see the ancient pillars standing in a row which gives you an idea how the forum building was during that period.
Back in time!. Just go there and see for yourself. Walking in the footsteps of the ancient Romans, between the remains of temples and monuments...
A must see. Who hasn't heard of the Forum? It's much bigger than I thought it was going to be, plan on spending a half of a day here along with the Palatine Hill.
Roman Forum and Palestine Hill. You cannot miss this..most of the Forum you can view from the Street...but don't if you only have a few days in Rome this is must see.

Essential Viewing. We went early to avoid crowds and hopefully cooler weather. Access to forum but we followed an audio guide downloadable off the web which told us all about things rather than use the one available
Visit included Imperial ramp. I had never seen the Imperial ramp before. This is a wonderful feat of engineering and of course amazing restoration.
Dead ends. This is an amazing place other than the two dead ends (one at the beginning and the other towards the end) that were never indicated anywhere. Hence, it wasted quite some time and effort.

History is fun!. I would highly recommend taking a guided tour of the Forum. You can gain a lot of knowledge of the place by reading the placards, but a guide or the audio guide will provide more information. Plan to spend several hours there!

Magical !. Decide on going here first. & When you're going to buy your ticket, decide on getting the bundle to visit the Palatine and Colosseum as well. It's around 12€/person for all three if a remember well. Besides, you won't have to wait in line to buy tickets at the other landmarks either. No cash accepted so be sure to have a credit card / CB. It's such a big walk, and the roads and pathways aren't all paved so do not wear uncomfortable shoes.. once you get these points on your head, you're ready for a very long and beautiful walk through the forum. Take loads of pics!

The heart of ancient Rome, walk in the ancients' footsteps. The Forum allows you to really immerse yourself in the world of ancient Rome. You can walk along the paths that ancient Romans walked, view some of the sites they viewed, and really get a feel for how ancient Rome felt. I was glad that we toured the Forum with a tour guide who was able to provide color and history to the places we walked. This is a site not to be missed if you want to experience ancient Roman history.

Very old remains from the Roman Empire. We didn't enter the Forum itself, because somebody (a tourist) showed the entrance, but this was temporarily closed (Colosseum-side). Nevertheless we walked a long time along the fence where we could however admire a lot of the ruins.
Fantastic. You can easily spend hours here walking through and past the ruins. So many fantastic sights to stop and admire. Such a great place to visit along with the palatine hills and ruins.

Transported back in time!. What an experience walking on the same grounds that the Romans walked on 2000 years ago! Brought back images of Rome portrayed in the movies about that time period. Great to be walking on ground that was such an important part of the history of civilization.

A Trip to the Forum. Another must see historical sight in Rome, we were not disappointed. We had a tour guide with us, so we were able to learn about the history of this ancient civilization. It was beyond cool.Be sure to bring good walking shoes, because the ground is rough and uneven, and not very handicap accessible. The only complaint I had was that the bathrooms there were small and kind of run down.

must see. Included in the price of Colloseum and very close to it. Here you can see the ruins of several important buildings of that period. This was the cultural, economical and social center of ancient Rome. On the hill next to it you can admire the ruins of the "bourguesie" houses and also a spectacular view of modern Rome

One of my favourite Rome sights. I really enjoyed my visit which takes you back in time. To really enjoy the place download Rick Steves Guide to Rome (free download) and listen as you walk through the different roads and recognise the buildings.
Great!. These ruins are a must visit! You can actual walk through the ruins and enter most of the structures! Go with ample time and explore the Roman Forum well!

Great if you are a history buff. Read up in advance or hire a tour guide. The Roman Forum is filled with history but you must bring your imagination and wear comfortable stable shoes as there is a lot of walking and the path is not always easy to navigate.
A must if want to get true feeling of Roman times. Purely a must do to walk and view the ruins of a previous era make sure it is on your Rome experience agenda for day time

Breath-taking every time. Be sure to visit the Roman Forum after the Colosseum.... your ticket for the Colosseum usually includes entry into Palatine Hill and Roman Forum!Try to get a view of the Roman Forum from the top of Palatine Hill.... it is truly remarkable! So fascinating, I can not explain in words the beauty of the relics that are left, unbelieveable that it is still there!Our guide explained that the Romans had an architectural process, that instead of tearing down the old, they simply built on top, which is why the Roman Forum is "underneath" the main part of the Modern day City.Make sure to go inside and check out the temples that are open to the public, and to take a photo from the Arch of Titus through to the other arch!Truly breath-taking for the history boff!

Not much to see. Because the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill flow into eachother it is not really clear where one ends and the other begins. Palatine is lovely and nice to visit, but the Roman Forum is small and there is not much to see or do. Be sure to take the entrance at the side, where you go into Palatine first. The entrance to the Forum is really crowded!

ancient ruins. we visited after the colosseum since it was in the price (12€ for both) but not entirely due to heavy rain. Didn't miss a lot because most of it you can see without paying, from the road from vittorio emanuelle building to colosseum.

busy and a lot of walking. Great place for ancient history. A must see but be prepared to walk a lot! There are outside buildings as well as Palatine Hill, a small museum type building with partial statues and lots of outdoor ruins. Don't miss it! Lots of people though. We had no issues but beware of those selling junk along the sides.

Wow.. I really do not know what makes this so incredible to me. There was just something about the fallen columns and the old buildings that were just breath taking. Your entry to the coliseum should include entry here and I highly recommend it just to see views of things left in time. It really is amazing to see. I really don't even know why or how to put it into words. I really think you have to love history to be able to fully appreciate it. Be careful of scammers. It seemed as if an elderly woman was walking with a cane up and down the entrance. I am almost certain (I hate to assume) that this was NOT in fact an elderly woman. She was fully clothed and had a ball cap on under a scarf that was tightly wrapped around her head and face so you could not see. She would not look up OR even speak anytime someone gave her a few pence. Really be careful who you give your money to out there.

Photo-op behind Rome's City Hall. Be sure to capture photos of the Roman Forum from the balcony behind Rome's City Hall! The views are spectacular as you look beyond the Forum all the way to the Colosseum. Enjoy the view and the full scale of the Forum from above.

Very cool. While walking around Rome, we saw lots of ruins, but very few opportunities to go walk amongst them (most are in pits, below street level). This was different. At the Roman Forum, you can walk pretty freely in, and around, some pretty spectacular ruins. There is a lot of walking though, and there is very little cover and no opportunity to buy food/water inside. I'd imagine rainy days and very hot days there are tough.

Roman Forum. Included in the ticket with Colosseum, its entry is 100 meters away from the colosseum. In ancient glory, the Roman forum was the centre of political, religious, commercial and social centre of Roman empire. Studded with magnificent buildings, temples, columns, gardens this place would have been really something in the past. But now it is just rubble and ruins. A guided tour is recommended if you want to make sense of everything.

A piece of history. The Roman Forum together with the Palatine Hill are definitely a long walk, but so worth it, especially if you are a history buff. It is pretty impressive, especially if you take the time to read and understand what it is that you are seeing.

So Much To See. If you are a history buff, the Roman Forum is a great place to go to when in Rome. Going through the entire thing will take you a couple of hours but it is well worth it. There's a lot of walking involved and bringing a good camera is advisable. Unfortunately, when we went, there was a long period of sun showers and by the time it was done, it was time to close up.

Limited- but still wonderful -. There was a lot of excavation going on and significant portions of the forum were closed, roped off and strictly off limits to us, which was incredibly frustrating to have come so far only to be stymied like that. However, we had a tour of the upper area which was informative and fun, and it was still remarkable to be in the presence of this place. Hoping the next time we go, we will be afforded more access. Looking forward to it. (Lots and lots of walking - this city is truly comprised of hills and inconvenient steps. Bring a walking stick if you have limited mobility, and an inhaler if you have asthma. Also, to hell with fashion and wear what doesn't make your feet feel like they're trapped in a pair of iron maidens. That's good advice, right there.)
Nothing special. I have go but I did not find something interesting. Maybe because we went without tour guide.. we paid a ticket for roman forum and colloseum together (12euro)

Ancient Rome. While their are many ancient structures in Rome, particularly in the southern part, this is the best way to see what it might have looked like. The temples are amazing as is the remnants of the Senate. Go early if possible.

When in Rome, do as the Romans did. You are actually walking in the centerpiece of ancient Rome. Sadly, you can't actually enter the remaining buildings but it is still worth it to see the exterior of the buildings and the layout of the place. There is also a small museum with artifacts of the time.

A must see!. I didn't really know what to expect from the Roman Forum, but this was one of the most interesting things I saw during my time in Rome. There is so much history here, tracing the path of Rome from its beginning as a trade center, to the peak of imperial Rome and gradual decline. The Roma Pass worked like a charm here. My husband and I bought them at a TI near our hotel. The first two attractions where you use it, it actually serves as your ticket. We were able to walk right by the line to buy tickets and straight up to the entrance - no waiting! We had the Rick Steves Rome book and used that to tour the ruins and understand what we were looking at. If you get the Roma Pass, be sure to visit the Forum and Colosseum on the same day because they count as just one use against the Pass.

An Amazing Walk. We spent about 3 hours wandering around the Forum after visiting the Colosseum. The ruins were amazing and plentiful. It must have been quite something to see when is use but it is still easy to imagine scenes from the day by looking at what has been preserved. Lots of walking but well worth it. The ticket to the Colosseum/Forum/Palatine Hill is good for 48 hours after you first enter one of the attractions so you have plenty of time to enjoy all 3.

Step back in time . So much history ...the Roman forum is amazing, areas are not well sign posted and I would advise that you get a map of the grounds to work your way around. Make sure you wear good walking shoes as the path ways are uneven.

Take a step back in time. The Roman Forum ruins gently transport you back in time. There is just so much to explore and look at at here. As with the Palatine Hill, give yourself a few hours to soak some of it in. There is usually a sizeable queue at the entrance, but it moves along fairly swiftly.

Too expensive tickets . Nothing what can cost about 10€ for entry. In neighbourhood there are plenty places where it is possible to see this place from top, what I think it's better for sightseeing of this place.

A 'must see' if you like history. Astonishing remains of former 'main street' of the whole Roman Empire. The scale of those buildings is enormous. I can only recommend to have some guide book and read about the buildings as you pass them. The ticket is very cheap as it is valid for both Forum Romanum and Colosseum and is valid two days (12 eur).

Not for a rainy day or the unfit. It's a fair old walk all the way around this forum, we spent over three and a half hours walking around it, so, not one you want to visit if you are in a hurry or if you have walking difficulties or if its raining - but well worth a visit

Super Cool place to visit. Both my wife and I thought the Forum was one of the top attractions we saw in our 12 days in Italy. Historical and very impressive. We spent a couple hours here on a glorious November day in Rome.

Full of history. You are like connecting yourself to the past when you walk alongside the ruins. Everything inside the Roman forum is few thousand years old. If you want to see what typical Roman city is like, the Roman is the showpiece centre. Just spare yourself enough time to walk around.

Literally tripping over ancient history!. The Roman Forum is overwhelming with the amount of ruins to explore so be sure to leave enough time. The combo ticket with the Colosseum is good for two days but includes only one entrance. So stay aware of your timing if you visit after or before the Colosseum. The doscents are serious about enforcing the closing time and start whistling to get you off the premises about 20 mins before the gates close which was unnecessary pressure.

History at its BEST. This was by far, my favorite excusrion in Rome! History at its best. Be certain to wear very comfortable shoes as the terrain is uneven at best. We had a private tour guide who was very well informed. I suggest going first thing in the morning to avoid the crowds and then head directly to the colluseum after your tour.
Very impressive. You know at first I wasn't too excited about visiting but after arriving and reading Rick Steve's travel books I really enjoyed it. It was very warm and this was the end of Oct.

Very touristy, of course.... If you're really interested in history, you'll be delighted. However, it seemed to me that most of the visitors were like us- "We're in Rome, let's visit this attraction!" It was crowded, everybody tried to take the best pictures and therefore I missed the atmosphere completely. And toilets- well, that's another story, you'd better not drink too much befor your visit.
Amazing! . It is hard to get your head around the layout and the history of this place. I would recommend a guide. Absolutely amazing! Take water in with you and Wear trainers!
Relaxed and amazing!. Its just an amazing and peaceful place to wander around imaging what it must have been like. Don't rush it to get to the Colloseum....take your time, it's worth it

Roman Forum vs. Palatino. The Roman Forum is really amazing, even if you're not too passionate about the roman history. You have a very nice view on top of the hill and there's really a lot to explore.With the ticket you also get access to the Palatino (which is on the left if you enter the area after the entrance). This part was not very exciting in comparison and probably needs a better preparation/knowledge about what it was before. Just walking through the ruins is probably not enough. The museum also was not able to capture us and we left it after five minutes.

Take your time!. There is a lot to explore here. Read the signs everywhere. You can hire a audio guide but i kept to reading signs and reading a guide book which i bought in my home country. There is a lot of ruins and also some places that is in good condition. Really good history to read about. Go here preferable in the morning and spend at least 2-3 hours(I used 5) in the romano area and add another 2-3 hours for the upper section (palatine hill).If you are thirsty or hungry there is a candy/soda machine at the Palatine Hill which is the upper section of the romano area. Go against the corner in the direction of St peters church. There is a machine located there, and also a nice view from a "balcony"
Amazing!. Beautiful views from across Rome, great to see and really lovely area. Not too miss when visiting Rome!

A Must Visit. The Roman Forum is a must visit if you're in the city and also convenient, being just a short walk away from the Coliseum and Palatine Hill. All three sites are covered by a single ticket. It helps to have an audio guide or guidebook of some sort as there is not much information available at the site itself. Rick Steves has a free audio guide that you can download which isn't that comprehensive, but does provide information and context to the site.

Felt like a kid in a candy store but ruins aren't edible. Actually, as a kid I would've preferred this place over candy. WOW! We went here following the Colosseum and a quick lunch. There is so much beauty in ruins and there are a lot of ruins!! I walked around in awe, wondering what it must have been like when the buildings were new and this was the heart and soul of Ancient Rome. So many fantastic views and it set out imaginations wild. Had the Roma Pass so just walked on in.
Roman Forum. Wow history at its best. We did a small tour and it was well worth the money. There is so much to see and the tour guide was able to walk us through history. A must see.

Whole day in the grounds of the roman ruins.. A day worth spending taking it all in. Advise is to book the Collosium and Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. Spend one whole day at Collosium and the next day at the other 2. The ticket is valid for 2 days bought at the ticket office at the Collosium.

A step back in time. This is my second time in Rome and probably my 4th trip through the Forum. Even though Roman ruins are seemingly everywhere in Rome, the Forum offers a look at how Rome looked 2000 years ago. It is easy to walk around the Forum and to mostly avoid the crowds and the tours to get a little time to reflect on what you are seeing. Well worth the time to visit.

puzzling maze. Palatine Hill, Forum and Coliseum part of same entry fee. Quickly see the Coliseum, then spend the remainder of your time exploring. The tourists you see on a terrace beyond the Forum are on the lowest level of the Capitoline Museum. Stunning panoramic views and the museum is aces.

Are you ready to step into history?. Note: the entrance ticket to the Roman Forum also covers the Palatine Hill, and the Colosseum. I missed that detail when I purchased my ticket when entering the Colosseum, I could have saved money. The Roman Forum like so much of Rome is a standing gem of antiquity. If you're looking for action, it's not here. Rather, the Roman Forum is a shadow of what once was. If you admire ancient architecture be ready for a nice walk and give yourself plenty of time. The Roman Forum, like Palatine Hill needs time to admire and appreciate.

A must see!. The Forum is full of history. We have been here twice. The first time we used the Rick Steves Audio Tour. This last visit we booked a tour through Rome with Kids, to make sure our two kids would understand it better. There is so much to see and not enough time! I would suggest getting the book with the overlays to help you visualize what it was like during the Roman Empire.
must do. it is one of the most important places to visit in Rome. The real old Rome lies here. great place, great history!

Definitely a must go !. There are so much to see and learn there. Go there with a guide, you will enjoy it much more. It will be a pity if you leave Rome without visiting it. Gardens, Palaces, Churches and many more...

Great for Students of History.. From the time of "I Claudius", these excavated ruins are a history lesson about life in the Rome of the Emperors. The stories can be as dry as dust, or as exciting as you care to make them.

Biggest collection of Roman sites in one place. The forum is a collection of so many temples, arches, throughfares and other structures, which span hundreds of years of Roman history. It is a must see for any tourist to Rome. Best to enter directly from Palatine Hill that sits above it, and exit via the steps leading up to Capitol Hill

Biggest collection of Roman sites in one place. The forum is a collection of so many temples, arches, throughfares and other structures, which span hundreds of years of Roman history. It is a must see for any tourist to Rome. Best to enter directly from Palatine Hill that sits above it, and exit via the steps leading up to Capitol Hill
Very nice. Can be a nice walk in the park except that many historic buildings still stands. Worth a visit, some nice views as well.

Don't leave Rome without seeing the Forum. Get a Roma pass and avoid the long line ups. We used the Rick Steves Audio Tour and it worked out great. Enjoyed the home of the Vestal Virgins, Julius Ceasars site and couldn't get over the immense ness of the forum buildings. We recommend that you wear very comfortable shoes and bring a water bottle and a good book or guide on the Forum and Paletine hill.

See Palatine Hill first, give yourself plenty of time. It's a shame that they only allow you a single entry to see the whole forum and Palatine Hill but I guess that keeps the crowds more manageable. It's such a wide area to cover, and there's no real place to take a rest and 'charge your batteries' to have the energy needed to really explore the place.The forum itself could use some better signs to bring it a little more to life, and I found the palace ruins on the hill to be much better but had already tired myself out going through every inch of the forum. Next time I'll start by going up the hill first and leave the forum for the last part.Overall I liked this much more than the Colosseum, and it takes much more time to see as well (maybe 30 minutes for the Colosseum and 3 hours for the forum and hill).

Could be so much better.. OK, so it's awesome. A town full of ruins, including a beautiful chapel, a rather ordinary museum, a fab Roman shopping street, and a lot of cobbles that will kill your feet. Take some good walking shoes because this is a long walk over a very poorly organised site with little in the way of directions or guidance. Like most of Rome's historical areas it seems very uncared for and overgrown in places. Maybe that is the point, but with some money and inspiration this could be an amazing place to visit. As it is, it lacks atmosphere, and is bloody hard work trekking around as there is no "flow" or design to the visitor experience.When we finally arrived at the Forum itself we had to grin. There are a couple of bits of stone that they think might have been in the area of the Forum but they can't be sure. We sat on one of the stones and rubbed our blisters.

An interesting stroll though history. These are ruins so you must supply the imagination. But there is plenty to stir it (how did they use chariots on those large-stoned uneven paths?) On a nice day, a pleasant place to exlore, with the Colosseum looming nearby.
a must do. you got to walk around here .we have been brought up learning about these place and here you are walking on the same roads .so much to see.am i really here was heard

Amazing hike through Ancient Rome. One of the most amazing historical sites I ever visited. In the heart of Rome lies the sprawling, gorgeous ruins of temples, basilicas, even the spot where Caesar was cremated, with the Colosseum literally across the road. Breathtaking.

Walk through a piece of anxient history!. It is helpful to carry some sort of map to explain what each building is or was and what it looked like. If you start at the Palatine end, you can finish with a great meal in the old Jewish Ghetto.

Made the mistake of doing Colosseum first..... We bought tickets in advance online for both the Colosseum and the Roman Forum and we made the mistake of going to the Colosseum first... anything that followed that wasn't going to live up to that! It was a good experience but found there wasn't as much to see and take in compared with the Colosseum. My advise, if you get tickets for both, defo do this one first, the Colosseum is located opposite.

breath taking. Visited with my wife. Was a stop off on the open top bus tour. Absolutely breath taking that such culture existed so long ago. Only problem and this applies to all of Rome and not just the Forum is the amount of vagrants and street sellers. Gave both my wife and I a real sense of unease meaning we had to be very aware of pick pockets.
Unique place. there is a lot of walking involved, make sure you have good shoes, and a hat in summer.good place for some great picture.
My dream come true. Where it all began. Big area with a lot of remains of buildings and houses. Especially I love columns there. Entrance tickets are valid also for Coliseum, we had Roma Pass.

A stunning area but requires a but of imagination. The Forum is an incredible area, to think you are walking in the footsteps of Julius Ceasar and the like, but it does require a bit of imagination to interpret the impressive remaining ruins. We did the Forum on a hot summer day straight after the Coloseum and could really have done with longer and more information. I imagine the more time you invest the more you get out of a visit.

So so sooo much to see!. We visited the Forum after our Colosseum tour, spending the entire afternoon strolling through the ruins. We did not have a tour guide for this area and while we still enjoyed our time, we definitely could have used a guide to help bring the sites back to life! There is so much to see you could easily spend an entire day here!

Perfect for history lovers. We set a day side to wander round here and we are glad we did - it is not somewhere you go for a quick look around!We initially entered from the Colosseum end which turned out to be a mistake. We wandered up this path (uphill) to to top, before it was clear that we could not get in that way and had to go all the way back and further up the road towards Circo Massiomo in order to get in. When you get inside, it is better sign posted. Considering the buildings are open to the elements, they are really well preserved and you can get a relaly good picture of what they may have been like 200 years ago. This is a great place to just wander around and let your imagination run wild! I am not sure that I would return her, as I don't think I would see or learn anything new, but it was an enjoyable day and I would thoroughly reccommend it. We went on a fairly warm day and there were lots of drinking fountains around which was good.

I wish I could see it as it was originally. I loved the area and found out facts that I didn't study at school. Nevertheless, I wish we can do a 3D visit being able to be delighted with its wonderful splendor. I did feel more at the Forum when I was at the Capitolini Museum than at the actual place.
Walking. Lots of walking. But worth it for the history and views at the top of the hill. Give yourself a few hours to get about too, it goes on and on ( if you include the Hill )
Another amazing experience!. To walk among these ruins and see all the history was truly an experience that everyone needs to be a part of!
Walking in the footsteps of Ceasar. Just let your mind wander as you look at these famous ruins. You are walking in the area where so many Roman greats walked. Just amazing
A must see!!!!!!. Superb!!!!!! Thoroughly enjoyed the forum and the views are amazing. So much history, another amazing sight!

Visiting the sites. I chose a lovely sunny day for my walk to the Forum and other places of interest. During the walk was approached by a Roman Soldier who ask whether I would like my photo taken with him as I was snapping all the sites on my phone - no mention of money. He asked a passing visitor to take the photo which transpired to be about 7 when finished he asked for 20e as a payment. Thought this out of order as I wouldn't have the photos taken you should have been told at the beginning. Did pay but feel that visitors should be aware that the is a catch if you are asked if you want a photo taken and no mention of money occurs. The site however was spectacular and the expirience didn't deter what I saw.
Nice mixture for viewing. Some buildings one can enter, some columns just standing and some piles of rubble. Watch for closing time
Unique Attraction. Ticket to the Roman Forum is included in the Combined Colosseum ticket, otherwise prob quite unnecessary to buy a ticket to go inside. Definitely, a must visit site!

Roman Forum. Wonderful way to submerse yourself in Roman history, walking around and within the ruins is a must on your first visit to Rome. Tickets are inexpensive at 12 Euros and also provide entry to the colosseum the next day. Plenty of water fountains for summer visits - although the weather was beautiful in November too. Tours are available although I didn't personally take one, greatly enjoyed just wondering about for hours!

The Roman Forum. Don't miss the Roman Forum and the Colosseum while touring Rome. We would highly recommend using City Wonders tour. It is reasonable and have great tour guides with easily identifiable meeting spots.

Beautiful Complex. Entire complex consisting of Roman forum and imperial fourums of Trajan and Augustus are non the less than amazing. Structures standing for 2000 years are breathtaking. Imagine the splendour when they were covered in white marble.
Magnificent. Did it in conjunction with the Palatine Hills and the Colosseum... a great threesome and spend the day!

A place of history. The last stop of our tour, I feel we were perhaps slightly exhausted and lacking in enthusiasm by the time we arrived at the Forum. The sheer size of this area is amazing. When you look down from the Palatine Hill above, you don't really get any sense of perspective and the scale of the buildings and columns that are left. It would perhaps benefit for a few more informative plaques around the area to identify the buildings and to explain to people just what would have gone on there. The whole are, however, has a real sense of history about it and you should most definitely visit when in Rome!

A stroll through Rome. Entry was a nightmare when approached from the Colliseum end, with one wild goose chase and signs pointing you at an exit as an entrance (we got in that way).Once in everything was amazing, well sign posted and easy to follow. Definately an experience not to be missed.

Fascinating; must see in Rome. Be prepared to walk up to Colosseum if you start at the bottom; cabs will likely leave you off at the bottom of the Forum on Saturdays when crowds at are their peak for the week.

Amazing experience - to stand in the centre of the history and Ancient world. That was an amazing experience, something I have dreamed about for many years. I have always been very keen on Ancient history so visit at Forum Romanum was extremely interesting for me and moving as well. You can see there the very beginning of the Roman Empire. The most interesting attractions for me were Regia (the seat of first Roman kings), the temple of Vesta and the house of the Vestales, Lapis Niger, where Romulus, the founder of Rome, died, and the altar where the body of Ceasar were buried. Also, there is a very mysterious place named Umbilicus Urbis which was believed to be the centre of the world and the point where real and spiritual worlds were connecting. What is more the ground of the lowest part of Forum Romanum is at the same level as it was in Ancient times. I recommend going to Forum Romanum from Colosseum, down Via Sacra. That is the way that processions in the Ancient Rome used and you can really feel the history there. Colosseum and Forum Romanum is free on the first Sunday of every month. Other days the fee is 12 euro (in 2015).

You are limited only by your imagination!. Echoing sentiments about the Forum and Colosseum (it's the same ticket to enter all 3 anyway) - wonderful historical pieces but seriously lacking in terms of content provided on site - who built what, when and how. Not even a site map with information given at the ticket booth.PS - start your trip at Palatine hill - there is usually no line or a very short line at the ticket booth there, rather than lining up for a ticket at the colosseum - get the ticket at Palatine, then go to the Forum then the Colosseum

Whole day required.. Loads to see here! A real step back in time. The site is actually still be excavated in places. Amazing value dual ticket for colosseum and here. Would advise 2 do on separate day as so much to see. Amazing view from the top amongst orange trees. They actually let us out and back in after lunch as we had a 1 year old and needed more time to explore the site. One of the most interesting places we have ever visited. Does not feel like your in the middle of a busy city. 2000 years of history here does really make you think that we have not come that far in terms of build quality.

Mid week break . A step back in time, a large number of ancient roman ruins, statues, columns etc, it is the site where legend has it that the emperor Julius Caesar was cremated and to this day the citizens of Rome still leave flowers on the alleged site
Readlly nice. Fantastic history around the Forum, well worth a visit when in Rome, so interesting. Great part of Roman history
History at it's best.. Loved wandering around the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. So much history. Lots of ongoing work on the site.
Can't miss this. To see antiquity standing is an unbelievable treat. This is easily an entire day trip. Outstanding views and photos.

Wonderful Place to Chill !!!. We booked combi-tickets for this and the Colosseum in advance, which turned out to be a great investment. The Forum and Palatine Hill are huge, so you can really spend hours here. The views from the top platforms are wonderful, as are the many little corners where you can sit and take a break. For me, the highlight was the triumph arch which shows the Romans sacking the Jewish Temple in Jerusalem - an act which still has ramifications today! ... One piece of advice: take food and drink with you. Once they've got your money and have pushed you through the gate, there's virtually nothing for you to buy.

Roman Forum. Spend 3-4 hours here and enjoy this site. There is plenty to see and many great shots for photographers. A MUST SEE when visiting Rome. Remember that your tickets to enter the Forum also provide you with access to the Colosseum and the Palatine Hill overlooking the Forum

Large Jig Saw. The problem with ancient Rome, and I am someone who is quite into their Roman history, is that Palentine and such sites are like several complex jog saws, 90% missing and thrown together.
Don't get me wrong they are awe inspiring, but it is difficult to get perspective and continuity to what you are seeing.
Roman Review. You can 'feel' the history all around and it's great to get up close to the ruins. Preserving the area is so important

Take time to visit both the forum at night again. Like the other reviews your ticket gets you into the forum and the colosseo-do both and visit the forum again at night. You need to take the guided tour, find the entry gate a little difficult at first and remember some sites are closed for repair work. At night this place had a huge wall at 9 PM of laser lights and music. Such an old and historically ruins place it is worth the trip. Plan 4 hours, and lots of people around so no worries about tourist safety.Tried to picture what life was like hundreds of years ago. Vast work was done to build this forum. Walk across the street to bleachers and sit for a while and just watch. Amazing on both sides of the street. Watch out for street vendors selling tons of items.

Ruins from the ancient world. There is a single entry ticket for Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palantine hill. In fact, the entrance for the the forum and the Palantine hill is the same. It's easier to get tickets from here than the Colosseum which could be overcrowded at times. The ruins are well preserved with lot of historical importance including the senate buildings, basilica, Ceasar's temple etc. You get a good overview from the top of all the structures. Carry a guidebook and map to understand what structure is what and how it looked ages ago. Overall you will feel as if you have drifted in the ancient area and are living in different times.

Impressive!. We thought the Colosseum was impressive until we visited the Roman Forum! Walking around the ruins and thinking about who may have walked there before you was mind boggling. It was a gorgeous sunny day with the opportunity for lots of incredible picture taking. Wish we could have stayed longer but they were closing for the day and we were pushed out. Hope to have the opportunity to return and do more exploring. Don't miss this if you are in Rome. We purchased combination tickets that included the Colosseum, the Roman Forum and Palantine Hill. Definitely wear comfortable shoes when visiting these attractions as there are lots of uneven surfaces with lots of walking and lots to see.
Not much left. Unfortunately there isn't much of the forum left, however it's one of the many amazing sights on the palatine hill
Ancient Roman meeting place. Very old area of Rome where those in charge met to discuss things of importance to Rome and their Empire around Europe

Surprising .... At first glance in a guide book, the forum might not seem all that exciting. However, after visiting, to walk among where those walked 2000 years ago and see what had been built at that time was surprisingly memorable. Tip, buy the tickets for the Colosseo at Forum and skip the long lines for the former.

Included with Colosseum ticket. If you visit the Colosseum (and who doesn't when it Rome?), your ticket also covers the forum. It was a bit confusing to actually get into the forum area right now due to restoration work, but it was well worth the hassle! We spent about 4 hours here (and on Palatine Hill) and probably could have spent another hour or 2 if they hadn't started to close for the evening. Lots of history, and I wish we had either taken a tour or had a good guide book to tell us about everything. Bring a water bottle as there are several places to fill up as you explore the area. As a side note, wear really good walking shoes; you are walking on all sorts of surfaces including cobblestones, dirt, and rocks.

Most Beautiful place in Rome. So much history and beauty, you can just wander round forever in this place. Your ticket gets you into the Roman forum as well as the Colosseum, But although we came to see the Colosseum, we spent the majority of our time here. we choose not to have a tour so we could explore all the bits that interested us most and we were not disappointed.
Stunning. On a recent city break to Rome, this was my "go back to" attraction. The history is fascinating and just captures the imagination. Definitely worth viewing.
a great insight here.. Seeing this area gave a great insight into how Rome looked at its peak in times of antiquity, a walk through the streets is just a walk through history.
Stumbled upon this on a walk. You can see everything you need too from the top and no need to really go below. We saw this in about 15 minutes from all angles

fascinating visit. This is the heart of ancient Rome. I was unprepared for how vast, multi-layered, and simply amazing this site would be. You access the Forum with the same ticket as the Colosseum and the Palatine Hill. The Forum and Palatine kind of flow into one another. We spent about 90 minutes in the Colosseum and about 2 hours in the Forum and didn't make it to the Palatine Hill. It's a lot to take in. If I were doing it over again, I would have allowed more time and gotten a guide book of some sort to help to understand the complex layers of what I was seeing, and the highlights that were not to be missed. But even a cursory visit was amazing.

Incredible Slice of History. To stand where Marc Anthony and Julius Caesar stood is surreal. It doesn't seem possible, but it is. We took a very interesting walking tour which was very informational. It was amazing, and pleasantly overwhelming. Difficult to retain the amount of information, without taking notes. We were so absorbed, we didn't realize til later that we probably should have taken or recorded some brief notes. But the weather was magnificent and it was just so very thrilling. We do recommend a couple good walking tours. Split up the different sights and do one per day otherwise it will be too much information. We suggest the walking tour morning to early afternoon and then finish up with a true Italian meal with some vino to end your day.
History. When you walk at the Roman Forum, your breath knowledge an culture from more than 3000 years ago. Tip go with a tour.Make all the difference
Spectacular. Visiting Rome you can just breathe the History, every corner it`s full of interesting things and this corner is one of the best.

Absolute must see attraction. The Roman Forum is an ancient plaza located near the center of Rome. In ancient times it was the center of public life and today is a world class, historical tourist attraction. Most of the important ancient buildings were located on or near the Forum. It is located in a small valley between Capital and Palatine Hills and is also located a couple of blocks west of the Colosseum (a very short walk).I visited this amazing historical site with my wife and daughter on a Monday morning in mid-March and REALLY enjoyed it. Arriving in the morning worked out well since it was not very crowded. I had visited this place several years ago but did not have enough time to really appreciate it. We hired a tour guide who seemed to know everything about this area and pointed out every important ruin. Without his help it would have been a little confusing since most of the structures were only partially standing. I highly recommend that you tour this area with an experienced guide.We bought a combination ticket for about 12 Euros which allowed us to visit the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. It was easier purchasing the ticket in the morning at the Palatine Hill location since there was no line at all. Make sure you keep track of your ticket as you will need to show it a second time when you get to the Colosseum (I just jammed it into my pocket and thought I had lost it).Overall I really enjoyed touring this ancient, famous historical site and highly recommend it. This is an absolute must see attraction when you are visiting Rome. Rome is amazing as there are several absolute, must see attractions within a short walking distance of each other.

Part of the Colisseum. This was included in the price when you visit the Colisseum which made this good value and well worth a visit.It is worth visiting the Colisseum early as you can then walk past the queues of people trying to get into the Roman Forum as you already have your ticket.

Bring a sunhat - and a good guide. Even in mid-October temperatures were mid to high 20s and the Autumn sun still strong. The many tour groups mean you can compare stories from the many tour guides: very different in level of detail, stories told and ability to reply convincingly to questions. The old senate building tantalising - are the steps for 300 senators still there? The original bronze doors are long gone 'for use by' the Basilica of St John Lateran, moved there in 1660 at the order of Pope Alexander VII. Amongst many inspiring remains, the memorial to Julius Caesar, the temple of the vestal virgins, the huge walls and arched ceilings of the Basilica, and the remarkably preserved rotunda and cupola of theTemple of Romulus, still with its original bronze doors ...
Historically great. Gives you a gaze in the past! Amazing for a history lover like me. Unbelievable to be amongst buildings people erected more than 2000 years ago!

Very interesting and full of history. You could spend a full day in the Forum if you stop to read all the tidbits of information. We have been three different trips and still see something new each trip, as they continue to uncover more and more of the Forum.

Suggestion on how to check out this area.... There is so much to see in this area! The Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Forum.If you don't like crowds and if you have the time, here's what I recommend:1. Get here in the morning and find out what time the last lot of people are allowed into the Colosseum in the evening.2. Walk on ahead... check out the Palatine Hill and Roman Forum in the morning.Colosseum is the most popular structure and you see it as soon as you get off the metro, so everyone rushes in there and it's a crazy rush. You can see it from the hill...Carry water to the Forum and Hill... especially in summer! This will easily take 2 hours and you're gonna be hungry at the end of it.3. Post lunch, if you got the energy you can probably check out the Piazza Venezia which is right behind the Foro Romano. You can do something else and return here in the evening 45 mins before for the time when the last batch was to be let in into Colosseum.- You have avoided crowds...- You catch the sunset from the Colosseum... (It's awesome!)
Breath taking. Amazes me every time it go to Rome ! Disappointed where St. Peter in chains was closed..my husband really wanted to go there again.we love Rome
Another must see, very busy though. A vast area with extensive remaining ruins to really give you an insight as the sheer organisation of The Ancient Romans and how they lived

It's what Rome is all about. Huge and impressive old time Rome. It's what Roman life is all about. But take a book with you to explain what you are looking at....we had a couple and the one with pictures and diagrams was the best. The ticket price with the Collesium is included and it's a great way to really understand what the Romans did for us in situ. Take a drink with you on a hot day. You will need it. Admire the views and immerse yourself in days of olde

Wow.... Loved it. Part of Pallentine hill tour and it was fabulous. Many old pillars, buildings archaeological finds and easy to navigate round. Stunning is all I can say words and pictures do not do this place justice... See for yourself.
Wow!!. Hard to believe how this could have been!! A lot to see, many signs in English. Difficult to walk on the uneven ground in a few places. 1 of the MUST see's in Roma!!

The essence of early Roman history and culture. Buy the combined collesseum and forum ticket ahead of time to avoid the huge crowds.This is among the top 5 attractions in Rome and a spectacular site to see. Try to get some form of tour if possible, but there are explanatory plaques that help with the huge area of restoration.

A different world. Very rarely does one get a chance to go back in time and experience an ancient city with most of its integral components impact and a walk through the forum did just that. Enough has been said already but let me just add a few tips that could come in handy - 1) Carry a lot of drinking water and avoid planning for it in high noon or when its too sunny 2) The ticket into the Colosseum serves as the entry ticket for Forum so keep that in mind 3) Might be a good idea to download an audio guide and do some background reading about that era prior to the visit as it may enhance the experience.

Don't miss it. This is the part of real Rome. It is ancient and still reveals great finds. They had everything in those days and the scale of things they built was so huge and in proportion. It reminded me of the excavations of Pompei. Same brick work and similar beauty.
History At it's best. Jaw dropping history with a guide or not this IS Rome you will walk through a piece of History gave me the chills with it's beauty and age this is no1 place to viste

Mind blowing!. Having learnt so much about the Romans at school (many years ago) it was great to see how they lived.
Take the time to visit and have a really good look around - its amazing :-)

Good for photographers. Loved the architecture. Fortunately, the sun was shining. No eating places. Ignore beggars. Mostly females with their heads covered and facing he ground. Could be a youngster underneath all that.

Don't miss going to the forum but take a small group guided tour.. All I can say is go there and spend the money on a small group guided tour. It is a terrific experience brought to life by the impeccable knowledge of tour guides.

Amazing. If you like ancient artifacts Rome is as good as it gets because there always something newly discovered or just redone.The only to improve it would be to have a night tour and recreate the missing parts of the building with a light simulation

ITALY. It was everything I expected to be and more! I love history and to be in a place where all that happened it was unbelievable to me. To walk on the same floor as Caesar was just unbelievable. Well worth the trip

Use your Imagination. Some parts are well preserved, but you have to use your imagination to visualize most of the buildings that were here in the heart of ancient Rome. You will need a travel book to help you appreciate all the ruins.
Full day out!. Together with palatine hill & colosseum, a full tiring day but well worth it. Enter all 3 via the forum or palatine hill entrances and skip the queues at the coliseum

Construction will be ongoing for the next couple of years. It is difficult to see the Forum with the total renovations going on. It will be better in a few years when it is done but trying to walk through on your own is almost imposible now with all the renovation that is underway.

Outstanding. For years I dreamed that one day I'd be able to visit Ancient Rome. Take guide books to get the best out of it. Spend a whole day there, rootling about the ruins, imagining life as a senator, slave, woman, general, vestal virgin , shopkeeper etc. Fascinating.
I'm not overwhelmed by it.... ...but if you are interested in the fine details of parts of Roman history, by all means go inside. For my money, I prefer the panoramic view from Campidoglio Hill.
A walk in the heart of Rome. You can enjoy the sights of ancient Rome, which include different buildings. You may imagine how Romans gathered together in the forums.

Stepping back in time to ancient Rome. The Roman Forum is an amazing window into ancient Rome. So much of it has been excavated and you need to allow at least 3 hours to view everything properly. The view from the high ground are stunning.

A must go!. This is a must visit place when in Rome! Near the Colosseum, if you buy your ticket to the Colosseum you can visit the Roman Forum for free in the same day. You'll see ruins and stones, but it's an incredible place.
Amazing. Combine with Coliseum and Palatine hill. Wonderful must see in Rome. Walk where the romans did all those years ago.

Architecture and history everywhere. Its like revisiting the statement you read in childhood again and again "Rome was not built in a day". Amazing architectures and art-works. The Roman-Fort is just outside the Colloseum and the same Collossium ticket could be used for the Roman-Fort too.Give enough time to explore this and you would not be disappointed. There are many things that are ruined, but its still worth to explore it.

Time well spend on Sunday morning. We got dropped off by the Colosseum after our 5am Sunday morning Rome tour and opted to head to the Roman Forum instead. There was a line already forming at the Colosseum but nobody seemed to want to visit the Roman Forums that early. We didn't know that the first Sunday of the month was "admittance free" day and it was a great little surprise for us. We spend the first hour walking around the Forum before anybody else showed up. About two hours into it got a bit more crowded but by them we started heading up the Palatine Hill. I loved being able to take my time and soak in the ancient structures and the sense of time passed without all the tourists crowd. It also helped with getting lots of pictures in better light without people (yep, I'm a photographer)... LOL
Incredible history. Amazing experience, so much history in one place, an absolute must. So many things to look at, you could spend a whole day here.
It's all about The Romans. Must see while in Rome does require some walking, one entrance at Coliseum and another right across street from information center.

Incredible buildings. The buildings in the Forum are truly impressive and it's fantastic to see so much history in one place. You can walk through quickly, or spend much longer and take it all in so do budget enough time in your visit if you want to enjoy all it has to offer.
Great History. A great spot to revel in all the history that surrounds Rome. We went with a tour group and enjoyed the commentary.

History around each corner. I love walking around the old sites like this one but wear walking shoes and take cold water because you will be here for a while. The staff have made the place very interesting as they have placed lots of walking tracks and signs to help you understand the history and what this place and the building where used as. Great

Amazing to see the infancy of Democracy in the Romam era. The Guide was like a historian who gaveexcelent details of the concept and construction of the forum and back ground like how the swamps were drained to reclaim land for this structure.
Tumbling over History. This is a must see for 1st time travelers to Rome. The history lesson from a free Rick Steves podcast was an excellent way to dig down through the centuries.

Ruins bring you back in history.... It's hard to review ruins. They are, well, ruins! But the benefit of seeing these is imagining yourself back in the day of early Rome. One of my concerns is how to preserve these structures without violating their authenticity. Rome seems to be doing some renovations. Hopefully, I will return in a few years to see what happens.
Walk into the History. Find a good Tour guide and walk into the more than 2000 years of Roman History throughout the Forum I just did once again and you will always learn something new .

Stunning archaeological site. Situated between Piazza Venezia and the Colosseum, this is one of the most important archaeological sites in the world. Formerly a marshland, this area was engineered and the land drained to become the main centre for the Romans. We found that the best views were from the terrace of Campidogilo, you need at least an hour or more to discover this fantastic site

Worth it!. This is a MUST in Rome, which you can see how the Romans used to live in Rome, in this dead hot area.Saw everything and when I was taking a picture, It looks like a painting more than a photo!!!
Amazing. An absolute must if you visit Rome. Interesting, amazing.However use the toilets before you go in as they're not very clean.

The Roman forum. This is included in the price of the collouseum which is pretty cheap as it is.
It's amazing to walk on the same streets that people did from another century. Here is lots to see here and you could loose hours of your day!
A tour guide is recommended to understand what it is you are seeing.
Amazing history. Regardless of if you give a damn about Roman history or not these ruins are amazing to see and learn about.
