Hey, it's right next to the Colosseum, so why not.. It is definitely worth visiting the Roman Forum for the history. Sadly there are not a great deal of buildings left standing. This is what happens when you go out of town and leave your kids alone for a few millennia.

Beautiful Roman Ruins In The Heart Of Rome!. The Roman Fora are one of the most spectacular ruin sights I have seen in the Mediterranean!
The most remarkable is the Forum of Cesar!
It is amazing that the architecture has been preserved. Will definitely be returning here in the near future to explore in depth to a greater extent.
Worth visit. Very near by to Colosseum. Plenty of walking needed. Good thing about this place is there are loads places where you get a drinking water.

Audio guide rocks. A must visit in Rome. It will take you 2 to 3 hours to do a moderate walk around the site. If you can, download the Rick Steves audio for the walk. I got an old 2012 version but it was great. Bring water, walking shoes, and a hat if sunny. Yes, 24 Celsius in November! Bathroom: far and away, just plan to go with time. The site does not have good signage so you move better with a book or an audio tour. Enjoy.

Fascinating and steeped with history!. Roman Forum sits 5 metres below street level and is full of ruins steeped with history. With many different parts of the forum open there is so much to see and learn about. We visited with Dark Rome Tours.

An Essential Visit of The Eternal City. The Roman Forum was the political center of Ancient Rome. Fortunately, the ruins are here to paint a picture of the time. I definitely recommend going with a guide! The history of the place really comes alive when you are informed... Otherwise, you're definitely missing out. The entrance to the Colosseum includes entrance to Roman Forum, so you might as well visit! You will explore what is left of the Victory Arches, Palatine Hill, Julius Caesar's Funeral Pyre, The home & temple of the Vestal Virgins, as well as other temples, churches, and structures.

Walking through history!. An unforgettable walk through Roman ruins gives you an idea of the Roman empire and its glory! It seems that you go back to those centuries and you get lost in the Forum paths!. In the evening the place is not ideally lighted but is worth a visit, even so for the whole atmosphere. The historic area and ruins just opposite the Roman forum is more beautifully lighted and romantic...and in the far end of the street the lighted Colosseum! No words enough.....
Immerse yourself in history with a visit here!. Walking amongst the ruins you can let your imagination run wild and visualise what it must have been like to live in the days of Caesar and Augustus.

Ancient beautiful Forum. You may explore it when visiting the Colosseum. It is what left from the ancient beautiful forum.
Majestic Arch and high standing vault... built with bricks.
So beautiful.
Man Forum. A must see, when you are in Rome. Try to visit early in the morning, when it's nice and quiet. Great to see all.

Wow. The Roman Forum is just over the road from the Colosseum and entry is included in the ticket purchased there. Just an amazing place and wonderful views from the top. If you have difficulty walking be aware that it is steep in areas and, by the very nature of the site, it is not paved - just something to think of but we managed! It was busy on the day we visited and warnings were being given out to beware of pickpockets - again just a matter of watching your belongings. Have a good time and take plenty. Of photographs!

Not just a few bricks lying around. The Roman forum is vast. There are many structures to see. This is definitely a place to have a tour guide. The forum is multi levels and is cobblestone through out. Sturdy shoes are a must. To really see the magnitude of the forum be prepared to climb steep terrain and hundreds of stairs. It is worth it to climb to the top and view the entire site. It is unbelievable how much is still standing. Our tour guide had several books with ancient drawings showing how many of the actually structures looked. I enjoyed the forum more than the colosseum.
overcrowded. Very busy with hordes of people all around,out tour guide showed us what was the place looked like in the original state-so it was interesting but otherwise can be a a bit much of ruins

More for the imagination than the eye. In planning a return visit to Rome I had fond memories of the year 2000 when we wandered from the colosseum through the forum eventually ending up at the Vatican.Alas in 2015 it is all fenced off and a 12 Euro charge.It is really only a donation as little remains of actual buildings bar a few columns. Having just been to Pompeii and having seen Jerash, and ruins in Greece these are the least impressive.

Amazing. We followed our visit to The Coliseum with a tour of The Forum. We ended up being there at the end of the day about an hour before closing time. No crowds made it very easy to see everything and really take time.

Amazing!. This place is like walking in an open sky city museum! It is something unique and singular: all the roman umpire history in one place. You can stay a whole morning or afternoon seeing old ruins and being guide by all places as if they were alive two thousand years later.

Put this on your Bucket List. The first time I went to Rome I looked at this from the street. You must not do this. You have to spend a long time just wandering around this amazing site lapping up the atmosphere. It conjures so many emotions and feelings. It is just incredible.

This place gets bigger and bigger with the ongoing excavations. You really need a full day to do the Colosseum and the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. I was here about 8 years ago and was amazed how much more has been excavated. You need to bring a snack and water too...you don't want to leave - there is so much to see. And the climb up Palatine Hill for the views is worth it. Incredible history.
Not to be missed. If you have a taste for history and historical monuments this is a place which you can't miss in Roma.
With a tour guide. In a group of 20+, our guide was excellent with a wealth of knowledge. Without the guide I would not have appreciated the area. Very interesting.

Take a guide or at least audio-guide. It's very interesting and ancient place which started whole western civilization. It's a little bit dusty, but still majestic. But! It's boring to look at it without listening to stories. Several objects have descriptions, but there are only bare facts and they are also boring.There is really stupid system of selling audio-guides: they don't sell it to you if you come from the entrance near Colosseum, but they have another entrance not far from the Monument of the Republic where you can take one. And if you entered at the Colosseum entrance you cannot go out to take guide, you will have to pay again. It's very stupid. The audio-guide costs only 5 euro. The ticket costs 12. Also take some water or at least a bottle. There are several places where you can get water to drink inside the forums. Otherwise there are a lot of guys who sells 0.5l bottles for 1 euro. Also you will probably need a hat and sun protection for your skin.The photos will be great anyway It's a great place, but I was disappointed because I could not get an audio-guide.
Beautiful. This is a great ancient ruins site where all the different eras of Rome can be seen. It is beautiful.

Amazing place. Combined ticket for the Forum, the Palatine hill and the Colosseum. It needs a little imagination to see how fantastic this place must have looked in ancient Roman times, but there are still enough complete buildings to give an idea.

One of the worlds most fascinating sites. Really is one of the things everyone should see at least once in their life. Also the importance of the tour guides cannot be stressed enough as the signage in the actual location was not overly explanatory and it takes a top quality guide to fully appreciate what everything is
Surprising and breath taking. We walked in the long road leading to the collisum and marveled at the remains of the old life. Well worth it
Amazing History!. I was in awe of the history of the Roman Forum. The guided tour of the site was well worth it and gave us a real taste for life in that time.

Really Not Much To See. This looks like a yard with some building foundations with a few arches standing. This was at one time torn down or burided and then they tried to restore it, but I was not impressed with it. Yes, I know that it is a historical place , but thaqt is aqbout it.
Not to be missed. Enjoyed the history attached to this venue. Was an amazing experience and definitely should not be missed if visiting Rome

Stunning views!. Go here to get your ticket for here & colosseum!
Amazed at the sheer size of these columns and buildings! It's a spectacle worth seeing!!
Great to see. We had a nice time wondering around the roman forum. Quite a large space and well worth walking to top of palatine hill for views across roman forum.

Be ready to be amazed.. We went to the colosseum first and the forum is just across from here. Omg so much history to see. What a lovely way to spend a couple of hours wandering round this amazing site. A must when in Rome
A big day!. We did this with the Colosseum and Palatine Hill combo ticket. Great relaxing day. Worth packing a picnic. Lots of water stations though.

Breathtaking!. The Roman Forum is just breathtaking - we visited on the combined Colosseum and Palatine Hill ticket. This is definitely fantastic value for money at 12 euros - I mean really fantastic value as the three places offer an all day sightseeing experience! I just wish that we had been able to spend more time there (only in Rome for 3 days and cramming in what we could!) to immerse ourselves in the history. Also, a great place for families with younger children to visit as they have freedom to explore in safety.

A must. This site is a true must for all lovers of ancient History. Even though not as well preserved as some other Roman cities in i.e. Turkey, the sheer historical importance of this place is overwhelming. Take the time to slowly walk around and imagine being at the heart of what once was the center of power of the world...
The true heart of history. It was such a stunning feeling to stand in the middle of the Forum, once busy with our predecessors.. Must.see.

Just amazing. At night spectacular. I'm roman, but every time I walk around Roman Forum is always a unique experience: the colors, in particular, give to the forum always a new shape and let you live new emotions and feelings. At night is something amazing.
Worth the time. Just wandering around is amazing. You can imagine what it was all like when it was in use. glad we took the time. Turns out it was at the end of the street we stayed on.

Average. I went in on a walking tour and it was good. By this time in the day I might have seen enough of ruins and stones so the Forum might have been more interesting. It is right next door to the Colosseum so you can visit both very easily.
Must see. Historical, in the heart of Rome, dating back to centuries of human civilization and provides an insight into Roman lives.

We did a tour of the colosseum, palatine hill and the forum together.. We booked our tour with Walks of Italy. We did the colosseum, palatine hill and forum together. Our guide was an archaeologist who had worked on the site. Due to timing, we were the only 2 on the tour. Our guide had an iPad with lots of pictures and was so helpful! She was fantastic! I would really suggest a tour with a competent guide. It makes a big difference.

Awe inspiring to see in person!. We spent an afternoon at the Forum and Colosseum. Take the guided tour and get an interesting history lesson! The guides really do make it interesting. It is astounding to hear the history of Rome!
Amazing. This is an absolutely amazing place to visit, and no trip to the Colosseum is complete without going to the Forum, too. The things that have survived 2000 years!
Taken back in Time. We had an excellent guide who gave us the most amazing insight into Roman history and the ancient time, Deborah. It is really amazing and worth the visit

awesome!. I didn't know what to expect and I was more than pleasantly surprised! There is so much history and things to see here, it's amazing. Also, if you buy a ticket to the Forum first, this will also include your ticket to the Colosseum so you won't have to wait in line there. Only 12 Euro! Highly recommend! Bring good walking shoes - I was there for over 2 hours!

One of the unexpected but best sites in Rome!!. We stumbled across the Roman forum by chance and to say it was breath taking is an understatement!! I would not recommend using a walking guide (we used one in the Vatican) as they want to walk through the site at 100mph and get you in and out! Buy a guide instead! This site is truly awesome!! A must visit! Queues are about 10 minutes long to get in which is doable! We attended in late Oct / Nov which meant the weather was really warm but not so hot, you couldn't enjoy it!! Take a drink and something to eat and walk up Palatine Hill so you can survey the entire site!

So much history. The size of this site and how much still stands is very impressive. We visited on a free sunday so it was very busy. Still very nice to see up close. In hindsight, a guide could be practical to get a better understanding about the different layers/ time periods of the things you see. We just walked around by ourselves and read the information and that was wonderful also.

The Forum!! 700 years of Western civilization. Be sure you have plenty of time to see this entire site, wear comfortable shoes, and bring drinks if during a sunny day. Bathrooms are available, but they are spread out. The Baths, Forum, Temple of Virgins, etc are all in one large open area that is one fee

As good if not better than the collisum. After visiting the collisum just across the square is the forum. You need a day to see all at the buildings and antiquities, would suggest taking a picnic, very impressive and unspoilt. If you go right through the "park" areas of the palaces you arrive at another fantastic building of marble. Leave another hour or so for this, View from roof terrace is fantastic!

Csodálatos élmény - Amazing experience. Aki Rómában jár, mindenképpen javasolt, hogy ide is ellátogasson, mert lenyűgöző így visszatekinteni az ókorból fennmaradt romokra. Ajánlott kényelmes cipőt húzni és készülni kell rá, hogy több órás lesz a program.Mi a jegyet úgy vásároltuk, hogy a Colosseumba is érvényes legyen, így ott egy elég hosszú sort ki tudtunk ezáltal kerülni.Amit viszont egy kicsit hiányoltam, hogy az adott rom előtt nem voltak látványok, képek, hogy ez régen hogy nézhetett ki. Ellenben segítségül szolgálnak a helyen elhelyezett nagy térképek, amik jelölik, hogy pontosan mi micsoda. A pénztárban lehet bérelni mobiltelefont, amin lejátszható az adott látványosságról sok sok információ - térkép, képek, stb. (magyar nyelven sajnos nem elérhető)A helyszínen vannak ivókutak, valamint toalett is.Érdemes korán érkezni, mert nagy tömegben nem túl kellemes barangolni.Tömegközlekedéssel könnyen megközelíthető. (Piazza Venezia vagy Colosseum)Who ever goes to Rome, it is a must to visit this place, because it is so amazing to see the ruins remained from antiquity. It is recommended to wear comfortable shoes, and one has to be prepared for a several hours long program.We bought tickets which were also valid to the Colosseum, so we could skip a long queuing there. I missed a little bit that there were no scenes, 3D images, that could have showed how the ruins looked like originally. On the other hand there are big maps that are helping to find out what is what.At the cash-desk you can borrow a mobile phone, on which you can listen to a plenty of information about the each sight. (maps, images) (unfortunately it is not available in Hungarian)You can also find some drinking fountains and toilets at the venue.It is worth arriving early because it is not very pleasant to walk in a large crowd.It is easily accessible by public transport. (Piazza Venezia and the Colosseum)

Amazing walk through history. Would recommend arriving early. We got there not long after opening and had the place nearly to ourselves. A couple of hours later it was packed with visitors. This was one of our favorite sights. Much more interesting than the colosseum.

Take a guided tour. This you can actually view from the outside. I'd imagine that a guided tour is the way to really appreciate this place as the history of the Forum is more interesting than what's left of it.
Loved it. Thisnsite viewing isnincluded in the ticket purchased for the Roman Forum, but it is a totally different experience, I traveled with 2 14 year old teen girls and they enjoyed it very mich.
Architectural wonder. You can see it from the outside if the gates, but it is worth seeing it up close. You really get the feeling of how big it was back in the day.

Excellent place to see and learn about ancient Rome. I thought this was the best attraction in Rome. I spent about 2 hours there and could have stayed more since I didn't get to every corner. Lots of interesting ruins to learn about and things to see. Climb the hills and go into the buildings (especially up "La Rampa") for great views. They have a system where each point of interest has a number and you can access that number and hear all about that particular thing. The whole site was very interesting, if tiring (lots to walk around and see).

Holiday in Rome. Amazing archtectual building to understand the sheer enormity of this structure it's well worth a visit also we bought the Discover Rome book from the lonely Planet which has a good history of all the Roman and places to visit when in Rome

A must see.. You have to use your imagination, but it is an amazing place to see.There are so many different buildings, and so much still there.We just wandered and read the signs, but you could easily spend several hours there.Not so good in the rain, but the scent of wild thyme is memorable.Take water, sunshade/ umbrella.

Lots to see. A lot to see - can be difficult to appreciate unless you have a good knowledge of Roman history - or a good guide book.The Palatine Hill is worth walking up - The museum is a bit of a let down however.

EDUCATIONAL. Our visit to the Forum was very educational; our guide was very knowledgeable and told us all about Caesar. She also showed photos showing cattle and sheep grazing at the same level as the door of the Tempio di Antonino e Faustina.
Very memorable. Wonderful views, amazing pictures, take your time and walk through and look at everything. Enjoyed this location as part of a self-directed walking tour of Rome. Loved it!

360 degree view of Ancient Rome. What a wonderful place, not too crowded and so much to see. Didn't have a guide just wandered around taking it all in. Very good value. Could have spent ages, if we return will bring refreshments as there are free water fountains but no where to buy food.

Ruins and stones. I am not into stones, rocks and ruins....but for people who admire ancient history this is the place to be! Same ticket for The Colosseum and the Roman Forum if visited on the same day, so make sure you ask someone to confirm that. For travellers with babies and infants - prams might not be the best option here: try a sling or baby carrier instead.

A funny thing happened on the way to the Forum….. Only viewed this briefly, but need to go back to do a proper tour and see how and why this magnificent area was so important. It was stunning and you can imagine what life was like.
Good. An enjoyable visit. I liked the fact that the joint ticket for the Forum and the Colosseum are valid for 2 consecutive days. You are free to explore and take in the sights at your leisure.

This place is huge - the excavations are tremendous and big change from 10 years ago when I was 1st here.. This place is incredible... You really need a brochure or a book to really appreciate the Roman Forum. Palatine Hill and its excavations have improved over the last 10 years also. A 1/2 day spent here is not enough... bring water and snacks if you plan on spending anytime there.
Breathtaking, day or night. Second time visit, this time with our 12 yr old son who was blown away. Very busy as always, worth taking an informative tour

Lots to see!. After our visit to the Colosseum, with its crowds, it was great to escape up to the Palatine Hill portion of the Forum complex. The Forum itself had a fair number of visitors, mainly school groups on midterm break apparently. As we're not fond of crowds we climbed up the hill and were able to enjoy the experience and the views.
A must for first Timers. The seat of government during the roman empire.A must see. You can walk the area on your own but having a guide gives you so much more information

Lots to see.. We bought fast track tickets from the net and hired audio tours. You do need too leave photo ID to make sure you return them. The place is very big and needs a lot of time to see it properly. It is well worth a visit but do take food and drink they only have vending machines, if you can find them. Wear sensible footwear.

A. You could spend a whole day wandering the ancient Roman Forum, there is so much to see! The temples are stunning and you really get a feel for the grandeur of ancient Rome! There is no shade, so on a hot day be prepared with lots of water!
Wonderful to see. We had a great time checking this out. It is great to see as you make your way to the Collesium.If you start at the Piazza Veneza and walk along you will see all you need to see.

Combine this trip with the Colosseum Tour. Here is my feedback on this place: - see it with a tour guide so you can to learn more about it- We combined this with a tour of the Colosseum and enjoyed the detailed information provided by our tour guide from Bruno Tours- there are drinking fountains so carry a water bottle with you that you can refill along the way since there is a lot of walking to do Hope this helps!

Remnants of a Society. We toured the Forum and the surrounding sites on a warm, rainy morning in October, 2015. We had a great time with our our guide Paola. See my separate review.It is amazing in some ways what has survived and in other ways, what has not survived. The cremation site of Julius Caeser, the site of the famous Roman Senate and government. You have to use your imagination but it is possible to imagine all of the old buildings.Coming from California, the concept of OLD is somewhere in the beginning of the 1700's because there really, except some heiroglyphs, isn't anything that is older than that other than Sequoia trees. Seeing what the level of civilization that existed in Rome in 0 BC/AD was is pretty amazing. I think this site is best experienced with a guide who can explain the site, the history and what has been done to bring it to its current state.Definitely worth seeing.

History... Walking in the footprints. I don't think we fully could comprehend the history here but we still quite enjoyed walking these hallowed walkways. We visited after the Colosseum. Buy one of those books that show what the ruins looked like original and walk around with it.
Worth visiting the old rome. The ticket price of 12 euros to see the colloseum includes entry to here, So why not take advantage and see them both.

Must go. When in Rome on a cultural/romantic break you should go to all of these locations. We went here on a day which started out sunny then ended up raining. Was still very nice a great to learn about the history behind the Roman Forum!

Outstanding- top site in Rome for me. Truly spectacular and great if interested in history and ruins. This was visited after Pompeii and Herculaneum, and I learnt a lot at these sites, but still downloaded an audio guide which was useful. It was not too busy which was great. I loved it.
Great!. Lots to see. Very steep so be prepared to walk....great views. Well preserved. Can be viewed from outside but these areas are being fenced off.
Lots of interesting ruins. walked through the forum after our Colosseum and Palantine Hill tour. very interesting and included in the price of the Colosseum ticket.

Amazingky evocative of Ancient Rome. This was my favourite place in Rome. A bit of a shambles of old bits of ruins, but plenty to see, and it was very atmospheric. It gives you the idea of what it must have been like to walk around the ancient forum in Roman times. The Palatine Hill is also on the same site. Also well worth the visit, with great views over Rome.

Amazing archeological site, well worth the visit!. In order to avoid the lines we purchased a pre-booked ticket to see the Colosseum, which included access to the Forum and Palantine hill, and we had a couple of hours to kill. It was well worth the visit! Although many of the original structures are only ruins, the grounds are well maintained, the sites are well marked and there are multi-language signs that provide an overview of the history and importance of each ruin. It was a wonderful way to take advantage of the beautiful October weather.
Historical site. Near the Colloseum, covered by the ticket in the Palatine hill. Take camera you, greate for shots. Take aware in the summer can be quite hot.

Wonderful!. These ruins are a wonderful expression of mankind's creativity. Walking through the remains was delightful. This excursion is an absolute must-see when you visit Rome and then go off to see the Colleseum for more splendour.

Carla Zaia Wonderful Private Guide for Roman Forum, Colosseum, and Palentine Hill. My wife and I (both retired educators) recently returned from 3 weeks in Portugal, Italy, and London. A highlight of the trip was our visit to the Colosseum, Roman Forum, and Palentine Hill in Rome. Our private guide was Carla Zaia. Her knowledge of that area is phenomenal, surpassed only by her passion for imparting that knowledge to her clients. She was totally focused on sharing this part of her city with us for 3 hours. We felt like a beloved member of our family was guiding us and teaching us about Ancient Rome. Visitors should know it is a WALKING tour, and that one is walking most of the 3 hours. There are some inclines and some steps, but it is very doable. Carla did an outstanding job of answering all our questions and helping us to understand the culture, the achievements, as well as the shortcomings of Ancient Rome. I would recommend this area as well as Carla for the tour. You can buy a combo ticket for all three attractions--Colosseum, Forum, Palentine Hill--and can do the tour on your own (without a guide). However we felt our guide enhanced our understanding of the area and was most deserving of both the fee as well as the gratuity we added.

Probably the most amazing place on Earth. We have visited the Palatine Hill, Roman Forum and Coliseum a number of times and it has never once failed to take our breath away. I love ancient history so I love to just investigate the area and the many attractions. We prefer to visit the Palatine Hill first (do the gentle climb first and then go down to the Forum) and if you pay for tickets there then you can get one that includes the Coliseum. This will last for 2 days and it will save queuing up at the Coliseum to enter the next day. It is about 12 euros each for all 3 areas - a bargain. In the Summer it can be very hot, but we have discovered that in October the temperatures are great for site seeing. The site also had plenty of toilets and areas to buy refreshments. In August it can be hard work if you don't like hot weather - walking around in 40 degree heat is hard work but well worth it.At night the area is all lit up and has that magical quality that only places steeped in history like this have. There is a new attraction which projects images on to the walls of one of the forum areas. It is 15 euros to sit and watch the audio, but we enjoyed it with just the visuals for free.Not far from the forum is the monument of Victor Emmanual and there is a lift which takes you to the top for the most amazing views of Rome on both sides.There are also lots of good places to eat nearby and the chance to sit and look out on to this amazing area, glass in hand and marvel at the wonder that was Rome at the height of its power. Enjoy

Scale was breathtaking!. In these days of space limitation and 'overcrowded building programmes' it was good to see that Rome has concentrated on making its heritage 'open to view' . A ticket combining forum and coliseum was well worth the price. A good tip is to buy your ticket at the entrance to the palatine forum... they allow the day of purchase and one extra day to get round the two attractions...one day is more than adequate... and if you purchase in the afternoon before 3.30 pm there aren't the queues to worry about.

Not to be missed. Wonderful- be aware that the palatine is accessed from the forum- don't miss out. To much to say just go! Also book ticket on line to avoid horrendous queues- get a combination of the forum, palatine and coliseum.

Great on a dry day, amazing place to see.. It was raining when we visited so not as good as it would be if it was dry. So much to see, you get a real feel for Ancient Rome, how life would've been. The girls and I loved stepping on the large cobble stones and imagining all the people who've trod them over the years.... A must see if you like to immerse in local history.
A wonderful open air museum. Well organized tour, you can walk at your own rhythm, tickets are good for the Colloseum, the Palatine hill and roman Forum. A must to do this 3 in Rome

Great attraction. We were there the end of october. There were many visitors but entry was fast and touring the place was very convenient and we did not feel the crowd. We spent there over 3 hours and we enjoyed the attractions. Afterwards we went out through the northen exit and we had a view from the outside in which eas also noce.
WALK FROM COLOSSIUM. This is truly ancient Rome. Take your time,use a guide, and marvel at history. Minimum 2 hours. Guides can be found at entry or the Colossium.

Amazing . Included in the entry price for the Colosseum this site is just as impressive. Could not get over the slabs of marble and broken columns being used as seats! ! Everywhere in Rome has a smoking area. Lot of climbing up steps and steep ramps (perhaps should lay off the smoking area ) here but take your time it's worth it.

Getting lost in Roman history!!. We started early around 9.15AM with online tickets, no queue & it was totally free to explore!! Huge pillars, arches, portions of building, statues, fountains & apartments- all in ruined state now as they have stood over 2000 years!! The place is quite vast, well organized with sign boards carrying information- hence its easy to navigate. Would require atleast 2-3 hours to explore the whole complex & take some fantastic pictures, but we had booked Colloseum slot after 2hrs, so had to rush through towards the end. It might get warm & crowded, so its better to start early, then move to Palantine Hill & finally Colloseum.There are multiple exits from this place - hence its better to see the layout map in the beginning to navigate, so that you will cover all key sites & exit at the right place. Enjoy this history at peace- when its least crowded!!
Majestic!. This place takes you back in time and the rich history surrounding you will definitely make you want to go back too! A must visit to everyone

Huge. The Forum covers a massive area. We spent four hours exploring! Be sure to take a good guide book as signage is relatively limited for such a rich area and it's hard to know what you're looking at. Closure is an hour before sundown, so it changes every day! Be aware that if you have the multi ticket for the Forum/Palatine and Colosseum, the Forum and Palatine count as one attraction so you have to do both at once or buy an extra ticket.

Amazing architecture and remains of a forgotten civilization. Ruins of times that went by over massive stretches. The architecture of the massive columns are a sight to withhold. Temple of pagan gods all over the place.Must visit.

Fascinating Attraction. A guide is a must if you want to get the most out of your visit. Combine with a visit to the Colosseum to get a good appreciation of what life was like in Roman times. Wear a strong pair of shoes as there is a lot of walking is involved over some rough surfaces. Do some research on the attraction beforehand as there is so much information to take in.

Set Aside a Half Day to See This Site Properly!. This is a "must see" if you have enough time in Rome. Explanations on the various artifacts are very good so it is not necessary to take the audio guide however a good map of the area would be helpful to ensure that you do not miss anything. If you do take the audio, make sure you ask (several times) where to pick it up as it is not close to the entry! We used our "free" entry on the RomaPass for this combined attraction, Forum, Palatine Hill and the Colosseum. It costs 12 Euros if you buy it on site however the line-ups can be long even in October. It is worth every penny spent. Set aside time to visit the Museum on the Palatine Hill (it is free) and make sure to take plenty of photos on the elevations. There are some terrific views out over the city. This is a difficult site to navigate for those with limited mobility.

Not so "Funny" if you had to queue. Buy a €12 ticket at the Palatine Hill and visit the big three. The queue will be smaller and you will be less exhausted. See the official website to make substantial savings (some categories of EU citizens). Free on first Sunday of each month.

History alive. We spent a pleasant afternoon exploring the Roman Forum and palatine hills. What worked:It is very nice to explore history in an open air setting, as opposed to a stuffy museum. Some of the structurs are very striking - the place is full of photo ops. What didn't :The line in front of the sole washroom was frighteningly long. Tips:1. The audio guide isn't really worth it - long stories disconnected from what you actually see in front of you. Either join a tour, or read the signs in front of the buildings and statues. Wear comfortable shoes - there is a lot of walking involved.
Amazing. As per my review of Palantine Hill this area is huge, I did not expect it to be so big. The scale of it just blew me away. Loved this whole area even. You need a good few hours.
Very interesting historical site. A step back in time, our guide was very knowledgeable and could answer any questions we had. Amazing architecture and views.

Walking in the footsteps of history. The forum is entrancing. It's awesome to contemplate the momentous historic evens that occurred there. Rome at its peak; now in rubble. What does it say for our future?? Very moving. Don't go to Rome without seeing the forum.

Don't miss it!. This is the perfect companion visit to the Colosseum (and your Roma Pass will get you into both of them for free). There is so much to see at the Forum, so much to imagine as you gaze upon the columns and temple remnants nestled among the beautiful umbrella pines. It is a treasure. Lots of uneven walking surfaces, lots of unmarked dead ends, but wander at will, and see all the site holds. Never to be forgotten!
Huge. The size of this area is amazing. When you look at the period where it was initially built and the size of the structures and scale of the landscape, it is pretty amazing.
Pleasant Experience. I purchased a guided tour through City Wonders. The guide was accommodating, pleasant and very knowledgeable of Ancient Rome and Roman Forum.

Smell the Roman history. Don't think that you will look and go out like an ordinary museum. At least one day, you need to take much time for understanding and taking photos. I advice you to take comfortable shoes. Take Roman forum trip before Colosseo, so you can use the same ticket for colosseo after Roman forum trip. You will not wait long queues.

Nice stroll after the Colosseum. Our Colosseum ticket also included the Forum and Palatine Hill. Audio guides were sold out and the queue to get in was badly managed with the people in charge changing the lines constantly to accommodate groups. Once inside, like everything in Rome, it's crowded. Ostia would be a much better option.

Get a Roma Pass and see this and the Colosseum, 2 for 1. This is such an impressive place. To walk in the path of Caesar and all of the other famous Romans is amazing. You can wander around as slowly as you want. I recommend finding a place to sit and watch the people go by and imagine you are back in ancient Rome. Just looking up at Palatine Hill and all of the other ruins is amazing. This is a must see place for your visit to Rome.

Very hot in the middle of the day!. This was a fun place to spend the afternoon but beware it can get very hot and there is no water to be bought once inside! Bring your own or at least a refillable bottle as there is a water source inside. Also, an umbrella for shade was helpful!

A must see sight in Rome. Part of a three sight ticket with Palatine Hill and the Colosseum. This is what most people imagine when they think of ruins in Rome. It is busy with tours, but not unbearable, but there are no refreshments and toilets are an unpleasant adventure.

When in Rome. We walked through Palatine Hill and the Forum. The Forum was truly magnificent. To think of the events that took place here was mind-boggling. It made me think back to those times and what had transpired there. A place that must be visited. We used Rick Steves' book for information, and that was enough to allow us to gain a deeper understanding of what took place here many years ago.
Beautiful place. The experience of being in a place like this is just overwhelming. Just to see the beauty of the old buildings and imagine how they were in the old days is amazing.

Really neat. All the history here is so cool. Make sure you take your time to go through it. I walked through it on the Rick Steves' audio tour which was really interesting and free (+cost of attraction). By getting into the Roman forum you get into Palatine Hill as well, two for one:)

Lack of signs leads to long walks. The forum is actually great compared to a lot of places in Rome in that there is information available for free about what you are looking at. However, a lack of any sort of clear signage about routes means you end up going round in circles and going up and down dead ends - which, on the road surface, makes you very tired very quickly.Queued for a while to get in, could really use either automated ticket machines or more kiosks. Also, one of the best preserved houses in the row beneath the paletine hill has been turned into a room containing vending machines....seriously!(?)

Fascinating. We visited the forum and Palatine Hill today after the Coliseum using the combined ticket.. The site gets very busy so getting around can be a little tricky.Site descriptions are in English and Italian and we didn't bother with an audio headset or tour guide., we had a fascinating walk around this site . This is a must see while visiting rome

Must visit. Great to visit! Important might be that if you buy a ticket for the colosseum, your ticket will be valid for here too. But you do not necessarily have to go to both places on the same day! Your ticket is valid for 2 days!
Awesome. So hard to believe the age on this, takes you back in time...amazing, the annoying people selling selfie sticks were a pain but apart from that, well worth a visit

Picturing the Roman Civic Heart. The Roman forum gave us a better picture of how the civic and political heart of Rome operated on a daily basis. We really enjoyed the site and especially my kids aged 8 & 10 which was surprising as we didn't have a guide and we only had a guide book and it can be hard to picture how the ruins looked. The area of the Vestal Virgins was in a lovely space and was easy to see how the buildings would have looked. The view of the forum is excellent from Palatine Hill and I would probably do the Forum first and then go to Palatine hill so you can get some context as to what you are seeing. We did the Forum and Palatine Hill a few days after the newly opened connecting tunnel but would have loved to see it linking both areas together. Quick tip- the two day pass for the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Forum is to be used as one day for Palatine and the Forum together, you can't seem them on separate days like we did but the lovely staff let us in anyway.

Nice to see from above. Didn't get to spend much time here since we lost our tour guide at the Colosseum but if you purchase a tour at the Colosseum it includes entrance into the Forum. We did a quick walk through. Wished we had more time

Skip the line is a scam. The queue is really not that bad like at the Vatican Museum. We bought the tickets for both the Coliseum and the forum which can be used in two days. I suggest you start with the Coliseum as it doesn't take that long and spend as much at the forum.

Great place to spend a day.. So much to see and take in, you could spend all day here and not see it all. Wear good walking shoes this could take it out of you but it is well worth it. Take the audio guide at least unless you have a great knowledge of Roman history. The views of Rome are breath taking.
step back in time. A look back in time at Roman Forum that contained an array of buildings, a library, temple , arch, and market to name just a few . Great !

Fabulous sites. We visited the Roman Forum straight after the colosseum it was included in our site seeing ticket.We had a fab guide called James, he was very knowledgeable and interesting giving you a great in depth knowledge from the start of Rome. Described all sites very well.We stayed around this site for about an hour.See Palantine Hill, the Beverley Hills of its day.In the centre of the Forum stands a ruined structure where flowers are placed year round. This structure is the foundations of the Temple to Julius Caesar, the flowers indicate the spot of Caesar's cremation.

Walking through time. We visited the forum and Palatine Hill today after the Coliseum using the combined ticket. Like I said in my Coliseum review the the combined ticket cab be bought online to save waiting in line, and under 18's go free (save for the online booking fee). The site gets very busy with loads of escorted tour groups so getting around can be a little tricky. The difficulty with this site is that it's both Roman, Middle Age, and much more recent so unlike Ephesus for example you're walking through 2 millennia of ruins. But that's history! Site descriptions are in English and Italian and we didn't bother with an audio headset or tour guide. You can learn a lot online. For anyone interested in the history of Roman empire this site is a must see.

Living antiquity. To write about the Roman Forum cannot do it justice. You simply have to visit to appreciate what it must have been like all those centuries ago. To touch some of the ancient stones and buildings gives one a direct link to the past.We visited this Autumn and were not disappointed.12 euros gets you a two day ticket that includes entrance to the Colosseum also.Highly recommended.

Amazing walk through an amazing history. We did this as part of the coliseum visit, we had a fascinating walk around this site the history and beauty of once an amazing city is breathtaking you can just feel what it must of been like to live back in ancient rome. This is a must see while visiting rome.

Amazing place. Must see. We spent about 4 hours wondering round the forum and the palatine, it is amazing how much is preserved and what great builders/engineers the Romans were. There are toilets and some vending machines inside. You get great views of Rome. Also they have just opened The Ramp which was the route from the emperor's palace to the forum, one of the most impressive things we have seen. If it's open do go. Also the museum inside the forum is worth a visit.

Get there early. Worth seeing whilst in Rome. I would definitely advise on booking a guided tour as soon as you know your travel dates because they sell out well in advance and it is kind of hard to tell what you are looking at without assistance. If you choose to get the audio guide instead I would still recommend booking your entry ticket online (combined with colosseum) and getting there early as it gets very crowded on weekends and during peak seasons.

So much to see and so much history. Our best view of this location was on the hill overlooking the entire forum. There are a lot of little scenic views and historic items on the sight as well. Some really cool stuff to see.

Amazing place. Apart from being a "Must See Place" to visit, it is the best place to visit first so that you can buy a combined Forum/Colosseum ticket thus avoiding the queues (lines) at the Colosseum entrance. You will need half a day at each to take (some of it) in. The combined ticket is valid for two days

Where the money met the brains met the politicians met the religious authorities. The Roman Forum was the centre of financial, political, religious and cultural Rome. It developed from insignificance in 500 BC to world dominance in the 1st Century AD. It was the centre of intellectual debate, public legal pleadings and executions, business was conducted here and it was the centre of Rome's religion with the houses of the Pontifex Maximus, that of the Vestal Virgins and a major concentration of temples to the Romans' gods and godesses.The Roman Senate met on the Capitoline Hill overlooking the Forum, Cicero and other famous orators spoke from its Rostrum. Condemned traitors were hurled from its Tarpeian Rock. It contained many of Rome's most important temples including those dedicted to Jupiter Optimus Maximus, Castor and Pollux, Janus, and many others.

Best Place in Rome. Absolutely the heart of it all, the Forum is exciting upon approach and magnificent walking along the imposing ancient ruins. It is amazing that anything is still left standing. Bring a guide or a good guidebook to understand everything you see. Buy tickets ahead of time to save time in line. It was not too crowded in the Forum as it is so spread out.

OK. Found the place to be a little confusing and, as a result, less satisfying than it could be. Am sure that we missed something here but suggest either a guide or a guide book to go through the place and appreciate it for what it is.

fantastic, unbelieveable,great experience... booked tour as go in first, before the huge queues!! good information,& an hour on own to explore.then another guide,in forum.great history,very interesting.make sure comfortable shoes/trainers, & water. very tired, but worth it..
I expected more. It was great to see but I expected more. information was skanty and upkeep could have been better considering how historical the site is.
Fascinating . Walking in the footsteps of so many centuries is amazing.So much to see and take in.Allow yourself some time for here.

I am in love with Rome and its engineering excellence. Everyone needs to see the Forum We went the next day after visiting the Colosseum. Our ticket included both. Our M>O> was to see an attraction and then find a restaurant for lunch. The weather was cool and refreshing.
Historic Place. Very thrilling to see the history hidden/ oozing from this place. Great to learn all about it through our tour guide.
Average. Like the Palatine Hill it has a lot of waste potential. Worth seeing, but could be much better with some miniature replicas and posters of original views of the side.

Amazing. Your ticket to the forum is 12 Euros and it includes the Coliseum and the Palatino, which I think is a great deal. Some people had downloaded an audio guide on their phones and were using that instead of renting an audio guide. There are bathrooms there to use as well.There is a small church on the right hand side when you are exiting where you can go in and see some statues. when you exit if you go right you can go into the church that has this in their lower level and view it from above. There is no fee for the church, the back wall is all glass to allow for the view of the statues below.

Fascinating afternoon . We went on a Sunday afternoon and we're lucky that the queue to get tickets was only 5 mins and it wasn't overly busy inside. We bought the €12 ticket to go to the Colosseum as well (can be done on 2 consecutive separate days). We are not hugely into archaeology so didn't have a guide but if this is something you are more interested in then I'm sure a guide would be good. We marvelled at the enormity of the site and how the buildings and columns had been built in the first place. Camera was used heavily throughout!

Remarkably Roman. Booked this as part of the Colosseum half-Day tour and it's highly recommended specially if it's not rainy as it's mostly outdoor with a lot of walking. Really informative and historical. It felt like being brought back in time and experiencing history up close.

Amazing history so get a guide and arrive early. My husband and I did a small group bible history tour through the Roman Forum and Colosseum, focussing maiming on the forum. It was our favourite tour whilst overseas. We arrived early (9am) and there was no line to get in and we could move freely around but by lunch time the forum was very crowded. The history in the forum is absolutely amazing and well worth the 12€ admission fee (includes colosseum entry as well). I would definitely recommend a visit but take a guide, the extra knowledge they can impart is invaluable. Also take snacks as it can take a while to get around the forum and you may need some energy food.
Vacation. This place takes you back in time and even down to the roads the the early church fathers walked on. A must do when in Rome.

Like going back in time. Take a tour with this as you will beat the lines and learn a lot. The tour is well worth it. My tour also included the Colosseum. Also, once the tour is over you can stay as long as you like. I was there in September of 2012. Also, be careful when taking a picture with a gladiator. They do charge and the price can be pretty steep. I've heard they charge around €30 or more! If you want to take a picture with a gladiator try to negotiate a price.Definitely a must see when in Rome. Just standing in the forum you can only imagine what it must have been like at that time.

Wonderful ruins in center of Rome, lots of walking, climbing required. The ruins are incredible and right in the center of Rome not far from Termini station and have great metro access. Suggest you join a group tour, or download an app for your smartphone which explains all the amazing ruins that you will see on this site. Some group tours include the Forum, Colosseum, Palatine Hill all in one which is what I did and felt it was well worth the extra money. My guide was an archeologist that worked for the city and coordinated with construction companies so she had lots of great stories and was well versed in the history of this site.

Could spend the whole day here. I loved walking through this interesting place, would recommend to take your time and drink in the surrounding area.We stayed until the alarms went off to ask for everyone to leave for lockup, The sun was setting and we arrived at the rooftops view. Was very romantic and unique.
So interesting. So much history! Book a tour guide they are very informative and worth paying for. Allow about 2-3 hours to have a good look around.
A Marketplace For All. The Forum is an ancient gathering place which is stunning for its collection of Roman Ruins. Julius Caesar walked "these streets." Another do-not-miss experience in Rome.
Interesting! But need a guide.. Need someone who has studied the period or pay for a guide, go early before crowds. Buy ticket before hand get in sooner.

Lotsa Rocks. Okay, a couple of these Imperial-age buildings still have a roof, and are certainly worth a visit, especially on a rainy day like we had. Some of these large columns are indeed impressive, too, but even though there are a few signs about, you really need a good guidebook or at least a map to know what you're looking at. A guide or guidebook gives you some context – some story about what you are seeing – otherwise it is just a ruin in the real sense of the word. Helpful hint: try Rick Steves or Reids Italy online for a good map. Buy the combo ticket and see the Coliseum (see my review) and the Palatine Hill.

Inspirational from start to finish. Don't hold back, breath in the history, remember the lessons from school and the films over the years and then realise that you are walking in the steps of all these historical characters.

Be Guided. Visited as part of skip the line tour to Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum. An extremely knowledgeable guide brought the Roman Forum to life and made the visit great value for money.

Excellent. My third visit and still find this place as fascinating as I did on the first. Unfortunately there is a lot of conservation work being under taken which I know is necessary but this year there seemed to be a lot more screened off than on my previous two visits.Make sure you take plenty of water in with you and that you wear good sturdy shoes as you will be walking on the original Roman stones and they're very uneven and wait to trip the unwary!Lots to see so take your time.

Amazing history. very impressive to be in the middle of a 20 century's place.1 day is necessary to visit Roman forum, colloseo and palatin.Audio guide is mandatory but not enough to catch all information (difficult sometimes to make the link between audio guide comment and what is in front of you), the best is an official guide to catch all details of that impressive history.

Good enough for Caesar, good enough for you.. Just think that Caesar, Anthony, Brutus, Nero and many other Roman Emperors walked these streets so long ago and so much of what the world is today originated here. Don't miss it!

It helps to know some history. For me the Forum was the highlight of the trip. I have just read the Robert Harris Trilogy about Cicero, so looking at things like the Rostra and Senate building which were prominent in the books just brought them to life. Also good idea to download an Audio Tour to your IPad, otherwise your just looking at a lot of ruins.

Incredible. A 'must see' if visiting Rome. The helpful signage gives lots of interesting information. It's a great example of ancient Roman architecture and gives an insight into how the Romans lives.

The Romans and Forum SPQR. To the untrained eye even with a guide book the Forum and Capitoline Hill are mostly rocks and ruins. A good guide will bring the Triumphal Arches the temples Julius Cesar Marc Antony and the rest of the Roman gang to life.

Take Your Time. We made a mistake I believe in combining this tour with the Colosseum. We spent an hour and half in each place. We could have done the Colosseum in under a hour, I would have loved to have wandered and explored more of the forum. By the time we had put in three hours with a rather sloooow moving tour guide I was tired. We did leave the tour guide at the end and wandered back through at our own pace. It would have been so nice to have relaxed, picnicked perhaps sketched a little in these amazing ruins.

Must see if you are in Rome. The forum is so interesting to walking through...you get a very real feel of Rome back in that time is history. We bought our tickets the day before and I'm glad we did as the line for tickets was very long and we walked right into the entrance .

Completed it. If you go to the coliseum you must complete this part of the Roma is like going back to the past, plus it's juts awesome to think people lived like this 2500 years ago and we still following they rules.

Amazing. Our excellent guide brought the ancient city to life...history has never been so instructional. We arrived early and didn't face any lines. She indicated the new security scans slow the entry process a great deal. Do be smart of petty left in the area...

Walking with the Romans. We visited the Roman Forum as part of a half-day tour of the Colosseum. We had a guide and were in a group of about 20. It was a very good way to learn about this part of Rome. I learned so much. Our guide was an archeology student and she continually gave us facts and interesting information. This is a place not to miss and having a guide just adds so much to the experience.

Worth having a tour guide.... This was my second time visiting The Forum. The first time I was with a group tour and found that the narrative provided by the tour guide really added to the experience.The site is fascinating, even without the tour guide... but the background information really brings the place to life.
Another must see. Buy a ticket at the Forum for both the Forum and the Colosseum and safe youself some time and see 2 of the most inpressive sites in Rome

Awesom. What a surprise - I was overwhelmed by the size and sense of history. Allow at least half a day to explore (and make sure you take water and a snack). The most memorable place in Rome for me. Queues were a bit long to get in - I advise getting a Roma Pass at a tabac for entry and priority with the queues.

Step back in time. What a site. Wandered around for a couple of hours. Absolutely magical. The Emperors walk was open so great to see inside the actual structures as they had been. A number of the buildings are open and have interesting wall murals and sculptures. Some of the carvings are absolutely wonderful. Walk to the top of the Palatine Hill for great views over the whole area.Price included with the Colosseum so for 12 Euros for both real value for money

HISTORY! Walk where Ceasar walked... First, this is just a walk through ancient ruins. If that is not your think, or you are not familiar this may not be exciting for you.For me, I love Roman History. To know how this area was used, where the temple of the Vestal Virgins stood. To see where Marc Antony gave his speech. You are literally walking the path of millions of historic Romans and through the heart of what was the Roman Empire.
Worth a visit. Ties in nicely with colosseum and palatine hill it's just a must see for anyone visiting Rome ,make time to do it

Beautiful history site to combine with the Colosseum. To compliment your visit to the Colosseum be sure to visit the adjacent Roman Forum. It will show you how vast the complex was and create a lasting impression!
Grat but not much left . Looking on the remaings of what's left , we should think there's was so much more there before. What's left is still great memory of the ancient architecture. Must see.
Great place to get lost for a few hours. Usually part of a tour and spending two hours there is enough. Be sure to take a moment to get lost and lose yourself in this gorgeous place!
Magical. The Roman Forum is an amazing set of intact ruins right in the middle of Rome. It gives you a very good sense of what it was like in ancient Rome. Definitely a must see.

You need a guide to make the most . The most overwhelming amount of history. You need a guide to talk about this part of Rome, otherwise it is just beautiful views and amazing ruins. The best view of the forum is from Palatine hill, you can group the tours together, expensive but well worth it.

Old is Gold!. Not to be missed! I enjoyed visiting Roman Forums and Palatine Hill just as much as Colosseum and Vatican. It's part of an overall experience of visiting Rome not to be missed at any cost!

A classic with loads of histori!. Since it's included in the combo ticket for the Colosseum and Palatine Hill, you'll get to see the Forum as well when you enter either of those places. The beautiful views combined with the history make this place powerful to see and a must-visit while in Rome.

Huge expanse of history. This forum is huge and so I would highly rec a guide. We arrived about 1pm and all the tours were booked and audio guides out. We used google to help but it wasn't the same. That said, the overwhelming sense of touching history was incredible and will draw me back here again.

To fully appreciate, get a guide. This was a wonderful experience, much better than the last time 10 years ago without a guide. As we toured this time, our guide made this area come alive with the history fully explained.
Loved it!!. I still can't believe we were able to walk through there and see so much history! We were there in early March and the weather was beautiful1
Fascinating. Brilliant place, so much to see and admire. We learnt so much about the Romans and how they lived. Allow yourself plenty of time to take in this fascinating site.
Bigger than we thought.. Very interesting, full of history but a lot of walking and unlevel pathways. Really enjoyable but be aware there are no toilets on site.

trip of lifetime. trip of lifetime should be on everyones bucket list palintine hill colesseum and forum should be seen with a tour guide for best knowledge recommend through eternity tour long version and make sure you are ready to walk

Imagine the days. The hustle and bustle of Rome is all around you but this place, along with the Palatini, slows everything down and you can imagine how life would have been (for the rich anyway) 2 millenia ago!

Excellent Experience. Very interesting visit to Ancient Rome. We were part of a group with a Guide but we did not enter the various sights. There is so much of Ancient Rome to see that a 2 hour walk through is not sufficient but it does give one a great overview of all the sights. We would love to return and spend one of two day with out Lonely Plannet Tourist Guide on Rome in hand and study some of the sights in greater detail.Planty of walking involved and plenty of photo opportunities.

you should be there !. If you are in Roma , You have to be there. It is a history place which you just must see. You can spend there almost all day and still like this place. Piękne miejsce we Włoszech, do którego powracam wspomnieniami. Historia zapisana w ruinach tego miejsca. Gorąco polecam !

Free Entry with Colosseum. isited because we had free entry with Colosseum ticket. Spent the whole morning at Colosseum on a tour then had lunch break in Monti neighbourhood and visited this after. Everyone was a bit tired of walking around by this stage - maybe better to do it on the 2nd day as ticket valid for 2 days.
Takes you back in time. When in Rome, You must stroll trough the Roman Forum. It is an experience that makes you feel how it was in the time of the Roman Empire, a whole city coming back to life.

History that still breathes in the air around you. If you have any sense of history and a little imagination you can transport yourself back to when these buildings, temples and the way of life were in full swing.Whether you follow a tour or simply listen to the audio guide (we've done both) you get to experience a wonderful journey in a simply magical setting.I'd recommend a tour after lunch as it seems less busy than the morning rush.The Forum is without a doubt one of the top three must see attractions in Rome.For a fantastic view over the Forum climb to the café on the top of the Vittoria Emmanuelle monument its worth the climb.

Very little to see. The ruins of Forum need you to have imagination in tons...otherwise it is difficult to discern anything from what is mostly rubble. That said, it is one of 'the' things to see in Rome and it is covered in the ticket price of Colosseum.If you really want to admire Roman architecture, visit Ostia Antica.

Saw this several years ago...free and okay. Lots of history. Do not need to spend much time here was our thinking. Very historic...but not that much of interest.; There are many other inspiring place to see in Rome.

Loved the ruins!. We took a tour with a very knowledgable guide through the forum along with the colosseum. This is something that I feel everyone should do when in Rome. The history is just fantastic. Our kids went with us and enjoyed it as much as we did.

Stroll through Rome's antique center and feel intimidated by all these huge temples and public buildings.. Book your ticket in advance online and get entry to the Forum and Palatine Hill, one attraction, and the Colosseum. The ticket is valid for two consecutive days. Print it at home for the queue for reservations is long. Both tourists with all kinds of questions and slowly working staff don't really help to minimize it.Take a whole day for this attraction, but bring your own food and drinks. There is only a vending machine with cookies and drinks at the site. Roam the old streets, imagine how the temples and basilica's must have looked like and imagine the shouting audience in court - they were paid to do so - or find the traces of senators who made little holes in the marble to play a dice game during breaks or dull moments.
Worth a visit. Best to wear comfortable walking shoes, and to bring a drink with you as it go go go - loaded down with history, one of those once in a life time tours
Neat to look at the old ruins.. Good spot to walk around and take photos. Imagination runs wild thinking of 2000 years ago and all the old movies you seen like Spartacus.

SIMPLY AMAZING!. If ever there was a must-see in Rome, Foro Romano (the Roman Forum) is it. As much as I loved touring the Colosseum, I have to say that if you can only see one thing while in Rome, go to the Roman Forum. This forum is huge in comparison to the other forums in Rome and houses many interesting ruins such as the Curia, which is where the Roman Senate conducted "business". There are two triumphant arches on either side of the forum with beautiful carvings contained within, Romulus is said to be buried within this forum but we could not locate the spot. Also, Caesar's ashes are buried here in a tiny building that you can enter! There are many other wonderful sites to see here, but for me, the ones that I love the most besides the ones that I just mentioned were the Temple of Antoninus & Faustina and the Temple of Romulus (not dedicated to the original Romulus--Founder of Rome) because they appear almost whole in comparison to some of the rest of the buildings, Casa de Vestalli (atrium and home of the Vestal Virgins) and the Temple of Vesta, which is my favorite of all! :)

Nicer ruins than the Palatine Hill. I had a pretty nice view of the Roman Forum from Capitoline Hill. Some of the ruins are very well-preserved and they are a testament of the greatness of Roman architecture.

Excellent history..use tour. We hired a private tour guide to help us understand the importance of what we were viewing. Last time I just walked it and the magnificent history was not brought to life. Private or group tour this site should not be missed.
Interesting. Close to the Colloseum, this is primarily Roman ruins. See both on the same day. Great views but hilly. Flat shoes, water and a parasol are musts. Terrific history

Great Tour!. This is another must see in Rome, actually one of the main "must sees". We had the best tour guide with Viator. Our guide was so knowledgeable and interesting. I would. To do it without a tour unless you already know what everything is.

The Way to do Urban Planning. The forum (really fora, or forums, plural) is a great series of architectural public spaces developed by emperors and great men of ancient Rome. The spaces typically had temples, public buildings for debates, law courts, and public restrooms, among other uses. Trajan's Column dominates one forum. The space memorializing the apotheosis of Romulus, a co-founder of Rome is worthy, as is the area where Julius Caesar was sent to the next world on his funeral pyre. The area is artistically lit in the evenings and near other attractions including the Colosseum and the V. Emanuel Monument.

Get lost in history. This is one for the history fanatics...loved this place. It gives you an idea on how great Rome was in olden times. Take your time to visit this place and get lost in Roman history.

Roman forum and Palentine Hill. Very cool exhibit of the Roman city. Lots of walking but does not disappoint . You can see where the old city meets the new and have a great view of the colosseum. I didn't have a guide but I would definition get one because on your own you don't get the historical significance or stories behind the places.
The Roman Forum and Colosseum are a must see!. The Roman Forum gives you a feel of the long history of the city and the power and splendor of the Roman Empire. An essential visit for any history buff

Amazing preservation of such a historical site. A lovely place to walk around in the sunshine, taking in all the history of Ancient Rome. You can hire audio guides but need to leave a piece of I.D such as driving licence or credit card at the main ticket counter, not ideal if you intend to leave through a different route as you have to walk back to collect it and hand in the audio guide and then walk back again, and it's not a short distance. Overall a lovely place to visit.
Such history. Recommend a walking tour with a private tour guide combine with other historic sites. So much to learn.

Hail Imperator!. The exit and entrances have changed over the years. Now via turnstile's costing 1 euro . We used the one halfway down the Via Imperiali. Whether you view from the many vantage points or feel the dust under your feet in the forum itself, the sense of history is palpable. Also the sense of thirst - take water and use the fountain system to refill as it does get hot there. The ancient track and monuments are quite uneven so care must be taken not to trip over.Caesar was murdered down here and the Senate met and debated. Triumph's were gazed upon and Archways such as the one still standing told the stories of the victory.You are touching base with one of the great ancient civilisations of the world!From here you can move onto the other major sites and vistas and imagine how it must have been.

Go on a group tour!. I enjoyed walking through the Roman Forum, I recommend going on a group tour to see the Colosseum and Roman Forum, there is just so much to hear about the history of this spot, make it a must see on your list

Big. Go with a tour guide (we arranged ours through our hotel). It is big and multi dimensional so without a guide it would be a bit hard to understand the significance of it all. If you don't want to use a tour guide, at least get one of the many books available all over the city where you have pictures of ruins with overlay pages of what the buildings would have looked like.

Best to do with a tour!. We visited the forum with a context tour in December and really enjoyed it. It is incredible how much remains considering the age of the ruins. Although it is enjoyable to wander through I definitely recommend a tour for this particular site to help understand what you are seeing and how it would have been used.

Nice place, worth careful planning. In Rome Colosseum is a must-see staple, and we feel the Roman Forum is as impressive. Our route is Colosseum-Forum-Palatine Hill. Starting from Colosseum at 8:30 am, stayed an hour and half, then walked to Forum, which is 5 minutes' walk to the west. At 10:00 am there were not many people in the Forum and we had a good time. Unlike the Colosseum which is so huge that it can only be used as photo background, there are many interesting things that you can use in your photos. I suggest that we need to to some reading about the Forum and get to know what it was like thousands of years ago. A lot of walking, so wear comfortable shoes. Only one drinking water fountain near the east entrance, can be very crowded especially in hot sunny days. No place to buy water or food. Around 11 am large tourist groups began pouring in, and the place became noisy and less attractive. Terribly long queues out of every entrance.

Glorious. Before heading overseas I had embarked upon Colleen McCollough's historical tomb, The First Man in Rome; an extraordinarily well researched and readable novel set in the Roman Empire. I was a few pages short of finishing the 1000 or so pages when we visited the Forum and Palentine Hill. It is an amazing area to walk around and imagine that these people with whom I felt so familiar, such as Gaius Marius, Sulla and Aurelia Cotta, had at some point had tread the same paths, strolled or paced between the same walls. Even now, with all the tourists, it can be incredibly peaceful up on the hill. Later that evening I picked up the book and read in the next paragraph of someone getting murdered in the Senate building, which I'd looked at just a matter of hours beforehand. An incredible place.

Great History!. This place is amazing, but also very crowded and has an audio guide that is hard to follow. This can be combined with a guided tour of the coliseum and the overview would have helped us. Otherwise, review site information prior to make the most of your visit. Like all of these overcrowded "must see" sites in Rome, they can be skipped on follow up visits. It's hard to live up to the hype and far from the best experience to be found in Rome.

Fascinating layers of history. By day and by night the Forum is fascinating. Though we did not end up taking it, there is an evening tour where sections of the Forum are lit up which looked very intriguing. We just watched from afar and were sorry we hadn't made plans to take the actual tour.

Amazing place in the heart of Rome. One of the top 10 places which you should visitduring your stay in Rome. You can buy tickets online and one ticket costb12€ and it is valid for colosseum, forum romanum nd palatin hill together. I liked it more than colosseum.

Fascinating . Great place to visit. I would recommend purchasing the Forum/Coliseum combination ticket as you can skip waiting in an addition line for tickets. There is so much to see and do go to the top areas as the views are wonderful. A must see when in Rome!
Ancient Rome at its Best. You must see this when you visit Rome. It is so interesting. I could spend all day there. Would recommend going early if possible, less crowds
Historical . If you like looking at old ruins and contemplating how people use to live this was great. There are also some great views. It is rather large and spread out.
A must see in Rome! A travel back in time.. A must see in Rome! A travel back in time. Well worth the 12 euros per person to visit (which also include the visite of the Colosseum and Palatine Hill).
Historical site. This is just brimming with historical significance, and a little reading about it before and after a visit is well worth your time.

Buy your ticket online. Colosseum and Forum tickets are sold together for a very reasonable 14 euros (with booking fee) and you can use the ticket over 2 days, so book your ticket online, see Colosseum first and head to the Forum. Mind you, Roman Forum is Massive! It'll take at least 2-3 hours to go around without a break so plan your trip accordingly. There are vending machine located here and there or better yet bring you pack lunch and enjoy it while taking a break and taking in the views. We climbed up straight to the Palatine Hill (first left after you enter) first and saw Circus Maximus...etc. before going down to the forum. I'd recommend arriving early -we did Colosseum at 8:30 and Forum from 11am- as it gets busy as the day goes by. It is a fascinating view from the hill and well worth having a break there.

'The most ruined of ruins' according to my guidebook. We were a bit history-ed out by the time we got to the forum on our penultimate day in Rome. It's worth going to as the ticket is included in the price of the Colosseum ticket. If you love history - it's very intriguing to see how the buildings have evolved over the years & there are some almost entirely intact temples, but the rest is in varying states of ruins. If, like us you become a little ambiguous, We treated it like a walk in the park, wandering round between buildings for a little while and moving on to wander the grand ruins at the Palatine hill. In total for both sites was around 1.5hours - but it could take much longer if you read everything in detail.

Best View!!!. This was also part of our Colosseum tour.The views from here are just amazing. There is a lot of walking to do, so make sure you wear comfortable shoes. this is another tour not miss when in Rome

You could spend hours exploring!. The ruins are spread over a large area so you could spend ages wandering around, getting lost in antiquity! Signs were very informative so it was quite clear what you were looking at. The ruins are quite atmospheric, and going later in the day provides wonderful photos.

Take a tour. I was amazed at just how large a site the Roman Forum takes up. It is incredible that it is still there, even in a city like Rome, where there is so much rich history that is uncovered so regularly. Fortunately, the historians and planners of Rome recognised the historical significance of the Roman Forum site and it is still there in all its glory for the modern generations to visit and admire. - so glad that we took a tour of the site as our guide made all of the buildings and monuments come to life for us with her rich descriptions and interesting anecdotes.
Ancient ruins. Pretty amazing place. It's a good idea to either do some research before you go or take one of the guided tours.
Amazing history. A must see part of old rome, in close walking distance to the collosium and other significant ruins.
Visting the Roman Forum. This site covers a large distance so if it is a warm day, bring water. It is a magnificent site and a must see on a trip to Rome.

It's a big site in the hot sun! Leave adequate time. We bought tickets for the Forum as part of a package with the Colosseum, and rather expected it would be a small area. Gosh, we were wrong!The forum site is actually quite large, full of temples and other remains of the old city, many in an excellent state of repair.Wandering through, you can easily feel the history of the place, and admire the skill and ingenuity of the builders and architects.There were a couple of issues - the site is large and there is very little shade, so remember the sun cream and a hat if you want to properly explore.We also really would have liked an audio guide for the site, but there were clearly far too few of these available, and we were not able to get one during our visit (we were on site for around 4 hours). With hindsight, we probably should have downloaded a guide onto our iphones before visiting.I'd also recommend bringing a bottle of water, as there does no't appear to be anywhere on site selling them.Even without the guide though, there is sufficient written information to make the visit informative and enjoyable. Well worth a visit.
Keep going. let your imagination run wild as you wander though these open history books...you won't be disappointed

A place one must see in Rome. One of the must see in Rome, a significant piece of history, showing magnificent reminders of the Roman Capital centrum. Buy your tickets online to skip most of the lines.
