you can touch where Ceazer was cremated. We spent the entire day exploring the Forum. You can close your eyes and see and feel how it must have been. You can just look around and say ok..I have seen it.....but touching where Ceazer was actually cremated is like touching a piece of ancient history.
not much left to see. Not much to see. Some ruins but in such bad shape that they hardly given any sense of what was once there at all.

Palatine Hill and Roman forum in the same place. Keep your tickets as the Coliseum, Palatine hill and Roman forum can all be accessed on the same ticket making it great value for money but make sure you leave enough time and the Roman forum is on both sides of the road leading down to the Coliseum so don't miss anything.

Impressive. Walking down roads steeped in history. The whole thing is just impressive. A lot of the buildings are significantly damaged, but you still get an impression of what once was here. A lot of the forum can be seen from other vantage points so you make take the view you don't need to actually enter it to get a good look around, but there's just something about being amongst it and walking down ancient paths and roads that adds to the experience.
Worth a visit as free!. You can easily access this free from the streets surrounding. Although you want a guide book for a good understanding to the history

ticket with the entrace of colliseum. If you buy the tickets to entrance the colliseum, they include the ticket to visit FORUM, you have to go there are a lot history in each part of that walls and columns

Walking in the Steps of the Ceasars. This is my third visit to the Roman Forum and I'd go back tomorrow if I could. It is amazing history and so different than an experience in America. You can walk up and touch all the ruins, sit on Roman capitals and feel like you're part of the history. You're not looking at the forum - the center of civic life in Rome - from outside gates or from behind rope lines, you're walking with the Ceasars. Divine!

A walk through the Roman Forum. Even if you are not a history buff, it is something to walk through the streets of the Roman Forum, listen to a guide telling you stories of what life was like in that time period and imagining how the store fronts, churches, business districts and gathering places must have been like. It is quite interesting to see how so much of building history is still able to be viewed today, so long after it was constructed. A great site to visit!

A must see.... This is it! All the stuff you've read about and seen on film...Use a guide book, the signing is not up to much , and read the background detail. We started up on the Palentine Hill and worked our way down into the Forum then across the road to Trajan's Market and Column.
a step back in time. when walking around the forum, it feels like you are away from the city environment. again. a good half a day can be spent wondering the sights of the forum and hill

Colosseum+Roman Forum+ Palatine Hill. One ticket goes for all three monuments. We didn't buy the audio guide for this one but did for the Colosseum (which was a great decision) so I guess audio guides would be a great help.

Cannot say enough about the decades of history on display here - it takes your breath away.. At every turn there is a beautiful new vista filled with ancient structures, statuary and archaeological treasures. Amazing, incredible!

Roman forum..eery.... This place is amazing. If you want the full experience then book the special guides that take you below ground....we will return because we didn't! We overheard a conversation between an American tourist and hid guide..it sounded fascinating and we realised we had missed a great opportunity...

Stones are mostly damaged. Deeply historical place. Stones are mostly damaged.Even somewhere its not possible to understand original shape of stones. If you know the story before you come it is more possible to understand and appreciate its story.

Get your ticket through Palatine. I'm sure you'll get the more in-depth info on the Roman Forum in places other than tripadvisor, so I'll save you the history mumbo jumbo. (not that I'm well versed in Italian history...)KEY: Buy your ticket through the Palatine entrance - no line! You can buy the ticket to Roman Forum & Colosseum right at the Palatine entrance. I'm not totally sure about how entering and re-entering works. But to be safe, we walked the entire Roman Forum, then exited (there's a turnstile) to hop on another line to get into the Colosseum. Definitely bring water and food with you. Once you're in, you're IN! You're not getting out of the Roman Forum anytime soon, make sure you have a snack. Better if you have some good food with you... maybe a flask of wine as well... haha.

Interesting stuff. It was very interesting to walk through the ruins and see what was left behind it really made you imagine in your head the parts what were missing and what it might have looked like. There are little parts left behind like dorm rooms and small coloured tiles. It is a lot of walking to do and the floor is uphill and gravelly so wear enclosed shoes if you do go. We bought our tickets at the Colosseum with it included which was better as you didn't have to queue at all and could just walk straight in. You can have a guided tour or walk around on your own which is what we did. We sat on the grass and looked at the views and was in there for the majority of our day. You are able to walk to the top and see the wonderful view of the entire roman forum which was very interesting and made you realise how big a place it really was. There is not any food really only a few vending machines selling crisps and sweets etc. Great day out and would 100% go again.

A lot of people.. We went from the Colosseum then Palatine Hill then the Forum so by the time we got to the Forum it was packed. More architecture compared to Palatine Hill so you can get some really nice pictures. There is a lot of metal fencing everywhere blocking some of the trails and in front of the structures. The sidewalks are uneven and you really have to watch your step. I almost fell once myself.

Breathtaking. The Forum was the place I wanted to visit the most during my Rome trip and it did not disappoint. The buildings are amazing and the commentary really brings the place alive. We bought tickets for the forum with our open bus tour which allowed us to avoid the lengthy queue for tickets.

Commune with the Ancient Romans. I suppose some people might be unimpressed with what is basically a collection of ruins, but if you have a sense of history don't miss a stroll through the ancient forum. This is the place where Romans did business, made contacts and talked philosophy (though not as much as the Greeks!); where Antony eulogised Julius Caesar; where the remains of temples and government buildings still stand.If you can sit on a column that stood here at the height of Rome's power, and don't feel a connection with a past that shaped so much of our present, then perhaps you won't like this place. Otherwise - don't miss it.
Relive the past and walk along historic paths.. When you buy the entrance ticket to the Coliseum, it is a duo ticket to the Roman Forum which is walking distance to the Roman Forum.
History. Just breathe taking. It is worth seeing. Very interesting. Not too far from the colosseum. Worth going

Take a walk through Ancient Rome. Great place to enjoy an afternoon. Enjoy a lunch in the area and meander through the forum. Take a self guided tour, walk around and contemplate life in a toga. The site is huge and well documented. I take a sketchbook, but anyone can find a place to sit and relax, this is history that can speak to you, just listen.

The temptation is to just visit BUT DO get a local guide. It's so easily accessible, and you feel all you have to do is stroll, so the temptation to do it alone is strong - I've done it alone AND with a private guide and there is a BIG DIFFERENCE.There is so much to the forum that requires knowledge (backed up by ipad or pictures) historical commentary - I STRONGLY recommend having you own private guide to add layers of added value to your visit to this historically important site.
so busy. A amazing place but absolutely packed with tourists so really difficult to see what you want or go where you want to you almost get carried along like a stream
Old Roman town. I've visit the Forum right after Colosseum visit.i bought roma pass, you can enter for free with this pass.

Wonderful sight, but too many people. Walking through the forum is an amazing sight. Just thinking about the history that took place here and imagining what it must have been like is very dramatic. This is a must see sight although the hoards of people even off season on a weekday is a bit overwhelming, not to mention the massive pushy tour groups that crowd everyone out of being able to enjoy this special place. I also wish there was a tour map or guide book that would give more insight into what you are viewing. The other issue is that most of the areas are blocked off from actually being able to get near them even though they had been more accessible in the past. This is understandable after seeing the crowds as this is way overused. If you want to see great Roman ruins that are completely accessible and no crowds, go to Ostia Antica...much better experience.

Roman times imagination.. It makes you live the old Roman time. People of great thinking and cleverness. One must never miss to visit while admire the huge and impressive intellective minds, they had.

Of course you're going to see this. It's the Forum! There's no way you're going to Rome and not seeing it. You get great (free) views of it all around, but walking through it is a bit of a thrill. I liked seeing where Cesar was cremated, for example. You can really imagine what it was like 2000 years ago here. We bought the audio tour, but I admit we quickly turned it off and just read the signs. The audio was so dry and we just were not in the mood for such seriousness.

Not to be missed. I advise a guided tour as there is so much to see! We used one from a street vendor and got a great deal as we did 3 tours in one, the colleseum, palatine hill and the Roman forum, the guides swapped after each tour and all had their own areas of expertise! This is definitely one not to miss x
Impressive, but overcrowded. Yes, it is impressive and a must-see, but with the masses of visitors not so enjoyable. It is not possible to walk around relaxed and let the atmosphere sink in.

Take the time to also see!!!. Since this is "free" with your Colosseum ticket it's really a "roman" experience...just to see the layer of ancient times that were unearthed is truly a "wonder" of the world!

Roman marvels. Getting your head around what you see here is very hard to do. Although it is all in various states of ruin, it is an impressive sight to behold and if you can stretch the imagination to think what these buildings were like in their time then it must have been an awesome sight.

Even our teenangers loved it !. The Roman Forum is a square surrounded by the ruins of several important buildings at the center of the city of Rome. It was for centuries the center of Roman public life and you almost sense it while walking around statues and grand monuments.Take a guided tour or rent an audio guide to get the best understanding.It is fantastic!

Outdated. The headsets were not available (allegedly all out) so we walked through the ruins with little guidance and poor markings. You better have your own map and descriptions when you arrive. Be prepared to walk on stone roads. Wear your most comfortable shoes.

Skeleton structures of history - a must see. This area of Rome is such a splendor. While you literally see the skeletons of what is left of building frames and columns - you can't help but see/imagine what history took place in the area. History was built right here!As we walked through there were several guides leading tours and we were able to hear bits and pieces of their talks. i would recommend researching to find a walking guide to accompany you as I'm sure I missed out on a lot doing it myself. Be careful walking as a lot of the path is stone and very uneven. There are some mud patches as well.

A little overwhelming. First, I will admit it was very hot the day I went, so that wore me out. However, walking through the Forum was mind-bending. I'm a Roman history buff, and it was incredible to imagine what it would have been like in its heyday, with colossal buildings, Romans everywhere and the heartbeat of western Civilization. As for family friendly -- it'll tire out the kids, but I could imagine them getting antsy and bored, wondering why they are staring at rubble and ruin. But an incredible experience for those who love being surrounded by history.

Take time to stand and stare. Went with a guide in a small group and well worth the cost as there is so much to see and learn. We couldn't avoid going on a Sunday so it was extremely busy but our guide managed to find quiet areas to give her talks. The palace at the top of the hill inside is huge with the gardens still being intact. Would recommend going to one of the higher platforms with views down on the whole forum, we could not do this due to the crowds
Fantastic. This was free with our collusium ticket. A must see while in Rome. I loved it. Alot of walking however so if your not able then this is not for you

grand old relics from long ago. The entry to this sight is included with your Palatine Hill and Colosseum tickets (tickets included in the Rome Pass). Once you're in, there is a lot to see. A grad relic in the middle of a modern city!

Impressive. Tickets included with the colosseum tickets and can do over two days if required.
Guided maps at ticket office would be advisable.
Amazing History. The ruins of roam far beat the ruins of Athens. So much to see you could get overwhelmed with the aww

Loved it. A part of history. Sends tingles down your arm that things built in a.d. still stand. Gives you a glimpses of how they lived. We did not go in but walked around the outside. However, I would take the tour the next time.

WOW. We loved the Roman forum. You can easily spend hours there exploring an extensive number of ruins. Great picture opportunities if you're interested in that sort of thing. You can't help but be impressed by the history you are standing in front of. Wear comfortable shoes and you can walk leisurely around the area. There are restrooms inside as well.

History brought to life . This was an incredible experience. I've watched and read films,programmes and books all my life about ancient Rome and it was amazing to walk through these ruins and realise you were treading on the same paths. It was a lot bigger than I imagined so took a long time and was great to see the remains of the buildings I'd heard about. After visiting the colloseum and Palatine hill it was the perfect way to end the day.

Impressive and always a great visit. We were lucky to get in on the first Sunday of the month where entry is free. Prices are super steep now, so that was a great cost saving. This time there was another part newly opened (for us). We find that every year new improvements have been made and new parts have been opened to the public. The whole area of the fori is entrancing - you can almost imagine what it was like 1000s of years ago in ancient Rome. We felt very privileged to be able to walk in our ancestors steps. It is a must to visit when in Rome.

amazing look into history. excellent location!! go with a guide that can give you an insight into what the area was used for and the important events that occurred there; otherwise you will not be able to appreciate the history behind the amazing area
Must see. Get a guide to escort you unless you're already an expert on Ancient Rome. So much to see and learn and you want to see it all. A little steep and uneven walking so wear the right shoes.
Must see. Get a guide to escort you unless you're already an expert on Ancient Rome. So much to see and learn and you want to see it all. A little steep and uneven walking so wear the right shoes.

Amazing!. You should not miss the Roman Forum. It is amazing. Staff that works in the Forum is not helpful at all. Waited 25 minutes in line to go to the restroom. Afte walking away found 2 more that were larger with no wait. Views are incredible, but staff put a cloud over the visit.

Wow! A very special place. This may have been 'ancient' Rome's showpiece but with a little imagination you can see it today as it must have been then.
It's an impressive sight!
No crowds, plenty of time to sit a while and just gaze in wonder at this amazing place.
You don't need to know the detail the picture is huge!

Touch of history. Great walk through the historical monuments, nice nature, old buildings, requires a lot of time. You can access this with the same ticket that is used to enter the Coloseum which was valid for two days when we were visiting.

The history of this city is amazing!. It was great seeing the old buildings in this area. They even have people dressed up as Roman soldiers but beware of them. They aggressively try to get you to take pictures with them. One of them did this with my sister and me and then wanted us to give him 40 euros. We did not, but he was not happy!

Wow!. Wow, what an amazing place. Roman History at its finest! If you have brought a coliseum ticket then the Forum is included in the ticket! Really worth it, be prepared for a lot of walking on uneven paths!
Get the free Rick Steves audio guide. Download the Rick Steves audio tour for free, then walk through at your own pace with your headphones. Entertaining and enlightening.

intriguiging history, a must to do with a tour guide. We did a combo tour of the roman forum and the colosseum. At first, the Forum wasn't my first priority to go to, but since it was a combined tour we went. Although the buildings and what is left of them is really cool to see, you don't know all the stories and history behind it if you don't go with a guide. I have to say I was very happy we went and had a guide to explain the background.

A Fascinating Step Back in Time. I have been fortunate to have visited Rome, IT on at least four occasions starting in 1975. I always return to the forum. I never fail to learn something about Roman History, Rome, and the Forum specifically as well as the historical figures that strolled along the paths and streets of the Forum and shaped history for centuries to come. Please note, the last time I visited Rome was in September of 2011.

Can be a maze to navigate around. The are around the Forum (Colosseum down to Emmanuele memorial) is a great place to walk around. You'd might as well buy the combined ticket for both. The audio guides are helpful to have but you could just as well have a good guide book. We happened to come across the sound and light show on the Sunday night which was a pleasant surprise. IT's one of the better performed pieces and you get to walk through the ruins (raised platform) after.
Beautiful place!. It's awesome to walk here where so many great things happened in the past. I did not wanted to miss it!!
Remarkable place to visit. You could easily spend all day here so much to see and take in. It really is a good place and seems to swallow up the crowd so doesn't seem busy compared to collaseum

old history. if you want to feel old history wind go and visit this place. You will feel like "Ben Hur" film or any other antic film. You will see lot's of pagan churches and you need good shoes it's a lot to walk

Go early in the AM if during the summer. This was such a cool place to visit - other than the extremely hot temperatures in June. I wish we would have gone first thing in the morning as I could have spent even more time here. We did the Rick Steves audio tour & it was fascinating to hear about all of the structures here & the fact that they are almost all still standing.

Truly mesmerising. Lovely summers day, several hours available we took advantage of the second day part of our 12 euro tickets that we bought for the colloseum the day before. We strolled around the streets and took it all in, again imagining we were there in Roman times and what would we be. Of course we was taken with the idea of being rich and powerful, but reality was we would have been working in the back rooms somewhere keeping the buildings operating...good fun though

Incredible Ruins. The Roman Forum is an incredible place to explore and walk amongst the ruins that were once government and important buildings. A good way to see the forum is from Palatine Hill where you can look down on it and see the entire area this large forum covers. The size of it is incredible. From there you will also see the Colosseum and other landmarks in the distance.
Ruins. Ruins is an understatement, there's not much left here, the guided tour was interesting but with not much to see it felt quite dragged out.

Must-see landmark in Rome. The Roman Forum and the Colosseum are must see attractions in Rome.The historical greatness is magical.The monuments take you back in time, they vibrate roman energy.Aprox 17 euros per ticket, including the Colosseum.

Great history. We loved this and seeing all the remaining ruins. I could imagine what it looked like 2 centuries ago with Julius Caesar. The ground is very uneven so wear good shoes and plan on doing a lot of walking. This is part of the colosseum pass so take advantage of both. Don't miss it!

Th most amazing place I have seen in my life, and gosh I have seen plenty!. Go, just go. See it for yourself, walk the narrow streets of distant past wondering and enjoying the privilege of being there. Really if you are pondering if it worth the time, travel and money I can only tell you YES!

History but not more !!. The Colosseum ticket includes the Roman Forum and Palatine hill.
The Roman Forums aren't that interesting very lil info on display.
Wonderful. Definitively worth a visit. Better than Colosseum, vast, impressive and one of a kind. Do not miss it.
Roman Forum. A MUST see if you're in Rome! I recommend being part of a tour so you can learn and understand the rich history that took place here.
Forum. We viewed this with a tour group so time was limited. Suggest you get a good map that details each site so that you'll know what the ruins are and allow yourself plenty of time.

Another must see. We got the ticket with the Colosseum one combined. Worth a visit. it is a huge area and you have Palatine hill as well. Make sure you don't "get lost" and are too tired to walk up the hill. I am sure we missed lots of things but it is quite exhausting.
Something not to be missed when in Rome.

Incredible Archeological Site. I absolutely love visiting this site although you must see this area with a historical guide. The guide will bring the archeological site to life and make your visit unforgettable. I only visit this site with a guide and I learn so much about the Roman Empire in doing so
Interesting. A lot of history as everywhere in Rome. Guided walks, even one at midnight which makes it quite special
Nice place for a walk. It's a nice place to admire ancient statues and buildings and have a walk in a sunny day.Admission ticket is the same as it is in Coloseo so you don't have to pay again.

Once housed the most important meetings of Rome. The Roman Forum is without a doubt, a must see in Rome. It was one of the most important buildings, housing meetings of the old Roman emperors. Further important sights around the Forum were erected, including temples and many of the remains still seen there today. History was made here.

Astonishing and full of History. You should definitely go when in Rome.. Unbelievable to walk through this place without to imagine how much history it holds. Is astonishing and very beautiful. Go with time to walk and to appreciate the city view from above. Remember to take water with you, the italian weather is extremely dry and hot.

Okay but not a must do. The Roman Forum is an impressive site, but certainly not a must do while in Rome. Dress appropriately because it involves a lot of walking to see the entire compound. There is also a museum onsite. If you plan on going to the colosseum, your colosseum ticket gets you access to the Roman Forum as well.

Lots to see!. Best viewed after first climbing Palantine hill so you can look down on the areas you wish to visit and pinpoint areas you most want to see. Hours can be spent here trying to ensure you see all the interesting bits
Rome Trip. As I said in my prior reviews the Forum, Colosseum, and Palantine Hill are probably the best parts of our trip. They are definitely worth seeing.

Fantastic. We didn't know a lot about the Roman Forum before we visited but wow. It was great. The area is huge and you could walk forever.
The history was so interesting. I would't think children would be of the same thinking though. It took us two and a half hours to go around the whole site.
Awe inspiring . Took a tour with Gladiator tours, Gregg was amazing. So much to see! Pack a picnic and spend a couple of hours there

From the Street. We saw this as we were walking to the Colosseum and it looked amazing from the street. You can enter this with your colosseum ticket and also Palatine Hill. Its great to walk amongst ancient ruins.
Worthy of your time to visit. This will take yout time (hours) to visit if you are a history buff where you get to appreciate every angle of this ruin.

A guide needed. We were fortunate to walk through (in the pouring rain ) with a archiologist. She painted a picture of what once stood a couple thousand years ago. Interesting the layers of buildings built on top of each other through the century's. The spot were Ceasear was killed and cremated was kind of interesting to imagine being so close to a story bought to life
A funny thing happened on the way to the forum. Amazing, a site to see.You can imagine what it was like when you see the ruins.You can see where people lived and worked.A must see.
Walking back through time. The guided tour is a must. Walking through the Roman Forum was like walking back into time. One of my favorite historical places that we visited in Rome.

Forum Romanum, the Heart of Ancient Rome!. The Roman Forum = Forum Romanum in Latin used to be the center, the turning point (market square) of all social and religious life in the time of Republican and Imperial Rome. Excavations in the 19th century still being in process allowing us to imagine how mighty Rome functioned at the time especially as many ruined but quite impressive temples, columns, arches etc are still in place.

Adventure lover. Very nice place, full of history and beautiful sculptures and structures. Tickets are sold on main entrance in Form and Palatine hill, if you see big lines, just go near the entrance and look for private tour, it will be worth to avoid line of waiting and to hear some interesting stories. You will spend a whole day if you want to hear and see all that beautiful things.

Roman history at its best. This is a vast area of historic ruins that take you straight back in your imagination to all those films - you can almost see the Romans in their togas wandering through the ancient streets. Soak up the atmosphere, you will really enjoy it.

Great History lesson. I cheated a bit while visiting the forum. There were so many tour guides that I overheard all the information just by walking around. incredible history and architecture. Ongoing excavation. Arch of Titus is incredible.

The highlight of Rome for me!. I loved, loved, loved the Roman Forum, it really gave me a sense of what life was like in Roman times! I really appreciated the architecture and loved seeing the columns, temples and statues etc despite the fact that some of them are obviously not still in their original condition. When you think how long ago it was all built it really is an impressive sight and I thought it was very atmospheric. The star of the show for me without a doubt! I would recommend anyone to see this attraction but the terrain is uneven so flat shoes are a good idea.

Pedestrians only on weekends!. On weekends they close the roads around the Forum & Coliseum so that pedestrians can walk with less fear of getting run over...very cool! It's certainly more crowded then, but it's also calmer.
Please leave more time for here. Please leave more time for here, every corner worth to go. See, watch and thinking, maybe, one day we'll all turn into a piece of junk.
Wow. My wife and I visit Italy for two weeks. This was one of my top 5 best places to see. It is breathtaking. It is a must see while in Italy. It has a unexplainable, intangible presence. Enjoy!
Great accomodation and amazin location. This is just a worderful hotel, from our balcony we could enjoy the forum. Centrally located with plenty of restaurants and shopping.Very good!!

Teeming. It's more than rubble, several buildings have been recopnstructed and it's impressive though you do have to use your imagination to imagien a Roman town teeming with people. It teems now with tourists.

A ton to see, but use a guide or audio tour. There is so much going on here, you really need an audio guide or a tour guide to understand what you're looking at. There are literally layers of history you're looking at as you stroll down the old roman road and it's fascinating to see, but without the information on what you're looking at, you'll miss an awful lot. We had a guide, but we've used Rick Steve's audio tours for other attractions and found them very good.
A journey back to the past. It is an amazing outdoor display of the Roman history. The visit should be combined with the Colosseum.

Walk were legends walked. So much to see, grasp a sense of walking through a section of a city. We saw as part of a tour of Colosseum. We also viewed the day before from a above, looking down behind the Marcello. Both were spectacular.

Easy access, beautiful views. Well preserved and breath-taking! Not very crowded in the morning hours, which was great for taking photos of the scenery. Easy to access and audio-guides are available for decent price in many languages.
Friends, Romans, Countrymen. If you truly want the historic then this is a must! Get a real feel for the past and wonder at the amazing skills of the master builders and sculptors.

Ancient history . I had no idea how big this place was,it is truly breathtaking.It is right next to the collusium and the ticket covers both attractions and in my opinion is better than collusium.Wear comfortable shoes as there is lots of uneven terrain.My only regret was not researching the area before hand and not getting a guide to explain exactly what I was witnessing but a must see and a lifetime memory.
Full of history. Another gem of a historical visit, the forum is stacked with history of Rome through the ages and well worth a visit.

Do this site on the combined ticket.. Busy, but great to visit. Ladies loos are excellent and plenty of drinking water available on the way round, so a very "comfortable" visit. Not too good for people with mobility problems, as levels vary and it is somewhat hilly, but well worth the try!

Amazing structures!. The buildings are amazing, what is left of them. Hard to believe that these were supposedly built without machinery. The architecture and the perfection in which these structures were build is striking to say the least. Structures are higher!

Roman Forum - nice snippet of Ancient Rome. Nice to see some ruins of Ancient Rome and to learn a bit more about its history. We went around 5pm and this was a nice time as the last entry is 5:15pm so the crowds were dispersing and we could walk through freely and didn't have to queue to get in.
Amazing.. Long queues so get there early in the day or later in the afternoon. would recommend an audio guide to make the most of your visit.
Imagination Required. The ruins of the forum are interesting to walk around but it does require you to use your imagination to visualize what it used to look like.

Fascinating, historical area. Plan to see this along with the Colosseum but if it were me and I only had time for one, i'd choose The Forum over the Colosseum. We did the Rick Steve's audio tour while walking through it.
Add to Tour. Did this with a guide in conjunction with the Colosseum. Worth doing as a package deal as one thing flows into the next. Also takes in the Roman Forum.

A large area to see. This area is made up of many buildings that are partially uncovered or mostly destroyed. There are remnants of buildings such as pillars still standing, watch your step as you walk over the rocks that the chariots drove over. The history is amazing.

Not to be missed. Enjoyed our November visit.. We visited the Forum in late November 2014. It was the perfect time to go as the crowds were down and the temps were still in the low 70s. So much history compressed into one small area! Utterly amazing!! Do it!!!!!

Nice for an hour or two of walking around. Your Colosseum ticket will get you into the Forum so you should visit. This is a nice place to walk around for a couple of hours and soak in some ancient Rome.

Have to see. This is great to see along with the colosseum. You can only
Imagine the history and past. Cant go to Rome and miss this.
Very nice.. You are walking around and see this, it's so amazing, the ruins, and at night is very nice. You should go :)
Great wandering . Rick Steves has a free audio guide, but it jumps around. Get his book and do things in the order that you walk by them.

Walking through Histroy. You will probably spend 2-3 hours here in conjunction with Palatine Hill. You will near to wear sturdy footwear; there is nowhere to shelter from the sun or rain so make sure you are prepared.

History in their backyard. An incredible piece of history in a beautiful city. What you are looking at is poorly described by the signage provided. You should come prepared with Rick Steeves audio tours or something similar if you want to know in depth what you are looking at. Where are the costumed characters talking in the language of the day? Food vendors selling what you may have eaten then?
Beautiful. Part of Palatine Hill attraction. This site is HUGE. The ruins are amazing. Over looking the hills which is so beautiful. Worth a visit for sure,

Not what it was . Still awe-inspiring of course, but much more closed-off since a visit 10 years ago. The extensive fencing channels the crowds into a much smaller area making it difficult to wander around and take in the ambience. Still well worth the (new) entry price when combined with the Palatine and Colosseum.
Fascinating. I could have spent all day here,fascinating place. So so much went on here. I would have loved to have heard all the speakers.

Number one. Of all the fantastic sites I saw in Rome when I visited, the Forum was the one area that took my breathe away. It is a massive site and almost like a movie set - but this is real! A must see.
Amazing.... You really need a good couple of days to visit here! The scenery and architecture is simply incredible! Wear comfy shoes!!

Very interesting!. The olden days Trafford Centre! Most of it is obviously ruins but you can still make out the public baths, a roman road & where the shops were. Well worth a visit, very interesting.

Stunning ruins. A visit to the Forum is a must. I suggest you couple it with a visit to the Colosseum since the ticket covers both the attractions and they are side by side. The forum was more interesting to me than the colosseum in many ways. Please ensure that you climb to the highest point to the view the length and breadth of the Forum. Marvelous place.

Must visit. There is something extraordinary about being able to walk around, touch, and explore this kind of historical site. It's mindboggling. If we were to do it again we would definitely hire a guide to show us around, as on our own we were left to try and make sense of it all.

Nice if you're already in the Colosseum. It's OK if you're already in the Colosseum. It's part of a ruin system. After a while it's all the same. Just more ruins. If you're really into the history of it I can see how you would like it. If not, then it's just OK.

Walk through history. To get a real sense of what you are seeing, either join a guided tour or get your hands on a guidebook of some kind. Rick Steve has a podcast that is quite good. Otherwise you know you are somewhere special but you don't know one pile of old marble from another....

Romam business center 2,000 years ago.. This is a must stop on your visit to the Eternal City. As you look at the ruins in your minds eyes you can watch the busy city of 2,000 years ago go about there busy, the Senators, the slaves, solders and common people. So much history of the Roman Empire and so many gifts to the Western Civilization. I love our visit.
Go cuz it's across the street from the Colosseum.. Worth going to, but not as interesting as other sites as the ruins are pretty ruined. Not so much to see.

Research before you go. We were fortunate it see this area with an archeologist tour guide. He had an app on his phone that would allow us to look at the site and see what buildings had been there. Otherwise, it would have been very difficult to I,aging what was there.I do suggest finding some videos on the area before you visit, as it will place the are in context.

You will need to wear flat shoes. Arrived early avoided all the queues. Dont forget to take water as no cafes on site. Enjoyed wandering around. A guided tour may be worth while to bring the Forum to life. The visitors centre on palpatine hill was very hot.

Facinating. Well worth the long day, make sure you have comfortable shoes on as loads of walking but fantastic. seems unbelievable, we had a guided tour and was well worth it as I'm sure you would have missed bits and not understood why or what some of the buildings were for. They are still finding ruins now.

Worth a visit. There's so much history here, and was fascinating to view in person. Make sure to go with a guide so that they can explain to you what life was like in each area as you stroll through the ruins!
History packed! . Huge place, full of history and different spots for quality photos. It's incredible how much you can learn just by being there and reading the notes.
Lot. The forums were also included in our Colosseum ticket. The structures and history here are amazing and worth the stroll. Highly recommend if you are into history!
Forum.. Worth a climb up the steps. Lots of statues. Backpacks must me checked in lockers. Nice plaza to hang out in. Lots of gravestones - not so interesting to me.

Lived up to my lifelong fascination. For archaeology buffs, walking through and along this incredible relic is priceless. A guide, either in the form of a book or live (be careful -- quality of live guides varies widely) is essential to get an idea what you are looking at, but the history and magic is apparent even if you are just wandering around. Especially recommended late in the afternoon, when it is less crowded and cooler.

A Rome must-see!. Every bit as interesting as the Colosseum, without the almighty queues and crowds. Generally a very nice place to go for a walk, as you have space even during busy season. Lots of fantastic Roman buildings to see, with useful explanation boards in Italian and English. Great value for money too.

Incredible, huge. The Ticket price is included in the Coliseum entrance and they are very close attractions. It´s a place with historical ruins of the Roman Empire. It´s huge. You can spend a good part of the day there, stepping into the past and rest in any of the green areas. Use comfortable shoes and visit the museum to listes to the story, when I was there I heard it in English and Italian.
Just so amazing to think that these ruins are still around today. Just so amazing to think that these ruins are still around today. I found this place really interesting!!

Nice but also Visit Ostia Antica. Everyone will go to see this attraction and its worth the 8 euros but look into going to Ostia Antinc. Just a bus ride or train but wonderful as it all available to walk around

Fascinating Look Into History, but OVERCROWDED. Similar to Palatine Hill this was a fascinating look into an ancient world and very well preserved. It is well worth attaching yourself to a group with a free guide. They are very informative and work on tips.My only other comment is that it is so overcrowded it can be hard to move.

wonderful. This is an amazing place. It is absolutely massive. You get a true picture of what Roman life used to be like. My advice wear good walking shoes as it is quite uneven in places. Well worth a visit.

A great insight into Rome's ancient history. These Roman ruins cover vast acres of land close to the Colosseum and if it is hot you will definitely need copious quantities of water and protection from the sun. The pathways between the various temples and other ancient sites are very dusty and, after a couple of hours "ruin fatigue" may set in. This site is well illustrated but is best visited early or late in the day to avoid the crowds

An awesome place to see. Ok good news, this place is so big it doesn't feel crowded. You walk among the ancient ruins and can really appreciate the effort that went into building them. One of the best ways to view it is from above though, you really get a feel for the size that way
Awesome feels!. I honestly can't describe how it felt to be there. I can stay there for hours. The effort to preserve history is amazing.
Very Interesting place. A very interesting place to visit. You can follow the layout of the old city and get some feel for what life was like back then.
Forum-Palatine-Colosseum: Do All Three!. Fascinating to see all of the excavated buildings. My favorite is the three-floor office building where city administrative functions were located.

Such a thrilling experience being amidst these ruins. Walking amongst these grounds, one gets a sense of what it would have been like during the Roman times - grand, beautiful, royal!! The scale of this forum is massive with temples and pillars left standing in pride. I spent a little more than an hour here, but no one seems to rush anyone out so take your time in here if you love Roman architecture and history. Forum can get crowded and hot, so make sure you take plenty of water, and sun screen, umbrella/hat and loads of energy! Tip - buy the 3-in-1 pass to the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum for EUR12 - it's worth it.

Amazing Roman Ruins. An extraordinary place with such a vast group of ruins. It was built over 2000 years ago and you are provide an opportunity to walk in the steps of the various Emperors and Romans of the past and touch the ruins they built or walked through. A must see along with the Colleseum -- all for the price of one ticket. They are within a block of each other.

Roman Excellence. This visit probably surprised me the most!I was not expecting to enjoy it as much as I did.Once again the history is just amazing, and that they have preserved what they have.Do wear comfortable shoes, make sure you have water on a hot day!!!Do not miss this, it is just spectacular....especially Palestine Hill

Excellent and atmospheric. The Forum is right next door to the Colloseum and a ticket bought for one also gets you into the other. Queues at the Forum ticket office are shorter than the Colloseum so that's where we started. Don't be tempted to buy your combined ticket and then "nip" through the Forum to get to the Colloseum in the hope you can get back into the Forum later - although tickets are valid for two days they're only valid for a single entry into each venue. The forum is a vast area of well-preserved ruins including temples, houses and palaces. The place is awash with atmosphere, especially early in the morning and a visit to the Palatine Hill (and museum) is particularly recommended. We thoroughly enjoyed this visit and couldn't recommend it too highly.

Brilliant but not for the elderly. The history of this place is incredible. Hands down my favourite place in Rome, it really is incredible. The only issue is that, whilst myself and my fiancée found it easy to wander through the forum, my grandparents really struggled. This is to be expected with the cobbled floor and uneven layout of Rome, but definitely something to consider as a wheelchair would be impossible.
Great experience!!!. Beautiful experience !!! So much history in one place !!! You need a map and a lot of time. Follow the map and you'll discover many hidden places that are great!!
Roman Town. There were not many visitors when we were here, which was a great break! and it is so very interesting, one gets a real sense of how life was back then

A walk through a nice park. The Roman forum is just a nice park with a lot of history. There is a small hill overlooking it which is also part of the park. Around every corner there is a drinking fountain and something historical to see, either it's a bathhouse, a statue or a ruined building...there is always something to see

Very Cool and a Must Do. Plan to spend some time walking around the Roman Forum before or after you visit the Colosseum. It is history at your feet. It is all outside so if the weather is comfortable it is a nice break from museums and churches. It is an amazing place and a beautiful, natural site.

can see almost everything from standing outside. If you have only 2 or 4 day in Rome, go to visit museums, galleries, shopping. This place is huge, but not so much remains. You can see most interesting part from the street and the Capitoline Hill.
Awesome. Don't miss this spectacular site if in Rome. The site is so well preserved and the atmosphere is fantastic. Wouldn't attempt it in a wheelchair or with push chair.

Experience ancient Rome's city center. It's a lot of hiking and ground to cover. But you get true feel for where Rome's Caesar lived, the city center was and where people from surrounding villages came to trade in the marketplace.

Walk in our ancestors' paradise!. I thoroughly enjoyed this visit was included in the entrance ticket to the Colloseum. This was quite an amazing walk, walking alongside historic remains which were once lived in by the Emperors of Rome. Fantastic views from every point you can imagine. I kept taking what I thought were incredible views and then kept walking and got closer and closer to the views so they were almost touchable, but not quite! Thoroughly recommend this visit, ideally on a good sunny day!

Interesting Visit. The Roman forum is interesting but there is little left of the original buildings to see, you need to bring your imagination. This is included in to Colosseum ticket if you buy on line (not sure at the gate)
Well worth your time. We loved this, the weather was perfect, not too crowded as we went at 10am. Just so nice to be outside and away from the hustle and bustle of traffic. So much to see and enjoy
Ancient Rome. Loved it, loved it, loved it. Absolutely must see when you are in Rome. History under your feet and all around you! You can really feel the ancient Rome.

A historic, breathtaking mass.. After arriving at the Metro station (collosseo) from Roma Termini we took a stroll and looked at the Colosseum from the outside. After this we thought it would be nice to take a stroll around the area and feast our eyes upon all of the history that remained.Its safe to say that the Roman forum did not disappoint, an extremely impressive even if slightly confusion lot of ruins. I would definitely recommend paying a small fee for entry (including entry to the Colosseum) and taking the ascent to the top of Palatine hill for some breath taking views overlooking this impressive site.
Lots to see for free. We walked around the edges of the forum--sometimes adjacent, sometimes above. It was fascinating and enjoyable, even without paying and getting in on the ground level.

The Fabulous Form of Rome. You can get an overview of much of the Roman Forum by merely walking on the street. Our hotel was within blocks of the Forum, so we were able to walk past it various times at different times of the day. But if you really want to get down into the ancient city you should take a tour.

Ancient civilisation . This is an ancient civilisation that is worth your visit! Do bring a pair of good walking shoe as the path is not a flat path... The view of the Forum from Capitoline hill is breath taking especially during evening time!
Nice. Ticket for Colosseum is valid in the Roman Forum. Beautiful attraction in Rome, little history to back in the moment when step in Roman Forum.

Behold ancient Rome. The beauty and history is one you must see in Rome. Give yourself a minimum of 2 hours to walk and admire the grounds and ruins. There are individuals who are more than happy to point out details you may miss, don't be hesitant to ask questions of them to come away with a clearer understanding of what transpired here over the years.

Stroll through the ruins. Tours can be book but I really enjoyed just strolling through the ruins with my daughter. We went at our own pace and refereed to our Lonely Planet book if we wanted more information. Well worth the visit
Visit on a good day. Steeped in history, this was a good experience. Remember to wear walking shoes while in Rome. Choose a dry day if possible, avoid a rainy day if possible. Get there early.

Ancient History . We paid €7.50 each for entry to the colloseum, forum and the palatine which was outstanding value for money. This was a reduced rate as we are both 24 years old. Definitely get your ticket at palatine entry as there are no queues and no waiting time. The best time to go start the palatine is mid afternoon, where you can stroll round, enter the roman forum directly after and get to the colloseum for about five o'clock in the evening. You will not have to queue for your ticket as you would have already bought it. The roman forum itself is a wonderful place and there is a lot to see. Perhaps it was worthwhile getting a tour guide (which we didn't) to explain a lot of the history behind what you are seeing. We couldn't believe the low ticket price having come from firenze where an art gallery was twice the price! We would highly recommend this attraction!

An ancient wonder. With our tour included a walk to the ancient forum which was another spectacular site with the history going back thousands of years, stand and take some time to soak it in and realize what you're actually looking at...spectacular!

Going back in time.. Unbelievable experience walking through what remains at this site, lose yourself in your imagination mingling with the citizens of Rome heading to and from the Forum centuries ago
Amazing . An area I wanted to see for a long time. Great to actually see it for real. So much history in one area. Good walking shoes Will help you enjoy this place more.

Uncovered a slice of history. We did a walking tour after the Colosseum and it was a bit arduous in the rain but we pressed on. We got to potential walk in the steps of Mark Antony and Julius Cesar according to our guide on one of the paths. But see all the creations from the early churches and palaces and large columned places including the vestal virgins corner building was something to behold. I don't think words could do justice to the amount of building the archaeologists had uncovered which had hot decayed over time.

Wealth of history. So much history, this was my main sight to see. I loved it. If there's someone who doesn't like history then it probably wouldn't be interesting to look at ancient ruins. But if you do love history or can appreciate the impact ancient Rome has had on the world then it is a dream come true. I recommend getting a good tour guide or even using a tour guide book so you know what ancient ruins you're looking at.

Awesome! Very cool!. This Historic Site was awesome! Just love the the history all around Rome. The tour guide was very helpful in teaching us alot about the Roman Forum. We learned alot and was very interesting
Nice . Great place to visit and see the history of Rome, there are a lot of places where you can take great and beautiful pictures
great walking through time. a must visit site if you want to feel like one of thr ancient Roman . just imagin yourself wearing a toga and sandals and go back in time

So Much Ancient History in One Spot--Definitely Worth Seeing. What surprised me about seeing the Forum is that you've got the house where the Vestal Virgins lived with Caligula's palace perched on the cliff above, Titus's Arch right up the road, the Temple of Saturn, Forum Main Square and the spot where Julius Caesar was stabbed 'Et tu Brutus' and the spot where his body was burned all in one place--plus a lot more. I guess it's always been a small world. These places are surprisingly preserved, but I'd recommend hitting Google ahead of time if you don't recall this history, or doing a little research before you go. It will make it all that much more interesting if you know what you're looking it. Wear comfortable shoes, the walkway is ancient stone. You'll want to bring a bottle of water in. If they sell any inside I didn't see it. There is one restroom and the line is a long one. Like all these ancient sites, convenience isn't there, but it's worth the small hassles to see it.(I went twice, and one day was in the rain. I think it's a good rainy day activity with the proper gear--comfortable shoes that WILL get wet and an umbrella.)

So relevant. We enjoyed roaming through the Forum. We have been here before it if it weren't for the Rick Steve's' tour book in my hand I wouldn't have been able to appreciate what I was seeing. Having just been to Ephesus, Pompeiii and The Acropolis, I have had the pleasure to visit these important excavations. The Roman Forum is BIG with it importance. You do need either a tour book or tour guide to appreciate this site.

History coming out of your ears .. Everywhere and I mean everywhere you look there is a little piece of history coming out of the ground ,some are huge some not so but all have a story to tell .One major problem for ourselves was trying to get round with a wheelchair as it simply wasn't possible not the fault of anybody but the original builders .We did try to avoid going back down the hill to the Colosseum (we were there earlier) so followed a road with cars up a hill by the entrance (a hard climb pushing a wheelchair) only to discover it was a dead end with only another church to see. But when in Rome go because you must.

A rip-off with historical significance. Beware that the Forum and Palatine hill counts as a single area and your ticket will grant you only one entry to the whole of it, even if it is a "two-day ticket". There is a lot to see and you will need to walk a lot. It will take you several hours but you can't go outside for a bite to eat and then "return" to see the next area.Only Collosseum counts as another area, which you can visit another day... I think? I thought the information on the official ticket sales' web site was unambiguous but as I learned, apparently not.I do recommend a good guidebook or an audio guide. Some ruins don't look like much but have much historical significance that would otherwise be lost for you. There are very few plaques inside.I was there a sunny day in mid-September, and it was quite hot. For someone from Scandinavia it was like high summer. I wouldn't want to visit in July.

Fascinating - so give yourself lots of time. If you are at all interested in history, there is no way you can see the whole of the Forum and the Palatine Hill AND see the Colluseum in a day. You really need half a day for the Forum and another for the Palatine. The Colosseum will take a couple of hours at least.Please note that the tickets purchased on line that includes all three are for SINGLE ENTRY ONLY. And the Palatine Hill and the Forum are the same site, So once you have left, you cannot get back in.

Take a walk in history. So many things you have to do in Rome, and this is one of the top 5. In fact if you're already at the Colosseum and Palatine Hill, you HAVE to do this. Make time to see it all, there is a lot of walking and tour groups to contend with, if you're going solo on the audio tour. Will take a few hours to see it all, obviously could be done in less time if you hit the highlights only.

No trip to Rome is complete without a visit to the Collusium and Forum. 2000 years ago this was the center of Western Civilization. Today it still gives a clear view of life in the distant past. You can pay to walk among the ruins but if time is an issue the ruins are visible from the street. Not quite the same but pretty close.

Historic Experience at it's best!. Remains of the Temples of Saturn, Vesta, and Castor & Pollux give one a good sense of the power of this place- ons can imagine the rest of these great buildings and what they must have looked like. Arches of Titus and Septimus Severus are also great examples of roman Architecture. One can picture Romans walking here 2000 plus years ago! Amazing. Be aware that during the summer months, it can be very hot here, but there is a water spout for drinking on the grounds. If you do the Colissuem, this is also a must see, and right next door! Been here twice and would go back again!

Must visit. A must visit. The ticket for colosseum should cover entry to the forum, and palatine hill too, and the queues here will be far shorter, if at all, than that for the entry to the colosseum. Don't underestimate how much there is to see in here. From the various arches, palatine hill, the temple of Saturn and much more you will want to spend at least a couple of hours in here.

A must see in Rome. I was here right after my visit to the Colosseum and the area is big! much greater than i first thought. Very much history and many different sites to see. Had no guide here but it worked well anyway, and there are quite a lot of info to read on the signs at the various sites and buildings. Admission was included in my ticket for the Colosseum, the Roman Forum and also the Palatine Hill.Well worth a visit!
Brilliant. This place is amazing. You will need to spend at least three hours going round. We visited at the end of September and it was very hot, Just a brilliant place to see.

Facisinating even after 20 visits to Rome.. The Roman Forum is a treasure trove of important historic ruins that shouldn't be missed if you are interested in architecture of ancient Rome. By examining the exposed brickwork one can get an idea of how these buildings were built. It is great to get an idea of the actual scale of these important buildings from 2000 years ago and you can still enjoy the nice proportions of these buildings.

A must do. very very interesting site. Loads to see. It's well worth checking out YouTube first though. Search for Roman forum reconstructed, loads of film showing the forum in its glory days and helps you to understand what it was really like in its glory days.

Excellent!. We enjoyed visiting these ruins as much or even moreso than the Colloseum. This is a walking adventure through the ancient city ruins, go at your own pace. Wear comfortable shoes that can navigate unlevel grounds. Not crowded at all, while the other typical tourist sites were very crowded during the same time period.
The old way. Get a sense of how the old days of Rome were. Use your imagination to recreate what happened in there day to day activities.

Walking tour nightmare. Very interesting walk through ancient Roman ruins. A vivid imagination is needed to experience the total effect. I would suggest reading up on the forum before visiting and bring a map. The incessant groups of tours stopping midstream and contesting or just plain stooping pedestrian traffic is insane. All the guides with there little flags or umbrellas take away from the experience. Buy the audio guide and walk at your own pace.
I love it. I love it to visit this ancient Roman village, with arcs, squares, markets and houses from that time, everything clean and lovely.

Great experience. I read some of the bad reviews and can't believe some of the complaints. This site is 2000 years old and it's still there! Can you name other sites this big in the middle of an urban area? It's remarkably preserved and with some imagination you can still see a lot. There are signs along the area that tell you more about the different parts. Don't be fooled by people who tell you there aren't. They were probably too busy sulking about small things to notice. The experience was amazing and I enjoyed every second of it.
Beautiful. A must go when in Rome, so much history of a fallen empire, so much to see you could spend hours here.

Must see!. You can't miss this place when you're in Rome. It's right next to Colosseum, so it's a perfect opportunity to see both Roman Forum and Colosseum! You can also reach the forum from Piazza Venezia. This is an amazing place with a lot of history.
.. Historic... a lovely place to take a romantic walk in the sun and absorb some history and beautiful sights..And bargain once you get free entry after being in the colluseam..

Incredible!. We were on a tour of the Colosseum, Palantine Hill & the Forum. A definite MUST when in Rome! The ruins, the history...breathtaking! One cannot even imagine what it must have been like living there back in the day.

Beautiful worth a visit. The only thing wrong with the forum is the fact it is next to the Colosseum and over shadowed by it but it is beautiful in its own right for sure again the tours are a good idea so you get extra info about the site but not essential, plenty to see and do.

HOT BUT INTERESTING. It was a very hot day when our group walked around the forum but very enjoyable. Our guide explained the history behind all the building's without being over the top. There are quite a few exits and we got lost so make sure you know which one you came in from. Recommended and take some walking shoes. There are a lot of fountains in the area which you can drink at.

Incredible sights, must do.. The Roman Forum is a large sprawling expanse of land that was once the center of Rome, a gathering place for people, market place, religious buildings and civic center. this must have been a spectacular sight back then. Today it is an open area with ruins, columns and pieces of buildings scattered throughout. Since there is all open, there is no protection from the weather. In August it was very warm and sunny. Hats are recommended, and a bottle of water. The Forum can be reached from Piazza Venezia and the Coloseum. Incredibly you can walk thru and amongst all these ruins. The hop on hop off bus will not leave you in a strategic position to reach it easily. A must on your trip to Rome.

History <3. This place was literally breath taking for me. It was so amazing feeling to walk on those same streets that the Roman aristocrats use to walk thousands years ago.I could not stop dreaming about all the events that took place there.Highly recommend you to visit.
A must see. This is an amazing place. When you look among the ruins, you get an idea of life in Ancient Rome. Don't miss this
Ruins everywhere. We had a nice time walking among the ruins. The Forum connects the Colosseum area with Piazza Venetia. No metro anywhere near you once you leave the Colosseum area.

Time Travel From a Distance. If you're in Rome you will have your plate full of things to see. Make sure this is one of them! You can not walk through the Forum but you can walk around it. I caught this attraction at sunrise and was mesmerized with how the structures captured the morning light.

Amazing ruins!!. Such an amazing area packed full of ruins! Many people only go through the area just next to the colloseum, but it continues over the hill with lots more. A bit of walking and steps on the hill portion, but worth it. Purchase a book that has what you see and what it use to look like, we did and it helped us envision the area much better.

Magnificent...but needs to be tourist friendly. The views are awesome.But experience could be better.Its a huge area for walking, not advisable for seniors. There are multiple paths but u are not sure u can exit once u take acertain path..its not very interconnected..u may reach a dead end and may have to walk back all the way to find an exit.There is just one toilet which is very filthy.There are maps at few points..but they are weary...and the " u r here" parts have come off on most maps.Thankfully there is chilled tap water available at some points, but im not sure of the hygiene part.
Interesting with a tour guide. Interesting to get the history, not s massive amount to see good location from the colosieium need the guide to explain the history

Must See Tour of Ancient Rome. The Forum is a must see for first time visitors. The 12 Euro fee for Palatine Hill, Forum, and Colosseum is well worth it. The Palatine hill encompasses a large expanse. There are several well preserved areas that give you an idea of what life was like for the upper class Romans of old. Continue on to the Forum to see the center of ancient Roman life. Temples, shops, and meeting places give a feeling of the importance of this area to Roman life. The Colosseum is fascinating. Read the signs - lots of great information. The ruins require some imagination or a good guide book to visualize the glory that was Imperial Rome.

Unbelievable. You can let your imagination run away with you as you wander around the forum. Pretending to be a gladiator, an emperor or a vestal Virgin!!! Make you you get as high as you can too, view it from above, simply stunning!

How did they do accomplish this?. Going back in time thousands of years, I stood in wonderment how the ancient Romans were able to accomplish so much without the help of modern city planning and building technologies. Amazing.

Difficult to understand without a guide . Such an important place, but so little done by the city to guide the visitors. Of course they charge you mony to get in, but it feels as if they are trying to force you to take a guided tour or else you will get no explanation obout this amazing site.

Roman Forum for History Fans. The Roman Forum is huge, which is good since there are huge numbers of visitors in it. Luckily they're spread out over the Forum itself and the Palatine Hill, which is part of the same site, with your ticket including both, so you're not shoulder-to-shoulder all the time.I am a history buff, and had done a lot of reading on Ancient Rome before we went. But even so, there is a limit to how much time you can spend on one site like this! I took the audio guide, and after an hour and a half I had only visited a small part of it, not even half of the Forum itself. Take the time to explore how the audio guide works, and pick and choose what you're interested in. There is a map on the screen showing all the numbers on the tour, plus you can see pictures of things, click on them and hear about them.Seeing things like the Rostrum, the Arch of Severus, and the Temple of the Vestal Virgins was amazing. But the more you know about it before you go, the better you'll be able to decide which parts of this massive site you want to spend time on.I found the Palatine to be of much less historical interest, but it has a great view of the Forum from the top.Your ticket to the Forum and the Palatine includes the Colosseum. Buy your ticket at the Forum (no line-up when I was there) and go there first, and you won't have to line up to buy a ticket to the Colosseum.
Magical ancient place. Breathtaking ancient piece of well preserved history. It's in the open without shade so grab a hat. Watch from pickpocketers.
The oldest place in Rome. Wonderful remains of ancient Rome, unbelievable how this was build ages ago! Also beautiful to look at from the top of the Palatino Hill

Amazing. Very nice place to visit with lots of different exhibits, from ancient to medieval buildings. Can be combined with Colosseum (single ticket) and it should be preferred as you can skip the line to the latter this way.If period of visit it summer (or sunny at least) you should have a hat and a bottle with water (which can be refilled at the taps available).

Mildly interesting. Its interesting if you are a history buff. I personally did not find it as interesting as people claim. Ensure you hire a guide if you want to truly enjoy it. You can buy a combined pass for the Colosseum & Roman Forum for 15 euros.
Spellbound . Such beautiful memories of visiting this place . It should be a must visit place . Just next to the colosseum. You forget the outside world once in there.

Interestiing place to have a walk and learn. if you enjoy walking and learning this is great outdoors, water available place to to get out of the sun a great way to get a feel of the size and how people lived in our ancient past

A marvelous step back in time.. You can see how the ancient Romans lived and governed. The United States has named and patterned much of our system of govenment from the Romans. The Roman Forum has many restored buildings and edifaces from more than 2,000 years ago. This site is informative and awe inspiring.
Really interesting. Enjoyed history facts and scenery. A must do attraction in Rome Our guide was excellent! Thanks Noemi!

Remarkable. Very inspiring and makes you think a lot about ancient technologies and building methods.
Beautiful place

One of the best places to see in Rome. One of the most interesting places in all of Rome. It gives you a perspective of size and scale of what Rome was like back in the day. I liked to just sit in many different places and just daydream of being there
Very interesting!. You could easily spend 3 hours or more just roaming around looking at all the ruins. Combo ticket with Palatine Hill and the Colosseum. We used our Roma Pass. A must-see in Rome!

An amazing step back in time. We visited the Forum in September 2015. We had a guided tour with Gartours The guide was great- knowledgeable and added so much incite to what we were seeing. The Forum was not over crowded and was a great walk through the ruins.

Lots to see. There is a lot more to the Roman Forum than meets the eye. We found ourselves wondering about the forum in the gardens with fuse for much longer than we actually spend on the ground. The area commonly seen from the street and the Coliseum only requires about 10 or 15 minutes. We have ever spent nearly two hours one in the other parts to the south in the East that provide some very good views. Make sure to check out the heights.
Pure history. Pure history! Definitely worth seeing and walking around where 2000 years ago the emperors walked! I would recommend to take a guide you get a lot more out of it!!

Very nice afternoon activity. I would really recommend this visit on the joint ticket with Paletine Hill & The Coliseum. Book before you go to avoid queues & leave a good 3 hours for your visit. It is best to get the audio guide as this means you don't miss anything out.
real history. Go to the Roman Forum early in the morning before it gets busy and hot for the best opportunity to envisage what it was like in ancient Rome.

interesting. it is amazing wandering around the ruins and gives an excellent insight into what it would have been like in the roman times. Once you pay for the visit to the colosseum, this ticket also gets you into theforum but you must go within 24 hours,

Spectacular. Did this as part of a tour and it proved to be a real highlight. This and Palatine Hill were just amazing. Could easily have spent the entire day just walking around these wonderful ruins. The history contained within is overwhelming. At the end of the day I felt as if I had sensory overload: so much to take in. But so glad I got to experience it. As with the Colosseum, either do a tour and then stay on or else get there early: no fun in standing around in a LOBG line waiting to get in.
Stepping back in time. Amazing historic site...a must see! Walk the adjacent Palantine Hill for great views of the entire Forum.
Forum. Great variable length visit - no matter how tired you are stop here after your tour of the Coloseum.
forum. It was very hot ,we sat on a bench in the shade before we started the walk lots of interest there to keep you busy , you follow the crowds for way out ,all u need is good shoes and water
Fascinating. We spent a fascinating couple of hours wandering round the Forum. We arrived at 9.30 on a Sunday morning and used the entrance near the Arch of Constantine, no queues at all

Must see when in Rome. No one should miss this. It is such an essential part of Roman history. Buy tickets in advance so you don't have to stand in line. Better yet, book a private tour - more costly but the added information is well worth it.

Roman Forum under the stars. The Roman Forum is near the Colosseum. We went on an evening tour of the Colosseum and a portion of the tour gave us a brief history of the Forum. We did not walk through the forum due to lack of time. (only had 2 days in Rome).
good walk. a good walk around these grounds will work off all that ice cream you would of eaten. will take about 2 hours to do, but worth the view from the heightest point.

Marvellous part of Roman history and a visit is a must!. This was old Rome and is in close proximity to the Colosseum. There are many very old ruins here and you could get a feeling of what old Rome must have looked like.I was particularly Interested in where Julius Caesar was cremated. I have always had an Interest in him and his life.The history is astounding and a guide would be well worth while to get the best from this visit.This is a place that should be visited if you love Roman history.Really amazing how civilised the Romans were when we were still savages!What did the Romans do for us? Lots!
A LOT of history. Seen after Palatine Hills and Colesseum. Worth the walk. Be prepared to walk a lot. See as much as you can.
Wow!. Expect to say "Wow!" Followed by "Wow!" again! Definitely worth a visit. We were amazed of the structure and engineering of the buildings and learning the history of this site.
Summer visit. We visited ...in August and even tough we were tired..the heat wasn't so bad...but perhaps you should go there first thing in the morning..that way you all be relaxed ☺

Very pleasant walk in time!. You go there with the ticket of the Coliseum. It's very pleasant atmosphere! As it really big, the people spread out and it is pleasant to walk around and enjoy the history. That was the downtown of ancient Rome with a lot of imagination you can go back in time.

Don't skip Palentine Hill. The views and sights are wonderful.. This is a "must see while in Rome. You can get a tour that includes ancient Rome and the Colosseum which I highly recommend. We booked through Viator. I enjoyed this more than the Colosseum. Lots of walking, but well worth it. Photographers will enjoy this opportunity.

Did it with a stroller, bumpy but doable.. You can buy tickets on the official site for the colosseum and get Acevedo to this place and the colosseum. It's very cool to walk around the ruins and see all the old temples, houses and streets. We did it with a pretty sturdy stroller (rubber, air filled tires) and it was a bumpy ride with a few up hills. So be cautioned. But if you have a decent stroller and aren't afraid of a little hard work its totally doable.
Must see in Rome. A must see while in Rome . Best to purchase combination ticket to colosseum , forum and palatine hill on line to avoid lines .
Recomended. Beautiful, you walk and feedl transported to the past! We took a walking tour, the Guide was very excellent, then we went t again by ourselves, we took our own pace , we loved too!

Roman forum. Requires a lot of walking, some uphill; Buy a twofer ticket her which includes roman forum and colosseum. guided tour earphones though is not a twofer, and have to be returned at the forum before going to colosseum. Lines here are shorter than colosseum, so it's one way to beat the long lines at colosseum. Hop on hop off stops here.

Take you time for it, it is worth it. Roman Forum is worth seeing if you like to spend some time outside and also enjoy the historical site. We visited it right after Colosseum (we had combined ticket with Coloseum). It took us some time to go all around but it was worth it. The view from Palatine hill was very nice. We regret not taking the audio-guides since we were wondering about few things and did not know much about them. It was still a nice afternoon with wonderful opportunities for taking photographs.

Interesting and Impressive!. We joined a guided tour which included the Colosseum, Palatine hill and Roman Forum which is highly recommended to get the extra details and information about the historic sites. The tour takes max 13 participants and in the Roman Forum we were only 4 which was awesome. (A&A Tours). Very interesting!

Hire an audio guide. Incredible history! Definitely go to forum and palatine hill before Colosseum- very short lines for tickets and then you can avoid queue at Colosseum. Takes at least 2 hrs to walk around and listen to audio guide. Plenty of shaded spots to stop for a rest so take a snack with you. Ensure you have plenty of battery and plenty of memory available on your camera - photo opportunities galore! NB if you hire an audio guide (recommended) you need to return it where you entered into forum - longer detour compared with normal exit which leads you straight to the colosseum.
History comes to life. The Forum is much larger than we expected. One could wander among the ruins for hours, or see the highlights in 30 minutes. No lines for admission.

Hopefully better with a real guide. We rented an audio guide and tried for some time to figure out where to start. We ended up just walking around using the guide a few times when we accidentally discovered a place with information. The audio guide is not worth the money and effort. Instead we used the rather limited information given by a few signs. I think this is one of the few places in Rome where a guided tour in worth spending the extra money on.It turned out that the ticket was valid for two days. However having just gone through the exit we were informed that you were only allowed to enter once per site (Forum and Colosseum). So we did not see that much of the Palatino hill as we had just excited for a cup of coffee.
Amazing . You can spend hours here strolling through the ruins of the fora romana. Lovely view from up above af the Palatine Hill

Get a tour!. As I mentioned in my review of the Vatican and St. Peters, get a tour for the Colosseum and Roman Forum. Tour groups are ushered in quickly to the attractions and others not on tours have to wait in line for the tour groups to pass. The money spent is a good value considering the time it takes to enter and the guides are very good in explaining the highlights for both attractions. We booked with “Around Rome Tours” and they were extremely good and organized.

The Center of Life in Ancient Rome Not to be Missed. The beauty of the ruins of this most famous landmark has given inspiration to artists, authors & the imagination of visitors like myself. I sat there daydreaming of "Forum Romanum" & what took place there.
