Use your imagination!. This is part of the ticket you buy for the colosseum ( Buy it on the internet to avoid the queues ) No need to have a guided tour for lots of money, just book you audio as well and you can take your time to see it all at leisure, same applies to the colosseum!!
Mrs. Absolutely loved the forum. Could spend hours there wondering about the place imaging how it use to be.

Loved it. Had an amazing time! Wish we had gone on an actual tour. So much history, I'm sure we missed out on alot of it. Be prepared to do alot of walking. Much bigger than I had expected. But so worth it.

you will survive regardless of crowds. This is just unique and huge (and this is why you survive crowds) that you must to see it. Of course prepay on Internet to skip the line. (you will buy it with Coloseum).

Blows your mind!. Plan for plenty of time. The forum is one the most spectacular places to visit anywhere. Bursting with ancient history and you can wander around it and sit on steps of temples just like senators used to. Fantastic!

Best to use a tour to get the most out of your visit.. I would definitely recommend taking a tour of ancient Rome. The tour guides are extremely knowledgeable and will give you all the history and stories about the different buildings. Out tour was booked as part of a package with a land/cruise tour.

palatino hill overlook. By having a guide we learned more of the historical data around the set up of the Forum, Palatino Hill. It is a must see to visit the garden of Paltino Hill as they are very distinct.

So much history . This place was stunning so much history, 14 euros entry includes the colluseam too and palatine hill so not bad on price, could do with some more pictures though on the information boards to show what it would have looked like 2000+ years ago
Fabulous. Excellent. This historical site is amazing. Wouldn't have missed this. The price is included in the cost of entry to the Coliseum.

wandering around and always finding something else interesting to look at.. The entrance to this is included in the entrance fee for the Colosseum, and it is a 2 day valid ticket, just in case you have enough walking done for one day. This is lovely, when we entered we thought lets just walk through to the exit and go, but found ourselves wandering around and always finding something else interesting to look at.
Loved it.. Unbelievable tour.But be warned, lots of walking on steep incline to reach the top.But well worth it, the history was amazing.
Great!. Even though we haven't been inside it looked really nice. Thankfully we had great weather so we managed to shoot some cool pics through the gates.
Walk through the times. Amazingly full of history spot in amazing full of history city! Must do and have the sensation of walking back through time! ABSOLUTE MUST and worth coming to Rome for it
Roman Forum with City Wonders. Amazing, so much to see. Went with City Wonders tour guide, which was fantastic, so much information.
Roman remains. Very nice roman buildings. Interesting to see how much remained from Roman times. Needs walking it is a big area.

Historic. The forum is a collection of ruins of some of the most important government and temples of Ancient Rome. It is one of the areas in which some of the more historic events transpired. It would have been stunning in the past and now it is just an epic. It would take about a one hour or two with a lot of walking to fully appreciate the forums as there are a lot of side tracks to explore. With some really old temples it is definitely a must visit for the history's buffs. It is also the entrance to palatine hill. It's sad that the forum is not lit up at night as it would make an amazing sight. The forum is a short walk from the colosseum and it is recommended to do both on the same day.

The History. To think of all the history that has taken place. The ruins need a little imagination to picture what they looked like 2000 years ago. Still my wife, who is a non-historian, had just as fun as I did taking great pictures with all the old columns and ruins. We were able to get in free with our Romapass which I would highly recommend, especially if you will take public transportation in some form. Paid for itself.

So interesting. This was an amazing experience walking through the old Forum and seeing the way the town had been set up. We enjoyed the information plaques and the opportunity to have some space around you to appreciate all that has gone before.

Forum Romanum. "The Imperial Forums" of Caesar and Augustus."Ruins of ancient Rome, for me the nicest, the impressionest and gloriously place of all in Rome ! -- Rome, developed on a site on a river (Tiber) where volcanic outflows had producted a group of hills in the close proximity. Square Rome, of the Platin Hill in front of the Temple of Apollo, was a good omen in founding a city ... -- It was this year in april 2015, that Rome celebrate his 2.768 (years) anniversary ! -- Romulus & Remus were on the Platin Hill nutrished by a wolf - ( so a legend) .Palatin, the most richly hill, here was born Augustus, live Cicero etc.- Temple of Venus and Roma, was on Velia Hill in a.d.135, Velia once of the 7 Hills of Rome, hill between the Palatinhill, l'Esculin and the Forum Romanum. Also between the Colosseum and Trajan's Markets was removed for the Viadei Fiori Imperiali.From Velian Hill begins the "Via Sacra", it was the oldest avenue of Rome (with big stones), which traverse all the Forum Romanum, from east to west.The Colosseum, was built by Vespasian in year 72.You can also visit the Mamertinum, (prison of St. Pierre and Paul), (old humide (grouft), stone grot in ca. 3 m ground.- You see rest of Saturn temple; Saturn was the mythic God of Italy, on the golden age of Rome.- Very nice to see : - The Arc of Titus ( 81 after J.C.  - the Arc of Septimus - Serverus - the Arc Konstantin Arc. Ah Roma !  Rome, the Eternal City !

Very impressive but crowded. I suppose this was the core of old Rome. It makes one wonder what our world would be like if Rome had not fallen. The level of their civilization, engineering, architecture, culture and political life is remarkable. We're not that far ahead today except for the benefits that the concept of 0 and an arabic numbering system provided. There are a lot of people visiting this place and you'll get bumped for sure. It would be nice if they provided a little more background information at each of the major remaining buildings but then I suppose that would rob the many guides of their livelihood. There are viewpoints outside the forum on the eastern side that actually provide the most comprehensive view. I would suggest that as an alternative or complimentary activity.

Awesome. A great walk into history and to see how the Romans lived. A must visit as you will get to understand the history of the Romans and how the heads lived. Great to take pictures just make sure that is sunny for stunning pictures and make sure you get a guide to walk you through the entire forum.

A lot of old, very old stones, if you like that sort of thing.. Maybe I had had enough of seeing a lot of the same bits of broken and incomplete structures by the time we visited or maybe it was just the heat, but I didn't find this any more interesting than any other site in Rome. The small areas of grass were most interesting seeing butterflies, dragon flies, bees and small lizards. The fact that the structures had lasted so long and survived earth quakes was impressive. The cost was OK, we had paid in advance as part of a deal and used the time before entering the timed slot for the Colossuem to browse around. There were some signs up describing the exhibits. The most stunning was 4 pillars of purple rock as we left via a side gate. There are no refreshments available.

All that history and Latin I studied at school paid off!. I have always been fascinated by Ancient Rome - studying Latin for 5 years certainly helped - so I was always going to love a trip to the Forum. We went on Sunday when it's free entry. I had no need of a tour guide as I had my trusty Forum book with overlays of all the ruins showing how they looked in their hey day. My kids like me are fascinated by history and mythology so we just explored every nook and cranny we could get to and read about everyone of them if I didn't already have a story to tell from my Latin class days. Don't rush this place. Sit, look around and just imagine what is was like 2000 years ago. Move to the next sit and do it all over again. Wear comfortable sturdy footwear as there is a lot of uneven ground to explore but make sure you do just that - explore. And do it at your own pace. While tours can give you a lot of info, they rush you through and you can miss the time to stop and let what this place is really sink in. Get a souvenir book - Rome Then and Now was my go to 35 years ago and I found a new copy at a bookshop at the Vatican that I used on this trip. It took us around the forum at our own pace.
Do your research. Its best to go as a tour so you know what you are seeing otherwise it looks just like brick and morter.
Great insight into the past. This was a very interesting place to visit and once again to marvel at what they made so long ago! It gave an insight into how they lived many years ago.
We were visiting Coliseum and decided to visit the Roman Forum at the same time.. Historical site....interesting. Took metro from Roma Termini, only a couple of stops. Restaurants nearby.
A Must See!. Loved it but then I enjoy the history of Rome and all the old structures. This is also a must see when you visit Rome.
Nice on a summers day. lovely way to spend an afternoon on a sunny day. Make sure to wear sensible shoes and take water with you. Value for money as joined up with tickets to collosium

Don't miss. You have to go there to have a good general view of how emperors lived in Ancient Rome. The magnificent temples are amazing to see, th Palatine Hill is an excellent place to recover your strenght. Be prepared to walk, don't forget to wear comfortable shoes, because terrain is somewhat irregular and sometimes rocky, you don't need to buy water on the outside, there are plenty of fountains for you to drink from or to refill your own bottle.

Sunday's are "Free" !!!!!. We turned up on a hot sunny Sunday quite happy to pay the price as we love this part of Rome......to our surprise, Sunday's are free.So off we trotted into the sun and wandered along with hundreds of other tourists soaking up the awesome energy of this place.....so much better than the coliseum in our view !There are many places to sit and soak up the history or watch the lizards chase bugs on the rock walls.As we have said this is a wonderful exhibit and would love to return one day !

Stunningly evocative. Jaw-droppingly awe inspiring of course, but without the right guide you will miss so much, both visually and intellectually. Our previous guide had inadequate English and spoiled our morning. Our guide for the forum was the opposite. He made what was always bound to be a wonderful experience into something really special. Lesson learned: Don't buy a ticket till you have listened to your ACTUAL GUIDE talking.

Refill water within the Forum. I hope it was just the language barrier, but the English speaking clerk at the ticket office told me I needed to buy water from the guys selling from their sports bags near the entry gate. As it turned out, there were many places to refill water bottles within the park. Very hot, so we were buying a water bottle each day and refilling it several times - saves a fortune! Poor advice from staff member who appeared she couldn't care less about customer service. We used a self guided tour in our Rick Steves Rome book, so felt no need to book a guide, and gained a lot from seeing this fantastic site.
Must See. Must see!!! Just the fact that this architectural site exists is mind blowing! Our guide explained so much of the history here that it was a virtual sensory overload...in a good way!

Unbelievable!. Even without a guide, wandering the grounds was amazing. There are lots of signs in English so you get an idea of what you are looking at but it is best to go with a good guide to really understand the history and use of the Forum. There are fabulous 360 views from the top of the hill and, of course, on the far end you can see the Circus Maximus. You look at the ruins and wonder how they ever built these fabulous structures that have lasted for centuries. The church, the temples, the gardens, the pool, everything is just incredible. The breadth of the space has to be walked to be appreciated. Definitely a must see when in Rome.

A must see. This site was fascinating.it was so interesting to see structures and columns that were built so many years ago without the use ot of modern tools. Probably a good idea to read about this site before you go so you are familiar with its history.

Bring a snack. Very interesting place with loads of history, but no option to buy any food once you are inside. If you plan on walking around for a while, bring a snack! It is located right next to the Colosseum so it is great to combine the two attractions.

Steeped in History. 1. Get a guide (We didn't)
2. Read up on it (We did)
3. Come with atleast 3 hours to spare (We did)
This is personally a better experience of Rome than even the Colosseum.

A waste of time unless you understand what you are seeing.. Strongly suggest that you have a good guide who can explain the different buildings and structures. Without the explanation, you might see it as just a bunch of old stones and pillars, whereas the facts are fascinating. Much bigger than I expected and many more buildings. Avoid the peak times if you can, so try to go early or late in the day, before or after the tour bus crowds.

Bring a picnic. Worth a look in, but arm yourself with as much water and food as you can carry. There are plenty of quiet shady places up on Palentine Hill to picnic but sadly whilst there are many water fountains there are (understandably) no food stalls. So bring your own and enjoy the great views

Another gem to visit while in Rome!. Be sure to wear comfortable walking shoes! The tour guide will provide the information for your imagination to take flight. I always thought the chariot races took place only in the Colosseum - great education! Try to take a couple notes or record some of the tour. When you get back to share your trip with friends it's easier to refer to some notes - good for the photo tags too!

Must see when in Rome. Combine with trip to Colosseum. Must see... this is what Rome is all about. Ruins, archeology, history. Have a good guide book or guide to really understand and appreciate the history and significance of the Forum

Interesting and historical. Brings back things about roman history I had forgotten from school days.. Everything is so ..old.. You can't help but think about the people from those times and their productivity to build things on such a scale with the equipment we have today
got to see it. did this with a tour company and well worth it for all the history and jumping the queue and then wander around afterwards.

roman forum/colosseum tour with dark rome tours. visited here with husband for his birthday in august , went with dark rome tours was a very interesting visit with loads to see, fantastic view`s of the ruins etc with the tour guide's explanation of what went on during the roman times etc just amazing to see it as it is and trying to understand how different life would have been then.. if you get the chance its a must see, visit the roman forum from there we went to the colosseum tour just amazing ..

Must see!. Must see when visiting Rome. Very impressive! Do not book guided tours. Get your ticket at the Palatine entrance, no queue when we were there at 10.30. Combination ticket is valid two days.

Must Visit. The ticket that covers the Forum and the Coliseum is good for two consecutive days, and includes Palatine Hill. The Forum and Palatine Hill are considered the "same" attraction and cannot be visited on separate days. Purchase the tickets online in advance to skip the lines. There is very little shade, and on a sunny day it can get very, very hot. Bring water and a brimmed hat. The history that lies within these ruins changed the world in so many ways.

Its a nice beautiful little walk you must experience. Tour guides will teach you plenty of interesting facts about the roman forum really interesting to see what it once was a almost two thousand years ago

Palatine hill over looks the chariot racing arena and a great view of some of Rome.. The history of this place is truely amazing. Be prepared for a lot of walking and as this place can take a day on its own to see it all I would advise taking some lunch with you as there is no where to buy any. There are drinking fountains which provide fresh water so take your botlle and fill up. We walked for hours so a comfy pair of shoes is a must! A little tip is that the ticket for this place cover the Colosseum as well but it is a once entry for each location.If you like history this is the place to go, well worth a visit.

History - right before your eyes!. Very incredulous to walk the grounds imagining what life must have been like back in the days. If only the walls could talk. We didn't do any of the tours or audio guides but were very happy with the information boards throughout the grounds.

Wow!!!. We were advised by Luca, our B&B owner to visit the Forum before the colosseum as the ticket allows entry to both places and the queues for tickets are shorter, he was right, no queue. What he didn't mention was how amazing it is. We spent hours there and were amazed by how much has survived through centuries. Incredible!!!
Well worth the walk. The Forum is part of the Colosseum tour; it takes a while to walk round but the ruins are worth visiting

Historical Roma. A wonderful walk through Roman history. Purchased combo ticket for Forum and Colosseum online to avoid the ridiculous long lines. Although the crowds were horrible, you could still stroll at leisure and take in as much as you prefer.A must to see in order to appreciate the history of this city.

My Favourits Site In Rome. This place above all others impressed me most and really gave me a feel for ancient Rome. I would advise a tour guide, and viewing the projection show (which is a little pricey at €15) across the road at the Forum of Augustus at 9pm. Fascinating.
a lot of walking. This place is very large and requires a lot of walking including up hill and stairs. There is alot of history here enjoyable but exhausting.

A lot 2 See. Your ticket for the coliseum gets you in here as well. You could spend a day seeing the odds and ends here easy. Not an afterthought after the coliseum. Your ticket is good for two days. Use it wisely. Great pic opportunities here.

Very impressive. Amazing to see so much Roman history. Such a large area. Seen at its best advantage looking down from Palatine Hill
Definitely one to visit

Fascinating - like stepping back in time. There are different levels of history here. It is important to get a guide that knows it. We chose Joy of Rome, with Francesca as our guide. It was well worth it. Informative and enjoyable.

It rained. I got wet. Still enjoyed.. Great if your interested in history. I got caught in a thunderstorm and got soaked but I loved it however I can see others got enjoying that experience. Get a combination ticket with the Colosseum and palatine hill for better value. Oh and the water in the fountains is safe to drink, take advantage of the roman water!
Better than I Thought. What an amazing landmark still under reconstruction! Don't miss this and see it from the top of Palatine Hill
So much too see, so little time.... Loads to see, so ensure you leave enough time to see everything. Stunning site with great views over the coliseum.
The best site in Rome. Loved this whole area. The forum is a stunning part of Rome and an essential area to visit. We took a good guide book and the information boards also informed a great visit.

History alive. We had the benefit of a very knowledgeable local guide, who escorted us through the Forum after visiting the Colosseum. It is spectacular and overwhelming. The number of temples and related buildings, in ruins and in restoration, is significant. Do this with either an excellent guide or a very good guidebook, or you will miss very significant information and shortchange your experience.

Awesome....from a height!!. While we really enjoyed our tour along with the tour of the Coliseum it was only when we went to Palatine Hill and saw it from a height that we really appreciated its scale and where we were in the scheme of things in Rome. This is such an awesome city and we felt so priveliged to be able to see all the things you go to Rome to see, we are very lucky indeed.

Very interesting. We went to the forum before the colosseum as the queues for tickets were short and we could use our ticket the next day to go to the colosseum which was a good way of doing it.The forum is badly labelled etc as lots of people have said but it is amazing , have a read about it beforehand and admire the roman build skills, the use of concrete , the carving , all the things that made the romans so advanced.Take water and wear a hat , it got very hot, although there are water fountainsyou can drink from which are cool and refreshing.
Stunning, historical location. Fantastic, a must see when visiting Rome. A beautiful, historical area that is gorgeous just to amble through at leisure.

Try to visit this along with Palatine Hill and Colosseum all together in one trip.. One of the best places for soaking up Rome's history. Such a vast array of Roman runs full of interesting buildings/temples/ancient walls. Wonderful attraction
Great Tour. This was included in our Colosseum tour and was very interesting, Hearing all about the history of that time and explaining myths.

Rich in history. Very interesting to see all the ruins and it's very apparent how rich the country was/is. A must if you are a first timer in Rome. Disappointing that you can't go in and see them all up close (couldn't see a way in anyway) but the view from the MASSIVE celebration building is perfect :)

A funny thing happened to me on the way to the forum..... Saw this along with toiur of Colosseum and was well worth it. It is quite a big site and it is up and down so have your walking shoes. Did this is late August and the weather was hot so have some water with you as you can't buy any inside. Some great sights to see from the Circus Maximus tp across the city to the arches and the other historic buildings.

Great view. This ruins require a guide or at least an audio guide. There a lot of buildings that need explanation. The pine trees look amazing, and if you climb the Palatin hill you can have a great view about the city and at the Colosseum.

I am glad I went but was not overwhelmed. Perhaps it was the cold and fever I had or the fact that we went on the hottest day in Roman history. I enjoyed a brief look. My daughter would have spent the whole day here. It might be my illness and the heat. A bit hard to find the entrance. It is across the street from the Colosseum.

Wow!. Wow what can I say this was another amazing sight to see and the size of the place was immense. To see a lot of the structures still standing and trying to imagine how they built everything is truly remarkable. After taking all this in have a walk up Palatine Hill the views are amazing looking over the Roman Forum and Rome.
Good on a dry day , ok on a wet one.. The centre of old Rome , one gets an excellent idea of how people lived and prayed and ruled way back in acient Rome.

Impressive!. The areal is so huge and it is so interesting to see how the old Rome looked like. There are signs everywhere so you know what it was you are standing on. The stadium was the most impressive to see (for me). Avoid the time before 3pm because the sun is really burning. There is shade around the area but still to hot around noon.The palatin museum was interesting as well. If you have the time take a look inside!

Forum and Colosseum together make sense. Why many people ask. Understanding who lived here and why the area was such a settlement and what was going on at the time. I like a local guide who can walk and tell me history. I understand it better. You will also understand what happens in history when old ruins building are left behind while a city moves on. Very much like today. Look at areas that a city leaves behind and it becomes run down. This is just the same just 1000's of years ago. Wow life does repeat itself. Enjoy your trip and see both on the same day.

Historic ruins. The Roman Forum is a must visit when in Rome.I love the history so it was a brilliant experience for me we had a guide that told us all about each part if the Forum.If you don't want a guide there's plenty to read And look at.I could spend hours there it was brilliant.

A Must See.. Steeped in history . Buy a Rome Pass this allows free travel on the bus and tube and some local trains It also allows free entry into some sites and museums. The Forum Palatine Hill and Colosseum count as 1 visit.

Almost nothing there. Historical, yes, but boring. I feel really disappoint with what are left of this "ancient wonder". You should have a glance on the book, "Rome, then and now" (I think it's sold quite popularly through the city souvenir shops), to see how much are left over. Almost nothing. Very primitive pillar, some broken grounds, total lack of guide, so visitors look at the ruin they don't even understand what is what. In the illustration book, the Roman forum is amazing, yet in reality, only 5-10% they can preserve.Anyway, a plus point is that if you don't want to queue in a long line to buy ticket at Colosseum, you can buy the ticket here (valid in all sites). And at Roman forum it's much less crowded.

You like history or not... We enjoyed walking around the forum while waiting for our time to go to the colosseum. Make sure you wear a comfortable shoes since there is a lot of walking to do. Though, it is a lot of ruins but it makes the history of the Roman Empire come alive.

AMAZING - PURE AND SIMPLE!. Looking thru my record on Tripadvisor, I am a little concerned at my percentage of "Excellent's" and "Very Good's" as opposed to lower ratings. But credit has to be given where credit is due - and this is one such case. It is made a little easier here as this is not a modern facility which is being assessed but something inherited from way back when.When one things of the limited facilities and tools they had "way back when" (apart from an unlimited supply of slaves) the Forum is even more remarkable. The structures (even where they haven't quite managed to stand the test of time" are amazing and the stories that were trotted out by our excellent guide brought the place to life.I can't agree that it is better to take a tour through the place on your own - I felt that we experienced far more listening to someone who had obviously spent a lot of time learning the history than struggling through on our own (a guide's license is an essential - so check on this). Our experience was made all the better by being in a small group of 11 so we really got "individual" attention.Bear in mind though, that the place is busy (very) especially on a Sunday when the Sistine Chapel is closed and tourists head toward the Forum and Collosseum. But once inside the crowds thin out, especially up the hill towards the palace.Don't miss either this or the Collosseum - although as a tourist those 2 are probably top of your list anyway!

Amazing for all of you History fans. You can actually feel the ancient vibe around you, almost as if you're there in the ancient times. amazingly preserved and lots of information available on the signs, just make sure to bring allot of water if it's a hot day! also, it's recommended to buy the combined tickets to the Colosseum.

A bit of history. We were here on private tour so we get know all the history behind it. Very nice even if you stroll through it yourself. I think that was great value generally but since it was first Sunday of the month we get in for free which make it even sweeter deal. Great hour spend in that place.
See both the Colosseum and Roman Forum together. Colosseum and Roman Forum make a great afternoon activity. hard to fathom that the ruins have been around for for 2000 years

Walking through history. Wonderful place to visit, you really are walking in history! The architecture is amazing, and the scenery and vies are worth the track up the hill. Very hot in summer so take water and wear comfortable and sturdy shoes, the ground is quite uneven.

History. Plain and pure history. You can almost smell the roman life walking around the forum. I fall in love every time I visit the roman forum because it gives me so many emotions, both culturally, artistically and aesthetically.

One of the best sites in Rome!. I found exploring the ruins in the Forum to be very interesting, if you're smart you can avoid the huge tour groups and end up with parts of it by yourself which is worth it! All the tour groups seem to take the same route so avoid these and you'll get some peace and quiet and some time to actually take in the splendor of the site.

History of Rome. The last of the few standing monuments of Ancient Rome this is a place all persons interested in history will not want to miss. There are fairly good descriptions at the site. We had an archaelogist who gave us a good tour and explanations. Visiting without a guide will be of no use as it is difficult to visualise.
History. This is the birth place of what we call modern government. The arches and history are wonderful. Stop by and take in the view and history.

The " must do" tour in Rome. This is a must if you visit Rome.You need good walking shoes as the paths are often cobbled or existing Roman roads.It is fairly steep in parts but worth every single step to walk these historic streets.There are fountains to replenish your water bottles and toilets at the entrance.The views are spectacular.It is worth going with an organised tour to explain what you are seeing.It is something I will cherish always.

Walking with Caesar!. We walked all over this area and found so many amazing historic places and took many great photos.It is hard to believe tha we werewalking in ancient Rome. Caesar walked here. Unbelievable!

Must see when in Rome!. Absolutely remarkable over the top history in a feW hours. You can not top this anywhere on this planet. Never could one imagine such history could be so well preserved for so long. thank God I brought a FILM camera!

Exellent insight into the Romans. Laid out over quite a big area this is one of the must see tourist spots of Rome, we had a guide who took us round and it was well worth it. Theres lots to see and it is amazing what is there.

Wow. Just WOW!. The Forum was so beautiful and has such a rich history. It is terrible that it was plundered for building other areas in Rome, namely Christian churches. You can envision how it would have looked and it is impressive even now, as ruins.

Hang Out Where Caesar Did. There is a plaque commemorating the site where Julius Caesar was cremated, but he used to spend leisure time here, along with other Roman leaders. You can get a good view of many parts of the Forum for free as you walk about this area of Rome, but it is worth paying to be able to touch and see up close the remains of what was the centre of the civilised world, and experience the sense of grandeur first hand. A very thought provoking site, should not be missed.

ROma. amazing place with beatiful and old buildings , which was saved very well.
I want to come back and to see one more time this places.
Unforgoting moments and history memories placement.

A walk through history. I went on a walk through the roman columns as apart of a colosseum tour I got. It has such different variations of history throughout and should not be missed. It has views from all angles and I would suggest you bring a good camera.

History. To have been at such a hiatorical place make one humble and thoughtful.
When we visited it was very few people and it made it extra special.
Come. Feel. Think.

L'antica roma. L'antica Roma is what you'll find overhere. We paid €14 for a skip the line ticket forum romanum, coloseum and palatine hill. And we had best feeling at the forum romanum. The real "old" Rome.

Walking in history. It was very hot whilst we were there so didn't actually do all of it sadly. What we did see was awe inspring when you consider how they lived back then. Its hard to imagine just how magnificent it must have been when the building we intact. Hope we get back one day, but a little cooler next time.
Ruin. Not much to see in this place because all was ruined but it makes you to study about this place and old roman traditions
Amazing History. Walked through and was amazed at the ruins. Amazing sites and really enjoyed the history of the area.

Lots to see. We took a guided tour because we didn't know a lot about the forum. There is a lot to see and learn about. Some of it just looks like old buildings and some of it is well preserved. Its on a large piece of land so be prepared to walk a lot. There is a bluff with a view of the ruins below and Rome that is worth going to, just to see the city. There are places to get water, and I recommend you take a bottle to refill. And refill whenever you see one because it might be a while until you come upon another.
Amazing place. Amazing place well worth a visit and allow a couple of hours to take in as well as the colosseum. Easy to get there via hop on hop off bus.

Interesting but........ I enjoyed the roman forum but it was chaos the day we went and this spoilt our experience, There is a lack of information for people to read and they expect you to purchase head phones or a guide . I wanted to wander and enjoy. It was also very hot which didn't help.

Make your old Latin books come alive!!. Walking in these ruins allowed us to take in the grandeur and vision of ancient Rome. We marveled at the use of marble and stone from many different countries, the frescoes and beautiful sculpture.

Very Enjoyable Area of Rome to See. This was one of our favorite areas to walk through in our 3 week stay in Europe. So much history here. We downloaded the free Rick Steves tour on our iPhone and listened to it as we walked, was a nice cheap way to learn more about the area as we walked at our own pace. Highly recommend it.

Impressive Ruins.. If you have got more than three days in Rome, consider buying a ticket (combi ticket with Colosseum) and spend a few hours at the Forum.Impressive is to see (mostly) imagine how the old Rome must have looked.A bit disappointing is that you're walking between ruins, or even less than that.If you've got less than three days, take a walk along the Via dei Fori Imperiali and have a look from the outside for free. Be creative, there is more to see for free than you might expect. Take the Via di San Petre in Carcere at the NW side of the Forum to get magnificient views over the site.Also look at the opposite side of the Via dei Fori Imperiali, where other remains are definitely worth a short visit.

A must see!. We spent pretty much a whole day wondering around. Only expected it to be a couple of hours but there was so much more here than we realised. Free on a Sunday too (or the first Sunday of the month), or in with the Colosseum ticket.

Great tour and very informative.. We toured the Forum as part of a Colosseum tour. Completely worth the price. We learned so much history and escorted to each ruin. Be sure to upgrade your tour to the Colosseum. We booked with City Wonder through Viator.

Roman mastery. The Roman Forum covers a large area and has a lot to look at. There are signs explaining some of the ruins and it is a easy to walk around. The site is very interesting and it is hard to imagine the size of the buildings when they were complete and the fact that most would have been covered in marble. The forum is included in the Colosseum ticket and Palatine Hill. We were told we could visit them over 2 days and that is what we did. Well worth a visit.
Breathe in the history. awe inspiring when you think of the history & what lead to such construction & subsequently the destruction. Art & Architecture in abundance

A Rome must do.. Must do in Rome. Very busy area. The ticket you buy to enter the Roman Forum also includes the Colleseum and Paletine ?Hill To avoid the ques buy your ticket at the Paletine hill enterance. Hardly anyone goes there and likely to be no que at all.

So much history. The Forum must be visited when you're in Rome. It contains ruins of buildings spanning hundreds of years of history. We visited as a family of 4 (two teens) on a hot day in July. We went first thing in the morning, which was good since it is very exposed to the sun and hot. We had a guidebook and used that to read about the sights we were seeing and imagine filling in the blanks. I think a guided tour might also have been good option. Going with no information would probably be boring, since there aren't many signs. We spent about 2 hours exploring the Forum, and stopped by as well for pictures another time or two while we were in Rome (it's centrally located and we found ourselves nearby often).

Great site, good ticket price/deal. Great site with the most amazing Roman ruins. A bit busy with group tours but the it is a must see in Rome. A ticket is 12 euros and gets you into the Forum, Colloseum and Palatine. Great value for money.

You have to visit the Roman Forum. I cannot say enough great things about Rome, Italy, it is a beautiful country with fantastic people. I love the experience in seeing all of the old buildings. I love anything about the history of a country.

Surrounded by history. If you go in July as we did then take something to cover yourself up with as you go around as your outside the hole time remember plenty of water as well another attraction well worth seeing if your into the history of the place
History first hand. Another wow place on the list of tourist attractions in Rome... we enjoyed the sense of scale and history.
Very Impressive. Amazing look into ancient history. Located near the Coliseum in Rome, it's worth the walk through these ancient ruins.

Interesting, history, beautiful. Very interesting, especially if you book a guide that explains everything. My recommandation is to book a tour to visit both the Roman Forum and the Colosseum. It's a half day tour for both together.

Very cool. Love everything about Rome but in particular the Forum ruins. Amazing to think about the history and all the debauchery that took place in this setting. The Palatine is just up the hill and Coliseum is next door. Get there early!

Think. Passing the Roman forum just makes you think about all the conversations that may have gone on there. The politics, deception, conspiracy, betrayal, and scheming. Even better is that it is free and there are bleachers to sit down.

Worth a look around. Definitely worth a visit if you've already paid for a ticket to the Colosseum as they're a few minutes away from each other. Quite a lot of walking to do. Nothing bad to say about it but not really my cup of tea, especially in the heat.

Wonderful Like Stepping Back In Time. Even my husband, the most reluctant traveler,could not help but feel the timeless beauty of the forum. You have to stand there and admire all the architecture and think of all the ideas about government that started here that are still in use today. Very easy to get to and don't think you would ever be tired of visiting here!
Cool excavations, lacks any signage. There is very little signage here which means learning about the ruins is not so easy. Otherwise an obvious must see in rome.
Must see. This is a great part of Rome to visit - it really gives you an idea about the ancient city, and the scale is breathtaking

History...<3!. Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill are simply magic places... You just must visit them!My favorite one was Roman Forum, not much left there, but you can use your imagination and feel the atmosphere of this place...Capitol Museum was great too- especially the original Capitoline she-wolf.Good piece of advice: every first Sunday of the month you can get there without any fee! As well to all museums and any archeological touristic spots in Rome.In any other day, fee to visit Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill is €12 per person.

Must visit place in Rome.. This is one of the most fascinating ancient Roman sites in the world. Allow plenty of time to see it all and take plenty of water with you... (It gets hot) Get a good guide book or you will miss much. The ticket gives you entrance to both the Forum and the Coliseum and it says it is good for 2 days, but... You only get into each place once. I went to the Forum late in the day and didn't finish. Next day I couldn't get back in again! Tip: Early in the Forum and do the Coliseum the next day!

Antiquity--one of the reasons we love Rome. Magnificent samples of antiquity--one of the reasons we love Rome. We did this the first time with a guided tour, which informed us which building was what and its significance, without keeping our face in a guidebook.
awesome . Alot of walking on uneven surfaces, was good seeing all the ruins, go to the roman forum after the Colosseum it's easy to do both in same day,
The mother of all parliaments. The mother of all parliaments.This is where the parliamentary principal of all democratic nations started, a system of government "by the people, for the people".
Well worth a visit. Quite a lot of very interesting architecture and artifacts over quite a large area . Only a few yards away from the colosseum so easy to do both in an afternoon.

Walk back in the past. We visited the Roman Forum, yesterday. We bought the tour online before we came to Rome via Viator which included the Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. Well worth doing as you skip the very long lines and have an informative guide. The tour took 3 hours but flew by because it was so good. However the tour didn't feel rushed. The Roman Forum is very old and you have to imagine what it looked like all those years ago but our guide showed pictures to help you imagine the Temples, Shops. Arenas etc. definitely well worth a visit

Amazing..!!!. If you buy a ticket for the Roman Forum you can also use the ticket to enter the Colosseum either the same day or the following day. The ruins are simply fantastic, we did not book a guided tour but simply went around by ourselves. There are some spectacular sights to see and well worth the 12 euros.

Breathtaking . It was an amazing visit. Will make you a little tiered as there is a lot of climbing to do, so many steps and a lot of area to cover by foot. Wear comfortable footwear and take out at least 1.5 to 2 hours to visit this amazing place. The entry free is very reasonable and value for money. Take a bottle of water with you, as it's mainly outdoors and it can get very hot this time of year.
Best in Rome. No other place in the city can you see as much history as here. We walked by ourselves, though the guided tours are supposed to be great. Go early!
First time in Rome . was amazed at the size of this site. Great price for ticket, 12 euro for this, Coliseum and palatine hill. Very busy however so worth visiting

A must see. The forum was the center of life for Rome during its glory years. There is much to see. We used a self-guided tour (downloaded fro free!) which helped much. The best and easiest (shortest lines) for entry were near the Arch of Titus, which celebrates his conquering of Judea. As we walked down, we pass the Basillica of Constantine, (at least remains of it!) which when complete was truley immense. Its importance lies in the fact that future Christian cathedrals were based on its design. Other key sites included a visit to Caesar's Temple, where he is buried according to legend, It is the place of Marc Anthony's famous funeral oration. The Temple of Antonius Pius (2nd century) was later taken over (as were many other temples) as a church. The Curia (Senate) building is also quite breathtaking, located near the Arch of Septimus (2nd century).Don't miss the chance to walk up from the Forum to Palatine Hill, with a wonderful view of the entire Forum complex, with the Coloseum in view as well.

Hard to find from the hill . The entrance to Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum is through a gate down the road from the Colosseum, only you walk for at least an hour to get through Palatine Hill to see the Forum. The remaining structures are impressive and gigantic. Love the history of it all, but not the crowds.

An amazing historical site. The Forum is absolutely stunning! To see so many historical buildings so close together is amazing. I recommend booking in advance (in the ticket which includes the Colosseum). I also recommend getting the audio guide, although we picked and chose which parts we listened to. As I was on crutches, it was a bit of a challenge to get around the Roman Forum, but I managed and the staff were really accommodating at the entrance. There is very little shade in the Forum, so I would definitely recommend wearing a hat. We stayed for 3 hours and still didn't manage to see everything. We only made it halfway up the Palatine Hill. I would recommend getting to the Forum quite early if you want to see everything, including the Palatine Hill. One of the buildings to which tourists have had access was inaccessible when we visited, but there was still plenty to see. It's definitely worth visiting the Roman Forum.

Overshadowed by the Coliseum, it has no right to be!. Exceptional value, €12 will get you entry to here and the Coliseum. It was recommended to me from guides books and friends to go here first as the queues are never long and it gets you straight into the Coliseum thereafter. It gives a great tour through the history of the Roman empire, through various ruins and structures left over from the various dynasties. There is also a great view of the city and of the Coliseum - much more worthwhile a view than from inside the Coliseum itself. Be warned it is a lot of walking, take a bunch of water (maybe some food) as it is a good few hours worth of journeying, not including the museum inside. I did not visit the museum myself and still spent over 4 hours wandering throughout.
A must visit. They say the visit takes about two hours, but reserve more than that. It took us almost four and still we believe we haven't seen everything. The hole complex is just amazing!

Pay and walk inside or walk around outside for free. Palatine hill or roman forum. Buy ticket here for euro 12 skip the crowds as this covers both the roman forum and the coliseum. The roman forum or palatine hill is huge and open air so go in morning when not too hot. Or free from walking around the outside.Preferred this to coliseum. Better value too although ticket covers both. But requires some time.

Not built in a day.. The ticket for this also includes entry to the Amazing Colosseum and the Palatine hill. If you have any interest in history you must visit the Forum, as it was once the centre of one of the most powerful civilisations ever to exist. From the ruins it is hard to imagine what it must have been like in it's glory days and it is probably best to have a guide (Audio or human) or a good book on the subject. To think of the great Emperors and Generals who must have walked those same streets is humbling. Give yourself a good few hours to look round and take some water with you if it is a hot day.

A Must See!. The forum is simply amazing. We spent about 4 hours here and could've easily spent the entire day here, soaking up all the history. It is a lot larger than what you first see walking in, as you climb up the hill to Palatine Hill. Once you reach the top of the hill there is a whole other "city" to roam. There is a small museum with even more ancient history to see. There are plenty of place to sit and imagine what Roman life during the empire would have been. Although we didn't have a tour guide, I highly recommend one. A few times I overheard a few of them talking and wished We had booked a tour to gain more insight and knowledge. Make sure you have comfortable shoes, water and snacks if you plan on staying a good amount of time. It is also quite dusty so long pants and socks are advisable.

Walk where Caesars used to walk..... The Roman Forum gives you the opportunity to Walk where Caesars used to walk....this is a place you can feel the power of the emperors. The famous ones have gate that was built to honor them and you can go and see the beauty of them.
History lesson at its best!. The forum romanum is definitely one of the must sees in Rome! It is great for a walking tour, but can be quite exhausting on a hot summer day.

Combine with Colosseum. The Roman Forum is a must-do in Rome. Rich in history and full of wonderful sights. We bought an audio guide (removed the headphones for better audio) which was a nice addition to the experience. TIP 1: Be sure to take a bottle of water with you when the temperature is hot. When empty, you can fill the bottle with water at numerous water fountains. TIP 2: Buy a combined ticket for the Colosseum and the Roman Forum at the Roman Forum entrance on Via di San Gregorio. The queue at the Colosseum is much longer.

This is amazing place and I think ever better than Colosseum. Prepaire to stay in the queue, there are lots of other people, but when you get inside the area you can enjoy several hours these wonderful history pieces and took lot of pictures. I think this place is my favourite in Rome.
The seat of the modern world. That it still exists is amazing. The scale breathtaking. And to walk the same paving as Cicero, Cato and Julius Caesar brings them to life.
Must see...!. When in Rome a must see. Several restoration projects ongoing at the time. We did Rick Steves audio tours. The history is amazing at the center of the beginning of Western civilization.

Roman Forum - One of the best places I have been :). One of the best places I have ever been to. 2000 years of history in 200 meters. Could spent all day here. Tip: Buy tickets at the entrance of the Roman Forum, the Colosseum and the Palatine Hill are included.
facinating. Very good tour.Mornings can get too hot so an evening tour will be more comfortable and less crowded.Take your water bottle with you

History at your feet . Foro Romano is definitely worth seeing when you visit Rome. If you buy a ticket to go to the Colosseum (which you should), an entrance to Foro Romano is included and it's actually right by the Colosseum. Make sure you have enough time to walk around since it takes at least 2-3 hours, but it's worth it! Foro Romano was the main center of the ancient Rome and you can find ruins of many important buildings there. It has a certain feel to it - since it's thousands of years in the history of the excavations. Don't miss it when you're in Rome!
Roman Forum. Another must see site on your visit to Rome ... close to the Colosseum ... we had an awesome guide who was well informed ..
Worth a visit. If only to say you have been. We had a guide to tell us all we needed to know without it I doubt my appreciation would have been so great

Okay . I would advise considering visiting the Roman forum if you've already bought a colosseum ticket, however, it's not worth it otherwise. The hills and architecture are very pretty, however, there isn't much else. This area involves a lot of walking up hill with limited sign posts as to where you are going - it's very easy to get lost! Purchasing an audio guide may have made the experience better, however, when we arrived, they were sold out. (There was a bunny in the field that everyone seemed more interested in than the rest of the tour so I think that says it all!)

Must do when in rome. Booked skip the line tickets through ticket bar. No issues getting in. Went up Palentine and walked around Roman forum. All very interesting. Can be very busy. Loved every moment of it. Would go again.

Lots to see!. Spent hourssssss in here. There is soooo much to see! Heaps and heaps of Roman remains. Right next to the palatine hill. Which itself is covered in things to see. Would recommend taking water and spend a good few hours wandering round.

Well worth the visit. The Roman Forum was another amazing experience although we made the mistake of visiting this on the same day as the Colosseum and with the temperature approach 40 degrees it was very uncomfortable. However, I would highly recommend visiting here, there is a good couple of hours in it.
Roman Forum - free on Sundays and so is the Colosseum. don't forget to take advantage of touring the Colosseum and the Roman Forum next door for free on Sundays.

Great but needs a clearer direction to follow to get around. An overwhelming amount to see and confusing as to where to start. It is very impressive, but we seemed to double track a lot, even with a guide book in hand! Perhaps a tour might be recommended for the area, although it gets very busy with the hoards of tours and not time to wander on your own. Ticket includes Colesseum also- get there early to enjoy without the crowds. Have seen you can download Rick Steves audio guide to phone before you go, but saw this afterwards- maybe worth a try.
Ancient Rome. Well worth a visit. This is close to the Colosseum and Palatino Hill, so you can visit both places at the same time.

Busy and fascinating. This is a full days experience if you take your time to explore all the areas of this historic area. Stop and take in the history and it comes alive, not just alive with the many tourists! It can get very vary busy, but alive with the insight into Roman life. It covers a huge area and is not the best underfoot so wear sturdy shoes or boots. Only one area to get refreshments at the end so take your own snacks and drinks. There are plenty of places to sit, enjoy the views, people watch and have a break. We would certainly return to visit this again if we are ever back in Rome as its a musytsee historic sight.

A must see. the roman forum is a must see while in Rome. no Rome visit is complete without taking in this wonderful glimpse into the past. i would absolutely recommend a guided tour. otherwise, this may just seem like a pile of broken down buildings & monuments without much meaning. the walking is a little rough, so be aware. there is also a couple of moderate hills & steps.

A must-see part of of Rome!. This was, by far, my favorite part of Rome. Such a rich history here. I highly recommend a tour or guide to get the full history of this amazing place. I also recommend walking through the forum at night - beautiful!

Too much history lessons for one day. It is a good walk full of ruins on both sides I walked from that circle were Trojan Column was all the way to the collusom it is about half a mile walk, but how much stop you wanna make and time you will spend imagining the past it will be up to you.I believe there is good collection that you will enjoy.C U around.
Amazing forum. This is a truly amazing site. Plan on spending the day if you visit the colosseum, palatine and the forum. Take a good guidebook to understand what you are seeing.

What a site!!. This site was amazing to see and so much history. We had a tour guide with Viator Booking and learned so much from Luca. You see so much history that had past though this area next to the Colosum. I would go back again to walk around. If you are wanting to go here I would book a tour guide with Viator so you can skip the line and also learn so much.

Fascinating ancient history. The sheer historical significance makes this a must see sight, but I would advise a good guide to explain the different remains which cover a significant area and time-scale. It is just amazing what the Romans achieved circa 2000 years ago. Avoid in midsummer as too hot.

Loved the Roman Forum. I think this was my favourite place in Rome. Our guide had a photo of how it all looked before and it was great to see original parts still standing. Going higher is better to get good photos.

Get a feel of ancient Rome. Great place to walk around and experience Ancient Rome, I had a guide and that gave me a real insight of how Ancient Rome operated.About 12 euros for entry and it's a journey through time, first Sunday of the month entry is free so food for thought.

You have to visit... I was there in Aug 2015 during my honeymoon trip in Rome.If you visit Colosseum ... you have to go to Roman Forum ...it is one ticket.It was an old spa in the past and it has alot of nice landmark there with very panoramic view.Thete is a palace there which is amazingYo can see the Rome in the top of hill there

So much to take in. We didn't do justice to what is perhaps the World's key Roman site as the weather was just too hot. There isn't a lot of shade (although the Museum on the Palatine Hill as air con by the door!) so visiting earlier or later in the year might be best but if you are there in August you shouldn't miss this site.Best to have some knowledge of Roman city organisation before visiting to make the most sense of what could be a quite overwhelming experience. Tours can get in the way of proper viewing so going to the top of the hill and looking down on the site early in your tour gives a good perspective if you can identify the different buildings below that are then worthy of a closer look at ground/street level.

Insight into what life was like in Rome at time of Emperor's. Fascinating to see. Lots of walking. Water fountains dotted around which is great when it's hot. Buy tickets here rather than the colosseum as the queue is much smaller and the tickets does both the forum and the colosseum.
Make time to really enjoy this place!. This is such a great place , even spending half a day here is not quite enough if you love your Roman history! Do the audio guide it is so worth it!

A must for history fans. We saw the forum from the top of the Spanish steps (across the plaza at the top and around the back of the buildings) at night - very evocative. Also saw it at daytime - really the only comment we can make is the the Forum exudes history - do some research before you go there and envisage the events of the past - it's only a ruin - but what a ruin! So much happened here that resonates right through to the present day - if you're into the historic past you need to spend time here. I love history - if you do as well you have to be here.

Just amazing. Don't miss it.. We bought our ticket here around 9am when there was no line. The €12 ticket provided entry to the Roman Forum, Palatine and Colosseum over 2 consecutive days (one entry to each place). We actually went to the Colosseum first and returned to the Roman Forum the next day. I would recommend this because the lines at the Colosseum were much longer. It was a really hot summer day in Rome - another good reason to start early. There is not a lot of shade here and you will do lots of walking. We took Rick Steves' free audio guide on our mp3 players and explored this truly amazing place for several hours.The bathrooms near the entrance (on the Via dei Fori Imperiali side) were pretty disgusting, but there were other bathrooms further inside that were much nicer.
Magnificent!. A must see place!We were there on a very hot day in August still the place was worth every minute of our time.
Excellent place to visit. Lovely place to walk around loads to see and take photo of, not much shade on a hot day so take plenty of water.
History right in the middle of Rome.. I enjoying walking on the grounds of the Roman Forum. So much history here and right next to the Colosseum.
History Buffs Must Visit. Great experience for history buffs. you will learn lot with a local guide about the reality of the history that went on in the Forum.
Live antique history. One of the top sights in Rome probably doesn't need to be commented. It is part of humanity history and ex-centre of life of great civilization.

Wonderful place. Great ancient area with great history and architecture. Been walking there without a guide and it feels that one would have made the experience richer because the explanations in the signs are kinda dry..

Stunning place to visit if you love ancient Rome. I love this place. You can walk around at your leisure and feel the history. They always seem to be unearthing new buildings/items. Well signpsted and lots of signs with information.

Ancient Rome at its best. Having a guide made this an interesting experience, as you learn about the history of Ancient Rome. It's an easy walk but be prepared for uneven cobblestones. There is a lovely refreshing water source there, for hot days.
A walk back in time.. It was amazing to walk around all of these ancient ruins. It was a nice way to spend a Sunday afternoon.

Visit on the first Sunday of the month - its FREE!. wow, this is a true glimpse of true Rome. The size, organisation, design and layout, it is totally phenomenal. You must see the Forum is a must see.

Great example of old Rome. Excellent example of old Rome plenty of walking on ver uneven ground so bring good walking shoes. There are water spouts throughout so just have a bottle to refil. Several good bathrooms. There are many different ways to learn about it as you go. Download a pod cast and just listen

free on 1st sunday - usually 12 euro pp. My third trip to Rome so I wasn't planning on entering the Forum but a tour tout mentioned that entry was free that day: always free on the 1st Sunday of each month. Which also explained the large crowds around it, The tout estimated that the line was 30 - 4 minutes, but we had time, got in line and entered within 8 minutes.So much of the Forum is now inaccessible to visitors ...

Friends Romans Countrymen et al. Well this is where so much of Rome's history was enacted. A not to be missed visit. So many temples and other historically interesting buildings. A not to be missed experience when in Rome.

Probably should separate from the other attraction. You go through so much at the other attraction and then to come here you're drained and if its summer you're exhausted and there is little to no shade.

Great fun . We had great fun clamouring around the Roman forum. The lack of signage wasn't as bad as we'd been led to believe, although I did take some additional literature to help figure it out. Absolutely amazing to be able to walk in the footsteps of such an important piece of history.

Informative. We visited the Roman Forum the day after we'd toured Pompeii and climbed mount Vesuvius! So we were very tired and also had just spent t the day looking at very "in tact" buildings. Obviously the forum is lots of levels of building remains. We did a tour with Viator so we had a guide with audio which was very welcomed as we had no thinking to do and the guide was able to explain what the different locations were all about. I'd say this area requires a lot more imagination to understand than others but such a significantly important place to see.Very busy with lots of people around but some incredible facts to learn about and see. Use a guide!
Wow. like stepping back in time, really peaceful experience in a very busy city. Dont miss it if in Rome!
Amazing journey through time . Amazing experience with our tour guide Sev Borzak who took the group on a time travel journey from ancient Rome through to the Renaissance and modern times.
Can't be Missed. This is where all the action happened in Ancient Rome. Between the Colosseum, Palatine Hills and the Roman Forum, you'll get plenty of education about life during that time.

Interesting to walk through . We bought combined tickets for this and the coliseum (€12 for adults, free for under 18 EU citizens) and took a walk through. It was really hot weather but there were water fountains inside. Could always take a picnic and enjoy the sights while eating (no shop inside). We probably spent about an hour inside.

Walk in The Emperor ' s Footsteps. We did this as part of an organised tour, it is incredible to think that you are walking in the political area that once ruled one of the biggest empires known to man. There are lots of information boards to read to get background information and there is at least one restroom, the ground surface is uneven so good shoes and care need to be taken, take plenty of water it can get really hot there and just take your time and drink in the past.

Huge place, be prepared to walk. Very interesting and you learn a lot about Europe. The thing with this was the shear size of it. Having been to Pompeii I expected similar but it's much more of a ruin and therefore more imagination is needed. It's well worth a visit and you need to be willing to walk and take time. We didn't have a guide and there is limited information inside, though there is some. It could spoil it though if there were too many signs. Queue wasn't bad but it was August.
Don't miss.. Must see when in rome. If you are interested in Roman history this is a must. Just to wander around and imagine what this place must have been like in its pomp.
Rome trip . Beautiful. The place is where the history of Rome lies, this is a must do for people who love history. This is close to the colloseum to walk.

Bring bottles and a snack!. You can fill up the bottles with drinking water at several places over the site, and if the sun is shining you will need it! The Forum is only a small part of the whole site, bring comfortable shoes and something to snack on (we found no cafeteria), because you will want to spend several hours there!
Adjacent Colosseum. Just sign up for a 2-3 hour tour of Colosseum, Forum, and Palatine Hill. Colosseum is the best part, but all good. Lots of walking though.
Time Machine. A must see while in Rome. You can't help but feel the atmosphere as it was all those years ago. It's sad to see it all disintegrating form the effects of the environment.
The hart of Rome. The Roman Forum is the hart of ancient rome and part of a great archeological site. colse your eyes and imagine you are walking in the time of augustus

Fascinating site to visit. Well worth a visit and good value as the 12€ ticket includes Palatine Hill and the Colosseum. Make sure you buy your ticket at the Forum to skip the huge ticket queue at the Colosseum.
What can I say - It's Great!. The Roman Forum really needs no review. It is old, famous, and a lot of fun to visit. Plan on spending a couple of hours here at least.

Higher than it looks - great views over Rome. Lovely peaceful parklike area. Tour at your own pace. Wonderful and informative museum at the top of the hill.
We used the side gate and there was virtually no waiting in line.
Roman Forum. So much ancient history has been uncovered and made visible to the adventurer looking for unique sights. A guided tour is recommended to get the most from your visit.

A must see!. Tickets for the forum visit come with the Colosseum tickets. You can spread your visit over two days an to see both properly it needs to be done that way.It is a wonderful sight and you can imagine how it was in Roman times. If you don't have time to visit there are points were you can look down on the forum from the road behind the Wedding Cake (can't remember proper name - sorry! ) Best view inside is looking down from Palatine Hill.
Top view. We walked to the overlooking view point and you can see everything. Panorama!!!! The ruins and gardens are breathtaking.

Something to Experience. We booked Hidden Treasures tour with Gate 1 with our pre cruise tour group. We walked the Forum and I learned so much by having our guide Christina. She was excellent. Looking at history for your first time..even if you study about it before going.....a guide gives you so much more. She was so passionate about the history when she spoke to the group. Amazing to see. Highly recommend visiting.

A taste of history. The Roman Forum, part of ancient Rome's city center, is a must for anyone interested in the history of republican and imperial Rome. It is located next to the Colosseum and the Palatine, and the entry ticket combines these three sites. It is best to book your ticket online before your visit, as this will save you a lot of time, especially at the Colosseum.

In the middle of history . If you like history you will love the roman forum. It is like you would be replaced 2000 years back in time. Just walk around and enjoy. Don't forget to bring something to protect yourself from the sun in Summer because there is not much shade in some areas.

You can peer down in for free, but worth the ticket price to walk where captures slaves walked. Walk with the captured slaves along the Via Sacra. See depictions like that of Vespasian brining Jewish captives from Jerusalem around 70 AD, carved in the monumental Arc of Titus. See where Julius Cesar's body was laid and then ritually burned after he was stabbed, as well as temples to Saturn and Apollo. Breath-taking! You can see down in from streets above, but worth it to get up close and feel the atmosphere of ancient Rome.

The Forum is a must see!. Toured the Forum in conjuction with the Colosseum through City Wonders tours. Worth every minute and every penny. It's so amazing how much of this has stood the test of time. We are just a spec compared to how long some of these amazing structures have been standing. Even if you are not a history buff this is totally worth a visit.
Historical sightseeing. Interesting historical sight, good to walk around on a lovely sunny day, magnificent old buildings and sites.
Worth visiting. Visited this place before the Colosseum. The ruins were amazing and much larger than I thought they'd be. On a hot sunny day, the water fountains were a relief.
Must see. The Roman forum is a must see and really close to the Colosseum. You have to pay to get inside, but allow yourself to "get lost" in that place. It's amazing.

The history is incredible. This was an amazing visit if a little hot. Unfortunately our guide, who was excellent, made us very late to finish this tour meaning we had little time before the next one. She really gave us too much information!
superb ruines. not to be missed, its beautiful lots of history, plan to have trainers on because its so big, and water.... the julius cesar tomb is disappointing but so long ago it was nice, enjoy
Remnants of the Roman empire. Amazing to see all the architecture left from the days of the early Roman empire. The columns and temples fill the area, and make you feel the passing of the centuries.

Surprisingly nice place to sit and think. The Roman Forum surprised me, I had low expectations but found it to be a very contemplative and quite place (hard to find in Rome). This could have been because I visited on a particularly hot day, but I sat in the shade and found myself reflecting on the fragility of society and the resilience of mankind.
Historical site. What can I say about it? It's just amazing! It's pure history! Tip: buy a ticket there that also gives you access to the colosseum, you'll avoid huge lines.

Don't go here right after Colosseum. Draining.. Have to appreciate the history of this place but can get tiresome after visiting the coliseum right after. I probably come back the next day. Too much history in a day. Also, the Italian summers are a killer. There is no shade there so don't go in the middle of the day.

Spectacular historical site. Visited here prior to going to the Colesseum. It was a wonderful place and there was so much to see and take in - history at its best. A must see for tourists visiting Rome.

Flashback in time. Must see in Rome, even if from afar. You can get an appreciation of the splendor that was Rome and what had to be done to create these magnificent structures. Incredible architecture. Hot and crowded in August though.

History in Rome.... All open and plenty of ruins to see. Very interesting to see so many ruins from the ancient Roman Empire. The visit will take you back in time definitely a visit to do when you go to the Colosseo

Ancient Rome at its' best. You really have to explore the forum. Spend time walking through and around the ruins and you will be rewarded. Look up so you don't miss the detail on the walls but watch your step as it can be uneven underfoot. A fabulous and fascinating scene, just imagine you are an Ancient Roman.

Several hours of ancient history. The Roman Forum and the Palatine Hall are among the main attractions in Rome. The entrance is very close to the Colosseum and usually the ticket includes all three attractions. For us, this was a day-long activity and it included a lot of walking. Try to have a break and rest a little after seeing the Colosseum and then go to the Roman Forum. If you're fond of history, it's a must see. However, it's quite interesting for regular tourists as well. It's a huge space, with beautiful views over the city.

Be transported back to anceint Rome. Wandering around here transports you back to ancient Rome probably better than anywhere else in the city. A guided tour will allow you to get the most out of it. Like most of Rome's big attractions, do book a ticket in advance to avoid horrendous queues.
Must see with guide. Saw the Forum as part of an Ancient Rome tour with Rome Provate Guides which really helped to understand the site.

Big part of Roman history. First of all I have to recommend that you book a tour during the morning hours,bcs we did it at 3pm (1st the Forum than the Colosseum) and it was way too hot and we barely got any shade or wind. Either that or wear those funny umbrella hats or whatever that can protect you from the hot roman sun. Also, guided tour is highy recommended. Our guide was a native Roman, and we really learned so many interesting facts about Forum and the very beginings of Rome and the way it grew through history.

A walk through history.. I had been before, but still enjoyed this visit (same ticket covers the Colleseum too in the same day), but to really cover it, allow half a day. I think a visualisation of what the ruins looked like, rather than just saturns Temple, would help for a lot of visitors, otherwise, you just look at ruins. Water fountains are around the site, so you can fill up the water bottles free, with clean, cool water (needed in Augusts 30+c temps). The Palatine Museum on paltine hill, which is inside the Forum, has some nice pieces of Roman sculpture.

Amazing!. The entrance fee is included with the colosseum -bargain!The Forum is spectacular, even the approach to it and the Colosseum you sense you are stepping into history- more so than I have ever felt before. You need plenty of time to take in the site, I would recommend taking plenty to drink- when we went temperatures were in the 40's and nearby vans selling drinks and ice cream were expensive.Make sure you leave enough time and wear comfy shoes!
Fascinating!. Part of the ticket for the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. Fascinating!Take time to explore and really get the feel for the way life would have been. A must for History buffs.

not enough time. As I had tickets to coliseum and forum I went here second. The place really deserves an entire day to appreciate what history is there. I did not need a guided tour as there is plenty of information available. More importantly the spirit of the romans lives on here and one gets a great appreciation or the way their life was. This is an incredible find in the midst of a densely populated city and well worth the visit.

Read your ticket! Forum and Palatine = one entry only. Okay, I'm not usually the dumb traveller maker rookie mistakes. We bought our combo ticket early in the morning - good for one entry to the Colosseum, Forum, and Palatine Hill. What I didn't realize was that "Forum and Palatine Hill" was a single entity. We walked through Palatine Hill, left to get lunch, and were refused re-entry to the Forum. Quite a bummer. Once you're in, plan to be there for a good several hours to take it all in! (Bring a snack and plenty of water, though "picnics" are not allowed.)But that said - get the Rick Steve's audio guide for the forum - download before you go and it walks you through great information and stories to help know what you're seeing at each ruin. You can also see a lot from outside the gates if you have to, but assuming you didn't mess up your ticket, it's worth doing it from the inside!

So much history . The roman forum is something you HAVE to see at least once in your lifetime. It's such a touristy attraction that you have to expect to see A LOT of people everywhere. If you are offered a tour from people outside the colosseum, TAKE IT. just make sure they have a tag hanging along their neck that says they have passed the state exam. It'll be worth it!! and everything has so much history that you will appreciate it better if you get a tour. Awesome!!

Ruins next to Collusium. This place is huge, allow a full day. The entrance is included in your Collusium ticket price (if next 1 or 2 days).Fantastic ruins and gardens... Climb to the top of the hill for amazing views across the city to take in its majesty.
Interesting. With a guided tour, this area came alive with interesting facts and information about the buildings.

Beautiful site. We came here on part of a walking tour and it was absolutely lovely! We had a wonderful time walking around with our tour guide and learning about the robust history and trying to envision what this place looked like in it's hay day. This location is super busy (like most Roman attractions), and you are reminded to be on guard for the pick pockets, but if you are interested in history, this is a must-see location in Rome!

An inspirational walk through history!. This was a great part of the day as many people seemed just be racing around to 'tick this off' as visited. This meant that we could amble through the artefacts and buildings taking photographs and really taking in the feel of what had gone before us in history. The information boards were excellent with English translations. Lots of areas to sit and contemplate/enjoy the surroundings.
A must place to be.... Another great place to see, you need to take a slow walk and absorb the essence and viberation of this place it is alive with high energy.be sure to visit, then you decide.

Nicely restored ruins of the heart of ancient Rome. The Roman forum is part of a greater complex of ruins of ancient Rome located in the same area as the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. We found the entire complex very interesting. The visit was somewhat tiring as we visited on an abnormally warm May afternoon.

Stunning site day or night. Another of Rome's ancient spectacles. Try to visit during the day and see the forum in its glory (and to take pretty amazing pictures too) but do visit at night when special lighting effects show what the buildings would have looked like
Historical gem. Absolutely stunning, but leave yourself plenty of time to wander around! Brilliant views from top of palatine hill

Historical spot. One of the most important places to visit, for the historic value and to use your imagination about a place that once was the center of an Empire that ruled almost the entire world and Caesar became a God.
