True Roman History. A must for everyone fascinated by Roman history. Recommend purchasing combined ticket with the Colosseum.

Interesting Complex. This is to be visited in conjunction with the Palatine Hill. Because it is a fairly large complex the number of people never seems to be overwhelming unlike Musei Vaticani and the Colosseum.
Very nice experience. I have visited this place also during day time and also at evening. Very nice laser show. It's a must go in this hystorical place
Must do in Rome. More interesting than the Colosseum. We put a Rick Steve's audio tour on our phones and it really added to the experience.

Give yourself plenty of time!. We bought the Hop On Hop Off as we only had three days in Rome. Part of the package were tickets to the Forum and Coliseum. We started at the Palatine Hill and made our way through a section of the forum. One gets over whelmed with everything there is to see. A little research would be beneficial so you understand what you are walking through. Trying to imagine the amazing structures and functions of the area are difficult when all you see is a rough outline of the foundation and bits of walls. There are some labels but bring a book showing a map of the area and pictures of what the building use to look like and their function. Doing this would make your time more worthwhile, and an incredible experience. Bring water, your camera, proper walking shoes as the surface is very uneven, and ensure you have several hours. The site would be very difficult for walking challenge people or baby buggies. We wondered for two hours and saw less than half of the area. We will save the other portion for our next trip to Rome. I do not remember seeing many washrooms around the site. However, there are facilities in the museum near the top of the Hill. Did I mention PROPER WALKING SHOES!
Worth seeing!. Really neat - went here as part of a tour with the Colosseum. Also went to the top of Palatine Hill - great view and cool history.
Roman forum. Yet another great price of history here. Walk where Julies ceaser walked. See where he was killed. A worthwhile visit.
not to miss. Make sure you get there an hour before close. They tell you it closes at 7, But they will stop letting people in around 6pm.

The Cradle of Rome. Here lies the cradle of the Western world. The Roman Forum is breathtaking. Ceasar's Parliament building (which was not actually completed when he died), the winding roads of red crumbling stone, and the sheer size of the area is awe inspiring. The remains of the Forum are a must-see. When we were here, in the month of August, it was hot! Bring lots of water and good walking shoes. From the Forum you can see the Vatican on the hill and the shadow of the Colosseum as well. It is hard to explain the feelings of standing within the Forum, knowing the history of these buildings.

Must see. . It's unlikely anyone would visit Rome without spending some time at this incredible site, my only advise would be have a tour guide explain the area to you. There is do much history here, it's invaluable to have someone that can point out the main points of interest.

Cool even if you're not into that stuff. I'm not overly interested in history or architecture, but this is still a pretty cool place to see. Don't need ages for it (unless you are overly interested of course!), but the tickets generally included in the colosseum ticket anyway. So go on the same day and follow it with a quick walk up to the Palatine to see it from above, it's just a really impressive and nice setting.

Roman history. Fantastic history- you can so end the day and just get started. Spectacular views in the center of Rome. Close to other historical sites. Recommend hop-on/off buses. Recommend. Take lots of photos.
A must see. A must see in Rome just across the street from the Colosseum.Wear comfortable shoes and buy tickets in advance.

A must see. The Roman Forum is situated right next to the Colosseum. Go there first and buy a pass for both and then you can skip the long queues at the Colosseum as your ticket gets you to skip the line (good tip!!). It is truly surreal to walk through this forum and get an appreciation of how they used to live. Well worth a look!

Amazing!!. This is a must do, we did this along with the Coliseum on a guided tour and it was well worth every penny. You would have no idea what anything is without some one telling you. This was one of my favourites whilst in Rome.
Amazing Roman Forum. What an amazing view te ancient Roman forum provides of ruins from a time, once so long ago. A real piece of history right in the heart of Rome.
St Peters/Paul's Prison. Mamertine Prison is located at the NE forum/Capitoline Hill Exit. Don't forget to visit this holy ground underneath San Guiseppe Church. Small entrance fee to maintain site.

Quite simply amazing!. The Roman Forum is a most go place to visit when in Rome. Although bustling with sightseers it was felt surreal. Make your way up Capitoline Hill to overlook the forum to get a better view of the layout of how it would have looked. Great view of the Colosseum from here as well.
Walking through histoty. Lovely to walk through this ancient market center. Do not miss going to the top of Palatine Hill to get a great view!
Great with Palatine Hill. We first looked at the hill and then the Roman forum. It is a landmark that you must see when visiting Rome.

Again you have to go. We did this area with the colessium, palantine and capitol hills. For anyone interested in the early Roman history it is a must. Julius C funeral prye, the original 8th century bc huts etc et al.
Then you can progress to the jewish area and then through to campio de Fiori for an excellent variety of historic Rome.

Journey through centuries . It is a magic place. I actually forgot about everything, I just felt the past here, all thousands of years, all millions of people, their life's... It is something so fantastic and unbelievable....

Lovely Roman Ruins. Loved the Roman Forum! We had a very pleasant time strolling around the grounds, taking pictures and imagining life there long ago. It is very large and there is much to see. Entrance is right across from the Colosseum. Our tickets that we purchased for the Colosseum [online, to avoid long-line waiting] got us in here as well (also no line or wait.)

Well worth a visit. We bought tickets in conjunction with the Colosseum and Palatine Hill before we travelled, a bargain at €14! After a drinks break following the visit to the Colosseum we ventured to the forum and weren't disappointed, even though the weather was baking hot. Massive amounts of History are everywhere you look and walk, we spent well over two hours exploring the site, finding the information that was provided very useful.

amazing!. amazing! great to know the history of the ruins not just taking photos of it. it can get a bit tiring though, this place is really huge. we went summer so it's really hot. there's a lot of water fountain so make sure to bring a water bottle.

Lovely afternoon visit. Visit the forum in the afternoon while it is quieter. Also use the side entrance as the queue is a lot shorter. Go passed the Colosseum with the forum on your right and it is about 200m up near where the tour buses park.

Another landmark that shouldn't be missed.. One of the many sites that are a must see when in Rome. We actually walked from the middle of Rome to and from this site (we enjoy walking). Took about 40 minutes. The history and buildings of this are just outstanding.
Not to miss!. What to say about Forum Romanum that is not already said. You can not visit Rome and not see it. Just bring enough of water and come early or later in the days because of heat.
Leave time for this after the Palatine Hill area . A fascinating place that needs quite a bit of time to fully appreciate it's history from the neolithic to the relatively recent past.

A beauty..... Probably one of the most authenthic construction (with the Pantheon and the Colosseum) in Rome; one advice: try to visit it with a guide (together with the Colosseum); the information you get gives it all an extra dimension. We, as flemish speaking people, organised a guided tour with "Gids in Rome"....

Excellent piece of history. You can get in with your ticket from the Colosseum. Sprawling, awe-inspiring grounds. Minimal shade. Can be very hot in the direct summer sun. Only a few areas to get water to fill your water bottle.
Amazing history.. To be walking where others have walked thousands of years before is very special. So much to learn about the past...

An absolute must!. By far the most amazing attraction in Rome. You can easily spend all day here. Take water otherwise you can buy for 1 euro from the vendors. Water fountains frequent to refill. Each part is spectacular and unique. Nowhere to eat so take snacks with you.
Roman Forum . Was part of our Colosseum tour and found it very fascinating. Recommend pre booking the Colosseum however if you only wanted the Roman Forum you wouldn't need to.

Amazing and humbling experience.. Immerse yourself in a one of the most well preserved and rich historic sites in the world. Wear very comfortable and safe walking shoes. Treat the place with care and respect and help keep it clean. Best to go in May or late August when the crowds are thinner and you are able to enjoy the place in peace and you can appreciate the space and get the real feel of it's story.Best to get a guide to take you around too - it adds value to your whole visit by highlighting the facts and descriptions of the life as it was.Sadly, that at times there are union strikes by the site operators and they would close The Roman Forum, & The Colosseum without prior notice and for an unknown number of hours or days.

land of roman impire. just walking hours in Roman Forum and Palatin Hill , and back to 2000 years a go , forget the time and enjoy of Colosseum view .think about Gladiators .... best experience in roma
Fantastic. Fantastic place to visit make sure you get a guide as there is so much to know. Allow a good two hours if including Coloseum

AMAZING!!. One of the coolest places I have been to in my life! You can just feel how ancient it all is and takes you back to a different time. Buy the double ticket to the Colosseum here - you skip the whole line!!

Great experience. Excellent place to go to and walk through the roman ruins of temples, gardens, houses, and basilicas. It includes one of the most ancient roman roads that was used up until the modern period. Take a BIG water bottle as there are no shops to buy food or water. Definitely worth the experience, I mean you will be walking where the Romans walked!

Prancing in the footsteps of Rome. I visited the Roman Forum two ways. In the morning, I went on a very hurried tour through the ruins in Roman heat (around 97F). Though we moved quickly, we saw a lot. Our guide seemed to be very interested in getting to her next gig with some of the members of our group, so rushed us through. Later, with a different guide, we did an evening tour with Walks of Italy. It was after hours, so we viewed the ruins from the vantage points behind the Capitoline Hill and walking down the pathway to the Colosseum. This tour was combined with a night tour of the Colosseum and well worth the effort. If you pay to enter the Colosseum during the day, the Roman Forum is included in your ticket. Our night tour did not enter the Forum.

Massive!!!. Just amazed at the size of this place! The height of the Coulombs that are still standing. How did they build them? More info signs about the place would have been useful. Apart from that a great day!

Must do, but highly suggested guide of some sort. If you are not sure what the Roman Forum is, it's a large area when remnants (ruins) or old Rome where many famous and ordinary people did their daily business. This is a very large area and has many ruins....RUINS. Hence you will many times not know what you are looking at. My suggestion, you need a guide. Do not get the audioguide offered at the entrance; it plainly sucks....horribly. If you don't want or can't afford a real guide (they are everywhere, just track one down and ask how much), then a close second option is to download Rick Steve's audioguide tour of the Roman Forum onto your cell phone. It really is a great tour and you will walk away from the Forum with a better understanding.

AWESOME. If you are interested in ancient history this is a must see. I wish I had several days to go through all there is to see. Bring water and comfortable shoes. The weather was good when we visited about 75F, humid, but with a light breeze.
travel to wonderous places in history. Seen from the outside makes you feel as if you are back in the golden ages.Beautiful architecture, beautiful surroundings.

in the heart of Rome. With the combined ticket you can see the Colosseum, the Forum and the Palatine affordable. Me and my friend thought he could visit the part of the holes that you can see from the road, we were wrong big! That part is perhaps one of the oldest but in hours of walking we could not see everything !! Beautiful place, left as it once was, with the original towers and breathtaking views. You absolutely must see the hole!!

Memories of a great Empire. The Roman Forum is one of the most important Roman attractions. Its dimensions and the big amount of remains of great buildings make it an overwhelming site. Don't miss Julius Caesar's tomb!

It's a must do.. Rome spoils you with history literally piled on history but the form is the open air market of all that is and has been great about Rome. You can spend a day here and not realise what you are walking past, sitting on or looking over. The extended area is so much bigger than we thought.!standing up on the hill looking down we saw right across central Rome and heard three different from cola nations of what we were looking at from the walking tour guides. You are really in Rome at the Forum

Very interesting place . We stumbled upon the fact that if you've been into the colosseum you actually also get entry to the forum as well no body told us this it was only by sheer luck that we did or we would have paid again to get in!! Very big site to walk around and I enjoyed it as well but definitely check your tickets as it's also valid for 2 days. Not a lot of shade on the site so remember your water,sun cream or umbrella comes in handy for the rain showers and sun shade really recommend taking one from home very not cheap to buy out there.
..great place... Historical building pieces everywhere! Loved the histories behind this place! Absolutely worth visiting!

One of the expperiences of a lifetime. Find an expat walking tour of the Forum (and other Roman places) (listed on TripAdvisor)and you will get blown away by the descriptions of life as it was then. These guys didnt have LCD TV or IPhones but they were just like us in the way they lived and died. The Forum (CBD area) is magnificent and the ghosts of Romans past bustle around you

A must see. An incredible place and my favourite that we visited in Rome. So many amazing ruins and so much history.Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum come as one that must be visited at the same time as they are in the same area.Allow 1 1/2 - 2 hours I would say. Make sure you have food shoes on and some water.

Amazing!. So much to see and learn. This was definitely a highlight of our trip. The queues to get in were not too long so I would suggest visiting the colosseum first and then the Roman forum. Would definitely recommend getting an audio guide or guide if you can so you can really visualise it .

Astonishing yet scorching and absolutely dehydrating (in july). Okay so this place IS amazing, breathtaking and all the good things you can say about a historic site. It actually is!! But the extreme hot weather in July makes you forget about all that and instead keep asking for water.... The weather is serious. I've never seen so many people laid down here and there at a tourist attraction. So keep that in mind when you plan a visit. PLUS I think it would be great to get a guide(dunno if there is one) because otherwise they all look like amazing and really old buildings.

Lovely stroll back in time. Basically a cool park with ancient ruins like odd massive pillars, foundations and temples. Even though nothing is intact you get a great feel of what it would have been like chilling with caesar.Worth having a look down on to the forum from capital hill or another high point to see the contrast of old and new across the city.Admission included in your Colluseum ticket. Can be used over 3 days but you can fit both in half a day unless you want to read every plac and have a picnic.

Awesome Historical Site. The Roman Forum is situated in the area between Piazza Venezia (a must see) and the Colosseum.I understand that it is considered one of the most Important archaeological sites in the world. The FORUM is the biggest and the most important of the Roman forums and is where people first began meeting at the time of the founding of the Roman Republic. this was the heart of Rome, commerce. The Forum was the original downtown of Rome, and we spent at least 4 hours meandering around the ruins, and trying to absorb that over 2000 years ago, this was a thriving area and the heart of ancient Rome. My wife and I really grasped the significance of the site after buying a neat inexpensive book (8-10 Euros) that shows the ruins, and the pop-up shows the actual srtucture as it was originally built. That really puts the Forums significance in perspective as a great historical site.

Use your imagination. You have to look around and visualize things a bit to appreciate the Forum. But it's a unique experience and a combination ticket with the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. There are rarely lines to by tickets here, because most first time visitors beeline it straight to the Colosseum, without realizing this is basically a skip-the-line entry. Very few people wandering around, you feel like you have the place to yourself, unlike the Colosseum. Take a walk up to the Capitoline Hill for a nice overview. Don't miss it.

Can't go wrong. All these historic sites in Rome are eye candy for history lovers. I am one of those. But, even if you are not, seeing these places in person is a must. The monumental architecture is so worth it!

Roman ruins at its best. Go early as the place get very crowded. Great place for people interested in Roman history. Good shoes are recommended as there is a lot of areas to cover. It is a short walking distance to the Colosseum. There is an entrance fee. Look you for pick pockets. During my visit there, I got followed by some doggy characters for half and hour. I reported that to the security officers at the site. They were not interested. I also heard that two couples have had either their wallet or hand bags stolen. I would not go there again.

Amazing. imaginining he way Rome once stood is almost unthinkable. The grand scale of what the forum was must have been quite a site to see. It now stands in ruins but the schemer scope of the structure is worth a visit.

too much history ,. We just visited after the colosseum as it was included in the ticket. you will have a lot of walk inside between the monuments which talks about the roman history and tells you about their life ,celebrations and meetings. its a nice place to see

Beautiful!. This was one of the most beautiful places in Rome. It's located next to the Colloseum.We took a nice walk seeing all the great architecture and a bit of nature, as well. We were amazed by tangerines being on trees in January. :) Really nice visit.

A journey that takes you back in ages!. A trip to Rome is incomplete if you don't visit the great Roman Forum, the place which once was the seat of huge Roman empire. The place is located next to Colosseum and Palatine Hill and runs across of stretch of couple of kilometers but takes you back in history. It has temples, artifacts, monuments and is definitely a place to visit!

Amazing To See. The Roman Forum is included in the admission to the Colosseum and Palatine Hill and it was our favorite. It didn't take long to see the entire place. We were able to see the entire place from the top of Palatine Hill which was an amazing view and the walk through it which was even more amazing. It was incredible to see these buildings still standing in some shape or form after so many years. Is a must see.

Interesting. Very interesting time. I was amazed when we listened to the tour guide telling us all about all the different structures. It is neat to know they were built so long ago. I loved hearing all the history behind them.

History. The Roman Forum has so much history and so many significant episodes down the years that is hard to take it all in. The center of Roman life and the essence of what it was like to be a Roman came from here. Definitely worth a visit

Overrated. The forum is not really well kept. Though it has an awful lot of history in it, it is not much more than a ruin. With a good travel guide, you might as well save yourself the cost of the entry fee and take a look from outside.

Experiance the History. We all have read in history books about the Roman Empire. The military dominance the Emperors that led it through history and the pictures of the grand buildings with amazing columns at the entry way and inside. All the pictures that those books displayed and articles that we read are nothing in comparison of experiencing it. Walking through the ruins and seeing the layout of how the buildings were constructed and the history that is described as to what materials were used in a given time period and the statues that are still in place in the garden with two ponds. We went in August which was the hottest time on the year so if you go make sure you bring water with you. There are fountains for filling bottles but there may be a long line to get to one. Allow yourself time to be able to read the signs to get a feel of the meaning of each site. There is an elevator at the entrance but I did not see one on the grounds and there are stairs and hills. Make sure to wear shoes that have support on uneven ground and are comfortable. You will walk the same streets that the empire was built on and Julius Caesar walked on. The columns are enormous and even after all the years that have passed several are are still standing. Being able to not only read the history but also feel it and experience it was to us a once in a lifetime trip. You never get to experience it for the first time again.

A journey back 2000 years. An amazing place to visit stretching over 2 or 3 kilometres and with numerous buildings from different eras of Ancient Rome. Reasonably detailed explanations of the various sites is given in English and although the site was very busy, it never seemed crowded..

Must go in rome. Must go, Its fill with historical buildings to visit. its besides the colloseum. very touristy. Get your camera and check when it closes so you can take your time to explore. amazing how the buidlings still stand after thousands of years
Family visit. Very interesting visit. Don't miss Hadrians burial chamber as we did, it's a long walk back up the spiral.

GetYourGuide Skip the Line: Colosseum and Rome Walking Tour. We booked tickets for this tour online and met the tour at the prescribed place and time. The tour is subcontracted to another operator. We were issued with radio receivers and headphones but had to change a couple of times to get ones that worked. Our guide gave us a brief overview and we set off to the Colosseum. Thank goodness for the skip the line tickets because the lines waiting to get in were enormous. Our guide was good giving a good incite to the building as we walked around the second level. There were plenty of opportunities to ask questions and take photos. From the Colosseum we went across the road to Ancient Rome again great to get in quick with skip the line tickets. Overall we enjoyed the tour and found the lady guide (Sorry but I forget her name, maybe Francesca) interesting and informative. I would recommend this company with the proviso they sort out their radio problems. Top tips: bring your water, EUR0.5 from supermarket – EUR2.50 from hawker stalls near Colosseum. Keep your empty bottle as several public water taps on tour route to refill bottle free!

Simply Amazing. Interesting history. Interesting history. You can see the old Roman structures and get a sense of how things would have been back in the day. You can see the Colosseum and the National Monument to Victor Emmanuel II from the top of the Roman Forums. Pretty interesting.

Some good examples of Ancient Rome...some unnecessary ones too. The Roman Forum was a mixture of buildings and pillars which gave a good, accurate insight into ancient Rome, with an equal number of pointlessly laid out ancient mounds of rock and stone which provided me with as much excitement as watching paint dry.This place was nice for some photo opportunities of the genuinely ancient artefacts but unless you have a tour guide or are extremely interested in rocks, a lot of the things here won't stimuate the imagination.

Going back in time. Its not a place with beautiful buildings or entertainment. But its an important excavated ancient roman site and helped historians learn a lot of the way of life from that time.If you just take in the site and imagine how it would have been like, then the place is fascinating!

Amazing to see! . Visited here on a blistering hot day; not much shade about so it got very hot. The site itself is incredible to see and definitely worth a visit. Water fountains in various places make it very easy for you to refill your water bottle. I did not however come across any toilets! Some amazing photo opportunities so make sure you have your camera. Under 26 years old with proof of age and you can get a discount so make sure you have photo ID when buying your ticket!
"Lots of old stones". I only saw it from above, but that was enough for me. It's interesting, but I am not sure that you will need a tour. If you're a history nut, go for it.

If you like history and ruins, this is it.. Beautiful ruins that bring you back in time. Very funny feeling walking down these paths, as if you entered a time warp. Palatine hill offers great views of Rome and worth the extra time. Enjoy.

Not to be missed. Take out a few hours for visiting this wonderful remains of ancient Rome. Located next to the Colosseum, it can be visited in one (half) day. Unfortunately not (or hardly) suited for wheelchairs. No long lines here but I advise to purchase tickets in advance or the Roma Pass (38 euros with unlimited acces tot public transport for 3 days) which also gets you in the Colosseum. We bought our Pass in the square in front of Termini station at a kiosk.

A fascinating look back at Rome. Like most travellers we had the ticket that allows entry to the colosseum, palatine and the forum, which are all next to each other. Feeling rather weary after walking around the colosseum in intense heat we struggled walking around the forum as it is huge! However the many water fountains were a welcome relief. The forum is absolutely stunning and my family found it more impressive than the colosseum - probably because you get more of an impression of what Rome would have been like. Surprisingly, for late July, it wasn't overly busy and we really enjoyed our visit.

Bucket List Trip. Did not enter the ruins as we have both seen many other type of Roman ruins and they all start to look the same. But saying that what we could see looked impressive, and if you have never seen Roman ruins before in would advise going then see them. They are located right next to the coliseum.

Absolute must see along with the Colosseum. While the Colosseum is the main attraction for most visitors, the ticket to get into the colosseum includes entry to both the forum and the palatine hill beside it for the same price, so even for that it would be a visit. Lots of the ruins are well preserved, but still I think the forum would be best seen with some kind of guide (They wouldnt give us audio guides when we were there because it rained earlier that day and they didn't want the sets getting damaged, even though the entire time we were there it was really warm and sunny, and there were no signs of rain whatsoever, which was annoying). Overall the combined attraction of the Colisseum, Forum and Palatine hill was definitely the highlight of our trip to Rome, and something I'll remember for a long time!! Really impressive place when you consider the historical significance of it all, and just as good as you expect before arriving!

Very interesting . Absolutely enjoyed learning about the history behind the forum so glad I had a tour around it still strange to be able to stand next to where Cezar. Was buried and to gain knowledge about the many different uses of the forum some of the history seemed morbid but still fascinating :)

The First Down Town. A colossal feat of architecture. You need to bring a pot full of imagination to enjoy the place to its fullest, otherwise its just a huge archaeological site with a bunch of ruins.I really fell in love with the place instantly. the grandeur the vision Romans had was phenomenal.1 extremely important tip Read about the place or better watch the documentaries about the place and its history to get the eccentric feel of the place.If you do not like history or not aware of the Forums Historical value you can skip it easily.Some tours include Colosseum and the Capitoline Hill but i would suggest to give yourself ample time to breath in the place.

One of the highlights of my trip to Rome.. Less crowded than the Colosseum and many other sites in Rome, this wide open attraction is amazing if you can stretch your imagination. Unfortunately, little of the forum remains intact compared to what it would have been like in its heyday, but you can get the gist of it from the remains with a little internal visualizing. I booked this as a tour with the hill and the Colosseum through City Wonders FKA Dark Rome. This will definitely be more enjoyable with a tour guide. A romantic journey through time for a couple of history buffs, it won't likely impress many modern couples/families with no interest in the past. If you want shopping, then Rome has it, but if you want history, then this is your stop.

Must see to believe. Toured the Forum as part of a guided tour that also did the Colosseum. Guide was excellent and friendly. From an Australian point of view we have no concept of "real" history and how Rome is layer on layer of foundations. This is clearly shown at the Forum.

if you only have time for visiting one historical site, this is it!. The coliseum is crowded and even with a skip the line ticket you have to stand in line twice to get headphones. The forum was easy to navigate and a lot less crowded. There were tour guides everywhere and all you had to do was stand by any spot and you could hear a guide talk about the site. It is quite large and every where you look there is something interesting to see. It is quite beautiful and the photo ops are EVERYWHERE! We went late in the afternoon and ran out of time. We did not know they slowly close down sections before the actually closing time in order to "herd" all the visitors out. We wished we would have explored the out areas first as they were closed to us by the time we wandered over to them. The forum is like stepping back in time and not to be missed.

You need an imagination. When you walk through the forum you'll need an imagination to conjure up the world as it was 2000 years ago. Some people look positively bored in there but not me, loved it. Just to feel that I was walking on the same paths as figures like Cicero and Caesar was enough for me. Well worth a visit and the ticket gives you the Colosseum as well.

Roman Ruin. This is one of the top must sees in Rome when visiting. You are able to get a great view from the road side if you do not wish to purchase a ticket. A combined ticked for the coliseum and Roman forum is around 12 euros. Which when you convert it back in your currency is around £7.50. Most of the site is of ruin, but just by seeing this you can imagine the full extent of the architecture that once stood fully here. There are a few lovely restaurants nearby to have a cold drink after a nice walk around the forum.

When in Rome . This was the political centre of Ancient Rome so is a must see!! The ruins are fascinating and spellbinding! Again book so you're with a group tour to avoid major queues - for example city wonders
Walk through ancient Rome. I loved seeing all of the Roman remains and imagining what the heart of ancient Rome might have looked like. Make sure to see the Forum from Pallatine Hill.

Perfect . We visited the Roman Forum a week ago. The visit was perfect. The ruins have been well preserved. The heat in August is stifling.We really enjoyed the visit as well as the museum. The Roman culture was well preserved.I would highly recommend this site to anyone visiting Rome.

Raw history well worth the visit. Such an interesting place and so full of history. You need lots of time and it helps to get a guide who can explain all the interesting little bits and pieces of history associated with this very raw historical site. We visited late one afternoon with very little sunlight (grey day and getting close to dusk) and still it was a great visit.

Expansive and evocative . Walking around the forum gives s great sense of Old Rome. The signs need updating (some are so burnt they are illegible), but I was grateful to the city for leaving this important facility open to the public.

Not to be missed!. The Forum is the cultural, commercial and political heart of ancient Rome. It is a place when you can walk in the footsteps of Caesar and ancient Romans soaking up the richness of ancient treasures from the Republican era to the late Imperial era of Roman history. Take plenty of water, in can be very hot with little shade to be found.The Roman Forum must not be missed.

Destruction of history. It is undoubtedly one of the must-see Rome sites.Although there are only the remained destroyed buildings, they clearly show its glory time.You must walk slowly around them and try to imagine all the past time. So, you can find its rich heritage.Furthermore, an audio guide (I am not sure if it exists) or a tour guide is recommended.

Magic walk into the past. Definitely worth visiting. An ideal place for history passionates. Do not forget to take a guidebook with you so that you can walk across the forum, read about the ruins of buildings you see and imagine how they looked in the past. If you don't have time to visit both Colosseum and Roman Forum, the second one would be my choice.

Incredible ruins. This is definitely worth a visit, like most places in Rome expect lots of tourists but the ruins are incredible and amazingly designed. It is an inspirational piece of history so take the time to walk there, relax and take it all in! Please note you do not need a tour; it's a good free attraction if you've brought a Colleoseum ticket!

Free views of the Forum. If you do not care to go into the Forum nor the Colosseo, there's a way to view the Forum for free. To me it's a better view b'cos it's a pano view. From the northern end of Via dei Foro Imperiali, theres a side road leading to the Capitolini museum. The side road forks out to one going down to a dead end but gives a flavor of what old Roman roads are like and through the barricades one can have many views of the Foro. Back tracking to the fork then walk the other road up to Captiolini hill to see a pano view of the Foro. If you have a good zoom lens, you can reach views further afield. However, if you intend to visit the Colosseo then buy the ticket at the Palatine Hill entrance, which got no line, then go in and visit both Palatine, Foro and then cross over to a special entrance to skip the line at the Collosseo. Enjoy.
Rich platue. best place to take photo of the roman forum is from the location beside the unknown soldier just walk few steps right to the huge white marble building

When in Rome............... The Forum is yet another place to visit right at the heart of Romes rich history. Very reasonably priced, (and buying tickets here for the Forum & Colosseum combined save lots of time at the Colosseum) you can easily spend several hours wandering among the ruins but it can be very hot, so remember to take water with you. All well explained and so impressive, its a wonderful place to be.

Great historical wite. Great view of colosseum and epic experience altogether. Best to be properly hydrated and prepared to walk as if you are hiking in order to enjoy fully the visit. One day may not be enough to take in the whole area.

its a ruin but.... its packs so much history that its a beautiful sight to see. a lot of variety and youll see how they lived their life waaaay back. its a big place so have fun!!! and its better than the Colosseum.

Allow Time. To do this site justice and take it all in you do need to allocate time. For anyone who hasn't seen Roman remains on this scale before, and that's probably most of us, you need to have a decent Guidebook to appreciate what it is you're looking at and understand it's purpose for being built and role in Roman life.If you're doing the Forum and the Colisseum book the online combined ticket - it's good value for a whole day's trip back into history.

So amazing . You see the history of the world as we know it all in one location, it is one of the best experiences I have hadTalk a tour & learn about the ruins & what they were back 2000 years agoYou need a good 3 hours to walk around & take it all in

Roman Forum made a deep impression. Roman Forum made a deep impression on me. I did not expect that I loved so much to walk there. Despite the crowds of tourists there, everyone can find the most interesting for him. On the Palatine hill I found a small garden with a fountain and orange trees. I also liked the ancient Roman road paved with large cobblestones where Roman chariots rode centuries ago.
This is a must while in Rome. Amazing site to explore.. Amazing site. We spent a couple hours walking around. It is incredible to think about how long these structures have been there.

Worth a visit. You need at least half a day to look properly around this site. You will need sun protection, if the weather is hot as there are very few places in the shade, a small umbrella served us as a sun shade so we could take our time and enjoy this lovely plcae

The Center of the Roman Empire. The Roman Forum is situated in the area between Piazza Venezia and the Colosseum. It is the most important archaeological site of the Roman Empire.The forum can be very confusing to the normal visitor. It is one place that I would recommend you do a little research in its background.You will be walking amount the same places the poor, rich, merchants and leaders of the Empire did their daily business. It can get very crowded in the summer months and very hot. Remember to bring extra bottled water. If you are an ancient history person then this is one place you will come away with a smile. It is an amazing place in the old city centre of Rome.

It's more than just an open space.... Journey back in time as you walk through the stone pavements where the ancient Romans tread. The structural remains of temples, statues, arches and basilicas in the Roman Forum depicts the social and political activities of the ancient times. It's a shame that most of the marbles were dismantled from the site and were relocated to the Vatican! On the Arch of Titus is a wall relief which reveals one of the most troubling scenes in all history, Roman soldiers carrying spoils from the destruction of the Temple of Jerusalem in 70 A.D. The Temple Menorah and the Table of the Shewbread.

Breath taking. A definite must visit on your tour. It's attached to Palatine Hill so it's great getting to visit it all in one. We didn't book a tour just strolled through at our own pace. Go early in the morning when it's alot cooler and quiet.

Take a walk amidst the ruins, sit in the shade of history!. It was a really hot day but still lovely to walk amidst the ruins. Since the Colosseum doesn't really let you walk among the old rocks and ruins, the Roman Forum gives you an opportunity to look at ancient columns up close, run your hands along rocks that were part of a building, and sit in the shade of history. Beautiful gardens, statutes, columns and church ruins.

Imagination Required . I think it important to point out that much of the enjoyment that can be had from visiting The Forum will depend on your preparation. If you are thinking of just turning up and wandering around for a few hours then there is the possibility to leave disappointed. Without any context or history the forums are just a pile of rocks. A little bit of reading before hand (or during) will transform your visit in to an unforgettable experience. In the end though the enjoyment taken from visiting the ruins will depend greatly on the limits of your imagination. It is also worth considering that excellent views of the forums are available free of charge just by walking along Via Dei Fori Imperiali or for the best view climb the steps up to Piazza Del Campidoglio.

Back to the pass. As soon as you step to this beautiful place you feel like you are in the past. It's very rich in history. Where ever you turn it's just beautiful. If you are in Rome you must visit this place

Historic one. Went an evening there.. was surprised at the huge structures.. interesting history behind..went with my family and kids.. they had great time looking at the huge pillars we took a voice guide that explained us the history behind.. worth watching..

You must visit.. The title says it all - this was exactly what i wanted to see, feel and touch - the best attraction in the city (imho). Wonderfully organsised and plenty of flexability to explore and spend as long as you want. Would recomend a good guide book as there are so many questions that this incredible site will stir in your mind.

If you get a chance try to walk through. It was very hot, so we did not get to walk through, instead we took the walkway that runs along side the street, and above this site. You can get a good view through the fence, but I wish we weren't as dehydrated and tired after visiting the coliseum to walk this.
Great!. Should visit there. Took walk tour started from Circo Massimo to Spanga. Saw many places where can spend time as long as you want. Should not miss when you in Rome!

A trip back in time. Along with the Coliseum, this is an absolute must-see in Rome. It's less busy than the Coliseum, and offers a real look into how the ancient city was laid out.The best thing about visiting the Forum is that you are truly able to take a trip back in time and walk among the ruins of ancient Rome. Start along the southwest side by the Coliseum and the Arch of Constantine and enter the Forum through the Arch of Titus. You can follow the paths around to visit ruins of temples, marketplaces, basilicas, monuments. White marble, rust red bricks... the variety of stones are still there and they create a beautiful scene before you.There are enough presentations around for your own self-guided tour. And if you want to take part in a guided tour, just open your ears... guides are talking all around you in many languages.

Great Site. This is part of the same €12 ticket for Colosseum & Palatine Hill sites.Is a sister sight to the other two and are all on the same area of Rome so easy to move between them.Really has numerous interesting aspects throughout the site. Has a number of drinking points, essential when hot so you can refill bottles.Would allow around 3 hours + to tour all the combined sites.Recommend.
Stunning, jaw dropping place. This was like stepping back in time. We had a tour guide to talk is through everything and I'd recommend getting one. Such a magical place.

nice lane for a stroll and great pictures of ancient rome!. The forum and coloseum are next to each other, as well as the national museum. A nice walk with ancient rome on both sides of the lane! A must visit centrally located in rome center! The area behind the coloseum looks very residential but has some of the best cafés and restaurants where you will find only romans!

One of the sites in Rome everyone has to see. It is a must see. Just a walk around the ruins. It would have been better with more information or a small tour. Really hard to get the flavor of the place with huge crowds and little information.

History. So much history here. Luckily we had a map in our Rome guide book so we knew what we were looking at. Don't go here without some sort of information or hire an audio guide else you won't know what you are looking at. Beware of gladiators just after the exit who will happily pose for photos and mess around with you then ask for money. This did not happen to us as if been prewarned about the gladiators but we did see a few people and one was most definitely not happy when asked for money storming off leaving his poor girlfriend running off after him.

You'll need a good imagination to appreciate it. We paid 12 euros per person for the Colosseum and you get free entry to the Palatine Hill and the Forum but you must visit within 2 days. It was a very hot day and we went to the Palatine Hill first and then the Forum. Having finished Palatine Hill I was so tired I didn't have the strength to walk through the Forum. There's no shade however it is a short walk to Capitoline Hill which is on the other side. There are great views of the Forum from the top of the hill. The Forum was home to politics, religious, shops and markets back in the day. It has survived a fire and an invasion but as it's all ruins now you'll need a really good imagination and some knowledge of the history to appreciate it. My husband was more fascinated than me.

Worth seeing!. To me the Coloseum and the Vatican are the can't miss sights in Rome. Once you've seen these 2 places and you still have time ... do see the Roman forum, the Palatine Hill they are just across from the Coloseum. Also walking distance are The Spanish Steps, Trevi fountain and the Pantheon.

A walk into history . It's amazing it's epic. Couldn't believe how this whole city is still standing today. It's a must visit place in Rome. With the entry tickets to colosseum will give you free access to Roman forum. Make sure you have comfortable shoes on, most of the path is uneven and stone and bricks spread out all over the place. There's not much place to sit and rest either, so make sure you have the energy toExplore - so plan ahead. It's a whole day activity to take your time. Apart from it's just great.

Ancient Rome set the standard for the world. I spent ages at this site and to be honest I could have easily spent many more hours here as its history is fascinating. There are so many boards to read on all the ruins and time has to be allowed here to appreciate all before the eye.The Romans were so ahead of their time and you can sense the pride the present day Romans have with all the information they provide giving a great account of its time. For those who may purchase a Roma Pass, the Roman Forum/Palatine Hill and Colosseum entrance can be used to view these fine landmarks so take advantage of a great day of viewing ancient Rome.

Amazing!. Talk a stroll through the Roman Forum before you head to the Colosseum!Tickets for the Forum are valid for both sites but you will not have to wait in a long line if you head to the Forum first.(no need to pre-book tickets and pay more,just purchase at one of the entrances to the Forum)The walk through the Roman Forum was fantastic-no tour guide ,no audio and we still enjoyed our experience.We managed to find plenty of places to stop and sit in the shade-on our stroll we overheard various tour guides so we picked up plenty of historical info but were able to enjoy the space at our own leisure.No need to worry if you need a 'comfort break'-toilets are situated in the Forum.I found a drinking fountain on site to top up my water bottle-far away end from Colosseum.Common sense must prevail-the ground is uneven so wear suitable footwear-many tourists in Rome seemed to have leg injuries!

Hot hot hot!. We did a full day in the forum and gardens. It was very hot!There is nothing inside, so take food and water with you! It was really spectacular to see all the architecture for real, amazing stones and preservation.Unfortunately the signs and information was poor. It would have been more interesting with clearer information and maybe a few stories of the times. The few information signs we saw were just small writing. Some pictures would improve things, particularly if you had kids to entertain!Amazing insight into Roman life! You can really feel the grandeur of it! Be prepared for heat and a little boring information!
Over looked gem. I used a free on line audio guide. It is just a lot of ruins but with the audio guide it comes to life. Well worth a vist.

Magnificent. We missed this beauty in daylight and only got to view at night. Unfortunately it is not lit up at all and you need to be careful going here at night, as it didn't feel safe. No photos due to poor light at night. This is located heading back towards the city, from Coluseum. You will see it on your left (take the left turn before the Unknown Soldier Palace). We missed it on daylight walk.
Another Don't Miss Part of Roman History. An amazing walk through history. Explore the nooks an crannies or just go for a stroll but don't miss it. Great views and ideal photo moments.

An amazing view of ancient Rome . It's an absolute must see in Rome. If you timed it right you could see the colosseum and then this straight after. This place takes about 1 and a half hours to see everything and I'd recommend taking your time and walking round everywhere.

Amazing site. Very interesting site, right next to colosseum. If you are In Rome for 2-3 days, get Roma pass, which covers all transport for those days and 1 or 2 sites/museums including colosseum and roman forum (counted as 1 entry). Buy on line. It also helps to avoid queues ( once you passed through the security ).

Great for history. Great place to visit and great sights to see such as the ruins and temples.Again booked this in advance with tickets for the Colosseum / Roman Forum and Palatine Hill and saved us a little time for the queues.

A must if you are in Rome.. Breathtakingly awesome! Just amazing to see such history right in front of your eyes!I'm surprised that this venue is not more widely advertised. Worth climbing the stairs in the hot temperature, the views are outstanding. Make sure that you can take panoramic photos for this visit. And don't forget to take your water and Sun cream!

Amazing place with history. Hello,In our trip to Rome my wife and me visited the forums and colosseum. It was so wonderful to see this history. Rome itself gives a lot of history because in each corner there is something to see and we didnt have time to see everything. Well, the forums, it's huge area and we recommend it. It was very interesting, especially with a guide.We can recommend that you visit this place if you ever go to Rome.Best wishesLucia & Jim

Walk in Caesar's footsteps. There is something magical about walking through the ruins of the Roman Forum. Get a guidebook before you go to see what the forum looked like during its heyday in ancient Rome and then imagine the life of the ancient city as you stroll along the same marble flagstones that Julius Caesar strode over as he returned triumphant from one of his conquests. Best to go early in the day during summer months, as there is no shade.

An Ancient Roman Marketplace!. Roman Forum was originally built as a marketplace; now, it is a square surrounded by the ruins of ancient governmental buildings. Back then, many public events took place here - elections, criminal trials, and commercial affairs. Visiting the forum (as well as all other ancient buildings in Rome) gave me a great feeling, as these ruins have been here forever!! It's like going back in time!
127 lynn. Yet again another place that you should visit when your in Rome another great location for visiting other sights
History. I enjoyed photographing the whole historic areas surrounding the forum. I enjoyed the idea of what I was looking at wonderful time. I will look at the history once again an soon!
Vast place to see. A huge sight-seeing attraction. Not too many places to rest but water fountain available. Good for a nice walk. Avoid during mid-day as the heat is unbearable.

Even better than Colosseum. We enjoyed the Roman Forum even more than the Colosseum probably because there were more ruins in the former compared to the latter. We enjoyed being close to the ruins and taking numerous shots all around the premises.

A must do. Another must do site to visit. There are just so many in Rome but add this on to your agenda. There are many surrounding sites to add on to this so you can cover a lot of ground in a day. Just be prepared to fight the crowds and take a deep breath. If you are traveling in the heat of summer, remember to bring your own water bottles to save a lot of money
A taste of history.. Gives you a feel for ancient Rome though you do need to use some imagination. Good spot to see the Colosseum from.

History!!. Walking through the Roman Forum and all of that history is an unforgettable experience. We had a private guided tour and there is so much to see. Definitely add this to your plans for Rome!

Do not go without guide or substantial prior research. Two options really: go prepared / with a guide, embrace history, take your time and move forward with a 4+ feedback
or
just wander around before entering the Colloseum, compare to Efes or any impressive historical site of the kind, do not really understand what you are exploring and go away with a 2 feedback

Amazing, beautiful ruins, take time to wander around. The Palatine Hill & Roman Forum are stunning. It is worth taking your time to wander around and see all the ruins; the view of the Circus Maximus and the city of Rome from various parts of the ruins are amazing. Highly recommended.

The Forum 2015. Just set aside a day to visit the Forum and Palatine Hill it's fantastic, take something to eat and drink as there's nothing to buy inside, suggest the use of a Roma Card for free use of the metro, buses and entry into 2 venues, you get to skip the queue as well.

A tour through history. Rome is just one fascinating city, just steeped in history. We visited the Roman Forum and got transported into the past. Thankfully we were on an organised tour which is the way to go, and were given an in depth account of the history of the Roman Forum. A must visit when in Rome.

A unique experience. The Colosseum and Roman Forum are well maintained, with a good mixture of archaeology, reconstruction, and modern improvements. The areas are mostly available to tour, and there are well built modern platforms for seeing everything. I recommend a small group tour with a guide, to help make sense of everything. I would recommend this to friends, but I am not sure I need to go back to see it. From the outside most can be seen, and the best photographs can be shot without being inside.

Needs a bit of imagination!. We had a guide when we went to see the forum and it was probably just as well because without her it would be very difficult to put the sights here into context. Even with a guide you need a lot of imagination to see the temples and streets as they would have been 1500 to 2000 years ago. Now it's just a pile of stone pillars and weeds. Worth a look but take a guide or a guide book!

Awe inspiring!. I don't think any film or book can capture what you feel when you walk in the footsteps of the Roman Emperor and see where Julius Caesar was slain. We arrived at the metro station mid-morning having driven to Rabibbia Station and parked for 1.50 Euro for 12 hours (yes 12) and paid 1.50 Euro each for a 100 min train ticket. We avoided horrendous long queues at the colosseum and walked straight past to purchase tickets outside the gates of the Forum (5-10 min wait). Definitely worth downloading Rick Steve's free tour to your phone beforehand as he brings it all to life. The scale and grandeur are beyond belief and to know how much is still copied in structures around the world today is a testament to the determination (and undeniable brutality) of the Roman Empire

Preserved ancient Rome. To visit the Roman Forum is a great experience! It is simply facinating how these constructions survived for so long and are full of histories to tell. It is also quite nice that you can visit both the forum and the Coleseo in one day with the same ticket.

Awe-inspiring. Visited Palentine Hill and Roman Forum after the Colosseum and was blown away by the grandeur and craftsmanship on show. Amazing to think these are still here. We entered at the Via di San Gregorio entrance - no queue and fuss free. No audio guide on this one but there are some information stands about to help you gain an idea about what was going on - you can also hear snippets of what guides are telling people as they visit. Completely overwhelmed.
One of the fantastics sites in Rome. This area is part of the must-sees in Rome. Don't visit it like it on a checklist. Actually walk around, imagine the history throughout the years. It's fantastic.

Not meaningful without a guide. We did the Roman Forum without a guide so it was not impressive since we only saw ruins. It was sooo hot so we cut our visit. I recommend a guide to understand the history behind it.
amazing to think these are still here. another fine example of craftsmanship at its finest when the buildings are still her after so long, it brings the past to life.

Feel and see the history of the Rome and mankind. If you like to visit historical places this is a perfect target to you. Our family visited Roman Forum again on February without rush hour and the whole area was more than interesting, and we have very comfortable afternoon there. You can truly feel the history. Go there and enjoy. Everything was well organised and we had purchased tickets in advance via Internet. We had very nice historical experience and absolutely good value for your denarius!

Forum Magnitude. When you first enter the forum it is truly an overwhelming experience. To imagine this as it was centuries ago is mind boggling. First of all it is immense and is like a city within a city. It is truly a sight to behold. Don't miss this on your trip to Rome.

The ancient heart of rome. Amazing Roman ruin complex. Difficult to grasp the enormity of the place and relevance from a book or from an unguided visit, so we'll worth the money investing in a guide. There are lots around and it doesn't need to be a personal tour: in fact most likely to be a group arrangement with 15-20 other people who thought the same as you. Walk in the footsteps of giants (of the ancient world). One last admission: was tough for our younger children (12 & 10) who didn't follow the history lesson quite as well as their parents.

Let your imagination bring you back in time. The Roman Forum is right beside the Coliseum, if purchase the combo ticket; you can go to both attractions. This is a fascinating place to visit. When I saw all the massive ruins, I can’t imagine how prosperous Rome was. At that time they didn’t have the equipment like we have today. How can they build such gigantic temples and arches?? How did they set up all the Marble columns?? If you do a little research and have a map on hand, you will know the temples and arches and let your imagination bring you back in time.Happy travelling!

not a shadow of its former self. The Roman Forum is located in a small valley between the two hills: Palatine and Capitoline. In the good old days, this was the center of public life. Given the status of the Roman Empire, this could be seen as the center of the world. Now all I saw was ruins, not impressive one at that. I cannot recall any particularly memorable site. Agora, its counterpart in Athens, looks like a garden and features a museum. The forum is purely an open-air museum, providing no shade in the July sun, but food for thought. I did not spend much time there, partly because I was tired, and mainly because no much was there. I exited the place through a door to the Capitoline Hill.

Wonderful Experience. I'd recommend you to buy or download an audio guide, because if not then nothing will be interesting to you. Also, come early in the morning because it's very hot and desserted in the middle of the day.

History smack in the middle of the city. Smack in the city, the Forum is spectacular I its history as well as place in that the city grew up around it. We spent several hours despite so rain, and could easily go back and spend several more hours!
Don't miss!. I loved this more than anything in Rome! You can use your combo ticket with the Colosseum to get in. Make sure you bring a water bottle because there are none for sale inside.

For history buffs!!!. I didnt know about this spot or but thanks for my tour , i made to this place. I saw the place where Julius Caesar is buried ! It is one of the Amazing places to visit.. So much to see . Take your time . The walk in long... you can spend hours in this place. Take the fast pass only for Colosseum and you can get a audio guided and do it on your pace. The ancient ruins lets your imagination run. Tip- come in a comfortable walking shoes.

Thoroughly enjoyed but was dragged to read every signpost. Beautiful grounds. Very informative with nice shaded areas and places to fill up your water bottles.Definitely worth a visit in the morning, or later in the afternoon, to miss the heat of the day in the summer.

The Most Amazing Place. My husband and i came to the Roman Forum in November 2013 and we like it so much - we spend the whole day there and could have spent more time but we were short of time - so we came back in February 2015 to take our daughter - some much human history throughout the ages - incredible

Ancient History Walk. Such a cool experience to be able to walk through these ancient ruins. Very cool to go up to Palatine Hill as well to see the brother Romulous's House ruins. Learned a great deal from our city wonders guide about how Rome was started and built so long ago.

Do not miss the night time show. We happened to be passing by the night video show and decided to get tickets. One of the best things we saw in Rome. Well produced and really gave you a sense of the history and scale of ancient life. Would recommend including this in your must see plans.

Use the same ticket as Colloseo. A must see, no need for long explanations...Only remembet that same ticket with the Colosseo is valid here and they may be bought (with some extra reservation fee) at the internet. You will still need yo wait about 20 mins for the Colosseo; less for the Roman Forum

A Trip back in History. Such an interesting place to sightsee following on from the Colloseum . A huge area to walk round, hilly and quite exhausting (so flat shoes recommended) but well worth the visit.

Forum Romanum - Forum Magnum. Here it all started... where Rome was built, not in a day ;)Make sure you have plenty of time when visiting and it's best to buy tickets in advance. This is a place everyone visiting Rome should see <3

Majestic Ruins. These are indeed majestic. we were caught up in one of the numerous infamous strikes that Rome often sees and thus had to go back the first day. However, the authorities did allow us to visit the next day on the same tickets. these ruins are undergoing some kind of a renovation work around the periphery. they share the complex with Palantine Hills and we took a guided tour for the same. the other way is to read up a bit before going there otherwise one gets into a bit of "ruin fatigue". since the area is vast please go prepared with water and umbrella in case it is sunny. absolutely recommended!

Amazing Ruins. Prior to visiting Europe and having the opportunity to "SEE" history, I never appreciated all those history lessons. Viewing the actual buildings from all those history books is amazing and makes you want to learn more. Do not miss the opportunity to throughly investigate the building remains at the Roman Forum.

Take A Stroll Through History. Incredible. Coming from a country that is only 200 plus years old, it is amazing to walk past and among ruins thousands of years old. The sights are amazing, and the tour guides were knowledgeable. If you come to Rome, you simply should not miss the Coliseum and then the Forum.

Excellent way to spend a day in Rome. First we went to the Colosseum, where we bought the tickets for it which were also for the forum. Colosseum was nice for us but the real treat was the Roman Forum. Ah, if you ever go to Rome, be sure to visit this place. Next time I will bring my lunch with me and a book so I can lay down in one of the gardens and enjoy the tranquility of the place. The history that went on there, the diggings that are going on, archaeologists doing their thin, etc., is really something special.

A Must See in Rome. The Roman Forum is basically downtown Ancient Rome .Anyone at all interested in history or Rome itself HAS to visit the Forum. You could fill a book just naming all the historical events that took place over the centuries in the Forum.You walk on the same ground as Caesar , Nero ,Augustus etc.. Its best to do a little research ahead of time , find a good book with a map and photos of the ruins so when you get there you know what you're looking at .It's also best to get tickets online so you can skip the line .Try http://www.tickitaly.com/tickets/forum-tickets.php...Also look into getting a Roma Pass which gets you into one or two historical areas ( according to the type of pass you buy ) discounts for other sites and museums and free public transportation for a few days ( again according to the type of pass you get ) Its well worth if if you're going to explore the history of Rome

MUST SEE in Rome. We all know the place so nothing to add. I bough the archeolgia ticket which permits entrance to several attractions. The place was full of visitors on a weekday. Probably not a good idea to go there on weekends. Very hot weather, remember to use sun lotion and wear a hat when visiting in summertime.

It's been here for a couple of thousand years - so why not?. Not to be done on a hot day, but a magnificent visit no matter how many times you've been to Rome. Access to Nero's Goldn House also available, and if you go in the arvo you can double up with a night tour of the Coliseum.
Fanastic and fascinating. Although heaving with modern tourists you can get a bit off the beaten track and image what it was like back in the day.

FASCINATING !. You can't go to Rome without visiting the Roman Forum, the Palatine Hill, Colosseum and the Vatican! There is so much history here in the Roman Forum and to think you are able to walk through it, is surreal. There are many nice restaurants nearby where you can take a break and enjoy the scenery.

Very disappointing.. Here's the thing, it's an amazing historic area with ruins from all different ages. So much must have happened here over the years. But you are really left to figure that out all by yourself (or I guess, go with a massive tour which is not something I enjoy). If you are used to sites that come with signage you will be sadly disappointed. Throughout it is truly a guessing game, sometimes you get a sign for what you are looking at. Every once in a while you get a sign pointing you in the direction of something. There are very rare maps (one of these was located in a fenced off area, so you couldn't even approach it, it would have been nice for them to move the map if they had to close an area down for safety).So basically, you end up wandering around with little information about what you're looking at and little idea how to get to the other parts of the site. I am certain we missed things we planned on seeing and it's hard to say whether it's because they were blocked off due to safety/archeological work or whether we just couldn't find them.Things that would have improved the experience immensely:1. A labeled map given to you when you enter.2. Signs throughout the site directing you which way to walk to see which things.3. Frequent signage directing you to restrooms and exit4. Signs telling you which parts are dead ends so you don't wander down a path to be met with a fence or wall.5. Any place whatsoever to recover from intense heat - I swear if they sold water in this place and had an air-conditioned information center they could make a killing. 6. Nicer restrooms - for those from the US - don't expect toilet seats, potable water, air-conditioning or clean floors.7. Benches to sit onPositives: The line was short, the ticket can be used at the colosseum allowing you to avoid the colosseum's massive line.

Worth Seeing. There is not much left of the forum, but if you are there anyway it's worth briefly looking at just because of it's historic significance. It's not a trip on it's own with so many other spectacular sights to see in Rome.

Amazing. Never tire of visiting this place. Always find out further bits of history that I wasn't aware of. Fantastic to be able to immerse oneself in history. To beat the queue join a tour with a knowledgeable guide.

Great to see . We did a tour for this place on a really hot day which made the tour less interesting, as there's not much shade at the forum. However the Tour was good, and we enjoyed learning about the ancient ruins and the story behind it. Worthwhile getting a tour to learn about the stories behind the ruins.
Amazing, a must see. Well folks I didn't want to go and see old ruins, it was amazing! Well worth the walk, absolutely fascinating
Such facinating history. We took a private tour of Forum and Palatine Hill. Well worth the $. Such history. Such magnitude that you can hardly imagine. Wonderful experience.

Take pics at sunset. Great pics as sunset. Go early in the morning or late at night. Set your camera up and take a video. Then take still shots of the videos. Editing and removing images that Are in the pic but not like the others = pictures without any tourists!

Hot work but worth it. In height of summer we suggest taking bottles of water with you maybe even a few litres as it is a big area to walk around and you can only enter with your ticket once and no cafes/stalls inside roman forum to purchase water from once inside. The views from the top overlooking the whole city was a highlight here. Far less preserved than the Colosseum as you may already know but still worth a visit. Advise getting combined ticket with Colosseum.

Great Place to learn about Roman History. This is a great place to learn about Roman History and the way the Roman Empire was governed. Many Temples and monuments of interest to anybody who wants to get insights into Roman system of governance. Palatine Hill gives greats views of Roman Forum and beyond. Entrance fee is 12 euros per person. Please avoid mid day in July it gets too hot. Please visit either morning or later in the afternoon. This is next door to Colosseum.

Amazing. It's very impressive what they managed to do all of those years ago! Would massively recommend visiting here, you could spend many hours walking around. Be sure to buy the combined ticket with the Colosseum and Palatine Hill as well, and the Palatine Hill ticket office tends to be the quietest!

Rome July 2015. After coming out of the Colosseum, head to the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. There was no queue when I went.You can wander about in here for a quite while. It is typically Roman ruins, but it's easy to imagine how things were in Roman times. There is no cover here, so can be very hot in the summer.

Hot!. If you're here in the summer, prepare to get burnt! You'll spend a lot of time walking in the open sun, with little shelter. If you can, get a guide to tell you about the significance of each building/structure, because it'll all seem like disconnected signboards scattered all over if you're walking it on your own.

Great & avoid the collosseum queue. Took 30 seconds to get in, would recommend taking a pic of the map on your phone before you go in, otherwise you may not realise what you walk past!Ticket can be purchased for Roman Forum and Collosseum

Acres of old rocks beautifully stacked. We had paid for a tour guide to take us thru the Forum but she dissapeared when the rain started. This is a fabulous place to just wander around with little signs here and there to inform you but it definitely would have been better with a guide. It spans acres and acres and you could look for hours. All sorts of arches and columns standing and laying on the ground and several spectacular buildings. There arE sections we did not even get to which we saw from the road later! Well worth a visit for about 8 euros by itself or a package with the Colosseum next door.

Nice additive to colosseum visit. Can't rate this as average as we are talking about years of history and culture. But not as epic as the colosseum (I guess that's fair). Fun to walk around after visiting the main event, until your feet get sore.

Walking through History. The Forum was the heart of city life in ancient Rome, beginning around 500 BC, located between Palatine Hill and Capitoline Hill. It was amazing to walk around and think about all the history made so many centuries ago.

Whoa. This is a vast his tick complex filled with amazing ruins. It is well worth the visit if you enjoy Roman history. Go super early to avoid standing out in the sun during summer! Download Rick Steve's auld io guide to avoid needing an audio tour for an additional fee!

Its the Roman Forum, what else is there to say?. After touring the Coliseum we went to the Roman Forum. I don't really know how to review it. Actually seeing ancient ruins in person is amazing. I want to go back, soon.

Boring. Went there by Bus as taxi men cheat.We were not impressed.You can read all about it but not worth a vista for us.This experience is for those that are interested in the history of old ruins.The place needs a face lift.Maybe Berlusconi should help out.

Walk through time. You cannot go to Rome and not visit this place. This was the heart of ancient Rome and it does not take much of a stretch of the imagination to see it as such.On a practical note, this is in a bowl surrounded by taller buildings and on a summer's day gets VERY hot. Wear a hat, drink lots - there are plenty of standpipes dispensing free and very drinkable water (as there is throughout Rome) and do use this water to splash over your head.With the cost of this and the Colosseum in one ticket, usable over 2 days, this is great value.

INCREDIBLE but please note..... I found the Roman Form (and Palatine Hill) to be fascinating. Seeing all of the ruins, thinking about how they lived so long ago....incredible! Please note the sidewalks are not flat and at the Roman Forum (and Palatine Hill) you walk on some stone from ancient Rome. It is slippery, hilly and uneven. Wear a sturdy shoe! I saw several people with sprained ankles.

Walk in the heart of ancient Rome.... The Roman Forum is place not to be missed on your visit to Rome. The Forum was the cultural, commercial and political heart of ancient Rome. It is a place when you can follow in the footsteps of Caesar and experience an abundance of ancient treasures from the early Republican era to the late Imperial era of Roman history.

Excellent. I went there with a friend who was not particularly interested in Roman history. However we ended up spending over 5 hours wandering the forum discovering new and unbelievably amazing historical sites. We chose not to get a tour guide but there is an app that will navigate and narrate you through it. Bring water as it can be quite warm but there are many fountains to refill your bottle so hang on to it (we found that out the hard was as we had to pay €2 for 250ml bottle inside). Only down side is that if you don't have the app or can't download it then you can easily get lost or will not understand what each of the remains are etc

Ancient Roman History lesson come alive. For all lovers of Ancient Roman History the Roman Forum is a must see. Wear good walking shoes, pack a bottle (or two) of water and if you not planning on having a guide, take some time to read up about it. It covers quite a large area and everything has a story behind it.

A lot of History. We lived not too far from the Forum. If you want to learn more history, you have to join the tour and listen to the story. We just read enough about the places not to do any formal tours. Very interesting to just see and feel those places. Huge impact on everyone's intellectual capacity.

Where the hell am I and what on earth is this bit?. Simple review. Go because you should. If you're pedantic about seeing everything & knowing what you're looking at then get a guide. If not get a guidebook & freestyle. Take water in with you & lots of sun cream. There's nowhere to buy water & very little shade. There are two ladies loos in the whole place and one of those wasn't working when I was there so take care in your water consumption!Don't get annoyed when there are coke cans & Pringle packets sitting next to a mosaic floor.

Loved the Forum, but take note... We went to the Forum around 9 to avoid the great heat. (Note to fellow EU-citizens: make sure to bring your passport which will grant you a discount of about 4€).Buying the ticket was fairly easy. After the purchase we went on to the Forum. (Be prepared: in case you are exploring with backpacks or big purses prepare for a quick security check before entering the Forum. I would recommend putting everything away so you don't have a mess upon security because right after that you'll be asked to show your ticket - lots going on, huh?)My boyfriend and I decided to rent an audio guide for 7€ a person. The administration of the Forum seems rather unorganized as we had to buy the audio guide far off from the entrance we took (close to the Colosseum). We honestly regretted getting the audio guide because the guy talking was really boring; I eventually stopped listening to him. The only good aspect of the guide was the map that would show you locations of water fountains, bathrooms and exits.Also, every monument is tagged with a number and the order of these numbers wasn't in order, whatsoever.All in all, the Forum itself is outstandingly awesome - a must on your list for your trip to Rome! The monuments are even cooler to look at in person than on the web. Although it looks like climbing Mount Everest you should do the Palatine from where you get a great view of Rome, and you can even see the Saint Peter's Cathedral (see pictures I took). I'll also give you a couple of tips for the Forum:- If you're an EU-citizen bring your passport (as said)- Inform yourself about other possible discounts. At every ticket office you can find a sheet with all available discounts listed- In summer: Depending on the amount of people you travel with, let's say you travel in a group of 4, bring 4 bottles and an extra one on top.
