The lines for the fountains are usually pretty long. - Speaking of water: stay hydrated!! If you don't you'll feel a fish out of water- Don't wear flip flops or sandals - the Forum is DUSTY- During summer: Bring sun screen. Make sure your kids (if brought) use SPF 50 or higher. If not, you and your kids will be fried - not kidding.- My partner and I figured this out: once you start sweating, it is NOT going to stop. After a couple minutes you'll look like a waterfall (that's why you should stay hydrated). What we did was finding shade and sit down or stand around for 15 minutes to cool off, drink water and wait until we stopped sweating

Impressive. You can expect to be walking around a huge site of ruins for a couple of hours. We walked slightly further down the road to come across a back entrance (walk down Via Di S. Gregorio - past the gated arch monument near the Coliseum) with a significantly smaller queue, we only queued for 5mins and then we were into the attraction. Well worth a look around and not too badly priced for the 2 day pass (€24)

Great opportunity to understand the Romans. There are really buildings left of the Forum -- the building materials were cannibalized for centuries to create other edifices throughout Rome. But walking from the Capitoline Museum (and visiting Marcus Aurelius and Constantine there) down to the Colosseum and then finally to the Column of Trajan… that walk, through several arches and hundreds of columns, can give you an idea of what Roman civic and religious life was. You will need to know what the columns mean… the explanations on site are not generous enough. But there are guides easily available that explain what was here & what it means. Get an online guide or a book - there is so much to see and learn here.
Definitely see this. The ruins and buildings are very interesting. Read about this site before you go to get the most out of your visit. A guided tour would be good here.
Incredible. Go with a private Tour.. Huge and amazing. We went with a private tour through Maximus tours and it was a wonderful tour. Guide was very knowledgeable and took us all around.

If you have any interest in world development, this is a must see. Actually many aspects of visiting the Forum are a bit disappointing. Many of the ruins/building do not have signs; what signs they have often jump into boring details of architecture and excavation instead of telling how the item was relevant in the Roman world; and places are often blocked for renovation/construction. Despite these challenges the Forum is amazing. Our Western world has largely been defined by the events and decisions made it. It is incredible to see what has lasted for 2000 years and to lament what was lost.

Amazing concentration of ruins. There is an incredible amount of history in this place. Definitely place the Roman Forum on your itinerary.There is a fee to enter the Forum but can be bundled with the Colosseum entrance.

Learn your history. It may just be down to the heat, but if you are unsure of what this is then make sure you read up. I am not a history person but know what most of the sites are, this i didn't and so in the heat I lost interest really quickly. Also it was quite unclear which way to travel until we realised you downloaded something on your phone!

An immersion in history. For someone who knows relatively little about roman history, forum romanum is pretty mindblowing when you first walk into it. To me it felt like being thrown back in history, and although I knew little about the buildings I saw, it left me with a stronger understanding of ancient roman society. One warning though: it can get EXTREMELY hot during the middle of the day, more so than the rest of the city, and there are little options for walking in the shadow. If I were to go another time I'd go earlier in the morning! Thankfully there are a lot of places where you can refill your bottle!

A great place fpr a historical walk. I was there today before the Colosseum. Actually I bought the ticket for both of them there. Make sure you wear a hat or even take a parasol. I got sunburnt even though I was wearing very high sub screen. Let yourself be lead by the lovely paths and stairways in it.

Buy your ticket online!!!. Well, it's beautiful and captivating! That is for sure! And you kinda have to go, if it's your first trip to Rome. But! It its hot like you would not believe (if in summer) and there is almost no shade! I could hardly concentrate about the beautiful columns, because I was only thinking "shade, water, now!" Be sure to book your tickets online! There is a little extra fee, nothing much, but you skip the line and the ticket is valid for two days for both Palentine hill, forum Romano and colosseum. And the forum has the best photo spot for getting that perfect colluseum selfie

A hodge-pudge of History - Some Suggestions. The Colosseum is most often combined with a trip through the Roman Forum and the imperial sites on Palatine Hill, overlooking the Circus Maximus. The Roman Forum spans the entire gamut of Roman History, from the 7th century BC to the 6th century AD (and beyond if you consider the conversions of several of these classical sites into Churches. No guided tour can give you a 'full tour' of the Roman Forum, no matter how talented the guide, since tours are constrained by time and other practicalities. So which do you see and in what order? Well, here are my humble suggestions. First, enter the area and descend. When you get to the bottom, turn around and look at the church with very tall columns slightly to your right. This is the Temple of Faustina and Antoninus Pius (probably Rome's best emperor, second century AD) - now a church. Then turn back around and look slightly to your right at the collection of rocks near you. This is the remains of the Temple of Julius Caesar. Turn to your right and walk down the road (the Via Sacra) to the arch in the distance. This is the Arch of Septimius Severus (early third century). He was born in what is now Libya, was a famous general-emperor, and was the first emperor to enter the city during a triumph in military uniform (an insult to the Senate). That act took place under this very arch. As you face the arch, turn to your 3- o'clock to face the brick building-church. This is the Curia, or Senate Chamber, and Julius Caesar was assassinated in this building or on the steps. Turn around behind you and face the stone platform. This is the Rostrum, or speaking platform. Many famous speeches were given from here, and Shakespeare had Marc Antony give his. rabble rousing speech from here. Next, turn back and face the Arch again. Walk round it keeping it to your left, and stair straight ahead. You will be facing the Mamertine Prison, where Peter was held before being taken to the Circus of Nero in the Vatican to be crucified at emperor Nero's order. Now turn around and return to your original entry place at the bottom of the entrance ramp, facing in the opposite direction. Turn a quarter turn to your right. Straight ahead, you will face several columns in a circular arc. These are the remains of the circular temple of Vesta, their house is just next door slightly to your left. Thirst are the circular remains of the Temple of Vesta. Now turn a quarter turn back to the left. This road, by the way, is the Via Sacra, down which defeated kings and generals were paraded in shame before the people and Senate of Rome. As you walk up this road, you will pass the Temple/Mausoleum of Romulus, son of the emperor Maxentius (great pagan rival of 'Christian' Constantine. The doors here are the original bronze doors from 309! Keep walking and there will be the remains of a huge basilica - that of Constantine and Maxentius (4th century). Continue up, curving round to the right. About halfway up the slope, there will be an Arch, that of the emperor Titus ( a rival for best emperor, and conqueror of Judaea and Jerusalem). On this arch you can see at head-height on one side (North) the triumphal chariot carrying a toga-clad Titus down the Via Sacra. On the south side panel you can see Romans carrying the booty from the Temple in Jerusalem, including the branched candlestick Menorah. Continuing up the slope, you rise to the top of the Palatine Hill. These are my suggestions of things to see in the Roman Forum. There is also an entirely different forum, that of Emperor Trajan, across the street to the north of this older Roman Forum. There are several interesting sites in that Imperial Forum as well. Enjoy!
Walking amongst ruins. I loved walking around the ruins, it seems to take you back in history. Really enjoyed my day there.

Definitely worth a visit!. Incredible experience. Kept so well preserved. The effect of the oculus is profound. Was crowded, as it is the high season, but that did not take anything away from it. Was cool seeing the to,b of the great painter, Raphael.

One of the Eternal City's must-sees. After visiting the nearby Colloseum, have a break and then take in the Forum. Better yet take a guided tour. There really is no better way to get a feel of the Roman Empire than strolling through here. Fantastic.
Difficult to Comprehend. This attraction is simply outstanding, to take in what the Romans achieved is very difficult.The scale of the site and the whole experience can't easily be described

Don't miss!. The Forum is probably the best area to visit in Rome. So much to see, all free, on way to the Colosseum so no excuse! Palatine Hill, Titus Arch, Circus Maximus. See Rome how it used to be. Best part of our visit!

The Center of Rome's Governance. 2000 years ago this was the center of governance for what we consider the Western World. If at all possible, try to arrange to spend time also at the Colosseum and on the Palatine Hill. Please, also, see my notes about the Colosseum and the Palatine Hill. What we are left with are the ruins. We do not see the bright colors of the painted walls, the movement of people from one point to another for political, social, and religious reasons. So, you need to try to imagine what it might have been like to watch Roman heroes parade through the arches bringing with them the spoils of their conquests.And, you can also see how the natural valley of the forum was filled in with rubble as the centuries passed. This allowed the building of the church that sits immediately next to the entrance of the forum. This is a common practice that we see in many cities where the center of the town is in a desirable location and the people rebuild over time.

A world of ruins. If you are not interested in archeology or history this isn't the place for you. However the forum is a quintessential part of Rome. The main reason to be a tourist in Rome is to see the history, and this is where it lies. You can spend about three hours walking around the ancient city and learning about the ruins. I highly recommend it if you are okay with a higher activity level from walking and climbing and if you are interested in standing in thousands of years of history!

Guided tour. really enjoyed this trip. As I mentioned in other reviews would advise a visit in cooler weather! However the tour was well worth it as our guide had pictures of how it would have looked in Roman times which really helped the imagination. Some of the statues were amazing well preserved, really interesting place to visit

Amazing. We spent have a day exploring this magnificent historical site. Such amazing relics of the Roman past. It is a must see if you plan to visit roman and wish to be enthralled by its history. Nice vantage points for photos of the site and beyond to Rome.

Walking in the Past. Went in later, about 5.30 and had an hr and a half. Time enough for an eleven yr old. Not busy and not crowded even in July. Hot but cooler than during the day. We got round the things we wanted and had a happy young boy.

Imagine you are living in Ancient Rome. Go early (8am-10am) and you will the place to yourself before all the tourist groups start packing in and before it gets hot. Also it was fun to imagine yourself living in Ancient Roman while walking around the ruins. Going in the ancient temples is a lot of fun.
Beauty and history abounds!. As always it takes my breath away to imagine what the area looked like 2000 years ago. to see the ancient abutting the modern is always an interesting sight!

Cannot be missed!. Remarkable...I don't know how I will go anywhere else and be as engrossed in history as I was here. I had a tour guide and we only had 4 people in our group which is the way to go. If you have a large tour group you will miss so much flavor.
Must see!. Just a super spot, crowded of course and so much more could be done but its a 'must see'. Loved wlaking the same stones as many Romans did all those years ago.

Don't go in Summer. Besides the heatwave, the place really has nothing for the non archaeologist/historian. You need not enter the ruins if you are not THAT interested in these kin of things. You can see it from the street and download some generic and free audio guide on your app.

Absolutely amazing . I loved this! It’s in a three way tie for my favorite experience of the trip. Buy your tickets online. It is worth the extra two euros. We had practically no line to wait in on Saturday morning. Definitely make sure to arrive earlier in the morning. There are plenty of people but a much more manageable number than the amount in the Forum by the time we got to it close to lunch. The ticket is good not only for the Colesseum but also for the Palatine Hill and the Forum. Get your money’s worth and go to all three. The Palatine Hill area is so extensive that I’m not sure that we saw all of it but we certainly tried. There are also some viewing areas that look out onto Rome with the Capital Building featured prominently as well as the Forum. These are great photo spots. Also, if you speak English or Italian, do not bother with a guided tour. Information placards abound. Be sure to take some time to appreciate the Titus Arch. The low-relief carvings tell the story of the destruction of Jerusalem in AD 70 in intricate detail. This trio of sites is not to be missed.

Extremely Intereting.. The ticket to enter costs $12 euros. It is a two day ticket which will give you access to Palatine Hill and the Colosseum. Go to the Palatine Hill box office first thing in the morning because it will have the shortest line. (go to the Colosseum the next day) Palatine Hill and the Forum are right next to each other and basically the same. If you go to Rick Steves website you can find a free audio tour. We walked around with a Rick Steves Italy tour book and got a description and historical facts for each monument. We could do this at our own pace.When you are up at Palatine Hill, there are many great spots to look down into the Forum and great views of Rome. When you are at Palatine Hill, look for and walk past the Convento San Bonaventura al Palatino. There is a great spot to take pictures of the Colosseum. Around lunch time, we left the Forum and went to eat at Cavour 313. When we went back to enter the Forum again, the ticket agent said we were not allowed to visit the forum twice in one day. We said we did not know and were not told this. The ticket agent was very friendly and said, ok, I will let you back in. So be warned, we got lucky, you may not be allowed back in. We spent the rest of the day in the Forum and were fascinated the entire time.
Wow. It was well worth booking a guided tour, to understand the historical significance of the area and Ancient Rome itself.

Roman Forum . Great but hot! This was amazing to see and so close to the coliseum. I think if I were to go back then I would try and do a tour if they have them so I could learn more about the history of the place. Very beautiful.

Must take a tour to enjoy. You really need a guide to enjoy the Forum. We tried to use the audio guide for purchase there but it was a joke. The device barely worked and we ended up leaving because we were so hot and thirsty. I'm sure it would have been great with proper preparation on our part. A tour guide is a necessity here to see in a timely manner.
Great sights, a must in Rome!. We loved touring this historical sight. It is a great family visit to go along with the Colosseum. We toured this with a guide, which gives you much more information.
A Walk back in Time. Fascinating, well worth booking a guided tour to really appreciate the history of this thoroughly interesting area. So much history to absorb

So much to take in. We took in the Forum, as part of a guided tour, that included The Colosseum. Again, the guided tour was well worth it, as the amount of sights makes you dizzy. Our guide explained everything. It's humbling to be in places such as this, with its depth and variety of history, and it's all accessible. Well worth a visit.
Very cool!. It was really need getting to see such a historic place but I would warn people not to go in July. It's so hot you can barely enjoy it!

Historically amazing!. When in Rome do what the Romans do...this place was incredible. The history of Rome is unsurpassed and all the sites we visited were amazing. Buy the skip the lines tours...the waits can be long and hot

All the History. If you want to learn about Romes past this is the place to go. Amazing site with artifacts and buildings everywhere. Right next to the Colosseum.
HINT: Get your tickets over at the PALATINO. No line.

Incredible and expansive ruins. The forums are a must-see for every tourist visiting Rome. If you're also intending to see the Colosseum, I highly recommend going to the forum first and buying your ticket for it as well as the Forum and Palantine Hill. The line is a lot shorter and faster than that of the Colosseum. As for the forum itself, it's packed with history and is worthwhile experience for to wander amongst all the ruins. Don't forget to head up to Palantine Hill and check out the ruins there and the museum as well. You paid for it in your ticket.

interesting take plenty of water, they do have water fountains but worry about foreign water from fountains. very interesting place, can get very hot, as open, we went with a guide, which I thought was very good and useful

No Queue. We planned to go to the Forum the following day but as we walked past the entrance at 4pm there was no-one at all in the queue so we had a quick change of plan and bought a two day ticket. So hint - no queue at 4pm.The Forum was not crowded, possibly because the weather was so hot. Walking around at a leisurely pace was comfortable and increased our enjoyment. I read somewhere that you can see all you need at the Forum for free from the road outs is but I would not agree with that. For the very reasonable fee of 12 Euros for the Forum, Palatine Hill and the Colosseum I think you get an absolute bargain. Inside the site you get a feel for the history of such an important place.I really enjoyed the visit, in spite of the heat!

Another ttip back into time. The Roman forum and palantine hill are a must seeSeveral eras of architecture are visible with structures in various stages of restorationLots of walking on hills and uneven streets

Nice as Part of a Tour. Like others have said, you get to visit the forum as part of a package deal. However, I think it would be most valuable as part of a tour to get the history behind it all. I'm not a big fan of tours but did appreciate the guide as we viewed many of the sites in Rome.

Fantastic!. The Forum is very well-worth seeing- but much better with a tour. We did a tour through the Tourist Information office on the main road towards the Coliseum ( Imperial)....in addition to the Forum, it included the Palatine Hill and the Coliseum, and we skipped all the lines. Our guide Loredana was excellent, our group was small ( under 15) and with our special earphones we could always hear her clearly even amid the throngs of tourists.She made it fascinating..... I recommend also to buy the Roma Pass .... a discount for the tour, as well as entries to other sites.

One Ticket, Three Places.. Don’t forget that you can see the Palatine Hill, the Roman Forum and the Colosseo with one ticket. The ticket is good for two days. Buy your ticket at the entrance of Roman Forum. The waiting line is much shorter. To see the Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum together, you need at least 2-3 hours or even more. It can also get very hot during the summer. Therefore, take your hats, sunglasses and water bottle with you. (There are some fountains with drinkable water around. You don’t need to buy water.) If you don’t like to visit historical places, you may skip this, because it is guaranteed that you will get very tired after your visit, especially if the weather temparature is around 40 degres.
The romantic ruins of the Roman Forum!. The Fora Romano was the civic, commercial and religious hub of the great city. A must to visit in Rome!

well worth it. The combined Colosseum/ Forum/ Palatinate ticket is well worth the price and can be spread over two consecutive days if you don't fancy doing it all on one day. We spent about 3 hours at the Colosseum on the first day and about 7 hours next day at the Forum/Palatinate so Eur 12 entry ticket was well worth it. I pre-booked to avoid queues and I would say that was better than the extremely long queues I bypassed. There is not a lot of shade at the Forum, so that can be problem in very hot weather (37C when I was there) but there are little oases under trees here and there and also lots of water taps to refill bottles! A fascinating site steeped in history and a must when in Rome.

Interesting but needs better signage. this was interesting and it was fun to explore. Signage was a problem though. I advise anyone visiting to take a tour or grab a guidebook beforehand as although there was some signage it's takes a lot of imagination to work out what's what
Wonderful History. Gawsh the history here. I spent a couple of hours here on a solo walk. Beautiful structures and history left behind for us to discover. Don't miss this amazing attraction.

Take a nice stroll down history. This site is pretty extensive and the actual forum is usually busy with tourist. On the day we went, the line up to go into the Forum was the shortest of all three sites (Colosseo / Palatino Hill). It was interesting to see the columns left standing and the different areas of business from the Roman era. There are two buildings that you can go into where you can see some artwork on the walls.
Exciting. What an experience this was. It was an odd feeling walking along the paths that Julius Caesar once walked! Wear decent footwear on the trip as you could spend hours exploring the site.

a bit of history. we got tickets for this as part of a tour package with the colosseum. it was worth having explained before we went in and made if more understandable, although, there are lots of signs in english inside.be aware that it covers a very large area but is def worth a visit
Was on my bucket lisy. As a fan of roman history and politics this was a must see. Wish I had more time and also done it with a tour guide. Was disappointed some of it was closed in summer.

Fires the Imagination, wondeful.. The forum itself was a wonderful experience, the concentration of ruins really stirred the imagination. I only wished I had read a little more about the site before I went around, so that I knew a little more about what I was looking at. Be warned it is very warm in summer, so make sure you carry water into the attraction, there are no vendors inside.I would have given the visit 5 stars except for the disorganised ticket collection area/office at the entrance. Huge crowds, signs/directions inadequate, so was not clear where you exchanged your pre-paid internet voucher for tickets? Still everybody and the staff were good natured and we got there in the end.
Great tour. The tour allowed everyone to see how the Romans felt about their government and how life was to be in those times.

Center of life in Ancient Rome. We had a private tour of the Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill and I enjoyed the Forum and Palatine Hill more. As a history geek, seeing ancient Rome before my eyes was a dream come true. The pictures don't do it justice. Even if it was very hot that day, the open skies, the trees, the ruins brought to life by our guide was a highlight for me. Do get a guide, otherwise, this may be just a pile of stones for you. Our guide had pictures to re-create what it was many, many years ago and I realized how many things are both alike and different today and in ancient times.

Ancient wonder. We were guided around the Roman Forum and The Colluseum by Ava representative of 'Together in Rome' she uncovered so much of the mystique of both places and made them come alive with the ancient places taking on a new meaning. If ancient Roman History is your enjoyment then this is a place not to miss. if you want to just look and touch history of the ages then it will siut you too.

Don't miss it, but don't miss the water before going in. Great tourist area to visit. Offers great pictures of the Colosseum from inside the Forum. But there are no venders inside so be sure to take bottled water with you when you go in. The place is very hot to visit and is 100% walking tour. Lots of steps. Be sure to visit, but do it right. Subway station close by if needed.

A nice concentration of ruins. This is a great spot to see a lot of ruins all in one place. Bring good walking shoes because what remains of the road is very uneven and hard to walk on. There are a couple of great vantage points for night viewing. It's lit very nicely, and makes for some great photo ops.

Incredible site-must see. . Just spent several hours at the Roman Forum with a guided small group tour. It was fascinating and definitely a must see on any itinerary to Rome. I would suggest a small group tour if possible because you will get so much more out of it. It is an education our family will take with us for years to come.
amazing place. Just across from Colosseum. Much larger than I thought it would be from pictures. Definitely worth seeing.

Second Time and Still Amazing. For the history geek - this place is just the best! Ancient Rome at your feet and there are lots of tourists and uneven ground. Wear senstible footwear!The best way to visit this place is to buy a ticket to the Coloseum/Roma Card which includes access to the Palantine Hill and Colosseum. Then I just stayed there all day. Pretty much everything was labelled and said what it was for. When we went in June, The Temple of Romulus was open too and we got to look inside. It was so beautifully preserved inside. So if it is open on your visit, it's well worth exploring. In terms of refreshments, there are only the over priced carts outside; so make sure you bring your own.

A missed opportunity. this is the heart of Europe where so many great events that shaped the western world were played out, yet there is almost no information about the buildings so you are left to aimlessly wander from one column to the next. There should be models, diagrams and artists impressions but nothing! Many of the paths are needlessly dead ends forcing you to retrace your footsteps. There is nowhere to rest, grab a coffee or ice cream and huge disorganised queues to enter and unbelievably also to exit through a primitive single turnstile. Don't go without a guide book, Italians should be ashamed of this site

No trip to Rome is complete without a visit.. I bought our tickets at the Palatine Hill entrance to the Roman Forum as advised by contributors on Tripadvisor before our trip. Bought tickets frothe Forum and the Colosseum and went straight in NO queues. The Forums is vast and could have spent hours here apart from the huge thunder storm, Having left the Forum in such inclement weather asked at the Colosseum if would could use our tickets the following day and was told no problem. Returned the following day in glorious weather and thoroughly enjoyed it.
It's Worth Lingering. The longer you look, the more you see. Really interesting. Make sure you view from all angles, including the terrace behind the Capitoline Museum.

To be with all the emperors in Rome... To be in Rome and not go to the Roman Forum where everything happened during the great Roman Empire, is not going to Rome: Julius Cesar, Mark Anthony, Caligula, and all the others, walked through those ruins and it feels that you are part of it !!

Download Rick Steve’s free audio guide app to get a better idea of what you’re viewing. The roman forum is a large public square located in the centre of ancient rome which contained numerous buildings of significance. It’s located adjacent to the colosseum and palatine hill and is covered by the same ticket. Understandably, over 2000+ years the buildings have degraded significantly and many of them were plundered for building goods – so what remains is a somewhat confusing and incomplete residue of history. You really need some sort of guide to make sense of it all. I would recommend downloading the FREE ‘Rick Steves Europe’ guide on your smartdevice (iphone, ipad) and bringing earphones. It has a map to guide you with various descriptions of what each structure is – so that you can get the most out of your experience. I would also recommend getting orientated by viewing the forum from the viewing platform of palatine hill – you can get a superb shot of the colosseum from this vantage spot also. A sensible and common approach is to have an ‘ancient rome’ day and combine a visit to the roman forum with palatine hill and the colosseum. Although there is certainly enough time in the day to do this, it’s convenient (they are located adjacent to each other and covered in the one ticket) you need to pace yourself – as it’s a lot to take in. I would suggest doing the colosseum and palatine hill in the morning and having a long lunch in the shade before seeing the forum in the afternoon (as it’s the least crowded). Bring plenty of water, sunscreen and a hat – as it gets hot! Takes about 1.5-2.5 hours (depending on the person).

Something you can't see in Paris or London. Brilliant and excellent scenery. This is something you can't see in Paris and London. You can see the ruins and imagine the might roman empire in the oldest day. Do bring water when you visit the area as there is no shelter over the day.

Strong shoes and a hat required. A huge, incredibly historical site with more to see than you can really take in. It's all open-air so make sure you take water and wear a hat and sun cream if visiting in summer months; also wear sensible shoes to allow for the cobbles and uneven ground and book a guided tour or you won't know the significance of what you're seeing. Always and rightly on the check list for any sightseeing tour of Rome.

Great. Seeing the center of Roman life was awesome. It is hard to describe how much history occurred in this place. Another place to visit while in Rome. Again you can find a tour guide or just read up a bit before you get here. Either way you will enjoy the experience.

A true step back in time. Must do.. We went to the Roman Forum right when it opened. I would recommend that you do the same, as we were in Rome during a very busy time, yet people didn't start arriving at the RF until about an hour after we got there. We did the audio tour, which was very interesting and cheap. Be sure to take a water bottle and possible a fan, because it is in a "hole" and the air does not flow. You don't want to have to rush through because each stop is incredible. You truly go back in time. When viewing each monument and listening to the audio, you can truly picture how they lived and what each monument was used for. Palatine Hill is also included. We walked up just to see how pretty it was. However, to be honest, we were tired, as it was about 95 degrees. I wish we would've had more energy to do the full Hill activities as well.

Tour guide or guidebook is a must. First, I do not recommend going in summer. There is very little shade and only a few water fountains. If you do decide to go, you absolutely should hire a guide or buy a guidebook.The scope of the forum is impressive but unfortunately most of the buildings have long since collapsed. The signs next to the ruins include very little information. My wife and I really wished we had a guide. It takes about 1.5-2 hours to review. I would have spent longer but it was stifling and there was just too little information about the various buildings.

Interesting. The Roman Forum should probably be on your list of places to visit in Rome, as the sheer size and scale of the buildings are unbelievable. I would suggest that you purchase a guide book or get information on the structures beforehand, otherwise it will quickly become just a lot of rubble in the fields. The guide books that show you what the structure used to look like and what it was used for, is very handy.

A site that requires time and information. We tried to go straight here after spending several hours in the Colosseum - not a great plan. Yes, the two sites are included on one ticket and within easy walking distance of one another, but each site requires plenty of time to fully enjoy. We left after a quick viewing of the ruins because everyone was fading and needed lunch. The expanse and variety of ruins here is amazing, and I wish we had returned after lunch to spend more time. Unfortunately, we had so much on our list to squeeze in that we short-changed the forum a bit. If you really want to appreciate all that these great ruins offer, make sure you schedule enough time - a whole morning or afternoon would probably do it.

Heart of the ancient world. I loved walking in the footsteps of Julius Caesar and standing by the rostrum site where Mark Anthony and others made their famous speeches. This was my favourite site in th city and it is free to enter

Ruins of Ancient History. A friend had recommended the "red book" before going and I wish I would have gotten one. It would have been nice to see the past and present illustrations. There is an incredible amount of history in this location. Definitely place the Roman Forum on your itinerary.

Very good. It seems a somewhat unpopular opinion but although I found the forum incredible I would actually recommend spending more time on Palatine Hill to be honest. Still a fantastic taste of roman history

Walk trough ancient history. The Roman Forum is a large and stately collection of ruins which represented the market place and political center of ancient Rome. It is situated in a slight valley between the Palatine and Capitoline Hills and a short walk from the Colosseum. It would be hard to appreciate the history of this place without a guide or headset explanation. This is a great opportunity for terrific photos. There is a fee to enter the Forum but can be bundled with the entrance fee to the Colosseum. There are great views of this area from behind the huge white monument to Emmanuel II.

nice history. I visited this place Friday and was able to get a guided tour with helpful information and he pointed out other buildings to us in the area that we were able to see. You got a great visual of ancient life in Rome. A must see.

Don't go on a Sunday, but once inside AMAZING. We figured the best way to see some sites in Rome post cruise would be to take an excursion. We lucked out in the morning with barely a wait to enter St Peters which was where our luck ran out. Our guides took us (38 people) on a "shortcut" to the Forum and since it was a Sunday it appeared everyone in Rome wanted to visit the forum too. With the construction near the entrance everyone was lumped into one indiscernible line when there were supposed to be two lines, booked tours and walk ups. We sat for over 90 minutes waiting for our tour guide to push her way to the front of the ticket window. While standing near the entrance for the better part of 90' we watched as the one police/security guard manually checked each entrants belongings; our other guide kept telling us this was because of the "Charlie Hebdo attack" no one on our tour could determine what one had to do with the other. If you're going to attempt to stop a terrorist attack, perhaps multiple guards and a few metal detectors to expedite the entry.

Allow time for this..... Give yourself an afternoon to visit the Roman Forum and surrounding areas. Don't rush it but realise that there are buildings from different centuries that are like layers of history. Try to get one of the books that have literal layers that show the ruins and how it was in their prime to get a feel of how majestic this place was in days gone by. Very relaxing and one of our more enjoyable visits in Rome.

Travel back in time and visit the Roman forum. The best views of the area is the Palatine Hill hill. Colosseum combination ticket you see all these things. A lot of historical residue over a wide area. The surrounding areas have little protection, so be sure to sun cream and drink. Definitely worth a visit.

Extremely hot, awe-inspiring trip through the past.. If you come to Rome for anything about the Imperial Roman past, you cant NOT go to the Forum. It was the center of Roman politics and power for centuries. Its walking through the past. It is also right next to the Circus Maximus which makes it a easy to go from one to the other.

LET YOUR IMAGINATION TAKE YOU. A fascinating walk through the ruins of the old city centre. Yes, it is true that you cannot make out clearly every structure but the scale and the general layout is still apparent. In fact the ruins lend a wonderful romanticism and beauty to an already spectacular scene. You are walking through another time and it is all unfolding around you - quite an unusual experience - you can almost imagine the life once there.

Forum demonstrates advanced civilization in Rome 21 centuries ago !!. Unbelievable sights mesmerizes and takes you back in time to 1st century BC. Its very hard to visualize and appreciate the advanced administration and government functions how it would have happened then. Also its surprising to see how they failed to sustain the momentum in subsequent centuries.

Roman Forum. Best take an organised tour around this wonderful place to try and understand what life was actually like all those years ago. Our tour guide was wonderful and she was able to bring the area to life with inneresting facts and stories that abound from this area.

Don't miss it. This is a fascinating site to wander around. Seeing the physical evidence all around you of such a inspiring civilisation is a wonderful experience. Also thoroughly recommend visiting Palatine Hill, another rich treasure trove of things to see including a small museum, and some breathtaking views across Forum, Circus Maximus, Coliseum and Rome.

Lovely place. We visited the Roman Forum as it was included with the ticket for the Colosseum. It was so beautiful and breathtaking. I really enjoyed walking around - my only regret is not getting a guide or book about it, so that I could have learned more about the history.

Interesting walk through history.... Find this attraction to be fairly run of the mill. Much of the structures are missing or collapsed beyond recognition as a pile of rocks. Included as part of your Colosseum ticket so worth the walk.

When in Rome ..... We had no idea what we were looking at most of the time. It was all just really cool old ruins. Lots of scattered and propped up ruins with scaffolding all over the show, but cool nonetheless. We are totally not into history but when in Rome ....Well, we decided to stay in Tivolli and just to trip in on the train for the day. Good choice. We saw Rome. We experienced Rome. You have to do it. One tip: everyone kept telling us to go queue at the Colosseum for tickets. I had read that there are no queues at the Forum and this was absolutely true. Loooong queues at the Colosseum and we walked around till we saw the little ticket office and off we went. This ticket served us well at the Colosseum skipping the ticket sales and just queuing to enter. Thank you to everyone for tipping us on that in their online reviews. It was the most crowds we encountered in Italy, but very enjoyable and a definite must do!

Loved it! Must see.. We visited this attraction as part of the multi ticket for the Colosseum. We visited here first as getting the ticket here when the queue is small allows you to queue jump at the Colosseum later.A stunning place, you can easily get lost in the history walking around here.Highly recommended.
Amazing site. Amazing history, a real must to see in Rome. I would advise to do a tour so you get the most out of this site.

Fantastic. Visited the Roman forum and to be honest the hairs on my back stood on end, although we didn't have a tour guide thought the ancient area was fantastic, very busy and very hot, would defiantly return, only stayed in Rome 2 nights on our tour, wish it was more.
To walk in history. To take a walk or a guided tour in Forum Romanum is really to take a walk in history. It is just a must do in Rome.

The Centre of Ancient Civilization. This was the heart of ancient Rome. The place where trade took place, the senate met and at that time was the centre of civilization in the world. A must-see when in Rome. Get acquainted with some history of the forum beforehand and you'll enjoy it even more

Roman Forum sights. Buy your tickets online ahead of time to avoid the long lines (www.coopculture.it) You'll still need to wait in line to exchange your reservation code for actual entry tickets, but the line is much shorter. Arrive early and plan accordingly since the combo ticket also allows entry to the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. The forum isn't just one sight, but comprised of multiple ruins (Curia, Imperial Rostra, Temple of Vespasian, Temple of Saturn and more). Have fun.

ancient rome. Tour organized through Walking Tours of Italy. Covered the Forum, Palatine Hill and the Coliseum. Excellent value for money, comprehensive narrative and time to look and experience locations.
Roman forum. Very atmospheric and you can imagine shopkeepers and senators wandering about. Use the earphone guide as this tells you what it all is.

Lovely history. The Roman Forum breathes history, the same goes for the palatine hill. I would recommend to buy a book(guide) which tells you the roman history in more depth. Keep in mind this trip contains a lot of walking (and stair climbing) without much shadow. So doing this on a day with a relatively low temperature would be wise.

Must See!. A must see if you are in Rome. It is across from the Coliseum so it is easy access. It is quite extensive and will take a bit of time if you really want to experience it. Be prepared for stairs, uneven walkways, and crowds. It is so worth it nevertheless. You can walk through and imagine the ancient activities, and you can get great views from above. Plan at least an hour or two to really take it in.

Deep dive into history. The forum and palatine hill sum up for me the depth of history in RomeAnd I mean depth when you realise how far below modern street level you areDon't get a tour guide, get a good book plenty available and take yourself around you will see things the guides ignore. And remember that a lifetime in Rome isn't long enough to explore
Historical dream. Loved it, paid when we got there, don't bother with the tour just get the headset. Try and book for the behind the scenes tour though it takes you right down to the bottom.

Awesome History. We studied roman history prior to coming to Rome. It was very enjoyable to imagine what is was like back 2,000 years ago while walking around the forum. This is a very worthwhile visit while in Rome.
Why No Starbucks?. Disappointing. It was a long day and they didn't even have a Starbucks. The icecream was good but we noticed that the sell-by date was a week before.

Ice Cream will never be the same!. Loved everything we saw in Italy, the history of it all was fantastic! Try and fit in everything you can to get the most of your trip. Local people were very friendly. I think we overdosed with eating their ice cream.

Brilliant photo opportunities. The Roman Forum was the centre of Ancient Rome and there is a still a significant amount that can be seen. Well work a visit which will give you the chance to take some great pictures, although an audio guide or map are handy to discern certain buildings.Useful tip: Purchase a combined ticket for entry into the Colosseum, Palantine Hill and Roman Forum at either Palantine Hill or Roman Forum entrances to avoid lengthy queues at the Colosseum (reduced rates are offered for 18-25 year olds, under 18's go free)

It's interesting, a walk through history. My wife and I walked thru the Forum; while it is very historical, we probably didn't get as much out of it as other people did.Still, it was interesting to walk among the 'ruins' and think of its history.
Beautiful Roma. Go to there and see the real history through your own eyes! This is a amazing experience to your soul.

Better than the Pope. We skipped out on the Papal audience to visit the Forum. We took a bus near the hotel and though a little crowded managed to get off overlooking the Forum. After a guided tour of the Coliseum we continued onto the Forum. What an amazing site. There is enough history to spend days looking over all the ruins. To think that two thousand years ago, this was the hub of the world and we were looking at the monuments and buildings that the people you read about in the history books walked the same place and built it. There are signs explaining everything in Italian and English. This trip was better than sitting with hundreds of thousands of people looking at the Pope.

Highlight of Rome visit. We really enjoyed the Roman Forum. We had a Roma Pass which allowed us to quickly get in. We went in the morning so that it would be a little cooler, as there is little shade. Many ancient buildings, some fairly intact and some in ruins, great for history buffs.

Strolling through history is fun for kids and adults alike. We visited the Forum with only a guide book and it worked out well. My granddaughter wanted to climb all over the ruins--and she did at times. I especially like the grave and remembrance of Julius Caesar.

A not-so-funny thing happened on the way back from the Forum. A must on the bucket list.A splendor of antiquity. Very sore feet because no taxi driver after waiting in their line, would drive me the 3 km short trip to the hotel. Very sore feet because no taxi driver after waiting in their line, would drive me the 3 km short trip to the hotel. So I had to hobble up and down stairs in the street with painful cobblestones Normally there is nothing wrong with that, unless you really want to get to the hotel and are in pain. I have a selfie to prove I was there!
A fair attraction.... I was less than whelmed with this attraction. It was only okay. I expected something else. Not a buff for ancient history. It's a quick look-see. It's okay if you like history.
Love the Forum. Unforgettable piece of history, not to be missed in Rome. Extremely well done, with plaques describing various sites.

Guide is a must to make the most of this visit. A good guide is a must for the history lesson. I learned of the formation of Rome by the twins Romulus and Remus through to the political history and of the buildings. Be careful that the guide doesn't try to add another more expensive tour later!

Get Tickets Here. If you're seeing Colosseum, then get your tickets at the Forum entrance just up the hill. The line is significantly shorter and it's the same 2-day pass. However, be careful with the pass as there's no readmission. "2-day" really means that you are allowed it once within the next 2 days.The Forum is gorgeous. Great buildings, gardens, and scenery. There's plenty of see and the combined ticket price would be worth just seeing the Forum.

Mature beauty. Was wowed with how old the structures were. Some are still being dug up all over the city. What great history. Pillars. Monuments. Pebbled roads. The same roads that kings and peasents walked on. Ruins are what they are. They show what ancient civilization looked like. I havent seen anything like it in my life. You learn about it in school and would never think one day you would see it in person. The ides of march, julius ceaser, and the roman empire. So inspiring and educational to be here in rome to see it for yourself.A must see !Entrance was free to the forum with the purchase of the colloseum tix. We saw the forum right away after the colloseum as it was right in front of the colloseum.

A walk through history.. We spend a half of a clear sunny day walking through this amazing site. It is hard to imagine a place that gives you more of a sense of life 2000 years ago and it's found in the centre of the huge, modern, thriving city of Rome. Be prepared to do some walking as the site is huge.
Must see when in Rome. Like I said, this is a must see when in Rome! So much history and architecture to see and learn about.

Historic Site. Having studied ancient architecture in college I loved visiting places like this and getting a feel for how it used to be back then. The tour was very informative and you could still see a lot of the buildings that are still standing today. This was part of the Colosseum tour so make sure you dont pay for both as we got a ticket that included both
Interesting. This place is interesting and full of history. Best way to explore the area is to have a good travel book or guide.

Third time to Rome and first time to the Roman Forum. Why didn't I come before?. This was my favorite site in Rome! It was far better than the Colosseum with more history and much more to see than the home of the gladiators. We had a great tour guide to walk us around here and I highly suggest you do the same. She gave us great insight on each site, why they were built the way they were, how life was when the Forum was in full swing, etc. I want to visit again because I just couldn't take it all in the first time.

Walk and listen. Take your time- get a guide or read up as you go. History is all around, and what history. Empires, love stories, innovations. And the beauty, it's everywhere, from the flora to the ornate carvings in small places and pieces.But, to really enjoy it- do you homework or get a good guided tour.We went on a tour and enjoyed the experience greatly. And, when we were done we could stay and retrace our steps and see more. There is water available, bring a container, and restrooms, and the site is served by city busses for easy transportation.

So much history!. Plan to spend at least three to four hours here. Take a guided tour if you can, or read up beforehand and bring a guidebook. Most importantly, take at least a minute to just sit down, unplug, and take it all in-- imagine whose footsteps you are walking in. You'll see the place where Caesar's body was put on display after he died and so many other things. It gives you the chills.

Roman feeling. I agree with what other reviewers wrote...when you are there and walk on those paths where once the great Emperors walked you get a good insight how it has been. Well maintained ruins, buildings, statues... magnificent is the right word. Yes some people should show more respect...damaging things for that one pic isnt the right way. It can get hot there and not many places where you can find some shade so be prepared. Admire this place and enjoy ancient Rome.

Your best view of ancient Rome. We were on a tour and so we were taken to an overlook of the Forum and did not get to walk among the ruins. I think everybody who goes to Rome should and was disappointed that our group did not. From our vantage point, though it looked very interesting. It is located right behind the Victor Emmanuel Monument (which also should not be missed - it is HUGE)

Amazing place but frustrating. It is well worth visiting (obviously) as it is a unique place of interest, however there are things to be aware of. The forum and palatine are accessed in one visit and I don't believe that multiple entries are possible (on the same ticket). This is frustrating because it is such a large area and there is so much to see it would be better to split into more than one visit. This is especially the case because the facilities inside are quite poor, for example there is nowhere to buy food. Therefore be prepared to take provisions for however long you intend to spend there, and I would say that you need at least 3 hours. I would also recommend that you take your own maps and guides as nothing is properly explained inside. I cannot see this being a suitable place to come with children.

History, history, history . My kids loved this - we had a private tour guide - we figured we spent all this money getting here so we may as well get a tour guide to make it even better. Fabulous place - incredible history and what they've uncovered is nothing short of amazing. Tip - go early in the morning before the security lines get too big.

Go at night. The forum is truly a peek into the past. So many structures and styles to behold. It has a sentimental value for me because I have a photo of my father here from before I was born - so I had to do the same thing. It's also beautiful at night with all the different lights. I was rather surprised to find it peaceful despite how busy other streets around it were. Definitely worth a visit at night for a different perspective.

So much to see. Wonderful site and as other reviewers have suggested you need a guide to fully appreciate it. We choose the audiotape tour it was some help. The Roman forum can be tough for people with strollers or wheel chairs.

WELL WORTH THE 25EURO. i have been to see rome three times and everytime i take the colosseum tour and with the tour you get to go around the forum as well the tour was in english and the fella doing the tour was very very well read and he made you feel as if you were there yourself well worth the 25euro

what a view of the city. The forum is a must see when you are in Rome. It is next to the Colluseum and Arch of Constantine. Make sure you bring walking shoes and walk to the top for the view of a lifetime that looks over the city. Its worth the hike up the hill.

Highlight of my trip to Rome. As a former Latin and world history student, it was amazing to walk the Forum in the same place where so much history has occurred over 3,000 years. We had a cruise tour excursion which allowed us to enter at a designated time without a line. We had two incredible guides who talked to us about so many of the ruins and former buildings. However, as a former student, I was aware of just where we were and what this place had once been. It was amazing to know how much of the Forum valley had been under earth over centuries of misuse. This experience was simply amazing and one of the places I have wanted to visit for a lifetime. I am so happy I have been and I highly recommend to anyone visiting Rome. It was incredibly crowded but worth being with so many people.

Get there on a Segway for the best view. Very good, but need to know the background before arriving. Best way is to arrive on a Segway (see my Segway post) as it can be quite a climb to the top of the hill to get the best vantage point. Also on a hot day using a Segway is a breeze.

When in Rome!!!!!. Absolutely amazing. I loved our long weekend to Rome, be prepared to do some walking too. The Roman Forum on a sunny day is a must as is the walk down to the Colosseum. Highly recommended.
A must do in Rome. Amazing to visit the very old Rome, with a guide, and being able to imagine how the Romans lived ! Well preserved site ; charming.
so awesome!. Had a great time taking pictures and learning the history here. Not too crowded. Be prepared to be out in the sun for a while as there is no shade

a guide is needed. Excellent site, so much to see but things need to be explained or you wont know what your looking at. There is a lot of walking on uneven ground and stairs. Bring a water bottle plenty of places for refills. It is amazing how visitors can get right on these ancient sites, saw a couple standing on top of monuments no respect shown, They should have more security to prevent people from doing things like that.

Walk where Caesar walked, live and breath the history, savor the moment!. Another of the many beautiful attractions in Rome. Located between the Piazza Venezia and the Colosseum, while today it's a ruin, imagine yourself in ancient Rome and walking through the magnificent architecture of the area. Remember to enjoy and live in the moment, you're in what was the political heart of the Roman Empire!
best in the kind. there ruins are the best in the kind. just walk there for 1-2 hour and you will hear the presence of an empire

Takes you back in time!. Walking through the Roman Forum takes you back in time. You can just imagine what it would be like two thousand years ago. All the structures are incredible and if walls and columns could talk, the stories you would hear. If you are in Rome for a day the Coloseeum and Forum are quite the tandem and across the street from one another for easy travel. Lots of vendors selling ice cold bottles of water for those hot days.

Fantastic Roman forum. The forum is a must-see and the same ticket is used for Colosseum.The audiotape is worth listening to but even without it, you feel such an emotion by seeing the huge remains of the past.Palatin is also included in the visit and from there you have a wonderful view on Roma especially at sunset.This visit is one of the best of my life.
very dissapointing. lack of explanation signs, so if you didn't came with a tour guide you will probably won't understand nothing. almost no places for resting.

Roman forum. . Brilliant place. Stones throw from the colosseum so you can do it before or after visiting it. Would allow at least 2/3 hours to walk around the site as once in its quite large and some parts are hidden especially up the palatine hill. Wear decent shoes as some parts are uneven. At the top you can see the circus maximus, top of St. Peter's as well as other sights of Rome.

Disappointing. I was really looking forward to walking in the footsteps of Augustus and reliving the killing of Julius Caesar, as I had seen this ruin of ancient Rome from a distance on a past visit to the city. However the experience was a wash out. The site is being worked on by archeologists so it must be the the subject of considerable research. However there were no audio guides available, no human guides to bring the place to life, no directed way round just a few boards here and there. How could the city of Rome waste this potentially enthralling experience????

Amazing . The Forum is one of the places you "must" visit. We visited with a guided tour that also included the colosseum. I'm glad that we did the forum with a guide, otherwise you are there, just staring at ruins, and you don't have a clue about anything at all. The forum is massive and you can easily spend all day there. But because we were with a tour we only got to spend an hour or so there, so we could only appreciate the highlights. The joint ticket for the colosseum and forum is valid for 48 hours but since we visited both attractions on the same day we weren't able to return to the forum to see the rest of it. That was a let-down.

Nicem but you can pass on it. The Roman Forum, Palatine Hill and the Coliseum are all under one ticket which costs $12 euros per person. You can buy your tickets at the main entrance of the Coliseum, the entrance to the forum, or the entrance to Palatine Hill. Many advice bloggers suggest to purchase your tickets either from the entrance of the Forum or Palatine Hill because lines are much shorter. Well, everyone know knows this advice and these lines are no longer shorter.I really think that the Forum is not a MUST SEE landmark unless you are into the history and architecture of ancient Rome. There was no WOW FACTOR in this area at all. A couple of pictures here and there, but that was it. TIPS:-There are several restrooms in the Forum as well as drinking fountains.-You can move from the Roman Forum to Palatine Hill. There is no special gate.-The backpack issue was hit and miss. I saw many people with regular full size pack packs.

Wear comfortable shoes!. Make sure that you wear very comfortable walking shoes and bring water when touring this site. Buying a guidebook is highly recommended to help you enjoy the splendors of this area.

You have to see this. The Roman Forum is, basically, the ruins of ancient Rome. It is just incredible. Do a guided tour so that you can get the really interesting bits of history that go with each building and artifact. Bring a bottle of water- there are fountains all over where you can refill it. It is hot, but not unbearable.The guided tour we did was $13 per person (plus admission) for both the Coliseum and the Forum. Well worth it. Tours are easy to find and worth the few bucks to get the back story.

Full of History. The Roman Forum and Palatine Hill are amazing and full of history. It is a must see in Rome and is located alongside the Colosseum. The forum shows much of ancient Rome's political history with many important government buildings once standing here. It does involve a lot of walking so I would advise wearing sneakers and dressing in light clothing as it does get hot.

avoid the Colosseum queues. The ticket for the Roman forum and Palatine hill include the Colosseum. I would recommend going to the Forum first (no queues at the ticket office), before it gets too hot. The ticket is valid for 48 hours, and lets you jump the ticket queues at the Colosseum.

Ancient Mall. Walking through the Roman Forum gives you a feel of the hustle and bustle that must have been a daily routine for its inhabitants. Judging by the modern Italian way of life, its intense communication, fun, gestures and dolce vita you can imagine Romans in togas walking across the squares, finishing their business and discussing politics over a glass of vino. The forum gives you a real feel of the emerging nature of Rome as an empire and its city. Lots of changes, emerging temples, streets, reclamation, water supplies and ongoing improvements of the city. The sheer space taken up is impressive and lends the centre a special gravitas.

Morning of Ruins. Forum & Palitine Hill are worth a visit, Interesting place and history. Pays to visit in morning as it gets very hot by Midday. Pleanty of drinking water fountians to keep you going in the heat
Romans were geniouses. Full of history, but you have to avoid it in summer, because it is a long visit and the sun kills you. Audioguides are very good.

Great, hot place. I didn't know a lot about the Roman Forum before I visited recently, but thanks to Rick Steves travel book and the useful signs there, I learned a lot. There's a ton to see, so give yourself lots of time. Also, if visiting in the summer, make sure to refill your water frequently and reapply sunscreen because it's super hot.

You have to come here really.. If your in Rome and you've seen the Colosseum. This is the other must see.It is just a short walk from the Colosseum, in fact in was all part of the same complex in Roman times. But whereas the Colosseum was about public spectacle, the Forum was about political spectacle.The whole imagery from Shakespeare: Julius Caesar and "Et tu, Brutus!" come to mind. All apparently played out on the steps of the Forum.There are a number of very well preserved Roman buildings here, and many ongoing archeological discoveries being made all the time. When I first came here as a teenager, the Forum itself was a large rectangular building with little less around other than the triumphal arch. However, while that building is still there (obviously, I may not be in my forties but if it's already lasted 2000 years!!!) there are a lot of new discoveries and the Forum is now placed as being one of these new findings.It's a great place with so much history. It's what you think of when you picture Rome.A lot of it is also wheelchair accessible. The Italians have done a good job in making it so, but clearly not everywhere in a place like this can be accessible. Just be prepared to have to push the chairs up some steep inclines!

Unimaginable if you don't give five stars for this. The Roman Forum...the cradle of early civilization. It is much better when you hire a interpreter, because there is so much to learn when someone with a deep understanding of the life back then...can interpret the times to you. Just to go walk it is nice, but I think you get so much more out of it with someone sharing their knowledge.. It's breathtaking though just to see. Early life began with the Egyptians, Greeks and Romans. This is a great display of time standing still thru centuries of changes. A historians dream to be here, an every day persons as well

Rich History. The place is just beside Colosseum, turn right from the colosseum exit and walk 10 minutes. The place is full of history. Make sure you have shades with you. No need to by expensive water as one can get chilled water inside (there is tap out there). It would be great if one hires a guide.Also, its entry is covered in online ticket that you purchase ..in 12 or 14Euro ticket covers Colosseum and Roman forum.

Most of what you see was buried until the beginning of the 19th century only becoming visible in the last vicetury. Just a must see in Rome. Take a tour, a little knowledge enhances what is one of the great experiences of the world.

A MUST see for any history teacher. Visiting the Roman Forum is a must see for any history teacher. By visiting this site, I was able to take copious amounts of photos to be able to incorporate them into my curriculum for teaching world history. By visiting in the off season, I was able to spend additional time wandering about without the challenges of navigating photos around tourists.

History was made here!. To be honest, it was a surreal feeling standing where countless Emperors and famous Roman Senators walked and spent their time debating, plotting and determining the direction of the Roman interests in the world! The cobblestone paths are the same paths used by these people. Rome being the epicenter of so much influence in the history of the world; it makes one feel very small. Seemingly hallowed ground. Take a step back in history and visit the forum! Be careful of the beggars that post themselves around the site.

Unhelpful staff. We bought tickets online for the Coliseum and forum. After visiting the Coliseum my partner lost his ticket. We went to the ticket office at the Forum to explain what had happened. He had with him photo id- his passport and the printed receipt for the tickets we purchased in his name on that day online and I still had my ticket. Even with all this proof they denied us access. I felt this was totally unreasonable and just money grabbing. I am disgusted with their attitude and refused to buy another ticket.
Rome is Amazing. Amazing the way they are still so well preserved but all of Rome is like that, only thing to watch out for is some coffee shop really rip you off we paid 12 Euro in one place.

Amazing place to visit. We went as part of a tour which included the underground Colosseum tour. Excellent tour guide and well worth a visit and the guide tells you all you need to know. No guide you will not know what everything is. Real Rome Tours were our tour operator. Meet on site and small groups and well worth the spend.
Back to Ancient. Not of much interest really, walk a big round in like an empty plot of land. Can visit if have spare time though

Big and impressive worth seeing bring water. over the top for seeing history up close. There was so much more to see then I had imagined. I saw lots of people with guides and overheard some of them and it seems like I missed out on a ton of info by not having a guide. So I would say get a guide so you know what your looking at. Also no where inside to buy water so bring some because you will get hot.
A must. A touch of ages, a feeling of history. It is almost unreal to walk on the streets that are thousands years old.
Great place to see!!. This might be one of the better attractions to see in Rome. Lots of history. Very well presented. Definately worth seeing. Plan to spend about an hour...

Study up a bit before you go. The fee for this site is combined with your Colosseo tickets. There is a guide with a map on display of the land but still it would make more since if you study a bit before going for a better connection. If you run out of water you can refill your water bottle at the fountain. It's a very interesting area with a lot of history.
Much History. The history that took place here is overwhelming. Highly recommend getting a guided tour to truly experience the history.

Combine with Colosseum. This is a combined ticket with the Colosseum. We used our Roma pass to access both. We had a private guide which was extremely helpful -- i'm not sure you can glean all of the history and what you're seeing without one. Even though you're seeing ruins, it's fascinating to learn what archaeologists have been able to ascertain about the level of sophistication of the Roman empire.

A Long Walk through the past.. I recommend this to all of those who enjoy history and want to kill a few hours of time. There are many different sections to this site that offer interesting insight to what the past looked like in ancient Rome.

Ancient Rome Tour. We toured the Roman Forum as part of an "Ancient Rome" tour. When in Rome for the first time this should be a must see. When on the tour you learn many things about the interworking's of the Roman empire's political system which has a direct effect on many of the other ancient sites you may visit in Rome. It the tour give you more perspective of what life was like in ancient Rome.

A must-see. This is one of those "Cannot Miss" sites of Rome. Why travel to Rome and then not visit the ruins of the old city? We combined our visit to the Forum with a visit to the Coliseum, which is at one end of the Forum. One walks through the ruins and eventually comes out by the Capitoline Museums. We visited the Forum on a lovely fall day. There were lots of visitors, but we did not feel hurried or crowded. Our only disappointment was with the signage for the various ruins. We had some difficulty in keeping track on our map where we were when we compared the signage (or lack of it) with the map. But this is just a small nuisance compared to the experience of standing in the Roman Forum and imagining what it must have been like at its peak.

So Much To See. The Forum was the centre of Roman public life. Ruins of the market, some government buildings etc. can still be identified. You can spend quite a while wandering the ruins here, and if you have a particular interest it is probably worth getting an audio guide. This is a large expanse of ancient ruins so without a guide, make sure you take the time to read the information panels to make sense of it all. I think it is worth buying the Colosseum/Forum/Palatine Hill multi-ticket, but note this ticket will only let you into each attraction once, despite being valid for 48 hours.

Forum!. Coming into the visit to Rome I had no interest in seeing the Forum. But I left with so much interest. May favorite attraction in the city itself so authentic and real! One downside is the amount of trash that is in this city which is gross at times.

I DID LIKE IT MORE BEFORE 20 YEARS AGO. I was visiting Rome 20 years ago and I find it nicer that today. You can sit arround walls of roman historic monuments and feel like part of it. I remember that I was feeling like I am sitting in the midle of muvie just sitting at walls around Forro Romano. Today you have a glass or fences and can't go near so it is not the same filling. I can understand that it is for saving monuments from people but I miss my Rome from 20 years ago. You can't even put a hand in mouth of La boca della verita

Amazing. We had brought a combi ticket which covered both Colosseum and Forum . Even with the ticket you have to stand in long lines for entry which is a sad things :( considering how hot it can be in summer !! But the place is amazing .You can spend hours together seeing each structure , remains of temple here . Michelangelo Square which is just adjacent to it is also nice place to visit . Not much things available to eat once inside except for gelato shop adjacent to Forum exit . So pack your snacks . It may get tiring walking around but really nice place to see ... especially view from Palatine hill .

Most interesting attraction in Rome. We enjoyed this attraction most of all the many places we visited. All these various temples and buildings (what's left of them, of course) speak to the imagination and we felt taken back in time approximately two millenia. We felt this was the highlight of our visit.

A Must See on The Itinerary. The Roman Forum is a must see when visiting Rome. Without a doubt the walk through ruins is a walk back in time and puts into perspective life during the height of the Empire. One MUST, before going to the site, look for drawings and renderings of what Rome looked like at the time. This lends a great visual as you walk from site to site and then up to the top of the hill overlooking ruins below. The columns, architecture, and engineering of the ancients were phenomenal. You will stand in amazement at the detail and intricacy of design and building. Walk out the back gate at the Arch of Septimius Severus and see the Mammontine Prison just 100 steps away. See my other review

Recommend using a guide book or audio tour.. This place is only interesting if you know what you are looking at. Bathrooms and water are limited so take care of those needs before hand. It is a long walk as well, but definitely worth seeing. FULL of history.

Ancient past, modern fascination. Loved the ruins of ancient Rome. The imagination runs wild knowing the history of these spots, the shear importance of the influences these very places made to the world is staggering to consider. Did not like that our ticket would not allow us to re-enter form a different gate we entered once we had visited the Colosseum but whatever! Really liked the fresh water accessible just as the water has always flowed here for citizens to drink.
Really cool. Really cool. Very hot in the summer - would suggest umbrella. They also have ancient water fountains to fill water bottles - otherwise bring water.

A pleasant, beautiful and interesting stroll. This is a must when in Rome. It is pleasant even before the history lesson begins, as strolling through the landscape with trees and buildings offer shadow as well as a view. The history lesson will teach you that western civilization rose from this point (if there is such a thing as western civilization). Anyway, one has to admire how the romans built a modern town so many centuries ago.

excellent, but I recommend a tour.. We really enjoyed it. We had an audio guide we'd downloaded, and I'd been on a tour the last time I was in rome, so I remembered some things to tell my boyfriend. I really recommend a tour, unless you're a total history buff, so you know what you're looking at.

Roman Forum, Palatine Hill, Colosseum. I did this review for the Colosseum, but also wanted to share it here:There is not much I can add to this incredible piece of history than what is already out there. However, I am writing this review to give tips to travelers going there for the first time. YOU DO NOT NEED TO BOOK A SKIP THE LINE TOUR if you follow these tips.Tips:1. DO NOT START AT THE COLOSSEUM. It's by far the longest lines and there is not point on standing in line when you dont have too. Instead, go in thru the Palatine Hill entrance. If you are taking the metro in, do not get off at the Colosseum exit. Instead go to the Circo Massimo and exit there. Then walk up the Via d. San Greggorio and you will see the entrance on the left. We had a two minute wait while the Colosseum entrance had a 1 hour wait. The same ticket, which cost 12 Euros (and its free for 18 and under), gets you into Palatine Hill and the Roman forum (which are attached) and the Colosseum (separate). To go into the colosseum, all you have to do is get on the "have ticket line" which is the same the tour companies use for their "skip the line" tours.2. It is going to take you 4-6 hours to see all three places, so get plenty of water and eat if you have kids with you. You cannot buy drinks or food once inside. Rome is hot, and this place is huge and hilly, so be ready for a good workout.3. Watch out for pickpockets. A lady tried to pick pocket my brother.4. Take the time. This is really an amazing place. Schedule plenty of time to really see it all.
Long weekend must see. Another must see, its a nice walk with lots to see.Cose to the Colosseum so continue there after that.

Roman Foru. It was an amazing experience. All that history, all that buildings were mindblowing if you are interested in roman/greek history.
It could be quite hot if you visit there in summer. So crowded as well. Bring a bottle with you, you do not need to pay for water because Rome is full of fountains!

When in Rome. Buy your tickets in advance to avoid the queues or buy a combined ticket here which includes the Palatine Hill and the Colosseum. There is so much history within touching distance to see that you are in danger of history overload! A photographers paradise.

A surprise that ended up more than I imagined. I'm embarrassed to say I didn't know of the forum until we arrived at the colosseum. We thought it would take about an hour to see... Well weren't we surprised. It was fabulous. It was incredible to walk through and imagine what it must have been like when it was an active community. All these places I had only heard of .. Ie vestril virgins. Make sure you wear walking shoes and take water.
Morning Excursion. Loved the ruins and it was a easy hike but super hot the day we went. IWe didnt take a guide and regretted it.

Walk through history!. Amazing to see all that this city has to offer, especially in the Roman Forum where there is a concentration of antique buildings and structures. Great place to stroll through after seeing the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. If you buy a ticket, it grants you entrance into all 3 attractions - Colosseum, Palatine Hill, and Roman Forum. Make sure you have at least half a day to fully experience these three amazing places.If you buy a Roma Pass, make sure you do this as your first or second attraction so you enter free - this is the most expensive attraction from their list.

Must do experience for history lovers and anyone interested in civilisation, politics or modern western life. The Roman Forum is part of a larger area of Temples and Roman Empire age relics and ruins. It is easy to miss as you walk around so make sure you either have a good map or use a guide. Like all the ruins it is a place you have to imagine, but this is the Forum where history was made and you are walking along the same pathways. It is an amazing place, but I would recommend knowing at least something of the history before you go. If you aren't a history buff then at least do a quick internet search.
