You will find lots of hints about beating the ticket queues, like which gate to use and to go early, all of which is good advice. I would add that it can get very hot on a sunny day, so wear a good hat and take water. And also allow heaps of time to wander around, you aren't likely to go again, unless you really love your history so take the time to look around well. It is a place where you get out what you take in with you... it is either another bunch of ruins or it is the amazing place of legend and history which has had such an impact on our modern life. Few places in this era are as significant as the Roman Forum.

Use a guide. Our second visit; the first time we were on our own, using a guidebook. Confusing ruins. This time we used a guide from Walks Of Italy, which made it a much more understandable and informative afternoon.

History at your feet. I bought tickets online for the Roman Forum and Colosseum which included the Palatino museum (on the Roman Forum grounds). It was a very hot day and there were lots of tourists but what can yo do it is a must see whilst in Rome. A great way to break up your day would be to go early and see the forum and museum, book your time for the colosseum for later in the day and go for a long lunch at a restaurant near the Piazza Venezia.Tip: wear comfortable shoes and bring a water bottle which you can refill at one of the spring fed fountains inside the grounds.

A fascinating insight into life in ancient Rome. We spent just over four hours exploring this fascinating site. The climb to the top of the Palantine Hill is well worth the effort and the remains gave us a good insight into life in days gone by. The sign boards were informative and, with a guidebook or internet we learned much to interest us. The sheer size of the buildings is awe-inspiring and there are many photo opportunities. I would suggest that the best time for a visit is in the afternoon or early morning to miss most of the crowds.

A must see.. We went in June and it was very hot. It is good to visit before the Colloseum as you can buy tickets for both places and avoid the queue. It is also very close to the mammertine prison where St. Peter and Paul were held in Rome and is something any believer would appreciate seeing.

Must visit while in Rome. This is an incredible place at the centre of ancient Rome. The sense of history is palpable. They're beautiful ruins. Find a viewpoint above it as well to get a sense of scale. Buy a ticket on line before you go and beat the queues at the ticket office. Good, free public washrooms on site.

A step back in time among st the ruins.. This was a step back in history with the remains of Rome back in Caesar's time. It is quite an expanse of ruins and we did not have a guide to explain what we were looking at, so that or a written guide book might be helpful.
Part of the rome experience. This is a must see for any history buff. Don't get taken in with the costumed gladiators outside they will take your photo with your own camera and then charge you 20.00

good. Like the colosseum don't go on a hot day as too much to see and if you are hot you won't want too. Better out of season. We did not buy a guide as I know a lot about Romans but in any case for most people there are enough information signs around to explain what you need to know

Another remarkable place. just keep walking, and see all the amazing things done thousands of years ago
Make sure you have enough batteries-so you miss a thing
amazing antiques everywhere

Must visit in rome. The forums are another great must visit in rome. Dont go there without knowing your history very very well or without some kind of guided tour or audio guide! If you just go there without one of these you might end up missing alot!

As I looked over the Ancient Roman Ruins I thought ........ of the Emperors like Augustus, Caesar, Hadrian, Vespasian, Marcus Aurelius and Cleopatra.I recalled the Popes, the Christians, the Vestigial Virgins, togas, the Roman Legions and those remarkable aqueductsThen there was Hannibal and his elephants, Spartacus, and of course - gladiators and slaves. And who can compare with those magnificent old mosaics and Roman statues. The bad times - like the Sack of Rome in 1527.And those Sword and Sandal Movies - like Ben Hur, Quo Vadis and The Robe.But I learned so mush watching the BBC series of 'I Claudius' - it bought them all to life so realistically. SPQR.Brian, from Perth. W. Australia.

Layers of History in one amazing site (important note of tickets!). We visited the Roman Forum and Coliseum on the same day during our trip to Rome in early June 2015. It was already 84 degrees at 9:00am so take water and stay hydrated. We used the Rick Steves podcast for descriptions of both sites as we walked for the several hours around both sites. Amazing to see the details of the construction of these structures that have stood for centuries. It's well worth spending all morning and into the afternoon in the area, knowing that it will be getting pretty hot as the day goes on. We came back the next day to see the Palatine Hill. The Palatine Hill and Circus Maximus was a long morning walking tour as well.Important note, the 3 site, two day pass that gives you entry (one time each) to Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill is a great value. Important note though, the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill are considered the same entry. We got lucky that our second day was a Sunday, and these sites were free to entry. Otherwise we would have been required to buy another one day pass to go back in the Roman Forum/Palatine Hill entrance for a second time.
Interesting site.. Like the Colosseum the Forum is a must see. We couldn't see everything as the site is so large, climb Palatine Hill for great views over the site and of the Circus Maximus.
History at its best. Recommend reading up before you visit so you know a hit about what you're looking at. Amazing to wander around the centre of the empire

A Must-See for History Buffs - GREAT visit!. If you have read Julius Caesar, know anything about Romulus & Remus, or care at all about the founding of Rome, This is your place. A beautifully preserved & protected site that speaks from the stones themselves about the story of Ancient Rome. See the triumphal arches and read the artwork on them that proclaims Roman victory over different peoples, visit the building from which Marc Antony gave Caesar's funeral speech, and be in awe at the remains of the once pagan temples. Don't forget to visit the Palatine Hill while you're here, too - a great place to find some shade and cool off!

Very Interesting if you love ruins and architecture. Another place to visit near Colosseum. Its huge, believe me its very very huge place. You can spend the whole day going through the Roman Forum with so many ruins and old old architecture. It totally depends on your capacity to walk that how much can you cover. We spent around 2 hours walking around enjoying the views, ruins, fountains and taking photos. We skipped a few places inside the Roman Forum as it was very far away. We them from the distance and then moved to our next destination. But believe me if you are interested in this place you can spend your whole day here. Worth a visit. How many time, it totally depends on your interest.
amazing. All I can say it's A-M-A-Z-I-N-G, I love culture trips and I love to known about tha past of a city visiting this types of monuments

Bundle it with the Coliseum. Bundled with the Coliseum and you have a full dose of the Glory and barbarity of Rome. The Forum is so historically significant it should not be missed even in a city chocked full of must see sites. You can get a ticket bundled with the Coliseum though and should consider doing so on line before arriving.
Experience Roman History. Fabulous to be able to experience and twalk through this ancient part of Rome .. Deep with history .

Need to use your imagination a bit. Being a bit of a amature historian this was a fantastic place to be. The detail in carvings on the arches was fantastic. You have to use your imagination a lot as there isn't much left standing but just to be there was a fantastic experience for me.Note is not suited for disabled people as the ground is uneven and not accessible.
Stunning. Spectacular site. Make sure you bring as much information as you can to help explain the site. It can be very confusing with so much to see so a good map and info are critical.

Very Interesting!. We visited the Forum as part of a walking tour. It is very interesting. Wear comfortable shoes - there are lots of rocks and cobblestones which can make walking difficult, and bring your water bottle. It was very hot the day we visited, but thankfully there are several fountains to refill bottles.
Rome is littered with history. Another wonderful place to visit in Rome which excited the brain in to thoughts of past lives of the people who built and lived around ... Love Rome

Lots of walking!. It was great to see this. Very hot very rough roads to walk. Take a hat and some water. Shoes are very important throw cute our for comfortable. Take advantage of any restroom you see in Rome!

Great for history buffs, not as accessible for folks with canes, wheelchairs. May damage power wheelchairs with big rock. Fantastic to see all the old buildings, courtyards, etc, but not so good for someone with a cane or who uses a wheelchair. The site could damage a power wheelchair as not all routes are paved or smooth - many uneven paths with large rocks. Go for the history.

Must see in Rome. We were on excursion from Royal Caribbean so had fast pass and jumped queues. we had official guide called Vacsimillian who was fantastic, so entertaining, painting pictures with words to give insights to how it was in roman times, describing how the Emporers used to live, we visited where Mark Anthony was buried and the Vestal Virgins crypt also. He was so vivid in his narrative you could feel the atmosphere around you. Truly amazing trip which I will never forget

Walk through history.. One of the great ruins spots on the planet. A place with surprises around each corner and each level. Roam by yourself for awhile and then opt for a guide if you want more information. The tours are pretty much on rails, but you can extract some nuggets from a good guide. A beautiful place to watch the day and weather change and no better place for unique photo ops.

Crowded but amazing. It was our 2nd visit the the forum. Tickets are combo forum & coliseum. Buy the tickets at the forum booth across from imperial forums. No line but there was an hour line to buy at the coliseum. Bring water bottles. It gets very hot once your in. Plan at least 2-3 hours to see additional hills.

Ancient Rome. A must if visiting ancient Rome. The ancient history is still very much in view and is worth the effort to visit. If you have read any history of Rome you will appreciate just how advanced the ancient Romans were. Not to be missed.

Part of World History . We all know that the Roman Empire made our society what it is right now in such many ways, and this is a good place to see how great the Empire was.It takes like 2 to 3 hours to visit all the site, so take the right timing to go there, take sunblock and water, there's not so much shadow to hide !By the way you can buy a ticked for the entrance of the colliseum at the same time, and there quite no line (because there's a huge line at the colliseum)A must do in Rome !
Must see. Must see. You can't fully understand the history of Rome without visiting these sites. Easy accessible location and worth the visit.

Roman Forum with Collesum tour. This was a great tour and awesome pics. There is some walking and on uneven bricks so be careful. Our tour guide took us through the Collesum and then when we were finished took us through a 30-40 minute tour of the Forum. Great to wrap the 2 together.
A deam come true. What a wonderful experience. It was hot, but wow, being able to experience what I've heard about all my life was amazing.

Great Piece of History. My wife and I had a guided tour of the Roman Forum that was an extension of the Colosseum tour that we paid 25 Euros each for but it was definitely worth it. Without the tour guide we probably would not have really know what we were looking at since some of the areas in the forum are just ruins. It was very neat to see the original structures from early Rome and get to walk where many historical figures walked. It was unfortunately extremely hot the day we went and there was not much shade so we did not feel like spending as much time there as we probably should but still a great place and we highly recommend.

Amazingly Preserved. This place is crazy. It's incredible how well preserved the buildings are, so you can wander through the streets almost as they were for the Ancient Romans. The information is a little lacking here, so we found Rick Steeve's audio tour useful. There's also a great app from the Italian government (search iMibac on the app stor) which is a sort of interactive 3D map of what it used to look like - the idea being you hold your phone out as if taking a picture and it shows you what that area looked like in all it's glory. Very useful if you're feeling a bit overwhelmed with ruins! The forum area is actually very small, but packed full with buildings, so take your time exploring here.

Must see but hell in the heat. Phenomenal historical building well set out for visitors and with audio guides. So very busy, even in June and boy do you queue. First for tickets, then for loos etc. however, leaves a lasting impression and understanding of the Roman Empire and the Greeks before. You can buy a triple ticket from Palatine gates (very reasonable indeed) prior to getting to Colosseum and the. Can get in quicker. The ticket gives you access to these two and the Forum are and can be used over 2 days so you do. To. We'd to do everything on that day. This also happened for museums when one bought a ticket it gave a number of central museums (not expensive) and one could take 3 days to use it. Impressive for visitor. 24 hour transport tickets for train, tram, buses again great value.

Poor Signs and Facilities. As mentioned on my review to the Colleseum, we managed to walk past the entrance to the Roman Forum, and circled it almost completely. As per other signs in Rome, the signs seem only to be visible to a passer by in one direction, so if you were going in one direction you would perhaps see it, but in another you wouldn't. Also the sight of the entrance was blocked by a refreshments truck, which didn't help. Also the lack of toilet facilities didn't give any particular help to recommend.That said, once there, there was a lot of historical buildings and structures to look out. There is a former vineyard which looks out over the Colliseum and the ancient parts of Rome which I would recommend visiting.

Beautiful architecture and landscape. This was one of the more enjoyable parts of our trip. The buildings were beautiful and the landscaping was gorgeous. The only thing that could make it better is if you had access to the buildings on site.

Fascinating visit. We had no idea what a large area is covered by the Roman Forum and the extent of its history. We decided to do a tour to make the most of the experience and had the most passionate, interesting and informative guide - Renata from ItalyWonders Guided Tours. She combined her knowledge with pictures of what the ruins would have looked like when they were first built - it really gave a very good understanding of what life was like at that time. We only paid and joined this tour 10 minutes before it commenced from outside the tourist Office near the Colosseum but it was a good decision - we certainly don't think we would have got so much out of the visit without Renata's knowledge of the site's history.

Amazing Must See. This is a WOW place -- the history here is stunning -- and the excavations continue. A guide really is a must if you want to hear the many stories and, if you're as lucky as we were, see pictures of what the ruins looked like back when they were in full use centuries and centuries ago. Wear comfortable shoes - the ground is uneven and you'll be going down steps to the 'old' street level, then climbing up again to today's street level. So many photo ops here -- the arches, the pillars, my goodness a trip to Rome wouldn't be complete without a stop here. From here go to the Coliseum (and a guided tour is a must there as well for full experience).
Good stroll through. This was good to walk after visiting the Colosseum, but nothing spectacular to see. Just an average stroll through the park.

fantastic history. essential to read up on history before you go. If you can, get on a guided tour, it will bring history to life. You can buy joint tickets with the colosseum and palatine hill which is very reasonably priced. Read up about the temple of Vesta and if you are lucky you will see someone reading out the famous speech,'Friends, romans, countrymen'. The site of Julius ceasars cremation is quite moving, often flowers are still left there
Worthwhile!. There are so many wonderful landmarks in Rome and this would certainly be in my top ten.I suggest allowing at least two hours for a sufficient tour.

Roman Forum. Standing on site you can almost see the way the forum was back in the day. Amazing to be able to visualize what you see in books. The guided tours make such a difference and the guides give you so much more information.

Fantastic Tour. We arranged a private guide for the Colleseum and Roman Forum. The tour provided us with all the history and insights we had hoped for. (Also, nice to be able to skip the long, long lines to enter the colleseum.)Our teenagers LOVED the Roman Forum - it was one of the highlights of our week in Rome for them.This is a must do while in Rome!

Wow, wow, wow! Valeria is an excellent guide. We booked tickets for the Roman Forum/Colosseum tour recently. We had Valeria as our guide and I like her controversial-type commentary. She was a blast! I learnt so much about ancient history - all I can say is wow, wow, wow! Tip - buy your tickets beforehand to avoid standing in line.

Walk where the early Romans lived. This place was awesome. Make sure you have something to tell you what you are looking at, we downloaded Rick Steve's audio podcasts, otherwise it could just be a walk around a bunch of ruins. The audio guide told us what we were looking at and explained its significants. Give yourself enough time to just look out and imagine what life was like during that time period. We spent about 1.5 hours. Walking can be a little tricky as there is loose gravel and uneven surfaces and many stairs don't have railings. Just be careful as you look up and walk at the same time. Side note - The entry fee for this sight includes the Colosseum.

Wonderful. Historic. Fills in some blanks in your knowledge of history to walk where Peter and Paul walked.. This was the most wonderful, uncrowded place we went. Walk where the Romans walked. Fill in the blanks in your knowledge of history leaves off. Makes history real to walk the streets where the ancients walked. The same streets Peter and Paul walked. One of our top places during our weeks in Rome. Actually see the buildings mentioned in the dry history texts. Makes it real to you.

Better do it on your own. In my experience, the tours that everybody peddles are too limited and the guides too pressed for time. You are better off getting a good map (Google Roma Roman forum) and then go early in the morning and walk around and try to imagine life back then, when Rome was all that existed in terms of civilization and wealth. What a difference with today!

Imagine life as a Roman. What an incredible experience to walk through what remains of the Roman Forum.There is so much to see you really need the services of a guide to help you fully appreciate what life was like as a Roman and the history of the various buildings and temples. It is possible to do a self-guided tour with an audio headset but we found in Rome that the tour guides are so passionate about their cities history that their presentation takes 'information' to another level.A definite 'must see' as part of any visit to Rome.

Make sure you allow enough time.. The site, including the Palatine hill, is absolutely vast and we spent many hours there. This was the second day of our Roma 3 Day Pass and it allowed us free fast track entry. Again, it opens at 8.30am and we got there for that time, which allowed us to see a heck of a lot before it started getting crowded.Do take plenty of water, although there are spouts dotted around where you can fill up.As we went further up the Palatine hill, there just seemed to be more and more to see. Eventually after about five hours we made our way out via the Via dei Cerche exit. We stopped to get something to eat from one of the stalls - which were remarkably good value for money (as well as being tasty).

Fascinating and historically important.. Situated between Piazza Venezia and the Colosseum it is one of the most important archaeological sites in the world. The forum was rediscovered in the 18th century and just walking round you have to try to imagine what it would have been like. It is a fascinating place. You can get a panoramic view of the forum from the terraces of Campodiglio. Not advisable to visit if you have difficulty in walking as the roads are all paved and quite uneven.

Amazing. We just happened to get there on the first Sunday of the month and it was free to get in. We started here before we went to the Colosseum (which was free too) and there were no lines even though there were lots of people. The whole place is really amazing and a must see if you go to Rome. There is also a small church there and they were setting up for a wedding. The church is beautiful and you should stop at it when you leave the Forum.

Let your imaginations run free. Visited this as part of a tour and compared to the colloseum a guide is really a good idea to have here.You will need to have good visualizations skills as the place is in ruins but the wonder and majesty of it is not lessened, rather heightend. Even with the crowds, you still feel the sense of history and majesty that was ancient Rome. I would definitely want to come back here and spend more time (and take more photos) walking around.Comfortable shoes and means to hydrate is required here. Shade is not plentiful and will likely be taken up already.

Walk through history. A visit to the forum and the Palatne Hill is not to be missed. To walk along the Via Sacra is very evocative as is seeing so many temples and houses of emperors. Allow plenty of time and get a guide or a headset to maximise the experience.

Hire a real life guide. Great historical site, but as so much is in ruin it's a really good idea to get a guide. You can of course hire a headset but a person brings it to life. I paid €15 to be part of a small group. Be prepared for steep walkways which are very uneven under foot. I saw many struggling along in heels and sandals: not a great idea. I would not recommend a visit in the height of summer. All in all a great experience.

Breathtaking. After visiting the Coloseum my Tour Guide took our party to the Forum, which was quite amazing. The views from the Palatine Hill were spectacular and the thought that this place was the fashionable Capital of the Roman Empire more or less 2000 years ago is so impressive.The Tour Guide was exceptionally informative, and made the visit come to life.

Visit Foro Romano After the Crowds Leave. This is one of the most awe-inspiring remnants of the ancient world. It is truly breathtaking anytime you visit, but some of the most amazing views happen early in the morning or late in the afternoon when the ruins are closed to visitors. Even when the ruins are closed, there is a beautiful view from the west, from Via del Campidoglio.

Must see place. Another where you wander around gazing in amazement picturing how it must have been in its hey day. Again book your tickets before you go the queues can be very long. Can be purchased along with entry to the coliseum. After visiting the coliseum the main entrance is directly opposite but this is usually very busy and there are less busy entrances down the right and left hand sides some 400m along the roads that run down the sides of the forum. Again it is worth a guide or you can pick up audio guides at the entrances. Allow 2/3hrs for the visit including the Palantine and Capitoline hills. It also gives you a view over the Circus Maximus too.

Nice Decent Walk. After experiencing the great Colosseum this was more of a nice walk around some old ruins that don't interest me that much as the Colosseum did, it does have some interesting ruins, good views of the city but nothing spectacular to say about this.

Simply overwhelming... When I reached the mound where Caeser's body was kept after his assassination, I was totally overwhelmed. You feel like a part of history. Like a trip back to the past and being a part of the events of the yore. That's what the Roman forum does to you. This is a part of the day trip to Colosseum . You have common tickets. Some people try and skip the Roman forum. By suggestion for them is never make this mistake. Colosseum might be more popular, but the Forum has the main attractions. Please don't miss this trip. Dress comfortable, wear walking shoes, carry plenty of water and be a part of the ancient history.
Loved it!. For a brief moment you are taken back in time... To the times of the old Rome. I loved forum more than colosseum. It gives you a taste of authenticity.

A MUST SEE WHEN IN ROME. Everyone , when visiting Rome, should and must include a visit to The Forum. This should be combined with a tour of The Colosseum & everything else attached to it.Get a good guide, a one on one guide from Viator was well worth the cost to us, as he had an extraordinary knowledge of everything relevant, & also managed to get around the queues.
Wonderful. It speaks for itself. One of the most important visible remains of the Roman Empire. It can be quite busy, but still absolutely mandatory when visiting Rome.

Roman forum / palatine hill. Thoroughly enjoyed this visit and took good few hours . Felt sometimes we wondered round aimlessly as no real guidance given etc - maybe it would have been better with a guide but there are explanations on boards that describe things . As long as you are prepared to walk for few hours and have plenty of water you will enjoy it . It was amazing seeing some wild parakeets flying in the old vineyard - beautiful birds but very well disguised in the trees !! Once you get used to how rude everyone is and you join in ( cos you just have too lol ) it's a great place to visit . Used my Roma pass as this and the colosseum count as 1 attraction .

A time capsule in the heart of Rome. An interesting mixture of artifacts from ancient Rome through early Christian existing side-by-side. Large enough to impress, yet short enough to walk through comfortably. Best to by a guide before hand so you can appreciate what you will be seeing. And, after walking through the Forum, you can go back to the guidebook for a more informed second reading. That way you get the mostout of your visit.
forum. remember to check opening times here as closes at 4.00pm great atmostphere and real sense of occasion
Real Rome. Do not miss a visit to the Forum, full of history walking where many famous enough Romans have walked

Impressive. What is Rome without strolling along the ruins of the cradle of western civilization? So incredibly powerful, intriguing and I would say well preserved when you think of the millenniums that have passed. Evidently there would be more standing today had it not been for one 'future' thinking Cardinal who tore down many buildings of the original forum to place the Alessandrine neighborhood over it! IMPRESSIVE
Interesting walk on a nice day. After the Colusseum this is a bit of a let down but it has sweeping views of parts of the city. Nice place to wander on a nice Roman day.

Ancient forum in the center of Rome. If you're a history buff, give yourself enough time to really explore this site. I only allowed one hour and could easily have spent 2-3 hours more. Lots of walking.

Get a Guided Tour. We really enjoyed the Forum (especially the climb to the top of Palatine Hill). However, to enjoy it and really appreciate it, you will need a guided tour. I highly suggest "Joy of Rome" tours, who took us on a tour of the Colosseum and the Forum. Also, once you enter the Forum, you can not leave and re-enter without buying another ticket. Since the Forum is so big, leave yourself plenty of time to explore, and bring water bottles, sunscreen, etc.

Skip the Line Walking Tour of Forum and Colosseum. Brilliant...not only do you skip a very long line but the guide (Barbara) is excellent in telling you the history of what you are seeing all around you...well worth it and would go again...the only word of caution is that it is a bit of a walk with stairs and un even pavements and so a bit tricky for anyone a bit slow on the toes but then again in our situation we all walked a bit slower so the others could keep up
Interesting look back to Ancient Rome. The forum is well worth a visit. It's an interesting glimpse back to how Ancient Rome once was and is very interesting to see.
Worth the walk across the street. The beauty and spender of it all is impressive. Just a quick stroll across the street and just a slight incline.

When Rome ruled the world. Visiting the Forum was such a surreal experience, the history and architecture was so amazing. I felt transported back in time. Be sure to brush up on your history before visiting so that you can really enjoy your time and get the full experience. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes. I love heels as much as the next girl but I would not recommend them when you are walking on cobblestones.
interesting. very interesting, nice to take your time and stroll around. it will take a few hours to stroll all the way around it .

Confusing, but good!. The forum is close to the Colosseum, and you can use your Colosseum ticket to go there.Bring a hat and a bottle of water. The sun was really strong when we were there and sometimes it was almost unbearable. We looked for audioguides for this attraction, but we were unable to find them, which really pissed me off as those things are usually on the entrance.You can get a good understanding of the buildings from the signs in front of each one of them, though. I felt the place lacked a signage system to guide visitors, but other than that, good attraction!

Be sure to download free audio guide in advance. Purchase your combo ticket online before you go or buy it at the ticket office in front of the Forum which has a much, much, much shorter line than the Colosseum. It's sort of tucked away as you walk down Via Imperiali, so look carefully. Finally, download Rick Steve's Audio Europe walking tour before you go. It's a bit corny, but it's free and very informative!

Roman Forum is a Must See!. This area is huge and part of the admission of the Colosseum. So much history if you have a private tour guide to tell you the side history. The streets, the games, the trials and many historical elements to see in center of all previous power in Rome. What an Amazing place at the end of the tour in the Piazza del Campidoglio with the bronze statue of Marcus Aurelius on the horse.

Pictures don't do this place justice..... This was one of the coolest things that we saw in Rome. And that said a lot. We didn't walk around it but our driver took us to a vantage point where we had a great view.

Veni vidi vici. Last here in 2002 (guess that coin magic worked!) and since then the archeologists have uncovered yet more. Or I missed a lot. Amazing to walk and behold the political and religious sites, then trek up the Palatine Hill to Augustus' palace. THey even uncovered the hut village there when several tribes lived in the area. A must see!

Amazing piece of history you just have to see to believe. The Roman forum was a truly amazing experience, is it quiet large so make sure you wear comfy walking shoes and lots of water. You could honestly spend a whole day here looking at all the different ruins. Get a guided tour though it's so hard to understand what is what so having someone map everything out for you makes you appreciate it so much more.

The whole area is a wonder!. We booked a tour through "Together in Rome" and Andrada was our guide. She was punctual, where she said she would be, and her knowledge of the history and area was superb. Her English was easy to understand and she understood most of our nuances in word choice. I HIGHLY, HIGHLY, HIGHLY recommend doing the coliseum, forum,and surrounding area with a guide. We are not big on tours or guides, but felt like a lot could be gained by doing this with a guide, and we were correct. The history of this area is unbelievable. There is no way we could have figured out everything we learned on our own. We were a small group of 8, which was perfect. The tour took three hours and we saw all the area. It was a fantastic way to se pe a wonderful piece of history.

Amazing place. what an amazing place, given its history, we strolled around and could only imagine what it was actually like back in its heyday . Immense and so magnificent. But took time to think of how's he slaves and minions must have felt withsomuch wealth an higher achy, must have been more than a little daunting!

Centre of Ancient Rome is Glorious. This landmark is arguably the most important of all the ancient roman landmarks as it was the centre of ancient rome and Julius Ceaser was cremated there. I don't know too much about ancient roman history but we got a tour of the colloseum, palatine hill and the roman forum and was totally worth every penny.

Absolutely gorgeous! . All people are captivated by history and especially ancient times when out civilization has started... roman Forum is one of must see placed during lifetime. Absolutely fantastic. The sensations you have there is amazing. I suggest to go to Rome in the beginning of October, fabulous time of the year, still very warm but less people than usually. And take forum in the morning, almost empty... You feel like walking in ancient Rome..

A little preparation goes a long way...and an overlooked side entrance.. The Forum is a must see for any history buff and, should be, for everyone else. The ruins have small placards in both Italian and English, with audio guides and plenty of "experts" willing to assist you as well. The offer of a "skip the line" is usually the catchphrase. If you wish to be guided, it can be worth it. Do your research and pick a reputable company. If you are going it on your own, I strongly recommend listening to Rick Steves' the night before, or to buy a guide book.An effective way to quickly get tickets and get inside to the Forum, Palatine Hill and the Colosseum, is to enter from a little known side entry opposite the Via Cavour where it runs into Via dei Fori Imperiali. It is a very small ticket office with a gate next to it. The queue was only 10 people on a Saturday where the main entrance had hundreds. For €12 you get access to all three for two days. You can only enter once per attraction, but can split over two days if needed.You will be walking and walking. Rough stone, stairs, mixed terrain and if after May, in hot humid conditions. Good shoes, sun screen, hat, water, etc. are highly encouraged. If you aren't comfortable, the sights won't matter, as the experience will be diminished. Palatine Hill does offer a cool breeze and some cover under the evergreens. You can also refill your water bottles from the many fountains along the trails.After either being overwhelmed by the history and sites, or, as my daughter put it, "seeing a lot of bricks," exit toward Via dei Fori Imperiali and use your ticket to skip the line and enter the Colosseum.
A striking attraction.. Definitely worth a visit. Shows how life was like for the wealthy. Just a short walk from the Colluseum.

Amazing to be there.. Being there means seeing all the history that happened right on the ground where you're standing. I was lucky to be a part of a tour group in which we were provided with the services of a local guide. It was incredible learning so much history while experiencing the beauty of the ruins.

The Forum this time on the Hill. Last time I visited the Forum...3 years ago, I stayed in the lower section among the market ruins. This year I was determined to climb up the hill and see what was up there. I think it's called the Palatine Hill. I didn't visit the villas, I'll save that for another year. Instead I walked way to the back where there were ruins of small houses and chapels. There were lots of beautiful mosaics remaining on thd floors, out in the open, and some beautiful architectural angles which whould only interest an artists like myself. Despite the fact that it was pouring rain, I forged ahead and saw many things that interested me.

A Nice walk around. Ticket for Colosseum includedd the Roman Forum so we queued for that too. It was worth the queue to walk about and picture old Rome in our heads. Definitely something to see when in Rome but probably wouldn't go back a visit.

Centuries of Life Revealed. A long walk but well worth it. It is best seen with a guide who can explain the excavations, changes and details contained within this area. Fascinating for those interested in antiquities and ancient culture. Arrive early and take your time to experience history.

Roman Forum. A short walk from the Colosseum and included in the ticket for the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. Worth taking a look! Can also get some great aerial views of the Forum from the top of Palatine Hill.

Huge. Loads to see, its hard to understand exactly what went on here as the majority of the areas to view are ruins, expect to spend a few hours to ensure you can see everything as it covers a large area.

A must see site. This and Palatine Hill together are a place in Rome you absolutely must visit. I recommend booking this, Palatine Hill, and the Colosseum altogether through a service like TickItaly. The size of the forum is incredible and it's even more incredible to think about how old the area is. I would recommend spending a couple of hours here. There is a quite a bit to see so just allocate the time here and don't rush through it, but also don't feel overwhelmed by how much there is to cover. Be sure to go up to the higher areas and take some great photos and also view it without the camera to make some mental images. The view of the surroundings are unforgettable. If you like history or know any of the history of some of Rome's earlier emperors this will be very interesting to you.
Breathtaking. This is a beautiful place to visit. So much history in front of your eyes. Lots of walking.A must see place.

A lot to see so take some food and drink with you. We went here the first day in Rome . The line was long into the Colosseum so we went across the road. We only had a bottle of water and wished we had some food. The ticket we bought there got us into the Colosseum as well on the next day so saved a lot of money. GOOD HINT. We were going to get a skip the line and so saved a LOT of money

Don't pay, just view. I would not recommend waiting and paying, unless of course your trip is just of Rome or you really care for the area. I would rather buy pizzas somewhere than pay for this attraction, however it is a fantastic thing to see from above ground. You can almost see it all from above.

A stroll through history. There were so many different pieces of history from many different time periods as you go further. It was a fascinating walk that everybody should see. we went here after the Colosseum, which made for a lot of great history in one day. You will not be disappointed going through this walk.
Very impressive. The Forum is a must-see, even though there are now many ruins. A guided tour is a must so that this cultural rich monument's history is not lost.
A must while in Rome. It is, in short a must, but it can be overwhelming. Be sure to read something about the Place, so that Yiou know what to look for.
Not impressed, bit scruffy. I know it's a ruin, but it looked scruffy. The grass was overgrown and there was a bit of rubbish about. Pre book tickets and you don't have to queue.

Rise and fall of the Roman Empire.. That's what I thought to myself when I saw the ruins. Very impressive and a must see. There is a lots of reading about the place. I recommend starting the visit on the Palatine Hill ruins. You get there with a bus, Via. di San Gregorio.The bus station is near the entrance. After visiting you stroll down to the Forum instead of climbing up the hill. The great benefit of doing it, is that the queue is the shortest. The visit will take your entire day and is involved with lots of walking. Go very early in the morning or afternoon. There is no shed from the sun. Take water with you.

A funny thing happened.... OK that cliche is totally worn out... But seriously watch your step. As you descend the hill into the Forum you will be walking on huge cobblestones with 2"-4" gaps between them. This is a dangerous situation. The Forum is only a bare shadow of what it once was. Though is was cool to see where Cesar was burned. Before you visit you may want to buy a "Before and After" book showing what the buildings looked like when they were complete
Walking in the past. What a great piece of ancient history. Fortunately, we were there in late Sept. and most of the crowds were gone.

The Fantastic Roman Forum. One of the most fascinating and historical sites in the world. It's amazing that these structures are still standing after two thousand years. Just loved walking around with the guide. Wear good walking shoes because you walk up and down hills with cobblestones.

Wonderful site. The Roman Forum is a great site to visit. Be sure to allow plenty of time as there is a lot there to see, especially if you are a history buff. I would suggest that you get your tickets at the Palantine Hill entrance. It is not as crowded as the Colosseum entrance (the ticket is good for both). That way when you see the Colosseum you can skip the much longer line. The Colosseum took us about an hour and a half to see. A must see.

Awesome History. We walked to the roman forum and palantine hill; purchasing an admission ticket for 12 euros each; this also included admission to the Colloseum. Firstly we walked around the forum using the Rick Steves audio guide and map to explain the various sites and history of the forum. We then walked up to the top of the Palantine Hill which afforded great view of the forum, Rome and the Circus Maximus. If you are into ancient Roman history, this is the place for you!

Get a Before and After Picture :). I recommend getting a book or some information about the way this area was before so that you know for sure what you're seeing for a lot of these places are almost unrecognizable and a few of them have a sign to tell you what they are; also, when they were destroyed materials were taken to build other things so you're not going to find all the pieces. All and all, it's a very instructive experience. If you get the ticket online together with the Colosseum you'll avoid the long lines. It's just across a park from it and from the Arc of Constantine so you can spend hours in the place, its awesome. Also, before getting into this area there's a "Y" in the path; right side takes you to the Forum and Palatine Hill for which you need a ticket, left side takes you to the Basilica of St. Bonaventura which is a very interesting place to visit. Enjoy!

It's a must visit. After all why have you come to Rome. Do not go without a guide as you'll not fully appreciate the place. There is so much history here it's beyond belief. There's sections of ornate columns just lying around. You can literally sit on something that was made by an ancient craftsmen over 2000 years ago.Although more or less in ruin it is a miracle that the site has remained untouched by modern hands. Even some of the restoration work is ancient. You could spend most of the day here easily hence bring drinks.We done this as part of a 3 part ticket which we bought outside the Colosseum metro station for 49 euro which included a guided tour of the colosseum , Palentine Hill and The Roman Forum. The 3 tours are staggered with a break in between which would take approx 6 hours to complete in total.I'm pleased I came and if I visit Rome again I'll definitely spend more time here.

Interesting look at the past but do your homework. My biggest regret about the Forum is that I wasn't able to really concentrate as much as I'd like and take it all in. I had done some reading in a Rick Steves Guide beforehand, which I'd also brought along - so I knew what some of the main points of interest were. However, I also had my toddler strapped to me and that interfered a little with the reading along. There was a lot here, more than I could take in! This place is best savored. There is a wide range of history here; it is the site of what used to be the main marketplace/city center of Ancient Rome and so there is this hodgepodge of various ruins and building remains spanning hundreds of years that were from temples, monuments, dwelling places and the old senate. However, if you don't know what you are looking at, it will just seem like some columns and building facades. So, take your time to study it, read along and really appreciate it. There are things that I didn't notice at the time that I wish I'd paid more attention to!Also, make sure to bring water bottles - there is very little shade, and it's a fairly big place. There are lots of fountains but they aren't very easy to drink directly from.Pace yourself and make sure to also visit Palatine Hill, which is included in the ticket price. In my view, the Colosseum is worth visiting but the bulk of your time should be spent here and Palatine Hill.

It's a must do when in Rome. They say "when in Rome..." and this attraction is a must do given the cultural and historical significance. Very easy walk to do on you own. Some placards which indicates the sites, but bone up beforehand. Enjoy!

Plan on spending hours to explore. The awesomeness of the Colosseum usually takes away a tourist's attention from giving the Roman Forum due justice. There are so many structures to visit and explore Gove yourself enough time to visit the entire Forum complex and save time to climb Palatine Hill - not to be missed as well.

ok for archeology buffs!. for me it was just above average place but for those interested in archeology i'm sure its a treasure trove. still shouldn't be missed. since this visit is combined with the colosseum would suggest this to be done first early in the morning followed by visit to the coliseum. also ticket lines are much shorter here so get the tickets at the counter here.

ONE OF THE TOP FIVE SIGHTS IN ROME~ADJACENT TO COLOSSEUM--EFFICIENT VIEWING DOUBLE. OVERVIEWThe basic history outline of the Forum is that it was designed by Vitruvius to be the commercial, governmental, religious and social center of Rome. Many of the now wholly or partially dismantled buildings were built in the period around 200 AD; for example the Arch of Septimius. The main sights of the Forum include the Arch of Titus, the Temple of Saturn, Temple of Vesta, and the church of San Luca e Martina. These were all linked by the Sacra Via, the main road through the Forum.You can get the basic historical sketch by Googling and I am not going to ramble on further about this in this review.BIG TIP: My mission in this review is to convince you of the necessity of finding a good tour company to point out the various ruins and the significance of them. Trying to do this on your own would be exceptionally difficult and time consuming. We tried doing it solo in 2000 and came away with only a smattering of information. This year we did a tour and efficiently learned at least the highlights. It would take several visits to fully appreciate these ruins.
Beautiful. A great attraction to see at an affordable price. Beautiful well maintained grounds and your ticket includes entry to the Colosseo!

2000 years back to the past. First of all, following recommandations, we bought our tickets on the entrance of Palentine Hill (valid for Roman forum and Colloseum too) because there was no crowd like in front of Colloseum. Strolling down Via Sacra was very uniqe expirience. Before you go, read something about ancient Rome and the Emperors or take a guided tour .
A Must See!. Take your time, and read the posted information. Loved just being quiet, and thinking of all those whose footsteps trod the same paths....

Worth a visit. Enjoyed seeing the several monuments here. However for some reason, our guide (who we assumed would show us all the 3 - Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum) did not come with us here. He left us after giving us a brief synopsis at Palatine Hill and then we had to figure things out ourselves. The signage is not too great. I would recommend audio guides for better appreciation of the monuments
Roman history. Wow it was amazing to imagine what it would have looked like,back in the day,well worth a visit to see

A funny thing happened at the Forum.. When you are at the Colosseum, make sure that you add a visit to The Forum. Immediately you are transported back in time, and because we've all got TVs and have watched Ben Hur you truly get an idea of what life might have been back then. The area is extremely well preserved, and offered some welcome shade - but not much - on the very hot day we visited.

Layers of history all in one place. Walking through The Forum from one end to the other is a history lesson on the go. Century after century of Roman life is chronicled around you. I highly recommend hiring a guide to get the most out of the trip.

We loved the overall viewpoint from Palentine Hill the most. The forum is incredibly impressive, and really large in size. We loved the overall view over the forum form the Palentine Hill and actually went there multiple times to see it, but we did not enjoy the actual walking around the Forum bit very much. I guess if you join a tour it might be more interesting?? For more tips on Rome, especially geared for families with kids, please read our blog post :) http://www.wanderluststorytellers.com.au/the-best-of-rome-when-travelling-as-a-family-with-kids/
Unique experience . Nothing beats the grandeur and charm of the Roman Forum. A must must must see in Rome. So much history in a very small spot. I keep going back on each visit to city.

Bring your imagination!. It's the heart of Rome. On a hot day it's unforgiving being out in the open, but take a stroll up Palentine Hill for some shade. Make sure you know a bit of Roman history before you go, and try to imagine the great Emperors in some of the buildings.

Originally Marshland. The area was originally covered in Marshland. The Roman Forum is situated in the area between Colosseum and the Piazza Venezia and is a very important part of the Roman empire. Worth spending the time.

Walk in the steps of Julius Caesar. Walking through the Roman Forum makes you feel like you are seeing life as seen by the Caesars. I was on a walking tour which included the Colosseum, the Pantheon and Plaza Navona, so we didn't stay long. I would have been nice to have a tour that was just the Colosseum and the Roman Forum because there was so much to see and more information would have been nice.

Lost my ticket, couldn't get another or a refund, even though i had receipt. Super stingy. Rome/Italy - the place where tourists are forced to pay through the teeth for absolutely anything. Refunds are non-existent. You'd think in this day and age they'd be able to tell whether i'd used my ticket or not but sadly Italy is still in the stone age when it comes to infrastructure. Additional Rome rant:We were almost fined a hundred euro each for not reserving a train ticket when the ticket machines didn't work and we had a global europe rail pass! (you have to reserve a seat even though you've bought a ticket, even for empty trains) Its more expensive for tourists with EUrail pass to train around Italy Than Switzerland, Austria, France combined. Oh yeah everyone in Italy is smoking and their country will soon be crippled with the costs of lung cancer.All in all Places like the forum are raking in a fortune for absolutely nothing. and if something goes wrong, the word refund is not in the Italians vocabulary.
Stunning. Such a beautiful area with large crowds as expected. Take a guided tour to get the best knowledge but be prepared for the cobble stone paths everywhere

Ancient Rome--Need I say more. Make sure you get a tour of Ancient Rome. There are many and most appear to be really good. The Forum stands as the seat of the power of Rome. No where else in Rome can we relate to this. It is a must see part of any tour.

Can't get over it. This place has accumulated history over the ages. On top of that, some of the greatest events in history have taken place here. With that knowledge, let the ruins talk to you.Be prepared for a long walk, and imbibe in the atmosphere.Unfortunately Julius Caesar's senate building is not for view yet. Hopefully that will be in the near future. If you can, do get to the top of the Palatine hill, you won't even notice the climb, and the breathtaking view is absolutely the best thing of the day.
See the ancient Rome. Must visit place. Trully unique. You can feel the rich history and all the important people that lived and walked around here.

Amazing ruins. Lots of history of the Roman ruins next to the Colosseum. Lots of different pillars and decorated mosaics on the walls. You don't need to enter the Roman Forum as you can see the ruins from a view and take snapshots but it is better to go in and explore the rich history it has

Hard to believe it is still here!. You look around and have to keep reminding yourself just how old this area is and in.some cases how well preserved the buildings are after two thousand years. Lots to see and many 'wow!' moments as you wander around. Understandably footpaths uneven in lots of places so comfortable shoes advised. Lots of toilet blocks and lots of drinking water fountains dotted around free of charge to top up your water bottles. The Forum plays second fiddle to the Colosseum but we found it more interesting as there's much more to explore and more surprises.Note that the Forum and Palantine Hill are effectively on the same entry so although your combined ticket (with the Colosseum) is valid for two days you have to do the Forum and Hill on the same day.

Deep in History. This was one of a couple highlights in our 17 days trip. Previously had only seen the Forum from the street, but this time we walked as much as our legs could carry us. This just takes you so deep into history. Using your imagination to see what may have happened in these beautiful ruins, so many centuries ago.

Monumentous. Well worth the visit, just being amongst it is amazing, so much history in one place, you can even get close up to these monument and see various styles of masaics on walks and floors.Small tunnel and passages the great pillars it's all here. It so awe inspiring , it certainly takes your breath away

Where an Empire Began. Easily one of the coolest most historic places in all of Rome. Near to the Colosseum I would definitely recommend stopping by if you have the time. Its a wonderful piece of history and a great addition to your travel stops!

Not to be missed. I was not particularly worried whether I got to this or not as I was more interested in seeing the Coliseum. Paid to join a Skip the line tour which did both Roman Forum and Coliseum. The tour guide was brilliant and it was so informative and interesting, so many things I was reminded of from school but had forgotten, she put it into a twenty first century perspective and was very humerous. Certainly one not to be missed.

Many years of history together at one place . This place is like the hundred of years of romance history built on blocks one over the other.many kings built great things during their respective times...best example of architecture at one place

Roman forum. May of helped if we had a tour guide. Julius Caesar is buried here. He lived in the forum with Cleopatra and was liked by the people. To this day people leave flowers at his burial mound.

Another visit to the Forum.. When you visit Rome, you have to visit the Forum. Don't skimp on the visit, pay the small charge and go into the forum rather than walk around it. Even if you don't take a guided tour, buy one of the easily accessible guides that illustrates Rome then and now. Get lost in the history, imagine what it would have been like in ancient times, find a place to be on your own and close your eyes and imagine ( if you do this make sure a friend is watching or your valuables are safe).

A visit to the Roman Forum should be on everyone's list of places to see. A visit to the Roman Forum should be on everyone's list of places to see, My top tip is that whilst you can visit the Roman Forum using your joint ticket for the Colosseum, I would strongly recommend using one of the private tour companies (Hint:see my other reviews). The reason is that without an expert, you will miss out on the importance of the Roman forum. In particular, you're expert will be able to show you what was in the forum, how the forum was arranged and how it was run. Without this, you maybe forgiven for thinking that this is just a collection of Roman pillars and arches.My tip is don't embarrass yourself by bestowing the "ides of March" in a loud voice. Julius Caesar's body was cremated here, he was actually killed close to Largo di Torre Argentina

Great visit. We went to the Forum on our first day in Rome. We are great fans of the Falco novels by Lindsey Davis so felt like we knew the area already. Unlike some of the reviews I have read, I could clearly picture what it must have looked like in its heyday and could imagine the scenes of everyday life. We didn't have to queue, one of the advantages of having a Roma pass. We didn't have to pay to visit this or the Colosseum. It was a very hot day and there isn't much shade so we didn't spend as long there as we would have liked but I found it very atmospheric and the site is bigger than I imagined it to be. Of course there is some preservation work going on, if you were that old you might need some help as well. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit and just wish it hadn't been so hot so we could have spent more time exploring.

Amazing experience. Theres so much to see here and it felt surreal to walk through such a old, historic area. It is well worth the 12 euro we paid per person especially since that includes the palatine hills and the colosseum.

Roman forum. Rome is all you could wish for and then some. Many attractions close to the forum. This attraction could take up to 4 hours depending on how much you want to see.where comfy shoes as the ground is uneven in places. This area is mainly central to most hotels so easily walked to, take a jacket in the evening. As goes chilly.

Amazing place!. The forum is very much a wonderful place to stroll around for at least a couple of hours. I felt like I was living in the Roman times as I wandered about in my own little world. For me, it was the highlight of my visit to Rome. All the different ruins to marvel at. I didn't want to leave! Not to be missed!

Retracing Augustus' footsteps. Amazing, immense, tiring, fascinating, , simply walking through the gardens of the temple of the vestal virgins and Augustus' villa, meandering through a 2000 year old retreat. Super.

Unbelieveable!. You really need to bring a guide book or something off the internet to really get the most from your visit here. That said I wondered around at first just marvelling at the remains of this fabulous site. THEN I sat down and looked at my guide so that I could make out all the buildings and the temples etc. To think that you are following in the footsteps of Caesar and his senators is mindblowing enough but now experts think they have identified where he was actually assassinated and you can see it too!! I spent a good half a day here, just sitting and soaking up all the history and culture. It's incredible to think of how long this has stood and how it will still be here long after most of us has departed this world......

Great Historical Site very educating. This was extremely educational, if you appreciate history and have a vivid imagination you will enjoy this tour. Take a guided tour as this is the only way you can appreciate the whole area because nothing exist.
Amazing Ruins. It was an amazing experience to walk through a time so long ago. It is a must see while visiting Rome.

Great gathering place, good merchandise. On my way back to my villa, after seeing the chariot races at the Circus Maximus-Karlus Edwardus won by one chariot length over Jeffrius Gordonius- I paused but the Forum. I was delighted to meet my friend Rosalita, we had a nice wine. I was told it came from the north, from newly conquered territories. We later dined on roasted lamb. Then we toured the mant merchant stalls, a sheer delight. Rosalita received a small bauble which was liberated by our conquerors in Gaul. We look forward to a return trip to the forum

breath talking!!!. To be honest with you I would never mind to live at the Forum my self . You will go there one way and and come back another, the view is simply irresistible and there are plenty of benches to sit on and gaze and they are under shady trees too . I must admit the weather is really hot there in the month of July , well it sure was pretty hot when I went there , not to mention the fantastic view you have of it at that Piazza Venezia whew , even more breath talking !!! Well Rome is the place you should plan your next vacation great Gelato great pizza great everything !!! A trip to Europe would be in vain without to stop by and visit Rome , So plan your next trip there today!!! Thank You Have a Great Day! (from Anita, age 10)

Outstanding...Must See the Forum ruins. This had to be one of the most surprising sites on our Rome visit. We had prepared to see the Colosseum (which was also great), and with our ticket also had the opportunity tour the Forum ruins. Well...to say the least - it was outstanding. Plan to spend three hours or more as your wander through the grounds down below and up above. We did not have a tour guide. This might be a nice enhancement for better understanding - however - there are signs along the way in English. 3 hours at the Forum and 1 hour a the Collesseum is the way to plan, our humble opinion.

Lovely Ruins. This forum contains a nice collection of outdoor ruins. Convienently located in the town centre and within walking distance of the Colosseum, it is frequently included in various travel packages (i.e. "Pay this much to get in to the Colosseum, and you can see the Forum, etc as well). However, I will tell the more seasoned historian and archaeologist that, while these ruins are lovely, if you are familiar with Roman ruins there are far better preserved ones out there.Still, this was an enjoyable experience.

A taste of life in the Roman Republic. This was the center of the action during the Roman Republic -- a locus for government, business and religion. Follow Henry James and all the others who have strolled here, reflecting and pondering a vanished civilization. It can get crowded so try to go at first opening or during the last couple hours of the afternoon.

Not to Be Missed. I had been to Rome before, but had not been able to fit everything in and did not get to the Forum.That was my loss, and I visited the Forum in late April 2015. Note that there is an entrance fee. I believe it is about 10-15 euros.You NEED to see this historic site. It's ruins range from hundreds of years BC until the fall of the Roman Empire, and reflects the growth, strength and prosperity of ancient Rome.Allow enough time - at least an hour or two - to stroll the grounds and take in the scope of their accomplishments. The temples and the ancient senate where the Roman States were allowed their say in their future should make you appreciate the foundation given to us by these impressive people.Will children appreciate it? Don't know, but probably not.Should you appreciate it? Definitely.Do yourself a favor. You will remember it always.

Do see this outdoor museum...not to be missed.. Start by buying your ticket for the Forum and the Colosseum on Palatine Hill...opposite the Colosseum, much easier for access to both. You will also have wonderful views of Rome when exploring the Forum with all its history before taking in the entire collosseum.

Awesome. Beyond amazing whether you are a history buff or not. It takes a god 2 hours to see everything, especially if you do Palentine hill with it. Which you should. Take some water and good walking shoes and a hat in the summer months as it can get very hot and covers a large area

Interesting. Although just ruins now, worth a look. Very interesting and it's easy to imagine how it use to be. We used a Pte guide but you could just get a gd guidebook. However I feel the guide brought more to or attention than we would have read.

Brilliant. Lined up for twenty minutes, was likely to be a over an hour in the queue even though we arrived early. A guide walked around offering a group tour which only cost an extra 15-20 Euro and meant we could move straight to the front of the line and enter the exhibit immediately. Highly recommend this option. The tour was amazing, the guide was so knowledgeable and thoroughly entertaining. This was the best thing to see in the whole of Rome. I will definitely go again.

Ruins from the heart of Rome!. Ah, the Roman Forum - this area was the governmental seat of Rome at one time and is a marvel to walk around. I've explored this area about 4 times since living in Rome and having visitors and I still have not seen everything. It is a very large area to cover and not convenient for those with mobility issues (using canes, balance issues, or in wheelchairs) since you are walking on road and walkways make from stones. Be aware yourself so you don't trip! Make sure you have a hat and sunscreen as it gets extremely hot due to lack of shade.Now I'm not a fan of tours (I don't like being in big groups) so other than an audio guide for a small fee why not take a book with you that gives you the information you will need while viewing the ruins. You could spend hours in this place and not see everything. Plan on a couple hours. There are water fountains and washrooms available throughout the Forum. I don't recall a cafe anywhere so bring snacks or even a lunch. Entrance: there are two that I'm aware of (near the Arc of Constantine); the second is directly across from Via Cavour (crossroad is Via dei Fiori Imperiali). Go to the Roman Forum before the Colosseo and purchase your ticket for both places. This duel ticket is good for two days (back to back) so if your tired after visiting the Forum you can go the next day to Colosseo and walk right in! No need to wait in a line! Enjoy!
Stepping back in time!. Fantastic experience - like you are stepping back in time! There is plenty to see and it is well organised so you are not joining queues and wasting your day.
Humbling. to walk in the same place that people did 2100 years ago is humbling. There are no words to describe touching the stone where Julius Ceasar was displayed
Everything I thought it would be. I'm a history and archaeology buff, so I was in heaven. The Forum is HUGE so bring comfortable shoes. In fact, you'll want comfortable shoes EVERYWHERE.
History comes alive. Lots of ruins to visit. One can only imagine what this looked like in "the day." We did the Forum with our tour of the Colosseum. Well worth the time and money.

Oh, to be part of history.. An interesting walk in time. A place of such history and power. Our private guide explained about the government, the
Vestal Virgins, the market. So many people it impacted the flavour of our experience.

great place for a cloudy day. it was very hot as I was here. So grab a hat and a water as you'll spend here at least 2 hrs under the direct sun.
don't rush, walk around, try to read the history in advance, so you can understand where you are walking

Ancient Rome. When you are walking around the Roman Forum, you will be walking on roads and walkways that were walked on by Cesar Augustus. The architecture is amazing. Make sure you walk up to overlook the Forum. Keep in mind there is little to no shade and the ruins get hot. Pay attention to where you are walking since the road were made with large stone. The site does not support wheel chairs and strollers are a challenge.

Amazing, but go with a guide. If you only pay a guide for one attraction, make it this one. There are so many ruined buildings and random columns it can be overwhelming. The most interesting part is the history, so get a good guide and enjoy!

The Forum. My husband and I traveled with Sassi Italy Tours and without a doubt this was the most amazing place I have ever seen. It is hard to believe that something built hundreds of years ago still exists. Our guide, Doug Sassi, was wonderful. He is extremely knowledgeable in Italian history and art history. He took us to many places and the most wonderful family run restaurants. If you are thinking of traveling to Italy, Sassi Italy Tours in the way to go.

Great place. This is a great place to visit. Not only were there not many people, but from the higher parts there is a splendid view over the city. If archaeology and architecture interest you, this is a must see.

The crowds, OMG the crowds!!. We were there early spring, and hoped that would mean no crowds which was wrong. Our day started a little late and we did the Colosseum first, once done we wander to the forum but simply could not endure the idea of queuing for what looked like a one to two hour wait. Frustratingly the hold up seemed to be solely due to an extremely inefficient security screening. In the end we wondered around the perimeter, which whilst not as fully immersive was still interesting.

Great historic, fun, expansive, beautiful and FREE thing to do!!!. I traveled to Rome alone and spent two days roaming the city and this was my second favorite part (next to the Vatican). There were a number of reasons this is a must visit in Rome. First and foremost...no lines!!! I went to see if I could get into the Colosseum (right across the street) and the line would have resulted in a 1.5 hour wait. I snapped my pictures and headed over to the Roman Forum instead which I walked right in to. Another great aspect of the Forum is that it's free! No fee for your regular admission, which I recommend because Wikipedia can tell you anything an audio guide can.Beyond the convenience and low cost aspects of this attraction, comes the actual value of making the stop. I am not one to try and save when on vacation, especially not when in Europe, but this place is a must see and just so happens to provide that luxury as well. It is a beautiful area, mostly outside, with gorgeous vegetation and architecture. Floral gardens, grand trees, and dense greens weave their way throughout the ancient ruins and hidden structures. It surprised me some of what I was looking at considering we were in the middle of the city still. This, along with some great views of the skyline and some larger structures make for great photo opportunities. I also got to nerd out a bit on the history that I learned walking around. There are a multitude of little fact cards corresponding with every building, statue, piece of infrastructure and fountain. These provide a great short summary of the history behind what you are looking at, and easily identify them as well so you can do further research on your own when you are not on vacation. Simply snap a shot of what you find interesting and the information card for future reference. There are some great large structures that provide more of a wow factor and hold great importance, in addition to all the interesting little nooks and rooms as well. Finally, they have a free museum on site that holds many incredible artifacts and provides some more detailed information about the Forum.Definitely visit here and do so, if possible, on the nicest day that you have. You will be walking outside a lot and for a few hours. They have public running, clean fresh water for drinking (something I am normally against but ran out of my bottle quickly so I conceded and am still here). It can get a little hot and tiring so just be patient, move slowly, and make sure you have plenty of time to enjoy as much of it as possible!

Wow!!. Just around the corner from The Colosseum is the amazing Forum. The ruins give you a sense of the scale and grandeur of Ancient Rome. There are breathtaking views in all directions. You'll need at least a couple of hours to fully appreciate the site. A must see when you visit Rome!!
Lots to see. I spent a good half a day exploring everything the forum had to offer. Some of the structures recovered are spectacular and definitely worth a visit.

This Is An Amazing Area To Visit. I never got around to reviewing these sites and posting photos and now I find this is a real challenge. I took thousands of photos while there and it seems like I am just seeing some of these places for the first time. The Roman Forum covers a very large area and we only spent about an hour there. I need to go back now to take additional photos plus the next time I am coming up with an easy identification system so I will know where I have been. For the traveler please allow me to provide a couple of tips. You cannot possibly see and absorb all if this area in a short time so make you plans for ample time to see at least part of the sights. Visiting Rome is I think one of the most fascinating experience.

Great Site to See While In Rome. A great site to see in Rome...there is so much to see here and so much history. Make sure you pay the extra money to get inside and check out the relics and artifacts. My whole family enjoyed this location. Will take you a few hours to go through it....A must see!
Thought Provoking. It's really amazing to see these ancient places up close and in person. If you take your time and think about all that must have happened here it is really thought provoking.

Do not get the audio guide!!!!. This place is awesome, just read other reviews. Now, let me tell you all about this audio guide. What are some words that come to mind? Monotonous, unengaging, fake British, wrong. I'd rather have text-to-voice narrate the Roman Forum Wikipedia article. Now that I've vented after sitting under a beautiful tree on the Palatine Hill, I'll continue to chill under the sun and walk around the ruins and not listen to the stupid audio guide.

Wow!!. A truly amazing place, you can't help but be in awe of what the ancient city would have looked like. Make sure that you give yourselves at least a couple of hours to explore this wonderful space, you won't be disappointed!

Remains are spectacuar and worth a visit. Just to wander around the ruins and the gardens is great. There are plenty of people who will guide you around but there is plenty of information on siet to tell you what the various bits are and its nice to just look at yourself, Be prepared to walk quite a distance as the site is huge. Well worth a visit.
You need a lot of time here. It's a must see for your trip to Rome but make sure you really give it the time it deserves. We had a great time here although tough with a stroller.

So much history. This was part of our Colosseum tour, and it was such a surprise to see the plaza where so much happened in Rome. White most of the buildings are gone, there are enough artifacts to see what it was like so long ago. Don't miss the place where Caesar's ashes are put to rest.
Very interesting place. Visted here and Palatine Hill and both were very interesting and as must-see. Got sopme great photos.

Amazing history, but not the best experience. This place is full of amazing history but like the Colosseum the signs around the place are real bad. Very hard to see them and arrows pointing in not soo correct directions.
Still.... Definitely a place to put on your 'must see' list while in Rome.

Heart of Rome. Recommend as a part of a tour as there are limited audio guides, and the condition of the ruins really require some colour and explanation to get the full history. A must see and can be combined with a trip to the colosseum as close by.

Amazingly huge ... it was some ages ago. The Roman Forum is a great and majestic place, piazza, which used to be the center, the core of the former Roman Empire. Now it’s only ruins, but some of them are still so huge and looks solid yet are so ruined. One can imagine still how Rome was looking at those years and just to imagine how it was, I imagined a nowadays poor guy took from the most faraway and poor village of any low developed country of Europe and just taken to New York between the skyscrapers. Maybe this is how Rome was at those ages, back in time.

The best ancient site in Rome. I've visited the Forum twice now on separate trips and this time it still blew me away like I'd never seen it before. The remains of ancient temples and market places are hugely impressive and the history is really interesting. I had an audio guide (one which I got free from Rick Steves, though I'm sure there are others) which I think is really important if you are visiting as it explains so much that would be missed by just wondering around.One point which may be worth mentioning is that, as it is an ancient site, the walking on uneven cobbles and pathways was not so easy for my grandmother. However, it didn't ruin our experience.In my opinion, this is the most wonderful part of the historical centre of Rome.

Step back in time. Don't bother reading this review. You're wasting time - just go and step back in time. This is Rome - AND YOU'RE ACTUALLY IN THE FORUM. It's magnificent, the centre of Roma, and the centre of Roman history. Drink water straight from the source when you get hot, see ruins older than most of your home towns. Whatever you do, read Wikipedia about the history then step back in time.

Interesting ruins. We got a hop on hop off your through Viator that includes front of the line passes to a range of things including the Roman forum. There are long lines for the tickets, even if you pre booked them as you still have to pick them up and you can not skip the security line which effectively means your front of the line pass is useless at this particular site. It was an interesting spot though

Ruins & history. There are so many ruins and so much history in Rome. It was a good thing we had a guide to explain the Forum and surroundings to us- he was very good. Now that we're home, it's a little difficult to remember all of it.

Very interesting to learn more about ancient Roman life.. The Forum is just beside the Colloseam.
