We had a guide to show us round and explain everthing thing. there was lots to see, temples, houses, markets, tombs, sports areas, spas, etc. it was brilliant to get an understanding of general ancient Roman life. You can use the roman water spring to drink from, wear sensibly shoes as its a bit uneven and there's lots of slopes and steps.

Interesting peek into the past. We did a self tour of the Roman Forum & Palatine Hill while in Rome & also the Colosseum. Hands down, we liked the Roman Forum the best. It was interesting to see the ruins & imagine what life must have been like back in ancient days. We used Rick Steve's Pocket Rome as our guidebook. There is a lot to see here and you can get some beautiful pictures too. It was very hot the day we went. I'd recommend a hat & water bottle. We took frequent breaks in the shade.

History rich site. Take a tour to get the best out of this amazing sight and go for a skip the line option. We went with City Wonders, a small group with a dedicated, knowledgeable guide that gave a live audio tour with headphones. We learnt so much about the history of the Roman Forum. It was the highlight of our time in Rome
great but get a guide. great place - one thing we didnt do was get a guide (real or audio) and this would have enriched our experience and made it more meaningful, so worth it to get a guide :)

Structurally Flabbergasted. Most incredible immersion into the lives of roman citizens oh so many years before us. If you don't see anything else (as if). See the Forum and do the Underground Rome tour. (Google it)

Roman Forum. Close to the Colosseum is the Roman Forum. I recommend a fast pass because the lines are long. We were in a tour group of 40 people which, in my opinion, was too large but the guide was good.

Amazing site of antiquity. The forum is composed of many buildings and areas where the Romans spent a great deal of time. The most impressive features were the Arch of Constantine, Arch of Titus, and the Temple of Julius Caesar. Well worth the walk through it and imagination should be used to understand this area. Fascinating.

Amazingly nice!!!!!!. I went to visit Rome and the first thing I decided to do was to walk around the city, it was the best.... The Roman Forum is like a huge archeological free camp. You can walk freely, and enjoy every part, like a time frame where is possible to observe marble columns, masonry walls, even a garden where you can sit for some minutes to take some fresh air…. I want to go back

Almost Missed the Temple of Julius Caesar.. One ticket gives you two days to visit the Colossum, the Roman Forum and Palantine Hill. Two days is not enough but when you only have five days in Rome, you can only spend so much time at this attraction. You need a good map or guide to appreciate the history behind the ruins. There are some well preserved columns and temples, but there are mostly remnants of foundations.I used a Rick Steves audioguide, but got disoriented at times. When I got to the end of the tour, i realized I had missed the Temple of JC. I had to run back and catch a glimpse and photo of the temple dedicated to the first Shakespeare story I read in high school.If pressed for time, you should definitely tour the Colosseum and save some time and energy for the Forum. You may pass on Palantine or just take a quick hike for the views.

See the glory of ancient Rome. As an avid fan of the Roman Republic/Empire this was a special treat for me, to see all the places you read about come to life before your eyes is, to me, a special experience. Some of the buildings are better preserved the others, but even the sheer size of the ruins can give you some perspective about the greatness of ancient Rome. If you are a history fan, you can spend over 5 hours here easily, others might wish to leave after about 2, the only con about this place is that it;s huge. My mother can't walk these distances easily anymore, and it wasn't easy for her, please take that into consideration when planning your visit.Even though, this is a must-see attraction in Rome, you might want to buy a combined ticket for the Forum and the Colosseum and do them both at the same day, preferably with a good lunch break in-between.

Dark and brooding.. Thunder and lightening only added to our visit. Walk through history as the ancient Romans did. Get a guided tour to fully get an understanding of what you are viewing and to explain the history of the forum.

The view of old Roman Empire . The place explains a lot of history about Roman Empire. This place is just opposite to the famous Colosseum. You need not search for this place as the Rome official tourism guides keep instructing you for the directions.Coming to what you can see in this place... It's all the very very old Roman Empire which was hidden beneath the ground and which is being excavated now. You can find the excavated temples of Venus,Mars and Saturn and also there are huge pillars which adds up to the beauty of the old architecture. At one point, the external view of Colosseum from Roman forum is just perfect. It offers the best view of Colosseum and don't miss to click the best shots of Colosseum from here.Here is do's and dont's:Ensure that you wear a nice pair of shoes while visiting this place as you need to walk a lot. Always pre-book the tickets via online to skip the long ques.Don't carry your huge bags.Hope these tips would help you for your visit to this place. If you are crazy on history and architecture.. Then this place should be must visited place for you
Under reconstruction. Yet another monument undergoing supportive works. You can see bits from the street but again there is the issue of queuing & I didn't want to bother.

Worthwhile. The forum can initially be a little disappointing, since there is not much left and the ruins are not marked, so you often don't know what you are looking at. I think it is worthwhile to book a tour, although be advised that it gets very hot in summer and there is not much shade. The sense of history can be felt as you walk through the ruins, I would not miss this.

Not much left. This was interesting and you can almost imagine the Senators sitting around in their robes deciding the fate of the known world. If you have limited time spend it at the Colosseum as there is more left and its next door.
Outstanding. Along with Palatine Hill (which i have already reviewed) this is a must see, spend as long as you can here it is well worth it

Amazing ancient ruins and spectacular architecture. The Roman Forum was amazing and you get the feel of ancient Rome. Walking along the same path as Caesar. An amazing place. We booked in advance with the Colosseum and Palatine hill tour, I prefer to be able to interact with a guide and ask questions, something which can't be done through headphones or a guide book. You will need very comfortable footwear that will not slip and can handle the uneven surfaces. Take a bottle of water too as you can refill it as you walk around Rome.

Contains the Temple of Caesar. This site is where ancient government buildings used to be, there are lots of ruins to be amazed by and there is also the Temple of Caesar, this is his burial site, there are some fantastic pictures to be taken and more importantly there's lots of history to be seen. Must do.

Was pleasantly suprised. I was surprised by how much I enjoyed everything in here, there's so much to see. Well worth taking your time and walking around a couple of times to take everything in.The remains are truly impressive and make for some great photos.
Rests of mighty imperium. It is amazing to be there. The places that we know so much and in fact so little. It's a small touch of eternity

If you're into Roman history, it's a must. Stunning remains that show the splendour and scale of Ancuent Rone. Consider using a guide or guide book to help make sense of the buildings as they are in a poor state of repair and you do need some knowledge of the Ancuent world to figure it all out.
Impressive. I'm not a history buff but really enjoyed just wandering though this site and Palatine Hill. Make sure to go up on Palatine Hill to look down on the Forum - spectacular views.

Tasting History. One of my very favourite places.
Here you can feel the history of Rome. The historic remains ooze the splendour and majesty and power that was once Rome.
Sit amongst the ruins and become a Senator for a day. Bathe in the tangible aura that fills the Forum

Nice. I went with my husband. We bought the combined ticket on-line for Colosseum, Palatine hill and Roman Forum. We were amazed to see these hard rocks still intact after 2000 years. Its just ruins, but some structures are still in place, which looks great. We hired a guide, so it was good for us as he explained us the significance behind each broken building. In short, It was worth a visit.

A must see - book a guided tour. We took a combined tour of Coloseum and Forum Romanum. So many interesting facts that we would not have received without a guide. It is a fascinating feeling to walk around in a 2000 year old feeling. Among other things, two doors made in metal still working fine. We want back the day after. It is easy to see parts of Forum Romanum from street level. I do not have any comission from any guide company. :-)

Stand back and imagine. Standing back and looking at the remains of massive columns and buildings you need to picture what this massive space must have looked like in ancient rome with a large open space at the centre surrounded by imposing buildings. The signs around the various ruins are interesting and detailed with good English to hep build the picture - including the temple housing the ashes of Julius Caesar - take some imagination with you and the piles of stone will blow your mind
Amazing History. Ancient Roman history comes to life in this walk through the Forum. Fantastic photo opportunities. Truly special.

Wasn't Expecting It To Be As Good As It Was. Me and my boyfriend recently visited this site and found it to be so interesting as a village so large could still be so intact. Whilst walking around there is a lot of information sheets so don't think you need a guided tour. I would especially recommend to walk up palatine hill to have a birds eye view of the Roman Forum which puts the layout of buildings into perspective. Definitely worth the money you pay to get in as it allows you into get into the colosseum also. If you are from Europe and aged 18-25 years old then take some form of ID with you as you pay half price entry (not just here but at most attractions) which is a great money saver!

Another must!!. This site is amazing! Make sure you allow yourself plenty of time to walk around and take it all in. This place is huge it just keeps going. The detail and the size of the ruins are amazing! I highly recommend you do this! Make sure you take plenty of water. And watch out for people taking selfies and not moving out the way for you!. We spent an amazing but warm! 3 hours here :) a must!

Try to separate your visit in two. So your ticket is valid for all three main attractions of Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Capitoline Hill. It is also valid for 2 days. So, try to separate your visit in two parts, with one day fully dedicated to say Palatine Hill and Colosseum and the other would be reserved for Capitoline Hill and the associated museums. This way you may avoid a sensory shock, a visual overburden and a vast array of historical facts all jumbled together. Another reason for doing so is that the walk down Via Sacra may get pretty tiring because of the rough cobblestones, uneven levels and the resulting continuous climbing. Which brings us to another advice importance of which can't be overestimated: good walking shoes or sneakers is a must! The Roman Forum is a multilayered area, both in terms of history and architecture, with some of the monuments combining in themselves historical periods distant over 1,800 years of each other. So, to fully appreciate and experience your sightseeing tour, you shall either do your homework prior to your trip or equip yourself with a good guidebook featuring digital or pictorial reconstructions of the scattered ruins in front of you, many of which merely look like a few solitary stones. Only by doing that one can feel virtually submerged into this religious, political, administrative and commercial hub of the ancient city.Highly recommended.

Well preserved and maintained.. This was a nice place to stroll around and get a feel for what "ancient" Rome was like. A guidebook would help. Also, wear a hat since the sun will pound down on you otherwise!

Not on strike this time!. No trip to Rome is complete without seeing the Roman Forum. It's difficult to describe what it's like to wander through these ancient ruins, marveling that they still exist, and struggling to image what the area looked like during the power and glory days of Imperial Rome. We hired a private professional tour guide for our group of 4 (I can't recommend this more!). We learned so much about the history of Rome, while walking in a place we'd dreamed of visiting for many years. 2 previous visits were either compromised by extreme heat or an unexpected strike, so we were very excited to make it through the grounds this time instead of walking the perimeter.

I think I suffered from cultural overload!. It was hot, it had been a long day, we'd been to the Vatican, the Colosseum and then the Roman Forum and I think I was suffering from a serious cultural overload! However, the history is so well known to all of us that to not include it after a visit to the Colosseum would be a sin.
So so. It was OK inside but I would feel the need yo pay to go in as you can see everything from the outside!

beautiful ruins - contradiction?. definitely not.this is amazing place.i felt like on different planet.my wife was dumbfounded.stay away if you don't have imagination.entry is included in colosseum ticket.

Imperial Rome in Ruins. We visited The Forum as part of The Imperial Rome tour with Real Rome Tours. We had a brilliant guide, and on that occasion there were only four of us. There is a great deal to absorb, and the history is fascinating. If you close your eyes and try to imagine the bustling senate, and the temples, and the area where Mark Anthony gave his famous speech "Friends,Romans etc. it is quite extraordinary to be standing there. The ground is very uneven, and gazing upwards can make you a little unsteady, so be careful. Great views to be had from The Palatine Hill and The Campidoglio.It can get very hot, so take water, a sun hat and sun screen.
History you must see. The place where the powerful met during the time of the Caesars. See where Julius Caesar was betrayed. The palace of the powerful.

A lot of ruins . It can get confusing knowing what everything is. Take a good map/guide with you which will explain in detail the history behind the forum. Nevertheless we still enjoyed ourselves. Beautiful place for scenic pictures. Again minutes from colosseum and seconds from the hill

Another great historical sight. The Forum is close by the other key historical attractions in Rome, easy to get to and not too strenuous to get around, albeit there are quite a few steps. To me this is a site that you need a tour guide as there is a lot to see and just walking around looking from a distance will not do the Forum justice.

Rome, as it were in the past. this is basically the remnants to the glorious Roman Empire. the entire city is in ruins. I personally did not know what i was looking at entirely. there were little writings laid around to help us understand , but I was too lazy to read them all. Would have been better if we took a guide i suppose, would have helped us loads in understanding what we were looking at. Although, it was still a fascinating sight. Plenty of photograph opportunities. you will need at least half a day to tour this place. i would recommend a visit ONLY if you have time to spare, as it will be very tiring and take half a day as i mentioned, so plan wisely :)

What a fascinating place to visit. 3000 + years of history. Like the tranquility of the place and the majestic ruins and structures. Great viewing platforms looking out over the city and the colosseum. Best with a guide as so much to see.Disliked inadequate toilet facilities in some parts of the site and a lot of sections closed to the public.

Transports you back in time. The Roman Forum oozes history and is a significant site. It is a must see when in Rome. After viewing the Colesseum which is close by we used our Roma pass to enter without having to queue. The site is impressive but lacks information about what you are seeing unless you get an audio or tour guide. A useful addition would be to have imagery of what the buildings would have looked like in their prime. Tip: wear comfortable footwear, head shade and take fluids.The views of the Forum from the terraces of the Campidoglio are fabulous and free.

Next door to the Colosseum. We really had no idea what to expect from the forum but it was stunning. We saw the colosseum and this was a follow on tour with our tour company. We were taken from end to end and given the history and then left to ourselves. The ruins are wonderful but to stroll afterwards up Palentine Hill was stunning. We thought it was just a view point for photographs but there were acres of ruins and viewpoint there that were completely unexpected. We spent another couple of hours wandering around after our tour and I'm sure we didn't see everything. It is a must for a Rome attraction, being next to the Colosseum makes it a complete day out for sight seeing. Do them both and you see the Roman Empire come to life.

Roman Forum. This ticket came free with my one to the Colosseum and it isn't something I would have paid for separately. It is ruins, and they look like ruins - a few are interesting, but after that they all meld into each other.

history. The Roman foroum and the Colosium very interesting part of the history of the imperial Rome, pay at the entrance of Foroum for both places and you saves time, can use a credit card visa o mc.

Great tour with Julieta from Walks of Italy.. Julieta has been studying these ancient ruins for many years and was able to tell us what is was like to live during that time, and what happened in each of the areas. If we had walked through on our own, we would have no idea what we were seeing.

Historical charm. We loved the Forum! Truly magnificent and filled with history. it was nice to be able to walk at our own pace and to explore as much as we wanted. The view from the hill was beautiful.

The Roman stuff. Loads of queues, did not go inside we could see a lot of it from outside the entrance and could see lots of people in the grounds very busy, very off putting, the same with all the Rome major attractions.Wonderful architecture.Visit in the winter!

Simply fascinating ! Can't take eyes off it. The Roman Forum is composed of two parts, the oldest and most famous Forum close to Colosseo, and the one called Foro and Mercati di Traiano, on the opposite side of the street Via dei Fori Imperiali. I love more the second one, that can be admired at any time during the day and the night (take a seat in front of it and imagine to have lived at that time). No entrance fee is required for this.
Bundles of history. A must do and give at least half a day to it, especially if its hot. Some research or taking a guide will help massively with what you are looking at.

Do your homework first. You'll enhance your experience of these dramatic ruins if you watch some of the 3-D video recreations available online first. The Forum is packed with ruins. The more you know, the more you'll be able to appreciate this incredible site. A first-rate guide will make it even more remarkable. If you are going to Rome, please make sure you add this to your list of must-see attractions.

Short cut the lines. While it is a good idea to buy your tickets online for the Forum and Colosseum (all-in-one ticket), if you can't do this, don't despair! Hint 1: Go as early as you can in the morning.Hint 2: The Colosseum line is horrendous so just go around the corner to the Roman Forum line. It takes less time by far. After getting your ticket, you then have to line up on a second line to show your ticket but it is still faster than the alternative.Hint 3: The tickets are valid for 48 hours. As the Forum is a huge area, you can always come back the next day with your ticket and bypass the line outside the Colosseum. Just walk past the ticket buying queue and get your ticket scanned. You're in!

Half of Rome is under restoration. This is my second time in Rome and it seems half of the monuments and sites are under restoration. The same is happening at Roman Forum, where many temples are closed.
Even the Vestas Temple was locked. A shame, because all the rose bushes were in flower and the view was lovely.

A whole city inside of a city. What's left of the Roman Empire tells alot about this vast empire that once ruled the earth... You can actually feel the history while walking around there... It's a must see

Just remember one thing ..... I understand it is a ruin, I am very happy to pay for the visit. But once you are in, most of the time you see pillars and foundations. I personally have no idea what I was looking at.If you want a good experience, make sure you don't visit at night, and do at least one of the following:a) Get a tour guide, so people could explain to you what you are looking atb) Get an audio guidec) Get the "before and after" book. (I bought mine at the bookshop in Colosseum)d) Do heaps of research online beforehandWith one of the above, it will definitely improve the experience. It would be ideal if the council (or whichever organisation that looks after this place), should put at least one signage with a "before" picture for each building. At the bare minimum, it would help people to visualise and realise the four pillars on the ground are actually the four of the many pillars of the original building, which happen to be a temple.P.S. Don't forget to allow for more time and wear comfortable footwear, it is huge.

A fascinating look back to the time of Rome's greatness.. Well worth a visit to look and imagine the days of Rome's greatness as a world power. The architecture shows the skill of the Roman builders and the beauty of the monuments they created.

Roman Forum - an easy must-see for first time visitors to Rome. The Roman Forum is an important collection of building ruins from ancient Rome. This area was the most important centre of social, political and commercial activity for many centuries and hosted great buildings of the ancient world, making it one of the most important archeological sights in the world. In the past, you could visit the Roman Forum for free, however, now you must purchase an entry ticket, which includes access to the Colosseum and Palatine Hill (€12 per person + €2 if reservations made online). Unfortunately, the grand buildings of ancient Rome have long been reduced to rubble and mostly cleared away. As such, we are left to stroll down the ancient Via Sacra road and wander the grounds of the Roman Forum, imagining what it must have been like to visit this place during the height of the Roman Empire. It must have been spectacular compared to the outside world. Tip: To get the most of your visit to the Roman Forum, it is advisable to purchase a good guidebook and to spend some time going over the various ancient temples, basilicas, palace houses and monuments that are to be seen before you arrive. This will help prepare you for what to look for when wandering the Forum grounds. Tip: You may wish to visit Palatine Hill first before entering the Roman Forum grounds. If you do this, you can walk up to a viewing area, overlooking the Roman Forum and see the entire Forum from east to west, prior to making your visit. This is can be helpful as well for preparing you for the various ancient buildings and ruins you will see there. Tip: The grounds around the Roman Forum can be uneven. Do bare this in mind when thinking about footwear. Tennis or hiking shoes are most suitable for exploring the grounds. Tip: We recommend visiting the Colosseum first in order to clear the queue you are very likely to encounter there when purchasing tickets. Unlike the Colosseum, you won't find the same problem with queues at the Roman Forum. Crowds may be an issue though. Overall, the Roman Forum is a marvel of the ancient world and wonderful place to visit. While much less remains that we would like, it is wonderful that we can still see what is here today. In this regard, this is an easy Must-See attraction for first-time visitors to Rome and a place that many repeat visitors will eagerly wish to return to.

Not a place to visit at night. We walked through most of the places that one does not have to pay. You can almost see just as much and you can also avoid the line ups. Several locations where the steps go through the trees from the higher levels to lower levels I noticed numerous undesirables lurking in the trees This place should only be visited throughout the day and in the afternoon as I believe an evening visit could possibly end up disastrous.

Use The Rick Steve's Book As A Guide. Without a guide of some type, the Roman Forum would have looked like a bunch of uninteresting ruins. But, I used the Rick Steve's Rome book which - a little imagination - really brought the forum to life. It was fun to stop at vantage point, understand what I was looking at, then imagine it as it must have been.A must see in Rome!

Once the "center of the world," at least for Europeans, west Asia, and North Africa.. the layers of history are remarkable. not to be missed. i'm not sure that a paid guide would help much, but it's worthwhile to read in advance. this is particularly true because ruins from different centuries are all seen in one place. harder to visualize than on might think....

"walking in the past". it was fantastic place watching the ruins of one of the most beautiful civilization. weather has been good , we can take one of the hop on hop off buses that can travel all over and drop to the site and have briefing about the city. Tickets for Colosseum and roman forum can be taken fron Forum as the queue is small. Instead of the audio guides i say go for the guided tours.

Incredible!. I had been to Rome before, but its beauty keeps impressing me! The view of the forum from the Palatinum is fantastic, it transports you to the time of the Emperors! It is very useful to buy one of those books that show the before and after, to get a better idea of what you are seeing.

History Comes to Life. We visited the Forum on a hot, sunny Sunday in May. We had bought a tour of the Colosseum that included the Forum. There are many buildings, columns, and ruins to see that compromise the Forum. Guido the Guide was extremely competent, thorough, and knowledgeable about what we saw. My biggest problem was that I was collapsing from information overload, as well as hours on my feet in the sun. If I had felt fresher, I would probably have been mesmerized. My suggestions: don't try to do to much in an afternoon.

Great architecture. The Roman forum was a surprise for me I didn't think it would be as large and complete as it was, it is well kept, informative and was very interesting. A little tip get your ticket here for the coloseum as the queues are a lot shorter and the ticket gives you entrance to both

Equally as cool as the colosseum!. The Roman Forum was right across the street from the Colosseum. It was a beautiful, ancient town that has managed to keep some parts of it together. It also features the place that Julius Ceasar was cremated. It was neat to walk around and hear about the history and stories believed at the time. Definitely a must see!
A MUST Visit. Definitely if you are interested in ruins, this should be in your list. Good few hours for your children in their history lessons. Keep it in your list for Rome

A Walk in the Past. Walking along the first road in Rome, standing in the place where Julius Caesar was stabbed to death and seeing where Augustus spoke his famous lines of 'Friends, Romans and countrymen...' certainly brings history to life.
A fascinating historical site. This has the ruins of many historical Roman buildings. The arrangement of the buildings is very interesting, and the guides are extremely informative.

Amazing Ruins!. Loved this! I visited with my husband and sister in May and it was absolutely gorgeous. Not too hot, the flowers were in bloom and everything was green, and the view of the city at the top of the ruins was breathtaking. Self guided walks are perfectly acceptable, but I asked for a guided tour and the woman said they were done for the day, even though the sign a desk down from her said there should have been 2 more available in English for the afternoon. She told me it was best to plan them ahead of time. Whatever, I wasn't in the mood to argue. We kind of wandered near tour groups in English while acting like gawking for the spots we were really interested in. I definitely plan on going back, getting an actual tour, and also spending an entire day so I can get the Colosseum experience as well, since the tickets cover the Forum, Palace, and Colosseum in one go. There's just so much to see and read, it's impossible to do in less than a week, and I only had a half day (due to flight cancellations and such) in my backpacking adventure. So take it from me, definitely carve out plenty of time to see these ruins and take it in! They're amazing and I wish I had a full guided tour, but I'm still pleased with what I got.

Large area with ruins everywhere. The walking through the Forum was particularly gruelling. Yes we were walking on the original basalt stone paths that Julius Caesar walked on, but my feet were not happy. The forum area is quite large with ruins everywhere. We saw arches and columns and statues and carved marble until we had had enough.

A step back in time. Stunning and extensive. You need plenty of time to visit all of it and make sure you protect yourself against the fierce sun - there is little shade anywhere. Comfortable shoes are a must and beware as some of the cobbles are very uneven and slippery.Also don't be taken in by the 'gladiators' hovering outside. They take your photo with them and then demand money for the privilege - not coins but notes!!A little oasis of calm can be found in the Hortus Botanicus near Palatine Hill which is a marvellous place to look down on all the ruins and imagine how it was like to live in Roman times. Links up nicely with a visit to Pompeii and Herculaneum too if you're into this age of history.
Another must. There is so much history but I find these preferable to a museum with pictures of the same old same old, although old, these buildings are still alive

Well worth a visit!. This iconic centre gives you a real feeling of what ancient Rome was all about. Entrance fee is 12 euro & this also gets you into the Colosseum which is near by. By visiting the forum first & purchasing the ticket you can bypass the queue at the Colosseum & get in quickly. As others have stated its a bit chaotic getting in but once inside you can roam at will. It is not particularly buggy or wheelchair friendly & is hard on the feet but you can get around.There are useful bits of information posted around the site but a guide book or an audio guide(5 euro) is a good idea. Ticket touts are always trying to sell you a guided tour where ever you go in Rome but our experience was it's cheaper to do it yourself & the audio guides are really good. Allow yourself plenty of time to do the Forum & the Colosseum justice. A very enjoyable experience

Breathtaking. . Incredible area, and so much to see. Definitely worth a look. Book a tour if you want to know the history it is well worth it. You could also spend hours just looing and taking everything in.

Where Cicero dwelled.... It´s easy to imagine Cicero walking among these fragments of marble and time-stained monuments or to imagine victorious emperors parading their spoils of war for all of Rome to see. This attraction is an absolute must and it entrance is included with the colosseum. The ticket covers the Palantine hill too and I recommend seeing that first, situated on your left when you enter. It would be useful to have read some background info beforehand, or to get the optional audio guide. Alternatively, you could do like we did and listen in on some of the many guided tours that are visiting. We went in the evening and it was open until 7pm in May. There were only a few tourists inside so we were able to really appreciate the place. I recommend getting the ticket online: No lines, no waiting and the ticket is not specific to a certain day. Once you validate it, it´s valid for 2 days. Overall, a very immersive experience

Forum was worth a tour. My boyfriend and I stayed in Rome for 5 days and had an awesome tour of the Forum. It was a hot day but there are some cool areas and we stood in the shade as much as we could. He history had us so interested...to imagine how they lived in those times amazed us. This is the highlight of our Rome trip...we could walk there from our hotel and ate at a nearby restaurant in the evening. Bring water if it is a hot day as it heats up in mid day.

Complete day of History. We did a full day of tours starting with the Colosseum and ending with the Roman Forum. Walking among such ancient structures has a surreal feeling. its a nice walk while learning history. Wear comfortable shoes and bring a bottle of water (they have many fountains that can refill water). The sun can get very hot early, so go towards the later afternoon. We used our roma pass and had no problems with lines.

Roman forum - a favorite. This was one of our favorite places to visit. Getting inside is a bit disorganized and chaotic. But once inside the kids could run and play and enjoy freedom under the sunny sky. Truly amazing to imagine what once was. The kids enjoyed leading the way through and jump across the stone walkways.

The heart of Ancient Rome. It's one of the most iconic sites in Rome, but I found it overwhelming. The artifacts and remnants are so close together that the area feels incredibly congested and claustrophobic. Nonetheless, if you've made the trip to Italy, you really should spend at least a little time here, because it is so rich with history.

Unbelievable. The Forum itself it's astonishing to know what went on here! I would recommend getting yourself a good guide or guide book so you have more understanding of what you're looking at.The organisation at the gate is horrendous, there were four different queues with no signage to show us which one we should join! It turned out the big long queue was for security so the benefit of a fast track ticket is totally out weighed by having to join an hour long security queue anyway. They have four ticket booths and only two security stands so double the number of people joining than they were able to take - insane! Once inside it is well worth it though, could easily spend the whole day here
Good vieuw. Great experience walking in the area where people lived so many years ago. Also a beautifull view looking over the of Rome.

Walking in the footsteps of history. Pre book your ticket to avoid the line, take as long as you like to walk slowly around the ruins, signs are good so you won't need an audio guide if you want to avoid this. Look for the location Caesar was cremated near the middle of the forum.

Read Your Guide Book Before Going. We entered through the Palatine Hill entrance and then walked through to the Forum. You will, however, need the book sold by tour guides in front of the Colosseum that shows the sites as they now are but with overlay pages showing what they looked like originally. This will make sense of what your are seeing. I'd use the Rick Steeves audio guides rather than buying the audio tour sold at the sites.

Dreadful organisation. I can t believe i am not giving this most important of monument 5 stars but the Rome tourist board is really letting it down.We travelled there independently and unbelievably had difficulty finding the entrance. When we finally did you are not actually sure if you are in the right place as there is just a long queue to what amounts to little more then a shed. There are no signs telling you how much it is or what you are buying a ticket for. When you eventually get in you will see signs indicating that headphones are for sale but there did not appear to be anywhere to rent one from.Anyway that aside the place is an amazing record of the might of the Roman empire and you can get a real feel for it here.

Times square in 3250 AD......?. Almost impossible to imagine that the was the true hart of an empire with 90 million souls in Roman Times. It is almost flattened to the ground so you can only see in reconstruction on the internet what is must have looked liked in those days. Sic transit gloria mundi. Let us be aware that also our "civilizations" are bound to die and what will we leave then in ruins? This is an enchanted place although I have to get used to the fact that you have to buy a ticket to see it.And that there are SO many tourists around nowadays, but still: very impressive.

Incredible history and size.. We went on a guided tour and I would recommend this as it's far too big to understand on your own. We even saw where the Vestil Virgins hung out. It takes a long time to see and understand everything as there is so many different one periods and parts of history to sink in. Take at least half a day, don't worry about the tourists around you and enjoy it.

Walk through history. Beware of the people trying to sell you tickets at enormous prices for the Colosseum and the Forum. Go to the Forum first, queues are shorter than for the Colosseum and you can buy a ticket for both. When you have been round the Forum you do not need to queue for the Colosseum.Both are incredible, seeing them on television cannot compare to the stunning reality of actually walking through the streets that saw so much history. Take a bottle of water with you as we could not find anywhere to get a drink. There are limited toilet facilities.

Panoramic. We took the entrance off Via di S. Gregorio and turned left. This led up the Palatine hill and made for a much easier traipse around the sights on the higher levels and then descending down to the rest, rather than the other way around. Also, no waiting to get in the gates like you will at Via Sacra. Amazing to see the surviving ruins and with all the space, it is easy to get around. Essential part of any trip to Roma.
Impressive. Quite the quintessential Roman remain. Step back in time as you appreciate Roman society and culture.

History comes alive!. We bought our tickets online (coopculture.it) for 14€ per person (tickets are generally 12€ each, but a 2€ booking fee applies). This ticket allowed full access for one day to the Roman Forum, the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. Our taxi dropped us off on Via San Gregorio, outside the entrance to Palatine Hill. This place was deserted and we walked right in without having to wait in any sort of queue.Palatine Hill houses a museum showcasing artefacts that were found in the vicinity, which has interesting video presentations. Admission is free.Most sites are signposted in Italian and French, with brief but good information. Was delighted at having seen the supposed dwelling place of the founder of Rome: Romulus. Palatine Hill offers beautiful panoramic views of the Roman Forum and the Colosseum. The Forum is connected to the hill and you just continue walking around the grounds. You'll need to exit the forum to cross the road to reach the Colosseum. Allow at least 4 hours to see everything, whilst walking at an average pace. 90% of footpaths are cobbled stones, so appropriate footwear is advised. There are no shops nearby, so I recommend carrying a bottle of water.

Enchanting. It was really like a walk through history. Right from the time we set our eyes on it from the Palatine hill, making our way down and actually walking through the ruins was an amazing experience. There's a beautiful, time stopping quality about the place, though try going in the morning or evening, as it can get quite hot! It's spectacular though so don't miss it!
Well preserved history. I went with a guided tour, but it is not needed. Buy a good book with a map and photos, and walk around by yourself. This is a big park full of Roman ruins. Simply marvelous!
Very nice to see. You have to take a walk around the ruins for about 2 hrs to see all around this ancient roman city. A good guide is essential.

My absolute favourite place in Rome. I loved everything about Rome but the Forum was just incredible. We didn't join a tour but did carry Rome - past and present, which helped picture how things were. Even though it was packed with visitors, there was still peaceful moments and areas.There are big and little delights around every corner and some uphill paths that lead nowhere.Took us longer than we planned and we could have spent a lot more time if we didn't have other things planned. Make sure you leave enough time to just sit and take in the views.

The true Ancient Rome. This is a really neat place, but I very much suggest a guide or a good guidebook. Otherwise you won't know what you are looking at, or the great history behind it. The walk up from here to Palatine Hill is steep, and comprised of uneven stones, so wear sensible shoes and bring a plastic bottle of drinking water. There is a fountain available that you can refill your bottle.Take some good pictures of the stunning arches, columns, ruins of Emporer's palaces, etc..

Breathtaking! You must see!. We visited The Roman Forum on a tour through City Wonders, which also included The Colosseum and Palatine Hill. Our guide Amber is an Archeologist so I took advantage of her vast knowledge of the Roman Empire. The Roman Forums and Palatine Hill were the highlight of the tour for me. There is so much history in the buildings and our guide Amber did an amazing job explaining everything to us. I was impressed at how many buildings had survived the test of time. My advice is do all three on a tour or you'll never get all the great information we did. Go early in the morning! Our tour ended at 1pm on Palatine Hill and I was glad because it was so hot! I couldn't imagine just starting the tour at that time. You cannot say you've seen Rome if you haven't seen where it all began!

Just Imagine. Don't be lazy. See the Forum from Palantino. Great view... Make enough reading about Roman Lifestyle before you go and just imagine how life was. Wish some parts would be reconstructed just like it was. It would surely be easier to understand the greatness of the Roman World.

Incredible structures. The structures are incredible, but it helps to know what you are looking at. I recommend a guide book, guide, or audio guide (we used Rick Steve's free downloadable audio tours), otherwise, it's difficult to appreciate what you are seeing.

rome at it's finest. Part of the palatine hill area.while walking around you think of your history books and what took place there.you think of all the names of famous people.you get chills thinking about it being around over 2000 years old and who's foot steps you are walking in.

A lot of imagination needed. I found a great wee book, it was actually for kids I think, which had renditions of what the original structures would have looked like overlayed on photos of the existing site. Really helped bring it to life.

Forum. Having studied latin for 6 years it was a surprise to see with my ownn eyes where all those people had said the mysterious sentences we had to translate. The best place to get an averall view is from the Capitol a little bit behind the Marc Aurele Statue and it is free from that location otherwise you have to buy a entrance -better on line- for the forum and the palatine hill

Good. Huge space. Very interesting but signage could be improved to bring it to life.I guess we could have got a guide, but looking at the people on tours, they looked like they were about to collapse from boredom/heat stroke.
Simply amazing. We had a guided tour which was very informative I learnt so much about the place and people who lived there.

Getting even better. More is being opened up and you can see the excavation taking place. It's always a must do in Rome. Water was being sold by an Italian vendor for €1 a bottle. The rip off merchants in the caravan stalls on the via Imperali were selling it for €2:50! When I visited there wasn't a lot of difference between the queues to puck up the pre purchased tickets and the ticket queue. That may change in summer. Go early and head straight to the left after the entrance in order to visit the Palantine first. , it was almost deserted when I visited. After you come out the exit be prepared to be harassed by hoards of street vendors selling " selpie sticks" SO Annoying!

Exit the Coloseum walk across the street to the Forum. We entered where the Caesar's lived looking down on the peoples Forum. Walking down to Constantine's Arch and the rest. Three hours, lots of fun and history.

Roman Forum and Colosseum in same day!. Good place to visit! We went to Roman Forum at 9 am and we didn't have to wait to get inside. Ticket was 12 euros and when we bought it at Roman Forum's gates it included pass the line ticket to Colosseum. That was the reason why we went to Roman Forum first. To get that ticket :D The park and Palatino Hill was so beautiful and full of art and architecture. And the best thing about Roman Forum? You can get amazing photos with Colosseum near the gates when you climb up. Photos of that below. But we combine this place with Colosseum and it was a good idea. But remember to take water bottle, something to eat and hat with you. When we were there it was 38 degrees with no shadows. I have write a post about our trip to Rome and to Roman Forum. You can read it here http://lookbymari.com/rome-part-2-roman-forum/ and Colosseum post in here http://lookbymari.com/rome-part-3-colosseum/ .Worth of visit!

Must see, but not what you might expect.. There are no grand ruins or monuments left for the most part. A few columns, the outline of a building, in many cases not well marked. But in the forum you will find the echo of history in every stone. The Arch of Titus, with it's bas relief inside of the loot of the Temple in Jerusalem, captured in 70 CE, The temple for emperor worship of Antonino and Faustina now turned into a church, are both reminders of the struggles Christians and Jews faced in the early centuries of the Common Era. The temple to Saturn, from which worship many of the customs of Christmas come, is there. A lot of Biblical history is touched on, if that is why you are there. Bathrooms are about halfway through on the left, past the vestals temple.

Interesting. Very nice and interesting. get ready for a nice walk in the sun (be prepared with water and sunscreen)The signs are clear and informative, easy to find your way and enjoy the Roman history

Good place to learn about history. Although it's a bit pricey, but 12 EUR for both colloseum and roman forum is a good offer. After all, you can spend 2-3 hours in the Roman Forum, if you're interested in history.

Awesome!. This one nearly slipped under the radar - but DO NOT MISS! This is one of the best sites in Rome. Top Tip: Download 'Rick Steves Audio Europe' app for free and listen to the guided tour as you walk around the ruins.....it really brings it to life.See where Caeser died!!

Colisseum , Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. We highly recommend that you book a tour guide to see the Colisseum and Roman Forum; we used The Roman Guy and were very impressed. The tour included a visit to the dungeons, the arena floor and top level, areas general public has no access to. Our guide was an archeologist and extremely knowledgeable which made the experience even better. Once again you move to front of the line avoiding the long queues. I say if you come all the way to Rome and visit these amazing structures, its well worth it to do it right. What we liked about The Roman Guy too is that the groups are small - there were 10 of us.

Walk Through History. Amazing ruins. Must see. Highlight of Rome. Tip: there is a great Caffeteria Italia restaurant above the Forum with super views. Take the Capitol Hill exit, bear right up the hill and enter Chiesa Santa Maria Aracoeli via back entrance. Beautiful church. Exit front doo and bear right past the sightseeing elevator to the Caffeteria.
Best example of ruins in Rome!. My favourite part of Rome, we walked all around this area, it was incredible, everywhere you look there was a different, ancient piece of Rome!

HOT!. Amazing archeological site! It was hot in in early May. Lots os hills with cobble stone on which to walk. A friend had a really difficult time walking around. There were no vendors in the Forum to provide water or other fluids.

Amazing!. Myself and my boyfriend decided to visit the forums after seeing the Colosseum. I didn't expect much from the forums if I'm honest, I didn't think there would me much to see. How wrong was I! The forum is in great condition considering how old the ruins are. Definitely a must see!

Must see newest part of excavation!. We had a Roma Pass and had already used it for our two free admissions, so we went to the ticket window to purchase discounted tickets for the Forum/Palatine Hill. We were at the entrance closest to the Coloseo.Spotted a small sign offering a guided tour in English of the Domus (house) of Augustus and Domus Livia. That sounded interesting. Sadly, we were too late for the 11:45am guided tour, but the ticket seller told us we could purchase ENTRY ONLY tickets for 12:45pm. I think they were 12E each.We wandered the general site for an hour, returned to the meeting point, and the ticket seller, who spoke some English, escorted us up and into the site, through some locked gates and doors and into this fantastic excavation. It was just 3 of us in these large, fascinating rooms, and when I asked how long they had been opened I was told "three days." So, we were among the very first to visit.As it happened, we had earlier been to the Museo Nazionale Romane where they have on display the frescos and mosaics from this very site, so while the walls of the excavated rooms had only faint paint left, in the museum you could see the vivid colors and intricate, lovely designs. I'd encourage anyone to pay the extra for entry to this very special, restricted area, probably even better if you can get on the guided tour.

An ancient city. Walking in the Roman Forums, you are walking in an ancient city, with each ruin representing a structure. Some of the ruins are just remaining’s of the building's structure or pieces of walls while others are huge pieces of walls with columns and stairs.In order to be able to visit the place you need either a ticket or the Roma pass. The good news is that there is a combination of the Colosseum and the Roman Forums so you either buy a single ticket for both attractions or you use a single free entry in your pass for both of them.The Roman Forum can partially be seen from the outside and you can take photos as well. However, the place is much bigger than it can be seen from the outside and I was surprised by that while visiting it. It represents quite a walk to go through all the sites and walkways. It is an amazing experience and worthwhile as you get to see buildings from a long ago time.Not all the structures are so well preserved, as I was saying, and the destination they had is unclear, some of the signs saying probably when explaining what it stood for, but they are still amazing nevertheless, considering the age and architectonical style.It is quite a walk and I advice you to have comfortable shoes, a few snacks and a bottle of water with you. I didn't see any bathrooms inside, but I think there is one at the Colosseum entry and another one at the middle exit.When you fist take the left alley, it seems that there is little to be seen there but then a lot of structures appear one after the another so you may want to consider that before spending too much time at each, taking photos and reading all the story written in there so you keep enough energy to visit all the area.This visit reminded me of the ancient city Ephesus in Turkey. Maybe this is a little bigger than that one, I'm not really sure and I had a guide in there. I think a guide would have made the difference in here too with some stories related to some of the structures.

A fantastic thing happened on the way to the Forum. Just WOW! Such history under your feet, walk where all the famous Emporers walked, and Cleopatra, Marc Anthony Thoroughly recommend downloading Rick Steves Rome Forum podcast- its free, very informative if you just want a small tour, rather than wandering around in the hot sun with a tour guideWarning though- no food for sale on site, there are the free drinking fountains. Can be quite a long wait for the toilets.

Stunning. Absolutely gorgeous. I could have spent all day in there.Getting a tour is highly recommended. We did not and regretted it (especially after overhearing part of another tour).The Coliseum and Forum are combined on one ticket. Purchase entrance to one and you have 2 days to visit the other free of charge. I would recommend doing the Coliseum first, as that takes roughly an hour. The Forum takes much longer and should be saved for last.This would be a great place to take a picnic lunch.Tips: The ticket lineup for the Coliseum is insanely long. If you didn't book a Coliseum tour, or pre-purchase a Coliseum ticket or Roma pass, then a quicker option would be to purchase a ticket at the Forum (a much shorter line) but do not enter the Forum. Take that ticket to the Coliseum and do that first, then proceed to the Forum (or come back the next day for the Forum). Since it's the same ticket, you just saved yourself at least a half hour lineup, and possibly up to 2 hours.

You walk in the footsteps of the Caesars.. It's like a combination of a ruin, a building site, Central Park and Disney Land. I was thrilled to see the antiquities and ruins. It definitely gives a feeling of what ancient Rome was like and brings the stories to life. I loved it. Probably my favourite activity in Rome.Go early to avoid queues but, once inside, there's plenty of space even on a busy day. There's a lot of walking on uneven surfaces so wear comfortable shoes. Probably worth reading up a bit on the history beforehand as there is almost zero signage or explanation. Also, if I can be practical, there are very few loos.

A huge site.. The area is very big. The ticket we had from the tour of the Colosseum allowed us to go to the front of the queue, show it and enter. There was hundreds of people in the entry queue, so well worth while. We spent many hours walking around and soaking up the history. It is good to read up before, so you are aware of the significance of the site. A must see whilst in Rome. There are some fountains so you can fill your water and some quiet places to sit.

Temple of Vesta - Interesting temple ruin in the Roman Forum. The Temple of Vesta was once an elegant building during ancient Roman times. Like the rest of the Roman Forum, it has long been reduced to ruinous conditions but makes for an interesting attraction to see and learn about when visiting the Forum. During its time, the temple was constructed of ancient Greek design and architecture, being round in shape and lined by 20 Corinthian style columns. The purpose of the temple was the worship of the Virgin goddess Vesta, a popular Roman religious deity during ancient times. Today, what is left of the Temple of Vesta is a small fraction of one of the circular wall sections as well as few standing columns. Behind the standing section, you can see the foundation of the old temple as well. To find the Temple of Vesta, just look at a map of the Roman Forum. It is located near the House of Vestal Virgins. Its standing wall fragment is recognisable amongst mostly levelled buildings in the area. Tip: You might wish to research a bit on this and other attractions, which you will see in the Roman Forum prior to visiting. This will help provide context to what you will see once you are walking around the Forum grounds.

Didn't like it much. We had pretty high hopes after reading about it but we didn't enjoy being there. It's missing proper signs and schematics how it's imagined the place looked in the past. Overall an unrewarding visit.

Use a guide to truly understand and appreciate. Same comments as for Palantine Hill as they truly belong together. We generally visit sites on our own, but for this and the Forum, a guide will help you understand. So much history, plan on reading guidebooks if you don't have a guide to explain everything. Otherwise it is a park with ruins.

Dedicated to the Gods. The most preserved and influential building of ancient Rome, said to be dedicated to the Gods. Just seeing and walking through the area is an incredibly privileged experience for our group of 18 pilgrims because it allowed us a glimpse into the marvelous and stunning world of Roman architecture. WOW!

The ruins you went for to Rome. Next to the Colosseum this is the second best thing to check out in Rome. Obviously the ruins give it a very good atmosphere even though they are pretty run down - no surprise they are ruins.You can walk around in less then an hour but if you want to take photos, sit down and enjoy the scene it takes much more than that. You can directly access the Palatinus gardens and make the best photos of the Colosseum.

Very Interesting But long Lines to Get In. The Roman Forum is well worth visiting, but on a not peak April weekday, the ticket booth line took us at least 1/2 hour to get through. Apparently you can buy tickets on line to save time, but we did not try that and do not know for sure that is so. In any case, once in the crowds dispersed due to the size of the place, and it was well worth the wait.

Wow. Just... wow.. Julius Caesar's funeral pyre and tomb?The Imperial palace.The history of Nero and his colossal statue. The home of the Vestal Virgins.Walking through this area and being so lucky to take in the history of these places was an absolute privilege. Walking the same route as emperors and Roman nobility... I was a little taken aback.There's the "gateway to hell" in there as well, but you'll need to ask someone or have a guide to find it. So much to see, and so much to lose yourself in for hours. Personally, I'd recommend a guide to show you in the ins and outs of everything in order to gain a better understanding, but even if you don't, the beauty of these structures is enough to leave you staring at them, thinking of how things must've been.

Walking History. Never really knew this place existed before we went. Spent a long time here taking it all in. Amazing place. Worth the trek up the hill for the ariel view. Also, the boards at the different sites are very informative.

Living History. In the centre of Rome, you can still see where Julius Ceasar was assinated over 2000 years ago. Makes Shakespear's Roman plays come to life in front of your eyes. There are remains of shop and offices from the period showing that people have not changed much in a couple of millenia, we now mobile phones instead of runners carrying messages around the Empire.Humbling.

Lots to see - consider going with a guide. I followed the advice offered by others which suggested to buy tickets at the Forum rather than the Colosseum (one ticket for both). Great advice! We got to the Forum early (about 8:30) and waited about 10 minutes to buy tickets - and this was on a long weekend! There is heaps to see here, so you'll probably need at least 1 1/2 hours. We found, however, that there wasn't a great deal of information on offer for those wanting to do a self-guided tour. A few signs scattered about the place gave you some information about the ruins, but after having a guide at the Colosseum later that day, we felt that perhaps we should have also gone with a guide whilst at the Forum. In saying that, if you are happy just to have a walk around, see some great historical sites and take photos, then you can quite easily do a self-guided tour, but if you are wanting to gain a better understanding of Roman life and history, and having someone tie everything together, then perhaps consider having a guide.
Stunning monuments . Stunning monument to the possibilities that man can achieve. Have you great insight to what life was like in Roman times, we loved it!

So interesting!. My daughter and I took a guided tour of the Forum. I recommend a guide as they will share interesting information and history of the Forum that you may not recognize. We learned how the Forum ground level kept getting higher, we learned that if a building was not converted to a church it was not preserved, and we saw the site where Julius Caeser's body was burned after his death. History really comes alive in the Roman Forum!

worthy addition to the visit of the Colosseo. It is very interesting to visit this site (same ticket as the Colisseo's) and imagine how certains parts of Rome looked like. Compare that to what cities look like today!

More astounding.............. I thought than the actual Colosseo - but that could be because of the huge size of the grounds and the Palatino included.Give yourself plenty of time to visit. The ticket to the Collosseo covers this as long as visited within 48 hours (one entry only)
Amazing. Huge. Really impressive and lots to see. We spent longer here than we thought we would as it was so big. Well worth a visit.

Advance knowledge. I followed TA review of buying tickets at the forum to include the colosseum. Best advice ever. The forum was great to walk around and enjoy the history. Walking past all those people in line at the colosseum waiting for tickets PRICELESS. The line at the forum took about 20 minutes- when we headed over to the colosseum the wait was two hours for those needing to purchase tickets. It took us about 5 minutes to get in and that was just because they walk you half way across the arena before you can enter. Both are a must see, this is definitely the way to do it.

Old rocks: great history. We loved that we could relate the Roman Forum to the Bible. There are a lot of ruins to see, and it was better with the book Rome With Kids by Pasquessi. Rather than just being a lot of rocks, they had the history on what they were seeing and could look for different landmarks. It pays to get the layout of the forum before you go to keep it from being just another set of ruins.
wonderful history. The forum used to be free in the past but is now included in your Colosseum ticket. It is so full of history and beautiful ruins. You can learn so much of the past.

Lack of information. This site could be so much more interesting with better information boards or reconstructions. Despite it being listed separately to the Palatine Hill, the sites are joined and only one entry is permitted to the entire site on the ticket. It still feels like something that has to be done whilst in Rome though.

Ancient relics. There are many parts of this that will seem less than awe inspiring as it is very broken. However, it is a must see. See the place Julius Caesar was cremated and see the vestal virgins living quarters.

The most beautiful site. The history of this ancient place, is far greater than my words can tell. From the first villages on those hills near the Tiber, to the might of Imperial Rome and the vastness of its forum is impossible to comprehend in a short time. The more time one spends in this eternal place, your sense of awe just increases at these incredible and their energetic ideas and actions. One can never cease feeling such a connection with the past than in the old forum and surrounding areas. I am in love with this past, and intend to live here when i can to explore it more
living history. It was incredible to walk the streets that the apostles walked. Being there brought the Roman Empire to life for me.

Next to the granddaddy of attractions but just as special. Whilst it is only a stones throw from the Coliseum, the Forum is easy to overlook on occasion. This is a huge flaw in many itineries as it so close, free and arguably as impressive as it houses so many more points of intrest. The only, minor critique would be that it can be tricky underfoot in sections, especially if it's wet. Otherwise a must see when in Rome

Amazing Archeological Site !. We loved walking around and through the Roman Ruins ! It is amazing to be able to walk right beside an archeological dig site ! To see how this area was laid out and the beautiful Curia (the building of the Roan Senate) was fantastic. Another tourist had downloaded Rick Steve's audio tour of this site and was sharing great details we would never have known. So download this free app before leaving home. Just super !
Amazing!. I was left speechless after the experience. Makes you want to learn about history all over again after actually seeing the place.

Good but not great . I worry about italy i really do, here they have inherited some wonderful ancient monuments and what to they do, put a bloody fence around it and charge entry that's it! the site itself is great but you really have to use your imagination there should at leats be boards with artists impressions showing what the place looked like in its former glory !

WOW. Rome is the place to be if you are a history buff. You have to take some time to sit and enjoy the sights and imagine what this place would have been like so many years ago. Once you get past all the vendors who are trying to sell you everything, you can feel the history all around you.

A real highlight. The Forum was a highlight of our trip to Rome. The sheer scale of it is fairly mind boggling and it is interesting to try and picture how it would have looked and imagine daily life here - we read up a bit before hand and had some idea, but it's still hard to visualise. It's also a very attractive space to walk around and the adjoining Janiculum hill has some fine views. We were with 2 children and it took us 3 hours to walk around everything.

Highlight of my trip. I went to a few places whilst spending 4 days in Rome but this for me was the highlight. It really is like walking in history. You are free to roam the whole area and walk on the very cobbles the ancient Romans did. You get a real insight how they lived over 2000 years ago. We went in April so it was busy but nothing like the Vatican or Colosseum. The line was about 10 deep and waited 2 minutes to get in. We used our Roma passes for free entry. The gardens on top of Palantine Hill are amazing. I could actually picture Romans using different parts of it . The place is just so huge that it never really felt overly busy. Some of the ruins are just so vast that you don’t really appreciate them until you are directly underneath. There’s a bit walking involved but my mum (62 years old) managed fine. If you want some pictures head up to the top to get some great views.

Love it!!. This was a great experience. Quite a lot to see in this area. It's good if you take another gate to get in rather than one in front of Colosseum. It would advisable to get guide fro this tour which i did not do. It would be more informative i am sure.
Great Roman Architecture. If you a historical lover you will really like everything in Rome, Italy. You can visualize the architecture of time the great roman empire runs.

You have to see this if in Rome. A magnificent attraction which is a must and very affordable. A glimpse into ancient history looking at remains over a vast area and picking out buildings across several periods of Rome's ancient history. The soaring colums are a vivid memory.

My favorite tourist attraction in Rome. December is a great time to visit Rome, especially for an attraction like the Roman Forum. The Forum was my favorite tourist attraction in Rome! It felt like I was part of an archeological excavation. The ruins are below the ground because of the thousands of years of sediment build-up. I went in December and did not have to wait in line. The weather was still warm! I listened to the Rick Steve's audio guide and it made the experience much more interesting. Make sure to treck up the steep hill outside of the Roman Forum and check out the museum and the views.

Walking through history. I cannot believe that the Italians just let you walk amongst such antiquities or is it because they have so much of it that they are so blase about it all. Amazing. Julius Caesar walked on those cobbles. There is so much to look at and it takes ages to walk through it all. You simply can't take it all in. The view from the top of the site is the best view that gives you the perspective. If you like your history, then do not miss this place. Your ticket for the Colosseum booked online allows you to skip the queues and is only £20.60 for 2 people. Be prepared for people everywhere

THE BEGINNING OF THE LATIN CIVILIZATION. I think that the title says everything.If you visit Roma for it´s culture and History, (and not for busy touristic "fakes", you should not miss this place and the Colosseo, as well.

Forum Rome. Amazing and breath taking, these ancient ruins. The Romans had foresight and it is a must to visited the Forum to see and absorb history. I think this is better than Athens. Tip, take a water bottle, it can be refilled and one of the 5 water taps that run constantly. Further download the free App "Roma waliking tour" which will give you narrative about four of the sites. Once downloaded, this App can be used without going on-line.

Must see... But Rome is missing a trick!. You must see the Roman Forum. It gives you an amazing insight to what it was like living in Ancient Rome. Get there early!!! I can't stress that point enough! We got there for 9.30 and walked straight in with our Colosseum ticket we purchased the day before. On the way out the queue to get in was about 100 deep and 200 deep just to buy tickets! The only downside to the Roman Forum is the lack of information on the exhibits. It's confusing and you have no idea what you're looking at. I would recommend buying a book to guide you round, or invest in a tour guide. Especially if you're interested in learning more about Ancient Rome. C'mon Rome! Invest in your wonderful history and provide us tourists with some information! Take some water with you. There is nowhere to buy refreshments and it's open so can get quite hot when the sun comes up!

Unreal. Got a ticket to the Roman Forum, Palatino and Colosseum for 12 euro. It's cheap considering you are able to visit three different sites!! The trick to avoid long queue is to get the ticket from the Palatino ticket office. Do no queue at the colosseum!! The line is massive!!! Ticket will last you 24 hours once you've validated it the first time. I enjoyed the Roman Forum. It's pretty unreal how people in the past were able to building something like this without the technology we have today. Do not miss this!
Must see. Did a tour of this which included the colosseum and palantine hill, so was knackered by the end, but worth it. The history of the place, and the sights are not to be missed.

the Romans really knew how to do it. these ruins are great and awe inspiring. we booked tickets from home on the internet for $14 for the 3, the forum, colosseum and the palantine hill. ticket was great and it was for 2 days and you could argue that you may have needed the 2 days if you were in Rome for long enough. ticket was also skip the queue which it did, but you still have to go through security checks, (which move quickly) so once you have done these checks you then skip the big queues for the box/ticket office. tip. when you book online from home also printout the barcode voucher and not just your general/ money receipt. so back to the Forum which were awe inspiring and my favourite was the Temple of Vesta with all the virgins in a line, which you can see clearly from 2 or 3 places, particularly when you move up the steps to the next level of the Forum. For buildings/ruins that are thousands of years old it is an absolute world renowned site and great to have experienced.

Holiday. This is up there with the colosseum. It is a fantastic place to visit and the history of the place is amazing. To see what the romans had more than 2000 years ago wow. Bedt done straight after the colosseum but is definately a must see place

Great ruins. 12 euros for coliseum, Palatine hill and the forum. Great set of ruins, for those who appreciate what's here, other people had no restraint or knowledge of what they were looking at, I found that irritating. These places had life and much death and as such respect should be shown. As far as ruins go....these are some of the best I've seen. A must see for interested parties pleasant views and great to imagine life 2000 years ago.
Forum. We can all agree that Rome has a lot of history - today was different - booked a tour and was in awe of the remains ruins and of course the history - must see when visiting Rome

History that comes alive BUT watch out for the Gladiators.. The size of these ruins and the intimacy of the place is a testament to the Roman civilization.I spent my last FULL DAY in Rome simply walking through History after realizing that the Forum and The colosseum could , and probably , SHOULD take me a good deal more time to savour However this will have to wait for a future visit. Please be aware of even the most "FRIENDLY" of the many "GLADIATORS" as before I knew it I was having my camera used to TAKE PICTURES OF ME with the friendly Gladiatore friend,all for only 50 euros!! Also watch out for parakeet men,the same scam but with parakeets this time-How frustrating,and then come the ubiquitous "Selfie Salesmen.
Very Nice. This is in the category of one of the must sees. A good morning / day is needed to see and take everything in. It it wonderful to see so many buildings still standing despite their age.

Everything you expect. I was expecting to be disappointed, however I was not. It is hard to capture the scale of the Colosseum and grandeur until you actually visit it. It is included in the 12 Euro which included the Roman Forum. Great value for money. Don't bother paying to skip the lines, get your ticket at the Roman Forum and the go see the Colosseum after.

Another shambolic entrance. Buy tickets to beat the queues and join the queue !! The visit is marred by the inefficiency of the Management of this place. TOP tip -- take a guide, there are no clear postings of what the various ruins were and after a few minutes in the crowd and under the sun you lose the will to stretch the imagination.

One of our favorites in Rome. There is so much to see here and were so glad that we were on a tour, since there isn't a whole lot to read to find out what the ruins are from. (Our tour included Palatine Hill and the Colosseum and this was our favorite of the 3, although all of them are excellent.) We could have spent the entire day here, instead of a couple hours.

The most spectacular place I have visited . My wife and I bought tickets that covered Palatine Hill, the Roman Forum, and The Colosseum for €12 each, and this proved to be great value. The scale is hard to describe, but being here really is like being transported back in time, and it really is an amazing experience. We spent the day exploring Palatine Hill and the Forum, but did not have time for the Colosseum, so will come back to that. One thing to bear in mind though, take drinks and snacks as there are none available. There are however places where you can refill water bottles.
Free and interesting. These ruins are exactly that. Great for photographers The ruins include fallen columns and ancient walls that are crumbling.

Good and huge area to visit. This area is best to beat the huge queues for tickets which exist in colosseum. If you are without a guide you would be disappointed as they have not mentioned a clear path to visit the huge area, and by mistake we took a wrong turn and were in front of the exit. Dont forget to bring your hats, sunglasses and sunscreen.
Great!. Imposing, magnificent building! One of the must-see sights in Rome. It is also very close to other monuments, so it will be easy to visit it too. Definitely recommended!

A taste of how the Romans live. We were lucky enough to be staying opposite these ruins. From the street it doesn't look much, but once you're inside your opinion changes. We visited late in the afternoon - it wasn't so busy and there were some shaded spots otherwise you're in full sun. You get a real taste of how the Romans lived, the Temple of Romulus is a must see. Our ticket was 14€ for the Forum, Palatine Hill and Colusseum so great value for money. We didn't use any sort of guide around the Forum as there are plenty of information boards around. It is hilly and paths are cobbled and uneven so may be a struggle for the less able or wheelchair uses. There is a lift to get you down to the lowest level, but it is hidden away on Via Fori Imperali. Well worth the visit

A great experience. The Forum was one of my favorite places in Rome -- it gives a real sense of Ancient Rome. For some reason it must not be on the list of places tours visit, because it was much less crowded and there were no lines. If I had to choose between this and the Colliseum, I would visit the Forum.
Wont believe your eyes. What an amazing place. Gave me shivers. The ticket is included once you buy the ticket for the Colosseum. Must see place in Rome

History Comes Alive. Even though we were exhausted, we enjoyed walking through The Roman Forum. We used an audio guide we downloaded on our smart phones. It was just so amazing to be walking in the same place where the ancient roman's walked.

Actually, I was a little disappointed! (Palentine Hill better!). I really thought that this most famous archaeological site would be the highlight of my trip. But I didn't really like it! It was hotter than hell in there (no wind, no shade), and, perhaps even worse than the conditions, was the signage... it barely existed (or I didn't find it! Could be!). And if it did, it didn't say much. There was no drawing of what the structure would have looked like intact, just a short blurb on what that partial wall was, etc. And some of the better-preserved sites were also rather vague - they're not totally sure who this temple was for, and they think that might have been this, or was it this? And there's this interesting bit here, but you can't really access it (so why tell me?! Urgh!).I'm sure ancient Roman archaeology is hard to distil for your average hoard of lay-tourists. But in a site as famous and well-visited as this, I really did expect a lot more effort than was apparently put in by the overseeing authorities!Also - crawling with tour groups that'll just run you over. I found this hard to endure, heat and lack of specific information in addition.And the girl at the gate was abominably rude. :) Not my favourite spot!Palentine Hill, however, just above the gulley that is the Forum, was one of my favourites.
