It was far less crowded, and there was quite a lot 'still standing' left to see, as well as some breathtaking views over the Forum (and a breeze! Nice!). The palatial complex was really impressive, even in ruins. Don't miss that!

Spectacular. I was blown away by the many intact structures to see from thousands of years ago. The Forum in Rome is a must visit. Approach from the Colosseum for a great view at the top. Kids and adults loved this site.

You cannot leave Rome without visiting this place!. I am not an expert on Arts or History but every time I visit a site like this, I wish I could know and learn more. It is well preserved and you could easily spend two hours just taking pictures! This place is also ideal for families with kids, because they can have a walk around the small grass fields and imagining how the place used to look like! Just make sure you carry a bottle of water with you (and apply sunblock). Facilities are good as well. I recommend online booking because there may be queues especially on high season. There is a combined ticket Colosseum+Roman Fora that can be used within 48 hours. The ticket I booked online had no specific date/time for entry, so I was able to scan it myself directly at the gate! Have fun!!

Ruins. We visited the roman forum after having been to the Colloseum and the Palatino. The ticket is a combined ticket which includes the Colloseum, Palatino and the Roman Forum that can be used on 2 days. The Roman Forum is crowded but not like the other places to visit so any time of the day is fine to visit.

Spend some time at the Forum and drift back in time a couple of millenium.. This sprawling place takes some time to walk. Tour guide or book needed. There's lots of stories here. I liked the Vestal Virgins.
Beyond beauty. When I saw it I got shivers all over my body... This is what I always saw on the pictures at school's lessons. It explodes your imagination. It became my favorite spot in Rome.

When in Rome...A Must See!. Simply put if you don't see the Forum Romani and the Coleseum, you've wasted a trip to Rome. Seeing the scale of the buildings and ruins in the Forum, instantly gives one a true sense of the grandeur and power of Ancient Rome. These were buildings that would fit into any modern city. In fact, the architecture has been copied and appears in every major capital in the world today - a testament to Rome's legacy and place in history. Even if you're not generally a fan of ruins, these are a must see.

Amazing when you use your imagination. If you try to take a step back and picture this place as it would have once stood bustling with Romans and vibrant with beautiful building then it really can take hold of youIts a beautiful area of the city which is untouched and very relaxing a mustbsee when in rome and just 2 mins walk from the Colosseum

Meander amongst the roman ruins with the one you love. I cannot think of a finer way to spend a day with the one you love, and learn and appreciate history as well as the Italian culture. We wandered around for hours soaking up as much roman history as we could, and enjoyed the different scenes immensely.

Allow plenty of time, it's big place. As suggested in my review of the Colosseum, buy your(combined) tickets on-line to miss the queue. The Forum, incorporating Palantine Hill, covers a massive area. Some of the remaining columns are so tall and the arches either end of the Forum are so detailed. This visit also includes the Temple of Romulus . The Ancient Romans didn't build in half-measures!

In my list..!. Tourists can indulge in the history and beauty of Rome and the ruins at the Roman forum are part of the experience. We walked and walked the city absorbed in sooo much..! Well worth a visit. Price is part of a package if you visit the colosseum..!

Ice cream scam. When you buy an ice cream cone from the cart out the front of the forum ASK the price first! We paid 5 euro for a "big" ice cream. What a joke! When I questioned the description of "big" they replied that was big. One scoop of ordinary ice cream is a joke, except the joke was on us. We didn't even want a "big" ice cream

Magnificent!. Walk the paths the Roman Senators walked...where Caesar strolled and where he was eventually murdered. Yes, it's a bit of a rubble, but take moments to look at the path you're walking on, the pillars that were crafted so long ago. And bring a flower to drop at the place Caesar was murdered...although no one can say for certain exactly where that was, I took my best guess and paid him tribute. :) There is a fee but it's included in your Rome pass that you can purchase before you begin your visits...it saves so much time standing in lines for tickets!

Magical. We went to the Roman Forum in April and had a magical experience. You can walk around it in about and hour. I would recommend a tour for this or staying around to absorb the environment afterwards. Great site!!! p.s. the toilet were clean for the men but not so much for the women.

Really wonderful. The Roman Forum was the first part of my Colosseum tour. I think we spent about an hour and 1/2 here and I could have spent a couple of more days. It was fascinating, and gorgeous, and it didn't feel rushed or crowded. Highly recommend!
Amazing and relaxing. Visited the Forum alongside Palatine Hill - found both very relaxing and interesting to walk around. Would definitely go again near the end of a holiday to relax.
Amazing. really interesting! We went here on a VIP tour so I'm not sure what the entrance fee is but its worth it. So much to see and so many interesting facts

Wow - amazing history everywhere you look.. Its an amazing place, have been before and will always try to come here if I am in Rome. My son loved the place, and especially all the lizards zooming about over the ruins. Just a very beautiful and powerful place. Recommend reading a little about it before you go and making sure your camera has a full battery and lot of memory ;-) Then just allow lots of time to just stroll and enjoy. We spent a whole day walking through the Palatine Hill, Forum and Colosseum. Awesome!

Strenuous. Be prepared to walk a lot. You need to have a comfortable pair of shoes that will take you through the hills and midst all the ruins. The hill offers great view but the one thing that bothered me about the visit was the fact that there was no helpful information around and one has to take the aid of a tour guide or the audio guide to get through the place and understand the things that one is seeing.

Amazing place to be - travel through time!. This is by far the best historic site in Rome. While the other places offer glimpses into the past, this place is like BEING in the past. Make sure you have an audio tour in your phone when you walk through here, preferably Rick Steeve's and it will be the best time you have in Rome, especially if history fascinates you!! Take out enough time and don't rush - you will need a whole day. Though you can club the colosseum with it! Also, buy the Roma Pass and you can enter the Colosseum and the Forum as ONE destination. The second free one you use on the Pass could be the borghese gallery. These 2 are the most expensive.

Fabulous. As many have already stated, a visit to the Forum is a must. We used our Roma Pass to enter and avoid line ups. It's amazing to walk through the ruins where kings, emperors and noblemen once walked. You'll see temples built to Faustina and Antonius, the cremation spot of Julius Caesar, the home and baths of the vestal virgins whose job it was to keep the flames burning..... a 30 year servitude! Further up Palatine Hill, you will find the ruins of the Imperial Palace and the museum. The purpose of building the palace at the top of the hill was to provide the best views and the views of the city are certainly very impressive. There is a lot of walking involved, so wear comfortable shoes. It can be a very tiring day when combined with the Colosseum, but well worth it!

That is the place to see. This place is absolutely amazing. Just imagine what a Roman civilization was able to create 2000 years ago. You can walk it through, touch it and even after several visits we have again found new things there. Simply a must if you are visiting Rome. The ticket office is usually not much crowded and the ticket is valid for the Colosseum as well. This will save you usually more than 2 hrs of queuing by the Colosseum!

Got to be done. Lots of ruins, but worth it. Real history. Go in palatine hill entrance, 2 mins down road and no queues. Audio guide is worth having, would be a bit lost without it re making sense of things.

A must see in Rome!. This came as part of a package with a tour of the colosseum. A guide is a must as the knowledge they give you really enhances your visit. Without a guide you would not get a full taste of the grounds you are walking on. If you have the time to visit the forum, book in advance and make sure you get a guide, it's worth paying extra!

Fabulous view from Palantine Hill!. We had a 3 day Omnia Vatican and Rome pass and this counted as one visit along with the Colosseum. We didn't spend a great deal of time here but the highlight was definitely the view from the top of Palantine Hill. While walking around lower down we noticed people quite high up and decided to see if we could find our way up. This was done easily by paths and steps. The view across the Forum and Rome was fabulous, well worth the climb! Also on top are lots more ruins of ancient palaces.

HUGE!. I had bought the combined ticket of Colloseum, Roman Forum and Palatine museum. I was amazed of how big the Forum is! I spent 3 hours there and haven't covered everything! It is amazing! Make sure you have a bottle of water to refill, a hat and sunscreen lotion!!!

Needed to spend much more time here!. Amazing! Everything you learned of Roman history happened right here! We only had a couple of hours but would have loved to have a couple of days! My top tip would be to see it as a part of a tour as they will be able to give you details about the place that really make it come alive. Oh and wear really comfy walking shoes!
A must!. This is a must see if you're visiting Rome. But make sure you get a guide so you can fully appreciate the history of this place! Absolutely fascinating, could have stayed all day.

By far the most interesting area in Rome.. The Palatino. The first Roman Palace built. 400 Bc the first Palace stood on this site. Due to fire it was rebuilt in 283 by The Emperor Diocletian. 400Ad it began to fall into decay, and today it is in verious state of decay. The main building is still standing and needs restoration in my opinion. There were lots we missed as we did not know they were there. Next to the Palatino is the first and second road ever built. 400bc. They have shells of shops up and down the road. The forth arch ever built which is the oldest arch to still exist. The second road ever built goes through it. We took a tour around this area which I thought was value for money. Lots a facts which are not in any of the books I have. Please enjoy.

Spend Some Time Here. There is so much to see here. I strongly recommend taking a guided tour, otherwise it mostly looks like a lot of broken down buildings and rocks. But it really is interesting if you can get a good explanation of what you are seeing. Don't miss this, but make sure you know what you are seeing. Note that the walking surface here is a bit rough.

*Exaggerated European shrug*.. At the risk of sounding overwhelmingly like a '90's child, I'd give the Roman Forum five stars for its historical significance, and 2.5 stars for how little you realize you actually care when you get there.Look. Don't get me wrong. Ancient Rome is so my thing. I can't get enough Ancient Rome. Ancient Rome gets me in the feels every time. But if you want bloody, magnificent Ancient Rome, go to the catacombs under the Vatican City. Go to the Colosseum. The Forum is a really lovely walk, and I get it - I do! - but when you're actually standing within it...it's only okay.It's not bad. Hell no am I going to be the bespectacled thespian who tweets "went to the forum. ancient rome is so 2768 years ago". The forum is a pretty sweet walk if you're a history buff. Even if you're not, it's a pretty little thing: red dirt and wind whistling between columns. You can truly get a feel of Rome and what it meant to the world, and what it thought of itself (clue: highly). But don't make a day of it. You'll notice the scaffolding clinging to buildings nearby and don't think your pretty little eyes will be blind to the white tarps, portaloos, and workmen wandering around across the way. I haven't the faintest idea what they were building, but it was definitely not something ancient and probably not anything iconically Roman. Maybe it was a Starbucks.But you can make some nice memories here, if you accept that it is what it is: rocks and dirt. When we were there, I was wearing a white Kings of Leon shirt and out of nowhere, there came a shower of warm summer rain. We were screaming with laughter and hiding under each other's coats and my white shirt was splashed with red mud. When I got home, that red mud wouldn't wash out of my shirt. It was stained bad, but no matter. I made great friends under those jackets.

Glimpse of history. To walk where the romans walked and see how/where they lived is humbling to say the least. Life then was not much different to life now and seeing in real life as well as being able to touch brings history to life. Fab

Best to get some kind of guide to what you're looking at. Otherwise, you will cheat yourself.. There are so many ruins in this city that it's difficult without some prior research to really grasp what you are looking at. Yes, there are the plaques that explain this and that. But, if you do it like we did, wandering with no guide or plan, you miss the significance of what is here. There is so much to see here, don't cheat yourself with your limited time by not being prepared. And, watch out for those damn fake gladiators who will do everything to separate you from your euros.
Highly recommended. The ancient ruins of the Forum are a must see for anyone visiting Rome. We were lucky enough to have a very knowledgable tour guide so we really got the most from our tour.
A place to explore with time.. After a small disappointment with the Coliseum, the forum was a nice surprise. It is hard to walk but is in a nice area and we can do a kind of "time travel".

Entry included with Colloseum ticket... Well worth the visit. Download an audio guide before you go or book a tour so that you get all of the history of this incredible site. Was very very interesting and I'm really glad we visited. I'd suggest about 1.5 hours to see it all. It's near the Colloseum so visit them both together.
top spot. One of the best things to see in Rome. Really beautiful. Combine with the Colosseum if possible. If you go there early there are not as many people there.

Awesome!. The dislike was that this will bore the kids pretty quickly. It is an amazing display of ancient Rome and how things were. I could have spent a whole day here. We popped on over after the Colosseum so it was a nice flow for the day. They have a lot of really interesting things and we managed to get a book before hand so we could tell the boys about what they are seeing. I loved this. It was my favorite place that we visited in Rome.

A must see for the History enthusiast.. We purchased a ticket over 2 days to do the set of Colosseum, Palantine Hill and Forum. As it was December the queues were not bad at all, this is not the case other times of the year. We didn't use a guide (we are into this stuff) but I would recommend one if you are not enthusiasts. You are walking in the footsteps of such amazing history and it was a great experience for all the family. I read this in another post and cannot agree more... always use the toilets and come with a big water bottle as there is lots of walking. If you are just keen to view the Forum this can be done from a vantage point outside the complex, but if you have the time go in.
Must visit in Rome. What a fabulous place this. NOt much else to say as it will be awesome and is a must do. I would say if possible get a guide or a very good book .

History, even in the rain. As far as my wife and I are concerned, Rome is just not Rome without a visit to the Roman Forum. We’ve been to the Roman Forum many times over the last 12 years, have read about it endlessly, and always enjoy exploring it – just wandering around through the ruins and imagining how it must have been when ancient Romans roamed the streets. Our last visit, however, gave us a new perspective. It started out as a beautiful, sunny day, but in the middle of our visit, a storm rolled in and it started raining lightly. The sky became very dark as the storm worsened, and it produced violent thunder and lightning. The rain turned torrential. The crowds of visitors scattered and then vanished, and the Via Sacra became a river several inches deep. It would have been wonderful to wander around in an empty Forum, but it was raining much too hard for that. We couldn’t help but reflect on the difficulties that must have been encountered by the ancient Romans in storms such as that. A couple of hours later, the storm passed, the sun reappeared, and all was well in Rome. We look forward another visit to the Roman Forum the next time we’re in Rome.
Breadhtaking. the view in this place is just amazing, walking through the rubble remenincing the old roman marching through the gate and julio cezar ruling over the army. a must go when in rome

Roman Forum, stepping through history. There is so much to draw one to Italy, especially Rome and its history as a once empire. The Roman Forum ranks right up there with the Collesium and the Pantheon. For those interested in the history of Rome, the Forum is captivating. This was there public place where shopping and business was done, speeches were made, and temples built. There is also a promontory from which they threw those who were convicted of political crimes. As you walk through the columns, and what remains of once grand temples of the Forum history rushes at you. If you want to prepare well, read The Rise of Rome, by Anthony Everitt, acompelling non fiction account of the rise and glory of what was once the power and center of civilization. And the Forum was the center of their society, life, and home of the powerful. It is also just across the street from the Collesium, and close to the Circus Maximus, and a walk to the Pantheon. Together, It's a compelling draw to make the trip to Rome.
Must see!. We loved being in this incredible place where so much history happened. It was a great learning opportunity for my kids as well. Do not miss this.

Must see. I would recommend having a guide or reading up beforehand on the Roman Forum and how it was used in its prime. The buildings are now mostly ruins, so you must use your imagination (or your tour guides book!) to imagine how it would have looked back in its prime.

So Amazing. You can walk through the forum and see Caesar's burial memorial and ruins. It is really cool if you can find a picture of what it used to look like to compare it with what it looks like now. Lots of rocks, so be careful.

Thrilling!. To walk on the same pathway as Caesar? The atmosphere of history permeates every nook and cranny. We purchased the book that allows you to see what the buildings looked like "back in the day" and found that helpful for really visualizing the grandeur that was the Roman Forum and Colloseum. There is perhaps nothing as thrilling as standing in a place where history happened - and this is one of the "bucket list" places. Our 16-year-old granddaughter enjoyed it as much as we did. April is the perfect time to go. High 60s during the day, low 50s at night.
Experience a taste of ancient Rome. This site is amazing, showing ruins dating back several hundred years. Situated near the Colosseum. Best to get a guided tour as there is much to learn and see

Take your imagination!. So little is left standing and it must have been one hell of a place when it was in its glory days and full or roman people. If you can take a guide or a boor or an audioguide around so you can get an explanation of all the rocks and pillars lying around and standing up seemingly randomly.And just imagine what it would have been like...!

Tour of Roman Forum.. Excellent day out whilst in Rome recently. We qued for quite a while so get tickets on line before hand if possible. Beware touts selling entrance to skip the line for ridiculous prices who approach you whilst you are in the que. The ticket includes the Forum, Palentine Hill and the Colosseum which you can use over 2 consecutive days. We had an English tour, which was a little bit extra (€9 each if I recall correctly) but we'll worth it as it brings the Forum and it's history to life. We had a tour guide called Antonio who wad excellent. He is an archaeologist and obviously enjoys his work as he was so pleasant and enthusiastic. He had pictures of the presented ruins you see today and what things would have looked like and had so much knowledge that he made the visit both educational and interesting. Highly recommended.

A getway to Life in Ancient Rome. Took a VIP guided tour. The guide was very good. We were given a brief history of Ancient Rome. She brought a file of pictures to illustrate how the ruins looked like before. A must for visitors to see Ancient Rome of the Pagans.

Be prepared to walk a lot. Its an excellent place, and audio guide is definitely recommended, Its better to buy tickets online. The tickets come as a group to colloseum, palantine hill and roman forum. So, once you have the ticket its better to visit the palantine hill first and then walk downhill towards roman forum as palantine hill entrance is less crowded.
get the audio player!. I got the audio player and my husband didn't, so I was the fount of information for him, which was kind of a fun way to do this! incredible history here.

part of coliseum tour and just as worth it. This has alot of history and we got a guided tour as part of the coliseum tour too which was really good. she had reconstruction pictures with her too and id advise buying one of these books to bring home(i found in a local gift store) was really pretty area right in the middle of the bustling city.
worth a visit-lots to see. take your time to explore this huge complex. buy the combo ticket,you walk where the Roman senators walked
Awesome!!!. Lots of seeing and walking. Use toilet when you see one and fill up your waterbottle then you'll be ready to walk all day :)
Best thing in Rome. Avoid all the other so called attractions and see this after the Pantheon & Vatican, there's really not much else to see in Rome until the Trevi fountains open in 2016

More History. We had a Tour of the colosseum, then went to Palantine Hill and finished off in the Roman Forum, and we would suggest that is how to see these sites, we only spent 40 mins in here and saw all there was. The one ticket covers all 3 sites, HOWEVER, The Roman Forum and Palantine Hill are the one site, so your ticket will not allow you to leave one gate and come in another, there are no gates between the two areas, just one road/path. When we got the tickets it tells you online about this, our tour guide also pointed this out, so no excuses for messing it up.The site has so many things, get a book, and enjoy. For all 3 sites we got tickets at 8.30 and left at 1pm, we could have spent another 90 mins in Palatine Hill, but we had plans for other sites, oh and Lunch
Must See!. Wow! Just to imagine they were here thousands of years ago and to currently walk on the same soil and roads presently there. Wish to go back in time just to see. A must see when visiting.

Rome Was Not Built in a Day, Don't Try to See it in One Day!. The Roman Forum is really layer upon layer of history right before your eyes and right beneath your feet. There are few places on earth where you can walk among such spectacular ruins and feel the centuries so profoundly. Recommend ample time to really appreciate it.

Another must-see when in Rome!. Stroll the street of the Forum and you will get a sense of history that took place here. There are temples, statutory pieces, ancient market places which are awesome. Nearby is the Arch of Constantine, built in 312 A. D. Within walking distance of the Colosseum. Gladiators walk the streets and, for a fee, you can have your picture made with them!

Amazing History!. I was very glad we got to see this site! The idea that these places were buried for so many years, and so much is still intact is insane! The detail on these buildings, knowing that they were made nearly 2,000 years ago is breathtaking! We did a guided tour and loved being able to find out more information about what took place there so many years ago! It is a must see!

Roman Forum. It's amazing how many of these things are still standing after all these years. This was included in our tour from Viator.com, so we were able to skip all the lines and go right in. Very good to have a tour guide to explain what all these buildings were. It is definitely a hodgepodge of buildings/ruins, but so much history in such a small place! We really enjoyed it. A must see!

IN ROME, FEEL LIKE A ROMAN. I think that this is the place where you can really feel how the Romans used to live. It is a place very beautiful to see the ruins and a great view of the city in the Palatine Hill. I only miss a good map to have an idea of the whole complex and there were very few signs telling about what you are seeing. If I had to choose just a place to go in Rome, for sure it would be the Forum, not the Coliseum.

Amazing civilization in the past and just unbelievable.. Roman Forum and Palantine Hills. Amazing civilization in the past and just unbelievable. This place just reminds you of how real the Ancient Rome were and how advanced their technology actually were. By looking at these buildings from some almost more than 2,000 years old, I actually think they are much better built than today's buildings. Yes it doesn't have the today's technology but that doesn't matter. They were far more superior and the way they built it just made these buildings last forever. Much respect for the Ancient Romans. Just jaw dropping and amazing experience.

Interesting but disorganized. As other reviewers have said, this is an interesting place to go but very disorganized. There's a line to get tickets and then another line to get through security and it isn't easy to understand what is what. There was a long line for tickets even in March and they only had 2 of the 4 ticket windows open. If you book a tour, you get to bypass the ticket lines but we did that at the Vatican and were unimpressed with how fast the tours push you through so we didn't want to do that again here. Once you get through the lines then all is well. It was about a 20-30 minute wait for us to get tickets and then another 15 minutes to get through security.That being said, it is hard to tell what you're looking at and most of the ruins aren't labeled so a tour may make more sense here. It's pretty big and takes a while to walk through so bring water and remember where the bathrooms are (they are hard to find once you're inside).One thing to note is that the line for the forum was MUCH shorter than the line for tickets to the coloseum but you can buy tickets for both the coloseum and forum at the forum. It's a much better idea if you want to see both as then you only need to wait in the security line at the coloseum (not the ticket line too) if you want to do both.

Most humbling experience. Alirght, imagine how cool it sounds to go to the ruins of a place which was built more than 2200(!!!!!!!) years ago!! Right, it is rellay hard to imagine that. But it is even crazier to actually stand in the forum and look at the remains of the Jupiter temple or the rebuilt Senate building. You can acutally look at the place where Julio Ceasar was killed! It is more than impressive how well the forum has been digged up and preserved. I spent about 2 hours just wandering through the ruins imagining how it must have been the center of ancient Roman life! Just amazing!!

Must see. Bring a picknick!. You cannot visit Rome without visiting the Roman Forum and the Colloseum. You could argue that without seeing these sights (or without eating pizza) you have not really visited Rome.On many fronts Rome is a rip-off place for tourirsts, but this is actually great value compared to other sights around the world. A 12 Euro ticket will get you entry to the Roman Forum and the Colloseum. Just make sure to take out plenty of time and bring a picknick to enjoy on a nice day on the grass somewhere up Paletine Hill.You can easily spend a few hours in awe on the Roman Forum, before walking over to the Colloseum where you get a speedy entrance with your ticket (the queues at the Roman Forum are usually smaller than at the Colloseum, so go to the Forum first!).At the Colloseum just try to imagine the horrors and brutality which went on there, and, unfortunately, try to imagine away the 21st Century additions, such as the Easter parade stage and the year 2000 Cross that has been erected. What a shame the pope seemingly was not content with having just Vatican city and needed to extend to this site of heritage with a meaningless relic.

Amazing ruins, poor organization. The Roman Forum is amazing, but the visitor services and information are very, very poor.I recommend bringing and audioguide on your smartphone: AudioViator (Spanish) or Rick Steve (English) are often mentioned.The different ruins are poorly signaled and it is almost impossible to imagine what they used to look like. The large "you are here" maps are a little more useful.If you can bring your own map of the forum it will help. You can also find books that let you see what each building used to look like and what it looks like today. Make sure you bring the map and or books with you or you will not be able to get a lot out of your visit.Important: NO BACKPACKS OR BIG BAGS ALLOWED AND NO LOCKERS / CLOAK ROOM AVAILABLE. Leave your backpack at the hotel or you will not be allowed to enter the forum :-(
history..... If history is your thing,then plenty is here. Though you often wish thieves,churches, vandals and barbarians had left us more to look at.. Take plenty of water.

What a History. After or before coliseum you can easyly access to this Ancient Rome city where you can use your ticket for both. What a history they have in Rome. Terrific venue. The view is perfect from the Palatine Hill. With a toddler it was a bit difficult to push the buggy on those cobbled stoned floors but it is definitely a must see. Simply amazing.

Worth going on guided tour. As our Colosseum ticket allowed access to the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill, we took the opportunity to wander through the ancient ruins. The ruins are very extensive and cover multiple time periods and it would have been worthwhile taking a tour to more fully understand the history that occurred here. Whilst a lot of the forum can be seen from the street, you don't appreciate the size of the columns still standing on the site.

Awe inspiring. What can you say? This is Roman history come alive when you walk through here. Take a good guidebook and take your time. You'll learn how and why it was first built and how subsequent Ceasars expanded and grew it to commemorate themselves and their power. It's just amazing and unbelievable. If you aren't absolutely in awe when here, you must not have much appreciation for history.

WONDERFUL WAY TO SPEND A MORNING. Terrific venue for spending a morning. Walk up Palatine Hill and soak it it. Don't miss the museum. Costs 14 euros to get in but that also allows you entrance to the Colosseum and you do not need to join the huge queues to buy tickets.

Ancient Rome. If you get a ticket for the Colosseum, the Roman Forum is included and is just a short walk from the colosseum and from the metro station.The Roman forum is a really good insight into ancient Rome and some of the ruins are stunning. You can get a really good view of the site from the terraces, where the orchards are.You need good weather for visiting, as it is all outside, and often involves a queue to get in. There appears to be no audio guides or maps (maybe I missed those) so it is probably a good idea to pay out for a guide, as there is no information as you go around.Take your time to observe and take in the significance of this place. It is worth a visit, but I recommend reading up before you go.
Great. We used the Rick Steve's guide which I downloaded for free to my iPhone and it was great. Didn't talk about everything in the Forum but gave a good overview.

Truley Amazing. The Roman Forum was the centre of life in Imperial Rome, evidenced by the many remains of triumphal arches, temples and basilicas.Today, the forum known as the Forum Romanum can look like a disorderly collection of ruins to the uninitiated, but with some imagination you can see the Roman Empire come back to life at this site. Remains of many buildings from different periods are visible; the forum was littered with temples, basilicas and triumphal arches.

MUST SEE!. I would like to return and spend a week just in this one location to take pictures and learn more about the history, design, and construction. If you go to Rome, probably many of you will visit the Vatican and the Colosseum, but you also should visit here. It's staggering the scale of the ruins here. You'd never think the ancient Romans could have built so high nor so ornate. Get a tour guide which was my mistake to not do so.

Great History. We had a tour guide for the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and this the Roman Forum. I would highly suggest a guide as you would have no idea what the Roman Forum ruins were if not. We preordered our guide tickets and our guide was amazingly informative. Wear comfortable shoes as there is a lot of uneven walking, hills and steps. We loved learning about this Roman history over 2000 years ago and knowing we walked basically as they did so long ago.
Better than I thought it would be.. Found this attraction more interesting than I expected. Would recommend tour guide to get information.

Get a Tour Guide. Our tour guide kinda rushed this, but the history here is amazing. Few structures still stand, but you can picture what this may have looked like in ancient Rome. Caesar is buried here, and you actually walk down some of the very first streets in the city. Amazing.

Amazing. What a life the Romans led! The ruins paint a picture of what life was like 2000 years ago and how sophisticated it was too. Amazing place to visit. Make sure you get a Roma pass online before you visit, and go to the colosseum then Palantine hill, forum / capitoline hill as it works a lot better that way and can be done in a day providing you have pre purchased tickets.

Great history. A guided tour is a must with little information around. Really beautiful ruins to see. Included in the palatine hill ticket price and see where ceasar was brought to be cremated. Only its altar remains adorned with flowers. Ques can be long for tickets so pre book

A must.... Make sure you take time to visit the Roman Forum, on your way to the colosseum or on your way back. There is a small entrance fee, but the line up is usually very quick. You can purchase Roman Forum tickets and Colosseum tickets at the Entrance to the Roman Forum. It may save you time on your Colosseum entrance. As for an organized tour, I would skip it unless you want the entire history of every stone explained to you. If you just want to appreciate the old architecture and snap some photos, in the dead heat of the day, skip the tour options, and purchase tickets, and guide yourself. most guide books will explain everything you're going to see in here.
Not super exciting. We went on a guided tour and it was somewhat interesting, but not very. We did enjoy seeing the Arch of Titus up close.

Wondrous Forum. On our way to the Forum (!) we were approached by a tour guide operator and decided to take up their offer of having an expert show us around the Forum and Colosseum. While this was interesting and helpful the downside was we didn't have long to explore the Forum site and museums, which was rather the point of the day! They concentrated more on the Colosseum and surrounding the Forum at street level. In retrospect we would have much preferred to wander around at our own pace with a good guidebook as it truly is a wondrous place. We have to return soon with plenty of food and drink and comfy walking shoes!

Get your Colisseum tickets here!. dont queue at the Colisseum for tickets. Get them at Pallatine Hill on your way to the Roman Forum. It's amazing to wander the ruins of the palace and the forum. So much history.

Amazing Ancient Rome. If you come to Rome it is one of the most important places which you should visit.In the middle of ruins you can find museum,where you can see how Ancient Rome looked like few thousands years ago.
Disappointed. Everything is fenced off. I was really wanting to go inside the old Senate, but it was not open. I was wanting to go inside the House of Augusta, but it was closed too.

Bring your own map!. After seeing the Colosseum, the Roman Forum provided a link to the Capitolino area. Enter at the east side (Colosseum side) and once finished, exit at the west side where the Arch of Titus is.We used our ROMA Pass cards and we were allowed in without queuing. Unfortunately, we didn’t have a map and this should have been provided at the gate. I’d noticed that a map was provided if tickets were bought from the booth. Instead we had to use the fixed maps provided along the paths.We tried to visit as much as possible by working our way west towards the Capitolino side. The Palatine Hill Stadium provided good views. The Palatine Museum contains a good collection of the findings from the Roman Forum archaeological site. The Temple of Romulus with its dome ceiling.The Colosseum and the Roman Forum are exposed so either bring rain-gear or plan your visit when the weather is good. Also good footwear is recommended as there’s a lot of uneven surfaces.No food is provided so bring your own stuff.Also, the Colosseum and Roman Forum is a combined ticket and counts as one of the two free main attractions with the ROMA Pass.

Interesting. Interesting but could really have done with more information boards. Probably worth hiring a guide, although I didn't! Definitely wear comfortable shoes. I saw one person trying to walk round in stilettos and she wasn't getting far. It's a huge site with tons to see. There are gardens in the middle, and the site of the first settlement of Rome. And don't miss the museum. I'd allow at least the morning to cover the site, probably a bit more. If you have a roma pass, the Colosseum and Forum are bundled so that if you see both on the same day, they only count as one of your free entries. Fantastic value for money assuming you get the one that is not bundled with the Vatican pass.

So sadly neglected. Fenced off and looking forlorn snd neglected, why not judt bulldoze it over and make a Disney style Roman attraction? When I first visited ghis site some 30 years ago, one could still freely wander and wonder at it. Now? Meh! Roma! Dove vai?

Walking in the footsteps of people who changed history.. With a little imagination and background reading you can immerse yourself in the grandeur of that was ancient Rome. Look not so much at the ruins for what they are but for what they were and what they represent and soon you will feel the shiver I got when I realised that this was the capital of the most powerful nation on earth at one time.

Interesting...but do your homework before visiting!. Very nice to walk around the monuments and ancient buildings!But do your homework before you go there, so you know what you are looking at or book a guide...there is rather little signs of what you are looking at...We went there after our visit at the Colosseum ( the ticket are valid for both Forum Romanu/Palatine Hill and the Colosseum for 2 days, one entrance each ).The time depends on how much interested you are or shall I say how interested your company are :) My husband is not so very keen on old stones as he calls it... But calculate for two, three hours if you go around just looking.It is great for us that have a lot of imagination and can imagine how it looked like 2000 years ago.There was a toilet at the sight, but it was not very clean...Nice to bring a little panini and something to drink at sit and just enjoy the surroundings on top of the Palatine Hill.

Perfect place who loves the Historic places. Very impressive place to visit. You should see here once in your life. An advice you can get Rome pass card for x3 visit historic places without wait queue.
Love it. Have been to Rome a few times and I love walking around here. Everything is so huge. I see different things every time I go. Love it.

Wear proper shoes. This is a great place to visit but there ia a lot of walking on uneven surfaces Wearing good shoes is a must. There are rocks, stairs and gravel. It can be very hot and not much shade. So plan for it. Sunscreen ,water and good shoes and a hat
Best ruins in Rome . Most expansive ruins in Rome I'd say. Plenty to see but it won't take too long as it's just wondering around. Don't forget your camera!

Take the time and go!. Most people aren't even aware of the Forum, which is completely sad. It is such an incredible place and an important part of Italian history. Even if you don't know anything about it, take the time to walk over after seeing the Colosseum and take an hour or two to walk around. It will be totally worth it. Also free on every first Sunday, so get there early!
Superb experience!. If you visit Rome this is one of the things that i would suggest you see. It is where it all began. It is great for history lovers!
Ms. Hard to believe that more cyan 2000 years ago, people walked where I did today. 2 hours there not enough to see everything. Amazing.
Leisurely stroll. Take at least a half day to walk through the very large grounds. We did it without a guide and enjoyed the freedom to explore. Wear comfy shoes and enjoy the most awesome sites!

Amazing!. The Roman Forum was the last part of our Colosseum-Palatine Hill-Roman Forum adventure and it was just as spectacular as the rest. There are some bathrooms that are well indicated which was nice but you can't drink the tap water so bring your own. The ruins were absolutely lovely, but with little signage which was too bad. I did buy an Archaeological Rome book at the Colosseum book store (not a terrible price either) but I probably could have picked a better one that explained what I was looking at. Just take your time if you want to buy a guide book from the bookstore and chose the one with the best pictures and descriptions.

Romans Rule!. Charge up your batteries and get ready to take a million photos of ruins that will blow your mind. When you visit this area you'll truly understand why the Romans ruled for so long. Wear comfortable shoes, and be sure to go to the restroom prior to visiting this area as no facilities are nearby.

Great history!. The forum is beautiful. You get admission to it with your colosseum ticket. We waited on the line for about 15 minutes and got in using our Roma pass. It's very interesting; there are random signs all over the place with information saying what the buildings were. It's a great way to soak up ancient history. Wear comfy shoes as the ground is uneven!

a captivating site for thousands and hidden inadequate toilet facilities. For 12 Euros you get poor and sometimes inaccurate signage and inadequate toilet facilities. Might as well self-catheter to enjoy this amazing historic site. We also got the run-around on the audio guide which had been recommended to us. One gate did not have it and after a long walk to another place were told at 1430 that it was too late in the day. There's no map or brochure. Expect confusion.
GREAT !. All I can say is "go there" - unbelievable to see these ruins after all these years. Along with Colosseum and St Peters basilica this was in my top three favourite places to visit in Rome.

Very interesting - but don't go if it's raining!. I'll start by the bad things: it was raining. I DO NOT recommend to go there if it's raining. We couldn't enjoy our visit there because of the rain.Besides that, it was very interesting, but not every one will enjoy it. A lot of people will look at it as a pile of ruins.There is a lot of history in that place. You need to try and imagine what was going on there ~2000 years ago.You should also get a map or guide to understand what each section is because not all the ruins have explanations, and you can miss important things.Again, because of the rain we couldn't see the whole forum and palatine hill (which are both part of the same site). It's a huge place!
Have to see! . For me, the best thing to see in rome. Read a bit before you go, so you'll have a better understanding of what you can see.

Another Gem!. Quite an amazing site to still have in the middle of a capital city. I knew nothing of the forum prior to visiting, so the vast size and beauty of it came as a nice surprise. I was especially happy to see the location of Caesar's final resting ground, one of my favourite historical people. Strolling through the streets gave a good insight as to what life would have been like back then

Enjoyable, but could bring it to life better. It is a very impressive sight to see - all the ruins from the prior homes from all those years ago. There are signs around showing what you are looking at, but the maps were hard to find to get a sense of a sensible way to look around the ruins. We had bought tickets online to get straight in and somehow that meant we didn't pass the audio tour purchasing place. Only people with maps were those who had taken their guidebook or had an audio tour from their or the coloseum (same map for both places). I'd have enjoyed it more if we had a little map showing what was there and if it were brought to life more with stories about what you were looking at rather than just facts. Great view of the coloseum and where the chariot races used to be held. No water in the taps at the toilets, which seems unhygienic!

Returned and loved it just as much. - I returned to the Roman Forum. I was 17 the first time and spent all day in there with my book on the subject. I returned at 46, this time I compiled a booklet from internet sources with a picture of each building (even if just a rubble of stones is left) and a picture of how it looked like. With some history notes. It was still magic, however more the flock of tourists has increased.- Buy your ticket on the internet, collect your Forum annex Colloseo ticket from the Forum ticket box, and don't forget to book a guide for the Colloseo (worth it).- You are allowed bringing in your snack and drink.- Getting in when the ticket office opens does give you an hour or so that the numbers of visitors is pretty limited.

STEP BACK IN HISTORY AND FEEL LIKE A ROMAN. You will see here ruins and remnants not buildings. But you can't help but feel the glory and size of what this place used to be like. Watching Gladiator or any of the 'Sword and and Sandal Movies' where the Romans held their victory parades show the grandeur of this place. Take a guidebook with you so that you can realise what these ruins used to be. I felt more of a sense of history here than the nearby colloseum.

One of the best attractions for us, Ancient city in a New City. My husband and i went to Rome twice and by far this as well as the Coliseum were the best attraction in Rome. It is quite big and so much to learn from history.

Wander among the ruins. Across the road from the Colosseum is the Roman Forum. There is enough still standing to be able to get an idea of just how grand this forum must have been at its peak, although if you want to “see” the buildings as they were you will need to use your imagination, as many are little more than an odd column, like the Temple of Dioscuri (Temple of Castor and Pollux) or a low row of brick walls. Although some of the exceptions are not entirely from Ancient Rome:• The Arch of Titus is in very good condition and has the much talked and written about scene of the menorah being carried away by Roman soldiers. This carving relates to the sack of the Temple in Jerusalem in 70AD, when militant Jews went toe to toe with the Roman army. Rome won and stripped the temple of its gold and anything valuable. On the other side of the arch is Titus riding in his chariot in a triumphal procession. Check the ceiling out: It’s coffered and has an interesting carving of Titus as an eagle.• Arch of Septimius Severus built in 203AD, recalls the victories of Septimius Severus over the Parthians.• The bulk of the Basilica of Maxentius and Constantine. Although this is a partial ruin, there is enough still standing to show its former size. Also the ceilings have an interesting pattern on them. Built about 312AD.• Temple of Antoninus and Faustina, built in 141AD and later converted into the Church of San Lorenzo in Miranda. It is only open a couple of hours a week (Thursdays I think).• Temple of Venus and Roma thought to be the largest Temple in ancient Rome. Started by Hadrian in 121AD, finished in 141AD. Damaged by an earthquake.• Temple of Romulus which is now inside or under the Church of Santi Cosma and Damian with its fabulous bronze doors, these used to be its entrance. The entrance to the church is now on Via dei Fori Imperiali. Apparently the inside is stunning.• There are a number of very old Churches that date from 6-8th century AD, these are on the edges of the Roman Forum.All in all what is still standing is remarkable considering that the first buildings (the Regia, now just a low wall remains) were erected here in the 7th century BC. The last thing erected in the Forum was the Column of Phocas in 608AD. From the Forum there are views to Palatine Hill and the ruins there.It’s worth considering wearing closed in shoes for comfort.Combined ticket Roman Forum, Palatine Hill and Colosseum.Not much shade, take a hat and water.

The continents and counting, THIS is the most amazing thing I've ever seen. . No exaggeration, this is the most impressive thing I've ever had the pleasure to witness. You can see what the city looked like when people lived there. I'll be back.

Great tour guide. Our English-speaking guide, Christian, from Canada, was both personable and knowledgeable. He brought history to life for our little group of tourists who had been standing in line at the Colosseum.

Learn history as no book could do. We had a group tour with a Rome step on guide, so got so much information about life at this time, politics, how the government worked. Things seemed well kept up, there were bathrooms easy to access. Be prepared for lots of walking and not too even ground

Spectacular. Take your walking shoes for this one! There is much to see and it's all spread out. My son and I had a spectacular visit though by renting one of the audio guides. It let us know what we were looking at and gave us historical background. My pictures are spectacular!

Well worth a visit. just a few meters from the Colosseum, it can easily be visited on the same day and can be covered by the Colosseum ticket. Apart from the three days Roma Pass, you can purchase a single ticket for the Colosseum, Forum and Palatine Hill. We strolled calmly, listened to almost every subchapter recommended by the audio guide and breezed through the Forum in a couple of hours. By the time we stepped back outside the gates, you could have knocked us down with a feather.for more info about our trip to Rome:http://theplanningmonster.gq/Theplanningmonster/English/Entries/2015/3/14_Roma_de_weekend.html

Stunning but a little hard to determine what was there originally. The Forum is the area in Rome that was initially the "heartbeat" of the city. Used for public speeches and where political decisions were made in ancient times. It is arguably not the best preserved area, and it was a little hard to determine what the areas inside the Forum were used for originally. The Forum is included in the price into the Colosseum and I do recommend visiting. We didn't have a guide to let us know what each of the buildings were for but my friends had been there before so that helped. Some people mentioned a guide to explain things, we didn't do that but it could be a beneficial addition to the visit.

Pieces of History Adorn a Pleasant Walk. There is not much to do in the Forum but take in the site of an archaeological treasure trove of history. Bits and pieces of the old Roman Forum linger on around the Colosseum, and serve as a pleasant and beautiful backdrop for an evening walk. While there are plenty of tourists about, they are mostly on their way to the Colosseum, leaving plenty of space open to those more interested in taking their time in the capital.

Live History!. Everything you had always learned during school time will be represented here in some way, be it a famous tale, an iconic character or a relevant political event. Be prepared for the sun, wear loads of sunscreen, carry your own bottle of water and keep drinking it!

TicketItaly Let us Down. We unfortunately bought tickets online from a company called Ticketitaly for the Colleseum and the Forum who failed to keep us informed that we would have to queue just to get in through the doors of the Colloseum due to new rules, which they were aware of! Tickets clearly stated that we should aim to be there 15 minutes before allocated time slot which was entirely wrong as the queues just to get to the ticket office were at least 45 minutes long, meaning we would have missed our time slot. This company let us down badly. My wife had recently suffered a bad knee injury and can’t stand for too long and we bought these tickets in good faith with the understanding that we wouldn’t have to queue. Sadly this was not the case and this lack of vital prior information which should have made clear to us upon purchase meant we had no other option but to return to the hotel without visiting any of the venues that were included on the tickets. Contacting their customer service is a waste of time as all they do is palm you off with excuses. Many other ticket offers out there, avoid Ticketitaly.
amazing. this place is huge and amazing to see ,its definitely worth a walk to ,shame its not better preserved as its so hard to imagine how regal it would of been

Amazing history. Who would have expected such ancient history center of today's Rome. I enjoyed our day here. Only issue is that map route doesn't match the actual route due to renovations in progress. It would be great to have some signs in English as well.

a walk in history. For 12 Euros you get access to the Roman Forum and the Colosseum. It is recommended to buy the ticket at the Forum, where the queue is shorter. Spent a few hours leisurely walking around the Forum, before going to the Colosseum and skipping the long ticket queue.The Roman Forum is a large area, covering many historical sites and buildings (or ruins of buildings). It is full of history. Walking there feels like a walk in history, as you see where Caesar was cremated, the temple of the vestal virgins, and other sites, the imagination rebuilds everything and takes you back in time.

The Best attraction in Rome. My wife and I loved this place. What a fantastic experience to be able to walk around these old buildings. We bought a ticket which allowed entrance to the Coliseum as well. 12 euros each. bargain! However, even though it says that the ticket provides entrance for two days it only provides a one time entrance. If you try and get in a second time you will not be allowed.The queue for the Coliseum is full of people who have already booked their ticket so if you think that by buying the joint ticket you can beat the queues then forget it. When in the queue you will be approached by tour operators with the promise of getting you in without having to queue with the other saps. Take it. We paid a further 18 euros each for the honour and it was worth it.As an aside, tour operators are a bane second only to the asian guys selling selfy sticks every 20 feet. I have never been to a place as bad as Rome for street sellers. These people are unregulated and a plague on this fine city.Anyway. As I said, a lovely place to spend your day.
Don't Miss. The Roman Forum is what remains of the early roman seat of politics and social life. It is where Caesar had his last breath, where people prayed to gods and where vestal virgins roamed.

Go early. Get the audio/ video guide.. I recommend going first thing in the morning. Fewer people and cooler. If you love history and archaeology, as I do, get the video/audio guide. Because there were so few people early in the morning, I took my time. I would listen to each segment of the guide several times and I had an exceptional tour and experience. There's a fountain just at the top of the forum where you can re fill your water bottle and take your time. I stayed about three hours and loved every minute!

A must see. To feel the real Rome, you have to check this place out. I would recommend taking an audio guide or some other kind of map or book with explanations so you can imagine how Rome looked like thousands of years ago. Great opportunity for amazing photos.

F YOU ARE IN ROME YOU UST SEE IT IT'S AWSOME!!!!!. I went to the roman forum in october 2014 and i loved it I did not want to leave I recommend if you go to Rome you get the Roma it will save you a lot of money . I recommend spending at least an hour there but I spent 3 so it depends
good old building to see. it be restored great by worker but you still get a good view of it ,but need to be fit as you need to walk to see it

Must see in Rome. I don't think I can add too much to the other reviews on here apart from it really is a place you have to visit if in Rome. There is so much more to see than we thought. I was thinking we would be done in a hour but we after 3.5 hours barely does it justice! The only thing is plan around decent weather

Another must-see in Rome. Always fascinating and atmospheric (if you can ignore the world wide phenomenon of amplified music from South American mime-flautists on the road nearby). I suggest trying the entrance to the Palatine Hill on via di Sam Gregorio if the main entrance at the Colosseum is busy. Make sure that you are in the right queue - there were separate queues for tickets and for security checks. We looked round ourselves rather than be in a tour group - you don't need a tour guide to free your imagination.

Wonderful. A fascinating place with lots of interesting ruins remaining. Great photo opportunities at every turn. Part of the 3 for the price of one ticket 12€ for forum, colosseum & palatine hill - good value. The only problem we had was finding the exit as you can't go down the hill the way you came. Don't follow sign up the hill as you'll be wandering around for hours! The turnstile exit is behind the large building (white I think) in which there are toilets. It's near where you go in. Only problem we found all over Rome was sparse signposting.

Could be better. Lots of brick and stone remains but hard to imagine what it looked like in Roman times. Despite an audio guide and lots of guidebooks it could have been so much more enjoyable if the signs were better and you could have seen how it looked in its day. Museum was great though.

Wonderful!. This place never ceases to amaze me with the amount of history available to see. You can spend the whole day wandering around it and up on Palatine Hill, all for 12 Euros which also includes Colleseum entrance. Take water and a snack in, there is nothing inside to buy. It is very hot in the forum in summer too.

ripped off. we bought a ticket, queued for over an hour, then when we reached the front they slammed the gates in our faces and told us to go as they were not letting anyone else in that day. I showed them my tickets but were told to come back tomorrow. I told them I was flying home tomorrow so could I have a refund? They said No, Go Away. They then let in a small group of Italians.

City break . This was fab. 3 attractions for 1 ticket of 12euro, here, the hill and coliseum, didn't like all the selfie stick seller's, very full on so have to be firm but what a fantastic city, worth exploring some of the back streets for a cheaper meal and drinks but still great quality

Link with visit to the Colosseum.. Loved our visit to the Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. Fabulous views from the top of the Palatine, where the imperial family lived and look out for ring necked parakeets. Then back down the hill and stroll through the streets of the forum itself. Fabulous - so photogenic.

Experience History. What a terrific experience! At times it boggles the mind is that the buildings and structures around you roughly 2000 years. What is even more amazing is realizing what took place and who walked those cobble stone streets! That stone your foot is on may be one of the stones Caesar stepped on. History truly comes alive. A guide book or tour will be helpful.

A must. Relatively inexpensive and an enjoyable sight to see. Better signed that Palatine Hill, it makes for an enjoyable walk through Roman history. The Ruins are fairly well laid out and have your camera ready as you should get some spectacular pictures here! We went during the off season & it was pretty busy. a tour guide or audio tour might be helpful, though we coped well without them.

A great historical visit. Like any ancient historical site, it is best to read about it before hand or get an audio guide. I would recommend that visitors enter through the side of the Colosseum and turn left, going up the hill first (but not to Palatine) and then making a right. There is a viewing platform where you can take in the full Forum prior to looking at via eye level. I think this helps you understand the grandeur of the place and then appreciate the eye level details you will get from walking around it. Also, several pathways are closed so getting this birds eye view is a better overall first strategy. After you finish this site, you walk to the Palatine (same area). Don't get there within one hour of closing as they start to move people out the gate 20 minutes before closing so you pay for 40 minutes and that is not enough time.
Wow!!!. This while area of Ancient Rome is amazing. We took a tour with an English speaking your guide. Just to hear all the history that has happened here is incredible. Another must see.

Huge and a bit confused area. The area of Roman Forum is very big with lot of extraordinary architecture remnants, but without any guide or video watched beforehand you will just flow through and learn a little. It would be nice to see a computer simulation, how the area developed and lived during the time so you can feel the spirit of the place. It's definitely worth of visit, but prepare yourself before hand so you know what are you looking at. I walked through in 1,5 hour, but with a guide book it could be easily a pleasant one day affair.It's accessible directly from Colosseum or from Piazza Venezia, there are exists also on Via dei Fori Imperiali.

Definitely worth seeing - do with audio guide!. What an interesting experience! We downloaded a Rick Steve FREE audio guide and it made our visit so much more meaningful! It is impressive to see but can be confusing if you just walk around and don't know what you are actually walking through and experiencing. When downloading this specific audio guide it comes with a map as well. When you go through the gate at the ticket office, go left and start at the entrance closest to the Colosseum ~The ticket you purchase gets you into the Colosseum as well!~Go there first thing in the morning - we queued for about 2 min☺It really is amazing, and with a little imagination it really can be a great experience!
Lot of walk . Lot of walk for virually nothing. There are better places to view the forum in rome. It can be busy and very confusing recomened reaserching history of the forum before hand

Amazing.... We intended to visit for an hour or so before visiting the Colosseum but ended up staying for almost four hours! We took a picnic and ate it surrounded by the ruins while the sun shone down on us, fantastic experience. Leave plenty of time to see everything and wear comfortable shoes so you can navigate the Palatine Hill easily. Great value for money, we booked online and there was no queuing time at all. Highly recommend, our favourite part of Rome.

Very cool place!. The best part about this place is that the ticket gives you access to both the Forum AND the Coliseum. This saved us tons of time because we were not stuck waiting in the HUGE lines at the Coliseum. The Roman Forum is very cool however; I really wish we had done a guided tour here. They provide maps and plaques for you to read but it's very hard to get the whole picture of what this place really was back in ancient times. We spent a couple of hours wandering around and then headed across the street to the Coliseum. Definitely worth checking out!

Amazing but confusing!. This is a must see sight, walking in the footsteps of generations of Romans. It is difficult to understand what is what, so make sure you have a decent guidebook or tour guide. The triumphal arches are stunning!

Historical place. Much nice if you love history and want to discover the places of the past.. go for it and enjoy it, lots of walking there... prepare for good shoes ... no high heels or flip flops ....

A Must Do in Rome. The Roman Forum was for centuries the center of Roman public life.Imagine this being the site for triumphal processions, criminal trials, gladiatorial matches and the nucleus of commercial affairs and you can stand in the middle of such history.A must do weather you are a history buff or not.

Walk in the footsteps of Tiberius and Nero. as part of the ticket to the Colosseum take advantage to walk into the palatine and forum. Whilst the earthquake and various empowers added to the ruins this site brings Roman history to life,walking the streets and through the temples and shops how splendid it would have been
go to the past!. one day is not enough to see really all the beauty of this site.I've seen it under sun and rain... beautifullfrom 11 AM to 15.30 PM with palatin...

Jaw-dropping. This is by far the most goosebumpy site in Rome. Palatine Hill/Roman Forum is just incredible and filled with 3,000 years worth of history.Take note that Palatine Hill consists of the Roman Forum AND the Colloseum so they can all be seen together in the one day. Walking around the Forum and trying to comprehend the history makes the hairs on the back of your neck stand. Take the underground tour around colloseum (€11) and then - perhaps after lunch - stroll around the Roman Forum/Palatine Hill fee of charge. Make sure you take in the museaum which details the history of the land you stand on.
Tour Guide is a Good Investment Here. I could walk around this area most of the day and marvel at the history but hiring a guide who knows what to look for really makes the Forum amazing.

History all around. Absolutely amazing area. Best to go early in the morning and miss the heat and crowds. Also having a guide is a must have, they can point out all sorts of things you'd miss otherwise. Don't bother doing the audio guide though.

A MUST place to visit. If you come to Rome, Forum is one of the place you Must visit. Overall, price for Colliseum and Roman Forum is just about 8 euros for both, and as far as I remember for 2 days.Although, suggest visiting not in winter, as most reconstruction is in winter.
interesting. You can't go to Roma and not visit the Forum! but bring a guide or something that explains you what you see, else it's quite difficult to tell!

The best if you are into antiquity. If you love the ancient Romans, their culture and the feeling of stepping in the footstep of all those famous, and infamous, Romans, this is the place for you.This site is much larger than you would guess from looking at the picture and we spent two hours here and didn't see it all! Felt that we just scraped the surface, really. What I really recommend you to do is to climp the stairs uf the Palatine Hill and look at the Forum from up there. There you will get a better picture of the entire area, plus walking in a much nicer and more quiet area. Also don't miss to go in the direction of the Colosseum and the Circus Maximus, here it is lush and green and there are spaces that are almost deserted. Bring a guidebook and glance through that and skip a guided tour. We arrived quite early, before 10 AM and as it was the first Sunday of the month admission was free. So admission was free to the Forum, the Palatine Hill and Colosseum (HUGE queues to that though). If you have the option to go on one of these "free" Sundays, be sure to get there early. There are more than one entrance, we took the entrance between Circus Maximus and Colosseum and not the one between Colosseum and Vittorio Emanuele Monument. More quiet and less queues. Toilets were also available here and a small gift shop. Do not rush, take your time, sit down and enjoy! This is magnificent!

A FANTASTIC VIEW BACK TO THE HISTORY. When you visit the Roman Forum you feel that you are doing a step back in time! You can understand how a roman lived his everyday life and how important was the spiritual quest for all the romans. It is a wonderfull experience!

In the Footsteps of History. It would be a sin to go to Rome and not visit the Roman Forum. One ticket will get you into the Palatino, the Forum and the Coliseum. The least crowded entry is into the Palatino, have a good walk around in the footsteps of emperors. The ticket is good for two days, but only allows one entry to each place. The Forum and the Coliseum are right next to each other. The Coliseum could easily consume an entire day and the museum around the perimeter is fascinating. Also, opposite the Palatino is the old grounds of the Circus Maximus. It is all just to amazing to be true---but it is!

Lots of history. Lots to see here but you really need a knowledgeable guide to get the full story. The forum was busy as it was a nice day, which you need really as there is little shelter around the forum. Lots of history and well worth a visit.

Such History!!!. We combined a ticket for the Roman Forum with one for the Colosseum (purchased online to avoid the queues). The Forum is another 'must see' for any first visit to Rome. There is just so much history here - it's quite amazing to walk the same streets that Julius Caesar & the senators of Ancient Rome walked. There are sign boards explaining a little bit about some of the buildings but we felt quite lost until we took out our headphones & again used our Rick Steves app on our Smartphones. Tours are available & the Forum is crowded even in off peak times so it's best to decide in advance which way you want to tour the area. There is a lot to see & much to take in.

good but a guide is needed. the forum is big and interesting but hard to follow. we used our guide books but really needed a guide. going it alone is not the way to do it, it was our fault not to get a guide. but it was still interesting and a must see. i was hoping that they would have clearer information about the forum but still, it was good.
Colosseum tour. Done this as part of the colosseum tour with a guide called Gregory, unbelievable knowledge and fascinating site, not to sure how you could go without a guide
Roaming the Forum. After paying a visit to the Colosseum went along to the Roman Forum very interesting in walking around to see the site. It was also nice to carry onto Palatine Hill.

Good visit but marred by entrance litter. Presence of overflowing litter bins did not create a good first impression, and the queuing lines were poorly managed. That said, the Forum (admission inclusive with Colosseum ticket) is a must-see, with some helpful interpretation panels dotted around the site. Lots of good photographic opportunities. There are a number of entrance / exit points, not all of which were open on our visit.

don't be fooled, it's huge!. after a fairly long day of walking around the colosseum and surrounding areas, we had access to the roman forum with our colosseum tickets. Looking at the entrance we thought we'd be able to pop around it all within an hour, but after walking up the hill and finding out (rather foolishly) that the huge circle we'd been walking around through the day, had infact been around the forum!I'm really glad we did persuade our feet to go on a few hours longer, as it was an incredible site, with a great little museum and lots of beautiful photo opportunities. A definate must for any history buffs or art and architecture lovers!If you're on a short trip like we were, you should try and cover as much of the forum and surrounding attractions as possible in one day, as there's so many things to see in rome you'll probably not get time to come back! However if you have the luxury of a longer trip, the colosseum and forum ticket can be used over 2 days, so i'd probably recommend spreading it out, so you can really take your time to explore the whole thing :)

Incredible!. What an amazing place. We tried to see it from every viewpoint both paying and non paying. Each time it still managed to take our breath away. Yes - it is in ruins but the scale of them and the centuries over which they span is mind-blowing. Can't wait to return!

Depends on the individual.. I had read a few reviews saying actually entering the Forum isn't required and it's true you can see a lot of it from the road above. But my contribution is that it is up to the individual to make that call.I went to mainly see the Colosseum, but the queue was massive so I went to Palatine Hill which connects with the Forum and allows you to skip the Colosseum line. Seeing all three sights invokes a lot of walking, and would probably be sweltering in summer. Even so, the ruins are interesting and it is all included in the single ticket price - why not make the most of it!? Overall I loved the area, it is so rich in history. Of you have the time make sure to see all three sites.

Always magnificent. PositivesViewsRestoration workAbility to work freely among ruinsNegativeThe inability of the Italians to organise queues, keep to a queue and sort out security. But always worth a visit

Sense of History. Take in a visit to the Forum before/after visiting the Colosseum and you will not be disappointed. The whole experience is a must for anyone remotely interested in ancient history and to walk the steps that the Romans walked was just awesome.Lots of ruins but soooo worth the visit.
Amazing. The ruins are great from every view. It helps to have a guide book to identify the structures. They sell a book that show what it originally looked like.

Should have used a Guide. It was a hot day and we had lost some time already on the morning we visited the Roman Forum. So we dropped our plans to visit the Palatine Hill and decided to head straight to the Roman Forum. We used our Roma Passes to get our first free tickets to enter. We used the Rick Steves audio guides again to make sense of the ruins. They say all roads lead to Rome or at least the Golden Milestone in the Roman Forum. But somehow, our paths didn’t cross it that day! The Roman Forum was a bit tricky to navigate with an audio guide. From time to time, I was unsure if I was listening to the correct audio for the place I was viewing. The kids must have been even more out of sync with the audio guide. I do wish I had used a tour guide here. We would have got a lot more out of the visit. It was a place full of stories about Julius Caesar, Vestal Virgins, the Rostrum, Romulus that we wanted to hear about in even more detail.Later on the vacation, we picked up a book on Rome for the kids, which shows the Then and Now pictures of many Roman monuments. I wish we had come across the book before we visited the Forum. We would have experienced the already awesome Forum on entirely another level.

Don't bother paying to go in. You get some of the best views of the Forum from the outside, so we saw little point in paying to go in. The ruins are particularly impressive viewed from the terraces just off Via di San Pietro in Carcere.

Worth the walk. This was the second half of our Coliseum tour. We were provide a great deal of information about what the place was like and used for when it was current. Very interesting with several structures still available for viewing from the outside. Using your imagination is needed to get the full experience.

Impressive but probably too ruined!. Yes it is a must see and yes it is quite remarkable attraction. But it requires a lot of fantasy to get to the point that you understand what it may have looked like. It is not on par with Ostica Antica, which is simply much better preserved and far more impressive. But then we are complaining from the highest levels. So go and see it - yes.

Nice to see from the air!!!. if you see i from the top of the building in piazza di venezia, from the colosseo, from the street, from the copiloting museum... you ve seen it all... and don't need to pay twice
Immense. Couldn't believe the size of the area and the amount of buildings still standing, trying to imagine what it would have looked like in its pomp is mind blowing.

It cannot get more ancient!. Near the old city, this is a must see for all history buffs. Our suggestion is to please review, read and update yourself before going there or use a guided tour or u may feel lost.
Fab - a must see. What an experience! Highly recommended, easy to get to and a real taste of history. A real step back in time

A must see!!! Pity that it's so ruined!. each and every time that I visited Rome, I visited the Forum! I go there and try to image the superb temples and palaces surrounding the area! My greatest displease is that the place was stripped off its statues and marbles just to decorate private residences, churches or found in museums! If only the possessors of such thing would "Return to Caesar what it was of Caesar"!!!

Awsome. The entrance directly opposite the Colosseum gets very busy, so walk 5 minutes around the corner and enter via Palentine Hill entrance, but only if you have a ticket.The Forum and views from Palentine Hill are spectacular, read about it first and you will gain so much more from walking around what was a very busy centre of power and influence.A stunning archaeological site and window into Roman life.

Got our Tickets here to save the long queues. Really a must see when in Rome! Great to be able to walk around the Forum and Imagen how it would of been, good amount of information around to help understand the history of the area. Really beautiful! Went on a day with blue skies and no rain which was great as if it had rained would of ended up very muddy!! Going in February it wasn't too busy, you had space to walk at your own pace and see everything. MUST see!
