full of history. After learning about Roman history for many years, it was amazing to visit the forum and see all the sites I had read about in person! The forum is a great place to go for anyone who has learned about Roman history

A must see place!. We did not go down into the forum, but observed from above. Next time, we will take a walking tour through the forum. The structures are so impressive and ancient! Much older than anything I will ever see in this country, and so well preserved.

Really wonderful. I guess it really depends on what time of year you go. I hear in the hot Summer the crowds and heat can make this place a nightmare. I got a beautiful warm sunny Spring day in February. The crowds were not bad. Plenty of time and space to sit down and drink in the history. Truly magnificent.
Beautiful and historical area. The Roman forum is a must really. It is a large area with a wealth of historical monuments and a great stroll too

Walk thru History. Walk thru 2000 year old ruins and breathe in the history. Truly beautiful place. Can get crowded on weekends. The same ticket gets you admission to the Forum, Colessium, and Palatine Hill for €12. Plan to spend several hours to take in all three, which are situated next to each other.

Interesting old ruins. Following advice from other travellers we bought our tickets for Forum, Palatine and Colosseum here (they are valid for two days so we saved the Colosseum for the next day.) We queued for about 40 minutes to buy our tickets and then for another 10 minutes to get in. The place is huge and we spent several hours walking around and looking at the immense structures, there are plenty of signs giving information about the ruins although no impressions of what they would have looked like before hand. Our children enjoyed the Palatine hill area and the museum of artefacts. We took drinks in with us which was just as well, there is no where to buy drinks. We found toilets, which were closed, in the Antiquarium Forense and then thankfully found more in a low building up the steps on the hill in the Gardens.A great place and very interesting.

Nice. Not as good as I thought it would be, but it was nice to see the old colonnas and the views from the higher ground. One bad thing was that the park closed very early, a quarter past four, so we didn´t get to see everything we wanted before we were told to go - immediately.

Fascinating detail if you avoid the qs. We had done the Colosseum the previous day and were aware that our ticket was valid for 2 days and included the Forum & Palatine Hill.However, having seen the Forum q we wanted to avoid this. So we went along for opening time - 08:30 - and no queue at all. Our first hour or so was almost totally alone, it only started to get busier later in the morning.It was good to get in amongst it, and there are lots of boards detailing what you can see.An issue though - there are two original houses with frescos, but you can't enter these without an additional paid for ticket, which we didn't know until we were at their entrance. We would have had to trek back to a specified desk elsewhere in the complex to get a ticket. There should be a system whereby you can pay at the entrance to those buildings, after all there was someone there checking on entry. It should have been set up so that she could collect the fee.

History Comes Alive. One of the most spectacular sites in Rome, you can imagine the bustling life in this archaeological area bursting with well preserved buildings. Unfortunately, there are often enough people to make it seem as if it were market day in Ancient Rome. You can look at this as a plus or minus depending on your viewpoint. Make sure to bring a good guidebook with you. The signs are not as thorough or as descriptive as one would like.

Breathtaking!. Breathtaking! Amazing life experience that must be seen! Was taken on a fascinating tour by Italywithus.com who were so passionate and brought the history to life! Glad it wasn't too busy !

good but it could be better. It includes a lot of exhibits but there were no signs to explain what each exhibit is. Despite the fact that the area is very large there are not enough signs to show you the exits.

An amazing collection of ruins. Make sure you take a good guide book and allow yourself plenty of time to soak up the history. We went on a sunny day in february so it was quite cool, but in summer it will be hot, so take drinks.

Must see if you are in Rome.. Be ready to stand in long lines and have water handy as it can get really hot in the summers. The colosseum looks prettier in the night with dim lighting(and lesser people).

Roman forum, a breathtaking place. For those who love history, this is one of the most stunning places in the world. Save at least half a day to visit Roman Fórum. I can guarantee each minute will Worth the time you spend there.

Missed it!!. We had tickets for the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Forum that were valid for 2 days, and were really looking forward to visiting. After we had visited the Colosseum we entered Palatine Hill an hour before closing (without being warned) and were then unable to go into the Forum the next day as the tickets allowed one entry only. It was not stated that entry for the Forum and Palatine are joint, and the 'valid for 2 days' did not include re-entry. We felt very cheated and were unwilling to pay again as you couldn't get tickets for the Forum only.

have to visit. Not much more can be said about this place than already has been in the previous reviews.we thought it was very interesting and does take a while to walk around.a guide book is a must.put it on your list of places to see!

Simply amazing this place!. Another must-see for lovers of Roman history. The visit can be made on the same day that goes to the Coliseum, which is across the street, but it is important to be guided to understand its magnificent history. Simply amazing this place!

Amazing Stuff Here!. After reading about the Forum in a couple travel books, I expected a few pillars and some dirt. WOW! This is an amazing site that they are still excavating thru that is so so beautiful and enjoyable to walk thru and take photos. We almost skipped it. SO glad we didn't. One of my favorite places to explore all week

Good one day visit. The first stop after you land in rome is the roman forum. Its a fantastic set of ruins set in a park and gives great insight into the ancient rome. Takes 5-6 hours for a detailed visit for the forum along with colloseum

Such good value!. We were advised via the internet that the best way to see the Coliseum in a timely fashion, we should buy joint tickets from the Palentine Hill which would also include the Roman Forum... The whole visit took around 3 hours.... you could definitely spend longer. One of the biggest archaeological sites I have ever seen. There's even one remaining standing column (which is rare). Excellent views of the coliseum also, with out the madness. Highly recommend... maybe take a guide book with you not a great deal of information. Lady at the Palentine Hill was really great!

HUGE. A really expansive area that is worth giving it the time it deserves. Allow a couple of hours and take some lunch - plenty of great places to perch and take it all in. Wear comfy shoes and embrace the history.

Very Interesting!. You have to use your imagination, but it's worth a visit. A large area of various temples, buildings etc in differing states but you can still imagine what it must have looked like in ancient times.

Peaceful and historic. Stunning, a glimpse of the past. A must for Rome. Didn't take a tour, the price quoted for an adult and student was 75euro. That did include the colosseum and hill. We paid 12 euro each and wandered around ourselves at our pace.... About 4 hours. That price also included the hill and colosseum .
Wear sensible or walking shoes.. The walking is uneven so take care. Take water or a drink of choice as it is all in the open with little shad.
Fascinating. Nothing to dislike all very interesting. Needs a few hours and do read all information otherwise sometimes difficult to know what is what.

A must!. Visited Rome in August 2014. I was absolutely blown away by this city and its history and savoured every minute. The Forum was amazing, my guide( group) was not much of a story teller however and simply ran off lots of facts and information so I ended up taking my ear piece out and wandering off on my own to explore. Very impressive, a must do!!
Absolutely beautiful!. The coliseum was a beautiful work of architecture. I was astonished standing in there and admiring everything. Make sure you pre-buy your tickets online!
Very Cool. The Roman Forum is a large exhibit of history. Right beside the Colosseum, and usually included in the price you can see ruins, and even fountains from the old Rome.

An Exciting Piece of History. A must see and every bit as interesting as the Colosseum. Walking across the floor of the Forum and also sitting up in the seats looking down makes your mind wander back centuries ago to wonder what really all took place here. We can only imagine.

The Forum. Great Historical Spot always buy ticket for Forum and Coliseum you can do both in one day and they are next to each other so it makes sense. Get a good guide book something small enough to carry around that has all the information on the forum and maps so you can identify where you are. It really helps we used a pocket sized DK Eye Witness Travel Book and it was a great help. Just enough information so that you know which ruin you are looking at and what its purpose was back in the day.

Touch Roman Life from 2000 years ago.. Just awesome. In many respects more impressive than The Colosseum. You really do get a sense of what ancient Roman Life was like and just how big and important this city was. This is a must see!
Beautiful place to visit!. The Roman Forum was one of the highlights of our trip to Rome. We spent several hours walking through the grounds on our own and would still visit again on another trip.

Breathtaking!!!! . What can I say? The whole experience of paying for the guided tour along with the view was spectacular! Trying to imagine "gladiator" makes you smile as you truly experience this opportunity of being in such a beautiful historical venue. It actually made me cry sitting quietly and thinking of the souls lost in such a spiritual place. One of my best 10 places to visit on your bucket list!!!

ancient rome. buying ticket at colesseum is a complete mess. we should look around for the correct line to stand in. Ancient roman ruins and colosseum in particular are amazing and are well kept. there is no food inside ofcourse and the visit is long. I advice to carry some water and food especially those with kids. Entire place is rich with culture and very lively. reserve a whole day for it.

An almost unimaginable concentration of history. We took a guided tour and spent around an hour learning about some of the history of the forum and its many monuments - great if you like ancient history but I found there was just too much information and found myself switching off. I would have been happier spending less time there, getting an overall impression with the help of a written guide

Impressive attraction, please read bellow for on-line tickets. It was an amazing attraction. It give you the chance to discover some important aspects about ancient Rome.But, please note that in order to enjoy the location, you should be well rested because it is quite large and there are a lot of archeological sites to see. Also, please pay attention to the signs for exits - it was tricky to find the exit closest to the Colosseum.Regarding tickets, a ticket is valid for both the Colosseum and the Roman Forum (we paid for our tickets on-line, and with the reservation code we collected our tickets from the ticket office). We initially went to the Roman Forum, where with our printed reservation we received our tickets - we skipped the line and went straight to the ticket office to collect our tickets (n.b. there is no sign to skip the line, just go ahead to the office and ask for your tickets).

So much to see, so little time!. Came upon it quite by accident, enjoyed walking leisurely through it. It's amazing to think that you are walking through such ancient grounds; history set in the site’s stones. Take your time and take it all in. Then go find a sidewalk cafe and enjoy an espresso or a crisp prosecco!
Impressive. Impressive still despite now being mainly ruins. Did not visit when in Ronme previously and glad i did this time.
A must see. I love this spot, and although its not a primo day trip for teens? Drag your kids to a monument to Roman history...its worth a visit!!
Foot sore site!. Amazing historic site covering a vast area. Mixture of gardens, monuments and wildlife. Almost overwhelming.

Worth a trip in itself. One of the highlights of Rome, don't just treat it as an add-on to the Coliseum but give it lots of time. The entire area will take up several hours of wandering, particularly if you explore the Palatine Hill as well while you're there.It's worth reading up on the area before you go, but even if you don't there are good information plaques here and there that give a flavour of this extraordinary civilisation.One tip: If you're visiting the Coliseum, buy the dual ticket that gives access to both sites. However the Forum site closes at 15.30, but the ticket is valid for twenty four hours, so it is worth coming back the next day to visit the Forum. Otherwise, start early and don't rush your tour.

included with colosseum entrance. We visited the forum romanum after we visited the colosseum.It is a nice place to walk around, but after half an hour you have seen it. The best way is to go up the hill, and then you have a beautiful view!

Amazing Ruins. The ticket to Roman Forum is included in the ticket to the Colosseum. It is also right beside the Colosseum so we went there after we visited the Colosseum. It is very large site that contains the ruins of the buildings that were part of ancient Rome. We used Rick Steve's description of the site to understand more completely what we were viewing. It took about 2.5 hours to tour the site and we left early as the rain was making it difficult to walk due to slippery rocks.

Could be organized better. We used their audio guide but it was not user-friendly, as we needed to constantly consult with the map to check when there is a guidance comment available or not... They had a two-hour tim limit to return the audio guide, which was too short for us to see both the Roman Forum and the Palitine Hill which we paid for... Would not recommend the audio guide.

AMAZING. The whole Forum Romanum is amazing, but it seems that the main of the traffic thins out before climbing the Palatine.The Villa Livia itself is worth the climb, but the museum is also fantastic. The exhibits are modern and well constructed and make you want to learn more about Rome.I would set aside an entire day for this, if I were to go again.There is nothing but good to say about this place.

An interesting walk. Very extensive ruins with good signage explaining what they are, when built and major architectural notes. Wear comfortable shoes and take time to dawdle. Also return at night to see the various buildings lit up.
what can be said??? impressiive. one of the places not to be missed, but with calm and a good guide, it is full of history, also the Palatine palace in the hill is not to be missed

Amazing.. It can be hard to explain to people who aren't interested in history how time wandering round ruins can be a good experience, fortunately i am not one of those people! The sheer size of the place overwhelming, and the amount of columns and brickwork that has survived over 2000 years is astonishing! There is alot of climbing up and down steps if you want to cover the entire area including the Palatine Hill which of course is exactly what we did!The only downside would be for any disabled visitors or people who struggle with walking as much of the area is inaccessible.Overall this is a must see in Rome, and it also provides a great view to take photos of the Colosseum!

Double up with the Collesium. This place just blew us away history wherever you look You can spend as long as you like just taking it all in You get a two day pass from the Collesium and don't forget any young people going take your photo ID Under 18 free 18-24 €7.50 amazing value and you could easily spend two whole days with these two historic sights

amazing. Ruins that cover a vast area in the centre of Rome. Viewed from hill you get to see the size of the site. Wandering throw the site loads to see and descriptions to read. Wear comfortable shoes!

Amazing. Breath taking always wanted to go here for as long as I can remember and I wasn't let down by the magnificent of it my advice is to pay for a guide round they give you good knowledge of the place and you don't afto quee either little bit more expensive but worth it and most of the guides you get to go round forum aswell all in price A MUST SEE IF YOU GO TO ROME

The scale and scope are breathtaking. I've submitted a review covering the Colosseum and the associated travails around the 2 day pass and will repeat do The Roman Forum and The Palatine hill on one visit and the Colosseum on a separate one , the we went on the 14th of February and after the colosseum we had some lunch we then went back and entered at the Colosseum side The Palatine is to the left and as my wife wanted the toilets that's where we headed first , once up in the gardens you can look down on the Forum which is AMAZING we then started to look around the Palatine hill itself WARNING IT IS HUGH AREA the scale and amount of things are staggering and we ran out of time not seeing all there was as you must leave by 16.30 no exceptions at this point we were unaware that they were both on the one ticket and planned to return the day after ,see above . As with all the major sites prebook online and it'll save you time also plan to get there as early as possible as I don't think there is an out of season as it was still very busy but worth it .
The view is amazing. Lots of low grade slope for the stairs. But worth the hike to the top. The view is amazing. Took tons of photos

Beautiful ruins. The Roman Forum was amazing, and the tour guide was very knowledgeable and hilarious. He also recommended other tours to attend and places to see. I personally just browsed after the tour, as it kind of moves quickly.

How the other half lived. When first seeing the forum I didn't realise the extent of the place. Viewing from above gives you an incredible in site into the origins of the roman empire.The site is huge and offers some of the finest examples of ancient ruins.

Incredibly impressive. Take a tour/hire a guide.. No real shock that the Roman Forum is an absolute must see while in Rome. What may not be apparent if you haven't visited before is its size and complexity. My family and I have visited twice and enjoyed it both times. One important caveat: if you really want to understand what you're seeing you either need to be an Ancient World history professor or sign up for a tour or hire an on-site guide. While everything is impressive even without a guide you will REALLY understand what you're seeing and be able to put all of the major "pieces" together. Tour guides are readily available at the sight and tours can easily be arranged in advance of your visit. We used Dark Rome for an Extended Vatican tour and can't imagine their Forum tour would be a bad one. Enjoy.

Simply A Must See - Entrance Included in Colosseum Ticket. I would suggest downloading Rick Steve's app and the Roman Forum walking tour as you could easily miss important pieces of the Forum.The ticket gets you into the Roman Forum, Colosseum and Palatine Hill too, valid for two days. HOWEVER, there is one entrance per attraction and the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill is together. I would suggest doing Colosseum one day and the other two the next. We did the Colosseum and then went to the Roman forum in one day, we went to go back and do Palatine the next day and we weren't allowed back in, which was really annoying.Take a moment to sit down and let the grandeur sink in of this amazing piece of history.

Did I Mention I'm a History Geek?. Is it pathetic to admit that I cried as we descended into the Forum? Here's the catch, though - if you don't study what it is that you are looking at when you visit THE Roman Forum, you will inevitably think, "Wow... What a wrecked pile of stone...". If on the other hand you read-up and use a little bit of imagination, you will likely be moved by the historical magnitude of the ground you are treading.

Rome was here.. amazing to see, get lost in the city centre at sunset....that's the best to visit Rome. don't think about buses and cars and noise...just get lost in the streets and find a good place where to eat italian. feel like on holidays!

Visited within our tour to the colloseum & Palatine Hill. Visited within our tour to the Colosseum & Palatine Hill was included in the ticket - must be visited with a tour guide as there's so much to find out about the place.
We were at this along with Palatine Hill for approx 2 hours but could have easily been for longer!

Ensure good walking shoes. For 12 euros you can have a day here and a day at the colosseum but be warned you need all day at the roman forum, it is a huge sight so much to see, we didn't do a tour we just went on our own there are plenty of information boards around .
Impressive builders. Ahead of their time with impressive structures, still standing today. Challenged with less tools than we have nowadays they managed to achieve more than we can do today.
Forum is a must. Second time to the forum and it didn't disappoint again, hopefully get a dry day as there's lots of cobbles , you can usually get a ticket that includes the colosseum and forum

Impressive. This place covers a huge area and decent walking shoes are a must. However as with a lot of the attractions in Rome, there is no real structure to touring these ruins. I f you are unaware of the history of these buildings, being amongst them will not educate you any further due to a lack of information available whist you walk around.

Brilliant. Visited this while in the city on a cruise. We had 5hrs to do whatever we wanted and i dragged the missus to this. She was not sold at first but once we were in the groove she loved it & so did i. Amazing to see the ruins & learn more about the place. I would suggest some reading up about the area first. We were walking around the ruins for hours but you can make it as short as you wish.Cost: €12 adult (included Roman Forum, Palatine Hill & Colloseum).

Wonderful. . So you can visit the Forum and the Colosseum on the same ticket which is handy. When entering the forum, you can walk all around, then go up to the Palatine Hill which is worth a walk up to see a whole arial view of the Forum and many nearby buildings. The museum at the top of the Palatine Hill is also worth a visit with free admission. We struggled to find the exit!! There are two.. Either back right of the Forum, or walking to the left of the Palatine Museum and down the far side.. This takes you out on the road near to Maximus Circus which is also cool to walk through.

Built to impress the barbarians. This is the centre of antique Rome. It used to be free, and sheer hell, now you pay and enjoy. It requires imagination to understand what it was at the time of the Caesars, so stop and think. Above you is the Palatine, same ticket so visit. Other side of the (wide) road is the Trajan market, visit that too.Rome was built to impress the barbarians, we are still impressed.

Interesting and impressive. Very crowded, but impressive and beautiful, and historically interesting. A "must" when in Rome! (Buy the ticket in advance, then you can just go straight through and skip the long line. We went to colosseum the day before and bought a ticket that was valid for bought the forum and the colosseum, and it was valid for 24h or so).

A must stop when in Rome. Along with the Colosseum, roman forum is a must to appreciate what this great civilization had to offer so early in the human existence. It was my second time in 10 plus years and it was equally awe inspiring to look around and look down the view from the top of the Palantine Hill and imagine what it might have been like. One thing I would suggest is to read in advance about the sites and possibly peek thru a picture book that show the old and current sites in comparison. One can even find this at local bookstores or buy one from a street vendor. Otherwise, most of these will likely appear as old ruins w/ little meaning in history.
really interesting place. Very interesting place which you could get lost in for hours. Each corner is a gem in its self. Must see!

Amazing journey through ancient Rome. The forum provides an amazing glimpse back in time to the heyday of the Roman empire. We went thru with an audio guide which helped identify the various buildings and ruins. We bought tickets in advance (combined with the Colosseum) but still had to wait about 20 minutes in the security line. very interesting site and not to be missed.
centre of civilisation. Here it is and you will be awed by it's ancient magnificence. Nearby is the Forum and one can almost hear 1st century Romans living within it. A must see.
Amazing. Good weather and flat shoes required. You need a guide book to see what each ruin was. A guide us also very helpful.

Beautiful ruins. Make sure you take the time to read the signs that explain what each building was
Local shops also sell past and present picture books if you're struggling to understand the magnitude of the area.
Really beautiful place.
Simply a must see. Long lines and crowded but simply worth every minute. You walk through with your mouth agape at the sheer amount of antiquities lying on the ground around you. It's awe inspiring.
Great history.. Need a guide to understand what the Forum once was. Today its totally ruins and hard to envision the original.
Fascinating. Very large area to explore. Spent a few hours exploring this interesting area. Research before you go and take your guide book along.

Amazing value. I think this is one of the only places in the world I have had to show my driving license to get discount! Half price for 18-25 what a brilliant idea!
The colosseum is very good and defiantly worth a visit but be warned there can be long wait times!

Join a guide group. Pay for a guide - plenty selling their wares outside. However guides that do Forum and Colessum together will be too quick if you want to wander and enjoy. However you need a guide to introduce you to this 5-acre site and bring it alive with stories that turn a lump of stone into someone's life story! The audio-guide is waste of five euros with no numbers marked on site - don't bother . Site includes August Ceasar's palace at top in garden area which has fantastic views over to Vatican - our guide didnt do this part. Probably dont need guide for colessum.

absolutely amazing!. Went there solo last month, as a classics geek i was in my element. I did have the assistance of a lonely planet which helped my guidance as it can be a little confusing /poorly marked. Close to everything

worth a visit. It's one of those places everyone must see at least once. Unfortunately, these places are full of people like you so it is crowded. Though the crowd takes away from the experience, I'm glad I did get to see it. The architecture and history is amazing and I enjoy watching and understand travel shows of this place a lot more since my visit.

An Amazing Sight. You walk around this huge attraction, and all you do is just keep saying "Wow". You cannot replace the feeling of seeing and being here, it is just so magnificent and amazing. This is a must-see attraction in Rome.
Impressive sight. The Romans building skills were very impressive. I had the Blue guide and the Oxford Archeological guide to help me identify the different buildings. Both were excellent.
beautiful disorder. Nice to walk around, take interesting pictures and read about each building. You can't miss it in Rome.
fascinating. didn't realize you have to pay to go through the forum. don't forget to climb the stairs up to the park for a great view
Good value. Lots to see and walk around. Good value fir money and Pallentine Hill is included. Be aware that it is very hilly and not particularly wheel chair friendly.

Ancient Rome at its greatest. We went to the Palatine entrance of the Roman Forum, as we'd come from the Colosseum. There was no queue at the entrance (at 2pm), and we walked straight in. We also had pre-purchased a combined pass for the Colosseum and the Forum, which was only 12 euro. The Roman Forum is the ancient original site of Rome, which largely lies in ruins now after being neglected for centuries. We had a look at one of the still-standing ancient aquaducts, and walked around the ‘shopping district’ of ancient Rome. There was a really lovely view of the Arc of Constantine and the Colosseum from the higher ground of the Forum. Head in to the main area of the Forum to get a closer look at the cremation site of Julius Caesar after his assassination in 44 BC. Some of the other highlights were the Temple of Concord (167 BC), the Arch of Septimius Severus (203 AD), and the famous Rostrum, from where many famous speeches were given. The dates and history of this area is absolutely mind blowing. Don't miss it!

Large area so be prepared to do a lot of walking. We spent about 4 hours at the Forum and could have spent more. We did not take along any tour books and that would have been useful to really understand what we were seeing. We were unaware that to see the private homes you must purchase a ticket at the entrance--a very great distant from the homes themselves so we have to skip them. Also be aware that there are limited toilet facilities--the line at the museum was over a half hour long. We did find a restroom with not waiting at the far end of the Forum. From the Forum you can look down on the Circus Maximus so unless you feel a need to actually walk into the grounds you can see what you need to from above. Take along your own food and drink. We did not see any cafes on site, and get a good map of the Forum.
Historical, yet boring!. Great history surrounds you, but unfortunately workers and scaffoldings everywhere ruin the whole experience!!!

Long walk but worth it. After you've done the Colosium it's just a logical way to walk to the forum, after entry walk up to the Palatino gardens for great views, then walk through the amazing Forum ruins to the Capatilono museum. The roof top restaurant is a great place for a break with a view. Then walk on to the Spanish steps
A must visit!. Loved our visit in this area! There is so much history here. It is helpful to study up before visiting as there is so much to take in once there. A must see!

A must-see!. Well worth the trip!! Open hours vary by time of year so definitely check online if you plan on arriving in the afternoon.Tickets (€12 as of Feb '15) give entry to both the Colosseum and the Roman Forum. Both are worth it!If you can, buy tickets ahead of time online (they give you an entry time) or you will stand in line like us. We tried to buy tickets online the day before, but they were either sold out or no longer available so it seems like the earlier you can do this, the better. While standing in line there was a QR code on signs in the line stating you could buy your tickets then and there and skip the line, but we didn't have internet so not sure if this would have also been unavailable. When walking up the street we noticed there was a line to the Roman Forum (on the right hand side near a gelato stand). It was very inconspicuous and we almost missed it. We stood in line for a good 30 minutes even thought the line was relatively short. On the right hand side, people that had pre-booked and group tours just walked right up and traded in their internet printout for tickets. We then went to have lunch and were able to walk right into the Colosseum first, before our tour of the Forum, past the ENORMOUS line of people. It was very unorganized, with no indication of where to walk in if you have a ticket. We just pushed our way in and through, but I would bet people with tickets thought they had to wait, too. There is a separate route to the left for those with tickets and groups.There are two entrances to the Forum that we could find, the one where we bought tickets and another that is easy to enter when exiting the Colosseum. This is the one we went into.It was amazing walking around and exploring. It didn't feel too crowded and there were lots of photo ops of the city when you're very high up. We saw some people having picnics although I'm not sure if this is allowed.Great experience!
Visit this with the Colosseum ticket. Definitely worth the queue to wander round and see the architecture and don't miss out on the museum and grounds of Palantine Hill.
History!. Rome is a bit of a walking museum and to take part of tthe Forum is one of the highlights! To hire a guide or at least an audioguide will be even better

Bring a guidebook and a sunhat. The Roman forum lies close to the Colosseum and you can buy a combined ticket for the two. Once the heart of the Roman republic, this was where the likes of Caesar made speeches. It's ruined now, but you can still see buildings and temples in various states of disrepair. You do need a bit imagination, and whilst there is some information there isn't a great deal, so I would recommend a good guidebook or a guided tour. You will share the experience with plenty of other visitors. There is not a lot of shade and so ensure you take a hat, suncream and plenty of water, especially if visiting in the middle of the day in summer. There's quite a bit of walking around to do, sometimes on uneven ground, so wear flat shoes. Read up on your Roman history - through novels like Robert Harris' Cicero books if you prefer - before you visit and it will all mean a lot more to you.

One of the best places to see in Rome. As you enter the area you walk past by an old well preserved archway that was surely felt the feet of many Romans as they walked through it. Past this gateway you find yourself looking down into a small valley that stretches away from you into the distance, full of various ruins that still stand despite the passing of centuries. On your left hand side is the Palatine hill, the seat of the Roman Emperors, overlooking the valley while an old Roman road of slabs stretch down towards the valley floor.This is the start of the Roman Forum, an ancient heart deep within modern Rome. Walking around the valley floor is a deep solemn experience, stepping in a piece of history. Words can't describe the experience, you have to see it for yourself to fully appreciate it. It is not just the forum; there is also the Palatine Hill, where the Emperors once lived and you can see the ruins there of their palaces and places of relaxation and entertainment.There is a lot to see here and you can easily spend a whole afternoon walking around, taking in the view and generally enjoying the epic landscape. There is some information scattered around to tell you what ruins are which but mostly you have to use the illustrations and your mind to imagine what the forum would have once looked like.You can pay for the forum and hill seperately or you can, as we did, take a guided tour of the neighbouring coliseum as we did which has the admission price for the forum and hill included in the cost. Between the two of these sites you have enough to see for satisfying yourself for a day's sightseeing within Rome.

Amazing location. If you visit Rome, make sure you go to this Forum, very historic and in a great location, for you guys who are selfie happy. Just make sure when you take pictures, to use the hashtag #RomanForumSelfieGameRidiculous

Just awe-inspiring!. You can't really understand the grandeur of Ancient Rome until you visit the Roman Forum. It is a massive area right next to the Colosseum filled with ancient runes that have been excavated in the last 100 years. Note that a ticket to the Colosseum includes the Roman Forum pass so there is really no excuse not to visit this. You will need to spend at least 2 hours to get a good view of everything. There are two entrances to the Roman Forum - one from the Colosseum itself (right near the white Arch), and a much quieter one which you enter from the actual main road leading to the Colosseum (next to the ancient Basilica). Best to go the 'secret' entrance as you will get in straight away and don't waste time.
Great pictures. The line for the forum is a LOT smaller than for the colloseum and includes both. The forum its self is large and impressive with a few points for great views
Excellent. Rome is just great! The Roman forum is a very important place to visit in order to understand the whole history of the Roman empire. After the Coliseum, this is a must.

Allow lots of time for this!. Friends had told us to go to the palace entrance to the forum to avoid the queues and they were right. Didn't have to queue and had a good look around the palace before heading to the forum. Could have spent much more time here but wanted to go to the Colosseum as well!

Unbelievable. This really was breathtaking. I can only imagine what the Forum would have looked like in it's former glory, but I'm sure it would have looked awesome. I'd definitely recommend a visit, but I'd advise you to wear comfortable shoes!

Must go. historical site, must go!! one gd thing bat rome is that each landmark are closed together, so a walk around rome is a good way to enjoy all the historical site. Roman Forum is one for the must go list.
Ancient History. The Forum is a great place to walk around, I do find that it is a bit cheeky to charge for the privilege. That said it is a great insight into the past.
Mandatory visit. There is far too much history wrapped up in ruins of the Roman Forum. It is impressive, must see. There is a fee to enter, audio guides are available.
Amazing. I loved that we visited off season and experienced the Forum without the maddening crowds. Can't imagine enjoying it as much during high season.

I knew I had arrived when I saw the Colosseum!. The quintessential icon of Roma! This is not to be missed. I have been three times and each time learn more. I would highly recommend doing your homework ahead of your visit so that you have some basic knowledge of the history of this stunning landmark. I did have a tour guide on one of my visits which included the Roman Forum. If you are doing the Forum make sure to have a guide. There is SO much that you won't discover unless you do.It is always busy but so worth every moment. If my memory serves me, they close off the street around the Colosseum on Sundays to motorized vehicles. Strolling down the street around the Colosseum was a wonderful way to take it all in before you go in.

MUST SEE!. I didn't expect must from the forum but I was very pleasantly surprised! We spent a few hours there, but could have easily spent more time. There are so many things to see, lots of great photo opportunities.

A must-see. You cannot go to Rome without visiting this spectacular building, it really is a sight to behold. I would recommend having a tour guide as it means queue skip and you get a full run down of the history of the building. Also, the tour guide will take you to the Forum afterward, which was my favourite part of this tour. The Forum is encompassed in beautiful gardens which you should take the time to explore afterwards, there was a beautiful view from the high levels and the orange tree garden is just beautiful.

Fascinating. As one of the must-see ancient parts of the city, the Forum didn't disappoint. I was surprised to find that on a Saturday there were virtually no queues, even at around 10.30am - but having pre-booked a Colosseum / Forum combined ticket, this was irrelevant for me. I would recommend having a guide - I did not and didn't get as much from my visit of several hours as I might have done (the pocket-sized green guidebooks available for sale are of little use and signposting leaves a little to be desired, but understandable to preserve the appearance). The views from the higher part are great and the variety of buildings there impressive. A few things are blocked off at present, and there was a fair bit of gardening going on, the teams of men in hi-vis outfits detracting from things a little. But overall, this is an essential place to visit for real understanding of the operation of Roman Rome. There is also the usual wand-scanning as you enter, the security guards here being a little more intensive than the same organisation's working at the Colosseum.
Great place to visit. You should see this enormous building and do not hesitate to take guided tour! Just be avare of anoying guys selling selfie sticks which are everywhere

AMAZING!. As a history buff, I was completely in my element. As I had seen on here before visiting, we bought our tickets at the Roman Forum for 12 euros and there was no queue. The signage around the Roman Forum was great, you really got a sense of what is what and what was going on.The signs tended to become a little more hard to find around the Palatine Hill and it did get a little tedious towards the end as there is ALOT of walking involved.After doing these, we went to visit the Colosseum and having already got our tickets, we got to stroll through the queue. This was equally as amazing to witness, you'll have to see it for yourself!All in all, a great day out!
Try the Forum entrance. There was no row at the entrance at the Forum, we got in very fast, bought the combined ticket. Recommended to try that entrance.

Roman Forum. This is another one of those attractions you see in Rome where your perspective will be greatly influenced by your knowledge of history and your ability to see past a few columns, broken stones and stairs and instead visualize the center of Roman life. So little has been done with so many of these magnificent antiquities that one has to wonder if Italians see them at all for more than the few dollars they bring in. There are several guided tours. As so many others they are hit and miss. They all do their best but often times what's interesting to you may not be anything at all to the guide. For example, I ran into a group high above the Forum on Palatine hill and waited until they were finished in order to take a photo. After about 10 minutes I was convinced the guide was giving a lecture on Travertine. He didn't just mention it in passing, he lectured on it as if he had done his dissertation on it! That may be fascinating to him but I gave up on the photo and moved on. On the other hand, if I had paid 30+ Euros like each of the group had I wouldn't have been a happy camper. The Forum is a fascinating part of ancient Rome but sadly has been allowed to sit and decay.

The Authentic Rome. In my opinion, Roman Forum and the surrounding area is the true representative of Rome than the magnificent Collosseum. With all the architectural diggings, old pillars and forums - you will feel as if you've suddenly entered the age of the kings and can make your imagination take you anywhere in the old times. I've heard that taking a tour guide works better as he can explain the various parts of this area of the city. However, given it was a long walk and many portions are marked with boards, we really didn't get bored or feel the need for extra information. For those who love ruins, this place is just heaven.

Spectacular!!! Must See!!!. The Roman Forum is incredible. All you need to do is buy the joint ticket with the Colosseum and after you stop (I use 'stop' loosely, because your Colosseum 'stop' should be at least 2 hours) at the Colosseum, walk on up the Via Sacra past the Arch of Constantine to the Roman Forum. Here you'll find an area with roots so deep in history you will be brought back in your mind to when it was full of people. You'll be able to envison the Basilica of Maxentius in it's full form. You'll be able to imagine what the Temple of Saturn must've looked like. You'll see where Julius Caesar's body was burned and be able to imagine Mark Antony giving his famous speech in Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar." It is truly spectacular, truly one of a kind, and truly not to be missed.

Beautiful place to explore. This review is highly directed toward palatine hill, which should not be overlooked in exchange for its companion sites (colosseum and forum). I had the benefit of visiting on a perfect, sunny day in January. The forum was very interesting, with amazing remains of temples and rooms. Palatine hill, however, was the champion in my book. The busyness of the forum faded away, apart from some photo op areas of the city from above, and one could go under, around, and through the ruins. There were wide open spaces and nooks and crannies where you could enjoy the echoing of running water bouncing off the old walls. It was also quite romantic, especially the garden area, if the couple making out intensely for at least 10 minutes (with some associated derriere-rubbing) is any indication. I spent about three hours in these two sites before closing and could've easily spent more.

Must go in Rome!. One of the top attractions in Rome is the Roman Forum that you should go just after visiting the Colosseum. This archeological site is big, so reserve some time and legs to walk around through thousand + old ruins, temples and statues. This is one of my favourite places in rome.You can also make it very quickly and without walking too much, just going trough the easiest ways, that should be enough to have a glimpse of the beauty of that old empire.

A must see in Rome. My wife and I didn't see the forum on our first visit to Rome so it was high on our list of things to see this time. We just did the Rick Steves tour from the guidebook and it was very easy to follow. One interesting thing I noticed that I also saw at Pompeii and Ostia Antica was grooves cut into the pavement stones by hundreds of years of chariot and cart traffic.

A beautiful historical experience. I wanted to have a history lesson live and face to an elegant antic world and the most magnificent panorama of this world. On a sunny and warm May's day, I decided to explore Roman Forum and Palatine Hill.The bought ticket included visits to Forum, Palatine Hill and Colosseum. The stroll through these sites was a pleasant experience. The nice weather and lush nature in spring have been the additional advantages for my beautiful experience.Roman Forum, as the gorgeous center of the ancient world /caput mondo/, included the monuments from two periods of history: Republica and Empire. I had a huge pleasure to discover the following: the Curia (Senate House), the triumphal Arch of Septimus Severine, the temple of Saturn, the basilica Julia, Venera temple, Trajan's terme... The three white columns with the emphasized elegance, that belonged to Castor and Polux temple, impressed me the most. While I walked along the main street of Roman Forum, called Via Sacra /Sacred Way/, I could imagine victorious emperor and generals returning from war paraded over this street.The red flowers, called Oriental poppies, bloomed up inside and around ruins of Roman Forum, created a stunning picture, composed of natural beauty and historical charm. These red flowers spread over Palatine Hill made the most beautiful flowery carpet. Amazing!Today, Roman Forum preserved a field of ruins that honestly tells us a little about Rome's original splendor. Although, it still manages to evoke the splendor of ancient Rome. We could learn how the old Romans had an excellent feeling and skills for organization of the city, the urban plan of its streets and buildings. The Romans have built Forum in order to celebrate Rome. The engineers have searched for urban solutions that will fascinate by its monumentality and magnificent in accordance with the grand Rome empire. This Forum served as model how to build other forums: Cesar's, August's, Trajan's, Vespasian's. Overall, I passed with pleasure through almost 3000 years of history. Dear visitors of Rome, I would like to enjoy discovering this site as I did.

I am indignant with the price that is put for non-European visitors!. Actually, my mood was spoilt by the point that I had to pay double price for the entrance. Talking about the Forum, it was impressive and the views from Palatine Hill are very beautiful.

A unique place. The Roman forum is a very unique experience. It is quite a vast place and takes quite a long time to get around. The ruins are very interesting and it is well worth a visit if you are in Rome

don't miss the Palatine Hill. Well, a traveler will believe that the most important site is Colosseum!For me not! Palatine Hill really traveled me to the past ! Don't miss it and climb to the top to have a unique view of Rome city.You can buy your ticket from the entrance of Palatine Hill or Forum, so you will avoid the long lines outside Colosseum.The price is 12 euros for the 3 sites, but there is no sign to inform you that you can buy your ticket and enter to the sites from wherever you want! So most of the people are just standing at the huge queue outside Colosseum and when they are visiting Palatine and Forum... they realise that they could have enter to the sites from there!!!

Truly Remarkable Place. We visited the forum on a hot September day and we thoroughly enjoyed it. This historic site is unique and while it is a ruin it gives you a very good insight into the center of one of the greatest empires in the world. There is so much to see that we believe a guide is a must, otherwise you will need to plan out your visit carefully. There is not a lot of information on the individual items as a matter of fact the labeling is very poor. While the guides can be very talkative and at times too much was being said, in our opinion it was well worth the money.We found it amazing so ensure you allow plenty of time as. To see the places from the stories around the Roman Empire and Julius Caesar was incredible. You can even see where Julius Caesar was killed.While this place is truly amazing there are some negatives including it can be a little difficult walking (broken/uneven ground), very little shade and generally there are lots of people visiting. We visited the place as part of a Backroads of Italy tour and so the queues were not a problem.My suggestion is to also take sunglasses, a hat and some water.We would happily revisit this place again.

Worth the visit. This is a great practical experience in roman history and archealogy..very informative way to learn about Rome and Vatican.I would recommend taking a tour and a guide also ngwith the underground tour of Coloseum, should be 40-50 euro PP.Do plan a visit at night since the lighting is enchanting...after 9 pm the crowds thin down giving opportunity for some great photos

Magnificent. This site has been well-described elsewhere so I shan't write much. In short, this is must-see attraction in Rome and it's historical significance can't be stressed enough. Furthermore, the views of Rome (including the Colosseum) are wondrous!

It's better to see Roman Forum than Colosseum. From the Palatine Hill and Roman Forum you have great view of the Colosseum and In my opinion seeing those historical sites is much more worthwhile than benches in the Colosseum that everyone queues for. Entering Roman Forum you get a pass for all three sites - and the queue is 4-times shorter.

A must see in Rome but falls short on its lack of information.. I visited today, my fifth or sixth time over a period of 30 years or so. These are incredibly important sites for an experience of ancient Rome, and a 'must see', but there are several features that reduce its accessibility in terms of understanding what it was all about. There is a serious shortage of information on the sites themselves. No audio guides. Occasional sign boards give info on specific parts, unrelated to the overall scenario, and not providing any context. These seem extremely dated. While it is pleasant to be able to wander around at will, this can make it seem like a jumble. A proportion of individual sites were under protective cover, some no doubt in the process of excavation, but again, little or no info on progress. In fact it looks to me as if any work that was underway has now stalled, due to lack of funds. The shortage of signage even extends to finding your way to one of the various exits. (In the meantime, all along one side of the Forum, outside the site itself, 'they' are constructing Line C, the third of Rome's Metro lines. Some of the ancient buildings have jacks propping them up! I bet the decision to build the Line here was very controversial. 83 months work scheduled, which I reckon will mean another 6 years worth approximately). My suggestion is that visitors should either join a guided tour or buy and study a good guide book- oh and know plenty about Roman history before you get there.

takes u back to the ancient times...... the roman forum is a rectangular forum[plaza] surrounded by the ruins of several imp n ancient government buildings at the centre of city of rome.in the ancient city,the citizens used it as a market place.for many centuries it was the centre of roman public life-site of triumphial processions and elections,venue for public speeches,criminal trials and gladiatorial matches and commercial affairs.it was believed to be the most celebrated meeting place in the world n in history.located in the small valley between the palatine n capitol hills,the forum today is a sprawling ruin of architectural fragments n intermittent archeological excavations.numerous structurs n buildings such as the earliest shrines,temples,basilicas n triumphal arches are located here.theres so much history here to see n read that u will be transported to another era.

A Step Back in Time. I always loved learning about ancient Greece, Rome, and Egypt so this was a delightful treat. There are some very interesting buildings on the premises - although some are terribly deteriorated - but none are open to the public. I hope they are able to restore some of these buildings so the public can go inside - just looking in the windows is spectacular. If you're at the colosseum, which if you're in Rome, let's face it, you'll be there, I definitely recommend walking across the street to see this site! FYI - It's included in your colosseum ticket price.

Great for the Government History Fan. The Roman Forum is interesting if you like history of other nations. It's a large complex with much of the buildings on the ground thanks to an earthquake years ago. Do have a guide with you who knows the area well, ours gave us a lot of information. The daily politics of the Roman empire was only done by 300 men but the Romans spread far and wide during their rein. This might be a bit dull for children under the age of 13 unless they are very keen on history.

History come alive. This tour that we took of the roman forum was included with our tour of the coliseum and was very worthwhile. You get to walk where julius caesar walked and was murdered. To see how the people lived back in those days which spans from about 500 bc . Once again this is a place you should read about before you go and have as much information about as you can before you go.

Very disappointing. Our visit was during November, so there was no queue. On the other hand, I wish we would go to there during summer, so I could give up to visit forum area when I see the queues. As soon as I got in, I knew that it was a mistake. There was nothing left to see only half pillars and a lot of broken pieces on the ground.The written descriptions were not enough at all. It is better to view the area from outside without paying €12. The view is a lot better that way.Also the restrooms were poorly maintained and smell horrible.

See it! With a tour is better. I went inside with a group from Around Rome Tours - was one of the best places in Rome to see! Loved having the guide that gave us all the information - I would have been lost in the Roman Forum without a guide because there are not many signs and not much information written at the monuments so I wouldn't have known what I was looking at.A beautiful place to see and highly highly recommended!!!

Must see Palatine Hill & Roman Forum. The ticket also covers the Colosseum. Followed the on-line advice to buy tickets from The Palatine Hill entrance but the experience can only be described as "very unhelpful"! The woman was so "off" it was unbelievable. Wanted to hire an audio set but all she could say was she wanted an ID card, being from UK I didn't have ... so ... no Audio tour! However learnt from The Colosseum (helpful lady) the next day that a credit card was fine. However the Palatine Hill ruins were wonderful, spent ages and finally moved onto The Forum, where an audio set would have been good. Had no time to visit The Colosseum, but the ticket can be used the next day up until 3.30 pm.

Take yourself back in time!. Once in there it's easy to imagine how was the ancient rome. You have to walk through the Roman Forum and the Palantine Hill with a guide because you sure want to hear the story behind all of those buildings. It is very educational and he will fill you up on how the ancient people lived and carried out daily activities. You'll get a better sense of their way of life. Our guide was simply amazing and very entertaining. You realize how great builders the Romans were! It is an amazing feeling to be able to walk along the same places that so many great people that we have learnt about in our history classes did thousands of years ago. When walking around you can feel and see history all around you. The Roman Forum is very big and you'll need a lot of time to explore all the ruins. It was particularly interesting to see where Ceasar was killed. Take your time to visit because it is a must place to visit when in Rome, you will not be disappointed.Don't forget, history is great for the soul.
stunning. never saw anything like this......simply unbelievable Hats of to Italy for marinating this historic monument

Stunning and free on the first Sunday of the month. we visited on the first Sunday of the month and found out that it was free which was a bonus. Get a ticket issued at either the colosseum or the Forum and this gives you access to both monuments. If you already have a ticket issued you can skip the long queues. Once inside you have entered another world, words cannot express the feeling you get when you close your eyes and imagine what Roman life would have been like here. A vast site that could take hours to visit if you have the guided or audio tour. There were some areas undergoing work but this didn't spoil it. There is an alternative entrance/exit near a circus Maximus, this was empty so if you don't want to wait it might be worth wandering down and checking it out.

Fantastic what else can one say. Rome has so many beautiful old historical buildings but in my opinion the Colosseuma and the Romn Forum have to be at the top of a travellers list.Don't bother doing a guided tour.Get yourself a simple guide book/map from WH Smith and enjoy all the sights at your own pace.Most of Rome is better achieved by walking rather than on a crowded noisy bus group.Lots of it is free or moderate price to get in.There is a lack of cafes around the forum so grab a few snacks before you set off.

going back 2000 years.... Loved the Forum...I really think you must have a guide to understand this area..at least getting familiar with the area beforehand is a must. So many period building remains...you walk the walk...just thinking of what this area was like in its day. A few steps from the Colosseum makes it a logical extension from that area. Again, you must experience this area when in Rome.

Great Tour. Francesca was wonderful and very entertaining, her passion and enthusiasm was delightful. Without this tour we would have never known so much about the area and especially the Roman Forum. Great tour and worth every penny!!

Nothing Changed in 30 years. This whole are seems to have gone the way of money greed with entry fees to the Colosseum and Roman Forum. The forum has not been excavated any more than it was 30 years ago, and still looks like a rubble pile in most places. No effort seems to have been made to revitalize the Forum, enhance the tour with artists drawings and explanation stations, or maintenance of the grassed areas.

combined ticket with the colosseum and palatine hill. I know you're not really here to read about my thoughts on the Roman Forum. Sure it was interesting, fascinating, etc. and all that jazz. But let's just cut to the chase. Here are some things you need to know:1. The Roman Forum is A LOT bigger than it looks. That being said, MAKE SURE YOU'RE WEARING THE RIGHT SHOES! It's almost like your hiking. Everything gets really dusty and dirty. Don't be that girl who wore her brand new cute sandals. (an no, thankfully - that girl wasn't me).2. If you bought a ticket to the Colosseum, this (along with Palatine Hill) is included in that one ticket price. I think you have to visit it in the same day you do the Colosseum (but don't quote me on that)3. Tip - if you want a view OF the forum, head to Capitoline Hill, or the Campidoglio (about a two minute walk).4. There. I just saved us both a lot of time :)

Forum takes your breath away. Best visited with the Colosseum (see my other review for this), the Forum is massive and with a bit of imagination you can visualize how the Roman government buildings must have looked like. Signage could be better, but still a magnificent place to visit. Must see...

superb. We booked a skip the line, small tour (us plus one other couple) which included a 3.5 hr tour with a wonderful knowledgable guide (Luca) born and bred in Rome. This included a walk up the forum. Cost was about £70pp, worth every penny. Best part of the holiday. Highly recommend

Building work !. We travelled in November 2014 and was disappointed that this beautiful fountain was under going building work and covered in scaffolding the same with the Spanish steps and collessum ! Maybe one attraction at a time !

Step back in Time. If your a history buff and want to get away from the crowds at the Colosseum then this is a must. Enter near the Colosseum and walk around the side of the hill before entering the Forum and wow. The site is fascinating and to see the old construction before entering the Forum. Before Medieval Europe, with large stone blocks, the Romans were using Bricks and Mortar and the site has stood the test of time. Well worth it.

put the collosseo to shame. I visited the forum and palatine hill before the collosseo as the queue for tickets was huge at collosseo. combined entrance to collosseo, forum and palatine hill was 12 euros. I wish I had done the collosseo first as the collosseo left me disappointed after being fascinated with the forum. I had downloaded rick Steves free audio guide (which I highly recommend) and this served me well. I nearly missed the entrance to the Palatine Hill as the signs are shockingly inadequate for such a magnificent site. You will need to take your time here and explore every nook and cranny. I loved this place, however to people who are interested in this period I would recommend some kind of downloaded guide as this can look like a lot of stones to the Inexperienced eye. A couple of places on the hill are not open to the public (livias house and one other ) which is a great shame. The day before I spent at ercalano and pompeii which is wonderful and access all areas so I left the forum feeling a little cheated, but really I am spoilt this trip! collosseo was a disappointment after the forum. do the collosseo first so it will not be an anticlimax. At the very least do some reading on the subject before going to truly appreciate the site. You can't miss it from metro stop collosseo

Amazing. Visited this on a combined ticket with the Colosseum. The sense of history is overwhelming. Could have spent another three hours there. Don't forget to visit the little museum and examples of ancient housing.

Very awesome part of historical high society!. Walking through the forum and hill with a guide was very educational and played great part filling in how the ancient people lived and carried out daily activities, along with getting a sense of their way of life.

Wish we'd had a tour guide. We enjoyed visiting the forum and the Palatine. It's exciting to walk among the ruins and amiagine what it would have been like in ancient times. My only criticism is that there is very little information on site, and no staff to explain things unless you hire a tour guide. If we were going again we would pay extra for a tour. The Palatine is beautiful and peaceful, with great views of the city. I really wanted to see the frescoes in the houses of Livia and Augustus but we were unable to get in. The House of Livia was closed for some reason, and the House of Augustus has limited opening hours, and we were too late. If we'd known it was closing at 1.30 we would have planned accordingly and got there in time. I think this information needs to be available when you enter the site.

Roman Forum & Palatine Hill, Rome. The Roman Forum & Palatine Hill is another 'must see' on any visit to Rome. What remains today is only a shadow of its former glory but it is still very impressive for the scale of the buildings and the area they cover. Before paying to enter the area it's worth going to one of the viewing points that overlook the area. The ones either side of the Palace Senatorio offer the best vantage point.

Very interesting.. It takes a good hour or two to see everything in here. But if you do visit the admission includes the colosseum which is close by. The place is bigger than it appears. And it's great for those who love history. You can really get a feel for the culture here and the way things were in the past.

more stones. Oh yes.. The Roman Forum and Palatine Hill, you sure want to hear the story behind those buildings, but really it's not that wow factor... I was already tired from visiting the Colosseum, but I hired a guide which explained very well everything inside, and it was amazing... something you should learn about... History's great for the soul.

A must-see in Rome. The entrance fee covers the Colosseum, the Roman Forum, and the Palatine Hill. Word of advice to those considering leaving the Palatine Hill to go to the Colosseum, and then going to the Roman Forum -- don't! The ticket only allows 2 entries -- one for the Colosseum and one for the Palatine Hill/Roman Forum. We learned this the hard way, and ended up buying another ticket so we can check out the Roman Forum --- which was still worth it!

Incredible Ruins. Buy a combo ticket to get entrance to Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. Saves a bundle.To be honest, I couldn't tell you the difference between the Forum and Palatine Hill :-) BUT the ruins in the Roman Forum where spectacular. Well preserved and really quite spectacular.In fact the entire town of Rome is simply full with ruins that are currently being excavated so there is never a shortage to view.However after about an hour I got quite bored to be honest and left.However it is something to behold, and the inclusive ticket price is well worth it. although you can see most of them from teh road, it is quite an experience actually standing directly in front of them. A Tip. TAKE LOTS OF WATER. No where in the entire park was thier running water or a fountain to drink from. Every "guard" we asked said over there, yet the pipe was dry or simply did not exist. VERY annoying as you cant even buy bottled water inside. This ruined the experience for me, and made me quite happy to leave.
Lovely. Lovely views from Paletine hill and the Roman forum has some great artifacts. It is worth a visit if you go to the Colosseum as it is free. It is l.ovely and relaxing.

Roman Forum. It's always hot in the Forum, so walking around is a bit for a trial. Like many other places in Rome this trip, there was a lot of maintenance going on with areas closed off and wrapped in polypropylene drapes. The biggest disappointment was that the Curia was locked.

History Plus. Fantastic sights representing mind-boggling history but for some older people there is a lot of walking and in the Forum in particular the walking surface is very uneven and two of our Globus women fell so care is needed, particularly when tired at the end of the tour.

WHERE IT ALL BEGAN. What an experience to walk just a short distance from the Colosseum to the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. Where it all began so many centuries ago the legendary birthplace of Rome. What great builders they were and how good it is that we can walk along the same path as so many great people that we have learnt about in our history classes .To walk beside the arches of Titus and Constantine, to view the remains of historic temples and mansions the mind can only dream of what went before and the majesty of it all, a beautifull place. It is quite a big site well spread out so a fair bit of walking is involved. A must place to visit when in Rome.

You must visit. The Forum and surroundings encapsulate the history of the development of Rome as a centre of the Christian world. It is surrounded by other important buildings from more recent times which are easily accessed.

A must see in Rome!. This place is connected to the Colosseum. There is so much history of the Roman forum, Palatine Hill and the Colosseum.Great to walk around with a guide or an audio guide to learn the history. The views of the city and surrounding areas are great. Take your time to walk around and soak in the ambience and imagine the scheming that was going on during the Roman Empire.Loved spending time here!

The best part of this area. The Roman Forum is a real historical treat. Once entering under the Arch of Titus, you're filled with pieces of architecture, Latin markings, partial ruins and a great walking path from which you can take your time framing photos. Be aware, this is time-consuming but well worth it.

Amazing reconstruction of architecture.. Get tickets in advance or in combo with the Colosseum. You can easily spend 2-3 hours exploring the forum at your leasure. Amazing to imagine walking in ancient Roman footsteps. For younger kids, highly recommend purchasing the "Rome Reconstructed" book which has photos of what the Colosseum and Forum look like now, along with overlays that show what the area looked like 2000 years ago. Helps the kids see that the area was once more than old ruins. The forum is stroller capable but there are a few stairs and on the Palatine hill side, the cobble stone and gaps make pushing a stroller difficult but doable.

Roman forum, Colosseum Roma, Italy. The place has a collection of old weapons used in the battle field. It is very near to Colosseum another historical place of Rome. At the Roma termini train station, you will get a metro-bus day costing of 6 Euros. From Roma termini you must use the metro trains, Metro line A this train takes you to the Colosseum station. The Colosseum is great building which was once used by the emperor of Roma to punish the prisoners by arranging a game of fight. The Roman forum has a beautiful church where you can see the beautiful paintings inside the church. Also there is a museum inside which has entrance fee. Overall the Rome is very beautiful city to visit.The weather is also good & you can find many visitors from all over the world visiting the city. Also you will find Indian restaurants to enjoy the Indian food at Ottorio Emanuale Metro station .It's worth visiting Roma once in your lifetime.

Place you need to see.. The forum is just ruins but if you are fascinated by Roman history it is a must see. I think we should have got a guide to get the most from it. The best view of all of this area is actually from a balcony on the extension to the Capitoline Museum , a different attraction.

Confusing but wonderful. We had prebooked 2 day combined entrance tickets online and arrived at the Colosseum to collect them. I was very disappointed that we were not given any sort of information or map on a leaflet about the sites. We did the Colosseum on the first day and the Forum and Palatine on the second. When we arrived at the Forum we expected to be given a leaflet there, showing a map of the sites and their names but weren't given anything on admission. I believe this must be different if you buy tickets at the entrance as I saw lots of people with red information leaflets. So we felt a bit "lost" a lot of the time. There are boards around the Forum with information on what was in front of you but the site is huge and if you can't walk the whole site you need some sort of information in advance on which way to go round.As someone with moderate walking difficulties, I found the Forum really hard and would definitely recommend you to start at the top of Palatine Hill and walk down, not the opposite as we did (all uphill and hard work on the uneven ground)

Walking, walking, walking. For me, the Roman Forum was more inspiring than the Colosseum, where I expected this to be the other way around. As you walk through the ruins you truly appreciate that you are walking through a significant part of history. Photo opportunities are plentiful here, so make sure your camera (or phone) is charged and ready to go. Also, don't forget your water bottle as it can get quite hot walking through the ruins. A Rome must-see!

Amazing. The Roman forum was the best place we visited in our whole stay. Only 12 euros to get in and was nearly a whole days worth of things to look at /walk to. Note though if it's hot take water in with you as there is no where to get any once you enter!

Camera required.. My wife and I visited Rome the first week of October. We were fortunate to stay in a hotel a short 5 minute walk to the forum. We visited the forum the first afternoon when we first arrived in Rome. We returned twice, once by ourselves as we walked around the forum and a second time as part of our tour. Each time we would see something "new". This site is a must see. Amazing to see such history.
Amazing. It was amazing to see the Roman Forum where Roman legions marched in triumph. Lot of walking but worth the effort.

Take a day to take it all in - Roman Forum. Worth the visit, the Roman Forum, need to purchase a ticket, is worth the visit. Walk along real roman cobble streets, take in the ruins and the history. With Palatine Hill, it is an all day event. Walk along the pedestrian only main street at night to take in the Roman nights and people. Lots of good restaurants in the area.
Roman Forum. What the archeologists continue to find is amazing. They uncover more every day! So much to see, but go early in the day because it gets very hot.

Great Historical Site. Be sure to reserve a couple of hours to wander through the entire Roman Forum. I recommend going mid afternoon, as the tour bus crowd seems to gather early morning for most of the historical sites.

Epic in scale. We went on a guided tour of the Forum and were blown away by the size. It takes a little imagination to picture the way is was two millennia ago, but there are enough restored ruins to get a feel for it. One word of advice; be careful as you walk. There are some original parts of the roads and many uneven rocks. As we walked, our guide would say, "look up there!" We learned to stop, then look or you could trip. Please, just don't stop dead in your tracks if people are right behind you.

It's one of those things you have to see once in your life. It's a historic treasure. Then again, there are many of this ruins around Rome. However, when you picture yourself in what was the buzzing city center of Rome some centuries ago, it is an image to behold.One tip, take with you one of those books that shows you how the buildings and squares would have looked like in their prime. Imagination only takes you so far, so if you can help yourself with some graphic references, it will make your visit to the Forum and surrounding areas all that much more interesting.

One of My Faves in Ancient Rome. Studied it in architectural school. First experienced it ten years ago, and anxious to go back. So we did!The scale is amazing, but what is really interesting to consider is that most of the structures were actually very tall. You get the impression now that it's open space (OK, it is ... most of the structures are gone!)But think what it was like with those tall structures still in place and with labyrinthine passages running between them.Cool to see the ongoing archaeological efforts at one of the world's most famous digs.The Forum is yet another icon of Rome!Take a few hours to explore and experience it!

A great walk thorugh the Roman Forum. As with the Colosseum, this is spectacular. So easy to close your eyes and try to see how things might have looked all those years ago! We were there just before closing. It was great - not too many people!

Ambition fulfilled. Amazing as expected, massive ruins and excellent pre-booked guide helped bring the place alive. You must pre-book online to avoid the queues. Try ticketitaly.comI could have spent hours there, recommend joint tour with Palatine Gardens and Forum, included in price.

Imagine what it was like.... There is very little left from Caesar's days; very much of the Forum is run down and destroyed. I would have loved to see it back when everything was new with important Roman politicians and common folk walking around. There's really nothing you're allowed to go inside to see either; kind of a must if you're in Rome, but not my highlight.

Ancient History. A great opportunity to wander the archaeological site and see buildings from ancient Rome. Sadly, like many other public places we toured, in a somewhat sad state of repair or disrepair, with litter and trash everywhere. Some ares were closed for repair, while other areas appeared closed because of lack of funding.

Away from the crowds. We found ourselves in the forum at peak time, and the main area between the entrance and the colosseum was crowded and overrun with guided tours - making it difficult to actually enjoy the place. By chance we went up the Palatine walkway, left through the vineyard and out beyond there to the top of the hill. This part was so much quieter, so we were able to enjoy the views over Rome and linger around the ruins. Apart from being brick, rather than marble, there is more to see up here, and we could get to the signs telling us what we were looking at, so did not need a tour guide to help out.

Impressive Ruins (Colosseum & Forum Ticket). As can be seen from the title we gained access to Forum once we had attended a tour of the Colosseum and we were quite glad we did.The forum, although ruins, are still really impressive.
