To consider the buildings and conversations that must have taken place here is interesting and the vastness of the space is awe inspiring.As the Forum is built on a hilly area it allows for some impressive vantage points and places to stop and take some time out of your walking.Also, keep an eye out for the water fountains, the water in Rome is drinkable and must have saved us quite a few euros with all the fountains throughout the city.Beautiful place with a lot of history.

must see. Went to the forum in august 2014 some of the monuments are under repair so you see a lot of scaffolding but thats true off a lot of rome at the moment I would have given more of a rating but there is to much under repair

A little imagination goes a long way. The Forum is one of those sights that is definitely worth seeing. However, the condition of the ancient buildings is poor to non-existent. There is a column or three here, the foundations of a temple there, an important fig tree, grape vine and olive tree that go almost unnoticed. Without a guide of some kind, this place causes only confusion. If you are not "into" ancient history, definitely book a tour. If you are a solo traveller, the cost of the audio tour is well worth it - only 5 euros for the Forum guide; 7 for the one convering both the Forum and the Palatine Hill. Go early - it gets hot!

Worth a visit, but nothing spectacular. OK, the place had to be spectacular 2000 years ago. The problem is that everything here is almost completely destroyed, to the point that it's hard to even recognize anything. This place also does not really do a good job in helping visualizing ancient Rome, and it may quickly get boring (particularly for kids).When visiting Colosseum you'll have the tickets for Forum Romanum anyhow, so take a walk here, but don't really expect anything great. In my opinion e.g. many cities in Turkey have much better ancient Roman remains.

Wow Factor-pay online& get a guide too!!. This place is worth every Euro it's so cheap for an attraction. €12 for 3 attractions and it lasts 2 days so you can come back. I recommend paying online for your tickets as the queues are huge all year round. They have a lot of school trips so this fills the line a lot. You must get a guide. They are totally worth it. Plus you get a little radio thing to listen to them live like a walkie talkie. The rest of the Roman Forum is outstanding too. It's so crazy that all these ruins have lasted thousands of years. In the heat, don't forget it's a long day trip so pack water and snacks & sun tan lotion. Have your camera/ smart phone fully charged for a lot of photos. You have a trigger happy finger because it's so amazing you feel you need to capture every moment.Enjoy an Italian icecream. They are the nicest on the planet!!! They are on every corner for a reason. Mmmm!!!We did a 5 day itinary which I recommend you find because there is so so so much to see and do in Rome you may become bamboozled for sure.

Very interesting!. We only visited the forum, not Palatine hill. We absolutely love Roman ruins, so we loved the Forum. We didn't research it beforehand so that was definitely to our disadvantage.But it was very interesting to walk around and the huge ruins really are spectacular. Rome was definitely our favourite city with ruins around every corner.

It's like taking a step into history!. Wow, it's the Roman Forums! It's surreal, after seeing the Colloseum you walk through the forums and all you can soak in is how you are in the midst of one of the oldest structures in the world and how much has gone down in these forums. All I kept thinking was SPARTTTAACUSSSS! Haha, on a more serious note you really feel a sense of history as you are walking through. You understand more about the Roman life and this is definetely a must see when you are in Rome!

Very interesting, would recommend a tour!. We had no intention of going to the Forum but we were given a free tour as part of our Colloseum deal. We met our tour guide, who was English but spoke fluent Italian and French, outside the Colloseum. We then walked down to the Forum where we began our tour. We found out so much history going back thousands of years, the tour was well worth it and we thoroughly enjoyed every moment. There were so many photo opportunities. I would say though... do the tour don't just walk round because you'll probably not appreciate the Forum for what it was without a well informed guide.
Roman Forum was Excellent. I wish I had spent less time at the Colosseum and more time exploring the Forum as it is just magnificent and charming.

Ah, ancient rome. This is next door to the Colosseum. As we exited the Colosseum, we continued on with the Roman Forum. You do need a ticket, but it's a combination ticket with the Colosseum, so "use it or lose it" kind of deal. It was hot when we were there during the first week of September 2014, so we didn't get to wander off to Palatine Hill. You can do a tour, bring a guidebook, or just walk around on your own. I recommend you wear sturdy walking shoes because those cobbled streets will be a challenge for some. It's "ancient Rome" you're walking through after all. Be prepared for outdoor weather. There is a bathroom (follow the signs). Bring water and munchies if you need to because once you exit, you can't go back in. See if you can find the door to the underworld while you are there.

Better rating due to Private tour.... Had my husband and I not done a Private tour with Veronica from Private tours of Rome, we would have absolutely no idea of what the Roman Forum and Palantine Hill was. On first glimpse it looks like a collection of rubble however through our tour we learnt what everything was or what it was used for. What it was built from and why it was built. Was a good place to visit - Close to the Colloseum and quite interesting if you have information or know the history of it all.Overall a nice place to visit.Handy Hints - it can be very hot so ensure that you cover up wear sunscreen and a hat due to the lack of shade and take plenty of water.- There are pick picketers in the area so be sure to keep your belongings close to you and hold your bags to the front. (They did call it over a P. a few times during our visit however they only said it in Italian so if it weren't for our guide we would not have known)- there is a lot of stairs and from what I remember I don't think this is a very wheelchair accessible area.

where ancient culture born. roman forum is inside the the ancient rome's district that the ancient roman culture was born there and affected the whole world. ruins of different buildings like temples,archs,etc. i liked very much the "sared road" which is the main road in the ancient rome placed exactly in the middle of forum that after a victory in a battle, the vicotorious emporor with his soldiers moved along this road with people in both sides welcome them,as what we saw in movies,and so i was very fond to see it. when walk on it, i thought about the emperors by all their pride,shaking happy hands and blessings to people,put their steps exactly here,which was amazing experience and unforgetable.u can visit roman forum with the ticket of closseum which can be used for 2 days and visit each in a seperate day to avoide tiresome, as we did,and we thanked this facility of 2 day value of tickets very much.enjoy it:)

Fascinating!. Just to tour the outside of the Colosseum is an incredible experience. The sheer size is breathtaking. We were privileged to enter the interior as well. Book online to "skip the line." We had downloaded Rick Steve's audio tour and listened on our iPhones to hear incredible historical facts as we felt the vibes of long ago.

Veryyy Interesting.... Keep your legs strong. Roman Forum is an awesome historical place. I would recommend you guys to take walking tour guide, history just passes by your eyes. Be prepared to walk walk and just walk. You can absolutely use the water from fountains. Carry umbrella, shades and Sunscreen lotion without fail.Roman forum is adjacent to Colosseum . Once you finish walking in Roman forum enter palatine hill. there is nothing much here except for one closed building.

Historical wonder. Beauty of being back in the Roman days of Cesar and the forum. Walking along the streets and looking at all the excavations and historical monuments and fascinated how advance the culture was in Roman Times.

Great history and background. I booked a tour with Dark Rome (now known as City Wonder). The guide, Sara, was informative and enthusiastic with the history. Her passion for the subject is undeniable. It was interesting to find out the history and gossip surrounding the Colosseum but by the time we reached the Roman Empire, a few of the tourists in the group (including myself), stopped listening and walked away as it was getting a little too academic. If you are a history buff, Sara is the guide to ask for. The Colosseum is majestic and breathtaking. If you have visited the Colosseum in Athens, the size of this is one in Rome less impressive.

Outstanding But Have a Tour Guide. Our visit to the Colosseum, Palatine Hill, and Roman Forum made a lasting impression due to having a tour guide with us that was arrange by our landlord. I can only imagine that without a guide we would have walked the entire area, admired the ruins, and gleaned some interesting information. With the guide it was an entertaining and deeply informative experience that could have continued on for ever. Have a tour guide.

The Essence of Power. The Palantine Hill of Rome is an awesome show of wealth and power. This was the seat of the Roman Emperor for several generations and clearly conveys the extent of Roman power and wealth. The ruins are extensive and far exceed even modern seats of power. I strongly recommend that, while in Rome, the Palatine Hill is a must to see.

Visually stunning!. My daughter and I booked a 1/2 day "skip the line" tour and thoroughly enjoyed the very informative tour! Fortunately, there were water fountains so we could refresh our water bottles as it was hot and there was a fair amount of walking. We would highly recommend seeing this.

Amazing history - but be prepared for crowds. As others have said, it's very much worth booking online for this attraction, or if this isn't convenient/possible, get your ticket from the ticket office at the Forum where there isn't a queue (or wasn't when we visited) - this saves you waiting in the very long queue for the Collosseum. The ticket covers all 3 attractions, and is good for two days - if you get tired out or feel you have missed some of it you can come back in the following day.What's to say about these ruins which hasn't already been said? The Collosseum is hugely impressive, and it's striking just how much is left intact. When we visited there was a fascinating exhibition about the development of reading and libraries in the Roman era which we found fascinating and kept us entertained for an hour or so. The Collosseum itself is as you see it in all the pictures, but it is extremely crowded and it's a bit irritating queueing up behind people taking selfies to see the view. I guess that's what it was like when the place was still in use (the crowds, not the selfies!) so perhaps that's appropriate.Crossing the road to the Roman Forum takes you out of the crush of people - there are plenty about, but not so much that you can't relax and enjoy your visit. This is a place that is just steeped in history - a short walk up the hill to where Romulus and Remus were found by a wolf according to the myth reveals the extensive remains of the Imperial Palace - this is where the word "palace" came from. There are information boards in English and Italian which fill in a lot of the gaps. I appreciate this as I'm not great at doing research in advance of this kind of visit, and it's so extensive that I wouldn't remember it anyway, and there's a danger of just looking at a pile of old rocks and walls and not knowing what they are. This is not a problem here, and there is plenty of information available for the casual visitor.Back down the hill there are extensive remains of the Roman Forum itself. Like most excavations and remains in Rome you have to look at all this from behind a fence - it's not like many archaeological sites in Greece and Turkey where you can roam around freely - and rightly so, they've lasted a couple of thousand years but I'm not sure they'd last so well if thousands of tourists could just tramp around.Overall, definitely worth braving the crowds - you can't come to Rome and not visit here.
beautiful. very very busy in peak season. didnt pay to go in but saw enough just walking around it. you feel like you have taken a trip back in time when you see this beaut.

You feel so small. We visited all the sights in Rome, but this was by far the best. Thinking how old this place is, makes you feel so insignificant in the world. Watch out for the "Roman Soldiers" outside trying to fleece you for a photograph. We had one taken with the kids, and they tried to charge 50 Euro. I eventually paid 2 Euro

The place for the strong traveller. It's a really amazing place, just few practical advices. Try to avoid to make the common queue for the tickets. It's really terrible. Go with the group or buy them when there are few people. It's also better to chose not a sunny day to visit it, as the stones make the temperature too hot and it's not possible to be in the shadow all the time. Audio guide is not enough convenient and logic, but the information provided is good.

heart of roman history. Didn't dislike anything. Just a tour to get in or you wait in a long line, to wonderful to describe and make sure you have a camera with a wide angle lens. Take notes for your photos, you won't remember when you get back. But the book, it helps.

Roman Forum, Palatine Hill and Colosseum. The Forum was so spectacular. Very close to great gelato shops and something to see. Palatine Hill is a must do along with the Colosseum. We hired an English speaking guide, I would do that again, well worth the money to know what we were seeing.

awesome places. these three places are must-go places in Rome. To avoid the long line and save your time, you should buy the ticket either in Palatine Hill or Roman Forum. The ticket is 12 eu for 2 days, then you can come back to Colosseo later or the day after!

tour of underground and top tier,stage, skip the lines. we went in August with a `17 year old grandson. Our group of about 20 met above the metro station with a guide named Nick, who told us so many facts about the place and toured with us as a skip the lines to the Palatine Hill area and the Colosseum. An archeologist accompanied us when we had access to the new wood stage, the underground area, and then opened stairs to the top tier, all 3 areas not accessible with a regular admission. Of course not waiting in line to get in the Colosseum saved us a lot of time on a very hot day. So much information shared, we wished we had taken notes or had a tape recorder. Brought the whole era in time to life.

Without them, Rome is not Rome.... Take all your time to visit, it is there since almost 2000 Yrs. the Grandeur of the place worth to be treated like in a Church, Sinagogue, Moske or a temple. Thousands Died to construct, Thousands Died to Amuse and Thousads pass by every day i would say ... to pay HOMAGE, you will love every stone and every alley of it. Thks

You really feel like your in the bustling streets of ancient Rome. The day we planned to go the Forum was closed due to a strike. We went the following day along with all the other tourists. We felt it was especially crowded due to the strike the previous day. We downloaded Rick Steves free audio tour along with the map which is a must. I wish I would have listened to it before and made notes on the map and then walked around at my own leisure. It truly is ancient. It really is pretty cool to be there and walk the streets the ancient people walked. So cool it's still available. Be mindful of the construction. The entrances and exits had changed from our original map. We also walked around the entire perimeter outside the forum and that was pretty awesome as well.

Impressive and worth the visit. For anyone with a love of Art & culture, this site is of utmost importance when visiting Rome. I would say to every traveller that they must visit this on their stay in the city.

Wished we had More Time. As it was quite hot in the afternoon, didnt have a problem with queues and got our tickets quite easily.Its an amazing experienceTo imagine that they built structures like these with none of the engineering equipment available today, is amazing.The only irritant being loads of ignorant tourists who continue to defy rules and stand on the pedestals, damaging years of history!!We didn't have time to do Palatine Hill..
It was worth visiting. I enjoyed the history and in particular the walk around Circo Maximo. Easy to reach on foot from my hotel at Trevi
tired legs. the palatine hill - a fabulous site but verrry tiring on the feet, almost too much to take in, needs more information boards though.

Fantastic -- Advice -- Buy Tickets in Advance. there is nothing NOT to like. It's beautiful. Wear comfortable shoes and bring water. Also, it is super important to purchase tickets in advance. It makes it so much simpler. No lines, no waiting. You just turn in your vouchers the day you have reserved for your tickets and in you go. There were long lines to purchase tickets and my group was very thankful that I had purchased our tickets in advance.

Colosseum. This is a must see but try and go very early in the morning during the summer months, otherwise it is brutally hot and takes away from the experience. Lots so walking but this historical site is something anyone visiting Rome must see.

Submersed in ancient Rome. Bring your best walking shoes, and stroll this fantastic area, making sure you get well into the remote areas of the Palatine Hill, where, at some point, you should feel that you are part of the ancient city. From the Palatine walk, you'll also get an unusual view of the Colosseum, and a feel for how it positioned in the evolution of the area.TIP: There are water filling stations around Palatine where you may refill your water bottles.

book your tickets online. was great, we wanted to take an audio tour but couldn't as in order to get the audio gadget you had to leave some form of ID which we didnt have.get there early in the morning as it get busy very
Amazing sights. I was amazed as to how well the structures were built considering the time in which they were constructed. It is nice to see Italy working hard to preserve these structures.
Worth a visit. We have been to the colosseum before but not the forum and palatine hill which are fabulous - very hot and open so take water and a hat!

Noise. Having been to the Roman forum 10 years ago,we were interested in seeing the more recent excavations. The area is jammed packed with Ancient History is very interesting to walk about and absorb. We were, however, very disappointed to find that huge helicopters were allowed to hover overhead. This made the experience unpleasant. The noise was such that we were unable to hear when the area was being closed for the evening and therefore were reprimanded when we arrived at the gate! The Italian gentleman just gave us the usual Italian shrug when we queried why this is allowed to occur. A great shame!

Roman History & the Empire. It's a few years since we went to Rome but one of the lasting highlights was a visit to the forum where visiting American history students gave free guided tours of the Forum and the Colosseum. Their comments and details helped to bring to life the fabulous history of the Roman Empire which was governed from the Forum and was, effectively, the capital of the civilised world. The architecture and design were still evident and showed the tremendous imagination of the ancient Romans as well as their flair for organisation and government even though they were, apparently, brutally ruthless. They didn't have air travel and yet they reached far-flung lands with armies equipped and trained to win battles and to impose Roman laws. No-emails or telephones to aid communication and yet they succeeded wherever they went with the backing of government centred in the Forum. A really historic world site.

Go to forum first!. The Forum is on same side of street just past the Colloseum (all the ruins down below street level). There you can pay €12 for the Colloseum, forum, & Palentine hill entetance. If u want to wait in line at Colloseum (1-2 hours) you will pay the same price (€12) but just for there. Skip the line and go to forum first! Lots of ruins and much ground to cover at the forum, but everything is well worth that entry fee. People will try to sell "guided tours" outside of both attractions for €30 or more. So you can do it on your own or pay over twice as much to go with a big your group. Definitely worth €12 for all three!

Breathtaking!. I had forgotten the size and scope of the Colosseum, had goosebumps thinking of the history. Only bad part of the visit: the ticket-seller demanding to have proof that one of the boys I was with was actually 15 instead of 19 (difference in ticket price; boy in question was thrilled however)
Do not hesitate worthwhile. If you are at Rome on first Sunday of the month it has free entrance. From the basics of a visit to Rome.

Go to the Roman Forum first before Colosseum. If you are planning a visit to both sites... take a massive hint.. get your tickets from the Roman Forum Booths. The line only took us around 20 minutes to get and best of all, its valid for 2 DAYS. We found that you could easily spend a whole day at the Roman Forum.. with plenty to see and fantastic photos of the Colosseum. We were offered the Rome 3 day pass.. but for value for money.. this ticket was far better. Not only could you enjoy your day at the Roman Forum, it was an amazing feeling when you could by-pass a queue for 4 hours for the Colosseum the following day. You've been warned ;)
I was more informed n my second visit !!. I read a lot before I go to a site and this whole area fills my imagination altho the Colosseum is very crowded, it is worth the wait.

Unique. A Fantastic building back in the history. The waitinglines are in the evening very okay! And you can use your tickets for the next day also for the Palatine part or vice versa for the ColosseumGreat place!

Must-see, very beautiful place and great view to Colloseum (for pics also). Amazing views and sceneries, monumental buildings, history in the air. This is what you really expect from Rome!What is also great is the view to Colloseum from a special area. Better come in the 2nd half of the day, we have been there at about 5 pm and there was nobody, so we had a possibility to take nice pics :)

School trip. I have been in Rome in 2011 in September from school. That was lovely trip. Even if Coloseum is just a part of town, between buildings, it was very interesting to discover more about it. What is not really agreable, are the street sellers whose are really annoying, they are doing it illegally, so ignore them. And one more thing shocked me, There was a man in Roman costume whitch you can take photo. After 5 photos he was asking 5 € from me !!! Unbelievable. But despite this, I love Coloseum very much and I would like to return there one more time.

Highlight of Rome. To think of what the coliseum meant to Rome, Italy and humanity is an awe inspiring reflection of what man is capable of and how far we have progressed. To stand in the very centre of this, the same spots where so many of these events occurred (and to see actual historical items from that very time preserved and displayed) is a privilege of the highest magnitude
Wow!. Those places were amazing. Lots of history! Don't regret my visit!It's a place you really need to see when you go in Rome for the first time!
Great part of History. It is amzing to see History so close to you. You can hear the sounds of romans and the battles there it is impressive.
favourite excursion. tour guide so exceptional for the entire tour. went out of her way to communicate with all ages and did extra for our teenagers.

Better things to do while in Rome. I love history. I love Roman history. I took 3 years of Latin in high school and liked it. But for my time and money, there are better things to do when visiting Rome. My take on the Roman Forum & the Palatine Hill is: Read the books & look at the photos. The effort of seeing these things in person is not rewarded with a "wow, this is great and so much better than the pictures!" moment. I first visited the Roman Forum 15 years ago and was underwhelmed then. In May 2014 we visited Rome again and I thought I'd give it another try. But I have no desire to return. Part of the problem this time was the signage and routing was inadequate and confusing. We met other tourists who shared similar experiences there. Better uses of limited time in Rome include the Pantheon, St Peters & the Vatican Museum, the Borghese, and the list goes on.
Step Back in Time. Loved it all. We also managed to do it for free as the first Sunday of the month is free. Didn't know this when we chose which day to visit so it came as a nice suprise.

Colosseum Underground Tour. For €9 the underground and 3rd level tour was very good value for money. Our guide was knowledgeable and approachable and took us to areas that it would be difficult to enter.We visited on the first Sunday of the month which allows free entry to the Colosseum (we were refunded our Colosseum entry but still had to pay for the tour) and were glad that we had booked the days first English tour as the Colosseum became very crowded.
Great guide!. Spend the money to book a guided tour. We used Real Rome Tours. Realrometours.com. Very professional and we loved the small group tour we booked.

Great experience with rich history!. We really enjoyed our tour of the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Forum! We ran into an english speaking guide before we got to the line. Very glad we did. We were in a ground of around 10 people, and paid about €30 each. We skipped the line (which was extremely long), and our guides were very knowledgable. We went in the afternoon, but would recommend going as early as possible to miss most of the queues and people. In saying that, it was crowded but not too overbearing. Tours weren't too long and are recommended for background knowledge. Very sad to hear the Vatican is to blame for the ruins… If you get a guide they will tell you more. Highly recommend a tour of the Colosseum :-)

worthing seeing - insight to ancient Rome. Walk through here with a guide and learn about the history of ancient Rome. Definitely have a guide. We saw several people that had no idea what they were seeing and were guessing (wrongly)

A must visit when you are in Rome. We figured out the best way to visit the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. Use the entrance on Via di San Gregorio for the Palantine. This cost us 12 Euros each and there were no crowds or line up. There is a bit of uphill climbing here as your visit the ruins but it is mostly downhill which leads you to the Roman Forum and the Via Sacra. If you enter the Roman Forum first by using the entrance on Via dei Foro Imperiali, you have a lot of uphill walking to do into the Palantine Hill. So it depends on how tired you are the time. Remember, this ticket is now good for entering the Colosseum which we did the next day. You avoid all the crowds and line ups at the Colosseum with this ticket and avoid everyone trying to buy their ticket to enter the Colosseum. It took us about 5 minutes to get into the Colosseum this way. So in order, to avoid line ups and depending how tired you are, do the Palantine Hill, followed by the Roman Forum and then the Colosseum. All wonderfully historic of course so do some reading ahead of time so you know what you are looking at in each area.
Hot!. It was August, it was hot, but oh so impressive!The Carabinieri are also hot (in their lovely little Porsche), but gosh don't they know it!

Go for the last hour to avoid the queues. We went to the Colosseum about 6pm to avoid the long queues. the down side is that you can't join a guided tour or have an audio guide but the fact that everything is much quieter and cooler really makes up for that. I would certainly recommend that to families to avoid the long hot queues as small children will still get the feel of the enormity of the place and be less easily lost!
No less than fabulous. If you're a history lover, you'll love it. We were in awe. Take in a walking tour. Well worth it with fabulous photo ops!

Disorganised - No Audio Guides or Information. We entered here in the afternoon through the Forum entrance with prepaid on the Archeologia Card and there were no Audio Guide available for anyone. We later found out that the only place to get an Audio Guide is at the Palatine entrance by the Aqueduct. Without an Audio Guide it was difficult to know what you were looking at, there was a surprising lack of information. We decided that it would be best to visit the Palatine Museum first but it was closed and covered in scaffolding and would be until end of September 2014, we were not informed about this closure until we got to the door.The Palatine Hill and Forum are impressive but we felt that we had only touched on the wonder of these ruins due to the lack of information.

Historical Rome a must. Those who came for the history of Rome. Needs to see this.Great places, nice vieuws, and a lot of history !.Just needs good shoes and water( can be hot in summer, pottable water is available in kind of fontains)

Awesome tour. Very crowded but if you have booked with an organized tour company you are in for a treat. So much history and stories that kept us captivated to our guide's every word. Worth every cent and best of all we could just enter with our guide, no time wasted on queuing.

Top Tip to beat the queues!. On arrival to Rome we headed straight for the Colosseum. We got there to see a huge queue of hundreds of people waiting to buy tickets. We were prepared to queue before we were made aware that even once we got into the colosseum the queue ran 11 columns long around the building. We then decided against it and agreed we would come back the following morning nice and early to beat the queue. We then headed to the Roman Forum, opposite the colosseum and were pleasantly surprised to find that our ticket for that also allowed us entry to the colosseum at no extra cost. It is €12 and is valid for 2 days. We walked around the Roman Forum and Pallantine Hill and went back to the colosseum the next day, skipping everyone in the queue to head straight in without queueing for more than 30 seconds. I can not recommend this enough. Do no queue for a ticket- head to the Roman Forum and buy your ticket there and walk straight on in... And feel so glad you are not queueing for hours in the sun (just like we almost did!)!!

a MUST see - all three!. For starters, make sure to go to the Palatine Hill and get your ticket for all 3 sights. It will save you hours of waiting in line at the Colosseum, no joke. Then start wherever you want and enjoy! All three sights have amazing history and significance. We didn't have a guide and didn't need one. There is plenty to read and do on your own, and you can always catch up with a book later.

So Much Better Than Expected. I am not into history at all, but I cannot tell you how much I enjoyed seeing these locations. The architechture is incredible! I want to do research on everything in Rome now.
too much tourists!!!. Place is wonderful but there are a lot of tourists and it was crowded. Italian must do more signs for entrance and divide groups to go inside.

Awesome. If you get a chance - book the tour of the hypogeum (bottom) and 3rd tier of the Colosseum. It's fantastic.The ticket lets you wander the rest at leisure and also gets you in to Palatine Hill and Roman Forum.The other tip - give yourself plenty of time at Palatino and the Forum - you need a minimum of 2 hours.It is all amazing.

Truely the greatest architectural and engineering skills of the Roman Empire!!. The greatest amphitheatre... Made of concrete and stones and some huge stone slabs making the roof kept in place only by other smaller stone slabs... that was wow!!Everyone who visits Rome must visit it. **Take a guided tour. Its worth it to know the history of Colosseum.** The ticket line is always huge. Prebooking can be done. Another idea which we used is to stand in line of Roman Forum which is usually smaller and try finding an official guy searching for guided tour candidates. You can thus skip the line and then buy a ticket valid for both Roman Forum and Colosseum.

Download an audio guide!. This was one of our favourite sights in Rome, but it wouldn't have been half as interesting without the audio tour. We downloaded Rick Steves' Europe Audio Guide App on our phone and within the app, downloaded the audio tour for the Colosseum and Roman Forum and both were really good! You can use your phone in airplane mode to listen to it once you have it downloaded. We heard it is better than the audio guides available there, plus you don't have to wait in a lineup for them!

Be prepared!. Make sure you book your tickets online before you go! I cannot stress this point enough!! There's no need to book a specific date and the tickets last you for 2 days so take your time and see it all. Of course the Colosseum is going to be busy so be patient when walking about. Bear in mind that all three of these attractions are mostly outdoors so wear sensible shoes and be cautious if the weather is very warm.

You have to go. We booked tickets online before we arrived in Rome with New Globus. It had 11.30am on the voucher and the instruction to arrive 15 minutes before this to collect our tickets. We eventually found out that there was no point at all in booking beforehand. We joined a huge queue at Palatine for reserved tickets in the raging mid day sun. We endured the queue for an hour and had to put up with the annoying illegal vendors trying to sell you things to find our ticket was not timed. When we saw the queue to actually get in to the colloseum we decided not to join it. Fortunately the ticket was valid for two days and we returned the next day at 5pm and walked straight in. We wouldn't recommend buying tickets online and paying a booking fee but turn up very early or at the end of the day instead. That said, the colloseum itself is amazing. It is currently being renovated so the outside is covered with scaffolding but inside you can still experience the age of the structure and learn about the events held here. You have to visit when in Rome.

Layer, Upon Layer of History. few places in the world compare to this location. You can see Greek, Roman, Medival, and modern structures clambering for visibility in this historical setting. So much history, so little time! One should truly spend at least 2-3 days to really appreciate all that this area has to offer. There was so much architecture to see with such eclectic history and origin that you MUST do this area with a guide!We spend three hours one morning between these sites with a guided tour which I would highly recommend (Real Roman Tour). Without a tour you don't get access into some of the great locations in the Colosseum, and you miss out on some of the history behind the Palatine Hill and Roman Forum. Sure you can find lots of the information in a guide book, but you'd likely to have to carry 3 guidebooks, plus a Rick Steves tour to get the same amount of detail in the same amount of time. The extra money was well spent, just to get into the underground of the Colosseum was worth every additional Euro spent!!Bring a water bottle, sunscreen, and comfortable walking shoes. You spend all your time on your feet, and walking on the uneven cobblestones can take a quick toll on you if you are not prepared.
Vast. Much bigger than expected. It is a most awe inspiring place to marvel at Rome's ancient history. There is ruin upon ruin at every turn. A must see when visiting Rome.

There's only one colosseum. The colosseum is a must. It will take all day. Choose a nice one but not too hot. Reserve your tickets with the colosseum itself, not through an agent. Its bigger then the one depicted on the TV or in the films. It is a fantastic place. The queues are horrendous, so please reserve them. And take your time to look around. It's great.

The queue is terribly managed. We were queuing for a very long time, outside under the sun and inside under the shade. When we're halfway to the front, some officer came to us and say "TWO QUEUES TWO QUEUES". We initially thought he meant only 2 person in the queue, so we moved accordingly. But he went behind us and repeated this, and people from the back rushed forward, cutting our queues and reach the other counter faster than us. Many of us in the queue were flabbergasted at this style of queuing.Other than that, the architecture itself was majestic, though there are visible signs of maintenance work.

Landmark..... When in Rome where else would you go. A must see even if you just pass by from the outside. This is a monument built such a long time ago , when you stand in its presence you ask yourself, how did they do this , how many people built this, how much longer will it be here,....

These tips enhanced our experience. First, we started with the Forum area and bought our combined tickets to the three sites at the Palatine Hill entrance. At 930am there were three people in the queue...wonderful. We had downloaded the Rick Steves audio guide for the area (and maps) and we were so glad we did. Each of us had this audio on our phones and we were able to chat and sort of "half listen" and discuss things that interested us. Without some type of guide, we would have missed so much of the history and stories. We took lots of photos and really enjoyed the Forum area. There are a couple of public fountains (really more of a hose) located within the gates, so bring your water bottles and continually keep them full. It has been very warm in Rome recently. We spent about two hours in the Forum area and then headed to the Colosseum. This is an extremely busy area with vendors and tour groups. I had purchased our underground and third ring tickets by calling Italy about three weeks prior to our arrival. Call during operating hours and when you get the first recording in Italian, hit 0. This should take you to another recording and then you will be put on the hold queue. It was maybe 2-3 minutes before someone came on the line. I immediatley said "English, please" and she switched to speaking English. After that, we did have to repeat a few things, but were able to get the tickets and before I hung up I already had the email confirmation in my inbox. When we arrived at the Colosseum, we went to the head of the line and the security person directed us which queue to follow. We had to go inside and find the "online ticket" line and waited maybe 5 minutes to get out tickets. We were told the number of our "meeting area" and those are a bit further down the hall....passed the restrooms. We had about an hour before our tour to explore on our own. Then, we went and met our group. Our guide had a microphone and we each had an audio phone. But, mostly we could just listen to her without it. Definitely do this tour. Getting to go into the areas not accessible without the tour was amazing. There are a lot of stairs, so not great for the really young or anyone unsteady with a lot of walking. There is also a water hose inside the Colosseum and the line was never more than about 8-10 people while we were there in the hottest part of the day.
Great Day. This would take about a day as there is so much to see.. Took my 12 year old son and he thought it was great.This is a must when in Rome.

Lions! Tigers! and Bears! Oh my!. This is a great tour if you want to hear about the entertainment of the romans. Its a little gory. It sucked if you were condemned person in those times, because you were about to be entertainment for the masses….and dinner for some animal… The history is rich of how the roman empire was run and the city was not easy to get around…then or now…Maybe the terrain was a little more flat and even?

Lots of Walking. If you are not interested and walking a lot don't do it. One guy even passed out from heat exhaustion. Very interesting overall and some good views of the Colosseum at varied heights. Lots of old churches and history. Must have a good guide to really soak it in.
Amazingly breathtaking. This historic site is beautiful and breathtaking!! I absolutely loved Rome and will go again and again! This is a must-see!!

watch out for touts. An amazing structure once you go round away from the scaffolding etc. Outside encircled by tour sales & vendors so be savvy and haggle the italian way and you will get savings.Be prepared to queue but once inside it is amazing and well worth going back at night when it becomes even more spectacular
Finally been.. Have wanted to see this ever since watching Bruce Lee fight Chuck Norris. Wasn't disappointed. The place beggars belief in its construction and history.

A "must-see" on your visit. Even though I have studied the Ancient Romans since I was a kid I was still taken aback by the scale of the buildings. The remains of the Basilica of Maxentius still tower over everything around and to be in amongst such history is incredible. The Curia (where the Senate sat) is still intact.It is worth having a guide as even knowing the layout it can be difficult to pick out the ruins from each other. Guides can be found on the Via dei Fori Imperiali. Another benefit of having a guide is that you bypass the queues to enter the sites. Not so important for us when we visited the Forum (August 2014) but the lines at the Coliseum were long and we were thankful we didn't have to wait in them. Our 2 hour tour of The Forum and Coliseum was €35 per adult and included the tickets for the Forum and Coliseum.

Beware Traveller. Ok, I didn't go in but was shocked at the amount of peddlers who constantly harass you to buy their wares on the outside. The site is policed by officers who are simply ineffectual and it is just tokenism. They will try to sell you Frozen waterSunglassesHatsUmbrellasThere are also Roman soldiers who will get you to take your picture with them at 10 euros a photo, most of them are quite muscular and probably not best messed with. Inside the Colosseum you are not safe as the peddlers climb the fences and try to pester you through the bars I saw this from the outside.Your ticket will costs approx 12 euros with a long queue or you can use an official guide which will cost you the same amount ontop again. It seems wherever you go someone wants your euro's
Fabulous. Went back twice. First on a tour to learn all about the history. Second time to take time to look around.

Very educational and interesting.... Not a huge history buff, yet traveling to Rome I had to visit the Colosseum and take in the architecture and ruins. Left wondering about all those who were used to build and entertain here, the slaves, animals, the various walks of life living in those times, etc. A real eye opener and thought provoking excursion that I was delighted with. Glad to have ventured out to see what there was and learn much more than I thought I was interested in.

The Roman Ruins are too Metropolitan. We were duly impressed with the size, scope and structure of the Roman ruins. What was lacking was the ability to meld into the world of the ancient Romans. Due to no fault of anyone, the ruins are embedded in a large, bustling metropolitan city; this takes away from the enchantment.
Tour. Pay the extra and get a tour guide, you learn quite a lot from the guides, and you can skip the lines. We normally don't do tours but its a must in Rome.
Colosseum. Well-worth the trip to the Colosseum & surrounding historical sites. Would recommend arriving early to avoid the long lines waiting to get in.

"History". All three are musts to be seen when one is in Rome, because there is so much history about it. One is immediately in a different world when one is walking along these ancient stones. Make sure that you protect yourself in summer against the sun, because it can be very hot. Best time to go: early in the morning or late in the afternoon.

So unique. The Colosseum is one of the most unique landmarks in the world. We jumped on a " Walking Tours of Italy" tour and loved being taken to the underground area of the colosseum. It was a highlight of our time in Rome

A must do even once.. Free on Sundays but busy. Great to see the real life construction which is far more solid and larger than I expected. Optional tickets to go to upper levels to the underground. A few parts are being restored to how it was in Roman times. Queues mid week were pretty good compared to other sites. Suggest go early then onto the forum.

A wonderful day out!. I have always wanted to visit the Colosseum and I got the chance in early January with a group of friends. We had so much fun taking photos and exploring. There was so much to see and do and it kept us entertained for an entire day. As we went at such a quiet time of year we didnt go for a guided tour and we are glad! Once we queued for around 5-10 mins (not long at all!) we got some of the headsets that you can purchase, they were helpful but only if you get ones that work! Half of our groups didnt function properly, however we did recieve a refund for those ones, so not a problem! The headsets kept us entertained for quite a while giving us lots of information and helping us explore the whole area. After this we walked back around and took more photos on the inside. I also bought a beautiful braclet from the gift shop which I was delighted was only about 4 euros! Highly recommended, a must see!!!

Fabulous Roman History at every turn.. The Forum/Palatine is simply superb, but as in all ancient monuments it is a work in progress to allow apprpriate modern access to unique history. Step back two thousand years- there is a gem at every turn, take good footwear.

Long tour. We found that a three and a half tour was too long. Palatine hill and the roman forum were a bit boring especially in the heat. The colosseum was interesting but our tour guide talked to much about very little. Overall it was just ok

Amazing!. Definitely worth the visit! The colosseum is amazing and from the inside you can really imagine the ancient fights and people that wanders around here. Roman Forum and Palatine Hill are next to the Colosseum, also nice to see.
Get a Reservation. A reservation for the guided tour will save you a lot of time from the crowds of spontaneous tour gazers.
A must do visit.. Lots of tourists but still a must see. Walking around the are outside Colosseum also gives a good view of ancient Rome
use italy with us!. theres a tour company called italy with us. use it. you wont regret it. if jot for the great guides and small groups. than sinply for the skip the line quick access
Amazing. Historically stunning and amazing. We did not have reservations and waited 2 hours to get in. BUY AHEAD. Splurge and get the skip the line tickets.
Great. Fantastic, but get a tour as you push the queue which is LONG!!! Not much shade when it gets hot! Definitely worth it

Beautiful park-like setting. Quiet setting for some of the most famous archeological treasures in the world. Have to admit that there are a lot of fly-by-night water and hat schillers working the sidewalks I could have done without.

Colosseum Exceeds Expectations. This is a must do if you are going to Rome. It did not disappoint. I URGE you to take the tour of the arena and Palatine Hill and Forum. (We did it through tickitaly). Our guide was excellent and gave us a ton of background. The colosseum is truly a wonder. WATCH OUT for any of the so-called Roman Soldiers lurking around. They want to take a photo with you and make it seem its free. They are thieves and hustlers and all they want is money. STAY CLEAR. (Same for the flower hustlers)

Amazing history, great views, well worth it! Buy a ROMA PASS.. We travelled to Rome in mid August and it was the perfect weather, nice and sunny, warm but with a breeze - the perfect weather for a long day out at the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum. Do yourself a favour and buy a ROMA PASS! You can get them at most train stations, mini newsagents and also online. You can find the details at http://www.romapass.it and it should be around $36. It saved us HOURS in the line and plenty of money. You walk straight in, it gets you into Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum as well as unlimited transport services within the 48 hours and discounted entry to plenty more places. It took us about 2hours to walk our way through the Colosseum and we bought an audio tour for $5euro once inside, which lets you play information at certain points and take your time. It was fantastic. Do not fall into the trap of buying the tours from randoms outside for $25 euros, so not worth it and the Audiotour tells you all the same details. BUY WATER OUTSIDE! There is none inside, only water fountains from the wall which you can drink but without a bottle and long lines, buying outside is better. It's fine to buy water from the men walking around saying 'water, $1 euro, ice $1 euro', they look suspect but its fine and heaps cheaper than that set up stalls for $5 euros. Set aside a good 4-6 hours to cover the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum and do it around 3pm to catch the perfect sunlight for shots. AMAZING.

You know you have to do it, and it is worth it if you plan ahead. Of course, you need to see the Colosseum. It is one of the best preserved structures from that period in the city. And the combined ticket for the three sites is a fantastic deal. If you are traveling with impatient kids, you will make yourselves MISERABLE if you go straight to the Colosseum for your tickets and wait in the impossibly long line. Forget that. Go to the Palatine Hill entrance (not Roman Forum, which also backs up) by late morning, and you will be able to purchase your combo ticket with little to no waiting. Tour Palatine Hill and Roman Forum on the day you purchase. Bring some water--it can be really hot with little shade. Then, use your same ticket THE NEXT MORNING at Colosseum. You'll beat the crowds in the door, skip the line, and enjoy the amazing space. There is not much signage or interpretative guidance, so read your tour book and download an audio tour for your phone or ipod. It is a very impressive structure, one that will awe even the seasoned tourist. With a little advance planning, you can survive it and will be glad you went.

Walked through history. You literally walk through history. Get a good guide, it makes the visit much more special and meaningful to understand what it is, what The Roman Empire was about and hear the history and facts.Lucky to have seen some of these ruins. Very interesting.

This is a place I would like to stroll through again. This is worth it's price in admission, not only for its many interesting historical pieces but for the sheer value of strolling around this huge park and enjoying Rome.

Roman Forum. My favorite place in Rome is the Roman Forum. To look up at these structures built so many years ago, is breathtaking. It is visited by so many travelers and it is wonderful to see the international flair amongst the tourists. Palatine Hill is very pretty too-just imagine living there.

Veni, Vidi, Vici. Make sure you allocate a full day to exploring the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum - there is so much to see. Let your mind wander back in time, imagining how these incredible structures used to house so many Romans.One final thing, avoid the long queues in the colosseum by buying the ticket skip the line ticket from the tour buses, or at the entrance to Palatine Hill.

Half covered for renovations in Aug 2014. Without derogating from the captivating beauty of this landmark, if you are travelling now please note:1. The place is half covered on the outside for renovations.2. Lines are about 2 hours long in a blazing heat of 36 dgrees. Invest in a VIP ticket to skip the lines!

Wonderful historical place!. I loved the whole area was just like a blast from the past. The colosseum is mighty and huge. There were spots under renovation, so the view is somehow incomplete. But, even with the renovation we managed to enjoy the place and took lovely photos. A must while you're in Rome.
Must see attraction. Go early and use your Roma pass to skip the queues - the Colosseum is brilliant. We did the audio tour and it was great - would go back again.

History = Colosseum. You cannot visit Rome without seeing the Colosseum. It is one of a kind and the history is incredible. It's great that you can see the inside, you can just about feel what ancient spectators must have felt. We were there during the summer and it was very crowded, still we thoroughly enjoyed it....

Historical. Amazing, historical place. Can only imagine life in the roman times!
Loved, loved, loved the Colosseum.
Promised 12 people, about 70 people at the end. We were told only 12 people will be in the tour. Afternoon Palatine Hill, Roman Forum tour had 70 people with no headphone nor microphone. Go figure :(
Not to be missed. Take your time and soak in the history of this area. Simply amazing. The tour of the Colosseum is well worth the time. What an amazing structure that has stood the test of time.
Amazing, cannot miss it!. Make sure to book a tour with an agency if you go in the summer, otherwise lines in the heat can take forever

Awe inspiring. What an amazing piece of history. You really have to see the colosseum in person to appreciate it and take it all in. Make sure you avoid the hundreds of people trying to sell you everything they can think of and don't queue in the colosseum for your ticket. Either buy it online or get it from one of the other attractions locally as you can skip the 1 hour wait this way!

Take a guided tour, well worth the extra $$. We started out at the Colosseum. Our tour included some closed off areas that the general public was not allowed in to. This was well worth the money. We go to go to the under belly of the beast and also to the very top. Great views of the Forum and Constantine's Arch.Forum is great to stroll through, Palantine Hill is cool for the history. But, after a while it's just a lot of broken stuff. Was great to see and check off the list. Still a must see in Rome.

Rome at its best.. Fantastic .. It's just like stepping back in history. There is nothing here to dislike. Nearest metro station is the colosseum. Costs 1.50 euros to travel the net work for 100 minutes.. Such good value.

Good Handicapped Access. How wonderful that there is an elevator at the Colosseum that allows for easier than expected access. There was a very short wait for the elevator. What can I add other than to say how privileged I felt to be somewhere with so much history. The Palatine Hill and Roman Forum provided less access but I enjoyed doing some people watching while my family explored these areas. They enjoyed their experiences. I can't imagine being in Rome and missing this.

Just some tips really.... I have visited Colosseum before but this time with two kids so I was more aware of the logistics etc.We visited pretty much at peak August and around midday. There are two obvious ways of doing this and the temptation for jumping the queue and joining a guided tour is obvious. The queue looks short from the outside but it winds its way inside too and likely takes at least an hour to an hour and a half. This was you can purchase adult tickets for 12euro each and kids under 18 are free. If you go guided you walk in but you pay on top of this 13euro ish for the guide, per person. I really dont see that is worth doing as the audio guides are 5euro and give you very specific and in depth guidance at your own pace.The place is worth seeing and if your kids have a specific interest in Rome from school or films like Gladiator it helps too. Overall you can probably get much of the spectacle from wandering the perimetre without paying a penny but its a nice place to have been inside and learned more about. I'd join the queue and get it over with.

To Walk Along the Paths of History.... Wow. This is kind of mind blowing to see. Rome was based on guts, intelligence, military might, law, and architecture. If you doubt the architecture part of it, go see the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. The technological breakthrough of the arch made so much possible-- domes, arches, more. The Colosseum was once composed of three rings of arches. The Triumphant Arches along the Apian Way pronounce military victor from ages past. The Basilica of the Forum with its arches was where the Romans went for law, news, and more. It is almost incomprehensible to walk amongst these ruins and not been impressed that the Colosseum was built in 8 years. Sagrada Familia in Barcelona has been under construction for a hundred years. The Apian Way is in better shape than many roads in Detroit in the US. I would recommend to anyone going to this historical sight to go with a guide so that you know what each of the areas actually was. Also take a water bottle.

A must see. A must see for Rome.We arrived at 10:40am and began queuing at the Collosseum. We didn't get in until 12:40, so make sure that you arrive earlier! The Italian's don't seem to have any rules about queuing, so people tend to push in and create their own rules! Get there early!!!There is a fair bit of walking involved for Palatine Hill and the Forum so make sure you wear comfortable shoes. Tip - Visit during the day but make sure you check it out at night as well. Lit up, the collosseum is beautiful!

History at its best. you can't imagine the number of monuments close at hand, colosseum, Roman forum & lots of temples.well organized, the only draw back is the crowd and the weather, try to visit it during winter, not summer.
Amazing. Breath taking and do the full guided tour including lower and upper levels you will not regret it. I was not disappointed and very little scaffold time we visited.

Amazing!!. Colosseum is well woth a visit! Tip: If you have a Roma pass you will automatically skip the line for entry to the Colosseum and many other attractions and museums. In this way will even put you ahead of tickets purchased online.

go and see. it is a must see in rome but be aware! buy the tickets online. spend some more euros to avoid enormous queueig! Colosseum is fine but do not expect to see something more than just ruins and tourists. Beware of steep stairs. Palatine hill was not so impressive but Forum Romanum was much better even in the evening.

Impressive historical location. Going round the Colosseum and Palatine hill is a dream for all lovers of history and the old Roman world. The Colosseum reflects the way Romans were entertained and shows the engineering knowledge of the Romans at the time. And the Palatine and Forum are another reflection of the life of the Romans at the time with magnificent structures of the period. A really worthy visit to both especially when booking online and skipping most of the queue.

A Step Back in Time- way back!. Very beautiful, but the Coliseum was incredibly crowded! The Forum was much better, and I thought it was much more beautiful. The Forum had lots of structures and columns and a much better energy. We got there as a storm was moving in, so it gave it this great intensity with amazing clouds, we got a light rain before we left and the darkening sky made for some great photo opportunities. It is a must see! Palatine Hill was nice too, not nearly as crowded. I think people may overlook it, but it is definitely worth a visit while you are there!

Very Impressive. Definitely one of the most popular tourist stops in Rome. Be impressed with the structure of the Colosseum and marvel at the intricacy of design and construction. Yes, it does have a sadistic and macabre history to it, and sadly, the wonder of the Colosseum came into existence at the cost of countless numbers of lives, cruelly lost. As you wander around the structure, there are exhibitions and commentaries dotted around in strategic locations, and if you spend enough time exploring it, you could be amazed at the ingenuity of the ancient Roman empire.Worth a visit, but allow sufficient time to have a good look.

A lot to see and buy tickets at Palatine. So much to see and a great value for 12 euros and two days. Sooo many people are in line at the coliseum when they can get the combo ticket at the Palatine hill/ Roman forum entrance that is good also for the coliseum. Beautiful views from Palatine hill and the coliseum has great pieces in the exhibit area and explanations/descriptions in English

Excellent. Colosseum is well worth a visit.
Tip - buy a guide book for 5 euros instead of audio guide per person and hard to follow set route with crowds.
Palatine hill and Roman Forum can become a bt repetitive but nice break from hustle and bustle of Rome and would be nice for a picnic to enjoy grounds

it's very old but still standing!. I didnt realise the colosseum had so much of its innards left! the lower levels are still very intact and it was great to see. :D
I strongly advise pre-booking tickets to avoid the queues and the really irritating street vendors trying to sell you 'skip the line' tours!

Avoid the queue buy ticket at Palestine hill . After reading a previous review on trip advisor we avoided the massive queue in the scorching heat outside the colosseum and got a combined ticket for palatine hill, roman forum and the colosseum. There was no queue at Palatine hill and we didn't realise that they do free tickets so many Sundays of the year and the day we decided to go just happened to be one of them. We had a nice walk around Palatine hill and the Roman Forum and then walked straight to the front of the queue for the Colosseum. It's definitely a must see when in Rome, even better when it's free and you haven't had to queue!

Amazing!!!. It's and exerience that I suggest to get. You really enter into another world, full of history and mythes. Enter from the Camidoglio square and exit from the Colisem, that's the best way to enjoy the ancient Rome. Absolutely a "must"

lovely day. Apart from the scaffolding across the sites it was well worth the visit. Lots to see and took a couple of hours to see it all. The workmen were busy on the bridges to the edge of the site and that was interesting to watch them work so carefully

A must for the visitor. I didn't think that the Colosseum would be that impressive.I have seen lots of Roman ruins before, but the Colosseum tops them all. One minor point: The organisation of entrance and tickets is on the bad side. Fortunately we did have tickets and didn't have to queue in the heat (approx. 1-2 hours!). Then they closed the entrance gate because of security reasons - we heard, there are only about 3000 visitors allowed inside - but plenty of tourists' buy their tickets up to 4 months in advance.
Early morning visit!. Booked online to avoid the queues and left my hotel at 0830 and arrived at 0900. Hired the audio guide and had a great time!
nice but needs more visual pictures of what it looked like.. interesting, but nothing inside need a guide. Needs to have pictures on the walls showing what it was like.

Roma Pass will help you skip the line! Awesome evening photos!. If you are planning on utilising buses at all during your stay then purchase a Roma pass and you will automatically skip the line for entry to the Colosseum and many other attractions and museums. Entry this way will even put you ahead of tickets purchased online! An early morning visit is a must if you want to take your time to look around but if you have the opportunity to go back at night it is an amazing sight from the outside as night falls and if you love your photos you will come home with some awesome memories.

A must see!. We took a great City Wonders tour with Sara. We did our research before the trip but it's good to have a guide to let you know what you're looking at. We also appreciated the context she gave us which was also helpful in the Vatican Museums the next day. (All those beautiful marble floors were Roman before the popes gave he order to "recycle" the old buildings.)The highlight was definitely the lower level of the Colosseum. It was easy to imagine the gladiators waiting, ready to fight. Chilling. Despite the crowds everywhere else, our group was alone on that level.There is lots of walking. Some members of our tour group had trouble with all the climbing. Water and sunscreen are a must.

When in Rome...... This was my first trip to Rome and I was going to see the Colosseum and Roman Forum and I am glad I did. I took advice from Tripadvisor and booked my guide in advance who took care of my tickets so there was no waiting in line. It was truly a memorable experience stepping back in time. Our guide was great in explaining the little things, the construction, the architecture and history of it all. This is a must see and I recommend a guide and advance ticket purchase. The crowds can be very long. I would also caution to look out for all the street vendors and the Roman soldiers posing for pictures. The vendors I was told were Bangladeshian and very aggressive and annoying. If you are going to take a picture with one of the "Roman Soldiers" I would agree on a price before the picture is taken. I saw them demand 20 euros from some chap for a picture after the fact. My family really enjoyed touring the Colosseum and walking where the emperors and gladiators had trod so long ago. The Forum was neat walking on the grounds of the Caesars. There is a lot of history and our guide made our time and our tour very meaningful

One word - Breathtaking (& goose bumps for my wife). If you are interested in history - you gotta see these. To see what those folks accomplished at the time they did it all, you just have to be impressed.
History doesn't stop here.. Steeped in history, this place is amazing. Everywhere you look there is another amazing ruin or building.

historically fascinating. Loved the history. And being able to relate to my travel book . Did not like the Guides that were pedalling their purely fabricated version of history . aka Dan Brown fantasy

Colosseum tour. Had a 3 hr tour of Coloseum, Roman Forum and everthing in between. Used Select Italy for tour. Very knowledgeable guide, Claudia took us to all the nooks and crannies of the Forum area. The Colosseum, of course, is a magnificent structure, and to find out all the history really enhances the viewing. Wonderful tour and well worth the price.

Amazing, but Crowded. Obviously a must see when in Rome, however get there early as it gets really crowded!! A visit to all 3 of these places is a lot of walking, so be prepared, but it is well worth it.
Rome~Colosseum, Palatine Hill, Roman Forum. This is not to be missed. The Colosseum was amazing, just the thought of the Roman's fighting there. It was very interesting.

Best advice on buying tickets for the Colosseum, Forum and Palatine. Best advice given on Trip Advisor regarding buying tickets for the Colosseum was buy them at the Palatine.I did just that for myself and seven friends. The queues were extensive at the Colosseum so we took a gently walk in the August heat and bought the combined tickets at the Palatine in a queue of four. The price was 12 euros for a combined Colosseum. Palatine and Forum ticket, that lasts 2 days.The Colosseum was awe inspiring and even better we walked straight in with having a prepaid ticket. Fantastic advice.

Magnificent, so rich . We visited the Colosseum and the roman forum late in the afternoon to avoid the August heat. The things that Romans had built which is still standing show the greatness of the empire architecture and commitment towards imperialism. The Romans had great modern systems such as sewage which some of our still stand till this day. The creative engineering at the time shows how great the empire was.I recommend visiting the sites with a tour guide which put things into perspective and explain exactly what the monuments are and from which era. This would make it more interesting as it can be better imagined. There is a lot to see, so anyone visiting should be as comfortable and patient as you can be. Also being fit would definitely help.

Great visits. Colosseum is well worth a visit. We had a tour although we did not find this too helpful. It cost €25 per person. We had not booked on prior to visiting, we joined a tour that was being advertised outside of the colosseum. It is worth mentioning that on the first Sunday of every month, the colosseum is free to enter for European citizens. It is for this reason that we also feel the tour was not worth the money- just arrive early enough to jump the queue before it gets too long!
An awesome place to visit, a must for Rome. Trying to imagine all the activities that would have gone on in there. The guide really brought it to life. A real must for Rome

Incredible. We had a wonderful private tour of the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum. City Wonders provided us with Paola and she was fantastic! Go with a private tour, not that much more expensive yet more informative.
Breathtaking places. Once in a lifetime opportunity to see Rome, the Colosseum, and Roman Forum. There is a lot of walking to see these places so make sure you have comfortable shoes.
Amazing building . Well worth a visit but expect huge crowds vBuy a skip the queue ticket which we bought as part of our bus ticket. You just walk straight in past the queues as they huge.
Be prepared for queues. It's vital to book ahead if you want a tour to avoid the very long queues, especially in the heat of the summer.

You must go but be sure to book on line beforehand!. As other people have said, avoid the worst queues by paying and printing off a voucher before you go. You still have to pick up your tickets there but for 2 euros more the queue is much shorter.I thought it might be over-hyped as an attraction but it isn't at all. The size and construction are amazing and you have to be inside to appreciate it. It takes very little imagination to see it as it was in its heyday and you feel the weight of its history. Although it is full of people it is so big that you don't feel too crowded and can get the views you want inside and out. There is some scaffolding on the outside but I expect there always will be so don't be put off by it. You can access the forum opposite. It is steeped in history but rather confusing as poorly signed. We didn't have time to visit the Palatine which may have been better. It is amazing to walk in the footsteps of Caesar, Augustus, Cicero et al though.
Interesting Stayed TOO LONG. Very cool but the colosseum was overkill. 2 hours should be the max. time for all three! I would do an audio tour but not pay for a guide.

Awesome. I didn't get to tour the upper levels last time I was here so that was amazing seeing the view the Romans did. Lots of overlooks to get different views. I enjoyed the visit. Watch out for all the folks trying to sell trinkets outside....very aggressive.

Worth the trip!. This was a very fun thing to finally see. Be sure to buy your tickets ahead of time and print them out (this is true for almost all of Rome's historical attractions). You will be able to skip the line and walk straight in, saving you probably thirty minutes.We visited in August 2014 while they were doing some restoration work, which was a little disappointing. We couldn't go into the bottom tunnels area, which we've read they've opened to tourists in recent years. We also toured the Palatine Hill area, which was included in the price of the ticket to the Colosseum. This is worth a visit, as well. BUT, as you're leaving Palatine Hill, ASK WHERE THE EXITS ARE. We walked in circles for thirty minutes before we found it, even with asking, and we weren't the only ones doing that - no one could find the exit. It's like they don't want you to leave.

Take plenty of water. All very good places to visit for their historical value but there is not a lot of shade and it is a good idea to take plenty of water with you. However there are drinking fountains around.

Must see location. Best to avoid the long lines and to take a guided tour.. First visit to the Colosseum with my kids (I had been before). In order to maximize the time, we took a guide for a day to see the major attractions in Rome. This allowed us to avoid the (incredibly long, sometimes 2+ hours) lines to the Colosserm, as the guides have access to a separate line which is very fast.The site itself is definitely worth a visit, although without the explanations of the guide (or an equivalent audio guide or in-depth guidebook) you will miss out on many of the fascinating points.Definitely worth going but plan in advance to make the most out of it.

Very cool!!. Definitely book your ticket online in advance! We walked past the longest queue I have ever seen, on our way to collect our tickets from the box office! The Colosseum itself is incredible, an absolute must do in Rome!

Guided tour is worth it. Amazing place. Completely awe-inspiring to think that this was built at a time when our country was making do with mud huts.We booked the official guided tour at the Coloseum itself. This seemed like a very good value, for a number of reasons. Firstly, when we arrived, it was the first Sunday of the month and it had just been announced that admission would be free on these days. As a result, it was particularly busy, although I have never been before so maybe this was just normal for school holidays in the summer. Anyway, they had big signs up saying that admissions would be restricted to 3000 people for safety reasons. We joined the long queue for admission, but the queue seemed to come to a stop. I'm not sure if this was just temporary, but we were very thankful that when we showed the guy at the gate our online booking for a guided tour we were waved straight through.Secondly, our guide was extremely knowledgeable and she had actually worked as an archaeologist at the site and was therefore able to give us a lot of insight into the building. For instance, she was able to explain that the common idea that the Coliseum was flooded in order to re-enact maritime battles is almost certainly wrong.Thirdly, and most importantly, being with a guide means that you have access to lots of areas that are otherwise not allowed for people with general admission. For instance, when you go onto the arena floor you do so at an entirely separate roped off area so you just have one tour party around you rather than hundreds of milling people. Plus, if you book the right ticket, you get to see underground at the Coliseum, and also the higher floors which again are not available to people on general admission.It is pretty easy to book the guided tours. You can't do this online, but if you go to the website they give the phone number for the call centre and I found that they speak very good English.
circular savagery. worth getting a tour as otherwise you can get swamped by tourists. there are so many interesting stories and perspectives to take in.

Unbelievable!!!. First off - a Tip for those who don't already know - Buy your Combo Ticket at the Forum's Ticket Office. I think we paid about 14EUR each, for the whole thing, and after you've strolled around the Forum, inside to the Museum and up Palatine Hill, then you can enter the Colosseum and walk straight through - no queuing!!!The Forum was the bit I was most looking forward to and it didn't disappoint - the history is phenomenal and you can breathe in the atmosphere - it is stunning. Uneven footpaths with loose stones etc, not ideal for lighter footwear, wheelchairs, or prams. The museum is fantastic with lots of items that have been found over the years - there is still on-going archaeological projects, but it didn't detract from our visit.The Colosseum - breathtaking!! It was unbelievably quiet - which was bizarre considering how busy it was when we were there - both times (2012 and 2014). The queues for this historical attraction were horrific - take my advice - buy the combo ticket at the Forum!! There are toilets here, I'm sure I saw a sign for a lift, and you can have a guided tour if you prefer, we chose not to and just wander, which suited us. There is also a little gift shop on the way out - reasonable enough.You can buy tickets in advance, but to be honest, if you buy them at the Forum there is no need - there is never a queue there, not that I saw anyway, and we have spent quite a few days of both our holidays around this area.This is a definite MUST SEE!!!

Large area to explore. The grounds are huge and we could have done with a guide to show us around and educate us on particular areas. We chose to not go with the audio tour as we would have been there all day and only wanted to spend a few hours exploring. A suggested tour map would have been useful.

Amazing Place. Very close to our hotel so tended to wander down to see it most nights after we had eaten. We did go in one day on the combined Colosseum / Forum / Palatine ticket. We did't use a tour guide, took a book and wandered around in our own time. Majestic place.
Italy. Awesome... A must see!! You cannot go to Rome and not visit this site...be careful for pick pockets at this location...
Great Vacation Spot. Great walk along the road to the Colosseum. Ancient cities, great artifacts. Needs more than a day to appreciate the historical buildings
Unbelievable! A Must See.. Architecture: Amazing.Engineering: Amazing.Historical Significance: Amazing.The whole tour is only about 90 minutes, but it's well worth the time and effort to get here.

Great Tour. We did this tour and it was amazing. There is so much to see in the Colosseum and so much to learn about the past. Palatine Hill was amazing and very interesting. We enjoyed seeing and learning about all of the old ruins of the Roman cities and empires at these three amazing sites.

Highlight of our trip!. We paid €55 to get a guide & I'm glad we did. Her name was Mary & she was so informative, we had a full detailed tour of the colosseum, roman forum & palatine hill. Our guide was witty, friendly & didn't hold back with all the gruesome goings on that took place inside the colosseum. Our group was varied in terms of age & ability & our guide made sure everyone had a great time. The colosseum itself was epic, despite the construction going on around the back. Unfortunately outside was full of 'lucky lucky' pests trying to sell anything from hats to water & everything in between!! The roman forum was interesting as was palatine hill, having a guide really helped as I didn't know much about either place. Out of all the things we did in Rome, this was the best.

Lots of Walking. Be prepared to walk a lot but you will see a lot of history right before you! The Colosseum was really beautiful and moving.
