The Palatine Hill and Roman Forum were not really very exciting and we buzzed through them. Get your tickets online before you go or you will stand in line forever!

History, History and more History. Everything about Rome is so cool to see and this is like walking through a history book! The ruins of it all are just amazing. Long lines everywhere but if you go in knowing that then it's really not a big deal. Go see it all!!!!!

Do not miss this!!!!! So much History and so Fascinating!!!!. We started with the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill since the ticket line was shorter and I waited too late to buy the tickets online! I highly suggest buying them online!!!! You can spend all day wandering around and looking at everything. There is lots of walking and climbing. You can even see current excavation activities going on. It was all so fascinating and amazing. The best pictures of the Colosseum are from the Palatine Hill!! And what is amazing is that there is more like this all over UNDER modern day Rome!!!! The Colosseum is amazing and yet very humbling when you realize the activities that occurred there during it's day. But the architectural details and feats are amazing when you consider how old it is. Even more amazing is that in ancient times they would actually flood the floor of the Colosseum and simulate sea battles! I would love to take the evening tour but it was booked up.

Amazing!!!. This is a stunning piece of architecture. Steeped in history. No need for guided tour but worth getting the audio guides. Need around 3 hours to comfortably explore. We took our baby buggy with us, which was fine

Must see!!. If you are in Rome, this is a must see!! Have me the chills when I walked in, I went with a tour group so there was no waiting, the line for tickets was extremely long, so if you can go with a tour group that offers no wait in line, or if you can purchase tickets online before I would recommend that.

Combined attractions to see in one day. Classic ruins, very close to one another, combined ticket, worth the price. A lot of history packed into a small area, a glimpse into the Roman times. Water free to drink in Palatine Hill and Roman Forum, especially good in a hot summer day. Lots of groups, every language possible, try to avoid to be distracted from the ruins.

Go First Thing in the Morning - Miss the crush of People. You cannot go to Rome (we've been there twice) and not visit the most incredible offering the city has for a lesson in Roman history! We were amazed on our first visit 10 years ago to this incredible city. On this visit, 10 years later, so much has changed and improved as Rome uncovers and restores their archeological sites. Three cheers to the City of Rome for taking the time, spending the money and working hard to restore the wonderful ruins that lie under a beautiful, historical city.

An informative guided tour. We had booked a 3 hour tour of the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Forum. Our guide was very knowledgable and friendly. She pointed out all the various features and uses of the different places.Make sure you have water with you, it gets very hot in all the areas during the summer and make sure you have plenty of memory free to take lots of pictures :)
A must see. You can't visit Rome without seeing these sites. Took the Dark Rome guided tours. Guides were informative, spoke English and we skipped all of the lines.
history, history and more history.. difficult to imagine how this place was built and even more difficult to believe what it was used for!! impressive and sickening. buy your tickets online.
WOW!. Go to the head of the line, get your tickets online. Take lots of water, lots of walking, it is a great tour.

Roma caput mundi. Let the ruins speak for themselves but do yourself a favour: avoid booking online, that will add 4Eur to each ticket. Go instead to the ticket office at the entrance of the Foro Palatino (Via dei Fori Imperiali) where the queue is almost absent. Tickets are 48hrs valid, you get enough time to have a peek on the whole area.
you have to visit. done a 3 hour walking tour.would definitely recommend as otherwise you will not know what you are looking at.time flew by.

too crowded. Historically interesting, however always crowded. The best time to go is afternoon, close to closing time (ticket is valid for more than one day). Great views of the surrounding at sunset.
Stay outside :). The Colosseum is beautiful from the outside, and not worth going inside. It is not worth your money or your time (or sanity).
fantastic. We arranged a tour on the day and throughly enjoyed it. Our guide, from Maya Tours, was excellent. She knew her subject well and was enthusiastic about it.

When in Rome, do as the Romans did. My son and my partner joined two different guided tours in Colosseum while I joined the girls in another activity. They loved it very much. Me and the girls did have chance to see the Roman Forum and found it exciting to see very old ruins.
outstanding. how did they build it and how did it last so long!? I have been here a few times and each time it impresses me. Take half a day to explore the whole area

what an experience!!. There is nothing like seeing a piece of history and where has more history than the colosseum and Palantine hill. The access you have is great, very open and free to wonder around. There is plenty of boards everywhere to explain what different buildings where. It was a great day. i would recommend taking drinks with you as the vendors here can be expensive and dont get fooled into thinking photo's with the 'centurions' outside are free.

Impressive. A must see when in Rome. Although it's a ruin it gives you a sense of what it would be like to watch the gladiators fight, and you can see the callers where they kept the people and the lions. The gardens opposite are quite lovely.

Disappointing.. I know its spectacular, but the immediate area is filthy with cigarette butts, rubbish and just dirty. I felt that this situation was so disrepectful to the Colosseum itself and takes away from it. Just not what I was expecting.
DO NOT MISS THIS!. Everyone should visit here! What you are seeing is so spectacular it is difficult to comprehend. Do not miss a visit to the Roman Forum. Read about what you will be seeing first.

Great Afternoon!. Had a brilliant afternoon at the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum. We did the tour without a guide so got to explore the sites ourselves and at our own pace. The Colosseum was very impressive not just the amphitheater itself but all of the exhibits in it too! The Roman Forum area and Palatine Hill was also impressive and alot bigger than i expected and a lot of walking on cobbled stones so make sure you have comfy footwear on!! Also ate opposite the Colosseum and hung around until it got dark so i could see the Colosseum lit up, that was beautiful! Such a good site definitely worth going to!
The one and only Colosseum!. What's there to not like? We went at the end of the day--shorter line and the colosseum just before dusk is awesome....my 10 or 11th trip there--never gets dull.

Most amazing place. Always wanted to visit and wasn't disappointed. What an amazing place, a must see when in Rome. Was on a guided tour of Rome and wish we could have spent longer than 1 hours, it just wasn't long enough.

Maximus, Maximus, Maximus. It's all that one can hope for and more! Being one of the most popular attraction in the world, there were massive crowds and it took well over an hour for us to get in. My suggestion will be to book online and avoid the queues.

Be smart and skip the lines !. Buy a 48 ours ticket from the OFFICIAL red hop on-hop off buses.The hotel provide the bus ticket. THEN : The first day you can buy the Colosseumticket from the guide on the bus and you skip the line to enter the Colosseum.The second day you may buy your entrance ticket to St.Peters Bassilica - and you can skip that line there, too. I really don´t understand why all that people stay in lines for hours to enter ...when it can be done this easily. The Spanish Steps and The Trevi fountain you visit without any kind of tickets, whenever you want. In this way you may visit Rome`s four biggest attractions in two days!( In addition to roundtrips the bus ticket gives you ! ) NICE !!!

Incredible piece of history. Do not miss these on your trip to Rome. The history behind these sites is fascinating. We hired a private guide through Walks of Rome to take us around, and he really made the places come to life. Even our 11 year old son was interested.

Surreal. The whole experience of being surrounded by and touring the ancient architecture is amazing, this was definitely the best bit of the holiday.
The first Sunday of the month is free entry, we werent however told this when we bought our tickets on the Saturday, you can use the ticket over 2 days so went to the Colosseum on Sunday.

awesome activities to do in one day. Your ticket is good for all three sites. The line at the Colosseum is generally longer than the other sites so buy your tickets at one of the others so when you get to the Colosseum you just need to go through security. Also, use Rick Steve's free audio guides for these sites. Very educational and good if you're on a budget. We went on a rainy/stormy day which was actually awesome since it have the place a spooky aura which was fun, and it was not very crowded. You can't come to Rome and not visit these sites, so do it and hopefully these tips can help you maximize your visit!

Amazing History Everywhere You Look!. Seeing the Colosseum, the Roman Forum and the other Roman ruins were amazing! Walking along the old roads and through the ancient city one has to respect what the Romans were able to accomplish and marvel at their engineering and building skills. A tour of these sites is a must if you're in Rome!
Good place to learn. Not only the arena itself some exhibitions inside are interesting too. I learn about wbat a human can do.

You MUST see. Amazing site, experience. Can't believe through all this time it exist , and its there for us thousands of years later. It tells the story visiting all three. Colosseum, and the Roman Forum goes hand in hand. Imagine its not ONE thing ......its two right NEXT to each other adding and aiding in your mind the REAL life of the Romans during their rein. Palatine Hill..........its all there....

Impressive ruins. We visited the forum right after the colosseum. It was incredible to see the ruins and to walk around the structures. The view is also beautiful from this area. We didn't have a tour guide, but it would have been nice to have one to describe the ruins and the history. Make sure you buy tickets (colosseum/forum/palatine hill) online- the lineups are very long and it's not worth wasting time waiting in line in the hot sun! We entered the forum around 11 am and it was very crowded, often it was very slow and difficult to walk- you need to make your way around the tour groups and many people. We could have definitely spent more time here, but it was too hot and crowded to see or enjoy much more of the forum. We then headed off the palatine hill - less crowded.

Cool place. Very historical. Well worth the visit. Very important tips:1. BUY YOUR TICKETS IN ADVANCE!!!!!! Get them online, you'll skip the line. It will save you a lot of time.2. Don't take pictures of the gladiators, they will charge you. If you want a picture, get a price first, then take the picture.3. A decent walking audio guide is the Rick Steeve's guide. Get it, worth it :)4. Since access gets you into the fourms as well, bring some water, as it will be a longer day, and if it is hot, you will get thirsty.

Get an advance ticket to skip the queues. One of the great must-sees of the world. No trip to Rome is complete without seeing this. There are huge queues at busy times - avoid the touts and the queues by booking tickets in advance online.

Must do.... It's the Colusseum and it's awesome to stand inside...spoiled a bit by helicopters buzzing overheadIf the queues are long for the Colusseum, go to the Forum or Palatine and get the ticket that covers all 3 venues from a ticket office with little/no queue
Overwhelmed. Absolutely overwhelmed at the Colosseum, stunning! Take a guided tour and a bottle of water! There is so much history to take in.

Every year under restoration. I visited here 2 times but it was under restoration. Last visit in july 2014; a big part of Colesso and whole way goes from Vanezia square to Colesso is under restoration. This year not only Colesso under restoration;Fontana di Trevi (Love fountain), Spagna square, and The church up to Spagna Stairs are under restoraiton. I don reccommend you to visit Rome till restoration will done.
You could imagine being there. Loved the guided tour and the guide was excellent. Worth booking in advance to save massive queues. Be prepared for constant hassle from traders around the Colosseum.

Impressive history. Definitely make reservations for this outstanding historical attraction. You can spend hours here imagining what occurred over two millennia ago. Incredible how they built the coliseum so long ago. Although this is a standard Roman attraction you should go visit. A must-see.
Amazing History. I wouldn't miss this iconic piece of history! It is amazing to walk through these areas where so much has happened in the past 2000 years.
Best Audio Tour. The Colosseum has the best audio tour. Plan to spend at least half a day or more to see the Palatine Hill and Roman Forum.

Too many scammers. Be careful here, gladiators fighting over tourist dollars, pick pockets,... Interesting to see but constantly being harassed was really annoying. Of course you have to see this when in Rome, but the police need to do more to make this a better experience for tourists.

Fantastic. Surreal experience to stand in the great Colosseum. We had a guided tour and had no wait to enter. In the height of tourist season, with all the other tourist, it was STILL amazing. Must see.
Is it real. Just an amazing place to visit knowing the history and just how old the structure and surrounding structures actually are.

Magnificent and brought to life by our guide. It looks imposing from the outside but only from the inside can you appreciate the scale of this monument. Our guide told us the stories of life in the Colosseum for the gladiators and about the building - it's construction, what happened there, life and death.If you go to Rome don't miss this - and get a guide!

Get your tickets in advance and bypass the queues!. I have already reviewed these sites separately, but just to say again, make sure you buy your tickets before leaving home, print out the confirmation and go straight to the last booth at the Roman Forums entry gate (to the right of Constantine's arch). This way you can bypass the queue, do the forums first (a lot of walking), then have some lunch at a nice, local pizzeria,then do the Colosseum.

Get a guide!. We would have missed out on so many interesting stories without our guide. As someone said if you walk around without a guide you are looking at a bunch of rocks. Spend the money for this once in a lifetime experience.

'We loved it'. Stayed in Rome for 3 nights.....booked a trip to the Colosseum online....best thing we ever did....totally cut the queues.....could not have stood in the horrendous queue that was forming....many people had tour guides....but we just booked entrance tickets and did our own thing which suited us....We found the Colosseum to be fabulous....very interesting.....and definitely something we're glad we've seen in our lifetimes.....!
A must see. Well worth the short walk from our hotel, but much of the Colosseum's exterior is under restoration.

Don't queue. We went with a guide in the morning who got us ahead of the line tickets but it was very crowded. People jostling for position. Better seen in the afternoon when the crowds have gone - our son did this and he had a much better experience

a days visit for 12 euros. with all these attractions in this vicinity it is paradise .first you go up Palatine hill & explore there .then you go round the forum which will take you ages as there is so much to take in & then you go accross the road to the colosseum to explore that & ALL THIS FOR 12 EUROS.MAGNIFICCO.

Outstanding piece of history. While standing in front of the colosseum I found myself picturing the Romans traveling back home as they do in every movie. The piazza is just a great place to hang out and take a step back to realize how long it's been there. The colosseum is a must do. They sell the tickets including the roman forum. Plan on a couple hours for both of these, you wouldn't want to rush it. Fun to explore but if I had to just do one it would be the colosseum I feel like you can see most of the Roman Forum from the street.

Not To Be Missed!!!. This was a highlight of our trip. The Palatine and Forum are incredible! A window into the past, it was so interesting to see these landmarks and try to visualize what it must have been like all those centuries ago! And The Colosseum? I been waiting since I saw pictures of it when I was a kid, and finally made it;) We went into the area with a guide who furnished headsets and his knowledge of the entire area enhanced our experience. Highly recommend!

Avoid the queue. We have visited the Colosseum before with a group tour but wanted to come back and spend time at our own leisure. The museum on the first floor is well worth visiting.Earlier in the day we went to the Time Traveller and bought a deal which included a voucher for the Colosseum. As well as being cheaper to enter the Colosseum there was no waiting in the queue. Brilliant. Go to the reservations counter at the Colosseum and swap your voucher for tickets. Brilliant. On the first Sunday of the month entry to the Colosseum is free but expect huge long queues.

Very Interesting. Rome has always been on my bucket list of places to visit and it did not disappoint. I was really awed standing in the colosseum and imagining all of the history that happened on that very spot. The only thing is that it was very crowded even though it was off season when we were there. One piece of advice is that we had a private tour company who booked our tickets in advance and we were really glad because we got to skip the really long line of people who did not buy in advance.

Amazing Architecture. Its very tiring to see them all in a day but its the curiosity which force you to go thru them all. Though Roman forum is all left with remains but there are still few very interesting things like Brass gate (one of the very few left in world). Palantine hill is Ok but not worth of having a look. Colosseum is the best out of three. You can use your ticket to come next day to see them as well.

Wouldn't have want to miss it. We visited the Colosseum at the end of our stay, so we were very tired. But still I wouldn't have want to miss it. It is bigger than I expected and amazing to see such a building still standing after centuries. And by your ticket at the Palatine Hill, so you don't have to wait as long to get in. The ticket is valid for both attractions.

This is what Rome is all about. We booked a tour through Walks of Italy which gave access down into the basement area and the third tier of the Colosseum where the public don't normally get. Access to the basement is only to the end area - you don't get to wander through the ruins of where the animals and gladiators were kept but it was worthwhile none the less. The Forum is fascinating and our tour guide was excellent. Thoroughly recommended.
Queue jump the Colosseum. Great to experience this amazing history. Look out for the tourist guides and pay a bit extra to queue jump and get an informative tour.
incredible. Get a skip the queue ticket and have your mind blown in this astonishing place. Take your time and don't miss the Palatine.

Wow!. The ruins, the colosseum....amazing! Hard to believe these structures still exist after such a long time. Well worth your time to see and experience them. Here is a tip for you when visiting the Colosseum: DO NOT STAND IN LINE AT THE COLOSSEUM as it always long. Go to Palatine Hill down the road and get your ticket there as it is good for all three sites! Great way to avoid the lines and see it all.

Must see. Top 5 of things to see in RomeBuy a Roma Pass to skip the lines or make a reservation. in high season the waiting line can be more than 2/3 hours.Be aware of pickpockets before the entrance as well as very pushy merchants & people offering you 'reduced prices to see the Colosseum'.

Excellent! (However very long queues). A must see whilst in Rome. We bought the Roma Pass so skipped the queue however the queue we would have been in was very long - at least 1 hour! We paid extra for the audio visual tour which was very useful and interesting.

An Amazing Experience. We were on a self tour guide of Rome, and the Forum was one of the best parts of the holiday. It is amazing when you are stood surrounded by these old ruins that you are stood in what was the heart of Ancient Rome. There is some beautiful scenery, and it doesn't matter whether you love history or not, anyone can appreciate how beautiful the Forum was.
Favourite.. I had always wanted to see this area, and was not disappointed it was the highlight of Rome.so ancient.

Mind Blowing. Without a doubt one of the greatest things we saw on the trip, we had a guided tour which I would recommend as you actually get to understand what you are looking at and how it was before. A tip for you the Colosseum and Forum Palace are FREE entry on the first sunday of every month - we didnt know but were lucky that is when we were visting :-)
Scaffolding!. A big part of the Colosseum is being cleaned, and covered in scaffolding. Also they are building a new metro line so it's all rather chaotic.
"Mind blowing". An amazing site with an incredible size,get in early in morning to beat the cues and pay an extra 5 euro on the price and you get a tour guide.

Get the tour guide!!. The tour guides from the official website (coop culture ) were amazing!!!! For colleseum defo book the underground , 3rd level tour guide. We can only do this by calling them with the numbers on the website. The tour guide brought us to the off limit areas for the normal tix. We had the chance to go like aforementioned places. The view from third level was amazing!! And the tour guide knows a lot of stuff and showed us the pictures of the colleseum in the past and willing to entertain any question!! We also recommend the tour guide in roman forum. She was amazing (ambra I think is her name) , we ordered it at the counter itself just for 5 euros pps but defo worth it, maybe can buy from the website! Some of the monuments may not look interesting at all until we know the history eg julius caesar's place , the place where he was cremated was under the roof and believe it or not til this day some ppl still give offerings to him eg food , coins, flowers!! Again beware of Trojan heroes asking whether u want a picture. It s a scam! Ask them first how much if you want. Saw a few got conned, they were surrounded. And also beware of men with dozens of roses in hand! They will try to give some to the lady in the group first after that will pester the man for money and refused to take back the roses! Saw a few got conned as well. They could be very persistent. Just say no and last resort shout polizie/ carabinieri !! The roses men are almost at every tourist attractions so beware!

TRAVELER SECRET!!!. Ok, so here's how you get in to the Colosseum without the line! Get a ticket at the Palatine Hill entrance, then turn right around, walk a block back to the Colosseum, and skip the line to walk right in. Otherwise, you're waiting an hour or more in queue. Trust me!
Around the Colosseum. A really fantastic sight, you can feel the atmosphere as you stroll through it and feel the history that exists.

Nice time. Book a tour on line before you go. 2nd time we've been and the first time we've known what we were looking at. If you want to go the the top rail or underground, you have to book early!! We waited until about 2 weeks before we left and missed out, but the the standard 45 minute tour was great.
More than we imagined. Very moving place to visit, the images it conjures up are quite moving. The guide we had was very informative and also covered The Forum would highly recommend.

Loved it - but you have to be in to history. Personally I loved it, including the Forum. We had no queues for either the forum or the colleseum.Top Tip - Day 1 - go to the Forum. Our hotel was near the forum and there were never any queues at all. Your ticket for the forum also covers the Colleseum on day1 or day2.Day 2 - Get up early, and get the Colleseum as early as you can - wee got there at 9.30 - there were no queues and we walked straight in.

Discover Rome Tours. We went to the Colosseum without a tour booking under the impression we could get onto a tour whilst there. As soon as we got within 25 meters of the Colosseum we were asked by a tour company if we wanted to go on a tour. We said yes and paid our 15 euro each and sat and hoped it was legitimate. Several others with an orange sticker placed on their chest were waiting in the same area, phew. Our tour guide's name was Paulo who was working through the Discover Rome Walking Tours company. He was a great tour guide. He spoke clearly with amicrophone and speaker so the whole group could hear. He gave us some good insight as to the history behind the Colosseum. The Colosseum tour was followed by an approximately 30 minute education session from David about Ancient Rome and the Forum whilst sitting by the Palatine Hill. This introduction was also very interesting and led us to book a further tour with David that night. You can buy drinks and food at the Colosseum. TOILETS--- we had some trouble finding them as they aren't signed well around the area. We could only find one set of toilet, they were to the left of the exit from the Colosseum. They cost 1 euro each and were relatively clean. Definitely recommend going with a tour guide, you will get so much more out of it instead of walking in and out.

Still Amazing. Very enjoyable to wander around 2000 year old ruins and imagine the luxury that was here. Just don't talk to the con artists dressed as centurions, because they'll take you for Eur 15 for a picture with them on your own camera.
A cool walk through Roman history.. A must do for a first time visitor. It was a hot day so would have been more enjoyable in the cool morning. A very large area so plan appropriate time.

Private Tours of Rome with Maria. Once again our tour was prvided by Maria of Private Tours of Rome and she did a fantastic job in giving us the tour and her knowledge and communication skills were fabulous, Maria graduated in Art History and has her Masters and currently working on her PHD, no better tour guide and persom!!

Epic adventures. This is the single most important cite to visit in Rome. Within an afternoon, you can visit the world's largest arena (i.e., the Colosseum), the world,s largest entertainment venue (i.e., the Circus Maximus) and walk on a section of the world's oldest engineer road. The forum is breath taking. Far more impressive than the Vatican Museums - which are really rather overwhelmingly boring, with the sole exception of the Sistine Chapel. The Vatican Museums have been filled up with a lot of average sculpture, which centuries of Pope's basically acquired at no cost. As soon as they had to start paying for it the quantity and quality of work drops right off (e.g., 1 Rodin, 2 Chagall, etc. etc.)

Worth the wait, but less than we thought it would be. Really nice place for some good pictures AT THE OUTSIDE. The inside is ruined, broken and without good views. It's nice as a once-in-a-lifetime experience, but nothing else.
Go in the morning. . Amazing site. Buy prepaid tickets and skip the line. Be there when they open in the morning at 08:30, when the heat is not to much.

A must see if you are in Rome. You have to see this to get an understanding of the sheer size of it. It is an amazing building - fascinating to look round. Tip - buy your entrance ticket from The Forum (which is 50 metres away and gives access to the Forum and the Colosseum - but is valid for 2 days - and means that you do not have to queue to get into the Colosseum - you can just walk to the front left hand entrance section and go straight in as you have a ticket.

Great photo opportunities!. Also really worth getting one of the audio guides for whilst you are looking around, they are really informative and pretty cheap. They point out a lot of things that frankly i just wouldn't have noticed otherwise so definitely worth a few euros if you are into your history (which surely is the whole point of visiting Rome)!

One of the best objectives in Rome. I liked the objective very much for it's history and good preservation. Too crowdy in july and i don't recomend the visit without a online reservation for the ticket before (i stayed 3 hours in the line, mostly in the sun).

"Great historical Place". Visited Colosseum with my family and I couldn't believe that I 'm standing in front of this historical place which I've seen in so many movies. Worth the visit to Colosseum if you are in Rome. Want to visit again, the Colosseum and Roman Forum.
Not to be missed. Suggest that you have a guide take you on a walking trip. THe crowds are quite large during the summer vacation season.

be careful. We have gone twice. Both times we went through these sights with a tour group that we chose there on sight. This last time we took our 2 kids and the tour guide for Palatine Hill & Roman Forum was a lazy guy. He was funny & interesting but spent 1 hour sitting under a shade tree talking about the sights & never took us on a tour around them!

Obviously a must see!. Tip ! Buy your entry ticket over at the forum. We were there at 10 am in July .. there were NO lines there, but a 3-4 hour line over at the colosseum! We paid 12 or 13 Euro per person to get in. CASH. They would not except Credit Cards on this day. We have heard that this policy changes back and forth - so be prepared. Also - we had high school students with us that would have been free if they had their passports!!!?? Another rule that changes on a daily whim apparently. They were obviously young, and had their student ID's , but the cashier wanted passports...which we didn't carry with us :\ So we paid entry for the students too. Still well worth it! We decided to book in advance a 3 hour tour guide to talk us through what we were seeing - at each location - which we enjoyed. One ticket gets you into both sites.
magnificent. it worth the long line to visit this place,we had a 45 guide each person 5 euro but if you read before entering the place you cab have the information

So much to see. I'm a sucker for historic sites but this group of attractions was one of my favourite on my recent trip to Rome. Lots to wander around and see. Plenty of photos to take. Made lots of happy memories. Would be happy to visit all sites again

Fantatstic. Go and see it!Go to the Forum / Palatine Hill first.Best place to get in is part way along the Via Dei Fori Imperiali heading in the direction of the Colosseum just after the excavated ruins on the right. Small kiosk there with no queue during my time in Rome.Allow a few hours inside to see both the Forum and the Palace, your ticket (12 Euro) will then get you past the ridiculously long queues for the Colosseum .
Fantastic area. A fantastic area with all these buildings from Roman times, all in close connection with each other.

Colosseum is just amazing. No matter how many times we have visited Rome, the Colosseum is just an amazing historical monument to visit. A tour inside the Colosseum would have to be a must for any first time traveller to Rome, guides are full of historical information etc. on this iconic building. Although covered in scaffolding in places, once completed, the Colosseum is a wow factor.

You need to see these on one visit!. These should be visited on the same day, although the forum looks sparse from a distance, you get a better perspective as you walk through it. Read all the tourist 'labels' for extra information, it fills in the gaps.
Excellent tour. Amazing venue steeped in history. The information provided gave a good account of the Colosseum and it's background.
Busy but good. Nothing to dislike about the colosseum, only bit was the q.Well worth the wait though.You could picture it in your mind what it was like all those years ago.

So interesting. Rome is so full of history and nothing beats the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum. Not to be missed when in Rome and make sure you do some research before you visit, or else hire the audio guide when buying your tickets, to make sense of what you are seeing.

Amazing building and history. An obvious must see when you visit Rome. It's an amazing building that you'll just marvel at. It's incredible to think that they were able to build something like that so long ago.
Buy your ticket at the Forum to avoid queuing. Well worth a visit, but buy your ticket at the Forum - there was no queues, we walked straight in. Excellent value at 12 euros (adult) and kids go free

Astounding!. Take a trip back in time when you visit here. I was in awe of the workmanship and the history. We booked a tour with "Together in Rome". Our guide, Eva, was brilliant. Well worth doing the tour as not only do you skip the queues but the whole area is brought to life. Could easily have spent the whole day in this one area.
Don't queue for tickets, get a guide outside. It was a 2hr wait for tickets, English speaking guides around outside.. Probably more expensive, we paid €30 adults, €18 teenagers, FOC children

Great ancient Rome. Must see for sure if you want to sum up the greatness and might of the Rome in the ancient time. Magnificent structures that stood time and are still there to tell the story about the times gone by long time ago.

A must visit.... Going to Rome and not taking a snap in the coliseum is just non sense.This iconic building is really worth its while. The street is quite busy and there is a metro station opposite to the facade.Be careful with the pick pocketers and just enjoy a piece of History.
Colosseum. When visiting pre book your tickets online with 'Tickitaly' and avoid the ques! It's well worth the visit but take some water with you if you visit in the summer.

Must See. The Colosseum Amphitheater is a must see attraction in Rome. You have to visit there to appreciate just how amazing the history is.I would definitely recommend the tour as this gives a lot of interesting information and also a bit of extra privileged access. However if it rains the lower level is closed off which was a disappointment. If you prebook you technically jump the seriously long que to get it.

5 hours there and we shall have to go back to see it all !! it is huge !!!. You would enjoy this place MUCH more if you read a little about the Roman method of ruling at the time. [ look it up on the net ] They had Senates, Praetors and jurisdiction officers; but even though this sounds like a fair way to rule apparently, it really did not turn out that way , cause lots of important positions were given out to important families just to curry favour and in lots of cases more qualified persons missed out. You will notice here that future Emperors had their forums; headquarters ,in the immediate area , like fan clubs for supporters to rally around. Lots of intrigue !!! Be real careful about robbers here; in just two days of walking here , we have personally witnessed a lady being assaulted by an attempted snatch and grab thief and a lady with a group of children having her money and cards stolen; all in broad daylight with police nearby and people all around. Do not rely on the police as they are just showponies and the locals just shrug their shoulders as if this happens daily; don't be the victim. In spite of all this do not let this deter you from exploring this fabulous area. Just be careful..

Walking tour of Colosseum. Valentina Mochi was our guide for this tour. She had a fantastic understanding / knowledge of the historical context for this sites antiquities. Five stars to her. Bring sturdy shoes, water and be prepared for an incredible tour
You cannot leave Rome without going here. The que was very long, but in the end it was worth it. make sure and hire the audio, this allows you to walk around at your ease

Good-but a little disappointing. when you first see the Colosseum you think wow.. then you get closer and notice how run down it is and that the Italians are just using it as a cash cow. they could renovate and restore it back to its original state, even if its only half of it to give the impression of what it looked like years ago.

Underground and Third Tier tour. We went on the tour in early July. I phoned to book about 4 weeks before and I had a couple of dates available but I managed to get in on the day I wanted easily, just remember to book in advance!On the day we walked towards the shorter queue and after just 10 minutes of queuing we had our stickers and were told where to stand.The tour itself was very informative and the guide was knowledgeable, the tour lasted about 75 minutes.I would recommend this tour to anyone who would like to see the coliseum from a different angle to what many people who visit get to see, from below the historic floor and a great view of the whole coliseum from above and wider Rome.
Awesome. Just a wow experience, sent shivers down my spine. Go and experience this ancient wonder if just for the amazing atmosphere and feeling you get when you walk in. Amazing.
So cool. You can't go to Rome and skip these incredible sites. They are crowded in summer, but worth it....think about it..how did they do this so long ago?
Roma. The Roman Forum is such a beautiful place. The structures take your breath away. It is best to visit in the morning, when it is not so hot and crowded.

still fantastic. Took a private tour, used trip advisor info to chose one. Do the complete tour of the Colosseum, the tour guide took up places only small groups went and the areas were roped off to the general admission individuals. The ancient sights at Palatine Hill were explained in detail. However, lots of walking - the tour company said you must be able to walk approx 3.5 miles - It did seem more like about 5 miles, wear your hiking shoes, the entire colosseum and surrounding area is all uneven and stone surfaces - not for anyone who would have problems walking - tired after this tour but well worth the time, a truly unforgettable tour.
Interesting. Highly recommend doing a tour to get the most out of this. Limited shade and hot in summer but worth it!
you have to go. There is no way to get a sense of palatine hill and the forum without actually being there. Be prepared to walk!!
Give yourself time to walk around...tour not recommended!. Such an incredible place! NOT worth a tour guide (except for skip the line, just get there early) if you know anything about Roman history!
Tour. Was very busy but we bought a tour from one of the guys outside which got us a queue jump and guide tour of the colosseum and palatine hill

Colosseum. We arrived at the Colosseum about midday. The line up was at least an hour, but we were approached by a tour company that offered a skip the line package. We took the package and it was the best decision we made. The tour was educational and was interesting. The tour guide was nice and spoke reasonably good English. The Colosseum and Palatine Hill were impressive. I would suggest if going to these places to book a skip the line other wise you will be there all day.

Awe Inspiring. This is a must see when in Rome. Amazing just to be there. Could easily spend a whole day and wander around the building looking at the various artifacts on display and of course the Colosseum itself
Worth it. buy CUT the lane ticket.. damn it, i forgot and paid for it.. but stilll even with 25min wait.. it was worth it

Must see, must go. There is not much one can say about places like this. You have to go and see. The history that lives in these places is amazing! A few practical tips are in order, though. First, either buy your ticket online or go to the Palatino ticket office instead of the Colosseo. Leave to visit the Palatino during fresher hours of the day, if it is summer. And take some food with you. Beyond water fountains, there is no food available either at the Colosseo or the Palatino. Also, take some guide with you. There is very limited info on site. Specially for the Palatino, a huge open area, there are very few maps around and nearly no signposting. It is a shame that such important attractions are so poorly fitted with touristic info.
Fabulous. I was awed by the structure and the history of the Colosseum. A must see in Rome. Ancient play ground of the Kings and Romans.

Not much to see of what it would have looked like. The Colosseum is immense, the scale is breathtaking but there is so little to see of what it would have been like. There is so much work to keep everything standing but very little to show how it would have looked that we felt a little let down. Sorry, but that's just an honest opinion...
A must see in Rome. You just cannot leve Rome without having visited these places. Take your time, have a wander around and really feel the atmosphere of this ancient city.

Full of History. The amount of history shared between the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum was immense! Seeing structures that dated back to BC time was incredible. We bought tickets online for around 14 euros each. Even with the 2 euro service fee, it was MUCH better than waiting in line. We didn't do an audio tour or anything, which might have helped some, but we really enjoyed just walking around and taking everything in.

Old Rome at its best. First of all buy your tickets at the Palatine Hill, 12 euros per person and a queue of about 10 mins compared to 1 hour 10 mins at the Colosseum. Secondly, take a bottle of water with you, if you drink it, refill it from the many aqua portable sites, not the street vendors who may be selling tap water anyway. Now down to the actual attraction, the vast site of old Rome 2000 plus years on, to still be standing is a feat in itself but as you walk down via Nova and appreciate that it was built in Nero's time and imagine the people who have walked before you, the amazing experience comes to life. It's easy after a while in Rome to become blasé to all the many attractions, after all they are around every corner, but this part which is so ancient is just beautiful. Don't miss it.

A must but beware: a few tips. Useless saying that it's a must in Rome.As an Italian I can give you a few usefull tips for making your visit easier.Be carefull in buying tickets: don't trust the people who try to sell them out of the Colosseum claiming you will skip the queue (they are often not regular sellers), you can buy the tickets at the ticket office of the Fori Imperiali with very small line and then avoid the queue at the Colosseum, for the right price.Don't get the double audioguide for 8€, get only one for 5.50 and bring your earcuffs (from your phone) and use those instead, it's the same.Prefer going during lunch time, there's less people.The ticket is valid for 24 hours, so it is a good idea to visit the sites in following days so you don't get overflowed and can enjoy more.At last always carry a little bottle of water from the supermarket, if you buy near the attractions you overpay everything (in general).If you plan with intelligence you enjoy more and spend less! Have a good visit!

Beware of guides outside of the colosseum. We were approached by one of the guides outside of the colosseum selling "private tours" of the colosseum and forum (45 minutes each). We (3 of us) elected to do this so we did not have to wait in the long lines. However, we ended up waiting about 10 to 15 minutes whilst the guide had enough people for the private tour. Our group ended up being about 25 people. Upon entering the colosseum we waited another 5 to 10 minutes (I think the guide was purchasing our tickets). After this we went out into the colosseum and were guided under a shaded arch where the guide gave us some information on the colosseum. He was difficult to understand and hear. We stayed here for about 15 minutes then literally went around the corner to another shaded arch and stopped again for another 10 minutes. After this, the guide announced he would not be taking us over to the forum as it was too hot and 3 tourists had collapsed with the heat the day before. We had the option of visiting the colosseum by ourselves, or meet back up with him 2 hours later! (They obviously knew this before they sold us the tickets). Needless to say, this was very disappointing and a waste of money. The colosseum was interesting, but really not worth all the hype.

Bring loads of water there.... It was quite pleasant, the Palatine hill is really nice. Also, you can buy the combined ticket here even for the Colosseum, so you can skip the long line there.However the place is huge and its very hot, so bring something to drink otherwise after a time you don't want anything else just leave and find drink.

A must visit. Ni visit is complete in Rome without checking this out. Is huge and a lot of walking. Takes more than half a day if you want to all 3 but the ticket is for all 3. One thing i don't like is that you always have to walk back out the same way you walk in as it is not connected.
Better than I remembered it over 15 years ago. They have a special exhibition area now inside that is quite interesting. Wish we could go down in the arena.

Must do in Rome.. Absolutely must visit. You can pre-book tickets online to beat queues. Alternatively, if queues at Colosseum are long, go to Palatine Hill where queues tend to be much shorter and buy your ticket there.

Truely historic!. Great walk around the ruins and journey through history through the Palatine Hill. We were awe struck walking through the Colosseum. Definitely get a jump the queue ticket as it does take ages when you line up.
Have to see it!. To imagine how long ago this was built. We did the audio tour and was well worth it. Buy tickets at counter not outside.

Absolute Must. Coliseum, Palantine Hill, and Roman Forum is absolute must if you are visiting Rome. It is a remarkable testament to what human beings are capable of both good, bad, and the ugly. You can get a glimpse of what life in ancient Rome must have been like. Definitely want to go back and see more. One travel tip. Bring your own water. Anything you purchase from street venders there is more expensive than what you would pay at the concessions during Super Bowl game or the World Series.If you are European reading this, I don't understand why you people put up with the high cost of everything. Pressure your governments to lower some taxes.
Colosseum!. Get tickets in advance; if not possible, purchase at Palatine Hill ticket office. MUCH shorter queue.
Awesome!. It felt so good to be able to see the Colosseum. Being in the dome, I could feel the presence and imagined the gladiators!

Marvellous to see. The sheer scale and design from all those years ago is just breath taking. It is a must see for anyone visiting Rome and is also a nice sight at night lit up and looks even better from the open top bus tour.
Late in the day is better. When we arrives around 2:00 in the afternoon there were no lines. The early birds had a more crowded visit than we did.
beautiful. Wonderful, atmospheric historic site, with plenty to see and learn. Horrendous queuing avoidable by buying the Roma Pass (or joining the many, expensive quided parties
As expected...tremendous!. Whats NOT to love about the colloseum...its magnificent. get there early (0830-0900) to avoid a big queue as after this time it can be a very long wait.
Great value for money. Allow the best part of a day for these three. 12 euros cover's all three. Start early at the Colossuem. Aim to get there before nine. You need about 5 hours to do it justice.
Ancient Rome. Live history. All you read in books in front of your eyes. Take a lot of water, something to drink and certainly don't leave Rome without visiting them.
Must see. Drink lots of water.. Be sure to book a tour to visit the Colosseum. For $10 more you skip the lines and have a very knowledgble guide.

An important piece of architectural history.. A must-see for all Rome travelers. The Colosseum is obvious, but Palantine Hill and the Forum are equally impressive. Plan to spend a good amount of time in Palantine Hill and the Forum; there is a lot of incredible Roman architecture to see, but it's time well spent. Bring water - you will spend a lot of time in the sun!

Colosseum PalatineHill RomanForum. We took the underground and third tier tour of the Colosseum. Very interesting and something to see. Need to book tickets by calling the Colosseum to arrange this private guided tour.The Colosseum looks much better at night - with all the lights. Very different in the day time.We arranged for a private guide for our group of 7, which was great when walking through the palatine hill and roman forum. The audio guides are good- if you have a large group, consider hiring a private guide to provided more details about the ruins and how life was more than 2,000 years ago.It is amazing to see the ingenuity and craftsmanship that was prevalent during ancient times. This is where is all begins for the rest of us.
Amazing. Liked the Living history. Enjoyed the area on tour bus and by walking through it. On Sundays the roads are closed to traffic and it was great to walk down towards the Colosseum.
Rome Colloseum visit. Wonderful, atmospheric historic site, with plenty to see and learn. Horrendous queuing avoidable by buying the Roma Pass (or joining the many, expensive quided parties.

Get amazed by Roman Heritage. Colosseum, Palatine Hill and R Forum is a mesmerizing experience.Frankly speaking you can't experience it all in a day or two. Its so vast, and has so much to offer. You will love it and on top of it, every minute you might just come across a greek goddess.So it will keep you interested.One word of advice: There are big queues for tickets esp for Colosseum and agents offering quick access<Skip the line>. Ignore all this and try this.All 3 places can be accessed on a common ticket and instead of buying it from Colosseum buy it from Roman Forum or Palatine Hill. The ticket counter at Roman Forum Exit that leads to main road (where artist are performing with spray paints, somewhere opposite to a Tourist office) is a hidden wonder which hardly had any queue. Buy your ticket there and save hours. Either get a pass before hand or try this else wait can be painful.
mmm. my husband and i enjoyed the architecture of this building. but both felt it was very errie in side knowing what when on hundreds of ago
Try to avoid the heat!. Fabulous, obviously, but if you don't "do" heat you will suffer for it if you go in the middle of the day :(

Awesome. The colosseum is truly awe inspiring - particularly if you use your imagination to think back to what it must have been like 2000 years ago - wonderful for the rulers and terrifying for the condemned.

Ancient picnic place. It's a huge complex of ruins full of various nooks and crannies. You need around 2 hours to carefully see everything. We didn't know it's gonna be this big, otherwise we would have taken picnic basket with snacks to just sit somewhere on the grass, have a picnic and enjoy the ancient surroundings. Seriously, it's a very good idea :). Among all the ruins and building, you can see there also lovely small gardens with springs of fresh water and orange trees. The best idea is to destine one day to see Colosseum and Forum Romanum together. This way you will be able to see everything carefully and enjoy it without making yourself tired.
Colosseum. The colosseum was amazing and seeing all the ruins of Ancient Rome was the highlight of this trip. There is nothing that I disliked
Pre-book. If you like waiting 2 hours in the sun to get in then don't, if you like your queues 4 people long - pre-book.Awesome spectacle, especially given when it was built.

Get there fast. Go quickly. We were advised that tourists might not be able to enter the Colosseum for ever, as the structure is becoming more unsound all the time due to the age, and the number of visitors!

Ancient History. The Romans have every right to dine out on past glories. The Colosseum is just outstanding and the crowds give a sense of what this place must have been like in it's heyday. The price of the ticket covers all three sites and can be used over two days. If you are having a short break then I'd recommend skipping the queues which costs double the price but is worth it if you are time poor.

A Classic, Quite Literally. The ticket for these costs 12 EUR, and it is very worth it. There are tours offered (and you can book ahead of time, or at the gates, but, if you want to book at tour of the Colosseum at the gate, you will still have to wait in the huge line. There are also unofficial tours that you can book outside the Colosseum that form tour groups on the spot. I have heard mixed reviews about all of the Colosseum tours, weather official or not (but, if you want to go to the "basement" or the third level, you have to be on a special tour (9 EUR, plus the online booking fee of, I think, 2 EUR if you do not want to wait in the line. You cannot book this tour from anywhere other than the Colosseum ticket booth) offered via the main website: http://www.coopculture.it/en/colosseo-e-shop.cfm). I did not go on any of the Colosseum tours, I just know they exist because I almost did the one that allows you to go to the "basement," but I opted for a cheaper tour of the Roman Forum instead (5 EUR, also the cost of the basic, official tour of the Colosseum and the official tour of Palatine Hill).I spent 5 hours among these three sites, including a one-hour tour. I would recommend a tour of either the Forum or Palatine Hill to give yourself some idea of what you are seeing. I have read a lot of negative things about the audio guides; but, at the same time, the tour in no way covered everything there (but, then again, there is so much to see that I don't know how it possibly could include everything there). There was so much to see that I can understand how the audio guide would become very boring very quickly. Also, as others have said, if you do not purchase a Roma Pass, buy your tickets at either the Palatine Hill or Roman Forum ticket booth (both located within 5 minutes of the Colosseum with SIGNIFICANTLY smaller lines). Then, you will be able to skip the huge line at the Colosseum. Even if you do not intend to enter the Roman Forum / Palatine Hill, I would still buy my tickets there just to avoid the Colosseum line.

A very good spanish guide !. I have been many times in Rome but never been with a nice, clear, and gentle guide in Spanish as we were in Colosseo. Thanks for a visit with information and interesting comments!

A "must-see". We only had 3 days in Rome and this was on the top of the list. We started early at Palatine Hill which gave us fast access to the ticket office (and bathrooms) and a quiet stroll in the morning. It flows right into the Forum so we did both with very little crowds. From there, you exit out the side and it is a short walk to the Colosseum. When we got there we heard the line for tickets was 1 hour 45 minutes. We breezed through because we had purchased our tickets at Palatine Hill. Go early in the day to avoid the heat and the crowds and wear comfortable shoes. We used the free Rick Steves app for our audio tour and it was perfect. You can print the maps ahead of time so you don't need to jump back and forth on the app to see where you are going. We were also glad we brought water bottles - there are fountains around the area that provide a cool refreshment.The only bad part of the day was getting back to our hotel. It took over an hour for our bus to come and it was jammed with people. We had to push our way on and that was miserable. I wish we had figured out a better way to get home (we were tired from all the walking and did not see any taxis). Also be aware that there is a fair amount of restoration going on in all of these areas.

Extraordinary door for kids to peek through into history/get advanced tix!. Iconic, majestic, pulsing with history...this extraordinary edifice oozes history from every ancient crevice. The "WOW" factor can't be expressed in words...from the moment a sliver of the Colosseum catches your eye from a distance to the moment you are standing right in front of it...you just have to stand there and say, 'wow!'. DO buy tickets in advance OR even better get a private guide to take you in. You will skip the CRAZY LONG queue. We made the mistake of not buying advance tix a few years ago and found ourselves in a Disneyland length line (and then some) ...sweating. We finally bought into a Spanish language group tour just to get in. WRONG WAY. This time we got a lovely guide who whisked us past the line, up the stairs and then dove deep into the history... regaling us with tantalizing tidbits about animals and gladiators and extraordinary feats of architecture (such as the awning/shade sails that hovered over the immense crowds of Romans cheering at the games). This is one of the wonders of the world and you will be lucky to see it when you are there!

A wonderful day out. This was an amazing experience. I was shocked that one ticket covered all 3. You can get a whole day out of this site. It os rich in history and I would recommend a tour. It is a beautiful site.

Waiting lines all over the place. These three are a must if you're in Rome, and it's a huge place so wear sensible shoes. The waiting lines are even bigger so do yourself a favor and buy the Roma Pass to skip them. The Colosseum is beautiful and worth seing for the history and the remaining architecture. At the Forum, the Forum Vestae is the most beautiful part, next to the two triumphal arches. Though the layout of the whole complex is quite confusing so getting lost will almost certainly be a part of the experience.

Must see. No trip to Rome would be complete unless you visited these iconic landmarks. We arranged a guided skip the queue tour through Viator for our group of 4. Perfect! The sites are all close together, easy to access, amazingly interesting & breathtakingly beautiful.

Amazing history, must see. Amazing to see the amount of history here. We went on a tour of the Colosseum and Roman Forum which I would recommend as you get to learn more about what you are seeing, don't miss anything and also don't have to wait in line to get inside!

History full on. The Colosseum draws the crowds big style but has to be seen. We took a guided tour (you will be accosted by many outside) and found it worth it. The only drawback was you did not get time to browse in the shop on site as youare led round on a schedule. That having been said we saw more than enough and then got a guided tour of Palatine Hill and the Forum which were equally enthralling if not better. Lot of walking and hills and steep steps to climb but a great day out.

Buy Ticket Online, Print, and Go!. You can buy a combo ticket for Colosseum/Roman Forum/Palatine Hill online at their official website. Do it. You will get an emailed ticket (that you must print) that let's you skip the lines and go directly to the turnstile. You can purchase audio guides online, too, but feedback from other travelers told me that they are old and dull. So, we did the Rick Steves' audio tours for Colosseum and Roman Forum (check your app store for the FREE Audio Europe app or you can go to his website). They're great and easily adaptable to your needs. People have different preferences on which order to visit the sites, I think you should choose what you most want to see and do that first. We chose to take a lunch break between the Roman Forum and Colosseum, which got us out of the heat for a bit. Wear sunscreen, a hat, and lightweight clothes - there isn't much shade at any of the locations, and you'll be hot in the summer! The tour groups are obnoxious, so be prepared, but you'd be cheating yourself out of a great experience if you miss these sites. Oh! And Sundays the roads are closed to car traffic around the Colosseum, so you can see a lot more. And if you exit out the back entrance of the Forum, it takes you to the modern-day capitol buildings, which is a neat perspective!

Magnificent. The Colosseum is always a mind blowing thing to see. It was commissioned in 72AD and took 8 years to finish. First known as the Flavian Amphitheater is was built to hold 55,000 people.As is with most of the antiquities of Europe, it has scaffolding attached to the outside. If you look closely, it is because it is being cleaned at the moment. The difference is amazing!

worth a visit. This is worth a visit, lots of history and worth walking around.be prepared to wait a long time for admission as the lines are long. they also do crowd control if there are to many people in you need to wait until some come out, this does prevent over crowing.

A peek in history. First of all, don't go with a demented expectation of images of gladiator movies. The structure is very old and obviously in a dilapidated state. The fact that it had survived thousands of years is more interesting than the sights inside. And yes, if you do intend to see it from inside, book tickets in advance (imo you can just watch it from outside and save time and money)

Step back in time. We did an Ancient Roman tour with Angel Tours. Thoroughly recommend both the tour and tour company. The tour guide was informative and we had plenty of time to soak in the ancient Roman history. It was good value for money

Visiting the Roman Forum is a must. The Roman Forum is a fascinating place. I don't think you realize the scale of the Forum if all you see are pictures. Once you are there it becomes apparent that the Forum is much larger than you imagined. There are three questions you must ask to determine your visit. 1) What kind of ticket? 2) Do you need a tour? 3) How long? If you are going to visit at least two major historic sites and/or museums, minus the Vatican, and use public transportation I would suggest the Roma Pass. It is worth the investment. If you are not familiar with Roman history and do not wish to read all of the interpretive signs you might want to seek out a tour. Make sure it is a legitimate tour worth investing in. I have a masters in history and my wife loves Roman history so we did the visit on our own. It will take you a couple of hours to go through the Forum and Palatine Hill quickly. If you plan on taking your time it will take longer. The ticket includes the Forum, Palatine Hill, and the Colosseum. Palatine Hill is where the Roman Emperor's palace was located and the ruins are worth visiting. Enjoy your visit and if you don't want to invest in a tour but do not know much about Rome get a guidebook, history book, or just do some intense research before visiting.
Amazing Experience. Like stepping back in a time machine. I had chills down my spine thinking of the history behind what I was experiencing. Will most certainly return.

a must do!!!. We did both the Colosseum and the forum the same morning and it worked well. We bought our tickets ahead of time online. You could get them there but the line was longer so just get them ahead of time and save yourself. As in many European tourist attractions, there can be some line entrance confusion. So make sure you are in the correct line! There is nothing worse than waiting an hour to find our you are in the wrong line! We went about 15 minutes before the Colosseum opened. There was a line for ppl with tickets and a line for people without tickets. As soon as the building opened, our line for ppl with tickets went through so quickly! Definitely do this! We actually had about 20 minutes in the Colosseum when there was hardly anyone there:) We downloaded the Rick Steves audio guide for this and that was PERFECT. There were audio guides for purchase but the Rick Steves one was great! We probably spent about 1 hour inside. We could stay on the ground floor and go up a floor. I think the underground is only for special tour groups. You'll have to decide how much money you want to spend. After the Colosseum we walked across the street to the Forum entrance. We also did the Rick Steves tour for this. We skipped Palatine hill because our feet were tired. This was about 10:30 am now and the crowds were picking up but still okay. this time of year though, it will get hot and you will get sunburned so be careful! There really isn't a line for the Forum and Palatine Hill, so do the Colosseum first and then these.

A must see when you are in Rome. A few tips. Even if you decide to go inside on a different day visit the outside of the Colosseum and Forum on a Sunday; the road between the sites is closed to traffic on Sundays and you get excellent views (and photo opportunities) for the Colosseum from the middle of the road. Check before you buy the Roma ticket, I think the Colosseum ticket gets you into the Forum and Palatine (and the other way around); I don't think you need to pay more for the Roma ticket. You will be accosted by lots of ticket sellers telling you what a fabulous deal they have saving you lots of money; we found the best deal was the normal entrance price paid on the way in.If any of your party are 24 or under take a photocopy of their passport for a greatly reduced entry cost.The unauthorised street merchants will sell you cold or frozen water at less than half the price of the vans and shops.

A must see but pay extra for queue jump!. Fantastic to see but at 40* a 2 hour queue was too much. We paid slightly more for the queue jump and walked straight in... You shouldn't have to pay extra but it was worth it. The ticket also includes Palatine Hill and Roman Forum so do not miss this. The ticket is valid for two days so if the heat is too much then go back again.

More structural work... After the disappointment of the work on the Trevi Fountain I was disappointed to see scaffolding on part of the structure. However it doesn't detract much from this 'must see' attraction which when viewed for the first time as you approach makes you catch your breath.

Well worth the price tag. We visited the colosseum as part of a group tour booked with Viator before we travelled. We skipped the line and had a tour of the underground area and of the upper tier. Our guide Sara was very knowledgeable and made the tour interesting.

Book in advance to avoid the queues!. The tour of the basement areas and top levels was fantastic and well worth the money - you need to phone Italy to book in advance, and I would strongly recommend you do it as otherwise the queues at the ticket offices are 2-3 hours long. The queues for the ladies loos are almost as long - use the gents!
Please wait.. Be patient. This is a site you must see on your visit to Rome. The only down side is the waiting time. We waited 2 and a half hours in the queue, but wee did enjoy it when we got in.
Excellent. Excellent, just excellent. History set out all before you. I would recommend getting a tour, just to avoid the queues and because there is so much to see.

Must see. The metro stops directly at this site if your not close enough to walk.Initially ,it's the size of the colosseum that impresses you ,then it's how did they do this with out modern machinery( you'll have to visit to find out.Down load Rick Steves free app that gives you audio tour of the major sites of Rome ,saving you a lot of money from hiring audio guides.)Photograph's don't do this site justice.Buy your ticket on line before you go as the crowds are huge.

Tiresome but brilliant. To avoid long queues it's much better to purchase tickets to colosseum beforehand, we flew through the long queue, and we're relieved that we had brought the Roma pass, which gave us entry to all three. The colosseum has breath taking views. A word of warning, outside the colosseum there are lots of men in red and gold roman outfits who will encourage to take photos with them, beware they will ask for €10 per person for photos you take with them. They don't tell you that in advance!! We needed up paying € 20 for photos that weren't even that good. :(
a must see in rome. I loved this area of rome very beautiful. need to make sure that they are not in the process of cleaning check before you go

Great Ruins, Weak Interpretation. These ruins are amazing, but I would like more interpretive material! Why don't they hand out maps for the sights with routes on how to best cover the sights and some basic information? The signage was inadequate at these locations as well. Also, some signs used non-Italian languages and some did not. Often we had to walk a fair distance before finding out that a sight was closed, when it could have been posted on the approaching path or road much sooner. Perhaps the tour companies have enough influence to keep it confusing for tourists so that they are more apt to hire the tour guides? Clearly the guided groups were favored by not requiring them to stand in the main lines. How about some large displays on how the sights actually looked (color and all) when they were at their prime. I saw no such displays. So many buildings and ruins that were open other times were closed for restoration or other reasons, at the height of tourist season. The museum for Palatine Hill was closed when we were there in July!

City Wonders Underground was Wonderful. Highly recommend the underground skip the line tour. We had a great guide who brought the whole area to life.
The skip the line worked extremely well.

Impressive engineering. My wife and I visited the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum on an overcast, rainy day. It was nice as we believe people stayed home due to the inclement weather. Fine by us as it only lasted 90 minutes or so so the place was not as packed as usual. The Colosseum is an engineering marvel despite all the bloodthirst that occurred there eons ago. A walk across the way to Palatine Hill and the Forum was edifying as well. Highly recommend Rick Steves' audio tour. Definitely helps understanding the ruins of the Forum and what it was like ages ago.

Take a walk through history!. The first time we were in Roma we took a tour and it was well worth it. We had booked the tour in advance and were able to just go past the line with our tour group. When our daughter went with us last year, I had done my research in the forums on TA and found that you could purchase tickets on the hill and the wait would be much shorter than the ticket office at the Colosseum itself. I had worries when I saw the very long line even at the office on the hill (lots of TA followers, I'm sure) but once we saw the other line, we were glad we had followed the advise!When you enter at the Hill you have a chance to walk thru the gardens and ruins and then on to walking thru the Forum to get to the Colosseum. It is all quite lovely! Beware of pick pockets and all the pushy sales people with fake designer goods as you walk up to the Colosseum entrance. This kind of activity is all over Europe at tourist attractions, so you just need to be aware and be cautious.The Colosseum is magnificent! The first time we went it was almost overwhelming. Don't be in a hurry! Take your time and sit on a step. Think about what you've read in the history books and take the place in! Lions on the floor. Gladiators on their horses with weapons ready. Caesar in the stands giving his nod. Amazing to be in the place where so much happened in history!When you go without a group you have the chance to linger longer. Walk around and experience it on all sides. If it is your first visit at least get the hand held guide to help understand. If you don't utilize the Hill ticket office. try to pre order tickets. The line is always long and I promise it will help. Enjoy!

Look good when it's finished !. A trip to Rome is not complete without a visit here.Queues not too bad the day we went and we did our own tour at our own pace .Just amazing :-) the Forum is even more amazing ! Just the sense of history is overwhelming if you get my drift !

One of the wonders of the world!. It is amazing what the Romans were able to achieve, even by today's standards it is an amazing engendering and architectural achievement. A true testament to what apowerful and succesful civilization the Romens were

A must see for visitors to Rome. The Colosseum was a great attraction to visit - although if you can get skip the line tickets beforehand I would strongly recommend. Once inside, it was a very relaxed atmosphere despite it being quite busy. We wandered round at our own pace, took many photos, and visited the gift shop. There were plenty shady places to recover from the heat so you weren't overheating. The Roman Forum was worth a visit. It was interesting to see what Ancient Rome was like.

Rome walking tour. We found this tour to be very good. We choose the hand held devices that allowed us to listen to each site instead of getting the guided tour. This way we could go at our own pace and in a much smaller group.

Amazing place and history . We were told before going to rome that the waiting time to get into the coliseum would be over an hour but there would be many people around selling tours that could get you through quicker. That was exactly right. We paid €24 pp to have a tour instead of €13pp to just walk around and I would say it was 100% worth it. There was so much information on the tour that was delivered in a way that kept you intrigued and the views were incredible the only thing that disappointed me was not being able to walk on where the gladiators fought or where they were kept under the "stage" but obviously that's not the coliseums fault. Amazing 100% must see in Rome!

Must do!. No trip to Rome is complete without visiting these iconic sights! €12 wil get you a 48hr ticket for 1 visit to each of the sights (there are concessions - €7.50 for EU citizens between 18 and 25 years old). If you buy your ticket at the Colosseum, the queues can be horrendous (up to 2 hr wait!) so it's a good idea to buy your tickets at the Palentine Hill or one of the other official outlets.
Amazing!. Well worth taking a tour to get the guides history of the area. It is a scary place when you know the back story! Take a tour! So worth it!

WOW!!!. Just go! It is amazing.
We inky had one night in Rome and selected the colosseum, blown away by so much history just smack bang in the city!!

A must see. Everyone must visit the Colosseum when in Rome! Our ticket price was included in our 3 day pass. Easy to get to via the open top tour bus (also included in our 3 day pass). The pass gave us fast entry past all the queues. It rained the day we visited but this did not matter. Still got plenty of photographs.

A must see in Rome!. You just have to see the Colosseum, it is breath taking. It oozes history, very impressive to see! We had bought the ''Roma Pass'' we recommend getting this if you will be in Rome for a couple of days. Not only did we skip the line up at the Colosseum, you can also take public transit for free and have free access to 2 other museums of your choice.Take some time and walk around inside the Colosseum, you don't have to be a history fanatic to appreciate it, I have chills just thinking about what I have seen. We spent about an hour or so walking around inside and didn't have a tour guide. There is a lot to look at and explore by yourself. Don't take pictures with the romans outside, it's a bit cheesy!

History at Lesson. You get a sense of living through Ancient Rome walking through the Forum. The ruins, sculptures are stunning. Wear good shoes as the paths are cobble stone and gravel. The view of Rome from the top of the hill is stunning. Bring lots of water. I did not find any public toilets in the area. The walk has up and down hill inclines.
Wow. What a fabulous site to see, well worth a visit, you can almost feel the Romans watching the entertainment. Loved it !

wheelchair. The roman Forum and Palatine Hill is beautiful to see but not for people in a wheelchair. I saw this at home when I was looking for info about Rome. But when we were over there, the people from the Roman Forum, 2 people, said against us that is is possible with the wheelchair. So we got in. And that is really not to be done. I was glad we were with the four of us otherwise I could do nothing at all. You can't trust the people who work there for info.

If you visited the Colosseum, you cannot miss touring the Forum. We went to the Colosseum, and since the lineup to get tickets for the Colosseum was too long, we bought it at the entrance to the Roman Forum, 100 m away.After visiting the Colosseum, we crossed the Forum. There are some great views and monuments. None of them as magnificent as the Colosseum, but still worth seeing as a whole.We brought our lunch (good panini and some wine), and sat on the grass under some old big trees in one of the multiple gardens within the Forum. Felt like old Romans! I recommend visiting the Forum on a sunny day. Theres

Wonderful relaxing site and amazing ruins. We really enjoyed walking around the ruins of the forum. - Definitely worth seeing. - Seeing all of history/ruins is interesting. Is a very large and impressive area. - Upper area is very relaxing - lots of trees, shade, flowers, benches. - Upper area also has some nice views out over the city - We didn't do the guided tour - but that wasn't an issue - it's such a huge site the joy is just walking around. - We went at around 4:00pm and it was not busy. One of the staff said it often is busy early in the day. Cons- more info plaques would have been handyTips - Buy your ticket online and print it out. You can get one ticket for collisium and forum. - Didn't see bottled water on site so pick some up at the food trucks near the entrance. - there are washrooms on site

Photographer's dream!. Seriously, anywhere you point your camera, anything you capture, will turn out like a post card. This area is truly stunning - the ruins against the bright colours of the gardens are captivating, and it's a really lovely way to spend an hour, just walking through. No need for a tour or anything, just turn up, purchase your ticket, and off you go. There is also a map on entrance so you know what you're looking at :) Some photos from my latest trip are here - http://ordinarygirlextraordinarydreamer.com/2014/05/20/il-foro-romano-the-roman-forum-rome-italy/

Doesn't disappoint. We'll worth getting up early to avoid the queues as then are able to get a lot more space to yourself. The ticket you buy is allows entry to the palatine hill too and is well worth the price (price is reasonable anyway). The audio guide is also very good as provides a lot of additional information.

Wonderful ancient ruins to see with your own eyes.
