The Roman Forum was a great place to look around. 12 euros entry for the Roman Forum, Colosseum and Palatine Hill and you can use the Roma pass for this.I really enjoyed seeing all the history before my eyes. Plenty of wonderful photographic opportunities and lots of stories and information to absorb from tour guides.Take lots of water with you as the heat is stifling with no much opportunity to hide in the shade.I would definitely recommend visiting the Roman Forum to absorb Rome's great history!

Superb. The Roman Forum is a must-visit for all history lovers. It is vast in size and contains so many ruins to have a look at. It is a fascinating insight into ancient Rome. We visited here after the Colosseum, which is nearby. You need a good few hours to explore it fully but it is well worth it!

"Robust Rome". Its strange how ruins can captivate you as they shout out their stories.Highly recommend you to take a map or a guide to tell you exactly what is behind all that rubble.We found some applications on our phone which guided us through the forum where there was one where we could experience how the forum actually would have looked in the days of Julius Caesar and Emperor Augustus more than 2000 years ago."Roman Forum-Codegrind AB" & "Rick Steves' Tour:Roman Forum" are two of those.

Crowds. Luckily we had the Roma pass, so avoided massive queues, but there are still huge crowds. The queue for the ladies toilet was more than half an hour. It was worth walking in such an iconic place, however my husband was pick pocketed and lost his wallet somewhere in the crowds, despite wearing "pickpocket proof" pants! Very very upsetting.

Forum in ruins. Although you can read descriptions of the buildings and temples etc here, and learn what they were for, in truth it is now all in ruins. so you wander through the rubble and think on what must have been.

A second visit required. The Roman Forum has lots to see and is well worth a visit. However doing it on your own I think is a mistake. If I were to return I would take a tour where all the statues and buildings are explained. Its a vast area so make sure you have plenty of time and good walking shoes!!!!

You're on your own at the Roman Forum. Tickets to the Forum and the other ruins nearby are expensive and you get no maps, no guidance, and zero information about any of the ruins. We walked around in the hot afternoon sun up and down dirt & rocky slopes and saw many exhausted tour groups. Besides that, unless you're interested in the other ruins, you can see the Forum from the sidewalk. Save your money.

Roman Forum. i bought an english tour for the colosseum. i was told that it included the Roman Forum . Ticket was good for two days. The Roman forum used to be free. NOW they charge for it. 21 euros a piece. I love Rome but if you dont be careful they will nickel and dime you for everything. We returned the next day and my husband forget his stub. We did not want to taxi back to the hotel. They told us they if we returned with the stub they would give us a refund and recharged us 21 euros a piece. This if after we already paid for the english tour that included the forum. We did it because we were promised a refund. DONT BELIEVE THEM. When we tried later to receive our refund, they asked for our paid stubs. I gave them what they wanted and then they said they could not issue a refund. This is after I was told I could by the gatekeeper and ticket office personal. 21 euros is almost 50 dollars. This was after i fully paid for the event the day before. They are rude and uncaring. They denied everything. Watch your money. Don't believe these people. Bad management and worthless supervisors. i ended up paying alot of money to see this event that should be free. Dishonest people at the forum gate. Watch our for yourself and if they tell you an event is included ask them what and how you are guaranteed entrance.

Ancient architecture. The Roman Forum is surrounded by the ruins of several important ancient government buildings that is nearby Colosseum.You can travel by metro from Termini to Colosseum then go to Roman Forum and Piazza VeneziaIt's very good if you have a trip visiting this place at night because sometimes we can see the Roma historical film on the wall at the right of the direction from Colosseum to Piazza Venezia.
Take a picnic to the forum. Absolutely brilliant ... Would recommend it to everyone .. Fascinating place : ) take a picnic ... It's like stepping back in time.
Walk up behind the forum on Palatine Hill. A nice walk up behind the forum on Palatine Hill will give you a quiet and pleasant escape from the crowds.

Historic landmark. The Roman Forum is centrally located near the Colosseum . The antiquity and history can be mind boggling. Definitely a must see in Rome. Be prepared for rain or shine. Since this is a low lying area, wear comfortable shoes that can take possible rapid run off water!

A must see in Rome. Pre-book entrance tickets to skip lines (http://www.florence-tickets.com/colosseum-%28-audioguide%29---roman-forum---palatine.html), and enjoy audio guide to get the most out of the visit. If you can find a guide for Roman Forum, it's most likely worth paying for (so much to see and learn).

So much history. Amazing place but pay for a tour (unless you know your Roman history) there is so much to see it is well worth the cost but to know what you are actually looking at makes it an amazing place.

Impressive. Plenty to see at the forum as the site is reasonably large and there is still a lot left standing which was a surprise. Though not as crowded as the Colosseum the site still had a lot of people there. I thoroughly enjoyed wandering through the site for a couple of hours. Like most ancient sites naked sure you have good walking shoes and plenty of drinking water.

History is never closer. I love Forum Romanum. I recommend doing a little reading about the place before entering it - it adds to the experience. This time we went in the early afternoon on a hot summers day. Big mistake. Forum is is of course located lower than the rest of the city, and the air stood still, making this visit strenuous this time. My advice: go early in the morning, before the city heats up. Because you should always visit Forum!
Amazing. To actually walk in the same footsteps as Marcus Aurelius and Julius Cesar was worth braving the rain! Take the time to walk along the paths, if you're a history buff its just surreal!

History before your eyes. It is just amazing to visit the Roman Forum. Avoid the very hot and sunny days. Try to enjoy the view from "Via dei for imperiali" in the evening with the sunset and you will remember me. Sad to think that to construct this specific "via" a large part of the forum romano had to be destroyed.

could've spent the entire day there. the roman forum was the best part of rome hands down! you easily could've spend the whole day there. there are so many trails to walk and explore we didn't even explore half of it. it is just amazing to think that these ruins are over 1000 years old. rome is such a great city because the forum is next to a busy road that you can see the forum from. the roman forum is just a short walk to the colosseum.

Just ruins. Not very much to see...only some marble columns-the vestiges of ancient temples,the marble Arch of Septimius Severus-probably the only structure pretty well preserved here.As for the rest-only spreaded stones.Nothing to remember you about the magnificence of that ancient times.

Get close to history. The Roman Forum is a great place to visit. Unlike other cities, Rome is a city where you are encouraged to walk in history's footsteps. You can actually get close to historical pieces, resting on columns that have been there hundred of years! If you are from the EU and under 18 or over 65, bring your passport as proof- you get in free! Also, bring water as there are very few shady places. It is well worth a visit though, you can still see the groves in the stone slabs where chariots were driven on them. There are some information signs dotted around so you can get the general idea of what happened and what everything was used for by reading as you walk, and you can spend as long as you like. I would recommend this attraction.

Enjoyable. Had a wonderful guide for this part of the tour, Rory took us on a walk through history and architecture of the Forum.Amazing views when you get to the top of the hill. If you are not good at walking hills you may struggle. does get a bit steep.

Beautiful ruins - lots to see.. I love visiting old ruins and walking through history, so I absolutely loved the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. Unfortunately we went during July, so we were at risk of over heating from just walking around. We bought the audio guide, but only used it from time to time - bringing a guide book may have yielded better results. I loved seeing the various temples in Forum area as well as the gardens. My partner was especially impressed by the arches, which is unsurprising because the Arch of Titus and the Septimius Severus Arch are obvious marvels of architecture and artistry. The Forum represents an important site and time in history and going there should be a must-do for anyone visiting the city. It's beautiful to be able to walk back in time like that. Make sure you bring plenty of water and wear comfortable walking clothes and shoes.

A great walk through history.. Amazing to think of everything that happened in this forum as you walk through it. Loaded with history, I'd definitely book a guide or tour to take you through this and help you understand what all the great structures were.

A fantastic tour. Booked on-line with Viator for a semi private skip the line tour. Our guide, Barbara a young lady from Poland, was brilliant. Her knowledge of each of the places was extensive. This tour is worth every penny.

Pure history. When you go to the Forum romanum you usually have the combined ticket which includes the admission for the colosseo just next to the Forum. You have to be careful with the entry because you can only enter once so decide wisely when you really want to visit the forum. You will need a lot of time in there, take sun screen and a hat with you. It would be recommendable to buy a guide or a brochure which explains you the old ruines since there are a lot.. but it is worth visiting the old ruines, very impressive!

If you're quiet you can feel it. There was a vibrant life in this area, busy night and day centuries ago, and if you stand or sit quietly, even amongst all the tourists, you can feel the energy. If you can find one of the books being sold locally called Now and Then, get it before you go into the Forum. It will show you what you are seeing Now and has overlays of what it looked like Then when it was part of the everyday life of Romans. You will understand it so much more that way. A walking tour is really worth the money, and can be combined with a tour of the Colosseum..a great package. Take your time, this has been here for centuries, you've waited for ever to come see, enjoy it. You can stay here after your tour guide leaves you, go back and take your time .

Very limited information about the monument. I really wanted to visit Roman Forum for years, but when I got inside, I was disappointed. You will not learn anything without the giude (extra fee) and I'm the type of tourist that likes to visit on my own. In Scandinavia when you visit monuments, where there are information about everything inside in several languages, and guides are available on request, but they don't stalk tourists. Apparently in Italy the culture is different. The written infrmation is very limited, the signes inside Roman Forum and Palatine Hill are quite misleading, so you go in circles, instead of having orderly tour.

rained and no shelter. It rained heavily and ruined our visit to the Roman Forum but I was disappointed with the lack of information about the places. Boards carried a lot of details if you are English speaking but there were a lot of maybes in there. Needs the time team to dig into it all.
Roman Forum. Tremendously interesting and historical site. The views from on top is gorgeous. The gardens are beautiful. Hours can be spend just wondering around and reading about the past.

Suggest a Tour. I loved this site! I would only suggest getting a tour: we bought a 2 day pass with the Collosseum, but didn't realize you could only enter each location one time. We entered the Forum late in the day, assuming we could go back the next day to get a tour. The ticket was only for one admission to each location, so we could not go back and get a tour as planned. Walking around, we did find many more signs along the public sidewalks that described more of the buildings that can be seen without a ticket.

What a feeling of being in touch with ancient history..... The Forum was, by far, the most impressive statement of the historical impact that Rome once was in the ancient world. I went to the Colosseum, the Pantheon, and countless other places, but none quite was as visual to me as what I could imagine being a normal day here in ancient times at the Forum. You can almost see it....the bustling vendors and the people at the market...I strongly recommend spending the time to see this site.
Ancient world spectacular. Thoroughly enjoyed seeing the Arch of Titus, the site where Caesar was cremated, the Forum. Makes my childhood history lessons come to life!

Good - but check opening times!. A group of 7 of us went to the Forum and were excited to see such a great piece of history. Sadly, due to government strikes it was closed for an unknown amount of time. There were no attendents and no one to explain why or when it woudl re-open. We only found out it was due to a strike because someone who spoke Italian told us what a piece of paper taped to a side gate said. While we were not able to get in you can still get great views from outside and we were able to admire and take good pictures from there.

Great walk, get a guided tour to appreciate what you're looking at. We got tickets for the Roman Forum from a guided tour we took through the Colosseum with Walks of Italy. We did the Eternity in a Day tour, which bypassed the Forum, but we got a little explanation of it from the outside. The next day we used our Colosseum tickets to get into the Roman Forum. I feel we should have probably gotten a guided tour through this place as it contains SOOOO much history and we couldn't really get a solid explanation of everything we were looking at and what took place in some areas until after the fact (i.e. Rostra, where Mark Antony gave Julius Caesar's euology). Signs are marked on some monuments throughout but it's short and leaves you wanting more knowledge of what you're looking at. Temple of Jupiter was impressive as well as the Arches. Worth spending about 1.5 hour there, after that you kind of get sick of looking at stuff in there, esp when all you have is a guidebook. Try to get a guided tour and justs get past the idea of walking in a group and wearing the funny headsets they give you. If you're a tourist, you're going to stand out regardless with all the water you carry, buying stuff from the street vendors and the likely backpack you're going to be wearing. It's not worth trying to blend in by avoiding the guided tours. I wish we would have. Not sure if Walks of Italy has a tour that actually goes into the forum. Check out their website though, we had very knowledgeable guides through the Colosseum and Vatican on the tour we did do.

History in full. The Roman Forum is full of ancient history that is very pleasing but the overall experience was not my favorite. Some parts of it almost look like a building graveyard. The highlight for myself was seeing the tomb of Julius Cesar where people still almost on a daily basis leave flowers. If you dont go in with a guide or someone who knows about some of the peices of building you will be lost and not know exactly what you are looking at.

Take a skip the line tour - queues are horrible otherwise. We had an italian guide with a lovely sense of humour and huge knowledge about the subjects. The Roman Forum was amazing and the old buildings breathtaking. To walk around a place that has so much history.... something you have to do once in your life.

Enjoyed the Roman Forum. There are really three entrances into the Forum. I took the one directly uphill from the Colosseum. The walkways are dark gray cobblestone and lead you through the arches, columns, and buildings from 2000 years ago. I visited in April 2014 and the wildflowers were beginning to come out in the grass around the ruins and some out of the ruins themselves. It added to the wonderful feel of the place. There are private walking tours available, but I chose to walk it alone with my Rick Steves’ guide book. They say you can walk it in an hour. I took two and a half hours and enjoyed looking at all the details you miss if you are walking right through it. I didn’t get to see it at night because the Pope was holding Good Friday Stations of the Cross and they were putting up tents and security. The Forum was one of my favorite sites to visit. Unfortunately I could not make it up to the Palatine Hill.

Overwhelming. We saw all these sights without purchasing a ticket. Our original plan was to get one, but in the end we could see so much of it without going in that it seemed a little unnecessary, especially with all the lines we would have to battle.Just be sure that you've done your research to know the history of the sites. For example, the arch of Julius Caesar, where he was killed---we could see that there would be no way to stand in the arch where he stood---it was all blocked off anyway. We got a better picture from a distance.

Enjoyed walking around and exploring Roman Forum. Our tour guide took us to the Roman Forum and narrated the history of Rome there. Had a nice walk at the Roman Forum and saw all the marvelous ruins. Were totally transported back in time.

Spectacular bit of history just meters from the Colosseum.. After visiting the Colosseum we only really headed to the Roman Forum as it was so close by and we are really glad we did. We used our second entry of our Roma card here and spend a good while walking about. The buildings are amazing and far bigger than I had imagined.

History at its best. A remarkable historical area well worth a visit. We bought a ticket from coopculture. Ordered online, printed it off, and the barcode scanned great. The advantage was getting past the long queue at The Colosseum to get in. There is a water fountain in the grounds of the Forum so make sure you fill up before you leave. Plenty of clean toilets as well.
old roman. If you want to really feel Rome then visit the roman forum. It provided so much context to our history of italy. It was breathtaking to be amongst the uncovered ruins.

A must see, along with the Colosseum - one admission price. This was a must see for us on our first trip to Rome. It's a combo ticket with the Colosseum, you cannot buy separate entrance. The ticket is good for 48 hours, but important to note that if you enter a site on day 1, you cannot re-enter on day 2. Therefore, if you enter both the Colosseum and Forum/Palantine Hill on day 1, there is no going back for day 2. This is an important distinction that is not always clear.We did this on a tour, with a group called Italy With US, whom we found outside (did not plan tour ahead of time). I would definitely recommend taking a tour if you can. A tour will allow you to skip the lines, which can be very long. In addition, you'll also learn a lot more about the site, the ruins. On your own, it may not look like much or you won't know what you are looking at, other than a ruin of something that was once spectacular. You could easily spend 2+ hours just in the Forum/Palantine Hill. We did our tour and then lingered around on our own for a while (tour was 2 hours for Colosseum and Forum, did not include Palantine Hill). The ruins of the Forum recall the grand empire that once existed. The Palantine Hill was interesting, but to a much lesser degree in my opinion. Could be that we were just tired after a long day but the ruins were not nearly as impressive as the Forum, you had to use your imagination a lot more to envision what was once there. Lots of walking, lots of uneven ground. There is a spout or 2 to refill water bottles. Wear comfortable, sturdy shoes. This might be unpleasant in the extreme heat of summer - was ok in mid-late May when we visited, although we definitely got some sunburn.

did this via a tour that included the colosseum. Our tour operator, Greg, was a funny guide. He took us from the Colosseum to the Roman Forum, which is a little walk away, so wear comfortable shoes, especially for what is next. So, you get to the Forum and go inside (entrance fee covered by tour) and you have to walk 100 steps, no joke. In the heat, at the pitch the steps were at, half our tour was huffing and puffing. Wear comfortable shoes. Lots of stairs on this one. There are a couple of those famous Rome water fawcets to top off your water bottle for free, so take advantage of the freebie.

Almost as exciting as the Colosseum- and free!. You don't need tickets to just walk around the Forum and Palatine Hill area and it's incredibly breathtaking. After you leave the Colosseum, walk up the sidewalk towards the Forum and then just follow the crowd around and you can see a lot of cool sites within a mile in ancient Rome.

Standing in the ruins of the Roman Empire. If possible, the Palatine hill is underappreciated as a destination, romantic, historic to itself, not as visited as the Forum. Excavations are ongoing in the back, promising to uncover even more about the days of the Roman empire. What is amazing about the Forum itself is the compactness of so many important structures in a defined area. Each ruin, each inch drenched in historical meaning.Take lots of water, and pace yourself for the climbs. Wear very comfortable shoes. It is crowded, and gets very hot.

Enormous. This was breathtakingly beautiful. But a warning: unless you have 7 hours to burn and don't have children tagging along, don't go in with the expectation of seeing all of it. Just walk through, enjoy where the trail takes you, and when you get tired call it a day. This place is gigantic. Wear plenty of sunscreen, a hat, water bottle, sunglasses, and bring some heavy duty walking shoes. No heels or flimsy shoes, because you will regret it.The roman forum is like stepping into another world. Straight away you are struck by the splendour and the scale of it all.Definitely a must see if you are visiting Rome.

Wish I had more time. Definitely worth the time to take a look at. So much history in the bones of the city.** Tip: If you plan on visiting the Colliseum the same day as the Roman Forum, buy tickets here first ! It's valid for admission to both, and having the ticket ahead of time saves you over an hour waiting in the massive line at the Colliseum. You literally bypass hundreds of people this way. **
A great place for the NFL. Loved the architecture. Hated that most of it was covered by scaffolding although I'm happy to see it's being cleaned.

Absolutely amazing!!. My husband and I visited the Roman Forum/ruins as part of our honeymoon trip to Italy. My husband is very interested in Ancient Rome and we had both done a fair amount of reading up on the subject before making the trip in order to try to get the most out of it. The ruins are so special to see and include the Arch of Titus, the Arch of Septimus Severus, various basilicas, the House of the Vestal Virgins, the hut village where it is believed Romulus may have lived, Augustus' house...the list goes on!! We originally visited the ruins as part of a Colosseum tour but we felt we were far too rushed in the ruins so we went back on our own later. We are glad we did!! To see everything in the ruins and to look at it in the depth which we wanted to took about 6 hours. The ruins are quite confusing and it is easy to miss large parts, so I recommend making a whole day of it and taking a slow walk round so as to see as much as possible. If you're not all that clued up about Ancient Rome then I'd also recommend reading a short introduction or watching Mary Beard's Meet The Romans series before you go, as although the ruins do have signposts offering some explanation, they don't go into great depth.The ruins really make you feel as though you're closer to the history of a great Empire and brought the books we had read to life. There are some really beautiful things to see, not just the Arches and the remains of the Temples but also the Farnese Gardens with its beautiful flowers and orange trees.If you are wanting to visit Augustus' house then be aware that this is only open between I think 10am and 1pm as guides have to be present so that only a few people at a time can go in. The part of the house that is open is small, but worth a look if only to see the remains of the decoration on the walls and ceilings. It's quite modest compared to Nero's extravagance but interesting nonetheless!!All in all we really enjoyed our time at the Roman Forum and would certainly go back if we are in Rome again.

History brought to life for us!. Had a wonderful tour of the Forum as part of a package we committed to at the Colosseum. It was beyond words to explain what it was like to wander through this space that was basically at the heart of so much of our history. To rest against pillars and hear the stories, then wonder if in fact Caesar had also leaned against this same marble. I was in heaven to finally have the chance to experience this space after dreaming about witnessing it for my entire life.

The Forum; Living History. It's incredible that modern Rome lives cheek by jowl with the ancient city. The Forum is the place to start, with a good guidebook if you want to grasp the foundations of the city. It is thrilling to walk through and touch the places where the ancients went about their days. If you only do one thing, this should be it.

Walk as the ancient Romans did 2000 years ago. Today I walked the streets, as a ancient Roman did, over 2000 years ago, the only difference is that the buildings I viewed were in ruins, and not in their luxurious condition way back then. As I walked the ancient street level, 10 meters lower than modern Rome's street level, it was very surreal to imagine chariots, being driven up and down the stone streets, carting the materials to construct these magnificent buildings, by hand and have stood the test of time, unlike todays buildings. Down side of the Forum area are:- the directional signage, once inside is very poor, - there are perhaps 2 toilet blocks (which are extremely dirty and unmaintained) for the while area, - there is no food available to purchase. There are only shady indian men sell water in some areas for €1- unless you hire a audio guide, paper maps are not provided. Tickets are €12.00 each and also include the Colosseum, which allows you to jump the very, very long queues at the Colosseum.Other than the few negatives, its a great outing to see Ancient Rome.

Vebatim. If you go to Roma- the Roman Forum is a must amongst the other infamous sites (Colleseo, Circus Maximus etc). This place is situated by the Colosseum & is very easy to navigate through. As you walk through the many arches a path leads you onwards to this magnificent area with remnants of what would've been the meeting grounds of many important figures back in time. Standing within this area, you can feel transported back in time- with the strong roman foundations right through the ambience and smells. Make sure you explore this site- not to be missed.

So Much History To See.. Visitors to Rome will enjoy this attraction.  Located next to the Colosseum, It is an important architectural site where you can see and learn so much. We completed the Colosseum Tour and then went to the Forum. By chance we found a side entrance where we were able to walk straight in without queuing. Entry is included with your Colosseum ticket price.It can be quite exhausting walking around this large area, particularly when the weather is hot. There is no opportunity to purchase food or drink so ensure you take with you what you need.  A truly remarkable historic site which  let's  your imagination run wild as to how it may have looked so many centuries ago! You really need a guide or information book because there are very few signs providing details of what you are looking at!wonderful photographic opportunities.

History amidst civilization. The best view of the Forum is from up above on the hill. Definitely need a map or audio guide as it is difficult to know what is what without one. Be sure to visit on an overcast or cooler day as there is little shade to keep you cool.

Who would go to Rome and not see this?. This was my second time seeing this site. It's crowded, it's touristy but you have to go and wonder at what the Romans built and that it's still around after all this time. It's really pretty amazing to walk on and into a structure that is that old and that has lasted through the dark ages into modern times. We took a Context tour this time and that made the whole touristy thing more pleasant since we bypassed the lines and had an amazing guide. After seeing a bunch of the other Roman sites (Domus, Pompeii, Herculaneum, Baths of Carcalla, etc.) this really capped off our tour.
Excellent Roman site. The Forum is a great place to view the runis and take a step back in time. Make sure you have an audio guide or you may not have any idea what you are looking at!

Fabulous history. Any ancient history buff will love the Colosseum. This is a great start to a history day, as you can spend a couple of hours here before moving on to the Forum. You do have to wiat in lines and pay to get in, but once you are in it is worth it.

A must see.. If this is the only thing you do you can leave Rome satisfied. Being there really helps you visualize the past. But it is just jaw dropping what they were able to build so long ago. Brilliant!
Amazing place full of history. This is an iconic place, vast and so well described that one can imagine it in its time -, barbaric as it now seems

Spectacular. One thing I would recommend is going through the Roman Forum first and buying your pass there. It cost 12 euros a person to get into the attractions at the gate. The line to buy the pass at the Forum gate is very short and takes about 5 minutes. If you go to the coliseum first the line is exceptionally longer, everyone wants to see this first or this only possibly. You will save LOTS of time entering the Forum first, and then walking over to the coliseum after because you already have your ticket to get in. Both places are excellent. If you like the Forum and want to see more like this I would recommend going to Ostia Antica and going through the ruins there. These ruins are not as popular but you can take the metro busses the whole way there from the main station in Berlin (termini). At Ostia you can walk throughout the ruins and touch almost everything there. We were there for 3 hours walking and only saw half the city. I would recommend Ostia Antica to anyone who wants to really see an ancient city.

Worth crossing an ocean for. My wife and I have travelled the world. These 3 places are among the top things we have seen in our lives, ranked up there with the Great Wall of China, the Moais of Easter Island, the fjords of Norway. The Palatine Hill (where Rome began 700 BC) with it's views and ruins of the homes of the various Caesars, the Coliseum that held 70,000 people 2,000 years ago, and the Forum with the breathtaking architecture and huge scale are truly awe-inspiring.

Part of the Included tour - Very good guide. This was part of the included tour in our Cosmopolitan Europe Tour. Amazing place and architecture and design specially of the Colloseum. The lower floor was amazing. Likewise, the ruins of the Roman Forum was something to behold. To top that we had a fabulous guide in Fabiola

A must see visit!. The audio trip was so informative. Learnt a lot about the history and was a great visit. Although the queue for tickets was long, it went quickly enough and was well worth the wait!

Incredible!. Even though we had skip-the-line tickets, the ticket process was confusing. I'm not sure if that was something to do with our driver's instructions or if it's the norm. Still, it was well-worth the wait. I wish now we had hired a guide. Even without one, it's an incredible place to see and think about the history of it all. Our favorite views were from the upper levels.

a must see. A City Wonder's tour (our guide was Nikola) covers all 3 areas and is so full of detail and fun facts - its a lot of walking and lasts around 3 hours but so worth it - my favourite day of our trip

Must see. I think the first place you have to see. It is just a dream. A well protected place. Tickets prices are normal. Colloseum is very attractive. In my opinion the best time to visit this place is May or begginig of the June. Becasue it is too hot. If you have a child with you it is better to not take stoller with you. Becasue the roads are not very suitable.

When in Rome.... If you're in Rome, you're here to see the main sights and there is no avoiding the tourist in this area of the city- but it's also something you must take advantage of at least once in life. I always recommend people to read up on these kind of places before going and not just in a little guide book while you are already in the area. If you know a bit about the history and stories of what has taken place here, you can truly enjoy these sights that are still available for us to enjoy today! A little bit of money out of your wallet to step back to hundreds and hundreds of years ago- is well worth it in my opinion! Find yourself a good guide (not something to find a cheaper option for) and you will really appreciate your trip in Roma!
Review. Great tour, very informative. A lot of walking so not really suitable for those with mobility issues. Open to the elements so not very good in the rain.

Private tour of the Colosseum. We booked a Presto Tours for the Colosseum and truly enjoyed it. We were told the tour would be a maximum of 12 people but there was only my husband and I. I was surprised they did not cancel the tour but was impressed they kept their part of the bargin and showed up for the tour. Our tour guide was excellent.
Amazing place to see. We visited all of these places Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forums. Spent an entire day there. We had a guided tour for the Colosseum. It was great. Highly recommend.
One of the Worlds Great structures. This is one of those places in the world where if you are in the city you have to visit and view. This has so much history and you have to respect that

Definitely worth a visit!. Amazing to see the ruins and visualise how these would have looked back in Empire times. We didn't have any issues with queuing in May (although prob best to avoid weekends if possible).
Work of art still preserved worth admiring. Gives us an idea how Human race believed in Courage & barbarism where man fought with animals worth imaginating

Don't Miss This One. I would imagine that the most visited landmark in Rome is the Colosseum and it's easy to see why.It's a truly spectacular place, one that you have to see with your own eyes to appreciate the size, beauty and elegance of what the Romans did thousands of years ago. Photos can't really do it justice.My big tip is to get a Roma Pass or equivalent as the queues are huge, even during the 'quieter' periods. They can easily snake half way around the Colosseum and take hours to get inside. With a pre-paid ticket it took about 10 minutes. My other tip is to get an audio tour which really helped me to understand the history of the place, and just how brutal and bloody the battles that took place there were.Palatine Hill & Roman Forum: These are a collection of buildings, structures and gardens that sit opposite and around the Colosseum. Again, there's a huge slice of history found inside and they are well worth a visit.

A Must See Part of Rome. This is my second visit it the Colosseum in 12 months. This time I was bringing my mother. The first time was a bit of a whirlwind. It was my first time in a Rome and it is a struggle to take it all in. To get the most out of the Colosseum you need to give it about 3 hours. There are several levels and a really good museum section with various finds from not just Rome but other important digs.My mum uses a stick and found the lift really helpful. The staff were also helpful as we came in with directions.I don't have any Cons just tips. 1. Get your tickets in advance, they can be bought over the internet, this is what I did. They also get you into the Forum and Palatine hill. They can also be bought as a Roma Pass from loads of places around Rome. You skip the queues completely. Also check if you are entitled to a free ticket. My mum is 66 and she was just a 2 euro processing fee.2. If you have a buggy or a wheelchair or just can't do stairs there is a lift. As you come in just keep going forward on the ground floor, it's about 200ft along.3. If you want to go to the underground levels or the top level you must be on an authorised tour.4. Water. In the hotter months don't buy more than one bottle of water. There are drinking fountains all over Rome and they are free and the water is cold and delicious . There is one in the colosseum on the ground level.5. Only one set of toilets, they are in a portacabin on the ground floor and in summer are very busy and a bit smelly. You have been warned.6. Don't bother with the souvenir carts outside. I think they are the most expensive in the city. The ones just outside the Forum are much cheaper. Also outside the a Forum is the man who paints Watercolours. His small mounted pictures are only 5 euro and very lively.7. Watch out for the Roman Soldiers. They are great to get your picture with but you will need to pay.

Not to be missed!. This trifecta includes so much history in such a walkable distance in the centre of the city. The guided tour was excellent or at least have a guide book or the Rick Steves audio download when you visit these places to get the most out of your visit.
fantastic. had a guide and it was fantastic, amazing place and took my breath away. so easy to find, just come out of the metro and its right in front of you.

A "must be". the place is incredible - don't miss. i suggest standing in line (for us, in May at 10:30 AM it took no more than 20 minutes and you get for 12€ a combined entrance). Don't buy the "special" tickets that cost much more and give you little extra...
A must see!. Make sure you pay for a ticket before you go but tick the box for the audio as it is very interesting and the footage is fantastic!

Great walking tour. We combined the Coliseum and Roma Forum and got a great double dose of history. I'd recommend you bring good walking shoes and prepare for some very uneven and stony walkways in the forum area. Folks in wheel chairs, using walking assistance and with baby strollers should do their homework on the forum walking areas and accessibility.

I have said Colesseum was my favourite but also did the rest here. This is my post for Palatine Hill and Roman Forum. It was ok but if you walk around the outside of this area you can see a lot anyway so if on a budget do that its then free. Would I do Colosseum again yes would I do the rest no.

This is what I came to see. Could easily spend all day at this amazing place, this is what people come to see, it is amazing to imagine what the greatest of ancient cities looked like in its heyday. I was busy with my camera, trying to take it all in - fantastic.
Step back in time. Wonderful to see how history has been preserved. Visited as part of our Roma Pass so great value. Didn't go on tour but others said was amazing as went to top of Colosseum

guided tour. we took part at a guided tour which they offered us in front of the colosseum. i would recommend doing that since you can avoid the lines. the tour took approx 40 min. and was 18 eur. the group was smal (max 15 people) and we only had to wait 10 min. until the tour started. the colosseum is a very historical place I would recommend to visit. the ticket also includes the palatine hill and the roman forum.
Love it. So much history. Truly amazing. Doing a tour here is worth it, you'll learn so much more. I'll come back and learn much more each time.

A must-see when in Rome!. If you're in Rome I assume you know you have to visit the Colosseum. What impressed me most is that the 2 day admission ticket costs just €12 and covers the Forum and the Palatine as well. It really is good value for money, and make the most of your time there by getting your ticket at the Forum entrance where the queue is way shorter than at the Colosseum itself. You can spend as long as you like at all three of the attractions, they are all fantastic sights.Bring a water bottle so you can refill at the many free fountains in the area. Colosseum was half clad in scaffolding when I was there but doesn't detract from the experience at all. Guess they should have built it a bit better in the first place.

Must do!!. We loved it, a few things that you need to know to avoid the crowds, purchase your ticket for all 3 sites from palatine hill ticket box, it's 3 minutes from the colosseum and will save you an hour at least.When you go back to the colosseum, there are people offering tours for about 15 euro, it's great value and you will skip the lines, these tours are all the same and are a great way to learn a little bit, there's no point wondering around if you don't know what your looking at!You can do all 3 in one day, it's a big day but it's such an amazing place, just watch the pick pockets!!Loved it and can't recommend it highly enough.
Amazing. Loved the Colosseum. I bought a fast track tickets online so did not have to wait in a big line. It was amazing. Would recommend. Just dont forget water and a camera.

Incredible. We visited as part of our Colosseum Tour. I have to say that without a guide you wouldn't really get the scale or importance of some of the buildings. In fact our guide had some sketches of what the area looked like 2000 years ago which really helped to bring the place to life.Well worth a wander through these ancient building and even better if you have a great sense of imagination!Take a bottle of water with you as it can get very hot with little shadeYou might feel that you've had enough but you really do need to walk up on to the Palatine Hill - stick with it because eventually you get the best view of the Colosseum - it all fits onto your camera and is the one you'll end up showing the folks back home...Hope this helps

A view of ancient Rome. To those who have read ancient European history, this is a time machine into the past. These are must see places. Much has been written, so I do not have to add to it. What I want to comment is that we took a semi-private walking tour with a company called "Overome". It was worth every penny.

Phenomenol. Remarkable. Take a tour for a more thorough understanding. Many will take you to the highest level that others can't get to, as well as the lower level. Afterwards, walk through the neighboring palantine Hill area, with its own ruins, structures, and so much history. Amazing stuff.Bring snacks!By the way, the bathrooms at the Colisseum aren't great, and have loooooong lines.

Overwhelming with history. Watching it I could almost imagine the buildings in their full splendour. When looking over the forum from the Capitoline hill you can have a real comparison between the sizes of structures and the people passing by down there.
ancient rome. Peaceful in forum, bur very busy in colosseum. Bring water and a hat, and wear flat shoes for the ancient paving. We had a guide which really brought it to life for us

The hub of the Roman Empire. There really is far too much to see in Rome in a single day and we only had the time to overlook the Forum from above rather than buy tickets to explore it at ground level. If we are ever in Rome again we will have to rectify this omission as all that I have read about the Forum certainly indicates that it is worth a long detailed look.

Exhausting to do in one day but worth it!. The ticket you buy is valid for all three sites and I'd recommend you get your tickets from the Palantine Hill/Forum entrance as there was barely a queue there and the Coliseum had very long queues. Also do the Palantine Hill and Forum first and the Coliseum second as that site will be quieter in the afternoon. Take a bottle with you which you can refill at one of the many drinking water fountains in the Forum. Don't skip the Palantine Hill - it's worth walking all round all of it. There's a great view over Rome from the top.

Jaw droppingly beautiful. Having not heard much about palantine hill and roman forum, i didnt really know what to expect. All i knew was that i had to go see the colloseum. We brought tickets from an operator outside the colloseum for 20 euros which enabled us to jump the extremely long queue and join a guided tour. This tikets also gave us entry to the palantine hill and roman forum. The collaseum is vast and stunning but for me the roman forum and palantine hills were breath taking. In no other place then here did i really feel like i was in rome the real rome which conquered half the world thousands of years ago. The craftmanship of these people is so impressive and there really is nothing in todays age that can compete. Take the time to read the information posts which give you a real insight into exactly what purpose each structure held. Get ready to be amazed at what the final resting place of the great caeser is and how disapointing a structure is it given this mans legacy. Tip... Wear comfortable shoes. By comfortable i mean trainers the roman paths are a little worn and walking on them all day will take its toll.

Rome's most important attraction!. Take at least one full day to visit all and include the "Mercatti di Trajano" close by. Either with a guide or by your own (use the Roma Pass and the audio-guide rented at the entrance).

Why?. I think that I have written this before. However I will repeat. This is why you are in Rome. If you don't go to the Form then you have not really been here. Not everything is open all of the time. If you know Rome then you know that this is true. The Servian terraces on the Palatine are exquisite; as is the temple of Venus and Rome. If they are not open, well then, you will just have to go back. Your Forum ticket will cover your visit to the Colosseum. And it will allow you to skip the horrendous line that it invariably has. Go when the weather is beautiful and spend for ever; or go when it rains and have it to yourself.

Impressive. This was a history filled day and quite frankly it was too much to do in one day, but well worth the time and effort. The Colosseum alone is almost a half day venture with lots of stairs. Get a Rome Pass. It is a must, to avoid the long lines. We bypassed all of the hours long lines and went right in. The audio-video self tour was the best because we could proceed at our own pace and really stop and see, and read, and photograph. Even so it took us almost half a day. The Palatine Hill and Roman Forum are also history rich and we enjoyed them immensely, at our own pace, but by the end of the day the cab ride to the hotel was a must!

The reason why I chose to visit Rome. Let's be honest - going to Rome just for the Renaissance sights isn't enough. In my eyes the "newer" structures are nothing in comparison to the ancient Roman remains, on top of which is the Colosseum. After seeing many other Roman sights in my own country Bulgaria and the neighbouring countries, seeing these places is like going to the source.

Every bit as impressive as I had imagined. Expect to queue unless with a guided tour and beware the steps they are very steep and if you have mobility issues you should seek out the lift which takes you to the upper levels

Private Tour of Underground. Great private tour. It started beneath the floor of the Colosseum and finished on the top level. A complete tour that shows how thinks we managed like a theater. There were lots of steps so get in condition to climb.

When in Rome.... These are among the sights you just HAVE to see when in Rome. The Colosseum is an impressive structure even in our modern era. It is unfortunate that most of the ancient buildings on the Palatine Hill and Roman Forum complexes have not withstood time as well, but still worth seeing. For all these attractions, I highly recommend getting the Roma Pass Card (available online or at Tourist Information Points around the city) to get into the express entry lines for these attractions (versus waiting 30-60 mins in the general ticket & entry lines).

Jump the Queue Tours. The best and easiest way to see the Colosseum, Forum and Palatine Hill is to go with a tour guide on a three hour tour and to skip the queue with approx. 25 others. The sights were inspiring and the guide gave lots of information and stories with a touch of humour. If you are flying from the UK it is cheaper to book these tours online before you go. Plenty of history and photos to take to remember these fantastic views and sights. Very busy with lots of commercialism outside of the sites but did not detract from the unique splendour and wonder of how these buildings were built. Some scaffolding around the Colosseum while it is being cleaned/preserved, but lots still to view. Well worth going inside the Colosseum as there is so much history and many artefacts still being dug up.The view from Palatine Hill is fantastic and a superb place to take photos of the surrounding ruins and buildings.

Fascinating Locations. We took our time & walked through and around these locations and were amazed of how well they have been preserved. Just trying to imagine what it would have been like to live in that time was mind blogging.

You can feel the history!. What an awe inspiring place. The size, its age and all that happened there. Incredible! A must see. I recommend you book a tour (Private Tours of Rome, for example). Make sure you take good shoes and water. There is A LOT of walking!

A Must of course. What can be said about these 3 main attractions of Rome that hasn't been said a million times before? Nothing! If you are in Rome, you are there for a reason, and one of those reasons is Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum. If you are into history as much as I am, you will be amazed at the grandeur of what was once the heart of the Roman Empire. Buy your tickets online in advance to avoid the lines. You can purchase 1 ticket that will cover all 3 sites. Start at the Forum, followed by Palatine, and the grand finale of Colosseum. You will need at least 4 hours, if you don't want to rush through it. Remember, that whether you go early in the morning, or in the afternoon, you will be surrounded by crowds, so don't even stress about the time. If you are planning on visiting in the summer, you will want to avoid going at noon, unless you enjoy 100 degree sun beating down on your head.And for those who like to dabble in photography-there are many wonderful opportunities for unbelievable pictures!
stunning. Looking at the Colosseum is just fascinating feeling. You can imagine what exactly was happening 2000 year ago and feel of the atmosphere
WOW!. Go and see it for yourself, you will not be disappointed. Watch out for pickpockets at all attractions and sites in rome.

I wanted more. While the whole experience was thrilling, I wanted more! It would have been wonderful to have been allowed to explore the lower levels where the animals were caged, or where the gladiators were gathered before entering the area. Luckily I have a vivid imagination, so the large crowds didn't detract from my enjoyment. Be prepared to climb lots of steep flights of steps. This is not a site for the frail or physically challenged.

Sensational area to visit. This is an amazing area to visit, you see so much that even with a guide it's hard to absorb everything, but we'll worth going. Only negative is all the street sellers outside peddling things and the regular warnings about pickpockets.

History at every turn!. Be sure to have a guide with you when you visit this area. Our group's guide was an archaeology professor. We learned so much from her. It's amazing to see how advanced the Roman Empire was - especially with tickets given at the Colosseum gates during ancient times!

not to be missed when you're in Rome. the colloseum is a truly unique experience in the world. a massive structure where roman games were held, very evocative. everyone knows this so it needs no intro. just saying that since I saw it last 20 years ago, it has improved a lot. much has been restored and more info is available. with 12 euro for a combination ticket with the forum, this is really a good deal. you'll need two half days to see it all.

Coliseum Tour. While we were able to skip the line, the Coliseum sponsored 1 hour tour was pretty average. The guide was not particularly enthusiastic- he was an archaeology student and we think he would rather have been digging!

wonderful but need energy not for faint hearted. It's a shame not all can share in this Vista to the eyes us of a certain age and strength could not push chairs up these hills and steps plus large cobbles must be of strong in legs these romans I suppose they where carried by there servants
Keep your ticket. Whichever one you go to first remember that the ticket also gives you entry to the others . Having the ticket saves you queuing for ages especially at the Colosseum.

So much to see here. Go early as the line/crowds build quickly. . Rent audiophones at the Colosseum. Lots to see in this area. Incredibly historical. Great walking area. Some hilly areas. Do it when the weather is good, as just about everything is outdoors. Not a place to visit in the rain, or even with high temps. Nothing to dislike.

Ticked off my list of places to see.... Glad we visited these, although I must say that I was disappointed with how they were maintained. I was expecting something really amazing, and was disappointed with the amount of scaffolding around, and the general air of ruin. Yes, I know, they are ruins... But considering the thousands of people who visit I thought more effort could have been made to ensure that the place looks its best. Overgrown greenery, no information signs, no map to guide you-- disappointing. Having said that, we enjoyed wandering around and I thought it was incredible to see how much history (that I will now research into myself) has been preserved.
Roaming around history. Amazing walking around these ruins seeing them up close after only reading about them........unbelievable!!

A Must See!. Of course this is truly an impressive site from afar, however inside it is even more breathtaking and I recommend getting a tour. We booked through tickitay.com (57 euros) and paid extra for a tour that included getting special entrance to the main floor, dungeon (which just opened 10/13) and the 3rd floor, which is not open to general public. It was well worth the extra money to just see this, however our guide made it even more interesting with her vast knowledge and excitement with the history. I am sure she did this tour daily but not once did I feel she was bored and was always very engaging, you could feel her passion! Please, please go inside as it is truly breathtaking!

Night tour. Went at night when closed to public, only 5 tours of about 20 people each inside. Lost some because at night but didn't have to deal with crowds or the ever present vendors. Got on floor as well as third level. Amazing history, hate the scaffolds were there but so be it. History of the area is amazing, truly can't miss.

Roman forum is worth going ... the Palatine hill, not so much!. I highly recommend going to the roman forum, not to sure if you should get the audio guide... You cant really tell when to press which number .- it is not organized/set up properly. The paletine hill, was not impressive at all. You can see better roman ruins around the city
Colosseum. Best advice we received from Limo in Rome - prebuy your tickets to the colosseum. Would do an audiotour next time though.

The ultimate Roman experience. Start at the Forum! There is always a shorter line, if any at all. Plan to go early, as the Forum closes around 6pm. This place is massive. You don't see the whole forum from the outside, you have to enter to see it all. An easy hour+ walkthrough without an audio tour. If you do the audio tour, it becomes an easy 3+ hours. Bring a lunch if you want, there are plenty of areas to sit and eat. And just think, you're having lunch where the ancient Romans used to walk! From there you can go to the Colosseum with the same ticket you have from the Forum. Now you get to skip the long line for ticket purchases and go straight inside! Colosseum closes around 6:30pm.
Coloseseum. Had a fantastic visit and tour of the Colosseum and Roman Forum. A must see for all visitors to Rome and would highly recommend a guided tour to truly appreciate the history of this area.

I recommend this to those who love History and Roman Empire. 2nd time to visit Colosseum, and I will keep on coming back. Lots of history here. The magnificent building and each blocks reminds me on how rich the history is.

Very interesting historical site. Unlike the Coloseum there are plenty of descriptions on site, meaning that you did not need a guide. We enjoyed a good three hours exploring and I learnt a lot about the area. I also found that the nearby forum was most interesting to see

Don't miss the Palatino. The colosseum is the "must see" attraction in Rome, but if you skip the Palatino, you'll miss the most interesting place. It's just across from the colosseum - our ticket got us in to both - but there are fewer people. It was fascinating to see where the "rich and famous" lived. Would also highly recommend for all Rome big attractions that you purchase online before you go....skipping the line everywhere made a huge difference to our ability to enjoy Rome.

Glad we saw it put wouldn't have waiting in the queues. Got to the colosseum around midday and thr queue was already 2 hours long. We paid an extra 13 euro each (so 25 each in total) for a guided tour and queue jump around the colosseum and roman forum, which was very informative and got you straight in to both areas

Do the lot in a day, start early. if you do all of this ina day on your own, start early, take water and apicnic, stop on the hilla nd take the views in for the picnic. There is so much tosee its a sensory overload and a cultural shock. Lots of reading, lots to take in.

Get a "Skip the Line Tour". We booked "Skip the line ' of Collosseum and ancient Rome, through Viator. it as administered by the City Tours. Our guide, Marriella, was fantastic. She is an Archiologist, and was a font of knowledge. She was easily heard through the earbuds, and she move along efficiently, while being very informative. This tour was a bargain because of what we learned.

OLD!!!. We were lucky enough to be with a Rick Steve's tour, we had pre-booked tickets and were the first to arrive, our Italian tour lady was superb!!! It is a great place to see and try to picture the history and how it is all still there after all these years!! have on good walking shoes!! Grazie! Kim
Great History. We went to Rome for the history and these sights delivered. Really enjoyed walking through the ruins and reading the information posted through out.

Brilliant place. I would love to be able to go back in time and see just how impressive this place was.The buildings, columns and ruins are really interesting. Very much worth a visit, wish I had more time to have a better look round.

Still grand today. Likes: My parents gained free entry as they were over 65! ( ID required for EU members) Quiet, so plenty of time to have a good look and take in the scale of the place.Disliked: Lots of scaffolding up at present on the outside, but repairs are being made. Also the amount of sellers on the streets surrounding the area trying to sell bags and tat. Spoils it a little!
Must see. An amazing place. Save yourself time by pre-purchasing tickets, the audio guide is also good to take you around the site.

Stunning. We arrived quite early on a Sunday morning and luckily beat the queues to the coliseum. We hired the audio tour, one of which unfortunately decided to stop on stop 3, but I would recommend doing this if you don't use a tour guide. The audio makes history come alive and you can imagine how it used to be like in its heyday. Palatine Hill was so much better than I could have imagined. Some of the sites are so well preserved and I found it completely fascinating.Would definitely recommend this if visiting Rome - was the highlight of our trip.We were lucky in that it was a warm day but not too hot, there is not much shade and I could imagine in the summer it would be very uncomfortable, there are no areas to buy water inside the attractions so buy before you go in from the various sellers outside, most charge just €1 for a bottle.

Wonderful venue!. Plan on spending half or more of your day here if you really want to enjoy it and not feel rushed - enter the Roman forum on the NE corner, but bring a sandwich and a bottle of water with you. The bottle can be refilled from the drinking fountains thru-out the site and the sandwich will come in handy by the time you reach the palatine hill in the late morning where you can find benches around the various gardens (there is no food service inside the venue). Enjoy a light lunch in the garden(s) and rest then proceed to the Colosseum.The Roma Pass is great for this because you will skip the ticket line at the Roman Forum and there is a dedicated (express entry) line at the Colosseum. The downside of the Roma Pass is that it does not include the 3rd ring and the underground at the Colosseum, nor the audio guide (maybe they will make this option available someday).

avoid the queues and buy your ticket at the forum. definitely worth visiting all 3 sites - amazing that so much is left in the middle of a huge city, 2,000 years on !We followed a tip from a guidebook and bought our joint ticket from the main Forum entrance (near the Largo Ricci, on Via del Fori Imperiali) - top tip, - as the queues there were about 5 mins, but were at least an hour outside the Colosseum entrance! The museums in the forum and on Paletine hill were closed for renovation (until Sept 14) which was a disappointment. The Colosseum was especially impressive.
Well worth getting Guided Tour. We took an offer of a guided tour, which cost an extra €18, but worth it to miss the queues & have a guided tour of the Colosseum & the Forum

Ruins everywheres. Couldn't believe all this stuff is still there.Having grown up seeing Disney and Las Vegas it took awhile to realize this is the real McCoy. Plan to go early to avoid lines. Reasonable at 12 Eurs to see all three areas. Don't get sucked into a tour from all the "guides" outside, just have a travel book, good shoes and the mind set to say WOW

A must see. That such a building is so preserved, after earthquakes, invasions and the ravages of time is quite amazing.It is an extraordinary feeling to stand in the Colosseum and soak up the atmosphere of Ancient Rome. This is somewhere you must visit in your life!
Not to be missed. Bought 2 day ticket and visited Forum and Palatine Hill one day and Colosseum the next. Highly recommend hiring an audio guide for both.

Must see in Rome. You can't go to Rome and not see this. I would recommend that you buy tickets in advance for the Colosseum. They are also selling tickets to go to the floor of the Colosseum and look beneath, but you may have to have a licensed guide to do this.

Colosseum. Unbelievable structure that was built nearly 2000 years ago. Well worth a visit. Buy pre paid tickets before you travel and avoid the enormous queues. Our ticket was 30 euros which included the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. Be prepared for lots of walking, but worth it.
Ancient history right before your eyes.. Ancient history right before your eyes. Extensive paths to explore Roman Fora, with amazing structures still standing (or partially standing).

Well worth going to see a must if you are in Rome. The coloseum was everything you expect it to be it was very fascinating. The palatine hill and roman forum was also worth going round too so much history and beautiful views of the city from palatine hill
Historical Excellence. I fulfilled a life time ambition & visited the colosseum & I was not disappointed. Another place off my bucket list. Worth every penny we spent.

Viator tour. We decided to go here with a tour. There is a lot of walking. We hit all the high points with the tour guide. The weather was great as we were there in April. Palatine Hill, there wasn't much to see. I was somewhat disappointed with the Colosseum. It was my childhood dream to see it, but more than half of it was wrapped in scaffolding. There is a lovely coffee place right across from the Colosseum. Great view.

A trip to Roman times. We spent an entire afternoon walking back and forth among the ruins of the Great Roman Empire, a place where so many things took place, where the Emperors and the peolple set the foundations for western societies. An amazing feeling, an incredible experience! Make sure you wear sunscreen and/or take something to cover your head because it´s an open place and it takes you a while to walk it all. You cannot leave Rome without going to the Forum.

Time travel. These three attracions are sold as one: for 12 Euros (which is a very good price for what you get) you get admission for the Forum, the Colosseum and the Palatin Hill, which is the place where the city of Rome is believed to have been founded. The Forum is a walk to the past, the place where it all happened, where the foundations for our society were set. An incredible feeling, walking among the ruins. The Colosseum is precisecly that: a colossal piece of architecture. It also gives you that feeling of spending a little while in ancient Rome. Absolutely wonderful and of course, a MUST in Rome.

Amazing Place. There are no words that can describe the feeling one gets upon entering the Colosseum. It simply takes you back in time to all of those movies that have been made about Rome and the gladiators, the catacombs, the lions, and the chariot races that really took place in this space. As the wind is gently blowing in your face, you can almost hear the crowds yelling for the lions to be let loose and the contests to begin. The Colosseum is just that awe-inspiring! While the lines can be hours long during the most crowded tourist months, if one has the stamina it is well worth the wait. The only dislike is the long wait one has to endure to see this epic wonder.

Fantastic with an awesome guide. We did this as a morning walking tour with Dark Rome Tours. Our guide Marella was enthusiastic, knowledgeable and personable. There is so much to see and so much history to be shared that a knowledgeable guide is a must.

Awesome Sites. The Colosseum, Palatine Hill, and the Roman Forum are must see sites in Rome. I spent about 5 hours touring these sites and the ticket which covered all three was only 12.50 Euro. Getting to the Roman Forum and Palantine Hill early to get tickets is a must since it opens at 0830hrs. The Colosseum opens at 0930hrs and since you have the ticket from the first two you do not have to wait in line,

You have to go here if in Rome. This was amazing trip. Get the RomaCard and pass the lineup - it is true, and you save at least 1/2 - 1 hour. We used the Rick Steve's audioguide and it was sufficient to get us around and appreciate all the areas (saves 5 euros for their audioguide and the lineup). Walk around, appreciate all the areas and views.

A fascinating tour. I guess we were lucky, our tour guide brought it all to life, because let's face it, the Coliseum is mostly reconstructed, and the Roman Forum mostly sundry randomly placed columns & stones... But if you bring a good imagination, and go on a tour (do jump the lines), you can really see the gladiators fighting and the Romans debating. Strong walking shoes will also help....
Amazing Ruins. Very crowded, but these attractions are a must see if you are in Rome. Lines are long, and be prepared for hiking. The facilities are well done and there were police everywhere.

Time Travel. The restorations are thankfully still proceeding in face of the economy. Third visit, each time gaining a better understanding of history, culture and architecture. A very interesting contrast with Imperial Rome just across the road. On my last visit, I was able to stand in the (restored) personal apartment of Julius Ceaser.

Disappointing. I would have rated this lower but for the Palatine Hill & the Roman Forum which we spent much more time at than the Colosseum. We had booked for the first English tour of the morning which included the 3rd ring & dungeon but you can imagine the angry people in the skip the queues line (which was not moving) when we were all told it had been cancelled with no explanation and that the 10.00am tour would be the first for the day so bad luck! Typical Italian response from guy behind counter who tells you then looks the other way. No face contact here. Anyway you are buggered as all other tours are booked out. Finito. The rest of colosseum is so so big but yeah? So we sent much more time with P/Hill & Forums which offer much more variety. Amazing history

Late Afternoons are best. We went with maximiser tours , our guide was Richard @ he was very good , the forum was amazing really was the hart of the city , our tour was 3.15 it was a warm day take water , lots of walking ,Well worth the visit but only if you have a guid that knows his stuff
A must see in Rome. Don't miss the Colosseum and go and see the inside as well. If you walk round the exhibition first it helps to understand Roman life and the Colosseum itself.
a must see. Despite the crowds, you cant visit Rome without seeing at least the Coloseum. Book your ticket online to skip the long lines, and avoid going on a Sunday.

Absolutely awesome!. We took a half day tour of these sites guided by City Wonders staff. I would highly recommend them. Our guide Elizabeth's knowledge made the venues come alive. Besides, skipping the lines (which are long) is enough of a reason to recommend a tour. The narration through the headsets really helps one understand the Roman culture better and makes sense of all that you are gazing upon. And believe me, there is a lot to see!
Great visit with semi private tour which also saves the queuing. Well informed visit with Dark Rome tours.Liked all the tour but audio equipment sound was breaking up a and it isn't cheap.

History in Rome. I do not need to say anything about these monuments apart from that they fully live upto or surpass one's expectations. A few tips, if you want to visit these then go in via the Forum, much shorter queue, your ticket covers the day of purchase and one other day. We saved the Colesseum for the second day and having a ticket enabled us to walk pass a huge throng of people waiting to buy their tickets. If you are a pensioner then take some form of identy with your birth date on, drivers license is perfect, and you get in for free.

The essetials of Rome. Colosseum with the adjacent Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum is the essentials of Rome. It´s the very heart of where the Roman Empire started. Inside the Coiosseum you really can feel the history creeping inside your skin. A least I could almost hear the agony of the dying gladiators in the sand on the arena. Cheered by a bloodthirsty crowd Only 2% of them survived. After visiting the Colosseum, continue to the Palatine Hill and then to the Forum Romanum, in that order. Entrance where the Hop-On-Hop-Off buses stop. You´ll then hae a downhill walk to the Forum instead of a exhausting climb uphill the other way.I would recommend a at least a two day visit to cover it all (2-3 hours at each place) and yet you´ll only be skimming the history on the surface, but if you´re in Rome for 1-2 days, these are the places you just have to visit. The cues might seem endless when you get there, but they move quite fast. Don´t fall for the "Fast line" offer. "Only 5 euro" more. It´s not worth it. You will get inside anyway. Take your time to explore these fantastic historical monuments. Never to be built again. Senior citizens do have a reduced admittance fee. At least if you are living within the European Community. Do ask for it. They will probably not tell you, if you don´t. Do wear good walking shoes. It is not plain ground you will walk through. It´s cobblestone and stairs that sometimes almost wears you out. And when you leave the Forum there´s still more to discover outside the fence, walking towards the Victor Emanuelle II monument.

You must visit all 3 attractions. Most people visit the Forum and Colosseum but the slightly daunting climb up Palatine Hill is worth it. See excavated villages, enter an original home with freacos still visible and wonder at the extravagant lives of the rich. Let your imagination run wild!

Time Travel. What an incredible sense of history to see these ruins of which I've read all my life! Having a private guide is pricey but enables you to see more in limited time, especially bypassing lengthy lines. Definitely worth it for a day you won't forget!
Great Trip. Very impressive - although it was very busy. The private tour guide (Brian from Scotland) was superb, bringing the experience to life

Get a Guide. If you are a history buff you have to visit both the Forum and the Colosseum. We had toured it before with just a hand map and no guide. If you get a guide you can skip the lines and the information they provide is so much more interesting then just reading about it.We hooked up with a young American guy who worked for RomAdventure Tours and excursions. The ticket was an additional 3 Euro over the base ticket price.It lasted an hour with any remaining time to be spent on your own.Well worth it.

Rome in limo took us to get tickets to bypass the entrance line and we got right into the colessium .. It was raining when we were there, but Rome in limo made certain we had umbrellas and took us right to the attraction & picked us up right when we were done

Totally Brilliant!. Secret tip- Buy your ticket for these sites from the entrance to the Forum and then double back on yourself and access Colosseum first/you sail past the extremely long queues waiting to go in and buy an audio guide unless you want a tour. We were a little 'toured' out by this stage but wish we'd had a tour. Audio quite good/guides would have been better. THEN go into the Forums and buy a bottle of drink at one of street stands on way as nothing inside. The Forums are very attractive gardens.

3 sights for one price. Arrived at the Colosseum the queue was all most ½ circumference the of the Colosseum. All the travel books say the queues are shorter at the Roman Forum, (and they were right) a 2 min walk and there were 2 people in front of us at the ticket booth. The Tickets covers The Roman Forum and Colosseum and Patatine Hill, tickets cost E12 each which are valid for 2 days. Walked around with Rick Steve’s Audio Guide down loaded free before we left home, having the audio guide made the place come alive.We did the Colosseum the next day, ticket in hand it was straight thru; again we had the Rick Steve’s audio guide on our phones, I have never been a fan of Gladiator movies, but after see the Colossuem I feel I have more understanding of the times, and would now happy watch a movie Gladiator movie from Historical point of view.
Impressive. This is one of the must visit at Rome, impressive ancient Rome structure. amazing to see how the ancient Roma has build the great structure in the past thousand years.
A great bit of Roman history. A very interesting and incredible look at Roman history. Should be on the "must see" list when visiting Rome.

Great Visit. We visited all these while on a Walks of Italy tour. Had the early morning VIP access to the lower and upper part of the Colosseum. Just great! weather was perfect and by noon we were tired after viewing all three but could have spent an entire day with all the great history. These three areas are part of the must see when in Rome.

Impressive Roman ruins. A truly wonderous look at the remains of an ancient civilisation. Worth getting a guide if you don't know much about the area, as it is a treasure trove of epic buildings. Buy your ticket for (and visit) the Forum first and you get to walk past the line queuing for the Colosseum-only tickets.
Beautiful. The Colosseum in itself is just unimaginable. Do not go on a hot day. It is always crowded but worth fighting the crowd to see.

Wonderful but lots of people. Allow at least a half a day. Lots of walking but well worth it. Starting with the Planting Hill, then went to the Forum and did the Coliseum last. Very crowded so be careful with your valuables.

Heart of Ancient Rome. If you come to Rome and don't spend time at these locations,plus the Capitoline Hill you might as well say that you don't know Rome. .In addition to being the major scene to ancient history theruins tell a story of what happened all those thousands of years. Seeing the Coliseum and other major sites at various times of the late afternoon and night will give you anidea of what beauty really is. The number #40 and #64 buses go from the main train station on their way to St. Peters, however on then way they go by the PiazzaVenezia - which is a bus hub and also where theVE II monument is located the start of the Forum area as wellas the Coliseum and the other sites. If you really want to know what you are looking at you should do some research so that you have an outline" that you can fill in as you enjoy your trip.

COLOSSEUM, PALATINE HILL, VIA IMPEROLI. My wife and I walked from Old Rome (near the Pantheon) down the Via Imperoli at night. Really cool seeing these ruins lit up at night. Walked all the way down to the Colosseum and it was impressive. Would highly recommend doing some sightseeing at night---the lighting is fantastic and makes everything look that much more spectacular (we did this with Trevi Fountain and Bernini's Four Rivers fountain in Piazza Navona--scenes in two movies, Hudson Hawk with Bruce Willis and Angels and Demons with Tom Hanks.
Wonderful and historic spot.. Good value for a ticket for all three venues. Beautiful and historic! Interesting to walk in the ruins dating back 2000 years -- or more!

Essential visit. Got to the colosseum before it opened and the queue was not too bad. As it was just opening I could walk around easily and have time to enjoy the sights. The colosseum was very atmospheric. The forum was busier and the ground extremely uneven underfoot. The ruins were spectacular and there were plenty of information boards around. Definitely a must see if you are visiting Rome.
