You could skip the Forum and Palatine without missing too much. The Coliseum was enjoyable - though the guide kept repeating stuff for one US guy who was very interested in the life span of gladiators and slaves (perhaps he couldn't understand her). (Then directions right, left, wait for the ladies to regroup after the restrooms.) Not much information. But there was a LOT of walking around the forum and palatine hill without much knowledge gained. We did better walking around town ourselves on the afternoon we arrived (Castel Sant Angelo, Piazza Navonna, Pantheon, Trevi fountain, Spanish steps, Piazza Populo). If I did it again, I would get the 3 day jump on/off bus tour.
My first sight in Rome. I couldn't wait to see the Colosseum on my trip to Rome and although we didn't get to tour it, just seeing it and the area was so special-great piece of history.

Irene with Skip-the-Line tours was an excellent guide. Having a great tour guide makes all the difference. We learned a great deal of Roman history from Irene of Skip-the-Line tours. If you are debating whether to go on your own or with a tour, do the tour!

No need to prebook tickets or queue for hours. There is nothing I can add about the awe inspiring magnificence of the Colosseum but make sure you visit the Palatine hill and Roman Forum as well. If nothing else there are a couple of great vantage points for views over the city.We arrived at the Colosseum late morning and the queue was around 150m long. However the queue you see is only half the story as there is also 20-30 mins queuing inside the colosseum before you get to the ticket booth. I reckon the queue was probably in excess of an hour.We walked to the Palatine Hill entrance which was a couple of hundred metres down the street next to where all he buses park and got our ticket to the 3 attractions there. The queue was less than 5 minutes. If you walk up the Palatine hill then follow the paths to leave via the Roman Forum by following the Colosseum signs you will be opposite the Colosseum entrance. Simply walk through the middle of 3 lanes entering the Colosseum and have a smirk at the seemingly endless line of people queuing on your right hand side:-)

Incredible history. You may be tempted to take a walk through of the ruins on your own, but I think that would be a mistake. There's so much history there and it's not always altogether clear what you're looking at (at least with respect to Palantine Hill). The Colosseum is especially epic. To have built this structure to hold 80,000 people nearly 2000 years ago is an absolute marvel of engineering. You can see the Colosseum in pictures, but there's no substitute for seeing it in person.
Trapped in Time. The history of these sites is fascinating, with more discoveries being made daily! A tour is a must if you want to get a real picture of the history of Ancient Rome
VISIT TO COLOSSEUM. Great experience - you are greeted by the Gladiators who are exceptionally friendly and happy to pose with you. The Colosseum itself is worth a visit.

back to Rome. worthed! always! cannot miss! during summertime, be there early, the lines are always so long! and possibly take a guided tour, it makes more sense. beautiful view of Rome from the Palatine hill.
Incredible. Must see for anyone visiting Rome! Nothing like witnessing ancient history and the incredible talent of civilizations of the past.

Worth the Trip BUT get there early. Can't miss this visit but you should plan to get there as soon as it opens. Large crowds and long lines after 10am. We paid for the guided tour which was about 40 minutes long but have great insight.

FUN TO SHARE THE EXPERIENCE. We took our 13 year old grandson to Rome. We had been there before, but it was so much fun seeing it thru the eyes of a young person. It is a great experience. The thing that gets me all the time is that American senior citizens appear to be the only senior citizens paying. EU members & Canadians do not.
plan enough time. You need a full half day for this at least. Please don't short yourself. it is a wonderful experience.
Can't go to Rome without seeing Colosseum. Once in a lifetime visit, loved the Colosseum tour! We had a wonderful tour guide, didn't have to wait long either.

Don't buy the audio guide!. We visited The Forum / Palantine Hill on a week day morning in May and there was hardly any queue to get in. We decided to buy an audio guide to enhance our visit which we soon realised was a mistake. You had to walk across the site to reach point 1 and there were 38 points in total. The hire was for 2 hours and then they charged €5 per hour. After listening to the introduction and point 1 we realised we would never comfortably make it through all 38 points. We used it for about an hour but found it confusing as there were no signs marking the points at which to listen so you had to guess. We felt we weren't enjoying the site with the audio guide so we returned it and the pressure was off! A lot of the same information was on printed boards all over the site anyway so save your money and enjoy it at your own pace.There is enough to see here for practically a whole day if you want to read all the information signs and take it all in. If it's a hot day bring a hat and sun cream, there is shade to sit in but the main ruins are in the sun. There were plenty of clean toilets dotted over the site as well as lots of water fountains. Take a picnic with you (there's no refreshments to buy in the site) and spend a day amongst some fascinating Roman ruins.

Very big, but worth it. If you want to have seen everything at the Forum Romanum, you'll be walking around for at least 3 to 4 hours and that's if you don't stroll. However, it is totally worth it. You can sense the history of the Forum in every remaining wall, building or pillar. I read some review where people brought their own audio guide (like Rick Steve's) and I think that might have made it even more interesting for me. There are people selling cold water bottles for €3 near the entrance, but if you have some patience and you walk into the Forum for a bit, you'll see the same bottles for €1.

Amazing. This is a amazing site but arrive early to avoid the queues, take some water into the Colosseum as there is no where to buy any until you leave, also visit the Forum steeped in added history.
Very interesting!. This site is much larger than what I had imagined. It is very interesting to walk around and admire the construction that the Romans did in that time period. Well worth seeing!

Colosseum tour. Thoroughly enjoyable tour. Our guide was david- great chap and very amusing. He was obviously passionate about roman history- could answer any question! It was a hot day so it was tiring but not boring. Wear comfy shoes- a must! We went on a sunday afternoon and even the walk there was lovely.the fiori imperioli was closed to motor traffic so you could stroll safely and there were plenty of things to see- magicians, artists, dancers etc. brilliant!

Stunning piece of history. Definitely put the colosseum of your Rome to-do list. It's an amazing building and an interesting piece of history. Rome is a very busy city, as is this attraction, so if you want to avoid as many crowds, I would recommend going around 4pm onwards.

Amazing. This was definitely on the must see list and we were not disappointed. We had the Roma 2 day Pass which I can recommend which enabled us to walk straight in. We did however hook up on a tour outside the Colosseum which gave us even more of an insight. We then in our own time toured the Palatino and Forum.

Underground tour. We managed to book an underground and third ring tour of the Colosseum through Co op Culture, Italy's equivalent of the National Trust or English Heritage. You have to keep an eye on the web site as they only release tickets two months at a time and you can only phone to book but the staff were efficient and spoke English, the whole process took only five minutes. Having trawled through lots of sites, this was by far the cheapest at 12 euros a person, you have to pay for entry to the colosseum extra, but is more than worth it for a great tour lasting just over an hour with a good English speaking guide.
Take a guide and enjoy. Book a guide jump the queue ,stay informed and amazed with facts and tales and the spectacle of the colleseum and Pallatine and forum

Amazing. The scale of this is unbelievable, just a shame a lot of it was stolen for building elsewhere. You must get tickets online as queues are very long, we booked online & walked up an empty lane to collect our admission tickets while the queue to buy tickets was massive. We did the guided tour which was worth it but the underground section (9 euros) did not take long. Keep your wits about you outside the Colosseum as it is mobbed with tourists & people trying to sell you things, no doubt pickpockets as well. Palantine Hill covers a large area as well.

The classic sights. I have already reviewed the Colosseum separately, but the Forum and Palatine Hill are all linked ticket-wise. These are the classic ancient Roman sights so must be seen, but I would advise some kind of guide, be it audio or book, otherwise you run the risk of lurching from one 'ruin' to the next without really understanding and appreciating what you are viewing - as we did! Without the knowledge of what you are viewing as our B&B guy said 'it can become (dare I say) boring'!You may want to split the viewing of these 3 areas over 2 days as the tickets were valid for 48 hours, but you must see them.

Really hair-raising experience. If you understand what really took place here thousand of years ago, this monument takes on a different atmosphere to any other Roman relic. Its totally unique and a real must see even for those that dont do Museums/Galleries etc.

Experience Ancient Rome. I highly recommend the ancient part of Rome. There is so much to learn not to mention the realization that you are walking through so much history. Palatine hill has many signs so you are still able to learn on your own or you can take a guided tour. I would recommend at least 2 hours, more if you are a history buff. You are walking through ruins so no restrooms or drink stands although there are fountains that are safe to drink from. The Colosseum is worth visiting but be aware everyone else is to, so save time for the massive lines.

If it's hot, buy some drinks before going in !. The sheer scale of Ancient Rome is breathtaking and the Forum and Palatine Hill are fantastic. I was surprised that once in the Archeological area there are no places to buy drinks, you have to exit and go back in.So, if it's hot beware.

Nice time at the Colosseum and Forum. Of course, the Colosseum was astounding. After viewing documentaries and tour videos, and after studying only reviews, histories and descriptions of the Colosseum and how it was built, etc. we had an idea what to expect. We were not disappointed. It would be foolish to visit Rome and not see the Colosseum. The same can be said of the Roman Forum.

Must see!. This is the attraction worth seeing inside. To skip the line, buy tickets for 12 € good for two days and both the Palatino and the Colosseum at the Palatino even if you just want to see the Colosseum, as the price is equal. The audio/videoguide tour is ok, not more, costs 7€. Impressive sight! Snacks for sale outside. Long lines for restrooms.
So impressive !. We feel very small face to the monuments ! It is difficult to imagine the monuments when they were built at the beginning !
Amazing. This place is just stunning, crowds let it down a little but I would definitely try to see this at night, its beautiful.
fab trip. loved being able to go inside and take pictures from all angles such a momentous place very impressive
Worth the tour. Walking tours of Italy with the behind the scenes restricted access well worth it! Palatine hill was explained to us by a 3rd generation tour guide amazing!

A must visit if you're in Rome. The landmark of Rome with a very interesting history. A guided tour is highly recommended as you can skip the queues that at worst are hours long. Alternatively you can get a Roma Pass and skip one line. The tour guide you want is David Battaglino, if he's not available I had a nice tour from Dark Rome Tours.

Should visit. Visit the Colosseum, Palatine and Roman Forum. You get a good feel of the ancient Romans.Personally, I preferred the visit to Palatine Hill and Roman Forum, although the colosseum is still quite impressive.Purchase tickets before you head out to Rome as you can bypass the queues. If you can't, buy the tickets from the Palatine Hill / Roman Forum ticket office as they have shorter queues.
Go for a view walk. We found the view from above the Forum gave you a better perspective of what it must have been. Go to the hill above Via di Foro Romano
get a Rome tourist ticket and save queuing. Wonderful experience but huge queues without the tourist ticket, allow plenty of time to take in the whole experience.

History like it really was. Very interesting tour of the main colosseum and it's surrounding buildings, well worth getting a tour guide to talk you through how things were during its construction and use. Who knew its had a canvas roof!?!?

impressive. If you really don't want to spoil the beautiful view, don't visit it in the day for the first time! I mean it. Go there in the evening, when it's dark. The get the best effect, travel by the underground and when you get out of the station, you will see it in its all beauty! Then go again in the day if you have time. It really is impressive!

Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum. Make sure to get a ticket in advance! Lines are long! Outstanding place to visit! Learn the history before you visit so you will understand what you are viewing.

Tickets. To visit Colloseum, Palantine Hill and Roman Forum we just used our i-phone in hotel room to book tickets for 14euros each person. Reception printed the tickets for us to take. This was excellent value and you could pay for audio and guides when you got there. We didn't feel we needed to do that though as there is a lot of information available. This was the only tourist sight that we needed to pay for and we went everywhere!

Absolutely amazing!!. I visited the colosseum in Rome on Monday 5 may 2014. Upon arrival i was approached by a few touts but I went to the queue at the entrance to purchase a ticket direct from the colosseum ticket office which costed 12 euros for levels one and two and also included entrance for the forum-palatine. The ticket is valid for 2 days and allows one entrance to the colosseum and one entrance to the forum-palatine. If you wish to see level three and underground in the colosseum it is a further 9 euros but I think you are taken on a tour for these areas and so you are allocated a time slot. Unfortunately these were all booked up so I missed out. It is therefore advisable to book for this in advance of your arrival direct with the colosseum. I was approximately in the queue for about 40 minutes. The colosseum was amazing and a definite must see!! Was well worth every euro!!

Bring a walking tour or purchase an audio guide. The ancient architecture and history at the Roman Forum is stunning. Truly, it is mesmerizing and mind-boggling to imagine the age and complexity of the ruins.Keep in mind that there are very few signs or explanations. It is not at all like a museum. You have to come prepared. We downloaded a Rick Steve's audio guide for the Forum. It helped us to picture what the ruins looked like in their heyday and also taught us a lot of history. We would have had no clue what we were looking at if it wasn't for the audio guide. On a similar note, we did not have any guide for the Palatine Hill portion, so many of the details were lost on us. The sights that were accompanied by the audio guide were far more enjoyable. Without the guide, we just saw artfully arranged rubble. Definitely bring some sort of guide to read or listen to. I think the site offered audio guides too, which could be purchased at the entrance for an additional fee. I cannot rate their guides since I did not know about this service at the time.The entrance fee pays for visits to the Colosseum, the Forum, and Palatine Hill. The Colosseum is just across the way with a separate entrance. The Forum and Hill can be reached through the same entrance since they are located adjacent to each other.

Amazing history in this beautiful city, you can't be disappointed.. TIP: Buy the ticket at Palatine Hill (combo ticket includes palatine hill, the forum, and the coliseum) The line at the Coliseum is always long. Don't stand in it. Plan to see the Palatine Hill first and buy your combo ticket there. Also browse through the forum. Then go back to the Coliseum and walk past all the people in line just to buy their ticket. We took a tour from one of the tour guides that is looking for business just out front of the Coliseum, the tour fee included the price of your ticket, and we walked in escorted with our guide and went right past everyone waiting in line. (did the same thing on our Vatican, Sistine Chapel, St. Peters tour) Seeing all of this amazing history is just amazing. Thousands of years of information waiting to be discovered. I can't imagine anyone not enjoying this.
Awesome. Submerge yourself in history! If you don't want to take a tour, splurge for the audio phones. Was great!
Wow. Absolutely wonderful place to visit.Big queues so buy a roma pass to skip the huge queues.Camera a must!

A step into the history of Rome. A long wait for tickets, good idea to pre-book fast track tickets before your visit. Vast area to cover, must be fit to attempt, everything from the Colosseum to the original starting place of the Roman world. Wonderfully varied sights,

Wonderful tour. Francesca from Dark Rome tours did the tour and it was outstanding! We got so many extra bits of information about everything that we could not have learned on our own. Booked the tour through Perillo Tours, outstanding in every way

Best tour ever!. The best possible tour in Rome is to combine a visit to the Colosseum, the Palatine, and the Roman Forum. It's quite a walk, but every picture is worth taking. Impressions - excellent!

Walk where Cesar walked. This was overwhelming ........ If you are into Roman history.
However, Rome is constantly filled with visitors so if you don't like crowds you will not enjoy this
There are lots of street hawkers and you will need to constantly fight them off

Wow!. These were very cool. I'd always wanted to visit the Colossium but didn't really know much about Palatine Hill or the Roman Forum. However, they are very interesting themselves and quite humbling. There is thousands of years of history to think about. If you can get a guide it is was worth it.

Amazing ancient ruin in middle of civilization, hussle and bussle. The tour buses provide an amazingly good view of the Colosseum. It's covered in holes where the marble was stripped off, some of which was used in the vatican. The colosseum sticks up, out of the surrounding modern city, like many of the historic sites in Rome. The work on the structure goes on, I would imagin keeping it up for future generations. Highly recommend.

read ticket carefully and ask if not sure. be careful as you are only allowed one admission to each attraction and palatine and roman f are one attraction, we did not realise this and could not enter the roman forum but i complained and we were let in.
Awe inspiring. The Colosseum is an amazing piece of architecture that has survived the ages. If you go here get the skip the line pass and do the audio tour which was an additional 7 euros!

Amazing!. Hard to believe this has all remained in existence this long! So much history to take in, and so much to learn about such an amazing place. And it's in the heart of Rome! We will visit again!

Great view of ancient history. For one ticket, you can get entry to the Colosseum, Forum and Palatine Hill. It is impossible to see these sites without feeling how old this culture really is. The Colosseum is huge! In addition to the structure itself, there are displays of artifacts from ancient Rome. The Forum and Palatine Hill have a number of interesting ruins - temples, gardens, etc. We spent several hours and thoroughly enjoyed the entire experience.

Fabulous sights. A trip to Rome would not be complete without a visit to the Colosseum. Absolutely awe inspiring. We spent a very long time just taking it all in. The audio visual guides were helpful to provide a good basic level of information. Palatine Hill also very interesting; and the Forum whilst a bit difficult to work out what's what at times has enough info in English to get by. A must- do trip.

Good combination ticket to purchase. Likes: The Colosseum was incredible. Highly recommend the underground tour. Palatine Hill was very interesting as well.Dislikes: I thought the Roman Forum was almost a waste of time. It is referred to a lot, but there isn't much to see. I guess I was expecting more so this was a let down. :(
Breathtaking. Don't miss this. Just amazing. We plan to return and spend a whole day there. Totally breathtaking.The sense of history is incredible, and there is so much to explore.

Awesome. The historical value of the Colosseum, Palantine Hill and the Roman Forum cannot be stressed enough. What remains allows you to just imagine the horrors and the good that took place there so long ago. It was very crowded so be prepared for long lines and pushy people.

Breathtaking. Absolutely amazing and bigger than you think. We skipped the line with our Roma Pass which was well worth it. Don't bother with the video/audio guide. Shame about the sellers outside. You can't stand still for even 10 seconds to take a picture without them bothering you!

Road to Rome. It is hard to describe this site there is so much to see you have a difficult time taking it all in.Our guide Nino was amazing his ability to explain the areas an historic significants made this a truly enjoyable tour. Do not miss this with a guide.

Third ring and underground tour a must. Definitely take time to book the third ring and underground tour for your visit. It's reasonably priced and over 90minutes you get to see hear about the history of the Colloseum, gain access to 'hidden' areas and be able to take some great photos.The tour made the trip to the Colloseum for us.

HIghlight of Rome. This is/was what it is all about. Again, one needs to understand the history and stories to get the most out of what one sees. Read up, or book a tour (which has the added advantages of skipping long line-ups)

A Must See. I urge all visitors to go & combine this with a visit to the Roman Forum beforehand. There is no finer way to see two of Rome's best attraction. The sense of history is tremendous. Get a guide if possible as you'll learn more this way.

Quite an Education. We booked a tour through Viator. The tour was conducted by City Highlights. Besides bypassing the lines at the Colosseum, we had the added advantage of having an archeologist lead the tour. We learned so much more than if we had gone through the ruins ourselves. We'd recommend it to others.
Colesseo Roma. Great view and crowds were not too bad! The best place in Rome. Palatine hill and Forum are ruins so if that works for you then great but it gold fast for me!

BUSY EVEN AT EASTER TIME!. Go early - i.e. As soon as it opens and before the coach tour groups arrive!
Take bottles of water and maybe a small pack of travel tissues as toilets seem to run out quickly!
great day out. Fab day out! So interesting and a little chilling when you think of its brutal hiatory. We bought a roma pass so we got to queue jump which is the ONLY way to go.

Just breathe the history!. A fabulous experience, allow at least half a day for the Forum and Palatine Hill alone and at least 2 or 3 hors at the Colosseum. I would definitely recommend going on a guided tour of the Roman Forum, an Audio guide for the Colosseum is fine but there is so much to see at the Forum. Also buy the Roma pass so that you can skip the queues....worth every penny( or cent) when you see the queue snaking back 1/2 a mile and you can sail to the front. Unmissable, we will definitely go back again...and again!

Archaeologists' dream. I loved the interpretation inside. There is a surprising amount of info and exhibition inside which I wasn't expecting. It's just spectacular and the building speaks for itself.

Rome's greatest stage.... a forest of marble.. Once considered the "engine room" of a vast empire,the Forum,is spectacularly beautiful. Situated in the valley between the Palatine and capitoline hills was for centuries, the heart of the greatest metropolis of antiquity. It was a showcase to the rest of the world,demonstrating Rome's power. this forest of marble was sourced from all the provinces and like all historical constructs it eventually collapsed,robbing us of the temples and buildings. It served as a quarry up till the 1800s. As, my femme and i,and 1000's of lemmings stroll the Forum's ruins,open to the Roman sky,it feels like an encyclopaedia of ancient history....... The Arch of Titus,celebrating victories in Judea,to the Temple of Vesta,the Virgin;s abode and the Temple of Antoninus and Fausina,which survived in excellent fashion due to its re-birthing as the church of San Lorenzo. Add to this,the basilica Emilia,the Curia Luvia and the two most important monuments of the Forum,the Septimus Severus Arch of Triumph and the eight columns of the temple of Saturn.

A must to for first timers. I have travelled to Rome many many times, and while I don't go in to the venues I always make a point to walk by and admire (and take tons of pics) of these amazing sites. I am not a history buff by any stretch of the imagination, but I find this absolutely amazing! It is always crowded mid day - I suggest getting up early and walking around before it's filled with tourists.. it is worth the sleep deprivation to have this spot almost all to yourself.

A must in Rome. Make sure to book in advance on Internet. The lines are TREMENDOUS, and you can easily waste 2-3 hours...The guided tours are highly recomendable, and they will bring you straight through the queues. Several options are available through internet.To visit the underground and top viewing points of the Collosseum you need to book a special visit. It was OK, but not spectacular.
Another must-see spot.. Lots of interesting things to see and walk around. Again, visit it at a time when half the world isn't there!! But it should be seen.
Lots walking. Lots of walking around, very interesting with fantastic views all over Rome. Leave plenty time for this we were there at least 3 hrs
Must see! . It looks bigger than I thought. It is definitely a must go in Rome and a place to admire the ancient engineering! Roma Pass to skip the looong queue!
A must!. when going to this attraction, its best to have a guided tour. You'll get a better knowledge of the place and may learn something new! I did!

Truly spectacular!. We absolutely loved walking around the Forum, taking in thousands of years of history. It's quite overwhelming when you realize that this was the heart of political activity in one of the greatest empires of all time. We got in using the Roma Pass (worth it!) and spent a good 2 hours here. Wear comfortable shoes, bring a bottle of water and take your time - you will not be disappointed.
antiquities. Hire a guide; it's worth it. Helped navigate the area and get through the crowds. They are very informative and can point out the most important areas.
Must see. You've seen it in pictures and movies but you must see it in person. The history jus just amazing. You walk among ruins that have been there over 2000 years. It is breathtaking.

incredible. Hard to believe 100 years ago this was still underground! the area is the best attraction in Rome after the Vatican, but there are so many sites in Rome you need a week, Walking tours of the area are fantastic.

well worth the visit. I booked this tour with aviator and enjoyed it very much. The guide was very enthusiastic and informative. I was travelling on my own and it was good to be in the company of others and having as much information possible about the sites. Have lots of brilliant photos and the stories behind them to tell people about. You can also volunteer to take photos of each other too.
Sore feet!. Too much to explore, but all very interesting and well worth a prolonged visit. Could do with some improved signage

A full 2 days for this. Enjoyed the underground tour which includes the regular tour but also the underground and third tier. Unfortunately you must reserve only by phone call. Some days there are time spots available for the same day so ask anyway, if you can't get reservations. You'll spend up to 3 hours total for this tour and then hanging around on your own afterward. The forum and hill will take easily several hours. Better do it the following day. If you buy the complete combo pass you'll have the same day or the following day to do the forum and hill. There's MORE to see with the foum and hill than the colosseum! FYI there are restrooms inside the colosseum and the forum area.

A must-see!. We loved taking our time strolling through the Forum. It was my husbands favorite part of our entire trip to Italy. I suggest getting a ticket ahead of time (good for Colosseum, Forum, and Palantine).
Too busy. Impressive but too busy. A big chaos even if you bought tickets in advance. The colosseum is more impressive from the outside then the inside.
History comes alive. The colosseum captured our imaginations. It was an awesome feeling to stand inside a building that holds so much history.

Watch your step, it's an original road you walk on. The excavations are still continuing so there was areas we could not go near but it was incredible to finally be able to visit this place from the past. We didn't realize how close the Forum was to the colosseum. You do need good walking shoes for to tour this area as the cobble stone walks are some of the original stones and not always level, so watch your step. We had a wonderful local guide give our tour and she really brought the place back to life for us, so check what's available as you get more in depth knowledge of these structures.

Amazing!. It was so amazing to see one of the Seven Wonders of the World up close. While in Rome you must visit this attraction. Make sure you walk around the entire Colosseum to see the different views of this massive structure. While we were there in April, there was construction on the Colosseum so at times it obstructs your view of it. The Roman Forum was very awe inspiring too, just knowing how long ago these buildings were constructed. To avoid the crowds, make sure you arrange for a tour guide because it will save you a lot of time.

Overrome tour of Colosseum, Palatine Hill, Roman Forum. We were lucky to have a private tour (when booked a small group) with Overrome. I guide was a bit odd, but excellent English, knew his stuff, and helped us understand the place. Obviously, one has not been to Rome if one hasn't seen this stuff.

Just amazing... I want to publicly thank this people of Rome who provided me with incredibly cost-effective guided tours of the Colosseum and the Sistine Chapel. Thanks to their incredible skills I could save hundreds.This is an incredible tool for DIY travel planners.Thanks Charlotte & Max :-)If you wanna know more just reply to my thread, otherwise follow hereunderhttp://bit.ly/QUmlz8

We'll worth a visit. You get a lot for your €13 admission. We got to the Colosseum at 9.00 and only stood in line for about 20 minutes. We were glad that we did not choose the organised guided tour as it is much nicer to just take the self audio tour and take your time. The tours always looked rushed. It was very pleasant to just wander around, especially on Palatine Hill, and around the Roman Forum.

Get tickets before you go.. There were massive queues here but, having bought tickets in advance on the net, we went straight in.Great sense of history abounds at this busy site. Nothing prepares you for the massive size.Tips: don't buy from the pesky vendors who approach you. Don't use the ladies' facilities; they are dreadful.
Fabulous. Fabulous, a must do attraction in rome! We went later on in the day around 3 o clock and the ques weren't huge. An amazing experience and the views are magnificent!

A "must see". So interesting and so much to see. We had a guide to see the Colosseum, which was well worth it and helped avoid the long queues. The Roman Forum was absolutely amazing and again, the guide was so informative and brought it to life. The Palatine was very quiet when we went and it was lovely to be able to wander and explore.

A M A Z I N G. My boyfriend and I visited both sites today. No words or photos can convey how amazing the ruins are and the scale is huge! Take comfy walking shoes as the path ways are tricky. We paid extra for the guided tours, which includes que jumping to beat the long lines. The guides were very entertaining and informative.

Amazing and amazing. Amazing and amazing!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!That’s what I can say in a nutshell.A must see in Rome.Originally known as the Flavian Amphitheatre, even after 200 years The Colosseum is the most recognisable of Rome's Classical buildings and is one of the most impressive pieces of architecture the world had seen.Hire a guide or at least go for the audio guide.Avoid the long ques to enter the Colosseum by booking online or buy an entrance ticket at the Palatine Hill booth for both the colosseum and the hill and skip any line at the colosseum.Don’t take the Gladiators standing outside the Colosseum seriously.

okay you HAVE to see Palatine Hill. There is so much history in this fairly small area. We saw the colosseum first and we were a little tired when we went here. Palatine hill has this ancient road that they use to travel, old churches, old seats of government, ect. Really incredible. I will definitely go back and spend more time there.

Excellent visit with Dark Rome/City Wonders.. We wanted to make the most of our time in Rome and booked a tour of the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum with Dark Rome/City Wonders - we are extremely pleased that we did. The tour provided access to areas (Colosseum floor/ underground and highest tier) only available with organised visits. The knowledge of the guide and the information provided made the visit one of the highlights of our few days in Rome.

Awesome, and a must see in Rome. So much to see, beautiful and unbelievable. Crowded, but not so bad that you can't enjoy it. A lot of school kids. A nice gift shop in the colosseum with nicer type souvenirs.
Brilliant place. Our guide Fabio from GLT certainly knew his history of the site and it's well worth paying for the service of a guide or picking up one of the headsets as the history is fascinating.

a few myths explained. You need the guided tour here otherwise you will not know that this was the centre of everything Rome was about. It is scary that it's just ruins now. The biggest empire ever reduced to this. Well worth the visit. Just to contemplate life.
Must see site!. Caesar's Forum in Vegas doesn't compare to the real deal in Rome. This is one of the "must see" sites in the Eternal City!

Breathtaking!. This is a must see in Rome! We used our Roma Pass which includes admission and let us bypass the long line. We also rented the audio/video guided headset. This was a good way to introduce us to some of the details of the Coliseum and it's history. Then we proceeded to Palatine Hill and the Forum. There's so much to see that you can get lost on the grounds. When we tired ourselves out we went to the Metro station and took the escalator to the upper level. There we found a nice cafe with a beautiful view of the Coliseum and relaxed with wine and pizza!
Great Place to visit. Great full of history but you must book on a tour before you go, the queues were so long! Make sure your tour includes the dungeons and the third ring.
Extensive. After the Colleseum travel on to here. It well worth an afternoon spent walking this extensive and wonderful site, from the Palace on the Palatine, through the forum with all its history.

A Must See. We pre-arranged a guide who gave a private tour to my wife and me. She was licensed and spoke very good English. It was good having seen the Colosseum after having been to The Vatican in order to appreciate some of the sculptures and marble facade which were stolen from the Colosseum and taken to decorate the Vatican. You could see and imagine where those statues used to be and how they would have made the Colosseum even more breath-taking during its glory. Fantastic.

A piece of history. We did not like that we spent too much time in the Forum and then climbed the hill; by the time we arrived at the colosseum we were tired and by that time of day it was packed with visitors. We complained to Dark Tours as this was backwards as to how our day should have been planned. The colosseum is very impressive and it is hard to believe all the history of Rome that happened right within the walls. Be sure to place your hand on the pillars, you can feel 'All the Glory that was Rome"

Stunning.. Hard to beat for the depth and quality of the exhibits. Coupled with a decent audio guide, this is a tour that can easily last half a day and probably a full day.Caution - To rent an audio guide, you will be asked to leave "ID" as security (passport or similar). I used my EHIC card, which seemed to be acceptable).
no words to describe. This is what makes Rome the most unique city in the world. The colloseum and the roman forum are no doubt the most indispenable visits while in rome. 6 stars.

Do more than the Colosseum. The Colosseum was impressive, but I was more impressed by the Forum. It's downtown Rome in the days of Julius Ceasar. Amazing ruins. Incredible sense of ancient history. The ticket to the Colosseum includes Palatine Hill and the Forum, so it is no extra cost.
Roman Forum and Palatin Hill under the blue sky of Rome. Marvelous walk among the pittoresque historical place, but avoid Easter holliday!Well preserved and unforgatable!
Wow. It's a very impressive building. Having read some of the information around the building, it is easy to imagine what an impressive show the Roman's put on
Stunning. Walking through the forum is walking through history. It's amazing to see what ancient Rome looked like. Buy a combo ticket at the Coliseum.

A must see. I would not buy souvenirs within the Colosseum because they are much more affordable outside of it, especially with good bargaining. You can visit Rome without experiences theses three sites. Buy your tickets in advanced because waiting in line would be a huge waste of time and the lines are long.

About eternal City´s Forum on Trip Advisor forum. It is really frustrating to search and NO find right words to picture feelings and emotions over coming to any tourist who find itself in those areas of eternity, You may feel only here.Just go and have Your own joy.
Amazing history. What can you say that others havent already said? The history here is amazing. Found a arch named after my wife's family so crazy

Can you believe this!. Like so much of ROme, this was a place of wonder before much of the new world was "discovered." What an education. What the Romans did without our engineering toolls and decision support systems.

Roma trip. Fantastic tourist attraction and a must for visitors to Rome. Unfortunately we didn't take the advice we were given and succumbed to the pressure of the touts to skip the queue which we did but they didn't tell us that we would have to hang around waiting for the guide to turn up. Quite frustrating

Great sites. These sites are a must see while in Rome. Same ticket gets you into both sites. Recommend that if you don't buy tickets in advance then get them at the Palatine not Colosseum...much shorter lines (like hours shorter)
Stunning and Sobering!. The Colosseum brings to life the history of the Roman Empire and puts perspective on the amount of knowledge and wealth that can be amassed and lost.

If you visit the Colosseum, you must do the Hill and Forum. Make sure you have a guide or a guidebook so you can appreciate what you are looking at. We spent a good amount of time just walking around in the Forum.

Book in advance. I highly recommend booking in advance to get the tickets that allow multiple entrances over two days. There is so much history to see, you will need the time. In the summer just remember to take water and breaks because it is a large, sun drenched area. Easily in the top 3 of things you must see in Rome.

Tremendous History Here. This was a must see on our bucket list (and I'm not even interested in Roman history), but with a guide from Joy of Rome Tours, they brought this pile of rubble to life in a way that made you feel like you were walking in the shoes of the ancient Romans.

speechless.. The Colosseum is just great, there are no flaws here (not even the million steps to get to the top!). Take the tour guides if you can, you'll actually learn so much more about this place, and it's so worth it. I've been here twice and took the tour twice! Every tour person is different and has a story to tell.

A must - when in Rome.. Such a great atmosphere. Really busy but a buzz of excitement to be looking at an incredible piece of history. Too much for us to do in one day so split it into two, if you can. A long way to walk so be careful if you struggle to walk but if you are able it's fantastic to walk all the way round.
Romans. Very interesting place to visit full of history long queues but we'll worth the wait you can also visit the roman fort and the roman ruins

HISTORY. it was a time traveling experience, loved everything about it except for the fact that I couldn't go down in the dungeons.you can book tickets in advance or buy them for a tour organizer outside for an extra fee to avoid the huge cue.
Impressive and good maintenance. Maybe the most impressive from antique Rome, worth the visit. Even if you do not go inside, very attractive spots for pictures while in Rome
Breathtaking. A day is not enough to see this incredible siteAs in my previous review book directly with the collosseums booking office you then get tickets which are valued for 48hrs

Bucketlist. Allow a minimum half day to just wander this incredibly old and historic area. The sights are truly amazing and jaw-dropping!!! Look out for the 'Roman Guards!' who pose with you for photos - I thought it was worth the £5 we gave him!

Must visit but without kids in stollers/ prams... The entire experience of walking through from the Colosseum up to the Palantine Hill and tge Roman Forum was extremely satisfying! However, the cobble stone uneven paths do not make it a comfortable journey with prams or strollers. In fact we ended up losing one wheel of our stroller post the journey up. We also found senior citizens having an issue with the walkways. However, we have no complaints aa such aa the experience all in all was excellent

Lovely walk through history. We started at the Colosseum, walked up Palatine hill to the Roman Forum. Every inch is covered in amazingly well preserved history, including the site where Julius Caesar was cremated. The Palatine Hill sites are, as with everything in Rome, very crowded but we found it easy to move around nonetheless. If you're unsteady on your feet or using a wheelchair or a stroller, be warned that the walking areas are very uneven and cobblestones are frequently missing.

Palace and Roman forum. Don't miss !!!! Allow at least 4 hours,good guide or guide book is well worth it Great walking tours available ,good shoes a must....settings well worth a visit. DON"T settle for just an over look view , really walk it and absorb the culture. Pack a light picnic and savor the memories. Suggest exploring on Google the specific features and perhaps printing off for review while visiting.
Reason to go to Rome. Recommend guide to fully understand what you are seeing. Be prepared to walk for at least four hours.

Another must see...take your time. You cannot walk Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum in a few hours. There is much to see and soak up. Photo's to take or just to sit down and look or draw. Spread our your visit over two days and enjoy a leisurely stroll back in time. Lovely.

Be sure that is you buy a 2 day pass that you complete both the Palatine and RF on one day--you cannot split them up.. The Colosseum was really too crowded. Go as early as you can. We went to the Palatine the first day and planned on seeing the Colosseum and Roman Forum the second day. They would not accept our Roman Forum pass for the second day, telling us we had to have used that pass the same day as we went to the Palatine. Buyer beware!

Could have stayed here all day!. Was really impressed that the admission price included the Colosseum and the Forum (especially as it only cost 7 Euros each with a student card - which was valid for three days!).We came in the winter, when the attraction closed at 4 which was a shame as we could have spent several more hours exploring. There was just so much to see! Some amazing views of the city from the top of the Palatine Hill as well as of the ruins.Would thoroughly recommend!
Very Interesting. Lovely to walk around but once again would not go in March as too many tourists and queues. February is a much better time of year to visit but we enjoyed it all the same.

wonderful this is Rome at it's best. If you buy a ticket from the office at the Roman Forum you can get a ticket that allows you into all three attractions once over 2 days for 12 euros per person which is really good value for money. You have to use a lot of imagination in some areas as there is not a lot remaining of some of the buildings

Must see!. The must see sight in Rome. TOP TIP: buy the entrance tickets online. You don't have to specify the day or time of your arrival and you sail straight to the front. When we visited, the regular queue was taking two hours!

Incredible history. Believe it or not, we almost skipped going into the Forum. I had made several attempts to buy a Roma pass (including at the Forum), but shockingly, they were sold out at every spot I tried. But in the end, I decided to pay the extra money and go in. I was really glad I did; it was worth it to see and experience the incredible history. I did not realize how big it is; we just kept ambling along, and with every turn in the path it seemed there was another amazing site. After years of studying Latin and Western Civilization in school, it felt surreal to be actually standing right in the midst of it all!

Very interesting. We booked via Viator and glad we did, the guide was excellent and so knowledgeable we saw many things we would have missed had we gone on our own. Many things to see, although the Colosseum was half covered by scaffolding you can still imagine what an incredible sight it must have been. If you want to get a feel of what Ancient Rome was like I would thoroughly recommend taking this tour.

Fabulous. So much history here, it is fascinating. Spend a fair amount of time here as there is much to see. There is a lot of walking to get around and see everything. See the museum that is there also.

A must do place - Start at the forum, and download audio tour before. Stunning places with great atmosphere, you walk in the footsteps of the great, and visit one of the starting places for the structure of modern governance and laws. We started at the colosseum, with the 20 minute queue, but if we'd started at the forum we would have avoided this! We downloaded Rick Steve's series of podcasts that had an audio guide to the forum, the colosseum and the palatino hill. You could download a map as well with a guide to the stops on route. It was good, as we could follow the trails at our own pace and got a lot more out of the site than we would have done from the static information boards. It will take 2-3 hours to do the forum and the colosseum so take water and a sun hat in the summer season!
Go alone and than on Rex Segway tours. why? because you will see the view from several different height and angles. As well as having Max from Rex segway the ultimate history buff enlighten you.

Even more impressive than the Colosseum. The Forum area is even more impressive than the colosseum itself. The sheer number of ancient ruins in superb condition make this, in my opinion, one of the greatest sites in the world today. You can see many of the ruins from the streets above, but to really see and appreciate them, you need to purchase a ticket and walk through the ancient Forum. If you buy the Rome Passe, you can get free entrance to this site and skip the lines (although there is not a sign, just go to the front and skip the ticket line).

Can't Miss. Even though it's the most impressive of the ruins in Rome, be sure the Colosseum isn't the only thing you see. When finding a tour, which is a must to get the full experience, find one that takes you through the Forum and Palatine Hill too. It takes a little time, but it's well worth it. Keep an eye out on the road to the Colosseum, because you're bound to find an agency offering tours. We found an excellent guide (if you can find James Sigmond Good, he is very knowledgeable) and a fascinating tour without too much trouble. When in Rome, don't miss the ruins.

Lots to Explore!. The Roman Forum is a great was to spend a few hours on a fair weather day in Rome. A guide is helpful to know what you're looking at, but it's also a really special historical site to stroll and enjoy at a leisurely pace. The ruins are elaborate and you can really forget that you're in a chaotic city. Not as crowded as some of the other places we visited either which is nice.

Top attraction. We bought our tickets online before we left home which avoided a huge line. We had a guided tour and got brought down into the dungeons and up to the 3rd level which is only done as part of the tours. It was worth the extra money and skipping the queues which are very long. Its a must for a visit to ROme

Brilliant. Definitely go inside the colosseum, but be careful, many people outside trying to scam you with tours. Do not do them, go inside and buy a real tour. They're cheap and if you get a guided tour the line is very short. Don't go into the longer line, it is for people not wanting tour. Tour is best. Also included in price is palatine and forum. Win, win.

Awesome... Awe-inspiring, treading same path as someone thousands of years ago. Good tip by someone yesterday was to buy tickets at Forum for all 3 sites (including Palatine). Cost 12 euros and saved queuing at Colosseum - walked straight in.

The Real Deal. Well, it's the colosseum and you don't get more exciting history than this! We bought our tickets online before we left home which avoided a huge line. We did have to queue up for the headsets but were happy we got them. It's hard to take in such ancient ruins without a little guidance to make it real.

Awesome. As soon as you enter there is so much to learn and what has happened in the past e.g how the gladiators fought... Anyways there is a huge line which is why I recommend you go with a tour : there is a separate line for them however you can also get a tour because there is no way you will be able to get everything into your head whereas the tour guide will be able to because whether they are new or not they will have been trained to talk in a way every one can understand. Nevertheless I strongly do not recommend for people who can not walk for long to explore this place even if it is on those tour bus stops.

Imagine how it was in all it´s glory. This was the place where all the romans could come and see the parade of the soldiers, the convicts fighting lions and the gladiators fighting each other. The best known gladiators where the todays celebrities, and even if they lost a fight, they still could be pardoned by Caesar if he had fought well.

Best attraction. This was for me and the 19 others in my group, 15 year old students and teachers, probably the most interesting attraction in Rome. History before us no matter which direction we looked. The Colosseum is enormous and the engineering skills to be admired. This building has a gruesome history and it is worth paying a guide to take you through the area. The whole Roman Forum has much to see, more than one can take in on a single visit. Read up on these places before you visit to understand what you are viewing. The power and wealth of the Roman Empire, and the size of the population at the time of the construction of these buildings is amazing. Not to be missed.

great!. i really enjoyed the roman forum and palatine hill. it was a lot of walking and spent a good chunk of my day exploring the historical part of rome. buying a ticket for the colosseum will allow you to gain entrance to roman forum and palatine hill as well.

Of this and that. The Capitoline museums are fantastic, especially the original statue of Marcus Aurelius. The extensive ruins can be exhausting, especially in the heat, there are no informative signs, and shade is rare.

Very interesting. We made all three things in one afternoon, and that was too little time to get under the skin of it. We had audio guide at Colosseum, but not at Palatine Hill and Roman Forum, and we missed it.

Don't waste your money buying a walk through. You can see everything from the adjacent street. On your walk to the coliseum you will see the forum on your right hand side. It's pathways of ruins if buildings and pillars. If you are a huge history buff go for the tour, if not take a picture with it in the background!

awesome. The Forum and ancient Rome and the Colosseum are awesome. History just comes alive. We took a guided tour with Brett and it just brought it all to life. Recommend that you take a guided tour as I would not normally but found this time it was well worth it. I got so much more from the guided tour than just reading the guide book. I could actually see the Romans walking on the very cobbles and stone slabs we were walking on. All in all this tour was for the high light and much better than the Vatican.

Major part of history.. Wow is the word I would use for this - absolutely amazing and kept my attention throughout. Couple of pointers tho. Don't queue at the colosseum for your ticket - go the the ticket office on Palentine Hill - no queue and straight in and then when you are done walk straight into the Colloseum. If you want an audio guide you need photographic id with you (or passport) we didn't know this and didn't take it so couldn't get one. Fortunately I had downloaded a free podcast by Rick Steves. It's the best free-be I've ever had. Walked you round the forum explaining everything - just fab - saved us €10 so my other half was happy too.
Amazing. So much to take in here,the history of it all I was in awe of it.Well worth the visit,the museum was interesting too,you could spend a week in there.
Huge area. Well worth the visit. A very large area to walk around so make sure you have comfortable shoes. Information boards tell you about the different areas.

excellent historical experience. My wife and I visited Rome in Apr 2014 and spent an entire day exploring the Roman Forum, Palantine Hill and Colosseum with a guided tour. The ambience, the temples, the ruins, the history was unmatched. We were really overwhelmed by the sheer size of the place and the feeling of history that envelopes you.It was like walking around ancient history and thinking about how the Romans used to live and move around in this place all those years ago. Having a great guide definitely added to the fun for us.Since our hotel was close to the Forum we came for evening walks along the Forum and saw it at dusk- was beautiful. Also, its great to climb up to the Capitoline Musei for a higher perspective on the Forum- very beautiful.

Beautiful, intriguing ruins!. It was exciting to see this famous historical place. I was awed. The pavement to walk on are either stony or cobbled stone. Comfortable shoes is a must as there are lots of walking involved with inclines and steps! The weather was nice in late March when we were there. A piece of advice, even if you will go at off peak season like we did, an advance tickets in your hand will be very nice. LINES ARE LONG EVEN IN MARCH! Get your tickets. As for other places, I can't say, because this is the only tickets I bought for our tour aside from hop on hop off. With hop on hop off, I suggest to buy them there, chances are, you will strike a good deal that will save you some Euros!

Buy tickets in advance!!. My advice would be to purchase your tickets ahead of time to avoid standing in line for hours. You can buy RomaPass before leaving home (at least 5 days before because it requires you to wait those many days before you can collect the tickets in Rome) or at any of their locations in Rome. Or buy tickets via www.coopculture.it It is so worth spending a few extra bucks on reservation fees.

Ancient place ,old huge structure. Here in ancient times , slaves , animals , were fought against each other and the kings were watching and enjoying . There are different galaries and one can move around and it takes almost two hours . The strucure is kept cleanThe fee is 12 Euros which seems to be high . Long Q and takes about 30 to 40 minutes to reach ticket window on odd day we visited .

Amazing - Make sure you buy tickets ahead of time. I loved wandering through the Colosseum, but it would not have been quite as nice had I waited in the 2 hour line to get in. Make sure you buy your tickets ahead of time online. If you're headed there from the city center, be sure to walk through the Roman Forum so you can see the sights all together and save time.

Epic.. Viewing the Palantine from the Colloseum, you could talk yourself out of exploring. It looks like a small site. Cross the road and up over the path lies everything you can remember from your Roman history lessons. It all becomes very real and so very interesting.

Marvellous. It's amazing that so many of the structures are still recognisable given how old many of them are! I'd recommend giving yourself time to enjoy and comfortable footwear. It's pure delight and wonder.

Nice to see. Colosseum :Nice monument, not that big and not much to see from the inside, better to book online and skip the lines...no services as WC or cafeteria available.Palatine Hill & Roman forum: good collection of relics if you want to see how original Rome was constructed

a must-see landmark, very crowded. even though it's April and not a nigh season yet, this area (just like any other popular tourist destination in Rome, though) was very crowded. The Colosseum was partly covered as the reconstruction works started. Went just around it, didn't take an excursion inside. Well, it's a must-see anyway, at least to cross out from bucket list :)

Amazing. Favourite part of trip to France, Italy and Greece. What an amazing stadium with so much history. The ruins of the old city are also so amazing. Need at least half a day to truly explore this historical area. Will never forget this day in my life

Beautiful. I visited the Colosseum and the Roman Forum, very interesting places if you like Ancient History, Unfortunately we had a problem with the tickets, we bought tickets for the 3 places, the Palatine and the Forum are in the same area, we did not know that, when we left the Forum were not authorized to visit the Platine.
Speechless!. For me and my three kids this was a majestic experience. I practically touched all walls and floors just to get some energy from all that glorious past! This place is a MUST.

A dream come true. What can you say about some of the most iconic travel sites in the world. The area is well situated in the city and easy to get to. I was impressed with the beauty and the ease from going from the Collosseum, then to Palatine Hill, and finally the Forum. It felt like you were seeing one site and not the remains of 3 sites. Only disappointment was that the Arch of Constantine was covered by half with scaffolding. That gives me a reason to come back!

Feel the history. We visited Roman forum during the winter time but luckily in late February the Rome was the warmest site of the whole Europe. We spent nice and relaxing morning and early afternoon session without hurry, just relaxing and feeling the history. It was not either rush hour or rush season. We knew the history of Roman empire quite well and therefore it was good to be on target. I was positively surprised, and if you only like the stones, just join the others in central area but I preferred the whole Palatine hill area. Altogether very suitable for lovers, or lovers with teenagers ;)
Amazing!. Imagining what it all looked like in its time. Walking in such ancient historical sights unimaginable. Rick Steve's guide books a great addition while sightseeing.

Step back in history. The combined ticket is good value. Excellent way to spend a day in Rome, a stroll through the Forum reviewing the temples and ruins. Then climb the hill to the Palatine to see the palace and the gardens then off to the Colosseum to be a Gladiator.
loved it. loved the Romans (men dressed up to take photos) .gifts in the shop were a good price which makes a change. food not over priced either, nothing to dislike

Amazing. All three of these attractions are close together and entry to all three is on the same ticket (and counts as one entry on the Roma pass, including a special turnstile to help you avoid the queues) . There is plenty of information around so that you can wander about and learn some of the history as you try to imagine what it would have originally looked like. Shame about the scaffolding on the Colosseum but I suppose it means that it is being restored and cared for! There are lots of "gladiators" around outside, who will let you take photo with them for €5 but beware, we saw one lady pose with a gladiator and another one stepped into the picture with them, and then they charged her €10!!

Walk in the past. Would really love to go on a tour through this fascinating structure of history for it felt like an aimless wandering around just by myself; perhaps cause I'm not familiar with the history of the Colosseum and so it became like I'm just solely appreciating the physical structure of it and that's all

great but overly commercialized these days. i've been there and lived nearby so can say that over the years the place is more and more commercialized. however, the sheer size and spectacle of the area are worth visiting.

Good mornings sightseeing. Loved the colosseum, very interesting we were very glad we had bought an omnia Rome pass as we jumped what must have been a 2 or 3 hour queue. Some other interesting sites nearby but don't waste time going to st peters prison this was probably the most bizarre visit during our time in rome

Magnificent. We took the 3.5 hour tour of Colosseum with the top and underground levels and the Roman Forum. Amazing! The views are breath taking. The history of the Colosseum is so rich and surprising. We were not sure if we should book a tour with a guide, or use an audio guide, or just get the ticket and and go on our own. We chose the guide and are very happy we did. Francesca was great! She was able to give us so much information, connect it with the history of Rome, with our modern understanding of gladiators and politics and show business and what not. Our family (me + my husband in our late 40's, 25 yer old daughter and 14 year old son) enjoyed this tour very much.

A must!. Just to walk around the grounds of the Palatine Hill, to see the well preserved and maintained remains of the Forum and to realise that the Romans ran their empire from here was quite humbling.

Antiquities for the Ages. A visit to the area of Ancient Rome is a must. The long lineups are a bit of a deterrent if you need a ticket. The best is to get a guide, skip the line as they look after the details. This is not the only benefit, they will tell you all the history etc. also you can rent radios and do a walkabout while listening to the info. We were fortunate to have a prearranged guide who knew her business, very pleasant. Be sure to get an all inclusive ticket so you can see all the sites in the area. A great way to spend the day.. At night it is all lit up, quite the spectacle.

Ancient Rome at its best. Get there early and definitely book a tour in advance as the queues are enormous for the Colosseum. And having a guide really helped you understand the history and all the facts that aren't mentioned in the guide books. Did you know Russell Crowe was too old to be a gladiator - the average age was 15!

Iconic. It is as extraordinary as you expect. An awesome building. Easy to imagine what it might have been like at its height. Make sure you buy a "combo" ticket for the Forum, the Palatine & the Coloseum from either the Forum entrance on Via dei Fori Imperiali or from the Palatine entrance on Via di San Grigorio. The queue at the Coloseum will be huge and with a ticket already bought you can walk to the front and go straight in; it saved us a couple of hours the day we went.

Quintessential Rome. My partner and I didn't take a guided tour around the Roman Forum. For us the view of the ancient ruins told a story in itself. The view from the main road and around the outskirts of the ruins is incredible. It's definitely worth stopping and admiring or talking a slow stroll around it to fully appreciate it.
Go see. Again this is a must visit on your trip to Rome if you go with a guide you will get so much more out of it the history is special

Pay for a guide!. To enjoy the Colosseum, it's absolutely necessary to pay a little extra to get a guide. It's an impressive monument from Roman times, but a lot has been destroyed by weather and military attacks, so to get a satisfactory picture of what Colosseum was before and what it is to day, a guide will give you a more complete experience, even though it costs a little extra.

Most of it.... ...was amazing! The Colosseum was too packed, but the Forum! Palatine Hill! So primitive and sophisticated, if you know what I mean. The feeling of importance and the sheer beauty of the area overwhelmed me. I thought it was one of the best things about Rome.
Interesting and relaxing. Buy your tickets upfront to save a lot of time queuing for tickets. The forum is a great place to be. A lot of history together with a park like nature where you can relax

Ancient wonders. Absolutely loved every second of it. We saw them all with our Roma pass, worth the money, and toured them using free rick Steve's walking audio guides that we downloaded with his app.

The Forum & Colosseum are a must visit. If you are visiting Rome, these sights are a must. Get your tickets on line or purchase them from the kiosk by the "Via Fori Imperiali", don't go and pay unofficial guides. take plenty of water, you can fill up for free at the Colosseum & Forum.

enjoyable visit. It was great to have the combination ticket of the Colosseum, palatine hill & Roman forum - defiantly worth a visit even if just for a stunning view of the city. The gardens are nice to stroll around when the weather is pleasant. Also if you head south of the main Colosseum gate there are some lovely reasonably priced restaurants.

Colosseo. The most fmous roman symbol. Incredible work of art and architecture. Fabulous. Extraordinary. You can't believe that roman people could have built these without machinery, without concrete, without computers. Just MAGNIFICENT!

When in Rome.... The best thing we did was book this tour, which we did direct with www.italy-museums.com.Firstly as we didn't queue for what would have been for over two hours in the heat and secondly because it was excellent. The guide really knew her stuff and was so passionate about the history, so much so we got really absorbed into it. Lasted about an hour and a half and then we were left to view at leisure. Tour takes you underground and up to the third tier.You can then tour the Roman Forum and Palantine Hill at leisure. Allow about 3-4 hours in total.Tickets just to go in on the day we're €12 each without a tour so well worth the extra you will learn so much more.

Great Visit - get the Audio Tour. The place is quite superb. Good interpretation on the audio tour and you can plug a second headset into the unit so you do not have to rent individual units... 1 between 2 is fine :)We thought the museum (small) was well displayed and interpreted (Italian and English).Get a ROMA PASS to get in without the long queue, the free transportation with the Pass is also worthwhile.

Afternoon picnic. A great place to take a picnic. To sit under the olive trees shaded from the sun was very relaxing. You need time to visit this area as it covers several hectares with fabulous ruins. So the picnic was a good break

Nothing else like it !. How did they build it ! No cranes no JCBs ! You can almost feel the crowds that used to watch the performances.The earliest version of a major concert location ! Watch out for the centurians who will encourage photographs with them and expect a 20 euro reward !

Awesome experience with 2 tips. Sites were magnificent. Two tips:
Buy your tickets in advance or buy the 3 day Roma pass BEFORE you go. Lines were ridiculous if you don't. I mean ridiculous. We just walked by them. :-)
Download Rick Steves free audio download for you MP3/Ipod/Droid. It was like having a personal tour guide.

Best $ ever spent. We had a "group" (up to 7, but we had 4) tour with Luca of Through Eternity Tours. I can't say enough positive things. Luca's breadth of knowledge, enthusiasm, and energy level were all off the scale. He speaks English like a native, but with a charming accent. I very highly recommend using Through Eternity, and look forward to doing other tours with them in the future.

Absolutely amazing. We went on a tour that included the Colosseum, the Roman Forum, and the Palatine Hill. All of it was simply amazing, but I am SO glad we had a tour. Not only because we got to skip the lines, but because we were with someone that could help us reconstruct the history that we were looking at. It was so much more meaningful. And the Palantine Hill--WOW! We didn't know much about this hill, other than it was a hill, before we came, and we were blown away as we were walking up it and seeing the size first hand. Reconstruct the history up there, and you'll be amazed. Also, on a sunny day, the view from up there can't be beat. Gorgeous!

What can you say. To experience these things that you have only seen in photographs is amazing. No photograph does justice to the feeling of history that you experience in the presence of these monuments
Really impressive. Really impressive site - just hard to imagine how it looked way back then. So much to see and do and lots of walking!

Lost in time. Stunning, beyond belief. I could write for hours on this and it would not even begin to do the area and attractions justice.Top tips:Buy your entrance tickets at the forum ticket kiosk. The queues are 90% shorter than at the Colosseum.The same ticket includes The Colosseum, the forum and Palatine hillThe ticket is actually good for two days. So if you have time, do the Forum/Palatine hill one day (it really is a full day to do it any sort of justice) and the Colosseum the next.In my opinion, cramming everything into one day is too rushed and you loose (and even become a little blaze) a lot of the 'wow' effect.
Spend a Full Day Here!. Lots to see and you will really feel the history and a strong connection to ancient Rome. Loved it. Be sure to check out Casesars final resting spot!

Roman Forum - audio guide useful. It is advisable to access the site on the right hand side of the main road, walking down from Piazza Venezia. The queues are shorter, waiting time (10am) was half an hour. You can buy a combined ticket for the Roman Forum/Coliseum. However, you CANNOT buy the underground tickets for the Coliseum at this site. Unless you have an excellent guide book, an audio guide would be useful as the site is poorly signposted (unlike GB) and there are only a few inadequate signs, that explain each area. We split this site and the Coliseum over 2 half days. The pathways are uneven so sensible shoes are a must. The site is extensive as you walk up to Palantine Hill and the gardens, which have good views of Rome.

Very good, worth the visit.. We did not know that you had to pay to get into the grounds of the Roman Forum and as such viewed it from above. I am not opposed to the paying of the fee, it just wasn't scheduled in our plans so we walked around it instead of through it. We visited the Palatine Hill and Colosseum separately and are both well worth the visit. I would have loved to walked through the Forum as it was absolutely beautiful from above.

Iconic. My wife and I visited the Colosseum and Forum using Around Rome Tours and their guide was outstanding. She took us around very professionally and really knew her subject inside out. No doubt it would be enjoyable with just a guidebook, but I think it was definitely worth paying for an expert's time.

Can't miss, but get a guide. Awe-inspiring, thought provoking, and just plain amazing. Hiring a guide or joining a tour is essential to bypass the sometimes colossal lines and to really make the most of the experience, helping one to appreciate what life was like in those times. Ancient crowd control was ingenious -- better than Disney!

Amazing. Amazing to see. Nothing built in our lifetime can ever compare.
Need a lot of time and would recommend that unlike us you book on line.
A mixture of history. The words have no meaning for that place. You have to walk between the ruins and to leave you mind to travel in the past.

Must see. Ancient Rome.....beautiful.
Easily spend 3 to 4 hrs here in the forum and palatine alone.need comfy shoes and get some food.

So awesome and deeply historic, but spoiled by scaffolding. On our first trip to Rome it was hard to know what to expect - so much of the iconic ancient architecture and the later monuments are famous worldwide. Would it be a disappointment? No, the classic ancient Roman Colosseum and Forum are truly awe-inspiring in their engineering perfection, but it was really sad to see so much of the best side of the Colosseum and several parts of the Forum shrouded in scaffold and sheeting. This review should be five stars but I can't give that in the current circumstances. That said, if the end result is better preservation and access for future visitors, we will just have to come again sometime.We can definitely endorse the recommendation for comfortable shoes and plenty of time, but even if you have to cram the sights into a short time a brief visit to these amazing monuments to ancient Roman civilisation is a must. Using the Roma Pass to bypass the queues and get around the city on public transport is good value - book it online at www.romapass.it and collect from a nominated Tourist Information Point.
A great heritage. I liked to visit and enjoy the anceint civilitations and cultures. Colosseum is one of them. Just imagine, the magestic was it at its time.
A must!. If you are traveling in April look for the guided tour - "Colosseum , underground and the third ring" . a must tour (and on the way you skip the line...)
History comes alive. The whole area is very atmospheric, lots to see, lots of walking to do so wear comfy shoes!! We loved it.
Best advice wear comfortable shoes. Parts of it are larger than life. Very amazing yo see how they lived. Takes a long time to walk around the whole thing. Be aware they can be lots of tourists
Great value for money. Buy a combined ticket online and save money and time queuing. The forum isn't well signed so buy a guide book in advance and use a map to explain each building.
Awesome!. You can do these 3 in a half day and they are all close together! Also the ticket for one covers them all.

Awesome, not to be missed.. You need a passport to get an audio guide. Although it is a two day ticket, it doesn't allow re entry so you can do colosseum one day but you have to do forum and palatine hill together as they are same entry point.The scale and engineering of the colosseum is just phenomenal. We felt Palatine more interesting than Forum, both contain so much to see. Lots of walking and take water as there no refreshments available.Palatine Museum was a bit disappointing.You can't see Rome and not go here!

Amazing. Decided to book a trip with I Love Rome and Eleanor our guide was fantastic you could tell you really loved her job and country. The Colosseum was breathtaking, really good idea to do a tour as they are more information and think you really need it for this particular tour.
This combo is amazing but also exhausting. Trying to see this all in one day can be exhausting so start your day early. The online combo ticket is a good way to avoid any lines.
Awsome. The remains of the ancient city are awe inspiring.To think that all these remains are still standing and that their are further buildings underneath all of this. truly mind blowing.

Amazing. I first visited the Foro Romano 10 years ago and found it very interesting. This time was just as good, and more areas have been excavated. It was a little disappointing how much was sectioned off but it is good to know that more is being discovered about this fascinating place. The carcere (prison) where St Peter and St Paul were imprisoned was also interesting. This is located just outside the Forum.
need more than one day to see it all. Make sure you divide your time so you get to see it all. Walk through the Forum and then walk above on Palatine Hill. Need lots of time and comfortable shoes.

Amazing. We thought we'd arranged a tour with Viator for £65 each but half an hour before got an email saying the tour was booked up.So as we were there already we decided to do our own tour! We downloaded a Rick Steves audio guide onto our phone and bought our tickets from the booth on the Palatine entrance following a tip on Tripadvisor - no queues and booked an on-site guide for €5 each! The ticket is €12 for 2 days and just as well because you really need more than a few hours to get around the whole site.The Colosseum is an amazing feat of engineering and also quite emotive. It has a terrible but fascinating history. The groups of bored teenagers taking selfies are quite amusing...!The Forum is simply stunning. It's quite a small site in comparison to Ostia Antica or Pompeii but just as interesting. Palatine Hill is peaceful and beautiful and really worth spending a few hours wandering around.My main advice about tourism in Rome is not to believe the 'pay to jump-the-queue' information from the tour guides.We travelled in early April and didn't queue anywhere apart from a 25 min wait to get through security at St. Peter's. It will be different in July but when we went we arrived in mid/late morning, the tour groups were already in and there were no queues.
Around rome. Nice to see this ,although scaffolding makes it a bit of an anti climax,don't sit for too long ever five secs there trying to sell you some old tat
