A place full of history. I loved to visit the Coliseum and the ruins of Roman Forum. It's completely amazing. It helps a lot if you book a guide to explain you all the facts about the place, definelly worth. I booked Angels Tour and I highly recommend. https://www.facebook.com/AngelToursRome

A dream come true!. What more can I say about this phenom! It was quite an experience just standing in this structure! You CANNOT visit Rome and not come here or you might as well say you didn't visit Rome.
huge and fascinating. take a tour guide--you will need it. overwhelming and spectacular if you like history. not to be missed.

Tour of Ancient Rome -loved by our children. We are a family of four 2 teenagers and did a 5 hour tour with through eternity tours of these areas. We learnt so much and feel that these sites need a guided tour to understand what it did look like, the whys and the when's answered. We loved touring thought the roman forum and learning first hand about the history . There are some sign posts but not many so it would be easy to not understand what you are seeing. The same applies to the colosseum - our guide had pictures so we could see what it would have been like. This is a full day walking through these sites but went so fast- our children loves this more than the Vatican and St. Peter's . It is an absolute must see as this living Ancient Rome. Practicalities - toilets along the way but crowded in each place. Fresh water fountains are in all sites. No lines at Roman forum at 9:30 when we got there. Long lines at Colosseum. Suggest pre booking or going on a tour and start with the Roman forum and work your way back to the colosseum in the afternoon. Taxi was $7 euro from the Piazza Novona .

forum-connect to the past. this is a review of the forum. for colosseum see my other reviewat the forum audio and video guide was quite good. though its much better with a real guide. you will need passport or drivers licence to receive the guidenot to bad of linesnotice: buy combined ticket at forum you will skip the massive lines in colosseumcarefull on the way with your passport

Tiring, but worth it!. Having climbed the hill to get to the top, you are greeted by a huge marble archway with detail engravings and etched sculptures, There are many paths leading off to various directions. We were here for about five hours so just pick a pathway and you will surely find where the others go.There are steps leading to higher stone buildings. Nearly every building, dwelling, statue etc has a plaque to tell the history behind it in Italian, French, English and German.Take a camera! There are spectacular views of Rome (the Panoramic feature on mine was handy!).Also take plenty of liquids and food as there is nowhere to buy any. It was sunny and hot when we went (yes in February!). There is so much to take in here so just take it at your own pace and leisure. Overall a must! (and I don't even like Time Team! lol)
Roman Forum well worth a visit. Dont leave the colosseum without visiting the riuns of the roman forum. We had a tour guide who was very helpful and made the riuns come to life with historic data.

Perfect with Rick Steve's free audiotour. I downloaded Rick Steve's free app which includes many audiotours. My daughter and I enjoyed sitting in the shade at the sites and listening to Rick Steves' narrative.

Awesome grandeur. Go early, get a guided tour to bring the whole experience alive. This is gigantic, impressive, inspiring history. Tyranny, dynasty, politics, wealth beyond compare but you need your imagination and a storey teller. The must see.
Not to be missed. As you walk around this area you just have to marvel at how much there is to see and absorb. Take your time to read all the information signs.

Pre-book your tickets. This time round, much of the Colosseum was covered in scaffolding, disappointing however, needed to preserve it. Luckily, this was the second time I'd paid the entrance to view it as travelling with a friend who has never been.The new museum exhibit was good to see, and wander round, having not been in place before. The Roman Forum and Palatine require a full day to really do them justice - and it is advisable to take food/water with you as there is nowhere on site to purchase any. A bit of advice though is to pre-book tickets online to avoid the queues.
Wow!. A definite must for any visitor to Rome. We did it all with a 4 month old baby, & yes it was a very bumpy ride with our stokke buggy but well worth it to see all the history.

interesting ruins. the Colosseum will be crowded. and its hard to get past the people selling tickets for the "last tour of the day" , and this was at noon. trust me, they are not tour guides. once inside you do have to climb very steep stairs to get around so be prepared. its very interesting to see the inside, what is left of it , and get a feel for how big it really is. they do have a bathroom but I would avoid it. the Forum was an interesting hike trying to imagine what it would look like when all the buildings were complete. some are down to just a few pillars ,but when you think how old they are... its very incredible they are there at all. Palatine hill is a lot more uneven terrain to get around. but well worth the effort. you can wander for an hour looking at all there is. wear good walking shoes. leave pretty shoes at home. and remember there are water fountains to refill your own water bottle all over, dont bother to buy over pried bottles from sketchy street vendors. the water in Rome is the best you will ever drink!
awesome!. never went inside-lines to long,will book guided tour in advance next time,but was amazing to see,as were all the sights

Disappointed. I agree , you cannot visit Rome without seeing the Colosseum. Yes , there are ways of 'skipping' queues but we do not like the regimentation of organised tours so joined the queue for a ticket . Don't be fooled by there being no queue outside, it snakes around the inside . We queued for about 45mins in which we were herded with others to the ticket office. When you get to the ticket office it is a bun fight to get one , no system in place so get your elbows ready. There was no build up, no music or sound effects whilst waiting and nothing to read. No imagination at all !! The Colosseum fortunately sells itself and is still worth a visit. We really enjoyed the Palatine as it was less crowded. Our overall feeling about all the sights is that they lack any imagination at all, signs are very basic so take a good guide book to help you. The lady in the Roma Pass office nearby was not interested in serving us at all and carried on her conversation with her friend , hence we didn't get one !! Will not be rushing back !

A MUST-SEE!. Go first to the forum, where the queues were non-existent for us in late March, and buy the combined ticket for 12 euros. Or, if you're over 65, show your passport for free tickets... I love the Italian consideration for older people! With your pre-paid (or free) ticket, you do not have to queue, which was good for the Palatine, but tremendous for the Colosseum, where there were two VERY long lines of people waiting maybe an hour to pay to enter, but we were just let in immediately. Ticket valid for 48 hours: we were glad we saw the Forum and Colosseum on the first day, as we found them more interesting and better preserved than the Palatine, which we could have coped better with not seeing.
Give it at least half a day.. Get a guide! Amazing without one, incredible with one. We managed to pick one up for 18 Euros and only had 10 in our group - more than worthwhile.
Obligatory. These are obvious "must sees". February was slim crowds with good weather. I can imagine it is swamped with people in the summer. Go prepared with snack and drink.

Mandatory for anyone interested in History. I took a guided tour that included all these historic sites. Absolutely worth every minute of it. Imagine standing where the Emperors of Rome (and leaders of the world at the time) stood and spoke to the people and even where the ashes of Julius Caesar are buried. Amazing so much of it is standing and available for us to see and learn from and be mesmerized by.Try to get the special Colosseum tour that includes the underground -- very interesting stuff. Lots of steps for all these sites, and it can be hot so be prepared and take water. Enjoy
Fine. We liked it a little bit more than Colosseum due to being less crowded. This place surely cannot be missed by first time Rome visitors but would never go there again.

Fascinating insight into Ancient Rome. Fascinating insight into Ancient Rome and their way of life. Such a shame their is only remains left as it would have been truly amazing to see more. The remains are very grand and you can see how the Romans did everything to a very grand scale
Take a tour. People approach you outside and ask if you'd like a tour, take it, they are good and you don't have to queue . Steep steps to climb inside

very tiring. wear good shoes and take water. I loved this tour with viator and it was good value for money. We did this in April and it was quite hot., All waiting in line skipped. Would hate to do this in mid summer. There is too much to take in with the temperature too high. Our guide was David who got the blend of knowledge and comedy just right. Could have spent a lot longer here had i been doing this on my own but would never have got all the info.

When in Rome. We paid €12 for the 3 sites............brilliant value, ticket lasts two days and you will need two days to explore all around...........look for the American lady in the gardens, if she says she will be your guide stop and chat too her!! She is great! Check out the bronze doors that are still there 2 thousand later, with the lock still working! Not good for wheelchair access.

Crowded and full of scaffoldings. Both visits are necessary if you go to Roma, but if you have the "bad" luck of going during the weekend, at least the Colosseum is crowded of people and you can't enjoy it as it deserves. So if you go during the weekend it's better to do the effort of going soon in the morning, in order to avoid the rush hours. The Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum are less crowded, but when we went they were full of scaffoldings and it makes them to lose part of their beauty, but if you have some imagination you can feel like if you were living in the ancient Rome and it's a very nice visit and experience. For this places be careful with the entering time because the last entrance finish earlier than the Colosseum one (at 15:45 I guess) so it's easy to arrive and find it closed. I highly recommend you to buy the tickets through the internet in advance, because you pay the same and you avoid queues, and you can use it during 2 or 3 days since the first usage.

An must, when in Rome!. A really an must, when you are in Rome.Lot of wlaking, so use good shoes!!Prepare for lot of people, but a really nice tour.We alked in Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum for 4 hours, without any guide.If you are really in to history, it may be worth to have an guided tour wich you'll be offered outside of Colosseum.

Must-See Trifecta. These three attractions can be enjoyed in one day. Make sure you find a guidebook to explain the ruins at the Palatine and Forum. I recommend the overlay flip-books they sell at the colosseum gift shop. They're an easy way to compare what you're seeing to what used to exist at the site.

Guided tour is best. We really enjoyed our tour of the Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. I strongly recommend a guided tour for two reasons-first, you can bypass the long lines and second, there is so much to see you need someone to make sure you see and explain the best sites. The cost is well worth it. We used a tour company recommended by TripAdvisor (City Wonders but they mentioned they were changing their name. Ask for Laura, she was great). If you are in Rome, the Colosseum is a must-see.

You can't visit Rome without going here. We visited the Colosseum first and the tickets included the Forum so we went there directly which was a mistake. We needed a break for a coffee and once in the Forum area couldn't come out and go back in very easily so ended up cutting the Forum area visit short. There are two entrances to the Forum area and the one furthest away is probably the best. Then you can spend a long time wandering the beautiful ruins of ancient Rome.

Good tour. We took a skip the line tour with upgrades to walk on the floor of the Colosseum. It was a nice tour. We opted for the 2:45pm tour and honestly would have enjoyed it better if we had gone in the morning. We were finished by 6pm and by then we were hungry and tired and there were other things to see in the area but opted to go back home. Definitely chose a group tour which helps you skip the ques.
WOW. Buy your tickets in Palatine hill and then go to Colosseum to save waiting in the queue. You need to take guided tour if you like to go to the third floor view on Colosseum.

Wonderful exploring and good historical variety. Spent a few hours exploring the Palatine Hill and Roman Forum. The views of Rome from the Hill, underground passageways, various ancient ruins and buildings, majestic trees and garden, statues, and history made this a highlight of the trip. I could spend another day just exploring and enjoying these sights.

Roman Ruins. No doubt there is a feel of ancient world in it. When I stepped in after walking big stoned cobbled Via Sacra, it was like I am entering wonderland. Vertical earthquake struck columns where absorbing me in them. It looks like its just a walk through but when you take steps down your eyes revolve around 360 degree to see the destruction of mighty power of the world in their times. Every stone speaks and tell what all these years they have seen, glory to destruction.Be careful while walking as it's really uneven and there should be water with you oh hot day and umbrella for unpredictable shower.Once you enter to the site, you have two options. Either go left to Palatine Hill or go straight to walk through forum and on right ruined temples. When you reach at the end under the marble pillars and Septimius Severus Arch, the view is awesome, specially when sun is setting down on your right.I would suggest to make your own marks with sunlight and take good shades, if you are keen photographer. You will be amazed with colours and angles you will achieve.You can exit on right half way through or at the end on right side - both bit steep upwards.Once you are out of site, there is no way in...as usual.Good luck.Contact at kqureshie@outlook.com if any questions still unanswered.

Visual History. We had visited in the past when we were herded around as part of a tour. This time we explored at our own pace and enjoyed it much more. As a UK pensioner it was free entry (as for all E.U. nationals) which is quite impressive when one considers the cost of visiting UK sites such as The Tower of London! Being early spring the various sites were not crowded which added to the enjoyment.
Guided tours. Very interesting but the Colosseum tour was very crowded and this was in February, the off season. Getting a guided tour with the no wait in line ability was a good idea.
great history. history fascinating,awe inspiring must have sensible footwear as it is a long way around.no good for anyone with walking diffaculties

Must-sees!. These three places are an absolute must-see for any traveler in Rome. Pay the €12 entrance fee for the Colosseum and your admission to the Roman Forum (plus Palatine Hill) is free. We used Rick Steves' audio guide app for a tour of the Colosseum and the Roman Forum and would highly recommend downloading the app. It is very informative and easy to use!

Ancient Rome at Its Finest!!!. I was completely amazed at the Roman ruins. Though the lines were long, you can get preferred entry by purchasing the Roma Pass. It's so worth the money and provides you with free entry to museums and use of transit. Be prepared to walk and make certain you are hydrated if you are going when the weather is nice. Be prepared to spend at a minimum 6 hours to tour all of the sites. Otherwise, you'll miss out.

Fantastic. Fantastic, we got the underground tour tickets and glad we did,and skipping the mega long que was a bonus, you can see colosseum in a couple of hours, but it so much more enjoyable to take a slow walk taking in all the wonder of the size,

Excellent. Pure history and a must, at the Palatine you really sense the atmosphere and how it would have been all those years ago. Very touristy but that's to be expected, eat of of the main drag and in town if you can, away from the usual chain eateries there are some wonderful family restaurants. Tour recommended as you bypass the queues depending on what time of year you go, but using the audio guides also works well as you can move around in your own time.

Step back in time. Some tips: Once you buy a ticket, hold on to it! The ticket gives you access to the three sites, but you can't re enter the site you already visited. The ticket is also valid for 2 days. If you have time, it would be better to do COlloseo on day 1, then just walkabout and eat in trattoria in the afternoon; then do Forum on Day2. BUT you can really do both on one day.
Go with a Guide. We went on a beet the Que organised trip, with access to the underground chambers and third tear. What a fantastic place well worth going with a guide they bring everything to life.
Colosseum. One of the favorite places we visited. It was amazing! We didn't have time for the Roman Forum or Palatine Hill, you will need all day for this

Beautiful. Stunning views of Colosseum and amazing scale and detail on some of the ruins and archaeological finds. Everyone who has any sort of interest in history should go!
Lots of walking - not suitable for anyone with mobility issues (lots of cobbles and uneven surfaces along with steep hills and steps)

Do the underground tour. By pre booking the entrance and the tour it was easy to enter the site. Our male English speaking tour guide Micheal was excellent. At each point he would explain the facts for a few minutes then give everyone a few minutes to take photos. Worth the extra euros for this particular tour.

The best. This can't be missed, to get a feel for ancient Roman history, and to imagine ancient Roman life. If you get the chance, go to the view terrace at the Capitoline Museum as well, as you can overlook the whole Forum area. Dark Rome (now named City Wonders) also did a nice tour of this whole area.

All 3 a must.. One pass gets you into all 3 places and it is only 12 euros. They are all fascinating and I enjoyed them all on Friday when I went with my wife. To learn about something 2000 years ago that is still intact somewhat is fascinating.

All three a 'must see'. World famous sites you must visit, others describe them more eloquently than I so here are some practical tips: one ticket buys entry to all three, buy your ticket at the Forum or Palatine Hill ticket offices to avoid the enormous queue at the Colloseum;There is no need to buy the Roma pass if you just want to see these sites;There are several fountains on the Hill and Forum to top up your water bottle with delicious local water;wear sensible walking shoes and a hat. Even in spring the sun beats down and there is little shade;It is easy to spend most of a day exploring just these three sites if you have the time;Unless you want to pay for the privilege do not have your photo taken with ther 'Roman soldiers' that lurk around these and other attractions. We saw them decline to return cameras until they had been paid.
Fantastic. Whole trip was great, bought a guided tour just outside. Best decision ever, would advise the tour to anyone going there

One of the reasons for visiting Rome. This is where Europe began, without the Romans and this city who knows what would have happened.. its essential viewing if you visit Rome. Popular so plan your trip well..

Walking through the centre of ancient Roman public life. Between the Palatine and Capitoline Hills, the Roman Forum was the commercial, political, religious and social centre of ancient Rome. This centre of public life would have been an impressive hub which housed the most important public buildings, temples and arches. Today there are extensive ruins and with some imagination, as you stand on the original paving stones that lined the road, placing footsteps where ancient Romans went about their business, this scattering of ruins begin to come alive. Having a guide also helped bring the ruins to life.We booked a small tour through Viator “Small-Group Ancient Rome and Colosseum Tour: Underground Chambers, Arena and Upper Tier” which included walking through the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill before going to the Colosseum. Our English speaking guide was very knowledgeable and we found it was a great way to see some of the main sites before going to the Colosseum. We definitely benefited from visiting these sites with a guide and would recommend, especially as there is not a lot of information at the site itself. In total our tour was around three and a half hours.There are some well preserved ruins remaining at the Forum, including the Arch of Septimius Severus and the Arch of Titus, the House of the Vestals and several temples, such as Temple of Antoninus and Faustina and the Temple of Romulus.Also a highlight on the Palatine Hill is the Neronian Cryptoporticus which is an underground corridor, 130 metres long.There is quite a lot of walking which we found enjoyable. Would recommend wearing comfortable shoes and a hat if sunny, also bring sunscreen. It did get quite warm and we were grateful that we had taken our own water with us.

take your time and enjoy. The admission covers multi days so don't rush trying to see it all in one day. The Palatine Hill section is huge and can get hot and dusty in the summer, bring water and don't miss the house of Augustus in the back.
Big site. Lot of walking to do as the site is bigger than when you look at it from above. Well worth it though. Get some good photos of the Colsseum from the Forum/Palatine Hill.

Loved it!. Lots to see. Incredible history. It's right by the Colosseum. We had a guide and I think it was better than wandering around trying to figure things out by the signs. Also, use the restroom BEFORE you go. There is literally one ladies room and one mens room for about 10,000,000 guests a year. Ridiculous.

Best attraction in town. The colosseum is amazing, but also the Palatine Hill with Cesar's Golden House will take your breath away. Beautiful views from the hill. It still is amazing to walk in these beautiful sites.

Palatine Hill, Forum. Last time we visited , it was free to enter the Forum. In the interim years , in the Forum many places are now railed off, which to my mind detracts from the experience. Getting a good photo now is not so easy. However it is still an unique place , full of history and awe. I was slightly disappointed in the Palantine Hill . I had expected to find more intact remains of dwellings etc. I thought Livia's villa was not well restored. It looks like a modern eyesore! However,by peeping in through one of the windows which didn't have a blind behind, we could see some frescos . The queue to Augustu's villa was long so we skipped that.
Expect Caesar to appear. Everything is exceptional, go to The Curia see where the Senate of Rome sat, Caesar, Mark Antony, Agrippa just the names bring it all to life. Wonderful stuff of legends!

Truly Majestic!. The Colosseum is truly majestic and awesome in every respect.A good tour guide really helps to give the historic background of the place and makes the place come alive.The story of the gladiators and the arena they fought in is eternally captivating and it is therefore a destination, not to be missed on your Rome tour.There is a lot of scaffolding around the building, but that still didn't spoil the visit for me.I do recommend taking your time and having a guide for this truly iconic building.One can hire a guide just for the Colosseum or combine it with a tour of Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum.It is slightly expensive but well worth it.
Don't miss it. Avoid long lines, be sure to take a tour. The tour of the underground Colosseum is not too be missed, it may require booking months in advance

Amazing. We chose english speaking guide who turned out to be Italian but her knowledge of the Colosseum was immense. We paid for joint trip to Colosseum, Palatino Hill and the Forum (we thought). Have already written review for Colosseum but it is a must if you visit Rome and even more interesting with information given by guide.Very impressed. Different guide for Palatine Hill and although he was very learned the tour stopped as we got to the Forum.We were left to walk round the Forum on our own with very little info from the guide before he left us. Turns out the tour we paid for did not include 'guided tour' of Forum so make sure their are no misunderstandings before the tour. Wouldn't have missed it tho and would recommend all 3 to anyone visiting the Colosseum as Palatine and Forum just across the road from Colosseum.
Carrani tour. Perfect tour starting from the hotel at 7:30am, we skip the long line and in a few minutes we entered inside the arena, emotional and fantastic experience!

A great chance to see the history books come alive!. I went to the Colosseum as part of a tour, and I must say I learned a lot more than I already knew! The Colosseum had been used as a storage area, and there were even bricks down on the bottom, proving that it had been used as a sort of warehouse. It was old, and colossal, and awesome! Highly recommended for anyone, and please get a guided tour, so that you may learn a few things on vacation!

Don't leave out!. We toured with "When in Rome", a great company. The tour was excellent, all due to Chaira, and well worth the time. We saw the Coliseum, Pantheon, Roman Empire and Trevi Fountain. Yes, it was over 3 hours, but we wouldn't have seen and learned so much. The next day we toured with on a Segway so if you're worried about being too tired consider this way. It was fun and easy to learn. Our weather (March) couldn't have been nicer!

Gotta be done - expensive tho!. These 3 together have got to be at the top of the When In Rome List and on its own, the Colosseum is so impressive. Be aware, there is a lot of roadworks and scaffolding up around the walls so go round the other side for photos. We didn't bother with a tour because of the crowds, but a walk round is worth it. Such a shame you have to pay to go into The Forum now. You can definitely appreciate the immensity of it if you walk round the edge as we did, but if you really want to experience The Forum, pay and go with a Guide. A Rome 'Must See' hence the 4 stars. Shame about the expense.

Amazing.... We loved the Forum but you need to know what you are looking at. For this we downloaded Rick Steves guides and printed some maps off. This allowed us to tour at our own pace and find the locations that were being mentioned. I can imagine this visit being very hot and getting extremely crowded later in the year. It was just comfortable in March although the Colosseum seemed packed. We didnt have to queue for tickets as we visited the Forum first, and the security line into the Colosseum was 10 mins at most. Overall our favourite location in Rome and well worth spending at least half a day there.....
Great. This was a great tour, love the Plalatine Hill view. It is really long if you have young children with only two bathrooms to be passed.

A must if this is your first visit to Rome, Italy. Joined a spontaneous guided tour because we were lining up. Heavily depends on the information by the guide, if not hard to figure out the importance of the historical sites.

must see but exhausting walking round. March is a good time to go as the temperature was 20 - 25c when we were recently which is a nice temperature to walk round its quite knackering walking round from one monument to the next, I would not like doing this in July or August although fascinating.

Tiring!. Pooped from all the walking, but impressed with our guide, Lynn, who was a friendly American who told us all the history of the place and answered all our daft questions. Her tour was a freebie added on to the Coloseum tour we bought - thoroughly enjoyed it.
Don't rush the visit. some much to see and understand.the forum was not as easy to visualise, and could have been looked after better, but that just my opinion, it has to be done though

48 hour ticket for Colosseum, Palantine and Roman Forum. we had been given advice by friends to pre book tickets before coming to Rome and booked our ticket to cover the Colosseum, Palantine and Forum. It certainly helped avoid the long queues at the Colosseum but we came unstuck by then going to the Palantine - we asked the man on the gate if we would be able to use the ticket at the Palatine the next day if we hadn't seen all the sights. We were told we could. We saw all we needed but on the hill but needed to still see the Roman Forum the next day. The next day we tried to use our 48 hour ticket at the Fourm but were told we couldn't use the ticket because we had used it the day before. Apparently although the ticket is for 48 hours you have to visit the Colosseum on one day and the other two sights on the same day. This was not explained clearly when buying tickets so we ended up having to pay twice.

Wear comfortable shoes- lots to see.... Try to get there early.. To avoid a long wait we bought tickets from the Palantine Hill ticket office. We probably queued about 20 mins on a Sunday. There are great views from the top of the hill and there is also a museum containing items that have been discovered on the site. When we had spent a couple of hours walking around we carried on to the Roman Forum. The ticket office there had no queues at all... The tickets are valid for 2 days so we saw the fantastic Colosseum the next day.. As we had a valid ticket we were able to walk past the long queues. I would recommend having a guide. Take something to drink too.There is a lift at the Colosseum .

get tickets from palative hill. You need at least 3-4 hours just to take a quick look. Toilets from the palatine hill entrance are not marked clearly but are on your right in a white building . In the colosseum the steps are really steep so use the lift a little further from the entrance, the walking stones are slippery, where comfortable shoes , there is drinking water in many locations. The guided tours cost 15 euros for each sight , while a ticket is 12 euros for all three.If you are under 18 or over 65 you get a 50% discount.

I would recommend walking exploring these ruins. One of the most amazing ruins here on palantine hill, so much history, it needs to be appreciated - I would read up on the history before coming here because it makes the experience 50 times more amazing when you know what its all about - dont miss this! I think the entrance is included when you purchase a ticket to the colloseum as long as you do it in the same day or the next then you dont have to pay additional

Visit Them All. These three sights/sites are linked with one admission charge, and the story behind each is very interesting. Book a tour or use an audio guide to get the most from your visit. One should not miss this while visiting Rome.

Ruins with a twist. You have to have a good imagination to appreciate what once was. Or have a good and passionate guide. Or stick around groups of children - their teachers are the best in explaining things.

Use Roma Pass to skip lines!. The colosseum was a major highlight of our trip. Make sure to use Roma Pass to skip lines and pay the 12 Euro or so extra to take tour underneath the colosseum into the passage ways. It is worth every euro!

Walk with History. Just a fantastic historic experience. Our tour guide was very knowledgeable of the whole area which made for a more interesting walk. You can just feel the history as you walk in the area. It is definitely worth the long and sometimes difficult walk.
Wonderful walk... through the history. It is very nice to have a walk because you can understand the way of the ancient Roman life.

Superb. Just magical, so interesting and to think about all of the history at these places. We paid for an organised tour which cost 36 euros, we jumped the queues and out guide was just superb. Tour took about 3.5 hours, brilliant.

Still standing. Going to the top of the Palatine Hill was very relaxing(once you got up there). The views of the Forum below and of the Colosseum from way up high were great! The Forum still has lots of ruins that are still standing. They're huge! It's so hard to figure out how the Romans were able to build these massive things without the machinery that we have now!

Pure history. I love ancient history so being in Rome in these places just brings you back 2000 years in history.
I think they could add more signs with comments and directions

An incredible resource, too many street vendors. No need to review the coliseum, it is a must-see for every human being, I just wish they would get rid of the endless street vendors who are literally, and I mean literally, in your face selling you all kinds of junk.
They would probably sell more if they weren't so annoying
WOW!!. Always wanted to visit these places and now I have. Just picture yourself back in the Roman times. How they built these is beyond me. Fabulous to see.

You will walk on the same land that is all over history books. Get ready to fell special.. The entrance is included with the paid ticket to the colosseo. Lots of ruins to see and also very big trees. Impressive all over. Go with comfortable shoes because the stones are very tricky if you have non athletic shoes.
Must See if you can avoid the gladiators. Loved the Coloseum. Palatino too. AVOID the Gladiators at all cost. Theyre scum. They will put a damper on your day.

Had a great Tour guide!. We toured all three and we chose to do the Colosseum and Palatine Hill with a tour guide and did the Forum on our own. It is absolutely breathtaking to walk where such amazing history took place! Definitely go and get a tour-guide if you can (it's worth the value).

Fantastic. When we got to the Colosseum first thing in the morning, this bloke came up to us and told us he could get us on the next tour. He was charging 25 euros for the two of us which included a tour guide of the colosseum, palatine hill. Both of these were amazing. We were then left to our own devices and left to wander around The Forum on our own. All in all, a fabulous time was had.
Just Great. Have a guide at the Colosseum, although you only need the guide from the ticket office and not from those outside the colosseum trying to sell inflated priced tickets.

A scaffolder's paradise. Obviously structures do require restoration and maintenance but sadly our timing was not so great with scaffolding and such marring the view of perhaps 60+ % of the Colosseum.Personally very disappointed.
History. Do not forget to visit this historical most important building and here you can with a little bit of imagination understand ithe real meaning of bread and circuses

Amazing!. This place is a must, I cant imagine anybody wouldnt be impressed by the Colosseum! We went early in the morning and im glad we did as it wasnt crowded allowing us to take our time, take photos and read information boards without being crowded by others. The best day out of our trip!
Great tour organised by Viator. The tour guide we had made this a very special morning, lots of interesting history learnt and stunning views.

Worth the price of addmission. I t never would have realized how much there was to see with out this private tour. I think we would have missed seeing and learning about all these sites. It was truly amazing what they accomplished long ago.

A little bit of history. Visited the Roman Forum on 27 February and spent all afternoon here and in the Colosseum. A perfect day for such a visit, warm sunshine with barely a cloud in the sky. We walked all through the Forum and visited the Arch of Titus, the Temple of Saturn, the statues of the Vestal Virgins and the house of Agustus and Livia. We pored over the excavations and wandered up and down the Palatine and Capitoline Hills. Also visited the Church of Saint Bonaventure. Amazing to walk in the footsteps of the Roman emperors, their wives and people around them. The Colosseum was amazing also, to see such architecture and workmanship was out of this world. For me the Roman Forum won hands down and I could have stayed all day poring over the history of the area. So much to see and do. Well worth the admittance fee.
Well worth 12 Euro's. Go early and avoid the queues. 12 Euros gets you access to all 3 areas. I suggest doing the Colosseum first.

A large chunk of history. You gotta open your wallet and go in. I didn't do it the first time I was in Rome and now I know what I missed.The ruins are amazing and if you know the background of what you're seeing (do some reading beforehand) you can easily spend over 4 hours strolling and paying attention to all the details.

rocking ruins. took the tour of the colosseum which was interesting and then opted to head up to Palatine hill with the same company. The tour probably wasn't necessary,just get a guide book and wander

A bit of a let down!. Worth going to see as your Colosseum ticket includes one for this site too, however I wouldn't spend long here compared to other sites in Rome, as all you can really appreciate is how old the site is and that's it. There's no pictures of what it would have been like and museum that was a definite let down nothing in english, and it was just old statues. Could really use a museum which shows what it would have been like from different characters perspectives even a short film in a museum on site would have added to it. Also, like the Colosseum would have been great to have paid a little extra for a tour guide who could make the forum come to life! All in all it was a bit of a disappointment :l 3/5 !

Make it with the guided tour!. The Colosseum in Rome is definetly worth seeing. But without a tour guide it will be just a damaged old building. I strongely recommend everybody to buy the tour that give access to the basement and third floor. It changed completely the image that I had from Colosseum. Beside that, I think that the elevator system are the highliths of this building. For those who just want to check a tourist attraction the main part is enough, but for a little bit more of impressive history the basement is a must! By the way.. we had this tipp from our free tour guide: buy the tickets at the foro romano!!! It's valid for the 3 places. it saves you the 2h line and/or the 4 € from the online purchase!

Amazing but watch the pickpockets outside. Amazing place. Get the audio guide, and aim to wander for a couple of hours. When outside this place, and the Colosseum, beware pickpockets, they are very nimble fingered, they don't look like pickpockets, and they are more prominent than you think. Basically don't leave anything to chance and keep valuables in your hand, in an inside pocket, or in your hotel. Sad, but true in Rome.

Impressionante. Unnecessary saying about how awesome this place is. The only problem are the "zingare" gypsies: poor women usually in black suits who approach you to ask money,but they are intent to rob you.

Walking through history. The Forum is absolutely amazing and well worth going to. There is so much to see that you could spend days here.
Tip - you buy a join ticket to the Forum and Colosseum - Don't stand in the queue at the Colosseum, buy it at the Forum with no queue.

Excelent. I made this trip in my third day in Rome and I enjoyed it so much! The Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum are next to the Colosseum so I visited these attractions in the same day. It's even better to those who like the Roman Imperium

History Come to Life. The Forum may not get quite as much attention as the neighboring Colosseum, but it is definitely worth setting aside a few hours to wander among the ruins and marvel at the grandeur of ancient Rome. Bonus: the line is shorter, too.

Disgraceful presentation. What should be an absolute highlight is no such thing. Scaffoldng everywhere, the best viewpoint over the Forum from the hill above shut. No labelling, signposting or explanation. Yes, it's a truly remarkable sight, but Rome shoud be ashamed of such abysmal, shambolic presentation.

The heart of ancient Rome. This was the highlight of my visit to Rome. Walking through these ruins, i couldn't help feeling that i was walking along the same steps as Caesar, Marc Antony, or Augustus. Theres so much to see. The site of the Vestal Virgins, The place where Caesar was cremated, The house of Augustus and so on. A must visit. Buying your ticket for the Colosseum will get you access to the forum.

A top highlight of our visit in Italy.. My husband and I visited via a Walks of Italy tour that combined them with the Colosseum, so our entrance fee was already covered and the tour allowed us to skip any lines (the tour was the best tour we've ever had, so I highly recommend it as well - a lot of interesting information is included in it). It's an incredible experience to visit and feel the presence of another time. And with so much open space, it's not crowded, so very relaxing to take everything in and take amazing photos. There are also pieces of ruins not sectioned off that you can touch. In our opinion, visiting is a must and if we visit Rome again, we will definitely go back!

Rich in Culture and History. If you have an interest in history and culture, the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill is a must. While most of the ruins are just exactly that, ruins, they give an insight into Ancient Rome. Entry here is included in the price of entry to the Colosseum. Buy your ticket here for entry to the Colosseum to avoid the long queues there. Allow around 2 hours for your visit to the Forum and Palatine Hill. While it is understandable considering how old it is, the ground is very rough and is not wheel-chair/buggy friendly.

What a great tour!. Spent the morning on at tour through Viator, and all I can say is if you want to know the true history of Rome this is the tour for you. My wife got this tour as a surprise for me, and needless to say I was like a kid in a candy store. There is no waiting in lines, you go in places the general public is not allowed. You here history from tour guides who that makes what you are seeing come to life. If you are in Rome and get the chance to take this tour take it. It will change how you see Rome for the rest of your life.

Centre of the world. There are few places on earth that can truly be called the centre of the world but the Roman Forum is one. For many hundreds of years it was the administrative capital of the world's first true empire. The senate of the Roman Republic ruled from here and victorious generals from Marius to Julius Caesar brought their triumphant armies, loot and captured enemies down the Via Sacra. The site is in ruins and those ruins are largely of a later era and yet the resonances of history and the site's importance are still strong here. If you wish to understand the site you will need an audio guide or a guided tour as the site is jumbled and confusing. Even without a guide the site is awesome. I believe I read somewhere that it is the largest open air museum in the world. So my tip is, whether or not you choose the guided tour, bring plenty  water and food, take plenty of time and soak up the experience of being in one of the world's unique historic settings.

On our own. We bought a pass on the internet, 13.50 Euro per person, and walked from our hotel nearby to tour these 3 places which are close to each other. It is value for money at our own leisure. Be sure to bring bottle water to last you a few hours of walking. There are plenty of eateries close by. We enjoyed touring on our own.

Another 'must visit' place in Rome. The Forum is like so many places in Rome, an amazing and convincing demonstration of the Roman Empire's construction skills. Something that also impresses me about the Forum and the other monuments in Rome is the lack of exploitation. If they were in England and were owned by the National Trust or English Heritage there would be a tasteless gift and souvenir shop planted at the entrance or exit. None if that tat here!

I have to go back to the Roman Forum !!!. If I had only 1 day in Rome..I would be sure to priorize this site. It's so interesting. You can pay extra for an "Audio Tour....but...I found that audio tour quite confusing. They give a map with it, which is extremely hard to follow and locate where you are...and there is just too much historical information in the audio to absorb...unless you are a history buff and know a lot of the stuff already. The signs posted around the site are much more succinct, interesting and easier to use !! On palatine hill...enjoy wonderful views over the city...as well as history as old as Caesar Augustus ....and even older too ! More Layers of history on Palatine hill are being uncovered currently in archeological digs !!

Lots to See!. A must do but make sure you sent aside enough time to see it all. The Forum itself takes a good 2 hours to stop and absorb everything. We only saw a little bit of Palatine Hill, would have liked to have spent more time there. Not a great place to visit with kids - we had a stroller and that was a huge pain to lug around, especially as the ground was rather muddy. This place will only be meaningful to kids who have studied some Ancient Roman history ...One very important lesson learnt. We came from visiting the Colosseum where we hired and returned the Audio Guide. We were told that the Audio Guide was meant to cover both the Colosseum and The Forum. The staff at the gate were totally unsympathetic when we showed them the receipt from the earlier rental and insisted that we went back to the Colosseum to try to get the Audio Guide again - we didn't bother. We still got a lot out of the visit minus the Audio Guide though.There is no food in the complex, so bring your own if you are visiting over lunch ...There are 2 crystral clear fresh water springs not far from the Arch at the entrance - the water tasted fresh and clean, but we only hope it was indeed so!

Better with a guide - Melhor com guia.. Following an advisor, we went to the visitor's center and requested a guide. As brazilians we asked one portuguese speaking and they asked for Ms Barbara Ponti that was fantastic. I do recommend a visist with her that turned the visit far more interesting and remarkable.
Gorgeous tucked away piece of Ancient Rome. After the hustle and bustle of the city of Rome, the Roman Forum is positively delightful. Go lateish afternoon when the sunlight is soft.

Interesting walk. Walking around this place you really feel like you have been transported back in time. Some of the structures and buildings around make you want to close your eyes and try to picture what life would have been like back then.But be careful of the men dressed up as gladiators outside the forum wanting to take your photo, they will try to rip you off by charing 20 euros.

Look at this chicken bone!. Here's my analogy for the Roman Forum. It's like if you visited a place, and the tour guide said "Look at this chicken bone! It used to be an enormous chicken. The chicken was delicious and important. Let me tell you a story about the chicken." See, thing is, mostly, I'm just hearing a story. Looking at the bone doesn't provide me with a ton of enjoyment. So while it's impressive and all that to think about the history of it, it's not really worth a ton of time if you're not a history BUFF. A quick 45 minute stroll will be plenty, then you can get out and enjoy the rest of Rome.

What a wonderful tour!!!. One thing I wanted to do in my life: visit the coliseum.But it is not so easy to find a good guide but we were lucky.Our guide Thomas has the advantage of being first and foremost an archaeologist and then with his passion he shows you things that others do not see. Great to see the excavations where he worked with his university.I never do, but this time I really recommend him to everyone!

Just an amazing place. The ticket we got visiting the Colosseum also covers the entrance to Forum Romano. This place is incredible and he silence and the nature makes you forget you are in a city. It's truly amazing how the ruins are still standing and what a great power they have in recreating at least a bit of that life and environment from the past and I am sure ancient Romans experienced the same gorgeous aunts we do now.
Amazing!. The Colosseum area is very special for me...........you cannot visit Roma if you cannot visit the Colosseum.......Looooool!!!!

Ancient history within a small area. You can get your taste of Ancient Rome within a confined area: The Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. Reachable via Metro (subway) (Colosseo station), once you step out of the station -- the Colosseo is there to greet you with its grand structure. It is free if you want to get pictures of the external building, but if you want to walk inside, you need to buy tickets (easier to book online, or purchasing it through the Roman Forum entrace -- as it has the same access to both sites).The Roman Forum and Palatine Hill features ruins of the early Roman city. It would be great if you have a tourguide (as I didn't have time). Great visit! Well recommended!
Beautiful site!. Walking through the Roman Forum was an amazing experience.Every piece of land and stone tells a story.I loved it.

"Vatican tour". Rip off ! Avoid this tour group!, my family and I hired the tour group named " Vatican tour" this past August. We paid for a 7 hour tour of Ancient Rome and the Vatican for 10 person at the cost of 150 euro pp. we were supposed to go to the colosseum , the roman forum, circus Maximus, the Trevi fountain, the Spanish step and the Pantheon, and then on to the Vatican. We were offered to pay cash to receive a discount on the tour of 10 %. They asked for a credit card to hold the reservation and purchase the museum ticket. The balance to be payed in cash at the time of the tour,for the discount.Although our guide was pleasant and knowledgeable, we spent ( by her dialogue ) so much time at the colosseum that we just did a drive by of circus Maximus and had to ask to stop to see the over look of the Roman Forum (not go to) . We didn't go to the Spanish steps at all!All of this could have been overlooked has they not ripped us off. My credit card was charged for the entire tour , no discount , no offer for it, and no appology when I reported their mistake. Avoid this tour group!!!

Ceaser sleeps here. A must see if in Rome, the history of Rome flows thru the Forum and the restoration of these ruins are a monument to this amazing civilization. Make sure you wear comfortable shoes the pavement is uneven and slippery. If visiting on a hot day carry head gear since the sun tends to bake this site. A must see is the site where Gais Julius Caeser was cremated.

Reserved Tickets. As with every other popular place in Italy, reserve your tickets ahead and avoid the lines. We got right in as others before us continued to wait to enter. There's a lot of info and even maps of the Forum online, so a guide or audio guide aren't necessary. Be careful and watch where you're walking since the ground is very uneven with loose stones. The cobblestones are varying heights and widths, so just watch and stop often rather than trying to walk and look. I've learned after falling in Chicago and in Paris that I can only do one thing at a time. We were sure we'd enjoy the Forum, but it's even more wonderful than expected. It was so moving to be where so much history took place. When I read Shakespeare in high school, little did I know I'd stand in the Forum one day. Goosebumps! With centuries of history and neglect until the 1900's, it's being restored to the late Roman Empire period. I've seen travel photos of the Forum packed with people. I'm telling you, fellow advisors, go in April!

Fascinating place. We much preferred the Roman Forum finding the Palatine Hill not as interesting (although useful for toilets). Buy your tri-ticket for the colosseum as well here to avoid the queues there - also under 17's from the EU get in free if you show their passport. Download your Rick Steves audio tour and you can feel very smug that you haven't paid for a tour or handset. The forum is fascinating - so interesting - especially the vestal virgins and where they lived and their lives. We went in October but it was very, very hot with no shade, so take it very slowly and sit down often, using the water fountains (also toilets in the forum).Definitely worth another visit.

An amazing place.. Been a couple of times and hugely impressed with the forum although the palatine hill less so. So much history and so complete. Walk where the emporers walked including Mr J Ceasar. (Named after a salad don't you know). Fresh flowers left on Ceasar's tomb to this day.Anyone that isn't inspired with the forum lacks imagination.

If you have time only for 1 thing, then this is it. This was my 2nd time visiting the Colosseum - but this time we prebooked a private tour that also included the basement and the 3rd floor visit - it is an absolute must - it was easily my favourite touristy thing to do in Rome - the guide was brilliant and she really made the place come alive. You ended up learning so much about how the Colosseum was constructed, about the materials used, you see the foundation, the walls etc - so much better than the general tour offered if you go there. Definitely pre book this.The forum also was fascinating - its a decent bit of walking - but definitely do not miss out - to see exactly how ancient Romans lived was really something. Also seeing where Ceaser was cremated, etc is pretty cool.Use www.tickitaly.com for prebooking your tours - they do a pretty good job of it.

Brilliant. For me, the Roman Forum was the highlight of our three night stay in Rome. While I enjoyed the Colosseum, I did find it a little underwhelming... but this wasn't so for the Forum which is quite simply stunning. It really is spine tingling, standing there in the Forum, imagining how it must have looked 2,000 years ago and how this was the nucleus of the arguably the most powerful and important empire the world has ever seen.I highly recommend downloading an audio guide and printing a map in advance (we used Rick Steve's audio guide which I can't recommend enough, Google it) otherwise it may prove difficult to work out exactly what all of the buildings were used for.

First time visitors to Rome ..... We got up early to visit the Colisseum but stumbled across the Forum and Palatine hill and was most impressed by the 12 Euros price for both attractions over a 2 day visit which was excellent value. The Forum is simply amazing and has so much to see, we read all the information boards and was able to spend over 5 hours in this area . The next day we was able to use the same pass and walk past all the crowds waiting to get in the Colisseum , so I really would recommend getting the 2 day ticket as it saves much time.

What you go to Rome for......... Our British/native tour guide Steve, ( http://www.toursbylocals.com/RomePrivateTours ) escorted us around all the sites and besides getting us onto the fast track for entrance to all the sites (avoiding the horrendous lines, even in September) gave us insightful anecdotes which really brought Rome, its emperors and history to life. Quite alot to take in all in one go and we were mentally and physically exhausted by the end of the day. But seeped in everything ancient Roman.

Time traveller.. Every time I am in Rome, I go to see the Roman forum. Why? Because it makes me feel that I live in another era, you can almost feel the smell of old Rome. This is like an outdoor museum that has everything, there are so much interesting "stuff" to see and to learn, I always discover something new even if I have been there time and time again. Try to get there as early in the morning, because at that time there are fewer tourists, and you can have a better experience.

Fascinating Ruins. My wife and I enjoyed our visit to the Roman Forum. We combined this with a tour of the Colosseum, and this was a good way to spend half a day in Rome. This is a good Monday option with most museums closed. The forum's grounds are vast, but the history and views are stunning. With some much to see and take in, it would be wise to visit this area more than once. Using the Roma Pass enabled us to bypass the ticket queues for the site. In summer, make sure that you have plenty of water with you.

Et Tu. Because we are both fascinated by Egypt and Rome, it was only natural for us to visit the forum on our recent trip. We had walked the forum a few years ago with a tour company called, Rome Walks, and had an outstanding experience. This time the experience was good in a slightly different way. First, a set of stairs has been built to the church that is built on part of the forum. Second, you could no longer walk out beneath the arch and instead go out through an elaborate gate mechanism to insure people pay to enter the ruins. Presume this is all part of efforts to stabilize these monuments and ruins. But instead of dwelling on what was a few years ago, the focus should be to what was during Rome's glory days - the Senate, where the great debates of the day occurred, the home of the Vestal Virgins, the place where Caesar was killed and where his funeral occurred. Also, you look up from the pit of the forum and realize how ancient Rome was buried under dirt and rubble and later incarnations of the city were sequentially built on top of the old city. The old ornate marble was stripped off and the underlying stone work, too heavy to move, was just buried. If you take it from the perspective of conserving resources and recycling what could be saved, we find that many ancient civilizations were doing what we are trying to encourage today - reuse, repurpose, renew....

Skip the Line: Ancient Rome and Colosseum Half Day Walking Tour. This was a wonderful experience. Our group was small and our guide, Stella was very knowledgeable. We booked the tour through Viator's website. We saw the Colosseum from top to bottom including places that were restricted to the general public. After that we went across the street to the ruins of the Forum and then we toured Palatine Hill. Stella knew her history and was able to answer all of our questions about these three amazing sites. When the tour ended around noon, Stella told us about some of the churches that were within walking distance and good places to grab a quick bite to eat. It was easy to get to the Colosseum via the metro and the tour started at 8:30 am. There aren't many bathrooms in the area except in the restaurants. Each of us were given a receiver and an earpiece so that hearing Stella was very easy.

An open air museum - get photos before it opens. The best way to see the Forum is to get up at sunrise and see it from the rear of the Vittorio Emmanuel II Monument where you can get numerous vantage points and get some great photos of the Forum without another soul in your photos. Then when you visit, you no longer feel the need to photograph away, and can just enjoy the visit instead. But just because you see it from the outside, still ensure you visit. It's a wonderful visit and very roomy and can be taken at your own pace. Another of Roma's must see attractions. An amazing open air museum.

History revealed. Many people have reviewed this, but I wanted to say that we really enjoyed viewing the Forum on the first day we spent in Rome. Coupled with an excellent guide, you can have a great time exploring these amazing ruins and putting together ancient life in your mind. We started out our day with San Clemente Church and the sites below it, then saw the Colosseum, and finished in the Forum. I must say that with my imagination and our helpful and very informative guide, I was picturing Rome in its glory days during the entire walk through the Forum. The highlights for me are the huge Basilica, the house of the vestal virgins, and the Senate building. I was amazed and awed by Rome's past glory in every sense. This was also a good attraction to pair with the Rome from the Sky elevator which is near the Forum exit.

Almost too much to see and absorb. Just browsing my ratings and saw that on the basis of my last visit I rated The Forum as Very Good and not Excellent. I cannot think what I was thinking - perhaps this difference this time was wandering around with a 13 year old rather than a tired five year old (what a difference eight years makes). This is one of the must-see sites in the world - all that history in such a relatively small area.

Much better experience than the Colesseum. If you have already visited Coleseum then you'll just have to visit the Roman Forum as well. First of all, you already have the ticket, it is the same as for the Coleseum. Then the lines are much shorter AND it feels a lot less crowded than the Colesseum. And there is really a lot more history as well. No wonder though, after all we are talking about various sites and buildings with different functions.I went with kids who are too young to care and so I didn't use a guide book. But there seems to be a number of apps out there that help you understand the ruins better. However, even without that information, it is still worth the visit.

Rome's multi-layered history revealed. If, like me, you have an interest in the Roman Empire and the evolution of Rome itself, this is a must see destination. Some homework beforehand and/or a guidebook would be a good idea, as these archaeological remains are not easy to understand in the absence of interpretive information. However, if you visit armed with a bit of knowledge to help with your interpretation of the many confusingly juxtaposed and seemingly inscrutable piles of marble, bricks and statuary, you will be rewarded with a satisfying glimpse into history, at the end of which you will probably want to either stay longer, or come back and see more. It is advisable to set aside a fair chunk of time to take it all in, but if you've had the foresight to have purchased a combined ticket, you can always spread the visit over a couple of days- I was able to re-enter the next day and continue my exploration of this fascinating area.

Best Historical Place. Doubt that we could add anything momentous to what is already said. The sheer extent is phenomenal; the oeuvre has great emotional impact. Even as non-Catholics, we are very aware of how much this has impacted Christian faith and Western culture.This was an detail high up on my bucket list and it was worth every notion of hype in my mind. We did not take a tour, but simply took our time admiring the space. With a circumstantial in architecture history, I was the main one in our group excited to see this miraculous place. There are too many miraculous details to name; it is simply something everyone must see for themselves. It is the most beautiful church I will probably ever step foot in. Please do yourself a favor and carve out a couple of hours in your day in Rome to see this awe-inspiring site.

Obligated must-see after Colosseum. We visited the Roman Forum after the Colosseum. We listened to Rick Steve's guide on the iphone app, which I believe is a short version of his full guide. It still took about an hour to go through the entire tour. When we were there (July 2013), the Roman Forum was under maintenance construction, several areas were closed and/or sealed off for that purpose, which made navigating the Forum more difficult. Outside of the Roman Forums, there were many street (con)artists and pickpockets, be sure to watch out for your belongings and don't fall for their tricks!

Compliments the Colosseum visit. Had free entry to these two as part of our Roma Pass otherwise we wouldn't have gone to see them. The Palatine Hill is covered in excavation work and is a huge area to cover by foot. Likewise the Roman Forum is constantly being discovered and for both of these unless you have a good guide book with you telling you exactly what you are looking at you will have no idea whatsoever of what is what! Yes I can see how it is interesting but it's such a vast area and it is all ruins so don't expect too much and I wouldn't really bother in the rain.

A beautiful place, but beware of pickpockets, we got robbed (twice in Italy).. We visited Roman Forum in the end of September. We bought combination ticket (cost 12 Euros) in Forum for all: the Roman Forum, Palatine Hill and for the Coliseum. Line was only ~15-20 min. We saved a lot of time compare to the lines in the Coliseum.It is beautiful place and full of history, we used Rick Steve’s book as a guide. We spent a lot of time in both Forum and Palatine Hill and honestly could spend even more, but we left because we also wanted spend some time in the Coliseum as well and we were not sure how much time we would need. You need more time for Forum & Palatine Hill than for the ColiseumRoman Forum is pretty crowded. It was also hot because it's all open space. There are a few places with water fountains, where you can drink or refill your bottle. There are no places to eat inside the Forum and not so many bathrooms. It’s huge; you need to be on foot for long time.We liked the place, but one person in our party was robbed on Caesar’s Tomb. Pickpocketing - wallet disappeared from pocket of our friend pants in blink of an eye. Some man asked to take a picture of him on Caesar’s Tomb and after this our friend's wallet was gone. He didn’t feel a thing. Beware! We read about pickpockets and thieves before the trip and tried to be careful, but it happened anyway. After this case we were afraid to carry all our money and documents with us. A couple days later we left Rome and went to Tuscany for a week. On our 2nd day in Tuscany our villa got robbed... We lost much of our money, credit cards, jewelry, documents including passport, driver's licenses, etc. Instead of enjoying Tuscany we were spending time in police and US Embassy. It really helped that we had copies of our passports, because we didn’t have any other documents left with our name on it. It took 3 weeks to restore all our documents after coming home. We will remember this trip for a long time. We travel extensively and it never happened to us before. Just be careful.

The epitome of history. You can not mistake the historic significance of the attraction and area...a tour will give you the best chance of appreciating all the nuances and prevent you from missing anything...

Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. Like all of Rome, the whole place is interesting but in terrible condition, you would think the government would invest in making the places of interest more user friendly!! On this point do not buy the audio guide from the entrance, wait for a guide (hourly) well worth the extra money, unfortunately we made the mistak of taking the audio guide which was a waste of time and very frustrating. The Forum and Palantine hill is totally useless for any persons with disabilities. Awful toilet facilities but that seems to apply to the whole of Rome, from restaurants to tourist attractions.

Walks of Italy -Best Tours of Rome. Walks of Italy provided us with the very best tour of the Colosseum,Forum and Palatine Hill.The tour guide was engaging and had excellent knowledge of the history of the whole site.From the moment the tour was booked walks of Italy looked after us - lots of information about where we had to meet and the agenda for the tour along with advice on what to ware at the venues.The ticket for the Forum which we visted firat also gives you access to the Colosseum so you avoid the very long line of people trying to purchase a ticket to that venue - we just walked in.So if you ever visit purchase your ticket at the Forum.The whole experience was outstanding - the real highlight was an evening tour of the Colosseum with Walks of Italy - you have to do this to experience this tour if you go to Rome its was just magic beyond words or description.
History!. Close to the Colosseum, it is a must see. Part of history, built around 2000 years ago. Do bring your walking shoes.

Impressive , but take your own guide material or hire a guide. This is lived up to an exceeded all expectations. Although always busy with tourists, you really can get a glimpse into the past. We bought the Forum Videoguide, and rated it 6/10. It was fine to start with but there was no signage to follow on the way and due to building works 3/4s of the way through we abandoned it. We had no other information , so it was better than nothing but I woudl have purchased a basic book in the Colesseum book shop had I known. Once you have finished there...walk up to Osteria dell Antiqario for a pizza, it is a little off the main drag and excellent value.

So much history. We visited here right after the Colosseum, it is part of the package with the tickets which we got ahead online, and that helps us skip the queue and go straight in to the Palatine. After that we visited the Roman Forum. It was a lot of walking to cover both, but there were drinking water fountains around, and it was really worth the 3 hours we spent there! We went on our own at the Colosseum, and the same with this, relying on our smartphone for the information.So much history starting in Palatine Hill, from the legend of Romulus and Remus, to Caesar Augustus and emperors after him, it felt surreal knowing they were right here! There are the ruins of the palace, its stadium, a Palatino museum and also remains of the residences of Augustus and Livia.The ruins of the Forum were amazing, especially the well-preserved monuments still standing. Was in awe of what it would have been like in its glorious history. Much more crowded here than the Palatine. The only downside is it would be very helpful to have signs with more description of each of the ruin for paying visitors.
History!!!. very close to Colosseum, doesn't take too long to walk there! but during a hot summer day, it just felt like an endless walk. if you visit Colosseum, i think you should also go to forums.

Incredible, amazing, fascinating and everything else!. We bought our ticket from the Forum/Palatine Hill and of course thought we would visit. It is truly a spectacular site completely full of history and to have buildings so well preserved from such a well known period is spectacular. There are restoration works taking place but they do not distract the visitor from this site. It is handy to either know something about the layout or to have a mini guide or booklet as whilst there are signs and display boards to help the visitor a little knowledge will help you appreciate the site a lot more.The site is mainly built on a hill with uneven pathways but there are plenty of places to rest and of course there is the Roman natural drinking water fountain available on this site. It really is an amazing place to visit and truly captivated my family

Get there early!. The forum and Palatine is both fascinating and frustrating lots of unique structures particularly the two triumphal arches and on the Palatine some of the remains are really impressive but the place does seem to resemble a bit of a Roman junk yard with limited interpretation confusing path ways and some clearly very important monuments having no details or explanation. I suspect those on a guided tour had a much better time but on this occasion I was not able to do that so as a solo visitor it was not so good. Having said that the frequent water fountains are a real boon. Finally it gets hideously busy as the day goes on so get there early

Amazing place!. This was a part of our Rome trip and the family enjoyed listening to the tour guide explain all of the history you are surrounded by!It is simply beautiful when every direction you turn has a building steeped in history dating thousands of years!Quite rocky so good shoes needed!Beautiful buildings in a beautiful city!

Outstanding tour. My wife and I recently were in Rome and had booked the semi-private tour "Nero's Rome: Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill" tour with Through Eternity Tours. Our guide was Mr. Guido Airoldi, who was an outstanding tour guide. Guido's English was perfect and his delivery style was very engaging. He was thoroughly knowledgeable about all aspects of ancient rome and its people. Touring the Colosseum, including the underground chambers and third seating tier, was on my bucket list and Mr. Airoldi made this tour even more special for me. I highly recommend this particular tour and I certainly recommend Mr. Guido Airoldi as an excellent tour guide. You will not be disappointed with this tour.

Best money we spent !!. |Met our hostess right where the photos instructed us to meet, David was our guide, he is very passionate about sharing his knowledge of the city he was born in, and calls home, excellent English, and a pace that was easily handled !! Cannot speak highly enough of the tour!!

A must if you're into Roman architecture. This was an amazing visit, and one that I'll always remember. It was worth it to be able to walk up close to the ruins and capture all the details with photographs. We did have a quide, but I actually learned more from a picture book that I had purchased called "Rome Reconstructed". It came in very handy when trying to figure out the structures that the ruins came from. It's basically a book that shows you the before (what it looked like in Roman times) and after pictures so you can visualize how it all comes together. Just don't buy it in Rome. It's much more expensive than getting it online through Amazon. Whether you have a guide or not, it's well worth a visit even with the difficulties of trying to put all the pieces together.The most interesting structure to me was the Temple of Antoninus and Faustina. It was converted into a Roman Catholic church in the 7th century and went through many reconstructions since that time. The church is now called San Lorenzo in Miranda. It is more known for being the "church in a temple". It's interesting because it was converted around the same time as the Pantheon.
Great 3hour tour in small group. Booked with official tourist office, max 12 persons group. (35/15 euro) very good!! Good value for money.

Worth the trip. We were lucky enough to have a primate tour. Luca was great. Not sure I could have appreciated everything without the background he provided. My high school history class did not do this era justice. Hard to believe so much property is still yet to be uncovered. Also hard to believe I walked the same paths Ceaser and others did!

With Eternity Tours we were able to explore the past as though we were there. The conducted tour covers so much more than a guide book. You can feel the excitement of the ancient civilisations and the passion that accompanied the various developments of the empire.
Not to be missed

History comes to life. A not to be missed experience, pay the extra for a guided tour, its well worth it as you get access to parts of the colosseum that the basic entry ticket does not include, also the Forum is quite difficult to picture what it was like in roman times and having a guide helps you make sense of it, oh, and wear "comfortable" footwear!
VIP tour. Well worth the money for the view from the Colosseum floor, and the knowledge of the guides about the sites.

Roman Forum Night Tour -- amazing by night. For a short time this year, the official Colosseum/Roman Forum ticket operator, http://www.coopculture.it , was offering night tours of the Roman Forum -- la luna sul foro romano (August 9 - October 25, 2013). We had an English language tour at 8:30 p.m. (meet at the Roman Forum ticket counter side entrance, off of Via dei Fori Imperiali). We had an excellent guide, Michele, who was extremely knowledgeable and entertaining to both the adults as well as the children on the small tour (less than 20 people). We toured the Basilica Amelia, the Curia (we were able to go inside), see the Arch of Septimius Severus and Temple of Saturn, the Temples of Castor and Pollux and Vestal, the Temple of the Divine Caesar, the Temple of Antoninus and Faustina, the Basilica of Maxentius, the Arch of Titus, and the Temples of Rome and Venus. The tour took about 1 1/2 hours and moved at a very good pace (although I would have loved more time in the Curia). Michele provided the right amount of information, easily providing more detail when one of the group had a particular interest. Touring the Roman Forum in the quiet of night was wonderful, and seeing the temples lit up was magical. If they are offering this tour -- book it (particularly if you have already seen the Roman Forum during the day). One caveat: the Via Sacra and paths are difficult enough during the day, much less at night. Wear sensible shoes and bring a small flashlight (we used the flashlight app on our iPhone) can really help.

Interesting, but definitely use a tour guide. The tour that we were on (an excellent Dark Rome tour) started at the Colosseum before we made our way to Forum. We were so thankful to be on a tour because once you have entered the Forum, it is quite confusing. There are ruins everywhere and very little information on what it is you are looking at. Our tour guide pointed out all the main things so we didn't have to worry, but I saw many confused looking people as we walked around, and even a few that tried to listen in to our tour guide! The whole area is quite large, especially taking into account everything up Palatine Hill, and we found it very interesting to hear what all the sections were in Roman times. There isn't any single building or ruin that compares to the wondrous Colosseum, but there is still plenty to see. Make sure you go with a tour though!

Find The Entrance. During our third visit to the Forum, we found it very difficult to find the entrance? There are many places to view the Forum, but you will need to walk along the left side half way down to find the entrance. Please make sure you purchase the Roman pass. It let's you bypass the lines at the forum, colussium, etc. it probably saved us 2-3 hours in line. Have patients and enjoy all that history.

only did roman forum. still not sure why our private guide skipped the palatine hill but my sister made all the arrangements. none the less, the roman forum was something to see. our guide was very informative. we went there on our first full day in rome and it was our first tour and it was very impressive. i found the stories about the vestal virgins most fascinating. you could spend hours at every site but most people don't have the time.i wish i would have brushed up on my roman history before arrivinga word to folks trying to go on the cheap, you paid to get to rome, spend the extra money to get a guide. why waste your time wondering when you could have someone explaining everything to youour guide (fransesca or frederika) was absolutely delightful

I Stayed All Day.. The Forum and The Palatine Hill are the a wonderful place to visit.
