We spent the whole of our first day in Rome here and I would have been quite happy to return on the subsequent 7 days.This is the centre of the Roman Empire! The description of the buildings are well done, but I would recommend a good guidebook if your interest in the Romans makes you really want to understand what you will see. The place where Julius Caesar was assassinated is there to see if you know where to look! Also I had purchased a 'then and now' type book which has overlays of the buildings to show how they originally looked. The site is very large and I did notice many guided tours missing out large areas of the available site.It was quite busy in the morning, although it's sheer size means that you are very often alone. In the heat of the afternoon, it was near deserted. Several archeological excavations are taking place and these are easy to view.I recommend a do it yourself exploration of this site, if you have a deep interest in the period. I almost walked my poor husband off his feet!

Lot's of history!. The forum is located across the street from the Colosseum and contains a lot of history pertaining to the romans and their way of life back in the day. Get the audio guide - it contains a lot more information than the signs at each site and makes the tour more meaningful.

Amazing. This one of my top favorite sites to visit. I had been about 10 years ago, but it was like brand new again to me. We hired a tour company to take us around here and then the Colosseum. The history that is in this area is amazing. You can just imagine how it was so long ago. The tour guides show you around and explain all of the important history. You even get to see where Ceasar was cremated. Go see this!

Definitely GO!!. We actually visited here after the Colosseum tour. We had a combo ticket and got in quite easily with our fantastic guide. Wish I could remember the cost, but for the Colosseum and Forum it was a great deal. We walked and he talked! How wonderful to have such a knowledgeable person direct us. The ruins were incredible, and we learned a great deal. It was as if history came alive for us here. It is a lot of walking on rough ground, so wear comfy shoes to really enjoy everything. Explore a bit on your own as well. Just fantastic!

Definitely worthwhile. I have been here with a guide and also using a headphone system. I enjoyed both, but the guide was better.....and free.If you love history and are not impatient to just see "the best bits" then this is a great place. The little known facts are great to learn, you see lots of different buildings and really get a sense of how Rome was.I loved thinking about who had walked there before me, who had touched this particular building and who had stood there etc. I know of several people who have bee to the Coloseum and missed the forum, and thats a tragedy. The Coloseum is great, but for me, if i could only see one thing, i would go to the forum instead

Breath taking. The Roman Forum was breath taking. It's hard to believe how old the ruins actually are. We spent a day here alongside the Colosseum and it was one of the main highlights of our trip. It also helped that the weather was perfect as you wouldn't want to walk around the forum on a wet day. Make sure you allow yourself plenty of time here as this is not one to be rushed.

Roman Forum. Well I already talked about the Colosseum. I actually thought I was not interested in Ancient Rome as I had already seen so many Roman artifacts but the Forum was truly awing, huge and worth the admission price (they only accept cash no credit cards) We loved it.

Combined ticket for The Colusseum and Roman Forum. How can one not be totally in awe of the old Roman ruins. The fantastic history of this place is amazing.One little word of advice when buying a combined ticket, if you can prove that you have an EU passport, or produce a driving licence, or some form of identification etc, then you get in for FREE. How good is that. The ticket lasts for two days.Recently when we were in Rome, we again visited the Forum which is fantastic and then went on to revisit the Colosseum. Unfortunately for us, (this was our last day in Rome before flying home) we arrived at the Colosseum to use our ticket, along with many many other people, at 5.30pm (on the board advising times of opening and closing times it said the Colosseum closed at 6.30pm). Fortunately I can speak reasonable Italian and when I spoke to the attendant he rudely told me that it was now closed, when I challenged him on the closing time he told me he was going home!There was a very large group of very disappointed people standing there. They spoke English so I informed them what was said to me. The point of this review is to let you know that firstly if you are a member of the EU then you can get in for free and secondly, don't leave it too late to visit the Colosseum or else you will be very disappointed when you can't get in. Don't trust the closing times on the board.

Step back in time. The Roman Forum is close to the Colosseum so if you are going to make it to the Colosseum, you should take the time to tour the Roman Forum. The architecture of here is amazing and it is interesting to see how well preserved the ruins are. There was an abundance of annoying beggars in the area during our visit.

A FUNNY THING HAPPENED TRYING TO EXIT FROM THE FORUM. Of course you have to see the forum when you're in Rome. But it's no easy task. It's hot and dusty and disorganized. Guidebooks seem not to be keyed at all to the layout, entrances or numbering at the site. GETTING IN IS DIFFICULT / GETTING OUT IS IMPOSSIBLE.Entrances are few and ambiguously marked. You can go all the way where you saw an arrow, but reach a dead end, then have to backtrack and find the real entrance. Getting out is worse. It took an hour to find an exit! Signs point in a direction, but it's not the exit. We were getting quite desperate to find a way out. Guide is very much recommended, if just to get in and out safely.

Walking through ancient Rome!. Once the heartbeat of ancient Rome. The common ground in the center of Rome’s 7 Hills. The civic center. The Roman Forum. We had a walking tour audio guide thanks to Rick Steves and it was wonderful. Beginning at the Arch of Titus, it walked us down the via Sacra and into the heart of ancient Rome. Amazing. It was so cool to walk through it all and hear it described in its original glory. A must-see! Also, you can buy a combination ticket here for both the Roman Forum AND for the Colosseum here so you don't have to stand in line once you get to the Colosseum (definitely worth it)!

Ancient Rome at its best. Situated near the colosseum, you find yourself in the midst of some of the most fascinating ruins in Rome. As a personal preference I loved the roman forum with all the temples, arches and houses. And being an active archeological site is even more amazing. I could be here for hours.If ancient architecture and culture is a favorite of yours, these ruins are a must see. And why not get a Roma pass, skip the queue and combine it with a trip to the collesuem.

Lots and lots of walking. I really enjoyed this, just note that there is a lot to see and you could easily spend three hours inside. The Forum gives you a glimpse into the Roman civilisation and we combined this with a trip to the Colosseum. We used the Roma Pass to get in, there is a dedicated line if you have the pass so you can get in without waiting in line to buy a ticket. One critisism there are very few toilets, poorly maintained and signposted. When doing this in summer make sure you have bottle of water with you and maybe something to eat, I didnt see any place selling anthing to eat or drink.

Amazing. Seeing the Roman Forum was one of our highlights. It is included in the price of the Coliseum ticket. Great price for the 2 attractions. I could imagine myself walking around in the old Roman times in a toga! Get some great photos from up the hill over the Forum as well. Don't miss it. Book your tickets online first. The queues can be big.

Hard to find. Here's when a guide would have been handy. After leaving the Colosseum, we looked for the nearby Forum. A LARGE colorful sign pointed up a hill so we followed throngs of tourists up the hill. No Forum. We could see some people off to the right walking through what we thought was the Forum, but fences kept us from getting there. So then we walked back down and another sign pointed up a different path of same hill. Also no Forum. Exhausted, we tried one more spot and fortunately found our way into the ruins. We used Rick Steves's free audio tour and found it adequate. I'm sure we'd have enjoyed the ruins more if the misleading signs hadn't sent us up the wrong hills twice.

a funny thing happened on the way to the Forum.... We were there when they were building a subway nearby. We asked 8 different people over 2 days where the entrance to the Forum was (we had a ticket and had been to the Colesseum) and each person gave us a different answer. We saw the Forum from every angle from above but never actually got in! We tried following the line of people that we saw inside but couldn't find a beginning or end. Good luck, hope you get in!

A MUST SEE.. We booked the Roman Forum on line which was very easy to do and saves you standing in long lines of people as it can get very busy, its quite a walk up to the Forum from the entrance, but its well worth the effort, what a site for sore eyes it is, walking along the cobbled streets almost makes you think you have gone back in time and you can feel the atmosphere, the monuments are astounding, there is a lot to see so allow yourself a good few hours to be able to take it all in. A great day out.

Essential!. The Colosseum is the poster child for ancient Rome, and a must-see attraction (especially the Underground Tour), but there is way more history and context in the Roman Forum (or Fora Romano). I spent several hours wandering and studying these ruins, aided enormously by the much-improved signage throughout the area. I was not able to locate an English-language guide, but had planned ahead for that and brought Rick Steves' small, paperback "Rome" book, which has an EXCELLENT self-guided tour of the place. You can also download his free audio tour on iTunes. I combined this material with some pre-trip reading about the site and was able to get an awful lot out of it just walking on my own. I also cheated now and then and caught a few words from some of the tour guides leading groups through the area, but I also heard some of them giving out some incorrect info. Nonetheless, if you're totally new to the Forum, you should consider a guide.One thing to bear in mind is that this area evolved and changed many times over the centuries, so you are not looking at a place that once stood, intact, at a specific moment in time. Think of how much Washington, D.C., or other major capitals have changed over the centuries and you will understand that these ruins are from buildings that existed hundreds of years apart. An example is the difference in age between the Arch of Titus and the larger Arch of Constantine, which were build hundreds of years apart and represented quite different events. Similarly, the Temple of Julius Caesar should be juxtaposed with the much younger (and vastly larger) Basilica of Maxentius and Constantine, which is nearby. The Temple of Caesar, where the assassinated dictator was cremated, is yet another site that lends context.I was disappointed that part of the west end of the Forum was blocked off due to construction and that the Curia building was closed. This is one of the few buildings that remains somewhat intact and once housed the Roman Senate. I was thankful that a worker allowed me to cross the line just long enough to take some pictures of the building, but would like to have seen the inside.If you are not at all interested in history, or perhaps bored by it, this may not be for you. However, if you have purchased a ticket to enter the Colosseum, Forum, and Palatine, you should at least stroll around the place and get a feel for all the history that unfolded here and all of the great historical figures who actually walked here.I did not visit the Palatine this time, but did tour it in 2009. It is interesting, but I found very little in the way of recognizable ruins compared to the Forum. Nonetheless, the same rule applies; if you bought the ticket and you have the time, give it a view.Be sure to remember that your admission ticket only gives you ONE admission to each of these sites. Once you leave, you cannot reenter without buying another ticket, so make the most of your time there.

Nice walk in the Fori Romani. It's a very nice walk within the Fori Romani, visiting some of the oldest sites where the Ancient Romans used to live. These spaces compose the site of the old city, the administration and entertainment centers, the athletics (sports) centers, the market and all the other necessary components of a big city, such as Rome at the times of the Roman Empire.You would need about 3 hours for a full visit, and in case of sunny days an umbrella and bottles of water would be more than necessary. There are beautiful gardens in the Fori space and some very interesting buildings (as far as architecture is concerned).

The heart of Ancient Rome. We visited this site over a four-hour period and were not disappointed. The Roman Forum is the heart of what ancient Rome was and is well worth the time. While the monuments are not what they were, it is still magnificent, especially when you understand what the area stood for. A must-see when in Rome.

It makes Latin class and ancient history come alive. The first time I saw the Forum it was like experiencing the Roman history I had studied in high school and high school Latin. The extent of what has been excavated is quite astounding; this is worth at least two hours if not a whole afternoon.

Cannot visit Rome without visiting The Roman Forum. The history of Rome and the Roman Empire! This is a must. It's worth going through with an audio guide (download one from the net for free) or get a tour guide (a lot more expensive and sometimes not all that much better).The size and scale of Roman architecture is immense and must be seen to be believed.Lots of famous Roman buildings to see.The lines are shorter than the Colosseum (when we were there on a Sunday in October). No toilets or food inside - so go to the bathroom first and bring snacks and drinks or get ripped off by the tourist stands outside.

Very nice piece of history not with stroller. site is under further digging so if you are going with baby and you have a stroller the roman forum is not for you at this time wait for your kid to be able to walk on an uneven ground... we tryed and had to go back after half a mile...

The Forum is a must see. We only had a few hours in Rome, and as we were on our way to the Colosseum, we stopped at the Forum. We didn't think we had the time, but made time, and was glad as it was amazing. The main square was amazing and you could take yourself back in time, when Rome was born here.
Roman Forum. Very interesting and well kept, is't amazing to be standing in the exact spot some of Romes great Emperors.

Nice Walk, Especially for Free. We had walked by the Roman Forum ruins on the way to the Coliseum and thought it looked cool but since you can observe from above for free we weren't going to pay to go down...but as it turns out, when you purchase a ticket to the Coliseum you can get into one of a few other attractions for free, useing the same ticket! So we chose the Roman Forum and we were happy we did. From below you can get much closer, it's more intimate and you get a better view. It's a nice little walk.

walk where Caesar walked, but bring a podcast. Just like the Colosseum, you will be surrounded by amazing structures nearly two thousand years old, but you won't have a clue what you are looking at because there are no signs. Download the free Rick Steves podcast.

Interesting peak into history. Though it was less spectacular and smaller than I imagined, The Roman Forum is definitely worth seeing and walking around. If you want to get the most historical perspective out of it strongly consider getting a tour guide or bring a book that shows what the buildings looked like in the past. Otherwise your imagination will have a hard time reconstructing the piles of rocks. Takes an hour or two to walk around the whole forum and see all the ruins, but you could easily spend half a day there if you wanted to study everything. Bring bottles of water (which you can refill with fountain water on the forum trail), and plenty of sunscreen because there is little shade. We had heard and found it to be true that the Forum ticket line is the best place to buy Colosseum tickets. We got there around 1 pm and there was zero line to get in. Our ticket was good for the colosseum which we went to immediately afterwards. There was a huge line to buy entry tix there so definitely head to the forum!

Stunning. I first sighted the Roman Forum from a distance. It turned out to be a good 30 minute walk to get there. I walked down the main shopping street and round several corners and down some steep steps. I was thinking maybe it was too far to walk to see the monument and then I reached the bottom of the steps and turned the corner. I was stunned by what I saw. This monument is well worth a visit when in Rome.

Impressive. We prebooked this tour as part of a package. The tour guide was an archeological student and really knew her stuff. She brought to life the Forum which is of course a ruin. I especially enjoyed the description of Diocletian palace on Palatine Hill. It's only ruins now but it must have been huge and impressive.

Need a lot of imagination. As our guide said up front, when you visit the Forum you need a lot of imagination. Almost totally destroyed by successive Christian dynasties that cannibalised everything to rebuild churches.

History at its best. An incredible experience. We started at the Colosseum and then headed to the Forum. It was astounding. You never really know what to expect, but the Forum blew my mind. It was huge. Being surrounded by so much history was awe-inspiring. For people who dont know very much (except the basics) of Ancient Rome, it is worth getting a guided tour so that you can understand and appreciate the history of the area and know what you are looking at. It is so vast that if you dont have a wide knowledge of the era, a lot of it will be lost on you, and that is just a shame. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes as the roads are uneven and cobbled. There are water fountains dotted around to refill water bottles, a lot of water will be needed on a warm day, its a long walk. It is also worth paying a visit at night to see it all lit up. The atmosphere is totally different when there are no people wandering around the ancient ruins. I would suggested doing the Colosseum and the Forum in the same day as they right net to each other, but they will take most of the day to see properly. I fyou have the Roma Pass this site is free entrance. I cannot stress enough how much the Roma Pass will save you, time and money!

Great History. We took a tour of the Roman Forum, and I would highly suggest you take a tour too. Our tour was with Maya Tours and it was great - we toured the Roman Forum and the Colosseum. Without a tour, you won't know what you are looking at, it will just look like a bunch of ruins. If you do have a tour though, the Forum comes to life and you can see what it would have been like all those years ago. The tour is also nice because you can skip all of the lines. Caesar is supposedly buried here, and you can see his "grave." The ruins are truly amazing and eye opening as to how life would have been thousands of years ago. We went in August, so it was very hot, I'd suggest bringing water with you.
Rome history. The area of the roman forum is very big, needs few hours to explore evrrything and know the history behind it. The roads are made of stones, so wearing a comfortable shoes is a must!

Amazing Roman Ruins. You can do the Roman Forum and Colosseum in the same day, but it will take all day. The Roman Forum/Palatine Hill is very spread out and there is lots to see and lots of walking. Bring plenty of water and good walking shoes!

Strange place. Italy could not be accused of Disneyfying The Forum. If anything it seems quite neglected, which is pretty nice. Visitors wander aimlessly on flat paths through uneven mounds of ancient rubble. Caesar's "grave" is covered by what looks like a rusty shelter on an old golf course. Some bits of the Forum that appear original were actually partially reconstructed at some point. Trying to exit at the Collosseum, which is signed, brought us to a dead end and a long D-Tour back and around by a side entrance across part of the Palatine Hill. Mobs of tourists in this part of the city of course, and various traders trying hard to relieve you of some money. But do not miss it on a trip to Rome. here, as elsewhere, often best and cheapest to buy tickets at the entrance. We were in line for just a couple of minutes on a hot September day.

The Forum. The Forum displays an exciting insight to the ancient days of Rome and how the city functioned. I would suggest having a guided tour but, be aware, some guides are better than others with the understanding and delivery of the English language.

Amazing. Really enjoyed visiting the Roman Forum. We went here before the Colosseum and got a joint ticket as the queue here was shorter. It was great to just walk around and soak in the atmosphere and see such great ruins. I would definitely recommend going here especially if going to the Colosseum as going to both together really adds to the experience.

Incredible to see but beware of large group tours!. We enjoyed seeing this of course, and only wished we had done our research beforehand, as we would have gotten much more out of it. We went in April and it was busy - can't imagine summertime! There were 3 of us and we chose to do a group tour - meet at a meeting point and proceed with a guide from there (with 3 fares it wasn't cheap). I think this was a mistake. The tour guide was very pleasant but because of her limited English she was unable to tell us much and the tour was uninteresting. We spent much of the time moving our cumbersome group about (40 of us?), oftentimes the headphones didn't work. After doing a private tour in Pompeii (you just negotiate with qualified tour guide and they take you around) we realize we should have done the same here! Forum and grounds are well worth seeing though.

Poor signage to the forum.. More crowded than our last visit in 2006. Signage to the forum entrance was confusing. There is construction. If you follow signs to the forum entrance you end up in a church. If you try the forum exit that doesn't work either. We had to go down via San Gregorio to the palatine entrance. Basically old ruins. There is a modern art exhibit of stark white figures that doesn't seem to us to add to the experience. Lots of hills and stairs - just in case you have difficulty with that. Constantine's arch is half covered in scaffolding.

How to avoid the lines. I won't tell you that the Forum is amazing, because you already know. I was there about 6 days ago and I was able to skip the lines by going at 4:30pm - cooler, no lines, 12E to get in at the gates, and not huge crowds inside. The entrance fee includes the Colosseum, can be bought at any of the three site entrances (Forum, Palatine, Colosseum), and includes entry for 2 days. Buy at the Forum entrance for smallest lines, and then walk right into the Colosseum. They let you into the sites until 6pm at this time of the year, and clear everyone out by 7pm. So if you wanted to do both, begin with one site (Forum and Palatine are together - if you enter at the Forum, you are walking towards the Colosseum), and then make sure you are into the second site (Colosseum) before the 6pm cut off...and you will still have an hour to explore. Going later also makes for better photos with softer light, less people, and the bonus of finishing the Colosseum just as its getting close to sunset. Grab a gelato nearby and stick around to view the Colosseum at night! Take a water bottle (which you can refill at a cold fountain inside the site) and a sun hat/ umbrella as there is limited shade.

History Made Even Better By Rick Steves. The one and only downfall of the forum as a tourist attraction is the lack of signage and information. You'll see something that looks pretty cool, but have no idea what it actually is (or once was). Enter Rick Steves! Downloading his audio tour was the perfect way to enhance our visit to the forum.It will probably be pretty crowded, especially if the weather is nice, and good walking shoes are a must because there is a lot of ground to cover and many spots with uneven terrain. Don't let that scare you though- this was the heart and soul of the ancient Roman empire and it really is amazing to walk where they walked. The house of the Vestal Virgins, the site of Julius Ceasar's cremation, and so many other interesting spots to see.I strongly recommend the Rick Steves tour. It is easy to follow and his commentary is interesting and informative, and it really adds something to the experience.

A walk through History!. There are a ton of amazing sites all over the world that are simply incredible, but the Roman Forum remains are just out of this world! I'm am absolutely shocked that this is not ranked higher on Trip Advisor as there is so much history there. The ruins are located directly next to the Colosseum and if you purchase an entrance ticket to the Colosseum, you get free access to the ruins for two consecutive days. The view from the top of the hill looking down at what used to be Julius Palace is just amazing. A must see if in Rome!!!

Roman forum good site to visit. worth a trip around the roman forum to get a feel for the size of the site. Good views from the Palatine Hill for photos. We visited on a very hot day so did not stay as long as we wanted to. Definitely worth a visit.

Roman forum suggeted itinerary. We took the roman forum iterary from this guide .we found that there is a mistake , the entrance to the forum is only from via dei fori imperiali and not as in the iterary rout map.

Breathtaking!. A visit to the Forum is a must when in Rome. If you're interested in visiting the Coliseum as well, the lines at the Forum are usually a bit shorter so a tip would be to start here and you'll sail through the lines once you get to the Coliseum (since one ticket gets you entry to both places). There is very little shade as you tour around so if you're sensitive to heat, etc. you might want to think about going first thing in the morning or later in the day when it starts to cool off. There are lots of fountains around where you can fill up your water bottles so be sure to grab a big one from a nearby supermarket first (about .55 euro) and keep yourself hydrated. There were lots of tours milling around but my husband and I downloaded Rick Steves' free audioguides and found them to be wonderful. Enjoy!

Integral to a visit of ancient Rome. The Roman Forum is located next to the Colosseum and can be visited on the same day for a single price. Best time to visit is early in the morning (we came at 9 AM in August). We chose to have a private tour guide through Rome Illuminated, which greatly enhanced our visit. Other visitors have recommended downloading an audio guide by Rick Steves through his website. Because the buildings are very incomplete, a guide is integral to your entertainment and education; otherwise the are just picturesque fields of broken stone. The Forum represents the heart of ancient Rome, where criminal trials, great speeches, worship, financial transactions, shopping and negotiations took place. It was Washington, D.C., New York, Las Vegas, Tokyo, and the Vatican rolled into one. A place to see and be seen. A mixture of the holy, the wealthy, the beautiful, the poor, and the every day. Triumphant legions marched down the paved Via Sacra, on the same stones you find there today. Slaves built the temples. Massive stone arches celebrated military victories, including the arch of Severus Septimius celebrating his victory over Jerusalem (note the soldiers bearing away the menorah). Fresh water was delivered via tiered aqueducts which could deliver water to all levels on the Palatine hills. Waste and rain were carried away by a sophisticated underground sewage system (which can still be seen through the stones). Vaulted arches, architectural and mathematical wonders, supported incredibly large palaces and temples. This book will enliven your imagination of what it used to look like: http://www.amazon.com/Ancient-Rome-Monuments-Past-Present/dp/8881620308/ref=pd_sim_sbs_b_1There are water fountains to refill your bottles outside the Colosseum. There are actually some shaded areas inside the Forum and some areas where you can sit on the fallen columns/ rocks. We did not climb the Palatine Hills as most of the buildings were concentrated in the Forum. The most important thing to remember is to plan before your visit, to get the most out of it. There is a nice gelateria to reward yourself on the street opposite the Colosseum, on the left side of the street, just on the street corner. Because of the unevenness and the number of small hills, strollers and wheelchairs will have difficulty.
awesome historical site. I got to the Roman Forum right at opening and it was beautiful and uncrowded in the early morning light. Nice overview of early Roman life.

A chance to experience one of the most important places that shaped world history; don't miss it. Very few places shaped world history more than the Roman forum (the heart of the Roman Republic). A visit is a must if you are interested in history at all. If you are not well versed in Roman history, I would highly recommend spending 2 or 3 hours reading about the role of the Roman forum in Roman society before visiting the site. It will really enhance your visit. I would also recommend spending 10 euro on a book like Rome Past and Present which includes photos of the ruins today and overlays/reconstructions of what the actual temples and buildings may have looked like during Roman times. The reconstructions really help you imagine what the forum looked like in its hay day (the book is available at the many newstands located around the Colosseum). If the forum is of particular interest to you, I highly recommend spending a few extra dollars and getting your own tour guide. The guides (who must be certified after substantial studies in ancient history) are full of knowledge that really makes the tour.Tip: Wear comfortable shoes as the uneven pavement is punishing on the feet; wear a hat there is very little shade and it can get very hot in the summer. Bring a water bottle as there are water fountains throughout Palentine Hill and the forum where you can fill up.
Amazing. The forum is amazing. You buy a joint Colloseum/Forum ticket. It's best to buy online ahead as the lines are huge in the summer.

Surprisingly interesting, beware of cave bugs. We came to the Roman Forum mostly because the ticket lines at the Colosseum were too long. Many TA reviewers reported that the wait was much shorter here. However, what appeared to be a much shorter line was incredibly slow moving. It still took us 45 minutes of waiting in the hot sun to get in. Once we got in, though, we found the Forum to be much more interesting than expected - so much so that we spent a couple of hours exploring and decided to use our tickets for the Colosseum the next day (they are good for one entry to each site within two days).What we found particularly interesting was being able to see a large complex of buildings and streets, walking along the same paths of long ago, and visualizing what life must have been like back then. Many of the buildings are more intact than we expected, though you cannot enter them. Plan on doing a lot of walking. Comfortable shoes are a must!We got the audio guide and accompanying map, but the quality of the content (and of the sound quality) was not that great (e.g., compared to what we got at the Vatican Museums). On top of that, the physical signs scattered around the complex had different station numbers from the map. That confused the heck out of us until we realized that they didn't match up and then used only the map. There are also multiple entrances to the Forum, so make sure you have your correct bearings by clearly finding the entrance you came in through on the map.Overall, we enjoyed our visit. Given the poor quality of the audio guide, it may have been better to pay for a live tour. But make sure you get something. Walking around without any guidance whatsoever - live or audio guide, detailed tour book - would leave much to be appreciated.One word of caution: there is a cave-like spot with some statues along the wall and where water is dripping from above into a small pool. We took shelter there because it was so hot and sat for a few minutes. But BEWARE of stopping there. In those few minutes, three out of four of us got a large number of insect bites.
Roma july 2013. we stayed close by te Roman Forum and were delighted to be in the old and still hub of this ancient city.

Don't need to pay when you can see a lot from walking past.. We paid 12 € for a joint ticket for the forum and the colloseum. Tip- go around 4pm (its quiet and cooler) and buy tickets at the forum entrance and then walk to the colloseum and you'll be right next to the metro station. Also, wear proper shoes! The forum is huge and full of roman finds. It's interesting to an extent but there isn't much information so it doesn't mean much. To be honest the best views are from the hill next to the forum. Filled out some hours tho and there are clean toilets available. As well as fresh water fountains to cool down.

The Sun on the Back of your Neck. A note about the Colosseum and the Forum. Ticket queues are very long at both and not good in the heat. The tickets for these two attractions remain valid till the day( time validation ending printed on the ticket) after purchase. Saves rushing round the two of them on the same day

See the history. Roman history isn't my strong point, but visiting the site of the Forum, and the associated temples/churches gave me a sense of the grandeur of the era and the high regard that Romans had for themselves.The visit made this era of history more tangible for me and I do recommend that you make time to view this area of Rome

Great to get a feel for Rome. Tickets for the Colosseum also include access to the Roman Forum. We enjoyed wandering round the Forum, looking at the ruins, admiring the orange trees and enjoying a little cool in the tunnel and with water from the fountains. Well worth a visit.

Plan well. We did the forum ruins etc in the same day as the Colosseum - your ticket for the Colosseum actually allows you access to the Forum and Palatine Hill area for two days - there is do much to take in that its probably a good idea to break them up - we did it all in one day and by the end of it we were looking at fantastic ancient ruins like second hand cars. Buy bottles of frozen water and take in with you - there are plenty of free drinking water fountains inside to top the bottles up. Hat and sunscreen are a must.

Roman Forum... Must see. We had already been to the Colosseum in a rushed tour the day before. So we had to line up in the hot sun for at least 30 minutes to buy our forum tickets. We discussed whether we needed an electronic information guide and decided we should pay the extra, both for the forum and the Palatine Hill. After finally getting the guide working, we found that the map and guide combined were very difficult to follow .... finally realising that this was at least partly due to sections that were closed and the guide and map not being updated... Then the guide was only hired out for two hours, anything more and there's a fine. We definitely hadn't finished the whole amazing site in two hours, so I had to run back with the guide and negotiate the crowds at the gate again. A confusing experience, but well worth the amazing sites. And there probably is enough information to go without the guide... As someone else said, just research it earlier.

Interesting Ruins. We had purchased our tickets on-line so were able to bypass the queues to enter the forum.We did not hire a guide as I researched the Forum before we arrived. Also purchased a before & after book before leaving home so you could see what the ruins were like in Roman times.We were here in July so it was very hot. Apply sunscreen, wear a hat & drink lots of water. Recommended.

Buy a book. We decided to forgo the hired guide and checked out a book from the library that had a walk-through of the Forum. I photocopied the appropriate pages and took that with us instead of the whole book, saving space and weight in our luggage. It was worth every penny and every minute spent preparing. The guide was essential to knowing exactly what we were looking at. NONE of the monuments would have meant even half of what it meant, without the explanation. For example, I never would have noticed the final resting place of Caesar, since it was behind a low wall and very unobtrusive. The fresh flowers laid there were very poetic though. The main thoroughfare, the Via Sacra, led us to walk the same steps as those of the ancient rulers of Rome. The triumphal arches were intricate and beautiful, and steeped with history. There were several restored buildings, including the Curia Julia, which was the meeting place of the Senate. There was an exhibit of WWII propaganda art inside of the lovely Temple of Romulus. My favorite location was Nero's somewhat restored rotating dining room overlooking the Colosseum. The view was spectacular and the idea of a rotating dining room that ancient was mind boggling.We visited in January. It was lightly drizzling but the rain was well worth the lack of a crowd. We had the place to ourselves completely for our full three hour stay. The fee (15.5 euro) got us into the Forum, Palatine Hill, and the Colosseum. Well worth the money. So much to see! Prepare to spend a while walking this wonderful site. Note: Avoid the small museum located at the top of the hill. It was not worth the effort, especially when you can go to the Musei Capitolini which is worlds better.

Must Visit Place. The forum is a must visit place at least for a first time visitor and any visit to this amazing historical city is incomplete without a visit here, but it is always packed with tourists. As with all ruins, this place should be explored and admired while either reading about the history or taking a guided tour. I took a guided tour which was much short than I expected it to be and did not cover everything. Be ware that due to the recent heat wave the weather is extremely hot, make sure to take a bottle of water and sunscreen.

All Roads lead to Rome - The Forum. There is little to add except that this is one of the most important historical sites in the world and is a real "Must See" for all visitors to the "Eternal City"Dream back among the beauty and the feel will surround you.Not as large as you might think, but manageable and fascinating.

History in recycling!. The forum is an amazing journey through Roman history. The repurposing of materials is incredible but if you are not scholar do yourself a favour and hire a guide. I highly Rome Private Guides for families. Worth every penny!

Lots of sites, get a book!. I bought the Rome, then and Now book and found it to be rather helpful in the forum as many buildings are no longer there or are merely stumps. It is exciting to be so close to history and to imagine what it was like when the forum was a bustling place to be. There is plenty to see and a lot of cool stories to go with each building so get a guide or a book so you know what you are looking at! I really enjoyed this visit and would have liked to spent more time there but the tour was moving on.

Visit forum 1st & buy Coliseum ticket at Forum to miss Q's. Not to be Missed. Shorter queue, wonderful walking around the ruins at a gentle pace, watch for uneven paths, see the coliseum and different angles. Exit and walk past the coliseum queue (which was huge) straight inside. Ask at desk for tours of upper and lower areas

Roaming the Roman Forum. There are not really good signs in Rome to the sights so we roamed awhile trying to find the entrance. We used our Roma passes to get in for free. There are not good informational signs so down load a Rick Steve's podcast. Also, the walkways are big ancient stones so wear good shoes. My sandals, which I have worn a lot, gave me horrible blisters. The ruins here are not real obvious so make sure you get some type of guide. There are also a lot of paths that lead no where.

Must see!. It was amazing to finally see the ruins of the Roman Forum if you are in Rome you can't miss it! It would have been even better if there was more signage telling you about the bygone beauties but you can always eavesdrop on a by standing tour guide and you end up learning about the site that way!

Atmospheric centre of Ancient Rome. Exploring the Roman Forum is an incredibly atmospheric experience; you can almost feel the hustle and bustle of what it must have been like to live in Ancient Rome! As it was a very warm day we wandered slowly around each part of the Forum, absorbing the history and the magnificent sites before us!

There, where History began.... There is not much to say about the forum,in the very centre of Rome. This is the Place to be if you have a passion for antiques, or even if you are just a fan of peplum movies. You can get a good glimpse of the place just strolling on via dei Fori Imperiali, from the Vittoriano to the Coliseum, but i warmly suggest you invest a little money to walk on the same roads that Ceasar walked. You can also see a lot of hidden gems, like the Temple of Romulus (the son of an emperor, not one of the two founder of Rome) the altar where the body of Jules Cesar was burnt and the temple of the Vestal Virgins. The stroll itself it's worth every single cent. the only prolem was I there on a very hot day in June and there was no shadow at all under th ruins.A hint: the 12 € ticket is also inclusive of Palatinum hill and Coliseum, and if you buy it here or at Palatinum entrance you can skip the looong queue at the Coliseum.

Still My Favorite. Just amazing. Rome is just full of history and the Forum is the heart of the ancient city. Biggest quibble is that the Forum is not labeled as well as you would like. Get the audio guide or do your homework before you go. Lastly, it gets very hot and there is little shade. Prepare accordingly.

don't do audio tour. Was excited about going to the Forum but left disappointed. We did the audio tour and it was horrible. Hard to find your way around. Doesn't have numbers listed anywhere. Map hard to figure out with different closures on the site. I would highly recommend getting a guided tour for this site. We normally do the audio tours and they work well for us. Not here. Without a guided tour, you will get bored, lost, frustrated, tired, etc.

Walking with the Ancients. First - get a guide book (like Rick Steves) so you can truly enjoy the many sights located at these two places. If you're not taking a guided tour, guide yourself through each ruin by reading about its history and significance. For me, the Roman Forum was the most amazing because I taught Shakespeare's Julius Caesar to my 10th graders for several years ... and just walking in the "hot spot" of political Rome allowed me to envision what it must have been liked ... Caesar's palace, the streets where he was killed ... Et tu, Brute? Read, read, read before & while visiting ... and you will enjoy this part of ancient Rome to the fullest!

A stroll through the Roman Forums, feels like a step back in time. I don't know what else to add, to the thousand plus reviews on this place, but I do want to speak of it in a highly positive note, as I am a big fan of history, and just imagining what it would be like to have lived during those ages when the empire was still in power. It was a very hot day at the time, and I am glad to have worn long-sleeve football shirt and pants, to not get seriously sunburned. Plus, carrying a water bottle around, there are plenty of water taps to stay re-hydrated. It does cost a fare to tour around, but it is worth it.

Badly maintained!. If you consider the number of tourists in Rome and how much money they make it is a wonder how the Roman Forum has fallen to such ill maintenance. I was saddened at the sight of it. A square so rich in history yet so ignored by modern day Italians. I say Italians and not Romans because the Romans were very organized people if anything and modern day Italians in Rome just don't seem that way at all.There are almost no signs telling you where you'd find what. There are no translations to what maybe ancient Italian or Italian. Nothing. You could almost miss Caesar's funeral pyre. In fact many tourists did. Everyone just walked by it because nobody knew what it was. You'd think that maybe they did not want to destroy the site by littering it with signs etc but think again. Everything you see has been tempered with. The pavements are not from the ancient times at least not for the most of it. It is nothing more than ruins of a once grand ancient empire. If you studied Roman history you would be sad to see it the way it is.Everything is about money. The ticket for the Roman Forum is the same 2 day ticket for the Colloseo. However, do not think you can visit the Colloseo twice although it says 2 day ticket. What it really means is, it is valid for 2 entries. We thought we could do the Colloseo the first day, the Roman Forum the next day and go back to the gift shop in the Colloseo the 2nd day to buy some souvenirs. We were not allowed to. When I told her (the girl at the entry) it doesn't say that anywhere that it is valid only for 2 entries, she just shrugged and started talking to her friend. Also the Roman Forum is not handicap friendly and neither is the Colloseo. I do believe, if they can build a souvenir shop in the Colloseo and there are even 2 rooms which were offices then they can somehow make a ramp or an elevator for the handicap.If you visit the Circus Maximus anytime soon, you'd know what I mean with disastrously maintained. A Spanish couple who were sitting on the edge of it, asked us if we knew where it was as we passed by. I just laughed and told them why of course you're sitting in it. She refused to believe me until I showed her the ring and the ruins of it on the other end.If you expect less than you'll appreciate more I guess.

Big. Be aware if you visit the Palatine Hill and the Forum that they are big and require a lot of time a good feet but well worth the effort. The funny thing that happened to me on the way to the Forum was to see a queue of men outside a loo. It would appear that urinals are in short supply and that gents' loos are all cubicles so they have to queue like us ladies are used to doing.

nice way to past the time. When your going to the colosseum you might as well get the 12 euro ticket that includes the roman forum and paltine hill, its well worth it and in the long run you save yourself 3 euro by gettin it all in one go. The roman forum is amazing to see as think of the history and that it is still standing.

See the ruins. This is included in the combined Colosseo/Foro/Palatino ticket valid for 2 days. Be aware though that the ticket allows only a single entry to the Colosseo and another single entry to both the Roman Forum AND Palatine Hill.Wear your most comfortable shoes and watch your step as this is an outdoor walk through rocky pathways. Do your homework and read up before coming so you'd know what you are looking at. The ruins at the Forum are closer together compared to those at Palatine Hill so it is easier to navigate but still requires a lot of walking.For those who would rather see but not walk among the ancient ruins, the 3rd level of the Colosseo provides a striking view of the Arch of Constantine with the east side of the Forum (Arch of Titus and Temple of Venus and Rome) completing the picture. However, the more stunning panorama would be from Il Vittoriano's terrazza where one can almost see the entire north-northeast side (from the top of the Arch of Septimius Severus extending all the way to the Arch of Titus) as well as the Colosseo and the Arch of Constantine. Postcard-perfect pictures guaranteed! For me, the Forum is worth a visit, the Palatine Hill though is another matter (see separate review), that one you can skip.

A wealth of history. The Roman Forum is a must when visiting the eternal city. The visual magnificence of the site alone makes it a worth while stop on your itinerary, but the amazing wealth of history that is centered in this place makes it a 'sin qua non' of any Roman vacation. That being said, i would strongly recommend some kind of audio guide while visiting the Forum (we enjoyed using Rick Steve's free iPhone app). Otherwise you might find yourself a bit bewildered as you attempt to navigate through the staggering amount of history in this enormous site.

Wonderful. We had a tour guide from the official tourist centre who was lovely. She showed us around the Colosseum and the Forum. The Forum was magnificent - you got a real sense of the might and power of ancient Rome. We particularly liked the palace and gardens of the Vestal Virgins.

Wonderful. I visited the Forum as a part of a tour for my study abroad class. I picked up a few tips from my professor during the tour. Go early! Especially during tourist season. So many go during the middle of the day, and the Roman sun can be brutal! If you plan to visit the Colosseum as well, buy your ticket at the Roman Forum first. A ticket you buy can include entrance to the Colosseum, but you can't buy a ticket at the Colosseum that is good for the Roman Forum as well. There is a lot to see here, so plan for a few hours even if you are just walking around and not looking up what everything is. Also, go to the top of the Capitoline Hill. It has a wonderful view of Rome! Wear comfortable shoes. The stones paths are big, and can be slick especially when wet, and there are lot of hills to climb up and down!

Take an “official” tour. I have little to add to the many prior reviews of the Roman Forum other than to mention the “official” guided tour of the Forum, which seems to receive very little publicity. The Italian cultural ministry (MiBAC), which is responsible for the Roman Forum, offers guided tours in Italian and English (and possibly other languages as well) several times a day. We were able to include an English-language tour during our recent visit and thought it was excellent. Our personable and enthusiastic guide explained that the tour is scheduled to run for one hour, but that she usually runs longer because she has "so much to share." In fact, our tour was about an hour and a half. Although she spoke rapidly (more of “so much to share!”), she was very easy to understand. Our group of 18-20 visitors walked with her to a number of the major sites in the Forum; she helped us to understand the function of each, how it would have looked long ago, and how the various sites fit together on the Forum’s complicated timeline. We thought she was very knowledgeable. The guide was happy to answer questions throughout the tour, and at its conclusion, offered individualized suggestions for what we should do next based on what we had already seen of ancient Rome.Tickets for this tour are available only at the Forum. It cannot be booked ahead by telephone or online (at least I was told this wasn’t possible). The “official” website for purchasing entry tickets mentions these tours, but the times listed did not correspond to the times offered on the day we visited. At the Forum, I found only a tiny sign with information about the tours and learned more by asking the person stationed at the entry gate. Guided tour tickets (as well as audioguides) can be obtained at the ticket window in a separate line from the one for the purchase of entry tickets. At a cost of €5 per adult, this tour may be the best value in Rome!Note that the cultural ministry also offers guided tours of Palatine Hill, but unfortunately for us, the times conflicted with our Forum tour.I recommend a visit to the Roman Forum and in particular recommend taking the informative “official” guided tour. The tour greatly enhanced our understanding of these important ruins.

Great History. After visiting the Colosseum we then went to the Roman Forum.I was a little disappointed as by then we had already walked most of the day and you really need to spend a day here to give it justice.

Historic - must see!. Definitely recommend to see the Forum. Really gives you an idea of how ancient Rome was. All of the columns and sights that have endured time & are still standing. Absolutely amazing. Loved it. Go thru this entrance to avoid the long lines at the Colosseum & buy the pass for the three sights. Skip the line at the Colosseum w/ the pass.

The Past Lives. Some logistics. The tickets allow 3 hours on site and you could easily spend that amount of time ranging over the Palatine Hill and the myriad remains in the valley of the forum. Cost is 12 euros (which includes the Colosseum) and there is an audio guide (which I didn't use). The entrance is off the via imperiali about half-way between the Colosseum and the Victor Emmanuel momument (go past the guys balancing on floating platforms, being cowboys etc.)As has been mentioned in previous reviews, this is a place for those sound in wind and limb as there is a lot of walking, climbing of slopes and stairs if you go up on the Palatine (and you must go up on the Palatine - just to see the view if for nothing else) and uneven surfaces on the Via Sacra. Be aware that bits may be closed off for digs etc.It's all amazing, the Basilica of Constantine is simply mind-blowing, and to be (almost) able to stand on the Rostra ('Friends, Romans etc') certainly gave me pause.The are toilets and water points and you can exit the way you came in or by the Colosseum.

Encapsulates Ancient Rome. Must see. Get some form of guide though!. Finding the entrance to this place was a nightmare, and it’s closest to and best approached from the Colosseum. I would recommend going to the Colosseum, then the Forum, and finally Palatine Hill, if you’re visiting all 3 historical sites in a day. The place itself was certainly interesting, and it was great to imagine the impressive scale of some of these buildings. Some of the remaining pillars give one an idea of just how grand and epic the place would have been. A few extant ruins are wonderfully intricate and detailed. Unsurprisingly, given the 2000 year interim, there is also a lot that is simply rubble, and it is sometimes hard to picture in its heyday. There were also no explanatory signs, so it is difficult to learn about the ruins you’re staring at, and gain much context. This was frustrating. Some information or placards would have been nice. If there is an audioguide, I would recommend getting it.The site itself is large and sprawling, and leads up to Palatine Hill. There were still excavations of the site taking place when I went. Unlike the colosseum, the Forum is regrettably far less intact, and requires some imagination and some prior background knowledge to get the most out of it, but it is nevertheless an important and interesting stop on any trip to Rome.

Very cool. A very cool spot to visit - kind of one of those "must-see" sites, despite the mandatory extensive walking and the sore feet afterwards. We found that the ticket to get in is a combination ticket that is valid for the Forums/Palatine Hill as well as for the Colosseum. We decided to skip the Colosseum as the lines were long and we had been there before, and bought our ticket at the entrance to the Forums instead (in hindsight, you could probably buy your combination ticket at the Forums and then take the quicker, already-have-your-ticket entrance into the Colosseum, but I can't say that for sure as we didn't try it ourselves). The entrance to the Forums is on the East side of the complex, on the road that goes south from the Colosseum. Not the most obvious place but they do have some signage indicating where to go. There was virtually no line and once you're in the park, it is really quite spacious. No signage of any kind though, so if you want to also understand what you're looking at, you will have to get the audio tour in addition to the entrance ticket. As mentioned, expect a lot of walking, still a must-see site though. THE place to see the remains of the ancient Roman civilization.
Beautiful Ruins. The Roman Forum is a must see in Rome. It shows how wonderful Rome must have been when it was the foremost power in the Mediterranean. However you need some imagination.

Something to see around every corner. Walk in the steps of Nero and Marc Anthony and see how they just randomly built house after house with the stones from other properties or just on top of disused buildings! Lots of walking and twists and turns, ancient marble pillars for you to rest on. We spent 4 hours here and we still did not explore it all. Entry price includes the Colosseum

Fun To Explore And Imagine. We spent a lot of time walking around this area on a late afternoon with very nice weather. We didn't actually go down into the ruins - we didn't know you could! There was no other people in any part of them and they seemed fenced off to us. However, I don't think you really need to go down into them. It's just as good to walk around them and use your imagination. I suggest grabbing an ice cream and just setting off on a wonder. You can still see everything up close and clear. It's a bit sad that it's practically falling apart and was not cared for when everything was still standing, but that's what imagination is for!

A Must See - but how to get in if you don't want to stand in line?. Off course you should see Roman Forum when in Rome - it doesn't need more elaborate descriptions.. but maybe an advise on how to get in without standing in line, which can be tedious and exhausting - and remember that you can buy a combo ticket both for Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine.Buy tickets online - and skip the linehttp://www.rome-museum.com/colosseum-tickets.php Or if you are already there and the line is long.. check Palatine.. it is the same ticket and maybe there is a shorter line there..Enjoy :-) PSBring a guide book - that will bring the place to live..

Amazing place. We visited the forum after we spent most of the day at the colosseum and would have spent more time there but were pretty tired. The ruins are absolutely amazing. I'm a huge fan of ancient architecture so i really enjoyed walking around looking at the remnants of the government buildings . It is so wonderful to see a part of history that is so ancient. Its pretty unbelievable.. the carving detail on the monuments are stunning. I could have taken thousands of pictures. From the top of the hill you get a great view of Rome, just be sure you wear comfortable shoes because the ground is uneven and rocky. We didn't go with a guide here like we did at the colosseum and chose to just look around ourselves with a map.

Fun at the Forum!!!. This was a very cool tour. You MUST NEED A TOURIST or you will not have the slightest bit of understanding what it is. It is better for children in Gr.5 and up. Loved this experience! It is good if you get a package with a tourguide because if you want to go to the Colosseum they can get you in there in about five minutes instead of 2 hours.

Walk around in ancient Rome and use your imagination. Directly linked to the Palatine Hill you'll find the Forum Romanum. It is a very nice and calm place to walk around and amaze yourself about the history that took place here. I definitly recommend you to go here and enjoy it.

Well worth doing.. We visited the forum as part of a package we got with our Colosseum tickets. It included Palentine Hill and entrance to the Forum. So entering it from the hill we missed the queues. It was really interesting. It bought it alive. You could imagine yourself walking with the senators. I couldn't get over how close everything was together. When the buildings were at full height they must have been very imposing. Our children (8 & 10 yrs) also enjoyed it. They had looked at the romana at school so enjoyed being there. We spent a couple of hours there. I could have spent longer but that was enough for the children.

The Glory of Ancient Rome is Here!. Do your homework before coming to the Forum and you'll enjoy yourself immensely. Imagine for a moment a triumphal procession just like in the movies moving through the Arch of Titus and progressing down the Via Sacra toward the Rostra across from the Basilica Julia. The bases where triumphal columns once stood are still there and the paving stones are the same that some of the greatest names in Roman history once trod. The garden in the House of the Vestal Virgins still has roses blooming by its two small pools of water, and the three lonely columns from the Temple of Castor and Pollux stand sentinel over its remains. Step towards the Arch of Septimus Severus. This is at the far end by an exit that leads to the Victor Emmanuel Monument. Look at the tremendous relief work in this arch. Take your guide book and walk around the site and take the time to explore. You can easily figure out where the Basilica Julia was located (the bathrooms are behind this ruin), and directly across the forum is the what's left of the Basilica Amelia where money exchange and commercial transactions took place. And the circular Temple of Vesta is another easily recognizable monument. Some locations are more difficult to imagine, such as the Basilica of Constantine and Maxeritius. The only thing that remains here are three huge vaults and some pavement that give a suggestion of how huge this building once was.Like any ancient ruins, the remains of the Forum suffered centuries of earthquakes and neglect, but they are part of the fabric of history and help to weave a story of what Ancient Rome must have been like. Take time to explore and to imagine the Glory of the Ancient Rome beneath your feet! You won't be sorry. And for those who aren't good on their feet, bear in mind that the terrain is rough and that the walking isn't easy. Remember that your combination ticket includes the Colosseum and the Palatine Hill. Enjoy!

History itself. Some people may dismiss this site as simply a collection of rubble...but if you have ANY sense of history you must visit The Forum. As you walk its short distance, you really can sense it's sheer history and relish the wonder of walking through the very heart of the Roman Empire. Tip: visit the Palatine first and then walk through to the Forum as you may avoid the entry line-up that way.

Humiliation of tourists. I've made the tour during my visit in april with my family. Rome is a beautiful city and we had very good time. however one bad experience destroyed our mood. Me, my wife and my 6 year old daughter went to see the forum area in the historical center. After the long queue, we came to the ticket office and bought 2 tickets because officer told us 6 year child is free of charge. However at the gate, we are told that 6 year old girl MUST pay FULL adult price because she is not EU citizen!!It is not possible to understand this kind of second class human treatment. what could be the extra cost for a 6 year old girl visiting an archeological site compared to a similar EU member child? paying 16 euros is nothing but this kind of treatment disturbed me extremely. I'll never visit italy again unless I'm forced to. I let EU citizens visit again and again themselves and enjoy freely..

Majestic Roman Forum !!!. Pictures do not do this building justice. Besides being constucted of 100% marble, the structure is filled with history of unbelievable proportion. This is a must see when visiting Rome for the first time.

Good but could be better. The building speaks for itself, you cannot miss it.Cue was massive cost was 12euros each, we went for an english speaking guide who presented himself to us near the entrance. The cost was 30euros each we were given a yellow sticker dot and told to wait. The tour started off with a lady who explained some history of the Col we then skipped the cues and went inside. There are plenty of clean and free fountains around both sites so take a bottle, it gets very hot in both sites you will need it as you cannot buy water inside the sites. The first part of the tour lasted approx an hour and the group was of around 25 people, there seemed to be no signs or explanations around the buliding so the tour was essentially the only source of information. We had the first 1 hour with this lady and was then given 45mins of our own time, we then met a man for the second half of the tour to Palantine hill we walked around the old palace grounds and were shown from a vantage point the main points of the Forum. this lasted approx another hour. Although the site speaks for itself I felt that it needed some TLC as weeds were growing around the exhibit and there ws a lack of visual aids to help imagine what the exhibits would have looked like in their splendour. We basically wandered around the Forum not knowing a Column from a Colonade :-) I just think that the expirience could be a lot more polished (I know its not Disneyland but the Italians could make a bit of an effort).

Overwhelming but Impressive. The Forum is impressive because it is a monstrous collection of ruins in the middle of Rome. While it definitely involves a fair amount of walking/climbing around, it is impressive and will take up several hours. There are also beautiful plants and fountains in the area, and lots of places to sit and relax. Admission to the Coliseum also gets you into the Forum, so it's worth a jaunt on over!

The remains of ancient rome.. Everyone goes to the Colloseum, but this place is full of history and is spacious and relaxing. If you like history and architecture you'll love this place. I watched the HBO Rome TV series and it really helped bring this amazing place to life in my mind. Wonderful at any time of year, and since it is such a big area you can always find a quiet space, unlike at the Colloseum

History before you. Such an interesting place in a beautiful setting. Even if you're not interested in Roman history or architecture, it's a beautiful and peaceful place. If you are going to get a joint ticket for the forum and for the colisseum, buy it at the forum. The ticket purchasing arrangements at the colisseum are a bit of a nightmare.

Shameful neglect. I last went to Rome in 1968. I read an article two weeks ago saying that the ancient ruins in Italy (Rome and Pompei) had suffered more in the past 30 years than over several previous centuries. This is more than true as I was able to verify on April 28th 2013... The Forum should be classed as a national shame. The place reeks of neglect ....filthy marble statues (or what is left of them) , cracked columns with nesting pigeons, moss eating into mosaics, weeds everywhere, often to such an extent that the ruins behind are impossible to identify. There are bushes and trees (often fig trees) growing out of the walls of ancient ruins ... It is time the Italians got their act together and started cleaning up the mess before the whole lot falls down...

A must you should avoid. When in Rome, there are some sites you are obliged to visit. The Forum is one of them. Even you should take the courage and avoid it. If you stay in Rome for just the weekend, it is a waste of time.But if you go in, you should join a guided tour as there are little describtion (or get a podcast tour) and half of the Forum is closed (so your maps have no use).Generally, the Forum is a park with lots of stone (ruin). All the valueable things are already in the Vatican Museums. And you will see enough ruin elsewhere in the city. Not worth it.

Excelent!. if u have roma pass is free. is also includes colosseum and the palatine hill. are alot of temples here and alot of ruins.is a very beautiful view. it takes at least 1 hour to visit everything even more if u have a guide. nice storys about castor and polux or about the women who take care about the fire!
fascinating place!. Right next to Palatine Hill and the Colosseum a must visit when you're in this part of Rome and would recommend doing all 3 as part of a tour!

Ancient history in the heart of contemporary ROme. Loved the Forum and weather was nice. Worth the $ to enter. We used the Roma pass - great deal (2 free museum/site entrances, can jump the long line, 3 days of public transit use). Marveled over just how old everything is. Sat in foyer of some ancient house up on the hill. We got their late and they were closing (4pm I think - seemed way too early). Wanted to stay more. You can bring a picnic, sit and relax among the ruins. Nice to wander through it all. Next time we'll try a guide for more info.

Wow. We had the tickets for all 3... well worth the visit. A real insite into ancient Rome. You can use your ticket over 2 days. but can only visit each site once. The Forum gives you a taste of how it used to be in Rome, Make sure you have comfortable shoes, water, and camera.

Worth visiting. Spent a sunny afternoon walking around the forum. Not too many crowds to annoy .. but just wonderful to wander around taking all the history in, A must see with the Colosseum,. Palatine Hill... The tickets are 3 in one and can re visit over 2 days. (only visit per attraction)

Touring the Forum and Palatine Hill. The Forum is worth seeing. You can walk among the ruins of ancient Rome and read detailed descriptions in multiple languages of the history of each building, column, or other structure. It's fascinating to be able to stroll among the actual ruins of the Roman Senate, the triumphal arch of Titus, and much more.You'll do a bit of walking on uneven cobblestone paths and rough walkways, plus up and down stairs, so if anyone in your group has serious mobility problems, you may want to think carefully about going in. That said, as a 60+ male with two bad knees, I had no problem getting around.In my opinion, there's no reason to bother paying for the audio tour. I rented it for both walks (there is a separate audio sequence for the Forum and for the Palatine.) Half of the narrations didn't work and the other half, while informative and interesting, actually went on too long. Because there are numerous explanatory signs, you'll be able to get the gist of the story without the audio tracks.Note that admission to the Forum does not get you admission to the Coliseum. That's a separate ticket.

Worth visiting. We spent a lovely afternoon walking round the forum having visited the Palatine Hill first. It's an impressive site- unfortunately we didn't have a good guidebook or audio so we didn't get as much out of the visit as we could have done. There were a lot of tourists there but it didn't feel too overcrowded. we'd definitely go again if we returned to Rome.

A Lot to See in One Afternoon. We spent most of a Saturday afternoon walking around the Roman Forum, and used the tour provided in Rick Steve's guide to Italy to navigate our way through (it did a good job). It is amazing to see such a concentration of ruins. It is located very close to the Colosseum, so consider doing both in the same day.

Go there earlier than 1 o'clock in order to take your time in visiting everything. Tip: the ticket costs around 12 EURO, it has included a free visit to the Colosseum and it is valid for 2 days. Try to visit it in the morning to have time to explore all the places which takes around 3 hours. The audio guide is available until 3 PM when you have to return it to the entrance next to Circo Massimo.The Roman Forum is full of history, there are some ruins where you will find pictures of how the archeologist thought the place looked like, there are numerous gardens to walk around in and most important try not to leave the theatre last as you may not have time to visit it. At 4 PM guards started whistling at us to reach the exit as soon as possible and we had to leave before taking a tour in the theatre.

Romantic Walk through History. A must do for all individuals traveling through Rome is a walk through the Roman Forum. You should plan a good 2 hours or so to simply wander and explore the history. The walk itself is also very romantic for couples with gardens, fountians, many sculptures, and classic Italian atmosphere. Well in Rome my Wife and I visited many historic locations and many of the tourist spots. That said the Roman Forum was one of our favorites. Make sure you make time to see it. Be sure to get there Early as lines grow rapidly into the afternoon.

Remarkable display of ancient history.. My wife and I both liked the Forum more than any other attraction in Rome. The old buildings and ruins were amazingly well preserved. It's just hard to imagine the ancient Romans lived and died here. It's a very peaceful place to stroll and think.

No way you can miss it. The Forum is an amazing place you have absolutely to go if it is your first time in Rome or even the 2nd or 3rd! Be prepared to walk and climb among the Roman ruins - you'll need very comfortable shoes, like sneakers or hiking shoes (it can be slippery if you insist to get closer to some spot in particular). The views are awsome and one cannot avoid to reflect upon the greatness of that old civilization. Try to buy a guide or an App for your phone because monuments in Italy rarely have a description in English.Avoid Easter and August. Easter because Rome will be full of tourists ad pellegrins and August not only because of the hordes of tourists but also because of the heat. Rome can be very very hot in Summer. Personally, I find October and May-June the best time to visit.

Mar 13. This was my favourite part of my visit to Rome. If you visit the Colosseum and pay for a guide you get entry into Palatine Hill and The Forum included plus you bypass the queues. The forum is actually " down town" in old Rome, and not a building a I thought. It's lovely to walk amongst the many partially standing buildings and picture what it must have looked like. The cobbles are huge and much easier to walk on than smaller versions. However, I would still recommend wearing comfortable shoes there is a lot of walking to do.

You enter into several worlds in one place!. Many different eras of building created the Roman Forum. Different arhitecture and building styles are clearly represented. We even visited the spot where Julius Caesar was cremated. Another world, within the city of Rome. Not to be missed. Warning: do not go in the summertime...too hot, and crowded! We went in January...much quieter!

The best of Rome. Even though Forum Romanum sits in the middle of bustling Rome, entering it was like stepping back in time. So many famous and decisive moments of history have taken place here among the ruins you walk today. It may be hard to imagine what it looked like, but most guidebooks have good illustrations which really helps. So, sit back, take your time, try to rule out the tourists and envision what it might have looked like when the emperor returned from his victorious battles or the orators made their speeches, or even when Julius Caesar was stabbed to death. You should put aside a few hours (at least two, in my opinion) to fully experience the splendid Forum. And it goes without saying that you need comfortable shoes! A combo ticket (Forum, Colosseum, Palatine) was 12 Euros, and definitely worth the cost. You can buy the tickets online so you don't have to wait in line in front of the ticket office. Also, go for the entrance along Via dei Fori Imperiali, as it seems to be much less crowded than the entrance outside Colosseum. There were surprisingly few signposts inside the Forum, so you should bring a good guidebook or buy an audioguide at the entrance. If you have a smartphone or a tablet, there are also informative guided tours available. (There's a good one from TripAdvisor CityGuides, and it's free.)

Impressive Roman Architecture. The Roman Forum is an excellent example of the prime of Roman Architecture. It is truly amazing to walk through ruins up to 8 stories tall, and see just how advanced the Roman's were. Sure you can see part of it from the main streets, but definitely take the guided tour to experience all the history this site has to offer!

Recommend using a guide.. Our tour set up through Tickitaly included the Forum. While not as well preserved as the colosseum if one uses their imagination they can easily see how vast the site must have been back in time. The parts that remain standing provide a small glimpse at a one amazing place. I recommend seeing the Forum with a guide for two reasons, first you bypass the line of general admission tourists and second the guide will provide some good history information.
Great experience. I loved the visit at Roman Forum. So much to see. March-april was excellent time for a visit.Prepare for lots of walking in different levels. Interesting visit.

One of Rome's Must Visits. If you are visiting Rome, then you are no doubt interested in old and ancient things. While the Roman Forum may not be ancient, it is very very old! I was fortunate to have my son's father-in-law, (a native Roman well versed in all things Italy) as my initial guide during my first visit to what he said was the largest and most significant of all the so called "forums" in Rome. While the amount of standing structure is limited, the rest of the ruins is well developed and a visitor will see the layout and can envisage what it must have looked like in its day. I would recommend a stop here as historically, this is one of the most important sites in Rome.

Wonderfull. We went to Roman Forum on a sunny day after visiting Colosseum (12 Euro ticket works for both Colosseum and Roman Forum). We entered from Palatine Hill entrance, which is 200 meters away to the right of Constantine's Arch (if you're facing Colosseum) , but were told there is another entrance on Via de Fori Imperiali. Recommend to spend at least an hour there and if you're interested in the history of the roman forum take a map or an audioguide, as the place itself is marked with little detail. Overall, it was our favorite moment of the entire visit.

Great Roman ruins. We went to see the Coliseum first, (at 9 AM before the lines started) then easily transited to the Forum which allows you to enter on the same ticket (12 Euro) - you can do it the other way around as well and skip usually much longer lines at the Coliseum. The Forum is great location to see some fantastic Roman ruins and structures such as two arches and a temple. This site must be visited in a non-raining day as everything is outdoors, do not waste time going if it is raining. Also wear comfortable shoes as the trails are rocky - no high hills ladies!
