Well worth the money and time but watch out for vendors outside the gates - they overcharge for everything, prices are double to include bad food ... recommend walking somewhere else to eat and buy souvenirs

Worth a couple of hours!. The Roman Forum is actually three sites combined in one ticket: the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Forum (I visited in that order). Palatine Hill and the Forum have the same point of entry, so really they are actually the same attraction. Personally I found Palatine Hill a little disappointing - appalling signage really lets it down and the House of Livia was closed without any explaination. There are however, some stunning views from the Hill. The Forum was far more interesting but again better signage and explanations would go a long way in improving the site - I doubt this is going to happen anytime soon, so make sure you have a good guidebook with you! I love Ancient Rome so just being at the Forum was exciting but the whole experience could be quite underwhelming for those without a keen interest or a guide to bring the place to life.The cost of the ticket is quite hefty so if you are on a tight budget and just want a great photo without paying for it then you are in luck - the best vantage point of the Forum is totally free! Just walk behind the Capitoline Muesum (Via del Campidoglio) and you'll be rewarded with an amazing view!
Top Rome attraction. Get there early, and be prepared to absorb information, and the Roman Forum is worth everything. Many attractions are covered in metal or caged, but this is a must see.

truly roman, must see!. wow...what do i say abot this place. Initially on my trip to rome, i thought it woud be boring to actually go inside the roman forum and look at all the ruins...i mean what could eb more there to see...But my husband being very much interested in history took me there and to my surprize, this place is just wonderful...it was so interesting with all that history and and the people in earlier rome lived and what they did...and the death place of Julius ceaser...must do!

You should really see it!. We took a guided tour of the Colloseum (which I would highly recommend - much more meaningful than walking around on your own) and an optional guided tour of the Forum came with it. It is so fascinating to walk around all those ruins from 2000 years ago. I disagree with the person who suggested to just view the area from outside. Although that is an option, there is just nothing like getting up close to the ruins to experience the culture that is all things Roman.

Forum Romana - Rome my Fav city !. Wondering round thinking of its 2000+ year old history I was blown away. Potentially walking on the same pavements as all those emperors and people of Rome! When I was there I asked how much to go in and was told Free so pick up a guide to make sure you know what you are looking at or get one of the audio guides or even better English speaking tour guides. All well worth the experience but don't rush, take some water with you and soak up the atmosphere. Love it !

A walk through ancient times. Buy a ticket to the Forum and enterance to the Colliseum is included! If you're in Rome, these are two must sees in my estimation. I would not recommend the self audio tour with one of those hand held audio devices. I found the guidance awful. The locations weren't marked at all on site to coorespond with the recording and it got rather confusing as I got to Augustus' house and the museum. Rather, opt for a group tour. Listening to the guides as I fumbled with my map seemed like a much more enjoyable and responsive experience.

Makes for a good afternoon of walking. The Roman Forum, which shares an entrance with Palatine Hill, is filled with numerous ruins and a scattering of what I would probably call museums. Well worth soaking in the atmosphere with a walk in the daytime, but do bring a guidebook or spend a few euros for the audio-guide if you want to bring context to your wanderings!
More ancient ruins to enjoy. Take the time to visit the ancient ruins of the Roman Forum. The views the ruins are amazing to see and experience.
The Roman Forum - Rome, Italy. Loved it! Spent over three hours looking around and enjoyed every minute. Is a must-see in ancient Rome.

Bring a Guide or a Book. Like many attractions in Rome, the Forum is one that is best experienced with a professional guide. The site is crammed with ruins and each has a story rich in history. This story, however, is not told with signs. Without a guide, or some very good books, you lose learning about the artifacts, the history, the meaning, and the culture of the people who worked and lived among these ruins. Added bonus of hiring a guide; they will pre-arrange tickets for you so you don't have to wait in line to enter. The Forum gets very crowded and skipping the line makes for a much more enjoyable experience. The Forum was the heart and soul of Ancient Rome and shouldn't be missed.

Simply amazing. To stand in front of the Roman Forum was an unbelievable experience. The Colosseum and Palatine Hill were the same. I felt that I had to pinch myself to know that I was looking at things that I had read about, learned about and didn't think I would ever see in real life! Loved the whole experience.

Just read... Roman forum is the most beautiful thing I have ever seen.You will like it as much as you appreciate old buildings and middle ages. I was thrilled that for only 12E You can so much to see, plus Colosseum, do not miss Roma Forum.I was in Rome, after a trip to Thailand and it was really refreshing, the whole town! Thailad is not expensive and its interesting but here I saw the real beauty and magnificent buildings, again I say matter of taste .. One of the best thing was fresh drinking water all over the place , in the Forum and all over Rome, it was so refreshing because in Thailand You don"t have drinking water anywhere except in stores...

It helps if you do a bit of homework!!. the best piece of advice i can give for the Roman Forum is either - do a tour or take an audio guide and perhaps read up about it before hand to be able to get some kind of understanding of this space. it is really badly signposted you could be listening to the audio guide about one Temple and realise you are looking at something totally different. try to go early before the hoards of groups so you can get a sense of what it was like to walk down via sacra. there are loads of water fountains so dont worry about getting dehydrated although remember in the Summer heat there is very little protection from the sun - again another reason to go early. if you take an audio guide you WILL have to bring it back to the same place so taking the nearest exit may not be an option. a book that might help bring this area to life is the translation of Seutonius book of the history of emperors.

Heart of Ancient Rome. The socio-economic heart of Ancient Rome, one requires a vivid imagination while walking here. Taking an audioguide is a must to enjoy while touring here.There is a lot to see and good amount of time should be dedicated at the forum. The view of the city from here are amazing and make for a good family photo. Tip: Start your day at the Roman Forum, spend about 2-3 hours over here before visiting the Colosseum towards mid-day.

A must-see. If you are going to go to the Forum - and you should - I would highly, highly recommend getting a guide. I have now been twice, once with a guide and once without, and the experience could not have been more different the second time. The place itself is phenomenal and you do get a sense of it when walking around, but to get context and explanation I think you really need a good guide! It is a fantastic place though, so much history in one area. You get goosebumps thinking that you are walking the same streets that Caesar would have wandered...

The Forum. Knew this place covered quite an area but were blown away as it just kept going, you think you've seen it all and turn a corner and more awaits you, you really do need good few hours to see the Forum.

So much history, all in one place!. From the moment you first see the remains of the Forum, it's is hard to believe how much history there is behind it. The ruins are impressive enough, but the stories behind what you see and to know that they took place where you are standing is worth the trip to Rome itself. A must see for any visit to this city.

Probably my favorite of Rome. I absolutely loved the forum! I was in Rome for only one day and I was happy that most of the hours I spent it here, seeing and feeling the history thru my eyes. I still get the chills that I got when walking around there. If you don't want to go in, no worries, plenty of walkable places from the Colosseum similar to it to take pictures. Get a Roma pass to get there without issues and waiting for long time and you are all set!

Amazing walk through history. Finding myself within the Roman Forum was really amazing and walking in the footpaths of ancient Romans cannot be beat. I rented an audio guide, which although was okay, did not do my visit justice. In the future I would definitely recommend a guided tour if possible. Go early in the day to avoid the long lines and also to see the morning sun shining through this ancient city. Stunning!

Rubble.. My wife and I visited Rome last July. Like most travelers we had to see ancient Rome. The Colosseum, though pillaged throughout the ages has retained it's magical quality. Unfortunately, I can't say the say about the Roman Forum. Yes, the history is amazing and if you can imagine what it must have been like 2000 years ago it's truly special. However, that's the problem. What you see is a lot of rubble and remnants of destroyed and vandalized buildings and consequently it makes it almost impossible to actually use your imagination. I especially liked the arches of Constantine, Titus and Septimius Severus. They are in great condition and much of their detail is still visible. Walking along the Via Sacra (the main street of ancient Rome) is guaranteed to give you goose bumps as you consider the many great Emperors who tread on the very flagstone your feet are touching. You have to see it and experience it. Please don't miss it! Nonetheless, seeing is believing and sadly there's not much left to see.

Amazing.. Don't know why the colosseum is widely known but not the roman forum. The Ronan forum is super impressive. It is very very old and still has some standing buildings. It is so impressive to walk where Julius Caesar once stood and see where he died. The history in this place us breath taking. Buy a combo ticket to get the best value.

Follow the footsteps of the ancient Romans. To enjoy a trip to the Roman Forum (especially during a warm clear day), you need the following: (1) a Roma Pass (to get in for free and to avoid the long queues); (2) a bottle of water; (3) a hat; (4) imagination; and (5) patience.Before you rush into the Forum, try to appreciate it from a distance at different angles. I recommend the view from the Capitoline Hill behind the Piazza del Campidoglio. From that vantage point you can see the western end of the Forum which has the Arch of Septimus Severus and the Temple of Saturn, among others. In the early morning sunlight, it is an impressive sight even in its ruined state. Then go around and then go near the Forum by way of the Mamertine Prison and Ss. Luca e Martina to get a closer view of the Arch of Septimius Severus.You can then enter the Forum at the entrance near the ruins of the Forum of Nerva. Make sure to check out the labels on the free-standing columns and structures to at least get your bearings in this vast complex. Just follow the Via Sacra, the main road inside the Forum, where one end gets you to the Arch of Septimus Severus and the other end gets you to the Arch of Titus. In the middle of the Via Sacra is the Temple of Vesta and the House of the Vestals, which contains a long green patch of land in the middle of the complex decorated with statues of famous Vestals, and was the holiest part of the Forum. You can get a brief respite from the sun in this area. Don't forget to look up to see Palatine Hill and the ruins of the Palace of Tiberius and Caligula. On the other side of the Via Sacra lies the Temple of Romulus and the Basilica of Maxentius and Constantine, the largest building in the Forum. You can check out the interior of the Temple of Romulus, which has been restored and used for movies.You can then make your way up Palatine Hill, where you can see great views of the Forum and the Colosseum. The Neronian Cryptoporticus (an underground corridor 130 meters long), the House of Livia (wife of Emperor Augustus), the House of Emperor Augustus, the Farnese Gardens, the Stadium of Domitian, and the Palatine Museum are all found in Palatine Hill. Make sure you time your visit to the House of Emperor Augustus right and have a great deal of patience ready because of the long queues. This isn't too easy especially if you can feel the heat radiating from the ancient stones around you as you wait your turn. They can only accommodate a certain number of people at any given time, considering the fragile state of such historic monument, so there might be a long wait.Finally, near the forum arch lie the ruins of the Temple of Venus and Roma, the largest temple in Ancient Rome. You can get a great view of this from the Colosseum. The Arch of Constantine is nearby.

Not just a pile of stone. After visiting the Colosseum we visited the Forum and were fortunate a) to have a pass and b) get there before the crowds. We'd read that due to the state of the site the Forum may not be as interesting to visit as some of Rome's other sites and I guess for the groups of school kids or bus loads of Quick Trip tourists this may be true. If on the other hand you have the time and a little imagination the visit is really unforgettable, especially if the weather is nice and sunny. We strolled round the site and took the time to sit on the benches, enjoy the view and absorb the atmosphere of the site. It only takes a little imagination to picture yourself 2000 years earlier, a really edifying experience.

A great place to visit on a warm day. We had access to the Forum as part of our Colosseum ticket and were blessed with fantastic warm weather and found this to be a great place to visit.It's lovely to walk around and see the remains of the Aquaduct and the Palace and all of the buildings that would have controlled everything that happened in Rome.There are lots of quiet places to sit by a fountain or relax on the grass if the weather is good so you can easily make a day out of it and bring a picnic.

Awesomw and humbling. The Forum as with most of Ancient Rome makes you realise how advanced the Romans were. No wonder they conquered so much of the world. The Forum allows you to really imagine that you are in ancient Rome, what it was like to live in a powerful empire.The scale and vastness puts life into perspective and really illustrates the saying 'Rome wasn't built in a day.'You must visit if you go to Rome. Highly recommend and would go again when I revisit Rome!!

A walk through time. My husband and I did a two day pass to the Coloseum and the Forum. We got to the coloseum in the evening and enjoyed walking through there as the people were leaving. The following day we returned and meandered through the forum. We didn't really have anything in particular we wanted to see but enjoyed meandering throughout the forum as well as the view to the city. I am usually an over planner, and in some ways wish I had prepared more for what we were seeing by reading up on the buildings but we also enjoyed just discovering... depends on what you prefer. I don't know if I would have wanted a guide. Some great photo ops.

Don't miss it!. This is a fantastic place to see, definitely don't miss out! Combine with a trip to the Colosseum (12 EUR ticket and both are included). It's really amazing place to wander around and see all the ruins of these great buildings. We navigated our way with a map we were given at the Colosseum and could work out what each building was from that. Don't go without any sort of information on it as you'll probably feel a bit lost - there's so much to see!

Wonderful place. Roman Forum is a place where you see the history. You can see how civilize and amatzing Rome is 1000 years ago. Roman Forum is actually the buildings, the town, the place where people 1000 years ago live their life. If you visit the Colosseum as well, then the ticket that you purchase for both attraction will cost 12 Euros and it is totally worth it. It takes approximately 2-3 hours easily to roaming around Roman Forum. The place is pretty big. Make sure you wear comfortable shoes, some part you walk in rock path, so make sure that your shoes are supportive. Roman Forum mostly features the ruin buildings of an ancient Roman city. It is really nice if you purchase the little book at the bookshop in Colosseum which will tell you the story of the places, I guess the name of the book is 'Everyday life in Rome' or something kind of similar name cost 12 Euros. I walk along and look at the book and see how it should be in an Ancient time and how it is now, quite interesting though. There is a house of Augustus as well that limited the number of people to get in there, very interesting place. I would personally recommend you to bring water with coz you might get thirsty during the walk. If you want to feel the past and imagine how it would be in Roman ancient city, definitely do not miss Roman Forum.

Trip into history. This attraction is right opposite the Coliseum and well worth it. It's very spacious and offers just about everything one can imagine. I studied Roman history in school and it felt just like walking back into history. What an awesome experience.

best to have a guide with you. we had a guide from Context with us - it made a difference... it is the only way to understand what was once there, the political and economical struggle of the time... plus all the background gossip behind the scene... :)

amazing beauty and history. don't just look at the ruins from above! make sure you go down among them - it really impacts you in a completely different way. so neat to walk among what remains of a people who impacted our history like none other

Huge with lots to see. We visited the Roman Forum directly after the Colosseum while we still had our “how it used to look” heads on.You could easily spend many hours here wandering around the streets of ruins as it is so interesting. Not much in the way of signage but you can get an audio guide. We didn’t and chose to just walk around and soak up the atmosphere.It can become very busy at times but because of the size of the place, you hardly notice.We recommend you read up on the history of the Roman Forum to fully appreciate the ruins. Well worth a visit.

Ah the Roman Forum....amazing. The forum is part of the Palatine Hill and Colosseum together. It is a long day to do all three, however it is worth it.Start in the morning, early when they open at the Palatine Hill to buy your tickets, the same price as the Colosseum however if there is a line it is short. Then you see the Hill on to the Forum and then the Colosseum for the one price and by pass the line ups.Make sure you carry a water bottle and you can refill it from the natural springs that are everywhere, yes its safe.Cheers

History to see. Amazing place to visit & think of all the history & how old it is. It was awe inspiring. This is another Must See place to visit when in Rome. I just stood in amazement looking at everything.

Amazing...center of everything. Standing in the Roman Forum it is hard not to think about the fact that this was the center of everything at one point in time. Wish we had started here rather than the Palatine Hill - we were pretty tired after that and were not ready to spend as much time as I may have wanted to spend here. Allow a good amount of time - there is a lot to see. So rich with history. Just utterly awe inspiring. Don't miss this!! Get a combo ticket ahead of time (it is good for Colosseum, Palatine Hill, and Forum) pickup for this was not bad at the Colosseum if they let you in the group entry to skip the wait - or you can pickup in the much shorter Palatine Hill entrance which is just past the Arch of Constantine away from the Colosseum. You don't want to wait in line!!!
Roman Forum. 2 days were not enough to explore this wonderful place. Allow plenty of time if you are interested in history (as well as achaeology)

imagine yourself being back in Roman history as soon as you walk in. an fantastic site to visit and imagine yourself being time traveled back in Roman historya great historic site that with what is the few remaining sites from ancient rome... where rome started and fellfrom the Arches to the churches to the ancient tombs.....to the only road on the Via Sacra....you are walking on the very same steps and ground that was once the most powerful empire to conquer the world...recommend downloading Rick Steves audio tour.. to listen to the great history that Roman Forum has...must stop to know the history of Romepart of the ticket with the Palatine Hill and Colesseum pass...

Historical Wonder. Just like the Coliseum situated right next to it about 10 min walk away, with the same ticket you are able to explore the Roman Forum at a leisurely pace. At a glance it looks like a bunch of rocks that have weathered away with time and placed artfully around the land, but with some of the historical knowledge of the area, this area truly is amazing to walk through. Bit like stepping back into time into one of the greatest ancient ages.

Roman Forum. Fantastic site to visit. Although we were on an EF tour with a guide, could not hear a single word she said because the broadcast device the company provided did not work properly. Noticed other people had mp3 players with someone telling them about each point of interest. I would recommend this over having a guide that you cannot hear. But the actual Roman Forum itself was very interesting.

A unforgettable experience.. How do you describe walking thru the heart of the ancient roman city. Walking on the same paths as some of the most memorable people in all of human history. It is humbling and awe-inspiring. There is nothing quite like it and it is something that I will never forget. From the Arch of Titus to the Temple of Saturn, the spectacle of the Roman Forum will not dissapoint.
Great area to see. it was awesome to walk around and see the forum, read the history of the vestal virgins really interesting

Another piece of history.... We walked through the Forum 10 years ago while visiting Rome for a day, but decided to book a tour this time that included the Forum so we could have more information. This was certainly the way to go (we booked a half day tour that also included the Colosseum - it was great!). Our guide was an archeology major who had actually worked on the grounds uncovering some of the ruins. He was incredibly knowledgable, and laid all the info out perfectly so that we could see the past in our imagination. It was simply incredible to know that we were walking on the same cobblestone roads that Julius Cesear walked on. I highly encourage you to have some sort of guide so you know exactly what your surroundings are.

So much to see, enjoyed it thoroughly!. Another must see in Rome - its like stepping back in time seeing the ruins of what used to be there, absolutely amazing, we prebooked tickets along with the Colosseum and Palatine Hill and it was definitely good value for money. There was so much to see we couldn't even do it all because our legs couldn't take any more! Definitely recommend.

Get a tour!. Of course, this is a highlight of Rome. It is difficult to understand what you are seeing unless you have a guide. I also recommend the transparency overlay books for the then and now pictures - it really helps!

A sight into the past. Good about Roman forum is that ticket price include Palatino and Colosseum (and it's valid for two days). The Roman forum gives you an idea of how they lived, they are ruins and no more; so not for everyone. But if you want a glimpse of the past, it's definitely worth it.Info: There are bathrooms, but no wheelchair access. You can buy food only outside.

Greta, in spite of lack of information.. The Roman Forum is perhaps the most important, neuralgic archeological site related to our current way of life for many reasons. Think of Juluis Ceasar, Cicero, Tiberius - you name it - the Forum encompasses all that great history.But if you don't want to wander around without really knowing what you are looking at, do your homework beforehand or get an audioguide at the entrance. The Forum surprisingly lacks adequate historic interpretation on site, so you may be unknowingly walking along, for example, were St. Peter was jailed. Same for the Palatine Hill.Remember, if you don't know their significance they may just look like a bunch os scattered stones.

Stunning!. To walk where once Julius Caesar. Augustus Caesar and all emperors who followed them walked and rules much of the then know world is an amazing feeling. Unfortunately much is in ruins but still walking there gives you an idea and feeling of the grandness of the place, in the old days. Go there and take a lot of pictures.

A lot to see. The Roman Forum is huge, you could easily spend hours walking around it. Although there were crowds, you can turn a corner and be completely alone, there is so much to see. A really interesting place to visit, well worth the trip!

Everything we expected. The forum was everything we thought it would be and enjoyed it even more with a tour through Eyes of Rome (Katie Farrar). We even received a bit fo an art history lesson from our guide who was very enthusiastic about all the sites we saw. Spectacular and beautiful, filled with history, this cannot be missed.

Use a guide or audioguide!. We used an audioguide which was helpful and interresting. This is one of those sites that you need help to understand. There are no signs telling you what you are looking at so you need help understanding the significance of the walls and ruins before you. If you are interested in history and archeology this is a good place to go, but if this is not something important to you you can look at most of the site from the road leading to the Colloseum, so you do not have to have "been" on top of the Forum unless this is interesting to you. It is included in the ticket price to the Colloseum though, and the Colloseum is a must see!

Rome wasn't built in a day. Take your time and wander through the ruins. Centuries of history are preserved (as much as possible) here - you don't realise the immense scale until you spend the whole day meandering through the whole area. Definitely get the audio guide.We got our day tickets after waiting in a queue for about 30 mins at the Via di San Gregorio entrance - much shorter than the queues outside the other entrances. Even better would be to buy them online beforehand.

Breathtaking. Included with the ticket to see the Colosseum, the Roman Forum is a site that cannot be missed. Whether walking through the forum or viewing it from above, it is absolutely spectacular. To see and walk through ruins that are 2,000 years old is definitely a privilege. History buff or not, anyone can appreciate the beauty of these architectural marvels. I visited in the summer, so it was quite busy and hot - but still worth it. If you go to Rome, make sure you give yourself a couple of hours to go through Palatine Hill and the forum.

Tour guide to maximise the experience.. We visited Palatine Hill & the Forum the day after with our Colosseum ticket. We had an awesome tour at the Colosseum and decided to get an audio guide for the Paltine Hill & Forum but it was possibly the worst audio guide we've had on our Europe trip. (I admit I had high expectations of this part of Rome & wish to have learnt more.) My recommendation is to just read the signage posted at various locations or get a tour guide if you really want to get a lot from it. A must see! It's incredible!

Loved the Forum. We entered into this area of Rome through the Palatine Hill, which we found fascinating. However, the Roman Forum was magnificent. The existing structures were spectacular in their scope and the whole area was steeped in history - the place where Cesar was buried, where the Vestal Virgins had resided, where the triumphant generals and troops returned, the first and last monuments erected defining the beginning and end of this period in Rome's history. The day was bright and the weather, although late December, was enjoyable. An experience not to be missed!

So much more................ On a recent visit to Rome we had picked up that the queue for the Forum is less daunting than the Colesseum and the ticket gives you access to both (on 2 consecutive days). However please remember that Italian method of organising queues is unique!!!! Anyway we only had to queue for about an hour and had a brilliant time wandering about the extensive site. There was so much to see and it was great to see the places that you had read about at school or on TV.Worth noting that there are no refreshment stands inside. Also we had a beautiful warm sunny day in December the lack of shade/cover would suggest that in summer or on wet days it would be less appealling.also ticket meant we walked into Colesseum next day without any queue!!!

Well worth it!. Well worth it. Make sure to allow enough time to have a thorough look around. We went with a tour group and while the tour guide had many stories and a great knowledge of the area, it was rather rushed and we missed out on seeing some parts. I will definitely return when in Rome next year.

Roman Forum. I visited the Roman Forum with family in April. We did not take a guided tour and chose to visit by ourselves. As I had been to the Forum on a previous holiday and re-read a lot of information before this visit, I did not feel that I missed out by not having a guide. Indeed it allowed the freedom to sightsee at your own pace and you can easily find your way around with a good guidebook that includes a map and some information about the Forum so you know what you are seeing. You can take photographs everywhere and make sure to take a hat / bottle of water in hot weather as there is not much shade. A little tip ... if you visit during Culture Week (as we did) the entry is free. A must see in Rome!

Ancient ruins of Rome!. As part of our "Roma Pass" we first saw the Colosseum and afterwards we walked over to the Roman Forum to see the ruins! This is very interesting as we witness what is left of the ancient city of Rome!

Too Tired to Care. I'm not proud to say that my visit to the Roman Forum was a waste. We were there for about an hour during an exhausting day tour, and I just didn’t have it in me to pay attention and appreciate where I was.A quick visit to Wikipedia will tell you more about the Forum than I can. All I remember is seeing a smaller, albeit an older version of the Arc de Triumph, walking down a sometimes uneven dirt road past a line of ancient buildings in various states of disrepair and restoration, and standing in a deserted town square. All the time, our guide’s voice hammering away in my ear through the radio headset, and the hot afternoon sun blaring in my face.My first piece of advice is to make sure you specifically want to see the Forum. Unless you’ve got some sort of passion for it, it’s just another bunch of ruins. The Pantheon and the Colosseum will satisfy any fleeting interest in Ancient Rome that you might have, whereas the Forum is more for the enthusiasts. And as for your enthusiasm, I really think you need a guided tour to get the most out of it.Secondly, make sure you’ve got the energy for it. We spent the entire day being marched from one landmark to another, and by mid-afternoon, we were completely drained. A fresh look at the Roman Forum should yield a much happier experience.Trust me, it’s not one to be jammed into a non-stop itinerary. Want to see it, take the time to see it, and enjoy it.

The Roman Forum. The Roman forum is one of the most beautiful sites I have ever seen.It has so much history attaced to it that it took us one entire morning with our audio guides to see the whole of it.Standing in the middle of these ruins makes you go back to the era when the romans were nature worshippers.You can almost feel the hand maidens coming in through the gardens to carry out fire worships in the temple of Venus.I could see Julus Ceaser andOctavius Ceaser striding down from the Colleseum to their private rooms.The Julia Church was a revelation where we saw all the artifacts belonging to that era displayed.The scarlet robes worn by the nobility are permenantly etced in stone in the headless status of a Court noble perhaps it is Julius Cesar.The entire experience was magicaland this was one site which truly tansported me back to the age of the Roman Emperors.The weather was excellent warm but with a cool breeze blowing.Ideal time of the year to visit this monument site.

History growing from earth. It's amazing how much history is buried in this piece of land. There is traces of three historic eras in Roman Forum and so much yet to be revealed and discovered.Save a morning or an afternoon to see all the Forum because it is so big and prepare your legs for a hike. My visit was in December so I recommend hot clothes because the temperatures are between 9ºC and 1ºC (at 4.30p.m. when dusk begins), but I believe that in the summer you'll need confortable and fresh clothes, hat and sun protector. There's some tree shadows but I believe they are not enough for so much visitors in the summer. Take water with you on winter or summer. You have a fountain (at least) near the Tito's Arch where you can refill your bottle. You don't have a bar or something like it where you can buy water or food so go prepared.When I visited the Forum I found four teams of archeologists working. It's very interesting to see the ruins coming out of the earth and all the methodological work around it. I think that the archeological work is a constant in that place.The Forum don't have an identification in everything that you'll see but I believe that some of those things they are also beginning to understand. It is like an huge 3D puzzle.You'll also find some areas closed to visits once they are under work/construction. So I think that if you visit the Forum in different years or with a months gap you'll find different areas to see. Unfortunately we couldn't some things like de Vespasian Temple.Of my visit I'd stand out the Cesar Tomb where, still today, people leave flowers, the Tito's Arch and the Septimius Severus Arch that has an amazing worked stone, the Curia (house of senate), the Romolo Temple.In the Palatine Hill (included in the visit of the Forum) don't miss the Augustus Residence and the Stadium where the roman athletes practiced for the Olympic Games. Also you can visit the "small" Palatino Museum where you can find some pieces that where found in the Palatino Hill.In the museum you'll find many copies of the original pieces once they are on the Capitoline Museum, but it's interesting to see gathered what was found exactly in that hill.In the Stadium is easy to find yourself picturing the athletes training in that space, it's a really interesting place.Use the maps that are all around to guide yourself and to realize what you have already seen and what is left. I think it's always something missing because there are so many things. It's a small town inside Rome. But these maps are really a good help.Near the ticket office you can rent an audio guide if you wish.Also, you have a combined ticket of the Forum&Palatine Hill and the Coliseum. We used the Roma Pass for both (it counts as one ticket).

Beware of new charges. We last visited the Forum a few years back and the entrance was free and easy. Now there is a charge of 12.50 Euros to go into the forum area (also includes mandatory charge for the Colosseum). Another sign that the Government is scraping fpr money wherever theycan find it...

wander back in time. Wear comfortable shoes and prepare to get dusty and sweaty if visiting in the summer, but it is well worth it. If traveling with kids, explain the history of the buildings that they are about to see....purchase a book that shows the Forum at its height with details of the historical events that occurred in each building. Notice the small enclosed site that is somewhat hidden and close to the arch...there may be a small group of people gathered there and flowers scattered nearby. It is not advertised, but this is the spot that Julius Caesar's body was cremated. Also ask a guard to point out the prison that housed 2 of Christ's disciples just before their murders (also not publicized). It is at the front of the Forum close to the Vittorio Emmanuel at the base of the glass museum. Also ask a guide or look in your book for the history of the symbols on the arch....fascinating!

Very interesting. Having bought a ticket with a guided tour of both here and the Colosseum we had an extremely interesting guided tour of the Forum with lots if interesting detail included. Found the tourore informative than the one at the Colusseum.

Walk into History. It was like walking back into time. Amazing structures and buildings fill the whole forum.I was surprised to find the location where Julius Caesar was cremated. Even the Senate building was still standing.It is a huge area, with cobbled streets....so do wear comfortable shoes.

worth the wait in line, take an audio guide. Your ticket is a combo ticket with the Form & the Colosseum. Unless you're able to get here at the crack of dawn to get in the Colosseum line I recommend waiting in line at the Forum because it's shorter. Once you have enjoyed the Forum you can walk over to the Colosseum and skip the outrageous 3-4 hour wait line because you already have your ticket from the Forum.The Forum in itself is great as well. Lots to see and such a big area, there's almost too much to take in. I recommend a guide or audio guide to appreciate what you're seeing. There will be people out front selling guided tours (usually around 13 euro pp), the site also sells an audio guide for around 5 euros. However, I recommend you download a free audio guide and take it with you to save a few euro - Rick Steve's has lots of great free audio guides you can download.

see the ruins. The Roman Forum is located next to the Colosseum. It is an area filled with arches, columns, temples and basilicas in ruins. You must use your imagination here to see what it looked like 2000 years ago when the Romans came here to see and be seen and to do business.

You must have a guide to see this. Walking through the Roman Forum truly is an incredible experience. The ticket is included with your ticket of the Colosseum. Since I was traveling with my college friends, we didn't want to hire a guide. Instead, I used my Trip Advisor offline app for the iPhone and followed one of the suggested itineraries for the Roman Forum, which worked out GREAT. Sure, we probably missed a lot of information, but we definitely learn a lot, for free! You have to get this app! It took us about two hours to follow it and totally worth it.

The Ancient Rome's center. The Roman Forum can be visited by buying the combo ticket with Colosseum and Palatine Hill. Even if the place is not very well preserved, you can still find some important ruins (but you must bring a guided book because there are no signs to tell you what every ruin is about). You must wear comfortable shoes as the pathways are not very smooth.

Magic of the Roman Empire. As I enter the Roman Forum just a 2 min walk from Colosseum I felt transported back to history. Its a humbling experience to walk down the awe inspiring ruins as it makes one realise that nothing is permanent in life. Even the most powerful empire lay in ruins!!Many people avoid Roman Forum as there quite a bit walking to be done. The time required is atleast an hour and a half. Many people have an aerial view and leave. I would suggest you walk down and past the monumental remains that was once a part of glorious history. You will be touched by its sheer beauty; magnificence and architectural brilliance of what ever is left. Hire a guide or take an audio guide.Its MAGIC!!

A walk through the ruins of Roman History. The first time I visited about 7 years ago, there was no charge to enter the Forum. But charge or not this is a place not to be missed. Firstly, it is very important to know a little of what you are visiting so a good guide book is indispensable. How about the eyewitness guide to Rome for starters. Why not read something of ancient Roman history before you go. Read about Romulus and Remus, about the Caesars, Julius, Augustus and Nero. Think about the intrigues, the poisonings and murders that happened around and in these ancient ruins, the place where Julius Caesar stood to address the crowds and where he was stabbed to death. The site of the Roman sennet. Go to the site of Augustus's house and look down into the great palaces and gardens where so much brutal and intriguing history happened. Gaze at the triumphal arches of Titus and Septimius Severus and read of their place in Roman history and imagine the cohorts of soldiers marching through them. Imagine the orators standing on the rostra begging the Romans to lend them their ears. Walk around the temple of Julius Caesar that marks the place of his cremation and wonder at the exploits of that great man. And after that there is still the house of the vestal virgins, the temple of Antonius and Faustina and much much more to consider. Fantastic, what a day out.

Beautiful grounds; impressive ruins. We visited the Roman Forum after touring the Colosseum. We didn't see nearly everything we'd like to see and plan a return visit to continue our tour. Ruins are not well marked so recommend an audio guide to use with the map of the site to allow you to move at your own pace. There's plenty of places to sit and enjoy the atmosphere and take in the georgeous views. Lots of people so be prepared, even in late September!

Unforgettable. If you can, get the guided tour with is about 5 EUR more expensive but totally worth it, there are guided tours in several languages and the guides provide an audio device to hear better what they say... our tour was in spanish and was simply excellent. Also, your entry fee will be good for the Roman Forum as well for 2 days... this is a must see attraction, you HAVE to go if in Rome...

Loved the History. I had read so much about Rome before my trip it was great to see the ruins of the Roman Forum. I had a small group guided tour (Through Eternity) and that made it so much more special as they explained everything to us, the history etc. Really made it more worth while. I saw so many other tourists walking around and looking at everything but it was learning the history about the different areas/ruins/columns/buildings that made it special for us.

If your a history buff.... You must see the roman forums. The area is not much anymore but there are still "traces" of pillars and posts here and there...but you get a real sense of where the building were and its great to walk where Ceasar himself walk once before

Sit & Dream. The Forum can be a little confusing as unlike Britain very little in the way of explanations are given at the site. We had a good guide book so were able to find our way around. However sometimes you can get carried away with the archeology and it is better to sit and just imagine what went on in the past. I found the garden of the Vestal virgins to be a haven of peace after the crowds in the forum. A very special place. I took lots of photos and then read up about what I had seen later. Just take in the atmosphere!

History. I liked that with the Roma pass we could get in to the Colosseum and Forum and spend a lot of time walking around. There are several cool buildings to see in the Forum area. A good first stop.

History laid before you.............. The Forum pretty much encapsulates everything you've seen, read or heard about Rome.2000 years of history laid out before you. If this doesn't move you, then get someone to check you're still breathing!Best to take a half day or more to fully take in everything the Forum has to offer. It literally is history at each step. I can't envisage too many places ANYWHERE that are so steeped in history, drama and mythology. To have this and the Colosseum within 5 minutes of one another is mind blowing.You don't need my words to tell you what the Forum is like.... go for yourself and feel part of history.
Awesome!. Must see. Buy the guide book the guides use which shows pictures of the forum as it is now and what it looked like 2000 years ago. Also, take drink and food with you. Limited facilities.

Stunning!. Tip: Go to the Roman Forum and buy your ticket (12€ per adult, free for children - valid for the forum, colliseum and Palatine Hill and valid for 2 days). You can then enter the colliseum without queuing. Amazing history. Take water - there is nothing for sale once inside but you can fill your water bottle from the drinking fountains.

The center of ancient Rome and of the Roman civilization, where everything happened. Not to be missed.. The center of ancient Rome and of the Roman civilization, where everything happened. Not to be missed. My favorite spots in the Forum are the temple of Divus Julius, where you can see the very place where body is was cremated and where Romans still place flowers: the house of the Vestales with the peaceful garden. I would also like to give two tips. The first I recommend to get the audiovisual: it changes the perception of the visit, as you get valuable information and you can see monuments as they used to be. The second is to visit the Palatine. It is the place where the imperial palace and the houses of the rich were built. It is less famous than the Forum but for some reason even more attractive. Do not miss the house of Augustus on the Palatine! Finally, buy the combined ticket which includes the Coloseum: you may use it even the following day and you will miss the very long queue. You should allocate at least three hours to enjoy the full visit.

A must see- and don't forget the tour!. The Forum is a must do in Rome and all the prior reviews give the highlights. I have to add a recommendation to catch the guided tour in English offered by the Forum. It only costs 5€ extra for the 1 1/2 hour tour AND you get to skip the long line for your 12€ ticket (which also includes the Coliseum and a 2nd day).  Also be sure to bring water with you - there is no where inside to buy any and it gets HOT. Also there is no food/snacks available within the Forum and picnicking is not allowed as of Oct 1.

History in front of you. The Forum is disappointing in that it is basically ruins and a lot of it was caused by the Romans themselves as recently as the 30's. That said a little imagination and you are walking where the Roman legions marched and Emperors ruled. The sites that you had read about or heard about or seen in films are right there in front of you and make you realise how powerful Rome became and how far they fell.Wear good shoes and take some water. Take your time and let your thoughts drift back to days of Rome.
Forum Romano and Palatino Hill. Combined with Palatine Hill these ancient ruins were not very crowded and really gave you a feel for what it would have been like in ancient times.

Magnificent ruins. At first, we plan to do a quick visit at the ruins area but ended up spending half day there because the place is quite a huge area to cover & has lot of interesting structures to see. Avoid going in the afternoon because it is quite hot. There are many high grounds which can be a great place to take panoramic view of the ruins. We stayed to view sunset from Roman Forum & it was overwhelming.

Take a step back in history. We saw the Roman Forum after our Colosseum tour. Entry into both the Forum and Palatine Hill is included with the Roma Pass as part of admission with the Colosseum. We forgot to get an audio guide when we entered but thank goodness that we had Rick Steves' book. It really helped us since the Forum is not well marked. Placing descriptions by the ruins would be a nice touch. You could easily spend hours here taking in the scenery and using your imagination.

Avoid the audio guide. First off - your admission ticket includes the Colosseum and is available for two days - and you'll need it. The Forum and Palatine Hill took us five hours and we still didn't see everything.We hired an audio guide - but it was perplexing to say the least. The marked route led us to a vineyard (!) in the middle of the site - obviously the wrong way but it had a wonderful view of the Colosseum and an archaeological dig of Nero's Domus Aurea was going on - so getting lost was a somewhat pleasant experience. However, once on the right track, the audio guide posts are not numbered so you have to figure it out yourself with the help of map which lacked detail. I would suggest going with a real-life guide to save the frustration.Many of the wonderous parts of the site were blocked - the Arch of Septimus Severis was undergoing restoration at the time of our visit in early October 2012 and could only be viewed from outside a fence. The Temple of Antonius and Faustina is covered with scaffolding and inaccessible. However, this did not detract from the site as a whole. Especially poignant was the site of the cremation of Julius Caesar which, after 2000 plus years, had flowers placed there.There are no cafes inside the Forum but there are plenty of places to fill your water bottle - and you'll need to as it is hot, dusty work walking around. There are clean, recently built restrooms near the Temple of Saturn. Wear comfortable shoes which have some grip as the marble is slippery in places. Also, don't miss the museum on Palatine Hill which contains treasures excavated from the site, such as busts of Imperial 'superstars' such as Agrippina II and Nero.Get there on opening, expect it to be tiring, take plenty of rest breaks in the shade and you will thoroughly enjoy your day (and it will take a day!).

THE Site for History Lovers. The amazing ruins of ancient Rome - a must-see for history lovers. Take the time to wander through and see the details up close or - like us - view the Forum from above from several vantage points.

Keeping focus in the Forum. This is a historical hotspot which is often beyond the comprehension of those of us whose history begins in 1776. It is, certainly, a ruin. You have to bring your imagination, a guidebook or better yet a guide to explain it to you. No visitor to Rome should miss this and the additional walk over to the neighboring sites. Reading up on the history of Rome will help you. In any case, it is worth it to just find a place to sit and pretend it is long, long ago.

Full of History, Empty of Information. It is a amazing place, so full of history. The Forum born with the firsts kings of Rome, 700 BC, was the hearth place of the republic and empire. You really feel the power of the place, but is in ruins now.You have to take a guide (a book or a person) to fully enjoy the ride, it will make a total different experience. Without one it's hard do understand or figure out the ancient builds and monuments. Even with a book isn't easy find yourself and to discover what you are seeing.I liked very much, but is because before my visit I had studied the place and knew the history. After my visit, I wish that everyone enjoyed the place as I saw it, so I decide to develop a iPhone App that allow you "see how the place was in the past". If you go to Rome and to Roman Forum (and has one iPhone, iPod or iPad) be my guest and do download "The Roman Forum Virtual Guide" in the App Store to use there. I hope you enjoy. Regards, Giuliano.

Hot in august. There is hardly any shadow on the Forum Romanum. So take a hat, umbrella and enough water to enjoy your visit ! There are some fountains you can drink from and find some refreshing. Be sure you read about the Forum befor you start your visit, or take an audio guide. There is so much to see and to experiance, but you will miss out on al lot if you do not know what to look for. We bought our tickets the evening before our visit. But in august, they say, it is not as crowded as in springtime. We did not have to wait in line, no queues. The visit took us more than 4 hours and on the Forum romanum, there is nothing to eat.
History. One of the reasons we stayed at the Hotel Nerva because it was so close to the Roman Forum...just fantastic to see history up close.

Fascinating. Don't miss a visit to the Forum while in Rome. We found it better to use a professional guide (David) who really helped us understand the importance of the area. He gave us a great history of the region and referred us to other worthwhile sites. Otherwise, you are left wandering around lots of ruins with no idea of what they are or why they are significant.

Make the Most of your inclusive ticket!. your ticket to the closseum, also covers entry to the roman forum and pallentine hill, and is valid for 2 days. To jump the queues at the Colosseum (legitimatly ) see the roman forum or palantine hill first - then walk through. Also worth seeing at night when it is lit up.

Free tours. You get free entry to the forum with your colosseum ticket so we walked over and spent a couple of hours exploring the ruins. There is not much of a plan, guide or explenation on the ruins so we pigy backed on a couple of tour groups and got filled in on the particulors;)

Foro Romano 2012. It is a nice archeological place. Till this day they excavate there. Finding things from BC and AD. These were the courts where the romans use to have parades also when they defeated countries at war.

Rome caput mundi!!. Rome is one of the most beautiful town in the world!! i took the tour to the Colosseum and Roman Forum. So impressive!! So fascinating!! The guide was very helpful and take me and my friend back to the Roman Empire period. Then we walk alot all around and discovered the main sights in the town. The only thing i can advise is this: if you go to Rome,make sure you stay four days at least. There is so much to see! Just be careful to choose where to eat. Unfortunately my friend and i followed a few recommendations but we got disappointed. Anyway you can not miss this place in the world. Bellisima!!!

Not Much Left. While there really aren't many edifices left in the Forum, you can still imagine how magnificent it used to be. and the Forum is surrounded by other ruins that place it in context. Don't make this the number one destination, but it would be good to see in a drive-by.

Amazing place, complete lack of information. The Roman Forum is an amazing area, full of the ruins of what used to be the center of Rome. Unfortunately the audio guide we had wasn't very good at explaining what we were looking at and the information it gave was very dry. We didn't know what we should be looking at when the audio guide was talking about the various ruins, there was no signs or descriptions anywhere about any of the buildings or artifacts on the site, so it was hard to know what anything was and who had built what.I'd definitely recommend you visit the place, but perhaps take a guide-book and/ or do some initial reading before going as it'll help you understand what you're looking at.

History!. What a place!, it is amazing, wonderful and impressive. You need to go to feel the grandiosity of the constructions. The ticket to access it is valid for two days and includes the colosseum, so you don't need to hurry to see the place in one day.

Special Place but bit disappointing. Foro Romano is a place where ancient Rome power was located. Being precise, Foro romano is where supposedly lor od different temples and basilicas where located. When I say supposedly is because for the most of it you will only see remnants of what once was there. Quite difficult to imagine how that place was. Few monumnets standing up in a recognizable way.

Quite boring actually. We bought an audio tour for the Roman Forum and were very disappointed. It was sooo boring and hard to hear/understand. Eventually we turned it off and just wandered between all the "old rocks".There are more interesting things in Rome (in my opinion)

A must to see. 3 years ago,in september, we visited the Roman forum -we came as suggested very early in the morning so we could easely walked through all those ruins without suffering of the heat . We tooked an audio guide and I had a book explaining almost everything on the site- we had a great time . This year, we came back in september with some friends. We showed up first thing in the morning. We already had our tickets since we went to the Colosseo the day before. We had to wait in line to take some audio guide . Unfortunately, the boot to buy the tickets and the audio guide are the same ...not to efficient! --There are several options to visit the Roman forun: a visit guided, the audio guide or the video guide ---We took the audio guide remembering that's what we did 3 years ago - BUT I didnt have my book explaining every thing, They gave you a plan of the forum and it shows you all the interest points . Unfortunately, the interest points are not showed on the site--- So sometimes, you are at No 1 and you dont have a clue if you are seeing the right thing..you are always guessing..... Knowing that , I would definitely opted for the audio guide which cost 1 euros more than the audio guide... A visit to the roman forum needed some guidance - either a guide, a book and an audio/video guide . Wear some good walking shoes, put some suntan lotion , bring some water and enjoy a magnificent time in those ruins

Old Stones Speaking Loud. Impressive, the voice of Darth Vader echoes in ones head when for the first time gazing upon the vast slopes of the Roman Forum against the Palatine hill, birthplace of ancient Rome. To walk upon the Via Sacra past the temple of Romus & Remulus, to pass the place where Julius Caesar was burned after his assassination (there are still flowers to mark the place), to wander in the most secretive and forbidden gardens of the Vestal Virgins, to speak and reason in the ancient Curia where the senators and caesars of Rome once sat almost 2000 years ago, to repose in the shadow of Saturn's temple, Castor & Pollux, the temple of the Julii, Caesar Augustus his triumph arch after defeating the actual Marc Anthony and Cleopatra in the battle of Actium, and so so much more... It is overwhelming. You haven't been to Rome, if you didn't pass by the Forum Romanum, birthplace of our modern western civilisation.

Get a Guide. If you are approached outside the Forum by a guide who offers you a 40 minute tour and a chance to jump the line, do it. The tour was well worth the few Euros more that you pay over General Admission. Frankly, even with a good guidebook, which we had, I don't think we would have gotten a tenth of the insight that we received. As much as I enjoyed our visit to the next-door Colosseum, this is a more interesting site, worth the time to explore in full. Don't forget to spend at least 30 minutes or so up on the Palatine Hill to see the Stadio, Garden, etc. Its part of your admission ticket. You need to allot at least 2 hours to a full visit, including the tour which turned out to be more like an hour.

Easy to lose track of time when walking through history. We visited the Colosseum, Palatino, Roman Forum, and Pantheon all in one day. The roman forum was my favorite, with so many ancient ruins to explore.

Ancient ruins. These ruins best come to life if you have a guide to explain everything. Listening to the history of the Forum while standing right in the middle of it is an experience not to be missed.
Lots of history. You must go with a guide - even a guidebook will not suffice. Otherwise just another place with a lot of ruins. The place is rich with history. Every ruin has a story behind it.

Well worth it, but take a Tour. Really enjoyed seeing all of the ruins of the Forum. But I wish that we had taken a Tour to be able to hear more of what we were looking at. We tried to do it with a book, but would have enjoyed it more if we had a guide.

Go with a guide!. A great area with tons of history and beautiful areas. We went with the Discover Rome tours (the ones that jump you from outside the Coliseum) and were not disappointed with the tour.
Informative and fun, the guide provided us with a good explanation and route through the impressive forum area.

Great - guide recommended. We bought a combined ticket for the Roman forum, palatine hill and colosseum, of which we enjoyed the forum most. We used Rick Steves audio guide and it suited us perfectly - if you're really into history and want all the details you may want something else. Overall, the ruins are truly fascinating.

An Ancient Roman Capital. The Roman Forum (Forum Romanum) is located next to the Colosseum. You can visit both the Colosseum and the Roman Forum in one day. I would suggest paying a visit to the Tabularium at the western end of the Forum. It is a record office that was the warehouse for official State archives, and there is an excellent panoramic view over the Forum. Exploring the Forum involves a lot of walking and is hard to find a shaded spot during the hot summer weather. Wearing a hat and comfortable shoes with bottles of water are recommended. The Roman Forum is an ancient social, business and political center similar to the capitals of modern countries. It was originally a marketplace and later developed with several government buildings. It became a power center of Rome for centuries. The Roman Forum today is an area of ruins of temples, arches and basilicasIt was not until the 18th century that the Forum was rediscovered, and the process to restore the ancient ruins was started. The restoration brought this long-standing historical site back to life. The site includes the temples of Concord, Vespasian, the Porticus of the Dei Consentes on the west, the Temple of Saturn, Basilica Iulia, the Temple of Castor and Pollux on the south, the Temple of Vesta and the Regia on the east, and the Basilica Aemilia and Curia Iulia on the north.

A major disappointment. Even with a guide book and the Rick Steves Roman guide, this place was very hard to picture or understand. We actually went back a second time and viewed it from the Palatine Hill to get a better overview and that still didn't help too much. Mainly everything is virtually ruins- we expected some more structures to be recognizable, but other than the Arches, it was just many piles of Rocks. We ran into another couple from the US on our second visit and they were as puzzled as we were about what we were seeing.I guess that theoretically this is a "have to see" in Rome, but I think the Colloseum, Pantheon and Circus Maximus were much more representational.

Take a walk through history.. It would be great to be able to time travel and see what really went on here in its heyday, this is a fascinating place and just walking through these ruins you can let your imagination run riot!Do some reading upon this site before you go and you will get so much more out of your visit.The weather was attrocious on the day we went so I don't feel we done it justice, felt we could have stayed longer to reflect on the events of the past.

Sprawling but magnificent. This is a vast site and incorporates the homes of the Caesars on Paletine Hill. As a Ruined Roman site it is absolutely fascinating and the murals still to be seen on the walls of Livia's house are just breathtaking. Be warned though, there is a lot of walking involved on rough ground so wear comfortable, sensible shoes and carry some kind of sun protection as it is very exposed and hot in the summer!
A humbling experience. You don't have to be a history buff to appreciate the significance of this site. It literally takes your breath away thinking of the events that took place as you walk around.

Ancient Rome Small Group Tour. My family had enjoyed the small group tours. It was affordable, not rushed by a bigger crowd and easier to interact with the tour guide. I really liked our tour guide, Francesca. Before the tour she had learnt that my mom is 84 years old and she really took care of her. Francesca has a degree in Roman Archeology. She was well organized and a good speaker. It was very worthwhile to have such a knowledgeable tour guide to walk us through the history and the hierarchy of the colosseum. The tour of Roman Forum was equally rewarding. We walked on the sacred road and Francesca painted us a vivid picture so that we could imagine that the place was for centuries the center of Roman public life.
Gladiator was here. Walk around the ruins and you will perceive how small and insignificant we are in front of History. I suggest to visit at sunset

Walk through the cradle of western civilization. Much of the ancient center of Rome has been covered by river silt over the ages and recently excavated. Suggestion, get a tour guide to explain all of the ruins, or do tremendous research in advance. Ruins are not marked, so you need to know what you are seeing to appreciate it.

Interesting site...take the guided tour. Guided tour made the visit more worthwhile in terms of giving you some perspective and historical information. Tours are assembled through the entrance to The Forum...we purchased our tickets for the Colloseum here as well (although on the side closest to the Circus Maximus, which is Palatine Hill--a separate "attraction" although connected to The Forum). You save money buying the combined tix for Forum/Colloseum and, you also can skip the lines at the Colliseum--which are quite long. Tickets for the tour of the Forum are purchased at the entrance to The Forum (so you can enter/purchase tix at Palatine Hill and walk through to The Forum to buy the tour of the Forum--which again saves you time on a line). Whatever you do, purchase tix here (Forum or Palatine Hill--but Palatine Hill will definitely be less crowded) or you will likely be stuck on a line at The Colliseum.

Not to be missed. Although crowded, the Forum (I should say forums, since there are several) should not be missed. One of my students once described it as a pile of rubble and I wanted to inflict corporal punishment. You do need a map to know what you're looking at but put yourself in the footsteps of Julius and Augustus Caesar, Brutus and Cassius and so forth and let your imagination wander as you do. Try to do so near dusk when the light hits the monuments so well. And don't hurry it!

Just being in this place gives you chills. Tha ancient ruins at the Forum give you a sense of life in this proud progressive place where the senate of Rome met. The garden of the Vestile Virgins remain somewhat intact and you can imagine life there for the chosen few. It was very hot when we were there so plan to go early so you don't have to suffer in the heat of the day. Since the Coloseum is adjacent tot the Forum we visited both in the same day. It was too hot to linger long at the Forum and we opted to skip Palentine Hill due to the extreme heat. In retrospect, depending on how thorough you want to be in your visit of these you might consider taking 2 days here in this are if the weather is too hot. There is no shade to escape the intense sun.

History before your eyes. What a sight magnificent. Get your ticket from the entrance to the Roman Forum about 200 yards away. for 12 Euro This lets you into both areas and for two days. You miss the ques this way.

A different world. Walking through the Roman Forum was a completely different experience, it is like walking through history. The ruins are incredible and you could easily spend quite a bit of time there wandering around.

Roman forum. We bought our combined tickets from the Palatino which allowed us entry to the Palatino, Roman Forum and the Colosseum for €12 per person! The ticket is valid for 2 days as well so you can take your time, though we did all three in one day. The forum is an incredible site to see, walk through and to sit in and appreciate!

A few tips for enjoying the Forum.. 1. The entrance is on Via dei Fori Imperiali halfway between the Colosseum and the Victor Emmanuel Monument. 2. If you can, buy a combo ticket online at www.ticketclic.it this will include the Colosseum and it will help you bypass the long lines at the Colosseum.3. If it is a hot day, take water and consider an umbrella. There is NO shade. We were dying after 40 minutes. There is a fountain to refill bottles near the Arch of Titus. Nothing is sold inside. 4. Rent either their audio guide, hire a guide or download Rick Steve's free audio guide. We used Rick Steve's it was OK and lasted around 45 minutes. If you are a history buff you probably want something more detailed than Rick Steve's. Nothing will make sense if you don't have some form of a guide.5. Do the Colosseum first, plenty of shade there, after baking in the sun at the Forum you won't feel like doing much else.6. It does make good sense to do both the Forum and the Colosseum together. They are right next to each other.

Impressive and thought-provoking. You really do need to take your time to appreciate this archeological site. We waited about 20 minutes in the heat of August for tickets to get in - if you are under 26 and a member of the EU, you can get a discount but they insist on seeing a passport for identification - we saw numerous young people being denied the discount because they didn't bring ID with them. The wait is only 20-30 minutes in line to get tickets once we found the entry - we heard it was a much longer line at the Coloseum, so get your tickets at the Forum. The tickets give you entry to both the Forum and the Colosseum. It was a very hot August day, but amazing to see so many historical sites and imagine how life was at the Forum in Ancient Rome. We were very moved by the site of the Vestal Virgins, ringed by headless statues but with the beautiful innner ponds intact with flowers where these young women sworn to chastity for 30 years served as priestesses guarding the adjacent temple flame. Fascinating to see the preserved site where Julius Ceasar's body burned for 7 days after his death, and the Arch of Titus which amazingly celebrated the destruction and looting of Jerusalem - so very moving. There are the ruins of the Roman court of justice here too - built on a vast scale. Many christian places of worship were modelled on this great hall of justice, including St. Peter's Basicllica at the Vatican, which you can see has to two wide side ailes and the centre nave, just as the ruins of the palace of justice have at the Forum. This is a site where it is best to read up ahead or follow a guided or audio tour, in order to understand what you are seeing and what used to be there. Just wish we could better picture in our minds how it really must have been two thousand years ago. So much history - not to be missed!

Ancient, good to visit but tiring. have atleast 4-5 hours allotted to this. You will get tired and it is gigantic in size. Along with the Colosseum and Palatino Museum it costs about 12Euros..better to go early morning to avoid the warm afternoon sun

Captivating ruins just read your ticket carefully. Ran out of time to view this properly on our first attempt – we went inside but only for about 30 minutes. Returned the next day but again fairly late around 4pm as had just been to the Vatican. We got to the turnstile but tickets were rejected even though the passes were valid for 2 days? Turns out they had introduced a new rule recently where the dual tickets are valid for 2 days but for only 1 entrance to the Forum/Palatine areas and the same for entry to the colosseum. It was written in very small text at base of ticket but we were never warned of this. We protested but it was no good. Luckily as this was the last admission (4pm) for the day a tour guide kindly gave us a spare ticket and the attendant then turned a blind eye and let us both in. We had an hour which was just enough time to walk through the areas we missed earlier.

The Eternal City , ROME. Well i have been to Rome so many times but never get tired of the ruins and the forum , they even have the exact spot located at the senate where JULIUS CAESAR was stabbed on the IDES OF MARCH , march 15th , i really loved world history so that's why i remember all this stuff and once i get back to LA i will post photos of all my many destinations . i hope all the people who read my reviews enjoy and learn from them , as you cann see i love traveling and its so much fun meeting other people and learning about other customs , that's one reason i perfer to travel alone . also the catacombs are very close and if i remember right i think its free and right besides it it the Roman Forum built around the first century ad , i think it took 8 years to complete , right near by is the Arch of Titus , so all and all it is quite an adventure , just down Via Cavour and you are there , again trip advisor doesn't go back far enough for an accurate date of the last time i was there , one thing though i always travel off season , better prices less waiting around at all the attractions and the prices are always better and Roma can get very hot and humid in the summer , will post pictures later

Amazing. If you have any interest in ancient history or history in general and find yourself in Rome, the Forum is a must. I'm American, and we just don't have any ancient sites on this scale in the States, so I was pretty overwhelmed (I'm pretty sure any Europeans observing had no trouble guessing where I was from. I might as well have been wearing a fishing hat and a fanny pack). Even though it's pretty delapidated, the place still looks amazing to me. Now I was with a group who hired a guide, which was fine, but as long as you know a bit about it you should have no problem enjoying the Forum on your own.

A piece of the World History. Heart of the Roman Republic and the Roman Empire, the Roman Forum is probably the most interesting place for seeing the roots of the Western history. Far from the bright of that golden age, 2000 years later there are still many surviving buildings: the Temple of Cesar, the Temple of Saturn, the Arch of Septimius Severus, the Regia, the Temple of Vesta among others, all with different grades of conservation. The visit, that includes the Palatine and the Colosseum in the same ticket, is really unforgettable. There were dozens of facts happened there, so a guide could help you a lot.

A delight to tour. Download the Rick Steve audioguide (it's free!) and wander around the Roman Forum. He does an excellent job of guiding you around via his map and guide and you can also feel like an amateur archaelogist wandering through the ruins. Of all the sites in Rome, this really seems to have the ghosts of ordinary and extraordrinary Romans wandering past you. Also marvel at the height difference between the ruins and the present-day Rome.

Eroded too much to appreciate. I had been looking forward to visit the Forum in particular but was bitterly disappointed by what I saw - or lack thereof. Judging by other reviewers I can tell that I'm in the minority and certainly it didn't help that we didn't go with a guide. I think to make sense of anything that you see in the Forum, you'd certainly need some kind of guide/audio tour. Most of the ruins were so eroded that they were little more than nubs in the dry earth - no matter how imaginative you are, there is simply not enough left to reconstruct in your mind's eye how it might have looked. I personally felt that these ruins were in such a bad state, that the whole area did not reflect good value for money. If you want Roman ruins, go elsewhere.

Fantastic. Julius Caesar was murdered and cremated here, the Vestal Virgins lived there. Constantine built this, Trajan's famous column is in full sight over there. Here's the Rostra, where Mark Antony gave Caesar's funeral oration, and Cicero spoke. The shops and markets from Trajan's time are across the road, and the Victor Emmanuel monument is round the corner.Get your ticket the evening before you intend to visit - thus avoiding lengthy queues. We entered by the Via San Gregorio entrance, onto the Palatine Hill and down to the Forum - again avoiding most people who enter from the Via dei Fori Imperiali. A 12 Euro ticket is good for two days. A couple of hundred metres from the V. S. Gregorio entrance, in the opposite direction to the Colosseum, is the Circus Maximus - or what little remains of it.Do not forget your guidebook. Many of the Forum ruins are not labelled very well, and you'll be surprised what significant buildings you'll walk straight past without a map.The Colosseum is right next door, as is the Capitol and Piazza Venezia an the other end. All within easy walking distance.Take water with you - the roadside vendors charge 4 Euros for a small bottle, and the same for a small scoop of ice cream. Toilets in the Colosseo Metro station.

To be seen in winter or spring. You could spare one full day for this place, but you wouldn't. Thus, have a great breakfast, get some snacks and lots of water. Get one audio guide for each person (if you're there with a group). Spend your morning there till noon (maybe a bit more). Then you might enjoy it. And DON'T do any of these in AUGUST. You don't want to be wandering around in a dead city (Roman Forum in Rome is huge)..under the burning sun. Lots of history, legends, myth....just like a journey in time...you can even see the first systematic pieces of the Roman alphabet...but NOT in AUGUST. Don't go there tired. This should be the first thing you do in the morning. For the rest of the day, go shopping, eat delicious food at some nearby restaurants, and so on, but the Forum and another huge attraction like the "Colosseum" might be a bit too much for a day. Yet, amazing history...I didn't add any photos...there are millions online...
Amazing. Loved the history and feel of the Forum, particularly, Pallentine (sp?) Hill. Amazing views.Lots of walking so waer comfortable shoes!

Most Amazing Place I Have Ever Been. The Roman Forum is the most amazing place I have ever been! It is so huge that it would take days to see the entire thing. I recommend going on a tour with a guide, which usually lasts 1 - 1 1/2 hours, then spend another 1 - 2 hours exploring it on your own. Make sure you stop by the House of the Vestal Virgins, which has some of the most beautiful flowers.

It is the ruins. The Roman Forum is located between the Coloseum & Vittorio Emanuele II monument in Piazza Venezia, Rome, Italy.This place was once the heart of the late Roman Empire. It was a public square where People were having meetings. Today, the place is almost destroyed. Columns and stone blocks are all that remain of some temples. You should keep with you a map of the forum with an audio guide to have some idea of what it was as there are no useful signs around. Good walking shoes are recommended with sufficient water to drink and light snacks to eat during your visit.
