Opens from 9 am to 6pm, you have to buy a combined tickets for euro 12 for entry into the forum, Colosseum and palatino . Take blue B line metro to reach there.

Lot's of history. We toured the Roman Forum as part of a tour we booked for the Colosseum. We spent about an hour and a half walking around the Forum, my feet crying the entire time. The number one suggestion I can give to you is make sure you wear comfortable shoes. The stone paths here are uneven and unforgiving on your feet. Pair that with the Rome sun in July and we wanted to take cover in the shade every chance we got. If you don't tolerate the heat well, you may not enjoy the slow pace of a guided tour. RIck Steves audio guides are a great way to learn about what you are seeing so give those a try if you have an iphone/ipad/ipod. As everyone says, there are water fountains where you can fill a water bottle to drink, or dump it over your head like I did.

A walk through roman history. A long walk to start with , but its well worth the visit . All that you will see is ruin. The Roman Forum is the public life of ancient times. I would recommend to walk through this with a guide as they will explain the life and each of these structures. Note that once you purchase the ticket for The Colosseum this too is included as it is a part of the same tour. Cold spring water is avalible at this place so remember to fill your bottles!

The Roman Forum. This is well worth a visit and if you have bought a ticket for the Colosseum then it will permit you entrance to the Foro Romano, Palatino and Mostra. The Foro is just across the road from Colosseo so no problem getting there.On the day we visited the weather was brilliant, sunny and hot, so be warned as there is very little shade once you are inside. Drinking water is available at various points at the site. Make sure you come well prepared with a bottle that can be refilled as it is an extensive site and you will need to keep hydrated.It's amazing how some of the old buildings here are so well preserved. There are good views over Rome from the higher places and a brilliant Octagonal Garden.Toilets are very few and when we were there there were long queues.

A must. I guess you must see Roman Forum when you are here :-) Even if I think Pompeji is much better! One good thing is that there are several places where you can refill your waterbottle with fresh cold water. Best view over the Forum is from Capitolum.

Walking through time. Waiting in line to get tickets under the swelting heat of a July morning in Rome was awful - we even thought about forgetting the whole thing. But, we got a ticket which included a visit to the Colesseum which meant we did not need to line up there. The line up to buy tickets for these attractions was longer at the Colesseum so it is better to wait in line at the Roman Forum. Once you get in you are outside, still under the swelting heat, but it's easy to begin dreaming about life back in ancient Rome. Worth a visit. Bring lots of water. You can refill the bottle at the water fountains on the grounds (even though its hot outside the water was refreshingly cold).

A step back in time. Going to The Roma Forum was like stepping back in time. It was amazing to see that the ruins have lasted this long. Just stand there and let you mind wander and imagine what it looked like 2000+ years.

Astonishing. You cannot visit Rome without seeing the Forum.We entered with a tour and then stayed for hours as there was so much to see. The size itself is overwhelming and mind boggling.I don't mean to use so many superlatives but there is no other way to try and convey how magnificent it is. One of the most amazing places I have visited. Worth the entry fee- you will not regret it.

Impressive "left overs". The Roman Forum used to be the grandiose downtown of Ancient Rome. When the Empire fell, so did it. The only power remaining in the city was that of the Catholic Church. And, then, the ruins were not so old and tourism wasn't such a booming industry. So, most of was left was scavenged to build new monuments... Christian monuments: churches and statues, mostly. What we see now, is what remained under ground, concealed from lazy scavengers' eyes, or what couldn't be taken apart for some reason (rope marks on some columns attest that these guys DID try). So, don't forget to bring your... (no, not your credit card!) your imagination! Even as it stands today after so many centuries of recycling efforts, it is somewhat impressive, and the closest anyone can be to walking through the capital of the Roman Empire.On the practical side, visitors get a ticket that covers the Forum, the Colosseum and the Palatine Hill. You may get the ticket for free as part of the Roma Pass: free entrance to 2 attractions is included, you have to choose where and when to use them; using one of them here is reasonable as it is one of the most expensive attraction fees in town.

Roman Forum - a glimpse into ancient Rome. This was the pinnacle of my Rome trip. I would not have missed it for anything. There are personal guides that give great info on each ruin. The guy with the British accent (Robert?) had a tour going through while we were there. He seemed knowledgeable and friendly. We used the Rick Steves book, which gave a good tour. I believe he RS even has a downloadable audio tour to walk you through with more in depth info.

The Roman Forum with Roman Odyssey. The Forum is incredible, a must-see if you're in Rome. We were in a small group, a half day excursion that included the Colliseum, with Julia from Roman Odyssey. I would highly recommend Julia and the company as a whole. Julia really made the whole thing come to life with her extensive knowledge of the Roman Empire... a highlight of our whole European vacation... thank you soooo much!!!

Loved it. My wife and I really enjoyed our visit to the Roman Forum and Palatino. Wear comfy shoes and drink lots of water - we drank the water coming from the fountains that can be found around the Forum, though some people were very cautions about it, we didn't get sick or anything like that.

Bring a Guide Book. This is my 3rd trip to Rome and I never had the opportunity to walk through the Forum. We decided to walk through it on our own and if I had not brought a guide book with me, we would have been lost. There is a lot to see and nothing is labeled. I had a teen with me and it still took up two hours to see it all. If you are there in the summer, like I was, bring your water with you. There are fountains but no place to buy water once you are in. Bottled water outside the entrance was going for 4 euros. We bought our water near our hotel at a market, six bottles for 1.80. You can enter/exit at two locations, one by the Colosseum and the other through a side street, Via Dei Fori Imperiali. The entrance fee of 12 euros gets you into the Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. The only bathroom I found was at the entrance near the Colosseum.

A Good Map or Book Guide Will Bring the Magic Alive Here!. The Forum isn’t very big. It’s easy to see it in roughly an hour. Just be careful with your footing as the paths are serious ankle-twisters! Please take a map of the site so you’ll be able to identify the ruins, or else you may be disappointed and bored. The highlights for me were the arches and also the Curia—former home of the Senate. It’s very dark in there to help preserve the interior. Inside, you’ll find some fantastic mosaic tiled floors and some carvings and wall mosaics. Very nice! It gets stuffy in there, however—very bad air flow.If you plan on seeing the Coliseum, Palatine Hill & Forum in one day, I'd advise that you visit in the order listed. After seeing the Coliseum, you'll exit behind the Arch of Constantine. Don't go back to the Via dei Fori Imperiali, which you'd likely take to access the Coliseum. Instead, take the road to the left of the Coliseum exit (Via San Gregorio) and go upwards to the lesser known entrance of the Palatine Hill. There should be either no line there or a very tiny one. When you are finished with the Palatine Hill, you can enter the Forum directly without reentering any lines outside. Go down the ankle-twisting original stone path carefully! You'll be facing in the direction of the Coliseum on this path and enter the Forum by the Arch of Titus.I booked my online reservations through OmniTicket before my trip: the Coliseum, Forum, and Palatine Hill three-in-one ticket. It cost 13.50 Euro per ticket for all three sites and no wait in line. There's no signs or separate entry area for the three-in-one ticket, so just go to the area designated for the Roma Pass, raise up your printed-out ticket, and the guards will let you in.

A Historical Pile of Bricks. Not much to see ,but ruins. If that's your thing then you probably will be happy. Get yourself one of the guide books with the plastic overlays. Then at lest if you lack imagination (like me) you can see what the Forum used to look like.

So Much History & So Many Ruins. The Roman Forum is a massive area chuck full of Roman ruins. We walked through it ourselves and enjoyed it, but taking tour or reading up on its history before hand is helpful, so that you know what each monument is and it doesn't just blend in with all the rest. Absolutely stunning.

Historic!. We bought the tickets to the Roman forums to avoid the lineup at the Coliseum. The wait at the ticket counter took us about 20 minutes, but it didn't really feel that long.The forum itself is filled with history, and I would highly recommend getting some kind of guide, whether by audio or by book. I used the Tripadvisor guide to get some more information about the things we were looking at.It's a good stroll and you can easily spend an hour here before going over to the Coliseum or the Palatine Hills.

Amazing to walk amongst all this history.. The entrance fee is included with the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. Have to say that all the ruins are simply amazing. We didn't have a guide or a audio guide so it was a little difficult to figure out what everything was. I plan to read up on it now that I am home but I should have been better prepared. It was very hot but there are water fountains where you can refill your water bottles - don't worry about the water in the fountains, it tastes fine and it perfectly safe all around Rome. An amazing sight.
I good incursion in ancient Roman world. I spent almost an half day going around Roman Forum and I don't regret it. Though, It is preferable not to do this in a very hot day, as I did.

Three for one deal. I hadn’t been to Rome in over 10 years and things have changed. Now the Forum ticket is combined with Palatine Hill and the Colosseum for 12 Euros, which is actually a fair deal. I recommend getting an audio guide or bringing a guidebook otherwise you won’t know what it is you are looking at, particularly in the Forum and on Palatine Hill. Rome was having a heat wave when I visited and so if you go when it is hot, a hat, sunscreen and water are indispensible. Allow yourselves plenty of time to visit the three sites. My best advice is to go early around opening time and do the visit in this order – The Forum, Palatine Hill and the Colosseum. When I got off the metro I turned right instead of joining the huge crowds lined up at the Colosseum across the street. You will see a small entrance a short way up the road on the left. This is the entrance to the Forum. There were only a few people in front of me so it went very quickly. When I got inside I had the place practically to myself for the first 20 minutes. It was magic to be able to take in so much history without any crowds and to be able to take some nice photos. After the Forum, I turned right up on Palatine Hill. No need to wait in line to get in as it is “attached” to the Forum”. There are less crowds up here than down below in the Forum section plus beautiful gardens and views to appreciate. Make sure to go all the way to the stadium. Then afterwards you leave the exit and go right across to the Colosseum and no need to wait in line as you already have your ticket! By having visited these three sites in this order you will have saved the “best for last” because the Colosseum is the mostly visually complete and impressive of the three. It is inconceivable that one would go to Rome and not see these sites! A must-do experience in spite of the crowds.

Huge attraction. We saw this as part of the colosseum/palatine hill tour (they were all included in our ticket). We didn't use the audio guides for the part where the forum is so I'll have to do some research about it but what a sight to behold. You don't realize until you are standing in it's shadow just how gigantic it is.

Lots of history. A great place to walk around & get a taste of what Rome was a long time ago.Can spend a lot of time roaming around. There is a price to enter the forum. A combination ticket can be purchased fro the colloseo & forum. The last time I was here, there was no price to enter & there were more statutes & figures on the pedestals--I guess they were removed & placed in museums.

Standing in history!. Our family loved walking through the Forum (3 boys ages 8,11 & 14). Truly like being transported back to ancient Rome. Next time we would get a guide to give us a tour, but we definitely enjoyed this place. A definite must do while in Rome (and your ticket gets you into Palatine Hill also - it's considered one exhibit).

incredible!. We loved walking around and taking hundreds of pictures at the Forum, Palatino Hill and the surrounding sites. Only 1 complaint - there are 2 entrances/exits - follow the signs or you will end up on a dead end street (learned the hard way)

Astounding history. Incredible to see over 2000 years of history unfold in front of you as you walk thru the forum. From the seat of the senate, to the vestal virgins, to the estate of Augustus. To think that it was all buried / hidden for centuries.... what an amazing site

A must see but with a tour guide. I don't know how you could tour this site without a guide. Unlike the Coliseum of which a large part remains intact, there are only scattered remains here. Even with a tour book, it is hard to conceptualize what was here and nothing is really marked. We booked a private tour guide several weeks before which brought the Forum to life with pictures, history and stories, well worth the time if you know what you are looking at. With a tour guide, we spent more than two hours here and even our teenagers were interested. Don't tour this without a knowledgeable tour guide.
Just amazing!. For me it is the most intersting part of Rome, it is a good tour of history for at least 2,5 hour. It is a place that you must visit.

Must-do but beware. The official audio guide was absolute rubbish. Hard to follow (and I'm usually an ace at these things) and a bit dull. Lots of parts fenced off, which made following a route difficult. I got lost several times. But it is a must-do place. Perhaps take a tour or get your own guide book/device.

Nice sightseeing. Nice sightseeing but to tell you the truth it wasn't much of interesting for us therefore we skipped the most of it. If you have a ticket for Colosseum you enter here for free and the Palatino.
Very Impressive. Our family spent about 2 hours touring the Roman Forum, and it was amazing. What a must see when you go to Rome!

Confusing, even with a map. A notable site but it has been used as a source of building materials for so long it is difficult to imagine it in history. There are few/no labels and once you get up onto the Palatine hill we found that the properties were closed and no access allowed. We did stumble across the Palatine museum and found that to be well worth a visit particularly if you like Roman sculpture. It could have all been done so much better. I guess it is a scheme to sell the guided tours (5 euro). When we visited there was an exhibition of Roman glass in the curia. That was fabulous but overall this is one of those places you visit because it is famous rather than enlightening.

Interesting - download audio guide before you go!. Fantastic history, take water bottle and top up while there from numerous fountains. Ticket includes colluseum entry too so found it good to do this first and then you get to skip all queues in colluseum. Hard to know what you are looking at unless you get a tour or I stumbled across Rick Steves audio tours and downloaded all the ones for Rome before I went...totally free ( there is a free app as well) and printed off the map to go along with it. It was great, took you all through the different points in the forum and had a lot of interesting info - would def recommend to anyone going.

Interesting. It was a huge place to explore and there were lots to see. Little "museums" here and there. It was every enjoyable and we took a lot of photos. IT was very hot but there were water fountains where you could fill up your water bottles.

Standing by the grave of Caesar. The Roman Forum is a must see. Again, do to the state of the ruins, you join a tour to be better informed about what you are looking at. Otherwise, you could be lost. Caesar's grave incredible, as I didn't realize that it still existed.
Amazing wish I had longer to explore. We visited here after the Colosseum and the place is huge. Beautiful views and area. Water fountains were much appreciated in the heat.

unless you take a tour you wont understand anything. unless you take a tour you wont understand anything. no labels, maze like, extremely busy washrooms (even the men had a 10 min line up). hot in the summer with little shade so be aware, and drink lots of water

An amazing island of archaeology in the center of Rome. We visited the Colosseum. The part I would have liked to have dug around in is the lower level, which is, understandably, off limits. I left my wife sitting on a rock, and walked down into the forum. As an artist, I was enthralled with the romance and design of the space. I would have loved to have been able to enter and explore the ruins, but again, understandibly, that too was off limits. I enjoyed my visit and exploration of the forum. Sometimes you don't need a map or information signs to enjoy an area

Use your imagination. A ticket for the Forum costs 12euros (children under 18 free) and covers the Forum, Colosseum and the Palatine. Come here first as the queue's are a lot smaller than the Colosseum. Visit early to avoid the heat oif the day as there is little shelter from the sun.I would advise on using a good guide book, one that shows the layout and what your looking at is a must as the jumble of ruins is quite confusing. You really need to use your imagination here to understand how it all fits together and children may get bored.

Nothing like this. On our recent trip to Rome we wanted to make sure we visited two major sites, the Colosseum & the Forum. We noticed the line for the Colosseum was extensive to we walked across the street to the Forum.When we got to the ticket booth we realized that the ticket you buy was for both the Forum & the Coliseum. For 12 Euros you get to check out both. WOW! To walk among the ruins is an unreal experience! We spend hours taking pictures and trying to relive Roman times. When then walked over tot he Colosseum and realized the long line was for tickets! We already had ours with the purchase at the Forum! We walked right in!

Modest. This sight is maybe offering something for those who has architectural interest for the sight. Otherwise Roma Forum is a brickwall with holes on it :)Maybe the sight is getting undervalueted because of colosseum close to it. This is a sight to check out if you have seen everything else already in Rome :)

Go with a tour group or a guide!. After having travelled to the Roman Forum without a tour group or a guide, I am sad that I wasn't able to piece together any history, my one suggestion would be to most definitely go with a tour group or hire a guide to get the most out of these ruins, it's such a shame to see such architectural wonder and not really know what you're looking at.

Strangely disappointing. You need either a good guide in person or an awesome imagination perhaps to put life into the Forum. Our children (14,12,10) struggled with this and so it failed to capture them in the same way as the Colosseum or Pantheon. We visited Ostia Antica and they loved that (less ruined, less crowded) and as an adult I would say go there as well as to the Forum. It didn't help that we explored Palatine Hill first (which was a TOTAL ruin) and that both bored and exhausted them. I would advise doing the Colosseum 1st, the Forum 2nd and Palatine Hill last (If you still have energy!) and then treat that as a stroll in a park.

An unforgettable place.... The Roman Forum is one of the most magical places in Rome, in my opinion. It takes you back in time and, if you are willing to imagine and dream, you almost can see the buildings raised and the ancient people walking around in your mind... This visit can only go wrong if you didn't search for information about the forum and haven't required a tour guide... In that case you might not enjoy the Forum as much as you would like to, because you will not know the most interesting facts and legends related to the place.Now a few tips. 1st: use REALLY comfortable shoes, because when you are visiting Rome by foot (which is the most beautiful way possible) you will walk a lot more than you predicted, without a doubt.2nd: inside the Forum look for the privileged sight of the Colisseum. It's stunning!

Excellent! but do a little pre-reading or get a tour. The Roman Forum was one of my favourite sights in Rome. I am not an expert at all but have read a bit on the Roman Empire and was excited to visit the forum. To walk around the locations I'd read about was fascinating and a window into the past. If this isn't your thing so much, it's a nice stroll and an interesting collection of ruins, but I could see it being a bit less exciting without the context of the events that occurred here.

Eerie with history. I really enjoyed walking thru the Forum. It was a hike (so be ready to walk), but because the site is spread out and the walking involved, it did not seem as crowded as some of the other sites in Rome. The sense of history was incredible. The ruins also did not seem as "manicured" - wildflowers grew among the ruins and also added to the appeal and made for some great pictures. As other people noted, there were some great photo opportunities, it is close to the Colosseum and included in the ticket price of the Colosseum. Look for the entrances either by the Colosseum or off of Via del Fort Imperial. There did not seem to be an entrance on the side of the Circo Massimo.

Top notch. If you are a history buff and have a active imagination about things past, you will absolutely love Roman Forum. As I wandedred along the giant columns and temple ruins, I imagined the kings of yore parading in their horses. Must see for anybody with even a couple of days..Beware the hot sun during summer months - there is very little shade, take plenty of water

Walk through History. I have returned to the forum since they fenced it in and it is so much better. So much more has been opened up and they continue to work on preparing more finds. This is an historical must see. The architecture, streets, temples, senate, basillica all are impressive and magnificent.

Fantastic site. The ruins of the Forum are really interesting and varied; I thought this was a much more interesting site to visit than the Colosseum, although both are covered by the same ticket.Walking through the Forum really sparks the imagination: The tall columns, the remains of a temple, a huge arch, an enormous garden complex, etc - it is just mind-boggling that this was built so long ago and still exists. One of my favourite spots in Rome for sure.

Deceptively large and very interesting. We visited the forum and set aside a morning to do so which in hind site wasn't enough time.There is a lot to see here!! The guided tour was fantastic and extremely interesting. The guide herself obviously loved her job and was simply brilliant. The depth of the history in these ruins is amazing. Well worth a visit.

CAESAR WAS BURNED HERE. Along with the other buildings, and monuments, be sure to see the little area where Julius Caesar was cremated. The Forum itself is a fabulous attraction with all of its pillars, relics, etcetera. See it all.

Do not miss - but go with a guide.. The Roman Forum is exceptional. To the previous reviewers complaining that things aren't labelled, that is a warranted complaint, however the overall site itself without explanation is magnificent. Your best bet is to find a tour guide, and when you fully understand the depth of the historical significance of this area, you'll be blown away.There were many tour guides offering services nearby, we used a company that employed international students (ours was a lovely Australian girl) for a very small fee, and we gave her a large tip afterwards as she was excellent. There were even free tours offered. Do it this way (or at least bring some sort of self-guided tour book) otherwise you will be overwhelmed by it all. Don't miss it.

Pick up a brick. It´s not one place. The forum is really the old centre of the Roman Empire. Much of the Forum can be seen from the street, but it is well worth paying the EU12 entry price to wonder around among it. You may even consider taking a tour to find out what it all means. Either way, just wondering around among the ruins is awesome. You can pick up bits of stone, marble or 2000 year old pieces of brick that are just lying there under your feet as you walk along.As stated previously, you should take drinking water and a bite to eat, as there is nothing available on site, but contrary to what has been stated, there are toilet facilities on site. You should allow a few hours, or even all day to wonder this site, time permitting.

History... unexplained. The fora, while large and over an extended area, only have limited signage to explain what was there, and nothing really to describe what it was about. You are best off buying a book to read (or hav a guide) in conjunction with your visit, so that you can better understand what you are seeing. When you understand that those pillars you are looking at, are related to a viaduct, and the purpose of that viaduct was... then it adds a lot more understanding to what you are seeing rather than just many pillars and foundation without context.There is also a museum at the top of the Palatine hill, but translations into English are limited, and many of the displays seemed to be replicas from my understanding of the Italian.

Great site before Colosseum. If you are wanting to do the colosseum I highly recommend going to the Roman forum to buy your ticket go through that first the go to the colosseum to avoid all lines. We did nOt wait in a single line doing it this was and even passed the people with a Roma pass. This is the way to do the colosseum/forum to avoid any lines!!

One of the Worst Sites I Have Been To. I have to say of all the sites I have been to across the 6 continents I have visited that the Roman Forum is the worst of them all. I was foolish enough to actually enter the site instead of just viewing it from street level. A word on that first. The Forum is essentially divided by one of the main streets in Rome. On one side the site is off limits to tourists actually entering it. The street is a few feet about the site and you can look down upon the ruins. Unfortunately nothing is labeled so everything just looks like either 1) standing pillars or 2) fallen pillars. The other half of the forum tourists can enter but everything can once again be seen from street level, which I highly recommend. I did foolishly enter the forum and walked around. Absolutely nothing is labelled. Once again it is either standing or fallen pillars. No perspective is given. The site is also very poorly kept. I did have the misfortune of using the restroom there. Fairly clean except there was no soap or any implement to dry your hands. I should just count my blessings that it had running water.

do the a-typical. Of course, visiting the Roman Forum is a must for anyone traveling to Rome the first time. Everyone will walk along the ruins below Capitoline Hill, but the tour will be much more memorable if you pack a picnic and climb to Palatine Hill where there is a wonderful view of either Circus Maximus or the City to the north. You can tour the excavations of the first settlements of Romulus and Ramus or visit the museum (not great) at the top of the hill.

Looking through the splendour of the past.. Knowing the history of the Roman Forum will make you appreciate the place.This was the center of political, religious and commercial life of ancient Rome. In here at the Capitoline hill is where the oldest ruins of the Forum. Today the archeologists continue their excavations in hoping to find some priceless fragment of antiquity.One should read some more of the Forum.. this can help understand their past.

A symbol of Imperial Rome. The Roman Forum is open for foot traffic along the ancient Roman streets which are restored to the late Imperial level.Today archeological excavations continue along with constant restoration and preservation of this place.The ticket cost is 12 Euros per each person (with the same ticket you can also visit the Palatino and the Colosseo).

Love to trace history by these marvelous sites.. Walking on all these places or just viewing the amazing relics made you feel great.These places were one time alive and full of people even until this time, a lot of people come and go to witness these wonderful sites within the city of Rome. The Roman Forum and the massive arches looked marvelous. Saw some students in archeology still painstakingly digging for more artifacts to be unearth. Anybody who appreciates history, arts, and architecture besides knowing the culture and character of the city, will love Rome.

Major Rome attraction, slightly spoiled by the awful audioguide. The Roman Forum is one of the major sights no visitor to Rome should miss. It covers quite an extensive area in the centre of the city and contains the remains of many Roman temples to deities such as Saturn, Vesta and Castor and Pollux, triumphal arches, such as the Arch of Titus, the senate house, and much more. Although we very much enjoyed our visit, we were disappointed by the poor quality of the audioguide. We normally pay for an audioguide when they are available, because we think they effortlessly allow the visitor to appreciate the key features of a sight at their own pace. In the forum there were no plaques by the monuments to identify them, and so half of the time we were using the audioguide, we were trying to make sure we were looking at the building or monument which was being described. Perhaps on this occasion a guided tour would have been preferable. However, despite this criticism, a visit to the Roman Forum is recommended, and if this is the sort of attraction for you, then I would recommend that you investigate a visit to Ostia Antica, a short train ride out of the city.
Forum May 2012. A bit hilly for any one with walking difficulities but well worth the effort if you can walk all the way round

well worth visiting. The Roman Forum is well worth visiting, especially for history enthusiasts. If you're not into history like me, make sure you research on the place first so you could really appreciate it. Otherwise it would just be a bunch of ruins. Bring bottled water, sunglasses or umbrella if you're visiting during summer because this is an open area.

almost nothing remained.. we were in roman forum last week and we bought a tour to see around, almost all buildings are collepsed and the guide could just show the imaginery pictures from the past, after colloseum, florence and venice it is not worth to lose time.

Walk through History. Definitely download the Rick Steve's App before going and you'll enjoy his guided tour. I can't say enough about how interesting it was to see the Forum and imagine it as it once was.

Wonderful, particularly if you are an archeology buff... The area which contains the Forum ruins is a large area which requires walking up and down hills. If it is hot outside, prepare to really perspire. The signage could be better. It would be nice to have more signs showing what specific areas looked like "back in the day." Overall, it is a great place to visit, especially if you have even a little knowledge of Roman history. It is located across the street from the Coliseum.

Bewildering without a guide/map. The Roman Forum is a great place to visit, but extremely confusing! The 'exhibits' themselves are not labelled etc so its anyone's guess as to what you're looking at. Many people found this annoying, but if you use your imagination, you can paint the picture yourself. There were guides and audio guides available so it's probably worth getting one if you're really interested in the site. Some of the relics and remains are really lovely and intact, especialy the columns and temple entrances, and are definitely worth visiting, even if you just walk straight through the site. Great value as 12euro gets you entry to the Forum, Colosseum and Palatino, and could last you all day. TIP: take plenty of water and a hat; there's very limited shade and it gets extremely hot.

Impressive - but you need a good guide. Rome seems to have an aversion to actually labelling their monuments. There are virtually no markings, signposts or even numbers on anything. You are totally on your own. It is my understanding that until recently Foro Romano was basically a park with ruins in it. Now though, it’s a part of the Colloseo and Palatine Hill “package”, your ticket gets you in to all of them.And since it is no longer free, they really need to up their game. The only way to learn anything about the structures is to bring your own book or app, or get a guide. We opted for the guide, unfortunately she wasn’t very good. We got one of the official tours, and while her English was fine, she didn’t really bring anything alive for us. Now, the actual forum and its history are amazing. Imagining the main throughway in its prime is a great way of getting a fix on ancient roman infrastructure. Just make sure you bring a book or get a good guide, because otherwise you will be totally on your own. The forum gets a 4/5, but the whole package only gets 3/5.

Roman Forum. What can you say? A whole lot of ancient history that Napoleon dug up with his army that was otherwise a garbage dump. If it wasn't for Renaissance history the old forum would be 4 times the size it is now. That being said, while only 6% of the whole thing is still there it is still one of the absolutely most incredible things you will ever see.
A nice walk in the ancient Forum.. This place is heaven for fans of ancient Rome.For the rest of us, it is a very nice one hour walk (and photo-op) through the ancient relics, that survived the eons.
Little of it.. I was disappointed in hte Forom, it needs a lot of attention, the paths were very rough and nothing was named, lacked atmosphere, think it will improve in time.
Roman Forum (Foro Romano):. the forum lies in between the hills where old Rome was thriving . The area is alive with history and is a must to visit

Feel the ancient history. Here you can feel the ancient histoty of Rome very well,
Buy the Roman pass and you don't have to wait to enter this place

Loved this place full of history. As an American it is an incredible experience walking through ancient ruins in the middle of a modern city. The forum is incredible. So much of it is preserved. It will not disappoint.

See the Forum at Night. For me, the only way to take in the Forum is late at night in the eery subtle lights that adorn the Forum at night. In it's heyday, the Forum was considered the Broadway of ancient Rome. The Forum was built in the marshy land between the Palatine and Capitoline hills, and it flourished as the center of Roman life in the days of the Republic before it gradually lost prestige to the Imperial Forums. During the day, it is flooded with tourist, but at night, you can almost here the ghosts of an ancient Roman night life. Take a stroll between 8 and 10 pm and you will not be disappointed.

Friends, Romans, Countrymen!. Temples, ceremonial arches, tombs, the Senate house, a church, house of vestal virgins ( no longer occupied! ), a prison, and a museum.... it has it all, along with an atmosphere of beauty and history which is unbeatable. It includes the building where Mark Antony delivered the speech mentioned in my title, after Caesar had been assassinated. I thoroughly agree with previous reviewers who state that this is a more complete history of Rome than the Colosseum with all its bloodthirsty tales. Get here early and don't forget to book your ticket for the Colosseum when you book for the Forum, as you not only save money, you save queueing as well. It is one of the stops on the hop on hop off bus tour, or is on the metro line. Asalways, beware of pickpockets and bag thieves.....I was robbed, and I would not wish the trauma to mar anyone elses trip.

Forum Romanum. Have been in Rome and seen many lovely places, but Forum Romanum beats them all, even Collosseum. You can literally feel the warheroes coming home to be greetet by the people, Really fantastic

Foro Romano. The Roman Forum was the literal heart of ancient Rome, a center for trade, religion and politics where triumphal processions took place, elections were held and th Senate assembled.Today, it is a rectangular forum surrounded by the ruins of several important ancient government buildings at the center of Rome. Many of the oldest and most important structures of the ancient city were located on or near the Forum. How to reach: The Roman Forum is located between the Capitoline Hill and the Colosseum. You may buy a combine ticket at 12 Euro for access to the Colosseum, the Palatine Museum and the Roman Forum (price as at April 2012).
interesting. This site is right next to Palatine Hill and it was a site. You must do it.

Overwhelmingly beautiful. We bought our ticket at the colosseum for twelve euro each. There is a better price for eu citizens. We arrived at the colosseum around nine am and the line was very short. Most people are on tours and go in a different line. When we went to see the forum we entered through palatine hill entrance. We had the frommers Italy guidebook, but it started from one of the many other entrances. Everything is badly labelled, so the people on guided tours probably got a lot more out of their experience. Many areas were being renovated or excavated so were closed to the public. Despite this, there was so much to see so close together that I was overwhelmed with wonder. Being from Canada, I couldn't help but think how the new world was a baby in comparison to Europe. tips: buy tickets early in the day, bring snacks, dress weather appropriate as there is no shade or shelter. There are water fountains and toilets. We finished the colosseum, palatine hill and the forum by two thirty. Lots of souvenir vendors and snack trucks located directly outside the area. Really worth seeing!

Go here BEFORE the Colosseum. The ruins in the Roman Forum are a must see while in Rome. If you go, go to the Forum BEFORE you visit the Colosseum. Even with "prebooking" you need to stand in line to get your ticket, but the lines at the Forum are MUCH shorter than the Colosseum. Your ticket is good for both places. The Forum is definitely not stroller friendly. If you can, skip the stroller or bring a baby carrier for this part of your visit (I did not see stroller parking)

Rome in a Snapshot. Reading up on Roman history is important before going to the forum to get a full appreciation of what in fact you are seeing. It is run down and not much can be made out, so a tour is not a bad idea, even if you know your history. It is touristy, but is still one of Rome's best places to visit. The history will not disappoint you.

Take your walking shoes. I spent a long time in the Roman Forum. It was a lovely hot day and it was very pretty. Don't expect to see full buildings, you are basically looking at ruins but there is a lot to see and the views are just beautiful. Allow yourself enough time to spend there and take plenty of water.

Like walking back through time. I visited the Roman Forum with my husband on my first trip to Italy, and was overwhelmed by the history of Rome, and the forum epitomises this. Each area is carefully sign posted, and it is well worth spending a morning or afternoon 'getting lost' in here. My absolute favourite part (which literally took my breath away) was walking to the top of the hill and looking out over the Colosseum. If you do nothing else, make sure you do this - you will never forget it.

You're in Rome, you need to see this. Hard to say anything about this site that hasn't already been written. The ruins are a bit of a jumble and the Italians certainly haven't spent any effort on signage or interpretation for tourists. Take a moment while you're there and wonder if this is what The Mall in Washington DC will look like in 2000 years.

Amazing afternoon. This was beautiful! We visited in the afternoon, and it was lovely to see the sun setting over the ruins. We had gone to the Colosseum in the morning and purchased a combined ticket, but we should have started our visit here in order to avoid the long lines at the Colosseum. Also, we heard that the Forum only merited an hour visit, but I could have stayed there for four or five! If you want to read everything and really take the time to see everything, you need at least 3 hours. Additionally, if you want to sit and chill on Palantine Hill, you really need a full afternoon. Bring food & water, though, because I'm not sure that you can go out and come back in. The combined pass is good for two days and there are reductions for students of art, history, or education. You need to have something that states your discipline. My student card wouldn't work because it didn't have my major on it. Additionally, you can get the reduction if you are an EU citizen <25 or >65. ISIC cards won't work.
Don't miss the Forum !!!!. Lovely gardens and flowers and interesting structures.

Amazing time machine!. Walking around the Foro Romano takes your mind back 2000 years to imagine what it was like in its glory. Everywhere you look there is something to see and envision the history behind it. I think this is the kind of place one could never tire of visiting as there is always something that was missed before. Everything is spread out so crowds were no problem except near the exit. We had an Architecture Pass, so we avoided any line on the way in.I found the Temple of Saturn, the view to the Capitoline museum, and Constantine's Basilica the highlights. It's all so cool to see!!

piece of history. Must see in Rome. Try to imagine all those big 'forums' where only a few columns remain...Nice overview on the colosseum where you can take great pictures. Very scenic overall. To be combined with a visit to the palatium and the colosseum.

Walk in Foro Romano and travel in time. Start your visit at the colloseum , walk in the remnants of the ancient Rome, end your visit in piazza Venezzia and the area designed by Michelangelo . You will feel yourself in the anciant Rome. You will know much more about it if you have a guide.

Simply jawdropping. This is my second trip to the forum and have to say that its still amazing! In fact, I think I find something new to appreciate each time.We had prebooked tickets but to be honest, when we arrived at 930am, there was no queue and could have walked straight in to buy tickets for all 3 (tickets include the Colosseum). Come from the Victoria Emmanuel memorial, you should take the road on the left and head towards the Colosseum, passing by the Trajan's Market. The entrance to the Forum and the ticket kiosk is on your right.There is a set of toilets behind the kiosk next to the book store before you enter the turnstiles.Wear comfortable shoes as the paths are not even. There are no set path and you could decide on an audio guide either from the bookstore or one of the free apps available online or you could just do like I did - a book. Whichever way, its still amazing to see the centre of the Roman empire.For me, seeing the forum is more amazing that the Colosseum. It is up there with the Parthenon and the Acropolis in Athens.We spent about 2 hours in the forum and another 2 hours in the Palentine Hill (which is accessible from the forum). There are water fountain spots in the forum but no cafes so feel free to bring some snacks.

History made real. The Roman Forums are history made real. It amazed me to be walking by the remains of buildings where early civilizations were shaped. I was really glad that we had both a guide book and our Rick Steves audio tour (a FREE app!) to direct our visit, because unless you have someone telling you what you are seeing, you have no idea what you're even looking at, much less its significance.I really enjoyed the Temple and House of the Vestal Virgins, and learning about them, and I marveled at the spot where Caesar was cremated. (People still leave flowers there today.) I think I would have enjoyed the Senate building more, but it held some other exhibit of artifacts and was clogged with teenagers on group tours, making it difficult to get a sense of the place and appreciate all that had happened there.This was a fascinating visit, and is a not-to-be-missed site for any Rome first-timer.

A long, but interesting day. We loved the ruins at the Forum. That so much is still there was impressive. To be where the Caesar's walked was very neat. Like the Vatican Museum, this is a place worth repeat visits.

Stunning but room for tourist improvement. The roman forums is breathtaking when you enter the grandiose columns and beautiful ruins really gives you a feel of how Huge the centre of Roma was. We purchased a 2 day pass (€12 each for EU members) which grants you access to the roman forum, the Paletine hill and the colloseum over the 2 days. I recommend doing the forum  and Paletine hill first, as the ques in the colloseum can be a couple hours. We also bought an audio guide (in uk English). This came with a map of the forum, which was badly put together, and the audio guide keypad itself which, with out headphones plugged in (not supplied), is quite difficult to hear. The audio guide comprised of numbers on the map which you entered into the audio guides keypad, this is then supposed to give you information about what you're seeing. However because the map is badly drawn, it is difficult to see what you are supposed to be looking at, and at times you will be looking around on the spot trying to see what the audio is talking about, plus the sites are rarely signposted; This can be very frustrating. There were parts of the forum blocked off making it impossible to follow the audio guide tour in a linear fashion. Whilst we were there we over heard an official guide tour group, he was himself saying how awful the audio guides are and that a tour guide (group) is the best way. However he went on to quite ingeniously con his group into paying €45 for a tour of the Vatican the next day, explaining that it is quite the same experience. Meaning that there are no plaques/ info points to help you know what your seeing.Our personal recommendation, is to get a guide book in advanced, there are many to choose from; the best being 'Rome and the vatican city, a complete guide with itineraries' this is a brilliant guide as it has all the architectural information as well as historical backgrounds and paintings information. It cost €10 in most souvenir shops in roma. If you plan to visit the forum and do the palatine hill also, it is a high recommendation to wear good strong foot wear and have plenty of drinks and food available, there are however fountains you can refill bottles at. Although there is nowhere to buy food, you will need it as you will use plenty of energy walking!

Exhausting but worth it!. After visiting the Colosseum we ventured into the Roman Forum as your ticket allows entrance to both. We thought we would only be there an hour or so but wasn't prepared for the vastness of it. It was a beautiful hot day and we had no food or drink with us as we thought we would be in and out in no time. The place is amazing, but huge. I would advise good walking shoes and a picnic as refreshments are not available on the site. Allow at least 2 - 3 hours to see everything.

Through Eternity, City of the Caesars Tour of the Roman Forum and Colosseum. I want to take this opportunity to tell you how much we enjoyed the City of the Caesars tour of the Colosseum and Roman Forum with our guide, Luca.Luca made the ruins of the Forum come alive with information about each major building and his English is flawless and the conversation so interesting. My husband said this tour was one of the major highlights of our trip to Rome.

Good if you like remains. The entrance was near to the Colosseum and you also had access to the Palantine from there. Toilets just inside the entrance. We walked through the Palantine then straight onto the Forum and spent an afternoon there wandering about. It was nice. Quite busy but still felt peaceful.

Ancient History Lives. This place is amazing. You are literally walking through history. Many of the sites are almost gone, while others are still standing. Many are being restored, so it is nice to know they will be around for many more generations to see. We did this on our own and the Rick Steve’s podcast. It was nice; we had the guided information and could go at our own pace. This is part of the ROMA Pass, and is in the same area as the Colosseum, Arch of Constantine and Palatine Hill so plan on spending half a day seeing all these sites. Luckily they are also close to a metro/subway stop.

Visit it the same day as the Colosseum. Roman Forum must be visited, you can't leave the city without having been there. It is right next to the Colosseum, so it is very convenient visiting it the same day as the Colosseum. Be sure to wear good shoes as you will be walking a lot looking at the remains of the buildings and statues.

Take a guided tour or a good guide book or you won't know what you are looking at. Confusing signs, misleading directions, incompetent staff... Not what we expected from the visit to famous ancient ruins, which themselves are of course impressive, but it is very poorly organized.Notice to visitors said that there would be a guided tour of the Forum in English. We inquired at the ticket booth where they confirmed this. When asked how long it would take, they said 3 hours. For some reason, the tour did not begin at the entrance, but at some "House of Livia". OK, we went there, wandered around the area for some 20-30 minutes, because there is almost no signs or they are just all confusing. We finally managed to find this "House of Livia" only to listen to something not very informative about some ancient mugs... The guide went in so much detail without giving a general background. It lasted for about 20 minutes and that was it! As it turned out, there was NO tour of the whole Forum area, only of this "House of Livia"!! But there was no way to know it, because nowhere at the entrance did it say that the "guided tour" means "the House of Livia" tour. Disappointment. They should have made it clear.

Great eduaction! could have stayed days in here. beware with pushcarts and little ones...rocky roads...you can park them and return for them later if you wish (we exited in a different place though), let the kid run it out. And plan to stay here all day. bring a picnic (grab a box o' wine, bread, mozzarella and pesto for the adults and juice boxes and snack bars for the kiddos), get yourself a guild book so you can identify what you are looking at, and take loads of pictures. let the kiddos explore and act out roles from ancient rome. a great family fun place!!

Roman history. This was one of my favorite sights in Rome and completely amazing that so much of it has been preserved. The Basilica of Maximus and the Temple of Romulus (1700 years old) very impressive. Good hiking shoes a must - the Roman cobblestones are killers - not like the regular cobblestones in the streets. The Rick Steves audio tour is very good for the Forum. RomaPass holders take note: You must visit Palatine Hill and the Forum in the same day as they are connected. If you buy a separate combination ticket it is good for 2 days, but not with the RomaPass. We visited Palatine Hill and the Colosseum 1 day and went back to the Forum the second day on the way to Capitoline Hill. We were told at the gate we had to buy a Forum ticket. When we were there the Arch of Septimius Severus was blocked due to renovation.

Fascinating and fabulous and yes you need some guidance.. We visited the Forum in late March -- perfect walking weather and low crowds. I highly recommend some form of guidance as there isn't signage describing what you are seeing. We used the FREE Rick Steves app/audio guide (on iPods with earbuds) which lasts about 45 minutes and took us from the Arch of Titus through all the various sites in the Forum (screen shows what you should be seeing) and does a fabulous job of setting the scene and describing the temples, columns, arches, the Senate, the rostrum — all things I wouldn't have understood without it. With it, the Forum was an amazing experience; you are transported back to the time of the Republic and its turnover to an Empire, you can walk in the steps of slaves and emperors, you can truly imagine its former greatness. The only area under restoration during our visit was the Temple of Antoninus and Faustina -- everything else was in its restored glory right beside the traffic of modern Rome. Not to be missed.

FOR PEOPLE WHO LOVE RUINS. We prefered to see the "Forum" from the outside although we probably missed some of the ruins that were not in sight from where we were standing.We saved the entrance fee which was a great idea.Overated !!!

The Roman Forum, another can't miss Rome gem!. If you are in Rome, don't miss the Roman Forum, it's got so much history for this city and the views are spectacular! Take your time and see it all! See photos

Must see. These ruins are spread over a very large area. It could easily take more than a day to see them all. As with the Colosseum, you need to have the visual aid of how they look now and how they looked then to truly appreciate them.

GET THE ROMA PASS!!!. When we arrived there was a very confused group of people at the entrance who seemed to have no idea what was going on so it took us a while to filter through. If I remember rightly, the prices seemed steep without the Roma pass. Make sure you read the signs carefully - the queueing system was a mess but you could probably shaved 20mins off the wait by being in the right area.As for the Forum itself, brilliant. Well worth any hassle. We found ourselves worn out from walking around Rome so had a bit of lunch - lovely place for a picnic, and great views of the rest of Rome.
real rome. A must see ,just a bit of imagination and you are in old imperial rome ,to go to rome and not visit this historic home of the emperors has not visited real rome
It's everywhere!. When you come upon the Forum, it surrounds you before you know it. There is so much to see and appreciate.

they are ruins after all. Before starting my slightly negative comments, the Forum and Palatino make for a beautiful day, as long as the weather is nice. A couple of things would have made it much, much better..When in Rome an imagination helps. In the case of this Forum and Il Palatino, the ruins are well, ruined. This of course, should be expected. However, the audio-guide and lacking markers made the experience extremely confusing. The intended path had been significantly altered due to ongoing work to restore things, but the result means not knowing where one should be as the guide goes on. Lastly, if you get the guide, make sure to ask for the full guide including both sights. I was a bit irritated when my audio guide stopped half-way through, for what would only have been another 2 EUR.

Breathtaking. The most incredible views of our entire trip were looking at the Roman Forum, and we didn't even get to go in. It takes a while, so don't go late in the afternoon. Absolutely amazing to see what still stands...

i can see the great things. I only could see from the the buildings terrace (Foro romano) and Church beside the building, but its the view like what i saw on the internet(photos traveler). i didnt know if i could visit or not to the debris building of Roman Forum

Very interesting place.. My wife and I enjoyed Pompeii more than the Forum. Still, this place is very interesting and rich with history. More signs and explanations about the place would be more helpful for solo travelers.

Incredible opportunity to be surrounded by history. We visited the Roman Forum as part of a guided tour that we took. It was incredible! It was a great place to buy the combo ticket for the Roman Forum, Palantine Hill and Colosseum. Our 12 euro ticket gave us access to all 3 places.We were part of a guided tour that we had arranged privately. I'm not sure of the literature we might have received if we hadn't been on a tour. I didn't see any signage as we walked around, so I'm not sure if you would have had any idea of what you were looking at as you walked through the Forum. Our tour spent about 1.5 hours at both the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. It was just incredible to be surrounded by such history!On a "mom" note - there were at least 3 sets of free toilets - which worked great for my little ones that were with me! There didn't appear to be anywhere to buy bottled water or get food. On the way up to Palantine Hill there was a water fountain to fill up bottles - and we had no problems drinking the water from the fountains.

Improving as more and more restoration work is done. I didnt used to think much of the Forum as it was mainly large stones lying on the floor which made it difficult to visualise what used to be there. However it seems to get better each time I vivist and there has been some very sympathetic restoration work done so it is getting better with time. Very hot in summer though on a sunny day

Great tiem. A piece of history with amazing views and buildings. Went on summer and were lucky to enjoy the Forums in a clear day with plenty of sun. The place is huge, and theres a ruin or building almost everywhere. Just walk about the gardens, enjoy the place and imagine the place 2 thousand years ago. If history and heritage places are your thing, this is a must. It´s right infront the Coleseum, so I recommend doing both the same day. Get a Roma Pass and avoid de crowds, it pays for itself!!

Get the "flip" book. There's a small souvenire book you can buy with photos of the Forum as historians believe it used to look that "overlay" current day photos so you can see what the Forum looked like in its heyday.  I highly recommend it!
RF. A must see when in Rome. You pay 12 euros for Palatine Hill, Colosseo and Roman Forum, it gives you 48 hours the explore it all. It is absolutely close to each other.
Roman forum. Loved walking all around here, so much history and lovely views.

Roman Forum in the snow. You can't go to Rome without seeing the forum I'm afraid. The centre of the Roman Empire spawned the modern world and just has to be seen. Once in and a few Euro lighter (so much for claims the forum is now free to visit on internet before we went) the extent of the world you now have to rattle around in is huge. This is our second visit to the forum and we saw loads second time around that we did not see first time. Take a water bottle though. No outlets inside but plenty of free fountains dotted around to fill your bottles from.

Great Stop, Even If You've Seen Pompeii. If you have seem pompeii or other runed roman cities and wondering if this is worth it, I would have to say yes. It gives a glimpse into how grand Rome was. The Basilica of Constantine up close makes it worth it (what most churches are now based off of).TIP#1 : The forum / colosseum ticket is purchased together. Purchase this one first, even if you go to the colosseum first, to avoid waiting in longer lineups.TIP#2 : I used the excellent and free Rick Steves audio guide with my mp3 player. It gave a great tour, and also saved me renting an audio guide (both lineup and cost savings).TIP#3 : Consider the Roma Pass. It wasn't worth it for me, but might be for you.

Interesting site with a complex history. The Roman Forum and the spectacular ruins that its houses are worth doing on any trip, though I would advise going with a guided tour or taking some detailed literature along to assist in you journey through history! There is a lot to take in, even without much knowledge of the significance of the site the ruins are beautiful, but it is worth having your experienced enhanced by an expert if possible.I saw guests with children and prams, so it is a family-friendly site too, and there is lots for children to look at and have a run-around as well.

Have not been in. We have not had the time to get in but Forum being accepted as the foundation of civilization is a place one must see. You can also walk around it no need to get in in order to see it but if you are a huge history fan and want to examine the slightest hint of it, you can get a detailed explanation of which were where in the forum and just not walk around the ruins aimlessly.

Worth a look. This was great but it's spread out over a huge area so it takes a consideralbe time to get round and do properly. We went after visiting the Colosseum so quite late in the day. Would recommend getting there much earlier and making this your only visit of the day so you can do at your own pace. There were queues to some sections which were so long we gave them a miss. There was one villa with amazing mozaics but it had guards preventing you from entering. We peeked through the windows: awesome. Would have loved to go in.

A very Snow covered Forum. We walked past the forum on our way down to the colloseum, having visited Rome a few times it wasnt somewhere we were going to visit again but it did look rather good covered in snow
Wear good shoes, it's a hike. We walked from the Colluseum to the front of the Forum. The map helped a bit, but a guide would have been even better!

Awestruck. It is just awesome to stand in the Roman Forum and imagine what it was like during the Roman rule. The extravagance and beauty is still evident in the remaining structures. This is a must see and free to everyone.

Nice walk. This is the last whole day in Rome. My feet were hurting. It was a really nice walk through this old park in which Roman Forum is located. Forum itself is nothing special but it has really great historical significance. It's a must see in Rome. Don't miss it.

Walking on History. I enjoyed the Roman Forum almost more than the Colosseum. There is so much history here. I really appreciated the free downloadable audio tour from Rick Steves. It helped me to see the ruins as they must have been at the time of the Caesars.
forum. wasted 14 Euros each; others were not stopped entering free thru the exit. no indiv maps; signs in English lots of info

Very Cool Place, Full of History. I would rank this place as another don't miss if visiting Rome for the first time. It's basically across the street from the Colosseum so just plan to hit sight in that general vicinity for a day. When we went in October there wasn't any line to get in, but I think there can be long lines in peak months. Do get an audio tour, either rent one or download a free one online. We downloaded free Rick Steves audio guides and it was very informative. Do be prepared to walk over a large area. Make sure you go into the "heart of the forum " see the Curia Jullia where the Roman Senate met; dpo see the place where Julius Caesar was cremated and there is many more.

Only In Rome. I have been told that this place is a bit hard to navigate when using the audio guide. However, I did without it and just took in the sights. Very nice. Just one of those places you should see. To be honest, you can see it from a reasonable distance without necessarily having to pay to see it up close. Just to Piazza Campidogllo and head around the back of it.
Nice stroll. A leisurely wander thru the forum is a pleasant way to spend a lazy Sunday morning
Best ruins I've seen. Very glad I took the time to visit Roman Forum in addition to Colosseum! A lovely insight into old Roman days.

Roman Forum. Get a guide to go round with as there is no information around the site to tell you what you are looking at and what it was in its time. If you don't have a guide you will wander aimlessly wondering what you are looking at. Wear comforable flat shoes as the ground is very uneven.

Not to be missed. Thankfully, we stoped here on a tour that also showed the Coloseum. The Forum is really impressive, and its the best and biggest roman ruins in one spot. Take a tour so you know what you are looking at!

Roman ripoff. We acquired a combo ticket for the Forum, the Palace and Colosseum. No where does it say that once you leave the palace grounds, you may not enter the forum. No where do they tell you that the palace entry is the same entry for the forum. Once inside the palace grounds, there are signs that say 'this way to the forum' but none actually ARE the way to the forum. When we finally went back to the entry gate, we saw NO SIGNS or instructions to enter the forum. We assumed we could exit here and find the forum entrance. When we finally realized (after walking a few miles and being accosted by numerous romans trying to sell me most everything) that the entrance to the forum is the same as the palace.. we were DENIED entrance! I explained and explained but they make a good living ripping off tourists. There was no way I was going to buy ANOTHER ticket so.. we missed the forum. Hint: Be rude... demand to know where the entrance and exits are.

Very confusing and badly signed :-(. We rented an audio tour however there was no guidance throughout the forum as to which section you needed to be listening to. This meant we were reliant from a small map and the audio tour dud not always make much sense depending on where you were standing, my advice - don't bother with the audio tour and just enjoy the forum as an. Attractive set of buildings and ruins.Don't bother going if you have mobility problems or find uneven ground difficult to walk on.

Interesting, but a bit difficult to navigate. I know they rent an audio guide, but I and my spouse like to go at our own pace. Our guidebook (we had two) did not have adequate information, and the map that is provided (in the Colosseum, where we got the combined ticket with our Roma Pass) was poor. Artifacts are poorly marked, if at all. So, unless you want to rent an audio guide (it also gets expensive to do so at each site), collect some information to bring with you about the Forum. We also found after a while that you are saturated with ancient columns and other ruins that begin to all look alike.

Bring your historical imagination.. Rome was the center of the western world for centuries and for much of that time these few acres is where all the action was. Do yourself a favor and prepare yourself ahead of time by familiarizing yourself with the monuments and remains in the Forum. If you don't, much of what you will be looking at will be little more than rock piles. If you do, your historical imagination will recognize the environs of Julius Caesar, Cicero, Augustus, the Vestals...the list is endless. The historical landscape is as vivid here as anywhere on earth.

Jan 2012 trip. We bought our Coloseum and Roman Forum tickets in front of the Coloseum. 2nd part of our tour was the Roman Forum. Absolutely hands down the BEST tour guide made this wonderful!! I wish I remembered his name. It was piles of rocks and columns and walls, but his stories brought to life the people who lived there so long ago. He also used his Ipad to show images of the structures and painting and marble works. And for his last statement, he said you HAD to visit the St. Peter's Bascilia in Vatican City to see where all the glories were taken, and then realize that the Roman Forum was several streets with many domed buildings and St. Peter's is ONLY 1 building, so multiply that and you would imagine Rome back then. Truly amazing and a GREAT tour!!

Walking along history. The Forum was a big place. We spent 3 hours wandering among the ruins and taking in a few nice vistas as well. Plenty of photo ops......it worked well with a morning visit to the Coloseum.

lots to see. we spent all day here and still didnt see anything. this place is huge, it just goes on and on with history and architecture everwhere. if this place was in the uk it would be split into 4 different attractons and cost twice as much. if you go to Rome, you must visit the forum, but allow yourself plenty of time, take lots of water and wear comfy shoes

Walk, wander, be amazed.. So much history! Walk around and enjoy the ruins, try to imagine what they once were. Plan a bit of time to see the forum and the palatino too! It's all in the same ticket price - colosseum too!

Amazing. You have no excuse not to walk around here :) Get an entrance ticket that for 11 euros gets you into the Colosseum, Palantine hill, and the Roman Forum. The statues, the pillars, the ornamented stones, it's not hard to imagine the people walking around here in the ancient times. It's something one should NOT miss when in Rome.
The forum. Brilliant, walked all over the sight. You use the same ticket as the Coloseum, great value

Amazing!. What's not to love?! To stroll amongst the ancient ruins is a treat for any lover of art and architecture. My husband and I didn't get a tour guide and were happy enough to get lost in the gardens, wind our way through the grounds, and simply enjoy the majesty of the Roman Forum. If you go at the end of the day, the lighting gets soft and warm and basks the ruins in great light that makes for wonderful pictures.

History of Rome unfolds before your eyes!. The Roman Forum is part of a trio of historical sites along with the colleseum and palatin hill.The Forum by itself is partly visible from the nearby street which has several view points on the Forum, but don't let that mislead you - visiting inside is definitiley worth every euro as you practically walk inside Rome's history - Columns, sites, buildings and gates unravel before you the might of the ancient Roman Empire - a real must.I recommend buying your combined ticket (valid for all 3 sites) on the roman forum entrance - saves a very long line in the colleseum (see roninrome.com for more details on this). visiting the Forum first and exiting near the Collesum for the grand finalle!
forum. would like to have read some of the history of the area before visiting. Guides are interesting but more knowledge would have enhanced the experience. Take water, very hot up there.

walking in the footsteps of Roman emperors. We dedicated one day of our trip to Rome, to visit the Colosseum & the Roman Forum(entry without a line was included in our Roma Pass Card) and then Trajan's Forum and the Vittoriano(you can climb to the terrace so you get an idea of how impressive the Roman Forum is seen from above, as well as a beautiful view of the Colosseum), Teatro Marcello and Campidoglio and then a romantic strool to the smallest island in the world Isola Tiberina(it is right behind the Teatro Marcello) and then we got back to see Colosseum by night, there was a full moon too when we got there so it made our day just perfect.

Where to start?. How do you begin to describe the Foro Romano? The ruins of an old city centre? But not just any city - the centre of the Roman Empire. Cobbled streets where Nero, Julius Ceasar, et al once strolled. Temples where they worshipped. The Curia where the Roman Senate met (and murdered). The weight of history is palpable in the very stones. Although large chunks of the Forum and the adjacent Palatine Hill always seem to be roped off for either safety or archeological work, there are still several acres of ruins (with new bits being put on show all the time) to gawp at. And if that isn't enough, the Trajan Markets and Colosseum are next door. If you only see one thing in Rome, this really has to be it.

Larger area than you'd expect, you can spend an afternoon there.. The ticket you buy will get you in the Colloseum and the Forum. The Forum area surprised us with what is left of that area. You could spend 2-5 hours to take in the entire site if you want to. Get a map and visit the other areas besides the ruins of columns. Some very interesting parcels up the hills and beyond in back to look at. We really enjoyed it here.

Different from what I expected. We spent a large part of the day walking the forum. It gave a good flavor of what life was like there. A lot of ruins. The "Forum" part was hard to decipher as so much of it was down. I almost wish that parts of the site had been restored to give some sense of what it would have felt like to live there (a home, the forum, etc.). We did, however, explore one of the underground passages where some of the plaster walls and frescoes were still intact. Had to peek through a window at the house of Lydia which is being restored, but the dust made it hard to see details. Still, it's interesting to see what the Romans were able to accomplish in terms of architecture and city planning without the aid of modern technology. The archways at both ends of the site are a "don't miss" feature as well as Nero's temple. The gardens are restful and the site was still a great way to spend the day exploring. Too much to see in a single day, well worth the trip.

Be sure to bring the flip book with you. I dug out my old transparency flip book and took it with me. I think I was the only person in the entire Roman Forum with that book. With it, I was able to constantly flip between the original buildings and the ruins. It really helped me visualize what I was staring at. Others without the book just walked past half pillars, stones, etc.
Very cool.. Loved this! Take the "Blue Guide:Rome" when walking around the Roman Forum so you can read in detail about all the ruins!

Great to visit if you are really into it. The Roman Forum is impressive in itself, so it doesn't need any introduction...however, we stopped going when they started charging entrance fee. We already saw the Coliseum, already saw Palatine (and once you seen them once, there's not much more to see and do 2nd or 3rd times), but the Roman Forum was great to stroll through because there is so much to see in the ruins. Waiting in line for tickets, or buying in advance when you don't plan to see the Coliseum or Palatine again is not worth it. IF you want to get a great view of the Roman Forum for free just go up to Capitoline hill behind the museum....or if you happen to go to Capitoline Museum too. Having binoculars helps with the details. We always bring a pair of light binoculars with us and they are quite useful.

So much history, pay for a tour.... We toured the Roman Forum in a package deal with the Colosseum. I had a baby on my back so although I couldn't hear too much of the tour, my husband absolutely loved it. After the multi-hour tour he wanted to continue walking around the grounds. There is so much history there and I would recommend visiting it while in Rome. Get a book, audio guide, or a tour guide because it's so big and one could easily take a wrong turn. The forum wasn't crowded when we were there so we took advantage of the wonderful views, sat down and drank from their water fountains. Our tour guide, Mark, was from Ohio (now living in Italy) and he was excellent. We booked his Vatican tour for the next day we liked him so much. I'm sorry that I don't remember the tour operator.

Ancient grounds. The Roman Forum is situated bang opposite the colosseum & one can combine the tour to the colosseum along with it.Take a tour guide or an audio guide as there is a lot of history assosiated with this place that makes for some interesting listening.

Roman Forum. To walk where Caesar walked is a must! It seems impossible, but you can actually see old chariot wheel ruts on the streets no less! By all means do not leave Rome without seeing the Roman Forum! It is right across the street from the Colosseum so you can easily see both on the same day!

Wonderful experience. I loved every bit of the Roman Forum, we visited with the travel guides S.P.Q.R which I highly recommend. There's water fountains inside where you can re-fill water bottles (we went in summer), bring a hat/sun shade and comfy shoes. It's a massive place and there's so much to see. I recommend going early in the morning if possible. The sheer scale of the monuments and structures inside is incredible. I really loved it.

A must see. Pick a sunny day to visit the Roman Forum. You need at least 3 to 4 hours. With a little bit of imagination you will be thinking that you are living in ancient times. Just take a guide book with two different maps, the actual ruins and the other how it was built.
Too much of a crowd. Since my last visit, the Forum is now a paying attraction and can take hours of queuing before you can get in. Go there early. It's a moving experience.

Fenced In. Were not able to walk around as they have fenced this off. It does look like it is falling apart so th efence may be for safety as well as preservation. If you want to see the forum, tour the colliseum and look down on the forum. You can see a fair amountt of the ruins.

Love the Forum. Will get the audio tour next time.. You can really imagine yourself back in ancient Rome. It seems so quiet compared to the busy street just outside. Plan on spending a lot of time here poking around the ruins. Google tips on how to avoid long lines to save yourselves some time. Take your lunch with you as there are no food options inside.

Don't miss it. You can't go to Rome and not visit the Forum. You need to spend at least a half a day, or even better an entire day, walking through it and the Palatine Hill. Be sure to rent the audio guide, which is very easy to use and extremely informative, particularly on the Palatine Hill. I read Roman history as a hobby, and I found the guide very informative.
Roman Forum is amazing. We loved walking around the Roman Forum. We enjoyed the history and seeing how well preserved the Roman Forum was. Its crazy to think of how old it really is...

Along with Colosseum. Visited the Roman Forum following our tour of the Colosseum ... the history of the area is amazing. Again, this was part of our tour of the area and we had a very good tour guide.

A confusing place full cluttered history. The Foro Romano is THE place to understand the course of italian history, however the map provided is no good and the signing poor. Hence, you are starring at things you cannot be sure what they are.
