In this specific part I was lucky to have bought a couple of books, the Rome Reconstructed and the Lonely Planet Guidebook for Rome, that made a bit of sense. It is an impossible place, but as soon as you realise what is what and the sequence of eras, it becomes an interesting one. Noone will help you in understanding it, but a thorough research or a good book.

Archaeologists must visit the Foro Romano. Seeing the Senate building, the Agora and other buildings we have read about in text books is overwhelming. No matter what our geographic specialty, the Roman Forum is a must see.

Grand Ruins!. The Roma Forum is quite spread out and the ticket you buy for the Colosseum covers the Roma Forum as well. However, be prepared to walk and take the audio guide. It can get a little difficult to follow the guide after a while which makes you lose track. Without an audio guide they are just ruins which you can't appreciate. Don't miss the famous arches (The Arch of Septimus Severus). The Roman Forum gives you a glimpse into the greatness of Rome and it's city centre. Wear a good pair of walking shoes and its best to go there when the sun is not very strong. Depends on how much time you want to spend here. If you don't have much time in Rome, then you can do it quickly otherwise you easily spend a day between the Colosseum and the Roma Forum.
Amazing place to visit. If you visit Rome for the first time the ancient Roman Forum is a must see. I highly recommend hiring a tour guide to better understand what you are seeing.
Ruins central. the forum is nearby the coloseum, you walk there. I would suggest going with a guide because of the rich history that you would not get by yourself. A lot to see.

My Roman Forum Visit. Wonderful sight. Only difficulty is to walk such a vast area for Physically challenged person like me. It is an amazing experience to walk through it- I could not beleive that once upon a time Julius Caesar used to walk through this road!!

Good history of Rome. We had a beautiful day to walk around the forum. It would have just looked like some old ruins, but the audio guide we listened to brought it to life for us. If you don't know about it, you may want to read about it or have an audio guide.

THE best ancient site in Rome. I traveled to Rome mainly to see the Colosseum (a life time dream) but I was blown away by the Roman Forum. I spent hours there but could have spent days. It was facinating and a must see for lovers of ancient history. Just walking on the same ground that Emperors had walked upon was a spectacular experience. So much history in such a small area!

Great History!. It was great to see all the history involved with the city of Rome. So much information that it can be overwhelming or completely misunderstood unless you have the help of a tour guide! The forum was an awesome site to see!

Amazing glimpse into the past. We skimmed through the Roman Forum and were very impressed by what we saw. I can only describe Rome as feeling like you are in a theme park - every corner you turn, you get a glimpse into the past. Fantastic, even for non history buffs like myself!

How could you visit Rome and not see the Forum?. Been through the forum several times and have enjoyed it immensely every time we visited. There is SO much history within this relatively small area that we learn something new every time.

Not to be missed. No visit to Rome would be complete without a visit to the Forum. We had a great guide, Dave, who went through the story of Romulus and Remus, and made it all so much more interesting than it would have been had we had our head in a quide book

Glad to have seen it, but won't bother again. My advice would be to ensure you have a small tour group. I think my disappointment came down to our tour guide / group. It was also raining. People were pushing and shoving, the tour guide wasn't impressing us with many interesting facts and the rain literally put a dampener on things. This might have contributed to the Forum seeming like a bunch of wet rocks, columns and arches.

English tour guide, small group. At this time of year there was only 20 or so of us in the group to see the forum and even though its not as iconic as the Colosseum, it is seeped in history and extremely interesting. Our tour guide was English and therefore easy to understand and was knowledgeable about his subject. Highly recommend a visit.
History and culture. If one wish to learn about the Roman culture, one should visit The Roman Forum after visiting the Colosseum. A very good combination.

A must see. We saw the Roman Forum with a 1/2 day tour. I feel this is the best way to expereince the Forum. It's so overpowering and it was nice to have a tour guide telling us what we were looking at. A great story!!!

Don't forget your Roma Pass. Included with the colosseum as one ticket with respect to the Roma Pass. Getting the Roma Pass was the smartest thing we did, and helped us bypass the big line-ups at the colosseum and forum.

So very grand. The Roman Forum is very overwhelming and it is always good to have a handy book when taking this road. The Forum is a square with several important ancient buildings dating back to the 7th century BC. When walking through this one should start from the Capitol side and lead upto the Arch of Constantine and Colosseum as opposed to starting from the colosseum end. To ensure that you get in from the Capitol I suggest you get off at the Vittorio Emanuele which is a station on Linea A of the Metro and walk from the Vittorio Emanuele till the Tarpeian Rock from where you can see the entire Roman Forum and proceed to enter the Forum thereafter.
Amazing history!. We had a great tour guide and were happy to learn about the history of the Forum.

need to see from above in the Palatino gardens to get the best view. We found looking down at the Forum much better than the wandering round and spent quite a time looking at it from the gardens of the palatino area and having a guide point out the different buildings and areas and their uses

Mind-boggling history right in front of you!. I never liked history in school, but I am fascinated by the history of the Roman Forum. It is an overwhelming place, and it could take many hours to cover the whole place if someone is really trying to process the historical importance of the site. I highly recommend that visitors read/study a bit before heading to the Forum. Otherwise, the mind-boggling history looks only like a lot of old things. I have been told that this is one place where hiring a private guide is a good idea, but we were on a time limit and just read up on the basics before we went. The Arch of Titus is incredible!

Brilliant historic site. Some structures date back to 500 BC, walk in the old senate house and tread the steps of emperors and senates! Go early as the tickets give combined entrance to the Colosseum and palentine hill

Historic site. Lovely sunny day helped, 18 degrees in mid November, but great to just wander round. Take your time and enjoy all the different stories.We bought a 'Rome reconstructed' book which is great as it shows how the areas looked in Roman times.

Fascinating.. this was a high point of our vacation in Rome. we walked through the ruins after our Colosseum visit. Even in ruins, this is amazing. the views here make for some incredible photos. what was really neat (and invaluable) were the abundance of fountains at this attraction. it was steady 90 degree days when we were there and drinking alot of water to stay hydrated was a must. we filled our water bottles several times. you will see these fountains at alot of other places while walking around Rome too. PS. make sure you wear comfortable walking shoes.

View this from above..... You can view this from above by going to the top of the Palazzo venezia, or from the back of the Museo Capitolini....unless you want to walk around the ruins in which case you have to pay!!

One of the best sites in entire Rome!. You definitely need to unfold your imagination and take your time walking through Roman Forum. Although almost the entire site is visible from the street, don't miss the chance to actually walk throughout the entire Forum for the true experience. (The ticket that gets you in is good for 2 days and gets you in Colosseum and Palatino as well) . For the complete experience its better to have a map with the explanations of objects in the forum and with a little imagination and knowledge, walk the streets of ancient Rome and re-evoke the everyday life of ancient civilization. Pay special attention to the house and atrium of Vestal Virgins, Tempo Di Saturno, Tempio di Romolo etc...

Roman Forum is spectacular even in it's destruction. The Roman Forum is very interesting in the stories told by the remains of this famous place. Movies like Ben Hur took place in a part of the forum and all the magnificent columns and ruins attest to the spectacular history of Rome

How can you go to Rome and not see the Forum?. This is probably one of your top 5 for your list while in Rome. Great memories with the family strolling through the forum making up songs in the rain. Some people might say it's just a bunch of old arch debris, but it is history. If you don't have a few hours to "roam" around inside, there are plenty of places to look into the forum from the outside without paying the fee. Not the same experience, but at least the minimum you should do.

Fantastic ruins, somewhat dimmed by the restricted access and since charges introduced. I've been to Rome several times over the years and the Roman forum has always been a great attraction that I've taken family and friends to for a stroll around. The ruins are impressive and give a real sense of what it must have been like in ancient Rome. I always thought the best way to approach the Forum was from the Capitoline hill after visiting the Campidoglio (and the continuing the walk to the Colosseum) but was disappointed (in fact rather annoyed) to find that they have introduced an entrance fee and barred access from either the Capitoline or the Colosseum (there are exit only gates now) and you have to walk around to a new entrance roughly in the middle of the site located on Via dei Fori Imperali and stump up a €12 fee (this does also cover access to the Colosseum and Palatine but since we had been to the Capitoline museums there wouldn't have been time to visit all the sites). A shame, not only has a great walking route (recommended in many guide books) been ruined, the fee will deter many visitors, especially those on a budget or with limited time. Also although it has been in place for a few years, we found we were among a stream of visitors still trying to approach from the Capitoline (it provides a great view of the Forum and a specific viewing area in the museum) only to be unable to be greeted by a No-entry sign and gate.
Gotta visit this. Read the history and visit it with a tour guide to maximise the experience. The Forum and surrounds (Colosseum, Ancient hills) are a must.

What! a load of rubble!. I've visited some roman ruins in my life but you can't believe the scale of this. We didn't pay to walk about the ruins, but walked around the outside of both the Trajan and Imperial Forums vastly impressive. It's a pity Italy is in such financial crisis because there is so much more to be excavated. at least the area is pedestrianised now , when I visited as a teenager traffic had priority.

A site of real interest.. The Roman Forum was the centre of ancient Rome, Romans used to meet, do business, politics and shop. In 46BC Julius Caesar built a new forum because the old one was getting small for the growing population of the city. Today modern Rome is 25 feet higher than the city was when the Forum was built because of the debris that has accumulated over the years. The Roman Forum today is an area of ruins of temples, arches and basilicas but still there is a lot to be seen. It i sthought this is where Caesar was killed.
Fasinating Forum. To walk through the forum is just an amazing experience. There is a combined ticket with the Colosseum and the Pallatine get in with Roma Pass.
Roman Forum. Not as much to see as I originally thought. Lots of stones, and grassy areas. Make sure you wear confortable shoes! It is uneven in places

MUST SEE. Get a guidebook to know what you are looking at- and pack a water. This is the heart of ancient Rome, and decisions made here changed the world for centuries. A Large site, could easily spend 2 hours here looking at the ongoing excavations and the exposed ones.( BTW, buy your water or coca cola in a store before you get to the Forum, as the food truck charges 3 euros for a water or a coke!)
A fabulous, expansive archaeological complex. Adjoining the Palantine and a truly impressive insight into ancient Rome.

Don't miss the Forum. Just about every major event in Ancient Rome happened in or around the Forum. On the Palatine Hill which overlooks the Forum lived the emperors of Rome such as Augustus and Caligula. The area is full of temples and triumphal arches and the Rostra in the middle is where Mark Anthony is reputed to have delivered his eulogy to Julius Caesar in front of the famous Roman Senate House. The Arch of Titus is still standing after almost two thousand years with its reliefs of the sack of Jerusalem. Take a guide book to explain what you're looking at otherwise you might miss things like the Temple of Vesta where the Vestal Virgins tended the flame of the goddess and temple of the Gemini (Castor and Pollux the twin gods). Great for history buffs and those who just like to see where history happened.
Incredible. This whole area is wonderful you can just get lost in time & imagine yourself walking in Roman Senators footsteps, I could not get enough of the forum.

Could see part of Forum with a Wheel Chair. They had a special elevator that took me down to the Roman Forum in the wheel chair. There was a long ramp to the building with the statues of Nero in it. There was another ramp down to the Forum.But, when you got there, the huge stones in the walkway made it impossible to do in a wheelchair. So, my husband walked around and took pictures, while I sat and enjoyed the sun and the view. (It was OK since I had been there years ago.)

Spare a day to wander through the Forum.. The opportunity to walk in the footsteps of citizens of centuries ago. The Forum is thought provoking, fascinating and a wonderful photographic opportunity. But the historical aspect and the advantage to witness the remnants of long ago Roman lifestyles and walk in homes and down streets is invaluable. A must do if in Rome.

Impressive. Amazing history. Take you time ot enjoy all the buildings. When we went there was a special Nero exhibit. It worth the wait in line to see this exhibit. Best to purchase your tickets for the old Rome sites (Fourm, Palentino Hill and Colleseo) at the Forum entrance as the line is smaller at the Forum entrance than at the other two sites.

Ghosts of the past. I don't think that one feels the presence of ghosts of the past anywhere in Rome more than at the Roman Forum. While the crowds of tourists are a distraction, it's possible to find oneself in spots that are reasonably uncrowded. In my opinion, if one has time to visit only one place in Rome, this is it.

Was Okay. You can buy tickets for the Forum and Colosseum together so it works out to be good value for money. The forum itself was interesting however it was much of the same thing all around. Good if you have the spare time whilst your in Rome, but otherwise you have to spend a good couple of hours there to see everything and it wasn't really my cup of tea

Took me to a different era. Walking through the Roman forum and the adjoining Palatine Hill was a scintillating experience to me. The serenity made me believe that I was altogether taken back from contemporary times. The ruins/remains of still speak of the Roman empire's valor. Don't miss the Temple of Venus, Caesar's crematorium, Nero's palace (or what remains of it) and the portico, the temple of Saturn and the last monument (a single tall column) signifying the fall of this great empire!

Lots of walking; included in Colosseo Admission. This is very similar to Pompeii; lots of ruins and would just look like piles of rocks if you didn't have some sort of tour or guide. We used Rick Steves' audio guide and was very helpful. Good luck finding a bathrooms in here! We had to leave the forum and go all the way around the colosseum to get to a bathroom, almost peed my pants.

Better outside than inside. It's very nice to see this place and imagine how the Roman forum would look like...My suggestion is to walk outside the forum, in Fori Imperiori street, and looking the Roman Forum from the road, higher than the forum actually is.If you walk inside the forum you cannot understand how big and beautiful this place is.
The awesome Forum!!!!!. Another can't miss stop while visiting Rome, so much history in a small area, very awe inspiring, a beautiful site.

Where is the information and what is the way?!. The forum is really nice with ancient remains of early Rome. But the only way to get an idea on what your are looking at, is when you take the audiotour. We got in with our romapass, which is recommended to cut costs and the entrance line. But once we were in was very hard to tell which buildings the remains are on what you are looking at because there are zero informationpanels around. Also there was a lot of maintanance done so some views were obstructies by scaffolding.The same goes for the palentino, no info on the ground and its very hard to find the right direction without a map.The best free views of the forum you can get from several viewingplatforms along the streets surrouding the forum behind il vittorino. When you are not really intrested in a bunch of old bricks, or when you are short on time, you still can get a nice set of pictures from the forumgrounds.Be aware that the forum and palentino grounds are prettig stretched out and that a lot of climbing and stairs are involved.

You must have a good imagination and appreciation for history.. These are ruins from 2000 years ago so don't expect very many buildings and architecture to marvel at. Although, there are a few buildings that have been renovated and restored. I would strongly suggest an audio tour to fully appreciate the history of the forum. Itunes offers Rick Steves audio tours for free and they are pretty good in comparison to the rental audio tours available at the entrance to the Forum.

Incredible history!. My husband and I visited the Forum after the Colosseum--it was incredible! So much history happened in this area. Being there is almost surreal! Definitely do not miss the Forum on your visit to Rome!

Walk Back in History. I visited the Roman Forum during a guided tour by Maximus Tours (combined with the Colosseum). The guide was definitely a good choice - there is just so much to see and learn and nothing has signs and even if they did, it would take ages to read over all of it.Go in the mid-afternoon when the entrance queue is virtually non-existant - your ticket will include the Forum, Colosseum and Palatine hill (the ancient emperial palaces next door to the Forum). The tickets are also good for 24 hours so if you can't see it all in one day, you can split it into two days. The Roma Pass will also get you in either free or for a reduced cost.Favourite highlights of the Forum - the remaining standing columns of the basilicas (originally public access buildings), the Arches of Septimus Severus and Tito and the Temple of Vesta were exceptionally beautiful. Sometimes there are also additional exhibits on display - one on Nero was running while I visited.

Forum & colesium closed all 3 days but guide saved us.. The Coliseum and Forum were closed all 3 days due to heavy rains and riot threat from the Occupy protesters. Our private guide saved the day with very interesting history lecture as we walked around the outside. The forum can be seen very well from outside and she took us to several very good vantage points and to some alternate forum ruins nearby. The history is incredible and we enjoyed it immensely from our outside vistas.

Take a good guide book. Make sure you take a really good guidebook when you tour the forum theres a lot to see and its really poorly signed.Some of the temples have been opened up since i last vistied and they are oustanding. Make sure you visit the villas on the hill to your right as you look towrads the colosseum to give some idea of the scle of the building.

Fantastic - but arrive early.. I was very pleasantly suprised by the Roman Forum. It had always been on our list of things to do in Rome but hadn't been our top priority. We did however visit it first thing in the morning on our first day as we had been told that the ticket for the forum could also be used to get in to the colosseum without so much queuing (this is true and I would strongly recommend doing this).  The Forum covers quite a large area really with a large number of buildings (or rather the remains of buildings) on the site. I personally enjoyed the curia (with bronze doors dating from ancient Roman times still intact), the house of the vestal virgins and the Arch of Titus to be most impressive. The views of the colosseum from the Arch of Titus are well worth taking a photo of. I'm very pleased that we arrived very early. We got there about 15-20 minutes after opening and there were only 2 people ahead of us in the queue so we were in in no time at all. When we left a couple of hours later the queue was horrendous! Do go early. They have an audio guide available which was fairly pricey and you have to leave an item of ID (such as passport or drivers licence) with them as security. Don't bother with this. Whilst I don't doubt the accuracy of the information contained on the audio guide it was dry, boring and unengaging and we stopped using it within the first 20 minutes of our visit. take a good guide book with maps of the forum with you instead.

Bumpy with a buggy!. We enjoyed the Roman Forum, we bought tickets early in the morning at the Palatine entrance to avoid queues. The sheer size of the ruins is humbling and it was nice to just walk around in the sun and take it all in. We had a baby in a buggy and beware the surface is very bumpy and we had to carry the buggy a lot! The exit to the Capitol is also tricky with a buggy, we luckily had help from strangers to lift it over the fence :)Definitely worth a visit but get your tickets early as the queues later in the day are horrendous, even in October.

Confusing. The forum represents one of the great ages in Roman history. Unfortunately, it is confusing to find your way around as it is poorly labelled. It would be a good idea to have a suggested route to follow, the guide book did not help greatly either.

A trip down memory lane. Walking through the forum was a trip down a collective (western) memory lane., Almost couldn't believe that we were seeing the sites where Marc Antony did his oration and where J. Caesar was cremated.

Great for history buffs. We love historical sites and the Roman Forum is like the holy grail of historical sites. No visit to Rome is complete without a long strong through the forum and Paletine Hill

Boring and confusing. We visited the Forum as part of the entry to the Colloseum. It wasn't very spectacular and appeared to be mostly a range of poorly signposted and unexplained rubble. We avoided using audio guides because of the added expense. The views from the top of the hill were great but there are better things to see in Rome if you're pushed for time.

Wonderful historic site. We did not visit the Forum on this visit but have done previously but it is worth reviewing now as it is a wonderful, historic site worthy of a visit - take your time, as we spent hours there soaking up the atmosphere and history.

Wonderful Experience. We visited the Forum on a private tour from Maximum Tours of Rome. The guide was great, an art student, pointing out all the finer points of this beautiful site. My wife was in a wheel chair and the entrance gate personnel was very accomdating, taking us down to the site level in an elevator.The tsite is a must see when touring Rome.

It worts to walk around. We have been to Rome in november, but the weather was still great and mostly sunny. The Forum is in a quite big area, but good to walk around. A loved the mix of the ancient monuments and the beauty green plants, (trees, etc.) We used Roma Pass to visit this attraction, which is a good idea to save money and avoid long waiting for cassa.

Roman Forum. An amazing site. You feel you are walking back in time to early Roman civilization. Easy to walk around and explore the many sites. Even though lots of people, the site is so spread out you don't feel crowded.

It keeps improving. We returned after 10 years and lots more to see,including Caesar's cremation area.There's an excellent section on Nero, with films, busts etc., in the Temple of Romulo.There's a lot of excavating going on so looking forward to returning in 10 years!

Excellent Roman History. It helps to have a good local guide or the Forum could be boring. Marco, our guide was great at providing appropriate information without too many boring details. You should try to visit this area during the cooler times. We were out in the hot sun most of the afternoon during mid September.
great. a must see when you visit the colesseum. It is worth the hike up to see the ruins and the city.

I Could Spend Days Here. So much to see, but do NOT miss the Arch of Titus near the exit on the Via Sacra. Notice at the top the golden Menorah, the Sliver Trumpets and other Temple treasures. The Forum is right near the Coliseum and can be used as a combo ticket on the Roma Pass. Pick up the guide book or audio guide so you know what you are looking at and get lost in Roman history!
Rubble that speaks to you. Make sure you download an audioguide or bring your guidebook for this one to help visualize what once was there. The Vestal Virgin villa and story were of great interest.
Another amazing ancient Roman site. To see these ruins in Rome sets you to daydreaming about all that went on to found modern civilization as we know it. I can stand there and imagine all of it.

Where is the Orator's Stone?. Rome must not have money for signs because they just were not in evidence once you got to a site. It was difficult to tell whether one had found the Forum site it or not. We traversed the huge archeological area and finally a guide pointed it out down several levels from where we were. We never found the orator's stone because again, no signs and no audio guide as far as we could tell. The map we received upon entering was useless. Get a a good book with lots of pictures of the monuments and local maps. We used Fodor's Italy 2011, but it wasn't enough and it was huge. I tore out the days pages for our tours every morning.

Lots of ruins!. the size of this site is staggering, but without the audio guide its just a lot of ruins.... the bit to the right of the entrance with tall columns etc is the most interesting. You have to queue to get in even with tickets, but only about 15 mins - much better than the Colosseum so if you've not got the joint tickets get them here and then go on to the Colosseum.
quick visit. just walked around as we arrived to late to go inside. Loved how they put on a little show with people dressed up as gladiators etc
Amazing. This is an absolutly amazing place so much history you must put it at the top of your list. We had spent a great deal of time here while in Rome:) enjoy it truly is amazing!

Take a guide. You really need a good guide for this site as it is a complete ruin and difficult to imagine how it must have been without help. But with a good tour guide and the help of some books offering resconstructions, you can really see how this impressive sight must have looked.
OK Place, not the best place either.... Compared to its neighbors... It wasn't great. However we saw cool Roman Structures so that was neat. Nothing else really

Great view. We stayed at the Hotel Kobe so when I looked out my window I was looking at the Forum. It is a great tour with the right guide who can fill you in with what all occurred there in Rome's history and how it looked in the past.
Roman forum with guide.... We used Rome Walks - Justin - to get a detailed wander around the area. Loved it, wished it hadn't rained and closed off our ability to go inside.

Feel the heart of Ancient Rome beating!. That's the true sight of Rome! Get a book with all the historical details of the Forum and just walk around it for several hours! Try to imagine what it was look like in the ancient times and how impressive all these ruins would have seemed back then! Unfortunately the entrance from Capitoline Museums are closed, so you will have to go all the way down to Colosseo and enter from the south entrance, but it is way worth it's money and tiredness. Wear comfortable shoes, as you will have to walk for a long time and begin your journey from the west part of it, along Via Sacra and then come back from the east part, where you will meet the majority of the well-preserved buildings. Highlights: Archs of Septimus Severus and Tito, really breathtaking! If you can stand a little bit more of walk, climb up the Palatine Hill, where you can enjoy your time in a full-of-green place, as well as a great view to the Forum and Colosseo.
AMAZING. The Forum is amazing, don't forget to go to The Curia, and also don't forget to look at Julius Ceasars tomb

The Romans were way ahead of their time. The Roman Forum is an incredible attraction. The architecture and sheer mass of some the buildings was amazing. Be ready for a lot of walking and wear shoes that will be suitable for lots of uneven cobblestones.

Not too critical to visit. We visited the Roman Forum as it was on the same tour as the Colosseum, however, personally I would not go out of my way to visit it again (especially if it is hot at the time). There are a lot of steps to negotiate and some distance to walk so if tired from the Colosseum you would not miss too much if you decide to take a rain check.
Roman Forum. Extremely interesting and well maintained. Archaeology work was going on while we were there. It is very difficult to find the entrance!
Amazing, amazing. I could have spent a week in the Forum- to see history up close is just fantastic.

A must see on any visit to Rome. The Roman Forum is one of the most fascinating places to visit in Rome.Queues for entrance are long, however the ticket for the Colosseum includes the Forum so you can skip the queue and walk right in. We arrives about Midday and they were out of audioguides, and it had changed slightly since I last visitied when tours were touted just outside the entrance. There are now no guided tours of the forum unless you book on a private tour in advance. However the audiotour is enough to get a feel for the forum and what it once was. Entrance also includes Paletine Hill. Get there in the morning to avoid crowds and midday heat!

Get there early. We got there after 2 and they wouldn't let us get the audio tour. A friend who went before said it's because they have about 6 hours of info you could possibly go through! The line is shorter at the Forum, and going there gets you the combo ticket for the Colliseum, so you won't have to wait in that line if you do this one first.

We loved walking around the Forum.. The forum was just so interesting. We used Eye Witness Rome as our tour, and it was very helpful. The site itself was well maintained and has bathroom available. I definitely recommend it. If you plan to see the Colosseum and the Forum, it may be worth getting the Rome Archeology Card (this is different than the Rome Pass). Gets you into those two plus the National Museum and a few others.

Must See with Rick Steves Free Audio Guide. We had the most beautiful blue skies while seeing the Forum. We used the Rick Steves Audio Guide and found it to be very informative, easy to follow, and not so overwhelming, just the highlights. Although I've been here before I got so much more out of it this time!

You cant miss the Forum. You cannot go to Rome and not see the Forum. Its possibly the most significant real estate in the history of human civilization. Skip the audioguide they sell and download the Rick Steves app on your smartphone.

Audioguide makes the ruins even more of a jumble; best to book a tour. We had booked a tour of the Forum with a private company, but a delayed opening delayed the start of our tour to a time when we had a conflict. We then attempted to tour the Forum on our own with the aid of the audioguide sold at the ticket booth. While informative, the audioguide only rarely attempts to orient you to the particular area that it is explaining, and frequently neglects to tell you that you should be moving on to another area while listening to an explanation that began at another point. You have only a tiny map with even tinier number signs on it to indicate when you should enter that number into your audioguide and listen to the explanation. Two thousand year old ruins look remarkably similar, so unless the audioguide said, "To the left of the three columns which are still standing is the _____" , you were at a complete loss as to whether you were actually gazing at the particular ruin the audioguide was describing. Going more or less blindly through all 13 explanations was a torture, and I observed my 15 year old's eyes glazing over at about #3. All in all, a frustrating excursion and a missed opportunity.

It's ruins folks! But consider what happened here.... Look, there wasn't a lot to see but a few columns and a couple of arches, but consider what took place here and the people that walked these paths. If you want to get a good look at the Forum without paying for a ticket or spending a lot of time, you can get a bird's eye view for free up on the Capitoline Hill at the very back.

This is a MUST SEE when in Rome!!!. The Roman Forum is something not to miss!!! There is such amazing history here and just walking around where the Romans walked thousands of years ago, is quite an experience. I HIGHLY recommend taking the guided 2-3 hour tours that include going to both the top, and down into the bottom, of the Colosseum. Having a guide that took us through the Colosseum and then the Roman Forum was well worth the $$

Interesting place. If you are going to the Colosseum, you may as well explore the Forums because the ticket includes both plus Palatine Hill. We got our tickets at the Forum entrance which had no line whatsoever, and the Colosseum ticket line was huge. Some parts of the Forum were disappointing as they are blocked off or covered by scaffolding for renovations. It's great that Rome is investing in taking care of the site, but when I was in Rome 4 years ago it was much more open to wander around. I had a tour for the site. I think you need either a tour guide or an audio guide otherwise it's hard to know what you are looking at. The water fountains inside the Forum were a definite plus as it was a hot day. The ruins are an interesting when you have a guide to give you the historical perspective, but the ruins at Pompeii are much better preserved and give you a much better picture of life in ancient Italy.

Fantastic historic scenery. For 50 years i have dreamt of visiting Foro Romanum and I was not disapointed. But before you go, read a lot about it and bring a visual guidebook. Or maybe better use guide. Negative: only one toilet for women and one for men before you enter the place, so be patient. If you are more than 65 entrance is free.

You have to pay to get in!. We were disappointed that you have to pay to get in and that many of the ruins were cordoned off so you couldn't get close. You had to buy a combined ticket with the Colossium and Palletine. We didn't want to go into the latter this time as we have visited before but we did want to just wander through the forum as we've done on previous visits. On the other hand there are loads of (free) viewing points where you can get nearly as close and get a much better idea of the size and layout.The visitor centre across the road is worth a visit just to see the scale model.And for a particularly good (free) view try the cafe level of the wedding cake.

Great look at Roman history. I loved walking around the Roman Forum - from the outside it looks deceptively small, but go into it and there are extensive buildings and gardens. It is an amazing look at how Roman society was organised and how streets and buildings were made. It's even more amazing that some of the adjoining buildings have been re-purposed and built on over time.It can be quite hot so it's good that the Fora actually has water fountains inside. My initial mistake was thinking that the area was small, so looking around here took more time than I had initially 'budgeted' for. Getting a tour to hear some of the history is something that I would recommend.The Forum and the Colosseum have a combined ticket so if you buy the ticket here you can skip the queues at the Colosseum. Even better is if you buy a Roma Card and you can skip the queues at both if you use this as your (combined) one ticket!Recommended.

Loved it!. After all those years of learning about ancient Rome, to finally get to see the Roman Forum was a real highlight of our trip to Rome!A few things I would recommend for your visit here.Take plenty of water, at least a bottle each. It gets very hot and there isn't much shade.Your entrance ticket for the colosseum also allows you entry here. So you don't need to pay extra.Buy your combi tickets ( here, palatine and colosseum) either here or at the Palatine. This saves you from standing in long queues at the colosseum. They are €12 each.Don't go at the weekend, it's far too busy.if you can, go mid week towards the end of the day.Your combo ticket is valid over 2 days, so it is perfectly possible to visit all 3 sites in the afternoons of 2 consecutive days.If you go to the Palatine first you can wonder round there...get to the gardens at the back, where you will see some stunning views over Rome and then wonder down a path at the back of the gardens into the Forum. Much better than having to go back outside and find another entrance to the forum.Take a good guidebook or an audio guide with you. Like many of the attractions in Rome, the visitor information is non-existent! Wondering around without a guide you'll have no idea what you are looking at, or the importance of it! It may seem a hasstle at the time but it's worth itFor those of you that like photography, you can get some absolutely fantastic pictures here. The ruins make some great images and come out stunning in black and white.It's definitely one of the top 5 things we did in Rome and I'd highly recommend it.

Remarkable Ruins Make History Come Alive. We booked a tour with Through Eternity and our guide was a graduate student who had a wealth of knowledge about ancient Rome. It's amazing to think that the centuries-old rubble in the Forum was the center of Roman life and public meetings. It was interesting to see evidence of games they used to play on the steps. So much history!Get the Roma Pass – 25 Euros per person lets you ride the Metro for three days plus first two attractions are free. Wear comfortable walking shoes as the entire site is on rocky, unpaved paths. Bring a water bottle and refill it frequently at the many water fountains all over the city. It was extremely hot in June (80 degrees in the shade) and the tour is almost entirely outdoors with no shade. Bring a hat, sunglasses and don't forget the sunscreen!

Roman Forum and Coloseum. We bought a Roma Pass at the Roman Forum which gets you into a different line for this and other attractions. It's very hot in the Summer so make sure you have lots of water which is available outside both attractions but not inside. If you can go late afternoon it is less crowded and not as hot. We ended up seeing the Forum and then taking a break before the Coloseum because it was so hot. Luckily our hotel was close enough to do that, Hotel Cosmopolita.

In case you miss Pompeii. In case you can't get to Pompeii, the Roman Forum ruins might be a good second. I have driven past this site before, but never took the time to walk inside the ruins. It was quite impressive. There is a in door, no AC, museum featuring Nero. Use good walking shoes as there is uneven, rocky pavement. There are bath room facilities and spring water drinking fountains. Sit down on century old rock chairs and take it all in.

Requires Imagination. Before going to see the Roman Forum, read a guidebook and look at the illustration of the reconstructed forum. Bring this with you so that when you see the each ruin, you can compare it with the illustration of the reconstructed forum and see what that building looked like during Roman times. For me the building that I liked most was the Arch of Septimus Severus, perhaps because this building is the one in the best condition. Do not expect too much of the Forum because other ancient Roman structures are in better condition and do not require as much imagination. However there are many good photo opportunities here.

Crowded but it's worth it!. We visited the Forum Romanum in August 2011. Because we were pretty early (like 10 o'clock), we didn't have to wait long to get our tickets. The tickets were 12 euro for an adult and 7,5 for a student. This seems much, but you can also get in the Colosseum with the same ticket! The Forum Romanum was certainly worth the visit. A couple of monuments are in pretty good shape and you can actually see how it was back then. Sometimes, we got tired, but that was mostly because of the heat (more than 30 degrees celsius!). So, when you're in Rome, you certainly can't miss this grand monument!

Lots of Walking, Not A Lot of Info, Still Amazing. The roman forum is big and full of ruins. Not many signs, especially in English so a tour may be worth it if your looking for some information/education on what your looking at. But, we just kind of "winged it" and still had a good time just looking around at our own pace. BRING A WATER BOTTLE WITH YOU. There are natural springs with perfectly clean, delicious, cold water scattered throughout the city that you can fill it with.

Rainy and chilly day, but the Forum is a MUST when in Rome.. I headed over to the Forum after my visit to the Colosseum, the entry fee was included in the Colosseum ticket. I used the Rick Steve's Ancient Rome Tour iPhone app and a book that shows what the ruins looked like when in their heyday. The day was chilly and rainy, which didn't stop me from enjoying my visit. I am a huge history buff and being in the Forum was amazing in and of itself, you definitely need a guide of some sort, whether it is in the form of an audio guide (app!) or an actual tourguide, otherwise you will have a hard time trying to figure out what you are looking at. The Curia (almost intact!) and the Temple of Julius Ceaser were highlights for me. Take your time, wear very comfortable shoes (there is a lot of walking on uneven ground) and enjoy!

Amazing history. My husband and I thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Colosseum and the Forum. There is such an incredible history here and so well preserved! We highly recommend taking a tour to cut down line ups and also so that you get much more information. Through eternity is a great option. Make time to visit this site in your trip to Rome.

The center of a great empire. The thing that struck me most about the Forum was that no one has built anything over it in 2000 years. It's basically a huge area with a bunch of trashed old buildings in it, taking up space in the middle of one of the biggest cities in the world. Just think how much this land alone could be sold for! But instead, the Romans honor the past. It's admirable, incredibly respectful, and astounding.This is a must see, for the history that happened here. As others have noted the ruins in it are not at all well marked- in fact they're not marked at all, so bring a guidebook. Like all other places we went in Italy, they do not hand you a free brochure with admission.The altar that Julius Caesar was cremated on is here, in a small enclosed area very near the semi-circular remains of the temple of the Vestal Virgins. To this day people still leave fresh flowers on the altar. Also check out the rostra, where Mark Antony is said to have delivered his "Friends, Romans, countrymen" speech (by way of Shakespeare). There is a reconstructed Senate building (the Curia, I believe) that's worth a look, although it wasn't what I would have pictured. I believe the Senate moved numerous times and took numerous forms. And Caesar was not killed here at the Forum. He was murdered at the nearby Largo Argentina, near the Pantheon and Campo de Fiore. (for Caesar buffs like myself!)

Brings home what it used to mean to be a Christian. Just looking through the tunnels towards the inside...thinking about having to walk through there and face a wild animal that was tearing people apart...simply because of something you believe...chills. We did not have time for a tour, but it is still impressive to walk around, look inside, and wander next door to the free parts of the Forum. We did not see bathrooms and had to go across the street to the subway station. Make sure you have .50 euros with you for the bathroom and bring your own toilet paper.

Incredible Piece of History. Across the street from the Colosseum, the Forum is an incredible piece of Roman history. The Forum itself is a large open area with numerous sights/ruins throughout. Signage is limited and virtually non-existant so be sure to bring a guideboook or download an audio tour in advance, otherwise you'll likely be disappointed. Plan on spending a fair amount of time here as there is quite a bit to see and alot of area to cover, especailly if you head over to the Palatine Hill area. We ended up spending nearly the entire morning here. There are a few water "fountains" available (one right near the Arch of Titus) which are great for refilling your waterbottles.This is one that should not be missed even though it may not have the same "wow" factor of the Colosseum or Pantheon - it's such an amazing piece of history and an incredible opportunity to step back in time.

INCREDIBLE SITE! WORST AUDIO GUIDE TOUR EVER!!! DON'T BUY IT!. The Forum, Palatine Hill, tour "audio" guide is the worst ever. The admissions desk charges quite a bit extra for it as well and trust me when I say this - it is NOT worth one euro!! Besides being more costly than any other audio tour I've taken - the tape you listen to does not match up with ANYTHING! You'll be walking on the path and the tape will point out things that are not there. I'm a VERY seasoned tourist and it was totally frustrating and a waste of our money. If I had to do it again - I would just pay a REAL guide (which is expensive) or just enjoy the site on it's own.

Incredibly Special! Bring a guide book or map!. This was an incredibly special place.You have to realize that the roman forum (and palatine hill) are layers of history built right on top of one another. Don't look for signs telling you this stone is this and this column is this. It's too hard to interpret in that sense and I figure people who leave reviews for this attraction negatively seem to only be able to see the world that way.We used the free Rick Steves Roman Forum Tour on his iPhone app. It was phenominal. It explains the layers of history, leads you to arches, the spot where Julius Ceasar died, public platforms, buildings, and really makes you imagine what it was like.There is no need to pay hundreds of euro for a guide here when you have Rick Steves for free and other excellent guides like that in the DK eyewitness tour book. Do yourself a favor - bring a guide of some kind and relax and enjoy this amazingly special place! To say it is not special, regardless of how well labeled the archeological site is, shows how out of touch some reviewers can be on here! You need to relax and appreciate this amazing place - and you can bring your own guide with you for free. No need to pay someone else!

Just mind-blowing.... The Forum is part of the Palotine Hill complex - on the same ticket as the Colosseum. This for me was my best experience in Rome. There are so many buildings and ruins in this complex and this area was the absolute heart of ancient Rome. It could take all day to see everything. in the end we only had the stamina to see about 2/3rdsof it then went for lunch. The only critisism is that the signage around the site is very poor - we wish we had taken the audio guides you can rent when you buy tickets.

Ruins are ruined by lack of information. I LOVE ancient Roman history and I was so disappointed during my long anticipated visit to the Roman Forum. Here is my experience:The Colloseum is cool because it is iconic but not too much history there. The Palatine Hill is great because of Augustus, Livia and Nero. But the Roman Forum is the most exciting place. If you love history and are also looking forward to the forum: do your homework and DO NOT make the same mistake I did. I wish I had believed the TA reviews warning that there is no information on the Forum grounds. (Unbelievable but accurate) Buy a guide book or find yourself a tour guide. Don't bother with the Roman Forum audioguides (with the included map) as they are useless. Other TA members have suggested specific guidebooks to purchase (read those reviews and buy the recommended books). If you hire a tour guide be careful-they do not always give a good tour. Many of the tour guides are burnt out and have (sorry to say this) contempt for American Tourists (read on for proof). I asked my Palatine Hill Tour guide if I should also hire a guide for my Roman Forum visit the next day. She assured me that there was no need to hire a guide and that I would find many signs in english explaining everything on the forum grounds. I believed her and thought the TA reviews were outdated. Not sure why this tour guide lied to me. Her english was perfect. She seemed nice. She gave a great tour (though a bit shorter than I expected). Everyone in our group was polite and respectful and interested in what she had to say. She went out of her way to convince me that I shouldn't hire a tour guide for my Forum visit as everything would be explained in signs in english. Because of her advice I walked in to the forum without anything and I actually cried when I realized that the best part of my visit in Ancient Rome had turned into a disaster. I was standing in the middle of history and had no idea what I was looking at. Hope this review helps you plan your visit better.

Included in your Colosseum ticket. The Forum was so quiet, I think there were 5 or 6 people there which was surprising as the views you get back to the Colosseum are very good. I would recommend visiting the Forum and getting photos of the Colosseum. We were mostly here on our own.

The very heart of one of the greatest empires the world has ever seen. The Forum is an essential part of any visit to Rome. I would suggest reading a guide book about it beforehand and buying one of those small books which allow you to see what the Forum looked like in its heyday. You can get, either on Amazon or in Rome, books which have transparent overlays over photos of modern day Rome. These are very useful to compare how it looks now with how it used to look. There's not much explanatory material in the Forum itself and many of the buildings are in a very ruined state which makes it hard to know what you are looking at if you haven't read up beforehand.Also, consider buying a Roma Pass or booking another advance ticket so that you can dodge the ticket queues.Within the Forum my favourite building is the spectacular Basilica Maxentius which is a large vaulted building. This building used to contain a giant statue of the emperor Constantine, who was an extemely influential person in history. The excellently preserved remains of this statue can still be seen in the Musei Capitolini which overlooks the Forum.

Worth the visit. we visited in February - very cold, and was trying to rain whilst we were there, but was neverthless very enjoyable. I would recommend getting the Rome Reconstructed book that you see in all the tourist shops, newspaper stands for this site - it gives you a much better idea of what you are looking at and what the site would have been like when it was built.I would also suggest visiting the forum before the collosseum - the queues really are much shorter for the tickets and then you can walk straight into the collosseum after.
Amazing History. The Roman Forum is full of amazing history and structures. Do not miss a chance to walk through this maze of archaeological wonders.

Very Pleasant and Interesting Walk. Any self-respecting Roman emperor considered it his duty to erect in the city if not its own forum, then at least the statue. Until our days the "eternal city" more-or-less preserved Forum Troyan (to the left of the wide street Via dei Fori Imperiale, hacked with Mussolini directly on the ancient ruins of the Altar to the Coliseum) and the Forum of Caesar and the Roman Forum (on the right side) and countless statues of emperors on the sides. Both forums are interesting: Forum Troy - well-preserved ruins of the shopping malls of the market, as well as constant column of the Emperor, and the right forum - the Arch of Titus, Temple of the Vestal, the ruins of the Temple of Saturn's famous Cloaca Maxima, etc. In addition, at Rome, in the middle ancient ruins, towering several Christian basilicas in excellent condition. Won "conglomerate" of the front tier of ancient columns (remaining from the pagan temple) and built them the facade of the Christian church. Generally, among the ruins of the forums are very pleasant and interesting walk. At least, so it was in February: the people a little, not too hot, but comfortable (15), we can all safely view. I think the summer there is not so rosy - red-hot stones to heat up to high temperatures, and the crowds are unlikely to quietly walk! At the checkout you can take the audio guide and a plan in Russian, for some reason we refused and very sorry! Outright to figure out what pieces of columns refer to the temple of Castor and Pollux, and which, for example, to the temple of Vestal - rather difficult. For example, we walk through the ruins and see a small round, half-grown into the ground structure, around which crowded Turistas with cameras and enthusiasm, this house is removed. Looking inside, we saw nothing except some hatch and heaped on him heaps of flowers. It was only later discovered that at this place in a kind of shaggy were burnt body of Julius Caesar!

Think Twice. I visited the Roman Forum as part of my included sightseeing with my Europe Tour. Although at first there were "some" interesting information that was given by the local guide it was a very long and drawn out visit and the local guide seemed more interested in losing his tourists than waiting for us.We had walked all over Rome on this day a 3 hour walking tour in the morning followed by the Colosseum followed by roughly an hour and a half in the Forum.It was extremley hot and he was not interested in stopping in the shade or walking any slower because most of the group by this stage were exhausted.If you must visit try not to fall asleep

Fanscinating insight into life in Roman Times. Visiting the Roman Forum is like stepping back in time. It is easy to imagine what life was like here during the height of the Roman Empire. It is right next to the Colosseum and Palatine so it is relatively easy to visit all three on the same day although visting all three doesw involve a lot of walking.Best to take a guidebook as otherwise it is not easy to work out which building you are viewing as signposts within the Forum are very few.Take camera and sturdy shoes.

An Amazing Site, But Very Poor Signage. The Forum is an amazing place--a gem of western civilization and truly fascinating. We visited last week and I have to say that it is unfortunate the folks who operate this site have such little regard for information. We visited on a day that was not especially busy, yet there were no audio guides and the map given with the tickets was close to useless. We returned to the bookstore and purchased a guide, but that, too, was poorly written with an incomplete map and very few photos. So, we enjoyed our visit, but it was frustrating to spend so much time trying to figure out what everything was. Really, a simple numbering system and map would be enough. If you're planning a visit to Rome, definitely see the Forum, but be prepared for the lack of information!

A Step back in time - check it out from the back of the Capitolini Museum. We had a wonderful overview of the Roman Forum, Imperial Forum, and Trajan's Column from the back of the Capitolini Museum and the Victor Emmanuel Memorial.Take the time to find a guide to take you through this walk back into time. A great spot for those interested in ancient Rome.

Superb - but Spoiled by Ticket System. I love the forum. We have been travelling to Rome twice a year for about 10 years now and have friends there.I used to enjoy taking a walk from the Campidoglio, through the forum to the Colosseum.This is no longer what is used to be as the natural route through is now fenced off.The forum for me is a place to wander through freely and often; not a museum exhibit.The new ticketing system also causes long queues and for me ruins what was once a wonderful experience.A couple of years ago, they even had a load of modern art installations throughout the forum; completely ruining photo opportunities of the original site!I have no problem whatever with paying to enter the site; but the "new" ticketing system completely ruins the natural flow of a visit.Admittedly the old ticket booths were perhaps a little too discreet; most people just used to walk through.Sorry to moan - but having the perspective of knowing the place over time, the "new" arrangements are a disaster.If you haven't been - still go! It is still superb - but the experience owes everything to ancient Rome and nothing to modern interference.CH
SEE THIS ATTRACTION. Do not miss the Roman Forum!!!! Before going though, bring a guide book because there is absolutely no information. Be preapred to spend at least 3 hours walking around.

Roman Forum. The birthplace of the common town square in big cities. This location has so much history and is invaluable as a tool to see into the past. However, you will need to use your imagination because only a few fragments remain intact. A good stop and walk.

A must see. This is one of the places which you have to visit when in Rome. An area full of antique buildings that were built over and over, and which miraculously have remained to our times. The Foro Romano is easily accessible as it is in the centre of Rome and there is a huge area. We bought the Archaeological card (28 euros entitled for entrances to several places) and jumped the queue waiting to buy the ticket. Take a bottle since in summer it is very hot - there are plenty of springs from which you can fill bottles - the water is good for consumption. A sort of guide is needed since there are many ruins - our book listed over 50 different buildings, and take your time trying to imagine the places as they were in antiquity. Enter the Forum building where sometimes different exhibitions are made.

Maximilio Tour of Roman Forum wa excellent!. We booked Maximilio Tour of the Vatican via internet and were amazed at how great the tour guide was. So good that we signed on with another guide from the same company the next day for the Roman Forum. 3 to 4 hours each time, mesmerizing and kept 2 restless tired 9 year olds entertained. These guides really know their stuff!!

Get a guided tour!. The Roman Forum, along with the Colosseum, is a must-see. There are two entrances: one closer to the Palatine Hill (on Via di San Gregorio) and the other closer to the northwest end of the forum (on Via dei Fori Imperiali). If you go through the Palatine entrance, be warned that there is a hike to get to the forum. Don't bother with the audio guide. Even though they give you a labeled map of all the ruins, it is very hard to figure out what you are actually looking at (as the ruins themselves are not labeled). My traveling partner and I spent a long time trying to figure out what we were supposed to be looking at. I would highly recommend getting a guided tour or at least having a very good map. Highlights include the Tempio di Vesta, the Arco di Tito, the gigantic Basilica di Massenzio, and the Arco di Settimio Severo. The whole place is very interesting and layered with history, but don't expect to see complete structures. Most everything is a fragment (or single column) of what it once was. Overall, it took us about 3 hours to get through but probably would have been shorter if we had known what things were. Entrance to the Roman Forum is included with your ticket to the Colosseum (and also includes Palatine Hill, which you can access from the Roman Forum), so take advantage of it.

The Best Tour Ever. Toured the Forum/Collisseum with John as our guide. There were 5 of us so the tour was highly personalized. John spent more than the designated 3 hours telling us "everything". His knowledge of the sites was bottomless. I found the history fascinating.Highly reccommend this company and John. Many tour companies get bad reviews it seems but we started on time with a small group......perfect.

Get the tour guide before you walk through the gates. We went to this place after purchasing our ticket at the Colloseum across the street. What we did not realize is once you go through the little gate you can not get the audio guide with out hopping back over the fence. So, you basically wasted a good ticket to go see ruins with out really knowing what significance is behind them. They look so interesting, but we were sad to not know what everything was.

Very cool....loved it. We bought our combo ticket at the Via San Gregorio entrance and finished our time at the Palatine. We come through the entrance to the Roman Forum. I break out my audio guide and start listening for awhile. I take lots of pictures as usual. Stop at the runs of the temples, stare at the amazing details of the arches, walk along Sacred Way, see the Senate house and marvel these structures have been here for thousands of years!After much time, we finally head out for exit, which takes you directly to the Colosseum. Make sure you wear sneacker or some sort of closed footware since you are walking around in dirt. It is still an active excavation site.

Pay for a tour of the Roman Forum. We booked our tour through Real Rome Tours and are very thankful that we did! The Roman Forum is nothing without the history behind it and the tour guide did a great job explaining. Any visitor to the forum will notice that the forum of today is not that of ancient Rome. A tour of the Forum requires a great imagination and open ears for the history that you will learn.

One of the highlights of our trip. We spent hours in the Forum, steeping ourselves in history. The Forum entrance across the street from the Colosseum is now exit-only, so we went to the north entrance at Via dei Fori Imperiali. What a thrill to stand where so much that shaped our modern culture took place! And it was very picturesque this May, with the poppies and roses blooming. A good guidemap of the Forum is in “Fodor’s See It Rome”, . We also studied Frommer's "Rome Past and Present" before the trip so that we understood the layout. What an incredibly significant site.

A true depiction of Ancient Rome. Please visit the Roman Forum. Prior to your trip, go to www.ricksteves.com and download his free map and audio tour of the Roman Forum. The self-guided audio walking tour lasts about 1 hour and helps to decipher what you are viewing. The audio tour is entertaining and informative. Ancient Rome is truly amazing and would not be complete without a stop at the Roman Forum!

You need a good imagination.... I studied Classics at university so was very excited about going to see the Roman Forum, have to say though that it was a bit of an anticlimax.Apart from some amazing arches, there's so little of it standing - a column here, a stone there - that you really need to be able to use your imagination to really understand how amazing it must have looked in its prime.Definitely still worth a visit - but get a great guide / guide book to tell you what you're looking at and don't spend too long out there. Apart from anything else you'll get frazzled by the heat of the day!

Have a good guidebook or go on a tour. This is a great free attraction, so take advantage of it by knowing what you're looking at. There are tours you can take, but I personally just read from a detailed DK Journal that mapped out what each monument was. It was hotter than heck when I went (mid-May), so definitely bring some bottled water! Take lots of pictures, and please, don't climb on top of these structures just for an interesting picture; it's disrespectful, you will get dirty looks and some native tour guides will scold you in front of their tour groups!

One of My Faves. Toured in November, 2007. As a history lover, this was one of my favorites. The skeleton remains of so many buildings makes you wonder and imagine the impressiveness of it in its day. I'd definitely recommend a guided tour or at the least an audio tour. I had a guide book with but it wasn't enough. There are only small signs in front of the remains noting their name and not much else. As a result, you won't get the history behind the buildings without more. After I returned, I discovered that there are free audio tours you can download to your mp3 player or ipod via tourcaster.com and others. I'd recommend trying them out if you can't afford the extra costs of the tour.It's an amazing place. Climbing Palatine Hill (entry is part of your entry to the Colessium and vice versa) will give you great overviews of the Forum. So will climbing Capitoline Hill.

A highlight of Rome. The Roman Forum is a free attraction ( except for Palatine Hill)The Forum was possibly the highlight of my visit to Rome, along with the Pantheon. BUT you need a guide book or an audio tour at least (audio tour is downloadable from audible.com for free, along with a map) ,if you arent joining one of the numerous paid walking tours. If you dont have a guide of some description, most of the time you wont know what you are looking at, so it will detract from the experience a bit.We visited in August and it was oppressively hot. There are numerous trees within the forum you can shelter under (most of the Forum is exposed) and there are numerous water fountains, so take a bottle with you in summer - you'll need it!

History in Ruins. The Roman Forum contains the ruins of the ancient Roman civilization. Strolling through the ruins gives an impressive sense of history. Most of the buildings are partially or completely gone, but are still impressive. There is something eerie about seeing the free-standing columns that have survived all of these years. It’s very interesting to see the remnants of a time gone by, but hard to understand the significance of the various sites without a guide. If you aren’t on a tour there is almost no information provided (signs / guides) to help you get around. We ended up listening in on one of the tours and got much more out of it than if we had wandered around on our own. As an alternative there are several guide books which offer self guided tours and give background info on various spots.

walking tour of Roman Forum. if you want to learn about the history of the roman forum without joining the typical "we are tourists!" tour group you could try a downloadable audio walking tour from walki-talki.com.you download the tour from their site, upload to your iPod or mp3 player and then follow the tour at your own pace. The tour includes a map showing the route but its not necessary as the directions on the audio are very clear and the route is fairly straightforward.you can start and stop the tour whenever you like and walk the route at your own pace. and while you stroll along with your headphones in you won't even look like a tourist.i think this is a good idea, i'd be interested to hear what other travelers think...

Read up on this amazing piece of history. As mentioned in other reviews its worth doing a bit of homework before you see the Roman Forum. This is a large archeological site consisting of the remains of many Roman buildings. The buildings and ruins each have a sign saying what they are but nothing else, so I would get a tour or bring a guide book as we did so that you know what you are looking at. Some of the buildings are so old it defies belief. To see Roman inscriptions and columns with your own eyes makes a visit here well worth it.

Amazing, but no information. This is a must-see. Don’t rush your time here – the site is amazing and probably our favourite in Rome. If you take a tour at the Colosseum, you can take a tour of the Forums and the Palatine Hill for free. As is usual with Roman historical sites, there is no information once you are there, so you need to read up on the area beforehand.

Take your time to walk around!. The Roman Forum turned out to be a pleasant surprise. If you are curious about each and every ruin and what it was and represented, you can get a book or an audio guide and walk through. My boyfriend and I just took our time and wandered around for a few hours. We enjoyed that and didn't have a map or a guide. It was even raining a bit, but that shouldn't stop you. The whole forum is very fascinating, don't rush through. A good idea is to see the Colosseum first and then wander through the Roman Forum. Get your tickets ahead of time online at (--)

Give the Forum Your Time. This was fantastic!I read a good bit before going, but, still it is overwhelming. Reserve time here, don't rush it. I would suggest that you read beforehand, go to the Forum and just walk for a while all around, then sit down, get your bearings and go through a good guidebook. You are probably not going to have a grasp of everything there (I don't expect to after ten visits) but, if you take your time, you can start to envision what was.Don't leave yourself 45 minutes to run through the Forum. Here is a really good website I found that shows the sites, gives very good basic information and locates each on a map. (-)vroma(-)I'll be back this summer and hope to understand a bit more.

An Unexpected High-point. Everything we saw in Rome bowled us over, but the Forum was the site that exceeded our expectations the most. Before we got to the Forum I was unclear about exactly what it was, and when we saw it, it really didn't look like much. But after taking a 3.50 Euro 1-hour guided tour (available at the ticket booth) led by a young archeologist, we were completely amazed by the amount of WORLD history contained in what looks like a vast pile of ancient rubble/excavation zone. And to think that 100 years ago, when the excavation began, most of this stuff was underground. Suggestion: We bought a small book available at souvenir stands all over Rome that shows photos of present-day ruins along with an acetate overlay showing what the structures probably looked like when they were intact. This book was a tremendous help to us in imagining the ancient world. (Bonus: it came with a CD-Rom which had even more stuff on it.)Don't miss the Mamertine Prison where St. Peter was held. It's under the church next to the Curia.

Best experience ever?!. You think you are familiar with all the sights of Rome, you've seen the movies, read the books, researched the Internet, but when you finally get there....the Eternal City surpasses all expectations, overwhelms the senses completely; and the Forum is the best of all. Advance preparation is the key, plus buying a good guide and allowing plenty of time - you cannot 'do' the Forum in an hour.In 5 days we went twice, plus pausing in the evenings and taking in the fabulous sights by moonlight and floodlight, not to be missed.We can't wait to get back. Wonderful.

Better than Colosseo. I visited the Roman Forum after the Colosseo and I was way more impressed! I brought along the guided tour from a Rick Steves' book which helped immensely for there was not much labeled. I ended up spending almost 3 hours walking around and taking pictures. I highly recommend this stop, but make sure you have something with to guide you as to what you are viewing. A truly amazing site. There were people excavating areas as well, so I guess I'll have to visit again to see what else they unearth! This was a lot better than I thought it would be. And it's FREE!

Roman Forum. When you visit the Roman Forum you are walking on what are among the most important few acres in the history of western civilization. Having said that, the significance of much of what you are looking at will not be readily apparent without doing some homework. I would not wait until you arrive in Rome to become aquainted with the forum and its environs. There is tons of good material available online and reading a good book or two on ancient Rome ahead of time will greatly enhance the experience.In addition, I would devote some time to the study of a good map of the forum. Once you have familiarized yourself with the area you will be less likely to walk by what you think is just a pile of rocks instead of recognizing, for example, the rostra, where Brutus eulogized Julius Ceaser and countless orators extolled the virtues and condemned the vices of Rome.A visit to the Roman Forum will be an unforgettable experience, and with good preparation it will be for the better.

Buy a good detailed guide book. This place is amazing and a must see. You need a good few hours to explore this area. We had a guide book that we brought in England, but it was a little confusing to work out what each building was. We decided to purchase a book from one of the stalls by the Colosseun for 10 Euros. It showed how the Roman Forum used to look and what it looks like now, so we were able to match up the two. We found it very useful and had a better understanding of what he would of looked like. You can also go on a free guided tour which meets outside the Colosseum, but we chose not to. This place is not to be missed, we went back twice.

Confused at the Forum?. As the previous reviews suggest, there are no English signs or explanations for the tourists at most of the tourist attractions. But then there is the old adage 'When in Rome..' We found the Forum a bit confusing with all the attractions but no explanations. Luckily the hotel provided a free guide 'Welcome Guida Di Roma' which was free and has pictures and English/Italian description of each of the attractions. We found this useful and identified the places we visited. The only thing surprisingly missing from the Guide was Julius Caeser`s grave/monument? One of the guides we overheard said that it was where he was cremated whilst another guide suggested that they burnt his remains there.

need a guide or guidebook. We don't like guided tours, but at the Forum, you could use one, or at least a really good book showing then and now pictures of the Forum buildings. We listened to some of the tour guides and they made it sound more interesting, but you still need a picture book (or a guide with a big picture book) to make it a good experience.

Need a guidebook. The Roman Forum was confusing. There are a lot of columns, steps, etc. However, it is not labeled. (Take a day trip down to Pompeii, which is much better.) While there was a feel of history, you were just not sure what you were looking at.
